496
00:24:44.460 --> 00:24:46.890
But that's not what's happening here,
right.

497
00:24:46.890 --> 00:24:51.530
So when you have a RDS,
a Role Delineation Survey, it results

498
00:24:51.530 --> 00:24:55.520
in minor tweaks to the exam, like this,
that are just not really a panic point.

499
00:24:55.520 --> 00:24:59.390
>> So Don, if I'm in the middle
of studying for this exam, and

500
00:24:59.390 --> 00:25:01.540
it's right around the corner,
three or four months away.

501
00:25:01.540 --> 00:25:04.500
I don't really have to worry about
changing anything in the path that

502
00:25:04.500 --> 00:25:05.040
I'm studying.

503
00:25:05.040 --> 00:25:06.790
I should be fine as we continue to go up.

504
00:25:06.790 --> 00:25:08.290
It doesn't look like it
actually just changed,

505
00:25:08.290 --> 00:25:11.400
but two different percentages,
I think would be fine, right?

506
00:25:11.400 --> 00:25:14.180
>> Yeah, and it does come down
to the materials you're using.

507
00:25:14.180 --> 00:25:19.190
So if you're using ITProTV's materials,
we based ours on the PIN-block itself,

508
00:25:19.190 --> 00:25:22.420
and the PIN-block hasn't changed,
so we covered all of it.

509
00:25:22.420 --> 00:25:23.430
It's fine.

510
00:25:23.430 --> 00:25:25.340
We did have to add one more show.

511
00:25:25.340 --> 00:25:31.040
If you're just catching up on this,
look for a show, it's part of the control.

512
00:25:31.040 --> 00:25:32.193
No, part of executing, right?

513
00:25:32.193 --> 00:25:34.792
The episode's called, Process Analysis.

514
00:25:34.792 --> 00:25:35.512
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

515
00:25:35.512 --> 00:25:39.209
if you go and look for the episode
called Process Analysis, that's where we

516
00:25:39.209 --> 00:25:43.039
added a little bit on Six Sigma, a little
bit on Lean, a little bit on Cam Band.

517
00:25:43.039 --> 00:25:44.594
ISO, I think it's a two parter, right?

518
00:25:44.594 --> 00:25:46.890
So ISO, CMMI, those guys.

519
00:25:46.890 --> 00:25:49.910
If you've never heard those acronyms,
we covered in that episode.

520
00:25:49.910 --> 00:25:51.440
Right, or those two episodes.

521
00:25:51.440 --> 00:25:53.420
But all the rest of
the material is the same.

522
00:25:53.420 --> 00:25:54.650
You don't have to panic.

523
00:25:54.650 --> 00:25:58.760
Now, if you're reading a book, and the
book is not based on the PIN-block, but

524
00:25:58.760 --> 00:26:02.850
is instead based directly on the exam
objectives, those have changed.

525
00:26:02.850 --> 00:26:04.040
And there might be gaps.

526
00:26:04.040 --> 00:26:06.650
Any of those things that were highlighted
in green when I was showing you the exam

527
00:26:06.650 --> 00:26:09.370
objectives, those are things
those books might be missing.

528
00:26:09.370 --> 00:26:10.940
And so
that's where you have to worry about it.

529
00:26:10.940 --> 00:26:13.480
So, it really boils down to what
your information was based on.

530
00:26:13.480 --> 00:26:15.460
And if it was based on the PIN-block,
don't panic.

531
00:26:15.460 --> 00:26:16.460
Keep studying the way you're studying.

532
00:26:16.460 --> 00:26:18.045
You'll be fine.
You'll do great on the exam.

533
00:26:18.045 --> 00:26:23.340
>> Another thing I think we can reassure
our viewers of is that here at ITProTV,

534
00:26:23.340 --> 00:26:25.520
if it does change significantly more,
we'll do what?

535
00:26:25.520 --> 00:26:27.040
We'll just record more episodes.

536
00:26:27.040 --> 00:26:30.064
>> Yeah.
And we've kind of been planning on that as

537
00:26:30.064 --> 00:26:33.425
the Pinbox sixth edition
starts to materialize.

538
00:26:33.425 --> 00:26:35.070
PMI's really open about it.

539
00:26:35.070 --> 00:26:38.010
And you can kind of keep up with
the changes they're recommending and all.

540
00:26:38.010 --> 00:26:41.130
And we'll probably end up just re-shooting
the whole series though to update it

541
00:26:41.130 --> 00:26:41.870
when that happens.

542
00:26:41.870 --> 00:26:47.090
But like I said, that'll probably be 2017,
or at a minimum, the end of 2016.

543
00:26:47.090 --> 00:26:51.160
So it's still a little early for that to
happen, but we'll see it down the road.

544
00:26:51.160 --> 00:26:52.720
>> All right, so that's a great place for

545
00:26:52.720 --> 00:26:54.940
us to actually think about that,
hey, if I'm ready for

546
00:26:54.940 --> 00:26:59.420
the current edition of it, that 2016
objective, I don't need to panic.

547
00:26:59.420 --> 00:27:03.730
I just can continue on my path as long as
I've got good study materials ahead of me,

548
00:27:03.730 --> 00:27:06.810
I'm really set for
what we have ahead of us as well.

549
00:27:06.810 --> 00:27:10.440
So, signing off for
ITProTV, I’m Ronnie Wong.

550
00:27:10.440 --> 00:27:11.048
>> And I’m Don Pezet.

551
00:27:11.048 --> 00:27:12.059
>> And we’ll see you next time.

552
00:27:12.059 --> 00:27:19.280
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don introduce the viewer to the Project Management Institute (PMI) framework for managing projects. They take a look at the Project Management Body Knowledge and cover some required terminology for the exam.
episodes.title: Fundamentals
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,846 --> 00:00:10,846
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,068 --> 00:00:22,649
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,649 --> 00:00:32,649
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,748 --> 00:00:36,337
All right, good morning,
afternoon, and good evening and

5
00:00:36,337 --> 00:00:39,610
welcome back to another episode of
ITPro TV and I'm your host Don Pizzette.

6
00:00:39,610 --> 00:00:41,650
Today with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:41,650 --> 00:00:42,640
How's it going, Ronnie?

8
00:00:42,640 --> 00:00:44,040
>> It is going well.

9
00:00:44,040 --> 00:00:46,940
I do not have any
reference to Eminem at all.

10
00:00:46,940 --> 00:00:48,210
>> No?
>> No, not a single one.

11
00:00:48,210 --> 00:00:49,210
>> The candy or the rapper?

12
00:00:49,210 --> 00:00:52,440
>> Both.
>> [LAUGH]

13
00:00:52,440 --> 00:00:55,490
Well, let me start off by welcoming

14
00:00:55,490 --> 00:00:56,170
everybody [LAUGH].

15
00:00:56,170 --> 00:00:59,427
We're gonna have Eminem rap-off later,

16
00:00:59,427 --> 00:01:03,170
[LAUGH] see who can
insult each other more.

17
00:01:03,170 --> 00:01:05,810
Let me welcome everybody to the first

18
00:01:05,810 --> 00:01:11,160
episode of the ITPro TV Project
Management Professional show,

19
00:01:11,160 --> 00:01:14,150
this is a kind of a new branch for us.

20
00:01:14,150 --> 00:01:19,330
Every show we've done up to this
point has been hardcore IT, right?

21
00:01:19,330 --> 00:01:22,860
We've been setting up servers, formatting
work stations, changing hardware,

22
00:01:22,860 --> 00:01:24,330
all IT stuff.

23
00:01:24,330 --> 00:01:26,970
And today we do project management.

24
00:01:26,970 --> 00:01:31,200
This is the first of our it's kind of like
a soft skill I think is what they call it.

25
00:01:31,200 --> 00:01:34,120
And you might ask yourself,
why are we doing this?

26
00:01:34,120 --> 00:01:36,790
Well in the IT world more so

27
00:01:36,790 --> 00:01:40,206
then in almost any other industry,
construction may be better.

28
00:01:40,206 --> 00:01:43,100
But in the IT world there are many,

29
00:01:43,100 --> 00:01:48,200
many things that we undertake that fall
under this envelope of being a project.

30
00:01:48,200 --> 00:01:53,830
And, if they are not properly structured
and managed, they are destined for

31
00:01:53,830 --> 00:02:00,030
failure over budget, behind schedule,
just terrible, terrible situations.

32
00:02:00,030 --> 00:02:03,710
That's one of the things that
happens when a project goes stray.

33
00:02:03,710 --> 00:02:07,750
And so project management has become
a hot button issue in the IT world over

34
00:02:07,750 --> 00:02:09,330
the last few years.

35
00:02:09,330 --> 00:02:13,800
And you really see it, around here you and
I both as instructors over the years have

36
00:02:13,800 --> 00:02:18,560
seen the request for
Microsoft project training and

37
00:02:18,560 --> 00:02:22,780
just general project fundamental
stuff like that really increasing.

38
00:02:22,780 --> 00:02:26,930
People want to know how to properly handle
their projects to ensure the highest

39
00:02:26,930 --> 00:02:28,360
degree of success.

40
00:02:28,360 --> 00:02:31,200
>> And more and more we're starting
to see this in the field of security.

41
00:02:31,200 --> 00:02:34,140
Where security is no longer
about just setting up stuff, but

42
00:02:34,140 --> 00:02:37,530
really properly maintaining and
then of course migrating

43
00:02:37,530 --> 00:02:41,250
as the security field is changing,
as we're getting more and more threats.

44
00:02:41,250 --> 00:02:44,330
The constant need to update and
to keep things going and

45
00:02:44,330 --> 00:02:49,170
keep things safe, is part of more project
management than it is the idea of actually

46
00:02:49,170 --> 00:02:52,470
having to worry about the individual
products and security any more.

47
00:02:52,470 --> 00:02:56,750
So you're gonna see this more often in
everything that you're doing in IT.

48
00:02:56,750 --> 00:02:59,520
Especially during
migrations a lot of times.

49
00:02:59,520 --> 00:03:04,590
>> So if you find yourself in
a situation where you've got a project.

50
00:03:04,590 --> 00:03:08,310
We'll talk a little bit more here in
a minute about what exactly a project is.

51
00:03:08,310 --> 00:03:12,140
But if you find yourself in a situation
where you need to manage a project,

52
00:03:12,140 --> 00:03:14,180
if this is the very first time,

53
00:03:14,180 --> 00:03:18,400
you might be scratching your head saying,
well how do I go about that?

54
00:03:18,400 --> 00:03:20,310
How do I do this, how do I do that?

55
00:03:20,310 --> 00:03:22,110
You don't wanna start from scratch.

56
00:03:22,110 --> 00:03:25,500
And so for those situations,
we have the PMI,

57
00:03:25,500 --> 00:03:28,760
the Project Management Institute,
and they've created the PMP

58
00:03:28,760 --> 00:03:33,150
certification that's built around
their model of managing projects.

59
00:03:33,150 --> 00:03:36,670
And it creates a standardized
framework that says

60
00:03:36,670 --> 00:03:41,570
here's how you perform XYZ activity as
far as managing the project is concerned.

61
00:03:41,570 --> 00:03:45,550
And if you have five different
project managers that are all PMP's,

62
00:03:45,550 --> 00:03:48,510
then they're all going to be
managing the projects the same way.

63
00:03:48,510 --> 00:03:51,390
That makes it easy to compare and
monitor projects,

64
00:03:51,390 --> 00:03:53,050
monitor performance and all that.

65
00:03:53,050 --> 00:03:56,740
And it just makes things a heck of
a lot more stable and consistent.

66
00:03:56,740 --> 00:04:01,390
So that's the real value of
something like the PMI's framework.

67
00:04:01,390 --> 00:04:06,320
And the PMP certification is your way to
designate that you know that information,

68
00:04:06,320 --> 00:04:07,720
you know how to manage a project that way.

69
00:04:07,720 --> 00:04:08,620
So very, very valuable.

70
00:04:09,852 --> 00:04:14,340
All right now, if you haven't already,
I really encourage you to go and watch,

71
00:04:14,340 --> 00:04:17,010
we did a little intro to PMP video.

72
00:04:17,010 --> 00:04:22,020
Just a video that
explained what the PMP was,

73
00:04:22,020 --> 00:04:25,220
how to get certified,
how to take the exam, the requirements,

74
00:04:25,220 --> 00:04:28,550
because not everybody meets
the requirements to take the PMP exam.

75
00:04:28,550 --> 00:04:30,160
If you don't meet the requirements,

76
00:04:30,160 --> 00:04:34,050
then there's not a heck of a lot of point
in trying to pursue the certification.

77
00:04:34,050 --> 00:04:35,800
But the knowledge is still very valuable.

78
00:04:35,800 --> 00:04:37,720
So don't feel like you
can't watch the show,

79
00:04:37,720 --> 00:04:40,090
just cuz you don't meet the requirements.

80
00:04:40,090 --> 00:04:43,480
There's a lot of value in knowing
how to properly manage a project and

81
00:04:43,480 --> 00:04:47,460
you can use that whether you're a PMP,
whether you're the project manager, or

82
00:04:47,460 --> 00:04:51,080
whether you're just a member
on that project team.

83
00:04:51,080 --> 00:04:55,500
Because if you understand how that project
manager is working, it makes it that much

84
00:04:55,500 --> 00:04:58,300
easier to communicate with them and
to get information out of them.

85
00:04:58,300 --> 00:05:02,500
Versus if you have no clue what it
is they are doing often times we

86
00:05:02,500 --> 00:05:06,290
think that they are stalling or
creating useless paperwork,

87
00:05:06,290 --> 00:05:09,080
when there's actually a reason for
what they're doing.

88
00:05:09,080 --> 00:05:12,034
So it's a very good
information to have and

89
00:05:12,034 --> 00:05:14,759
definitely a good thing to be aware of.

90
00:05:14,759 --> 00:05:19,220
All right now, the PMP itself
is an interesting certification.

91
00:05:19,220 --> 00:05:23,310
A lot of vendors that are out there,
like Microsoft and Cisco and so

92
00:05:23,310 --> 00:05:26,550
on, they had these exams and

93
00:05:26,550 --> 00:05:31,180
there's no book or whatever that
says what's gonna be on the exam.

94
00:05:31,180 --> 00:05:31,950
They give you an outline,

95
00:05:31,950 --> 00:05:36,200
and they say here's an outline of the
possible topics that could be on the exam.

96
00:05:36,200 --> 00:05:37,580
And you should know these, right?

97
00:05:37,580 --> 00:05:39,220
And then it's up to you to go out and

98
00:05:39,220 --> 00:05:41,590
learn everything you can
about each of those topics.

99
00:05:41,590 --> 00:05:47,780
Well, with the PMI, the exam is
entirely based off of one book.

100
00:05:47,780 --> 00:05:51,210
And that book is
the Project Management Body of Knowledge,

101
00:05:51,210 --> 00:05:53,665
or the PMBOK is what
a lot of people call it.

102
00:05:53,665 --> 00:05:58,390
P-M-B-O-K, the project management body
of knowledge, which is a collection of

103
00:05:58,390 --> 00:06:01,258
all the different information they
have on how to manage a project.

104
00:06:01,258 --> 00:06:03,118
It's about 600?

105
00:06:03,118 --> 00:06:03,737
>> Yeah.

106
00:06:03,737 --> 00:06:06,950
>> It's huge, it's a big book.

107
00:06:06,950 --> 00:06:10,420
And so it's a lot of information to handle
and that's where our show comes in,

108
00:06:10,420 --> 00:06:13,040
is that we're gonna go through and
kind of put it into a way that

109
00:06:13,040 --> 00:06:15,192
is a little more logical makes
a little bit more sense.

110
00:06:15,192 --> 00:06:21,365
In today's episode we're actually
gonna go through part of the PMBOK.

111
00:06:21,365 --> 00:06:22,775
In all the other episodes,

112
00:06:22,775 --> 00:06:26,385
we won't do that, cuz the PMBOK,
it doesn't read like a book.

113
00:06:26,385 --> 00:06:28,675
You're not suppose to read
it from cover to cover,

114
00:06:28,675 --> 00:06:32,945
it doesn't make sense to read it in the
order that the information is in there.

115
00:06:32,945 --> 00:06:34,915
It's designed as a reference book,
more like an encyclopedia.

116
00:06:36,085 --> 00:06:38,475
You'd never read an encyclopedia
from cover to cover,

117
00:06:38,475 --> 00:06:41,190
it's too many disjointed
ideas slapped together.

118
00:06:41,190 --> 00:06:44,000
But if you wanna learn about
the Queen of England and

119
00:06:44,000 --> 00:06:48,085
you go and you crack open the E
volume in the encyclopedia and

120
00:06:48,085 --> 00:06:51,250
you go to England or U or
whatever it would be under.

121
00:06:51,250 --> 00:06:54,490
Then you could go in there and find it and
there's the information you need.

122
00:06:54,490 --> 00:06:58,405
That's what the PMBOK
is designed to be like.

123
00:06:58,405 --> 00:06:59,590
All right.

124
00:06:59,590 --> 00:07:03,410
So, before we dive too much
into crazy specifics or

125
00:07:03,410 --> 00:07:06,950
whatever, let's start off
with some general concepts.

126
00:07:06,950 --> 00:07:07,480
>> Right.

127
00:07:07,480 --> 00:07:12,740
>> Ideas, theories, words, definitions
that we need to be aware of for the exam.

128
00:07:12,740 --> 00:07:16,400
Part of the exam is not
just knowing an idea, but

129
00:07:16,400 --> 00:07:18,350
knowing the PMIs terminology for it.

130
00:07:18,350 --> 00:07:22,660
They have special words that they use
when they refer to certain things,

131
00:07:22,660 --> 00:07:27,100
and you might use completely different
words out in your day to day operations.

132
00:07:27,100 --> 00:07:29,920
But on the exam you're gonna get
it one way and that's the PMI way.

133
00:07:31,630 --> 00:07:34,350
So let's start off with
probably the most important

134
00:07:34,350 --> 00:07:38,010
thing that we're gonna learn in
probably the entire series of shows.

135
00:07:38,010 --> 00:07:39,950
What is a project?

136
00:07:39,950 --> 00:07:43,460
Right, cuz not everything is.

137
00:07:43,460 --> 00:07:49,990
Let me see, actually I guess it'd probably
be worth while to show the PMBOK.

138
00:07:49,990 --> 00:07:54,637
If you join the project
management institute you

139
00:07:54,637 --> 00:07:57,363
get a free copy of the PMBOK.

140
00:07:57,363 --> 00:07:59,197
A digital copy and
that's what I've got pulled up here.

141
00:07:59,197 --> 00:08:01,682
If you aren't a member
you can go ahead and

142
00:08:01,682 --> 00:08:06,246
buy them they're not incredibly
expensive I think they're I don't know.

143
00:08:06,246 --> 00:08:07,290
>> $67 I think.

144
00:08:07,290 --> 00:08:07,870
>> Are they really?
>> Yeah.

145
00:08:07,870 --> 00:08:09,400
>> That seems a little high doesn't it?

146
00:08:09,400 --> 00:08:13,670
Let's see if we can find
it on old Amazon here.

147
00:08:13,670 --> 00:08:16,110
A Guide to the Project Management Body
of Knowledge.

148
00:08:16,110 --> 00:08:17,170
>> Which edition?

149
00:08:17,170 --> 00:08:20,880
Oh that says-
>> January 1, 2013, that's probably,

150
00:08:20,880 --> 00:08:24,050
oh it is 5th edition, all right.

151
00:08:24,050 --> 00:08:27,430
>> 20 bucks.
>> Wait a minute, $21 to rent?

152
00:08:27,430 --> 00:08:29,210
What is that, you can rent things now?

153
00:08:29,210 --> 00:08:29,935
>> I guess.

154
00:08:29,935 --> 00:08:31,830
>> [LAUGH] All right, well.

155
00:08:31,830 --> 00:08:32,450
Here we go.
>> There it is.

156
00:08:32,450 --> 00:08:33,460
Yeah.
Fifty bucks.

157
00:08:33,460 --> 00:08:35,290
>> So to get a paper copy is 50 bucks.

158
00:08:35,290 --> 00:08:37,100
To get the Kindle edition is 20 bucks.

159
00:08:37,100 --> 00:08:39,140
>> Yeah.
>> That's the way to go right there.

160
00:08:39,140 --> 00:08:43,500
You can go out and buy a copy, or if you
join the PMI, you get a copy for free.

161
00:08:43,500 --> 00:08:45,700
You can get one, one way or another.

162
00:08:45,700 --> 00:08:50,710
The pinbok, the project management body
of knowledge, is the PMI framework.

163
00:08:50,710 --> 00:08:52,310
This is what the exam is based on.

164
00:08:52,310 --> 00:08:53,570
This one book.

165
00:08:53,570 --> 00:08:58,590
Every answer to the exam is in this
book somewhere you just have to know it.

166
00:08:58,590 --> 00:08:59,782
But it's a big book.

167
00:08:59,782 --> 00:09:01,670
All right.
So like I've said I've got my

168
00:09:01,670 --> 00:09:03,740
PDF right here.

169
00:09:03,740 --> 00:09:10,000
And you'll see that it is a pretty
big document, 615 pages, the PDF.

170
00:09:10,000 --> 00:09:13,280
And as you go through
it breaks things down.

171
00:09:13,280 --> 00:09:17,750
And we're going to start off right
here with just,what is a project,

172
00:09:17,750 --> 00:09:18,890
what is project management.

173
00:09:18,890 --> 00:09:23,880
These general concepts and we're going
to stay true to this all the way through

174
00:09:23,880 --> 00:09:27,410
to about here,
at the end of project phases.

175
00:09:27,410 --> 00:09:31,810
Because then it starts to go into
project management processes here and

176
00:09:31,810 --> 00:09:34,140
that's where things start
to go kind of crazy.

177
00:09:34,140 --> 00:09:34,640
Right?

178
00:09:35,960 --> 00:09:40,150
They follow a very regimented
model of providing that data.

179
00:09:40,150 --> 00:09:44,395
It's not necessarily in an order
that makes sense to us normally.

180
00:09:44,395 --> 00:09:46,360
Right.
It's a barrier to learning.

181
00:09:46,360 --> 00:09:50,140
So we're going to rearrange everything
after that point in the book.

182
00:09:50,140 --> 00:09:53,270
To follow the chronological
order of managing a project.

183
00:09:53,270 --> 00:09:56,360
Put it in context, and say,
"I'm a project manager.

184
00:09:56,360 --> 00:09:59,720
How do I work with all this
stuff down here?" Well,

185
00:09:59,720 --> 00:10:03,710
we'll put it in order from when
you get started and so on.

186
00:10:03,710 --> 00:10:08,660
For example, you look here in the book and
you'll see stuff listed towards the end

187
00:10:08,660 --> 00:10:11,095
of the book that is stuff you
would do early on in the project.

188
00:10:11,095 --> 00:10:14,678
So as I move later on,
I'll show you an example.

189
00:10:14,678 --> 00:10:16,510
>> Look at 13.1.

190
00:10:16,510 --> 00:10:19,720
>> Well, yeah, here,
Plan Stakeholder Management.

191
00:10:19,720 --> 00:10:23,180
You do that very early on in the project,
it's darn near the end of the book.

192
00:10:23,180 --> 00:10:27,360
So it's put an order here
based on your job role,

193
00:10:27,360 --> 00:10:30,400
what it is that your
job responsibility is.

194
00:10:30,400 --> 00:10:32,090
But we'll take it and
make it chronological.

195
00:10:32,090 --> 00:10:33,580
It makes a little more sense there.

196
00:10:33,580 --> 00:10:37,580
But definitely good information in here
you want to have a copy of the PIMBAC

197
00:10:37,580 --> 00:10:40,630
handy just as a reference
to see the official way.

198
00:10:40,630 --> 00:10:41,920
And, they got some nice diagrams.

199
00:10:42,930 --> 00:10:45,240
You can always count on
the PMI to have good diagrams.

200
00:10:45,240 --> 00:10:48,950
So definitely worth looking at there.

201
00:10:48,950 --> 00:10:52,130
All right.
So I want to start off with that basic

202
00:10:52,130 --> 00:10:57,670
idea of what is a project, and
PMI has a very very specific

203
00:10:57,670 --> 00:11:01,670
definition of what that project is, and
it's this first sentence right here.

204
00:11:01,670 --> 00:11:06,770
A project is a temporary endeavor
undertaken to create a unique product,

205
00:11:06,770 --> 00:11:08,345
service, or result.

206
00:11:08,345 --> 00:11:08,930
Okay?

207
00:11:08,930 --> 00:11:14,370
That one sentence,
it sounds really simple,

208
00:11:14,370 --> 00:11:17,140
but it's communicating something very,
very important.

209
00:11:17,140 --> 00:11:19,315
That keyword being temporary.

210
00:11:19,315 --> 00:11:20,410
Right?

211
00:11:20,410 --> 00:11:24,320
You never have open ended projects.

212
00:11:24,320 --> 00:11:27,270
Somethings is either a project or
it's not.

213
00:11:27,270 --> 00:11:30,970
Projects have to have
a defined finish point.

214
00:11:30,970 --> 00:11:32,982
A way to know that they are complete.

215
00:11:32,982 --> 00:11:34,170
All right?

216
00:11:34,170 --> 00:11:36,650
In a company you have two
different types of activities.

217
00:11:36,650 --> 00:11:42,384
You have projects, like these, and you
have what are called on-going operations.

218
00:11:42,384 --> 00:11:43,124
All right?

219
00:11:43,124 --> 00:11:46,820
On-going operations don't have
an end date, they're not temporary.

220
00:11:46,820 --> 00:11:50,330
Their long running projects are temporary.

221
00:11:50,330 --> 00:11:50,930
>> Yeah.

222
00:11:50,930 --> 00:11:54,430
>> So for example,
let's say that you work for

223
00:11:54,430 --> 00:11:57,900
Ford Motor Company, so a car manufacturer.

224
00:11:57,900 --> 00:12:02,160
And you as a company decide that
it's time to create a new car.

225
00:12:02,160 --> 00:12:04,180
So what's a Ford?

226
00:12:04,180 --> 00:12:05,365
>> Let's do a Ford Focus.

227
00:12:05,365 --> 00:12:06,410
[LAUGH]
>> A Ford Focus.

228
00:12:06,410 --> 00:12:09,510
All right,
we're picking the luxury vehicle.

229
00:12:09,510 --> 00:12:11,280
Alright so the Ford Focus.

230
00:12:11,280 --> 00:12:14,238
So we decided hey, it's 2014 right now.

231
00:12:14,238 --> 00:12:15,090
>> Right.

232
00:12:15,090 --> 00:12:20,580
>> 2015's around the corner, so
we need to design our new Ford Focus.

233
00:12:20,580 --> 00:12:22,210
So we create a project.

234
00:12:23,390 --> 00:12:27,800
Creating that Ford Focus,
creating the new model for 2015.

235
00:12:27,800 --> 00:12:30,070
That is a temporary endeavor.

236
00:12:30,070 --> 00:12:34,680
You're not gonna be constantly creating
a new model for 2015 in 2016 or 2017.

237
00:12:34,680 --> 00:12:38,090
So you've got a deadline too.

238
00:12:38,090 --> 00:12:40,970
We need to finish that design
by a particular time so

239
00:12:40,970 --> 00:12:42,950
that we have time to manufacture
the car so it's ready.

240
00:12:42,950 --> 00:12:47,590
And we're in May, of 2014, so
2015s are probably already out.

241
00:12:47,590 --> 00:12:48,350
>> Yeah.

242
00:12:48,350 --> 00:12:52,530
>> So lets say it's the 2016 Ford Focus.

243
00:12:52,530 --> 00:12:56,820
Well, we probably need to have that
done by December of this year.

244
00:12:56,820 --> 00:13:00,150
So that it can manufacture it and
get it on sale by summer of 2015,

245
00:13:00,150 --> 00:13:02,650
since that's what they seem
to do with the models.

246
00:13:02,650 --> 00:13:04,140
So, we got a deadline.

247
00:13:04,140 --> 00:13:06,510
We need a new design for this vehicle and

248
00:13:06,510 --> 00:13:11,260
manufacturing process in place
by December of this year.

249
00:13:11,260 --> 00:13:12,420
All right?

250
00:13:12,420 --> 00:13:14,300
Now, we start to create
the project around that.

251
00:13:14,300 --> 00:13:18,020
We assemble our team members, we come
up with our work breakdown structure.

252
00:13:18,020 --> 00:13:20,680
All the various things that we need
to do to manage the project, and

253
00:13:20,680 --> 00:13:23,050
we work towards that deadline.

254
00:13:23,050 --> 00:13:27,550
And when we hit that deadline,
how do we know if we're successful?

255
00:13:27,550 --> 00:13:29,390
Did we finish what we set out to do?

256
00:13:29,390 --> 00:13:33,610
Did we come up with a design for
the new 2016 Ford Focus?

257
00:13:33,610 --> 00:13:35,540
And is it ready for manufacturing.

258
00:13:35,540 --> 00:13:36,440
All right?

259
00:13:36,440 --> 00:13:37,510
That's a project.

260
00:13:37,510 --> 00:13:41,990
Now when that project's done,
we create a design.

261
00:13:41,990 --> 00:13:42,670
Right?

262
00:13:42,670 --> 00:13:45,380
So now the company starts
manufacturing that car, and

263
00:13:45,380 --> 00:13:49,240
they're gonna manufacture
not one 2016 Ford Focus.

264
00:13:49,240 --> 00:13:53,460
They're gonna manufacture
tens of thousands, hundreds,

265
00:13:53,460 --> 00:13:55,290
I have no idea how many
of those cars they sell.

266
00:13:55,290 --> 00:13:57,710
Probably hundreds of thousands,
I'd imagine.

267
00:13:57,710 --> 00:13:59,610
You see them all over the road.

268
00:13:59,610 --> 00:14:02,360
So they're gonna manufacture tons of them.

269
00:14:02,360 --> 00:14:04,610
Well, those aren't projects.

270
00:14:04,610 --> 00:14:06,495
That's an ongoing operation.

271
00:14:06,495 --> 00:14:08,400
Right?
They're manufacturing cars

272
00:14:08,400 --> 00:14:09,770
every single day.

273
00:14:09,770 --> 00:14:12,560
Might be different cars, but
they are manufacturing cars every day, so

274
00:14:12,560 --> 00:14:15,250
that's an ongoing
operation of the company.

275
00:14:15,250 --> 00:14:19,330
Ongoing operations are normally
how your company makes money.

276
00:14:19,330 --> 00:14:21,880
Your company doesn't normally
make money from projects,

277
00:14:21,880 --> 00:14:23,248
they normally make it
from ongoing operations.

278
00:14:23,248 --> 00:14:24,141
Right?

279
00:14:24,141 --> 00:14:29,120
An exception would be in IT.

280
00:14:29,120 --> 00:14:33,270
If you're a contractor and
somebody hires you to perform a project

281
00:14:33,270 --> 00:14:36,370
well you're making money
by doing that project.

282
00:14:36,370 --> 00:14:38,780
But the company that is
sponsoring this project.

283
00:14:38,780 --> 00:14:40,090
They're not only making money from that,

284
00:14:40,090 --> 00:14:42,820
they're making money from
the ongoing operation of it.

285
00:14:42,820 --> 00:14:43,770
Alright?

286
00:14:43,770 --> 00:14:48,010
So, for example, I might create a project
here for our studio, and say, boy,

287
00:14:48,010 --> 00:14:50,130
this light over here
just seems too bright.

288
00:14:50,130 --> 00:14:54,060
So I'm gonna create a project that is to

289
00:14:54,060 --> 00:14:57,500
redesign our lighting solution here for
the studio.

290
00:14:57,500 --> 00:15:00,720
So I go out and I find a contractor
do the whole process and

291
00:15:00,720 --> 00:15:02,035
get them to come in and do this.

292
00:15:02,035 --> 00:15:02,560
Right?

293
00:15:02,560 --> 00:15:04,150
So now I've got a project.

294
00:15:04,150 --> 00:15:06,220
I'm not adjusting lights every day.

295
00:15:06,220 --> 00:15:09,090
I'm just having them come in and
do it this one time, get things set right.

296
00:15:09,090 --> 00:15:10,720
All right?
And then we stop.

297
00:15:10,720 --> 00:15:13,820
Now, we don't make money because
our lighting is right, or

298
00:15:13,820 --> 00:15:18,140
because of that project, but once the
lighting is right, our videos look better,

299
00:15:18,140 --> 00:15:20,640
people want to watch them more,
and that's how we make money.

300
00:15:20,640 --> 00:15:22,480
So that's an ongoing thing.

301
00:15:22,480 --> 00:15:25,129
When we film an episode,
that's an ongoing operation for us.

302
00:15:26,770 --> 00:15:28,278
Getting us to show up.

303
00:15:28,278 --> 00:15:29,642
>> [LAUGH] l
>> That's the project around here.

304
00:15:29,642 --> 00:15:31,239
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

305
00:15:31,239 --> 00:15:34,060
>> All right.
So keep that in mind on the exam.

306
00:15:34,060 --> 00:15:36,500
The keyword here, temporary.

307
00:15:36,500 --> 00:15:37,760
Right?
Temporary, and

308
00:15:37,760 --> 00:15:40,440
it has to have a well defined finish.

309
00:15:40,440 --> 00:15:41,872
Some way that we know we're done.

310
00:15:41,872 --> 00:15:43,070
All right?

311
00:15:43,070 --> 00:15:47,200
If you have a project that doesn't have a
well defined way of establishing that it's

312
00:15:47,200 --> 00:15:49,036
done you are doomed to failure.

313
00:15:49,036 --> 00:15:50,542
All right?

314
00:15:50,542 --> 00:15:54,003
When I was a kid,
Mom would give me a chore.

315
00:15:54,003 --> 00:15:55,490
She would say clean the house.

316
00:15:55,490 --> 00:15:58,742
Well how do you know when you are done?

317
00:15:58,742 --> 00:16:00,599
How do you know when the house is clean?

318
00:16:00,599 --> 00:16:02,561
Well I'll tell you as a kid it isn't,
right?

319
00:16:02,561 --> 00:16:04,581
So there is no finished, right?

320
00:16:04,581 --> 00:16:08,180
So no matter how much or
how little you do it's not done.

321
00:16:08,180 --> 00:16:10,110
So we need to have something
that's well defined, and

322
00:16:10,110 --> 00:16:13,880
we say all right if I clean the house
I mean you need to vacuum the floor,

323
00:16:13,880 --> 00:16:17,460
all the dishes need to be washed and
the garbage needs to be taken out, right?

324
00:16:17,460 --> 00:16:20,520
That's something I can measure against,
are those three things done?

325
00:16:20,520 --> 00:16:21,670
Yes, the house is cleaned.

326
00:16:21,670 --> 00:16:22,970
Are those three things not done?

327
00:16:22,970 --> 00:16:24,270
No, it's not clean, right?

328
00:16:24,270 --> 00:16:26,440
So, that's another part of a project.

329
00:16:26,440 --> 00:16:29,100
It's got to be well-defined.

330
00:16:29,100 --> 00:16:34,722
All right, and we're going to see
that as we go through the show.

331
00:16:34,722 --> 00:16:38,615
Having things well-defined is really the
key to success because, otherwise you can

332
00:16:38,615 --> 00:16:42,179
end up with, we'll talk about this later
also, which is called scope creep,

333
00:16:42,179 --> 00:16:45,854
where if you don't define your project
with rigid boundaries, your project has

334
00:16:45,854 --> 00:16:49,475
a tendency to grow and get bigger and
bigger and messier and messier, and before

335
00:16:49,475 --> 00:16:53,297
you know it you're way over budget, way
behind schedule, and doomed to failure.

336
00:16:53,297 --> 00:16:55,330
Alright.

337
00:16:55,330 --> 00:16:58,080
So keep that in mind as we go forth.

338
00:16:59,630 --> 00:17:02,410
Alright now the result of a project,

339
00:17:02,410 --> 00:17:06,300
when a project is done a lot of us think
of it as creating something tangible,

340
00:17:06,300 --> 00:17:11,185
something you can hold but, I'll tell you,
in IT, that's not always the case.

341
00:17:11,185 --> 00:17:15,175
The result of the project might
be to create a web server or

342
00:17:15,175 --> 00:17:17,985
a website or something like that and
then you do have something tangible.

343
00:17:17,985 --> 00:17:20,645
You can see this new website but,

344
00:17:20,645 --> 00:17:25,175
many times the project might be
simply to create a process, right.

345
00:17:25,175 --> 00:17:27,430
Using the forward example again.

346
00:17:27,430 --> 00:17:29,460
If we created the design there, right.

347
00:17:29,460 --> 00:17:31,880
The design for the 2016 Ford Focus.

348
00:17:31,880 --> 00:17:33,308
We didn't actually make the car.

349
00:17:33,308 --> 00:17:35,630
We might have done some prototypes,
as part of the project but

350
00:17:35,630 --> 00:17:37,570
we didn't actually create the car.

351
00:17:37,570 --> 00:17:41,430
We created an idea, a service, a process.

352
00:17:41,430 --> 00:17:42,080
Right?

353
00:17:42,080 --> 00:17:45,308
And then that process gets used to
create the actual tangible item.

354
00:17:45,308 --> 00:17:48,116
All right.

355
00:17:48,116 --> 00:17:52,347
So, there are a few other terms we
need to be aware of that can be kind

356
00:17:52,347 --> 00:17:54,850
of confused in the world of projects.

357
00:17:54,850 --> 00:17:55,500
Right?

358
00:17:55,500 --> 00:18:01,570
So, we have projects,
portfolios and programs.

359
00:18:01,570 --> 00:18:02,380
All right?

360
00:18:02,380 --> 00:18:03,680
What the heck are these?

361
00:18:04,770 --> 00:18:10,840
Well any given company might have one
project going on at once, they might have

362
00:18:10,840 --> 00:18:13,910
ten projects going on, they might have
fifty projects going on at once, right?

363
00:18:13,910 --> 00:18:17,460
So you might have many many projects
going on at any given time.

364
00:18:18,740 --> 00:18:20,700
If you take all of those projects and

365
00:18:20,700 --> 00:18:25,030
group them together that is
what's called your program.

366
00:18:25,030 --> 00:18:30,240
Okay, a program is a collection
of projects that have similar or

367
00:18:30,240 --> 00:18:31,340
related goals.

368
00:18:31,340 --> 00:18:35,080
In fact, I think they say that in here
somewhere, but, you know, similar or

369
00:18:35,080 --> 00:18:35,990
related goals.

370
00:18:35,990 --> 00:18:40,380
One of the best examples that I can
think of, you know, we're in the U.S.

371
00:18:40,380 --> 00:18:42,760
So I always think of U.S. based examples.

372
00:18:42,760 --> 00:18:48,280
The United States government has
the United States space program, right?

373
00:18:48,280 --> 00:18:51,430
Our space program is headed up by NASA,

374
00:18:51,430 --> 00:18:56,187
the National Aeronautics and
Space something.

375
00:18:56,187 --> 00:19:00,100
[LAUGH] So we have NASA that
heads up our space program.

376
00:19:00,100 --> 00:19:04,370
And they have a number of projects,
every spaceship launch,

377
00:19:04,370 --> 00:19:06,850
every time they launch a rocket,
every time they launch a shuttle,

378
00:19:06,850 --> 00:19:08,630
which I guess they don't do anymore.

379
00:19:08,630 --> 00:19:13,210
Any time they do those things, each one is
a project, but all of them are working to

380
00:19:13,210 --> 00:19:17,410
a similar goal, to do research and
exploration in outer space.

381
00:19:17,410 --> 00:19:22,510
And so a similar goal, different unique
projects all grouped together into one

382
00:19:22,510 --> 00:19:28,740
program, then, the United States
government has more than one program.

383
00:19:28,740 --> 00:19:33,420
So we get the space program but
we also have the education program, and

384
00:19:33,420 --> 00:19:37,240
other things, like welfare program,
each of these different social services.

385
00:19:37,240 --> 00:19:39,010
Each of those are programs.

386
00:19:39,010 --> 00:19:42,230
If we gather all those programs together,

387
00:19:42,230 --> 00:19:46,890
that's our portfolio and I mean,
you got to be big to have a portfolio.

388
00:19:46,890 --> 00:19:48,650
Yeah.
I use the United States Government,

389
00:19:48,650 --> 00:19:51,930
how much bigger of a company
can we think of, you know,

390
00:19:51,930 --> 00:19:56,710
in the private sector it's not often
that you see programs like this.

391
00:19:56,710 --> 00:19:57,660
>> Yeah.

392
00:19:57,660 --> 00:20:05,770
>> Microsoft, Oracle, HP, huge companies
like that they may well have a portfolio.

393
00:20:05,770 --> 00:20:07,473
We'll use HP, right.

394
00:20:07,473 --> 00:20:10,760
So HP they have various divisions inside
of their company, they have service

395
00:20:10,760 --> 00:20:15,750
divisions, server divisions, desktop and
laptop, consumer and business.

396
00:20:15,750 --> 00:20:19,330
So each of those might be
part of their programs.

397
00:20:19,330 --> 00:20:22,340
And then each program then has
individual projects inside of it, so

398
00:20:22,340 --> 00:20:24,330
it just depends on the size
of your organization.

399
00:20:24,330 --> 00:20:27,730
You may or may not have these three
elements, but just be aware that

400
00:20:27,730 --> 00:20:31,660
portfolio, program, project,
three distinctly different things.

401
00:20:31,660 --> 00:20:35,642
>> Yeah I know the example you were using
about Ford Motor Company itself, right?

402
00:20:35,642 --> 00:20:38,841
You actually can have different divisions,
like their car division and

403
00:20:38,841 --> 00:20:42,050
their truck division again,
each of those may be programs within that.

404
00:20:42,050 --> 00:20:45,308
Each particular design match should
be a project unto itself and

405
00:20:45,308 --> 00:20:48,400
then year by year there may be
sub projects underneath that.

406
00:20:48,400 --> 00:20:52,930
So again, a lot of times, when you
take a look here, you'll see that.

407
00:20:52,930 --> 00:20:55,440
Just about any company can actually
have a number of different

408
00:20:55,440 --> 00:20:57,260
projects that are going on within,

409
00:20:57,260 --> 00:21:00,300
that may be controlled by different
programs that are actually under them.

410
00:21:00,300 --> 00:21:04,120
So just realize that everybody actually
is going to fall in there somewhere

411
00:21:04,120 --> 00:21:05,300
in the midst of project management.

412
00:21:05,300 --> 00:21:08,370
You're going to actually see that
it's going to really again determine

413

some of the ways that our project develops

414
00:21:10,870 --> 00:21:15,050
depending on where we are actually in
that particular portfolio and program.

which a completely forgot about, and

it jogged my memory about

See here how they've got

and then from there it divides down.

And normally under the portfolio
you'll have programs,

It's up to your company to create

And then under the program that's

sub programs and

So projects are that bottom Line entry,

434

436

437
00:22:23,550 --> 00:22:27,210
So those are some of the different

438
00:22:27,210 --> 00:22:32,020
After that we need to talk a little
bit about what a project is made up of

439
00:22:32,020 --> 00:22:35,625
because a project can be a very,
very big thing.

440
00:22:35,625 --> 00:22:38,275
It can contain all sorts
of different elements and

441
00:22:38,275 --> 00:22:41,855
components, and it's difficult to
kind of envision the whole picture.

442
00:22:41,855 --> 00:22:46,765
So I did a drawing which I've got
around here somewhere, here we go.

443
00:22:46,765 --> 00:22:50,810
And this is basically what a project is.

444
00:22:50,810 --> 00:22:54,190
A project is broken up into five phases.

445
00:22:54,190 --> 00:22:56,540
Now this is a PMI thing.

446
00:22:56,540 --> 00:22:58,600
PMI has five phases.

447
00:22:58,600 --> 00:23:03,180
You'll see other people like ITIL.

448
00:23:03,180 --> 00:23:04,780
If you start digging through ITIL and

449
00:23:04,780 --> 00:23:07,410
finding their project management
stuff they have six phases.

450
00:23:07,410 --> 00:23:13,250
So different vendors, different frameworks
but with PMI you have five phases.

451
00:23:13,250 --> 00:23:18,080
You have initiation,
which is just the project getting started.

452
00:23:18,080 --> 00:23:21,120
How do we know to start a project and
get it up and going?

453
00:23:23,330 --> 00:23:26,570
After that we have planning,
the planning phase is, okay,

454
00:23:26,570 --> 00:23:30,350
we've decided to do this project,
what do we need to do, right?

455
00:23:30,350 --> 00:23:33,150
And if you're a good project manager

456
00:23:33,150 --> 00:23:35,425
this is probably where you'll spend
the bulk of your time, right.

457
00:23:35,425 --> 00:23:40,280
You got to figure out how many people do
you need, how much money do you need, how

458
00:23:40,280 --> 00:23:44,480
much time do you need or if you've been
assigned time and money how do you get

459
00:23:44,480 --> 00:23:47,940
everything done with the amount of time or
with the amount of money that you have?

460
00:23:47,940 --> 00:23:52,146
You really have to look at all the stuff
that gets done in the project and

461
00:23:52,146 --> 00:23:54,440
what makes up those aspects, right?

462
00:23:54,440 --> 00:23:59,712
So, arranging to get everything, setting
out that plan, that schedule, that budget.

463
00:23:59,712 --> 00:24:02,173
All the things that you're
going to live and die by.

464
00:24:02,173 --> 00:24:04,020
As this project goes on.

465
00:24:04,020 --> 00:24:10,197
Once all of your planning is done,
then you have execution.

466
00:24:10,197 --> 00:24:14,250
Execution is where you
actually do the work.

467
00:24:14,250 --> 00:24:17,040
As a project manager, you're probably
not the person doing the work.

468
00:24:17,040 --> 00:24:19,680
You're overseeing,
making sure that it's getting done.

469
00:24:19,680 --> 00:24:24,730
So maybe you've got a construction
project, and so you're building a house.

470
00:24:24,730 --> 00:24:28,870
And so in the planning phase, you come up
with all the different elements necessary

471
00:24:28,870 --> 00:24:32,810
for what it takes to build a house.

472
00:24:32,810 --> 00:24:37,680
But when it gets to execution, you've got
contractors, you've got carpenters and

473
00:24:37,680 --> 00:24:38,440
master builders, and

474
00:24:38,440 --> 00:24:43,220
all those people who are actually in
there doing the work to build that house.

475
00:24:43,220 --> 00:24:49,040
While they are building the house,
you are monitoring and controlling.

476
00:24:49,040 --> 00:24:51,320
That's our fourth phase,
monitoring and controlling.

477
00:24:51,320 --> 00:24:53,450
The monitoring piece is
pretty self explanatory.

478
00:24:53,450 --> 00:24:54,280
We watch.

479
00:24:54,280 --> 00:24:55,010
Right?

480
00:24:55,010 --> 00:24:59,780
Is work getting done on schedule,
on budget, meeting requirements, right?

481
00:24:59,780 --> 00:25:01,130
Three things that we constantly watch for.

482
00:25:02,260 --> 00:25:05,120
If yes, great, we do nothing, right?

483
00:25:05,120 --> 00:25:06,919
Well, paperwork.

484
00:25:06,919 --> 00:25:10,010
If no, we control, right?

485
00:25:10,010 --> 00:25:12,820
We step in, and we correct the issue.

486
00:25:12,820 --> 00:25:13,900
Why are we over budget?

487
00:25:13,900 --> 00:25:15,220
What can we do to fix it?

488
00:25:15,220 --> 00:25:16,480
Why are we behind schedule?

489
00:25:16,480 --> 00:25:18,090
What can we use to get back?

490
00:25:18,090 --> 00:25:20,680
Why am I, not meeting this requirement?

491
00:25:20,680 --> 00:25:22,500
What can we do to finish it?

492
00:25:22,500 --> 00:25:24,970
And there's actually two
sides to this whole thing.

493
00:25:24,970 --> 00:25:28,070
So, why am I over budget
is easy to think of, but

494
00:25:28,070 --> 00:25:31,095
you might also have why am I under budget?

495
00:25:31,095 --> 00:25:33,280
>> Mm-hm.
>> Why am I not spending as much money as

496
00:25:33,280 --> 00:25:34,440
I thought I was going to?

497
00:25:34,440 --> 00:25:36,260
>> Yeah.
>> What's wrong, what's missing?

498
00:25:36,260 --> 00:25:40,210
Why am I not meeting that requirement,
because often times the,

499
00:25:41,270 --> 00:25:44,370
this is a quote from Dude?

500
00:25:44,370 --> 00:25:45,838
>> [LAUGH]
>> The Dune books,

501
00:25:45,838 --> 00:25:48,132
I quote those entirely too much but,

502
00:25:48,132 --> 00:25:52,578
sometimes the absence of a thing is
as deadly as the presence of a thing.

503
00:25:52,578 --> 00:25:55,170
So the absence of spending money, why not?

504
00:25:55,170 --> 00:25:57,810
Maybe that indicates that I let
something fall through the cracks.

505
00:25:57,810 --> 00:25:59,840
I was supposed to order something and
didn't.

506
00:25:59,840 --> 00:26:03,790
Or contractors were supposed to do
some work, but they didn't do it and

507
00:26:03,790 --> 00:26:06,090
they didn't bill me, and
that's why I haven't spent that money.

508
00:26:06,090 --> 00:26:08,370
So definitely pay attention to that.

509
00:26:09,560 --> 00:26:12,950
And then lastly,
when all the requirements have been met,

510
00:26:12,950 --> 00:26:16,780
when everybody's signed off on everything,
we have closing.

511
00:26:16,780 --> 00:26:19,410
We shut the project down,
and we determine whether or

512
00:26:19,410 --> 00:26:22,220
not it was successful or a failure?

513
00:26:22,220 --> 00:26:24,980
And boy,
that's a phase that a lot of people skip,

514
00:26:24,980 --> 00:26:27,080
they just let the project peter out.

515
00:26:27,080 --> 00:26:29,350
But, it is important to
do a proper closing and

516
00:26:29,350 --> 00:26:32,120
we'll talk about that in a later episode.

517
00:26:32,120 --> 00:26:34,790
But basically, this is what's going
to define that whole project.

518
00:26:34,790 --> 00:26:37,470
These five phases, right here.

519
00:26:37,470 --> 00:26:39,970
You wanna memorize these for the exam.

520
00:26:39,970 --> 00:26:42,700
>> Now remember, since this particular
certification is about project

521
00:26:42,700 --> 00:26:43,910
management, right?

522
00:26:43,910 --> 00:26:47,340
It gives us the ability,
regardless of the size of the project,

523
00:26:47,340 --> 00:26:51,730
to essentially be able to kind of chop
them down into manageable chunks,

524
00:26:51,730 --> 00:26:53,845
which is the whole idea behind
the project management.

525
00:26:53,845 --> 00:26:55,870
>> [LAUGH]
>> Instead of just going here's things

526
00:26:55,870 --> 00:27:00,680
that I have to accomplish right, we can
be begin with the idea of initiation, and

527
00:27:00,680 --> 00:27:02,930
just making sure it
gets started correctly.

528
00:27:02,930 --> 00:27:05,150
And then go from that point here,
without going,

529
00:27:05,150 --> 00:27:09,050
I wonder if the invest is gonna be okay,
we go ahead and begin the process and

530
00:27:09,050 --> 00:27:11,650
we follow these particular steps through.

531
00:27:11,650 --> 00:27:14,890
And once we do so, we'll actually
see that if everybody else is doing,

532
00:27:14,890 --> 00:27:17,240
it makes it very easy like
we said at the beginning.

533
00:27:17,240 --> 00:27:21,270
That if we have to step in in the middle
of a project, we know where the project

534
00:27:21,270 --> 00:27:24,330
is and that we might be able
actually take over when we need to.

535
00:27:24,330 --> 00:27:28,120
Or again, if we actually have to help out
we know exactly where we are as well.

536
00:27:28,120 --> 00:27:31,130
So, knowing these five steps and
these processes,

537
00:27:31,130 --> 00:27:34,319
are really the key to understanding
the whole of project management.

538
00:27:35,570 --> 00:27:38,530
And now, also keep in mind
that what you're seeing here,

539
00:27:38,530 --> 00:27:42,640
this is the text book definition
of how the five phases work, but

540
00:27:42,640 --> 00:27:45,200
in real life things
are a little bit different.

541
00:27:45,200 --> 00:27:47,600
So, understand that there
is some deviation for

542
00:27:47,600 --> 00:27:50,220
this, and
you'll even see that on the exam.

543
00:27:50,220 --> 00:27:54,010
So I created two diagrams, I created
this one, project phases logical.

544
00:27:54,010 --> 00:27:56,435
But, I also created
project phases reality.

545
00:27:56,435 --> 00:27:58,850
>> [LAUGH]
>> In reality,

546
00:27:58,850 --> 00:28:02,240
it's a little bit different
than what we just saw.

547
00:28:02,240 --> 00:28:08,440
So, for example, we start out with
initiation, just like I threw in earlier.

548
00:28:08,440 --> 00:28:11,660
And that transitions us into planning,
okay?

549
00:28:11,660 --> 00:28:15,250
But from planning, execution and

550
00:28:15,250 --> 00:28:18,840
monitoring and controlling
really happen at the same time.

551
00:28:20,010 --> 00:28:22,610
Some people are executing
the project work,

552
00:28:22,610 --> 00:28:27,140
they're getting it done, and
other people are watching that work.

553
00:28:27,140 --> 00:28:30,330
To ensure that it is getting done,
that it's on schedule, on budget,

554
00:28:30,330 --> 00:28:34,120
meeting requirements,
verifying all that is happening.

555
00:28:34,120 --> 00:28:38,480
Those two happen at the same
time at least, normally they do.

556
00:28:38,480 --> 00:28:42,630
There are some projects where somebody
executes, then somebody monitors, so it's.

557
00:28:42,630 --> 00:28:46,170
One after the other, but typically
they're done at the same time, and

558
00:28:46,170 --> 00:28:51,274
when we talk about controlling that
means hey something is not right.

559
00:28:51,274 --> 00:28:51,806
How do we fix it?

560
00:28:51,806 --> 00:28:56,530
Well, how do we fix it requires us to go

561
00:28:56,530 --> 00:29:00,830
back to planning, and
we plan for our correction.

562
00:29:00,830 --> 00:29:04,100
These are generally represented as what
are called change management tickets.

563
00:29:04,100 --> 00:29:06,790
We'll go well into depth later on.

564
00:29:06,790 --> 00:29:09,300
But you're changing the project.

565
00:29:09,300 --> 00:29:10,870
Something didn't go as planned.

566
00:29:10,870 --> 00:29:12,750
Now, you've got to update the plan.

567
00:29:12,750 --> 00:29:17,090
So we have to go back to the planning
phase, make adjustments, and

568
00:29:17,090 --> 00:29:19,760
then go back to executing and
monitoring again.

569
00:29:19,760 --> 00:29:20,380
Right?

570
00:29:20,380 --> 00:29:22,910
And if everything goes great, wonderful.

571
00:29:22,910 --> 00:29:27,750
But if our changes don't work, if we're
still behind schedule or over budget or

572
00:29:27,750 --> 00:29:30,430
whatever, we go back to planning again.

573
00:29:30,430 --> 00:29:34,650
We might cycle through
these three phases ten, 20,

574
00:29:34,650 --> 00:29:38,370
100, 1,000 times as the project goes on.

575
00:29:38,370 --> 00:29:42,110
Leaving from execution and
monitoring, back to planning, and

576
00:29:42,110 --> 00:29:44,790
back to executing again just as we go.

577
00:29:44,790 --> 00:29:47,650
Every change ticket that
we process is really

578
00:29:47,650 --> 00:29:50,000
returning to the planning phase,
all right?

579
00:29:50,000 --> 00:29:52,730
So, I kind of drew some
arrows to send us back.

580
00:29:52,730 --> 00:29:55,620
And then, when the work is done,

581
00:29:56,940 --> 00:30:02,520
execution doesn't really lead to closing,
so I did a little dash line.

582
00:30:02,520 --> 00:30:03,920
Basically, people execute.

583
00:30:03,920 --> 00:30:07,190
They do the work, and then they stop.

584
00:30:07,190 --> 00:30:11,620
And when the monitoring phase,
when these people who are monitoring

585
00:30:11,620 --> 00:30:16,140
the system look at it and say,
yes now you meet the requirements.

586
00:30:16,140 --> 00:30:21,560
It's the monitoring phase that
actually moves us into closing, but

587
00:30:21,560 --> 00:30:24,210
you can't do that until execution is done.

588
00:30:24,210 --> 00:30:27,950
So, really they both point to closing,
but it's truly the monitoring and

589
00:30:27,950 --> 00:30:29,840
controlling side that sends us there.

590
00:30:29,840 --> 00:30:32,240
So this diagram,
this is just one that I did,

591
00:30:32,240 --> 00:30:37,020
it's not in the pinblock, but
it kind of shows how things really go.

>> Yeah.

>> So keep that in mind, as we move
through each of the different phases.

00:31:49,460 --> 00:31:51,910
