621
00:31:53,000 --> 00:31:55,417
All right, let's start with project team.

622
00:31:55,417 --> 00:31:59,530
When we have a project, the project,
that's that overall goal,

623
00:31:59,530 --> 00:32:02,185
that thing that we're trying to achieve.

624
00:32:02,185 --> 00:32:06,023
The project team, are the people who
are working to achieve that goal.

625
00:32:06,023 --> 00:32:06,743
Now.

626
00:32:06,743 --> 00:32:09,948
Don't confuse that with the people
that are actually doing the work.

627
00:32:09,948 --> 00:32:15,319
In a small company, like us ITProTV,
we're a small company, if there's

628
00:32:15,319 --> 00:32:21,120
a project the odds are every single
one of us is involved in that project.

629
00:32:21,120 --> 00:32:25,910
So we might be the ones managing project
and the ones executing, we might be doing

630
00:32:25,910 --> 00:32:30,790
the actual work but in larger projects,
that's not the case, very rarely the case.

631
00:32:30,790 --> 00:32:34,420
So for example,
the largest project that I worked on,

632
00:32:34,420 --> 00:32:38,920
I dealt with a couple that were in
the 2 plus million dollar range and

633
00:32:38,920 --> 00:32:44,360
a large project like that rarely is the
project manager the person who's actually

634
00:32:44,360 --> 00:32:47,140
doing the work, that's not your expertise,
that's not what you're getting paid for.

635
00:32:47,140 --> 00:32:49,660
You are making sure
the project is successful.

636
00:32:49,660 --> 00:32:54,530
So on those projects,
you have a project team that consists at

637
00:32:54,530 --> 00:32:58,380
a minimum a project manager, right and
in a small business, maybe that's it.

638
00:32:58,380 --> 00:33:00,790
That is the whole project team,
but in a large business,

639
00:33:00,790 --> 00:33:04,990
you'll typically have an accountant,
maybe one or more lawyers,

640
00:33:04,990 --> 00:33:09,555
you may have scheduling assistants,
you may have clerks, you may have

641
00:33:09,555 --> 00:33:14,150
sub-project managers, you might have
various people that are involved,

642
00:33:14,150 --> 00:33:19,880
not in actually pulling off the project,
as far as the manual labor, but

643
00:33:19,880 --> 00:33:24,690
managing, if I can say it, the bureaucracy
of doing project management.

644
00:33:24,690 --> 00:33:28,170
The bigger a project is the more
paperwork and bureaucracy you have, and

645
00:33:28,170 --> 00:33:30,840
you're going to need
people to help with that.

646
00:33:30,840 --> 00:33:33,910
Many, many organizations out there
have scheduling coordinators,

647
00:33:33,910 --> 00:33:36,910
people who are scheduling who
can do what work what day.

648
00:33:36,910 --> 00:33:39,645
The project manager's making
sure the work gets done but

649
00:33:39,645 --> 00:33:40,935
they're not actually doing the work.

650
00:33:40,935 --> 00:33:44,215
So somebody else is coordinating getting
that in place, getting those people to

651
00:33:44,215 --> 00:33:46,835
where they're supposed to be on time so
that the work can happen.

652
00:33:46,835 --> 00:33:47,495
All right?

653
00:33:47,495 --> 00:33:51,405
So your project team can be made up of
a number of different types of people,

654
00:33:51,405 --> 00:33:54,880
depending on your organization and
the size of the project.

655
00:33:54,880 --> 00:33:58,470
If you're running a NASA level project,
your project,

656
00:33:58,470 --> 00:34:01,940
your project team,
might be hundreds of people or

657
00:34:01,940 --> 00:34:07,190
your project team might be five people,
just the people running the project.

658
00:34:07,190 --> 00:34:09,820
For example, you'll have the PM,
the project manager,

659
00:34:09,820 --> 00:34:14,270
you probably have an architect, you have
the financial consultants or whatever, so

660
00:34:14,270 --> 00:34:16,260
those are people that will
be on the project team but

661
00:34:16,260 --> 00:34:20,250
then you have the guys who pour cement for
the foundation, the plumbers,

662
00:34:20,250 --> 00:34:23,560
the electricians, the drywall installers.

663
00:34:23,560 --> 00:34:25,840
All of those people,
they're not on the project team,

664
00:34:25,840 --> 00:34:28,650
they're not submitting change tickets,
they're not managing budget.

665
00:34:28,650 --> 00:34:30,150
They're just doing the work.

666
00:34:30,150 --> 00:34:30,680
All right.

667
00:34:30,680 --> 00:34:33,400
So they influence just
the work that's assigned to

668
00:34:33,400 --> 00:34:35,400
them not the project as a whole.

669
00:34:35,400 --> 00:34:38,730
Versus project team members that
will typically influence the project

670
00:34:38,730 --> 00:34:39,660
as a whole, right.

671
00:34:41,060 --> 00:34:43,050
So it's important that we have
that separation in our mind and

672
00:34:43,050 --> 00:34:46,680
we understand not every single
person makes up the project team.

673
00:34:46,680 --> 00:34:49,230
These are just the people who
are assigned to the project itself.

674
00:34:49,230 --> 00:34:53,870
And the reason I highlight that is when we
start a project we're going to go through

675
00:34:53,870 --> 00:34:57,090
a planning phase, and
that planning phase is where we're

676
00:34:57,090 --> 00:35:00,040
thinking of what needs to get
done as part of that project.

677
00:35:00,040 --> 00:35:01,910
We're not actually doing it yet.

678
00:35:01,910 --> 00:35:06,760
So if I'm building a house and
that's my project and I'm planning, right.

679
00:35:06,760 --> 00:35:09,010
I don't need my drywall installers today.

680
00:35:09,010 --> 00:35:12,980
The house doesn't even have you know
struts yet, the foundations not poured.

681
00:35:12,980 --> 00:35:14,480
We're not going to put up drywall.

682
00:35:14,480 --> 00:35:17,210
I don't need the drywall
installers until I'm ready for

683
00:35:17,210 --> 00:35:19,100
them, when I'm in the execution phase.

684
00:35:19,100 --> 00:35:22,590
The foundations done, the walls are up,
now I need the drywall installers.

685
00:35:22,590 --> 00:35:27,410
So the project team will be assigned
very early in the life of the project,

686
00:35:27,410 --> 00:35:31,170
because they're part of the that
planning process, right?

687
00:35:31,170 --> 00:35:35,620
And then when we get into execution,
our project team grows if necessary.

688
00:35:35,620 --> 00:35:38,850
At least our worker base
grow to get that work done,

689
00:35:38,850 --> 00:35:40,340
to get that project moved to completion.

690
00:35:42,610 --> 00:35:43,740
So that's our project team.

691
00:35:43,740 --> 00:35:51,444
Now where do our project
team members come from?

692
00:35:51,444 --> 00:35:54,215
They come from all sorts of races and
backgrounds and cultural diversity and

693
00:35:54,215 --> 00:35:56,911
all that but what I mean is if I need
an accountant where do I get them right.

694
00:35:56,911 --> 00:35:58,641
Well that really does
depend on your company.

695
00:35:58,641 --> 00:36:01,531
Maybe you already have staff that's in
place in your company that you're able

696
00:36:01,531 --> 00:36:03,980
to use and allocate to borrow to use for
your project team right, or

697
00:36:03,980 --> 00:36:05,803
maybe you don't and
you have to hire them right?

698
00:36:05,803 --> 00:36:11,333
If I'm kicking off a project and I don't
have the resources I need to go out and

699
00:36:11,333 --> 00:36:16,440
hire the resources I need to hire
subproject managers or accountants,

700
00:36:16,440 --> 00:36:22,227
scheduling coordinators, people like that
to be able to support that project or

701
00:36:22,227 --> 00:36:26,994
in a lot of larger organizations,
we have something called a PMO,

702
00:36:26,994 --> 00:36:30,950
and a PMO is a Project Management Office.

703
00:36:30,950 --> 00:36:33,408
And this is something that a small
company's not going to have.

704
00:36:33,408 --> 00:36:35,880
Even a mid-size company's
probably not going to have it but

705
00:36:35,880 --> 00:36:39,340
if you're a large organization,
a PMO's job,

706
00:36:39,340 --> 00:36:44,080
the project management office's job,
is to provide resources to project teams.

707
00:36:44,080 --> 00:36:46,750
So, when we think of a project right,
Ronnie,

708
00:36:46,750 --> 00:36:48,270
let's think of a project for ITProTV.

709
00:36:50,100 --> 00:36:51,430
>> Well
>> Put you on the spot here.

710
00:36:51,430 --> 00:36:54,100
>> Yeah, can't come up with one
right now off the top of my head.

711
00:36:54,100 --> 00:36:59,010
>> Let's say that our project is to
get rid of all the Macs on the set and

712
00:36:59,010 --> 00:36:59,940
replace them with PCs.

713
00:36:59,940 --> 00:37:00,560
>> All right.

714
00:37:00,560 --> 00:37:01,810
Sounds good.

715
00:37:01,810 --> 00:37:04,700
>> All right.
[LAUGH] It's a joke backstage for

716
00:37:04,700 --> 00:37:08,485
us that our set is slowly
being eaten up by Apple.

717
00:37:08,485 --> 00:37:11,640
[LAUGH] We have more and
more Apple equipment these days.

718
00:37:11,640 --> 00:37:14,380
But, so we decided that we were going
to get rid of all that and go to PCs.

719
00:37:14,380 --> 00:37:15,130
Okay?

720
00:37:15,130 --> 00:37:18,910
Well, somebody has to come
up with that idea and

721
00:37:18,910 --> 00:37:23,395
that somebody has to be somebody,
I want to say, somebody with power!

722
00:37:23,395 --> 00:37:24,400
[LAUGH] But it's not so

723
00:37:24,400 --> 00:37:27,510
much power as it is, somebody with
the authority to make the change, right?

724
00:37:27,510 --> 00:37:29,488
>> Right.
>> So if we have a mail room clerk,

725
00:37:29,488 --> 00:37:34,010
which we don't, we're not that big,
but if you have a mail room clerk,

726
00:37:34,010 --> 00:37:38,402
they can't say we're going to cut
expenditures by 30% this year.

727
00:37:38,402 --> 00:37:39,360
>> Right.

728
00:37:39,360 --> 00:37:40,174
>> Well
>> You're a mail room clerk,

729
00:37:40,174 --> 00:37:41,080
you're not going to do anything.

730
00:37:41,080 --> 00:37:43,470
You're going to put letters in mailboxes.

731
00:37:43,470 --> 00:37:48,180
So but if the CEO comes down, or the
Vice President of Finance comes down or

732
00:37:48,180 --> 00:37:50,660
whatever and says hey,
we're going to cut expenditures,

733
00:37:50,660 --> 00:37:54,740
we need to do a project to find out here
we're going to pull this off, right?

734
00:37:54,740 --> 00:37:56,610
They have the authority to do it.

735
00:37:56,610 --> 00:38:00,900
They become what's called
the primary stakeholder.

736
00:38:00,900 --> 00:38:04,870
A project has stakeholders, I think I am
jumping a little bit ahead of our list,

737
00:38:04,870 --> 00:38:10,070
but they're the person who has
a vested interest in that project and

738
00:38:10,070 --> 00:38:14,680
since it's their idea,
they're what's called the sponsor.

739
00:38:14,680 --> 00:38:18,290
So the sponsor is the person who
lends their authority to the project.

740
00:38:18,290 --> 00:38:20,870
The project can't get done without
authority to do it, and so

741
00:38:20,870 --> 00:38:22,140
you need a sponsor.

742
00:38:23,250 --> 00:38:26,930
Now in an organization with a PMO,
see as I tie it back in.

743
00:38:26,930 --> 00:38:29,300
The sponsor goes to the PMO and

744
00:38:29,300 --> 00:38:33,540
says, I've got this idea,
I want to replace the Macs with PC's or

745
00:38:33,540 --> 00:38:36,790
the other way around I want to replace
the PC's with Mac's, whatever it is right.

746
00:38:36,790 --> 00:38:38,470
I want to throw them all away and
switch to Linux.

747
00:38:38,470 --> 00:38:39,150
Right.

748
00:38:39,150 --> 00:38:40,650
So we'll do that project.

749
00:38:40,650 --> 00:38:42,760
We're going to ditch everything and
just to go to Linux.

750
00:38:42,760 --> 00:38:47,120
So the sponsor goes to the PMO and
says here's my project.

751
00:38:47,120 --> 00:38:51,220
I want to replace all of these PCs and
all the Macs with Linux.

752
00:38:51,220 --> 00:38:52,310
All right?

753
00:38:52,310 --> 00:38:55,560
I need some resources and
the PMO will say you know what,

754
00:38:55,560 --> 00:38:57,980
we've got just the project manager for
you.

755
00:38:57,980 --> 00:39:00,370
Let's assign this project manager to it.

756
00:39:00,370 --> 00:39:04,700
The sponsor then gives authority
to the project manager.

757
00:39:04,700 --> 00:39:08,397
And we are going to talk about that more
in the initiation and planning phases

758
00:39:08,397 --> 00:39:12,152
later on but they give that authority
to the project manager, and the project

759
00:39:12,152 --> 00:39:16,380
manager can look at what the sponsor
wants and start to formulate their needs.

760
00:39:16,380 --> 00:39:18,680
And the project manager can
turn around to the PMO and

761
00:39:18,680 --> 00:39:22,500
say, okay, I'm going to need
one scheduling coordinator,

762
00:39:22,500 --> 00:39:25,549
I'm going to need two sub project
managers, I'm going to need an accountant.

763
00:39:26,750 --> 00:39:31,670
And I don't need full time attorneys,
but I may need an attorney on

764
00:39:31,670 --> 00:39:35,780
retainer just for consultant throughout
the project and the PMO will say, "Oh.

765
00:39:35,780 --> 00:39:36,310
Okay.

766
00:39:36,310 --> 00:39:37,440
Here's what you need.

767
00:39:37,440 --> 00:39:38,150
Here, you can give it to you.

768
00:39:38,150 --> 00:39:39,120
You need a web developer?

769
00:39:39,120 --> 00:39:41,380
Alright, you can have this
web developer these days.

770
00:39:41,380 --> 00:39:44,100
And they start to assign
the resources to the project.

771
00:39:44,100 --> 00:39:48,740
That's the primary goal for a PMO,
is management of resources.

772
00:39:48,740 --> 00:39:53,420
And by resources I mean not just human
resources, but also material resources.

773
00:39:53,420 --> 00:39:55,790
So the PMO is kind of that gateway.

774
00:39:55,790 --> 00:40:00,725
In fully projectized environments,
the PMO may also be the ones that

775
00:40:00,725 --> 00:40:05,764
make the decision as to which projects
to do, and which ones not to do.

776
00:40:05,764 --> 00:40:06,845
>> Yeah.
>> Ronnie,

777
00:40:06,845 --> 00:40:11,580
I'm having a hard time remembering
the name for the, PMI doesn't hit on it.

778
00:40:11,580 --> 00:40:17,080
But there's this name for
when a PMO in a fully projectized

779
00:40:17,080 --> 00:40:22,560
environment where the PMO is running
the show, people submit project ideas.

780
00:40:22,560 --> 00:40:25,300
And the PMO will quantify
those projects and

781
00:40:25,300 --> 00:40:30,520
rank them based on risk versus reward,
cost and benefit analysis, they'll do

782
00:40:30,520 --> 00:40:35,080
all that stuff to determine which projects
are the most beneficial to the company and

783
00:40:35,080 --> 00:40:38,680
which ones aren't, and then just the ones
that are most beneficial get approved.

784
00:40:38,680 --> 00:40:42,210
So the PMO may actually be picking
which projects your company takes.

785
00:40:43,290 --> 00:40:46,960
I've never worked in an environment
that had a PMO with that much authority.

786
00:40:46,960 --> 00:40:49,780
Most of the places where I've
worked that have had PMOs

787
00:40:49,780 --> 00:40:51,600
have really just been resource management.

788
00:40:51,600 --> 00:40:54,450
So there's different levels
of project management office,

789
00:40:54,450 --> 00:40:58,430
depending on how projectized
your company is.

790
00:40:58,430 --> 00:41:01,650
>> Now sometimes you actually hear
there's three different terms with them.

791
00:41:01,650 --> 00:41:03,810
One is just the idea of being supportive,
right?

792
00:41:03,810 --> 00:41:06,420
Where they do actually just
manage their resources.

793
00:41:06,420 --> 00:41:09,695
Other ones are as directive,
as what Don just described.

794
00:41:09,695 --> 00:41:11,150
>> Mm-hm.
>> And then there's that mix and

795
00:41:11,150 --> 00:41:11,910
balance of them.

796
00:41:11,910 --> 00:41:14,750
Where again, they're working
with a project manager, and

797
00:41:14,750 --> 00:41:18,940
they're really just again coordinating
with the project manager themselves.

798
00:41:18,940 --> 00:41:22,880
So when you see these types of PMOs,
they could actually just be as simple as,

799
00:41:22,880 --> 00:41:27,130
all right, we're taking over
a project here and here's the stuff

800
00:41:27,130 --> 00:41:30,850
help me project management office,
to figure out what I really need to do.

801
00:41:30,850 --> 00:41:33,030
And some of them do provide
the idea of guidance.

802
00:41:33,030 --> 00:41:36,180
It may be a project manager doesn't
know exactly what to do, but

803
00:41:36,180 --> 00:41:39,050
yet they have that project
management office that can help them

804
00:41:39,050 --> 00:41:41,420
to be able to flesh things out
a little bit better, yeah.

805
00:41:42,550 --> 00:41:45,450
>> Yeah, so that is a growing concept.

806
00:41:45,450 --> 00:41:48,550
A lot companies are starting
to adopt this concept of PMO.

807
00:41:48,550 --> 00:41:52,320
There's still plenty of organizations
out there that don't have a PMO at all.

808
00:41:52,320 --> 00:41:56,360
If you don't have a PMO,
that project sponsor,

809
00:41:56,360 --> 00:42:00,510
when they give authority to the project
manager, they're also giving them

810
00:42:00,510 --> 00:42:03,050
authority to reach out and
grab the other resources they may need.

811
00:42:03,050 --> 00:42:07,140
And they'll have to coordinate that
with the various departments and so on.

812
00:42:07,140 --> 00:42:09,470
Now, I mentioned departments.

813
00:42:09,470 --> 00:42:13,410
Inside of a company,
most companies are not projectized.

814
00:42:13,410 --> 00:42:16,250
Now I used that term earlier and
I didn't qualify it.

815
00:42:16,250 --> 00:42:21,780
The term projectized means that in
a company, I almost want to jump ahead and

816
00:42:21,780 --> 00:42:25,025
talk about organizational structure,
let me see in my notes.

817
00:42:25,025 --> 00:42:26,960
It's way down there, isn't it?

818
00:42:28,080 --> 00:42:31,520
Well, let me just try and
use non committal terms.

819
00:42:31,520 --> 00:42:32,220
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

820
00:42:32,220 --> 00:42:33,530
>> So, in your company,

821
00:42:33,530 --> 00:42:37,070
if your company's primary
focus is performing projects,

822
00:42:37,070 --> 00:42:39,640
then your project managers are going
to have a lot of authority.

823
00:42:39,640 --> 00:42:40,520
Right?
They're going to be

824
00:42:40,520 --> 00:42:42,620
people in charge of other people.

825
00:42:42,620 --> 00:42:44,490
But most companies aren't setup that way.

826
00:42:44,490 --> 00:42:46,220
Most companies are not project driven.

827
00:42:46,220 --> 00:42:47,680
They're product driven.

828
00:42:47,680 --> 00:42:50,750
They sell some kind of a product and
that's what makes the company money.

829
00:42:50,750 --> 00:42:54,300
And that's where they
really put their focus.

830
00:42:54,300 --> 00:42:58,050
Well, remember I said earlier in the show
that what makes your company money

831
00:42:58,050 --> 00:43:00,450
is normally the ongoing activities, right?

832
00:43:02,070 --> 00:43:05,510
Inside of a company like that you
may have project managers, but

833
00:43:05,510 --> 00:43:08,740
you'll typically have
functional managers also.

834
00:43:08,740 --> 00:43:10,120
And a functional manager,

835
00:43:10,120 --> 00:43:13,750
that's a person who's in charge of
some of those ongoing activities.

836
00:43:13,750 --> 00:43:14,910
And in most companies,

837
00:43:14,910 --> 00:43:19,660
almost every company I've worked for, the
functional managers have more authority.

838
00:43:19,660 --> 00:43:21,250
So let's put this in IT terms.

839
00:43:22,380 --> 00:43:26,190
In the IT world,
you might have a network manager,

840
00:43:28,270 --> 00:43:31,380
system administrator, manager,
the system management team.

841
00:43:31,380 --> 00:43:37,280
You might have a chief information
officer, and IT manager, or IS manager.

842
00:43:37,280 --> 00:43:42,900
These are managerial positions that
govern the ongoing operations of IT.

843
00:43:42,900 --> 00:43:46,700
And that manager title that they
get lends them authority over

844
00:43:46,700 --> 00:43:50,780
all of the employees that
are a part of that department.

845
00:43:50,780 --> 00:43:52,560
But then you have a project manager, and

846
00:43:52,560 --> 00:43:54,680
the project manager doesn't
have any employees.

847
00:43:54,680 --> 00:43:56,640
Nobody answers to the project manager.

848
00:43:56,640 --> 00:43:58,720
The project manager is assigned projects,
and

849
00:43:58,720 --> 00:44:01,970
then they borrow employees from
these functional managers.

850
00:44:01,970 --> 00:44:06,530
And so project managers have to work very
closely with functional managers to get

851
00:44:06,530 --> 00:44:07,580
things done.

852
00:44:07,580 --> 00:44:11,280
Because if a project manager gets mad
at an employee they can't fire them.

853
00:44:11,280 --> 00:44:12,520
It's not their employee.

854
00:44:12,520 --> 00:44:15,670
They have to go and
talk to the functional manager, and say

855
00:44:15,670 --> 00:44:18,720
this employee is not living up to their
responsibility inside of the project.

856
00:44:18,720 --> 00:44:21,650
And it's the functional manager
that actually has authority.

857
00:44:21,650 --> 00:44:25,350
That's one of the biggest challenges
with being a project manager,

858
00:44:25,350 --> 00:44:30,010
is that while you have manager in your
name, you're managing the project not

859
00:44:30,010 --> 00:44:35,870
necessarily the direct report or
whatever for any of the employees.

860
00:44:35,870 --> 00:44:39,292
So you don't necessarily have hire and
fire responsibilities which is-

861
00:44:39,292 --> 00:44:41,380
>> Challenging.

862
00:44:41,380 --> 00:44:45,160
>> And in employee views that
usually would mean authority.

863
00:44:45,160 --> 00:44:47,320
So that's a big deal.

864
00:44:47,320 --> 00:44:50,270
If you have a PMO,
if you are fully projectized,

865
00:44:50,270 --> 00:44:53,090
your project managers
have a lot of authority.

866
00:44:53,090 --> 00:44:56,670
If you're not projectized,
if it's a functional organization,

867
00:44:56,670 --> 00:44:59,230
businesses have a lot
of ongoing activities.

868
00:44:59,230 --> 00:45:02,390
Then you have the same
authority as your sponsor.

869
00:45:02,390 --> 00:45:05,663
The higher up in the tree your sponsor is,
the more authority you have.

870
00:45:05,663 --> 00:45:11,260
So when it comes to these projects,

871
00:45:11,260 --> 00:45:14,660
I mentioned how a PMO is going
to evaluate the projects and

872
00:45:14,660 --> 00:45:17,440
pick which ones are the most beneficial,
right?

873
00:45:17,440 --> 00:45:20,610
PMI refers to this as business value.

874
00:45:20,610 --> 00:45:23,400
Every project has to have some
kind of a business value.

875
00:45:25,210 --> 00:45:29,850
In IT, we have a unique perspective in
IT because in other industries, like in

876
00:45:29,850 --> 00:45:33,550
construction, if you have a project to
build a house, you're gonna build this

877
00:45:33,550 --> 00:45:38,240
house and then you're gonna sell it for
more money than the house costs.

878
00:45:38,240 --> 00:45:43,450
So your project actually makes money and
that's how most projects are.

879
00:45:43,450 --> 00:45:45,982
In IT, that's almost never the case,
right?

880
00:45:45,982 --> 00:45:46,690
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

881
00:45:46,690 --> 00:45:48,520
>> Most of our projects in IT

882
00:45:48,520 --> 00:45:50,190
cost money without generating it.

883
00:45:50,190 --> 00:45:56,370
So a great example would be,
one of the bigger projects I worked on,

884
00:45:56,370 --> 00:46:01,060
I worked for a bank and
we had 90 branches across four states.

885
00:46:01,060 --> 00:46:06,220
And the project was a complete
network infrastructure redesign.

886
00:46:06,220 --> 00:46:09,760
We replaced every router,
every switch, every firewall, and

887
00:46:09,760 --> 00:46:11,460
every communication line.

888
00:46:11,460 --> 00:46:16,890
Every data line that was run to newer
updated hardware and faster lines.

889
00:46:16,890 --> 00:46:20,310
Completely redesigned the network,
it was a multi-million dollar project.

890
00:46:20,310 --> 00:46:23,720
And during the life of that project,
we spent some money.

891
00:46:23,720 --> 00:46:24,860
We spent several million dollars.

892
00:46:24,860 --> 00:46:27,070
New equipment, new lines, and all that.

893
00:46:28,370 --> 00:46:33,310
Did our bank sell more mortgages
because we had better firewalls?

894
00:46:33,310 --> 00:46:34,220
No.

895
00:46:34,220 --> 00:46:39,090
Did our bank get more
certified deposits because

896
00:46:39,090 --> 00:46:41,800
our switches were layer three
instead of just layer two?

897
00:46:41,800 --> 00:46:43,130
No.

898
00:46:43,130 --> 00:46:48,040
So, where we saw earnings,
we didn't, right.

899
00:46:48,040 --> 00:46:49,110
But, we did save money.

900
00:46:49,110 --> 00:46:50,920
Our data lines became less expensive, so

901
00:46:50,920 --> 00:46:54,870
we started getting returns every
month as far as our Telco bills, and

902
00:46:54,870 --> 00:46:59,600
then the stability of the network
allowed employees to get more work done.

903
00:46:59,600 --> 00:47:01,940
They didn't have outages
like they used to and so

904
00:47:01,940 --> 00:47:05,020
that stability led to
performance improvements.

905
00:47:05,020 --> 00:47:09,620
Not necessarily monetary improvements,
and may take a while,

906
00:47:09,620 --> 00:47:13,640
may take five years, seven years, for
that investment to pay itself off.

907
00:47:13,640 --> 00:47:17,120
But it was the right thing to do to have
the right infrastructure available to

908
00:47:17,120 --> 00:47:18,980
perform that service.

909
00:47:18,980 --> 00:47:22,800
In IT, our projects are typically viewed
as what are what are called cost centers.

910
00:47:22,800 --> 00:47:26,750
And that means they don't generate
revenue, they cost money.

911
00:47:26,750 --> 00:47:29,830
And then it's other things
that offset that cost so,

912
00:47:29,830 --> 00:47:32,820
can we sell more mortgages as
a result of having new firewall?

913
00:47:32,820 --> 00:47:34,632
Yes.
Did the new firewalls make us money?

914
00:47:34,632 --> 00:47:37,010
Not necessarily.

915
00:47:37,010 --> 00:47:40,300
So that's something we
have to keep in mind.

916
00:47:40,300 --> 00:47:42,870
So, for a PMO,
they've gotta look at your project and

917
00:47:42,870 --> 00:47:46,850
they've gotta figure out,
does it have a business value?

918
00:47:46,850 --> 00:47:49,200
Does it add something to our organization?

919
00:47:49,200 --> 00:47:51,100
Does it improve our ability to make money?

920
00:47:51,100 --> 00:47:54,445
Or does it help to make us more stable,
right?

921
00:47:54,445 --> 00:47:55,966
A great example of that,
disaster recovery.

922
00:47:55,966 --> 00:47:59,866
You might have a project to create
a redundant data center for

923
00:47:59,866 --> 00:48:01,251
your organization.

924
00:48:01,251 --> 00:48:05,428
If your main data center fails,
earthquake, hurricane, power outage,

925
00:48:05,428 --> 00:48:06,104
whatever.

926
00:48:06,104 --> 00:48:09,715
Having another data center that can kick
in and take over, avoids that down time.

927
00:48:09,715 --> 00:48:12,631
That data center is gonna
cost you a lot of money, and

928
00:48:12,631 --> 00:48:16,030
if you never have a disaster,
you never recoup that money.

929
00:48:16,030 --> 00:48:16,800
>> Right.
>> Right.

930
00:48:16,800 --> 00:48:23,060
If I have a $5 million disaster recovery
facility, and I never have a disaster.

931
00:48:23,060 --> 00:48:25,140
It's 5 million that I wasted.

932
00:48:25,140 --> 00:48:26,060
>> Right.

933
00:48:26,060 --> 00:48:27,950
But the instant I have an earthquake and

934
00:48:27,950 --> 00:48:32,870
the main data center goes offline that
$5 million data center kicks in, and

935
00:48:32,870 --> 00:48:37,370
for every minute that it's in business
it's paying itself off, right.

936
00:48:37,370 --> 00:48:39,950
But does that mean that
we shouldn't do that?

937
00:48:39,950 --> 00:48:43,610
No, how much money would we lose by
having that data center offline?

938
00:48:43,610 --> 00:48:48,827
I read this article about how Amazon,
if Amazon were to you know Amazon dot com

939
00:48:48,827 --> 00:48:54,124
online shopping company retail whatever
if their website went down they would

940
00:48:54,124 --> 00:48:59,259
lose over a million dollars per hour if
their website went down so does it make

941
00:48:59,259 --> 00:49:04,746
sense for them to have a redundant data
center if it costs them a million dollars.

942
00:49:04,746 --> 00:49:08,670
Absolutely cuz for every hour they're down
it's costing them that much It makes sense

943
00:49:08,670 --> 00:49:11,810
to spend that kind of money to
create that infrastructure.

944
00:49:11,810 --> 00:49:14,630
Definitely something that needs to
be evaluated for every project.

945
00:49:14,630 --> 00:49:18,110
>> Yeah, it's hard to see the actual
value of it in terms of business.

946
00:49:18,110 --> 00:49:21,030
Until you realize the efficiency
that some of the things generate.

947
00:49:21,030 --> 00:49:23,020
Like for example,
our business at one point.

948
00:49:23,020 --> 00:49:25,370
We were just using regular
Telephone lines, but

949
00:49:25,370 --> 00:49:27,210
then we switched to a VoIP system.

950
00:49:27,210 --> 00:49:30,570
And by doing that, even though they
actually had some up front costs,

951
00:49:30,570 --> 00:49:35,670
it really did end up making it better
production, we got a lot more features for

952
00:49:35,670 --> 00:49:36,380
what we actually had,

953
00:49:36,380 --> 00:49:39,810
and we were able to actually control
our phone system a lot better.

954
00:49:39,810 --> 00:49:43,060
I did offer some business value
that we thought was worth it.

955
00:49:43,060 --> 00:49:47,570
>> Later on, we're gonna talk about cost
benefit analysis and feasibility analysis

956
00:49:47,570 --> 00:49:52,240
or analyses, however you want to say
it where you make that judgement.

957
00:49:52,240 --> 00:49:52,840
Is it worth it?

958
00:49:52,840 --> 00:49:54,770
How long will it take to pay if off?

959
00:49:54,770 --> 00:49:56,320
Is it something that makes sense?

960
00:49:56,320 --> 00:49:57,600
>> Right.
>> And so we'll get a chance to see

961
00:49:57,600 --> 00:49:58,450
that later on.

962
00:49:58,450 --> 00:50:01,690
All right,
now I mentioned stakeholders earlier.

963
00:50:01,690 --> 00:50:06,800
A stakeholder, is anybody with
a vested interest in the project,

964
00:50:06,800 --> 00:50:09,330
right anybody that the project influences.

965
00:50:09,330 --> 00:50:12,430
A stakeholder doesn't necessarily
influence the project.

966
00:50:12,430 --> 00:50:15,680
But the project definitely
influences the stakeholder.

967
00:50:15,680 --> 00:50:18,400
I've mentioned two important
stakeholders already.

968
00:50:18,400 --> 00:50:22,180
The project sponsor, the person who
came up with the idea for the project,

969
00:50:22,180 --> 00:50:25,640
the person who's authority is
allowing that project to be.

970
00:50:25,640 --> 00:50:28,500
That's the sponsor, and
they're the primary stakeholder.

971
00:50:28,500 --> 00:50:29,250
All right?

972
00:50:29,250 --> 00:50:32,570
The project manager is also a stakeholder.

973
00:50:32,570 --> 00:50:34,590
They have a vested interest
in the project succeeding,

974
00:50:34,590 --> 00:50:37,690
cuz if it fails, they probably get fired.

975
00:50:37,690 --> 00:50:38,870
[LAUGH]
>> That is true.

976
00:50:38,870 --> 00:50:41,560
>> Nobody likes the project manager
when the project goes over budget.

977
00:50:43,890 --> 00:50:47,300
Those are two stakeholders, two people who
have a vested interest in the project.

978
00:50:47,300 --> 00:50:53,070
But there are tons of other
people who are stakeholders.

979
00:50:53,070 --> 00:50:56,230
The PMI specifically calls
out functional stakeholders,

980
00:50:56,230 --> 00:50:59,100
organizational stakeholders,
operational stakeholders.

981
00:50:59,100 --> 00:51:01,280
These are really all names for
the same thing.

982
00:51:01,280 --> 00:51:06,340
If I have a project, let me use
the insurance company as an example.

983
00:51:06,340 --> 00:51:10,410
We had this project to roll out new
claims processing software, all right.

984
00:51:10,410 --> 00:51:12,600
It was an IT department project.

985
00:51:12,600 --> 00:51:15,910
The IT department had to set up
the servers, had to install the software,

986
00:51:15,910 --> 00:51:20,170
had to configure the databases,
had to set up backups and restore plans.

987
00:51:20,170 --> 00:51:20,920
That was the project.

988
00:51:20,920 --> 00:51:22,540
It was an IT department project.

989
00:51:23,540 --> 00:51:27,110
But the software, was for
claims processing, and so

990
00:51:27,110 --> 00:51:30,860
the entire claims department was
gonna have to use this software.

991
00:51:30,860 --> 00:51:33,030
They had to learn how to use the software.

992
00:51:33,030 --> 00:51:34,570
They had to understand how it operated.

993
00:51:34,570 --> 00:51:37,840
They had to come up with work flows for
how a claim would be processed.

994
00:51:37,840 --> 00:51:39,470
That was stuff that the IT
department didn't know.

995
00:51:40,710 --> 00:51:43,240
While the IT department
was doing all the work,

996
00:51:43,240 --> 00:51:47,490
the claims department was directly
influenced by that project.

997
00:51:47,490 --> 00:51:50,320
This is new software that
they were gonna have to use.

998
00:51:50,320 --> 00:51:53,890
The entire claims department becomes
a stakeholder in the project.

999
00:51:53,890 --> 00:51:57,940
Now, you don't want every claims agent
to be a part of your project, so

1000
00:51:57,940 --> 00:52:03,320
usually it's the head of that department
or if they have some mid level managers or

1001
00:52:03,320 --> 00:52:05,030
whatever they become
a part of the project.

1002
00:52:05,030 --> 00:52:09,070
So that they can provide feedback and
influence as the project progresses.

1003
00:52:09,070 --> 00:52:13,050
You want to get that, you want that
feedback, cuz what you don't want

1004
00:52:13,050 --> 00:52:16,370
is to roll out this software and
then the claims department hates it,

1005
00:52:16,370 --> 00:52:20,930
won't use it, and then you've got to roll
back the project, it was waste of time.

1006
00:52:20,930 --> 00:52:25,940
You want to get their feedback and input
and the earlier you get it, the better.

1007
00:52:25,940 --> 00:52:27,300
You'll find it, as time goes on,

1008
00:52:27,300 --> 00:52:31,890
that the earlier a change occurs in
a project, the less expensive it is.

1009
00:52:31,890 --> 00:52:36,540
But the further down the road you are,
change becomes really expensive.

1010
00:52:36,540 --> 00:52:38,170
And we'll see an example
of that a little bit later.

1011
00:52:39,510 --> 00:52:42,540
All right, so
stakeholders are pretty important,

1012
00:52:42,540 --> 00:52:46,850
just remember that the entire
project team, they're stakeholders.

1013
00:52:46,850 --> 00:52:49,880
But then there's other people who
aren't on the project team who are also

1014
00:52:49,880 --> 00:52:51,380
stakeholders like the sponsor.

1015
00:52:51,380 --> 00:52:55,290
And just like any other employee
that might be affected by

1016
00:52:55,290 --> 00:52:59,130
what that project is producing.

1017
00:52:59,130 --> 00:53:02,160
Well Ronnie we need to talk a little
bit more about terminology as far as

1018
00:53:02,160 --> 00:53:04,640
the project manager themselves, but

1019
00:53:04,640 --> 00:53:06,354
looking at the clock it's a pretty good
>> Oh yup

1020
00:53:06,354 --> 00:53:07,213
>> Spot to stop for a break

1021
00:53:07,213 --> 00:53:08,050
>> Sure enough

1022
00:53:08,050 --> 00:53:08,830
>> Why don't we stop here and

1023
00:53:08,830 --> 00:53:11,650
take a break when we get back
we got a little more terminology

1024
00:53:11,650 --> 00:53:14,513
before we move into something
a little more interesting.

1025
00:53:14,513 --> 00:53:17,445
>> Yup
>> All right stay tuned we'll be back in

1026
00:53:17,445 --> 00:53:17,970
a few.

00:53:17,970 --> 00:53:24,877

00:53:24,877 --> 00:53:26,350
Welcome back.

00:53:27,370 --> 00:53:31,040
We talked about some of the different
concepts as far as like project team and

1030
00:53:31,040 --> 00:53:32,880
the project team members and staff.

1031
00:53:32,880 --> 00:53:36,140
Let's talk a little bit about

1032
00:53:37,270 --> 00:53:40,350
As the project manager

1033
00:53:40,350 --> 00:53:43,000

00:53:43,000 --> 00:53:45,260
Completes successfully.

00:54:33,860 --> 00:54:40,920
A project manager can drive a project team

00:54:40,920 --> 00:54:44,672

1050
00:54:44,672 --> 00:54:49,330
So calls out three specific

1051
00:54:49,330 --> 00:54:51,110
as a project manager.

And they are knowledge,

1053
00:54:55,660 --> 00:54:56,660
All right?

1054

Knowledge is the first one.

1055
00:54:58,280 --> 00:55:03,370
if you say you're a project manager,

1056
00:55:03,370 --> 00:55:07,000
You need to have that knowledge to

1057
00:55:07,000 --> 00:55:11,150

1058
00:55:11,150 --> 00:55:14,240
how to properly plan,

1059
00:55:14,240 --> 00:55:17,630
how to do all the various activities

1060
00:55:17,630 --> 00:55:19,660
And if you don't know

00:55:19,660 --> 00:55:21,840

00:55:21,840 --> 00:55:24,050
You should constantly be

1063

that's why the PMP has a continuing

1064
00:55:29,290 --> 00:55:30,520
Knowledge is a big deal.

1065

The second one is performance.

00:55:33,060 --> 00:55:36,460
You need to perform at

00:55:36,460 --> 00:55:39,990

00:55:39,990 --> 00:55:44,160
I used to work with a project

1069
00:55:44,160 --> 00:55:47,300
this one project in particular, and

00:55:47,300 --> 00:55:49,356
You were there.
Where things were going wrong,

1071
00:55:49,356 --> 00:55:54,314
there was a very goo possibility for the

00:56:23,850 --> 00:56:27,590
You're a project manager, you've got

00:56:32,650 --> 00:56:33,580

00:56:40,710 --> 00:56:43,290
And then the last thing

00:56:56,185 --> 00:56:57,595

00:57:22,577 --> 00:57:24,637

what's expected of him.

1327
01:08:29,310 --> 01:08:31,275
Some people just don't know
what's expected of them.

1328
01:08:31,275 --> 01:08:31,930
>> Right.
>> And so,

1329
01:08:31,930 --> 01:08:34,350
I can coach him to make
him a better employee.

1330
01:08:34,350 --> 01:08:36,270
If I just cut him from my project,

1331
01:08:36,270 --> 01:08:39,530
all I'm doing is pawning him off on
the next project manager, and so,

1332
01:08:39,530 --> 01:08:42,790
it's going to be this constant
burden on project after project.

1333
01:08:42,790 --> 01:08:44,580
Versus if you can coach somebody.

1334
01:08:44,580 --> 01:08:47,930
Make them a better employee,
make them a better team member.

1335
01:08:47,930 --> 01:08:51,760
Not only do you benefit, but the next
project manager and the one beyond.

1336
01:08:51,760 --> 01:08:53,500
And if you build a rapport
with that person,

1337
01:08:53,500 --> 01:08:56,305
maybe you continue to have them
as part of your project team.

1338
01:08:56,305 --> 01:08:58,090
>> Yeah.

1339
01:08:58,090 --> 01:09:01,260
>> Now the last thing I want to
call out here is not a soft skill.

1340
01:09:01,260 --> 01:09:05,130
But something that's very important,
which is the code of ethics.

1341
01:09:05,130 --> 01:09:09,580
The project management institute
has a published code of ethics that

1342
01:09:09,580 --> 01:09:14,710
one if you're a PMI certified individual,
if you have your PMP or CAPM or

1343
01:09:14,710 --> 01:09:19,110
whatever, you are required to
follow the PMI code of ethics.

1344
01:09:19,110 --> 01:09:20,346
All right?
Failure to do so

1345
01:09:20,346 --> 01:09:23,444
will result in your work
certification being revoked.

1346
01:09:23,444 --> 01:09:24,008
All right?

1347
01:09:24,008 --> 01:09:28,473
If you are not a PMI certified person,
then you don't have to follow the code of

1348
01:09:28,473 --> 01:09:32,440
ethics, but it's on the exams, so
you're going to want to know it.

1349
01:09:32,440 --> 01:09:35,140
But it's also just a good idea in general.

1350
01:09:35,140 --> 01:09:37,260
The code of ethics is on their website.

1351
01:09:37,260 --> 01:09:38,500
You can download it.

1352
01:09:38,500 --> 01:09:42,840
If you go to PMI's website,
here I am on www.pmi.org.

1353
01:09:42,840 --> 01:09:43,600
You can go to About.

1354
01:09:45,650 --> 01:09:50,190
And on the About screen,
you will see Read the PMI Code of Ethics.

1355
01:09:51,690 --> 01:09:53,950
And, when we go into the code of ethics,
on the right side,

1356
01:09:53,950 --> 01:09:56,720
you'll see where you can download
the code of ethics in multiple languages.

1357
01:09:56,720 --> 01:09:57,745
I'll do English.

1358
01:09:57,745 --> 01:10:01,440
>> [LAUGH]
>> I could go crazy.

1359
01:10:01,440 --> 01:10:02,570
I'll do Chinese today.

1360
01:10:02,570 --> 01:10:04,390
Let's have some fun.

1361
01:10:04,390 --> 01:10:05,520
So here we go.

1362
01:10:06,550 --> 01:10:10,770
And basically what it does is
it lays out the code of ethics.

1363
01:10:10,770 --> 01:10:12,950
Now the reason I highlight this here,

1364
01:10:12,950 --> 01:10:17,700
a lot of people don't realize this but
the code of ethics is on the exam.

1365
01:10:17,700 --> 01:10:19,680
This is testable material.

1366
01:10:19,680 --> 01:10:24,200
So the exam comes from the PMBOK
as well as the code of ethics.

1367
01:10:24,200 --> 01:10:26,630
Now the code of ethics,
if you buy the physical pinbock.

1368
01:10:26,630 --> 01:10:29,120
Code of ethics is actually
in the back of the pinbock.

1369
01:10:29,120 --> 01:10:30,850
So it's kind of all in one.

1370
01:10:30,850 --> 01:10:33,200
But if you get the digital version,
like I have.

1371
01:10:33,200 --> 01:10:36,050
You've gotta get the digital
version of the code of ethics.

1372
01:10:36,050 --> 01:10:36,770
But it is free.

1373
01:10:36,770 --> 01:10:38,390
You just go and download it.

1374
01:10:38,390 --> 01:10:39,610
It shows who it applies to and

1375
01:10:39,610 --> 01:10:43,820
you'll see all PMI members as well
as those holding a certification.

1376
01:10:43,820 --> 01:10:47,910
And then basically here it gets
into our responsibilities.

1377
01:10:47,910 --> 01:10:48,490
Right?

1378
01:10:48,490 --> 01:10:51,230
We need to make sure that we
follow certain standards.

1379
01:10:51,230 --> 01:10:55,440
We only accept assignments that
we have the necessary experience,

1380
01:10:55,440 --> 01:10:56,840
skills, and qualifications for.

1381
01:10:56,840 --> 01:10:58,280
Right?
I had talked about that earlier,

1382
01:10:58,280 --> 01:11:01,250
you have the knowledge to
perform that activity.

1383
01:11:01,250 --> 01:11:05,190
That we take actions based on
the best interest of society,

1384
01:11:05,190 --> 01:11:07,530
public safety, and the environment.

1385
01:11:07,530 --> 01:11:10,640
And it goes on to list continual,
or continuing things.

1386
01:11:10,640 --> 01:11:13,980
These are all different aspects
that we need to follow.

1387
01:11:13,980 --> 01:11:16,220
That we need to basically
make sure that we're

1388
01:11:17,820 --> 01:11:21,140
acting in the best interest of
our customer or our company.

1389
01:11:21,140 --> 01:11:23,710
That we avoid the appearance
of impropriety.

1390
01:11:23,710 --> 01:11:26,130
Right?
That's in here somewhere,

1391
01:11:26,130 --> 01:11:30,392
which is the fancy way of saying,
one, don't do bad things.

1392
01:11:30,392 --> 01:11:32,980
>> Right [LAUGH].
>> And two, even if you're not,

1393
01:11:32,980 --> 01:11:35,440
avoid the appearance that you
might be doing something bad.

1394
01:11:35,440 --> 01:11:36,220
All right?

1395
01:11:36,220 --> 01:11:39,575
So for example as a project manager you
might be in charge of a project budget.

1396
01:11:39,575 --> 01:11:40,430
All right?

1397
01:11:40,430 --> 01:11:43,320
So let's say you're working
a multi million dollar project and

1398
01:11:43,320 --> 01:11:45,090
you're responsible for that budget.

1399
01:11:45,090 --> 01:11:48,790
Could you go to the bank and cut yourself
a check for $2 million and walk out?

1400
01:11:48,790 --> 01:11:50,655
Yes, you have that authority.

1401
01:11:50,655 --> 01:11:53,010
Right?
So your books,

1402
01:11:53,010 --> 01:11:55,460
your accounting books,
they're going to be monitored.

1403
01:11:55,460 --> 01:11:55,960
Right?

1404
01:11:55,960 --> 01:12:00,050
Any expenditures, any money that comes out
of the accounts, you need to record and

1405
01:12:00,050 --> 01:12:01,262
show how it was tied to the project.

1406
01:12:01,262 --> 01:12:02,975
All right?
Now, if you're not embezzling,

1407
01:12:02,975 --> 01:12:06,096
that's what they call it when you
are stealing money from your company.

1408
01:12:06,096 --> 01:12:08,889
If you're not embezzling and
you've got your books,

1409
01:12:08,889 --> 01:12:10,962
you're keeping everything up to date.

1410
01:12:10,962 --> 01:12:14,210
And an auditor comes and
says, let me see your books.

1411
01:12:14,210 --> 01:12:16,880
And you say no,
I don't wanna show them to you.

1412
01:12:16,880 --> 01:12:20,460
And you stall, and you push them away, and
you don't let them look at your books.

1413
01:12:20,460 --> 01:12:21,900
What are they gonna think?

1414
01:12:21,900 --> 01:12:24,910
They're gonna think, here's somebody
who has something to hide, right?

1415
01:12:24,910 --> 01:12:25,960
They must be doing something wrong.

1416
01:12:25,960 --> 01:12:27,220
They don't want me to see the books.

1417
01:12:27,220 --> 01:12:29,740
In reality, maybe it just means
you didn't update the books.

1418
01:12:29,740 --> 01:12:31,060
>> Yeah.
>> Maybe you're behind or whatever.

1419
01:12:31,060 --> 01:12:32,590
Maybe you're running a little over budget.

1420
01:12:32,590 --> 01:12:34,910
You don't want people to know,
cuz you're gonna correct for it later.

1421
01:12:34,910 --> 01:12:38,930
Either way, you've created
the appearance of impropriety, and

1422
01:12:38,930 --> 01:12:41,940
that's as bad as actually
doing the impropriety itself.

1423
01:12:41,940 --> 01:12:47,180
So, we need to make sure that we always
act in a transparent manner, that

1424
01:12:47,180 --> 01:12:52,380
we let people know where we're at that we
truly report the progress of our project.

1425
01:12:52,380 --> 01:12:56,900
If we're behind schedule you tell people
you're behind schedule, you don't try and

1426
01:12:56,900 --> 01:12:58,200
hide the fact and

1427
01:12:58,200 --> 01:13:02,540
mask that, these are all things that
are apart of the code of ethics.

1428
01:13:03,680 --> 01:13:08,970
Everything here under mandatory standards,
are things that you must do.

1429
01:13:08,970 --> 01:13:11,720
If you're caught not adhering
to any one of these.

1430
01:13:11,720 --> 01:13:14,390
You will have your certification,
and your membership revoked.

1431
01:13:14,390 --> 01:13:18,100
All right,
there are other standards in here though,

1432
01:13:18,100 --> 01:13:22,110
that are not requirements,
that are more like guidelines.

1433
01:13:22,110 --> 01:13:23,510
Things that you should be doing, but

1434
01:13:23,510 --> 01:13:25,860
especially that section
where it says requirements.

1435
01:13:25,860 --> 01:13:26,840
You need to adhere to those.

1436
01:13:26,840 --> 01:13:30,450
But you'll see other things here,
negotiating good faith.

1437
01:13:30,450 --> 01:13:35,140
In other words,
if you're building a house and

1438
01:13:35,140 --> 01:13:39,810
you need drywall installers, and your
brother-in-law is a drywall installer,

1439
01:13:39,810 --> 01:13:42,510
that you don't just automatically
give the bid to them, right?

1440
01:13:42,510 --> 01:13:46,810
That you do a bid, you get
responses from various contractors,

1441
01:13:46,810 --> 01:13:50,240
and if your brother-in-law has
the best bid, then you pick them.

1442
01:13:50,240 --> 01:13:53,950
But, if they don't have the best bid,
you pick the other person, right?

1443
01:13:53,950 --> 01:13:55,990
You make sure that you
negotiate in good faith.

1444
01:13:55,990 --> 01:13:59,190
So, these are things
that are pretty standard.

1445
01:13:59,190 --> 01:14:00,345
Most of them are common sense.

1446
01:14:00,345 --> 01:14:01,320
>> Mm-hm.

1447
01:14:01,320 --> 01:14:02,800
>> But, it is on the exam.

1448
01:14:02,800 --> 01:14:05,750
We're not aloud to talk about what
questions are on the exam, but

1449
01:14:05,750 --> 01:14:09,800
I know that I had several code of
ethics questions that were on the exam.

1450
01:14:09,800 --> 01:14:11,680
And so it's testable material.

1451
01:14:11,680 --> 01:14:15,400
The book itself is eight pages I think,
yeah eight pages.

1452
01:14:15,400 --> 01:14:18,040
So, it only takes a minute to read,
it's free.

1453
01:14:18,040 --> 01:14:19,680
Definitely get it.

1454
01:14:19,680 --> 01:14:22,670
If you become a PMI member,
they send this to you in paper, so

1455
01:14:22,670 --> 01:14:25,320
you actually have a hand
help copy you can look at.

1456
01:14:25,320 --> 01:14:28,740
But, make sure you make it part of your
study materials, you need to be aware

1457
01:14:28,740 --> 01:14:33,360
of what's in here and like I said,
most of it is pretty straight forward.

1458
01:14:33,360 --> 01:14:37,030
This is just appendix stuff here at
the end so, it's really six pages.

1459
01:14:37,030 --> 01:14:39,990
No reason not to read that, and
they should be easy questions on the exam.

1460
01:14:42,550 --> 01:14:46,400
All right, so code of ethics
definitely an important one.

1461
01:14:46,400 --> 01:14:48,100
Well, we've covered a lot of material so
far.

1462
01:14:48,100 --> 01:14:51,820
We still got more to go just in
our general project concepts.

1463
01:14:51,820 --> 01:14:54,440
But, this is a pretty good spot for
us to wrap up the show.

1464
01:14:54,440 --> 01:14:58,780
And what will do is a part two,
re-jump into the remainder of this.

1465
01:14:58,780 --> 01:15:02,740
Let me just remind everybody,
if you have any questions on this,

1466
01:15:02,740 --> 01:15:06,420
live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live,

1467
01:15:06,420 --> 01:15:08,530
and you'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

1468
01:15:08,530 --> 01:15:11,720
Post your questions, we monitor and
answer during the show.

1469
01:15:11,720 --> 01:15:13,570
If you have questions after the show,

1470
01:15:13,570 --> 01:15:16,670
like if you're watching this
recorded here's our Q&A system.

1471
01:15:16,670 --> 01:15:18,880
If you hit the Q&A link
at the top of the page.

1472
01:15:18,880 --> 01:15:20,160
Top of every ITProTV page.

1473
01:15:20,160 --> 01:15:24,000
It will take you to our Q&A forms,
you can post your questions there and

1474
01:15:24,000 --> 01:15:25,662
again we monitor and answers.

1475
01:15:25,662 --> 01:15:28,320
We wanna make sure you guys get
the answer to the questions you have.

1476
01:15:28,320 --> 01:15:29,480
So, be ready for that exam.

1477
01:15:29,480 --> 01:15:31,192
That's our goal.

1478
01:15:31,192 --> 01:15:32,640
All right,
I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1479
01:15:32,640 --> 01:15:35,060
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pozet.

1480
01:15:35,060 --> 01:15:36,340
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1481
01:15:36,340 --> 01:15:37,588
>> And we'll see you next time.

1482
01:15:37,588 --> 01:15:41,524
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don break down the five phases and ten knowledge groups of a project. They then introduce the viewer to project management processes and take a look at how to inputs, tool and techniques, and outputs are arranged according to the Project Management Institute.
episodes.title: Fundamentals Part 2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:03,726 --> 00:00:13,726
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:22,521 --> 00:00:23,021
[SOUND]

3
00:00:23,021 --> 00:00:33,051
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,051 --> 00:00:35,289
All right.
Good morning, good afternoon, and

5
00:00:35,289 --> 00:00:36,301
good evening.
And

6
00:00:36,301 --> 00:00:38,120
welcome back another episode of IT Pro TV.

7
00:00:38,120 --> 00:00:39,120
I'm your host.

8
00:00:39,120 --> 00:00:41,080
Don Pezet today with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:41,080 --> 00:00:42,030
How's it going, Ronnie?

10
00:00:42,030 --> 00:00:43,750
>> It is going well, today.

11
00:00:43,750 --> 00:00:48,400
I am again at a loss of a Ghostbusters
quote to return back to you.

12
00:00:48,400 --> 00:00:49,070
>> No?
>> Yep, yep.

13
00:00:49,070 --> 00:00:50,850
>> I wasn't sure where
you were going just yet.

14
00:00:50,850 --> 00:00:54,710
I thought you were going to say you got
in a fist fight with Jay Z and Beyonce.

15
00:00:54,710 --> 00:00:59,020
>> Well, that did happen but
that's not until the court date comes up.

16
00:00:59,020 --> 00:01:01,170
I'm not allowed to talk about it.

17
00:01:01,170 --> 00:01:03,643
>> Are you gag ordered?

18
00:01:03,643 --> 00:01:04,178
>> Yes.
>> Anyhow

19
00:01:04,178 --> 00:01:04,691
>> [LAUGH]

20
00:01:04,691 --> 00:01:07,490
>> So this is part two to our

21
00:01:07,490 --> 00:01:10,910
introductory, beginning,
fundamentals or whatever for

22
00:01:10,910 --> 00:01:12,740
project management professionals.

23
00:01:12,740 --> 00:01:16,180
And we left off in the last
episode having talked about

24
00:01:16,180 --> 00:01:19,560
some of the things that
are expected of a project manager.

25
00:01:19,560 --> 00:01:23,570
And some of the general terminology that's
used to describe the project manager,

26
00:01:23,570 --> 00:01:27,160
project manager skills,
as well as the project team, and

27
00:01:27,160 --> 00:01:28,940
some other associated things.

28
00:01:28,940 --> 00:01:30,255
A lot of terminology.

29
00:01:30,255 --> 00:01:30,780
Right?

30
00:01:30,780 --> 00:01:33,640
Real important,
because that's what we see on the exam.

31
00:01:33,640 --> 00:01:35,430
Now, we're going to switch
gears a little bit,

32
00:01:35,430 --> 00:01:39,860
and talk a bit about how we
actually manage the project.

33
00:01:39,860 --> 00:01:41,440
Right?
We talked about people before,

34
00:01:41,440 --> 00:01:43,420
now let's talk about the project itself.

35
00:01:44,620 --> 00:01:48,730
One concept that really important to
understand, when you go into a project.

36
00:01:48,730 --> 00:01:52,500
You've got to sponsor the person who
comes up with the idea for the project.

37
00:01:52,500 --> 00:01:56,490
And you’ve got a project manager who’s
responsible for making it happen.

38
00:01:56,490 --> 00:01:58,676
Right?
So, one person dreams up the idea,

39
00:01:58,676 --> 00:02:01,290
the other person has to make it happen.

40
00:02:01,290 --> 00:02:02,800
But, that’s not it.

41
00:02:02,800 --> 00:02:04,170
It doesn’t stop there.

42
00:02:04,170 --> 00:02:08,255
There are a lot of people and things that

43
00:02:08,255 --> 00:02:13,055
influence how that project gets done or
even if that project gets done.

44
00:02:13,055 --> 00:02:17,450
And so PMI highlights that as some
of the organizational influences.

45
00:02:17,450 --> 00:02:21,140
So what are some of the things
that influence a project and

46
00:02:21,140 --> 00:02:24,260
kind of change how we manage it, right?

47
00:02:24,260 --> 00:02:28,410
The way I like to think of it is,
what makes my company unique?

48
00:02:28,410 --> 00:02:31,680
Every company has something that makes
it different than the other guys

49
00:02:31,680 --> 00:02:32,510
that are out there.

50
00:02:32,510 --> 00:02:36,150
So you'll find that no two companies
manage projects exactly the same.

51
00:02:36,150 --> 00:02:37,700
We might have the same framework.

52
00:02:37,700 --> 00:02:39,610
We might follow the same basic guidelines.

53
00:02:39,610 --> 00:02:44,150
But there's little things that
change based on our company, right?

54
00:02:44,150 --> 00:02:48,507
There's an energy company here in
town that, very, very successful.

55
00:02:48,507 --> 00:02:51,520
Multi-million dollar
business,been around for a while.

56
00:02:51,520 --> 00:02:54,370
And I think they're actually in
the hundreds of millions of dollars.

57
00:02:54,370 --> 00:02:56,630
They're a very successful organization.

58
00:02:56,630 --> 00:03:00,090
And they have a rule that says,

59
00:03:00,090 --> 00:03:05,320
no policy in the company can be bigger
then what fits on a post-it note.

60
00:03:05,320 --> 00:03:07,160
And so
whenever they write up a company policy,

61
00:03:07,160 --> 00:03:08,710
it has to be able to
fit on a post-it note.

62
00:03:08,710 --> 00:03:09,950
If it's got more terminology then that,

63
00:03:09,950 --> 00:03:12,760
they don't do it, and
they're a very successful company.

64
00:03:12,760 --> 00:03:15,020
But that changes the way
that they do business,

65
00:03:15,020 --> 00:03:18,550
right, versus,
let's say the United States Government.

66
00:03:18,550 --> 00:03:22,750
Where any policy they write has to be
bigger than the encyclopedia of Britannica

67
00:03:22,750 --> 00:03:24,150
otherwise they won't do it.

68
00:03:24,150 --> 00:03:28,010
And so
these are the things that influence us.

69
00:03:28,010 --> 00:03:30,420
So let's take a look at a few of these.

70
00:03:30,420 --> 00:03:33,455
The first one that I've got is culture and
styles.

71
00:03:33,455 --> 00:03:34,290
Right?

72
00:03:34,290 --> 00:03:36,430
Every organization has
a different type of culture.

73
00:03:36,430 --> 00:03:38,250
That energy company I was mentioning.

74
00:03:38,250 --> 00:03:40,170
They try and keep a very personable,

75
00:03:40,170 --> 00:03:43,500
a very simple communication model
between all of their employees.

76
00:03:43,500 --> 00:03:45,440
They want to be treated
like a giant family.

77
00:03:45,440 --> 00:03:49,750
A family that has thousands of members,
but basically a giant family.

78
00:03:49,750 --> 00:03:54,860
That kind of culture,
means that a rigid, full on paperwork

79
00:03:54,860 --> 00:03:59,900
style beuaracratic way of managing
projects, is not really suitable for them.

80
00:03:59,900 --> 00:04:03,670
They're a little more of a fly by the seat
of their pants kind of organization.

81
00:04:03,670 --> 00:04:04,700
You'll see that.

82
00:04:04,700 --> 00:04:07,020
Then there's other organizations
like governments and

83
00:04:07,020 --> 00:04:09,630
military where they're very very rigid.

84
00:04:09,630 --> 00:04:11,900
Right?
Just as a matter of fact when you're in

85
00:04:11,900 --> 00:04:16,640
the military, things that you do have life
and death consequences in a lot of cases.

86
00:04:16,640 --> 00:04:21,390
So there is no just kind of
do just enough to get by.

87
00:04:21,390 --> 00:04:24,560
You want to make sure that it is
going to withstand the test of time.

88
00:04:24,560 --> 00:04:27,900
Different organizations have
different cultures and styles for

89
00:04:27,900 --> 00:04:28,750
how they do business.

90
00:04:28,750 --> 00:04:31,870
And we're seeing that in
Silicon Valley a lot right?

91
00:04:31,870 --> 00:04:35,920
That it used to be that if you wanted to
be a successful IT company, look at IBM,

92
00:04:35,920 --> 00:04:37,800
it was a bunch of people in suits and
ties.

93
00:04:37,800 --> 00:04:38,510
>> Right.
>> And

94
00:04:38,510 --> 00:04:41,398
now you've got a kid who's been sober for
30 minutes-

95
00:04:41,398 --> 00:04:42,073
>> [LAUGH]

96
00:04:42,073 --> 00:04:42,980
>> [LAUGH] And

97
00:04:42,980 --> 00:04:45,974
he bangs out a web application and
sells it for $2 billion tomorrow.

98
00:04:45,974 --> 00:04:46,930
>> Yeah.

99
00:04:46,930 --> 00:04:50,320
>> So companies change the way
that we develop things change and

100
00:04:50,320 --> 00:04:51,405
every company is unique.

101
00:04:51,405 --> 00:04:55,060
>> Yeah, with the project manager they
have to be able to understand this.

102
00:04:55,060 --> 00:04:56,360
That it's going to influence them so

103
00:04:56,360 --> 00:04:59,860
even if they come in from the outside
they've got to deal with these factors

104
00:04:59,860 --> 00:05:02,980
hear particular factors here culture is
by far one of the biggest influences.

105
00:05:02,980 --> 00:05:05,240
And of course you have to actually
understand that culture as you

106
00:05:05,240 --> 00:05:06,260
move through.

107
00:05:06,260 --> 00:05:09,050
If not, that's going to influence
your particular project in a way

108
00:05:09,050 --> 00:05:10,200
you don't want it to.

109
00:05:10,200 --> 00:05:12,610
So make sure you pay attention here.

110
00:05:12,610 --> 00:05:14,380
>> The next thing,
we've got our communications.

111
00:05:14,380 --> 00:05:16,345
How does your team talk?

112
00:05:16,345 --> 00:05:18,520
Right?
Here at IT Pro TV,

113
00:05:18,520 --> 00:05:20,860
we are a cubicle company.

114
00:05:20,860 --> 00:05:23,880
So we've got our studio and if any
of you have ever come by the studio,

115
00:05:23,880 --> 00:05:24,890
you're welcome to come in and see it.

116
00:05:24,890 --> 00:05:26,230
It's not that exciting.

117
00:05:26,230 --> 00:05:29,470
But we've got our studio, which makes
up a good portion of our building.

118
00:05:29,470 --> 00:05:31,340
And then we've got a bunch of cubicles.

119
00:05:31,340 --> 00:05:35,260
So most of the employees can
actually hear me talking right now.

120
00:05:35,260 --> 00:05:41,020
So when it comes to us communicating and
sharing information, we just talk.

121
00:05:41,020 --> 00:05:44,840
We might have to shout over a cubicle
wall or whatever, and actually one or

122
00:05:44,840 --> 00:05:46,830
two people are outside of the main room.

123
00:05:46,830 --> 00:05:50,010
You might have to walk a couple feet,
or pick up the phone.

124
00:05:50,010 --> 00:05:51,180
But everybody's right here.

125
00:05:51,180 --> 00:05:53,885
I see every employee every single day.

126
00:05:53,885 --> 00:05:54,520
Right?

127
00:05:54,520 --> 00:05:56,950
That makes communication really easy.

128
00:05:56,950 --> 00:06:00,540
What if you are a multi-national company,
if you have offices all over the world?

129
00:06:00,540 --> 00:06:01,880
You don't see every employee every day.

130
00:06:01,880 --> 00:06:04,140
You might not see every
employee every year.

131
00:06:04,140 --> 00:06:05,070
So how do you communicate?

132
00:06:05,070 --> 00:06:05,930
By phone?

133
00:06:05,930 --> 00:06:08,090
By video conference, right?

134
00:06:08,090 --> 00:06:11,470
Those types of communication
are less personal, and

135
00:06:11,470 --> 00:06:14,400
can breed uncertainty
in a lot of situations.

136
00:06:14,400 --> 00:06:17,140
So the way we communicate
influences our project.

137
00:06:18,730 --> 00:06:22,140
If I can physically see somebody working,

138
00:06:22,140 --> 00:06:24,940
I might not need a status update
from them every single day.

139
00:06:24,940 --> 00:06:27,490
But if they're across the world.

140
00:06:27,490 --> 00:06:29,910
If they're in China, I can't see them.

141
00:06:29,910 --> 00:06:31,840
I don't necessarily know
what they're doing,

142
00:06:31,840 --> 00:06:34,600
then maybe I do need
a status update every day.

143
00:06:34,600 --> 00:06:36,960
So I know what's going on,
where they're progressing.

144
00:06:36,960 --> 00:06:39,040
That's an important thing.

145
00:06:39,040 --> 00:06:40,690
So we've gotta keep that in mind.

146
00:06:40,690 --> 00:06:43,840
Communications influence
how your project functions.

147
00:06:43,840 --> 00:06:45,380
>> There's gonna be some
organizations again,

148
00:06:45,380 --> 00:06:47,610
where the communication
is relatively informal.

149
00:06:47,610 --> 00:06:50,720
And there's some organizations where
the communication has to, again,

150
00:06:50,720 --> 00:06:53,120
be in a certain manner.

151
00:06:53,120 --> 00:06:57,120
Again, whether it's by email or
whether it's a telephone call every day.

152
00:06:57,120 --> 00:07:00,800
Whatever it is, the process may be more
formalized in that particular method.

153
00:07:00,800 --> 00:07:02,470
So again,
you have to fit in that culture as well.

154
00:07:02,470 --> 00:07:04,640
>> All right, and

155
00:07:04,640 --> 00:07:09,660
then the last thing that we need to
highlight is the organization structure.

156
00:07:09,660 --> 00:07:12,875
Now organization structure,
I'm gonna bring up the PMBOK on this one,

157
00:07:12,875 --> 00:07:16,110
because they have some
really good stuff in here.

158
00:07:16,110 --> 00:07:17,420
If I can remember what page it's on.

159
00:07:17,420 --> 00:07:20,860
Zoom out of it here.

160
00:07:22,010 --> 00:07:23,800
There we go.
All right.

161
00:07:23,800 --> 00:07:27,630
So, in the project management
body of knowledge,

162
00:07:27,630 --> 00:07:32,242
you'll find a section in there where they
talk about organizational structure.

163
00:07:32,242 --> 00:07:33,550
All right?

164
00:07:33,550 --> 00:07:36,530
Companies can be structured
in one of three forms,

165
00:07:36,530 --> 00:07:39,070
I know it looks like there's more
there but there's really just three.

166
00:07:39,070 --> 00:07:42,305
Functional, matrix, and Projectized.

167
00:07:42,305 --> 00:07:45,005
Now I used that word projectized
a few times in the last episode so

168
00:07:45,005 --> 00:07:46,765
now we are gonna really see what it means.

169
00:07:46,765 --> 00:07:51,545
Well most companies today are what
are called functional companies.

170
00:07:51,545 --> 00:07:55,472
You have departments,
maybe you have sale marketing, accounting.

171
00:07:55,472 --> 00:07:56,907
Each department has a manager.

172
00:07:56,907 --> 00:07:57,483
Right.
And

173
00:07:57,483 --> 00:07:59,829
departments are made up
by what those people do.

174
00:07:59,829 --> 00:08:02,952
If I deal with the bookkeeping,
I'm in the accounting department.

175
00:08:02,952 --> 00:08:05,832
If I am selling things,
I'm in the sales department.

176
00:08:05,832 --> 00:08:08,969
The sales manager is responsible for
all the sales, and

177
00:08:08,969 --> 00:08:11,130
that's where authority lays.

178
00:08:11,130 --> 00:08:15,840
Those managers then answer to a higher up,
that's a very typical structure for

179
00:08:15,840 --> 00:08:16,990
an organization today.

180
00:08:18,610 --> 00:08:22,920
That structure has been around for
hundreds, thousands of years.

181
00:08:22,920 --> 00:08:24,860
And it doesn't really allow for
project managers, so

182
00:08:24,860 --> 00:08:28,290
project managers don't really
fit into this model very well.

183
00:08:28,290 --> 00:08:30,234
And we'll see a diagram
here in just a moment.

184
00:08:30,234 --> 00:08:37,600
Project on the other hand is where
project managers are the managers.

185
00:08:37,600 --> 00:08:39,490
But there are no functional managers.

186
00:08:39,490 --> 00:08:42,450
There might be a sales department,
but there is no sales manager.

187
00:08:42,450 --> 00:08:46,210
Instead, each sales person is
attached to a different project, and

188
00:08:46,210 --> 00:08:48,460
so they answer to a project manager.

189
00:08:48,460 --> 00:08:52,040
In this environment the project
managers have all of the authority.

190
00:08:52,040 --> 00:08:53,370
And that's not very common.

191
00:08:53,370 --> 00:08:56,690
You see it at places like NASA
where everything is a project.

192
00:08:56,690 --> 00:08:59,840
But you don't see it at your
normal average company.

193
00:09:01,190 --> 00:09:04,800
A matrix is where we blend the two ideas.

194
00:09:04,800 --> 00:09:08,270
We blend functional and
project ties together so that we have

195
00:09:08,270 --> 00:09:12,470
functional managers with authority and
project managers with authority.

196
00:09:12,470 --> 00:09:14,520
And you get varying results out of this,
but

197
00:09:14,520 --> 00:09:16,870
it tries to provide
the best of both worlds.

198
00:09:16,870 --> 00:09:19,320
It usually creates confusion.

199
00:09:19,320 --> 00:09:20,570
>> Right.
>> This is

200
00:09:20,570 --> 00:09:23,850
one thing that you'll hear people who've
been in the military talk about it a lot.

201
00:09:23,850 --> 00:09:27,970
If you have more than one boss,
who do you listen to, right?

202
00:09:27,970 --> 00:09:30,550
It's very confusing for
an employee to be in that environment but

203
00:09:30,550 --> 00:09:33,260
that hasn't stopped a lot
of people from trying.

204
00:09:33,260 --> 00:09:35,990
So let's look at each of these and
I'll just use the diagram

205
00:09:35,990 --> 00:09:40,790
straight from the PMBOK so
this is PMI's representation of it.

206
00:09:40,790 --> 00:09:43,880
Here's a standard functional organization.

207
00:09:43,880 --> 00:09:46,550
Your departments are divided
up by their function.

208
00:09:46,550 --> 00:09:49,870
Each one has a functional manager,
and the functional manager

209
00:09:49,870 --> 00:09:54,210
answers to some kind of chief executive,
president, CEO, whatever their title is.

210
00:09:55,650 --> 00:10:00,280
And if there's a project,
there's no project manager in here,

211
00:10:00,280 --> 00:10:02,640
see the project manager
is not even on the chart.

212
00:10:02,640 --> 00:10:06,220
And so in this scenario the project
manager is borrowing people.

213
00:10:06,220 --> 00:10:09,470
Borrowing somebody from this department,
borrowing somebody from this department,

214
00:10:09,470 --> 00:10:10,770
and from this department, and

215
00:10:10,770 --> 00:10:14,650
then they have to coordinate with the
functional managers to get those people.

216
00:10:14,650 --> 00:10:16,210
Hey, can I have them Tuesday afternoon?

217
00:10:16,210 --> 00:10:17,800
Can I have them Monday morning?

218
00:10:17,800 --> 00:10:19,770
Are they gonna be available?

219
00:10:19,770 --> 00:10:23,010
The project manager is really at
the whim of the functional managers to

220
00:10:23,010 --> 00:10:24,220
get things done.

221
00:10:24,220 --> 00:10:27,650
It's not a very project
supportive environment, but

222
00:10:27,650 --> 00:10:29,280
it is the most common environment.

223
00:10:29,280 --> 00:10:31,902
So this is where a lot of you guys
are gonna end up in the workplace.

224
00:10:34,945 --> 00:10:36,790
All right.

225
00:10:36,790 --> 00:10:39,530
In a projectized environment.

226
00:10:39,530 --> 00:10:43,325
These are the matrix,
let me jump down to projectized.

227
00:10:43,325 --> 00:10:48,350
Projectized is like the same thing except,
instead of having departments,

228
00:10:48,350 --> 00:10:49,770
I have projects.

229
00:10:49,770 --> 00:10:53,550
I might have like this staffer
right here might be an accountant,

230
00:10:55,840 --> 00:10:57,540
and this staffer might be an accountant,
and this staffer might be an accountant.

231
00:10:57,540 --> 00:10:59,650
So each project has an accountant.

232
00:10:59,650 --> 00:11:03,680
It's like an accounting department, but
there's no real department in this model.

233
00:11:03,680 --> 00:11:06,330
Each one is assigned
to a separate project.

234
00:11:06,330 --> 00:11:09,690
And same thing, we might have a lawyer
here, a lawyer here, a lawyer here.

235
00:11:09,690 --> 00:11:10,800
I don't have a legal department,

236
00:11:10,800 --> 00:11:13,390
I just happen to have a lawyer
attached to each project.

237
00:11:13,390 --> 00:11:16,300
Might even be the same lawyer attached
to more than one project, but

238
00:11:16,300 --> 00:11:19,590
they work for a project manager, right?

239
00:11:19,590 --> 00:11:23,900
The positive here is your project
managers have a lot of authority, right?

240
00:11:23,900 --> 00:11:26,340
Very easy for them to manage resources.

241
00:11:26,340 --> 00:11:30,260
But, it doesn't really allow for
ongoing operations, right?

242
00:11:30,260 --> 00:11:32,940
Day to day activities that
occur outside of a project,

243
00:11:32,940 --> 00:11:34,430
this doesn't really allow for it.

244
00:11:34,430 --> 00:11:37,010
Well, if you're somebody like NASA and

245
00:11:37,010 --> 00:11:42,790
you got a project that they're looking
at the whole colony on Mars thing.

246
00:11:42,790 --> 00:11:46,350
So that's a project for them, and
they've got a project manager and

247
00:11:46,350 --> 00:11:48,220
they've got teams underneath it.

248
00:11:48,220 --> 00:11:50,400
And those people work for that project.

249
00:11:50,400 --> 00:11:54,210
They don't work on any other projects,
they just work for that one.

250
00:11:54,210 --> 00:11:57,000
On a positive note,
everybody knows who they answer to and

251
00:11:57,000 --> 00:11:59,950
everybody's got one goal,
the project that they're on.

252
00:11:59,950 --> 00:12:03,010
On a negative note,
what happens when that project is done?

253
00:12:03,010 --> 00:12:04,160
They all get fired.

254
00:12:04,160 --> 00:12:04,685
>> Right.
>> Right.

255
00:12:04,685 --> 00:12:05,875
It sounds negative, but

256
00:12:05,875 --> 00:12:07,055
that is what happens, right?
>> Yeah.

257
00:12:07,055 --> 00:12:08,275
>> They're all under contract for

258
00:12:08,275 --> 00:12:08,975
that project and

259
00:12:08,975 --> 00:12:13,100
when the project is done, literally their
contracts end, they're out of a job.

260
00:12:13,100 --> 00:12:15,221
Now that doesn't mean that
they are truly fired,

261
00:12:15,221 --> 00:12:17,200
they usually just sign
onto another project.

262
00:12:17,200 --> 00:12:19,970
A new project starts or
whatever and they move onto that.

263
00:12:19,970 --> 00:12:22,540
But it does create a little
bit of uncertainty for

264
00:12:22,540 --> 00:12:26,572
the employees that are working for this
project, and that is their entire job.

265
00:12:26,572 --> 00:12:29,320
All right.

266
00:12:29,320 --> 00:12:33,180
Now the hybrids, the matrices models,

267
00:12:33,180 --> 00:12:36,150
they're the ones that kind
of blend the solution.

268
00:12:36,150 --> 00:12:39,730
So here they're showing a weak matrix.

269
00:12:39,730 --> 00:12:43,150
Most companies that are just now
implementing project management,

270
00:12:43,150 --> 00:12:45,200
are gonna fall in this weak matrix model.

271
00:12:46,300 --> 00:12:49,820
With the weak matrix, we still have a CEO,
or a chief of some sort,

272
00:12:49,820 --> 00:12:55,040
you still have your functional managers,
but when someone's assigned to a project,

273
00:12:55,040 --> 00:12:57,720
like these three people here
are assigned to a project,

274
00:12:57,720 --> 00:13:03,610
the project manager is assigned
as their pseudo-manager, right?

275
00:13:03,610 --> 00:13:08,175
So now these employees have to
report to two different bosses.

276
00:13:08,175 --> 00:13:11,390
They have their functional manager
they work for most of the time, and

277
00:13:11,390 --> 00:13:14,400
they now have a project manager
they work for some of the time.

278
00:13:14,400 --> 00:13:18,300
And when there's a conflict,
the functional manager wins.

279
00:13:18,300 --> 00:13:23,260
And so PMI calls this a weak matrix
because as a project manager you

280
00:13:23,260 --> 00:13:26,980
get some authority but not nearly
as much as a functional manager, so

281
00:13:26,980 --> 00:13:33,570
you have a weak level or weak matrix.

282
00:13:33,570 --> 00:13:35,790
The next one is a balance matrix and

283
00:13:35,790 --> 00:13:38,635
while it looks good on paper it
is one of the most nightmare-ish.

284
00:13:38,635 --> 00:13:43,780
[LAUGH] In a balanced matrix, it's the
same model we just saw in a weak matrix.

285
00:13:43,780 --> 00:13:49,070
The difference here is the staff is
actually assigned to the project manager.

286
00:13:49,070 --> 00:13:51,350
So notice I've got
the project manager here.

287
00:13:51,350 --> 00:13:55,870
The staff gets assigned to them and
so the staff now has two bosses.

288
00:13:55,870 --> 00:13:58,726
If I'm this staffer right here I
answer to my functional manager and

289
00:13:58,726 --> 00:14:00,070
to my project manager.

290
00:14:00,070 --> 00:14:01,340
And not only that,

291
00:14:01,340 --> 00:14:05,200
the project manager is in a department
with their own functional manager.

292
00:14:05,200 --> 00:14:08,095
So now I've got multiple
tiers of management.

293
00:14:08,095 --> 00:14:09,715
This becomes very challenging.

294
00:14:09,715 --> 00:14:13,375
The project manager gets more
authority than they had before, but

295
00:14:13,375 --> 00:14:15,825
it's at the cost of
confusion of the staff.

296
00:14:16,925 --> 00:14:20,785
This is called a balance matrix cuz it's
trying to find a balance between project,

297
00:14:20,785 --> 00:14:21,469
and functional management.

298
00:14:24,640 --> 00:14:27,340
And then lastly we have a strong matrix.

299
00:14:27,340 --> 00:14:31,290
And with a strong matrix, the functional
manager that the project managers work

300
00:14:31,290 --> 00:14:35,840
for, is actually a manager
of project managers, right?

301
00:14:35,840 --> 00:14:39,310
So this might be the program manager,
right?

302
00:14:39,310 --> 00:14:43,460
Remember your program is made up of all
the individual projects that you have.

303
00:14:43,460 --> 00:14:47,250
So that person's in charge of them,
and then staff is getting assigned.

304
00:14:47,250 --> 00:14:51,450
Now Staff still has two bosses, but
the project managers are being backed up

305
00:14:51,450 --> 00:14:55,780
by their manager, which generally
will have more authority than, for

306
00:14:55,780 --> 00:14:58,250
example, the functional managers.

307
00:14:58,250 --> 00:15:01,530
So definitely a interesting mix there.

308
00:15:01,530 --> 00:15:05,320
But if we go back to this chart here.

309
00:15:05,320 --> 00:15:10,420
They kind of break it down, where you'll
see in a projectized environment,

310
00:15:10,420 --> 00:15:16,480
the project manager has the highest
authority possible, beneath the CEO.

311
00:15:16,480 --> 00:15:20,790
In all of the other models you'll see,
it gets to be less and less and

312
00:15:20,790 --> 00:15:24,130
less until you have next
to no authority whatsoever.

313
00:15:24,130 --> 00:15:26,770
And remember, this is the model
that most of us are working in.

314
00:15:28,150 --> 00:15:31,760
But you'll notice some of the other
benefits that we get as far as resource

315
00:15:31,760 --> 00:15:36,020
availability and things like that
really does become kind of handy.

316
00:15:36,020 --> 00:15:40,630
So be aware that the way
your company is structured,

317
00:15:40,630 --> 00:15:44,660
is going to directly influence
how you can run your project.

318
00:15:46,170 --> 00:15:47,760
So that's a big deal.

319
00:15:47,760 --> 00:15:50,670
These are definitely something
that's gonna show up on the exam.

00:15:50,670 --> 00:15:54,286
So while you don't necessarily need to

321
00:15:54,286 --> 00:15:55,830
you wanna memorize the concept.

00:15:55,830 --> 00:16:00,317
Understand what each of the three matrix
type models are as well as the projectized

00:16:00,317 --> 00:16:01,692
and functional models.

00:16:01,692 --> 00:16:06,278
And so, really, this chart here is

325
00:16:06,278 --> 00:16:10,894
Alright, some of the other things

326
00:16:10,894 --> 00:16:15,047
that influence our projects.

00:16:15,047 --> 00:16:20,780
I'm trying to think of the best
