00:16:22,890 --> 00:16:24,670
We'll just tackle these individually.

329
00:16:24,670 --> 00:16:28,270
There are two elements
that influence almost

330
00:16:28,270 --> 00:16:30,950
every single process
throughout our project.

331
00:16:30,950 --> 00:16:31,690
All right.

332
00:16:31,690 --> 00:16:33,060
So, they're pretty important.

333
00:16:33,060 --> 00:16:36,060
They're ones that we want to be familiar
with at least conceptually because they

334
00:16:36,060 --> 00:16:37,570

335
00:16:37,570 --> 00:16:41,842
The first one is called
Organizational Process Assets.

336
00:16:41,842 --> 00:16:42,500
All right.

337
00:16:42,500 --> 00:16:45,380
It's a big name, let me bring up my notes.

338
00:16:45,380 --> 00:16:46,930
Where are my notes?

339
00:16:46,930 --> 00:16:47,430
There.

340
00:16:49,480 --> 00:16:52,530
So I'm talking about
these guys right here.

341
00:16:52,530 --> 00:16:55,390
Organizational Process Assets.

342
00:16:55,390 --> 00:16:56,490
All right.

343
00:16:56,490 --> 00:16:58,240
When you're managing a project,

344
00:16:58,240 --> 00:17:02,590
it's extremely rare that you are starting
out with absolutely nothing.

345
00:17:02,590 --> 00:17:03,330
Okay.

346
00:17:03,330 --> 00:17:06,660
It's very rare for you to have a project
that is for you to start a company.

347
00:17:06,660 --> 00:17:09,850
So almost always,
your company's already in business and

348
00:17:09,850 --> 00:17:12,870
your project is adding
something to that business.

349
00:17:12,870 --> 00:17:17,900
In that scenario, your company likely
has certain assets that you can use.

350
00:17:17,900 --> 00:17:19,100
Now if it's a brand new company,

351
00:17:19,100 --> 00:17:22,465
if your project is to start the company,
then you don't have any assets.

352
00:17:22,465 --> 00:17:24,350
Right.
You can go out and get things, but

353
00:17:24,350 --> 00:17:25,720
you don't have assets themselves.

354
00:17:25,720 --> 00:17:27,840
And by assets,
I don't necessarily mean materials.

355
00:17:27,840 --> 00:17:30,020
I don't mean like a company car or
whatever.

356
00:17:30,020 --> 00:17:33,670
What I mean are processes and procedures.

357
00:17:33,670 --> 00:17:39,360
You might have rules,
specific ways of doing business defined,

358
00:17:39,360 --> 00:17:42,472

359
00:17:42,472 --> 00:17:43,635
All right?

360
00:17:43,635 --> 00:17:45,515
So for
example I'm about to start a new project.

361
00:17:45,515 --> 00:17:47,985
I just gotta assign the project
management position.

362
00:17:47,985 --> 00:17:49,665
And I'm about to run it.

363
00:17:49,665 --> 00:17:52,655
I might look and see what the other

00:17:52,655 --> 00:17:58,140
So if they've already done projects I

365
00:17:58,140 --> 00:18:03,210
They already have processes and
procedures in place for how to submit

366

our budget, how to report on the budget.

367
00:18:10,960 --> 00:18:12,390
All that stuff may be already defined,

368
00:18:12,390 --> 00:18:14,750
if we have a well defined
project management environment.

369
00:18:14,750 --> 00:18:15,410
Right?

370
00:18:15,410 --> 00:18:17,730
So those assets are going to influence us.

371
00:18:17,730 --> 00:18:21,360
I might have one particular chart that I
might like to use, but when I look and

372
00:18:21,360 --> 00:18:25,530
I see the five last projects
of a different type of chart,

373
00:18:25,530 --> 00:18:27,530
I might choose to use that other chart.

374
00:18:27,530 --> 00:18:29,950
Just because I know the employees
are already used to it and

375
00:18:29,950 --> 00:18:31,650
it's what they expect.

376
00:18:31,650 --> 00:18:34,050
So we always need to look
at what we already have.

377
00:18:34,050 --> 00:18:37,520
I always say, don't reinvent
the wheel if you don't have to.

378
00:18:37,520 --> 00:18:42,600
If somebody's already done the work,
then you shouldn't have to do it again.

379
00:18:42,600 --> 00:18:45,520
Unless you can make it better,
that's process improvement.

380
00:18:45,520 --> 00:18:48,800
You start getting into six sigma there.

381
00:18:48,800 --> 00:18:50,780
Right, continual process improvement.

382
00:18:50,780 --> 00:18:53,536
So [LAUGH] Well [INAUDIBLE]
try [INAUDIBLE].

383
00:18:53,536 --> 00:18:56,160
So anyway just keep that in mind.

384
00:18:56,160 --> 00:18:58,480
You probably already have certain assets.

385
00:18:58,480 --> 00:19:01,100
And processes and
procedures are very common.

386
00:19:01,100 --> 00:19:02,795
Less common is a knowledge base.

387
00:19:02,795 --> 00:19:06,170
Right?
I love it when you find a company that has

388
00:19:06,170 --> 00:19:11,700
these, odds are, people have made
mistakes in the past and the odds are.

389
00:19:11,700 --> 00:19:14,930
If you knew about those mistakes,
you could avoid them better yourself.

390
00:19:14,930 --> 00:19:15,510
Right?

391
00:19:15,510 --> 00:19:19,570
Learn from other people's mistakes and
that's what knowledge bases are all about.

392
00:19:19,570 --> 00:19:21,120
At the end of every project,

393
00:19:21,120 --> 00:19:24,316
you're supposed to create what's
a called a lessons learned.

394
00:19:24,316 --> 00:19:25,560
Right?
The information that

395
00:19:25,560 --> 00:19:27,080
you learned is part of your
project if part of your project.

396
00:19:27,080 --> 00:19:28,990
What went wrong,
how you fixed it and so on.

397
00:19:28,990 --> 00:19:31,420
If that becomes part a of
a company knowledge base,

398
00:19:31,420 --> 00:19:35,610
you can search across that, and
you can say, I need to hire.

399
00:19:35,610 --> 00:19:39,490
Maybe my projects building a house, so
I need to hire a dry wall installer.

400
00:19:39,490 --> 00:19:42,600
Let me look at some of these other

401
00:19:42,600 --> 00:19:45,820
And I can use that to build my

402
00:19:45,820 --> 00:19:46,430
Right?

403
00:19:46,430 --> 00:19:50,910
Or, hey, I'm about to order some servers

404
00:19:50,910 --> 00:19:53,280
Well, this other project
just did the same thing.

405
00:19:53,280 --> 00:19:54,610
Let me look at what price they got.

406
00:19:54,610 --> 00:19:55,880
Did they already deal with a rep?

407
00:19:55,880 --> 00:19:57,910
Can we get volume discounts, right?

408
00:19:57,910 --> 00:19:59,150
Sharing that information,

409
00:19:59,150 --> 00:20:03,840
looking at information that other projects
really can make a big difference.

410
00:20:03,840 --> 00:20:04,400
>> Yeah.

411
00:20:04,400 --> 00:20:06,020
It also saves time, right?

412
00:20:06,020 --> 00:20:09,450
Once again, because we're not reinventing

00:20:09,450 --> 00:20:12,950
actually taking a look at all
the possibilities here in terms of

00:20:12,950 --> 00:20:16,390
possible failures or
setback other projects have had.

415
00:20:16,390 --> 00:20:18,950
And if they do match in line
with what we want to do,

416
00:20:18,950 --> 00:20:22,350
it may actually give us a head start and

417
00:20:22,350 --> 00:20:26,492
For us to be able to do those things and
not have to worry about 'em.

418
00:20:26,492 --> 00:20:29,420
>> All right, so
organizational process assets,

419
00:20:29,420 --> 00:20:33,292
those are things that
your company may have.

420
00:20:33,292 --> 00:20:35,320
All right, you may have these,
you may not.

00:20:35,320 --> 00:20:37,580
You may not have any of this, and

All right?

The other thing is,

All right?

425
00:20:43,490 --> 00:20:46,835
Enterprise environmental factors
are things that your company has to have.

426
00:20:46,835 --> 00:20:47,890
All right?

00:20:47,890 --> 00:20:50,515
So this isn't something

If you are regulated by the US Government.

429
00:20:53,405 --> 00:20:55,815
>> Yeah.
>> Right, there might be certain rules and

00:20:55,815 --> 00:20:58,345
standards that you have to follow.

431
00:20:58,345 --> 00:21:02,950
If your company is voluntarily
chosen to become ISO 9000 certified.

432
00:21:02,950 --> 00:21:06,510
There's rules you have to follow
to maintain that standard.

433
00:21:06,510 --> 00:21:07,600
Right?

434
00:21:07,600 --> 00:21:10,830
You might have certain governance
requirements, so for example,

00:21:10,830 --> 00:21:11,950
here in the state of Florida,

00:21:11,950 --> 00:21:15,040

So all of your records need

If you do a bid process,

You might be private sector.

Right?

00:21:23,630 --> 00:21:26,130
But you might be

In which case, all the financial

00:21:31,910 --> 00:21:32,650
Right?

00:21:32,650 --> 00:21:36,690
Those are things that are part of your

These are requirements that are imposed
upon you, and you don't have a choice.

00:21:40,430 --> 00:21:40,950
Right?

So you may know a better way to do things.

A different way to manage your project,

00:21:46,436 --> 00:21:49,470
You're ISO 9000 certified.so you've
gotta have this paperwork in

00:21:49,470 --> 00:21:51,480
place whether you like it or not.

452
00:21:51,480 --> 00:21:54,612
Or you can lose your ISO 9000 designation.

00:21:54,612 --> 00:21:57,210
So that is an enterprise
environmental factor.

454
00:21:57,210 --> 00:21:59,230
I put governance standards.

00:21:59,230 --> 00:22:02,165
Those are some pretty black and
white ones.

00:22:02,165 --> 00:22:04,340
>> Right.
>> We do have some gray area things.

00:22:04,340 --> 00:22:04,970
Right?

458
00:22:04,970 --> 00:22:06,780
Like risk tolerance.

459
00:22:06,780 --> 00:22:12,740
So risk tolerance is your company may or
may not be big into taking risk.

460
00:22:12,740 --> 00:22:13,680
Right?

461
00:22:13,680 --> 00:22:17,770
We're in IT, and so
almost IT company takes risks.

462
00:22:17,770 --> 00:22:19,340
>> Right.
>> Cuz God only knows what your computer's

463
00:22:19,340 --> 00:22:20,090
going to do tomorrow.

464
00:22:20,090 --> 00:22:26,700
[LAUGH] And so,
you'll have people that are risk seekers.

465
00:22:26,700 --> 00:22:29,560
People who are looking to take risk
because they know the bigger the risk

466
00:22:29,560 --> 00:22:32,440
the greater the reward,
assuming it pans out.

467
00:22:32,440 --> 00:22:35,330
You also have people that are risk averse.

00:22:35,330 --> 00:22:39,450
These are people who would rather not

00:22:39,450 --> 00:22:41,660
Would maybe settle for lower profits or

00:22:41,660 --> 00:22:44,860
slower project because
they weren't taking risk.

471
00:22:44,860 --> 00:22:49,220
Or hopefully as a project manager
what you are is called risk neutral.

472
00:22:49,220 --> 00:22:52,000
A risk neutral person and

00:22:52,000 --> 00:22:54,700
I'll post these with the episode.

00:22:54,700 --> 00:22:56,670
Because these are the official terms.

00:22:56,670 --> 00:22:58,630
We'll talk about them again later but.

00:22:58,630 --> 00:23:01,640
So you have risk seeker, risk neutral,

477
00:23:03,210 --> 00:23:08,140
which I spelled wrong, and-
>> No, I think you did it right.

478
00:23:08,140 --> 00:23:08,960
>> Was I right?

479
00:23:08,960 --> 00:23:10,990
See my risky spelling.

480
00:23:10,990 --> 00:23:12,530
And then you have risk averse.

481
00:23:13,770 --> 00:23:15,020
Ree osk a verse.

00:23:15,020 --> 00:23:16,230
There we go.

00:23:16,230 --> 00:23:16,886
All right.

484
00:23:16,886 --> 00:23:22,220
So those are kind of our three Little
levels of Risk Tolerance right there.

485
00:23:22,220 --> 00:23:25,260
If you're a Risk Seeker and
somebody comes to you and says hey,

486
00:23:25,260 --> 00:23:27,280
I wanna do this project.

487
00:23:27,280 --> 00:23:32,000
There's a chance that it could
double our sales by next year, and

488
00:23:32,000 --> 00:23:36,150
it's a 10% chance [LAUGH] that
it could double our sales.

489
00:23:36,150 --> 00:23:41,730
Well you might look at that and say 10%
one out of ten chance let's do it, right?

490
00:23:42,740 --> 00:23:47,190
Or you might be riskevers and say what are
you crazy 10% that means there's a nine

491
00:23:47,190 --> 00:23:50,690
out of ten chance that this is going to
fail forget you we're not going to do it.

492
00:23:50,690 --> 00:23:51,860
Right?

493
00:23:51,860 --> 00:23:53,990
Or you might be risk neutral and say well,

00:23:53,990 --> 00:23:56,320
one out of ten chance

00:23:56,320 --> 00:23:57,580
What happens if it fails?

00:23:57,580 --> 00:23:58,720
Is it gonna cost us money?

How much money?
You start to qualify.

498
00:24:00,564 --> 00:24:04,407
You start to evaluate and look at
the numbers and you say all right well

00:24:04,407 --> 00:24:05,480
>> It's pretty risky,

500
00:24:05,480 --> 00:24:09,471
but at the end of the day if it doesn't
work, it's only gonna cost us this much,

501
00:24:09,471 --> 00:24:11,240
let's go ahead and do it, right.

502
00:24:11,240 --> 00:24:13,280
Or, no,
the odds are it's going to fail and

503
00:24:13,280 --> 00:24:16,190

00:24:16,190 --> 00:24:19,100
Being risk neutral is

00:24:19,100 --> 00:24:23,080
Project managers should
always be risk neutral.

00:24:23,080 --> 00:24:28,220
If you're risk averse, you may be
passing up opportunities that were.

00:24:28,220 --> 00:24:30,260
Possibly beneficial for your company.

508
00:24:30,260 --> 00:24:33,440
And if you are a risk seeker,

00:24:33,440 --> 00:24:38,280
you might be taking unnecessary risks

510
00:24:38,280 --> 00:24:39,780
So being the neutral person, and

00:24:39,780 --> 00:24:44,470
we have that here, right,
it's kind of one of our running things.

00:24:44,470 --> 00:24:48,010

Tim, he's a risk seeker.

00:24:48,010 --> 00:24:53,420
He has big vision ideas all
packed full of risk and

00:24:53,420 --> 00:24:55,990
I'm the risk neutral guy that
tries to like back that down.

00:24:55,990 --> 00:24:59,750
Let's start to kind of keep
that a little more contained.

516
00:24:59,750 --> 00:25:03,010
But at the end of the day,
if you don't take risks,

517
00:25:03,010 --> 00:25:04,410

00:25:04,410 --> 00:25:07,530
So you definitely wanna make
sure you keep that in mind.

00:25:07,530 --> 00:25:11,170
But that risk tolerance, your company's
risk tolerance, your sponsor's risk

00:25:11,170 --> 00:25:14,780
tolerance, the tolerance of your
stakeholders, your shareholders, right,

00:25:14,780 --> 00:25:18,440

00:25:18,440 --> 00:25:23,340
If your company is a risk seeker,
you might have very aggressive timelines,

00:25:23,340 --> 00:25:24,430
very aggressive budgets.

00:25:25,690 --> 00:25:29,430
But if you're risk averse, you might

00:25:29,430 --> 00:25:30,610

00:25:30,610 --> 00:25:33,060
Or you might have bigger
budgets that allow for

00:25:33,060 --> 00:25:34,820

00:25:34,820 --> 00:25:39,030
So you might have safety cushions to

00:25:39,030 --> 00:25:41,720
So it just depends on how
your company is built,

530
00:25:41,720 --> 00:25:44,720
the kind of people that are in it, which
one of those you're gonna fall under.

531
00:25:44,720 --> 00:25:48,120
And then the last one I've got
is marketplace conditions.

00:25:48,120 --> 00:25:51,610
This is one that wreaks havoc

533
00:25:51,610 --> 00:25:55,900
I can't tell you the amount of
times that I started a project and

00:25:55,900 --> 00:26:01,410

Telco systems, hardware, whatever.

535
00:26:01,410 --> 00:26:05,350
And when when it came purchase time,
the prices were different, right.

536
00:26:05,350 --> 00:26:08,940
Marketplace conditions are going to
change what we can and can't do.

537
00:26:08,940 --> 00:26:13,940
If you're a construction company and

but the housing market falls to

You might start building 2000
square foot houses, much smaller,

because they sell easier.

541
00:26:22,330 --> 00:26:27,050
So that's the kind of thing that starts to
influence what projects get selected, but

542
00:26:27,050 --> 00:26:28,320
as far as what project, or

543
00:26:28,320 --> 00:26:32,640
how projects are carried out, marketplace
conditions can effect that too.

544
00:26:32,640 --> 00:26:37,430
If I set a budget and I said I'm
gonna spend x amount on servers.

545
00:26:37,430 --> 00:26:42,040
And all the sudden I find out there's
gonna be a great big sale on servers.

546
00:26:42,040 --> 00:26:44,970
I might not have intended on buying
those servers for another month, but

547
00:26:44,970 --> 00:26:47,140
now I know if I buy them right now,
I can save 20%.

548
00:26:47,140 --> 00:26:49,420
I might do that.

549
00:26:49,420 --> 00:26:52,990
I might rearrange my project a bit to buy
those severs early cuz I know it's gonna

550
00:26:52,990 --> 00:26:57,880
save me money, and improve the chances of
my org, my project finishing under budget.

551
00:26:57,880 --> 00:27:01,320
So marketplace conditions can
directly influence your project.

552
00:27:01,320 --> 00:27:03,560
It can even lead to it being cancelled.

553
00:27:03,560 --> 00:27:04,690
>> Yeah.
>> Right.

554
00:27:04,690 --> 00:27:06,390
You're seeing that with
he military right now.

555
00:27:06,390 --> 00:27:09,200
The US military, where they have that,
what's it called?

556
00:27:09,200 --> 00:27:10,870
The Joint Strike Fighter, JSF?

557
00:27:10,870 --> 00:27:11,430
>> Yeah.

558
00:27:11,430 --> 00:27:14,500
Where, I mean,
this is something ridiculous,

559
00:27:14,500 --> 00:27:17,970
like 32 billion per plane to create it.

560
00:27:17,970 --> 00:27:20,860
And apparently they were cool with
that ten years ago when they started

561
00:27:20,860 --> 00:27:23,790
the program, but now, they're like,
ooh, that might be a little expensive.

562
00:27:23,790 --> 00:27:26,439
>> Yeah.
>> It takes ten years to figure that out.

563
00:27:26,439 --> 00:27:28,990
[LAUGH] So now,
they're canceling the project.

564
00:27:28,990 --> 00:27:31,580
They're 10 years in,
they put ten years of work in there.

565
00:27:31,580 --> 00:27:35,610
The project wasn't failing,
it was moving along as expected.

566
00:27:35,610 --> 00:27:40,600
But the marketplace has changed and now
people's perception of 30 some odd billion

567
00:27:40,600 --> 00:27:44,700
per plane has been seen for
what it is, which is ludicrous.

568
00:27:44,700 --> 00:27:46,005
So the project gets cancelled.

569
00:27:46,005 --> 00:27:47,470
[LAUGH] That can happen,

570
00:27:47,470 --> 00:27:50,032
a project can be terminated
because of marketplace conditions.

571
00:27:50,032 --> 00:27:50,532
Yeah.

572
00:27:51,536 --> 00:27:55,090
All right well, Ronnie, that's a pretty
good spot for us to stop and take a break.

573
00:27:55,090 --> 00:27:55,680
>> All right, sounds great.

574
00:27:55,680 --> 00:27:56,670
>> So, why don't we stop here?

575
00:27:56,670 --> 00:27:59,280
When we get back, we've got some
real important stuff to talk about,

576
00:27:59,280 --> 00:28:01,290
because we're gonna look at processes.

577
00:28:01,290 --> 00:28:04,440
We kind of talked a little bit about
processes, so we've got some more of that,

578
00:28:04,440 --> 00:28:06,460
and the project life cycle
we haven't touched on.

579
00:28:06,460 --> 00:28:08,320
So, good stuff coming up.

580
00:28:08,320 --> 00:28:12,187
Stay tuned, we'll be back after this.

581
00:28:12,187 --> 00:28:19,780
[SOUND] All right, welcome back everybody.

582
00:28:19,780 --> 00:28:23,740
So what I'd like to talk about now,
is the project life cycle.

583
00:28:23,740 --> 00:28:28,575
Which is really just complex way of saying
what happens while your project runs?

584
00:28:28,575 --> 00:28:31,070
>> Right.
>> Projects have a well-defined

585
00:28:31,070 --> 00:28:32,810
timeline which we mentioned earlier.

586
00:28:32,810 --> 00:28:34,310
Well I guess in the last episode.

587
00:28:34,310 --> 00:28:36,420
That projects are a temporary endeavor.

588
00:28:36,420 --> 00:28:39,020
So they have a start and
a finish, if they don't,

589
00:28:39,020 --> 00:28:42,640
if they don't have a well defined start
and finish you're destined for failure.

590
00:28:42,640 --> 00:28:46,170
Very difficult to be successful
with a project like that, so

591
00:28:46,170 --> 00:28:48,350
PMI has what they call
the project life cycle and

592
00:28:48,350 --> 00:28:51,280
it kind of shows what happens
through out your project.

593
00:28:51,280 --> 00:28:53,260
Basically you start your project,

594
00:28:53,260 --> 00:28:57,360
this is what we call initiation, it's just
the beginning, somebody thinks of an idea,

595
00:28:57,360 --> 00:28:59,790
hey, i want something to happen,
all right.

596
00:28:59,790 --> 00:29:04,390
And then we start moving into
the actual activities of the project.

597
00:29:04,390 --> 00:29:08,670
A project charter is written
which kicks off the real project.

598
00:29:08,670 --> 00:29:11,620
So you'll see this dotted line,
this is how many

599
00:29:11,620 --> 00:29:14,960
employees you have dedicated to the
project and how much money you've spent.

600
00:29:14,960 --> 00:29:18,430
It's pretty low in these
first two stages and

601
00:29:18,430 --> 00:29:21,870
the reason is you're not actually
doing the work yet, you're planning,

602
00:29:21,870 --> 00:29:24,660
you're thinking,
you're coming up with eventualities.

603
00:29:24,660 --> 00:29:28,340
You have your project team and that's
about it and your project team may even be

604
00:29:28,340 --> 00:29:33,190
very small at this stage, right,
so this is all just getting ready.

605
00:29:33,190 --> 00:29:38,350
And then once you're done planning,
now the real work happens, right.

606
00:29:38,350 --> 00:29:41,460
Carrying out the work,
getting things done.

607
00:29:41,460 --> 00:29:43,790
This is where you spend your budget.

608
00:29:43,790 --> 00:29:46,510
You'll see you go up to your
maximum employee amount.

609
00:29:46,510 --> 00:29:51,420
You start expending, you buy materials,
you bring in contractors.

610
00:29:51,420 --> 00:29:53,450
Work is getting done.

611
00:29:53,450 --> 00:29:57,060
And when the work is done,
then we go into closing.

612
00:29:57,060 --> 00:30:00,700
We release the employees to work in
other projects, we're done with them.

613
00:30:00,700 --> 00:30:03,750
We release our contractors who
have fulfilled their contract.

614
00:30:03,750 --> 00:30:08,430
And we go right back down to just being
the project team and shutting down, right.

615
00:30:08,430 --> 00:30:11,550
The project is only over when
the last employee is released and

616
00:30:11,550 --> 00:30:13,240
the last employee is the project manager,
right.

617
00:30:13,240 --> 00:30:15,800
So the captain goes down
with the ship [LAUGH] right.

618
00:30:15,800 --> 00:30:19,820
So this is basically what happens
throughout the life of a project.

619
00:30:19,820 --> 00:30:22,520
They call it the project life cycle,
all right?

620
00:30:22,520 --> 00:30:24,810
Now, it's pretty common sense.

621
00:30:24,810 --> 00:30:26,850
Why do we need to be aware of this?

622
00:30:26,850 --> 00:30:31,890
The main reason we need to know is
how change can affect our project.

623
00:30:31,890 --> 00:30:33,420
I made a comment in the first segment,

624
00:30:33,420 --> 00:30:38,530
I said how change can be very
expensive as time goes on.

625
00:30:38,530 --> 00:30:42,110
Well it's not just change,
it's really risk.

626
00:30:42,110 --> 00:30:45,250
Risks, things that can go wrong in
the project, anything like that,

627
00:30:45,250 --> 00:30:47,820
becomes more expensive down the road.

628
00:30:49,210 --> 00:30:51,120
They actually have a chart for
that in here somewhere.

629
00:30:51,120 --> 00:30:52,040
Here we go.

630
00:30:52,040 --> 00:30:56,680
So notice that,
at the very beginning of our project,

631
00:30:56,680 --> 00:31:00,160
we might have a lot of risk and
a lot of uncertainty.

632
00:31:00,160 --> 00:31:04,280
We just don't know how things are gonna
go at the beginning of our project.

633
00:31:04,280 --> 00:31:10,240
But as we near the end of our project,
our risk goes down and our uncertainty.

634
00:31:10,240 --> 00:31:11,710
We know a lot more.

635
00:31:11,710 --> 00:31:13,860
We know we're almost to the finish line.

636
00:31:13,860 --> 00:31:17,010
So it's a lot less risky and
a lot less uncertain.

637
00:31:17,010 --> 00:31:22,960
But if we want to change, notice this
cost of change, it steadily increases.

638
00:31:22,960 --> 00:31:28,200
So making changes at the last minute
can be incredibly expensive, right.

639
00:31:28,200 --> 00:31:30,340
I equate this like a college degree,
right.

640
00:31:30,340 --> 00:31:34,660
[LAUGH] So if you're pursuing a four-year
degree, and in your first year, right.

641
00:31:34,660 --> 00:31:35,990
Maybe you're wanting to do.

642
00:31:35,990 --> 00:31:37,400
Well you take me for an example.

643
00:31:37,400 --> 00:31:38,745
I did political science.

644
00:31:38,745 --> 00:31:44,370
And in my first year of college, if I had
decided hey, I don't wanna do political

645
00:31:44,370 --> 00:31:48,710
science I wanna switch to computer
sciences, computer information sciences.

646
00:31:48,710 --> 00:31:52,160
Well if I made that change my first
year it's not a big deal I only had

647
00:31:52,160 --> 00:31:55,930
one semester maybe two semesters under my
belt not a lot of classes most of those

648
00:31:55,930 --> 00:32:00,890
were general education stuff anyways so
no big deal, change majors, great.

649
00:32:00,890 --> 00:32:01,445
But that's not what I did.

650
00:32:01,445 --> 00:32:02,291
[LAUGH] I changed majors my fourth year.

651
00:32:02,291 --> 00:32:08,247
I was basically done with my degree
when I decided I wanted to switch.

652
00:32:08,247 --> 00:32:09,602
Well that's a big deal,

653
00:32:09,602 --> 00:32:12,775
I had a ton of credits that I'd
already done in one degree.

654
00:32:12,775 --> 00:32:15,668
And now I switch, and
ended up just finished both,

655
00:32:15,668 --> 00:32:17,750
because it kind of made sense.

656
00:32:17,750 --> 00:32:22,700
But, it was an expensive change,
I had to take a lot more courses.

657
00:32:22,700 --> 00:32:24,190
That's how your project is.

658
00:32:24,190 --> 00:32:26,550
If you decide to change the time line.

659
00:32:26,550 --> 00:32:29,810
If you decide to change the budget,
which is next to impossible.

660
00:32:29,810 --> 00:32:32,150
If you decide to change the requirements,

661
00:32:32,150 --> 00:32:35,420
to add more requirements
at the end of the project.

662
00:32:35,420 --> 00:32:37,690
In order to get those new
requirements done and

663
00:32:37,690 --> 00:32:40,550
still meet your time line,
it's gonna cost money.

664
00:32:40,550 --> 00:32:42,560
You're gonna need to bring in more people.

665
00:32:42,560 --> 00:32:45,770
It's very dangerous to do that kind
of change at the end of a project.

666
00:32:46,840 --> 00:32:50,600
So, we need to understand that
because the cost of change increases,

667
00:32:50,600 --> 00:32:52,785
the likelihood of change decreases.

668
00:32:52,785 --> 00:32:53,690
>> Mm-hm.
>> So normally as

669
00:32:53,690 --> 00:32:58,270
you reach the end of your project,
you're gonna see less changes happening.

670
00:32:58,270 --> 00:33:01,400
You might see a lot of change,
right here while we're planning.

671
00:33:01,400 --> 00:33:03,290
As we learn more we recognize more.

672
00:33:03,290 --> 00:33:07,410
We modify and
adapt to meet our requirements.

673
00:33:07,410 --> 00:33:09,660
We improvise, adapt, overcome, right?

674
00:33:09,660 --> 00:33:11,670
The Marine Corps motto.

675
00:33:11,670 --> 00:33:13,430
Or unofficial one I guess.

676
00:33:13,430 --> 00:33:18,570
And then when we actually go to carry out
the work, we've got people doing stuff.

677
00:33:18,570 --> 00:33:22,800
If we've already laid the foundation for
the house, and

678
00:33:22,800 --> 00:33:27,620
then the buyer comes and says that,
I wanna add one more room.

679
00:33:27,620 --> 00:33:32,890
We've already poured the foundation,
now we have to extend the foundation out.

680
00:33:32,890 --> 00:33:36,800
It can be done, but there's already
walls here, we've got to take those out.

681
00:33:36,800 --> 00:33:40,220
The further along that
house is in its build,

682
00:33:40,220 --> 00:33:42,240
the harder it becomes to add on to it.

683
00:33:42,240 --> 00:33:43,480
But if we think of it early on,

684
00:33:43,480 --> 00:33:47,280
before the foundation's laid,
it's a marginal thing to add, right?

685
00:33:47,280 --> 00:33:48,810
That's how change is with our project.

686
00:33:48,810 --> 00:33:52,440
So, we need to be aware of where
we're at in the life cycle.

687
00:33:52,440 --> 00:33:57,400
Here in the planning phase,
change is okay, don't be resistant.

688
00:33:57,400 --> 00:33:58,830
Allow change to occur,

689
00:33:58,830 --> 00:34:02,460
make sure that it still conforms to
what you set out in the original.

690
00:34:02,460 --> 00:34:04,580
Well, we'll talk about
the project charter later on.

691
00:34:04,580 --> 00:34:06,690
But it meets that kinda stuff, and

692
00:34:06,690 --> 00:34:09,320
that we don't deviate too
far from our original goals.

693
00:34:09,320 --> 00:34:11,730
But, it's okay to make change here.

694
00:34:11,730 --> 00:34:16,280
It's also okay to make minor change,
when you're executing.

695
00:34:16,280 --> 00:34:18,770
Major change is possible too,
it's not impossible.

696
00:34:18,770 --> 00:34:21,860
We just need to make sure we
understand what it's gonna cost us.

697
00:34:21,860 --> 00:34:25,800
And usually that cost is
represented one of three ways.

698
00:34:25,800 --> 00:34:33,060
And I don't really, let's see if I can
do my silly drawing here real quick.

699
00:34:33,060 --> 00:34:37,860
Projects are made up of
a number of requirements.

700
00:34:37,860 --> 00:34:43,300
And they really rotate
around three concepts,

701
00:34:43,300 --> 00:34:46,140
so let me show you what I mean.

702
00:34:46,140 --> 00:34:50,680
Let me get a nice big triangle here.

703
00:34:50,680 --> 00:34:56,140
And when we do project management, we're
really balancing three different ideas.

704
00:34:56,140 --> 00:34:58,560
We start off with, for example, Budget.

705
00:35:01,254 --> 00:35:09,660
Here we go.

706
00:35:09,660 --> 00:35:15,381
So we've got Budget,

707
00:35:15,381 --> 00:35:18,694
Schedule and

708
00:35:18,694 --> 00:35:23,813
[LAUGH] there we go and

709
00:35:23,813 --> 00:35:28,038
Requirements.

710
00:35:31,763 --> 00:35:34,870
All right, so
at the beginning of a project.

711
00:35:34,870 --> 00:35:37,200
Somebody comes up with these three things.

712
00:35:37,200 --> 00:35:39,600
And that somebody is, who knows who?

713
00:35:39,600 --> 00:35:42,740
It could be the project sponsor,
it could be the PMO.

714
00:35:42,740 --> 00:35:47,290
It's whoever it is that defines
projects for your organization, right?

715
00:35:47,290 --> 00:35:49,760
And when we complete the project,

716
00:35:49,760 --> 00:35:52,030
these are the three things
that we're competing against.

717
00:35:52,030 --> 00:35:55,050
We need to meet a certain Schedule.

718
00:35:55,050 --> 00:35:58,930
If I need to be done by December 1st,
all right?

719
00:35:58,930 --> 00:36:01,830
Everything I do has to be
built around that date,

720
00:36:01,830 --> 00:36:04,640
I've got to be done by December 1st.

721
00:36:04,640 --> 00:36:07,736
If my budget is $500,000,

722
00:36:07,736 --> 00:36:11,240
I can't spend any more than $500,000,
I need to figure that out.

723
00:36:11,240 --> 00:36:15,060
And then Requirements,
here's what I need to achieve,

724
00:36:15,060 --> 00:36:17,790
here's the checklist of
what I've got to do.

725
00:36:17,790 --> 00:36:20,670
If I don't do any of this stuff,
my project fails.

726
00:36:20,670 --> 00:36:22,530
If a change comes in, and

727
00:36:22,530 --> 00:36:26,180
somebody wants to add more requirements,
what's that gonna do?

728
00:36:26,180 --> 00:36:29,190
Well, it may take more time.

729
00:36:29,190 --> 00:36:32,100
I need to add more to my schedule, right?

730
00:36:32,100 --> 00:36:33,440
More time.

731
00:36:33,440 --> 00:36:36,880
Or, if I can't add more time,
if December 1st is still my date, but

732
00:36:36,880 --> 00:36:39,940
they're adding more requirements,
I may need to add more staff.

733
00:36:39,940 --> 00:36:40,480
>> People.

734
00:36:40,480 --> 00:36:42,910
>> Yeah,
that's gonna increase my budget, right?

735
00:36:42,910 --> 00:36:46,540
I'm gonna need to spend more money,
all right?

736
00:36:46,540 --> 00:36:50,850
But, if they add Requirements, but
don't add time to the Schedule and

737
00:36:50,850 --> 00:36:52,800
don't add Budget.

738
00:36:52,800 --> 00:36:53,730
Can we do it?

739
00:36:53,730 --> 00:36:55,550
>> No.
>> [LAUGH]

740
00:36:55,550 --> 00:36:56,220
>> Maybe, but

741
00:36:56,220 --> 00:36:58,700
there is a lot of risk right there.

742
00:36:58,700 --> 00:37:00,860
So, this is the kind of change
we don't want to allow.

743
00:37:00,860 --> 00:37:05,520
We're constantly playing a balancing game,
between these three things right here.

744
00:37:05,520 --> 00:37:08,740
Now the terminology that I've used
here is our standard terminology.

745
00:37:08,740 --> 00:37:11,010
But, you'll here other terms
thrown around for this.

746
00:37:11,010 --> 00:37:16,970
Instead of schedule,
you may hear it referred to as time.

747
00:37:16,970 --> 00:37:19,870
And Budget you might
hear referred to as cost.

748
00:37:19,870 --> 00:37:22,460
And Requirements you might
hear referred to as scope.

749
00:37:22,460 --> 00:37:23,910
We haven't talked about scope yet.

750
00:37:23,910 --> 00:37:25,730
So, you may hear different terminology.

751
00:37:25,730 --> 00:37:28,520
So let me just update this
to reflect both terms.

752
00:37:28,520 --> 00:37:34,019
So, this would be like Requirement/Scope,

753
00:37:34,019 --> 00:37:40,795
and Schedule/Time, and
Budget, I can type, please.

754
00:37:40,795 --> 00:37:47,336
There we go, Cost.

755
00:37:47,336 --> 00:37:53,780
And, so these are the three things that
we're competing against with a project.

756
00:37:53,780 --> 00:38:00,430
I used to use a car mechanic, that had
this sign above his little mechanics bay.

757
00:38:00,430 --> 00:38:02,330
And the sign basically said,

758
00:38:02,330 --> 00:38:06,500
something that really kinda
ties into this same idea.

759
00:38:06,500 --> 00:38:09,060
Let me write it over here.

760
00:38:09,060 --> 00:38:12,566
It basically said,
we do three types of jobs here.

761
00:38:12,566 --> 00:38:17,850
We do Good, Fast, and Cheap.

762
00:38:17,850 --> 00:38:18,480
Right?
>> [LAUGH]

763
00:38:18,480 --> 00:38:20,440
>> It said we do three jobs.

764
00:38:20,440 --> 00:38:21,159
You can pick.

765
00:38:23,050 --> 00:38:24,970
So, if you want your car fixed, and

766
00:38:24,970 --> 00:38:28,890
you want it to be good and
fast it's not gonna be cheap.

767
00:38:28,890 --> 00:38:32,030
If you want it to be fast and
cheap, it's not gonna be good.

768
00:38:32,030 --> 00:38:35,950
And if you want it to be good and
cheap, it's not gonna be fast.

769
00:38:35,950 --> 00:38:37,120
You have to pick two of the three.

770
00:38:37,120 --> 00:38:40,810
Well, that's how project management is,
when you want your project done.

771
00:38:40,810 --> 00:38:43,740
If you want it to be done fast,

772
00:38:43,740 --> 00:38:47,690
on a low budget, then you're not gonna
be able to pick a lot of requirements.

773
00:38:47,690 --> 00:38:52,260
It's gonna be a simple project, but
if you wanna complex project with a lot of

774
00:38:52,260 --> 00:38:57,040
requirements, and you wanna it done fast,
you're gonna need a big budget.

775
00:38:57,040 --> 00:39:01,020
This is what we're doing we're juggling,
between these different elements in our

776
00:39:01,020 --> 00:39:04,210
project as we try and plan things
we try and get things in place.

777
00:39:04,210 --> 00:39:09,150
So this is a constant balancing game,
and when you look at that project life

778
00:39:09,150 --> 00:39:14,570
cycle back here change, way down here,
adding new requirements to whatever,

779
00:39:14,570 --> 00:39:16,170
that's going to affect your schedule and
budget.

780
00:39:16,170 --> 00:39:18,528
You got to balance and plan around that.

781
00:39:18,528 --> 00:39:20,190
All right.

782
00:39:20,190 --> 00:39:24,960
So that's basically the project life
cycle, and what we're involved in.

783

I just kind of made it a little

1117

So under inputs, you'll have a series

1118
00:55:54,166 --> 00:55:59,645

00:56:17,620 --> 00:56:20,170

As things that could influence our

Every process, needs to be put

00:56:42,580 --> 00:56:45,350
The organizational process assets,
that your company has,

So there's usually only

Different tools and techniques, you use to

1141
00:57:19,385 --> 00:57:22,131
So if I have a process,

1142
00:57:22,131 --> 00:57:27,780
like Develop a Project Charter, right?

1143
00:57:27,780 --> 00:57:33,200
My inputs are going to be things that I

1144
00:57:33,200 --> 00:57:37,370

that's to create a project charter.

I wanna create a project charter.

Well, we're gonna talk about

just to sum it up briefly, it is and what

00:57:52,430 --> 00:57:53,610
What you're gonna be doing?

But most importantly,

00:57:57,750 --> 00:58:00,810

00:58:00,810 --> 00:58:03,820
So, this is where a project

00:58:03,820 --> 00:58:07,540
This is the single most important
document in your entire document, right?

00:58:07,540 --> 00:58:09,200
So, I wanna create that document.

1158

I need a couple of things.

1160
00:58:14,020 --> 00:58:15,630
I need a statement of work.

1161

I need a business case

1162

1163
00:58:22,340 --> 00:58:23,690

Those are things that I need.

Because they're gonna

1166
00:58:29,390 --> 00:58:32,780
And then I need my enterprise
environmental factors,

1167
00:58:32,780 --> 00:58:34,930
and organizational process assets.

1168
00:58:34,930 --> 00:58:37,310
These things that influence my project.

1169

I take all of that as information.

1170
00:58:40,870 --> 00:58:43,580
And then, I apply two things.

1171
00:58:43,580 --> 00:58:45,110
Number 1, Expert Judgement.

1172
00:58:46,160 --> 00:58:48,350
Expert Judgement is your brain.

1173
00:58:48,350 --> 00:58:53,220
Use your brain, use your common sense,

1174
00:58:53,220 --> 00:58:55,490

00:58:55,490 --> 00:58:57,310
So, I need to know grammar.

1176

[LAUGH] I need to know
basic writing skills.

1177
00:58:59,840 --> 00:59:02,340
Those are things that fall
under Expert Judgement.

1178

I also need Facilitation Techniques.

1179
00:59:06,050 --> 00:59:10,220
I need to facilitate the needs
of all of these things.

1180
00:59:10,220 --> 00:59:15,750
I need to combine them, in a way where

1181
00:59:15,750 --> 00:59:19,550
where I meet my legal requirements,

1182
00:59:19,550 --> 00:59:23,930
I used the tools provided by the company,

1183
00:59:23,930 --> 00:59:28,270
I incorporate a business case,
that shows this project is worthwhile.

1184
00:59:28,270 --> 00:59:30,180
I put all that stuff together.

00:59:30,180 --> 00:59:32,600
And I might have to
negotiate a little bit, or

1186
00:59:32,600 --> 00:59:35,910
whatever to facilitate getting all
of those working hand and hand.

00:59:35,910 --> 00:59:37,510
And when they're done.

I create a document that's called

Because, we haven't done planning yet, and

So, the process is really telling us,

I can't create a Project Charter

You'll have a set of tools and techniques

if I just skim ahead and try and

the direct and
project management work process.
