1247
01:02:51,200 --> 01:02:55,300
The only part that really deviates is when
we get into the execution, because there

1248
01:02:55,300 --> 01:02:59,500
we're doing a lot of monitoring, and so
our inputs are gonna be status updates.

1249
01:02:59,500 --> 01:03:02,753
And our outputs will oftentimes
be more status updates [LAUGH].

1250
01:03:02,753 --> 01:03:05,280
>> Yeah.
>> So there will be status updates with

1251
01:03:05,280 --> 01:03:07,910
the possibility of change tickets,
if we've

1252
01:03:07,910 --> 01:03:11,780
deviated from where we're supposed to be,
if we're behind schedule or whatever.

1253
01:03:11,780 --> 01:03:14,280
We'll have change tickets that
are us trying to correct,

1254
01:03:14,280 --> 01:03:17,380
to control the environment,
put it back on schedule, all right?

1255
01:03:17,380 --> 01:03:20,270
So, we'll see all of that stuff as we
go through the later episodes, but

1256
01:03:20,270 --> 01:03:22,070
at a simple level, this is it.

1257
01:03:22,070 --> 01:03:24,510
It's pretty cool,
it really does work well.

1258
01:03:26,870 --> 01:03:30,000
All right, well, Ronnie,
that's probably it for this episode.

1259
01:03:30,000 --> 01:03:31,654
We just kind of wanted
to cover the basics.

1260
01:03:31,654 --> 01:03:32,900
>> Right.
>> We're ready to move into

1261
01:03:32,900 --> 01:03:35,330
the specific stuff, but we don't
have much time left in this episode.

1262
01:03:35,330 --> 01:03:37,278
So, why don't we wrap it up here?

1263
01:03:37,278 --> 01:03:41,600
I do wanna remind everybody,
if you have any questions on this stuff,

1264
01:03:41,600 --> 01:03:45,800
keep in mind that live during the show,
you can go to itpro.tv/live.

1265
01:03:45,800 --> 01:03:48,840
You'll see our video screen, and
the chat is right beneath it.

1266
01:03:48,840 --> 01:03:50,420
You can post your questions there.

1267
01:03:50,420 --> 01:03:52,600
We monitor and answer during the show.

1268
01:03:52,600 --> 01:03:55,830
If you have questions after the show,
if we're running reruns or

1269
01:03:55,830 --> 01:03:57,650
whatever use the Q&A forms.

1270
01:03:57,650 --> 01:04:00,880
You'll see a link that says Q&A at
the top of every page, click on it,

1271
01:04:00,880 --> 01:04:01,860
it'll take you into forums.

1272
01:04:01,860 --> 01:04:04,350
You can post your questions there,
we monitor and answer, and

1273
01:04:04,350 --> 01:04:07,480
make sure that you get the information you
need, so that you're ready for that exam.

1274
01:04:07,480 --> 01:04:10,270
So, all right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1275
01:04:10,270 --> 01:04:13,280
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1276
01:04:13,280 --> 01:04:14,100
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1277
01:04:14,100 --> 01:04:15,908
>> And we will see you next time.

1278
01:04:15,908 --> 01:04:25,908
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don explain the layout of the PMBOK which is a resource available when joining PMI. They also begin explaining the initiating the project management process. Emphasis is given to describing the project management constraints, the Project Management Process--beginning to end, and briefly talk about Project Management Charter and the authority it gives to the project.
episodes.title: Initiation Phase
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:06,649 --> 00:00:16,649
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:23,416 --> 00:00:24,657
[SOUND]

3
00:00:24,657 --> 00:00:33,297
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,297 --> 00:00:36,520
All right.
Good morning, good afternoon, and

5
00:00:36,520 --> 00:00:39,120
good evening, and welcome back
to another episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:39,120 --> 00:00:42,200
I'm your host,
Don Pezet Back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:42,200 --> 00:00:43,140
How's it going Ronnie?

8
00:00:43,140 --> 00:00:44,890
>> I am saddened this morning.

9
00:00:44,890 --> 00:00:47,200
>> Oh.
>> I did not get my solo on Glee.

10
00:00:47,200 --> 00:00:47,760
>> No?
>> No.

11
00:00:47,760 --> 00:00:49,000
>> And you worked so hard.

12
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:49,920
>> I did.
>> You've

13
00:00:49,920 --> 00:00:51,400
been singing Creed songs-
>> I have.

14
00:00:51,400 --> 00:00:52,130
>> Backstage all week long.

15
00:00:52,130 --> 00:00:53,290
>> I have.

16
00:00:53,290 --> 00:00:54,630
Yeah.
[LAUGH]

17
00:00:54,630 --> 00:00:55,590
>> That was the first band

18
00:00:55,590 --> 00:00:56,090
I could think of.

19
00:00:56,090 --> 00:00:57,160
That was ridiculous.

20
00:00:57,160 --> 00:00:57,685
Creed.
>> Yeah.

21
00:00:57,685 --> 00:01:01,380
[LAUGH] >> [LAUGH] Now that I have time
to think about it I would have gone with

22
00:01:01,380 --> 00:01:01,970
Nickelback.

23
00:01:03,200 --> 00:01:08,090
So welcome back to another episode
of Project Management Professional.

24
00:01:08,090 --> 00:01:12,280
Our first two episodes that we filmed,
they were centered around just like

25
00:01:12,280 --> 00:01:17,030
general project management concepts and
some of the ideas of the PMI's

26
00:01:17,030 --> 00:01:20,880
terminology definitions and
just general things we needed to know.

27
00:01:20,880 --> 00:01:24,820
Today, we're actually gonna start
the project management process, all right?

28
00:01:24,820 --> 00:01:27,680
So, as far as what
you're actually expected

29
00:01:27,680 --> 00:01:30,940
to do out there in the real world,
today is really gonna mark that.

30
00:01:30,940 --> 00:01:33,830
And, the PMBOK,
it is a wealth of information.

31
00:01:33,830 --> 00:01:36,010
It's packed full of all sorts of stuff.

32
00:01:36,010 --> 00:01:38,472
But it's not organized chronologically.

33
00:01:38,472 --> 00:01:39,110
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

34
00:01:39,110 --> 00:01:40,839
>> And
I think we showed that in an episode.

35
00:01:40,839 --> 00:01:44,120
Where there's things that happened at
the beginning of the project might be at

36
00:01:44,120 --> 00:01:47,380
the very end of the PMBOK,
and so what we're gonna do

37
00:01:47,380 --> 00:01:51,760
is we're gonna rearrange things
to fit chronological order.

38
00:01:51,760 --> 00:01:55,430
How a project starts and how we go
through things in a normal project.

39
00:01:55,430 --> 00:01:57,490
Now every project's a little different,
and so

40
00:01:57,490 --> 00:02:00,690
in your environment you might
need to rearrange some of this.

41
00:02:00,690 --> 00:02:03,440
But I think for the most part we're
gonna be able to go through this and

42
00:02:03,440 --> 00:02:06,520
you kind of cover the way that
a lot of typical projects run.

43
00:02:06,520 --> 00:02:08,900
>> Yeah.
When we start talking about this idea,

44
00:02:08,900 --> 00:02:12,590
we're actually beginning with those
bigger phases in terms of projects here,

45
00:02:12,590 --> 00:02:14,950
with the idea of the initiation.

46
00:02:14,950 --> 00:02:17,410
And then we go into the idea
of the planning stage, and

47
00:02:17,410 --> 00:02:22,150
then the controlling and
monitoring, I missed one, didn't I?

48
00:02:22,150 --> 00:02:22,660
Planning, oh no.
>> [LAUGH]

49
00:02:22,660 --> 00:02:25,280
>> Initiation, planning, controlling.

50
00:02:25,280 --> 00:02:26,200
>> Executing.

51
00:02:26,200 --> 00:02:31,290
>> Executing, controlling, and monitoring,
and of course the idea of closing as well.

52
00:02:31,290 --> 00:02:35,120
So we're gonna spend this
first particular series or

53
00:02:35,120 --> 00:02:36,935
episode here on the idea of initiation.

54
00:02:36,935 --> 00:02:37,990
>> Mm-hm.

55
00:02:37,990 --> 00:02:40,570
All right, now.
Let me go back to the chart that we

56
00:02:40,570 --> 00:02:41,830
brought up in a previous episode.

57
00:02:41,830 --> 00:02:42,710
This guy right here.

58
00:02:42,710 --> 00:02:47,080
Basically the guide map to
running a project, right?

59
00:02:47,080 --> 00:02:51,213
While the PMBOK itself was not organized
in chronological order, this is.

60
00:02:51,213 --> 00:02:51,762
>> Mm-hm.

61
00:02:51,762 --> 00:02:55,065
>> When a project runs we
start with initiating and

62
00:02:55,065 --> 00:02:59,905
we go from left to right all the way
to closing, with the remembering that

63
00:02:59,905 --> 00:03:01,165
executing and monitoring-
>> Yeah [LAUGH]

64
00:03:01,165 --> 00:03:02,645
>> Those basically occur at the same time.

65
00:03:02,645 --> 00:03:04,478
So, when a project is starting,

66
00:03:04,478 --> 00:03:07,497
we're staring here in
the initiating process group.

67
00:03:07,497 --> 00:03:11,262
Now it happens to be one of
the smaller ones in closing, so

68
00:03:11,262 --> 00:03:13,810
it's kind of easy one to grasp.

69
00:03:13,810 --> 00:03:18,570
We're gonna start we've got two processes,
there's develop a project charter and

70
00:03:18,570 --> 00:03:21,180
then way down here identify stakeholders.

71
00:03:21,180 --> 00:03:25,240
Well, you can't identify stakeholders
until you have a charter cuz

72
00:03:25,240 --> 00:03:27,740
you really can't do anything until
you have a charter in place.

73
00:03:27,740 --> 00:03:31,680
So, this is the actual first
step of a project right here,

74
00:03:31,680 --> 00:03:33,420
developing the project charter.

75
00:03:34,600 --> 00:03:38,390
So, every project starts with an idea.

76
00:03:39,450 --> 00:03:45,050
It's not a project yet, it's just an idea,
and people have tons of ideas.

77
00:03:45,050 --> 00:03:47,760
Some are good, most are bad, right?

78
00:03:47,760 --> 00:03:51,086
And so, a lot of things never
make it out of the idea stage.

79
00:03:51,086 --> 00:03:54,950
I was thinking of like Homer Simpson,
where he has all these different ideas and

80
00:03:54,950 --> 00:03:56,180
most of them are not good.

81
00:03:57,460 --> 00:03:59,490
Somebody has to be that gateway,

82
00:03:59,490 --> 00:04:04,160
that person who sits in between
an idea becoming a reality, right?

83
00:04:04,160 --> 00:04:08,370
And so, every project kind of
starts out that way, as an idea.

84
00:04:08,370 --> 00:04:10,050
Think of something, and

85
00:04:10,050 --> 00:04:15,060
then, if it's got merit, we decide to
move forward with it as a project.

86
00:04:15,060 --> 00:04:16,880
Now, how do we know if it's got merit?

87
00:04:16,880 --> 00:04:19,940
Well, unfortunately we need to gather
some information together, and

88
00:04:19,940 --> 00:04:22,800
by the time we're at that point we're
really already in project mode.

89
00:04:22,800 --> 00:04:27,570
So, someone has an idea,
and they take that idea and

90
00:04:27,570 --> 00:04:30,490
they turn it into what's
called a project charter.

91
00:04:30,490 --> 00:04:31,490
And a project charter's just a document.

92
00:04:31,490 --> 00:04:37,263
It's a document that basically kicks
off a project, it starts the project.

93
00:04:37,263 --> 00:04:41,139
So, you don't have a project until
the charter has been drafted and

94
00:04:41,139 --> 00:04:43,935
that's why it is this
first step on the journey.

95
00:04:43,935 --> 00:04:47,116
>> Yeah, this is where we start talking
about the idea of formalization, right?

96
00:04:47,116 --> 00:04:50,230
That we're really gonna put
things down on paper and

97
00:04:50,230 --> 00:04:54,332
that way we can refer to it as
the project begins to develop along, and

98
00:04:54,332 --> 00:04:59,460
we use that as really kind of the guide
to help us to push everything along here.

99
00:04:59,460 --> 00:05:03,510
So in getting this first step done, it's
by far one of the most important things

100
00:05:03,510 --> 00:05:06,250
that we wanna spend time and
take a look at, and

101
00:05:06,250 --> 00:05:09,330
make sure that we understand what
the purpose of this thing is and

102
00:05:09,330 --> 00:05:11,047
how it helps us throughout
the remainder of our project.

103
00:05:11,047 --> 00:05:17,520
>> All right, so how does somebody
even come up with the idea, right?

104
00:05:17,520 --> 00:05:20,950
So somebody, usually an executive in
your company is sitting around and

105
00:05:20,950 --> 00:05:26,800
they have an idea they say,
our company would be better if XYZ.

106
00:05:26,800 --> 00:05:28,330
If we did this.

107
00:05:28,330 --> 00:05:31,660
So maybe your company
don't have a website.

108
00:05:31,660 --> 00:05:33,180
So an executive is sitting around saying,

109
00:05:34,310 --> 00:05:36,900
I bet we're losing customers
because we don't have a website.

110
00:05:36,900 --> 00:05:39,260
People see we don't have that,
and they think we're antiquated.

111
00:05:39,260 --> 00:05:41,210
So we want a company website.

112
00:05:41,210 --> 00:05:43,340
So they've got this idea, right.

113
00:05:43,340 --> 00:05:45,320
Is it a good idea, is it a bad idea?

114
00:05:45,320 --> 00:05:47,500
That's not, no, a this point.

115
00:05:47,500 --> 00:05:49,030
It's just an idea.

116
00:05:49,030 --> 00:05:53,320
And so if they're powerful enough in
the company, if they control resources,

117
00:05:53,320 --> 00:05:57,640
if they can authorize work,
then they can kick off a project.

118
00:05:57,640 --> 00:06:00,660
And they say all right I need
to get this project started.

119
00:06:00,660 --> 00:06:04,750
And if there's a PMO, a Project Management
Organization, they can go to the PMO, or

120
00:06:04,750 --> 00:06:06,210
Project Management Office.

121
00:06:06,210 --> 00:06:09,190
They can go to the PMO, and
they can say, all right,

122
00:06:09,190 --> 00:06:13,440
here's this project I want done and
I'm the Vice President of marketing so

123
00:06:13,440 --> 00:06:15,230
I got the authority,
let's do this project.

124
00:06:16,890 --> 00:06:20,270
The PMO can then make that decision
whether or not the project can actually go

125
00:06:20,270 --> 00:06:22,690
through, we can start to
kick things off from there.

126
00:06:22,690 --> 00:06:25,540
Or, maybe you don't have a formal
environment like that, maybe it's a little

127
00:06:25,540 --> 00:06:30,830
more like here, at ITPro TV where
we have a fairly small office,

128
00:06:30,830 --> 00:06:35,815
not a ton of employees, and so if any
one of us has an idea we just say it.

129
00:06:35,815 --> 00:06:37,020
>> Yeah.
>> Hey Ronnie,

130
00:06:37,020 --> 00:06:41,225
I think it'd be a really good idea if,
well, like our Roku channel, right?

131
00:06:41,225 --> 00:06:42,590
>> Yeah.
>> We'll use the Roku

132
00:06:42,590 --> 00:06:43,440
channel as an example.

133
00:06:43,440 --> 00:06:47,160
When we first launched our company,
we didn't plan on doing a Roku channel.

134
00:06:47,160 --> 00:06:49,820
One of the other gentlemen here,
Tim, came to me and

135
00:06:49,820 --> 00:06:52,060
said, I really think we
should have a Roku channel.

136
00:06:52,060 --> 00:06:54,880
I think people would like to
watch these shows on their TV and

137
00:06:54,880 --> 00:06:57,630
they don't want to have to
tether to a computer to do it.

138
00:06:57,630 --> 00:07:02,950
Roku boxes are cheap, their inexpensive,
let's do that, let's get a Roku channel.

139
00:07:02,950 --> 00:07:07,210
And I said, well,
let's get the company launched,

140
00:07:07,210 --> 00:07:10,040
let's do this stuff first and
then do a Roku channel.

141
00:07:10,040 --> 00:07:13,810
But at the end I said, well, if it's not
that big of a deal we can roll forward.

142
00:07:13,810 --> 00:07:14,880
Let's find out more.

143
00:07:14,880 --> 00:07:15,680
All right?

144
00:07:15,680 --> 00:07:18,210
That right there,
that conversation between Tim and

145
00:07:18,210 --> 00:07:20,540
I, that was what kicked off that project.

146
00:07:20,540 --> 00:07:21,670
That was what kind of started it.

147
00:07:21,670 --> 00:07:24,370
That's where the idea came from,
the idea came from Tim, and

148
00:07:24,370 --> 00:07:27,160
then we decided to formalize it.

149
00:07:27,160 --> 00:07:31,700
Now you formalize it by creating
a charter, a document that says we

150
00:07:31,700 --> 00:07:36,740
are going, at a minimum, to look at
the possibility of doing this and

151
00:07:36,740 --> 00:07:39,610
here's the authority
that we assigned to it.

152
00:07:39,610 --> 00:07:43,880
So the project charter can start from
a conversation at a water cooler,

153
00:07:43,880 --> 00:07:47,840
it can start from being written on
a cocktail napkin at a restaurant.

154
00:07:47,840 --> 00:07:50,670
But, it's got to get
formal credence somewhere.

155
00:07:50,670 --> 00:07:51,713
And the project charter is what does it.

156
00:07:51,713 --> 00:07:57,721
Let's take a look at the process itself,
which I've got a drawing of here.

157
00:07:57,721 --> 00:08:03,000
So we have the develop
a project charter process.

158
00:08:03,000 --> 00:08:07,030
And it's got a number of
inputs that feed into it,

159
00:08:07,030 --> 00:08:11,150
that we then work with to finally create
this one document, the project charter and

160
00:08:11,150 --> 00:08:13,810
we'll take a look at that
document here in a little bit.

161
00:08:13,810 --> 00:08:16,990
You can't create the document
though without certain information.

162
00:08:16,990 --> 00:08:17,500
>> All right.

163
00:08:17,500 --> 00:08:20,480
>> And if you just had a conversation
at a water cooler you likely don't

164
00:08:20,480 --> 00:08:21,760
have all that information.

165
00:08:21,760 --> 00:08:25,332
So that's where we need to start
gathering our data together to get ready.

166
00:08:25,332 --> 00:08:26,350
All right?

167
00:08:26,350 --> 00:08:30,050
And so you'll see some of the different
things that we want to feed into it.

168
00:08:30,050 --> 00:08:32,070
The first is probably the most important.

169
00:08:32,070 --> 00:08:36,040
It's called the project statement of work,
and

170
00:08:36,040 --> 00:08:39,030
this is the summary of what we want done.

171
00:08:39,030 --> 00:08:40,930
So in that conversation that Tim and
I had,

172
00:08:40,930 --> 00:08:44,920
it was Tim saying, I wanna have a Roku
channel with all of our episodes on it.

173
00:08:44,920 --> 00:08:46,080
So that people can watch it.

174
00:08:46,080 --> 00:08:47,680
So that our customers can watch it.

175
00:08:47,680 --> 00:08:48,460
Alright.

176
00:08:48,460 --> 00:08:49,740
That's our statement of work.

177
00:08:49,740 --> 00:08:51,110
It doesn't have to be complex.

178
00:08:51,110 --> 00:08:52,350
We don't know all the details yet.

179
00:08:52,350 --> 00:08:54,010
We don't know what all is involved.

180
00:08:54,010 --> 00:08:57,250
So we just say,
here's what we're looking to do.

181
00:08:57,250 --> 00:08:59,510
That's what a statement of work is.

182
00:08:59,510 --> 00:09:03,920
It's supposed to be a high-level judgement
of whether the project is successful.

183
00:09:03,920 --> 00:09:05,310
At the end of this project,

184
00:09:05,310 --> 00:09:08,810
do I have a Roku channel where
my customers can watch the show?

185
00:09:08,810 --> 00:09:10,050
Great, we succeeded.

186
00:09:10,050 --> 00:09:11,200
Do I no have that?

187
00:09:11,200 --> 00:09:12,360
Then no, we failed.

188
00:09:12,360 --> 00:09:14,272
It's a very,
very high level at this point.

189
00:09:14,272 --> 00:09:15,400
Right?
Non-committal,

190
00:09:15,400 --> 00:09:17,420
this might change during planning.

191
00:09:17,420 --> 00:09:21,519
So this is just the kind of first stab
at what needs to be done in the project.

192
00:09:22,950 --> 00:09:27,005
Now you'll frequently see a statement
of work abbreviated as S-O-W.

193
00:09:27,005 --> 00:09:30,010
So they are not talking about sow or

194
00:09:30,010 --> 00:09:32,470
a kick, they are talking
about a statement of work.

195
00:09:32,470 --> 00:09:35,780
And so you'll see it written that way and

196
00:09:35,780 --> 00:09:39,860
the statement of work does it kind of gets
made up, it's what somebody wants done.

197
00:09:41,190 --> 00:09:45,420
After that, well let me jump
over to the official P-M-I site.

198
00:09:45,420 --> 00:09:46,290
Right?
So

199
00:09:46,290 --> 00:09:49,930
with PI they identify some of the things
the statement of work should contain.

200
00:09:49,930 --> 00:09:50,430
Right?

201
00:09:50,430 --> 00:09:55,170
And they highlight three things
specifically, there's a business need.

202
00:09:55,170 --> 00:09:58,800
So why do we feel the need do
to this in the first place?

203
00:09:58,800 --> 00:10:02,300
Cuz it shouldn't just be something done
on a whim, there should be a response.

204
00:10:02,300 --> 00:10:06,210
So, maybe the business seed is
we have customers asking us hey,

205
00:10:06,210 --> 00:10:07,820
can we watch your shows
on the Roku channel.

206
00:10:07,820 --> 00:10:09,780
We'd love that if we could do that.

207
00:10:09,780 --> 00:10:11,040
There's our business need.

208
00:10:11,040 --> 00:10:12,510
Or if we're losing customers.

209
00:10:12,510 --> 00:10:15,100
Customers are saying I'd do
it if you had a Roku channel,

210
00:10:15,100 --> 00:10:17,105
otherwise I just don't want to subscribe.

211
00:10:17,105 --> 00:10:17,630
Right?

212
00:10:17,630 --> 00:10:20,430
Now we have a business need for
doing the Roku channel.

213
00:10:20,430 --> 00:10:22,580
It could just be on a whim though.

214
00:10:22,580 --> 00:10:24,550
If somebody is powerful
enough in the company.

215
00:10:24,550 --> 00:10:27,990
If it's the president who says I don't
care if the customers want it or not,

216
00:10:27,990 --> 00:10:29,730
we're gonna do a Roku channel.

217
00:10:29,730 --> 00:10:35,170
There's our business need,
because he said so.

218
00:10:35,170 --> 00:10:40,120
So business need is one thing that we need
to have in that project charter in that

219
00:10:40,120 --> 00:10:41,403
statement of work.

220
00:10:41,403 --> 00:10:43,644
Right?
Another thing is a product scope

221
00:10:43,644 --> 00:10:45,190
description.

222
00:10:45,190 --> 00:10:49,849
PMIA sounds really formal right here,
but again it's high level and

223
00:10:49,849 --> 00:10:51,223
subject to change.

224
00:10:51,223 --> 00:10:55,555
A scope we'll talk about later
is where we define exactly what

225
00:10:55,555 --> 00:10:59,520
it is that's required
of us in this project.

226
00:10:59,520 --> 00:11:03,740
But we don't necessarily know
exactly what's required of us yet.

227
00:11:03,740 --> 00:11:07,430
So again this is a high level statement
of what our scope is gonna be.

228
00:11:07,430 --> 00:11:11,660
Our scope is, I wanna have a Roku channel,
and I want that channel to have

229
00:11:11,660 --> 00:11:15,460
every one of our episodes on it, and
I want it to have the live stream on it.

230
00:11:15,460 --> 00:11:19,600
So people can watch live, and I want
it to have some free content in there.

231
00:11:19,600 --> 00:11:22,570
So that people who aren't subscribers
can at least see the channel and

232
00:11:22,570 --> 00:11:23,720
watch a few episodes.

233
00:11:23,720 --> 00:11:27,290
Kind of get an idea of how it works,
a free sample.

234
00:11:27,290 --> 00:11:28,390
So there's my requirements.

235
00:11:28,390 --> 00:11:29,500
High level.

236
00:11:29,500 --> 00:11:32,320
There might be other things that we
need to figure out later on, but

237
00:11:32,320 --> 00:11:33,632
high level, here's what we need.

238
00:11:33,632 --> 00:11:35,020
All right.

239
00:11:35,020 --> 00:11:38,620
And then the last thing
is a strategic plan.

240
00:11:38,620 --> 00:11:44,290
The strategic plan is how this is gonna
be leveraged within your company.

241
00:11:44,290 --> 00:11:45,920
What's your plan for achieving this?

242
00:11:45,920 --> 00:11:49,480
Are you gonna bring in contractors to do
it, are you gonna try to do it in house?

243
00:11:49,480 --> 00:11:51,720
Again, high level, subject to change.

244
00:11:51,720 --> 00:11:52,930
This is all optional.

245
00:11:52,930 --> 00:11:54,880
It can just be a matter of sentences.

246
00:11:54,880 --> 00:11:58,720
It doesn't need to be some giant,
formal thing in your statement of work.

247
00:11:58,720 --> 00:12:02,080
But the more information you have,
the better of you'll be.

248
00:12:02,080 --> 00:12:07,180
Now in the initiation phase, we expect
to not have much information and in fact

249
00:12:07,180 --> 00:12:11,070
most of the planning phase is spent
getting the information we didn't have.

250
00:12:11,070 --> 00:12:14,710
So don't feel like you have to
go crazy on a project charter.

251
00:12:14,710 --> 00:12:17,160
The goal when I make a project charter,

252
00:12:17,160 --> 00:12:20,440
I want the entire charter to fit
on one side of a piece of paper.

253
00:12:20,440 --> 00:12:22,900
Right.
So that charter should fit right here, and

254
00:12:22,900 --> 00:12:24,990
including a signature block on the bottom.

255
00:12:24,990 --> 00:12:27,330
So I'm not talking about
a ton of information here.

256
00:12:27,330 --> 00:12:28,440
So really high level.

257
00:12:30,490 --> 00:12:32,050
>> The overall goal right now, right,

258
00:12:32,050 --> 00:12:35,330
is for us to establish we have
a mission in front of us here.

259
00:12:35,330 --> 00:12:38,400
And that we know what that mission
actually includes for us here.

260
00:12:38,400 --> 00:12:39,890
So bringing all those things together.

261
00:12:39,890 --> 00:12:43,930
Why we need it, in terms our business
need, the idea of scope, essentially

262
00:12:43,930 --> 00:12:48,440
giving us limitations or saying, this is
what we really want to accomplish, and

263
00:12:48,440 --> 00:12:53,050
then lastly, why does fit in to
the overall reason why we also exist.

264
00:12:53,050 --> 00:12:55,940
Is part of the idea of actually
getting this thing started.

265
00:12:55,940 --> 00:12:59,310
The statement of work very important for
us at the beginning, cause if not,

266
00:12:59,310 --> 00:13:01,770
that can actually end up being so
diverse and

267
00:13:01,770 --> 00:13:05,940
so vague that we go okay we'll start
it at some time, we may do it.

268
00:13:05,940 --> 00:13:08,700
But here it actually gives us again,

269
00:13:08,700 --> 00:13:10,790
things that we can
accomplish when we need to.

270
00:13:10,790 --> 00:13:12,470
>> Yeah.
Absolutely.

271
00:13:12,470 --> 00:13:17,650
All right, so our charter so far is
going to contain the statement of work,

272
00:13:17,650 --> 00:13:19,760
the statement of what it is we want done.

273
00:13:19,760 --> 00:13:22,430
As a part of that, you'll typically
have your business case in there.

274
00:13:22,430 --> 00:13:25,860
And PMI breaks that business case down
into a number of different things that it

275
00:13:25,860 --> 00:13:27,040
might be, right?

276
00:13:27,040 --> 00:13:30,160
So, my business case might be
because the boss told me, all right?

277
00:13:30,160 --> 00:13:30,720
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

278
00:13:30,720 --> 00:13:32,060
>> But what are some of the other ones,

279
00:13:32,060 --> 00:13:36,440
and if you're jotting down notes
feverishly in the background.

280
00:13:36,440 --> 00:13:39,210
I've actually already kind of jotted
down some of these notes down in

281
00:13:39,210 --> 00:13:42,520
a file that I'll post with
the episode on the website.

282
00:13:42,520 --> 00:13:46,050
I say that I'll make Nate,
our producer, post it with the episode.

283
00:13:46,050 --> 00:13:48,520
So, anyhow, so I do have this.

284
00:13:48,520 --> 00:13:52,420
Let's pull up my notes for a second so
you guys can see, that business case,

285
00:13:52,420 --> 00:13:55,010
can actually be made up of
a number of different things,

286
00:13:55,010 --> 00:13:57,790
or typically it's just one thing, right?

287
00:13:57,790 --> 00:14:01,155
I mentioned, for example, we might have
customers that are asking for something.

288
00:14:01,155 --> 00:14:01,750
Right?

289
00:14:01,750 --> 00:14:04,040
That would be customer request,

290
00:14:04,040 --> 00:14:09,114
customers are asking hey, you guys at
IT Pro TV, could you guys do IT training?

291
00:14:09,114 --> 00:14:10,960
We'd really like to see ITEL.

292
00:14:10,960 --> 00:14:14,510
All right, we really hadn't planned on it,
but if we get enough requests we'll do it.

293
00:14:14,510 --> 00:14:17,204
Customer requests leads to that project.

294
00:14:17,204 --> 00:14:18,120
Right?

295
00:14:18,120 --> 00:14:20,170
It might be market demand.

296
00:14:20,170 --> 00:14:24,900
It might be that your competitors
are selling more than your company

297
00:14:24,900 --> 00:14:26,835
because they offer
a service that you don't.

298
00:14:26,835 --> 00:14:29,900
Right?
You see this all the time with banks.

299
00:14:29,900 --> 00:14:33,750
Banks that have online banking have
more customers than banks that don't.

300
00:14:33,750 --> 00:14:36,830
And that's because people want online
banking they'll actually switch

301
00:14:36,830 --> 00:14:37,510
banks to get it.

302
00:14:39,360 --> 00:14:41,030
Organizational need.

303
00:14:41,030 --> 00:14:43,910
The project might be
the result of something that

304
00:14:43,910 --> 00:14:46,735
happens inside of your company,
not necessarily revenue generating.

305
00:14:46,735 --> 00:14:50,560
Right?
Maybe your company had ten employees, and

306
00:14:50,560 --> 00:14:52,360
now it's got 10,000.

307
00:14:52,360 --> 00:14:56,581
And you're finding that your business
processes that are in place,

308
00:14:56,581 --> 00:14:58,390
more designed for scale.

309
00:14:58,390 --> 00:14:59,550
Can't handle that many employees.

310
00:15:00,700 --> 00:15:02,980
So your company needs to redesign.

311
00:15:02,980 --> 00:15:03,580
Right.

312
00:15:03,580 --> 00:15:05,090
You see this with school boards.

313
00:15:05,090 --> 00:15:06,330
School boards do this a lot.

314
00:15:06,330 --> 00:15:11,770
Where as the amount of children in
their area starts to grow, or as new

315
00:15:11,770 --> 00:15:16,280
subdivisions and developments are built,
they have to readjust their bus routes.

316
00:15:16,280 --> 00:15:16,840
Right?

317
00:15:16,840 --> 00:15:19,720
So they kick off a project,
to reevaluate the bus routes and

318
00:15:19,720 --> 00:15:23,040
design a new bus route, and
they do this every couple of years.

319
00:15:23,040 --> 00:15:27,640
So it's almost like an ongoing activity,
but it is a project they do every

320
00:15:27,640 --> 00:15:32,470
few years, to evaluate their current
bus system, redesign their maps.

321
00:15:32,470 --> 00:15:35,290
The routes that the busses take
to get the optimum efficiency.

322
00:15:35,290 --> 00:15:36,310
So that's an organizational.

323
00:15:36,310 --> 00:15:37,920
They don't make more money.

324
00:15:37,920 --> 00:15:40,250
They might save some money if
they do better bus routes or

325
00:15:40,250 --> 00:15:41,310
a little more efficient.

326
00:15:41,310 --> 00:15:44,310
But it's done because they
had an internal need.

327
00:15:45,480 --> 00:15:48,060
There might be a technological advance.

328
00:15:48,060 --> 00:15:48,950
>> Yeah.

329
00:15:48,950 --> 00:15:51,780
>> We see this in IT all the time.

330
00:15:51,780 --> 00:15:55,277
You've got all of your servers
deployed with Windows Server 2008, and

331
00:15:55,277 --> 00:15:57,362
then Windows Server 2008 R2 comes out.

332
00:15:57,362 --> 00:16:00,201
Or Windows Server 2012, or
now Windows Server 2012 R2.

333
00:16:00,201 --> 00:16:02,151
Right?
Software keeps updating.

334
00:16:02,151 --> 00:16:04,427
You need to update to stay under support.

335
00:16:04,427 --> 00:16:07,248
Today, you have a very timely one.

336
00:16:07,248 --> 00:16:10,970
There's many companies out there
that are still running Windows XP.

337
00:16:10,970 --> 00:16:14,360
Microsoft ended support for
that last month.

338
00:16:14,360 --> 00:16:16,370
Now, you've got to upgrade.

339
00:16:16,370 --> 00:16:19,570
So, you kick off a project
because of technological advance.

340
00:16:19,570 --> 00:16:23,610
Or, maybe there's just some new technology
that can save your company a ton of money.

341
00:16:25,480 --> 00:16:27,620
Your dentist's office.

342
00:16:27,620 --> 00:16:32,120
Dentists, they can make false teeth and
in the past they were made by hand.

343
00:16:32,120 --> 00:16:35,300
So there were techs that would sit
there and actually make these teeth.

344
00:16:35,300 --> 00:16:37,890
Now they can use 3D printing machines.

345
00:16:37,890 --> 00:16:41,643
Just [SOUND] generate a tooth and
it's done much faster and

346
00:16:41,643 --> 00:16:43,606
to a higher tolerance level.

347
00:16:43,606 --> 00:16:46,550
So, maybe they decide hey
we wanna implement this.

348
00:16:46,550 --> 00:16:51,150
We wanna go to these automated 3D
printers or whatever to generate teeth.

349
00:16:51,150 --> 00:16:52,650
Well, they kick off a project to do that.

350
00:16:55,220 --> 00:16:56,140
This is my favorite one.

351
00:16:56,140 --> 00:16:56,703
>> Legal requirements.

352
00:16:56,703 --> 00:16:58,680
[LAUGH]
>> Legal requirements.

353
00:16:58,680 --> 00:17:01,365
You create a project cuz
the government told you you had to.

354
00:17:01,365 --> 00:17:02,719
[LAUGH]
>> That's right.

355
00:17:03,800 --> 00:17:06,650
We saw these really big,
what ten years ago,

356
00:17:06,650 --> 00:17:09,670
when HIPAA complaints in
the US became really big.

357
00:17:09,670 --> 00:17:13,760
All of the hospitals across the United
States had to kick off projects to

358
00:17:13,760 --> 00:17:18,380
become HIPAA compliant, or
Sarbanes-Oxley, or whatever.

359
00:17:18,380 --> 00:17:21,163
These are US ones, cuz we're in the US,
but in other countries,

360
00:17:21,163 --> 00:17:23,880
I'm sure you guys have the same
bureaucracy that we do.

361
00:17:23,880 --> 00:17:28,560
So then you probably have a different
requirements that you have to adhere to.

362
00:17:28,560 --> 00:17:32,980
I was working for a bank in Seattle when
the state of Washington passed a law

363
00:17:32,980 --> 00:17:35,860
that said online gambling was illegal,
right?

364
00:17:35,860 --> 00:17:36,970
Well, no big deal.

365
00:17:38,900 --> 00:17:40,590
You can argue that banks
are gambling institutions,

366
00:17:40,590 --> 00:17:44,070
but you're not a formally
recognized gambling institution.

367
00:17:44,070 --> 00:17:46,100
So, it didn't affect us, right?

368
00:17:46,100 --> 00:17:49,900
Well, there was a rider
on the law that said,

369
00:17:49,900 --> 00:17:55,020
if you're caught online gambling,
you can be penalized.

370
00:17:55,020 --> 00:17:58,000
It was like a misdemeanor,
felony or something like that.

371
00:17:58,000 --> 00:18:02,800
And then it went on to say, if you
provide a computer to someone else, and

372
00:18:02,800 --> 00:18:06,540
they use it for gambling, you're guilty as
well because you provided the computer.

373
00:18:06,540 --> 00:18:07,160
>> Yeah.

374
00:18:07,160 --> 00:18:10,200
>> That set off an alarm, right?

375
00:18:10,200 --> 00:18:14,790
That meant that if one of our employees
used one of our computers to go to online

376
00:18:14,790 --> 00:18:19,060
gambling sites, we could be held
responsible for that, the bank.

377
00:18:19,060 --> 00:18:23,090
And so we had to kick off a project
to put in a new web filter

378
00:18:23,090 --> 00:18:25,600
that could block access
to online gambling sites.

379
00:18:25,600 --> 00:18:26,930
We had to do our due diligence.

380
00:18:26,930 --> 00:18:29,320
So we didn't want to do that.

381
00:18:29,320 --> 00:18:32,350
Web filters slow down access,
they're hard to maintain, so

382
00:18:32,350 --> 00:18:33,700
we didn't want to implement that.

383
00:18:33,700 --> 00:18:37,751
But we had to, because these laws,
if we didn't do it we were at risk.

384
00:18:39,724 --> 00:18:40,816
All right.

385
00:18:40,816 --> 00:18:44,159
Ecological impacts, or ecological impacts,
however you wanna say it.

386
00:18:45,660 --> 00:18:50,050
We may find that there's things that we do
within our organization that carry a large

387
00:18:50,050 --> 00:18:56,330
carbon footprint, or
just aren't environmentally sound.

388
00:18:56,330 --> 00:18:57,920
McDonald's in the 80s.

389
00:18:57,920 --> 00:19:01,910
If you bought a Big Mac in the 80s,
it came in a styrofoam clam shell,

390
00:19:01,910 --> 00:19:03,560
and it was awesome, right?

391
00:19:03,560 --> 00:19:05,090
Kept the burger nice and warm.

392
00:19:05,090 --> 00:19:07,810
And they said well,
styrofoam doesn't biodegrade,

393
00:19:07,810 --> 00:19:12,270
people in general were really opposed to
it, and so they said we've gotta move.

394
00:19:12,270 --> 00:19:13,830
And we'll switch to just papers or

395
00:19:13,830 --> 00:19:17,080
wax wrappers now which,
do those even biodegrade?

396
00:19:17,080 --> 00:19:18,090
>> Who knows?

397
00:19:18,090 --> 00:19:20,780
>> So
they switched not because they wanted to,

398
00:19:20,780 --> 00:19:23,510
not because it saved them money,
I think it ended up costing more.

399
00:19:23,510 --> 00:19:26,840
But because of the environmental and
ecological impact.

400
00:19:28,420 --> 00:19:31,510
And then lastly, social need, right?

401
00:19:31,510 --> 00:19:35,170
Social need is you're
doing something because

402
00:19:35,170 --> 00:19:38,140
there's a societal-
>> Want.

403
00:19:38,140 --> 00:19:42,410
>> Yeah, that take ITPro TV.

404
00:19:43,620 --> 00:19:44,740
Our company,

405
00:19:44,740 --> 00:19:49,680
the reason we founded this whole thing
was IT training is incredibly expensive.

406
00:19:50,920 --> 00:19:54,470
And if you are already in
IT it's not a big deal.

407
00:19:54,470 --> 00:19:56,080
You get your company to pay for it.

408
00:19:56,080 --> 00:19:57,670
So you can absorb that
large training cost.

409
00:19:57,670 --> 00:19:59,230
That's why the cost is so high.

410
00:19:59,230 --> 00:20:01,860
But if you're just getting started in IT-
>> Yeah.

411
00:20:01,860 --> 00:20:04,450
>> You can't afford those classes,
they're too expensive.

412
00:20:04,450 --> 00:20:08,240
So we wanted to create something that was
lower cost that could be affordable for

413
00:20:08,240 --> 00:20:11,020
people who are career
changers that kind of thing.

414
00:20:11,020 --> 00:20:13,610
And so that was a social need.

415
00:20:13,610 --> 00:20:17,120
People out there wanted this,
there wasn't somebody that provided it, so

416
00:20:17,120 --> 00:20:18,410
we stepped in to do it.

417
00:20:18,410 --> 00:20:20,750
Now, it could be there's
other social needs.

418
00:20:20,750 --> 00:20:25,110
There's a lot of organizations that
do charity outreach and stuff.

419
00:20:25,110 --> 00:20:27,990
And those things are, again,
they're not doing it to make money,

420
00:20:27,990 --> 00:20:30,010
they're not doing it cuz
it helps their business.

421
00:20:30,010 --> 00:20:32,060
Well, I guess they get
a little PR out of it, right?

422
00:20:32,060 --> 00:20:35,140
But for the most part of the deal
because they want to fill a social need.

423
00:20:36,600 --> 00:20:40,920
All right, so those are all possible
reasons that we might kick off a project.

424
00:20:40,920 --> 00:20:44,170
Anyone of those and
there's even more just aren't here, but

425
00:20:44,170 --> 00:20:47,960
these are the ones that PMI recognizes
in the the PM box specifically.

426
00:20:47,960 --> 00:20:51,010
So any one of these can be
a reason to kick off a project.

427
00:20:51,010 --> 00:20:55,190
That's a business case and
that goes in to our project charter also.

428
00:20:57,140 --> 00:20:58,970
The other things that we have is inputs.

429
00:20:58,970 --> 00:21:01,210
So if I go back to my diagram here.

430
00:21:01,210 --> 00:21:03,466
So some of the other inputs we've got,
agreements.

431
00:21:03,466 --> 00:21:04,715
All right.

432
00:21:04,715 --> 00:21:09,750
Agreements are contracts or even verbal
communications we might even have

433
00:21:09,750 --> 00:21:15,055
with other people about either performing
a project or just certain aspects of it.

434
00:21:15,055 --> 00:21:18,378
So, we see this really
clearly with contracts.

435
00:21:18,378 --> 00:21:22,890
If you're gonna be moving
from Windows XP to Windows 7,

436
00:21:22,890 --> 00:21:27,350
and you have a volume license agreement
with Microsoft, well, that's a contract.

437
00:21:27,350 --> 00:21:31,420
So the way you handle that roll out,
the way you handle your procurement and

438
00:21:31,420 --> 00:21:33,340
stuff is going to be
governed by that contract.

439
00:21:33,340 --> 00:21:34,690
So we need to be upfront about that, and

440
00:21:34,690 --> 00:21:36,420
make sure it's mentioned in
the charter ahead of time.

441
00:21:36,420 --> 00:21:38,660
So we understand that that is there.

442
00:21:40,850 --> 00:21:45,040
It also might be that we're not
doing this project for ourselves.

443
00:21:45,040 --> 00:21:46,720
If we are a contractor.

444
00:21:46,720 --> 00:21:49,620
If somebody's contracting us to do some
work, and that's what's kicking off this

445
00:21:49,620 --> 00:21:53,370
project, that contract is going
to become part of the charter.

446
00:21:53,370 --> 00:21:55,590
In fact, it will really have
the statement of work in it.

447
00:21:55,590 --> 00:21:57,020
Any contract should.

448
00:21:57,020 --> 00:21:59,370
You might have memorandums
of understanding,

449
00:21:59,370 --> 00:22:02,300
which is just a fancy way of
saying I want to put this in

450
00:22:02,300 --> 00:22:05,760
writing to make sure we're
both clear on a topic, right?

451
00:22:05,760 --> 00:22:10,380
Service level agreements where
you're promising a certain

452
00:22:10,380 --> 00:22:12,000
amount of functionality, right?

453
00:22:12,000 --> 00:22:13,450
We see this with phone lines.

454
00:22:13,450 --> 00:22:17,230
They guarantee you'll have
phone service 99% of the time.

455
00:22:17,230 --> 00:22:20,790
And if there's a failure you get a credit
to your account, that kind of thing.

456
00:22:20,790 --> 00:22:24,210
Those need to be documented so
we understand them.

457
00:22:24,210 --> 00:22:25,990
The rest of these are all
kind of the same thing.

458
00:22:25,990 --> 00:22:26,880
Letter of agreement,

459
00:22:26,880 --> 00:22:29,570
letter of intent, these are just
putting it in writing, right?

460
00:22:29,570 --> 00:22:31,780
Putting it in writing that you
are going to do something, but

461
00:22:31,780 --> 00:22:32,770
it doesn't have to be in writing.

462
00:22:32,770 --> 00:22:34,030
It could be a verbal agreement.

463
00:22:34,030 --> 00:22:37,260
It could be that conversation
at the water cooler.

464
00:22:37,260 --> 00:22:39,140
We were talking about
a project this morning, and

465
00:22:39,140 --> 00:22:41,290
I was like,
I bet we could get Nate to do that.

00:22:41,290 --> 00:22:43,950
And Nate was over there,
he said sure, I'll take care of that.

467
00:22:43,950 --> 00:22:47,900
And so that verbal agreement that
he'll be working on the project,

468
00:22:47,900 --> 00:22:51,920
that kind of stuff falls in and
becomes part of our project.

469
00:22:53,690 --> 00:22:57,730
Email, written agreements, all of these
are just different types of agreements.

470
00:22:57,730 --> 00:23:01,160
You may have none of these,
you may have one or all of these,

471
00:23:01,160 --> 00:23:03,550
it just depends on your current situation.

472
00:23:03,550 --> 00:23:09,550
And then the last two are inputs
that we almost always see,

473
00:23:09,550 --> 00:23:13,170
enterprise environmental factors,
and organizational process assets.

474
00:23:13,170 --> 00:23:14,660
I talked about those yesterday.

475
00:23:14,660 --> 00:23:16,770
Remember the enterprise
environmental factors?

476
00:23:16,770 --> 00:23:19,950
That is things like laws
that govern your business,

00:23:19,950 --> 00:23:22,710
regulations, standards that you follow,

00:23:22,710 --> 00:23:27,425
certifications that your company holds,
that dictate the way that you do business.

479
00:23:27,425 --> 00:23:31,095
Organizational process assets,
that's historical stuff.

480
00:23:31,095 --> 00:23:31,725
Documents and

481
00:23:31,725 --> 00:23:35,805
processes that your company already has
that you can use as part of this project.

482
00:23:35,805 --> 00:23:39,890
So when you go to create this project
charter, you might have a template.

483
00:23:39,890 --> 00:23:40,880
A template document.

484
00:23:40,880 --> 00:23:43,700
A Word document that says here's

485
00:23:43,700 --> 00:23:44,260
All right.

486
00:23:44,260 --> 00:23:46,880
That would be an organizational
process asset.

487
00:23:46,880 --> 00:23:49,290
You have that template so
that all charters look the same.

488
00:23:50,880 --> 00:23:51,790
All right.

489
00:23:51,790 --> 00:23:54,390
So basically we gather all
that information together.

00:23:54,390 --> 00:23:58,071
All the stuff from these five inputs,
which we may have only one of,

491
00:23:58,071 --> 00:24:00,087
or we might have all of those things.

492
00:24:00,087 --> 00:24:02,473
So this could be a huge
amount of documentation, or

00:24:02,473 --> 00:24:05,977
it might just be a conversation at
a water cooler, and that's it, right?

494
00:24:05,977 --> 00:24:08,061
And that's the input we have.

00:24:08,061 --> 00:24:11,816
We then apply some tools and
techniques to it,

496
00:24:11,816 --> 00:24:15,390
to then create the final chart, all right?

Now, at this stage in the game, there's
not really a whole lot of tools and

00:24:19,260 --> 00:24:20,140
techniques.

The main one is gonna be expert judgement,

00:24:21,760 --> 00:24:25,220
which I said in the last
episode is this right here.

501
00:24:25,220 --> 00:24:26,430
It's what's in your head?

What you know and understand,
so that you can go in and

00:24:33,210 --> 00:24:35,600
You're just writing,

But what if a project is something you

What if I've never even heard of the Roku,
and

And so, when it comes to expert judgement.

It may not be your expert judgement,
it might be somebody else's okay?

But, it could be consultants, or SMEs,

You'll see it throughout the pinball.

This is one of those, I always say SME
you'll hear people on the internet and

some say SMEs.

cuz their the expert.

They know, what's kind of in store for me?

And it's a great way to

You may not have a subject

It's a really great opportunity and

So, instead, you might wanna rely on

Industry groups, are ones that

And boy, let me tell you, the information

it's amazing.

One of the ones that I've used over the

a.

00:29:25,040 --> 00:29:28,130
And then lastly, I've got like

00:29:28,130 --> 00:29:29,870
When you're kicking off a project and

00:29:34,500 --> 00:29:37,760

a standard charter form for you,

00:29:37,760 --> 00:29:42,665
and the required information and all of

00:29:42,665 --> 00:29:44,100
>> Mm-hm.

609
00:29:44,100 --> 00:29:48,700
>> Now, the project charter may or

610
00:29:48,700 --> 00:29:52,570
may not be drafted by the project manager.

611
00:29:52,570 --> 00:29:55,530
I you have a PMO, it's not uncommon for

00:29:55,530 --> 00:29:58,390
you not to have a project
manager in the initiating phase.

613
00:29:58,390 --> 00:30:02,280
A project manager makes a project happen.

614
00:30:02,280 --> 00:30:04,290
If a project doesn't exist yet,

615
00:30:04,290 --> 00:30:06,700
the project manager doesn't
have anything to do.

616
00:30:06,700 --> 00:30:09,690
So, when we're talking about
the project charter, oftentimes,

617
00:30:09,690 --> 00:30:13,180
this is being drafted by the sponsor,
the project sponsor.

00:30:13,180 --> 00:30:15,900
So that might be the CEO or
vice president,

619
00:30:15,900 --> 00:30:19,040
somebody like that,
not the project manager in the end.

00:30:19,040 --> 00:30:22,130
In a small company,
it may very well be the project manager.

621
00:30:22,130 --> 00:30:25,180
But often times,
it's being drafted by somebody outside.

622
00:30:25,180 --> 00:30:26,660
And that's where the PMO comes in handy.

623
00:30:26,660 --> 00:30:31,400
So the vice president goes to the PMO and
says, we wanna deploy a SAN.

624
00:30:31,400 --> 00:30:32,860
I'm authorizing it.

625
00:30:32,860 --> 00:30:33,650
What do I need to fill out?

626
00:30:33,650 --> 00:30:36,150
And they say, here, you need to
fill out this charter statement.

627
00:30:36,150 --> 00:30:40,170
And in the charter statement they put how
they what it done, when they want it done?

628
00:30:40,170 --> 00:30:44,640
And then they sign off on it giving the
authority, for that project to kick off.

629
00:30:44,640 --> 00:30:45,890
No project manager involved.

630
00:30:46,950 --> 00:30:49,610
That's how it works in
large organizations.

00:30:49,610 --> 00:30:52,390
Think about the space program,

00:30:53,510 --> 00:30:58,490
NASA was already in existence,

00:30:58,490 --> 00:31:02,790

00:31:02,790 --> 00:31:04,130
This is what we want.

00:31:04,130 --> 00:31:07,320

the project sponsor.

He said,
I wanna put a man on the moon, and

00:31:14,920 --> 00:31:18,900
And that created the funding, and
the focus, and the dedication for

00:31:18,900 --> 00:31:20,570
NASA to then pursue that.

00:31:20,570 --> 00:31:23,270
And then, either put a man on the moon, or

00:31:32,150 --> 00:31:35,130
So, that's basically what happened and

00:31:35,130 --> 00:31:37,980

That the project manager is not
the person coming up with the idea in

They're the one who is

00:44:24,070 --> 00:44:27,600
which is picking the right
people to be in the meeting,.

890
00:44:27,600 --> 00:44:31,590
There's going to be people that should
be there and people that shouldn't.

891
00:44:31,590 --> 00:44:34,440
And if you leave out people
that should have been there,

892
00:44:34,440 --> 00:44:37,720
then what you do in the meeting is not
going to be as valuable as if you had all

893
00:44:37,720 --> 00:44:39,210
of the right parties in place.

894
00:44:39,210 --> 00:44:42,090
You might make decisions
that are inaccurate

895
00:44:42,090 --> 00:44:44,470
because you didn't have
the right people there.

896
00:44:44,470 --> 00:44:48,730
We start by inviting the right people,
people that we know will have input,

897
00:44:48,730 --> 00:44:51,750
people that we know have
the authority to make decisions,

898
00:44:51,750 --> 00:44:53,925
you don't want people that don't
have authority to make decisions,

899
00:44:53,925 --> 00:44:56,110
cuz they can't give you
any valuable feedback.

900
00:44:56,110 --> 00:44:56,810
All right.

901
00:44:56,810 --> 00:45:00,610
And we make sure that we have our subject
matter experts, the people who know what's

902
00:45:00,610 --> 00:45:03,410
going on who could help us, give us
the information we need to make decisions.

903
00:45:04,750 --> 00:45:07,740
Then, once we get in the meeting,

904
00:45:07,740 --> 00:45:13,100
we need to have a list of things that
we want to achieve in that meeting.

905
00:45:13,100 --> 00:45:13,720
All right?

906
00:45:13,720 --> 00:45:14,570
These are.

907
00:45:14,570 --> 00:45:16,410
Action items or.

908
00:45:16,410 --> 00:45:17,270
Bullet points.

909
00:45:17,270 --> 00:45:19,540
There's different terms for
them that are out there.

910
00:45:19,540 --> 00:45:23,800
But not necessarily like meeting minutes,
that is detailed stuff.

911
00:45:23,800 --> 00:45:26,760
But just high level, here's
the bullet points, here's my agenda,

912
00:45:26,760 --> 00:45:30,090
here's what I want to hit in that meeting,
all right?

913
00:45:30,090 --> 00:45:34,240
You have the meeting,
you hit each of those topics, and

914
00:45:34,240 --> 00:45:36,520
you generate what are called action items.

915
00:45:36,520 --> 00:45:40,980
And action items are the single reason for
having a meeting,

916
00:45:40,980 --> 00:45:44,540
you have a meeting because there's
some action that you can't take and

917
00:45:44,540 --> 00:45:47,010
you need to get information
to take that action.

918
00:45:47,010 --> 00:45:50,600
The end of the meeting you now should
be poised to take that action.

919
00:45:50,600 --> 00:45:54,030
Action items should be assigned
to people in the meeting.

920
00:45:54,030 --> 00:45:55,980
I always say if we end a meeting and

921
00:45:55,980 --> 00:45:58,230
there's no action item,
we shouldn't have had the meeting.

922
00:45:58,230 --> 00:45:59,132
There's no point.

923
00:45:59,132 --> 00:46:04,240
All right, that's a real big deal
there everybody should either

924
00:46:04,240 --> 00:46:08,050
have input, have an action item, or both.

925
00:46:08,050 --> 00:46:11,140
If there was somebody at the meeting
that didn’t provide any input, and

926
00:46:11,140 --> 00:46:13,280
didn’t get an action item,
they shouldn’t have been there.

927
00:46:13,280 --> 00:46:16,470
They served no purpose,
you wasted their time.

928
00:46:16,470 --> 00:46:17,880
Managing that meeting is important.

929
00:46:17,880 --> 00:46:19,860
And when you’re doing brainstorming,

930
00:46:19,860 --> 00:46:24,040
it's important to kind of set boundaries
to that cuz people start to have ideas.

931
00:46:24,040 --> 00:46:27,530
We're planning an iPad app and
somebody says well, what about Android,

932
00:46:27,530 --> 00:46:28,800
let's do an Android app.

933
00:46:28,800 --> 00:46:33,145
Well, that's great but, it's a separate
platform, it's a separate design,

934
00:46:33,145 --> 00:46:36,400
let's move that into a separate project,
let's not brainstorm that now.

935
00:46:36,400 --> 00:46:43,424
Let's stay on target with what this
particular project is or Chrome-cast.

936
00:46:43,424 --> 00:46:44,250
>> Yeah.
>> Or whatever,

937
00:46:44,250 --> 00:46:46,710
there's all these different
platforms that out there.

938
00:46:46,710 --> 00:46:47,960
You have to stay on target.

939
00:46:47,960 --> 00:46:51,220
And it's the person who's
running the meeting, which

940
00:46:51,220 --> 00:46:54,610
maybe a project manager at this stage,
but often times it's still the sponsor.

941
00:46:54,610 --> 00:46:56,280
>> Yeah.
>> This person who's initiating.

942
00:46:56,280 --> 00:46:57,410
Who's doing that.

943
00:46:57,410 --> 00:46:58,430
Having control of that meeting,

944
00:46:58,430 --> 00:47:00,980
making sure you're actually
moving towards a goal.

945
00:47:00,980 --> 00:47:01,770
That's a skill.

946
00:47:01,770 --> 00:47:03,050
That's a talent that you learn.

947
00:47:04,810 --> 00:47:05,390
Yeah.

948
00:47:05,390 --> 00:47:09,490
I hate meetings, and as a result,
my meetings are always brief.

949
00:47:09,490 --> 00:47:11,490
And, hopefully, to the point.

950
00:47:11,490 --> 00:47:15,060
You have your points, you hit them, you
assign your action items, and you're done.

951
00:47:16,860 --> 00:47:19,750
All right, when we use these tools,

952
00:47:19,750 --> 00:47:25,150
we then have gathered enough
information to kick off the project.

953
00:47:25,150 --> 00:47:28,340
And so the only thing left to
do is generate our output,

954
00:47:28,340 --> 00:47:31,300
which is the project charter, all right?

955
00:47:31,300 --> 00:47:34,150
The project charter is a document.

956
00:47:34,150 --> 00:47:37,850
And like I said,
I try to keep it to one sheet of paper.

957
00:47:37,850 --> 00:47:42,070
One side, I don't even like to go two
sided on it, if I can avoid it, that is

958
00:47:42,070 --> 00:47:46,780
the high level statement of what this
project is gonna be and has the sponsor's

959
00:47:46,780 --> 00:47:50,810
signature on the bottom giving authority
for that project to move forward.

960
00:47:50,810 --> 00:47:54,200
Now the project charter is made
up of a number of components and

961
00:47:54,200 --> 00:47:55,410
it's up to you what goes in there.

962
00:47:55,410 --> 00:47:58,610
Remember that PMI It's a framework.

963
00:47:58,610 --> 00:48:00,210
It's a recommendation.

964
00:48:00,210 --> 00:48:02,640
Here's things that can go in your charter.

965
00:48:02,640 --> 00:48:04,050
You don't have to have it.

966
00:48:04,050 --> 00:48:06,985
In fact, the only thing you
have to have in the charter,

967
00:48:06,985 --> 00:48:10,304
is a description of the project,
and the sponsors signature.

968
00:48:10,304 --> 00:48:11,348
Those two things,

969
00:48:11,348 --> 00:48:15,731
that's really all that's required of
a project charter to kick off a project.

970
00:48:15,731 --> 00:48:19,135
If you're missing either of those
>> If you don't have a description of

971
00:48:19,135 --> 00:48:21,098
the product, you don't know what
the heck it is, or the project,

972
00:48:21,098 --> 00:48:22,100
so there's no point in doing it.

973
00:48:22,100 --> 00:48:24,380
And if you don't have
the sponsors signature,

974
00:48:24,380 --> 00:48:28,090
you don't have the authority to move
forward, again, no point in doing it.

975
00:48:28,090 --> 00:48:31,360
So those are really the only two
things that are required, but

976
00:48:31,360 --> 00:48:35,040
what are some of the other things we
can put in there to be thorough and

977
00:48:35,040 --> 00:48:36,220
make sure we have the right information.

978
00:48:36,220 --> 00:48:37,970
Well, PMI gives us a list.

979
00:48:37,970 --> 00:48:39,080
And so here's the list.

980
00:48:40,420 --> 00:48:44,550
Basically the project purpose or
justification, right.

981
00:48:44,550 --> 00:48:47,960
So what it is we're trying to achieve and
why we're doing it.

982
00:48:47,960 --> 00:48:50,610
Why our company needs to move
forward with this project.

983
00:48:50,610 --> 00:48:52,550
There should always be a justification.

984
00:48:52,550 --> 00:48:54,870
And that's typically the business case,
which,

985
00:48:54,870 --> 00:48:58,050
we saw back here as one of our inputs,
right.

986
00:48:58,050 --> 00:49:01,140
The business case, so
we've probably already drafted it, and

987
00:49:01,140 --> 00:49:04,560
we do a little copy and paste action
to throw that into our project charter.

988
00:49:04,560 --> 00:49:08,310
Really, a lot of times, our outputs
are just copy and paste actions.

989
00:49:09,380 --> 00:49:13,560
>> The measurable project and
objective and related success criteria.

990
00:49:13,560 --> 00:49:17,450
This really does even go back to that
idea of the statement of work, right.

991
00:49:17,450 --> 00:49:20,580
Maybe a little bit more fleshed out for
us, but it really is that.

992
00:49:20,580 --> 00:49:24,280
It's trying to say hey, we now know that
we're ready to proceed with this and

993
00:49:24,280 --> 00:49:25,940
here's the way that we can quickly and

994
00:49:25,940 --> 00:49:29,590
easily measure that we're starting
to accomplish this stuff as well.

995
00:49:29,590 --> 00:49:32,650
So, including it in the project charter,
again, gives us that, too.

996
00:49:32,650 --> 00:49:35,670
Again, another formalized stick.

997
00:49:35,670 --> 00:49:36,830
>> High level requirements?

998
00:49:36,830 --> 00:49:41,020
Requirements are project objectives and
success criteria.

999
00:49:41,020 --> 00:49:43,330
You have to meet these
requirements to be successful, so

1000
00:49:43,330 --> 00:49:45,660
it's really just different terminology for
the same thing.

1001
00:49:45,660 --> 00:49:47,890
>> But notice they say, high level.

1002
00:49:47,890 --> 00:49:49,900
That's straight out of the pin bock.

1003
00:49:49,900 --> 00:49:51,630
Don't go in crazy detail right here.

1004
00:49:51,630 --> 00:49:54,520
The project charter is not the place for
detail.

1005
00:49:54,520 --> 00:49:55,780
The planning phase is.

1006
00:49:55,780 --> 00:49:56,930
So we'll see this again.

1007
00:49:56,930 --> 00:50:01,800
We'll revisit this and the project charter
we'll see is an input to a number of other

1008
00:50:01,800 --> 00:50:04,102
processes where we get
that super crazy detail.

1009
00:50:04,102 --> 00:50:04,795
Yeah.

1010
00:50:04,795 --> 00:50:09,360
>> Along with that that also goes back to
that idea of that project scope comes down

1011
00:50:09,360 --> 00:50:12,310
to the idea of the assumptions and
the constraints as well

1012
00:50:12,310 --> 00:50:16,470
that tells us hey here's the limitation of
what we're really thinking it's gonna be.

1013
00:50:16,470 --> 00:50:20,130
And here's what we're assuming we can
accomplish with what we have on hand as

1014
00:50:20,130 --> 00:50:24,390
well and so it really does help us to
again provide a little bit more definition

1015
00:50:24,390 --> 00:50:27,570
to the overall work that
we're gonna accomplish.

1016
00:50:27,570 --> 00:50:31,290
>> All right so,
assumptions and constraints.

1017
00:50:31,290 --> 00:50:32,620
Right?

1018
00:50:32,620 --> 00:50:34,270
Every project starts.

1019
00:50:34,270 --> 00:50:36,030
>> Yeah.
>> Without a full set of information.

1020
00:50:36,030 --> 00:50:39,540
[LAUGH] So if there is anywhere
that we are lacking information,

1021
00:50:39,540 --> 00:50:42,280
we need to be able to
recognize that early on, okay.

1022
00:50:42,280 --> 00:50:44,630
And the earlier we
recognize it the better.

1023
00:50:44,630 --> 00:50:47,320
And so let's go with iPad app, right.

1024
00:50:47,320 --> 00:50:51,550
So, if we decide we want
to create an iPad app,

1025
00:50:51,550 --> 00:50:55,390
we're making the assumption that
our customers want that, right.

1026
00:50:55,390 --> 00:50:59,360
Now I might actually have a survey result
or whatever from our customers that

1027
00:50:59,360 --> 00:51:02,550
says they want it, right, but
I don't, I don't have that.

1028
00:51:02,550 --> 00:51:04,440
So that's an assumption
going into this product.

1029
00:51:04,440 --> 00:51:07,000
I'm assuming that this is
something that people want.

1030
00:51:07,000 --> 00:51:10,670
So, by putting here on paper,
I know when I get to the planning phase,

1031
00:51:10,670 --> 00:51:12,475
we should probably find out if
that assumption is correct.

1032
00:51:12,475 --> 00:51:13,400
>> [LAUGH].
>> Because if that

1033
00:51:13,400 --> 00:51:16,900
assumption is not correct,
maybe we shouldn't move forward, right.

1034
00:51:16,900 --> 00:51:18,490
But if it is correct, then we're good.

1035
00:51:18,490 --> 00:51:22,400
We move on, but for right now, I'm just
assuming that that's there, all right.

1036
00:51:22,400 --> 00:51:24,690
And then, constraints.

1037
00:51:24,690 --> 00:51:26,670
What are my limits?

1038
00:51:26,670 --> 00:51:31,130
I know that if we create an iPad app,

1039
00:51:31,130 --> 00:51:35,360
Apple has some crazy rules about how
things work, I think you have to

1040
00:51:35,360 --> 00:51:39,960
pay 30% of all your sales have to go
into Apple, different things like that.

1041
00:51:39,960 --> 00:51:44,450
So those are some things that I have to be
aware of, that it's gonna hit our bottom

1042
00:51:44,450 --> 00:51:48,740
line and there's certain limitations,
there's only so much we can discount

1043
00:51:48,740 --> 00:51:52,070
our product before we start to lose
money and so we can't do that.

1044
00:51:52,070 --> 00:51:52,720
>> Yeah.

1045
00:51:52,720 --> 00:51:55,980
>> So these are constraints
that will limit this project.

1046
00:51:55,980 --> 00:51:58,130
There's also other things like resources.

1047
00:51:58,130 --> 00:52:01,320
I may not have a lot of resources,
a lot of people, and so

1048
00:52:01,320 --> 00:52:02,410
I need to identify that here.

1049
00:52:02,410 --> 00:52:05,050
If I say I'm willing to dedicate

1050
00:52:05,050 --> 00:52:08,620
our web developer a couple
of hours every day, right.

1051
00:52:08,620 --> 00:52:12,330
Well that's going to affect the timeline
of this project versus whether I had web

1052
00:52:12,330 --> 00:52:13,640
developer full time.

1053
00:52:13,640 --> 00:52:16,590
So any constraint like that,
any restriction,

1054
00:52:16,590 --> 00:52:21,400
if we were a medical company we
would need a list that we have

1055
00:52:21,400 --> 00:52:25,060
a constraint that says anything that
we do has to be HIPPA compliant.

1056
00:52:25,060 --> 00:52:26,570
Has to meet those limits, so

1057
00:52:26,570 --> 00:52:30,140
these are things that we need to set

1058
00:52:32,432 --> 00:52:35,770
All right, we've also got our high level
product description and boundaries.

1059
00:52:35,770 --> 00:52:37,280
Very similar to the one's above.

1060
00:52:37,280 --> 00:52:39,700
A lot of these are different terms for
the same thing.

1061
00:52:39,700 --> 00:52:44,420
So, just an overall description of
what our project is going to be, and

1062
00:52:44,420 --> 00:52:45,440
the boundaries of it.

1063
00:52:45,440 --> 00:52:47,330
The boundaries are saying what
we are going to accomplish.

1064
00:52:47,330 --> 00:52:49,840
And what we're not going to accomplish so

1065
00:52:49,840 --> 00:52:52,670
maybe we say we're going
to develop an iPad app.

1066
00:52:52,670 --> 00:52:59,940
We are not going to develop a web OSF at
this time or an Android app at this time.

1067
00:52:59,940 --> 00:53:02,480
That's another project,
we'll do that later, right.

1068
00:53:02,480 --> 00:53:05,550
So set the boundaries so
you don't get Scope creep.

1069
00:53:05,550 --> 00:53:07,737
They start bleeding and
bringing in all sorts of extra work.

1070
00:53:09,744 --> 00:53:11,560
High level risks.

1071
00:53:11,560 --> 00:53:15,070
Do we know of any risks about
this project, from day one?

1072
00:53:15,070 --> 00:53:15,610
Right.
Is there

1073
00:53:15,610 --> 00:53:17,042
something we know about right now?

1074
00:53:17,042 --> 00:53:21,270
Risk is, is a whole huge section
that we'll talk about later on,

1075
00:53:21,270 --> 00:53:24,020
that we'll have to do
a very deep level analysis.

1076
00:53:24,020 --> 00:53:28,990
But at the high level, are there any risks
that we're aware of right now, all right?

1077
00:53:28,990 --> 00:53:33,430
So there's a risk that doing a mobile app

1078
00:53:33,430 --> 00:53:37,760
might create another pathway for
piracy of our content, right.

1079
00:53:37,760 --> 00:53:41,700
That's a risk, and we just need to
evaluate whether we accept that or

1080
00:53:41,700 --> 00:53:44,090
if there's a way to minimize it or
whatever.

1081
00:53:44,090 --> 00:53:49,200
There's a risk that Apple's percentage
of our profits might exceed our profit

1082
00:53:49,200 --> 00:53:53,640
margin and in that case, we might be
losing money, so we need to evaluate that.

1083
00:53:53,640 --> 00:53:55,690
These are things that we
might know ahead of time.

1084
00:53:55,690 --> 00:53:57,660
There's other risks
that we might not know,

1085
00:53:57,660 --> 00:53:59,310
stuff that we just have no idea about.

1086
00:53:59,310 --> 00:54:00,730
For example,

1087
00:54:00,730 --> 00:54:04,670
Apple has certain rules as far as what
applications they'll allow or won't.

1088
00:54:04,670 --> 00:54:08,310
And so, maybe we spend all this
time developing an iPad app and

1089
00:54:08,310 --> 00:54:11,380
then Apple just rejects it because
we broke one of their rules, right.

1090
00:54:11,380 --> 00:54:13,510
And they say, oh, you can't do that,
and they reject it.

1091
00:54:13,510 --> 00:54:16,580
Well, could we have identified
that ahead of time,

1092
00:54:16,580 --> 00:54:18,850
could we have taken
the means to prevent that.

1093
00:54:18,850 --> 00:54:20,790
We could have,
we just didn't know at this point, right.

1094
00:54:20,790 --> 00:54:23,251
And again, in the initiation that's okay.

1095
00:54:24,794 --> 00:54:29,775
Summary Milestone Schedule, any project
has a start and a finish, right, so

1096
00:54:29,775 --> 00:54:33,290
we know what we're trying
produce at the end.

1097
00:54:33,290 --> 00:54:35,590
But it's a good idea to set milestones.

1098
00:54:35,590 --> 00:54:36,570
Throughout the project so

1099
00:54:36,570 --> 00:54:39,210
that you have things that you're working
towards constantly, things that you can

1100
00:54:39,210 --> 00:54:43,060
use to meter and measure your progress

1101
00:54:43,060 --> 00:54:47,110
So at a high level, can we think of
some of those milestones, right.

1102
00:54:47,110 --> 00:54:52,160
So, getting a iPad app running on
our internal test environment and

1103
00:54:52,160 --> 00:54:54,680
then getting it submitted
to the app store and

1104
00:54:54,680 --> 00:54:57,120
then actually getting it

1105
00:54:57,120 --> 00:55:00,560
Each of these might be milestones
that we monitor it against to see

1106
00:55:00,560 --> 00:55:01,840
how we're moving alone.

1107
00:55:01,840 --> 00:55:04,050
Just real high level, summary milestones.

1108
00:55:04,050 --> 00:55:05,230
Again, we'll revisit this later.

1109
00:55:06,890 --> 00:55:08,490
This one is one of my favorites,

1110
00:55:08,490 --> 00:55:10,100
Summary budget.

00:55:10,100 --> 00:55:12,340
At this stage of the game it is so

00:55:12,340 --> 00:55:14,780

If, money is no object you

You still need to figure
out what things cost.

1115

We just don't know what it's going to be.

1116
00:55:21,270 --> 00:55:23,470
So, we may or
may not have this information.

00:55:23,470 --> 00:55:27,140
But, you might say I wanna
