1803
01:28:08,484 --> 01:28:10,391
then we're not going to be able to use it.

1804
01:28:10,391 --> 01:28:14,227
So I would put in your information about
who makes those technical decisions or

1805
01:28:14,227 --> 01:28:17,085
decisions that we've made already,
if we've made any.

1806
01:28:17,085 --> 01:28:21,651
So I might put in here,
that it must use 110v power,

1807
01:28:21,651 --> 01:28:25,540
cuz here in the US that's the common,
right?

1808
01:28:25,540 --> 01:28:29,083
I don't want anything,
not volts, it's watts, isn't it?

1809
01:28:29,083 --> 01:28:29,965
>> Yeah, that's right.

1810
01:28:29,965 --> 01:28:31,394
>> Oh, it is volts?
All right.

1811
01:28:31,394 --> 01:28:32,544
So, 110.
Cuz, I don't want 220.

1812
01:28:32,544 --> 01:28:35,144
In Europe, you get 220 all over the place,
but not in the US.

1813
01:28:35,144 --> 01:28:38,130
So most use 110 volt power and

1814
01:28:38,130 --> 01:28:42,880
must support sleep mode for
power conservation.

1815
01:28:42,880 --> 01:28:47,240
I don't want this thing eating up power
all the time if nobody's using it.

1816
01:28:47,240 --> 01:28:49,518
So I wanna make sure that
it actually gets handled.

1817
01:28:49,518 --> 01:28:50,690
All right.

1818
01:28:50,690 --> 01:28:53,700
Conflict resolution.

1819
01:28:53,700 --> 01:28:57,990
If a conflict should arise,
if two people butt heads or whatever.

1820
01:28:57,990 --> 01:28:58,580
If Nate and

1821
01:28:58,580 --> 01:29:03,430
I are butting heads over the design,
he's the originator, I'm the sponsor.

1822
01:29:03,430 --> 01:29:04,950
I'm also the project manager.

1823
01:29:04,950 --> 01:29:07,020
We need to put the resolution.

1824
01:29:07,020 --> 01:29:10,412
Normally, I just put a one
sentence thing here.

1825
01:29:10,412 --> 01:29:12,368
>> [LAUGH]
>> I put,

1826
01:29:12,368 --> 01:29:18,140
decisions will be made democratically.

1827
01:29:19,340 --> 01:29:20,560
Which means we'll take a vote.

1828
01:29:20,560 --> 01:29:21,790
Majority wins.

1829
01:29:21,790 --> 01:29:22,290
Okay.

1830
01:29:26,090 --> 01:29:31,770
And then I put,
ties will be determined by the PM,

1831
01:29:31,770 --> 01:29:34,140
the Project Manager will
make that decision.

1832
01:29:34,140 --> 01:29:37,490
Now your's might be different,
you might say the sponsor,

1833
01:29:37,490 --> 01:29:40,520
the person who's true authority
makes the decision, right?

1834
01:29:40,520 --> 01:29:44,610
And I've had that, where I was the PM for
a project and there was a tie.

1835
01:29:44,610 --> 01:29:48,790
And I was leading towards one side,
but our CIO, he was the sponsor.

1836
01:29:48,790 --> 01:29:50,340
He was leading towards the other side.

1837
01:29:50,340 --> 01:29:51,340
That's the way we went.

1838
01:29:51,340 --> 01:29:53,140
He had that authority.

1839
01:29:53,140 --> 01:29:55,370
As a PM we don't take this personally.

1840
01:29:55,370 --> 01:29:56,970
It's the decision of the company.

1841
01:29:56,970 --> 01:29:58,950
So you have to do what's right.

1842
01:29:58,950 --> 01:30:01,750
I'm gonna put in here ties to
be determined by the PM, but

1843
01:30:01,750 --> 01:30:06,160
again determined entirely by your company,
right.

1844
01:30:06,160 --> 01:30:09,580
And then lastly, we've got
the project manager, which is me.

1845
01:30:12,180 --> 01:30:17,900
And the sponsor or, there's typos
in this thing, or originator,

1846
01:30:17,900 --> 01:30:23,710
and so in this case the originator
is going to be Nathan Copeland.

1847
01:30:24,730 --> 01:30:28,010
And so now we've got it in
here where we can come in and

1848
01:30:28,010 --> 01:30:32,280
we can fill in our names,
dates, and all that good stuff.

1849
01:30:32,280 --> 01:30:33,890
Get this thing filled out.

1850
01:30:33,890 --> 01:30:38,510
This form is worthless in it's current
form because it has no signatures, right?

1851
01:30:38,510 --> 01:30:42,970
It's the signatures that are really
gonna give this thing power.

1852
01:30:42,970 --> 01:30:50,180
So we need to print this out, get it
signed and now we've got a full charter.

1853
01:30:50,180 --> 01:30:50,800
All right.

1854
01:30:50,800 --> 01:30:53,560
Now that took a lot longer to
fill out because I was talking

1855
01:30:53,560 --> 01:30:56,050
about every entry as we went, but

1856
01:30:56,050 --> 01:30:59,010
a project charter should really take
you about ten minutes to fill out.

1857
01:30:59,010 --> 01:31:01,670
It's not a big deal,
it's just high level stuff.

1858
01:31:01,670 --> 01:31:05,600
The key thing is this block right
down here, because what it is,

1859
01:31:05,600 --> 01:31:10,080
is the sponsor giving authority to
the project manager to get to work.

1860
01:31:10,080 --> 01:31:13,540
As a project manager,
if you're a project manager right now

1861
01:31:13,540 --> 01:31:18,680
you should never start a project
without a signed charter in hand.

1862
01:31:18,680 --> 01:31:21,810
Without that signed charter you don't
have permission to spend money.

1863
01:31:21,810 --> 01:31:23,500
You don't have permission
to run that project.

1864
01:31:23,500 --> 01:31:25,010
You've got to get this done.

1865
01:31:25,010 --> 01:31:25,730
It's very, very important.

1866
01:31:27,820 --> 01:31:32,671
All right, so
when we're all done we'll save that and

1867
01:31:32,671 --> 01:31:38,270
let me just do a Save As here and
we'll create a new folder here.

1868
01:31:38,270 --> 01:31:44,530
This is gonna be our arcade cabinet build,
or maybe we'll just call it a project.

1869
01:31:44,530 --> 01:31:46,000
>> Yeah.

1870
01:31:46,000 --> 01:31:47,220
>> There we go.

1871
01:31:47,220 --> 01:31:51,260
And I like to name my files with
the phase at the beginning.

1872
01:31:51,260 --> 01:31:53,825
So I'm gonna call this
initiation-project charter,

1873
01:31:53,825 --> 01:31:56,630
cuz I might develop several
different documents.

1874
01:31:56,630 --> 01:31:59,590
And another thing I like to do,
you can do this in the file name or

1875
01:31:59,590 --> 01:32:00,380
you can do it elsewhere.

1876
01:32:00,380 --> 01:32:03,550
I like to do it in the file name and
just put version 1.0.

1877
01:32:03,550 --> 01:32:05,970
This is version one of this document.

1878
01:32:05,970 --> 01:32:09,220
I'll probably only have one version of
this document because we're allowed to

1879
01:32:09,220 --> 01:32:13,950
change, but when we get into the planning
phase, we're gonna have multiple

1880
01:32:13,950 --> 01:32:17,242
versions of documents as we
revise them and change them.

1881
01:32:17,242 --> 01:32:19,280
Stuff happens, things have to change and

1882
01:32:19,280 --> 01:32:21,670
having a version number that
you track is important.

1883
01:32:21,670 --> 01:32:25,720
A lot of software, even in Word,
if I go to file and properties,

1884
01:32:25,720 --> 01:32:30,630
I'll see where I got all these things that
I can put inside of the document as far

1885
01:32:30,630 --> 01:32:35,610
as doing tracking for,
if there had been changes or whatever.

1886
01:32:35,610 --> 01:32:37,200
So it can track version numbers here.

1887
01:32:37,200 --> 01:32:41,160
So this is revision number two,
right now I must have saved it before.

1888
01:32:41,160 --> 01:32:44,890
So it can track it here, but that's hard
for people to see, they don't know it.

1889
01:32:44,890 --> 01:32:47,540
So that's why I like to stick
it right in the file name.

1890
01:32:47,540 --> 01:32:50,530
So somebody comes to me with a document
version 1.0 and I'm like man,

1891
01:32:50,530 --> 01:32:52,360
we're on version 2.5 by now.

1892
01:32:52,360 --> 01:32:54,390
You need the latest version.

1893
01:32:54,390 --> 01:32:58,160
Easy to tell if people
have the right document.

1894
01:32:58,160 --> 01:33:00,480
All right, so that is the project charter.

1895
01:33:00,480 --> 01:33:04,590
I need to print this out now, and I need
to sign it, and Nate needs to sign it,

1896
01:33:04,590 --> 01:33:07,070
and now we're ready to
rock on this project.

1897
01:33:08,930 --> 01:33:11,510
All right, so
that's basically a project charter,

1898
01:33:11,510 --> 01:33:14,820
now our initiation phase isn't done,
we still have more to do.

1899
01:33:14,820 --> 01:33:18,090
We need to deal with our stakeholders,
which we have a very small list here, so

1900
01:33:18,090 --> 01:33:19,910
what we'll need to get
some more going in there.

1901
01:33:19,910 --> 01:33:22,460
But, for right now I think
that's a pretty good start.

1902
01:33:22,460 --> 01:33:23,960
Ronnie can you think of
anything that we left out?

1903
01:33:23,960 --> 01:33:24,480
>> I don't think so.

1904
01:33:24,480 --> 01:33:26,660
I think the examples are good example for
us.

1905
01:33:26,660 --> 01:33:29,170
It gives us the ability to
actually start thinking that way.

1906
01:33:29,170 --> 01:33:32,880
And so we're ready to actually
identify our stakeholders next once

1907
01:33:32,880 --> 01:33:34,080
we continue to move on.

1908
01:33:34,080 --> 01:33:34,840
>> Sweet.

1909
01:33:34,840 --> 01:33:37,760
Well, let's go ahead and
wrap up here for this episode.

1910
01:33:37,760 --> 01:33:39,870
And we'll do stakeholders
in our next episode.

1911
01:33:39,870 --> 01:33:44,340
So let me just remind everybody if
you have questions on any of this,

1912
01:33:44,340 --> 01:33:48,530
live during this show you can go to
itpro.tv/live and you'll see our video,

1913
01:33:48,530 --> 01:33:50,070
the chat box is right beneath,

1914
01:33:50,070 --> 01:33:52,960
you can post in the chat box,
we monitor and answer during the show.

1915
01:33:52,960 --> 01:33:56,600
If you have questions after
the show use our Q&A forums.

1916
01:33:56,600 --> 01:33:59,820
You hit the Q&A link at the top of
the page it'll take you into our forums,

1917
01:33:59,820 --> 01:34:02,322
you can post a question there,
we monitor and answer that too.

1918
01:34:02,322 --> 01:34:05,170
We wanna make sure you guys
get the answers you need so

1919
01:34:05,170 --> 01:34:06,162
that you're ready for that exam.

1920
01:34:06,162 --> 01:34:09,520
All right well I hope you guys enjoyed
the show, stay tuned because we're gonna

1921
01:34:09,520 --> 01:34:12,620
be picking up with more episodes
on project management soon and

1922
01:34:12,620 --> 01:34:13,730
we hope to see you then.

1923
01:34:13,730 --> 01:34:16,180
Signing up for ITPro TV, I'm Don Pisset.

1924
01:34:16,180 --> 01:34:16,880
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1925
01:34:16,880 --> 01:34:18,504
>> And we will see you next time.

1926
01:34:18,504 --> 01:34:28,504
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a deeper look in how to develop a project management charter and identify the stakeholders. They show the breakdown on how to develop the project charter and how identify the stakeholders. They show some of the templates that can be used to help complete the initiation phase.
episodes.title: Initiation Phase Part 2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:01,669 --> 00:00:11,669
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,359 --> 00:00:22,560
>> Alright, good morning,

3
00:00:22,560 --> 00:00:27,798
good afternoon and

4
00:00:27,798 --> 00:00:33,035
good evening, and

5
00:00:33,035 --> 00:00:37,520
welcome back.

6
00:00:37,520 --> 00:00:38,970
To another episode of IT Pro TV.

7
00:00:38,970 --> 00:00:43,160
I'm your host Don Pizzett once again with
Mr. Ronnie Wong, how's it going Ronnie?

8
00:00:43,160 --> 00:00:47,785
>> It is going well and I am excited and
ready for my future in the Warp Tour.

9
00:00:47,785 --> 00:00:51,500
[LAUGH]
>> Ronnie is taking his daughter to

10
00:00:51,500 --> 00:00:55,975
the Warp Tour soon and we have made
endless It's fun of them about this.

11
00:00:55,975 --> 00:00:59,350
[LAUGH] Ronnie who is your favorite band?

12
00:00:59,350 --> 00:01:02,290
>> It's whatever one that I
can get a t-shirt with and

13
00:01:02,290 --> 00:01:05,670
so I don't know [LAUGH] we'll
call it Campbell soup cup.

14
00:01:05,670 --> 00:01:08,630
>> You strike me as a Fallout boy person.

15
00:01:08,630 --> 00:01:11,970
>> I think I may be fallout
boy definitely that or

16
00:01:11,970 --> 00:01:15,650
Coldplay one of the two wonderful
>> [LAUGH] I don't know which is worse.

17
00:01:15,650 --> 00:01:16,280
>> Me neither.

18
00:01:16,280 --> 00:01:17,220
>> All right well ladies and

19
00:01:17,220 --> 00:01:21,250
gentlemen in the last episode we were
working through project initiation.

20
00:01:21,250 --> 00:01:23,710
We were taking about getting
a project started and

21
00:01:23,710 --> 00:01:26,390
we took a look at the project
charter process and

22
00:01:26,390 --> 00:01:30,380
actually creating that project charter
which is our kickoff document, all right?

23
00:01:30,380 --> 00:01:34,740
Well, in normal project management form,
I printed it out,

24
00:01:34,740 --> 00:01:37,210
I took it over, I signed it as the PM.

25
00:01:37,210 --> 00:01:37,730
>> Yup.

26
00:01:37,730 --> 00:01:41,540
>> Nate signed it as the originator,
so we've got a, wait, where is that?

27
00:01:41,540 --> 00:01:43,450
Hang on,
I've got that sitting around somewhere.

28
00:01:43,450 --> 00:01:44,490
Let me pull it up here.

29
00:01:44,490 --> 00:01:50,070
We're gonna go official here, so
let me see, where did I park that?

30
00:01:50,070 --> 00:01:54,390
That would be in our arcade cabinet
project that we started right, so So

31
00:01:54,390 --> 00:01:55,240
here's my PDF.

32
00:01:55,240 --> 00:01:58,840
So here's the project charter that
we drafted in the last episode.

33
00:01:58,840 --> 00:02:03,190
We fired it up, we got it set,
and we've got it signed.

34
00:02:03,190 --> 00:02:08,170
Here's something that I learned
long ago in a previous life,

35
00:02:08,170 --> 00:02:11,970
I worked at a law office,
you always sign things in a blue pen, so

36
00:02:11,970 --> 00:02:13,940
you can tell if you've got the original or
not.

37
00:02:13,940 --> 00:02:16,850
If you have it black or
white it might be a photo copy.

38
00:02:16,850 --> 00:02:19,830
But, we're signed,
our project is kicked off.

39
00:02:19,830 --> 00:02:21,270
We're ready to rock.

40
00:02:21,270 --> 00:02:26,050
And now we're ready to move to the next
part of the initiating process.

41
00:02:26,050 --> 00:02:27,520
So develop a charter?

42
00:02:27,520 --> 00:02:28,750
Done.
We are chartered.

43
00:02:28,750 --> 00:02:29,830
We are ready to rock.

44
00:02:29,830 --> 00:02:30,750
All right?

45
00:02:30,750 --> 00:02:34,490
Now we're ready to step forward to
the only other process group we

46
00:02:34,490 --> 00:02:37,740
have in the initiation phase which
is identify the stakeholders.

47
00:02:37,740 --> 00:02:38,400
>> Yeah.
>> So

48
00:02:38,400 --> 00:02:42,600
when we go to identify the stakeholders,
we're trying to come up with that list of

49
00:02:42,600 --> 00:02:47,470
all the people, not necessarily
that are apart of the project, but

50
00:02:47,470 --> 00:02:48,690
that are effected by the project.

51
00:02:48,690 --> 00:02:49,840
The people we need to communicate with.

52
00:02:49,840 --> 00:02:52,510
>> A lot of times times when we
start talking about the idea of

53
00:02:52,510 --> 00:02:53,840
stakeholders, right.

54
00:02:53,840 --> 00:02:57,960
When you take a look at it just from a
peer paper point of you, you may actually

55
00:02:57,960 --> 00:03:02,060
say, hey, these are people that have some
authority or power in the actual project.

56
00:03:02,060 --> 00:03:04,210
Or at least have some vested
interest in the project,

57
00:03:04,210 --> 00:03:06,630
whether it's gonna effect them directly or
whether or

58
00:03:06,630 --> 00:03:09,410
not they're gonna actually have to do
something or perform something here.

59
00:03:09,410 --> 00:03:11,490
So a lot of times just by
looking at it in that way,

60
00:03:11,490 --> 00:03:14,540
if you wonder who the stakeholders are
they're the ones that either are making

61
00:03:14,540 --> 00:03:17,720
decisions a lot of times or the decision's
gonna directly affect them and

62
00:03:17,720 --> 00:03:20,520
that's why they're taking interest
in our particular project.

63
00:03:20,520 --> 00:03:21,230
>> Yup.

64
00:03:21,230 --> 00:03:23,070
All right, well let's take
a look at the process itself.

65
00:03:23,070 --> 00:03:24,515
I've got it around here somewhere here.

66
00:03:24,515 --> 00:03:26,260
>> [LAUGH]
>> Identify stakeholders, so

67
00:03:26,260 --> 00:03:30,800
here's the identify stakeholders process
and it's a pretty straightforward one.

68
00:03:30,800 --> 00:03:34,800
We've got a bunch of inputs, all right,
which we kind of expect at this point.

69
00:03:34,800 --> 00:03:36,630
And we have just a handful of tools and
techniques.

70
00:03:36,630 --> 00:03:39,860
But the end result is that we're gonna
create what's called a stakeholder

71
00:03:39,860 --> 00:03:40,880
register.

72
00:03:40,880 --> 00:03:43,460
And the stakeholder
register is simply a list.

73
00:03:43,460 --> 00:03:45,180
A list of our stakeholders and

74
00:03:45,180 --> 00:03:49,050
some basic information about them that
we need to be aware of, all right?

75
00:03:49,050 --> 00:03:50,660
So let's start with these inputs.

76
00:03:50,660 --> 00:03:55,220
Notice the very first input is
the project charter, all right?

77
00:03:55,220 --> 00:03:58,070
We just created that, and
in the project charter,

78
00:03:58,070 --> 00:04:01,960
if you watch the last episode, we had
a field in there called stakeholders.

79
00:04:01,960 --> 00:04:05,410
And what we did is we
took our first ballpark

80
00:04:05,410 --> 00:04:10,240
Dart in the dark type approach to figure
out who we thought our stakeholders were.

81
00:04:10,240 --> 00:04:13,320
So, we've already got a couple of people

82
00:04:13,320 --> 00:04:15,380
that are ready to go into
our stakeholder register,

83
00:04:15,380 --> 00:04:19,500
people that we just guessed during
the beginning of the phase, all right.

84
00:04:19,500 --> 00:04:21,770
So, that's gonna serve as an input,

85
00:04:21,770 --> 00:04:24,440
the project charter is
an input into this process.

86
00:04:25,440 --> 00:04:27,720
Then we've got procurement documents.

87
00:04:27,720 --> 00:04:30,770
Now what are procurement documents?

88
00:04:30,770 --> 00:04:34,500
In your mind, with PMI language, right,

89
00:04:34,500 --> 00:04:38,690
any time you see procurement you need to
change that in your head to contract.

90
00:04:38,690 --> 00:04:40,850
These are anybody that
we have a contract with.

91
00:04:40,850 --> 00:04:44,330
If we have a contract with a company for
doing some of the work or providing

92
00:04:44,330 --> 00:04:49,910
the services anyone listed on that
contract is a stakeholder in the project.

93
00:04:49,910 --> 00:04:55,590
They're either the purchaser, usually us
and so we want the goods to be delivered.

94
00:04:55,590 --> 00:05:00,120
Or they're the provider, they're
the ones that are providing the service.

95
00:05:00,120 --> 00:05:02,580
So they need to deliver so
they get paid, right.

96
00:05:02,580 --> 00:05:06,670
So anybody named in that contract
is going to be a stakeholder.

97
00:05:06,670 --> 00:05:10,740
So, you may not have any contracts,
but if you do, page through them.

98
00:05:10,740 --> 00:05:12,440
Look for anyone named in them.

99
00:05:12,440 --> 00:05:14,649
Any, anyone who is, they're going
to be stakeholders, all right.

100
00:05:15,900 --> 00:05:19,490
And then we have our two,
almost given ones, right.

101
00:05:19,490 --> 00:05:23,570
Enterprise environmental factors and
organizational process assets.

102
00:05:23,570 --> 00:05:27,310

00:07:01,250 --> 00:07:04,240

00:07:28,750 --> 00:07:33,710

00:39:50,440 --> 00:39:52,920
So we'll pop him over here.

807
00:39:52,920 --> 00:39:53,740
All right.

808
00:39:53,740 --> 00:39:55,910
Then we've got the ITProTV viewers.

809
00:39:55,910 --> 00:39:59,602
Now the ITProTV viewers,
you guys are customers.

810
00:39:59,602 --> 00:40:01,529
It's kind of an interesting thing, right.

811
00:40:01,529 --> 00:40:04,511
You don't have power in
the company in terms of,

812
00:40:04,511 --> 00:40:09,820
you're not our employee you don't work for
us, you don't have a title.

813
00:40:09,820 --> 00:40:15,780
But you're our customer, and if you
guys give us feedback we act on that.

814
00:40:15,780 --> 00:40:18,390
So while you don't have power in
the company, you'd be low power,

815
00:40:18,390 --> 00:40:20,900
you're actually gonna be high influence.

816
00:40:20,900 --> 00:40:25,970
If you tell us to do something,
we're gonna listen in most cases.

817
00:40:25,970 --> 00:40:28,300
So I'll put the ITProTV viewers there.

818
00:40:28,300 --> 00:40:30,680
Now obviously as my
stakeholder list grows,

819
00:40:30,680 --> 00:40:32,830
I'll have people kind of
fall into different areas.

820
00:40:32,830 --> 00:40:37,660
But remember what they were
suggesting in the PMI manual there,

821
00:40:37,660 --> 00:40:41,770
that each of these quadrants kind of
corresponds to a different action.

822
00:40:41,770 --> 00:40:43,360
How do I handle these people?

823
00:40:43,360 --> 00:40:47,686
And I don't have anybody
in the just monitor area.

824
00:40:47,686 --> 00:40:49,778
We could put Jason, our director,

825
00:40:49,778 --> 00:40:54,030
who wouldn't have a lot of power as
far as this project is concerned, and

826
00:40:54,030 --> 00:40:58,028
he wouldn't have a lot of influence
in it cuz we don't respect him.

827
00:40:58,028 --> 00:41:04,340
[LAUGH] It's fun to make fun of people
when they don't have a microphone.

828
00:41:04,340 --> 00:41:06,270
So we can throw him in there if we wanted,
but

829
00:41:06,270 --> 00:41:08,360
we don't really have anybody
that falls in that scope.

830
00:41:08,360 --> 00:41:10,220
So we've got Don and Ronnie.

831
00:41:10,220 --> 00:41:11,280
We need to be managed closely.

832
00:41:11,280 --> 00:41:12,840
Well, we're the ones doing the managing,

833
00:41:12,840 --> 00:41:15,040
so not really anything
to worry about there.

834
00:41:15,040 --> 00:41:19,590
And then these guys down here,
we need to communicate with them,

835
00:41:19,590 --> 00:41:23,370
keep open channels and
try and keep them happy.

836
00:41:23,370 --> 00:41:25,642
That's what the PMI is suggesting here.

837
00:41:25,642 --> 00:41:27,130
Keep informed.

838
00:41:27,130 --> 00:41:29,480
Make sure that we're doing what they need.

839
00:41:29,480 --> 00:41:36,390
So now when we start to go and
look at their influence,

840
00:41:36,390 --> 00:41:44,370
here's where we're gonna put
things like manage closely.

841
00:41:44,370 --> 00:41:47,240
And Nathan was keep informed.

842
00:41:48,790 --> 00:41:50,540
Ronnie was manage closely.

843
00:41:51,740 --> 00:41:53,129
Rob was keep informed.

844
00:41:54,680 --> 00:41:57,470
And ITProTV viewers, keep informed.

845
00:41:57,470 --> 00:42:00,470
And we're gonna use this information
later in our communications plan, but for

846
00:42:00,470 --> 00:42:03,520
right now this is the influence
we've assigned to them.

847
00:42:03,520 --> 00:42:06,400
And these terms,
you can use whatever terms you want.

848
00:42:06,400 --> 00:42:08,380
So you might want to assign them colors.

849
00:42:08,380 --> 00:42:09,330
I've seen red, yellow,

850
00:42:09,330 --> 00:42:13,490
green like a stop sign, where you have
here's people that are in the green,

851
00:42:13,490 --> 00:42:16,850
here's people that are in the yellow and
here's people that are in the red.

852
00:42:16,850 --> 00:42:19,930
And you set up your communications
pattern based on that.

853
00:42:19,930 --> 00:42:23,690
The people in the red, those are the ones
that you interact with regularly.

854
00:42:23,690 --> 00:42:28,785
People in the green, they're low risk,
you kind of let them cruise.

855
00:42:28,785 --> 00:42:33,222
All right, so when we're done,

856
00:42:33,222 --> 00:42:40,240
what we've got is
a stakeholder analysis matrix.

857
00:42:40,240 --> 00:42:41,500
So now we've got the matrix.

858
00:42:41,500 --> 00:42:42,610
It's filled out.

859
00:42:42,610 --> 00:42:44,420
I do need to save this in my project.

860
00:42:44,420 --> 00:42:49,390
So I will save it, and pop that in here.

861
00:42:49,390 --> 00:42:54,445
So again, this is gonna go back to
Initiation- Stakeholder Analysis Matrix

862
00:42:54,445 --> 00:42:56,460
v1.0.

863
00:42:56,460 --> 00:42:58,570
>> Yeah, now this matrix for

864
00:42:58,570 --> 00:43:03,580
us is really important in terms of
adding new stakeholders as well.

865
00:43:03,580 --> 00:43:07,650
As more stakeholders may come onto the
project, we need to be able to place them

866
00:43:07,650 --> 00:43:11,040
where we need to and be able to know their
influence and their power right away.

867
00:43:11,040 --> 00:43:14,160
And so maybe we can't actually
understand it right away.

868
00:43:14,160 --> 00:43:16,110
But maybe by bringing this matrix up,

869
00:43:16,110 --> 00:43:19,640
it gives us that ability to kind of
visualize it and then go, I know exactly

870
00:43:19,640 --> 00:43:23,020
where I need to actually keep them in line
with the communications process here.

871
00:43:24,690 --> 00:43:26,620
>> All right, so we've got that done.

872
00:43:26,620 --> 00:43:29,140
We've got our stakeholder register
pretty much filled out now.

873
00:43:29,140 --> 00:43:31,610
I might need to come back and
update some of this later on.

874
00:43:31,610 --> 00:43:33,990
But for the most part we're there.

875
00:43:33,990 --> 00:43:35,670
Most everything is done.

876
00:43:35,670 --> 00:43:37,770
I did forget to talk about one thing.

877
00:43:37,770 --> 00:43:41,355
I mentioned under classification how
we were doing primary and secondary.

878
00:43:41,355 --> 00:43:43,930
I didn't mention any of the other
types that were out there.

879
00:43:43,930 --> 00:43:47,776
And PMI actually calls
out a few in the PMBOK.

880
00:43:47,776 --> 00:43:48,276
Where's my notes?

881
00:43:49,520 --> 00:43:52,200
So if you go into the PMBOK,
you'll find a few other ones.

882
00:43:52,200 --> 00:43:56,550
Some people choose to classify them based
on whether they're internal or external.

883
00:43:56,550 --> 00:44:00,285
Internal meaning, are they your employees,
or external, somebody outside.

884
00:44:00,285 --> 00:44:02,134
You know,
if you're dealing with contractors and

885
00:44:02,134 --> 00:44:04,180
things you have internal and external.

886
00:44:04,180 --> 00:44:08,830
You might also choose to break it down
by supporter, neutral, or resistor.

887
00:44:08,830 --> 00:44:13,900
Supporter, somebody who wants to help
your project succeed and finish.

888
00:44:13,900 --> 00:44:18,590
You have resistors, people who
don't want your project to succeed.

889
00:44:18,590 --> 00:44:19,380
And neutral people,

890
00:44:19,380 --> 00:44:23,390
people who don't care either way, they're
just there to get the project going.

891
00:44:23,390 --> 00:44:24,550
And classifying them that way,

892
00:44:24,550 --> 00:44:27,700
again, is just kind of that meter
stick you can use to measure this.

893
00:44:27,700 --> 00:44:33,175
Now keep in mind,
just like with the project charter,

894
00:44:33,175 --> 00:44:35,635
remember on the charter,
how I deleted several fields?

895
00:44:35,635 --> 00:44:37,105
I said hey,
these don't really apply to us.

896
00:44:37,105 --> 00:44:38,075
We'll drop them out.

897
00:44:38,075 --> 00:44:40,445
That's how the stakeholder
register is too.

898
00:44:40,445 --> 00:44:44,065
At a minimum,
you don't need all of this information.

899
00:44:44,065 --> 00:44:48,550
At a minimum you need name and
role, right?

900
00:44:48,550 --> 00:44:51,500
Preferably name, role and
contact information.

901
00:44:51,500 --> 00:44:53,590
But name and role is really all you need.

902
00:44:53,590 --> 00:44:57,410
The person and
what their role is within the project so

903
00:44:57,410 --> 00:45:00,600
you can keep track of everybody
who's attached to that project.

904
00:45:00,600 --> 00:45:03,610
If you don't get the contact
information that's gonna be difficult.

905
00:45:03,610 --> 00:45:06,460
But really that's the minimum you need.

906
00:45:06,460 --> 00:45:11,150
So let's say, for example, that you're
in a politically sensitive environment.

907
00:45:11,150 --> 00:45:14,629
You don't want to put somebody on here and
throw their classification as resistor and

908
00:45:14,629 --> 00:45:18,059
put manage closely and all of that stuff,
because they're gonna read that document

909
00:45:18,059 --> 00:45:20,350
and say, wait a minute,
are you calling me a resistor?

910
00:45:20,350 --> 00:45:22,130
Who do you think you are?

911
00:45:22,130 --> 00:45:24,400
And you can really ruffle some feathers,
right?

912
00:45:24,400 --> 00:45:27,050
So in that type of an environment
you might say, you know what?

913
00:45:27,050 --> 00:45:29,310
It's not worth even tracking that.

914
00:45:29,310 --> 00:45:32,480
And so you might choose to ditch
that particular column and

915
00:45:32,480 --> 00:45:36,100
just say I don't need that
classification or whatever.

916
00:45:36,100 --> 00:45:38,240
So you may choose to
knock some of these out.

917
00:45:38,240 --> 00:45:40,350
As with all this stuff,
it's designed to be modular.

918
00:45:40,350 --> 00:45:42,360
You pick and choose the pieces you want.

919
00:45:42,360 --> 00:45:45,075
But like I said,
at a minimum you need their name and role.

920
00:45:46,982 --> 00:45:50,170
All right, so now that we've got that,
we've got our stakeholder register,

921
00:45:50,170 --> 00:45:51,570
let me just make sure I save that.

922
00:45:51,570 --> 00:45:56,805
We've got our stakeholder analysis matrix,
and as we go through planning and

923
00:45:56,805 --> 00:45:59,675
we identify more people,
we may have to come back and edit this.

924
00:45:59,675 --> 00:46:02,205
So this is a bit of a living document.

925
00:46:02,205 --> 00:46:05,415
It doesn't have lasting effect
on our project as a whole, so

926
00:46:05,415 --> 00:46:06,665
we don't worry about that too much.

927
00:46:06,665 --> 00:46:08,782
We'll see other documents
where that's not the case.

928
00:46:08,782 --> 00:46:10,622
But I think that pretty much knocks out.

929
00:46:10,622 --> 00:46:13,188
Anything else?

930
00:46:13,188 --> 00:46:14,582
>> That's just about everything.

931
00:46:14,582 --> 00:46:16,192
>> No, that does seem to be it.

932
00:46:16,192 --> 00:46:18,662
So those are the things that
we need to keep in mind.

933
00:46:18,662 --> 00:46:21,570
Just to kind of review a few things.

934
00:46:21,570 --> 00:46:24,400
When we do the identification of people,
we identify what they are,

935
00:46:24,400 --> 00:46:27,520
what their role is,
we also do our assessment.

936
00:46:27,520 --> 00:46:32,450
And with the assessments I was saying
whether we need to manage them closely or

937
00:46:32,450 --> 00:46:34,320
just monitor or whatever.

938
00:46:34,320 --> 00:46:37,370
You might also have other things like

939
00:46:37,370 --> 00:46:42,000
keeping track of what phase in the
lifecycle they have the most interest in.

940
00:46:42,000 --> 00:46:43,960
They might not have interest
in the whole project.

941
00:46:43,960 --> 00:46:48,270
So like, Rob, who's gonna be building
this cabinet for us, he might not care so

942
00:46:48,270 --> 00:46:52,950
much about initiation and
closing and monitoring and analysis.

943
00:46:52,950 --> 00:46:57,810
But planning and execution, right,
he's gonna care about those.

944
00:46:57,810 --> 00:47:00,520
So I might wanna get even that
detailed and start to break that down.

945
00:47:00,520 --> 00:47:04,112
These are all different things that
we can choose to do if necessary.

946
00:47:04,112 --> 00:47:08,819
All right, but otherwise that wraps
up the stakeholder analysis, and

947
00:47:08,819 --> 00:47:11,731
really this wraps up the initiation phase.

948
00:47:11,731 --> 00:47:15,540
Now I want to talk about one last
thing before we wrap up this show,

949
00:47:15,540 --> 00:47:18,480
which is there is a phase called closing.

950
00:47:18,480 --> 00:47:22,180
And the closing phase, a lot of us
think about it in terms of closing

951
00:47:22,180 --> 00:47:24,670
the end of the project, and
that's definitely true.

952
00:47:24,670 --> 00:47:29,540
But you can also use the closing phase
at the end of every other phase.

953
00:47:29,540 --> 00:47:33,150
So we just closed,
we just finished initiation.

954
00:47:33,150 --> 00:47:35,500
We may choose to implement
closing right now.

955
00:47:36,845 --> 00:47:37,989
And that doesn't mean
shut the project down.

956
00:47:37,989 --> 00:47:40,975
It means by closing we go and
double check.

957
00:47:40,975 --> 00:47:42,565
Did all the work get done?

958
00:47:42,565 --> 00:47:45,885
Did all the documents get generated
that should have been documented?

959
00:47:45,885 --> 00:47:49,785
And then we gather the documents and
distribute them to the stakeholders and

960
00:47:49,785 --> 00:47:51,235
say, here's where we're at right now.

961
00:47:51,235 --> 00:47:53,305
We just finished initiation.

962
00:47:53,305 --> 00:47:58,757
So as a part of our project,
as a part of our ITProTV cabinet project,

963
00:47:58,757 --> 00:48:03,363
if I go in here and look,
I have generated four documents,

964
00:48:03,363 --> 00:48:06,183
I generated a project charter, and

965
00:48:06,183 --> 00:48:12,210
I've got two copies because one is
the original and the other one is signed.

966
00:48:12,210 --> 00:48:14,560
So it's a PDF, the one that's signed.

967
00:48:14,560 --> 00:48:20,090
I've got our stakeholder analysis that
we did and our stakeholder register.

968
00:48:20,090 --> 00:48:23,450
Here is our project so
far, these four documents.

969
00:48:23,450 --> 00:48:25,450
Now we're ready to move into planning.

970
00:48:26,680 --> 00:48:29,940
So when we get into that planning phase
we'll see that these service inputs,

971
00:48:29,940 --> 00:48:32,160
we can't get into planning
without doing these first.

972
00:48:32,160 --> 00:48:33,950
Now we're done, we're ready to move on.

973
00:48:35,072 --> 00:48:37,860
All right, well, this is a pretty
good spot for us to stop right here.

974
00:48:37,860 --> 00:48:41,881
We're going to wrap up this show a little
bit early, cuz we're done with a phase and

975
00:48:41,881 --> 00:48:43,898
we're ready to move into the next phase.

976
00:48:43,898 --> 00:48:47,205
Let me just remind everybody if you
have any questions on what we've done,

977
00:48:47,205 --> 00:48:50,890
I know it's been pretty softball so
far, so nothing really challenging.

978
00:48:50,890 --> 00:48:55,420
But if you have any questions, live during
the show you can go to itpro.tv/live and

979
00:48:55,420 --> 00:48:57,980
you'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

980
00:48:57,980 --> 00:48:59,060
Post your questions there.

981
00:48:59,060 --> 00:49:01,070
We monitor and answer during the show.

982
00:49:01,070 --> 00:49:04,360
If you have questions afterwards,
make use of the Q&A forums.

983
00:49:04,360 --> 00:49:05,370
They're there for you.

984
00:49:05,370 --> 00:49:08,680
You click on the Q&A link on
the top of every ITProTV page,

985
00:49:08,680 --> 00:49:11,880
it'll take you into the forums so
you can post your questions.

986
00:49:11,880 --> 00:49:12,860
We monitor and answer.

987
00:49:13,920 --> 00:49:15,340
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed this show.

988
00:49:15,340 --> 00:49:18,630
Stay tuned because we're gonna be coming
back with the planning phase next.

989
00:49:18,630 --> 00:49:21,640
If you're watching live,
it'll probably actually be tomorrow.

990
00:49:21,640 --> 00:49:24,860
So we'll jump into that, start tackling
some of the cool things that are there.

991
00:49:24,860 --> 00:49:25,913
And we'll have some fun with that.

992
00:49:25,913 --> 00:49:28,534
So excitement down the road.

993
00:49:28,534 --> 00:49:32,323
All right, well, ladies and gentlemen,
signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

994
00:49:32,323 --> 00:49:32,969
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

995
00:49:32,969 --> 00:49:34,889
>> And we will see you next time.

996
00:49:34,889 --> 00:49:44,889
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don begin to tackle the most detailed phase of project management, the planning phase. They begin by talking about the purpose of developing a plan and why we need it. The project management plan is the result of developing how to manage the constraints of project time, project costs, project requirements and stakeholders.
episodes.title: Planning Part 1
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,312 --> 00:00:02,145
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:02,145 --> 00:00:02,645
[SOUND]

3
00:00:02,645 --> 00:00:12,645
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,642 --> 00:00:34,610
All right, good morning.

5
00:00:34,610 --> 00:00:35,870
Good afternoon, and good evening.

6
00:00:35,870 --> 00:00:37,180
And welcome back.

7
00:00:37,180 --> 00:00:38,860
To another episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:38,860 --> 00:00:42,200
I'm your host Don Pezet,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:42,200 --> 00:00:43,030
How it going, Ronnie?

10
00:00:43,030 --> 00:00:44,570
>> I am doing well this morning.

11
00:00:44,570 --> 00:00:48,250
My Carmen Electra tattoo
cover up went very well.

12
00:00:48,250 --> 00:00:48,940
>> Excellent.

13
00:00:48,940 --> 00:00:49,940
>> So I'm doing very well.

14
00:00:49,940 --> 00:00:52,260
>> What did you get, a pink unicorn?

15
00:00:52,260 --> 00:00:52,980
>> Two.
>> Two?

16
00:00:52,980 --> 00:00:54,100
>> Two pink unicorns.

17
00:00:54,100 --> 00:00:56,050
>> Pink unicorns butting heads, right,

18
00:00:56,050 --> 00:00:58,365
because that's the manliest
tattoo that we can arrange.

19
00:00:58,365 --> 00:01:02,710
[LAUGH] All right well,
speaking of tattoo cover ups, right.

20
00:01:02,710 --> 00:01:04,160
If you're in that situation,

21
00:01:04,160 --> 00:01:07,725
it's probably because in your life,
you made some bad decisions, right?

22
00:01:07,725 --> 00:01:10,480
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, that was a bad decision.

23
00:01:10,480 --> 00:01:12,150
>> Good decisions don't
lead to tattoo cover ups.

24
00:01:12,150 --> 00:01:12,700
>> There you go.

25
00:01:12,700 --> 00:01:14,310
>> And how could we've avoided that?

26
00:01:14,310 --> 00:01:15,172
WIth good planning.

27
00:01:15,172 --> 00:01:15,700
>> Planning.
[LAUGH]

28
00:01:15,700 --> 00:01:16,620
>> See, this is an awesome segue.

29
00:01:16,620 --> 00:01:20,500
All right, so
in project management we mentioned in

30
00:01:20,500 --> 00:01:23,670
a previous episode that there's
five phases we need to worry about.

31
00:01:23,670 --> 00:01:25,930
Actually, let me bring
up our phases diagram,

32
00:01:25,930 --> 00:01:28,490
I've got that thing sitting
around here some where.

33
00:01:28,490 --> 00:01:32,270
And there we go, our five phases,
I've got the logical diagram here,

34
00:01:32,270 --> 00:01:33,820
which I like a little better anyway.

35
00:01:33,820 --> 00:01:36,062
But Initiation is what we
covered in the last episode,

36
00:01:36,062 --> 00:01:37,340
just kind of getting started.

37
00:01:37,340 --> 00:01:37,890
>> Right.

38
00:01:37,890 --> 00:01:40,180
And the next one is Planning.

39
00:01:40,180 --> 00:01:43,860
There is no substitute for good planning.

40
00:01:43,860 --> 00:01:46,240
You need to dedicate some time to this.

41
00:01:46,240 --> 00:01:51,000
In fact, in many projects,
you'll spend more time Planning,

42
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:55,280
than you actually do in Execution,
Monitoring, Controlling, and Closing.

43
00:01:55,280 --> 00:01:59,070
The bulk of your time is spent here and
I know I've used NASA as an example a few

44
00:01:59,070 --> 00:02:03,150
times, just because they're
high visibility projects.

45
00:02:03,150 --> 00:02:06,610
When they send a rocket into
space to deploy a satellite,

46
00:02:06,610 --> 00:02:10,320
that mission takes three, four days, but

47
00:02:10,320 --> 00:02:11,780
it might have had years
>> Years.

48
00:02:11,780 --> 00:02:14,460
>> Of planning leading up to it
because they wanna make sure they have

49
00:02:14,460 --> 00:02:15,750
the best information possible.

50
00:02:15,750 --> 00:02:17,170
Now, in the private sector,

51
00:02:17,170 --> 00:02:19,830
we don't normally have years to
make something happen, right.

52
00:02:19,830 --> 00:02:24,650
Especially not in IT, time will pass us
by, so we typically have to be faster.

53
00:02:24,650 --> 00:02:28,230
But you still wanna make sure
you perform adequate planning.

54
00:02:28,230 --> 00:02:32,200
Good planning now can save you from
that tattoo cover up later on, right?

55
00:02:32,200 --> 00:02:32,730
>> Yeah.

56
00:02:32,730 --> 00:02:35,850
Many project managers will
pretty much tell you that

57
00:02:35,850 --> 00:02:38,460
projects don't really fail at the end.

58
00:02:38,460 --> 00:02:40,260
When you talk about the idea
of project failure,

59
00:02:40,260 --> 00:02:41,540
it normally happens at the beginning.

60
00:02:41,540 --> 00:02:43,630
In other words, during the planning stage.

61
00:02:43,630 --> 00:02:46,780
That we're not careful here, if we don't
try to get as much information as we can

62
00:02:46,780 --> 00:02:49,950
here, that's where the project
really begins to fail.

63
00:02:49,950 --> 00:02:53,590
So it is really actually for
our sake right, important

64
00:02:53,590 --> 00:02:56,790
that we actually understand everything
that we can about the Planning stage.

65
00:02:56,790 --> 00:02:57,420
>> Yep.

66
00:02:57,420 --> 00:02:59,565
>> And
>> And so the PMI recognizes this.

67
00:02:59,565 --> 00:03:03,295
>> Yeah.
>> And they address it with a process

68
00:03:03,295 --> 00:03:04,095
all itself.

69
00:03:04,095 --> 00:03:05,935
And this is a super important one.

70
00:03:05,935 --> 00:03:08,365
Let me pull the PMBOK up here.

71
00:03:08,365 --> 00:03:09,205
Here we go.

72
00:03:09,205 --> 00:03:10,565
So when we take a look at,

73
00:03:10,565 --> 00:03:15,930
you know yesterday or last episode,
we wrapped up initiating, so that's done.

74
00:03:15,930 --> 00:03:17,520
Now we're moving into Planning.

75
00:03:17,520 --> 00:03:22,510
The very first process group that
we have here, or the first process,

76
00:03:22,510 --> 00:03:26,552
is the develop Project Management Plan,
all right?

77
00:03:26,552 --> 00:03:28,160
This is kind of a funny one and

78
00:03:28,160 --> 00:03:31,150
you're going to see this
throughout the processes.

79
00:03:31,150 --> 00:03:34,990
Anytime you see that word, develop a plan.

80
00:03:34,990 --> 00:03:38,380
That doesn't mean we're actually
planning for our project.

81
00:03:38,380 --> 00:03:40,586
We're planning, [LAUGH] what have I done?

82
00:03:40,586 --> 00:03:41,510
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're planning for

83
00:03:41,510 --> 00:03:43,660
projects in general, right?

84
00:03:43,660 --> 00:03:46,630
So we're saying we need
to come up with a plan of

85
00:03:46,630 --> 00:03:49,610
how we're going to manage our project.

86
00:03:49,610 --> 00:03:50,210
Right?
So,

87
00:03:50,210 --> 00:03:52,660
it doesn't matter what the project is,
per se.

88
00:03:52,660 --> 00:03:55,010
There are little variations
from project to project, but

89
00:03:55,010 --> 00:03:58,852
just overall,
how are we going to manage this project?

90
00:03:58,852 --> 00:03:59,850
All right?

91
00:03:59,850 --> 00:04:02,290
So they call that developing
the Project Management Plan.

92
00:04:02,290 --> 00:04:05,270
And what it is is
a collection of safeguards,

93
00:04:05,270 --> 00:04:08,660
to make sure that we've taken a look at
all the things that we need to look at.

94
00:04:08,660 --> 00:04:09,870
That we've done our due diligence.

95
00:04:09,870 --> 00:04:13,310
That we've gathered the information
we needed, before we make decisions.

96
00:04:13,310 --> 00:04:17,110
So we ensure that we're doing
the proper level of Planning.

97
00:04:17,110 --> 00:04:20,090
You don't have to do this process,
you can leave this off.

98
00:04:20,090 --> 00:04:22,520
Say, screw it,
I'm going to fly by the seat of my pants.

99
00:04:22,520 --> 00:04:23,720
You can do that.

100
00:04:23,720 --> 00:04:28,030
But then halfway through the project, when
you realize, I really should have sent out

101
00:04:28,030 --> 00:04:32,470
some quotes and bids, I should have had
a backup seller in case one fell through.

102
00:04:32,470 --> 00:04:35,810
Then you'll say oh, I wish I would have
thought about that back in Planning.

103
00:04:35,810 --> 00:04:39,260
If you've got a good
Project Management Plan in place,

104
00:04:39,260 --> 00:04:40,950
then you'll know to do
that stuff early on.

105
00:04:40,950 --> 00:04:42,480
You'll know if your missing something,

106
00:04:42,480 --> 00:04:45,870
and you can take care of that before
it becomes an issue down the road.

107
00:04:45,870 --> 00:04:47,020
Really important.

108
00:04:47,020 --> 00:04:48,820
>> Yeah.
To tell you'll how important this is

109
00:04:48,820 --> 00:04:50,850
to the idea of PMI, right.

110
00:04:50,850 --> 00:04:54,340
Of those 47 actual actions that we can do,
okay,

111
00:04:54,340 --> 00:04:58,185
24 of them reside in this
particular group here.

112
00:04:58,185 --> 00:05:01,300
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I mean, you can't say that hey,

113
00:05:01,300 --> 00:05:03,570
they didn't emphasize this enough.

114
00:05:03,570 --> 00:05:07,310
So if 24 out of the 47
actually reside here and

115
00:05:07,310 --> 00:05:10,350
the rest of them are actually divided
over the other process groups,

116
00:05:10,350 --> 00:05:13,190
you gotta realize that this is by far
the most important thing we're gonna do.

117
00:05:13,190 --> 00:05:14,580
>> Did you count those Ronnie or
did you read them?

00:05:14,580 --> 00:05:15,603
>> I did.

00:05:15,603 --> 00:05:16,263
That's awesome.

120
00:05:16,263 --> 00:05:18,170
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,
when I read it I was like, no,

121
00:05:18,170 --> 00:05:20,442
that's not true, oh, it is, it is true.

122
00:05:20,442 --> 00:05:21,720
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right,

123
00:05:21,720 --> 00:05:24,060
so obviously we gotta lot of
effort here in Planning and

124
00:05:24,060 --> 00:05:29,645
it all starts right here with coming up
with the plan for our planning, right?

125
00:05:29,645 --> 00:05:33,210
[LAUGH] So it's develop
a Project Management Plan, and

126
00:05:33,210 --> 00:05:35,860
it looks like a very
simple little process,

127
00:05:35,860 --> 00:05:40,040
but the challenge with this process
is how many outputs it has.

128
00:05:40,040 --> 00:05:43,150
Let me go back to my diagram, and

129
00:05:43,150 --> 00:05:47,800
if we go into our Develop a Project
Management Plan, we've got our inputs that

130
00:05:47,800 --> 00:05:50,870
feed into it which is really all
the data we have at this point.

131
00:05:50,870 --> 00:05:52,060
>> Yeah.
>> Now if we just initiated,

132
00:05:52,060 --> 00:05:54,410
we probably don't have a lot of input.

133
00:05:54,410 --> 00:05:56,320
We have a project charter, right?

134
00:05:56,320 --> 00:05:59,340
We gotta have that to, don't go into
Planning without a Project Charter.

135
00:05:59,340 --> 00:06:00,790
So we should have that.

136
00:06:00,790 --> 00:06:03,740
And Enterprise Environmental Factors,
Organizational Process Assets,

137
00:06:03,740 --> 00:06:05,250
those are ones we've already talked about.

138
00:06:05,250 --> 00:06:08,780
But then you see this,
output from other processes.

139
00:06:08,780 --> 00:06:11,770
Well, we've only had two processes so
far and

140
00:06:11,770 --> 00:06:15,950
their output was the Project Charter and
it was basically what we created and

141
00:06:15,950 --> 00:06:20,040
a brief look at a,
like a requirements document,

142
00:06:20,040 --> 00:06:23,150
not anything heavy, and
that really ended up in the charter too.

143
00:06:23,150 --> 00:06:26,530
So what are they talking about there when
they say Output from Other Processes?

144
00:06:26,530 --> 00:06:32,560
Well they're talking about Output
from Other Planning Processes.

145
00:06:32,560 --> 00:06:36,530
So if we look down here develop
a Project Management Plan,

146
00:06:36,530 --> 00:06:40,010
that plan is made up of
several other subplans.

147
00:06:40,010 --> 00:06:42,360
And, Ronnie,
you listed them in the notes, didn't you?

148
00:06:42,360 --> 00:06:43,170
>> Yeah.

149
00:06:43,170 --> 00:06:44,250
Here.

150
00:06:44,250 --> 00:06:47,380
So the Project Management Plan is
what we're going to be creating.

151
00:06:47,380 --> 00:06:50,830
That's our output and
it looks really simple right here.

152
00:06:50,830 --> 00:06:54,030
Just Project Management Plan,
easy one output, that's it.

153
00:06:54,030 --> 00:06:58,660
But it's made up of subplans
that are all these things.

154
00:06:58,660 --> 00:07:03,260
Your Scope Management Plan, your
Requirements, Schedule, Cost, Quality.

155
00:07:03,260 --> 00:07:06,740
All these individual plans that
say how you're going to manage

156
00:07:06,740 --> 00:07:10,430
that particular aspect of your project,
all right?

157
00:07:10,430 --> 00:07:12,490
So cost,
how am I going to going to manage that?

158
00:07:12,490 --> 00:07:15,940
How am I going to manage coming up with
estimates for what things are going cost?

159
00:07:15,940 --> 00:07:18,434
How am I going to manage

160
00:07:18,434 --> 00:07:19,360
Tracking it?

161
00:07:19,360 --> 00:07:20,820
Who is going to be writing the checks?

162
00:07:20,820 --> 00:07:22,199
How do I handle all of that stuff?

163
00:07:23,210 --> 00:07:27,160
Well your Cost Management Plan
will tell you exactly

164
00:07:27,160 --> 00:07:30,690
how you're supposed to manage the cost and
how you're supposed to handle that.

165
00:07:30,690 --> 00:07:33,080
And so you would just take

166
00:07:33,080 --> 00:07:36,720
go down and fill out the information
as it pertains to your project.

167
00:07:36,720 --> 00:07:38,410
And now you would know how that works.

168
00:07:38,410 --> 00:07:41,280
And that would become a part of
your Project Management Plan,

169
00:07:41,280 --> 00:07:44,840
so building this is a lot of work.

170
00:07:44,840 --> 00:07:48,680
I might not be able to build that
Cost Management Plan right now.

171
00:07:48,680 --> 00:07:51,060
I might need to go and
take a look at my costs.

172
00:07:51,060 --> 00:07:51,992
I haven't even looked at them yet, right?

173
00:07:51,992 --> 00:07:55,880
And if we go here,
we'll see down in cost, right?

174
00:07:55,880 --> 00:08:00,514
Project Cost Management,
you'll see in here Plan cost management.

175
00:08:00,514 --> 00:08:04,714
That is coming up with that particular

176
00:08:04,714 --> 00:08:08,660
which will become a part of

177
00:08:08,660 --> 00:08:11,360
So you don't just sit down and say,

00:08:11,360 --> 00:08:14,330
I'm gonna whip out a project
management plan like this.

179
00:08:14,330 --> 00:08:17,060
No, you're gonna have to come
back to this several times.

180
00:08:17,060 --> 00:08:20,446
So you might do a quick draft that's very,
very simple, maybe one page.

00:08:20,446 --> 00:08:23,726
And then as you go through
these other processes,

00:08:23,726 --> 00:08:27,250
you come back to the management plan and

00:08:28,970 --> 00:08:33,700
That's what happens if we have absolutely

00:08:33,700 --> 00:08:36,800
if this is the first formal project

00:08:36,800 --> 00:08:37,350

00:08:38,480 --> 00:08:41,460
But for

00:08:41,460 --> 00:08:45,000
Most companies already have formal

00:08:45,000 --> 00:08:49,410

00:08:49,410 --> 00:08:51,730

They've already got these drawn up, and

00:08:58,850 --> 00:09:01,850
So when we look at this

00:09:01,850 --> 00:09:06,410
this first entry here, this 4.2 develop

00:09:06,410 --> 00:09:11,500
referring to companies that already

00:09:11,500 --> 00:09:15,630
All we do, and this would be

196
00:09:15,630 --> 00:09:17,260
our company already has it.

00:09:17,260 --> 00:09:21,385
We go to our PMO or

00:09:24,700 --> 00:09:28,240

00:09:28,240 --> 00:09:31,250
They'll give you what

00:09:31,250 --> 00:09:33,940
It will contain all of this stuff.

00:09:33,940 --> 00:09:39,840
The overall project management plan as

00:09:39,840 --> 00:09:44,260
requirements management, all of these
other things, and maybe others.

204
00:09:44,260 --> 00:09:46,920
We've got that May Include Others.

00:09:46,920 --> 00:09:50,800
So they'll give you this booklet

00:09:50,800 --> 00:09:55,960
you then just have to go through and fill

207
00:09:57,080 --> 00:09:59,470
So in that environment,

00:09:59,470 --> 00:10:03,480
you might be able to just get started

00:10:04,850 --> 00:10:08,660
But if this is the very first time,

00:10:08,660 --> 00:10:10,800
nobody else in the company

00:10:10,800 --> 00:10:14,380

00:10:14,380 --> 00:10:15,480

I am not going to start here with a

00:10:21,560 --> 00:10:25,010
So then you skip it and

00:10:25,010 --> 00:10:27,020
You start working on them.

00:10:27,020 --> 00:10:32,460
And as you work on them, each one, if you
look down the line here, see how each one,

00:10:32,460 --> 00:10:36,000
plan scope management, plan schedule
management, plan cost management,

219
00:10:36,000 --> 00:10:38,860
plan quality management,
plan human resources management,

00:10:38,860 --> 00:10:43,370
each one is generating

00:10:43,370 --> 00:10:47,170
And so you may move through each knowledge
area, over here on the left side,

222
00:10:47,170 --> 00:10:48,860
these are our knowledge areas.

223
00:10:48,860 --> 00:10:54,220
You might move through each knowledge
area, and create a plan one by one.

224
00:10:54,220 --> 00:10:59,360
And when you're done, you then combine all
of those plans into one big super plan,

225
00:10:59,360 --> 00:11:03,070
and that's what fulfills the needs

226
00:11:04,557 --> 00:11:08,230
So one of the things I wanna make
sure I drive home with you guys,

227
00:11:08,230 --> 00:11:09,740
that everybody has
a good understanding of,

228
00:11:09,740 --> 00:11:14,410
is while the project has a certain
chronological order that it follows,

229
00:11:14,410 --> 00:11:18,440
initiate then plan then execute and
monitor at the same time then close.

00:11:18,440 --> 00:11:21,210
Because that's the kind of
normal processes we follow,

231
00:11:21,210 --> 00:11:26,540
that's fine up there at

But inside of a phase it's

233
00:11:30,940 --> 00:11:34,080
So you might be jumping way

234
00:11:34,080 --> 00:11:36,290

00:11:36,290 --> 00:11:38,080
It's not the greatest idea, but you can.

236
00:11:38,080 --> 00:11:40,860
So you might be moving things around, or
they might be happening at the same time,

237
00:11:40,860 --> 00:11:42,590
you have different teams planning.

238
00:11:42,590 --> 00:11:45,150
These are all things that

239

All right, so let's pretend,
Ronnie, that we've got a project

The first thing that you're

So I've been kind of

00:12:56,019 --> 00:12:58,980

So if we look here just kind of looking

That there's no one temple that

And it's really simple,

00:13:46,400 --> 00:13:48,370

Now we haven't really

We need to have a methodology of

What steps can we take?

00:14:18,590 --> 00:14:23,266
Well, we might just go and follow

00:14:23,266 --> 00:14:24,660

00:14:24,660 --> 00:14:26,170

00:14:32,445 --> 00:14:33,524

00:14:33,524 --> 00:14:36,740
Plan scope management,

00:14:47,460 --> 00:14:48,490

00:14:53,401 --> 00:14:58,930
So in that plan I would specify what tools

00:14:58,930 --> 00:15:00,370

00:15:00,370 --> 00:15:05,190
So we put in here run

00:15:05,190 --> 00:15:11,020

00:15:11,020 --> 00:15:14,270
A very simple general thing just

Just think like who, what, when,

Except the when and where is gonna

How do we create our

[LAUGH] Our WBS structure,

>> How do we create a work breakdown

structure dictionary and

How do we do scope baseline maintenance?

In other words,

00:15:52,220 --> 00:15:55,920
What defines the methods that allow for

00:15:55,920 --> 00:15:57,810
If I say the project is done, I'm done!

00:15:57,810 --> 00:15:58,935
That means I've finished something.

00:15:58,935 --> 00:16:02,662

Well, what are the criteria for

00:16:06,678 --> 00:16:09,060
Cuz they might say, no, it's not done.

00:16:10,740 --> 00:16:14,300
And now you're left saying, well, I think

322
00:16:14,300 --> 00:16:14,800
What do we do?

00:16:14,800 --> 00:16:16,370

00:16:16,370 --> 00:16:20,600
So we would need to define what it is

00:16:22,010 --> 00:16:24,680
And then scope and

00:16:24,680 --> 00:16:28,510
Scope and requirements, we'll see this in

Well, that's not always possible.

Especially in software development

00:16:38,370 --> 00:16:40,450
tiny very specific requirements.

00:16:40,450 --> 00:16:44,320
So we break them down into pieces and

00:16:44,320 --> 00:16:48,720
How are they integrated when I measure
acceptance, am I measuring it just to get

00:16:48,720 --> 00:16:52,640

00:16:53,920 --> 00:16:57,150
We define that here,

Here's how we make that decision, right?

00:16:59,610 --> 00:17:02,890
We're not actually putting the scope

339
00:17:02,890 --> 00:17:05,820

340
00:17:05,820 --> 00:17:07,110
How do we manage the requirements?

00:17:08,290 --> 00:17:10,540
That's what these plans are all about.

342
00:17:10,540 --> 00:17:13,958
And the key thing to remember

343
00:17:13,958 --> 00:17:18,520
Because once you've develop them one time,
you can reuse them over and

344
00:17:18,520 --> 00:17:20,340
over and
over again in all of your other projects.

00:17:20,340 --> 00:17:22,840
You might have to make
minor tweaks to deal

00:17:22,840 --> 00:17:24,710

00:17:24,710 --> 00:17:29,030
But for the most part, you'll find where

00:17:29,030 --> 00:17:30,580
And it's very, very handy.

00:17:30,580 --> 00:17:32,280
And that's where these templates

00:17:32,280 --> 00:17:34,760
That's why I wanted to make

Right?

See if my navigation skills

00:17:44,400 --> 00:17:49,220
So we've got the scope management plan,

And so that's the next one here,

>> Yeah.

Nate says, I want an arcade cabinet, but

>> So, in my collection,

I might have a statement that says,

00:18:32,175 --> 00:18:35,765
Step two,
bounce that off of subject matter expert

00:18:35,765 --> 00:18:40,660
to verify whether that's complete,

00:18:40,660 --> 00:18:43,130
And you see this in web

00:18:43,130 --> 00:18:44,570
Somebody says I want a website.

00:18:44,570 --> 00:18:46,910
And then they want menus

00:18:49,800 --> 00:18:53,063
And then that's their requirement, and

00:18:53,063 --> 00:18:55,370

00:18:55,370 --> 00:18:58,390

00:18:58,390 --> 00:18:59,760

Does the website need to be responsive

00:19:05,940 --> 00:19:07,730

All these questions come up, right?

Well, we need those answers before

00:19:13,620 --> 00:19:15,530

00:19:15,530 --> 00:19:20,230
So, those are requirements that the

00:19:20,230 --> 00:19:21,050

00:19:21,050 --> 00:19:23,470
we now need to go back to

So we put that in our

Do we need to go through,

00:19:37,180 --> 00:19:39,095

All right, how we're gonna handle analysis

Analysis is just looking at them to

00:19:51,229 --> 00:19:53,170
>> Yeah.
>> Categories.

400
00:19:53,170 --> 00:19:54,350
You'll have some requirements.

401
00:19:54,350 --> 00:19:58,480
I think we were talking about it before
the show where I said a lot of times I'll

402
00:19:58,480 --> 00:20:03,370
have primary requirements, secondary
requirements and optional requirements.

403
00:20:03,370 --> 00:20:05,670
Primary, those are the ones

404
00:20:05,670 --> 00:20:07,410
We've got to get these done.

405
00:20:07,410 --> 00:20:11,360
Secondary ones are ones that we would like
to achieve that can change if necessary.

406
00:20:11,360 --> 00:20:14,880
If things start running behind schedule
we might be able to eliminate them, but

407
00:20:14,880 --> 00:20:16,580
the things that we'd like to achieve.

408
00:20:16,580 --> 00:20:20,810
And then optional requirements are if
things are running perfect let's try and

409
00:20:20,810 --> 00:20:22,040

00:20:22,040 --> 00:20:24,280
But if we don't,
they're the first things to cut.

00:20:24,280 --> 00:20:27,790
We're not worried about it, we can always
do that in version 2.0 or whatever.

00:20:27,790 --> 00:20:30,020

00:20:30,020 --> 00:20:31,360

00:20:31,360 --> 00:20:35,250
Who makes the decision over what's

00:20:35,250 --> 00:20:38,590
So we define that structure here.

00:20:38,590 --> 00:20:41,860
Not saying in our project,

00:20:41,860 --> 00:20:43,060
That's not for this document.

00:20:43,060 --> 00:20:43,980
This is the plan.

00:20:46,410 --> 00:20:50,320
What documentation is required

00:20:50,320 --> 00:20:52,020
What do we need to get from people, right?

00:20:52,020 --> 00:20:54,270
Do we need to get it in writing?

00:20:54,270 --> 00:20:55,225
Is it just a phone call?

00:20:55,225 --> 00:20:59,270
Cuz a phone call, man, it's hard
to get signatures on a phone call.

424
00:20:59,270 --> 00:21:02,440
>> Right.
>> So, what documentation is necessary to

425
00:21:02,440 --> 00:21:05,900
collect requirements and
then have them stored and accepted?

426
00:21:05,900 --> 00:21:07,230
Prioritization.

427
00:21:07,230 --> 00:21:10,320
If you've got more than one set of,
or more than one requirement,

428
00:21:10,320 --> 00:21:12,480
which ones are the most important,
which ones are the least.

429
00:21:12,480 --> 00:21:14,870
That way we can do our
scheduling appropriately.

430
00:21:14,870 --> 00:21:17,050
For high priority requirements,

431
00:21:17,050 --> 00:21:20,440
you might assign some extra
resources to guarantee success.

432
00:21:20,440 --> 00:21:24,240
For low priority requirements you
might assign the minimum resources

433
00:21:24,240 --> 00:21:26,480
knowing that if they don't succeed
it's not the end of the world.

434
00:21:28,030 --> 00:21:28,960
>> Yeah.
>> Metrics,

435
00:21:28,960 --> 00:21:30,990
how do we measure the requirements?

436
00:21:30,990 --> 00:21:32,770
A lot of requirements are really easy.

437
00:21:32,770 --> 00:21:36,520
Hey, I want a form on my website and
when somebody hits submit,

438
00:21:36,520 --> 00:21:38,530
I want it to send me an email.

00:21:38,530 --> 00:21:41,470
Well, if I hit submit,

440
00:21:41,470 --> 00:21:43,080
Yes, it worked.

441
00:21:43,080 --> 00:21:44,060
No, it didn't.

442
00:21:44,060 --> 00:21:46,630
So a lot of metrics
are really easy to measure.

443
00:21:46,630 --> 00:21:48,450
Some are harder though.

444
00:21:48,450 --> 00:21:50,515
I want my website to look modern.

445
00:21:50,515 --> 00:21:52,600
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay,

446
00:21:52,600 --> 00:21:55,990
well who's the judge of what looks modern,
right?

447
00:21:55,990 --> 00:21:57,670
So that's a subjective thing.

448
00:21:57,670 --> 00:22:02,930
So we have to put in here in our plan
that anything that's subjective,

449
00:22:02,930 --> 00:22:04,320
we need to come up with
a way to measure it.

450
00:22:04,320 --> 00:22:05,720
So everything's got to be measurable.

451
00:22:05,720 --> 00:22:10,530
So, we say all right, for any subjective
thing we're gonna use focus groups.

452
00:22:10,530 --> 00:22:16,833
And, with the focus groups,
we need an opinion rate of 75% or higher.

453
00:22:16,833 --> 00:22:21,630
So, 75% of the polled people in
the focus groups say, yeah, look modern.

454
00:22:21,630 --> 00:22:23,550
Then that counts, right?

455
00:22:23,550 --> 00:22:25,108
And so how do we measure that?

456
00:22:25,108 --> 00:22:28,500
And we can take things that
are subjective, and turn them into

457
00:22:28,500 --> 00:22:34,040
quantifiable numerical values that we
can represent and use to gauge success.

458
00:22:34,040 --> 00:22:38,800
Real important that you get buy in on this
stuff from the sponsor, because again,

459
00:22:38,800 --> 00:22:39,980
it's subjective.

460
00:22:39,980 --> 00:22:45,880
You could have a website that 100% of your
focus group attendees say looks modern.

461
00:22:45,880 --> 00:22:49,970
But if the sponsor looks at it and
says, that looks like 1997.

462
00:22:49,970 --> 00:22:52,690
Well, you gonna argue with the sponsor?

463
00:22:52,690 --> 00:22:54,760
But if you have it in paper,
here's how we measure it,

464
00:22:54,760 --> 00:22:57,510
the focus groups agree, this is modern.

465
00:22:57,510 --> 00:22:59,550
That's the kind of thing that
you have to worry about.

466
00:23:02,200 --> 00:23:04,050
Traceability structure.

467
00:23:04,050 --> 00:23:08,100
When we have requirements,
requirements get tied to other things.

00:23:08,100 --> 00:23:11,210

They're tied to the testing that verifies

470
00:23:16,250 --> 00:23:21,485

traceability to keep all of this intact.

471

You also have like billing
that you need to track too,

472
00:23:24,295 --> 00:23:28,465
like you're having to pay different people
to create these various requirements,

473
00:23:28,465 --> 00:23:30,735
to create the deliverable
from the requirement, and

474
00:23:30,735 --> 00:23:35,035
so where is that getting billed, code of

475
00:23:35,035 --> 00:23:36,870
We need to keep track of that, so.

00:23:36,870 --> 00:23:42,300
We define right here again how we're

477
00:23:42,300 --> 00:23:45,570
which ties into tracking,and reporting.

Those are all kinda tied
right together right there.

00:23:47,920 --> 00:23:50,440
Tractability, tracking, and reporting.

480
00:23:50,440 --> 00:23:54,690
Traceability and tracking, keeping
a record of how all this ties together.

481
00:23:54,690 --> 00:23:57,490
And the reporting, how we're gonna
output information about it.

482
00:23:57,490 --> 00:24:02,156
So, when a requirement is met,
we know that because we've got our.

483
00:24:02,156 --> 00:24:03,875
Tracking and traceability.

00:24:06,174 --> 00:24:10,100
Are we going to be sending emails,

What tools are available for

00:24:13,370 --> 00:24:15,280
Cuz, you'll find in high

If it's a medical project and you're

email is not a tool that's available, and

00:24:27,190 --> 00:24:28,820
Validation, right?

492

We say we've met the requirement,

00:24:31,960 --> 00:24:36,060
So, again, the tools and techniques and
stuff that's available to us for

00:24:36,060 --> 00:24:37,280

00:24:37,280 --> 00:24:39,380

Configuration and change management

If they are not properly followed, they

00:37:04,950 --> 00:37:08,950
he has a saying, which is,
you don't know what you don't know, right?

00:37:08,950 --> 00:37:12,770
So we need to recognize when we

into a system with it.

742
00:37:14,740 --> 00:37:16,980
So problem solving may
not be something we do.

743
00:37:16,980 --> 00:37:19,640
We might solve the problem by hiring
somebody else to solve the problem.

744
00:37:20,850 --> 00:37:23,980
>> And last lastly your favorite,
the idea of the meeting.

745
00:37:23,980 --> 00:37:25,860
>> Yep
>> Meeting facilitation for

00:37:25,860 --> 00:37:28,400
us is actually a very important part of it
>> Once again,

747
00:37:28,400 --> 00:37:31,320
making sure that the meeting moves,
making sure that we actually do have

748
00:37:31,320 --> 00:37:33,960
action items that are actually gonna
be accomplished at the end here.

749
00:37:33,960 --> 00:37:36,780
These are all goals that we

00:37:36,780 --> 00:37:40,990
to help us to come up with that

00:37:40,990 --> 00:37:41,870
And again,

00:37:41,870 --> 00:37:45,110

00:37:45,110 --> 00:37:45,630
>> Yep.

754
00:37:45,630 --> 00:37:46,650
>> Yeah.

755
00:37:46,650 --> 00:37:48,500
So that's all gonna happen there, and

00:37:48,500 --> 00:37:52,120
then basically we feed all

757
00:37:52,120 --> 00:37:53,670
We may have to do several revisions,

758
00:37:53,670 --> 00:37:56,430
this is where the version numbers

759
00:37:56,430 --> 00:37:59,210
Because I might have a cost

00:37:59,210 --> 00:38:02,672
but then we make some adjustments,

00:38:02,672 --> 00:38:05,260
And when we have a meeting,
we need to announce that and say,

00:38:05,260 --> 00:38:09,817
okay today we're going to be taking a look
at cost management plan version 1.3.

00:38:09,817 --> 00:38:11,820
Does everybody have 1.3?

764
00:38:11,820 --> 00:38:14,590
Oh you still have 1.2,
let me give you the updated copy, right?

765
00:38:14,590 --> 00:38:18,020
You make sure that everybody's
working from the same data and

766
00:38:18,020 --> 00:38:22,310
that there all kind of in sync right,
that's the important part.

767
00:38:22,310 --> 00:38:24,080
When it's all said and done.

768
00:38:24,080 --> 00:38:26,960
This is gonna get put in to your
overall Project Management Plan.

769
00:38:26,960 --> 00:38:31,140
And if you are a small company, your
Project Management Plan may not exist,

00:38:31,140 --> 00:38:33,040
you might just be flying by the.

00:38:33,040 --> 00:38:35,760
They might be one page just

00:38:35,760 --> 00:38:37,820
But if this is a high dollar project,

00:38:37,820 --> 00:38:41,030
if this is something that's in
a very formalized environment.

774
00:38:41,030 --> 00:38:44,900
Your Project Management Plan may be
called a Project Management Book.

00:38:44,900 --> 00:38:46,600
There are companies that call it that.

00:38:46,600 --> 00:38:48,370
And it may be a spiral bound book or

something like that that
is 100 pages 200 pages.

00:38:50,690 --> 00:38:54,720
But it's basically saying here's how you

779
00:38:54,720 --> 00:38:57,400
as a project manager need
to act on this project.

780
00:38:57,400 --> 00:39:02,220
So they do that because if they
hire new project managers,

781
00:39:02,220 --> 00:39:05,370
how does the new project manager
know how our company does business.

782
00:39:05,370 --> 00:39:06,800
Well they have to learn it, and

783
00:39:06,800 --> 00:39:09,880
if we want them to learn fast we've
already got a book that shows them.

784
00:39:09,880 --> 00:39:11,910
You give them our Project Management Plan.

785
00:39:11,910 --> 00:39:14,660
We say here is how we manage projects.

786
00:39:14,660 --> 00:39:18,650
And in that book you have all of
these management plans that we're

787
00:39:18,650 --> 00:39:20,736
talking about cost,
schedule, human resources.

788
00:39:20,736 --> 00:39:21,861
All that stuff to find in there.

789
00:39:21,861 --> 00:39:23,160
How we manage it.

790
00:39:23,160 --> 00:39:25,600
And you put all your
templates in that book.

791
00:39:25,600 --> 00:39:28,800
Here's the templates for all the forms and
things that you might use.

792
00:39:28,800 --> 00:39:31,890
Here's how we like to have them arranged,
right?

793
00:39:31,890 --> 00:39:34,660
At your last company, you might have
had a template that you used for

794
00:39:34,660 --> 00:39:36,860
scope statements, and
it might have been great.

795
00:39:36,860 --> 00:39:37,850
But that's not the one we use.

796
00:39:37,850 --> 00:39:40,540
We use a consistent form here,
here's the form.

797
00:39:40,540 --> 00:39:43,350
FIll it out,
make sure you follow our method, right?

798
00:39:43,350 --> 00:39:47,450
Consistency across projects makes
monitoring and governance so

799
00:39:47,450 --> 00:39:48,300
much easier, right?

800
00:39:48,300 --> 00:39:50,130
So much more possible, all right.

801
00:39:50,130 --> 00:39:54,684
So that's an important thing, this gets
put together and you have the generic

802
00:39:54,684 --> 00:39:58,895
plan that's a part of your company's
organizational process assets.

803
00:39:58,895 --> 00:40:02,800
But you may also have to create
a custom one just for your project,

804
00:40:02,800 --> 00:40:04,650
if it's different.

805
00:40:04,650 --> 00:40:06,480
If that's the case,
then you gotta do that.

806
00:40:06,480 --> 00:40:07,710
You gotta revise it.

807
00:40:07,710 --> 00:40:08,850
Make sure it meets your needs.

808
00:40:08,850 --> 00:40:13,040
If it's some kind of improvement, maybe
you push that improvement to the general

809
00:40:13,040 --> 00:40:15,930
plan that applies to your company but
if its just for this

810
00:40:15,930 --> 00:40:20,080
project you modify there and it becomes
part of your project modifications.

811
00:40:20,080 --> 00:40:24,930
When you rap up this project,
at the end when everything is done.

812
00:40:24,930 --> 00:40:27,380
We're gonna put together
our project archive.

813
00:40:27,380 --> 00:40:31,570
It's a collection of all the data
that we generated during our project.

814
00:40:31,570 --> 00:40:35,960
And this project management plan should
be one of the very first things in there.

815
00:40:35,960 --> 00:40:38,600
It's not going to be the first but,
you know charter's there.

816
00:40:38,600 --> 00:40:43,310
But it's going to be one of the first
things because we use that to gauge

817
00:40:43,310 --> 00:40:46,830

818
00:40:46,830 --> 00:40:48,430
And when there's a failure.

819

A lot of times you can trace that
failure back to not following the plan.

820
00:40:52,050 --> 00:40:52,960
>> Yeah.
>> You know?

821
00:40:52,960 --> 00:40:56,030
The proper form wasn't submitted
with the proper information.

822
00:40:56,030 --> 00:41:01,140
Well in the plan, it defined what form to
use and what information to put on there.

823
00:41:01,140 --> 00:41:02,170
We just didn't do it.

824
00:41:02,170 --> 00:41:04,570
>> Yeah.
>> So there's where our failure started.

825
00:41:05,940 --> 00:41:07,620
So definitely important stuff.

826
00:41:07,620 --> 00:41:10,590
All part of that project management plan.

827
00:41:10,590 --> 00:41:14,010
All right, well, once we've got that
in place, or if we've already got it,

00:41:14,010 --> 00:41:15,700

00:41:15,700 --> 00:41:16,780
Now we're ready to get to work.

00:41:16,780 --> 00:41:20,450
Now, if you've already got it for your

831
00:41:20,450 --> 00:41:23,720
If you have to create it yourself, you
probably haven't created it at this point.

832
00:41:23,720 --> 00:41:25,210
Right?
We have an idea now.

833
00:41:25,210 --> 00:41:26,370
We have a collection of templates.

That's great.

But now we got a lot of work ahead of us.

So what we're gonna do is in the upcoming

Like the next one that we're gonna

00:41:43,920 --> 00:41:46,580
what goes in there,
how we manage the scope and all that.

842
00:41:46,580 --> 00:41:49,700
And we talk about that scope
management plan what goes in and

00:41:49,700 --> 00:41:50,970
how we manage the scope.

00:41:50,970 --> 00:41:53,480
And so we'll kind of create
that as we go along the way.

845
00:41:53,480 --> 00:41:56,530
And then that all gets gathered
together in to this overall

00:41:56,530 --> 00:41:58,090

847
00:41:58,090 --> 00:42:00,620
Just keep in mind,
it doesn't have to be crazy complex.

Doesn't have to have

849
00:42:02,436 --> 00:42:03,770
The more simple it.

850
00:42:03,770 --> 00:42:07,540
The easier it is to follow, the more words
you get in, it becomes really complex

851
00:42:07,540 --> 00:42:11,780
like, there' s a story I always heard

852
00:42:11,780 --> 00:42:17,060
Did you know that in the very first
draft of the United States tax code

853
00:42:17,060 --> 00:42:18,740
it was seven pages long.

854
00:42:18,740 --> 00:42:19,740
Seven pages.

855
00:42:19,740 --> 00:42:21,930
So any citizen could sit down and

856
00:42:21,930 --> 00:42:26,110
read seven pages and understand how
taxes work and pay their taxes.

857
00:42:26,110 --> 00:42:26,820
Right?

858
00:42:26,820 --> 00:42:30,090
Today, they have what's
called the IRS Tax Library.

859
00:42:30,090 --> 00:42:31,400
It's an actual library.

860
00:42:31,400 --> 00:42:35,980
It's got thousands of volumes

00:42:35,980 --> 00:42:38,970

00:42:38,970 --> 00:42:39,480

00:42:39,480 --> 00:42:41,680

00:42:41,680 --> 00:42:44,690
And you have to hire an accountant

00:42:44,690 --> 00:42:46,170
So, it's kind of gotten out of hand.

00:42:46,170 --> 00:42:48,690
Well, that's how your project

The more simple it is, the easier it

868

The more complex it becomes.

Now the project manager needs an assistant

So, it becomes very,

very challenging when you have a really

>> Yeah, sometimes you actually

If you're new to this,

I wanna take an interest in this, is
remember that the plans that we're talking

They're really talking about how

So keep that in mind as we start

We're actually talking

Well Rodney, why don't we wrap it up here.

I don't want it to too much overlap.

So I think that's a pretty

Let me remind you guys if you

Live during the show,

Make use of our Q & A forums,

Post your questions there,

So we want to make sure you

00:44:07,940 --> 00:44:09,090
All right.
Well, signing off for
