they might be one things.

67
00:03:39,971 --> 00:03:42,200
We'll talk about that in just a moment.

68
00:03:42,200 --> 00:03:48,620
But these guys right here, are really
defining the work you need to do.

69
00:03:48,620 --> 00:03:51,230
Not how much time you have,
not how much money you spend, but

70
00:03:51,230 --> 00:03:53,800
just what is the work you've got to do.

71
00:03:53,800 --> 00:03:56,450
And then these other two
serve as the boundaries for

72
00:03:56,450 --> 00:03:58,810
what's gonna hold us
back from achieving this.

73
00:03:58,810 --> 00:04:03,280
But having a solid understanding
of what work you have to do,

74
00:04:03,280 --> 00:04:07,080
from the very beginning will
set you up for success.

75
00:04:07,080 --> 00:04:10,620
Too many projects kick off
with a lot of gray areas,

76
00:04:10,620 --> 00:04:12,720
a lot of undefined information.

77
00:04:12,720 --> 00:04:15,590
And then,
when we think the project is over,

78
00:04:15,590 --> 00:04:19,970
we find out we haven't met the needs
of the customer and there's conflict.

79
00:04:19,970 --> 00:04:21,660
And, we think the project's done.

80
00:04:21,660 --> 00:04:23,100
They don't think it is.

81
00:04:23,100 --> 00:04:27,020
Now the project continues on and
immediately goes over schedule,

82
00:04:27,020 --> 00:04:30,860
over budget, and now you've
really got a problem, all right?

83
00:04:30,860 --> 00:04:34,830
So, this is probably one of the more
important things we do in planning

84
00:04:34,830 --> 00:04:39,090
is just making sure that everyone's
on the same page, right?

85
00:04:39,090 --> 00:04:41,030
Now, we do that with a project scope.

86
00:04:42,220 --> 00:04:48,300
Now, if I take a look at here,
collect requirements process,

87
00:04:48,300 --> 00:04:52,110
we'll see that there's a whole bunch of
stuff here, and it's really talking about

88
00:04:52,110 --> 00:04:56,340
just requirements, so
what is this scope that I'm talking about?

89
00:04:56,340 --> 00:05:03,440
Well, this scope, it's defining in simple
terms what our project needs to achieve.

90
00:05:03,440 --> 00:05:05,540
But our project may not be simple.

91
00:05:05,540 --> 00:05:06,760
It may be really complex.

92
00:05:06,760 --> 00:05:09,750
There may be tons of details
that we need to meet.

93
00:05:09,750 --> 00:05:15,535
And so the requirements are that detailed
breakdown of what we need to achieve,

94
00:05:15,535 --> 00:05:16,280
right?

95
00:05:16,280 --> 00:05:18,270
Your scope may be general.

96
00:05:18,270 --> 00:05:20,370
Your requirements may be very detailed.

97
00:05:20,370 --> 00:05:23,270
At the end of the project, you really
need to meet both of them because they

98
00:05:23,270 --> 00:05:27,970
contribute to each other and that's why I
combined them here, saying requirement and

99
00:05:27,970 --> 00:05:30,390
scope really tie together, all right?

100
00:05:30,390 --> 00:05:32,470
Think of it in terms of building a house.

101
00:05:32,470 --> 00:05:36,180
I wanna buy a house and
I want it to be four bedrooms,

102
00:05:36,180 --> 00:05:40,030
two bath with the two car garage and
a white picket fence, right?

103
00:05:40,030 --> 00:05:42,240
Those are some pretty
general terms right there.

104
00:05:42,240 --> 00:05:46,770
And I can say I want it
done by December 31st and

105
00:05:46,770 --> 00:05:48,370
I wanna spend less than $250,000, right?

106
00:05:49,700 --> 00:05:50,372
So there's my requirements.

107
00:05:50,372 --> 00:05:52,462
Well, those are good.

108
00:05:52,462 --> 00:05:56,310
They're pretty general, but
there's some specific stuff too.

109
00:05:56,310 --> 00:05:56,982
I said I wanted two bathrooms.

110
00:05:56,982 --> 00:05:58,573
Are they full baths, right?

111
00:05:58,573 --> 00:06:01,850
Do they have a bathtub and a toilet or
do they just have a shower?

112
00:06:01,850 --> 00:06:03,530
Do they just have a toilet and that's it?

113
00:06:04,630 --> 00:06:07,110
We said four rooms,
how big should the rooms be?

114
00:06:07,110 --> 00:06:12,370
Is there a master bedroom, guest bedrooms,
is there an upstairs and a downstairs?

115
00:06:12,370 --> 00:06:15,230
There's a ton of other details
we need to know, all right?

116
00:06:16,370 --> 00:06:19,400
And some of the details, the customer
doesn't specifically care about.

117
00:06:19,400 --> 00:06:25,450
I don't care whether
the trusses are metal or wood.

118
00:06:25,450 --> 00:06:27,400
The builders can do
whatever they want there.

119
00:06:27,400 --> 00:06:29,280
I don't see what's inside the walls,
right?

120
00:06:29,280 --> 00:06:31,840
So these types of things
we have to define.

121
00:06:31,840 --> 00:06:37,690
That scope statement may be too general
to actually use as a litmus test.

122
00:06:37,690 --> 00:06:39,150
Test to see whether you've succeeded.

123
00:06:39,150 --> 00:06:42,010
So you may have a very
detailed requirements list

124
00:06:42,010 --> 00:06:44,250
that does go into all of that, all right?

125
00:06:44,250 --> 00:06:48,130
So often times what you'll
see is the scope statement

126
00:06:49,160 --> 00:06:52,410
attached to the requirements list,
that they get combined and

127
00:06:52,410 --> 00:06:55,040
we just kinda work with them together,
all right.

128
00:06:55,040 --> 00:06:58,780
Let me show you guys a template
that I made for the oh,

129
00:06:58,780 --> 00:07:01,843
I don't have my scope statement, shoot.

130
00:07:01,843 --> 00:07:06,045
Well we'll talk about it later.

131
00:07:06,045 --> 00:07:09,527
All right, so the scope statement,
it really is pretty simple.

132
00:07:09,527 --> 00:07:13,310
The scope statement document you really
just specify in a paragraph just in

133
00:07:13,310 --> 00:07:16,923
a conversational way of writing what
your project is going to achieve.

134
00:07:16,923 --> 00:07:19,661
And if you go back to
your project charter,

135
00:07:19,661 --> 00:07:24,685
remember we drafted a project charter for
our little arcade cabinet charter,

136
00:07:24,685 --> 00:07:27,591
and in here I put high-level requirements.

137
00:07:27,591 --> 00:07:32,950
Those high-level requirements kind
of become this scope statement.

138
00:07:32,950 --> 00:07:35,800
And if they'll fit right here
in one little box like this,

139
00:07:35,800 --> 00:07:39,740
if this is everything that I need
I may just take my charter and

140
00:07:39,740 --> 00:07:43,170
turn that into my scope statement and
run with it.

141
00:07:43,170 --> 00:07:46,490
The scope of the project is
what work we're going to do.

142
00:07:46,490 --> 00:07:48,830
But I likely do need to get more detailed.

143
00:07:48,830 --> 00:07:52,160
In software development projects
you absolutely need to get very,

144
00:07:52,160 --> 00:07:53,200
very detailed on here.

145
00:07:53,200 --> 00:07:55,648
So that you have specific boundaries
as to what you're going to achieve.

146
00:07:55,648 --> 00:08:01,333
If you don't, what happens is, it's
invariable, just as your project goes on,

147
00:08:01,333 --> 00:08:06,305
the sponsor will throw out suggestions,
Changes, recommendations.

148
00:08:06,305 --> 00:08:09,302
Oh, I said this but
what I really meant was,

149
00:08:09,302 --> 00:08:12,380
I said that I wanted every
room to have a door.

150
00:08:12,380 --> 00:08:16,310
But what I really want is that
door to have little windows in it.

151
00:08:16,310 --> 00:08:17,800
And things like that.

152
00:08:17,800 --> 00:08:21,310
I want the doors to open out not open in
and you've already put the doors in place.

153
00:08:21,310 --> 00:08:23,210
That kinda stuff starts to happen.

154
00:08:23,210 --> 00:08:26,720
And you end up with what's
called scope creep.

155
00:08:26,720 --> 00:08:28,640
Scope creep, that's the official term.

156
00:08:28,640 --> 00:08:29,990
You'll see it on the exam.

157
00:08:29,990 --> 00:08:33,960
Scope creep is where we start
adding things to the scope.

158
00:08:33,960 --> 00:08:35,750
We start changing and adding things.

159
00:08:35,750 --> 00:08:37,100
And it gets bigger and bigger and

160
00:08:37,100 --> 00:08:42,390
bigger until it becomes impossible
to meet our budget and schedule.

161
00:08:42,390 --> 00:08:46,630
It's just not possible anymore and we've
basically set ourselves up for failure.

162
00:08:46,630 --> 00:08:49,450
>> So a lot of times you might not
only see the idea of what is actually

163
00:08:49,450 --> 00:08:50,190
gonna be required in there.

164
00:08:50,190 --> 00:08:53,130
But you might even see somebody say look,
let's make sure that some of

165
00:08:53,130 --> 00:08:57,750
this stuff doesn't happen, and even
define what it won't actually accomplish.

166
00:08:57,750 --> 00:09:00,810
And that way people don't try and
bring a lot of scope creep into it that we

167
00:09:00,810 --> 00:09:04,310
can't easily say this is not
what it's supposed to do.

168
00:09:04,310 --> 00:09:09,890
>> So what you'll find is that when you
get into collecting the requirements,

169
00:09:09,890 --> 00:09:15,010
okay, this is something you're gonna need
to go through more than once, all right?

170
00:09:15,010 --> 00:09:18,416
Because you're gonna talk to
the original project sponsor and

171
00:09:18,416 --> 00:09:21,570
they're gonna give you
a list of requirements.

172
00:09:21,570 --> 00:09:23,392
And then you're gonna take
those requirements and

173
00:09:23,392 --> 00:09:25,178
you're gonna take them to
subject matter expert.

174
00:09:25,178 --> 00:09:28,440
And they're gonna look at them
at come up with more questions.

175
00:09:28,440 --> 00:09:31,060
And you're gonna have to go back
to the sponsor and say, okay,

176
00:09:31,060 --> 00:09:32,590
we need a little more information.

177
00:09:32,590 --> 00:09:35,560
And you start getting more and
it starts to grow and grow and grow.

178
00:09:35,560 --> 00:09:37,123
And you do that over and over and

179
00:09:37,123 --> 00:09:41,107
over again until the subject matter
expert doesn't have anymore questions.

180
00:09:41,107 --> 00:09:44,125
Until they say, all right, we've got all
the information we need to get started.

181
00:09:44,125 --> 00:09:45,797
All right, then we're ready to rock.

182
00:09:45,797 --> 00:09:50,332
Now, there is a little extra kind
of thing that gets thrown in as we

183
00:09:50,332 --> 00:09:52,650
identify stakeholders.

184
00:09:52,650 --> 00:09:57,460
The stakeholders might have requirements
also, and if they have requirements,

185
00:09:57,460 --> 00:09:58,860
they may need to get incorporated in.

186
00:09:58,860 --> 00:10:03,620
Now, at the end of the day
the project is the sponsor's project.

187
00:10:03,620 --> 00:10:06,700
Whoever it is that lent their authority
to the project it's their project.

188
00:10:06,700 --> 00:10:09,290
So they can override anybody else's
requirements that they want,

189
00:10:09,290 --> 00:10:11,140
it's their project, right?

190
00:10:11,140 --> 00:10:15,090
But a lot of times the stakeholders
will have very valid needs.

191
00:10:15,090 --> 00:10:22,310
So you might have, you're getting some
new insurance underwriting software.

192
00:10:22,310 --> 00:10:25,070
This project is to deploy
the insurance underwriting software.

193
00:10:25,070 --> 00:10:29,820
And the vice president of underwriting
is the one who's the sponsor for

194
00:10:29,820 --> 00:10:30,810
this project.

195
00:10:30,810 --> 00:10:33,460
And so she comes down and
says I want this software.

196
00:10:33,460 --> 00:10:34,610
I want it deployed.

197
00:10:34,610 --> 00:10:38,640
This is gonna make underwriting, for
us, and all new great thing, right?

198
00:10:38,640 --> 00:10:40,440
Well, she's the vice president.

199
00:10:40,440 --> 00:10:41,730
She runs that department.

200
00:10:41,730 --> 00:10:45,510
There's other people in that department,
mid-level management and so on.

201
00:10:45,510 --> 00:10:48,010
And one of the mid-level managers might
come to you and say, you know what,

202
00:10:48,010 --> 00:10:49,450
I think this software's great.

203
00:10:49,450 --> 00:10:50,243
I really like it.

204
00:10:50,243 --> 00:10:51,868
The plan is good.

205
00:10:51,868 --> 00:10:52,820
We're gonna roll it out.

206
00:10:52,820 --> 00:10:53,930
It's wonderful.

207
00:10:53,930 --> 00:10:57,720
But I'm worried about
my people having enough

208
00:10:57,720 --> 00:11:01,020
training to be able to properly
use the software on day one.

209
00:11:01,020 --> 00:11:05,410
So I'd like to add a requirement to
the project that we put in training.

210
00:11:05,410 --> 00:11:09,420
That we train these employees
prior to the roll out, all right?

211
00:11:09,420 --> 00:11:11,670
Well that came from a mid-level manager.

212
00:11:11,670 --> 00:11:13,260
It didn't come from the sponsor.

213
00:11:13,260 --> 00:11:14,440
But the sponsor will look at that and

214
00:11:14,440 --> 00:11:18,690
say, that's a valid concern,
let's make that a new requirement, right?

215
00:11:18,690 --> 00:11:22,160
So a new requirement is, not only do we
roll out the software on December 1st.

216
00:11:22,160 --> 00:11:24,676
But we start training on November 1st, and

217
00:11:24,676 --> 00:11:29,240
we get a good month of training in before
the new software rolls out, all right?

218
00:11:29,240 --> 00:11:32,752
The thing here is, when other
people start adding requirements,

219
00:11:32,752 --> 00:11:34,580
the sponsor needs to be involved.

220
00:11:34,580 --> 00:11:36,710
The project manager needs to be involved.

221
00:11:36,710 --> 00:11:42,560
We have to all be in agreement to add
something in otherwise we get scope creep.

222
00:11:42,560 --> 00:11:45,130
And we're gonna talk about change
management in another episode cuz it is

223
00:11:45,130 --> 00:11:46,280
very important.

224
00:11:46,280 --> 00:11:50,875
Changes to the scope are the most
dangerous because they're changing

225
00:11:50,875 --> 00:11:53,865
the success and
failure criteria of your project, right?

226
00:11:53,865 --> 00:11:55,495
So, we've gotta be really
careful with these.

227
00:11:56,745 --> 00:12:00,295
All right, so let's take a look at this
collect requirements process, all right?

228
00:12:00,295 --> 00:12:02,075
It starts out with a couple of inputs.

229
00:12:02,075 --> 00:12:04,680
If you have a scope
management plan already,

230
00:12:04,680 --> 00:12:06,520
that's an input cuz we
need to follow that plan.

231
00:12:06,520 --> 00:12:09,267
Whatever that plan tells us to do,
we need to do it, all right?

232
00:12:10,290 --> 00:12:13,940
After that, we probably already
have a list of requirements.

233
00:12:15,210 --> 00:12:17,060
Well, I'm gonna change that.

234
00:12:17,060 --> 00:12:18,800
We definitely have a list of requirements.

235
00:12:18,800 --> 00:12:20,320
It might not be a very good list.

236
00:12:20,320 --> 00:12:22,300
It's whatever was in our charter, right?

237
00:12:22,300 --> 00:12:24,050
So there's gonna be something in there.

238
00:12:24,050 --> 00:12:26,160
It may not be very well
fleshed out though.

239
00:12:26,160 --> 00:12:27,980
So we will probably have to revisit this.

240
00:12:27,980 --> 00:12:30,570
So we'll at least have something
because we did get started.

241
00:12:31,920 --> 00:12:34,400
We'll have a stakeholder management plan,
well maybe.

242
00:12:34,400 --> 00:12:35,750
We haven't drafted ours yet.

243
00:12:35,750 --> 00:12:38,850
But you might have a stakeholder
management plan in place already.

244
00:12:38,850 --> 00:12:43,748
If you do, this is gonna tell you how to
reach out to people to find out about

245
00:12:43,748 --> 00:12:45,250
more requirements and

246
00:12:45,250 --> 00:12:49,853
how to reach agreements on adding
new things into the requirements.

247
00:12:49,853 --> 00:12:51,014
Your project charter.

248
00:12:51,014 --> 00:12:53,742
I mentioned that if you don't have
a well-defined list of requirements you at

249
00:12:53,742 --> 00:12:55,630
least have your project charter.

250
00:12:55,630 --> 00:12:57,620
And then lastly,
your stakeholder register.

251
00:12:57,620 --> 00:13:02,040
These are the people that you need to talk
to, to find out about new requirements,

252
00:13:02,040 --> 00:13:03,620
new things that we need to put in.

253
00:13:03,620 --> 00:13:06,140
And we drafted the stakeholder
registry in an earlier episode.

254
00:13:07,380 --> 00:13:10,720
So that's all the information that
we may or may not have already.

255
00:13:10,720 --> 00:13:13,980
We feed that in to our tools and
techniques,

256
00:13:13,980 --> 00:13:18,010
and this is probably one of
the largest ones in the entire PMBOK.

257
00:13:18,010 --> 00:13:20,000
There are a ton of techniques for

258
00:13:20,000 --> 00:13:23,843
gathering information about
our requirements, all right?

259
00:13:23,843 --> 00:13:28,437
But just in general for right now,
each of these are a different way

260
00:13:28,437 --> 00:13:32,226
of finding out what
requirements we've got, right?

261
00:13:32,226 --> 00:13:35,430
Once we've got it all hammered out,
we document them.

262
00:13:35,430 --> 00:13:38,170
So we have requirements documentation.

263
00:13:38,170 --> 00:13:40,490
We document each requirement and
what they mean.

264
00:13:40,490 --> 00:13:42,100
We put them in no uncertain words, right,

265
00:13:42,100 --> 00:13:45,010
you do not want subjective things
in your requirements list.

266
00:13:45,010 --> 00:13:50,100
These need to be measurable things that we
can tell if we've succeeded with or not.

267
00:13:50,100 --> 00:13:54,420
All right, and we also create
a requirements traceability matrix.

268
00:13:54,420 --> 00:13:58,510
Who was it that introduced this
requirement, we need to know that, right?

269
00:13:58,510 --> 00:14:02,110
Who is responsible for
meeting the requirement, and

270
00:14:02,110 --> 00:14:07,160
then is this requirement tied to somebody,
to some other requirement, all right?

271
00:14:07,160 --> 00:14:10,870
And I've got a requirements traceability
matrix template we'll look at a little

272
00:14:10,870 --> 00:14:11,690
bit later.

273
00:14:11,690 --> 00:14:15,620
But this is the documentation that
we're trying to create, all right?

274
00:14:15,620 --> 00:14:17,950
But it might be that we create
a requirements document,

275
00:14:17,950 --> 00:14:21,780
list all the requirements and
then we just take it and

276
00:14:21,780 --> 00:14:24,760
we feed it right back in
as an input again, right?

277
00:14:24,760 --> 00:14:29,400
We take it and we run it through
all of these options again.

278
00:14:29,400 --> 00:14:30,240
So these tools and

279
00:14:30,240 --> 00:14:35,080
techniques are gonna get used multiple
times as we refine our requirements list.

280
00:14:35,080 --> 00:14:39,370
If you're on a project, and
your requirements list is version 1.0, and

281
00:14:39,370 --> 00:14:44,030
it's never been revised,
it's like spotting a unicorn,

282
00:14:44,030 --> 00:14:46,340
it's something that just doesn't happen.

283
00:14:46,340 --> 00:14:51,620
So you'll normally have a requirements
list that's been revised multiple times.

284
00:14:51,620 --> 00:14:55,810
Well the cool thing is when
you're in planning, that's fine.

285
00:14:55,810 --> 00:14:59,440
Changing requirements in
planning doesn't cost you money.

286
00:14:59,440 --> 00:15:03,380
But if you're in execution,
if work is already being done and

287
00:15:03,380 --> 00:15:05,130
you start changing requirements,

288
00:15:05,130 --> 00:15:08,910
you might be invalidating work that was
already done, which is wasting money.

289
00:15:08,910 --> 00:15:11,680
Or you might be adding to it
which is gonna cost you money.

290
00:15:11,680 --> 00:15:14,510
It's going to affect your schedule and
your budget.

291
00:15:14,510 --> 00:15:17,220
So now's the time to make change.

292
00:15:17,220 --> 00:15:20,975
So be patient, run the requirements
through the ringer several times,

293
00:15:20,975 --> 00:15:25,270
cuz it's better to find out stuff
now than it is down the road.

294
00:15:25,270 --> 00:15:26,490
>> Yeah.

295
00:15:26,490 --> 00:15:31,450
>> All right, so let's talk about each
of these tools and techniques, right?

296
00:15:31,450 --> 00:15:34,530
For me,
every project starts out the same way.

297
00:15:34,530 --> 00:15:36,890
It starts out with an interview.

298
00:15:36,890 --> 00:15:39,250
We talk to the sponsor, right?

299
00:15:39,250 --> 00:15:42,530
Or if the sponsor is the originator,
that's who we start with.

300
00:15:42,530 --> 00:15:45,790
But if the originator is somebody else,
the sponsor's just giving authority, so

301
00:15:45,790 --> 00:15:47,790
we'll probably wanna go to the originator.

302
00:15:47,790 --> 00:15:51,410
We go to that person and
we find out what they want, right?

303
00:15:51,410 --> 00:15:54,954
We sort of already did this
when we did the charter, right,

304
00:15:54,954 --> 00:15:58,240
cuz they've already got a few
requirements that are in there.

305
00:15:58,240 --> 00:16:01,750
But now we go and we say, okay,
in detail, be exhaustive.

306
00:16:01,750 --> 00:16:05,209
Give me everything that you want,
and be as specific as you can,

307
00:16:05,209 --> 00:16:08,620
every aspect of what you want As
a part of this project, right?

308
00:16:08,620 --> 00:16:11,558
And you'll create a list and
hopefully it's a big one.

309
00:16:11,558 --> 00:16:15,282
The bigger the list is,
the more accurate it is, right?

310
00:16:15,282 --> 00:16:17,240
If it's a really short list.

311
00:16:17,240 --> 00:16:21,602
I wanna build a new car that
gets 54 miles to the gallon,

312
00:16:21,602 --> 00:16:23,360
all right, well that sounds good.

313
00:16:23,360 --> 00:16:26,110
I wanna build a car that
gets 54 miles to the gallon.

314
00:16:26,110 --> 00:16:28,880
But how many seats does it need to have?

315
00:16:28,880 --> 00:16:31,410
How many wheels, could it be a motorcycle?

316
00:16:31,410 --> 00:16:33,620
There's so much other variables and

317
00:16:33,620 --> 00:16:37,907
options in there that it's really
challenging to be successful with.

318
00:16:37,907 --> 00:16:41,191
So in an interview you need to just
sit down and you talk to somebody.

319
00:16:41,191 --> 00:16:44,935
Maybe via phone, Skype,
video conference, whatever, but

320
00:16:44,935 --> 00:16:49,619
you just sit down and you talk to them and
you find out what it is that they want.

321
00:16:50,850 --> 00:16:54,490
>> The second tool that we have here is
allow the idea of focus groups, right?

322
00:16:54,490 --> 00:16:56,270
Now, when we start talking
about the idea of focus groups,

323
00:16:56,270 --> 00:16:59,040
we're really doing a little bit of
demographics a lot of times, or

324
00:16:59,040 --> 00:17:03,510
we're trying to group together the people
that have a vested interest in this, or

325
00:17:03,510 --> 00:17:06,902
we're again targeting maybe
an age group of some sort here.

326
00:17:06,902 --> 00:17:09,410
They wanna make sure that the product
that we actually have is gonna

327
00:17:09,410 --> 00:17:11,000
be suited for what they want.

328
00:17:11,000 --> 00:17:13,210
And so
you may actually have something like that.

329
00:17:13,210 --> 00:17:16,220
Or again if you're ready to talk in
subject matter experts you may go hey,

330
00:17:16,220 --> 00:17:20,090
I wanna just make sure that if we
were to present this tool to you

331
00:17:20,090 --> 00:17:23,030
what do you think would actually happen
with this feature or whatever it might be.

332
00:17:23,030 --> 00:17:25,960
And that could really help you to zoom
in on that particular requirement that

333
00:17:25,960 --> 00:17:27,160
you may wanna present.

334
00:17:27,160 --> 00:17:31,490
>> Now you see focus groups
more in manufacturing, right?

335
00:17:31,490 --> 00:17:34,800
So if we're gonna be manufacturing,
or if designing a new car,

336
00:17:34,800 --> 00:17:36,590
what did I use in the earlier episodes?

337
00:17:36,590 --> 00:17:37,375
>> Ford something.

338
00:17:37,375 --> 00:17:40,940
>> Oh, the Ford Focus, right, so
we're designing the 2016 Ford Focus.

339
00:17:40,940 --> 00:17:45,050
So already our quality
level is set nice and low,

340
00:17:46,220 --> 00:17:50,320
so [LAUGH] when we design that
we know what our CEO wants.

341
00:17:50,320 --> 00:17:51,980
We know what our head engineer wants.

342
00:17:51,980 --> 00:17:54,710
They want a car that doesn't cost as
much to make but that we can sell for

343
00:17:54,710 --> 00:17:55,400
a lot of money, right?

344
00:17:55,400 --> 00:17:56,610
We know what they want.

345
00:17:56,610 --> 00:17:58,890
But we need to know
what the people want so

346
00:17:58,890 --> 00:18:00,670
this would be a product that we can sell.

347
00:18:00,670 --> 00:18:01,570
So we have a focus group.

348
00:18:01,570 --> 00:18:03,850
And the focus group
doesn't contain the CEO.

349
00:18:03,850 --> 00:18:06,340
It doesn't contain the head engineer.

350
00:18:06,340 --> 00:18:09,346
It contains people on the streets.

351
00:18:09,346 --> 00:18:11,536
Not necessarily people who
live on the streets, but

352
00:18:11,536 --> 00:18:13,594
I just mean people that
are out there in society.

353
00:18:13,594 --> 00:18:15,850
[LAUGH] It's all homeless people.

354
00:18:15,850 --> 00:18:19,420
So we get people, and
just your average Joe,

355
00:18:19,420 --> 00:18:22,780
nice statistically diverse demographics,
right?

356
00:18:22,780 --> 00:18:26,320
You want women, men,
multiple races, multiple heritage,

357
00:18:26,320 --> 00:18:31,360
whatever and you present your idea, your
kind of requirements you've got right now.

358
00:18:31,360 --> 00:18:33,090
You say, all right,
we're looking to build this new car.

359
00:18:33,090 --> 00:18:36,280
We're hoping it'll get 54 miles to
the gallon and this and that and

360
00:18:36,280 --> 00:18:38,000
these are the colors we're thinking about.

361
00:18:38,000 --> 00:18:39,520
And you get feedback from people.

362
00:18:39,520 --> 00:18:43,720
And you may find that some of
your requirements are good, but

363
00:18:43,720 --> 00:18:44,810
people don't care about them.

364
00:18:44,810 --> 00:18:48,890
And if they don't care about them you're
introducing an extra cost that there's no

365
00:18:48,890 --> 00:18:51,000
real purpose for.

366
00:18:51,000 --> 00:18:52,850
We deal with this at ITProTV.

367
00:18:52,850 --> 00:18:55,850
When we pick a new
certification show to do,

368
00:18:55,850 --> 00:18:59,492
there have been times where we pick
a certification and nobody cared about.

369
00:18:59,492 --> 00:19:02,460
They're like,
it's nice that you're doing that but

370
00:19:02,460 --> 00:19:04,455
I don't wanna get that certification.

371
00:19:04,455 --> 00:19:09,010
So, you have to kind of pull the people,
find out what they want,

372
00:19:09,010 --> 00:19:13,140
find out what aspects of that project
are what they're really looking for so

373
00:19:13,140 --> 00:19:14,460
that you tailor your needs to it.

374
00:19:14,460 --> 00:19:16,100
So focus groups are really useful for
that.

375
00:19:17,730 --> 00:19:21,200
Similar to focus groups
are facilitated workshops.

376
00:19:21,200 --> 00:19:25,020
Facilitated workshops, that's where
you have your own staff, your people,

377
00:19:25,020 --> 00:19:28,040
the engineer, the CEO, these people,
and you get them together,

378
00:19:28,040 --> 00:19:29,760
and you start working together.

379
00:19:29,760 --> 00:19:33,340
This is where we'll start seeing
things like brainstorming, and well,

380
00:19:33,340 --> 00:19:36,760
some of the other stuff I know we've
talked about in other episodes.

381
00:19:36,760 --> 00:19:40,200
But we start communicating with them and
finding out the information they've got.

382
00:19:40,200 --> 00:19:44,790
What it is that they're looking for
and when they're all in one room,

383
00:19:44,790 --> 00:19:48,260
one person throwing out a requirement
might trigger an idea in somebody else.

384
00:19:48,260 --> 00:19:52,330
Oh, you know what, actually if you do that
we also need to do this, this and this.

385
00:19:52,330 --> 00:19:54,650
Maybe it's something they want,
maybe it's something you have to have.

386
00:19:54,650 --> 00:20:00,540
Like oh, if you want 54 miles to a gallon
we can not do a standard fuel engine,

387
00:20:00,540 --> 00:20:02,480
we're gonna have to do
a hybrid fuel engine and

388
00:20:02,480 --> 00:20:05,450
that kinda stuff kinda comes out
as a part of those meetings.

389
00:20:07,220 --> 00:20:09,470
So really, really handy there.

390
00:20:09,470 --> 00:20:12,220
>> The next one that we have
here is idea of the group

391
00:20:12,220 --> 00:20:14,300
creativity techniques that we have.

392
00:20:14,300 --> 00:20:17,920
Now again, a lot of this comes
from also brainstorming, right,

393
00:20:17,920 --> 00:20:19,958
if we're actually just trying
to come up with ideas.

394
00:20:19,958 --> 00:20:22,382
But there are also ways
that we actually go, hey,

395
00:20:22,382 --> 00:20:25,039
there's four different things
that we want to do, but

396
00:20:25,039 --> 00:20:28,700
we really need to focus in on what it is
that we can accomplish at this point.

397
00:20:28,700 --> 00:20:31,404
And so along with that,
you may have some different techniques.

398
00:20:31,404 --> 00:20:34,212
And they go in PMBOK and actually
inscribe some different ones there.

399
00:20:34,212 --> 00:20:34,861
>> Yeah.

400
00:20:34,861 --> 00:20:37,332
They start with brainstorming,
which I already mentioned, right?

401
00:20:37,332 --> 00:20:39,696
Brainstorming, you just sit around,
you come up with ideas,

402
00:20:39,696 --> 00:20:41,695
you throw them on the wall and
kinda see what sticks.

403
00:20:41,695 --> 00:20:44,960
And it's just a great way of getting
everything out in the open, so

404
00:20:44,960 --> 00:20:47,660
people can see it, and
start to make recommendations.

405
00:20:49,510 --> 00:20:53,276
The second one they talk about
is nominal group technique.

406
00:20:53,276 --> 00:20:56,710
All right, nominal group technique
is very similar to brainstorming,

407
00:20:56,710 --> 00:20:58,940
you get a group of people
they throw out ideas.

408
00:20:58,940 --> 00:21:03,150
The difference is when you do
brainstorming everybody's equal.

409
00:21:03,150 --> 00:21:06,110
You treat everybody the same,
no idea's a bad idea.

410
00:21:06,110 --> 00:21:07,950
Let's just get them up on the board.

411
00:21:07,950 --> 00:21:10,690
We'll figure it out and
you kinda sort through things later.

412
00:21:10,690 --> 00:21:14,364
With nominal group technique you're
throwing out ideas the same way.

413
00:21:14,364 --> 00:21:19,382
But if the CEO throws out an idea it
gets a little more weight, right?

414
00:21:19,382 --> 00:21:23,109
If the head engineer throws out and idea
it gets a little more weight than if just

415
00:21:23,109 --> 00:21:26,553
one of the salespeople throws out
an idea that gets a little less weight,

416
00:21:26,553 --> 00:21:27,680
less priority.

417
00:21:27,680 --> 00:21:30,370
And so when it comes to
the end of this where we're

418
00:21:30,370 --> 00:21:34,210
picking out which ones are our winners,
some are already biased, right?

419
00:21:34,210 --> 00:21:36,403
Some are already predisposed
to being selected.

420
00:21:36,403 --> 00:21:38,872
And, while a lot of companies
say they don't do that,

421
00:21:38,872 --> 00:21:40,546
almost every company does, right?

422
00:21:40,546 --> 00:21:44,495
You almost always give
precedence to your executives.

423
00:21:44,495 --> 00:21:46,856
They're executives for
a reason, well hopefully.

424
00:21:46,856 --> 00:21:49,375
>> [LAUGH]
>> They have a better understanding

425
00:21:49,375 --> 00:21:52,275
of the marketplace.

426
00:21:52,275 --> 00:21:55,615
We've got ideas/mind mapping.

427
00:21:55,615 --> 00:21:56,879
Very similar to brainstorming.

428
00:21:56,879 --> 00:22:00,255
With brainstorming we're just building
up ideas not necessarily linking them

429
00:22:00,255 --> 00:22:03,315
with idea and
mind mapping we link them and

430
00:22:03,315 --> 00:22:07,160
I showed an example of that software
that we use, let me bring that back up.

431
00:22:07,160 --> 00:22:09,410
So that was-
>> Mindomo.

432
00:22:09,410 --> 00:22:13,980
>> Yeah, Mindomo and
these guys make some mind mapping software

433
00:22:13,980 --> 00:22:17,880
which you can use for brain storming
just for throwing ideas up on the board.

434
00:22:17,880 --> 00:22:22,740
But you can also use it for
idea and mind mapping.

435
00:22:22,740 --> 00:22:23,770
You link them together.

436
00:22:23,770 --> 00:22:26,230
So here they've got
conflict management styles.

437
00:22:26,230 --> 00:22:28,720
They're trying to come up with some
different ways of resolving conflict.

438
00:22:28,720 --> 00:22:32,010
So they've got competing,
avoiding, accommodating, right?

439
00:22:32,010 --> 00:22:33,150
So these different ones.

440
00:22:33,150 --> 00:22:35,258
Why is my mouse doing that?

441
00:22:35,258 --> 00:22:36,327
Oh, whatever.

442
00:22:36,327 --> 00:22:39,990
But, so they've got these different
ones that they're doing here,

443
00:22:39,990 --> 00:22:43,080
based on what they come up with and
then they start branching those out.

444
00:22:43,080 --> 00:22:46,780
All right, well, if we deal with avoiding
then that breaks down into strengths and

445
00:22:46,780 --> 00:22:47,730
weaknesses.

446
00:22:47,730 --> 00:22:50,417
And they have the strengths of it and
the weaknesses listed,

447
00:22:50,417 --> 00:22:51,953
kind of branching out from there.

448
00:22:51,953 --> 00:22:54,791
So idea and mind mapping,
same as brainstorming,

449
00:22:54,791 --> 00:22:58,623
we just connect it all together so
we have more of a diagram type view.

450
00:22:58,623 --> 00:23:00,492
>> Yeah,
a lot of times with all the stuff and

451
00:23:00,492 --> 00:23:04,020
all the different things that can come
up during that brainstorming session,

452
00:23:04,020 --> 00:23:07,760
you may actually do something that
we call affinity grouping, as well.

453
00:23:07,760 --> 00:23:10,940
Once again, everything is just listed up,
but then you start circling things and

454
00:23:10,940 --> 00:23:15,030
going, all right, so these ideas
seem to really belong together and

455
00:23:15,030 --> 00:23:16,090
you group them together.

456
00:23:16,090 --> 00:23:19,100
And you may again actually just
find out that there were four or

457
00:23:19,100 --> 00:23:22,730
five things that they actually would like
rather than what you actually had in mind.

458
00:23:22,730 --> 00:23:24,110
>> I like affinity grouping,

459
00:23:24,110 --> 00:23:27,490
because when you do it,
if you're looking at the project as whole,

460
00:23:27,490 --> 00:23:31,180
you're gonna need to bring in your subject
matter experts to kinda break things down.

461
00:23:31,180 --> 00:23:35,080
Well, a subject matter expert,
if we're designing a new car, right?

462
00:23:35,080 --> 00:23:38,070
If we're coming up with a new car design,
you might have somebody who knows

463
00:23:38,070 --> 00:23:40,888
everything there is about
fuel efficiency and engines.

464
00:23:40,888 --> 00:23:43,850
Right, but they didn't know
anything about aesthetics and

465
00:23:43,850 --> 00:23:45,810
overall body design of a vehicle.

466
00:23:45,810 --> 00:23:48,370
So you might have an arts or

467
00:23:48,370 --> 00:23:52,160
design team that does the aesthetics,
the exterior body.

468
00:23:52,160 --> 00:23:54,639
Meanwhile you have an engineering
team that's doing the engine.

469
00:23:54,639 --> 00:23:56,897
They don't need to necessarily be
brainstorming with each other.

470
00:23:56,897 --> 00:23:58,881
Now there is some overlap.

471
00:23:58,881 --> 00:24:00,933
So if I have a bigger engine,
I'm gonna need a bigger hood.

472
00:24:00,933 --> 00:24:02,753
And the design is gonna have
to accommodate for that.

473
00:24:02,753 --> 00:24:04,040
So you do want them to communicate.

474
00:24:04,040 --> 00:24:07,560
But when you do affinity grouping,
you group these objects together.

475
00:24:07,560 --> 00:24:12,215
And you say, all right, let's get the
engineers focused in on this one group,

476
00:24:12,215 --> 00:24:14,550
cuz that's where they're an expert.

477
00:24:14,550 --> 00:24:17,110
But then we'll maybe
have just their manager

478
00:24:17,110 --> 00:24:19,180
in the overall meeting that
covers the whole project.

479
00:24:19,180 --> 00:24:20,700
So affinity grouping is
really good at that.

480
00:24:20,700 --> 00:24:23,320
Let me see if I can find a picture,

481
00:24:23,320 --> 00:24:27,871
let me just do like a Google Image
search here and see if somebody posts.

482
00:24:27,871 --> 00:24:31,730
Well actually,
these are pretty good right here.

483
00:24:31,730 --> 00:24:33,360
There's a bunch of post-it notes.

484
00:24:33,360 --> 00:24:37,899
But what they're doing is they're
throwing ideas up on the board.

485
00:24:37,899 --> 00:24:40,918
And you can't really read that at all.

486
00:24:40,918 --> 00:24:45,096
I wonder if I can find
one that's semi-legible.

487
00:24:45,096 --> 00:24:46,590
Oh, yeah.

488
00:24:46,590 --> 00:24:47,100
To a point.

489
00:24:47,100 --> 00:24:51,950
>> Well yeah, it's super pixelated but see
how they threw up ideas onto the board and

490
00:24:51,950 --> 00:24:56,910
then they circled them to say these are
the areas, like the people, the job roles,

491
00:24:56,910 --> 00:24:58,180
or whatever that would apply to them.

492
00:24:58,180 --> 00:25:00,830
I can't really read what those say.

493
00:25:00,830 --> 00:25:05,090
But by doing that, we can start to have
people focus in on the areas that they

494
00:25:05,090 --> 00:25:06,980
really know what they're doing.

495
00:25:06,980 --> 00:25:09,962
I don't know what's going on there so
apparently they colored their fingers.

496
00:25:09,962 --> 00:25:13,560
But, yeah, so
that's the idea behind this kind of thing.

497
00:25:13,560 --> 00:25:19,420
When you're looking at a wall
where you've done mind mapping,

498
00:25:19,420 --> 00:25:22,160
or just brainstorming,
people threw up a bunch of ideas.

499
00:25:22,160 --> 00:25:23,580
You can have a lot of ideas.

500
00:25:23,580 --> 00:25:24,800
It could be a super mess.

501
00:25:24,800 --> 00:25:27,930
But when you can group them together it
becomes a much more manageable thing.

502
00:25:27,930 --> 00:25:30,900
And so that's what we're looking
at with affinity diagrams.

503
00:25:32,580 --> 00:25:34,870
All right, I believe we've got one more?

504
00:25:34,870 --> 00:25:35,410
>> Yeah.

505
00:25:35,410 --> 00:25:39,900
>> Yeah, the last one we've
got is multi-criteria decision

506
00:25:39,900 --> 00:25:41,510
analysis, all right?

507
00:25:41,510 --> 00:25:43,750
We're gonna talk about
this one more a lot later,

508
00:25:43,750 --> 00:25:47,900
cuz it's important in the bidding and
specifications stuff.

509
00:25:47,900 --> 00:25:52,390
But, with multi-criteria that's
where we basically rank our ideas.

510
00:25:52,390 --> 00:25:54,600
We have to choose, we have to pick, right?

511
00:25:54,600 --> 00:25:57,760
And so
when you pick you have multiple criteria.

512
00:25:57,760 --> 00:26:02,750
I hate to use the word in the definition,
but you have several different aspects

513
00:26:02,750 --> 00:26:07,140
of that idea that you measure against
to determine who's the winner.

514
00:26:07,140 --> 00:26:12,240
So for example, if I say,
I know that I need

515
00:26:12,240 --> 00:26:17,910
a car that can get 54 miles to the gallon,
and it can

516
00:26:17,910 --> 00:26:23,560
do zero to 60 in under five seconds, and
I have these different criteria, right?

517
00:26:23,560 --> 00:26:26,666
Well, when somebody comes up with
an idea of how to achieve that,

518
00:26:26,666 --> 00:26:30,335
we could achieve that if we did this
particular engine and these tires, and so

519
00:26:30,335 --> 00:26:33,400
on, versus other solutions that
might provide the same thing.

520
00:26:33,400 --> 00:26:35,030
So, how do we pick between those?

521
00:26:35,030 --> 00:26:38,700
We have multiple criteria,
we look at it, we reach that decision.

522
00:26:38,700 --> 00:26:41,260
And then the one that we finally
decided on, that's the new requirement.

523
00:26:41,260 --> 00:26:44,180
We require the use of this engine and
these tires.

524
00:26:44,180 --> 00:26:47,340
Because they allow us to
achieve this other goal, right?

525
00:26:47,340 --> 00:26:49,420
So multiple criteria
kind of feed into that.

526
00:26:49,420 --> 00:26:51,960
We'll see some more examples
of that down the road.

527
00:26:51,960 --> 00:26:55,840
Especially when it comes to bids and
requests for quotes.

528
00:26:55,840 --> 00:26:59,890
If we get a bunch of bids back on
something, how do you pick the winner, and

529
00:26:59,890 --> 00:27:01,520
we'll use multiple criteria for that.

530
00:27:01,520 --> 00:27:05,400
So definitely stuff that
we need to hit on there.

531
00:27:05,400 --> 00:27:07,410
All right, now we got a lot more inputs,
but Ronnie,

532
00:27:07,410 --> 00:27:09,010
we're starting to run
a little bit low on time.

533
00:27:09,010 --> 00:27:09,950
So why don't we do this?

534
00:27:09,950 --> 00:27:14,660
We just left off with our
group creativity techniques.

535
00:27:14,660 --> 00:27:17,590
I kinda led into group decision
making techniques a little bit.

536
00:27:17,590 --> 00:27:19,027
So we still have that to talk about.

537
00:27:19,027 --> 00:27:22,139
And I knew we've got like another
six objectives or tools and

538
00:27:22,139 --> 00:27:23,612
techniques to get through.

539
00:27:23,612 --> 00:27:24,400
>> That's right.

540
00:27:24,400 --> 00:27:25,310
>> So why don't we stop here.

545
00:27:39,650 --> 00:27:42,400
All right, welcome back everybody.

546
00:27:42,400 --> 00:27:47,800
So, in the first segment, we took a look
at the collect requirements process and

00:27:47,800 --> 00:27:51,720
we got almost halfway through

548
00:27:51,720 --> 00:27:53,280
We have quite a few more to get through,

549
00:27:53,280 --> 00:27:57,110
Some of the different things we're gonna
use as we gather together our requirements

550
00:27:57,110 --> 00:27:59,320
and get ready to build
our scope statement.

551
00:27:59,320 --> 00:28:05,200
So, the one we left off on was number five
which is group decision-making techniques.

552
00:28:05,200 --> 00:28:10,430
When you have one person,
it's really easy to make decisions.

553
00:28:10,430 --> 00:28:13,670
But when you have a group of people
like your project management team or

554
00:28:13,670 --> 00:28:18,050
the various stakeholders together,
now we need ways to make those decisions.

555
00:28:18,050 --> 00:28:22,510
And PMI recognizes, was it four,
four different ways, something like that?

556
00:28:22,510 --> 00:28:27,769
Four or five different ways that
it's generally accepted to do this.

557
00:28:27,769 --> 00:28:28,390
>> Yeah,

558
00:28:28,390 --> 00:28:31,260
the first way that we actually have
listed here is what we call unanimity.

559
00:28:31,260 --> 00:28:35,380
Now that's a strange word to actually just
say here but this is fairly simple for

560
00:28:35,380 --> 00:28:38,702
us in terms of unanimity, and
this is when we actually say look,

561
00:28:38,702 --> 00:28:41,122
what we want is a unanimous decision,
right?

562
00:28:41,122 --> 00:28:45,201
Everybody ends up agreeing to what is
gonna be done on this course here, and

563
00:28:45,201 --> 00:28:48,658
you just keep working it out
until everybody actually agrees.

564
00:28:48,658 --> 00:28:53,610
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] unanimity, it's one of
those words that we wouldn't normally use.

565
00:28:53,610 --> 00:28:55,100
Its root word is unanimous.

566
00:28:55,100 --> 00:28:57,420
So when you have unanimity,

567
00:28:57,420 --> 00:29:02,680
that means that everyone agrees on
the course of action without dissent.

568
00:29:02,680 --> 00:29:03,320
>> That's right.

569
00:29:03,320 --> 00:29:05,760
>> So if you have a group of people and

570
00:29:05,760 --> 00:29:10,330
you're using unanimity as you're deciding
your methodology, that means that

571
00:29:10,330 --> 00:29:13,895
everyone has to be in agreement
of the direction that you choose.

572
00:29:13,895 --> 00:29:19,410
That if even one person says no,
then you've not reached a decision,

573
00:29:19,410 --> 00:29:23,765
and you need to continue doing
decision-making techniques and

574
00:29:23,765 --> 00:29:28,385
negotiation and stuff until you can
finally get 100% of the people on board.

575
00:29:28,385 --> 00:29:31,705
It's got to be a 100% unanimous decision.

576
00:29:31,705 --> 00:29:33,155
Now I don't think I've ever used this,

577
00:29:33,155 --> 00:29:36,030
because sometimes it's very
difficult to get people convinced.

578
00:29:36,030 --> 00:29:40,250
But in theory if you're
making the right decision,

579
00:29:40,250 --> 00:29:43,390
it should be easy to convince people
to go with the right decision.

580
00:29:43,390 --> 00:29:45,892
So that's what is the premise
behind the unanimity.

581
00:29:45,892 --> 00:29:51,530
All right, next one is majority and
this is probably the most common of them.

582
00:29:51,530 --> 00:29:54,050
But, the other ones still come into play.

583
00:29:54,050 --> 00:29:56,592
Majority, we have a group of people,
we take a vote.

584
00:29:56,592 --> 00:30:00,412
And whichever choice gets
the most votes wins, right?

585
00:30:00,412 --> 00:30:04,423
Even if it's just 51% versus 49%,

586
00:30:04,423 --> 00:30:09,817
as long as it's not a tie,
then that one decision wins.

587
00:30:09,817 --> 00:30:10,535
>> Yeah.

588
00:30:10,535 --> 00:30:12,390
And the other one is the idea
of the plurality, here.

589
00:30:12,390 --> 00:30:15,160
Now there may be more than one
decision that needs to be made.

590
00:30:15,160 --> 00:30:18,820
So what if your particular group ends
up dividing up into well, three or

591
00:30:18,820 --> 00:30:20,530
four different positions here?

592
00:30:20,530 --> 00:30:22,380
The idea of plurality
just pretty much means,

593
00:30:22,380 --> 00:30:26,550
whoever gets the most votes at that point,
whether it's 50% or over.

594
00:30:26,550 --> 00:30:28,730
That's the one you're actually gonna
end up going with a lot of times.

595
00:30:28,730 --> 00:30:31,580
But it's actually kind of a tenuous

596
00:30:31,580 --> 00:30:33,590
position a lot of times
when you start doing that.

597
00:30:33,590 --> 00:30:37,120
>> Yeah the thing with plurality and
actually if we kinda look at it from

598
00:30:37,120 --> 00:30:42,420
the perspective of majority, majority just
requires 51%, right, to have a majority.

599
00:30:42,420 --> 00:30:47,350
That means you could have as much
as 49% of your team saying no.

600
00:30:47,350 --> 00:30:49,650
That's not the strongest
decision in the world,

601
00:30:49,650 --> 00:30:52,650
so a lot of times you'll set
a higher level than that.

602
00:30:52,650 --> 00:30:55,870
With a plurality, we say we don't
care what the percentage is,

603
00:30:55,870 --> 00:30:57,860
it's just whoever gets
the biggest percentage.

604
00:30:57,860 --> 00:31:02,430
So in Ronnie's example, he said what if
you get more than one decision, right?

605
00:31:02,430 --> 00:31:07,340
So what if, for example, let me just
do it another little note here.

606
00:31:07,340 --> 00:31:13,010
So I have choice 1, choice 2 and choice 3.

607
00:31:13,010 --> 00:31:14,903
I've got three different choices, okay?

608
00:31:14,903 --> 00:31:18,861
And we take a vote, and
choice 1 one gets 40% of the vote.

609
00:31:18,861 --> 00:31:24,898
Choice number 2 gets 20% of the vote,
not let's got 25%.

610
00:31:24,898 --> 00:31:26,396
25% of the vote.

611
00:31:26,396 --> 00:31:29,774
And choice number 3 gets 35% of the vote.

612
00:31:29,774 --> 00:31:33,380
Okay, did anyone get more than 50%?

613
00:31:33,380 --> 00:31:34,280
>> Nope.

614
00:31:34,280 --> 00:31:37,280
>> No, nobody got half the votes.

615
00:31:37,280 --> 00:31:43,250
But choice number 1 would win
because it has the plurality, right?

616
00:31:43,250 --> 00:31:44,716
It's not a majority.

617
00:31:44,716 --> 00:31:46,215
It doesn't have over 50%.

618
00:31:46,215 --> 00:31:47,650
It's a plurality.

619
00:31:47,650 --> 00:31:50,410
It's got more than anybody else,
but it's 40%.

620
00:31:50,410 --> 00:31:53,590
And this is something
that is extremely common.

621
00:31:53,590 --> 00:31:55,930
We always equate this stuff
to governments, right?

622
00:31:55,930 --> 00:31:58,670
In European governments,
you have a lot of coalition governments

623
00:31:58,670 --> 00:32:01,840
where multi-party systems
end up with this.

624
00:32:01,840 --> 00:32:04,080
In the US we just have two parties.

625
00:32:04,080 --> 00:32:04,950
They both kinda suck.

626
00:32:04,950 --> 00:32:07,005
But anyhow, we have two parties, and so

627
00:32:07,005 --> 00:32:10,276
this idea of majority is what we're
kind of used to as a society.

628
00:32:10,276 --> 00:32:16,439
But even here, we've had where
the pluralities in the past But this one.

629
00:32:16,439 --> 00:32:20,674
It's another one where we say,
we're going with this choice but

630
00:32:20,674 --> 00:32:23,470
only 40% of the team agreed with it.

631
00:32:23,470 --> 00:32:26,010
So is that really the best choice since

632
00:32:26,010 --> 00:32:29,380
less than half of our people
actually thought it was a good idea?

633
00:32:29,380 --> 00:32:32,890
Maybe these other people have enough
merit to make us think, you know,

634
00:32:32,890 --> 00:32:37,900
here's 60% of my team
thought this choice was bad.

635
00:32:37,900 --> 00:32:38,670
>> Yeah.
>> Right?

636
00:32:38,670 --> 00:32:40,400
That something else was better.

637
00:32:40,400 --> 00:32:42,490
But I'm about to go with this one
that only 40% of the team chose.

638
00:32:42,490 --> 00:32:44,590
>> Yeah.
>> So, pluralities are not something we

639
00:32:44,590 --> 00:32:47,590
see very often just because there's so
much

640
00:32:47,590 --> 00:32:48,255
>> Room for doubt.

641
00:32:48,255 --> 00:32:50,392
>> Mm-hm.

642
00:32:50,392 --> 00:32:53,090
>> All right, and
then the last one is my favorite.

643
00:32:53,090 --> 00:32:54,015
Dictatorship.

644
00:32:54,015 --> 00:32:54,870
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right?

645
00:32:54,870 --> 00:32:56,175
We might listen to other people.

646
00:32:56,175 --> 00:32:58,240
>> [LAUGH]
>> We might take some recommendations.

647
00:32:58,240 --> 00:33:01,250
But, at the end of the day,
we're going to make the call, right?

648
00:33:01,250 --> 00:33:02,790
>> My decision.

649
00:33:02,790 --> 00:33:07,420
>> This is really useful in environments
where you need to move rapidly,

650
00:33:07,420 --> 00:33:12,960
where you don't have time for debate and
sitting around in a committee or

651
00:33:12,960 --> 00:33:18,415
whatever, but the problem is you can
>> And in a lot of cases make mistakes.

652
00:33:18,415 --> 00:33:22,245
And you can make mistakes faster
[LAUGH] because it's a Dictatorship.

653
00:33:22,245 --> 00:33:24,905
You see this in companies though.

654
00:33:24,905 --> 00:33:25,405
Apple for

655
00:33:25,405 --> 00:33:29,790
the longest time who had Steve Jobs who
would absolutely not listen to anyone.

656
00:33:29,790 --> 00:33:33,580
He had an idea and
vision and he was right.

657
00:33:33,580 --> 00:33:36,400
All those years, the company
kept making more and more money.

658
00:33:36,400 --> 00:33:38,470
That was an example of a Dictatorship.

659
00:33:38,470 --> 00:33:42,770
But then you have other organizations
like Microsoft where they do have all

660
00:33:42,770 --> 00:33:45,820
the mid-level management that
gets involved in the decisions.

661
00:33:45,820 --> 00:33:47,810
And they're making progress.

662
00:33:47,810 --> 00:33:51,020
It's slower progress, but
generally it's a little bit more safe.

663
00:33:51,020 --> 00:33:53,700
So those four methods right there,

664
00:33:53,700 --> 00:33:57,680
those are group making
techniques that PMI recognizes.

665
00:33:57,680 --> 00:34:01,530
In other words, these are the four
that you'll see on the exam.

666
00:34:01,530 --> 00:34:03,900
In real life,
you might have other techniques.

667
00:34:03,900 --> 00:34:08,178
You'll see like a two-thirds
Majority is pretty common.

668
00:34:08,178 --> 00:34:11,140
And a two-thirds Majority
means somebody has to

669
00:34:11,140 --> 00:34:15,650
score of 66% in order to be the choice.

670
00:34:15,650 --> 00:34:18,908
You can see like
a three-fourths majority 75%.

671
00:34:18,908 --> 00:34:20,380
So there's variations of these.

672
00:34:20,380 --> 00:34:21,950
But just these four general concepts.

673
00:34:21,950 --> 00:34:23,690
These are the ones that we're
gonna see on the the exam.

674
00:34:25,650 --> 00:34:26,380
All right.

675
00:34:26,380 --> 00:34:28,640
Some of the other things that we've got.

676
00:34:28,640 --> 00:34:29,960
Questionnaires and surveys.

677
00:34:29,960 --> 00:34:30,510
All right.

678
00:34:30,510 --> 00:34:32,880
We talked earlier about focus groups.

679
00:34:32,880 --> 00:34:35,590
The problem with a focus group is
you've gotta get independent people

680
00:34:35,590 --> 00:34:37,110
outside your company to come in and

681
00:34:37,110 --> 00:34:42,050
sit in the room and take part in
an hour of questioning and stuff.

682
00:34:42,050 --> 00:34:44,190
It's not convenient, not fast.

683
00:34:44,190 --> 00:34:47,220
And it's not really an option for
a lot of people.

684
00:34:47,220 --> 00:34:50,030
Questionnaires and surveys,
on the other hand, are much more simple.

685
00:34:50,030 --> 00:34:52,840
You write up your questions and
you send them out to people.

686
00:34:52,840 --> 00:34:59,050
You send them out to a sizeable enough
portion that it's statistically valid.

687
00:34:59,050 --> 00:35:02,400
And you send it out to these people, or
statistically significant I think is

688
00:35:02,400 --> 00:35:06,180
the official term we're supposed to use,
and so we send that out to the people.

689
00:35:06,180 --> 00:35:09,290
And you're only gonna get a portion of
those surveys and questionnaires back,

690
00:35:09,290 --> 00:35:11,380
right, some people just
aren't gonna fill them out.

691
00:35:11,380 --> 00:35:13,020
But of the results you get back,

692
00:35:13,020 --> 00:35:15,970
you can start to make decisions
based on the responses.

693
00:35:15,970 --> 00:35:19,350
Just understand that there
are limitations to surveys.

694
00:35:19,350 --> 00:35:20,390
>> Yeah.
>> For example,

695
00:35:20,390 --> 00:35:22,530
if you're doing a phone survey.

696
00:35:22,530 --> 00:35:26,180
And you call various people by
phone to ask them questions,

697
00:35:26,180 --> 00:35:29,505
you're limiting yourself, one,
to people who have phones, right?

698
00:35:29,505 --> 00:35:30,890
>> Mm-hm
>> Not everybody does.

699
00:35:30,890 --> 00:35:34,550
And, two, you're limiting yourself to
people who have listed phone numbers.

700
00:35:34,550 --> 00:35:36,500
And so what you'll find is
when you do a phone survey,

701
00:35:36,500 --> 00:35:42,200
you're excluding the poverty classes,
and you're excluding the wealthy elite.

702
00:35:42,200 --> 00:35:45,650
And you're really just
polling the middle class.

703
00:35:45,650 --> 00:35:48,900
Right, the middle class society
is who's going to have phones and

704
00:35:48,900 --> 00:35:50,310
be listed in the phone book.

705
00:35:50,310 --> 00:35:51,820
And so
that's all your phone survey is hitting.

706
00:35:51,820 --> 00:35:54,190
And so you need to understand
your demographic and

707
00:35:54,190 --> 00:35:57,480
which is the best way
to reach out to them.

708
00:35:57,480 --> 00:35:59,910
If you do an internet survey, well,

709
00:35:59,910 --> 00:36:02,350
an internet survey assumes that
you've got people on the internet,

710
00:36:02,350 --> 00:36:06,990
that are using computers and so again,
you're excluding a lot of the elderly.

711
00:36:06,990 --> 00:36:11,200
People who didn't grow up using computers,
you're excluding the youth, you know?

712
00:36:11,200 --> 00:36:13,800
People who are too young
to get on the internet.

713
00:36:13,800 --> 00:36:17,664
You're excluding the Amish, so
if you're selling Amish goods,

714
00:36:17,664 --> 00:36:20,920
[LAUGH] wooden barrels or whatever,
then that's not going to work out so well.

715
00:36:20,920 --> 00:36:24,920
So you do need to tailor this so they
can be questions and surveys by paper.

716
00:36:24,920 --> 00:36:28,000
You can have a person just
walking around asking people.

717
00:36:28,000 --> 00:36:30,370
You can do all sorts of
ways to get information.

718
00:36:30,370 --> 00:36:32,989
It's kind of a cheaper
version of a focus group.

719
00:36:32,989 --> 00:36:36,410
>> Yeah.
>> Alright.

720
00:36:36,410 --> 00:36:37,950
Number 7 is Observations.

721
00:36:37,950 --> 00:36:41,550
Now, in the IT world we don't
see Observations that much,

722
00:36:41,550 --> 00:36:45,460
actually we did it here with
ITProTV with our redesign project.

723
00:36:47,050 --> 00:36:50,930
As a viewer, I don't know how long you
guys have been with us as a customer.

724
00:36:50,930 --> 00:36:54,420
But at the end of March in 2014
we did a website redesign.

725
00:36:54,420 --> 00:36:56,230
We had a website that looked one way.

726
00:36:56,230 --> 00:36:58,450
And then at the end of
March they changed it.

727
00:36:58,450 --> 00:37:00,150
And now it looks completely different.

728
00:37:00,150 --> 00:37:00,750
Right?

729
00:37:00,750 --> 00:37:02,710
Except the logo.
I think everything else is different.

730
00:37:02,710 --> 00:37:09,030
So that was actually the result of
a series of surveys and observation.

731
00:37:09,030 --> 00:37:14,110
We used Google Analytics to monitor how
people were navigating through our site.

732
00:37:14,110 --> 00:37:16,030
What links were the most clicked on.

733
00:37:16,030 --> 00:37:18,470
How long people spent on web pages.

734
00:37:18,470 --> 00:37:19,870
And we use that information,

735
00:37:19,870 --> 00:37:24,890
observation of how people use the page, to
make the decision of how to redesign it.

736
00:37:24,890 --> 00:37:28,220
If there was a link that nobody ever
clicked on, it didn't need to be there.

737
00:37:28,220 --> 00:37:29,250
It could go away.

738
00:37:29,250 --> 00:37:33,880
But if people are constantly clicking five
times to get to a particular destination,

739
00:37:33,880 --> 00:37:36,680
then it makes sense to move that so
that they will only have to click once.

740
00:37:36,680 --> 00:37:40,870
So, Observations were a direct contributor
to how we redesign that website.

741
00:37:42,160 --> 00:37:43,450
I say we.
I don't think I did anything.

742
00:37:43,450 --> 00:37:46,427
So we'll have the web designers
redesign the website.

743
00:37:46,427 --> 00:37:50,110
>> [LAUGH] The next one that we have
here is the idea of prototyping.

744
00:37:50,110 --> 00:37:53,470
Prototyping, again,
can come in many various forms for us.

745
00:37:53,470 --> 00:37:56,860
So they really do list about
three different examples

746
00:37:56,860 --> 00:37:58,310
in our PMBOK here for this.

747
00:37:58,310 --> 00:38:00,570
And the first one is just
a simple working model.

748
00:38:00,570 --> 00:38:01,240
Right?

749
00:38:01,240 --> 00:38:03,300
We again may not have everything done.

750
00:38:03,300 --> 00:38:05,820
We may say, hey,
here's a particular working model, and

751
00:38:05,820 --> 00:38:07,360
let's see how this works here.

752
00:38:07,360 --> 00:38:11,560
And we try it out, and again, depending
on how people take a look at this,

753
00:38:11,560 --> 00:38:13,690
then they go, that's exactly what we want.

754
00:38:13,690 --> 00:38:14,660
>> Yep.

755
00:38:14,660 --> 00:38:17,780
Yeah, you see Prototypes with any
kind of manufacturing project.

756
00:38:17,780 --> 00:38:22,520
I mentioned, for example, maybe we're
designing the new 2016 Ford Focus.

757
00:38:22,520 --> 00:38:24,430
And so we create a few Prototypes.

758
00:38:24,430 --> 00:38:26,370
That doesn't mean we
create full size cars.

759
00:38:26,370 --> 00:38:28,810
Maybe they're little clay models or
whatever.

760
00:38:28,810 --> 00:38:32,990
And so the designers create a few of these
and we use those in our focus groups and

761
00:38:32,990 --> 00:38:34,200
surveys and stuff.

762
00:38:34,200 --> 00:38:37,215
So it just gives people
a tangible ability to see it.

763
00:38:37,215 --> 00:38:42,035
Maybe you're creating some kind of hand
held, you know, iPod, MP3 player and

764
00:38:42,035 --> 00:38:46,075
so you want people to hold it in
their hand and see how it feels.

765
00:38:46,075 --> 00:38:51,560
That's easy to do if you have a real
prototype versus something that is just

766
00:38:51,560 --> 00:38:53,780
on a computer screen.

767
00:38:53,780 --> 00:38:55,170
>> Yeah.
>> Now with our website,

768
00:38:55,170 --> 00:38:58,870
the way that redesign went is
the designers actually submitted to us

769
00:38:58,870 --> 00:39:00,060
a wire frame drawing.

770
00:39:00,060 --> 00:39:01,700
And they said, here's what
the website's going to look like.

771
00:39:01,700 --> 00:39:02,540
what do you think?

772
00:39:02,540 --> 00:39:04,620
And we went back and
forth a few times as they revised it.

773
00:39:04,620 --> 00:39:05,950
Those were Prototypes, right?

774
00:39:05,950 --> 00:39:08,520
>> Yeah.
>> Just mock ups of what the website was

775
00:39:08,520 --> 00:39:09,870
going to look like.

776
00:39:09,870 --> 00:39:14,000
Storyboarding you really see with
things like movies and books, right?

777
00:39:14,000 --> 00:39:18,570
If you're gonna be doing a movie you've
got a whole plot to deal with, so.

778
00:39:18,570 --> 00:39:21,500
I was joking around
about it the other day.

779
00:39:21,500 --> 00:39:25,230
There was the movie 300 about the Spartan.

780
00:39:27,090 --> 00:39:28,730
>> Stand up thermo.

781
00:39:28,730 --> 00:39:31,200
No, thermopoly.
>> There you go, the thermopoly.

782
00:39:31,200 --> 00:39:33,250
So anyhow, they made a sequels
of the dag gone things.

783
00:39:33,250 --> 00:39:36,100
So, they made 300 parts to it,
or whatever it was called.

784
00:39:36,100 --> 00:39:39,470
And I remember saying at the time man,
how do they storyboard that.

785
00:39:39,470 --> 00:39:44,020
Because they had to say all right, first
thing, everyone died in the first film so

786
00:39:44,020 --> 00:39:45,550
I guess we're going to
need to overcome that.

787
00:39:45,550 --> 00:39:50,410
So we'll put that in here [LAUGH] so they
probably did a few different mock ups of,

788
00:39:50,410 --> 00:39:54,560
here's how we can resurrect all these
dead people and have a story out of it.

789
00:39:54,560 --> 00:39:56,550
So they do these storyboards.

790
00:39:56,550 --> 00:39:59,130
and then kind of play
out to see how it goes.

791
00:39:59,130 --> 00:40:00,320
>> All right.
>> Did you see that movie?

792
00:40:00,320 --> 00:40:01,560
>> I did not.
>> I curious how they get around.

You can't kill everybody and

794
