Mabye it's a prequel.

795
00:40:05,440 --> 00:40:07,840
>> Yeah.
>> Who knows.

796
00:40:07,840 --> 00:40:08,492
These are the things that way on my mind.

797
00:40:08,492 --> 00:40:10,510
>> You know they did do that
with the godfather movies.

798
00:40:10,510 --> 00:40:13,214
They'd kill everybody at
the end Michael Corleone.

799
00:40:13,214 --> 00:40:14,690
[CROSSTALK] Just goes back in the past.

800
00:40:14,690 --> 00:40:17,360
>> All right.

801
00:40:17,360 --> 00:40:18,540
Some of the other things.

802
00:40:18,540 --> 00:40:20,440
Benchmarking.

803
00:40:20,440 --> 00:40:22,880
If we have more than one solution.

804
00:40:22,880 --> 00:40:24,820
Right?
More than one requirement.

805
00:40:24,820 --> 00:40:26,170
We may need to do some Benchmarking,

806
00:40:26,170 --> 00:40:28,340
to determine which one actually
achieves what we want.

807
00:40:28,340 --> 00:40:31,130
If we know that we want to
get an engine that will

808
00:40:31,130 --> 00:40:34,560
give our car 54 miles to a gallon, right?

809
00:40:34,560 --> 00:40:39,400
Well then I might have more than
one engine that can do that.

810
00:40:39,400 --> 00:40:43,620
And so I might need to do Benchmarking
when I say here's my measure,

811
00:40:43,620 --> 00:40:47,390
I wanna have 54 miles to the gallon,
let's try these three or four engines.

812
00:40:47,390 --> 00:40:48,910
And see which one does the best,

813
00:40:48,910 --> 00:40:52,410
and it may be that we find one
that 58 miles to a gallon, and

814
00:40:52,410 --> 00:40:55,440
that's not what we wanted it's better and
so we choose to go that route.

815
00:40:55,440 --> 00:40:58,350
You know we don't know unless we
start to compare the different ones.

816
00:40:58,350 --> 00:41:01,010
And then once we've picked that,
we make that part of our requirement.

817
00:41:01,010 --> 00:41:02,780
We require that we use
this particular engine,

818
00:41:02,780 --> 00:41:05,847
because it gives us the performance
characteristics we want.

819
00:41:08,090 --> 00:41:10,125
All right, we have Context Diagrams.

820
00:41:10,125 --> 00:41:15,150
[LAUGH] Sometimes when we look at just
an individual piece of the project

821
00:41:15,150 --> 00:41:18,730
by itself everything is simple and it
looks like we've planned for everything.

822
00:41:18,730 --> 00:41:21,200
But then when we start to
string it all together and

823
00:41:21,200 --> 00:41:24,690
put it into context,
we see problems creep up.

824
00:41:24,690 --> 00:41:25,590
Right?

825
00:41:25,590 --> 00:41:28,310
This is really true with building a house.

826
00:41:28,310 --> 00:41:32,650
You're building a house so you might
secure a contractor to do the plumbing,

827
00:41:32,650 --> 00:41:36,120
a contractor to do the electricity,
a contractor to do the drywall.

828
00:41:36,120 --> 00:41:39,090
Well, you don't want people
putting up the drywall

829
00:41:39,090 --> 00:41:42,250
before the electricians
run the electrical cable.

830
00:41:42,250 --> 00:41:44,730
And you don't want
the plumber coming in and

831
00:41:44,730 --> 00:41:46,990
running plumbing that gets in
the way of the electrician.

832
00:41:46,990 --> 00:41:50,850
And so independently it's really
easy to plan and line them up.

833
00:41:50,850 --> 00:41:54,800
But getting them to kind of work together,
that becomes a bit of a challenge.

834
00:41:54,800 --> 00:41:58,290
And we start to do Context Diagrams kind
of showing how all of this is going to

835
00:41:58,290 --> 00:42:02,730
work, any inputs into the systems,
the actors that are apart of it and so on.

836
00:42:02,730 --> 00:42:05,450
We can start to see complexities
that we didn't see at first, and

837
00:42:05,450 --> 00:42:06,440
we can start to plan for those.

838
00:42:07,830 --> 00:42:10,150
>> You know the last one here is
the idea of Document Analysis.

839
00:42:10,150 --> 00:42:13,490
Sometimes, it is getting
information from the past again and

840
00:42:13,490 --> 00:42:17,560
coming in and being able to actually
add in something into the scope itself.

841
00:42:17,560 --> 00:42:21,150
Or maybe even examining a comparison
product that you may actually want to do.

842
00:42:21,150 --> 00:42:23,280
And take a look at some of
the documentation behind it.

843
00:42:23,280 --> 00:42:26,370
And pulling information from that to
help you build your scope as well.

844
00:42:26,370 --> 00:42:28,840
So I mean there's a couple of
different neat techniques here for

845
00:42:28,840 --> 00:42:31,060
us to be able to help us
fulfill what we need to.

846
00:42:31,060 --> 00:42:35,120
>> Now the key thing to remember here,
it's not necessarily your documents.

847
00:42:35,120 --> 00:42:37,780
I mentioned the Gardner Group
in an earlier episode.

848
00:42:37,780 --> 00:42:40,540
When I engage in a high level IT project,

849
00:42:40,540 --> 00:42:42,040
I'll usually reach out
to the Gardner Group and

850
00:42:42,040 --> 00:42:45,170
say hey, do you have any documentation
from other companies that have done this?

851
00:42:45,170 --> 00:42:47,700
And that way I can get a copy
of their project document.

852
00:42:47,700 --> 00:42:48,850
So I'm not analyzing mine.

853
00:42:48,850 --> 00:42:49,790
I'm analyzing theirs.

854
00:42:49,790 --> 00:42:53,010
And saying okay,
how can I benefit from what they learned?

855
00:42:53,010 --> 00:42:54,460
How can I streamline my system?

856
00:42:54,460 --> 00:42:56,700
So that's a very useful thing to have.

857
00:42:58,430 --> 00:43:02,370
All right, so those are all the tools and
techniques available for

858
00:43:02,370 --> 00:43:03,660
collect requirements.

859
00:43:03,660 --> 00:43:05,460
Are we going to use them all?

860
00:43:05,460 --> 00:43:06,350
Probably not, right?

861
00:43:06,350 --> 00:43:09,500
Maybe if you're super thorough, but
normally you're only going to need three

862
00:43:09,500 --> 00:43:13,130
or four of these to be able to get
the information that you need.

863
00:43:13,130 --> 00:43:17,010
Now you might pass through it more than
once, you might do a set of focus groups,

864
00:43:17,010 --> 00:43:21,180
make some changes and then do another set
of focus groups, make some more changes,

865
00:43:21,180 --> 00:43:22,610
then maybe do some surveys.

866
00:43:22,610 --> 00:43:26,590
You know, so you'll mix and match these,
you'll go through it several times and

867
00:43:26,590 --> 00:43:29,030
that's why, when we reach the end of this,

868
00:43:29,030 --> 00:43:32,720
we've got requirements documentation,
where we write out our requirements.

869
00:43:32,720 --> 00:43:36,800
And then we may just feed that right
back in here as our requirements and

870
00:43:36,800 --> 00:43:37,550
repeat, right?

871
00:43:37,550 --> 00:43:40,350
Rinse and repeat, you can cycle
through this one several times.

872
00:43:40,350 --> 00:43:42,900
You continue cycling through it

873
00:43:42,900 --> 00:43:45,820
until everyone agrees that
you've covered all your bases.

874
00:43:45,820 --> 00:43:50,010
You don't want any surprise requirements
creeping up later on because

875
00:43:50,010 --> 00:43:54,870
you won't have planned for them and
they're gonna slip through the cracks.

876
00:43:54,870 --> 00:43:58,280
The other output that we have, though,
aside from the requirements documentation,

877
00:43:58,280 --> 00:44:00,910
is the requirements
Traceability Matrix and

878
00:44:00,910 --> 00:44:03,730
I know I've talked about this
one a couple of times now.

879
00:44:03,730 --> 00:44:06,970
But the main goal of that Traceability,

880
00:44:06,970 --> 00:44:10,250
actually we've got quite
a bit of stuff here.

881
00:44:10,250 --> 00:44:11,960
Let's talk about
the Traceability one first.

882
00:44:11,960 --> 00:44:12,660
>> Okay.
>> And then we'll

883
00:44:12,660 --> 00:44:14,390
come back to the other one.

884
00:44:14,390 --> 00:44:18,720
So when we're talking about that
Traceability Matrix, this guy right here.

885
00:44:18,720 --> 00:44:26,090
What it's doing is it's helping us to keep
track of the requirements themselves,

886
00:44:26,090 --> 00:44:30,440
where they came from, who's responsible,
how they're interrelated.

887
00:44:30,440 --> 00:44:33,380
And so we need to make sure
we've got a record of that.

888
00:44:33,380 --> 00:44:37,220
Now, some of this we'll be able to fill
out right away, some we won't because

889
00:44:37,220 --> 00:44:40,900
we'll see it's tied to another document
called a work breakdown structure, and

890
00:44:40,900 --> 00:44:42,740
we don't have the work
breakdown structure yet.

891
00:44:42,740 --> 00:44:47,200
So we may have to go and design that and
then come back and revisit this again.

892
00:44:47,200 --> 00:44:49,600
So that Traceability Matrix
is a pretty neat thing, and

893
00:44:49,600 --> 00:44:51,320
we'll take a look at it in a moment.

894
00:44:51,320 --> 00:44:52,920
But I wanted to step back and

895
00:44:52,920 --> 00:44:56,690
take a look at some of this
Requirements documentation.

896
00:44:56,690 --> 00:45:00,250
When we create that requirements document,
we're identifying

897
00:45:00,250 --> 00:45:04,660
every requirement that we catalog and
some basic information about about it and

898
00:45:04,660 --> 00:45:07,910
PMI has three categories that
they really hit on there.

899
00:45:07,910 --> 00:45:12,980
They have Business Requirements, Solution
Requirements, and Project Requirements.

900
00:45:14,050 --> 00:45:16,560
>> One more,
that's Stakeholder Requirements.

901
00:45:16,560 --> 00:45:17,924
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> The Stakeholder Requirements

902
00:45:17,924 --> 00:45:19,697
are probably the most important of them.

903
00:45:19,697 --> 00:45:24,460
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, when you go into a project,

904
00:45:24,460 --> 00:45:27,080
>> The one that you're hearing about first

905
00:45:27,080 --> 00:45:29,890
is you're hearing about what's
coming from the originator.

906
00:45:29,890 --> 00:45:32,100
Right?
That person who's kicking this off,

907
00:45:32,100 --> 00:45:33,790
who wants to get this thing done.

908
00:45:33,790 --> 00:45:36,010
It's their baby, their project, and

909
00:45:36,010 --> 00:45:38,400
they wanna make sure that
it gets taken care of.

910
00:45:38,400 --> 00:45:39,860
It's actually, I guess,
that should be indented.

911
00:45:41,940 --> 00:45:43,500
So those are what we're working on.

912
00:45:43,500 --> 00:45:46,240
But other requirements come
from different places.

913
00:45:46,240 --> 00:45:49,930
So our business might have it's
own set of requirements for

914
00:45:49,930 --> 00:45:51,750
any project that we undertake.

915
00:45:52,800 --> 00:45:57,260
So for example, you might have a
governance requirement, that says whatever

916
00:45:57,260 --> 00:46:01,760
project you're in, you've got to do
weekly financial status reporting,

917
00:46:01,760 --> 00:46:04,330
to show your current budget allocation.

918
00:46:04,330 --> 00:46:06,530
Are you above, below, or on budget?

919
00:46:06,530 --> 00:46:08,080
So we want to know and
want it to be weekly.

920
00:46:08,080 --> 00:46:12,490
There might be other requirements in there
that say, all along the way, any time you

921
00:46:12,490 --> 00:46:16,615
cut a check, you've got to submit this
paperwork into the accounting department.

922
00:46:16,615 --> 00:46:19,985
And so these become requirements that
aren't something to work towards.

923
00:46:19,985 --> 00:46:23,150
We just have to make sure we follow as
we go through to meet that requirement.

924
00:46:23,150 --> 00:46:24,605
>> Mm-hm.
>> So they may have their own

925
00:46:24,605 --> 00:46:26,965
values in there, all right?

926
00:46:26,965 --> 00:46:29,530
And you'll see some of the things here
that we gotta make sure that we have

927
00:46:29,530 --> 00:46:32,060
Traceability which we'll
see with the matrix,

928
00:46:32,060 --> 00:46:36,260
that we've got other business rules for
performing, right?

929
00:46:36,260 --> 00:46:38,800
You have to meet certain
performance levels, and

930
00:46:38,800 --> 00:46:43,035
we've got just the general
[LAUGH] Guiding Principles.

931
00:46:43,035 --> 00:46:43,655
There we go.

932
00:46:43,655 --> 00:46:47,595
The general Guiding Principles of our
Organization and how they do business.

933
00:46:47,595 --> 00:46:48,535
This would be like Google.

934
00:46:48,535 --> 00:46:51,295
>> Yeah.
>> Google has that motto, don't be evil.

935
00:46:51,295 --> 00:46:53,255
Right?
That's their company motto.

936
00:46:53,255 --> 00:46:55,205
So whatever project they undertake,

937
00:46:56,250 --> 00:47:00,600
which that project might be illegally
capturing people's data across America.

938
00:47:00,600 --> 00:47:01,680
>> No.
>> Which they did.

939
00:47:01,680 --> 00:47:04,550
But as long as they did it by not
being evil then that's okay, right?

940
00:47:04,550 --> 00:47:05,090
>> That's true.

941
00:47:05,090 --> 00:47:06,980
>> So I think they failed on that one.

942
00:47:06,980 --> 00:47:10,370
So yeah but those are things that
might come from the business.

943
00:47:10,370 --> 00:47:10,870
>> Yeah.

944
00:47:12,200 --> 00:47:14,880
Now the stakeholder I talked
about this one earlier,

945
00:47:14,880 --> 00:47:18,400
this isn't necessarily the originator
this is any stakeholder that we attach,

946
00:47:18,400 --> 00:47:21,398
remember I mentioned
that example of training.

947
00:47:21,398 --> 00:47:25,400
So a mid-level manager says boy,
I'm really worried about our people being

948
00:47:25,400 --> 00:47:27,580
trained up on this software
we're about to deploy.

949
00:47:27,580 --> 00:47:30,090
Can we add to the project
a training period, right?

950
00:47:30,090 --> 00:47:35,060
So here's a new requirement that
creeps up and the originator or

951
00:47:35,060 --> 00:47:38,080
stakeholder may look a that and approve
it, and say, yeah, that's a good idea,

952
00:47:38,080 --> 00:47:39,310
let's put that in there.

953
00:47:39,310 --> 00:47:44,930
So we have this when we impact other
organizational areas in our company.

954
00:47:44,930 --> 00:47:47,480
These are other people that have
requirements because they're affected

955
00:47:47,480 --> 00:47:48,190
by the project.

956
00:47:49,360 --> 00:47:53,860
Same thing with entities, inside or
outside of the organization,

957
00:47:53,860 --> 00:47:57,520
that we may have contractors or
more commonly our customers.

958
00:47:57,520 --> 00:48:01,445
So, when I worked for the bank and we
were replacing all these networks, well,

959
00:48:01,445 --> 00:48:04,920
we had to take the ATM machines
offline while we replace the networks.

960
00:48:04,920 --> 00:48:07,679
That inconvenienced our customers,
and so we had to

961
00:48:07,679 --> 00:48:12,080
make sure to schedule that during a time
when it would impact the fewest customers.

962
00:48:12,080 --> 00:48:16,910
So we wanted to replace the network lines,
but there was a new requirement that was

963
00:48:16,910 --> 00:48:19,860
we had to do it while
minimizing customer access.

964
00:48:19,860 --> 00:48:24,240
So we had to analyze what times
the ATM machines were busiest and

965
00:48:24,240 --> 00:48:26,230
what time they were the least busy, and

966
00:48:26,230 --> 00:48:29,340
schedule the changeover to happen
when the ATMs were the least busy.

967
00:48:29,340 --> 00:48:31,480
Our customers determined
our migration schedule.

968
00:48:34,270 --> 00:48:36,648
And then lastly,
just general communication requirements.

969
00:48:36,648 --> 00:48:40,310
The other stakeholders that are out
there may not actually have influence on

970
00:48:40,310 --> 00:48:41,250
your project.

971
00:48:41,250 --> 00:48:43,260
They just need to be informed.

972
00:48:43,260 --> 00:48:46,950
And so we might have to introduce
requirements that pertain to how we

973
00:48:46,950 --> 00:48:52,040
communicate that, and we'll see that
with the communications management plan.

974
00:48:52,040 --> 00:48:54,250
Now the solution requirements.

975
00:48:54,250 --> 00:48:57,670
These are generally the ones that come
in the beginning from the originator,

976
00:48:57,670 --> 00:49:02,400
from maybe the sponsor, but
whoever it is that kicked this thing off.

977
00:49:02,400 --> 00:49:06,690
They have a set of requirements and we've
got to meet those to make the solution for

978
00:49:06,690 --> 00:49:07,690
their system.

979
00:49:07,690 --> 00:49:12,820
But we may identify other things as
we go that we have to live up to.

980
00:49:12,820 --> 00:49:16,930
Now when a person comes up with a list
of requirements for what they want,

981
00:49:16,930 --> 00:49:19,930
they're generally functional and
nonfunctional requirements.

982
00:49:19,930 --> 00:49:22,330
A functional requirement is
something that's needed for

983
00:49:22,330 --> 00:49:26,430
this device to perform its function or
for this solution to work.

984
00:49:26,430 --> 00:49:29,920
There's nonfunctional ones that
aren't necessarily required for

985
00:49:29,920 --> 00:49:34,590
the service or device or
whatever to perform its function but

986
00:49:34,590 --> 00:49:38,300
are still required for some other reason.

987
00:49:38,300 --> 00:49:40,500
So for example, the ITProTV website.

988
00:49:40,500 --> 00:49:42,340
Our website doesn't have to look nice.

989
00:49:42,340 --> 00:49:45,880
It could look like vintage
1997 if we wanted it to,

990
00:49:45,880 --> 00:49:50,090
as long as people were able to log in,
subscribe, watch videos and do that stuff,

991
00:49:50,090 --> 00:49:51,730
as long as the functionality was there.

992
00:49:51,730 --> 00:49:58,040
But we chose to have it look a little more
modern because, well, people like that.

993
00:49:58,040 --> 00:49:59,420
It's part of the experience.

994
00:49:59,420 --> 00:50:01,960
We want you guys to have an enjoyable
experience when you hit the web page.

995
00:50:01,960 --> 00:50:03,609
So those are our kind of
nonfunctional requirements.

996
00:50:05,400 --> 00:50:09,420
All right, technology and
standard compliance requirements.

997
00:50:09,420 --> 00:50:11,700
These come from whatever our industry is.

998
00:50:11,700 --> 00:50:15,505
So if you're in the banking industry
you might have SAS 70 requirements or

999
00:50:15,505 --> 00:50:17,190
Sarbanes-Oxley to deal with.

1000
00:50:17,190 --> 00:50:19,430
In the medical industry
you have HIPAA compliance.

1001
00:50:19,430 --> 00:50:22,832
So we may get requirements that come not
from the originator but from these laws,

1002
00:50:22,832 --> 00:50:24,294
these statutes and regulations.

1003
00:50:27,568 --> 00:50:30,810
All right, support and training I
kind of already talked about I guess.

1004
00:50:30,810 --> 00:50:34,970
If we need to make sure that people are
prepared to use what it is we're doing.

1005
00:50:34,970 --> 00:50:38,360
If we're designing the new 2016
Ford Focus, we need to make sure

1006
00:50:38,360 --> 00:50:41,570
the engineering team knows how to
build what it is that we're designing.

1007
00:50:41,570 --> 00:50:44,910
And you see this all the time in
technology but in other industries too.

1008
00:50:47,892 --> 00:50:50,490
Quality requirements,
these are kinda hard to define.

1009
00:50:50,490 --> 00:50:53,530
For most of us, quality simply
means meeting our requirements.

1010
00:50:53,530 --> 00:50:56,680
Whatever requirements we define,
if we meet them all, we hit our quality.

1011
00:50:56,680 --> 00:51:00,850
But in manufacturing you
have a certain yield rate.

1012
00:51:00,850 --> 00:51:02,767
In manufacturing,
it doesn't matter what you manufacture.

1013
00:51:02,767 --> 00:51:06,936
You can manufacture blue jeans, and
out of 1,000 pairs of blue jeans,

1014
00:51:06,936 --> 00:51:11,169
you're going to have some-
>> Defect qualities, defects?

1015
00:51:11,169 --> 00:51:11,969
>> Defects, that is the exact word.

1016
00:51:11,969 --> 00:51:13,747
So you'll have some defects.

1017
00:51:13,747 --> 00:51:17,940
And the defects, they're just there and
it's a part of that process.

1018
00:51:17,940 --> 00:51:21,337
And so maintaining quality is
minimizing the amount of defects.

1019
00:51:21,337 --> 00:51:24,803
And that's where you see
things like Six Sigma and CPI,

1020
00:51:24,803 --> 00:51:26,945
Continual Process Improvement,

1021
00:51:26,945 --> 00:51:30,290
where they're not working
to change the processes.

1022
00:51:30,290 --> 00:51:32,510
They're working to reduce the defects.

1023
00:51:32,510 --> 00:51:34,019
The less defects you have, the better.

1024
00:51:34,019 --> 00:51:38,252
In IT, when Intel makes processors,
when they make CPUs,

1025
00:51:38,252 --> 00:51:43,515
they print them in sheets that are several
hundred processors on a sheet.

1026
00:51:43,515 --> 00:51:46,637
And they just plan from the beginning
that they know they're gonna have

1027
00:51:46,637 --> 00:51:48,110
a failure rate in there.

1028
00:51:48,110 --> 00:51:52,399
And when they make a brand new processor,
like these new Bay Trail ones right now,

1029
00:51:52,399 --> 00:51:54,710
their yield rate is something like 40%.

1030
00:51:54,710 --> 00:52:00,410
They're losing over 60% of those CPUs and
they just become trash in a lot of cases.

1031
00:52:00,410 --> 00:52:01,913
But over time they get better and
better and

1032
00:52:01,913 --> 00:52:03,640
better at it,
until their yield rate is 90%.

1033
00:52:03,640 --> 00:52:07,190
And so they're always going
to be throwing some away.

1034
00:52:07,190 --> 00:52:09,689
When you have millions of
transistors that close together,

1035
00:52:09,689 --> 00:52:11,410
you're always gonna have some defects.

1036
00:52:11,410 --> 00:52:17,030
And then the reporting requirements, these
usually come from the originator also.

1037
00:52:17,030 --> 00:52:20,090
They say hey, as this project goes on,
I need to be kept in the loop,

1038
00:52:20,090 --> 00:52:21,760
I need to know this information.

1039
00:52:21,760 --> 00:52:25,270
But if they don't ask for it, we need
to impose it as the project manager,

1040
00:52:25,270 --> 00:52:29,370
as part of our openness and
clarity as we share the information.

1041
00:52:29,370 --> 00:52:29,980
>> Accountability.
>> Yeah,

1042
00:52:29,980 --> 00:52:34,550
absolutely, so the best way to
avoid the appearance of impropriety

1043
00:52:34,550 --> 00:52:37,290
is to be open with your information,
so keep it available.

1044
00:52:38,820 --> 00:52:40,850
All right, and
we're running short on time, but

1045
00:52:40,850 --> 00:52:44,220
let's just hit some of these last
ones here real quick before we stop.

1046
00:52:44,220 --> 00:52:45,930
The project requirements.

1047
00:52:45,930 --> 00:52:49,010
So these are requirements that come
from the project management plan.

1048
00:52:49,010 --> 00:52:52,890
In the project management plan it'll
define any special requirements we have,

1049
00:52:52,890 --> 00:52:57,085
and these'll be things like our level of
service, performance, safety, compliance.

1050
00:52:57,085 --> 00:53:00,615
That's things that we have to live up to
because the company has designated that.

1051
00:53:02,115 --> 00:53:06,655
Then the acceptance criteria also coming
from that plan, saying when this project

1052
00:53:06,655 --> 00:53:11,335
is done, how do both sides
know it's done beyond a doubt?

1053
00:53:11,335 --> 00:53:13,585
So what is that acceptance criteria?

1054
00:53:13,585 --> 00:53:16,250
If we've met all the requirements,
then you get acceptance.

1055
00:53:16,250 --> 00:53:17,660
The project's closed.

1056
00:53:17,660 --> 00:53:19,570
If we haven't met the requirements,
what do we do?

1057
00:53:19,570 --> 00:53:22,702
What do we do to obtain that,
to get acceptance?

1058
00:53:22,702 --> 00:53:25,360
How do we get up to speed?

1059
00:53:25,360 --> 00:53:27,164
Transition requirements.

1060
00:53:27,164 --> 00:53:31,787
If you are in a multipart project,
a project of multiple subprojects,

1061
00:53:31,787 --> 00:53:36,718
when your subproject is done, we
transition into the next subproject, and

1062
00:53:36,718 --> 00:53:40,980
there's information that has
to be shared and other things.

1063
00:53:40,980 --> 00:53:44,510
The second team has to be ready to receive
whatever it is that we've produced.

1064
00:53:44,510 --> 00:53:47,760
And so we've got requirements
to ensure interoperability.

1065
00:53:47,760 --> 00:53:52,780
That's what broke down with the United
States Healthcare website, healthcare.gov.

1066
00:53:52,780 --> 00:53:57,840
They had one big healthcare
website to design and

1067
00:53:57,840 --> 00:54:00,472
they used 25 separate contractors.

1068
00:54:00,472 --> 00:54:03,627
They had one big one that oversaw it and
then 25 subcontractors.

1069
00:54:03,627 --> 00:54:09,190
And each contractor worked independently,
produced these 25 pieces, QCed them.

1070
00:54:09,190 --> 00:54:10,960
They all passed, they all worked well.

1071
00:54:10,960 --> 00:54:12,520
And then they just threw
them all together and

1072
00:54:12,520 --> 00:54:14,310
they assume they would work,
which they didn't.

1073
00:54:14,310 --> 00:54:18,310
And so for months the site was unusable,
and that's what happens.

1074
00:54:18,310 --> 00:54:21,980
You've gotta have transition requirements
so you're readied for that interoperation.

1075
00:54:23,600 --> 00:54:29,060
And then lastly, requirements assumptions,
dependencies and constraints.

1076
00:54:29,060 --> 00:54:33,780
This is anything else that we know
that could limit our project.

1077
00:54:33,780 --> 00:54:37,550
Dependencies and constraints,
these are usually tied to budget,

1078
00:54:37,550 --> 00:54:42,840
schedule, resources, when you can
get people available and so on.

1079
00:54:42,840 --> 00:54:45,340
And then assumptions are just,

1080
00:54:45,340 --> 00:54:48,110
at this stage in the game
there's things we don't know.

1081
00:54:48,110 --> 00:54:54,181
We're making some assumptions about our
project and hopefully they stay true, but

1082
00:54:54,181 --> 00:54:59,582
they might not, so we need to make sure
that's all documented in here too.

1083
00:54:59,582 --> 00:55:00,415
All right, so

1084
00:55:00,415 --> 00:55:04,730
those are the primary outputs as far
as the requirements documentation.

1085
00:55:04,730 --> 00:55:08,200
We're gonna take a look after the break
at a template of what that documentation

1086
00:55:08,200 --> 00:55:09,810
looks like and how we catalog it.

1087
00:55:09,810 --> 00:55:12,680
And then we'll take a look at
the requirements traceability matrix also,

1088
00:55:12,680 --> 00:55:14,050
get a chance to see that.

1089
00:55:14,050 --> 00:55:19,350
It's some pretty neat stuff, so definitely
something to take a look at there.

1090
00:55:19,350 --> 00:55:21,520
All right, well, ladies and
gentlemen, stay tuned.

1091
00:55:21,520 --> 00:55:24,730
When we get back,
more requirements after this.

1092
00:55:24,730 --> 00:55:30,788
[MUSIC]

1093
00:55:30,788 --> 00:55:33,150
All right, welcome back, everybody.

1094
00:55:33,150 --> 00:55:38,060
So before the break, we were talking
about requirements documentation, and

1095
00:55:38,060 --> 00:55:41,230
then afterwards we still had
the traceability matrix, right?

1096
00:55:41,230 --> 00:55:44,434
So on the requirements documentation,
it sounded like a lot and

1097
00:55:44,434 --> 00:55:47,058
when you look at those notes,
where'd my notes go?

1098
00:55:47,058 --> 00:55:50,178
Here, requirements documentation,
I started here and

1099
00:55:50,178 --> 00:55:54,802
went all the way down here and good gosh,
there's just so much stuff there, right?

1100
00:55:54,802 --> 00:55:55,949
But at the end of the day,

1101
00:55:55,949 --> 00:55:59,127
requirements documentation is
actually pretty straightforward.

1102
00:55:59,127 --> 00:56:02,607
If you start with a template, so
I've got my little template here for

1103
00:56:02,607 --> 00:56:06,569
requirements documentation, you can
start with something fairly simple and

1104
00:56:06,569 --> 00:56:10,770
throw information in there, knowing that
we can always be more specific later on,

1105
00:56:10,770 --> 00:56:14,391
but we need to get the basics here so
that it's everything identified.

1106
00:56:14,391 --> 00:56:18,644
And so using this template you
would basically go through and,

1107
00:56:18,644 --> 00:56:21,250
first you'd figure how to zoom in.

1108
00:56:21,250 --> 00:56:22,900
That's gonna help me some.

1109
00:56:24,040 --> 00:56:25,330
There we go.

1110
00:56:25,330 --> 00:56:27,650
And you go through and
you just start to fill it out.

1111
00:56:27,650 --> 00:56:31,220
And like any of my templates,
we put the project title, project manager,

1112
00:56:31,220 --> 00:56:34,490
date prepared up there at the top, and
then you get into the real information.

1113
00:56:35,530 --> 00:56:38,580
With each requirement we
need to track a few things.

1114
00:56:38,580 --> 00:56:40,700
Every requirement should
have an ID number.

1115
00:56:40,700 --> 00:56:43,920
The ID number, or letter or name,
whatever it is you want to use,

1116
00:56:43,920 --> 00:56:47,630
I almost always use numbers,
helps us to refer to these later on.

1117
00:56:47,630 --> 00:56:49,450
Hey, I'm working with
requirement number seven.

1118
00:56:49,450 --> 00:56:50,920
Can you take a look at this?

1119
00:56:50,920 --> 00:56:54,320
Or requirement number seven actually
depends on requirement number

1120
00:56:54,320 --> 00:56:55,850
four being complete.

1121
00:56:55,850 --> 00:56:59,710
Having a number makes it much easier
to write this and represent it.

1122
00:56:59,710 --> 00:57:04,570
So we can pick whatever we
want those numbers to be, and

1123
00:57:04,570 --> 00:57:06,020
just kind of throw those in there.

1124
00:57:07,294 --> 00:57:10,400
You might want to pretty this up
a little bit or something, I don't know.

1125
00:57:10,400 --> 00:57:12,584
But basically you throw that
information in there and

1126
00:57:12,584 --> 00:57:15,090
then you start to list what
your requirements are.

1127
00:57:15,090 --> 00:57:18,480
Now remember, your original
stakeholder gave you some requirements

1128
00:57:18,480 --> 00:57:22,250
back in the charter draft when
we were trying to do that.

1129
00:57:22,250 --> 00:57:25,710
And so if a project manager was
already attached at that time, they

1130
00:57:25,710 --> 00:57:29,115
were probably filling out this document
even though we weren't in planning yet,

1131
00:57:29,115 --> 00:57:30,700
cuz that saves a little time.

1132
00:57:30,700 --> 00:57:32,960
But otherwise, we can just cut and paste.

1133
00:57:32,960 --> 00:57:36,050
We can get the requirements from
the charter and throw them in here and

1134
00:57:36,050 --> 00:57:38,660
start to add to it as we go.

1135
00:57:38,660 --> 00:57:44,796
So we might have a color consistency

1136
00:57:44,796 --> 00:57:48,890
requirement and so on.

1137
00:57:48,890 --> 00:57:51,130
You know we just start to list
these various requirements.

1138
00:57:51,130 --> 00:57:54,710
We specify the stakeholder, where they
came from, so this one came from me,

1139
00:57:54,710 --> 00:57:57,180
and a category.

1140
00:57:57,180 --> 00:58:00,660
Now I said I like to do Primary,

1141
00:58:00,660 --> 00:58:05,650
Secondary and Optional as my categories,
but you can use whatever category

1142
00:58:05,650 --> 00:58:09,170
system you want to be able to rank and
prioritize these.

1143
00:58:09,170 --> 00:58:12,830
Now you'll see this particular
form has a priority column also.

1144
00:58:12,830 --> 00:58:14,040
You may not need both.

1145
00:58:14,040 --> 00:58:19,480
You may just need one, so
customize it however you want.

1146
00:58:19,480 --> 00:58:21,340
But if I continue down my requirements,

1147
00:58:21,340 --> 00:58:26,360
maybe I've got a couple of primary
ones that have to get done, but

1148
00:58:26,360 --> 00:58:29,630
this one's priority number one
because it's got to be done first.

1149
00:58:29,630 --> 00:58:31,860
These other guys may be
in a different order.

1150
00:58:31,860 --> 00:58:34,500
So I come through and
I start to prioritize these.

1151
00:58:34,500 --> 00:58:36,890
That way if I ever have to
make a choice between one or

1152
00:58:36,890 --> 00:58:40,636
the other, I'll assign priority
to one that's a higher priority.

1153
00:58:40,636 --> 00:58:44,140
All right, acceptance criteria.

1154
00:58:44,140 --> 00:58:46,300
How do I know when I've
met the requirement?

1155
00:58:46,300 --> 00:58:49,690
So what test is being
used to measure that?

1156
00:58:49,690 --> 00:58:51,550
Now there's two ways to go about this.

1157
00:58:51,550 --> 00:58:55,210
If it's a straightforward yes or
no, it's complete,

1158
00:58:55,210 --> 00:59:00,500
tangible good received, then we can
put that, tangible good received.

1159
00:59:00,500 --> 00:59:04,830
So if I have a requirement
that five prototype

1160
00:59:06,050 --> 00:59:12,130
wax mold Ford Focus 2016 models
are created, I'll know that it's done,

1161
00:59:12,130 --> 00:59:17,540
I'll accept that, when I have five wax
model 2016 Ford Focus models in my hand.

1162
00:59:17,540 --> 00:59:20,490
Right, so you don't need anything crazy.

1163
00:59:20,490 --> 00:59:24,500
But, what if it was the result of
focus groups and opinion surveys and

1164
00:59:24,500 --> 00:59:25,630
stuff like that?

1165
00:59:25,630 --> 00:59:28,570
In that scenario,
you might need to have some kind of

1166
00:59:28,570 --> 00:59:32,390
test where you run a test to
find out if you're meeting that.

1167
00:59:32,390 --> 00:59:35,030
So we're designing a process, and

1168
00:59:35,030 --> 00:59:38,980
the process is the process of how
we're going to manufacture blue jeans.

1169
00:59:38,980 --> 00:59:42,310
And we should be able to manufacture
1,000 blue jeans per hour

1170
00:59:42,310 --> 00:59:45,040
with a 10% defect rate.

1171
00:59:45,040 --> 00:59:49,890
Well, if I want to accept that process
is being done I'm gonna need to run

1172
00:59:49,890 --> 00:59:54,440
a test and so I may have a QC or
QA, quality control,

1173
00:59:54,440 --> 00:59:57,750
quality assurance test that we run.

1174
00:59:57,750 --> 01:00:02,640
And maybe we do 1,000 pairs of blue jeans
and we see what our defect rate is.

1175
01:00:02,640 --> 01:00:06,960
And if it's under 10%,
then we know we've met that requirement.

1176
01:00:06,960 --> 01:00:09,590
But if it's over 10%, we know we
haven't met the requirement yet and so

1177
01:00:09,590 --> 01:00:12,900
we go back to the books and
we continue to refine our process.

1178
01:00:12,900 --> 01:00:15,630
So different projects are going
to have different needs.

1179
01:00:15,630 --> 01:00:18,260
You may not have acceptance criteria for
everything.

1180
01:00:18,260 --> 01:00:26,160
Your acceptance criteria might
be to pass the validation tests.

1181
01:00:27,360 --> 01:00:29,670
And so then you would just jump
over to this other column.

1182
01:00:29,670 --> 01:00:32,680
But if it's something like this,
tangible good received, you don't

1183
01:00:32,680 --> 01:00:37,600
need a validation method for that, so
you just put non-applicable and that's it.

1184
01:00:37,600 --> 01:00:41,010
So you basically fill this out based
on the information that you need.

1185
01:00:42,010 --> 01:00:45,560
Understand that the first
time you fill this out,

1186
01:00:45,560 --> 01:00:47,050
you're not gonna have
all your requirements.

1187
01:00:47,050 --> 01:00:48,240
It's a rare thing.

1188
01:00:48,240 --> 01:00:49,600
I've never had it happen.

1189
01:00:49,600 --> 01:00:53,090
Maybe somebody smarter than me or
something does, but for

1190
01:00:53,090 --> 01:00:53,830
me that never happens.

1191
01:00:53,830 --> 01:00:58,140
So we're gonna revisit this
document over and over again.

1192
01:00:58,140 --> 01:01:01,840
Every time we have a brainstorm meeting,
every time we send out a survey and

1193
01:01:01,840 --> 01:01:05,550
we start to get this information back,
we identify new requirements and

1194
01:01:05,550 --> 01:01:06,620
we throw them on here.

1195
01:01:06,620 --> 01:01:09,490
So I've got room for seven, right?

1196
01:01:09,490 --> 01:01:14,290
But you just keep adding somehow, there.

1197
01:01:14,290 --> 01:01:16,910
So we just keep adding
as we've got more and

1198
01:01:16,910 --> 01:01:20,600
keep fleshing it out until we've got
all the various ones that we need.

1199
01:01:20,600 --> 01:01:22,656
And now we've got our
requirements document.

1200
01:01:22,656 --> 01:01:25,772
Just a straight-up list
of the requirements.

1201
01:01:25,772 --> 01:01:32,270
All right, this is a slightly
living document at this point.

1202
01:01:32,270 --> 01:01:38,530
When the planning phase ends, this should
be treated as if it's set in stone,

1203
01:01:38,530 --> 01:01:43,390
because all the planning you've done is
built around meeting these requirements.

1204
01:01:43,390 --> 01:01:46,880
And if these requirements change,
your plan is thrown out the window, right?

1205
01:01:46,880 --> 01:01:49,900
So while we're in the planning
phase this can change.

1206
01:01:49,900 --> 01:01:51,280
It can change regularly.

1207
01:01:51,280 --> 01:01:57,110
But when we go to move from planning
to executing, we do a freeze.

1208
01:01:57,110 --> 01:01:58,220
And we say that's it.

1209
01:01:58,220 --> 01:02:01,090
These are the requirements.

1210
01:02:01,090 --> 01:02:02,029
This is what we're gonna do.

1211
01:02:03,580 --> 01:02:08,020
If there needs to be a change, we'll have
to institute a change management process.

1212
01:02:08,020 --> 01:02:09,960

Can anybody thing of anything else?

1436
01:13:57,490 --> 01:13:58,142
We add some more stuff.

1437
01:13:58,142 --> 01:14:00,320
Version 1.2, right?

1438
01:14:00,320 --> 01:14:04,180
And you keep doing that until you've
got one that you're ready to act on.

1439
01:14:04,180 --> 01:14:05,960
And as the project manager,
you sign off on it.

1440
01:14:05,960 --> 01:14:08,200
You say, this is cool, I'm good with this.

1441
01:14:08,200 --> 01:14:09,630
And then we start to act upon it.

1442
01:14:09,630 --> 01:14:13,670
But it still might change
while we're in planning.

1443
01:14:13,670 --> 01:14:14,730
So just keep that in mind.

1444
01:14:14,730 --> 01:14:16,552
You may have to come back to this many,
many times.

1445
01:14:16,552 --> 01:14:19,100
All right.

1446
01:14:19,100 --> 01:14:22,480
Well the next thing we're gonna move
into is the scope statement, and

1447
01:14:22,480 --> 01:14:23,830
then the work break down structure.

1448
01:14:23,830 --> 01:14:28,302
So you know Ronnie,
that might actually be better to put,

1449
01:14:28,302 --> 01:14:31,052
let's see how do we want to do this?

1450
01:14:31,052 --> 01:14:32,168
Should we put that in the next episode?

1451
01:14:32,168 --> 01:14:33,514
Or do you think?

1452
01:14:33,514 --> 01:14:35,718
>> Sure.

1453
01:14:35,718 --> 01:14:37,770
>> [LAUGH] [INAUDIBLE] I
hate starting a topic and

1454
01:14:37,770 --> 01:14:40,750
then having to end the episode cuz we only
have so much more time left in this one.

1455
01:14:40,750 --> 01:14:44,780
So why don't we do this, why don't we go
ahead and wrap up this episode and when we

1456
01:14:44,780 --> 01:14:48,090
get back, for those of you watching live
we'll come right back in a few minutes.

1457
01:14:48,090 --> 01:14:52,420
But for those of you watching recorded,
in the next episode, we're gonna jump into

1458
01:14:52,420 --> 01:14:56,300
that scope statement and the WBS and
kinda wrap up this part of the planning.

1459
01:14:56,300 --> 01:14:57,580
So, we'll move into that.

1460
01:14:57,580 --> 01:15:00,367
But yeah,
this is all pretty important stuff, right?

1461
01:15:00,367 --> 01:15:02,350
Early on, easy to make mistakes here.

1462
01:15:02,350 --> 01:15:04,590
If you miss a requirement, bad news.

1463
01:15:04,590 --> 01:15:05,790
All right, so stay tuned for that.

1464
01:15:05,790 --> 01:15:06,740
Let me just remind you guys.

1465
01:15:06,740 --> 01:15:11,627
If you have any questions live during
the show, you can go to itpro.tv/live and

1466
01:15:11,627 --> 01:15:15,000
you'll see the chatroom right beneath
the video, post your questions.

1467
01:15:15,000 --> 01:15:16,930
We monitor and answer during the show.

1468
01:15:16,930 --> 01:15:20,170
If you have questions after the show,
check out our Q&A forums.

1469
01:15:20,170 --> 01:15:23,930
If you hit that Q&A link at the top of all
our pages, it'll take you in the forums.

1470
01:15:23,930 --> 01:15:26,220
Post your questions there and
again, we monitor and

1471
01:15:26,220 --> 01:15:28,380
answer to make sure you get
that information you need.

1472
01:15:28,380 --> 01:15:30,440
So, definitely take advantage of that.

1473
01:15:30,440 --> 01:15:32,350
It is there for you.

1474
01:15:32,350 --> 01:15:35,170
Well, I hope you guys enjoyed the show,
signing off for IT Pro TV.

1475
01:15:35,170 --> 01:15:36,123
I'm Don Pezet.

1476
01:15:36,123 --> 01:15:36,889
>> And I'm And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1477
01:15:36,889 --> 01:15:38,840
>> And we'll see you next time.

1478
01:15:38,840 --> 01:15:48,840
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue to plan the project scope and statement using the templates. They emphasize the need and parameters that make up the project scope. The scope statement will be used to help define the success of the project.
episodes.title: Planning Project Scope Part 2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:04,039 --> 00:00:14,039
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:34,154 --> 00:00:34,873
All right.

3
00:00:34,873 --> 00:00:35,453
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening and welcome back.

4
00:00:35,453 --> 00:00:38,490
To another episode of IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:38,490 --> 00:00:41,660
I'm your host Don Pezet back
again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:41,660 --> 00:00:42,470
How's is going Ronnie?

7
00:00:42,470 --> 00:00:44,190
>> It is going swell this morning.

8
00:00:44,190 --> 00:00:48,025
We started off the day with
a Bette Midler song, so we are ready go.

9
00:00:48,025 --> 00:00:51,170
>> [LAUGH]
>> One of my all time favorites, right?

10
00:00:51,170 --> 00:00:53,190
I celebrate her entire collection.

11
00:00:53,190 --> 00:00:53,735
>> Constantly.

12
00:00:53,735 --> 00:00:58,850
[LAUGH] The guys in the office
are tormenting me today with bad music.

13
00:00:58,850 --> 00:01:02,283
But Miller, that pretty much sums it up.

14
00:01:02,283 --> 00:01:06,440
[LAUGH] All right, so today we're
gonna be taking a look at, well,

15
00:01:06,440 --> 00:01:07,690
our scope statement Statement.

16
00:01:07,690 --> 00:01:11,000
In our last episode we started
talking about what's involved in

17
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:12,600
creating our project scope?

18
00:01:12,600 --> 00:01:14,920
That's the knowledge area that we're in,
and

19
00:01:14,920 --> 00:01:20,815
actually here let me get my pinblock
pulled back up and we'll kind of jump but

20
00:01:20,815 --> 00:01:27,785
basically we started talking about our
scope statement and how its important.

21
00:01:27,785 --> 00:01:31,005
And how we cant really just jump
right into the scope statement.

22
00:01:31,005 --> 00:01:34,788
How we actually need to jump into
some other things first and so

23
00:01:34,788 --> 00:01:37,535
we dealt with requirements yesterday.

24
00:01:37,535 --> 00:01:41,870
What do we actually require our project
to do to consider it successful?

25
00:01:41,870 --> 00:01:44,620
So that's what we were looking at
there was collector requirements 5.2,

26
00:01:44,620 --> 00:01:49,060
now we are going to take a look at 5.3,
which is define the scope.

27
00:01:49,060 --> 00:01:53,050
We probably have enough information
now to create our scope statement.

28
00:01:53,050 --> 00:01:56,580
I say probably, because we may have
to revisit this a few times and

29
00:01:56,580 --> 00:01:58,900
I know I've said it
a hundred times by now.

30
00:01:58,900 --> 00:02:01,550
It's okay here in planning for
us to do that.

31
00:02:01,550 --> 00:02:05,020
We make adjustments until we
find what fits perfect, right?

32
00:02:05,020 --> 00:02:07,820
So let's take a look
at that defined scope.

33
00:02:07,820 --> 00:02:10,560
Well, before I throw up that
process diagram on the screen,

34
00:02:10,560 --> 00:02:13,180
let me just start with
something really simple.

35
00:02:13,180 --> 00:02:20,020
A scope statement is, well,
I mentioned earlier that the project

36
00:02:20,020 --> 00:02:25,720
charter was the single most important
document to the project as a whole, right?

37
00:02:25,720 --> 00:02:31,300
Because it's what gives the project
manager authority over the project and

38
00:02:31,300 --> 00:02:33,380
it's what allows the project to kick off.

39
00:02:33,380 --> 00:02:36,450
So from the perspective of
the project as a whole,

40
00:02:36,450 --> 00:02:39,470
yes the project charter is
the most important document.

41
00:02:39,470 --> 00:02:43,130
The scope statement is
a close second place

42
00:02:43,130 --> 00:02:47,470
because the scope statement is what's
going to define beyond a doubt

43
00:02:47,470 --> 00:02:52,630
exactly what it is we need to achieve for
this project to be successful.

44
00:02:52,630 --> 00:02:55,590
We already did that in
the charter right in our charter

45
00:02:55,590 --> 00:02:59,020
we put some high level statements in
there, but it's not very detailed.

46
00:02:59,020 --> 00:03:01,390
It's not really fully objective,

47
00:03:01,390 --> 00:03:03,260
there might be some subjective
statements in there.

48
00:03:03,260 --> 00:03:04,800
It's not really what we want to live and

49
00:03:04,800 --> 00:03:07,430
die by because there's
too many gray areas.

50
00:03:07,430 --> 00:03:12,240
So as we prepare our scope statement we've
really gotta have our ducks in a row.

51
00:03:12,240 --> 00:03:15,260
We've got to make sure we
understand all our details,

52
00:03:15,260 --> 00:03:18,530
what it is we need to achieve and
we put it here.

53
00:03:18,530 --> 00:03:23,390
And the scope statement we are gonna look
at throughout the life of our project.

54
00:03:23,390 --> 00:03:26,980
You will constantly be referring
back to your scope statement.

55
00:03:26,980 --> 00:03:29,680
The charter you'll probably
never look at again.

56
00:03:29,680 --> 00:03:32,500
Right.
It got signed, it's extremely important

57
00:03:32,500 --> 00:03:35,770
because it's what gives us that authority
but you don't need to go back to it

58
00:03:35,770 --> 00:03:38,460
because we're going to replace everything
that's in it with other documents.

59
00:03:38,460 --> 00:03:41,080
We're going to supersede them with
other ones that are more accurate.

60
00:03:41,080 --> 00:03:43,610
The scope statement is the first of these.

61
00:03:43,610 --> 00:03:48,210
Now the scope statement,
in it's most basic form, is a paragraph.

62
00:03:48,210 --> 00:03:50,630
You write a paragraph,
this is what you're gonna do.

63
00:03:50,630 --> 00:03:55,670
But the more detailed you can be,
the better off you'll be all right?

64
00:03:55,670 --> 00:03:59,090
So let's start, I'm going to do this one
in a little different order, all right?

65
00:03:59,090 --> 00:04:02,330
Let's start with what
a scope document looks like.

66
00:04:02,330 --> 00:04:04,310
I'm gonna bring up my template for

67
00:04:04,310 --> 00:04:08,830
a scope document which I've
got around here somewhere.

68
00:04:08,830 --> 00:04:10,560
Where is my project scope statement?

69
00:04:10,560 --> 00:04:11,585
There it is.

70
00:04:11,585 --> 00:04:12,440
All right.

71
00:04:12,440 --> 00:04:16,270
So here is an example of
a Project Scope Statement.

72
00:04:16,270 --> 00:04:21,520
And what you'll see is we have several
different things that can go in here.

73
00:04:21,520 --> 00:04:26,190
And you can be extremely detailed or
you can be a little less detailed,

74
00:04:26,190 --> 00:04:29,810
smaller projects you might
not need crazy detail.

75
00:04:29,810 --> 00:04:33,870
But you're typically going to want
to be very thorough here, all right.

76
00:04:33,870 --> 00:04:37,170
We're going to put our
project scope description.

77
00:04:37,170 --> 00:04:40,770
A description of our project,
what it is we're going to achieve,

78
00:04:40,770 --> 00:04:43,070
what it is we intend to do.

79
00:04:43,070 --> 00:04:45,850
And you just write it out
plain English style, you know.

80
00:04:45,850 --> 00:04:48,480
Don't use any crazy technical
terms if you can avoid it.

81
00:04:48,480 --> 00:04:51,660
Lay out the information about the project,
all right.

82
00:04:51,660 --> 00:04:58,200
The project deliverables, that's going to
be what we are going to be producing and

83
00:04:58,200 --> 00:05:01,580
when you produce something, it's really
easy to, in our mind, lock into the idea

84
00:05:01,580 --> 00:05:05,340
of a tangible object, that we're going
to produce a physical item, right?

85
00:05:05,340 --> 00:05:09,580
So like arcade cabinet example,
we are going to create an arcade cabinet,

86
00:05:09,580 --> 00:05:11,280
a physical item, right?

87
00:05:11,280 --> 00:05:13,750
But you might not be
producing a physical item,

88
00:05:13,750 --> 00:05:17,670
it might be some intangible like you
might be doing a service improvement.

89
00:05:17,670 --> 00:05:21,070
I gave the example in the last episode
that if you work for a manufacturing plant

90
00:05:21,070 --> 00:05:26,290
when you manufacture 1,000 pairs of
jeans maybe you have a 20% defect rate.

91
00:05:26,290 --> 00:05:31,130
So maybe your project is to
get down to a 10% defect rate.

92
00:05:31,130 --> 00:05:31,830
Right?
So

93
00:05:31,830 --> 00:05:36,600
it's the process, what you're doing to
change the company that you're creating.

94
00:05:36,600 --> 00:05:38,290
That's your deliverable, right?

95
00:05:38,290 --> 00:05:41,870
So we'll list whatever those deliverables
are right here to say when this project is

96
00:05:41,870 --> 00:05:44,050
done this is what we're going to give you.

97
00:05:44,050 --> 00:05:46,930
We're going to give you a fully
functional arcade cabinet,

98
00:05:46,930 --> 00:05:49,930
we're gonna give you a four bedroom,
two bathroom house.

99
00:05:49,930 --> 00:05:53,690
We're going to give you
a fully redundant data center,

100
00:05:53,690 --> 00:05:57,680
located in another state that you can fail
over to in under three minutes, right?

101
00:05:57,680 --> 00:06:00,100
We specify what that
deliverable is going to be.

102
00:06:01,500 --> 00:06:05,020
Then, your project acceptance criteria,
right?

103
00:06:05,020 --> 00:06:07,280
How do we know that we're done?

104
00:06:07,280 --> 00:06:12,065
If we meet this list of requirements
within these range of tolerances,

105
00:06:12,065 --> 00:06:15,550
then we're done and if you disagree,

106
00:06:15,550 --> 00:06:18,990
it doesn't matter because right here
we specified what had to be met.

107
00:06:18,990 --> 00:06:20,655
And if we met that, then it's done.

108
00:06:20,655 --> 00:06:21,565
All right?

109
00:06:21,565 --> 00:06:24,285
This is where it's really important
to make sure that we don't have

110
00:06:24,285 --> 00:06:25,295
any subjective statements.

111
00:06:25,295 --> 00:06:28,975
Anything where two people can
interpret it in different ways.

112
00:06:28,975 --> 00:06:32,315
So, I want my website to be fast.

113
00:06:32,315 --> 00:06:33,200
Okay?

114
00:06:33,200 --> 00:06:34,000
How fast?

115
00:06:34,000 --> 00:06:34,530
Right.

116
00:06:34,530 --> 00:06:38,468
How do we measure fast because fast to me
might be different than fast to Ronnie.

117
00:06:38,468 --> 00:06:42,443
Well that's definitely true [LAUGH] right
because you've got that satellite internet

118
00:06:42,443 --> 00:06:45,530
at home [LAUGH] So
people's perception of fast is different.

119
00:06:45,530 --> 00:06:49,800
So we need to say the page load
time needs to be under one second.

120
00:06:49,800 --> 00:06:50,390
Right?

121
00:06:50,390 --> 00:06:54,180
Now I've got something measurable and
if it's under one second and

122
00:06:54,180 --> 00:06:58,100
then the original sponsor says,
well it still feels kind of slow to me,

123
00:06:58,100 --> 00:07:00,230
then you can say,
too bad, it's right here.

124
00:07:00,230 --> 00:07:04,030
We said one second,
if you want it less than one second.

125
00:07:04,030 --> 00:07:08,640
Well, we can do another project, or we
can go back and we can update our scope,

126
00:07:08,640 --> 00:07:12,760
make some changes, and then move forward
with trying to get it even lower, right?

127
00:07:12,760 --> 00:07:14,810
But it needs to be right here.

128
00:07:14,810 --> 00:07:17,940
That's why we're gonna refer
back to this document so much.

129
00:07:17,940 --> 00:07:20,580
We're gonna live and
die by this document right here.

130
00:07:20,580 --> 00:07:22,049
It's gonna determine our success.

131
00:07:23,900 --> 00:07:28,250
Now one thing I like to do,
is when we list our deliverables and

132
00:07:28,250 --> 00:07:32,390
our project scope description,
that's what we're going to do,

133
00:07:32,390 --> 00:07:36,050
I like to list what we're not going to do,
all right?

134
00:07:36,050 --> 00:07:37,140
This is a good idea.

135
00:07:37,140 --> 00:07:40,070
In fact, let's do an example here.

136
00:07:40,070 --> 00:07:42,431
I worked on a project a few
years ago that was a,

137
00:07:42,431 --> 00:07:44,380
I'll call it a medium sized project.

138
00:07:44,380 --> 00:07:46,212
It was I worked for a bank and

139
00:07:46,212 --> 00:07:51,314
we had a disaster recovery facility
that the headquarters were in Seattle,

140
00:07:51,314 --> 00:07:55,320
Washington and
the DR site was in Portland, Oregon right.

141
00:07:55,320 --> 00:07:58,180
So separate state,
it was a few hours away.

142
00:07:58,180 --> 00:08:02,360
And the DR site,
it was getting pretty old.

143
00:08:02,360 --> 00:08:04,010
It hadn't been kept up to date.

144
00:08:04,010 --> 00:08:07,120
There were some systems that were
production systems that weren't

145
00:08:07,120 --> 00:08:08,750
in the DR site.

146
00:08:08,750 --> 00:08:11,590
It was a building that we rented,
or leased.

147
00:08:11,590 --> 00:08:12,860
We didn't actually own it.

148
00:08:12,860 --> 00:08:17,050
So there were a number of different
things that were of concern for us.

149
00:08:17,050 --> 00:08:17,670
>> Right.
>> So we

150
00:08:17,670 --> 00:08:20,700
decided we needed a new
disaster recovery center.

151
00:08:20,700 --> 00:08:22,350
And so we created a project.

152
00:08:22,350 --> 00:08:27,240
We kicked it off and said,
we want to create a new data center,

153
00:08:27,240 --> 00:08:32,340
a disaster recovery center that
recreates all of our necessary systems.

154
00:08:32,340 --> 00:08:34,720
We weren't very picky about were is went.

155
00:08:34,720 --> 00:08:37,020
So, we had some options there
that were part of the project,

156
00:08:37,020 --> 00:08:40,840
as far as, selecting where
this location would be, and

157
00:08:40,840 --> 00:08:44,820
selecting who the hosting provider,
or the facility was, and so on.

158
00:08:44,820 --> 00:08:48,000
But, as we stated specifying
our requirements,

159
00:08:48,000 --> 00:08:52,520
one of the system admin team,
actually this is an admin manager.

160
00:08:52,520 --> 00:08:55,600
He came forward and
he said well, you know.

161
00:08:55,600 --> 00:08:59,380
At the time, so this was in 2007, 2008.

162
00:08:59,380 --> 00:09:04,620
Windows Server 2003 was the standard
operating system at the time for the bank.

163
00:09:04,620 --> 00:09:09,430
We still had many servers that were
running Windows Server 2000 at the time.

164
00:09:09,430 --> 00:09:12,860
And, so the sysadmin manager said, well
hey, if we're gonna be moving this data

165
00:09:12,860 --> 00:09:15,980
center, now would be a great time
to upgrade those servers too.

166
00:09:15,980 --> 00:09:16,560
Let's go ahead and

167
00:09:16,560 --> 00:09:20,720
upgrade them, cuz they're gonna
go offline when we move them.

168
00:09:20,720 --> 00:09:23,940
And, we looked at it, and we said,

169
00:09:23,940 --> 00:09:27,210
I understand that you want to upgrade
these to server 2003, I understand.

170
00:09:27,210 --> 00:09:31,200
And I understand it looks like a great
opportunity to do it because the service

171
00:09:31,200 --> 00:09:32,420
will be offline.

172
00:09:32,420 --> 00:09:36,560
But here's the risk,
we move the servers to this new site and

173
00:09:36,560 --> 00:09:38,260
all of a sudden they don't work.

174
00:09:38,260 --> 00:09:41,370
Well, is it a problem with the new site?

175
00:09:41,370 --> 00:09:43,770
Or is it a problem with
the upgrade that you did?

176
00:09:43,770 --> 00:09:44,390
Right.

177
00:09:44,390 --> 00:09:47,460
Too many changes at once can
result in too many problems.

178
00:09:47,460 --> 00:09:52,530
So when we created that scope,
what we did is we put a specific

179
00:09:52,530 --> 00:10:01,530
exclusion that said server
configurations will not be updated.

180
00:10:01,530 --> 00:10:02,200
Right?

181
00:10:02,200 --> 00:10:06,035
Servers will be moved or

182
00:10:06,035 --> 00:10:10,320
replaced as is, Right?

183
00:10:10,320 --> 00:10:12,680
Which meant if we had a server
that was really old and

184
00:10:12,680 --> 00:10:17,280
we had to buy new hardware that was fine
we'd buy new hardware, but the operating

185
00:10:17,280 --> 00:10:20,880
system would stay the same, the software
configuration would stay the same.

186
00:10:20,880 --> 00:10:25,190
We didn't want to make changes there
because it introduced too much risk.

187

things like this, See Exhibit A.

424
00:23:11,420 --> 00:23:13,169
All of a sudden this single page or

425
00:23:13,169 --> 00:23:16,470
two page document becomes
a 30 page document, right?

426
00:23:16,470 --> 00:23:17,850
Those exhibits are pretty important.

427
00:23:19,470 --> 00:23:24,260
All right, now, this information here,
I pretty much just made up as we went.

428
00:23:24,260 --> 00:23:27,420
Well, I didn't make it up,
it comes from a prior experience, but

429
00:23:27,420 --> 00:23:31,100
if you're the one charged
with filling this out,

430
00:23:31,100 --> 00:23:32,880
how do we get to the point
that we can fill this out?

431
00:23:32,880 --> 00:23:35,260
How do we get to where we
have that information?

432
00:23:35,260 --> 00:23:39,250
That's where the scope
statement process comes in.

433
00:23:39,250 --> 00:23:40,850
Which I've got parked right here.

434
00:23:40,850 --> 00:23:43,659
So we've got the define
scope process that tells

435
00:23:43,659 --> 00:23:47,850
us what we do to start to build up this
scope statement and get it defined.

436
00:23:47,850 --> 00:23:49,330
All right?

437
00:23:49,330 --> 00:23:51,530
Now, we'll start with the inputs.

438
00:23:51,530 --> 00:23:54,531
This is one of those, and you see these
a lot in the early stages of the project,

439
00:23:54,531 --> 00:23:57,190
that pretty much everything
that you have becomes an input.

440
00:23:57,190 --> 00:24:00,090
So, we've got a project charter.

441
00:24:00,090 --> 00:24:01,580
So that's gonna be an input.

442
00:24:01,580 --> 00:24:04,640
We've got a requirements document
that we drafted in the last episode.

443
00:24:04,640 --> 00:24:05,270
So we've got that.

444
00:24:05,270 --> 00:24:10,580
We bring that in, and then our
Scope Management Plan, if we have one.

445
00:24:10,580 --> 00:24:13,030
Which is going to tell us
how we go about drafting it.

446
00:24:13,030 --> 00:24:14,720
And the Scope Management
plan might be very simple,

447
00:24:14,720 --> 00:24:18,630
it might just say, use this scope
template and off you go, right?

448
00:24:18,630 --> 00:24:20,120
Or it might have something
far more detailed.

449
00:24:21,400 --> 00:24:24,040
The only other thing we got
are Organizational Process Assets,

450
00:24:24,040 --> 00:24:28,430
which would be the templates and
other resources we might have available.

451
00:24:28,430 --> 00:24:30,910
So we take that information and

452
00:24:30,910 --> 00:24:34,380
based on it, we start to create
the scope statement, right.

453
00:24:34,380 --> 00:24:36,450
And you can do what I did and
just grab that template and

454
00:24:36,450 --> 00:24:37,960
just start filling it out.

455
00:24:37,960 --> 00:24:41,340
Or we've got several tools and
techniques that we can use.

456
00:24:41,340 --> 00:24:44,210
So what I did a minute ago,
that was expert judgment.

457
00:24:44,210 --> 00:24:47,390
I just used what was in my head and

458
00:24:47,390 --> 00:24:50,200
memory in that case, and
kind of just wrote it out there.

459
00:24:50,200 --> 00:24:53,150
And you can do that,
small medium project that's probably fine.

460
00:24:53,150 --> 00:24:55,890
In a large project though, you need
to be a little more detail oriented.

461
00:24:55,890 --> 00:24:57,840
And so we've got other things.

462
00:24:57,840 --> 00:24:58,720
All right?

463
00:24:58,720 --> 00:25:01,310
Number two, product analysis.

464
00:25:01,310 --> 00:25:05,060
This is one that we can spend
a lot of time on because we're

465
00:25:05,060 --> 00:25:09,460
looking at the products, what we're
gonna produce, our final deliverable and

466
00:25:09,460 --> 00:25:14,070
we analyze it to break down what all
decisions have to be made to create it.

467
00:25:14,070 --> 00:25:16,680
I gave an example of this on
the last episode on a website.

468
00:25:16,680 --> 00:25:19,100
Somebody says, I want a website and

469
00:25:19,100 --> 00:25:22,230
I want it to have fancy menus where
you float your mouse over it and

470
00:25:22,230 --> 00:25:27,550
they drop down and I want to have it
where it looks very modern and it's fast.

471
00:25:27,550 --> 00:25:29,030
So you take that to your
subject matter expert and

472
00:25:29,030 --> 00:25:30,020
you show it to them and they go, okay,

473
00:25:30,020 --> 00:25:33,560
well if they want to have fancy menus,
what do they want in the menus?

474
00:25:33,560 --> 00:25:35,250
What menu items to they need?

475
00:25:35,250 --> 00:25:36,866
What exactly is going up there, and

476
00:25:36,866 --> 00:25:39,350
they want it to look modern,
what does that mean?

477
00:25:39,350 --> 00:25:42,310
Do they want flat logo images,
do they want multiple colors,

478
00:25:42,310 --> 00:25:44,120
do they want it to be black and
white, you know?

479
00:25:44,120 --> 00:25:45,550
What is it exactly that they want?

480
00:25:45,550 --> 00:25:49,310
And we start to refine that and
get more and more detailed information.

481
00:25:49,310 --> 00:25:52,930
That's a part of product analysis,
all right?

482
00:25:52,930 --> 00:25:57,660
You might have a end design
already figure out but

483
00:25:57,660 --> 00:26:01,932
getting to the end of that
is part of the challenge.

484
00:26:01,932 --> 00:26:05,480
All right, now the PMI, they break own
several different components of product

485
00:26:05,480 --> 00:26:10,720
analysis and
do I have this document, let's see.

486
00:26:12,710 --> 00:26:15,098
Somewhere around here,
I've got this document.

487
00:26:15,098 --> 00:26:17,632
Not here.

488
00:26:17,632 --> 00:26:22,580
[LAUGH]
Ronnie made some really good notes on

489
00:26:22,580 --> 00:26:24,140
this, I want to pull them up.

490
00:26:24,140 --> 00:26:27,410
Now I have to figure out
where I put them though.

491
00:26:27,410 --> 00:26:28,610
This is Planning.

492
00:26:28,610 --> 00:26:30,550
>> It might be
>> Be in the part one there.

493
00:26:30,550 --> 00:26:34,360
I don't know why but
it may still be in there.

494
00:26:34,360 --> 00:26:36,730
That kind of a lot stuff together.

495
00:26:36,730 --> 00:26:37,892
>> Here we go.
Defiance.

496
00:26:37,892 --> 00:26:41,330
All right so you'll see the PMI
breaks down product analysis and

497
00:26:41,330 --> 00:26:42,750
they break it down into
a number of different things.

498
00:26:42,750 --> 00:26:45,490
So what I was talking about that
was product break down right.

499
00:26:45,490 --> 00:26:48,760
We take that product and we break it
down into its individual components.

500
00:26:48,760 --> 00:26:52,700
We figure out all the different things
that need to be determined here early on.

501
00:26:52,700 --> 00:26:53,350
>> Right?

502
00:26:53,350 --> 00:26:55,350
We also have Systems Analysis.

503
00:26:55,350 --> 00:26:58,670
System Analysis is basically
the same thing as Product Breakdown.

504
00:26:58,670 --> 00:27:03,640
Product Breakdown is when you have
something physical, a website,

505
00:27:03,640 --> 00:27:04,410
a 2016 Ford Focus.

506
00:27:04,410 --> 00:27:05,570
>> Yeah.
>> Something that you're

507
00:27:05,570 --> 00:27:07,200
physically producing.

508
00:27:07,200 --> 00:27:11,290
A Systems Analysis that's when we're
dealing with something that's a little

509
00:27:11,290 --> 00:27:12,785
more logical, right?

510
00:27:12,785 --> 00:27:17,165
I'm trying to get our defect
rate from 20% down to 10%.

511
00:27:17,165 --> 00:27:21,220
Okay, what all is involved in
manufacturing these blue jeans?

512
00:27:21,220 --> 00:27:23,110
What systems are involved in that?

513
00:27:23,110 --> 00:27:24,210
How do they interact?

514
00:27:24,210 --> 00:27:25,810
How do those systems work together?

515
00:27:25,810 --> 00:27:28,940
So, we've go one system that actually
cuts the fabric and another system that

516
00:27:28,940 --> 00:27:33,040
stitches the buttons on, and another
system that stitches the fabric together.

517
00:27:33,040 --> 00:27:35,360
>> Well, where are defects coming from?

518
00:27:35,360 --> 00:27:37,740
Where do we need to focus in on this?

519
00:27:37,740 --> 00:27:39,510
How do these systems tie together and

520
00:27:39,510 --> 00:27:42,010
then that's gonna start to set some
of the scope of our project too.

521
00:27:42,010 --> 00:27:45,030
So, Systems Analysis,
very similar to Product Breakdown.

522
00:27:46,950 --> 00:27:52,600
Requirements Analysis, we get a list of
requirements from our sponsor or whoever.

523
00:27:52,600 --> 00:27:55,480
Now we start to look at those
requirements to identify additional

524
00:27:55,480 --> 00:27:56,550
information we need.

525
00:27:56,550 --> 00:27:58,820
This is where a subject matter
expert can really help, right?

526
00:27:58,820 --> 00:27:59,570
They can look at it and

527
00:27:59,570 --> 00:28:02,460
find those additional questions
that we need to break down.

528
00:28:02,460 --> 00:28:03,490
All right.

529
00:28:04,740 --> 00:28:08,430
The next two, Systems Engineering and
Value Engineering, right?

530
00:28:08,430 --> 00:28:12,360
Systems Engineering, this is saying, all
right, we've got multiple systems involved

531
00:28:12,360 --> 00:28:16,110
in this process
>> Do we need to make changes to them?

532
00:28:16,110 --> 00:28:17,810
Are we gonna have to reinvent them?

533
00:28:17,810 --> 00:28:19,800
How detailed are we gonna get in here?

534
00:28:19,800 --> 00:28:24,730
And so we might have to create new
systems to achieve what we want.

535
00:28:24,730 --> 00:28:28,670
Or we might be able to retrofit existing
systems to achieve what we want.

536
00:28:28,670 --> 00:28:32,130
And the other thing is there might be
other projects that are going on at

537
00:28:32,130 --> 00:28:35,280
the same time that are doing
the same type of thing.

538
00:28:35,280 --> 00:28:37,960
We might be able to integrate
those projects together.

539
00:28:37,960 --> 00:28:41,570
There might be overlap there to be
able to save time and resources and so

540
00:28:41,570 --> 00:28:45,910
that's where Systems Engineering comes
in is finding where we can create these

541
00:28:45,910 --> 00:28:49,670
new systems, or modify the ones we have.

542
00:28:49,670 --> 00:28:53,390
Value Engineering, this ones
a little bit different, all right?

543
00:28:53,390 --> 00:28:57,440
If my goal that the thing that I
want to product is an item, right?

544
00:28:57,440 --> 00:28:58,740
The 2016 Ford Focus, right?

545
00:29:00,230 --> 00:29:03,420
There are ways that I can build value

546
00:29:03,420 --> 00:29:06,780
into that product from the very beginning,
right?

547
00:29:06,780 --> 00:29:08,930
I don't have to, but I can.

548
00:29:08,930 --> 00:29:13,720
When you buy a car today a lot of cars
come with a 30,000 mile warranty, right?

549
00:29:13,720 --> 00:29:18,480
So for the first 30,000 miles, it's
under warranty and if somethings wrong,

550
00:29:18,480 --> 00:29:20,040
they'll fix it for you.

551
00:29:20,040 --> 00:29:22,620
But there's other cars out there that
come with a 100,000 miles warranty.

552
00:29:22,620 --> 00:29:23,260
>> Yeah.
>> Right?

553
00:29:24,340 --> 00:29:25,390
Do they have to do that?

554
00:29:25,390 --> 00:29:26,550
They don't, right?

555
00:29:26,550 --> 00:29:28,990
They choose to because they
get good marketing out of it.

556
00:29:28,990 --> 00:29:30,690
And maybe they trust their cars enough.

557
00:29:30,690 --> 00:29:32,340
Or they just know the expense
won't be that great.

558
00:29:32,340 --> 00:29:33,600
So they do it anyway.

559
00:29:33,600 --> 00:29:36,020
That's a part of Value Engineering.

560
00:29:36,020 --> 00:29:40,900
We can choose to build that value
into our product if it's required or

561
00:29:40,900 --> 00:29:43,650
if we just feel like it's
the right thing to do, right?

562
00:29:43,650 --> 00:29:47,340
That kind of goes hand in
hand with Value Analysis.

563
00:29:47,340 --> 00:29:51,260
We can look at a system and say,
you know what, in our prototype for

564
00:29:51,260 --> 00:29:54,920
the 2016 Ford Focus,
we did an all steel body.

565
00:29:54,920 --> 00:29:56,210
>> Yeah.
>> Right?

566
00:29:56,210 --> 00:29:57,810
What if we went to.

567
00:30:00,380 --> 00:30:01,770
Shoot, what's that really cheap?

568
00:30:01,770 --> 00:30:02,800
>> Carbon fiber?

569
00:30:02,800 --> 00:30:03,990
No, that's expensive.

570
00:30:03,990 --> 00:30:06,470
Kevlar.
>> Yeah, carbon fiber's probably fine.

571
00:30:06,470 --> 00:30:07,990
>> Yeah.
>> What do they make those Jon Boats and

572
00:30:07,990 --> 00:30:10,880
stuff, the cheap fishing boats,
what are they made out of?

573
00:30:10,880 --> 00:30:11,780
>> Fiberglass.
>> Fiberglass!

574
00:30:11,780 --> 00:30:12,370
There we go.
>> Oh, okay.

575
00:30:12,370 --> 00:30:14,640
>> What if we went with, I was trying
to think of something super cheap.

576
00:30:14,640 --> 00:30:16,260
>> Yeah.
>> Carbon fiber's not always cheap.

577
00:30:16,260 --> 00:30:20,440
But what if we went with a fiberglass body
or like the Saturn's the plastic body.

578
00:30:20,440 --> 00:30:21,200
>> Yes.
>> Right.

579
00:30:21,200 --> 00:30:26,180
We don't have to have steel and somebody
might say, well if we want our customers

580
00:30:26,180 --> 00:30:28,750
to survive a crash,
we probably don't want to go plastic.

581
00:30:28,750 --> 00:30:32,950
And somebody else might say, you know
what, we can go with a plastic body but

582
00:30:32,950 --> 00:30:37,000
we can build in a stronger
cage inside of it,

583
00:30:37,000 --> 00:30:40,170
so it's structurally sound,
even though it's got a plastic body.

584
00:30:40,170 --> 00:30:41,720
So you start looking at things like that,
and

585
00:30:41,720 --> 00:30:46,540
you say, all right, is the value
of having a steel body worth it?

586
00:30:46,540 --> 00:30:50,600
Is the value of going with something less
expensive, sometimes less expensive and

587
00:30:50,600 --> 00:30:52,980
you create a piece of junk and
people don't buy it.

588
00:30:52,980 --> 00:30:55,160
You can hurt the project by going cheap.

589
00:30:55,160 --> 00:30:58,500
So Value Analysis is where
we weigh the odds on that.

590
00:30:58,500 --> 00:31:00,550
We look at the materials
that we're choosing and

591
00:31:00,550 --> 00:31:02,920
we say is this the right decision.

592
00:31:02,920 --> 00:31:08,160
Because sometimes we manufacture something
in plastic just because it was easy.

593
00:31:08,160 --> 00:31:10,030
Not because we have some other reason for
it.

594
00:31:10,030 --> 00:31:12,180
Not because it saved us money or anything.

595
00:31:12,180 --> 00:31:14,890
It might just be that
whoever was the designer,

596
00:31:14,890 --> 00:31:17,990
that was the material they had
sitting there at the time, right?

597
00:31:17,990 --> 00:31:20,230
We're gonna build this arcade cabinet.

598
00:31:20,230 --> 00:31:23,720
Well, we could use really nice wood.

599
00:31:23,720 --> 00:31:26,580
We could get some cedar, well you probably
wouldn't want cedar, but we could get

600
00:31:26,580 --> 00:31:27,580
>> Oak or something like that, and

601
00:31:27,580 --> 00:31:29,540
building this cabinet would
be incredibly expensive.

602
00:31:29,540 --> 00:31:33,670
But, if we just happened to have a couple
of sheets of plywood laying around,

603
00:31:33,670 --> 00:31:35,850
we might choose to use that
just because it's here.

604
00:31:35,850 --> 00:31:36,450
Right?

605
00:31:36,450 --> 00:31:39,230
Well, we might want to do
some Value Analysis and say,

606
00:31:39,230 --> 00:31:42,100
well, over the years that
plywood is not going to hold up.

607
00:31:42,100 --> 00:31:45,019
It's going to break down,
it's going to look terrible.

608
00:31:45,019 --> 00:31:48,980
So, there will be some value in going
ahead and using a higher quality material.

609
00:31:48,980 --> 00:31:49,700
All right?

610
00:31:49,700 --> 00:31:51,840
That's Value Analysis.

611
00:31:51,840 --> 00:31:56,070
Alright, so
all of that falls under product analysis.

612
00:31:56,070 --> 00:31:57,370
It's a general umbrella.

613
00:31:57,370 --> 00:32:00,220
You have to look at what you're producing,
service or good.

614
00:32:00,220 --> 00:32:02,130
You know, tangible or intangible.

615
00:32:02,130 --> 00:32:04,690
And figure out questions that
haven't been asked, right?

616
00:32:04,690 --> 00:32:06,280
>> Right.
>> All the different details and

617
00:32:06,280 --> 00:32:09,170
get that nailed down This will really
become part of your requirements list.

618
00:32:10,920 --> 00:32:14,420
Alright We got a few others but
I think I talked a little too long.

619
00:32:14,420 --> 00:32:15,690
>> Yup.
>> I see our timer's run out.

620
00:32:15,690 --> 00:32:16,760
So let's do this.

621
00:32:16,760 --> 00:32:17,890
Let's stop and take a break.

622
00:32:17,890 --> 00:32:18,910
>> Okay.
>> When we get back,

623
00:32:18,910 --> 00:32:20,930
we're gonna talk about some
of the other tools and

624
00:32:20,930 --> 00:32:23,420
techniques we have generating
that scope statement.

625
00:32:23,420 --> 00:32:26,440
And then we'll see about wrapping
that one up and moving on.

626
00:32:26,440 --> 00:32:27,830
We still have our work breakdown structure
>> Yup.

627
00:32:27,830 --> 00:32:29,530
>> and a few other things to get to, so.

628
00:32:29,530 --> 00:32:31,449
We'll stop here and
we'll see you back in a few minutes.

629
00:32:31,449 --> 00:32:38,393
[MUSIC]

630
00:32:38,393 --> 00:32:39,078
All right.

631
00:32:39,078 --> 00:32:40,550
Welcome back everybody.

632
00:32:40,550 --> 00:32:42,180
So, we've got a couple more tools and

633
00:32:42,180 --> 00:32:45,720
techniques to cover as far as
developing our scope statement.

634
00:32:45,720 --> 00:32:47,830
The next one is one that I like.

635
00:32:47,830 --> 00:32:52,140
It's actually kind of a neat one,
it's called alternatives generation.

636
00:32:52,140 --> 00:32:56,550
And basically,
when your sponsor comes to you and

637
00:32:56,550 --> 00:33:00,120
kicks off this project and
gives you what they want,

638
00:33:00,120 --> 00:33:03,410
it's your job to figure out how
you're going to achieve it and

639
00:33:03,410 --> 00:33:08,320
there is usually more more than one way to
achieve what the sponsor is asking for.

640
00:33:08,320 --> 00:33:11,560
So what you need to do is
you need to get creative and

641
00:33:11,560 --> 00:33:13,490
try and think of the different ways.

642
00:33:13,490 --> 00:33:16,480
If you just take the first solution
that comes along, it might work.

643
00:33:16,480 --> 00:33:20,220
But there might be other
solutions that have less risk or

644
00:33:20,220 --> 00:33:24,550
are more cost efficient,
work better in a certain time schedule.

645
00:33:24,550 --> 00:33:28,580
There's always different ways
that we can solve that problem.

646
00:33:28,580 --> 00:33:32,425
So alternatives generation is simply
a process of us figuring out,

647
00:33:32,425 --> 00:33:36,295
what alternative means do we have for
achieving this goal.

648
00:33:36,295 --> 00:33:37,145
Alright.

649
00:33:37,145 --> 00:33:41,245
For example,
we wanna design the 2016 Ford Focus.

650
00:33:41,245 --> 00:33:43,830
Do we design an entirely new car?

651
00:33:43,830 --> 00:33:48,720
Or do we just take the 2015 and
maybe make some minor tweaks to it and

652
00:33:48,720 --> 00:33:51,960
remarket it as the 2016,
which is what they usually do.

653
00:33:51,960 --> 00:33:52,880
So, do we go that route?

654
00:33:52,880 --> 00:33:54,890
So, you got some kind of choices there.

655
00:33:54,890 --> 00:33:57,290
And then if it's something
like building a house,

656
00:33:57,290 --> 00:33:59,030
there's more than one
way to build a house.

657
00:33:59,030 --> 00:34:02,640
You can build it fully custom,
or you can do a modular

658
00:34:02,640 --> 00:34:05,550
design where you just buy
the components and stick them together.

659
00:34:05,550 --> 00:34:07,160
So, tons of different options there.

00:34:07,160 --> 00:34:10,130
You need to take a look at
each of the alternatives and

661
00:34:10,130 --> 00:34:13,330
choose which one best meets
the needs of the sponsor.

662
00:34:13,330 --> 00:34:13,850
>> Yeah.

663
00:34:13,850 --> 00:34:16,840
Sometimes because we're limited just
because of the way we're used to

664
00:34:16,840 --> 00:34:17,690
doing things,

665
00:34:17,690 --> 00:34:21,200
we don't think that there may be more
than one particular approach doing it.

00:34:21,200 --> 00:34:24,160
And we may find out that another approach
is actually better than the way that we

667
00:34:24,160 --> 00:34:26,790
were thinking about, so
always keep an open mind even at

668
00:34:26,790 --> 00:34:29,270
this point even though you're
starting to define the scope, and

669
00:34:29,270 --> 00:34:32,110
trying to figure out is there
another way that we can approach is.

670
00:34:32,110 --> 00:34:36,170
>> Yeah, and this is something I've
learned repeatedly over the years.

00:34:36,170 --> 00:34:38,120
I have networking background.

00:34:38,120 --> 00:34:41,840
I've been a network manager for several
companies, I've worked with Cisco and

And I know a lot of stuff about

00:34:48,040 --> 00:34:48,600

00:34:48,600 --> 00:34:51,100
I'm not special or anything,
I've just used it a lot.

677
00:34:51,100 --> 00:34:55,030
And so, when somebody asks me to do

00:34:55,030 --> 00:34:59,220

I know at least one way to do it.

00:34:59,220 --> 00:35:03,880
But there's always other ways and

00:35:03,880 --> 00:35:06,310
I learn every time,
you're always seeing something new.

681
00:35:06,310 --> 00:35:10,640
Because I may have deployed it in one

00:35:10,640 --> 00:35:13,780
there's other environments with different
needs that modify how that technology

00:35:13,780 --> 00:35:14,620

684
00:35:14,620 --> 00:35:16,920
So you always want to be open-minded,

00:35:16,920 --> 00:35:20,020
bring in subject matter experts or
contractors or

686
00:35:20,020 --> 00:35:24,090
somebody to get their opinions too and
