687
00:35:24,090 --> 00:35:27,870
So some of the ways we do that,
brainstorming we've already talked about.

688
00:35:27,870 --> 00:35:31,850
You get a bunch of people in a room and
you say, anybody got some other ideas?

689
00:35:31,850 --> 00:35:32,890
Let's just throw them out here.

690
00:35:34,550 --> 00:35:36,930
You also do what's
called lateral thinking.

691
00:35:38,000 --> 00:35:42,230
Lateral thinking is where we look
at the steps to achieve our goal.

692
00:35:42,230 --> 00:35:45,250
And we say okay,
we're going to pick this one step.

693
00:35:45,250 --> 00:35:45,800
We can't do it.

694
00:35:46,800 --> 00:35:48,310
What are our other options?

695
00:35:48,310 --> 00:35:51,800
Think of a lateral solution
that does the same thing.

696
00:35:51,800 --> 00:35:55,890
So if we talk about building a house and

697
00:35:55,890 --> 00:35:59,430
step one of building the house

00:35:59,430 --> 00:36:02,080
And so we come in and we say all right,
let's pretend that for

00:36:06,020 --> 00:36:08,250
Well you can build a house

00:36:08,250 --> 00:36:11,220
you can do the raised,
what do they call that?

00:36:11,220 --> 00:36:12,420
>> Stilts, house on stilts?

00:36:12,420 --> 00:36:15,070
>> Or you can do a stilt one,

>> Here in Florida,

00:36:18,040 --> 00:36:19,920

And, I'm not talking about mobile homes or

I'm talking about actual houses that

00:36:32,510 --> 00:36:36,220
they'll have giant cement,

Pylons, that's the word I'm looking for,

00:36:37,930 --> 00:36:41,400
that they rest on instead of

00:36:41,400 --> 00:36:44,470
So what are the pros and cons, right?

00:36:44,470 --> 00:36:47,860
Is there a benefit of going

00:36:47,860 --> 00:36:51,040
With the pylon solution

But if somebody pours concrete slab down,

So it's an alternative solution

Which one's gonna be better for us?

It depends.

I know a lot of people
prefer to have the cement

So you know you dig one inch down and

So, we don't have that here.

Again, different areas you're going

know up there,
up north you may do a basement.

00:37:54,260 --> 00:37:57,870
So, lateral thinking is just

738
00:37:57,870 --> 00:37:59,620
is there something else I can do.

00:37:59,620 --> 00:38:03,410
I find it better to break it

00:38:03,410 --> 00:38:04,935
So, usually you get the whole things.

741
00:38:04,935 --> 00:38:07,770
All right, so
we're going to build this house this way.

00:38:07,770 --> 00:38:09,560
What's another way to do it?

743
00:38:09,560 --> 00:38:13,800
When people think big picture,
it's hard to come up with an alternative.

00:38:13,800 --> 00:38:18,180
But if you take it down to one component,
this one component, for

00:38:18,180 --> 00:38:20,100
whatever reason we can't do that.

746
00:38:20,100 --> 00:38:21,610
What else do you got?

00:38:21,610 --> 00:38:26,970
That's what lateral thinking is all

Just because there is an alternative

00:38:31,670 --> 00:38:34,620
>> So sometimes you'll get people that

good recommendations, but they just don't

And I just watched a movie a few

But, you have to look at that and say,

all right,

00:39:17,410 --> 00:39:20,210
Sure, this other one is faster,

00:39:20,210 --> 00:39:23,280
But, the cost is gonna make it higher,

00:39:23,280 --> 00:39:25,120
customers, and

We shouldn't go that route, right?

So, just because an alternative exists,

00:39:29,830 --> 00:39:31,520
Doesn't mean you should go that route.

00:39:31,520 --> 00:39:35,930
You've got to weight them together and

00:39:35,930 --> 00:39:39,880
throughout this show especially when

We gonna see how we can compare

00:39:43,152 --> 00:39:46,177
make those decisions but for

00:39:46,177 --> 00:39:49,881
general concept of you just need to

00:39:49,881 --> 00:39:53,180

779
00:39:53,180 --> 00:39:55,729
>> Okay,
the last tool's another one we've already

00:39:55,729 --> 00:39:59,403
talked about which is facilitated

00:39:59,403 --> 00:40:02,958
those are just where we have a meeting and

00:40:02,958 --> 00:40:06,985

agenda that we go through, and we try and

00:40:12,340 --> 00:40:16,460
With all that information in hand now,

00:40:16,460 --> 00:40:18,540

00:40:18,540 --> 00:40:22,320
Now the scope statement, if this is the

00:40:22,320 --> 00:40:25,300

00:40:25,300 --> 00:40:26,690
But then when you're done,

789
00:40:26,690 --> 00:40:30,970
you're going to send it out to everybody,

00:40:30,970 --> 00:40:35,080

00:40:35,080 --> 00:40:39,870
When the scope statement is done, there's

00:40:39,870 --> 00:40:45,130
Our constraints, our time cost scope,

00:40:45,130 --> 00:40:48,710

00:40:48,710 --> 00:40:50,910

00:40:50,910 --> 00:40:52,940
Things like that.
We might have found new things.

00:40:52,940 --> 00:40:56,510
So, we're gonna start seeing this
with processes from here on out.

797
00:40:56,510 --> 00:40:59,730
Most of our processes
are gonna include two outputs.

798
00:40:59,730 --> 00:41:02,300
One which is whatever it is
we were trying to produce.

799
00:41:02,300 --> 00:41:06,100
And the second one is,
project document updates.

800
00:41:06,100 --> 00:41:09,000
That means we might have
found something new, and

801
00:41:09,000 --> 00:41:12,550
we need to go back and update some

802
00:41:12,550 --> 00:41:15,530
We might need to go and
update our project management plan,

803
00:41:15,530 --> 00:41:17,330
to reflect something new
that we're doing here.

00:41:17,330 --> 00:41:21,160
We might need to go and
update our requirements list.

00:41:21,160 --> 00:41:21,890
You, typically,

806
00:41:21,890 --> 00:41:25,800
don't go and update the charter, usually
the charter stays the way that it was.

807
00:41:25,800 --> 00:41:28,800
But, you may have to come back and
revise this document.

808
00:41:28,800 --> 00:41:32,190
If you've already produced your scope
statement, then when you run through here

809
00:41:32,190 --> 00:41:35,200
a second time, you're doing
an update to the scope statement.

810
00:41:35,200 --> 00:41:38,720
So, we'll start seeing that project
document update on each of the processes

811
00:41:38,720 --> 00:41:41,640
that we look at.

812
00:41:41,640 --> 00:41:45,290
When you're done,
you should be left with a scope statement

00:41:45,290 --> 00:41:49,030
that adequately defines

00:41:49,030 --> 00:41:53,230
And this scope statement will

00:41:53,230 --> 00:41:55,760
At the end of this project
when everything's said and

00:41:55,760 --> 00:41:59,930

00:41:59,930 --> 00:42:04,430
And you should be able to say okay

00:42:04,430 --> 00:42:06,460

819
00:42:06,460 --> 00:42:08,330
Alright, yes or no?

00:42:08,330 --> 00:42:12,550
Is the location,
does it meet the FDIC requirements and

00:42:12,550 --> 00:42:15,116
is it [INAUDIBLE] compliant.

822
00:42:15,116 --> 00:42:16,317
Yes or no right?

823
00:42:16,317 --> 00:42:20,400
Is all existing, or was all existing
functions at the old center

824
00:42:20,400 --> 00:42:22,550
recreate at the new center, yes or no?

00:42:22,550 --> 00:42:24,830
And we just kind of keep going.

826
00:42:24,830 --> 00:42:27,100
Did we replicate that functionality?

827
00:42:27,100 --> 00:42:31,030
Were we able to complete a BRP fail over?

828
00:42:31,030 --> 00:42:33,510
Were we able to flip over to it,

829
00:42:33,510 --> 00:42:34,080
Yes or No?

00:42:35,410 --> 00:42:36,750
Did we exclude these things?

00:42:36,750 --> 00:42:39,150
That's easy, cause we're

00:42:39,150 --> 00:42:41,090

00:42:41,090 --> 00:42:43,250
Did it cost less than 500 grand?

834
00:42:43,250 --> 00:42:45,800
Did we meet all

835
00:42:45,800 --> 00:42:46,910
Yes or no?

836
00:42:46,910 --> 00:42:50,770
And then the assumptions you don't really

00:42:50,770 --> 00:42:53,685
But you could say Were these

00:42:53,685 --> 00:42:54,475
Did we meet those?

839
00:42:54,475 --> 00:42:55,245
Yes or no?

840
00:42:55,245 --> 00:42:58,815
If we answered yes, to all of those

841
00:42:58,815 --> 00:42:59,415
>> Right.
>> Right?

842
00:42:59,415 --> 00:43:02,545
We've completed it, it's a success.

843
00:43:02,545 --> 00:43:07,480
If we answered no to any of those
questions, the project is not done and

844
00:43:07,480 --> 00:43:08,380
the project is a failure.

845
00:43:08,380 --> 00:43:13,850
Well it's a failure if you're past this
date and you're at your budget, right?

846
00:43:13,850 --> 00:43:17,550
But if you still have time left and
you still have budget money left,

847
00:43:17,550 --> 00:43:20,760
and you still have resources
then you can keep moving.

848
00:43:20,760 --> 00:43:23,310
So you use this as a checklist
throughout your project.

849
00:43:23,310 --> 00:43:26,810
This becomes the guiding
element of your entire project.

850
00:43:26,810 --> 00:43:31,420
And that's why I say the charter
is the most powerful document.

851
00:43:31,420 --> 00:43:35,720
It's what empowers the project manager and
kicks off the project, gives it authority.

852
00:43:35,720 --> 00:43:38,680
But this document Is the one
that serves as the guide for

853
00:43:38,680 --> 00:43:40,662
the whole rest of the project.

854
00:43:40,662 --> 00:43:45,560
All right,
as such this document is very special.

855
00:43:45,560 --> 00:43:48,590
Changes to this document could
change your whole project.

856
00:43:48,590 --> 00:43:53,430
If you start adding new requirements to
a requirements register, our exhibit A.

857
00:43:53,430 --> 00:43:58,190
If we start adding more requirements
there, they might cost us more money,

858
00:43:58,190 --> 00:43:59,780
they might require more time.

859
00:43:59,780 --> 00:44:01,770
So we run the risk of failing.

860
00:44:03,020 --> 00:44:06,400
If we need more time or
we need more money we need to come and

861
00:44:06,400 --> 00:44:11,100
update the scope statement to reflect that
we got more money, that we got more time.

862
00:44:11,100 --> 00:44:15,400
So changes to this need to be strictly
controlled and we're gonna have a show

863
00:44:15,400 --> 00:44:18,670
just on change management later
on where we'll address that.

864
00:44:18,670 --> 00:44:20,510
But this document,

865
00:44:20,510 --> 00:44:24,310
changes to it should not be taken
lightly after the planning phase.

866
00:44:24,310 --> 00:44:26,630
Right now we're in planning,
we can change it all we want.

867
00:44:26,630 --> 00:44:31,420
But once we get out of planning we really
need to try and keep this set in stone and

868
00:44:31,420 --> 00:44:32,374
not deviate from it.

869
00:44:32,374 --> 00:44:33,225
All right.

870
00:44:33,225 --> 00:44:36,526
Now we have an idea of what we need to do.

871
00:44:36,526 --> 00:44:41,570
Let's figure out how we're gonna do it,
all right?

00:44:41,570 --> 00:44:46,150
As a project manager, the odds are you're
not going to be a subject matter

00:44:46,150 --> 00:44:48,520
expert for what your project does, okay.

So for example, for me at the bank,

The network side, I know the network side,

And, as we all started

00:45:27,790 --> 00:45:28,930
I had to work with them to say.

00:45:28,930 --> 00:45:33,100
Okay, what work are you guys going to

to not lose data,
to keep things operational.

00:45:40,270 --> 00:45:44,700
the actual work that's gonna be done

The way we come up with that list

breakdown structure.

And I showed a work

But this is a diagram and basically
what we do is we take our project, and

for our project to be a success.

So deliverable number one for

Table of contents,
the rest of the book and

00:47:21,500 --> 00:47:22,400
So we need to sy, okay for

a table of contents what
actual work needs to be done?

00:47:26,780 --> 00:47:28,600
Well, it's easy to think

929
00:47:28,600 --> 00:47:32,110
We can say, well I need to,
I need to just write a table of contents.

00:47:32,110 --> 00:47:34,470
Well table of contents

931

You've got your main areas and

00:47:42,510 --> 00:47:45,320
So, we've got to have an agreement.

935

Ronnie and I have to agree on

00:47:48,400 --> 00:47:51,396
And then we probably need to divide

that you get half, I get half, and so

00:47:53,083 --> 00:47:56,359
we're not overwhelmed with trying

939
00:47:56,359 --> 00:47:59,460
So we start breaking this process down.

940
00:47:59,460 --> 00:48:04,289
And at the end of the day we come up with
a list of the actual work that needs to be

941
00:48:04,289 --> 00:48:06,950
completed to achieve that deliverable.

942
00:48:06,950 --> 00:48:10,980
So when it comes to printing, we might
have to have a graphics designer create

943
00:48:10,980 --> 00:48:14,650

944
00:48:14,650 --> 00:48:17,760
they have to print it out, right they

945
00:48:17,760 --> 00:48:19,700
The binding, the printing, the shipping,

946
00:48:19,700 --> 00:48:23,910
you know all of these are actual work
elements that we need to identify.

947
00:48:23,910 --> 00:48:28,920
Right, now each of these are what
are called work packages.

948
00:48:28,920 --> 00:48:33,120
A work package, and this is the official
term, what you'll see on the exam.

949
00:48:33,120 --> 00:48:37,150
A work package is just a granular or

950
00:48:37,150 --> 00:48:42,310
compartmentalized segment of work
that needs to be performed that, when

951
00:48:42,310 --> 00:48:46,620
combined with other work packages, results
in the production of your deliverable.

952
00:48:47,800 --> 00:48:50,650
The hardest part about creating a WBS

953
00:48:50,650 --> 00:48:53,170
is identifying all the work
that is necessary.

954
00:48:53,170 --> 00:48:55,130
Because it's really easy
to leave things out.

955
00:48:55,130 --> 00:48:59,830
And if you leave things out it's going to
make it hard to determine schedule and

956
00:48:59,830 --> 00:49:00,740
budget later on.

00:49:00,740 --> 00:49:04,560
So we've got to be thorough, so
we've got several tools available for

958
00:49:04,560 --> 00:49:06,770
us to help make sure
we're thorough about it.

00:49:06,770 --> 00:49:08,130

00:49:09,300 --> 00:49:12,030
Let me bring up my,

Alright, so we have a WBS process.

Create the work breakdown structure

So basically it's saying gather up

So we gather those together and

00:49:47,752 --> 00:49:52,510
All right, now getting to work really

Decomposition and

with expert judgement that's where we

So it is important that when we say expert

You don't necessarily know how to

Get a second opinion.

Because if you've got one project manager

All right?

So what we'll typically do is a process

Progressive elaboration, is another term

I might start high level, so

I wanna build a house, lay foundation,

Eric builds houses for a living.

[LAUGH] And so I can go and get Eric and

00:52:27,730 --> 00:52:33,240

so when I say something

00:52:42,230 --> 00:52:43,060

well, we need to bring this machinery in

He knows that stuff,
he knows it cuz he does it for a living.

00:53:13,120 --> 00:53:15,700

00:53:15,700 --> 00:53:16,880
And you want that,

1051
00:53:16,880 --> 00:53:21,700
you want more than one set of eyes on
this work breakdown diagram because

1052
00:53:21,700 --> 00:53:25,890
you might know the deliverable, and you
can think of some high level activities.

1053
00:53:25,890 --> 00:53:30,530
But then that expert comes along and
they take that high level activity and

1054
00:53:30,530 --> 00:53:34,580
they break it down into additional
work packages that are smaller.

1055
00:53:34,580 --> 00:53:35,360
All right?

1056
00:53:35,360 --> 00:53:39,420
Now here's a key thing that may
not seem like common sense, but

1057
00:53:39,420 --> 00:53:41,220
on the exam it's important.

1058
00:53:41,220 --> 00:53:46,580
In a work breakdown structure If you have
a work package and you break it down

1059
00:53:46,580 --> 00:53:53,810
into subpackages, this work package
should not actually be work itself.

1060
00:53:53,810 --> 00:53:58,626
There's zero work associated with
this entity right here, 2.1.

1061
00:53:58,626 --> 00:54:03,018
But instead If activity 2.1.1 and 2.1.2,

1062
00:54:03,018 --> 00:54:10,230
if those two work packages get done, they
complete this work package, all right?

1063
00:54:10,230 --> 00:54:16,300
So these guys, deliverable to activity
2.1, those are just placeholders and

1064
00:54:16,300 --> 00:54:22,100
then it's the lowest level that actually
represents true work, all right?

1065
00:54:22,100 --> 00:54:24,430
So this might say it lays foundation.

1066
00:54:24,430 --> 00:54:27,830
And then I have work packages for
all the work,

1067
00:54:27,830 --> 00:54:30,720
the actual work that needs to be
done to lay that foundation and

1068
00:54:30,720 --> 00:54:34,040
when all of these are done,
this one is automatically done.

1069
00:54:34,040 --> 00:54:39,360
There's no actual work associated
with that element, versus over here,

1070
00:54:39,360 --> 00:54:43,610
these have no sub elements, so
these are actual work, right?

1071
00:54:43,610 --> 00:54:45,260
So it's whatever the lowest tier is.

1072
00:54:45,260 --> 00:54:52,550
These are actual work, this is actual
work, this is not, it's a place holder.

1073
00:54:52,550 --> 00:54:56,040
This is not, it's a place holder.
The project as a whole is a place holder.

1074
00:54:56,040 --> 00:54:59,290
This is the actual work,
the lowest level, here.

1075
00:54:59,290 --> 00:55:02,730
The lowest level inside of that
tree is the actual work package.

1076
00:55:02,730 --> 00:55:07,660
Somebody has to go and
do this physical work to get this done.

1077
00:55:07,660 --> 00:55:11,530
That's what a work breakdown structure is
all about, and you're not gonna get it

1078
00:55:11,530 --> 00:55:15,660
on the first draft unless you're repeating
a project that's been done before.

1079
00:55:15,660 --> 00:55:19,460
If you're building a house odds are you're
not the very first person to build

1080
00:55:19,460 --> 00:55:20,530
a house ever.

1081
00:55:20,530 --> 00:55:23,640
So there's probably a work breakdown
structure in your environment that

1082
00:55:23,640 --> 00:55:25,320
already shows the stuff
that needs to be done.

1083
00:55:25,320 --> 00:55:27,260
So how is this going to be customized?

1084
00:55:27,260 --> 00:55:29,310
So you might have some unique
stuff that's in there, but

1085
00:55:29,310 --> 00:55:33,310
the overall process for building
the house is going to be the same.

1086
00:55:33,310 --> 00:55:36,160
So you might start out with a work
breakdown structure that already has

1087
00:55:36,160 --> 00:55:38,320
some data in it and
then you just elaborate.

1088
00:55:40,160 --> 00:55:41,630
So progressive elaboration,

1089
00:55:41,630 --> 00:55:44,550
that's an important term,
remember that one because it will turn up.

1090
00:55:46,240 --> 00:55:49,020
All right, well Ronnie looking at the

00:56:16,910 --> 00:56:21,171
One of the components here inside of our

00:56:21,171 --> 00:56:21,740
Right?

Which is somewhat morbid,

00:56:25,000 --> 00:56:29,470
But, all it means is
taking a work package and

1104
00:56:29,470 --> 00:56:31,640

00:56:31,640 --> 00:56:35,120
And continuing to do that until we

00:56:55,690 --> 00:56:59,050
Don't worry about how much it's gonna

So

well hey I'll talk about that in a second.

Now we know all the work to buy land,

find the realtors, make a list,

this is time that's measurable, it's an

Somebody is going to have to do this,

Another thing that's

I kind of wrote this out chronologically.

But it isn't necessarily in

I'm just trying to figure out

We'll worry about timing

Well, it's kind of up to you.

You also don't wanna micromanage because

we want to leave some room for them to,

when it comes down to the pen bach,

they kind of describe this

The idea of breaking it down in terms

the point where it's

A manageable work package.

So you don't have to micromanage the book.

Someone's gonna have to choose, or

01:03:12,629 --> 01:03:17,390
each realtor, right?

So maybe one of my criteria is
how many houses have they sold

So, realtor A might have 500 houses,

01:03:28,860 --> 01:03:31,217
So, I need to know what the criteria are,
and

01:03:31,217 --> 01:03:34,020

01:03:34,020 --> 01:03:39,168
Then I need to assign

1255
01:03:39,168 --> 01:03:45,360

1256
01:03:45,360 --> 01:03:48,040
So, I need to determine which

1257
01:03:48,040 --> 01:03:50,400
And then, finally, I need to select.

01:03:50,400 --> 01:03:51,580
The winner.

So like who it is that's actually

So you do this,

It's like a subproject at that

Where it's something that's,
it's gotta be trackable.

1277

Right?
We gotta be able to monitor its progress

1278
01:04:50,310 --> 01:04:54,320
and know when it's done, so
don't have something subjective in there.

1279
01:04:54,320 --> 01:04:57,340
And, basically break it down to that.

I usually do outlines, just like what

the other thing is these don't always make

Usually when I deal with diagrams,

I worry about it when we

So once we've done all of that, now

that is interesting, I would have assumed

Well, the work breakdown structure, right?

01:06:56,320 --> 01:06:59,470
The work breakdown structure,
that list of work that needs to be done.

Well, the work that needs to be done,
it's being done to fulfill the needs

1321
01:07:03,910 --> 01:07:08,325

01:07:08,830 --> 01:07:11,670
>> Now that term baseline,
what does that mean?

1324
01:07:11,670 --> 01:07:15,960
A baseline is a snapshot,
a point in time reference.

1325
01:07:15,960 --> 01:07:21,210
This is the work that needs to
be done as we know it right now.

1326
01:07:21,210 --> 01:07:24,100
Through the life of your project,
changes are gonna happen.

1327
01:07:24,100 --> 01:07:25,780
You're gonna submit change tickets.

01:07:25,780 --> 01:07:27,490
Modifications will happen.

1329
01:07:27,490 --> 01:07:30,720
Modifications will often happen to
the work breakdown structure as you

find new work that needs to be done.

1331
01:07:32,590 --> 01:07:36,050
So you'll have multiple
versions of your WBS.

01:07:36,050 --> 01:07:38,680
Your scope baseline, your original one,

So now you've got a newer

1336

that you compare back to that baseline.

Cuz you used the baseline to plan

01:07:54,540 --> 01:07:55,580
all that good stuff.

1339

So the WBS itself,

1573

Quality really means our, you know,

1574
01:19:20,530 --> 01:19:22,450

1575
01:19:22,450 --> 01:19:25,460
Cost, requirements, schedule or budget.

1576

So those are the next things

1577

Right, so these are some other

But the next three things that we do are

1583

1584
01:19:49,400 --> 01:19:50,850
>> So we're gonna start to see that.

1585

All right Ronny I think that pretty

[LAUGH] all right well ladies and

Hit that Q&A link at

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue to define the scope of determining the requirements of the project. These are the deliverables that we will expect at the end of the project. They talk about how to make sure you can determine these requirements.
episodes.title: Determining Requirements

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don begin to cover the largest topic within the planning phase--scheduling the project. They show some of the templates used and show some basic Project Management Scheduling Utilities that can be used to help with project time management. They talk about defining the activities, sequencing the events and assigning resources to activities.
episodes.title: Time Management Part 1

00:17:06.450 --> 00:17:10.740
So it was called X11 for the longest time,
it's the X Windows system.

338
00:17:11.870 --> 00:17:17.330
X Windows was the original graphical user
interface developed for Unix like systems.

339
00:17:17.330 --> 00:17:20.880
And so it was ported to
support Linux very early on.

340
00:17:20.880 --> 00:17:24.520
And if you wanted a GUI in Linux,
X Windows was all you used.

341
00:17:24.520 --> 00:17:27.100

342
00:17:27.100 --> 00:17:31.760
And so over the years,
people have written KDE and

343
00:17:31.760 --> 00:17:35.310
Gnome and XFC and stuff like that.

344
00:17:35.310 --> 00:17:40.700
That lay on top of X Windows, and gives
it all sorts of additional functionality.

345
00:17:40.700 --> 00:17:41.870
So think of it kind of like Linux.

346
00:17:41.870 --> 00:17:45.710
With Linux you had the Linux kernel, and
then the various distributions out there

347
00:17:45.710 --> 00:17:48.390
have all the tools that wrap
around it to create your OS.

348
00:17:48.390 --> 00:17:51.820
Well X windows is kind
of like that kernel.

349
00:17:51.820 --> 00:17:55.410
It's the heart of your GUI and
then your desktop, your

350
00:17:55.410 --> 00:17:59.100
Window manager is what that's called, your
window manager lays on top of that and

351
00:17:59.100 --> 00:18:02.360
it's what creates what you actually
interact with on the screen.

352
00:18:02.360 --> 00:18:05.090
So you're picking between all sorts
of different window managers.

353
00:18:05.090 --> 00:18:08.550
I might pick KDE or I might pick Gnome.

354
00:18:08.550 --> 00:18:12.290
At the end of the day underneath it is X.

00:18:12.290 --> 00:18:16.150
Now X went through several revisions over
the years, and so it was X11R5, X11R6,

356
00:18:16.150 --> 00:18:19.380
each of the different releases.

357
00:18:19.380 --> 00:18:24.680
And then with X11R7,
they renamed it to just x.org.

358
00:18:24.680 --> 00:18:28.010

00:18:28.010 --> 00:18:31.400

00:18:31.400 --> 00:18:35.870

00:18:37.840 --> 00:18:41.350

X-Windows, sure it can draw
the graphical user interface for

01:07:52.110 --> 01:07:54.980
a program on your screen and
you can use it, but

01:07:54.980 --> 01:07:59.070

It can draw it to anybody's screen.

01:08:01.790 --> 01:08:03.610
X-Windows is a server.

01:08:03.610 --> 01:08:06.760
You're running the X-Windows
server on the back end.

1324
01:08:06.760 --> 01:08:10.740
You just happen to be running the client

1325
01:08:10.740 --> 01:08:13.120
That client is letting

1326
01:08:13.120 --> 01:08:15.260

01:08:15.260 --> 01:08:19.450
You can run the client on a completely
separate computer if you want, and

1328
01:08:19.450 --> 01:08:23.670
people can connect to it and see those
windows and launch applications and so on.

01:08:23.670 --> 01:08:25.920
It's really, really cool, okay?

01:08:25.920 --> 01:08:28.780

01:08:28.780 --> 01:08:30.060

01:08:30.060 --> 01:08:32.480
So let me show you what I mean.

1333
01:08:32.480 --> 01:08:36.710
First off, X-Windows is set to only
allow local communications by default.

1334
01:08:36.710 --> 01:08:41.420
So what we can do is we can open it up to
allow connections from other machines.

1335
01:08:41.420 --> 01:08:42.820
Now it's not gonna open it wide,
for the world.

1336
01:08:42.820 --> 01:08:45.641
People still have to connect and
authenticate and all that good stuff.

1337
01:08:45.641 --> 01:08:50.390
But what we can do,
let me get it back into a terminal and

1338
01:08:50.390 --> 01:08:55.462
I need to elevate my privileges
here real quick to do this.

1339
01:08:55.462 --> 01:09:00.171
We have a command called xhost, and xhost
is what defines who's allowed to connect

1340
01:09:00.171 --> 01:09:04.629
to this system and the default is that
it is just limited to local connections.

1341
01:09:04.629 --> 01:09:08.110
And what I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna use xhost to open it up.

1342
01:09:08.110 --> 01:09:12.170
Now, normally what you do
is you say xhost + and

1343
01:09:12.170 --> 01:09:17.100
a user name or xhost + and a host name for
a computer and that'll say that

1344
01:09:17.100 --> 01:09:21.000
that computer is allowed to connect or
that user is allowed to connect.

1345
01:09:21.000 --> 01:09:23.170
I'm gonna go ahead and say xhost+, and

1346
01:09:23.170 --> 01:09:27.740
that will say access control disabled,
clients can connect from any host.

1347
01:09:27.740 --> 01:09:30.220
I'm saying anybody can
connect to this machine.

1348
01:09:30.220 --> 01:09:33.150
Now, I'm not completely throwing
security out the door here.

1349
01:09:33.150 --> 01:09:37.030
People still have to authenticate
to get to it, and on your network,

1350
01:09:37.030 --> 01:09:38.510
if you're allowing connectivity
with the Internet,

1351
01:09:38.510 --> 01:09:41.960
you should be using a firewall to control
who's even allowed to touch this.

01:09:41.960 --> 01:09:46.234

up on your taskbar up at the very top,

I'm pretty sure it's not gonna talk.

1831
01:35:27.750 --> 01:35:29.690
Although it is gonna think for a while.

1832
01:35:29.690 --> 01:35:32.570
[LAUGH] If you want the screen
reader to work, it's probably

1833
01:35:32.570 --> 01:35:36.450
a good idea to have a sound card,
which I'm pretty sure I don't on this one.

1834
01:35:36.450 --> 01:35:40.730
There's the screen magnifier,
which is incredibly useful because boy,

1835
01:35:40.730 --> 01:35:43.480
screen resolutions are getting higher and
higher.

1836
01:35:43.480 --> 01:35:47.570
So, if you are, not necessarily
legally blind but if you are just

1837
01:35:47.570 --> 01:35:51.188
visually impaired Impaired,
if your vision is half as bad as mine is.

1838
01:35:51.188 --> 01:35:52.260
>> [LAUGH]
>> Mine's pretty bad.

1839
01:35:52.260 --> 01:35:55.685
I don't think you can see it on camera
exactly how thick my classes are, but.

1840
01:35:55.685 --> 01:35:59.406
[LAUGH] So if yours are as bad as mine,
you can use this screen magnifier,

1841
01:35:59.406 --> 01:36:00.532
it's really handy.

1842
01:36:00.532 --> 01:36:02.705
It just follows your mouse,
and it magnifies And

1843
01:36:02.705 --> 01:36:05.944
you'll see there's actually two
levels of magnification by default.

1844
01:36:05.944 --> 01:36:08.613
So I've got three panes on my screen here,

1845
01:36:08.613 --> 01:36:13.359
one that is magnified a decent amount and
one that's like super magnified,

1846
01:36:13.359 --> 01:36:18.800
again, trying to help me line up that
mouse to be able to click and operate.

1847
01:36:18.800 --> 01:36:20.110
Hm.

1848
01:36:20.110 --> 01:36:22.461
We've got Enhance contrast in colors.

1849
01:36:22.461 --> 01:36:25.586
You'll see my screen goes mostly black and
white.

1850
01:36:25.586 --> 01:36:31.752
If you have a visual impairment then this
make things really stand out, right.

1851
01:36:31.752 --> 01:36:37.136
So I know I had my Uncle Bud who had very,
very bad tunnel vision, and telling

1852
01:36:37.136 --> 01:36:42.710
the difference between subtle color
variations is not something he could do.

1853
01:36:42.710 --> 01:36:46.300
Using Enhance contrast
in colors really helped.

1854
01:36:46.300 --> 01:36:47.850
We can also make text larger.

1855
01:36:47.850 --> 01:36:51.070
I know a lot of people are doing that on
high resolution monitors these days, and

1856
01:36:51.070 --> 01:36:53.050
that'll just make the general text bigger.

1857
01:36:53.050 --> 01:36:56.170
This is a great option, but
it does cause problems with some software.

1858
01:36:56.170 --> 01:36:59.020
A lot of software is not written
to respect the setting and

1859
01:36:59.020 --> 01:37:00.120
that's an unfortunate thing.

1860
01:37:00.120 --> 01:37:03.710
I do wish more software was
compatible with this stuff.

1861
01:37:03.710 --> 01:37:09.010
But you might see screen artifacts, things
not rendering properly, that does happen.

1862
01:37:09.010 --> 01:37:10.660
All right.

1863
01:37:10.660 --> 01:37:13.470
You'll see Sticky Keys is the next option.

1864
01:37:13.470 --> 01:37:15.990
Press keyboard shortcuts
one key at a time.

1865
01:37:15.990 --> 01:37:20.820
That's where if I tap shift and let go,
now I'm actually holding the shift key,

1866
01:37:20.820 --> 01:37:22.250
even though I'm not actually holding it.

1867
01:37:22.250 --> 01:37:25.690
And with the very next key I press
it'll enter it in as a capital letter.

1868
01:37:27.450 --> 01:37:30.880
Ignore duplicate key presses,
that's the bounce keys and

1869
01:37:30.880 --> 01:37:34.330
then press and hold keys to accept them,
that's slow keys.

1870
01:37:34.330 --> 01:37:36.660
So in other words,
if you just tap it that won't count.

1871
01:37:36.660 --> 01:37:40.340
You have to hold the key down
before it registers it as a press.

1872
01:37:40.340 --> 01:37:45.360
So each of those are basically supporting
a different use case scenario.

1873
01:37:46.490 --> 01:37:49.200
>> Now these options here,
these accessibility options,

1874
01:37:49.200 --> 01:37:51.795
these are baked into Gnome,
was that correct?

1875
01:37:51.795 --> 01:37:55.340
>> Mm-hm, yep, with the default packages
that we installed here in the OS.

1876
01:37:55.340 --> 01:37:55.847
Yep.
>> Nice.

1877
01:37:55.847 --> 01:37:56.520
>> All right, so

1878
01:37:56.520 --> 01:37:58.706
if I turn some of these things on.
I'll go ahead and

1879
01:37:58.706 --> 01:38:00.920
turn on, I'll do Sticky Keys.

1880
01:38:00.920 --> 01:38:03.940
A lot of these have
keyboard shortcuts also.

1881
01:38:03.940 --> 01:38:06.770
So for example Sticky Keys,
if I wanted to turn it on,

1882
01:38:06.770 --> 01:38:09.880
one of the things you can do is you
can tap the shift key five times.

1883
01:38:09.880 --> 01:38:12.590
And when you tap it five times
that'll turn on Sticky Keys.

1884
01:38:12.590 --> 01:38:15.170
So, a lot of them have
little shortcuts like that.

1885
01:38:15.170 --> 01:38:18.340
And like everything in Linux there's
always more than one way to do stuff.

1886
01:38:18.340 --> 01:38:20.430
This is a really simple screen.

1887
01:38:20.430 --> 01:38:23.950
It's designed to get you what you need,
so you can get logged in.

1888
01:38:23.950 --> 01:38:26.090
Once we're logged in,
there's actually more options.

1889
01:38:26.090 --> 01:38:26.950
Let me show you those.

1890
01:38:28.220 --> 01:38:32.420
So I'm going to log in here, as dpizat,
probably need to punch in my password and

1891
01:38:32.420 --> 01:38:33.380
not my username.

1892
01:38:33.380 --> 01:38:35.050
There we go.

1893
01:38:35.050 --> 01:38:36.620
So I'll get logged in.

1894
01:38:36.620 --> 01:38:40.970
Once I'm logged in,
I can go up to System, and

1895
01:38:40.970 --> 01:38:43.360
Preferences and
you'll see Assistive Technologies.

1896
01:38:43.360 --> 01:38:45.805
It's the same icon the blue
circle with the stick man in it.

1897
01:38:45.805 --> 01:38:46.330
>> Mm-hm.

1898
01:38:46.330 --> 01:38:50.110
>> And when we fire that up here's
where we can start to do some advanced

1899
01:38:50.110 --> 01:38:50.960
customizations.

1900
01:38:52.220 --> 01:38:55.530
For example under Assistive Technologies
I've got Preferred Applications.

1901
01:38:55.530 --> 01:38:57.172
And here's where I can
set my screen reader.

1902
01:38:57.172 --> 01:38:59.390
See how I've got Orca chosen?

1903
01:38:59.390 --> 01:39:04.020
I can do Orca with Magnifier,
GNOME Magnifier, KDE Magnifier.

1904
01:39:04.020 --> 01:39:07.425
If I had installed a third party one,
I could choose custom and

1905
01:39:07.425 --> 01:39:11.470
choose that other screen reader,
or my visual enhancement here.

1906
01:39:11.470 --> 01:39:15.480
Any mobility options that I might need,
like the onscreen keyboard, we can set

1907
01:39:15.480 --> 01:39:18.750
them to run at start, so they're
automatically running and waiting for us.

1908
01:39:18.750 --> 01:39:20.615
So we've got various functionality there.

1909
01:39:20.615 --> 01:39:22.310
>> Mm-hm.

1910
01:39:22.310 --> 01:39:23.730
So then Don, maybe this is, yeah.

1911
01:39:25.490 --> 01:39:28.790
So let's say that you don't
have GNOME installed, and

1912
01:39:28.790 --> 01:39:31.120
you are just running on
the straight up command line.

1913
01:39:31.120 --> 01:39:34.860
Is there any kind of accessibility options
that we have just running like a straight

1914
01:39:34.860 --> 01:39:37.320
up basic minimal install?

1915
01:39:37.320 --> 01:39:39.540
>> It's much more limited,
it's much more limited.

1916
01:39:39.540 --> 01:39:41.110
I've never used that.

1917
01:39:41.110 --> 01:39:45.150
So from just a native command line,
a lot of this stuff,

1918
01:39:45.150 --> 01:39:48.240
like Orca depends on X Windows.

1919
01:39:48.240 --> 01:39:52.910
And so it's really expecting to be in that
GUI as part of the screen interpreter.

1920
01:39:52.910 --> 01:39:54.670
That's not to say that you can't.

1921
01:39:54.670 --> 01:39:55.680
Somebody might make it.

1922
01:39:55.680 --> 01:39:57.530
I'm just not familiar with it.

1923
01:39:57.530 --> 01:39:58.550
>> Right on.

1924
01:39:58.550 --> 01:40:04.000
>> My exposure, I personally don't have
a need for most of the assistive tools.

1925
01:40:04.000 --> 01:40:05.885
Most of them.
I do actually use one or two.

1926
01:40:05.885 --> 01:40:06.587
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

1927
01:40:06.587 --> 01:40:07.640
>> But for most of them.

1928
01:40:07.640 --> 01:40:10.520
But I know I grew up with my Aunt Maureen,
who was deaf.

1929
01:40:10.520 --> 01:40:14.690
And that's where I got exposed to a lot
of this was through her needs, and

1930
01:40:14.690 --> 01:40:16.430
helping her get things set up.

1931
01:40:16.430 --> 01:40:19.940
And my Uncle Bud,
who was severely visually impaired.

1932
01:40:19.940 --> 01:40:23.740
So you know it may not be you that
has specific need for these, but

1933
01:40:23.740 --> 01:40:27.930
learning to support them, man it is
worthwhile because the moment that you

1934
01:40:27.930 --> 01:40:32.090
find somebody who needs that help,
when you can take away that obstacle and

1935
01:40:32.090 --> 01:40:35.510
let them use a computer,
that's big deal, that really is.

1936
01:40:35.510 --> 01:40:40.290
So, we'll see other options in here
like our Keyboard accessibility options.

1937
01:40:40.290 --> 01:40:43.422
Here we can go in and manually, not just
turn the options on, but tweak them.

1938
01:40:43.422 --> 01:40:48.380
So like Slow Keys, how long do you have
to hold the key for before it registers?

1939
01:40:48.380 --> 01:40:52.288
Or Bounce Keys, how long do you wait
to invalidate a double press, right?

1940
01:40:52.288 --> 01:40:57.490
Cuz that can get annoying if you're typing
a word like bookkeeper that has double Os,

1941
01:40:57.490 --> 01:41:00.500
double Ks, double Es all in a row, right.

1942
01:41:00.500 --> 01:41:04.160
If you've got Bounce Keys turned on it's
frustrating to type a word like that.

1943
01:41:04.160 --> 01:41:05.690
So, adjusting those values.

1944
01:41:05.690 --> 01:41:07.930
You've also got things like Mouse Keys.

1945
01:41:07.930 --> 01:41:11.320
See how I've got Pointer can be
controlled using the keypad?

1946
01:41:11.320 --> 01:41:15.080
That lets you use the arrow keys on your
keypad to move the mouse pointer instead

1947
01:41:15.080 --> 01:41:16.000
of using your mouse.

1948
01:41:16.000 --> 01:41:20.291
That's a neat feature,
if a mouse is not something you wanna use.

1949
01:41:21.450 --> 01:41:22.800
You can also do Typing Break.

1950
01:41:22.800 --> 01:41:25.780
This one I've never used,
I think it's more for controlling kids.

1951
01:41:25.780 --> 01:41:30.810
But if you're worried about fatigue,
if you don't want to

1952
01:41:30.810 --> 01:41:33.890
have somebody using a keyboard for
too long, you can set it to lock

1953
01:41:33.890 --> 01:41:37.050
your workstation after a certain period
of time and hold it locked for a while.

1954
01:41:37.050 --> 01:41:42.870
So basically enforcing breaks so that
you don't wear yourself out, all right?

1955
01:41:42.870 --> 01:41:44.570
You'll see a lot of other options in here.

1956
01:41:44.570 --> 01:41:47.190
Really it is just a ton of options.

1957
01:41:47.190 --> 01:41:49.780
And so it's a matter of finding
the ones that are right for

1958
01:41:49.780 --> 01:41:52.050
the scenario that you need.

1959
01:41:52.050 --> 01:41:56.470
>> Having that one mouse one where you can
control your mouse cursor with the arrow

1960
01:41:56.470 --> 01:42:00.700
keys, I find that at times on my XPS,
where I need something like that to help

1961
01:42:00.700 --> 01:42:02.126
me get around the little-
>> [LAUGH] Because

1962
01:42:02.126 --> 01:42:02.670
your touch pad is so bad.

1963
01:42:02.670 --> 01:42:04.280
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, the touch pad on there.

1964
01:42:04.280 --> 01:42:04.970
On this one.
>> Yeah.

1965
01:42:04.970 --> 01:42:09.050
It just goes to show these assistive
technologies, they're for everyone.

1966
01:42:09.050 --> 01:42:10.180
Anybody can benefit from these.

1967
01:42:10.180 --> 01:42:14.130
Anybody who is having difficulties
interacting with that desktop.

1968
01:42:14.130 --> 01:42:17.810
Because just because there's
a common use scenario

1969
01:42:17.810 --> 01:42:20.020
doesn't mean that's the use
scenario that fits for you.

1970
01:42:20.020 --> 01:42:22.790
You may need to adjust
things to meet your needs.

1971
01:42:22.790 --> 01:42:23.630
All right.

1972
01:42:23.630 --> 01:42:27.180
So those are the basics of
the assistive technologies.

1973
01:42:27.180 --> 01:42:28.720
There are more out there.

1974
01:42:28.720 --> 01:42:30.400
There's tons, third party ones.

1975
01:42:30.400 --> 01:42:33.390
There's a lot of great websites out there
that catalog different software that's

1976
01:42:33.390 --> 01:42:35.770
available and you can make use of that.

1977
01:42:35.770 --> 01:42:39.420
Don't ever feel like you shouldn't
be able to use a computer.

1978
01:42:39.420 --> 01:42:42.419
There's the tools to make it happen, it's
just a matter of putting them together.

1979
01:42:42.419 --> 01:42:46.843
And unfortunately a lot of vendors out
there haven't taken the time to make their

1980
01:42:46.843 --> 01:42:49.966
software compliant and so
it may be a bit of a challenge but

1981
01:42:49.966 --> 01:42:51.479
it can definitely be done.

1982
01:42:53.020 --> 01:42:54.202
>> All right, nice.

1983
01:42:54.202 --> 01:42:57.530
>> All right, so I think that's
about it for assistive technologies.

1984
01:42:57.530 --> 01:43:01.570
And really that's about it for
the graphical user interface.

1985
01:43:01.570 --> 01:43:06.340
Remember the GUI only makes
up 8% of the second exam.

1986
01:43:06.340 --> 01:43:07.920
So the first exam is all CLI.

1987
01:43:07.920 --> 01:43:12.378
The second Exam is 92% CLI.

1988
01:43:12.378 --> 01:43:14.790
So we don't spend a ton of time in here.

1989
01:43:14.790 --> 01:43:17.160
So we're just gonna have the one
episode here on the GUI.

1990
01:43:17.160 --> 01:43:19.110
I think we've covered
a decent bit of stuff.

1991
01:43:19.110 --> 01:43:22.100
Most of the things people
want to know anyway.

1992
01:43:22.100 --> 01:43:23.510
>> Yeah.
>> All right,

1993
01:43:23.510 --> 01:43:28.750
well let me just remind everybody that if
you ever have any questions on this stuff,

1994
01:43:28.750 --> 01:43:31.360
live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live.

1995
01:43:31.360 --> 01:43:34.560
You'll see the chat box
right beneath our video.

1996
01:43:34.560 --> 01:43:36.290
You can post the questions there.

1997
01:43:36.290 --> 01:43:38.840
We monitor and answer during the show.

1998
01:43:38.840 --> 01:43:40.480
If you have questions after the show,

1999
01:43:40.480 --> 01:43:43.530
like if you're watching this recorded,
use our Q&A forums.

2000
01:43:43.530 --> 01:43:45.820
At the top of every page at itpro.tv,

2001
01:43:45.820 --> 01:43:48.720
you'll see a Q&A link that'll
take you right into the forums.

2002
01:43:48.720 --> 01:43:50.360
You can post your questions there.

2003
01:43:50.360 --> 01:43:51.938
We monitor and answer.

2004
01:43:51.938 --> 01:43:55.850
[LAUGH] I know Ronnie's kicking my butt
right now on answers, so I need to get in

2005
01:43:55.850 --> 01:43:58.240
there to do some more answers, but
we do monitor and answer there.

2006
01:43:58.240 --> 01:44:01.880
We wanna make sure you guys have the
answers you need to be able to study and

2007
01:44:01.880 --> 01:44:03.120
be successful on that exam.

2008
01:44:03.120 --> 01:44:05.430
You should never go into
an exam with questions, right.

2009
01:44:05.430 --> 01:44:07.040
That's not the way you wanna go about it.

2010
01:44:07.040 --> 01:44:09.695
So, they'll have plenty of them
in the exam room for you already.

2011
01:44:09.695 --> 01:44:11.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right.

2012
01:44:11.400 --> 01:44:12.770
Well, I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

2013
01:44:12.770 --> 01:44:15.461
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

2014
01:44:15.461 --> 01:44:21.909
>> I'm Nathan

2015
01:44:21.909 --> 01:44:28.364
Copeland.

2016
01:44:28.364 --> 01:44:34.836
>> And we will see you next time.

2017
01:44:34.836 --> 01:44:36.136
[MUSIC]

2018
01:44:36.136 --> 01:44:36.820
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don they show the process of estimating the duration of activities within a project. They use different project management software to show how the duration of activities affect the overall duration of the project as well. They show the most common methods of estimating durations and describe the critical path and demonstrate how to determine it.
episodes.title: Time Management Part 2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,601 --> 00:00:34,682
All right.

3
00:00:34,682 --> 00:00:37,224
Good morning, good afternoon, and
good evening, and welcome back.

4
00:00:37,224 --> 00:00:39,419
To another episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:39,419 --> 00:00:41,881
I'm your host, Don Pezet,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:41,881 --> 00:00:42,647
How's it going, Ronnie?

7
00:00:42,647 --> 00:00:44,040
>> I am saddened this morning.

8
00:00:44,040 --> 00:00:48,927
I did not get on Kim Kardashian's wedding
list for the summer event of the year.

9
00:00:48,927 --> 00:00:50,587
>> Didn't she already get married?

10
00:00:50,587 --> 00:00:51,644
>> No, apparently not.

11
00:00:51,644 --> 00:00:54,361
>> Are you telling me they had
a kid before they got married?

12
00:00:54,361 --> 00:00:54,907
That happens?

13
00:00:54,907 --> 00:00:55,870
>> Yes, yes that happens.

14
00:00:55,870 --> 00:00:57,345
>> That's shocking news.

15
00:00:57,345 --> 00:01:02,301
Kim Kardashian, she is a never
ending source of entertainment.

16
00:01:02,301 --> 00:01:03,462
>> That's right.

17
00:01:03,462 --> 00:01:08,184
>> [LAUGH] All right, well since there's
a big wedding that's being planned,

18
00:01:08,184 --> 00:01:11,811
obviously, one of the big deals
that you deal with there.

19
00:01:11,811 --> 00:01:17,249
That is a project right there, even for a
normal person's wedding, not little note.

20
00:01:17,249 --> 00:01:20,005
>> When Jay Z made it and
I didn't make it, I was shocked.

21
00:01:20,005 --> 00:01:23,208
>> [LAUGH] Even for
a D-list actress, there's a lot.

22
00:01:23,208 --> 00:01:24,032
Is she an actress?

23
00:01:24,032 --> 00:01:25,590
What is she?

24
00:01:25,590 --> 00:01:27,260
>> Who knows?
>> Yeah, I'm sorry.

25
00:01:27,260 --> 00:01:30,810
So, anyhow, one of the big aspects
we deal with is scheduling, and

26
00:01:30,810 --> 00:01:35,480
that's what we were doing in the last
episode, which was planning project, or

27
00:01:35,480 --> 00:01:38,890
planning our schedule really, and it was
part one, we got through some good stuff.

28
00:01:38,890 --> 00:01:41,050
Let me pull up the process list here.

29
00:01:41,050 --> 00:01:43,770
So basically we were in
the planning process group, and

30
00:01:43,770 --> 00:01:46,170
we were dealing with
project time management.

31
00:01:46,170 --> 00:01:51,710
We took a look at the schedule management
plan, defining our activities,

32
00:01:51,710 --> 00:01:55,520
sequencing our activities, and
estimating our activity resources.

33
00:01:55,520 --> 00:01:59,860
Now that last one we didn't spend
a ton of time on, because down here,

34
00:01:59,860 --> 00:02:02,390
we've got our human resource management,
so

35
00:02:02,390 --> 00:02:05,200
really, up here,
we're just thinking more like materials.

36
00:02:05,200 --> 00:02:08,730
And even then, with materials,
you focus a little more on cost.

37
00:02:08,730 --> 00:02:11,860
So that one kinda gets broken up
into the other two a little more.

38
00:02:11,860 --> 00:02:15,380
All right, but today, today we're

They don't think of
the other 45 processes.

They think of these two right here.

The project manager is building
a calendar, who does what, when.

48
00:02:44,460 --> 00:02:47,550
Well, that's kinda what we
tackle right here, all right?

49
00:02:47,550 --> 00:02:49,280
So these are a big deal.

50
00:02:49,280 --> 00:02:52,260
We created a list of activities yesterday,
right?

51
00:02:52,260 --> 00:02:54,690
So here's all the activities
our project needs.

00:02:54,690 --> 00:02:58,114
And then we sequence them,
what order do they need to follow, and

00:02:58,114 --> 00:03:01,619
what activities are dependent
on what other activities, right?

54
00:03:01,619 --> 00:03:04,588
Do we have finish to start relationships,
start to start relationships,

55
00:03:04,588 --> 00:03:05,775
all those different things.

56
00:03:05,775 --> 00:03:13,050
Now we need to go through and figure out

00:03:13,050 --> 00:03:15,410
So, when we start to do

00:03:15,410 --> 00:03:20,452

I'm using different software today.

I'm gonna try and rotate through

So I was using GanttProject yesterday,

This one is called ProjectLibre,

00:03:34,190 --> 00:03:36,840
it's another open source
project software out there.

00:03:36,840 --> 00:03:41,370

it's designed to be a little

00:03:44,960 --> 00:03:48,700
So it's got some more advanced features,

we had to move away from GanttProject.

00:03:50,430 --> 00:03:54,110
So, here I've got a bunch of

00:03:54,110 --> 00:03:57,480
it defaults to just one day for

00:03:57,480 --> 00:04:00,330

00:04:00,330 --> 00:04:03,120

00:04:03,120 --> 00:04:04,980
One day question mark.

00:04:04,980 --> 00:04:09,830
That means that it's an estimate, and

00:04:09,830 --> 00:04:13,400

until you tell it otherwise.

76
00:04:13,400 --> 00:04:15,800
So you can see down here where

77
00:04:15,800 --> 00:04:17,390

00:04:17,390 --> 00:04:21,530
These are ones where I told it,

00:04:21,530 --> 00:04:25,390
or it may still be an estimate but it's my

80
00:04:25,390 --> 00:04:27,550
So this is the number that
we're gonna work with.

81
00:04:27,550 --> 00:04:31,480
That's just a visual cue to let you

82
00:04:31,480 --> 00:04:35,110

83
00:04:35,110 --> 00:04:38,230
You'll also see that I've got

00:04:38,230 --> 00:04:41,582
Now why would I have one set to zero days?

A zero-day activity, or a zero-hour or

86
00:04:47,310 --> 00:04:51,380
some kind of tracking activity
most commonly a milestone.

87
00:04:51,380 --> 00:04:53,520
And so
you'll see I've got milestone one here and

00:04:53,520 --> 00:04:57,510

89
00:04:57,510 --> 00:04:59,940
PMI doesn't have an official icon for

90
00:04:59,940 --> 00:05:03,690
That's just what most
project software sticks with.

91
00:05:03,690 --> 00:05:07,050
Here, that computer example we
gave yesterday, we're going to

92
00:05:07,050 --> 00:05:11,300
receive 400 computers, we're gonna unbox
the computers, we're gonna set them up.

93
00:05:11,300 --> 00:05:14,190
When that's done, the hardware is ready.

94
00:05:14,190 --> 00:05:19,050
And so I created a milestone that

95
00:05:19,050 --> 00:05:20,540
our hardware will be ready.

96
00:05:20,540 --> 00:05:24,080
All right, do we hit that milestone or

97
00:05:24,080 --> 00:05:29,470
Do we not get there, right, where are we
at in terms of hitting that milestone?

98
00:05:29,470 --> 00:05:33,747
And we're gonna talk when we get
