99
00:05:33,747 --> 00:05:38,480
how we track our progress to see if
we're gonna hit that milestone, right?

100
00:05:38,480 --> 00:05:41,130
So we may create those, but
milestones are not really activities,

101
00:05:41,130 --> 00:05:42,280
they don't have a duration.

102
00:05:42,280 --> 00:05:43,970
They're just an event that occurs,

103
00:05:43,970 --> 00:05:46,300
we don't really have to do
anything as a part of that event.

104
00:05:47,392 --> 00:05:50,010
All right, so
as we start to map these things out,

105
00:05:50,010 --> 00:05:53,840
we may just be putting them all in as one
day when we're sequencing the event just

106
00:05:53,840 --> 00:05:55,610
trying to figure out the order.

107
00:05:55,610 --> 00:06:00,700
Now we need to come back and
add how long they're truly going to take.

108
00:06:00,700 --> 00:06:04,670
And we'll find there's a lot of factors
involved in determining that duration.

109
00:06:04,670 --> 00:06:08,935
So, PMI's made a nice little process for
us, which is not this.

110
00:06:08,935 --> 00:06:11,680
>> [LAUGH]
>> Which is this right here.

111
00:06:11,680 --> 00:06:14,100
Estimate Activity Durations.

112
00:06:14,100 --> 00:06:17,240
And this is just a collection
of tools that are available for

113
00:06:17,240 --> 00:06:23,340
us to use to go in and try and figure
out how long things are going to take.

114
00:06:23,340 --> 00:06:29,490
Now, to make good decisions you
need good information, right?

115
00:06:29,490 --> 00:06:31,942
You need as much
information as you can get.

116
00:06:31,942 --> 00:06:36,260
And it's from a book,
I can't remember what book it was,

117
00:06:36,260 --> 00:06:38,550
probably a Dune book
cuz I read those a lot.

118
00:06:38,550 --> 00:06:42,980
But it was from a book where they said
like, too much information never makes for

119
00:06:42,980 --> 00:06:44,450
easy decisions, right?

120
00:06:44,450 --> 00:06:49,280
So sometimes the more information you
have the harder it is to make a decision

121
00:06:49,280 --> 00:06:53,040
because you keep finding out things
that you just don't know enough about.

122
00:06:53,040 --> 00:06:55,600
So there are limits,
the information that we get.

123
00:06:55,600 --> 00:06:58,972
But when you look at this process the
first thing you'll probably notice is just

124
00:06:58,972 --> 00:07:00,951
the record setting amount of inputs,
right?

125
00:07:00,951 --> 00:07:02,831
When you go to estimate durations,

126
00:07:02,831 --> 00:07:05,595
you need information from
every source you can get.

127
00:07:05,595 --> 00:07:10,675
At a minimum you're going to
need your activity list, right?

128
00:07:10,675 --> 00:07:13,025
Because you need to know
what activities to plan for.

129
00:07:13,025 --> 00:07:16,240
And that activity list might be your
list that you created if you did

130
00:07:16,240 --> 00:07:17,360
the dedicated list.

131
00:07:17,360 --> 00:07:20,630
It might be your work breakdown
structure if you just did that.

132
00:07:20,630 --> 00:07:23,610
Or it might be that you've already fired
up your project management software and

133
00:07:23,610 --> 00:07:25,040
sequenced your activities there.

134
00:07:25,040 --> 00:07:26,430
So that's your list, right?

135
00:07:26,430 --> 00:07:27,160
But one way or

136
00:07:27,160 --> 00:07:30,830
another, you need a list of all the
activities that are going to occur, right?

137
00:07:30,830 --> 00:07:35,280
It's definitely a good idea to also
have activity resource requirements,

138
00:07:35,280 --> 00:07:39,900
because if I have three activities
that are occurring all in a row, and

139
00:07:39,900 --> 00:07:43,320
it's the same employee
attached to all activities, or

140
00:07:43,320 --> 00:07:45,880
all three of those,
they've gotta happen one after the other.

141
00:07:45,880 --> 00:07:48,530
I can't run them at the same time.

142
00:07:48,530 --> 00:07:51,480
I should have already figured that
out when we sequenced, but, if not,

143
00:07:51,480 --> 00:07:55,490
we can see it here, too, if we've got
our resource requirements, all right?

144
00:07:55,490 --> 00:07:58,210
Other things like resource calendars,
if I have that employee,

145
00:07:58,210 --> 00:07:59,560
when are they available?

146
00:07:59,560 --> 00:08:00,464
They have different schedules.

147
00:08:00,464 --> 00:08:02,751
Different people have different
schedules that we have to track.

148
00:08:02,751 --> 00:08:05,643
Our project scope statement,
which is kind of

149
00:08:05,643 --> 00:08:08,970
a higher level activity list
>> But the project scope statement is

150
00:08:08,970 --> 00:08:11,423
gonna specify things like
dates we need to be aware of.

151
00:08:11,423 --> 00:08:15,290
The project needs to be done by this date.

152
00:08:15,290 --> 00:08:16,760
When I'm calculating my durations and

153
00:08:16,760 --> 00:08:21,220
stuff, I always need to keep that scope
statement or the schedule specification in

154
00:08:21,220 --> 00:08:24,810
the scope statement,
in the front of my mind, all right.

155
00:08:24,810 --> 00:08:27,320
Our risk register,
which we haven't created yet

156
00:08:27,320 --> 00:08:30,260
because that's gonna show us
some of the risks we have and

157
00:08:30,260 --> 00:08:33,510
the mitigations, what we can do
if there's a failure, right?

158
00:08:33,510 --> 00:08:39,600
So, if I'm planning an outdoor
rock concert and it rains,

159
00:08:39,600 --> 00:08:43,180
we may have to postpone that rock concert
and put it on again a month later.

160
00:08:43,180 --> 00:08:44,300
Well what's that going
to do to my schedule?

161
00:08:44,300 --> 00:08:46,220
It's going to blow it out of the water,
right?

162
00:08:46,220 --> 00:08:47,900
But if I've got it in
the risk register and

163
00:08:47,900 --> 00:08:51,180
I see that,
I can work that into my schedule.

164
00:08:51,180 --> 00:08:54,660
And now it's an expected value and it's
not gonna ruin my project if it rains.

165
00:08:54,660 --> 00:08:55,360
We plan for that.

166
00:08:55,360 --> 00:08:57,060
If it rains, we go back a month.

167
00:08:57,060 --> 00:08:58,460
That's just how it is, right.

168
00:08:58,460 --> 00:09:00,220
And it becomes part of the process.

169
00:09:01,630 --> 00:09:05,410
The resource breakdown structure,
we may or may not have created this, but

170
00:09:05,410 --> 00:09:07,860
just like the work breakdown
structures listing the people and

171
00:09:07,860 --> 00:09:11,120
what activities are attached to them and
then our favorites, right.

172
00:09:11,120 --> 00:09:14,570
Enterprise environmental factors and
organizational process assets.

173
00:09:14,570 --> 00:09:18,050
So this is really anything
that relates to activities

174
00:09:18,050 --> 00:09:20,160
that are gonna happen
as part of our project.

175
00:09:21,500 --> 00:09:25,552
Alright now we take that data and
we sift it through a number of techniques.

176
00:09:25,552 --> 00:09:29,920
We're gonna see expert judgment because
that one's pretty much always there right.

177
00:09:29,920 --> 00:09:34,300
Use your noodle, use your brain and
make sure you make good decisions.

178
00:09:34,300 --> 00:09:36,560
But the other ones that are on here,

179
00:09:36,560 --> 00:09:41,400
these are estimation techniques,
and we're gonna see them here for

180
00:09:41,400 --> 00:09:45,930
estimating duration, but we're gonna
see them again for estimating cost.

181
00:09:45,930 --> 00:09:47,480
It's the same technique, right?

182
00:09:47,480 --> 00:09:49,120
Estimating is estimating.

183
00:09:49,120 --> 00:09:51,190
So you pretty much have the same methods.

184
00:09:51,190 --> 00:09:53,790
It's just the data you work with
that's different and that's it.

185
00:09:53,790 --> 00:09:56,930
So this is very similar to what
we're gonna have with cost.

186
00:09:58,550 --> 00:10:02,050
All right,
the first one is probably the easiest and

187
00:10:02,050 --> 00:10:04,740
it's called analogous estimating, right.

188
00:10:04,740 --> 00:10:06,070
It's one of my favorites.

189
00:10:06,070 --> 00:10:10,640
If you're about to build a house and
it's 2400 square feet, right.

190
00:10:10,640 --> 00:10:14,150
You can go out and
maybe within your company or

191
00:10:14,150 --> 00:10:16,250
within other companies and find.

192
00:10:16,250 --> 00:10:20,540
Someone else who just finished building
a 2400 square foot house with the same

193
00:10:20,540 --> 00:10:23,670
plans, how long did it take them, right.

194
00:10:23,670 --> 00:10:26,510
There you go,
use their numbers as your numbers.

195
00:10:26,510 --> 00:10:31,070
You can find another project or somebody
whose done the same work that you're about

196
00:10:31,070 --> 00:10:34,100
to set out to do and use their number.

197
00:10:34,100 --> 00:10:36,100
It's kind, it's almost cheating, right?

198
00:10:36,100 --> 00:10:37,660
>> [LAUGH]
>> But they've already been through it.

199
00:10:37,660 --> 00:10:41,040
They went through it in real life,
you haven't necessarily at this point.

200
00:10:41,040 --> 00:10:42,250
So you're using their data.

201
00:10:42,250 --> 00:10:45,340
It can be really handy
as far as shaving down

202
00:10:45,340 --> 00:10:47,120
the amount of time it
takes us to estimate.

203
00:10:47,120 --> 00:10:50,250
They're not even really estimates anymore,
now it's based on factual data.

204
00:10:50,250 --> 00:10:54,030
This is how long it took them, that's
probably how long it will take us right.

205
00:10:54,030 --> 00:10:59,940
So analogous estimating is great unless
you're doing something brand new.

206
00:10:59,940 --> 00:11:04,410
If nobody else has done it well it's
pretty hard to use their numbers.

207
00:11:05,730 --> 00:11:08,850
All right, so
that is analogous estimating.

208
00:11:08,850 --> 00:11:10,020
It's my favorite.

209
00:11:10,020 --> 00:11:14,530
It takes the least amount of time and it's
the most reliable so it really is like

210
00:11:14,530 --> 00:11:19,310
the Holy Grail of estimating techniques,
if it's available, all right.

211
00:11:19,310 --> 00:11:24,750
If it's not available, then we go to all
these other ones that are listed here.

212
00:11:24,750 --> 00:11:25,930
Well, except reserve analysis.

213
00:11:25,930 --> 00:11:27,640
That one's always there.

214
00:11:27,640 --> 00:11:30,260
So the next one is parametric, all right.

215
00:11:30,260 --> 00:11:34,230
Now, parametric estimating,
it sounds like something complex, but

216
00:11:34,230 --> 00:11:36,290
it's really not that big of a deal,
and that is,

217
00:11:36,290 --> 00:11:41,300
you effectively hire somebody
to figure it out for you, right.

218
00:11:41,300 --> 00:11:44,900
And by hiring somebody I mean,
you might have software,

219
00:11:44,900 --> 00:11:47,130
estimation software that
does the estimate for you.

220
00:11:47,130 --> 00:11:50,860
You might use somebody like, I think I
mentioned the Gardner Group in an episode.

221
00:11:50,860 --> 00:11:54,690
So you might have them where they
have other projects they look at and

222
00:11:54,690 --> 00:11:56,470
information they know from the market.

223
00:11:56,470 --> 00:12:01,340
And they look at your data, right,
the parameters of your project and

224
00:12:01,340 --> 00:12:03,110
they calculate out what they
think it's gonna take and

225
00:12:03,110 --> 00:12:04,770
they tell you that estimation data.

226
00:12:04,770 --> 00:12:09,840
So, parametric is really just where
we rely on some sort of external data

227
00:12:09,840 --> 00:12:11,770
to come up with our estimate.

228
00:12:11,770 --> 00:12:14,860
And you see this most often
with estimation software.

229
00:12:14,860 --> 00:12:16,960
Every good construction company.

230
00:12:16,960 --> 00:12:20,070
Uses estimation software,
cuz every project they do,

231
00:12:20,070 --> 00:12:22,210
every building is a little bit different.

232
00:12:22,210 --> 00:12:26,500
If you're building a 20 story office
building, or you're building a 25 story

233
00:12:26,500 --> 00:12:31,235
office building, it's not that
it's just 20% more construction.

234
00:12:31,235 --> 00:12:34,845
It's different things, different
materials, different weight loads, and so

235
00:12:34,845 --> 00:12:37,315
you need software to be
able to manage that.

236
00:12:37,315 --> 00:12:39,895
>> Yeah,
the nice thing about the idea of this is,

237
00:12:39,895 --> 00:12:42,035
we provide whatever we're asked of, right.

238
00:12:42,035 --> 00:12:44,050
So, we hire a consulting group, they say,

239
00:12:44,050 --> 00:12:46,260
all right, what are the parameters
that we need to work with?

240
00:12:46,260 --> 00:12:49,420
And then they figure it all out and
then we get the results back.

241
00:12:49,420 --> 00:12:51,850
So it really does work out for us,
especially if we're doing that.

242
00:12:51,850 --> 00:12:55,410
And that's what all that type
of software really does for us.

243
00:12:55,410 --> 00:12:58,290
We just have to know what
it is we really want.

244
00:12:58,290 --> 00:12:59,680
>> Yeah.

245
00:12:59,680 --> 00:13:02,400
All right, now,
what if we are doing something so

246
00:13:02,400 --> 00:13:06,110
new that there's nobody out there
with estimation software for this.

247
00:13:06,110 --> 00:13:11,110
Our business is such a niche business
that nobody else is doing this, and

248
00:13:11,110 --> 00:13:14,120
so there's no historical stuff for
us to do analogous estimating.

249
00:13:14,120 --> 00:13:17,690
There's no companies out there doing
the estimates for us to do parametric.

250
00:13:17,690 --> 00:13:19,880
So we're kinda left to our own, all right?

251
00:13:19,880 --> 00:13:23,340
Well, there's a neat,
simple principle that we can use,

252
00:13:23,340 --> 00:13:25,745
called three-point estimating, all right?

253
00:13:25,745 --> 00:13:29,040
Three-point estimating is
the last of the mathematically

254
00:13:29,040 --> 00:13:30,988
sound ones that we have before
we start shooting in the dark.

255
00:13:30,988 --> 00:13:32,068
[LAUGH]
>> But

256
00:13:32,068 --> 00:13:36,790
three-point estimating is kind of a neat
little formula, and it comes in two forms,

257
00:13:36,790 --> 00:13:37,970
but they work on the same principle.

258
00:13:37,970 --> 00:13:42,090
Let me bring up my notes screen here.

259
00:13:42,090 --> 00:13:45,320
We'll just do it like a blank note for
now, all right.

260
00:13:45,320 --> 00:13:50,000
So I wanna talk about three-point
estimates, all right.

261
00:13:50,000 --> 00:13:53,970
Basically, what you do,
is you get three people

262
00:13:53,970 --> 00:13:58,360
to come up with their best guess for
how long something is gonna take.

263
00:13:58,360 --> 00:14:01,680
So you go to your subject matter expert,
if you've got one on staff.

264
00:14:01,680 --> 00:14:05,390
Or maybe it's a web development project
and you have three web developers and so

265
00:14:05,390 --> 00:14:07,290
you get opinions from each of them.

266
00:14:07,290 --> 00:14:09,990
Or if it's outside,
you're hiring contractors, you get.

267
00:14:09,990 --> 00:14:12,200
Quotes from three different contractors.

268
00:14:12,200 --> 00:14:14,980
Get three opinions at a minimum, right.

269
00:14:14,980 --> 00:14:18,130
You can get more, but
at a minimum get three.

270
00:14:18,130 --> 00:14:22,140
And you're gonna classify
the three like this,

271
00:14:22,140 --> 00:14:27,280
I'll use the official ones,
you have the most likely.

272
00:14:28,470 --> 00:14:34,440
You have the most optimistic and

273
00:14:34,440 --> 00:14:40,260
you have the most pessimistic,
which is spelled wrong, there, okay.

274
00:14:40,260 --> 00:14:44,600
So when you go to somebody, you say,
all right web developer number one,

275
00:14:44,600 --> 00:14:49,580
what do you think is the best case
scenario, worst case scenario?

276
00:14:49,580 --> 00:14:53,120
And the most likely amount of
time that this is gonna take.

277
00:14:53,120 --> 00:14:58,640
And I do this in networking all the time,
is I say okay, we're gonna be installing

278
00:14:58,640 --> 00:15:03,990
some MPOS lines between five cities and we
need to get that networked out, all right.

279
00:15:03,990 --> 00:15:08,930
If the ISPs have done their job and
I walk into that building,

280
00:15:08,930 --> 00:15:13,590
and the MPLS lines are in place, and all
I've gotta do is configure the routers,

281
00:15:13,590 --> 00:15:16,640
I can have that job done in one day, easy.

282
00:15:16,640 --> 00:15:22,760
So, my most optimistic would be one day,
okay.

283
00:15:22,760 --> 00:15:29,520
But if the ISP screwed up and they didn't
even put the order in and the MPLS

284
00:15:29,520 --> 00:15:34,720
line isn't deposited I know that it
takes 60 days to get a MPLS sign put in.

285
00:15:34,720 --> 00:15:39,630
And so at a most pessimistic
it could take 61 days.

286
00:15:39,630 --> 00:15:44,290
So I recognize that it wasn't installed,
I put in a new order,

287
00:15:44,290 --> 00:15:47,580
wait 60 days and then I go out and
there's the one day of work that I can do.

288
00:15:47,580 --> 00:15:51,800
That would be the worst case scenario,
they completely drop the ball, all right.

289
00:15:51,800 --> 00:15:56,704
But more likely, all the orders will go
in, I'll get down there, and maybe one or

290
00:15:56,704 --> 00:15:59,635
two of the cities just
aren't connected right.

291
00:15:59,635 --> 00:16:03,314
And so, I've gotta do a help desk ticket,
I gotta reach out and

292
00:16:03,314 --> 00:16:07,843
kinda do some troubleshooting, and so
maybe- Four days is the most likely.

293
00:16:07,843 --> 00:16:12,095
I say, it'd probably be one day of work,
but give me a couple of extra days to

294
00:16:12,095 --> 00:16:16,930
deal with support tickets and stuff just
to get it all squared away and in place.

295
00:16:16,930 --> 00:16:20,820
And maybe there might be
an option where I have to go to

296
00:16:20,820 --> 00:16:23,180
one of the other cities to fix it so
I need some flight time.

297
00:16:23,180 --> 00:16:26,040
So let's just say four
days as the most likely.

298
00:16:26,040 --> 00:16:26,710
All right.

299
00:16:26,710 --> 00:16:30,060
So, here's my three quotes for
how long this is gonna take.

300
00:16:30,060 --> 00:16:32,860
My most optimistic would be one day.

301
00:16:32,860 --> 00:16:34,530
My most likely is four days.

302
00:16:34,530 --> 00:16:37,760
My most pessimistic is 61 days, all right?

303
00:16:37,760 --> 00:16:42,970
We can then feed this into a formula and
if I get quotes from more than one person,

304
00:16:42,970 --> 00:16:46,790
I take their most likely and I average
them, I take their most optimistic and

305
00:16:46,790 --> 00:16:50,590
average them and their most
pessimistic and average them and

306
00:16:50,590 --> 00:16:52,930
I like to get estimates from three people,
minimum.

307
00:16:52,930 --> 00:16:55,680
That's something I learned in
statistics a long time ago.

308
00:16:55,680 --> 00:16:58,670
And so
you may want to get multiple quotes.

309
00:16:58,670 --> 00:17:00,260
If you've got multiple people.

310
00:17:00,260 --> 00:17:06,210
But if I'm the only tech available to do
it, then you'll just take what I say.

311
00:17:06,210 --> 00:17:09,130
And then we take this and
we feed it through one or two formulas.

312
00:17:09,130 --> 00:17:11,290
The two formulas work like this,

313
00:17:11,290 --> 00:17:20,220
there is the Triangular Distribution and

314
00:17:20,220 --> 00:17:23,890
there is the Beta Distribution
which is the more common.

315
00:17:25,580 --> 00:17:32,230
And what they do is they take most likely,
which is abbreviated tM,

316
00:17:32,230 --> 00:17:36,900
most optimistic, which is tO, and

317
00:17:36,900 --> 00:17:40,180
most pessimistic, is tP.

318
00:17:40,180 --> 00:17:44,020
There T for time, and

319
00:17:44,020 --> 00:17:48,000
then you've got your,
actually, is most likely M?

320
00:17:48,000 --> 00:17:48,500
It is, okay.

321
00:17:48,500 --> 00:17:53,010
All right, and so you have M, O,
and P for these other ones, right?

322
00:17:53,010 --> 00:17:56,480
And we run them through a simple formula.

323
00:17:56,480 --> 00:18:01,870
With a Triangular Distribution,
we really just end up averaging the three.

324
00:18:01,870 --> 00:18:09,676
So the way the formula works is like this,

325
00:18:09,676 --> 00:18:15,955
we say tM + tO + tP divided/3.

326
00:18:15,955 --> 00:18:17,040
Okay.

327
00:18:17,040 --> 00:18:19,880
So we add the three values and
then we divide them by three.

328
00:18:19,880 --> 00:18:20,810
That's just averaging right?

329
00:18:20,810 --> 00:18:22,220
>> Yeah.
When you take an average,

330
00:18:22,220 --> 00:18:25,510
you add the numbers together and you
take however many numbers there were and

331
00:18:25,510 --> 00:18:27,080
divide it by that number.

332
00:18:27,080 --> 00:18:28,030
That's an average.

333
00:18:28,030 --> 00:18:32,090
So this is gonna give
us a average estimate.

334
00:18:32,090 --> 00:18:35,950
And in our scenario this would be 4 days

335
00:18:39,140 --> 00:18:43,970
plus 1 day plus 61 days.

336
00:18:43,970 --> 00:18:46,670
Divided by three which is gonna
equal something that I can't

337
00:18:46,670 --> 00:18:47,700
figure out in my head.

338
00:18:47,700 --> 00:18:50,820
So let's fire up our calculator.

339
00:18:50,820 --> 00:18:56,820
And we'll say 4+1+61 and
then we'll divide that by three.

340
00:18:56,820 --> 00:19:01,569
So 22 days will be the result of this
if we do a triangular distribution.

341
00:19:01,569 --> 00:19:02,100
Right?

342
00:19:02,100 --> 00:19:05,880
The problem with doing
a triangular distribution

343
00:19:05,880 --> 00:19:08,360
is it doesn't handle outliers very well.

344
00:19:08,360 --> 00:19:09,540
All right.

345
00:19:09,540 --> 00:19:13,270
And you'll see here one day,
four day, 61 days.

346
00:19:13,270 --> 00:19:17,570
That's so far out there that
it's skewing this pretty bad.

347
00:19:17,570 --> 00:19:22,470
When my most likely is four days,
but I planned for

348
00:19:22,470 --> 00:19:25,060
22, that's pretty big
overkill right there.

349
00:19:25,060 --> 00:19:27,200
So that's the problem with
the triangular distribution,

350
00:19:27,200 --> 00:19:29,460
it doesn't handle it very well.

351
00:19:29,460 --> 00:19:35,155
So instead with a beta distribution,
we modify it a little bit, okay?

352
00:19:35,155 --> 00:19:39,175
What we do is we basically add
a weight to the most likely.

353
00:19:39,175 --> 00:19:42,095
We make the most likely more important.

354
00:19:42,095 --> 00:19:45,345
And we do that by multiplying it by four.

355
00:19:45,345 --> 00:19:48,215
And you'll see the formula
written two different ways.

356
00:19:48,215 --> 00:19:51,585
You'll see it written this way,
which is, here, I'll just take this one.

357
00:19:53,150 --> 00:19:54,492
And do a little copy and paste action.

358
00:19:54,492 --> 00:19:55,190
All right.

359
00:19:55,190 --> 00:19:58,250
So we take that most likely and

360
00:19:58,250 --> 00:20:00,850
you can write it out,
actually I usually see it this way.

361
00:20:00,850 --> 00:20:07,216
Where you've got
the optimistic plus the most

362
00:20:07,216 --> 00:20:11,910
likely and
then we just do that four times.

363
00:20:11,910 --> 00:20:14,700
We come in here and say,
one, two, three, four.

364
00:20:14,700 --> 00:20:17,560
And then we divide the whole thing by six.

365
00:20:17,560 --> 00:20:22,090
So, the optimistic is counted once,
the pessimistic is counted once, and

366
00:20:22,090 --> 00:20:24,850
the most likely is counted four times.

367
00:20:24,850 --> 00:20:30,567
And a simpler way to write that,
is to just take these and

368
00:20:30,567 --> 00:20:37,787
make it four times The most likely,
and I could

369
00:20:37,787 --> 00:20:42,700
do more parentheses, I guess, but order
of operations would be correct there.

370
00:20:42,700 --> 00:20:48,250
So, the optimistic plus 4 times the most
likely, plus the pessimistic divided by 6.

371
00:20:48,250 --> 00:20:50,540
It's the same formula,
just different way of writing it.

372
00:20:50,540 --> 00:20:53,546
All right, so for

373
00:20:53,546 --> 00:20:59,560
us it would be 4 is the most likely so

374
00:20:59,560 --> 00:21:04,772
it would be 1 + 4 x 4 + 61,

375
00:21:04,772 --> 00:21:07,990
all divided by 6.

376
00:21:07,990 --> 00:21:13,270
And in this scenario,
that is going to equal what?

377
00:21:14,610 --> 00:21:18,522
So let's get back to our calculator.

378
00:21:18,522 --> 00:21:24,510
All right, so it's 1 plus 16 plus
61 divided by 6 which is 13.

379
00:21:24,510 --> 00:21:29,760
And what you'll see here
is we use the same numbers.

380
00:21:29,760 --> 00:21:35,100
But because we gave more weight,
more value to the most likely number,

381
00:21:35,100 --> 00:21:40,950
the most likely estimate, it's brought our
number down from 22 days down to 13 days.

382
00:21:40,950 --> 00:21:45,310
And most people find that this is
a much more accurate number, right?

383
00:21:45,310 --> 00:21:50,700
That going 13 days,
it's still overkill in most scenarios,

384
00:21:50,700 --> 00:21:52,660
but at least it's only
overkill by nine days.

385
00:21:52,660 --> 00:21:53,820
If the most likely occurs,

386
00:21:53,820 --> 00:21:59,220
we're only over by nine days here
versus up here we're over by 18 days.

387
00:21:59,220 --> 00:22:03,140
So almost twice, exactly twice
the amount of time for our overage.

388
00:22:03,140 --> 00:22:06,350
So it is a little more accurate
to go with the beta distribution.

389
00:22:06,350 --> 00:22:10,030
And so you'll see most people refer
to this method right here, and

390
00:22:10,030 --> 00:22:12,230
it's usually the one that
makes it on the exam.

391
00:22:12,230 --> 00:22:16,210
But the triangular distribution
is the rawest form of this.

392
00:22:16,210 --> 00:22:21,020
These are all called three point estimates
because we've got three points right here.

393
00:22:21,020 --> 00:22:24,890
Most likely, most optimistic,
most pessimistic, all right.

394
00:22:24,890 --> 00:22:29,950
And you can remember this simple mnemonic
is MOP so those are the three points.

395
00:22:29,950 --> 00:22:31,790
And then we just run them
through a simple average.

396
00:22:33,250 --> 00:22:34,240
All right.
So,

397
00:22:34,240 --> 00:22:37,290
this is good if we're doing
something all new, right.

398
00:22:37,290 --> 00:22:38,850
There's just so many unknowns.

399
00:22:38,850 --> 00:22:40,960
That you gotta work with
the information that you have.

400
00:22:40,960 --> 00:22:47,010
So you get that best case scenario, worst
case scenario and the likely estimate.

401
00:22:47,010 --> 00:22:48,730
Now there are some people who say,
you know what?

402
00:22:48,730 --> 00:22:50,320
Let's just go with the likely.

403
00:22:50,320 --> 00:22:54,080
And if there's going to be an overage,
maybe we can plan for

404
00:22:54,080 --> 00:22:55,390
that in our schedule reserve.

405
00:22:55,390 --> 00:22:57,540
And so we'll talk about
that here in a little bit.

406
00:22:57,540 --> 00:23:01,390
But you can go that route, remember it's
entirely up to you on your estimates

407
00:23:01,390 --> 00:23:06,340
because even if I go 13 days,
my most pessimistic is 61.

408
00:23:06,340 --> 00:23:10,130
I could still end up going 61 days so
I'm still gonna be way over.

409
00:23:10,130 --> 00:23:13,630
So, it may not make a difference for
me if I go four days versus 13.

410
00:23:13,630 --> 00:23:16,230
So we always need to evaluate
that as we go with the estimate.

411
00:23:16,230 --> 00:23:18,190
But that is a three point estimate.

412
00:23:20,460 --> 00:23:21,130
All right.

413
00:23:21,130 --> 00:23:25,950
Let me take that and move that inside
of our show notes for this one.

414
00:23:27,070 --> 00:23:28,850
So let's see.
We've got our three point estimates

415
00:23:28,850 --> 00:23:29,980
here, so.

416
00:23:29,980 --> 00:23:32,410
Yes, we've got those various values,
triangular, beta,

417
00:23:32,410 --> 00:23:36,330
and, I'm just going to throw
it in here as a example.

418
00:23:36,330 --> 00:23:40,544
No, wait it's in the notes

419
00:23:47,739 --> 00:23:54,810
All right, okay, so
those are some easy to use tools, right.

420
00:23:54,810 --> 00:23:57,390
Now, there are some other
things that we can use and

421
00:23:57,390 --> 00:24:00,080
it kinda comes down to desperation, right.

422
00:24:00,080 --> 00:24:03,138
If we get to a point where we
just don't have good data, right,

423
00:24:03,138 --> 00:24:04,479
you gotta make a decision.

424
00:24:04,479 --> 00:24:06,266
You have to make a decision and
move forward.

425
00:24:06,266 --> 00:24:09,121
You can't just sit there and
wait for new data to come out.

426
00:24:09,121 --> 00:24:12,378
And so that's where we get our group
Decision making techniques and

427
00:24:12,378 --> 00:24:14,160
we've already talked about these.

428
00:24:14,160 --> 00:24:15,670
>> Yeah.

429
00:24:15,670 --> 00:24:16,410
>> You just get everybody together.

430
00:24:16,410 --> 00:24:21,330
And you come up with the best information
that you can and you make a decision.

431
00:24:21,330 --> 00:24:23,850
And document how you made that decision,

432
00:24:23,850 --> 00:24:26,610
because if it's completely
wrong down the road.

433
00:24:26,610 --> 00:24:29,400
You can say look,
we were breaking new ground here.

434
00:24:29,400 --> 00:24:31,910
Nobody knew,
we didn't have anything to act on.

435
00:24:31,910 --> 00:24:34,450
We did the best we could with
the information that we had.

436
00:24:36,302 --> 00:24:41,900
All right, so that is pretty important
there as far as the group decision making.

437
00:24:41,900 --> 00:24:44,460
Now I mentioned reserve analysis.

438
00:24:44,460 --> 00:24:47,010
Reserve analysis is a really tricky one,

439
00:24:47,010 --> 00:24:52,280
because it can be a violation
of ethics in some cases.

440
00:24:52,280 --> 00:24:55,330
I always think of Star Trek, right?

441
00:24:55,330 --> 00:24:58,100
I think it's Star Trek anyway,
I'm not a Trekkie.

442
00:24:58,100 --> 00:25:01,650
But in the original series,
you had Scottie, and

443
00:25:01,650 --> 00:25:04,890
the captain would call down and
say Scottie, I need warp nine!

444
00:25:04,890 --> 00:25:06,910
And Scottie would say,
I'm giving her all she's got!

445
00:25:06,910 --> 00:25:08,740
And the captain would say,
come on, I need it.

446
00:25:08,740 --> 00:25:10,290
How soon can you have it?

447
00:25:10,290 --> 00:25:13,050
And Scotty would say, give me three hours.

448
00:25:13,050 --> 00:25:15,693
And then Captain Kirk would say,
you've got one, right.

449
00:25:15,693 --> 00:25:19,060
>> [LAUGH]
>> So Scotty kind of like built it into

450
00:25:19,060 --> 00:25:23,600
his mind over time that hey,
I always need to say a higher number,

451
00:25:23,600 --> 00:25:26,320
knowing the captain is
going to cut it down.

452
00:25:26,320 --> 00:25:30,115
Or if we have the same
thing in the tech world,

453
00:25:30,115 --> 00:25:31,570
>> [LAUGH]

454
00:25:31,570 --> 00:25:33,980
>> under promise, over deliver.

455
00:25:33,980 --> 00:25:37,700
If you promise three days and
come in at one you look like the hero.

456
00:25:37,700 --> 00:25:42,250
If you promise one day and you come in at
one day well, you did your job, right?

457
00:25:42,250 --> 00:25:44,380
So a lot of people will do that.

458
00:25:44,380 --> 00:25:46,790
They will artificially pad their estimate.

459
00:25:46,790 --> 00:25:47,590
That's what it's called.

460
00:25:47,590 --> 00:25:50,510
That's what it will be called in
the exam is padding your estimate.

461
00:25:50,510 --> 00:25:55,730
And padding your estimate is
forbidden in the code of ethics.

462
00:25:55,730 --> 00:26:02,040
You should not pad your estimate without
clearly designating it as reserve.

463
00:26:02,040 --> 00:26:02,630
All right.

464
00:26:02,630 --> 00:26:07,540
In other words, if I've got
a three-day activity on the calendar,

465
00:26:07,540 --> 00:26:09,560
it needs to take three days.

466
00:26:09,560 --> 00:26:14,160
And if we agree that reserve needs to
happen, maybe I decide there needs to be

467
00:26:14,160 --> 00:26:16,970
two days of reserve afterwards
in case it runs late,

468
00:26:16,970 --> 00:26:21,870
I need to put it on my schedule as
a three day activity and then two days of

469
00:26:21,870 --> 00:26:26,770
reserve clearly marked on the schedule so
that everybody knows there is reserve.

470
00:26:26,770 --> 00:26:30,610
If it's a three day activity and
we put it in there for five, we're lying.

471
00:26:30,610 --> 00:26:31,150
>> Yeah.
>> All right?

472
00:26:31,150 --> 00:26:32,860
We are not telling the truth.

473
00:26:32,860 --> 00:26:36,600
It is not a five day activity, and this is
one of the biggest challenges we have as

474
00:26:36,600 --> 00:26:38,900
a project manager is, we understand that.

475
00:26:38,900 --> 00:26:41,170
We understand that reserve
is a necessary thing.

476
00:26:41,170 --> 00:26:42,930
We just need to be open about it, but

477
00:26:42,930 --> 00:26:46,930
the people doing the work on your
project probably don't know that.

478
00:26:46,930 --> 00:26:49,070
And especially if you're
dealing with contractors,

479
00:26:49,070 --> 00:26:52,530
they almost always pad their values.

480
00:26:52,530 --> 00:26:57,160
And so I make it a habit when I
bring in a contractor, is to be very

481
00:26:57,160 --> 00:27:02,310
up front at the beginning and say look I
understand that these ties are not exact.

482
00:27:02,310 --> 00:27:04,100
I understand that things happen,

483
00:27:04,100 --> 00:27:06,010
and things don't always go
the way we want them to.

484
00:27:06,010 --> 00:27:10,280
I understand that and I understand
that you need reserve time in case.

485
00:27:10,280 --> 00:27:12,860
The only thing I ask is that
you're upfront about it.

486
00:27:12,860 --> 00:27:14,970
That you tell me what
that reserve time is.

487
00:27:14,970 --> 00:27:19,050
You tell me you should have it done in
three, but we're going to do five days.

488
00:27:19,050 --> 00:27:22,000
We're going to do two extra days just for
reserve, just in case.

489
00:27:22,000 --> 00:27:24,480
If they're upfront with me,
I'm okay with it.

490
00:27:24,480 --> 00:27:28,330
I can plan around it, and
now my stuff is accurate.

491
00:27:28,330 --> 00:27:31,170
If they tell me that, what I do is
I look around at my calendar and

492
00:27:31,170 --> 00:27:34,640
I say you know what,
let me do some contingencies here, right?

493
00:27:34,640 --> 00:27:37,210
Contingency planning is what
this is really all about.

494
00:27:37,210 --> 00:27:41,510
If I have task five and it's scheduled for

five days, then task six would

In my head it's great.

Let me diagram this so

So, here let's just say

00:27:58,840 --> 00:28:02,870
I reach out to my contractors, they

00:28:02,870 --> 00:28:04,260
So it's a five day.

501
00:28:04,260 --> 00:28:06,811
Whoops.
Oh stop.

00:28:12,456 --> 00:28:15,430
There we go.
All right, so it is a five day task right?

00:28:15,430 --> 00:28:20,490
It's actually a three day task, but they

00:28:20,490 --> 00:28:24,640
So for whatever reason it doesn't

00:28:24,640 --> 00:28:25,520
Whoops.

506
00:28:25,520 --> 00:28:26,160
Little crazy.

00:28:26,160 --> 00:28:28,700
All right, there, so five days and

00:28:30,330 --> 00:28:30,930
All right.

00:28:30,930 --> 00:28:35,773
So they tell me it's going to be five days

00:28:35,773 --> 00:28:41,020
And Task 6 is another five day

00:28:41,020 --> 00:28:45,280
activity and
it's going to be linked to Task 5.

00:28:45,280 --> 00:28:48,340
So I'm just going to come in here and

00:28:48,340 --> 00:28:50,230
Like that, one after the other.

00:28:50,230 --> 00:28:53,630
So, task five happens,
it's five days, task six happens.

00:28:53,630 --> 00:28:54,810
Now, in reality,

00:28:54,810 --> 00:29:00,010
Task 5 has two days of reserve in it,

00:29:00,010 --> 00:29:03,670
So then they get to work and

00:29:03,670 --> 00:29:05,270
They finish in three days.

00:29:05,270 --> 00:29:09,000
Well, I don't have Task 6

So what happens Thursday and Friday?

00:29:10,690 --> 00:29:11,440

00:29:11,440 --> 00:29:12,870
We sit and we do nothing, right.

00:29:12,870 --> 00:29:16,650
We don't move forward because
those guys are done and

00:29:16,650 --> 00:29:20,620

00:29:20,620 --> 00:29:25,460
But if I knew that they were going to be

00:29:25,460 --> 00:29:32,140

00:29:32,140 --> 00:29:39,905
I could've inserted a Task 5 reserve,

00:29:39,905 --> 00:29:43,545
In as a two day activity, all right?

00:29:43,545 --> 00:29:46,115
And let me just update

00:29:46,115 --> 00:29:47,175
So this one's going to depend on 19.

00:29:47,175 --> 00:29:48,615
This one's going to depend on 20.

00:29:48,615 --> 00:29:52,535
There, okay and
now I have the same thing, right?

00:29:52,535 --> 00:29:59,410
I've got the three day activity, followed

00:29:59,410 --> 00:30:00,375
My calendar's no different.

00:30:00,375 --> 00:30:01,470
Okay.

00:30:01,470 --> 00:30:04,540
But looking at this as a product
manager I can say you know what,

00:30:04,540 --> 00:30:09,490
let me reach out to these guys and say,
hey you guys you got a five day activity.

00:30:09,490 --> 00:30:12,550
If this contractor finishes by Wednesday,

00:30:12,550 --> 00:30:15,360

00:30:15,360 --> 00:30:18,810
And they can start looking at their

541
00:30:18,810 --> 00:30:22,190
Or we've got three people assigned to it.

00:30:22,190 --> 00:30:24,520
One of them is available on Thursday and

543
00:30:24,520 --> 00:30:27,090
So if you can get in there early,
they can get a head start and

544
00:30:27,090 --> 00:30:32,340
that'll increase the odds of this activity
finishing early, finishing on schedule.

545
00:30:32,340 --> 00:30:36,290
And you can start to gain time that'll
help you out later in your project.

546
00:30:36,290 --> 00:30:41,050
You can make those decisions if you

547
00:30:42,520 --> 00:30:47,325
So, as a project manager,
if you're a PMI member,

00:30:47,325 --> 00:30:51,435
you're required to designate

00:30:51,435 --> 00:30:54,055
And depending on your
project manager software,

00:30:54,055 --> 00:30:57,295
a lot of times I will come in here and

00:30:57,295 --> 00:31:02,189
the bar style to make this one look a

00:31:04,320 --> 00:31:08,040
an activity that needs work,
yeah, so you can do that.

553
00:31:09,070 --> 00:31:11,850
But you wanna clearly denote it.

554
00:31:11,850 --> 00:31:14,650
And if you're acting on
information from your contractors,

00:31:14,650 --> 00:31:16,710
you've gotta make sure that they tell you.

556
00:31:16,710 --> 00:31:18,640
But if you don't ask,
they're not gonna tell you.

00:31:18,640 --> 00:31:19,980
They're not gonna say oh yeah, yeah.

00:31:19,980 --> 00:31:21,080
We cooked those numbers.

00:31:21,080 --> 00:31:22,360
We added a few extra days.

560
00:31:22,360 --> 00:31:24,720
Right, because they'll do that.

561
00:31:24,720 --> 00:31:27,490
They'll cook the dates,
they'll cook the budge.

00:31:27,490 --> 00:31:30,060
They're just used to that

00:31:31,150 --> 00:31:32,140
I'm OK with that.

00:31:32,140 --> 00:31:33,920
I fully understand safety nets.

00:31:33,920 --> 00:31:35,190
I use them myself.

566
00:31:35,190 --> 00:31:38,530
But I'm very clear about it,
we wanna have that on the schedule.

567
00:31:40,120 --> 00:31:42,670
All right, so
keep that in mind as reserve.

568
00:31:42,670 --> 00:31:47,190
And so this last technique here,
reserve analysis, that just means we

569
00:31:47,190 --> 00:31:51,750
need to look at our activities and
determine where we need some reserve time.

570
00:31:51,750 --> 00:31:53,660
And we're gonna talk about reserve cost or

571
00:31:53,660 --> 00:31:57,290
money later but
reserve time where we need that.

572
00:31:57,290 --> 00:32:00,774
And if we can allocate, or
if we can assign it now and track it,

573
00:32:00,774 --> 00:32:03,790
we can still take advantage
of it if we don't need it.

574
00:32:03,790 --> 00:32:06,927
If we don't track it, we're not gonna be
able to take advantage of that later on if

575
00:32:06,927 --> 00:32:07,981
we're ahead of schedule.

576
00:32:07,981 --> 00:32:09,235
So that's what reserve
analysis is all about.

577
00:32:09,235 --> 00:32:14,044
Digging into that, finding out where
it's needed, and then planning what you

578
00:32:14,044 --> 00:32:19,290
can do with it, if you don't use it,
can you get ahead of schedule, right?

579
00:32:19,290 --> 00:32:20,950
I think that's about it for
Reserve Analysis.

580
00:32:20,950 --> 00:32:21,490
Isn't it Ronnie?

581
00:32:21,490 --> 00:32:22,271
>> That's it.

582
00:32:22,271 --> 00:32:24,674
[SOUND]
>> Yeah, that's it, and

583
00:32:24,674 --> 00:32:27,856
we'll see like base line tracking,
where we get into the monitoring phase.

584
00:32:27,856 --> 00:32:31,751
And we wanna track, so we know when we use
that reserve, and when we didn't use it,

585
00:32:31,751 --> 00:32:35,105
because we can put that in our lessons
learned at the end of the project.

586
00:32:35,105 --> 00:32:39,150
We can use that to track whether we
actually needed that reserve or not and

587
00:32:39,150 --> 00:32:40,021
learn from it.

00:32:40,021 --> 00:32:43,690
So, all right, well, that's a pretty good

00:33:06,396 --> 00:33:08,030
All right, welcome back everybody.

00:33:08,030 --> 00:33:11,530
So we took a look at all the tools and

597
00:33:11,530 --> 00:33:15,580
And when we apply those to generating
our estimates what are we left with at

598
00:33:15,580 --> 00:33:16,280
the end of the day?

599
00:33:16,280 --> 00:33:17,600
What are our outputs?

600
00:33:17,600 --> 00:33:21,380
Well, the main output that we're
generating is this guy right here,

601
00:33:21,380 --> 00:33:24,060
the activity duration estimate.

602
00:33:24,060 --> 00:33:27,660
We should have an estimate for

603
00:33:27,660 --> 00:33:29,520
So we're reaching out to
our subject matter experts,

604
00:33:29,520 --> 00:33:31,200
reaching out to all these individuals and

605
00:33:31,200 --> 00:33:35,120
they're saying, yeah, that'll take
two hours, that'll take five weeks.

606
00:33:35,120 --> 00:33:37,900
And you wanna be a little
more specific than that.

607
00:33:37,900 --> 00:33:43,090
You wanna get them to say, well it'll

608
00:33:43,090 --> 00:33:46,400
if I could have two people,
we'd get it done in one week, right?

609
00:33:46,400 --> 00:33:51,520
Some activities, you have this, we're
gonna talk about it a little bit later, so

00:33:51,520 --> 00:33:57,160
I don't wanna get too far ahead of myself,
but, you have fixed duration activities.

611
00:33:57,160 --> 00:34:00,490
And then you have other activities
that are what are called fixed work.

612
00:34:00,490 --> 00:34:01,970
And with a fixed work activity,

613
00:34:01,970 --> 00:34:05,490
that means you have a certain amount
hours of work that need to be done.

614
00:34:05,490 --> 00:34:10,030
The more people you have
the faster that work can get done.

615
00:34:10,030 --> 00:34:12,550
A great example might be painting a house,
all right?

616
00:34:12,550 --> 00:34:16,550
If I have one person painting the house
it might take them four days.

617
00:34:16,550 --> 00:34:20,410
If I have two people painting the house
maybe they can get it done in two days.

618
00:34:20,410 --> 00:34:24,090
If I got three people painting the house
maybe I can get it done in one day.

619
00:34:24,090 --> 00:34:29,340
The more people I attach to that activity,
the faster it gets done, right?

620
00:34:29,340 --> 00:34:31,870
That's called effort-driven work, right?

621
00:34:31,870 --> 00:34:34,780
The more effort we put in,
the faster it gets done.

622
00:34:34,780 --> 00:34:39,756
So when we come up with these estimates,
we need to know is this a fixed duration,

623
00:34:39,756 --> 00:34:43,500
something we can't do anything about,
or is it fixed work?

624
00:34:43,500 --> 00:34:47,807
There's a certain amount of man hours or
woman hours or whatever [LAUGH] people

625
00:34:47,807 --> 00:34:51,810
hours that need to be done in
order to complete this activity.

626
00:34:51,810 --> 00:34:53,760
So I gave an example
of painting the house.

627
00:34:53,760 --> 00:34:54,690
That would be like fixed work.

628
00:34:54,690 --> 00:34:56,030
There's a certain amount of hours,

629
00:34:56,030 --> 00:34:58,500
the more people you have
the faster it gets done.

630
00:34:58,500 --> 00:35:03,810
But you might have something like,

631
00:35:03,810 --> 00:35:07,390
So maybe as part of our project we need

00:35:07,390 --> 00:35:09,180
to Orlando so
it's gonna have to be driven.

633
00:35:09,180 --> 00:35:11,490
And that's about a two-hour drive, right?

634
00:35:11,490 --> 00:35:16,430
So I put in a activity that says
drive to Orlando, two hours, right?

635
00:35:16,430 --> 00:35:19,040
That's an example of a fixed duration.

636
00:35:19,040 --> 00:35:23,175
If I have one person driving that car,
it's gonna take two hours.

637
00:35:23,175 --> 00:35:25,235
What if I have two people in the car?

638
00:35:25,235 --> 00:35:25,855
Two hours.

639
00:35:25,855 --> 00:35:26,745
Three people?

640
00:35:26,745 --> 00:35:27,365
Two hours.

641
00:35:27,365 --> 00:35:29,855
Doesn't matter how many people, well
eventually you max out the car I suppose,

642
00:35:29,855 --> 00:35:32,035
but it doesn't really matter
how many people are in the car,

643
00:35:32,035 --> 00:35:34,465
it's gonna take two hours
no matter what we do.

644
00:35:34,465 --> 00:35:36,465
You might speed,
break the law, or whatever, but

645
00:35:36,465 --> 00:35:38,005
it's just gonna take that two hours.

646
00:35:38,005 --> 00:35:39,715
That's fixed duration.

647
00:35:39,715 --> 00:35:42,895
There's no sense in assigning a bunch
of extra resources to it when

648
00:35:42,895 --> 00:35:44,490
we're not gonna make it any shorter.

649
00:35:44,490 --> 00:35:45,500
So, it's fixed duration.

650
00:35:45,500 --> 00:35:50,400
So, when we get these estimates,
we need to be thinking about that also.

651
00:35:50,400 --> 00:35:54,580
When we do the duration, there's really
a couple of things we need to think about.

652
00:35:54,580 --> 00:35:56,680
Let me jump back to my notes here.

653
00:35:57,860 --> 00:36:03,010
So, we've got details of an estimate.

654
00:36:04,260 --> 00:36:09,360
And really it's of a time estimate,
cuz cost is gonna be different.

655
00:36:09,360 --> 00:36:16,672
So, is it fixed duration or

656
00:36:16,672 --> 00:36:20,580
fixed work, right?

657
00:36:20,580 --> 00:36:22,930
Can I assign more people to it?

658
00:36:22,930 --> 00:36:25,150
I'm kinda leaving out
the most important part,

659
00:36:25,150 --> 00:36:30,000
which is how long,
how long will it take, right?

660
00:36:30,000 --> 00:36:31,290
That's really what this is all about.

661
00:36:31,290 --> 00:36:34,120
And how you measure that
is up to your project.

662
00:36:34,120 --> 00:36:36,680
If it's a short project,
you might measure it in hours.

663
00:36:36,680 --> 00:36:40,190
If it's a long project,
you might measure it in days or weeks.

664
00:36:40,190 --> 00:36:41,300
You might even go months.

665
00:36:41,300 --> 00:36:42,146
We don't normally do months.

666
00:36:42,146 --> 00:36:44,110
Remember our 8/80 rule?

667
00:36:44,110 --> 00:36:48,710
We're trying to keep things in 80-hour
maximums, which would be about two weeks,

668
00:36:48,710 --> 00:36:52,830
so we don't normally go too crazy, but
how long is this activity gonna take?

669
00:36:52,830 --> 00:36:55,710
Is it fixed duration or fixed work?

670
00:36:55,710 --> 00:36:59,040
Very important to know that, cuz we can
use that to adjust our schedule later on.

671
00:37:00,290 --> 00:37:02,980
We also need to know is
there a reserve time?

672
00:37:04,840 --> 00:37:06,646
If so, how much?

673
00:37:06,646 --> 00:37:07,276
Right, so

674
00:37:07,276 --> 00:37:11,980
that we can designate the reserve time
in there as we designate it also, right?

675
00:37:11,980 --> 00:37:18,730
The last thing we need is,
are there any constraints, okay?

676
00:37:18,730 --> 00:37:21,190
Constraints are an interesting thing and

677
00:37:21,190 --> 00:37:26,480
in the pin they mention it but
it's kinda spread throughout.

678
00:37:26,480 --> 00:37:30,100
I don't think there's like one big
designation of how the constraints are.

679
00:37:30,100 --> 00:37:31,490
But it's something that we need to gather.

680
00:37:31,490 --> 00:37:35,420
So you might not see this one on the exam
but in real life it's pretty important.

681
00:37:35,420 --> 00:37:39,750
When you have an activity
there're certain factors that can

00:37:39,750 --> 00:37:44,220
influence where it falls on your
schedule and we can see those.

683
00:37:44,220 --> 00:37:49,370
Let me get rid of some of these windows.

684
00:37:49,370 --> 00:37:52,521
Yeah, we don't need that.

685
00:37:52,521 --> 00:37:57,698
[SOUND] And I'll just take,
actually this one

686
00:37:57,698 --> 00:38:03,564
has a constraint already so
let me pull it up there.

687
00:38:03,564 --> 00:38:08,184
All right, so kinda looking in here,
I've pulled up an activity in my project

688
00:38:08,184 --> 00:38:12,220
management software and
you'll see this constraint value.

689
00:38:12,220 --> 00:38:16,960
And there's eight different values
here in the constraints, okay?

690
00:38:16,960 --> 00:38:22,770
Most project management software will
use what are called soft constraints.

691
00:38:22,770 --> 00:38:24,420
And there's two of them.

692
00:38:24,420 --> 00:38:27,650
As soon as and as late as possible.

693
00:38:27,650 --> 00:38:32,600
Okay, so when we add this activity into
our calendar we're normally saying

694
00:38:34,820 --> 00:38:38,630
it can start as soon as possible.

695
00:38:38,630 --> 00:38:41,390
So just look at our dependencies and
based on the dependencies,

696
00:38:41,390 --> 00:38:43,910
start as soon as you can.

697
00:38:43,910 --> 00:38:47,160
We use this when we're trying
to schedule a project and

698
00:38:47,160 --> 00:38:50,050
get it done as fast as possible,
which is what most of us are trying to do.

699
00:38:50,050 --> 00:38:53,580
So as soon as possible do this, all right?

700
00:38:53,580 --> 00:38:57,850
But sometimes there's projects
like the Olympics, right?

701
00:38:57,850 --> 00:39:01,890
If we're planning the Olympics,
the Olympics start on a particular day,

702
00:39:01,890 --> 00:39:04,720
there's not a lot of sense in
getting things done early.

703
00:39:04,720 --> 00:39:08,660
We wanna plan on getting things
going right at that moment.

704
00:39:08,660 --> 00:39:13,840
And so you may have something that's
as late as possible, all right?

705
00:39:13,840 --> 00:39:18,200
Based on the other activities that
we depend on, our preceders and

706
00:39:18,200 --> 00:39:21,420
our succeeders, those guys, based on that

707
00:39:21,420 --> 00:39:25,710
we'll start as late as we can without
missing our finish date, all right?

708
00:39:25,710 --> 00:39:29,720
So those two as soon as possible is what
almost every project management software

709
00:39:29,720 --> 00:39:30,810
defaults to.

710
00:39:30,810 --> 00:39:35,450
They're called soft constraints
because one activity can move in

711
00:39:35,450 --> 00:39:37,820
time based on the stuff that's around it.

712
00:39:37,820 --> 00:39:40,410
If something else finishes early,
this one can start early.

00:39:40,410 --> 00:39:42,130
We might not have that, though.

00:39:42,130 --> 00:39:44,060
If you're dealing with contractors, and

00:39:44,060 --> 00:39:49,940
the contractors say it's gonna take three

00:39:49,940 --> 00:39:52,450
So, now it's not just that

717
00:39:52,450 --> 00:39:54,480
It's gonna take three days from July 12th.

718
00:39:54,480 --> 00:39:57,509
No matter what happens before,

719
00:39:57,509 --> 00:40:02,129
All right, so in those scenarios,
we have to use harder constraints,

720
00:40:02,129 --> 00:40:05,752
constraints that are a little
more restricted, okay?

721
00:40:05,752 --> 00:40:10,128
And the recommendation is that you
still have some flexibility, so

722
00:40:10,128 --> 00:40:13,220
you'll see
>> As soon as, as late as, and

723
00:40:13,220 --> 00:40:17,900
then you've got start no earlier,
start no later.

that's called the critical path.

01:04:22,700 --> 01:04:26,350
Most project software will highlight
it in red like what I'm seeing here.

1177
01:04:26,350 --> 01:04:31,440
And that lets me know if any one of those
activities, if any of these red activities

1178
01:04:31,440 --> 01:04:36,190
fall behind schedule, my whole
project will fall behind schedule.

1179
01:04:36,190 --> 01:04:36,720
Right.

1180
01:04:36,720 --> 01:04:38,490
That's a big deal.

1181
01:04:38,490 --> 01:04:40,920
Right?
We need to be careful with that

1182
01:04:40,920 --> 01:04:43,510
because those are the ones
that are the most sensitive.

1183
01:04:43,510 --> 01:04:46,830
If some of these other things fall behind,
it's not a big deal, right?

1184
01:04:46,830 --> 01:04:51,030
In our planning stage we often don't
know what are critical path is,

1185
01:04:51,030 --> 01:04:54,080
and that's because our durations
are still somewhat in flux.

1186
01:04:54,080 --> 01:04:56,580
As we go through and
we start assigning durations and

1187
01:04:56,580 --> 01:05:00,740
things like that,
we'll see that things can actually change.

1188
01:05:00,740 --> 01:05:05,080
So while we're planning,
our critical path might change.

1189
01:05:05,080 --> 01:05:09,020
See how by bumping that up,
I now have two critical paths?

1190
01:05:09,020 --> 01:05:11,360
Now both of these are tied together.

1191
01:05:11,360 --> 01:05:15,670
If either one falls behind,
my project falls behind.

1192
01:05:15,670 --> 01:05:20,200
So I've created a dual
critical path environment.

1193
01:05:20,200 --> 01:05:25,700
That can happen, and so you've got to
be sensitive to both of those tracks,

1194
01:05:25,700 --> 01:05:28,950
and it can be where one
critical path replaces another.

1195
01:05:28,950 --> 01:05:30,100
That can happen, too.

1196
01:05:30,100 --> 01:05:33,340
There's all sorts of various scenarios.

1197
01:05:33,340 --> 01:05:35,203
Oh, I've got fixed resources.

1198
01:05:35,203 --> 01:05:37,501
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's why it's getting upset.

1199
01:05:37,501 --> 01:05:41,760
I'm getting weird days in here now
because of my resource availability, but

1200
01:05:41,760 --> 01:05:44,890
these are all different things
that can kinda come into play.

1201
01:05:44,890 --> 01:05:46,850
And you've got to watch them and

1202
01:05:46,850 --> 01:05:49,480
pay attention to how your
calendar's developing.

1203
01:05:49,480 --> 01:05:52,910
>> Yeah, a lot of times on this critical
path if you're actually using this project

1204
01:05:52,910 --> 01:05:56,380
management software, just like Don
pointed out in the areas of float,

1205
01:05:56,380 --> 01:05:58,910
most of the time when you see
this in the critical path,

1206
01:05:58,910 --> 01:06:03,210
this is actually the line of tasks
which tend to have no float in them.

1207
01:06:03,210 --> 01:06:07,120
And that's why any delay
along these ticker tasks

1208
01:06:07,120 --> 01:06:11,735
are gonna cause a delay to your actual
finish on your overall project so

1209
01:06:11,735 --> 01:06:15,865
you can actually determine it that was too
just by looking at a lot of times as well.

1210
01:06:15,865 --> 01:06:19,455
>> I just modified some of my
durations and see what happened.

1211
01:06:19,455 --> 01:06:21,265
This path is no longer critical.

1212
01:06:21,265 --> 01:06:23,425
This other path is now critical.

1213
01:06:23,425 --> 01:06:27,675
Any delay on this new path will cause
my entire project to be behind but

1214
01:06:27,675 --> 01:06:31,320
I've got some room down here where
I can have delay and I'll be ok.

1215
01:06:31,320 --> 01:06:35,490
Now, how do I know how much delay I
can have, and where can I have it?

1216
01:06:35,490 --> 01:06:38,350
Well, your project management software
is figuring that out for you.

1217
01:06:38,350 --> 01:06:41,090
But on the exam we've gotta do it by hand.

1218
01:06:41,090 --> 01:06:45,280
And so we have what's called the CPM or
Critical Path Method.

1219
01:06:45,280 --> 01:06:49,370
And it uses a standard diagram that,

1220
01:06:49,370 --> 01:06:51,520
I think I brought it up
in an earlier episode.

1221
01:06:51,520 --> 01:06:54,250
It looks really intimidating,
but it's not that bad.

1222
01:06:54,250 --> 01:06:55,690
>> Nope.

1223
01:06:55,690 --> 01:06:59,110
>> Basically you map out
your activities like this.

1224
01:06:59,110 --> 01:07:03,710
And so I've got an activity here and it's
got a finish to start relationship with

1225
01:07:03,710 --> 01:07:07,680
these two activities, and then they've got
finish to starts with the next one and so

1226
01:07:07,680 --> 01:07:12,590
on, as it moves through my project
to the project end, right.

1227
01:07:12,590 --> 01:07:14,570
So that's kind of the path.

1228
01:07:14,570 --> 01:07:17,570
And I just did a simple project here,
right.

1229
01:07:17,570 --> 01:07:21,110
And we start off Just by putting
in some simple labels with

1230
01:07:21,110 --> 01:07:22,010
the information that we have.

1231
01:07:22,010 --> 01:07:25,130
Now you'll see there's several
different things in here.

1232
01:07:25,130 --> 01:07:28,300
Let me just throw in
a little text block here.

1233
01:07:28,300 --> 01:07:35,420
And basically what we have are- That's
gonna be really small, isn't it?

1234
01:07:35,420 --> 01:07:38,120
Let me bump this up until it's legible.

1235
01:07:42,440 --> 01:07:46,800
All right so ES that equals Early Start.

1236
01:07:48,480 --> 01:07:52,060
EF is Early Finish.

1237
01:07:52,060 --> 01:07:58,500
We've got let's see, LS,

1238
01:07:58,500 --> 01:08:03,850
which is Late Start,
LF which is Late Finish.

1239
01:08:05,090 --> 01:08:08,920
We've got DU which is Duration.

1240
01:08:08,920 --> 01:08:12,810
And I didn't put them on here but
you have FF which is Free Float.

1241
01:08:14,740 --> 01:08:18,230
And TF which is Total Float.

1242
01:08:18,230 --> 01:08:24,080
All right, when you're dealing
with the Critical Path Method,

1243
01:08:24,080 --> 01:08:26,690
these are the values that
you're gonna be working with.

1244
01:08:26,690 --> 01:08:28,690
And when you get started,

1245
01:08:28,690 --> 01:08:32,650
a lot of times you only know one of
these values which is duration, right?

1246
01:08:32,650 --> 01:08:36,500
We just did our duration estimates so
we have how long each of these are going

1247
01:08:36,500 --> 01:08:40,155
to take and so we can go through and
plug these into our activities.

1248
01:08:40,155 --> 01:08:42,630
And I should have labeled these
a little better like activity A,

1249
01:08:42,630 --> 01:08:44,320
activity B, and so on.

1250
01:08:44,320 --> 01:08:46,440
I just labeled them activity, right.

1251
01:08:46,440 --> 01:08:49,840
So we're gonna do an example and
get a chance to see what this is like.

1252
01:08:49,840 --> 01:08:50,620
All right.

1253
01:08:50,620 --> 01:08:54,600
I threw an extra square up here to use as
a legend so we could remember what these

1254
01:08:54,600 --> 01:08:56,590
stand for, because we're going
to put numbers in here and

1255
01:08:56,590 --> 01:08:59,120
it won't necessarily make sense anymore.

1256
01:08:59,120 --> 01:09:06,334
I'm going to update these a little bit
here to show this is activity A and

1257
01:09:06,334 --> 01:09:12,360
then up here we've got activity B,
activity C, and so on.

1258
01:09:16,140 --> 01:09:18,295
This is turning out to be a little tricky.

1259
01:09:18,295 --> 01:09:20,465
But that way I can just
tell the activities apart.

1260
01:09:21,685 --> 01:09:26,775
So basically I map it out exactly like I
would in my project management software.

1261
01:09:26,775 --> 01:09:30,285
Just so I can kind of identify what
activities have what relationship.

1262
01:09:30,285 --> 01:09:34,585
And then all I have to do is go back and
plug in whatever their duration is.

1263
01:09:34,585 --> 01:09:37,430
So each one has a certain amount
of time that it's gonna take.

1264
01:09:37,430 --> 01:09:40,120
And the unit of time we need to determine.

1265
01:09:40,120 --> 01:09:44,490
Is it gonna be an hour,
is it gonna be a day or whatever?

1266
01:09:44,490 --> 01:09:48,170
So I'm just gonna use days here
'cause that's gonna be easy for me.

1267
01:09:51,500 --> 01:09:52,203
All right.

1268
01:09:52,203 --> 01:09:54,780
So there's my activities.

1269
01:09:54,780 --> 01:09:57,510
So then I go back and
I plug in their durations.

1270
01:09:57,510 --> 01:10:01,150
My very first activity,
it is going to have a duration,

1271
01:10:01,150 --> 01:10:07,350
let's just say it is one day, and then
I'll go through each of the other ones.

1272
01:10:07,350 --> 01:10:11,350
Maybe activity B is two days.

1273
01:10:11,350 --> 01:10:14,390
Activity C is, maybe it's three days.

1274
01:10:15,550 --> 01:10:17,620
Maybe that's one day,
and this one's one day.

1275
01:10:17,620 --> 01:10:21,910
We'll do maybe four days for this one and

1276
01:10:21,910 --> 01:10:27,140
at the end of my project we'll
say this is two more days.

1277
01:10:27,140 --> 01:10:29,280
So I'm just plugging in my duration.

1278
01:10:30,770 --> 01:10:35,170
Now, identifying the critical
path Is actually really easy.

1279
01:10:35,170 --> 01:10:39,650
All you have to do is look at the multiple
paths that you have in your project and

1280
01:10:39,650 --> 01:10:41,050
figure out which one is the longest.

1281
01:10:41,050 --> 01:10:41,800
Right?

1282
01:10:41,800 --> 01:10:45,040
I have two paths in my project right now.

1283
01:10:45,040 --> 01:10:48,220
I've got a path that goes A, B, C, F, G,

1284
01:10:48,220 --> 01:10:52,480
and I've got another path that goes A,
D, E, F, G.

1285
01:10:52,480 --> 01:10:54,310
So, if I come in here and
write those down.

1286
01:10:54,310 --> 01:11:00,222
If I say, it was A,

1287
01:11:00,222 --> 01:11:05,676
B, C, F, G, and then there was A,

1288
01:11:05,676 --> 01:11:10,390
D, E, F, G, right.

1289
01:11:10,390 --> 01:11:12,349
Those are my two paths that I have.

1290
01:11:13,900 --> 01:11:15,930
Let's go a little bigger here.

1291
01:11:15,930 --> 01:11:16,440
All right.

1292
01:11:16,440 --> 01:11:20,100
So these are the two paths that I have,
and I just need to add them up, right?

1293
01:11:20,100 --> 01:11:24,890
So, A is one day, B is two days,
C is three days, F is four days,

1294
01:11:24,890 --> 01:11:28,230
and G is off my screen, two days.

1295
01:11:28,230 --> 01:11:30,220
I just need to add these up.

1296
01:11:30,220 --> 01:11:33,188
I've got one, three, six, [INAUDIBLE]
>> 12.

1297
01:11:33,188 --> 01:11:34,200
>> 12, right?

1298
01:11:34,200 --> 01:11:37,201
You'll be my official mathematician for
this project.

1299
01:11:37,201 --> 01:11:38,560
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so 12.

1300
01:11:38,560 --> 01:11:41,350
That path is 12 days long.

1301
01:11:41,350 --> 01:11:45,820
The bottom path, well if I add those up,
right, one plus one plus one.

1302
01:11:45,820 --> 01:11:49,280
So three, seven, nine, all right,
so the bottom path is nine.

1303
01:11:51,430 --> 01:11:56,190
So the path across the top is 12 days,
the path across the bottom is nine days.

1304
01:11:56,190 --> 01:11:59,530
The path across the top
is the critical path.

1305
01:11:59,530 --> 01:12:04,040
If the path across the top falls behind,
the whole project will take longer.

1306
01:12:04,040 --> 01:12:07,190
If if falls a day behind,
my project's now gonna take 13 days.

1307
01:12:07,190 --> 01:12:11,250
But if it's on schedule,
my project will take 12 days.

1308
01:12:11,250 --> 01:12:13,700
Now the bottom path is nine days.

1309
01:12:13,700 --> 01:12:14,661
So what if it falls behind?

1310
01:12:14,661 --> 01:12:18,818
What if it takes ten days, what if takes
11 days, what if it takes 12 days?

1311
01:12:18,818 --> 01:12:20,535
That's okay.

1312
01:12:20,535 --> 01:12:25,840
Because my project is 12 days long anyway,
so my project doesn't fall behind.

1313
01:12:25,840 --> 01:12:29,330
The problem here is,
I guess it's two fold.

1314
01:12:29,330 --> 01:12:34,610
The main problem is, it's not that I can
have three days of delay wherever I want.

1315
01:12:34,610 --> 01:12:38,040
It's that I can have three days
of delay in very specific places,

1316
01:12:38,040 --> 01:12:42,870
because if activity A falls behind,
that effects both paths.

1317
01:12:42,870 --> 01:12:47,850
If activity F or activity G falls behind,
it effects both paths.

1318
01:12:47,850 --> 01:12:53,020
So I can really only have three
days of delay in activity D and E.

1319
01:12:53,020 --> 01:12:57,975
I can only have delay in activities
that aren't shared between the paths

1320
01:12:57,975 --> 01:13:01,560
cuz otherwise you're introducing
the delay on the other path also.

1321
01:13:01,560 --> 01:13:02,700
All right, so

1322
01:13:02,700 --> 01:13:07,340
just knowing the critical path doesn't
tell us where we can have delay.

1323
01:13:07,340 --> 01:13:11,040
We have to do a little bit more
work to kind of sort that out and

1324
01:13:11,040 --> 01:13:14,120
figure out what our float is, okay?

1325
01:13:15,240 --> 01:13:18,970
Now, looking at this,
the top half is my critical path.

1326
01:13:18,970 --> 01:13:21,730
I've got three days that I
can delay if I need to and

1327
01:13:21,730 --> 01:13:25,730
I'll see my various paths
that I've highlighted.

1328
01:13:25,730 --> 01:13:30,280
On the exam you're gonna see simple
projects like this that we can do in our

1329
01:13:30,280 --> 01:13:32,620
head or with basic calculator work.

1330
01:13:32,620 --> 01:13:36,720
In real life, your project might
have thousands of activities.

1331
01:13:36,720 --> 01:13:40,860
Your project might have 50 different paths
and trying to calculate this stuff out

1332
01:13:40,860 --> 01:13:45,000
is a nightmare, and every time you
change a duration of even one activity,

1333
01:13:45,000 --> 01:13:47,120
you have to recalculate it all.

1334
01:13:47,120 --> 01:13:52,540
So doing this by hand is near impossible,
to do it accurately in real life land.

1335
01:13:52,540 --> 01:13:54,500
And that's why we use
project management software.

1336
01:13:54,500 --> 01:13:58,080
That's why we have Microsoft Project,
GanttProject, ProjectLibre,

1337
01:13:58,080 --> 01:14:00,980
whatever it is that we're using,
because they calculate this for

1338
01:14:00,980 --> 01:14:03,770
us across many very complex paths.

1339
01:14:03,770 --> 01:14:07,670
Microsoft Project can calculate
it across multiple project files.

1340
01:14:07,670 --> 01:14:09,520
You might have five different
projects that are running.

1341
01:14:09,520 --> 01:14:11,100
You can do a path across all of them.

1342
01:14:11,100 --> 01:14:12,360
You can do some really fancy stuff.

1343
01:14:12,360 --> 01:14:15,190
It would be a nightmare
to do that by hand.

1344
01:14:15,190 --> 01:14:19,210
But on the exam, they'll give you
fairly simple diagrams like this and

1345
01:14:19,210 --> 01:14:21,630
you'll need to calculate
what's the critical path.

1346
01:14:21,630 --> 01:14:23,880
And you'll see questions
that'll say things like,

1347
01:14:23,880 --> 01:14:28,320
if this activity now takes this amount of
time, what happens with critical path?

1348
01:14:28,320 --> 01:14:31,560
Stays the same, changes,
you now have two critical paths,

1349
01:14:31,560 --> 01:14:33,190
you'll have some different options.

1350
01:14:33,190 --> 01:14:36,120
So, you'll need to be able to calculate
that out and figure it out and

1351
01:14:36,120 --> 01:14:40,050
you'll need to be able to do it somewhat
quickly cuz it's a four hour exam.

1352
01:14:40,050 --> 01:14:42,640
And you gotta make sure you
get to all your questions.

1353
01:14:42,640 --> 01:14:43,422
All right.

1354
01:14:43,422 --> 01:14:47,200
So now know this top
path is my critical path,

1355
01:14:47,200 --> 01:14:51,310
I know I've got three days of float.

1356
01:14:51,310 --> 01:14:53,690
So I can have some delay
in that bottom path.

1357
01:14:53,690 --> 01:14:57,400
I know that D and
E are the only non shared activities.

1358
01:14:57,400 --> 01:15:01,140
So, that three days of flow really
just applies down here on D and E.

1359
01:15:01,140 --> 01:15:05,020
All right, so,
if that's all I needed, I'm done.

1360
01:15:05,020 --> 01:15:07,000
Was critical path method hard?

1361
01:15:07,000 --> 01:15:08,720
No.
It was pretty intimidating but

1362
01:15:08,720 --> 01:15:10,670
it really was pretty easy.

1363
01:15:10,670 --> 01:15:13,660
Well, you might notice these four
other values we haven't messed with.

1364
01:15:13,660 --> 01:15:14,540
All right.

1365
01:15:14,540 --> 01:15:19,760
The problem we have here is
you have not just float, but

1366
01:15:19,760 --> 01:15:21,840
you have times when you can use it.

1367
01:15:21,840 --> 01:15:25,110
And so,
float gets broken up into two pieces.

1368
01:15:25,110 --> 01:15:27,490
Total float and free float.

1369
01:15:27,490 --> 01:15:28,140
All right.

1370
01:15:28,140 --> 01:15:32,150
That three days that we just counted,
that's called total float.

1371
01:15:32,150 --> 01:15:38,790
That's the total float this path has that,
if activity D is three days late,

1372
01:15:38,790 --> 01:15:41,910
that doesn't mean activity E can
be three days late also, right?

1373
01:15:41,910 --> 01:15:46,020
It's shared, so
that's total float for the path.

1374
01:15:46,020 --> 01:15:49,330
We need to look at where it
can be used individually and

1375
01:15:49,330 --> 01:15:51,810
calculate what's called Free Float.

1376
01:15:51,810 --> 01:15:55,190
Free Float is where one
activity can be delayed and

1377
01:15:55,190 --> 01:15:58,700
it doesn't affect any
other activity whatsoever.

1378
01:15:58,700 --> 01:16:01,090
It's completely isolated
in that one activity.

1379
01:16:01,090 --> 01:16:04,000
This will help us to isolate
where that can occur.

1380
01:16:04,000 --> 01:16:07,180
And it's even more important when you have
things like contractor's scheduled on

1381
01:16:07,180 --> 01:16:08,520
a specific day.

1382
01:16:08,520 --> 01:16:11,570
Just because you could be late
doesn't mean that you really can,

1383
01:16:11,570 --> 01:16:15,070
cuz you might have contractors fixed
to come in at a particular time.

1384
01:16:15,070 --> 01:16:19,512
So Float is very nebulous.

1385
01:16:19,512 --> 01:16:22,690
It comes and
goes based on various criteria.

1386
01:16:22,690 --> 01:16:23,490
All right.

1387
01:16:23,490 --> 01:16:25,530
So how do we use all these other values?

1388
01:16:25,530 --> 01:16:30,000
Well, each of these other values captures
a characteristic of an activity.

1389
01:16:30,000 --> 01:16:34,330
Early start is the earliest,
best case scenario,

1390
01:16:34,330 --> 01:16:36,990
the earliest that that
activity is able to start.

1391
01:16:38,150 --> 01:16:41,170
Late start is worst case scenario.

1392
01:16:41,170 --> 01:16:45,840
What's the absolute latest that that
activity could start without delaying

1393
01:16:45,840 --> 01:16:47,380
the next person in line.

1394
01:16:47,380 --> 01:16:49,490
It's always thinking about
the next person in line.

1395
01:16:49,490 --> 01:16:50,750
Same thing with finishing.

1396
01:16:50,750 --> 01:16:54,640
What's the earliest we could
finish best case scenario, and

1397
01:16:54,640 --> 01:16:59,480
what's the latest we could finish without
bothering the next person in line?

1398
01:16:59,480 --> 01:17:00,060
Okay?

1399
01:17:00,060 --> 01:17:02,720
So we've always got to look at
that as we calculate along and

1400
01:17:02,720 --> 01:17:04,110
figure out these values.

1401
01:17:04,110 --> 01:17:06,720

01:28:58,630 --> 01:29:01,450
It'll tell us where it is by
having all zeroes along it.

1631
01:29:01,450 --> 01:29:03,630
Now we just look for
a path with all zeroes for total float.

1632
01:29:03,630 --> 01:29:04,440
That's our critical path.

1633
01:29:06,340 --> 01:29:08,620
The bottom path, here, though,
we'll see differences.

1634
01:29:08,620 --> 01:29:13,160
Right, so six minus three, five minus two.

1635
01:29:13,160 --> 01:29:17,112
Both of those if I do five minus two
I've got three days of total float.

1636
01:29:17,112 --> 01:29:20,863
And activity E, six minus three,
I can come in here and

1637
01:29:20,863 --> 01:29:23,628
say that's three days of total float.

1638
01:29:24,670 --> 01:29:28,106
Now I can see if I,
let me zoom out a little bit.

1639
01:29:30,281 --> 01:29:31,640
Can I get this whole thing on my screen?

Probably not.

1641
01:29:34,020 --> 01:29:35,740
Well, we can see it right here.

1642
01:29:35,740 --> 01:29:39,010
So I have zero, zero, zero, zero, zero.

1643
01:29:39,010 --> 01:29:44,720
Zero, I've got zero, three,
three, zero, and so on, right?

1644
01:29:44,720 --> 01:29:49,430
So looking at it this way I can

1645
01:29:49,430 --> 01:29:52,550
Not just the fact that I have

1646
01:29:52,550 --> 01:29:54,980
I can see where I'm allowed to use it.
