01:29:54,980 --> 01:29:57,740
I can't use it on activity A,
I can't use it on activity F or

1648
01:29:57,740 --> 01:30:00,230
G, cause that'll delay the whole project.

1649
01:30:00,230 --> 01:30:05,550
But these guys are sharing three
days that they can use and

1650
01:30:05,550 --> 01:30:08,400
not affect the project as a whole.

1651
01:30:08,400 --> 01:30:09,150
All right.

1652
01:30:09,150 --> 01:30:12,980
That is total float, and
it's pretty easy to calculate.

1653
01:30:12,980 --> 01:30:14,750
You just take Early Start,

1654
01:30:14,750 --> 01:30:17,680
Early Finish, subtract the smaller
number from the larger number.

1655
01:30:17,680 --> 01:30:19,960
What's left, there's your flow.

1656
01:30:19,960 --> 01:30:21,730
Or you can do it with the starts or

1657
01:30:21,730 --> 01:30:25,040
you can do it with the finishes,
whichever you want.

1658
01:30:25,040 --> 01:30:26,430
Did I say start early, finish?

1659
01:30:26,430 --> 01:30:30,850
It would be early start, late start,
or early finish, late finish.

1660
01:30:30,850 --> 01:30:31,680
Let me just clarify that.

1661
01:30:31,680 --> 01:30:34,720
You're always dealing with the same ones,
yeah.

1662
01:30:34,720 --> 01:30:38,690
You would get weird stuff,
if we did early start and early finish,

1663
01:30:38,690 --> 01:30:41,580
you'd end up with one,
and that's not right.

1664
01:30:41,580 --> 01:30:44,080
Okay, so now we've got our total float.

1665
01:30:44,080 --> 01:30:45,760
So what is free float?

1666
01:30:45,760 --> 01:30:49,880
Well free float is the amount
of time we can delay

1667
01:30:49,880 --> 01:30:54,840
without affecting the next person in line.

1668
01:30:54,840 --> 01:31:02,150
And what we do here with this one, is we
basically take whatever our finish is,

1669
01:31:02,150 --> 01:31:07,090
okay, and we compare our late finish.

1670
01:31:07,090 --> 01:31:10,960
To the next person's,
the latest that we can finish.

1671
01:31:10,960 --> 01:31:13,180
Well actually hang on,
let me make sure I'm doing this right.

1672
01:31:13,180 --> 01:31:18,960
It would be our late finish and we compare
that with the early start of the next guy.

1673
01:31:18,960 --> 01:31:25,005
All right, if there's a difference
Actually, did I do my numbers wrong?

1674
01:31:25,005 --> 01:31:26,537
Here, let me make sure I've
got this math right, here.

1675
01:31:31,660 --> 01:31:32,206
Oh, sorry.

1676
01:31:32,206 --> 01:31:33,255
I see what I'm doing.

1677
01:31:33,255 --> 01:31:34,720
[LAUGH] All right.

1678
01:31:34,720 --> 01:31:36,840
We look at when we're gonna finish, right?

1679
01:31:36,840 --> 01:31:41,660
So this one, if it finished on day five,
what's gonna happen is activity E is going

1680
01:31:41,660 --> 01:31:44,040
to have to move to accommodate that,
right?

1681
01:31:44,040 --> 01:31:45,640
So starting at day five, for

1682
01:31:45,640 --> 01:31:50,570
us, is going to affect somebody down
the line and cause a problem, right?

1683
01:31:50,570 --> 01:31:53,470
If I finish at day five,
it's no longer possible for

1684
01:31:53,470 --> 01:31:56,100
activity E to finish on day three, right?

1685
01:31:56,100 --> 01:31:59,070
Or to start on day three,
it's gonna have to move.

1686
01:31:59,070 --> 01:32:04,200
But if we look at activity E,
it could finish as late as day six.

1687
01:32:04,200 --> 01:32:05,960
And if it did, if it finished at day six,

1688
01:32:05,960 --> 01:32:09,570
would that affect the early
start of this guy?

1689
01:32:09,570 --> 01:32:10,330
No.

1690
01:32:10,330 --> 01:32:13,600
If we finished as late as possible here,

1691
01:32:13,600 --> 01:32:17,160
the Early Start of F
would not move at all.

1692
01:32:17,160 --> 01:32:17,860
Right.

1693
01:32:17,860 --> 01:32:22,470
That means we could be late
without effecting the next guy.

1694
01:32:22,470 --> 01:32:23,810
Over here, activity D,

1695
01:32:23,810 --> 01:32:29,020
if we finish on day five, the early start
of activity E would no longer be valid.

1696
01:32:29,020 --> 01:32:31,180
We effected, we've moved it.

1697
01:32:31,180 --> 01:32:33,440
Our late finish.

1698
01:32:33,440 --> 01:32:36,540
Is higher than the early
start of the next activity.

1699
01:32:36,540 --> 01:32:38,810
The other activity has to move, okay.

1700
01:32:38,810 --> 01:32:40,950
And doing the math,
I'm trying to do the math in my head,

1701
01:32:40,950 --> 01:32:43,000
mathematically this looks really weird.

1702
01:32:43,000 --> 01:32:46,780
But if you think about it common
sense wise, if this one goes late,

1703
01:32:46,780 --> 01:32:48,140
does it delay the next one?

1704
01:32:48,140 --> 01:32:48,690
Yes.

1705
01:32:48,690 --> 01:32:49,330
All right.

1706
01:32:49,330 --> 01:32:53,160
If that happens,
then you don't have free flow.

1707
01:32:53,160 --> 01:32:56,160
Free flow is movement you
can have in one activity.

1708
01:32:56,160 --> 01:32:58,490
That doesn't affect anyone else.

1709
01:32:58,490 --> 01:33:01,130
No one else feels the repercussions.

1710
01:33:01,130 --> 01:33:05,900
Well, activity D, when it's done,
activity E can immediately start.

1711
01:33:05,900 --> 01:33:09,400
So any delay whatsoever right here.

1712
01:33:09,400 --> 01:33:11,370
Is going to affect activity E.

1713
01:33:11,370 --> 01:33:17,970
So while we have three days of total
float, we have zero days of free float.

1714
01:33:17,970 --> 01:33:22,090
There's zero days that we can use
without affecting anybody else.

1715
01:33:22,090 --> 01:33:24,970
Alright, meanwhile activity E,

1716
01:33:24,970 --> 01:33:29,080
if it finishes on day three
Activity F still can't start.

1717
01:33:29,080 --> 01:33:33,920
If it finishes on day six,
activity F will start the next day, but

1718
01:33:33,920 --> 01:33:35,750
that's its plan anyway, right?

1719
01:33:35,750 --> 01:33:39,780
So, any variation there, we have, and

1720
01:33:39,780 --> 01:33:43,180
so we just subtract that out, and
it's basically our total float here.

1721
01:33:43,180 --> 01:33:45,800
And we'll end up with that
value of three there also.

1722
01:33:45,800 --> 01:33:48,710
So activity E has three days of free flow.

1723
01:33:48,710 --> 01:33:52,650
If activity E runs behind
no one will notice.

1724
01:33:52,650 --> 01:33:57,030
It's not going to effect any other
activity what so ever right.

1725
01:33:57,030 --> 01:33:59,670
I need to know this as the project manager

1726
01:33:59,670 --> 01:34:03,590
because that says if this runs behind I
don't have to take any actions right.

1727
01:34:03,590 --> 01:34:05,080
But activity D,

1728
01:34:05,080 --> 01:34:08,720
if it falls behind it's not the end of the
world right it's not on the critical path.

1729
01:34:08,720 --> 01:34:13,280
But if it falls behind, I need to call the
people that are working on this activity.

1730
01:34:13,280 --> 01:34:15,890
And I need to tell them hey guys
you're going to be starting a little

1731
01:34:15,890 --> 01:34:16,610
bit late right.

1732
01:34:16,610 --> 01:34:19,840
You're going to start late because
these guys aren't done yet.

1733
01:34:19,840 --> 01:34:21,800
It doesn't effect the whole project.

1734
01:34:21,800 --> 01:34:24,360
Our deadline is still on day 12.

1735
01:34:24,360 --> 01:34:26,920
But, I still have to move this guy.

1736
01:34:26,920 --> 01:34:29,590
So, free float is awesome.

1737
01:34:29,590 --> 01:34:31,570
Anybody can do free float and it's great.

1738
01:34:31,570 --> 01:34:34,700
It doesn't affect anybody else and
I'm not gonna take any action.

1739
01:34:34,700 --> 01:34:38,340
But, you don't have it in most cases.

1740
01:34:38,340 --> 01:34:41,000
Most of the time you just have
what's called total float.

1741
01:34:41,000 --> 01:34:42,970
And total float is gonna
require some work on our part.

1742
01:34:42,970 --> 01:34:45,940
Any time we use it,
we have to contact everyone

1743
01:34:45,940 --> 01:34:49,910
else that's sharing that total float and
let them know that we're moving back.

1744
01:34:49,910 --> 01:34:53,080
And if it's a contractor with
a constraint on their start date.

1745
01:34:53,080 --> 01:34:54,820
>> Yeah.
>> We may not be able to do that.

1746
01:34:54,820 --> 01:34:58,920
So, even though we have total float,
we might not be able to use it here.

1747
01:34:58,920 --> 01:35:02,330
If activity E has to start
on a particular day,

1748
01:35:02,330 --> 01:35:04,630
I don't care that there's
total float here.

1749
01:35:04,630 --> 01:35:08,660
I can't use it, because these guys
have to start on a particular day.

1750
01:35:08,660 --> 01:35:10,022
That's why we need to know free float.

1751
01:35:10,022 --> 01:35:11,550
All right.

1752
01:35:11,550 --> 01:35:14,660
Now on your critical path
you've got zero total float so

1753
01:35:14,660 --> 01:35:19,420
you've got zero free float also
right that's just how it works.

1754
01:35:21,740 --> 01:35:24,754
So we can go through and
populate that across these.

01:35:30,581 --> 01:35:31,359
There we go.

01:35:31,359 --> 01:35:37,004
All right, so that is calculating

You need to know how to

>> Right.
>> All right?

What's the best way to do it?

Practice.
>> Yeah.

Make a chart.

Make a chart like this and

In fact, on the exam,

Which is which.

All right?

Write a project path, a diagram on there.

01:36:24,200 --> 01:36:27,500
Leave all the blanks empty, and

1779

Go forward, go back.

1781
01:36:32,500 --> 01:36:34,490
Do your forward paths,
your backward paths.

1782
01:36:34,490 --> 01:36:35,250
Run through it.

1783

The more you do it,

So really easy to do.

If this is the first time you've seen

The more you do it, the more you get

The book, the pin box does call out one

The difference is
the critical chain method

The reserve or

Of it in there.

So, you likely won't see this on the exam,

It's a little harder to calculate this way

through the rest of our tools and

1861
01:40:18,100 --> 01:40:20,520
then we'll see actually creating
that schedule baseline.

1862
01:40:20,520 --> 01:40:23,120
The schedule that we start work
with when we go into execute.

1863
01:40:23,120 --> 01:40:24,190
>> Right.
>> All right.

1864
01:40:24,190 --> 01:40:25,800
So stay tuned for that.

1865
01:40:25,800 --> 01:40:29,411
Let me remind you guys that if you
have any questions on this stuff,

1866
01:40:29,411 --> 01:40:30,390
feel free to ask.

1867
01:40:30,390 --> 01:40:33,210
Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live.

1868
01:40:33,210 --> 01:40:34,500
You'll see the chat room.

1869
01:40:34,500 --> 01:40:35,440
Post your questions there.

1870
01:40:35,440 --> 01:40:37,150
We monitor and answer.

1871
01:40:37,150 --> 01:40:40,790
If you have questions after the show
when we're you know not on the air.

1872
01:40:40,790 --> 01:40:42,080
You can use the Q and A forms.

1873
01:40:42,080 --> 01:40:46,200
Hit that Q and A link at the top of every
webpage at IT Pro TV, and you can go in,

1874
01:40:46,200 --> 01:40:47,200
post your questions.

1875
01:40:47,200 --> 01:40:48,510
We monitor and answer there too.

1876
01:40:48,510 --> 01:40:49,730
Take advantage of that resource.

1877
01:40:49,730 --> 01:40:51,160
It's there for you.

1878
01:40:51,160 --> 01:40:54,030
All right, well, signing out for
IT Pro TV, I'm Don Pezet.

1879
01:40:54,030 --> 01:40:54,810
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1880
01:40:54,810 --> 01:40:56,490
>> And we will see you next time.

1881
01:40:56,490 --> 01:41:06,490
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take the outputs of the activities planning, duration estimates and resource assignments to develop a schedule to manage the project. They show how the project plan can be compressed and adjusted to fit the project scope.
episodes.title: Time Management Part 3
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,487 --> 00:00:10,487
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,623 --> 00:00:36,940
All right, good morning, good afternoon
and good evening and welcome back!

3
00:00:36,940 --> 00:00:38,489
To another episode of IT ProTV.

4
00:00:38,489 --> 00:00:41,630
I'm your host Don Pezet,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:41,630 --> 00:00:42,420
How's it going, Ronnie?

6
00:00:42,420 --> 00:00:43,610
>> I am sad today,

7
00:00:43,610 --> 00:00:48,190
because I have learned that Macaulay
Culkin has a band that honors pizza.

8
00:00:48,190 --> 00:00:49,880
That's a little bit unusual.

9
00:00:49,880 --> 00:00:50,850
>> That's his life mission?

10
00:00:50,850 --> 00:00:52,054
>> That is, yeah.
>> That's what he's gained from

11
00:00:52,054 --> 00:00:52,934
a career in Hollywood acting?

12
00:00:52,934 --> 00:00:53,793
>> Yeah.

13
00:00:53,793 --> 00:00:56,013
After his one particular apode.

14
00:00:56,013 --> 00:00:59,740
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's the only thing you know him for.

15
00:00:59,740 --> 00:01:02,110
And now,
he's honoring pizza through a band.

16
00:01:02,110 --> 00:01:05,120
>> You know, it's not uncommon for
a celebrity to choose a cause.

17
00:01:05,120 --> 00:01:06,800
We haven't chosen our charities yet.

18
00:01:06,800 --> 00:01:10,785
You know, you've got Bono, who is helping
to fight AIDS across the world and stuff.

19
00:01:10,785 --> 00:01:14,030
And Macaulay Culkin,
who is promoting pizza awareness.

20
00:01:14,030 --> 00:01:14,920
So good to know.

21
00:01:14,920 --> 00:01:20,457
Now, in the world of pizza awareness.

22
00:01:20,457 --> 00:01:22,790
One of the big things that we
have to worry about is schedule.

23
00:01:22,790 --> 00:01:27,880
How do you have time with a busy career,
as Macaulay Culkin I'm sure has.

24
00:01:27,880 --> 00:01:30,330
How do you find the time
to get things done?

25
00:01:30,330 --> 00:01:33,750
So that's what we've spent
our last two episodes on.

26
00:01:33,750 --> 00:01:38,730
And we're back again, for
part three of schedule management.

27
00:01:38,730 --> 00:01:40,850
We already went through all of our inputs,
and

28
00:01:40,850 --> 00:01:44,060
we went through maybe about half
of our tools and techniques.

29
00:01:44,060 --> 00:01:47,120
But even though it was only half,
they were big.

30
00:01:47,120 --> 00:01:51,115
So we went through our
critical path method, our CPM.

31
00:01:51,115 --> 00:01:55,150
We talked a little bit about critical
chain, and got a chance to see those.

32
00:01:55,150 --> 00:01:59,880
We did our mathematical operations,
if I can say it.

33
00:01:59,880 --> 00:02:02,250
For calculating out the forward pass and

34
00:02:02,250 --> 00:02:06,910
backward pass to calculate out your float,
your total float and free float.

35
00:02:06,910 --> 00:02:10,580
And so today, we're gonna continue
on kind of working with that.

36
00:02:10,580 --> 00:02:13,570
So by this stage in our project,

37
00:02:13,570 --> 00:02:17,770
we should have a pretty good idea
of what activities need to be done.

38
00:02:17,770 --> 00:02:21,590
The sequence those activities
are going to occur in, and

39
00:02:21,590 --> 00:02:23,630
how long each one's going to take.

40
00:02:23,630 --> 00:02:27,640
That was part of the estimate
activity duration process.

41
00:02:27,640 --> 00:02:31,820
So what we're left with is actually
creating the schedule, right?

42
00:02:31,820 --> 00:02:37,040
So, develop the schedule, and
that critical path chart that we did,

43
00:02:37,040 --> 00:02:40,160
that's pretty close to what
your schedule's going to be.

44
00:02:40,160 --> 00:02:44,520
In fact, the only thing it
didn't have were real dates,

45
00:02:44,520 --> 00:02:47,430
real live dates that we can act upon.

46
00:02:47,430 --> 00:02:49,500
It just had, hey,
this is gonna happen on day one.

47
00:02:49,500 --> 00:02:50,980
This is gonna happen on day five.

48
00:02:50,980 --> 00:02:52,500
This is gonna happen on day ten.

49
00:02:52,500 --> 00:02:54,550
Well what day is day ten?

50
00:02:54,550 --> 00:02:57,430
Is day ten March 1st, 2014?

51
00:02:57,430 --> 00:02:59,170
Or is it March 1st, 2020?

52
00:02:59,170 --> 00:03:00,540
Right?

53
00:03:00,540 --> 00:03:02,790
What is that particular day, and

54
00:03:02,790 --> 00:03:07,230
that's what we've gotta kinda sort out
here in the last part of scheduling.

55
00:03:07,230 --> 00:03:11,910
So let me bring up my diagram and
this guy right here.

56
00:03:11,910 --> 00:03:15,350
And basically we went through
all our inputs which is

57
00:03:15,350 --> 00:03:17,830
pretty much every document
we've generated so far.

58
00:03:17,830 --> 00:03:22,220
And we got through number three here,
as far as our tools and techniques.

59
00:03:22,220 --> 00:03:26,550
Everything else that we see after this,
so from four down,

60
00:03:26,550 --> 00:03:32,190
is focused on getting real dates attached
to when this stuff is going to happen.

61
00:03:32,190 --> 00:03:37,770
And the first one that we've got is what's
called resource optimization techniques.

62
00:03:37,770 --> 00:03:42,940
When you're juggling activities, somebody,
some human being at some point or

63
00:03:42,940 --> 00:03:47,420
another is gonna be the person responsible
for making that activity happen.

64
00:03:47,420 --> 00:03:51,380
So if I have an activity that says,
install 15 routers and

65
00:03:51,380 --> 00:03:53,350
configure the routing protocol.

66
00:03:53,350 --> 00:03:57,030
And I want Ronnie to do it,
Ronnie is now my resource.

67
00:03:57,030 --> 00:04:00,840
So I've got to plan around his
calendar and what he's doing and

68
00:04:00,840 --> 00:04:04,220
I've got his resource calendar
here as one of my inputs.

69
00:04:04,220 --> 00:04:05,590
So I had to plan around that.

70
00:04:05,590 --> 00:04:09,480
And then I have to find ways to
optimize the time that I've got him.

71
00:04:09,480 --> 00:04:13,510
Because I don't necessarily
have him open ended.

72
00:04:13,510 --> 00:04:16,510
So we've got a couple of tools
that are available for us.

73
00:04:16,510 --> 00:04:18,910
I'm just gonna bring up our notes here.

74
00:04:18,910 --> 00:04:21,950
So when we talk about our tools and
techniques and

75
00:04:21,950 --> 00:04:23,930
we look at our resource optimization.

76
00:04:23,930 --> 00:04:26,390
POI calls out two in specific.

77
00:04:26,390 --> 00:04:32,282
So they talk about resource leveling and
resource smoothing.

78
00:04:32,282 --> 00:04:37,980
All right, these two things right here
are very similar and very easy to confuse.

79
00:04:37,980 --> 00:04:40,300
So we have to be careful,
because they kind of work the same way.

80
00:04:40,300 --> 00:04:41,380
All right?

81
00:04:41,380 --> 00:04:44,310
Resource leveling,
that's where I say, all right.

82
00:04:44,310 --> 00:04:47,130
I've got an activity that
needs to be performed.

83
00:04:47,130 --> 00:04:50,230
And it is a 24 hour activity.

84
00:04:50,230 --> 00:04:56,085
And that means it's going to take
24 man hours of work to get done.

85
00:04:56,085 --> 00:04:59,245
PMI doesn't use these terms specifically,
but Microsoft does.

86
00:04:59,245 --> 00:05:01,675
You have duration which PMI recognizes.

87
00:05:01,675 --> 00:05:04,175
But you also have effort, and

88
00:05:04,175 --> 00:05:07,725
effort is a term that we see in a lot
of project management software.

89
00:05:07,725 --> 00:05:10,860
That's not saying this is gonna
take 24 hours to get it done.

90
00:05:10,860 --> 00:05:14,270
It's gonna say that there's 24
hours of actual work to be done.

91
00:05:14,270 --> 00:05:17,845
And so, if I have two people,
I can get it done in 12 hours,

92
00:05:17,845 --> 00:05:20,100
cause I've got two people both working.

93
00:05:20,100 --> 00:05:23,590
So one hour passes,
they just did two hours of work.

94
00:05:23,590 --> 00:05:25,240
If I have three people working,

95
00:05:25,240 --> 00:05:29,090
I can do three hours of work in
each real hour as we progress.

96
00:05:29,090 --> 00:05:33,740
So you have that duration and effort,
or the actual work being done.

97
00:05:33,740 --> 00:05:38,380
So when I look at Ronnie, there's only so
much work that he can do during a day.

98
00:05:38,380 --> 00:05:42,630
Working a standard work week,
that's about eight hours of work per day.

99
00:05:42,630 --> 00:05:48,420
So, if you do a 40 work week, five days
a week, you're working eight hours.

100
00:05:48,420 --> 00:05:52,330
If I look at his schedule and
I assign him a 24 hour activity.

101
00:05:52,330 --> 00:05:54,220
An activity that's going to
take 24 hours of his time.

102
00:05:54,220 --> 00:05:59,536
And he's only working 8 hours a day, how
long is that going to take him to do it?

103
00:05:59,536 --> 00:06:02,140
I could give him 24 hours
in 1 day if I wanted.

104
00:06:02,140 --> 00:06:02,880
Good luck, Ronnie.

105
00:06:02,880 --> 00:06:03,760
Here you go, get to work.

106
00:06:03,760 --> 00:06:04,600
Don't sleep.

107
00:06:04,600 --> 00:06:05,190
No lunch breaks.

108
00:06:06,360 --> 00:06:07,460
But it's not realistic.

109
00:06:07,460 --> 00:06:08,010
Right.

110
00:06:08,010 --> 00:06:11,030
So instead we do what's
called resource leveling.

111
00:06:11,030 --> 00:06:14,180
And resource leveling is
where we take Ronnie, and

112
00:06:14,180 --> 00:06:16,650
we say he's gotta do 24 hours of work.

113
00:06:16,650 --> 00:06:21,920
But he's only working 8 hours a day so
I've got to spread that over three days.

114
00:06:21,920 --> 00:06:26,590
Three days working eight a day,
Ronnie would get 24 hours of work done.

115
00:06:26,590 --> 00:06:31,570
So while the activity itself is 24 hours,
and in theory could be done in one day.

116
00:06:31,570 --> 00:06:35,970
Now it's gonna take three days because
it's just Ronnie working on it, and

117
00:06:35,970 --> 00:06:38,340
I need to spread it out so
I'm not paying overtime.

118
00:06:39,350 --> 00:06:43,200
That's the basic premise
behind resource leveling.

119
00:06:43,200 --> 00:06:45,980
As we start to add resources or

120
00:06:45,980 --> 00:06:50,660
take away resources, our project schedule
may get longer or shorter depending.

121
00:06:52,520 --> 00:06:53,770
It does go both ways.

122
00:06:53,770 --> 00:06:55,700
Let me see if I can work
up an example here.

123
00:06:55,700 --> 00:07:02,140
I should have thrown on Microsoft Project
cause it does a really good job with this.

124
00:07:02,140 --> 00:07:06,720
Working with something like Project Libre
I don't have a ton of experience with, but

125
00:07:06,720 --> 00:07:09,420
let's see if it will do leveling for
us kind of automatic.

126
00:07:09,420 --> 00:07:13,000
So when I come in here and
I create a task.

127
00:07:13,000 --> 00:07:15,800
Right?
So I'm just going to have Task 7.

128
00:07:15,800 --> 00:07:20,360
And for
Task 7 I'm not going to list a duration.

129
00:07:20,360 --> 00:07:25,010
Let's see,
does it track a estimate here, work.

130
00:07:25,010 --> 00:07:29,305
See how the duration is one day,
and then work is eight hours.

131
00:07:29,305 --> 00:07:30,220
Okay.

132
00:07:30,220 --> 00:07:35,102
It's eight hours and if I bump that up I'm
going to say this is 24 hours of work.

133
00:07:35,102 --> 00:07:38,610
All right,
now the duration is still one day.

134
00:07:38,610 --> 00:07:40,860
I'm saying that it's 24 hours of work, and

135
00:07:40,860 --> 00:07:46,810
when I say that, you'll notice that now
that duration changed to three days.

136
00:07:46,810 --> 00:07:49,765
It's 24 hours of work being
done over three days.

137
00:07:49,765 --> 00:07:53,359
Because it's assuming one person
working eight hours a day, right?

138
00:07:53,359 --> 00:07:56,186
And, I'm going to move this
start date to a Monday, so

139
00:07:56,186 --> 00:07:58,710
we'll be able to see this
a little more clearly.

140
00:07:58,710 --> 00:07:59,940
Let's take it to.

141
00:08:04,351 --> 00:08:06,150
Nope, that's not what I wanted.

142
00:08:06,150 --> 00:08:06,690
There we go.

143
00:08:06,690 --> 00:08:08,250
There it is.

144
00:08:08,250 --> 00:08:09,830
So, I've got it on three days.

145
00:08:09,830 --> 00:08:13,037
You know, I need to move it to
the future or it's gonna be mad at me.

146
00:08:17,147 --> 00:08:21,936
If you try and schedule something in the
past, it's gonna show as behind schedule,

147
00:08:21,936 --> 00:08:22,820
so there we go.

148
00:08:22,820 --> 00:08:24,180
>> Let me go to a different year.

149
00:08:24,180 --> 00:08:26,060
>> I know, now we're way off.

150
00:08:26,060 --> 00:08:26,910
See?

151
00:08:26,910 --> 00:08:28,450
This is
>> There we go.

152
00:08:28,450 --> 00:08:29,950
>> This is why you need
a good project manager.

153
00:08:29,950 --> 00:08:31,060
So there we go.

154
00:08:31,060 --> 00:08:32,590
I'm gonna go under my resources and

155
00:08:32,590 --> 00:08:36,140
I'm just gonna create a couple of
people here on my resource sheet.

156
00:08:36,140 --> 00:08:40,800
So I'll create a, maybe there's
some kind of programming job.

157
00:08:40,800 --> 00:08:45,460
And so I've got Developer 1,
Developer 2, and Developer 3.

158
00:08:45,460 --> 00:08:48,130
So I've got three people
available to do work.

159
00:08:48,130 --> 00:08:52,120
And I'm just using my default resource
calendar, which is eight hours a day,

160
00:08:52,120 --> 00:08:54,010
Monday through Friday.

161
00:08:54,010 --> 00:08:57,670
When I go back to my task view here, and

162
00:08:57,670 --> 00:09:02,490
I take task 7, I left the duration in
estimate, so it's calculating that out.

163
00:09:02,490 --> 00:09:05,460
The work I set at 24 hours.

164
00:09:05,460 --> 00:09:08,920
And if I come in here and
I start to assign some resources, so

165
00:09:08,920 --> 00:09:13,453
I'm going to assign Developer 1, 2, and

166
00:09:13,453 --> 00:09:17,410
3, and I'm gonna assign those out.

167
00:09:17,410 --> 00:09:21,140
So now Developer 1, 2, and 3 are attached.

168
00:09:21,140 --> 00:09:26,517
Now that there's three people attached,
It's going to go and, see it didn't

169
00:09:26,517 --> 00:09:31,428
do the calculation, all right let's
see if we can't change this here.

170
00:09:33,563 --> 00:09:38,344
I am gonna put each one of them down for
eight hours of work, there we go,

171
00:09:38,344 --> 00:09:41,798
and I'm going to assign each of them for
just a day.

172
00:09:44,514 --> 00:09:45,540
Or is it calculating it?

173
00:09:45,540 --> 00:09:47,500
>> I think it's trying to calculate.

174
00:09:47,500 --> 00:09:48,780
>> All right, we'll give it a break.

175
00:09:48,780 --> 00:09:50,370
This is one of the difficulties we have.

176
00:09:50,370 --> 00:09:54,100
Project management software a lot of times
will do the calculations for you, and so

177
00:09:54,100 --> 00:09:56,950
it's trying to sort some things out for
me, and did it do it?

178
00:09:56,950 --> 00:09:58,060
Yeah, it did it, good.

179
00:09:58,060 --> 00:10:01,030
All right, so notice, now that I've
got the three people attached,

180
00:10:01,030 --> 00:10:03,270
see how the duration went down to one day?

181
00:10:03,270 --> 00:10:04,700
It went down to one day, and

182
00:10:04,700 --> 00:10:09,120
I can see that I've got three people
that are working eight hours each.

183
00:10:09,120 --> 00:10:13,540
And so now it's taking just three
days to get this thing done.

184
00:10:13,540 --> 00:10:18,450
Okay, but maybe I get a call from
the head office, or whatever, and

185
00:10:18,450 --> 00:10:23,780
they're like hey, you got three
employees working on this activity.

186
00:10:23,780 --> 00:10:25,560
We gotta get your budget down, all right.

187
00:10:25,560 --> 00:10:27,390
We can't give you three people like that.

188
00:10:27,390 --> 00:10:30,650
You're gonna think of going down to two,
or we need one for another project,

189
00:10:30,650 --> 00:10:34,840
or maybe we need one to go to some other
activity that's going on at the same time.

190
00:10:34,840 --> 00:10:38,420
So, I can take that person away and
then level

191
00:10:38,420 --> 00:10:42,340
out the resource allocation to accommodate
the employees that I've already got.

192
00:10:42,340 --> 00:10:45,770
And most software will do this
automatically if you just go in and

193
00:10:45,770 --> 00:10:48,010
remove one of the people.

194
00:10:48,010 --> 00:10:54,440
So if we go in and take Developer 3 and
remove them, now that they're gone,

195
00:10:54,440 --> 00:10:59,210
when I go back, now, now it's got me
at one and a half days for some reason.

196
00:10:59,210 --> 00:11:02,500
But if I pull up my resources,
I can see they're each working 12 hours.

197
00:11:02,500 --> 00:11:06,580
So it's a 24 hour project again but
being done in 12 hours.

198
00:11:06,580 --> 00:11:07,800
Oh, that's why it's one and a half days.

199
00:11:07,800 --> 00:11:11,190
So each of them are working eight
hours for that first day, and

200
00:11:11,190 --> 00:11:13,290
the second day,
each of them are working four hours.

201
00:11:13,290 --> 00:11:16,090
And so that's where we get
that kind of distribution.

202
00:11:17,360 --> 00:11:20,740
So by doing that,
this software is leveling for me.

203
00:11:21,960 --> 00:11:24,900
But sometimes,
we need non-standard leveling.

204
00:11:24,900 --> 00:11:29,750
People get this in their head that
leveling always means a nice flat line,

205
00:11:29,750 --> 00:11:31,380
but in project management, it doesn't.

206
00:11:31,380 --> 00:11:35,090
There's several different styles
of leveling that we can do, and

207
00:11:35,090 --> 00:11:37,395
if I pull that task back up.

208
00:11:37,395 --> 00:11:40,527
See how I've got Developer
1 working 12 hours, and

209
00:11:40,527 --> 00:11:42,715
they have a work contour that is flat.

00:11:43,765 --> 00:11:47,855
If I drop that down, you'll see several
different contours that are available, and

00:11:47,855 --> 00:11:50,115
this'll vary from software to software.

00:11:50,115 --> 00:11:51,581
I know Microsoft Project has a weird one.

They have turtle and different weird ones.

00:11:54,337 --> 00:11:57,452
But you'll see back-loaded.

00:11:57,452 --> 00:12:01,537
Back-loaded means they'll have very little
work the first part of the project, or

216
00:12:01,537 --> 00:12:05,080
part of the activity, and
they'll have a lot of work at the end.

217
00:12:05,080 --> 00:12:09,180
So you'll see, instead of going eight
hours day one and four hours day two.

00:12:09,180 --> 00:12:12,560
If I chose back-loaded, it would flip
it around, four hours on day one,

219
00:12:12,560 --> 00:12:14,860
eight hours on day two, back-loading it.

00:12:14,860 --> 00:12:18,880
Front-loaded is the default or whatever.

00:12:18,880 --> 00:12:22,040
We do all the work we as we can up front.

00:12:22,040 --> 00:12:25,580
Double peak, a lot of work in the
beginning, a little work in the middle,

00:12:25,580 --> 00:12:26,840
a lot of work at the end, right?

00:12:26,840 --> 00:12:28,640
So it creates a, what's that called?

00:12:28,640 --> 00:12:29,150
A parabola?

A parabolic curve, or something like that?

00:12:31,620 --> 00:12:32,880
>> Yep.
>> Early peak,

228
00:12:32,880 --> 00:12:36,520
means that you get a lot of work
right at the very, very beginning and

00:12:36,520 --> 00:12:37,790
then it tapers off.

230
00:12:37,790 --> 00:12:41,000
Late peak, you get a lot of work
right there at the very end.

231
00:12:41,000 --> 00:12:43,560
A bell,
all the work is done in the middle,

232
00:12:43,560 --> 00:12:46,060
it's valleys at the beginning and end.

233
00:12:46,060 --> 00:12:50,410
And a plateau, we spike up,
stay at that level, and drop down again.

00:13:38,110 --> 00:13:42,840

00:13:46,780 --> 00:13:47,310

So those are some of the ways that we can

253
00:13:55,480 --> 00:13:59,430
For the exam, we need to be aware
of what resource leveling is.

254
00:13:59,430 --> 00:14:03,910
Spreading their hours out over time
to fit the needs of what we've got to

255
00:14:03,910 --> 00:14:06,490
make sure that we don't go into
overtime and stuff like that.

256
00:14:06,490 --> 00:14:10,000
We don't want people exceeding eight hours
cuz our cost would go up if we do that.

257
00:14:10,000 --> 00:14:14,520
And the other option is some
project management software,

258
00:14:14,520 --> 00:14:20,050
not all, but some, will have
the ability to do resource leveling,

259
00:14:20,050 --> 00:14:22,940
and you'll see, oh,
is this one not gonna show it?

260
00:14:24,640 --> 00:14:28,690
Here we go, where we've got
a leveling delay, which is,

261
00:14:28,690 --> 00:14:30,710
we can have it where it
goes a flat model for

262
00:14:30,710 --> 00:14:35,420
a little while, and then applies the
leveling after a certain period of time.

263
00:14:35,420 --> 00:14:39,340
So you can set that leveling delay to
offset when that leveling kicks in.

264
00:14:39,340 --> 00:14:42,590
I don't normally use that
during the planning phase.

265
00:14:42,590 --> 00:14:43,580
You shouldn't need it.

266
00:14:43,580 --> 00:14:48,307
But, down the road, while you're in the
execution phase, things are moving along,

267
00:14:48,307 --> 00:14:51,222
you might already be partly
through an activity, and

268
00:14:51,222 --> 00:14:53,966
now you're trying to level
to sort out a problem.

269
00:14:53,966 --> 00:14:56,166
And that's where you'd need to
introduce a leveling delay,

270
00:14:56,166 --> 00:14:59,390
cuz you don't want to level something
that's already happened, it's too late.

271
00:14:59,390 --> 00:15:02,900
You only want to level things in
the future, so see you've got that.

00:15:02,900 --> 00:15:06,340
Microsoft Project actually has an auto
leveling feature that I absolutely

00:15:06,340 --> 00:15:08,820

00:15:08,820 --> 00:15:11,970

00:15:15,550 --> 00:15:17,830
You can just go in by hand and

So that's good, but at the end of the day,

00:15:44,180 --> 00:15:46,797
I've got a little bit
of extra time built in.

00:15:46,797 --> 00:15:51,850
And I would normally represent that by

286
00:15:51,850 --> 00:15:54,648
And, or actually, you know what?

00:15:54,648 --> 00:15:57,344
I just added resource.
I would add a task on called reserve,

00:15:57,344 --> 00:16:02,212
attach developer 1 and 2 to that reserve
and assign them two hours a day for

289
00:16:02,212 --> 00:16:07,560
that and that way I've clearly noted,
here's the reserve that I've got.

290
00:16:07,560 --> 00:16:11,150
And that'll prevent me from

00:16:11,150 --> 00:16:13,620
I forgot here, I'm actually

00:16:13,620 --> 00:16:15,500

00:16:16,870 --> 00:16:20,020
But yeah, those are some examples
of things that we can do there

294
00:16:21,930 --> 00:16:26,520
to try and get this stuff moving along,
get things put in.

295
00:16:26,520 --> 00:16:30,050
Doing it by hand,
If anything goes wrong, it's your fault.

But at least you know what happened,

00:16:31,600 --> 00:16:35,560
and you're not trusting

00:16:35,560 --> 00:16:39,070
So that's an example of how

00:16:39,070 --> 00:16:42,030
Now Resource Leveling was just one

00:16:42,030 --> 00:16:43,310

The other one was Resource Smoothing.

00:16:51,160 --> 00:16:55,080
spreading those activities over days to

So how is that any different

Well the difference here is with resource

within the free and total float, okay.

Every activity on that critical

Have it take a little bit longer and

That is a very real thing.

00:18:46,770 --> 00:18:51,180
When we do that, we just level

00:18:51,180 --> 00:18:53,800
that is called Resource smoothing.

00:18:53,800 --> 00:18:55,900
It's the same thing as Resource leveling,

00:18:55,900 --> 00:18:59,910
except it doesn't effect

Resource leveling almost always

00:19:04,510 --> 00:19:06,420

Typically, lengthening it.

But it's a direct effect on time.

00:19:12,512 --> 00:19:16,630
All right, so those are resource

00:19:40,680 --> 00:19:43,570

When you've got that kind of in place, you

If you're still in planning and you don't

That cuts out the overtime or adds time to

00:23:40,330 --> 00:23:42,580
So it's a two day purchase activity.

438
00:23:42,580 --> 00:23:43,924
Now it's a four day project.

439
00:23:43,924 --> 00:23:46,884
I would go out there on Friday,
buy the stuff.

440
00:23:46,884 --> 00:23:50,135
Stay in a hotel Saturday and Sunday and
then come back on Monday, oh,

441
00:23:50,135 --> 00:23:51,434
that's not so realistic.

442
00:23:51,434 --> 00:23:52,008
Listed.

443
00:23:52,008 --> 00:23:52,658
Maybe I just drive back.

444
00:23:52,658 --> 00:23:55,616
But you guys get the idea that
once you stretch over weekend,

445
00:23:55,616 --> 00:23:58,140
that may not be something that's possible.

446
00:23:58,140 --> 00:24:00,940
So it's important to do
these what if analysis, and

447
00:24:00,940 --> 00:24:04,760
if you're doing it in computer software in
a project management information system,

448
00:24:04,760 --> 00:24:08,200
PMIS, it becomes pretty easy to do.

449
00:24:08,200 --> 00:24:09,330
You just punch it in.

450
00:24:09,330 --> 00:24:10,970
Use your undo, right.

451
00:24:10,970 --> 00:24:15,070
Make sure you save your project before
you start doing this just in case

452
00:24:15,070 --> 00:24:17,920

you can't undo them for some reason,

453
00:24:17,920 --> 00:24:20,100
you can just go back to
your saved document.

454
00:24:20,100 --> 00:24:23,470
But it's a quick and
easy way to kind of analyze that.

455
00:24:23,470 --> 00:24:25,900
Yeah, what if scenarios
are really cool and

456
00:24:25,900 --> 00:24:28,450
definitely something
that you're going to do.

457
00:24:28,450 --> 00:24:31,090
Especially in planning, but
I do them in execution, too.

00:24:31,090 --> 00:24:35,130
You know, as I'd look ahead, I always
look at the various activities for

00:24:35,130 --> 00:24:37,610

460
00:24:37,610 --> 00:24:38,820
What if this one falls behind?

461
00:24:38,820 --> 00:24:40,220
What if this other one falls behind?

462
00:24:40,220 --> 00:24:42,660
What if two of these fall
behind at the same time?

463
00:24:42,660 --> 00:24:43,260
What am I gonna do?

464
00:24:43,260 --> 00:24:47,030
And I try and
formulate my I plan ahead of time.

465
00:24:47,030 --> 00:24:49,930
I plan for that so that I'm ready,
I'm not surprised.

466
00:24:49,930 --> 00:24:51,170
Oh I fell behind, great.

467
00:24:51,170 --> 00:24:52,000
I'm ready for that.

468
00:24:52,000 --> 00:24:53,440
Not, oh my gosh, I fell behind.

469
00:24:53,440 --> 00:24:54,260
What am I gonna do now?

470
00:24:54,260 --> 00:24:55,790
I gotta go find all my options.

471
00:24:55,790 --> 00:24:57,720
And you're running on a deadline and
you're under pressure.

472
00:24:57,720 --> 00:24:58,701
So, what if analysis,

473
00:24:58,701 --> 00:25:01,680
It's really as simple as that,
you come up with scenarios.

474
00:25:01,680 --> 00:25:04,210
What if event X happened?

475
00:25:04,210 --> 00:25:05,670
What if event Y happened?

476
00:25:05,670 --> 00:25:07,970
What if event X and
Y happened at the same time?

477
00:25:07,970 --> 00:25:10,990
What would I do, how would it effect the
schedule, how would it effect the project?

478
00:25:10,990 --> 00:25:12,830
So really simple to do.

And just go back and forth to kinda see

All right?

Some project management software even goes

00:28:37,520 --> 00:28:40,200
So I have Task 2 right here.

00:28:40,200 --> 00:28:43,650
And maybe I go in and I take Task 2.

00:28:43,650 --> 00:28:47,931
And maybe I'll call this Task 2

551
00:28:47,931 --> 00:28:52,809
optimistic.

552
00:28:52,809 --> 00:28:56,810
And then I'm going to make
a Task 2 pessimistic.

553
00:28:56,810 --> 00:29:05,622
Let's say insert That's not what I wanted.

554
00:29:07,584 --> 00:29:11,050
There, so
I'm gonna make a Task 2 pessimistic.

555
00:29:11,050 --> 00:29:11,630
Right?

556
00:29:11,630 --> 00:29:13,510
So on the optimistic side.

557
00:29:15,360 --> 00:29:16,000
Is it two esses?

558
00:29:18,550 --> 00:29:20,620
>> Yes.
>> [LAUGH] Oh, my spelling abilities.

So the duration is three
days in the optimistic one.

560
00:29:22,780 --> 00:29:25,280
I'm gonna set it to six days

00:29:25,280 --> 00:29:28,360
All right, so there's my two,
and let me just go over here and

00:29:28,360 --> 00:29:31,980
update my predecessors to
make sure this is all even.

563
00:29:31,980 --> 00:29:38,060
All right, so these guys are both preceded

00:29:38,060 --> 00:29:39,020
All right.

565
00:29:39,020 --> 00:29:42,180
So now, I've got two different
versions of the same task, and

566
00:29:42,180 --> 00:29:46,580
if I look over here on my Gantt chart,

567
00:29:46,580 --> 00:29:50,280
And then it's gonna go into one

00:29:50,280 --> 00:29:52,260
And then when task 2 is done,

then it's gonna go to its milestone

And in Microsoft Project, it is

You have this inactivate button.

573

And so I can take task 2 optimistic and

574

Now I can see what my project looks
like in the pessimistic view.

575
00:30:18,630 --> 00:30:23,730
And then I can reactivate it, and
I can inactivate the pessimistic one,

576
00:30:23,730 --> 00:30:27,510
and now I see what my project
looks like in the optimistic view.

577
00:30:27,510 --> 00:30:31,950
And so you can build those one if
scenarios in, and leave them there, so

578
00:30:31,950 --> 00:30:35,060
throughout the life of your project you
can come back and turn this on and off,

579
00:30:35,060 --> 00:30:39,250
and just kind of see how things go
this ability to turn activities on and

580
00:30:39,250 --> 00:30:42,560
off is really nice, but
it is a function of the software.

581
00:30:42,560 --> 00:30:45,670
So I'm not showing it here for
you guys to know, oh,

582
00:30:45,670 --> 00:30:48,450
here's how I use Microsoft Project,
cuz you might not use it at all, and

583
00:30:48,450 --> 00:30:52,685
on the exam, there is no
specific software package used.

584
00:30:52,685 --> 00:30:56,230
[LAUGH] I'll tell you, almost all the
screenshots are from Microsoft Project,

585
00:30:56,230 --> 00:30:57,710
but that doesn't mean you're gonna use.

586
00:30:57,710 --> 00:31:00,990
You don't have to know how to use
any project management software.

587
00:31:00,990 --> 00:31:03,230
The important part here is the concept.

588
00:31:03,230 --> 00:31:06,750
A what if scenarios is where we
bounce some ideas off of our project.

589
00:31:06,750 --> 00:31:08,360
What if this happens?

590
00:31:08,360 --> 00:31:11,510
What if that's a six day activity
instead of a three day activity?

591
00:31:11,510 --> 00:31:12,860
Well, I can find out.

592
00:31:12,860 --> 00:31:14,780
If I inactivate the three day activity.

593
00:31:14,780 --> 00:31:16,690
It's not going to be
happy about that is it.

594
00:31:16,690 --> 00:31:19,920
And then I activate the six day activity,

595
00:31:19,920 --> 00:31:22,110
now I can see here's what
it's going to be like.

596
00:31:22,110 --> 00:31:24,380
Here's when these other
activities are gonna happen,

597
00:31:24,380 --> 00:31:27,340
when they're going to fall on and
when that finish date is.

598
00:31:27,340 --> 00:31:29,960
So now, I can see that I'm
gonna finish on October 1st.

599
00:31:30,990 --> 00:31:35,944
But if things go the right way,
and we finish this way,

600
00:31:35,944 --> 00:31:38,758
we'll finish on, what is it?

601
00:31:38,758 --> 00:31:39,948
September 26th, right?

602
00:31:39,948 --> 00:31:44,197
So now, I can kinda get an idea,
see that, and figure out what's what.

603
00:31:44,197 --> 00:31:47,656
All right, so
those are what if scenarios and

604
00:31:47,656 --> 00:31:51,090
that was our kind of chance to see those.

605
00:31:51,090 --> 00:31:53,738
Really pretty straight forward, right.

606
00:31:53,738 --> 00:31:57,880
You can get really crazy
scientific on this stuff.

607
00:31:57,880 --> 00:32:00,570
What if scenarios are really
not crazy science?

608
00:32:00,570 --> 00:32:05,070
It's just come up with possibilities,
see how they affect your calendar.

609
00:32:05,070 --> 00:32:09,100
There is something called
a Monte Carlo simulation.

610
00:32:09,100 --> 00:32:11,320
And a Monte Carlo simulation
,is where we try and

611
00:32:11,320 --> 00:32:17,190
create a more statistically accurate
average of what's going to happen.

612
00:32:19,060 --> 00:32:20,710
If you took statistics in college,

613
00:32:20,710 --> 00:32:23,840
then you've probably dealt
with Monte Carlo simulations.

614
00:32:23,840 --> 00:32:25,990
But in real life,
we don't see them that much,

615
00:32:25,990 --> 00:32:29,540
because they're terrible inefficient,
kind of a pain in the butt to make.

616
00:32:29,540 --> 00:32:32,440
Basically what you do
is you create a chart.

617
00:32:32,440 --> 00:32:37,110
And you chart what you are expecting
to happen, so what you're estimate is.

618
00:32:37,110 --> 00:32:38,276
And so you map out, you know,

619
00:32:38,276 --> 00:32:40,960
how much work is expected to be done
on these particular time lines.

620
00:32:42,150 --> 00:32:45,370
And then you just start
throwing out possibilities.

621
00:32:45,370 --> 00:32:46,240
What could happen?

622
00:32:46,240 --> 00:32:47,520
This could happen, that could happen,

623
00:32:47,520 --> 00:32:49,190
you're just throwing
out dots on that chart.

624
00:32:49,190 --> 00:32:51,330
Basically you just scatter them along.

625
00:32:51,330 --> 00:32:54,110
The more dots you have, the more
accurate your numbers are going to be.

626
00:32:54,110 --> 00:32:57,880
Because at the end of the day, after you
have plotted all the possible outcomes,

627
00:32:57,880 --> 00:33:01,740
you average them together, and
hopefully they equal your estimate.

628
00:33:01,740 --> 00:33:05,060
But if they don't ,you adjust your
estimate to equal the average of these

629
00:33:05,060 --> 00:33:05,650
possibilities.

630
00:33:05,650 --> 00:33:08,700
So the nice thing about a Monte Carlo is,

631
00:33:08,700 --> 00:33:13,250
that it makes it easy to
combine more than one estimate.

632
00:33:13,250 --> 00:33:16,400
So if you have 50 different estimates,
50 different possibilities for

633
00:33:16,400 --> 00:33:20,670
the outcome of an activity, you can plot
them all out and average them together.

634
00:33:20,670 --> 00:33:23,845
Versus something like a what if scenario,
which is really just two possibilities.

635
00:33:23,845 --> 00:33:25,780
Right?
What if it happens this way?

636
00:33:25,780 --> 00:33:26,570
Or this way.

637
00:33:26,570 --> 00:33:28,730
If you start bringing in three or
four elements into that,

638
00:33:28,730 --> 00:33:33,850
the what-if scenarios become really
difficult to manage, all right.

639
00:33:33,850 --> 00:33:38,176
Monte Carlos are not something
that I use very frequently, but

640
00:33:38,176 --> 00:33:43,005
let me see if I can find you guys
an example of a Monte Carlo simulation.

641
00:33:44,213 --> 00:33:46,671
Let's see if we can't
just find something here.

642
00:33:46,671 --> 00:33:48,588
That's a nice one.

643
00:33:48,588 --> 00:33:53,100
[LAUGH] Well, yes, these aren't.

644
00:33:53,100 --> 00:33:55,450
They're terribly difficult to interpret.

645
00:33:55,450 --> 00:33:57,760
All right, this is a good one right here.

646
00:33:57,760 --> 00:33:59,860
So yeah.
So this is from contiuum.io.

647
00:33:59,860 --> 00:34:02,320
I'm not familiar with that website.

648
00:34:02,320 --> 00:34:06,940
But basically they've plotted several
paths of a particular value of an asset.

649
00:34:06,940 --> 00:34:08,875
So, something is happening.

650
00:34:08,875 --> 00:34:12,045
And it's got a dollar
value attached to time.

651
00:34:12,045 --> 00:34:15,875
And so over time,
the cost of this element is increasing.

652
00:34:15,875 --> 00:34:19,725
And they've plotted,
it looks like a good 20,

653
00:34:19,725 --> 00:34:23,870
maybe 30 different scenarios for it, so
you see all these different colors, and

654
00:34:23,870 --> 00:34:29,950
each one representing a slightly different
outcome based on some analysis, right?

655
00:34:29,950 --> 00:34:34,400
So you chart 'em out like this, and then
you average them together, and you'll see

656
00:34:34,400 --> 00:34:37,810
that, just visually you can just see,
where that average is going to be.

657
00:34:37,810 --> 00:34:39,130
And you act upon that average.

658
00:34:39,130 --> 00:34:41,440
So that's what a Monte Carlo
simulation is.

659
00:34:41,440 --> 00:34:43,170
They're very time consuming.

660
00:34:43,170 --> 00:34:45,230
They require a lot of data.

661
00:34:45,230 --> 00:34:48,500
But when you need the best estimate
possible for planning out a schedule, or

662
00:34:48,500 --> 00:34:52,140
cost, or budget, or whatever,
Monte Carlo scenarios are good for that.

663
00:34:52,140 --> 00:34:55,950
So you'll see these in
big dollar projects.

664
00:34:55,950 --> 00:34:59,460
Projects that are built around,
especially built around sciences.

665
00:34:59,460 --> 00:35:03,010
Like the space community,
when they are sending a rocket into space,

666
00:35:03,010 --> 00:35:05,450
whatever, they'll do these because
they're very, very effective.

667
00:35:05,450 --> 00:35:06,710
But if you're building a house,

668
00:35:06,710 --> 00:35:09,810
there's really not that many
scenarios that you have to deal with.

669
00:35:09,810 --> 00:35:11,870
People show up for work, or
they don't show up for work.

670
00:35:11,870 --> 00:35:13,330
They put up a wall, or
they don't put a wall.

671
00:35:13,330 --> 00:35:17,503
Right, so it's not like you've got
radiation levels, and launch windows, and

672
00:35:17,503 --> 00:35:21,210
all that stuff, that can affect
when that rocket's going up.

673
00:35:21,210 --> 00:35:23,980
So if you're not dealing
with a huge variable set,

674
00:35:23,980 --> 00:35:26,410
Monte Carlo's scenario's gonna
often be a waste of time.

675
00:35:26,410 --> 00:35:30,650
But if you have a large variable set,
these are kinda the only option right?

676
00:35:30,650 --> 00:35:34,020
This allows us to chart all that out, and
find out what that average is going to be.

677
00:35:34,020 --> 00:35:38,460
And not just do it at one point, but do
it throughout the life of that activity.

678
00:35:38,460 --> 00:35:44,350
Here doing time and cost,
which is probably the most common.

679
00:35:44,350 --> 00:35:46,365
I'm not familiar with that website,
let's see what they do.

680
00:35:46,365 --> 00:35:52,637
What does continuim.io do?

681
00:35:52,637 --> 00:35:55,150
I like to give credit
to where credit's due.

682
00:35:55,150 --> 00:35:56,230
Oh, they're an analytics company.

683
00:35:56,230 --> 00:35:57,590
That makes sense.

684
00:35:57,590 --> 00:36:01,060
These guys make their money
doing this kind of thing.

685
00:36:01,060 --> 00:36:02,240
Look's like they do web services.

686
00:36:02,240 --> 00:36:05,420
Anaconda is a web platform.

687
00:36:05,420 --> 00:36:08,605
And so they probably take a look
at software packages, and

688
00:36:08,605 --> 00:36:13,160
look at the response time, and maintenance
costs, and support values over time.

689
00:36:13,160 --> 00:36:14,520
So they specialize in it.

690
00:36:14,520 --> 00:36:16,700
It makes perfect sense,
that they would deal with that.

691
00:36:16,700 --> 00:36:20,010
Because there's so many different
scenarios that affect web servers.

692
00:36:21,215 --> 00:36:22,475
All right, cool.

693
00:36:22,475 --> 00:36:23,775
I'm glad they served that picture up.

694
00:36:24,815 --> 00:36:27,125
All right, so
that's a Monte Carlo analysis.

695
00:36:27,125 --> 00:36:30,365
It's basically just a very
advanced what-if scenario.

696
00:36:30,365 --> 00:36:33,309
Tons of different models,
all being averaged together.

697
00:36:34,860 --> 00:36:38,380
All right, we had a few last
concepts to throw in here.

698
00:36:38,380 --> 00:36:40,330
Leads and lags we already talked about.

699
00:36:40,330 --> 00:36:45,233
As far as, you know, we may need to
attach a delay, or a lead, or whatever,

700
00:36:45,233 --> 00:36:46,570
to an activity.

701
00:36:46,570 --> 00:36:49,570
The example I gave was it last episode,
or the episode before,

702
00:36:49,570 --> 00:36:50,880
they all kind of blend together.

703
00:36:50,880 --> 00:36:55,930
Was, if I've got an activity that says,
receive 400 computers, and

704
00:36:55,930 --> 00:36:59,630
then unbox 400 computers, and
then set up 400 computers.

705
00:36:59,630 --> 00:37:02,940
Then, I don't have to wait for
all 400 computers to be unboxed,

706
00:37:02,940 --> 00:37:04,660
before I can set up the first one.

707
00:37:04,660 --> 00:37:09,360
In fact, if they just unboxed 100 of them,
we can get started setting up those

708
00:37:09,360 --> 00:37:13,000
hundred, while they're
unboxing the other ones.

709
00:37:13,000 --> 00:37:18,780
The key thing to remember, is that
lead time is when we can start early,

710
00:37:18,780 --> 00:37:21,900
lag time is when we have to start late,
right.

711
00:37:21,900 --> 00:37:23,500
There's a delay for some reason.

712
00:37:23,500 --> 00:37:26,830
But most project management software
represents them the same way.

713
00:37:26,830 --> 00:37:29,810
And I did it in, I think I did it
in Gantt Project the other day,

714
00:37:29,810 --> 00:37:32,940
which just had one value,
which I believe was called delay.

715
00:37:32,940 --> 00:37:36,080
Different project management
software is well, different.

716
00:37:36,080 --> 00:37:41,964
So if I jump over to Microsoft project,
that was different, there we go.

717
00:37:41,964 --> 00:37:44,588
My little transition
was kind of slow there.

718
00:37:44,588 --> 00:37:48,873
That we can come in here, and
take a look and say like,

719
00:37:48,873 --> 00:37:55,088
receive 400 computers, which I will
set to be like a four-day activity.

720
00:37:55,088 --> 00:37:55,713
Actually you know what?

721
00:37:55,713 --> 00:37:56,275
We'll say one day.

722
00:37:56,275 --> 00:37:58,845
Maybe they just all show
up on the same day.

723
00:37:58,845 --> 00:38:02,480
And then unbox 400 computers.

724
00:38:02,480 --> 00:38:04,620
And we'll say that's a four day activity.

725
00:38:04,620 --> 00:38:07,410
So we're basically unboxing
a hundred computers a day, and

726
00:38:07,410 --> 00:38:12,360
then we'll set up 400 computers, and
we'll say that that's a ten day activity.

727
00:38:13,810 --> 00:38:15,830
I'm just gonna link these guys together.

728
00:38:17,840 --> 00:38:18,850
There we go.

729
00:38:18,850 --> 00:38:24,310
So there's my layout as
it stands right now.

730
00:38:24,310 --> 00:38:26,020
These are finish to start relationships.

731
00:38:26,020 --> 00:38:27,760
One finishes, the next starts.

732
00:38:27,760 --> 00:38:30,870
But if I'm saying hey, 400 computers.

733
00:38:30,870 --> 00:38:32,800
After the get the first hundred unboxed,
so

734
00:38:32,800 --> 00:38:35,500
after the first day, the other
guys can go ahead and get started.

735
00:38:35,500 --> 00:38:36,620
They don't have to wait.

736
00:38:36,620 --> 00:38:42,350
So I can go in, and I can take this
activity, and I can set a lead time on it.

737
00:38:42,350 --> 00:38:46,590
When I pull up that activity,
no its bar, but the activity itself.

738
00:38:46,590 --> 00:38:47,650
There we go.

739
00:38:47,650 --> 00:38:52,110
When we go to set it up, you'll see in
here when we go to like predecessors,

740
00:38:52,110 --> 00:38:54,570
here it depends on unbox 400 computers.

741
00:38:54,570 --> 00:38:55,770
It's finish to start.

742
00:38:55,770 --> 00:38:57,820
And it's got zero days of lag.

743
00:38:57,820 --> 00:39:01,970
So Gantt Project called it delay,
Microsoft calls it lag.

744
00:39:01,970 --> 00:39:05,060
On the exam, it's lag and lead.

745
00:39:05,060 --> 00:39:08,770
But in Microsoft,
a lead time is simply a negative lag, so

746
00:39:08,770 --> 00:39:13,070
if I set it to a negative three days, that
means I can get started three days early.

747
00:39:13,070 --> 00:39:18,070
And when I say, okay, you'll see
we get one solid day of unboxing.

748
00:39:18,070 --> 00:39:20,240
And then the next activity starts.

749
00:39:20,240 --> 00:39:21,780
So that's lead time.

750
00:39:21,780 --> 00:39:25,610
We can get started early, and
that shortens the length of our project.

751
00:39:27,190 --> 00:39:31,080
The opposite of that, you know,
we've got building a house.

752
00:39:31,080 --> 00:39:35,990
Pour foundation, and then frame the walls.

753
00:39:35,990 --> 00:39:36,670
Right?

754
00:39:36,670 --> 00:39:38,237
So we pour the foundation to the house.

755
00:39:38,237 --> 00:39:40,338
Once that's done,
then we stick the walls up.

756
00:39:40,338 --> 00:39:43,073
Well, the walls can't go up
until the foundation is done, so

757
00:39:43,073 --> 00:39:44,294
that's a finish to start.

758
00:39:44,294 --> 00:39:48,554
And I'll say that you know, it's just
going to take one day to pour that

759
00:39:48,554 --> 00:39:53,108
foundation but it's gonna take five
days to frame up the walls, all right.

760
00:39:53,108 --> 00:39:56,495
But they pour the foundation and
then it's gotta dry.

761
00:39:56,495 --> 00:39:59,820
We've gotta leave three
days of lag time for

762
00:39:59,820 --> 00:40:02,730
it to dry before people get in there and
put up the wall.

763
00:40:02,730 --> 00:40:05,240
So I just go right back
into frame up the walls.

764
00:40:05,240 --> 00:40:09,116
And this time for that lag,
it's going to be a positive value,

765
00:40:09,116 --> 00:40:11,900
three days of lag time.

766
00:40:11,900 --> 00:40:15,060
And here, the opposite of this one
where I got started three days early,

767
00:40:15,060 --> 00:40:18,380
now I'm waiting three days, and
this one included the weekend.

768
00:40:18,380 --> 00:40:19,950
I need to pay attention to that, right?

769
00:40:19,950 --> 00:40:21,970
Because if the weekend counts for
the dry time,

770
00:40:21,970 --> 00:40:24,180
do I actually need three days of lag?

771
00:40:24,180 --> 00:40:28,430
No, I can get started on Monday cuz
technically this is five days of lag.

772
00:40:28,430 --> 00:40:32,740
So we do have to pay attention to that as
we plan out why we've got that lag time.

773
00:40:32,740 --> 00:40:35,950
It might be something like we place
an order and we're waiting to receive it.

774
00:40:35,950 --> 00:40:39,870
Our estimated ship time is
six to ten business days, so

775
00:40:39,870 --> 00:40:44,210
I might put a lag time of ten days
to allow for that shipping to occur.

776
00:40:44,210 --> 00:40:47,450
Whatever it is,
it's just the opposite of a lead time.

777
00:40:48,600 --> 00:40:52,100
So those are pretty straightforward,
lag and lead time.

778
00:40:52,100 --> 00:40:56,350
All right, now,
how can we use that to our advantage?

779
00:40:56,350 --> 00:41:00,860
Well, lead time is something
that people often overlook.

780
00:41:00,860 --> 00:41:03,875
When we come up with our project schedule,
when we're doing the sequencing of

781
00:41:03,875 --> 00:41:08,165
activities, we're not really thinking
about getting things started early.

782
00:41:08,165 --> 00:41:10,425
We're just trying to plan
out the relationships.

783
00:41:10,425 --> 00:41:13,250
So when we did our project
schedule network diagram,

784
00:41:13,250 --> 00:41:15,895
when we did our sequencing
of activities process and

785
00:41:15,895 --> 00:41:20,070
all of that, we probably
haven't optimized our schedule.

786
00:41:20,070 --> 00:41:22,920
And that's the last part,
really, of planning for

787
00:41:22,920 --> 00:41:25,340
the schedule side of things,
is to go through and

788
00:41:25,340 --> 00:41:30,890
see how we can optimize our schedule
to get it as efficient as possible.

789
00:41:30,890 --> 00:41:33,330
And for that we've got a couple
of other little tools.

790
00:41:33,330 --> 00:41:36,650
But before I move on to that, have I
left anything out on lag and lead time?

791
00:41:36,650 --> 00:41:37,460
>> I don't think so.

792
00:41:37,460 --> 00:41:38,110
>> Okay.

793
00:41:38,110 --> 00:41:42,490
Just be aware on the exam,
it will be called lag time for

794
00:41:42,490 --> 00:41:45,570
a delay, lead time for
getting started early.

795
00:41:45,570 --> 00:41:50,045
Even though your project management
software probably only uses one term,

796
00:41:50,045 --> 00:41:52,445
on the exam you'll see two separate terms.

797
00:41:52,445 --> 00:41:57,305
So you really won't see a negative lag
time on the exam like you would in your

798
00:41:57,305 --> 00:41:58,087
software.

799
00:41:58,087 --> 00:42:03,101
All right, so
let's talk about optimizing our schedule.

800
00:42:03,101 --> 00:42:07,762
When we talk about optimizing the
schedule, we're trying to get our schedule

801
00:42:07,762 --> 00:42:12,209
as short as possible, so that we can
either finish as early as possible or,

802
00:42:12,209 --> 00:42:14,256
if we're working for a deadline,

803
00:42:14,256 --> 00:42:18,948
then we can leave as much space as
possible to ensure that we're successful.

804
00:42:18,948 --> 00:42:22,788
So we want things to take
as little time as possible.

805
00:42:22,788 --> 00:42:26,984
The way we do that is through
a technique called schedule compression.

806
00:42:26,984 --> 00:42:29,344
And schedule compression takes two forms.

807
00:42:29,344 --> 00:42:31,454
There's crashing and fast tracking.

808
00:42:32,634 --> 00:42:37,964
Crashing is where we look at our schedule
and we say, okay, here's my schedule.

809
00:42:37,964 --> 00:42:41,262
This project is going to take six months.

810
00:42:41,262 --> 00:42:44,102
But I get a call from the higher-ups and
they say,

811
00:42:44,102 --> 00:42:48,422
look, I know the project's up to six
months, but can we get it done in five?

812
00:42:48,422 --> 00:42:50,912
If we can get it done in five months,
there's a trade show.

813
00:42:50,912 --> 00:42:53,130
We want to announce our product.

814
00:42:53,130 --> 00:42:54,460
We really want to get that ball rolling.

815
00:42:54,460 --> 00:42:55,160
Can you get it done in five?

816
00:42:56,510 --> 00:42:58,790
And you look at your calendar and
you say, you know what?

817
00:42:58,790 --> 00:42:59,685
I'm sorry, guys.

818
00:42:59,685 --> 00:43:00,601
I didn't lie.

819
00:43:00,601 --> 00:43:01,810
I didn't pad my numbers.

820
00:43:01,810 --> 00:43:03,110
These are legitimate numbers.

821
00:43:03,110 --> 00:43:05,180
This project is gonna take six months.

822
00:43:05,180 --> 00:43:06,203
And they say, well, what can we do?

823
00:43:06,203 --> 00:43:09,270
What can we do to get
it down to five months?

824
00:43:09,270 --> 00:43:13,095
Well, there's one answer, and
that's throw money at it.

825
00:43:13,095 --> 00:43:14,220
That's what I always tell them.

826
00:43:14,220 --> 00:43:15,650
Throwing money at the problem.

827
00:43:15,650 --> 00:43:19,192
You can throw money at almost
any problem and solve it.

828
00:43:19,192 --> 00:43:23,120
[LAUGH] I know that's a jaded,
negative thing to say, but

829
00:43:23,120 --> 00:43:25,160
in the world of project management-
>> It's true.

830
00:43:25,160 --> 00:43:28,695
>> It is true,
you can fix anything with money so

831
00:43:28,695 --> 00:43:31,832
[LAUGH] just look at the US government.

832
00:43:31,832 --> 00:43:35,320
[LAUGH] So if we want to get it
done in five months, you say, well,

833
00:43:35,320 --> 00:43:36,570
here's the deal, guys.

834
00:43:36,570 --> 00:43:42,320
If I had twice as many employees or
if I could approve overtime.

835
00:43:42,320 --> 00:43:46,005
Or I've only got one payloader,
and if I had two payloaders or

836
00:43:46,005 --> 00:43:49,925
seven dump trucks instead of three dump
trucks, I can get us done in five months.

837
00:43:49,925 --> 00:43:51,655
It's going to cost you guys money,
but we can get it done.

838
00:43:52,865 --> 00:43:55,845
And if the sponsor or whoever it is,

839
00:43:55,845 --> 00:43:59,445
that approving authority,
if they look at it and say, you know what?

840
00:43:59,445 --> 00:44:01,925
It's worth it, let's do it.

841
00:44:01,925 --> 00:44:03,150
That's a change to your project.

842
00:44:03,150 --> 00:44:11,860
That is a change to your
project constraints.

843
00:44:11,860 --> 00:44:14,500
They want to get it done early,
so what do they do?

844
00:44:14,500 --> 00:44:20,250
They come in and they tell you, our new
schedule time is going to be shorter,

845
00:44:20,250 --> 00:44:23,780
and to compensate for that,
our budget cost is gonna go up.

846
00:44:23,780 --> 00:44:25,630
We're okay with that cuz
we wanna get done faster.

847
00:44:26,690 --> 00:44:28,839
That is schedule crashing.

848
00:44:30,140 --> 00:44:33,800
It's typically the result of
the sponsor changing their mind.

849
00:44:34,880 --> 00:44:40,670
They decide that they want more
requirements done in the same amount of

850
00:44:40,670 --> 00:44:43,640
time, or they decide that they want
the same amount of requirements done

851
00:44:43,640 --> 00:44:45,340
in a shorter amount of time.

852
00:44:45,340 --> 00:44:48,790
And the only way we can adjust for
that is budget and cost.

853
00:44:48,790 --> 00:44:51,650
There are some times they say,
can we get it done in five months?

854
00:44:51,650 --> 00:44:54,550
And to do that we'll cut
off some requirements.

855
00:44:54,550 --> 00:44:56,300
Remember these three are linked.

856
00:44:56,300 --> 00:45:00,190
So to make one better,
to lower our budget or lower our schedule,

857
00:45:00,190 --> 00:45:01,762
we're going to have to cut requirements.

858
00:45:01,762 --> 00:45:04,470
And it kind of works all
throughout that linked triangle.

859
00:45:04,470 --> 00:45:07,265
So when they come in and and they say,
we want it to get done faster,

860
00:45:07,265 --> 00:45:12,860
the easiest solution is typically to throw
money at the problem, increase our budget.

861
00:45:12,860 --> 00:45:16,160
We can get more people, get more
resources, get things done faster.

862
00:45:16,160 --> 00:45:21,940
So that's the premise behind schedule
crashing and you'll see the official PMI

863
00:45:23,540 --> 00:45:28,840
definition to approve overtime, to pay
extra to get people to work more, bring

864
00:45:28,840 --> 00:45:33,100
in additional resources, more employees,
and paying to expedite delivery.

865
00:45:33,100 --> 00:45:37,550
These are things that we can
do to shorten that schedule.

866
00:45:37,550 --> 00:45:41,464
>> On this particular definition, remember
that when you start doing the idea of this

867
00:45:41,464 --> 00:45:46,810
crashing for us here, you're always
gonna do it along the critical path.

868
00:45:46,810 --> 00:45:49,920
Because doing it along those areas which
are not on the critical path are really

869
00:45:49,920 --> 00:45:51,840
not gonna shorten the duration here, so

870
00:45:51,840 --> 00:45:54,720
make sure you do it along the critical
path as you crash the plan.

871
00:45:54,720 --> 00:45:55,461
>> Yeah, great point.

872
00:45:55,461 --> 00:45:58,710
[LAUGH] If you crash an activity
that's outside of it what do you get?

873
00:45:58,710 --> 00:45:59,880
More flow time, you know?

874
00:45:59,880 --> 00:46:01,800
So you really don't achieve anything.

875
00:46:01,800 --> 00:46:05,340
It would be critical path, and
that highlights another danger.

876
00:46:05,340 --> 00:46:08,590
If you start crashing the critical
path and shortening the critical path,

877
00:46:08,590 --> 00:46:09,820
what can happen?

878
00:46:09,820 --> 00:46:12,330
A new critical path could emerge, right?

879
00:46:12,330 --> 00:46:14,500
>> Yeah.
>> That is not an uncommon thing.

880
00:46:14,500 --> 00:46:18,265
So as you start manipulating things,
as you start shrinking that project down,

881
00:46:18,265 --> 00:46:22,380
your critical path might change, and
we definitely have to be aware of that.

882
00:46:22,380 --> 00:46:24,100
I wonder if I could
simulate that real quick.

883
00:46:24,100 --> 00:46:28,458
I could probably whip something up in
Project pretty quick, but as I said,

884
00:46:28,458 --> 00:46:32,347
as you shorten one path,
another path may become the new long one.

885
00:46:32,347 --> 00:46:34,647
That's where project software
management software is really handy,

886
00:46:34,647 --> 00:46:35,728
cuz you'll see that right away.

887
00:46:35,728 --> 00:46:39,483
But if you're calculating CPM by hand,
you're gonna have to go through and

888
00:46:39,483 --> 00:46:41,135
calculate it with every change.

889
00:46:41,135 --> 00:46:42,215
It's very time consuming.

890
00:46:43,315 --> 00:46:44,690
So just keep that in mind.

891
00:46:44,690 --> 00:46:48,510
Very useful technique, though,
if you've got where somebody's willing to

892
00:46:48,510 --> 00:46:52,400
cutback on their requirements or
they're willing to increase your budget,

893
00:46:52,400 --> 00:46:57,040
then you can absolutely
shorten time in that scenario.

894
00:46:57,040 --> 00:46:59,112
Another scenario is what's
called fast-tracking.

895
00:46:59,112 --> 00:47:01,430
Now fast-tracking's
a little bit different,

896
00:47:01,430 --> 00:47:04,490
because with fast-tracking I'm not
really throwing money at the problem.

897
00:47:04,490 --> 00:47:07,750
I'm not diving in there and
dropping requirements.

1350

They don't just say,
here's 800 grand, good luck.

1351
01:10:43,480 --> 01:10:47,318
They say okay,
your first disbursement is $200,000.

1352
01:10:47,318 --> 01:10:49,889
And when you show us
you've done this work,

1353
01:10:49,889 --> 01:10:53,935
you'll get your second
disbursement of $200,000 or so on.

1354
01:10:53,935 --> 01:10:56,745
And so they'll have scheduled
disbursements based on

1355
01:10:56,745 --> 01:10:58,033
the work that gets done.

1356
01:10:58,033 --> 01:11:01,702
And in that case, your budget is
working around these disbursements.

1357
01:11:01,702 --> 01:11:04,510
You can't do work unless
you have the money.

1358
01:11:04,510 --> 01:11:06,975
And so cost starts to affect the schedule.

1359
01:11:06,975 --> 01:11:08,050
So we may see that.

1360
01:11:08,050 --> 01:11:09,730
Not every project has that.

1361
01:11:09,730 --> 01:11:12,760
The reason banks do it is
if you don't do the work,

1362
01:11:12,760 --> 01:11:15,860
the bank has to seize the property and
sell it, and they can only sell it for

1363
01:11:15,860 --> 01:11:17,770
the value of what's been done to it.

1364
01:11:17,770 --> 01:11:18,890
If you haven't done any work but

1365
01:11:18,890 --> 01:11:21,990
they gave you the full amount,
they're left holding the bag.

1366
01:11:21,990 --> 01:11:24,840
So that's the reason you see that.

1367
01:11:24,840 --> 01:11:27,899
Different industries have different
requirements, so just be aware,

1368
01:11:27,899 --> 01:11:29,964
you've gotta adapt this for
your environment.

1369
01:11:29,964 --> 01:11:34,153
All right, let me just check the notes,
make sure I didn't leave anything out, but

1370
01:11:34,153 --> 01:11:35,748
I think that's pretty much it.

1371
01:11:35,748 --> 01:11:39,041
Oh Ronnie,
you got a few extra things in here,

1372
01:11:39,041 --> 01:11:43,950
like as we generate that schedule data,
what, no I mentioned that.

1373
01:11:43,950 --> 01:11:46,910
Resources, we might do a histogram,
a bar graph.

1374
01:11:46,910 --> 01:11:51,040
I showed that earlier like the resource
utilization screens in project.

1375
01:11:51,040 --> 01:11:55,490
Where it does the bar charts to show
how busy people are on different days.

1376
01:11:55,490 --> 01:11:59,990
We might have alternative schedules,
right, if we're doing what if scenarios.

1377
01:11:59,990 --> 01:12:02,370
I don't normally print those out,
I keep them for my own benefit.

1378
01:12:02,370 --> 01:12:05,625
But you might have several of
those that are output also.

1379
01:12:05,625 --> 01:12:09,580
And any contingency reserves,
I say you should go ahead and

1380
01:12:09,580 --> 01:12:11,110
clearly denote those in the project.

1381
01:12:11,110 --> 01:12:13,070
So you don't need a separate document for
it, but

1382
01:12:13,070 --> 01:12:14,996
that is another thing
that might be output.

1383
01:12:14,996 --> 01:12:15,710
>> Right.

1384
01:12:15,710 --> 01:12:18,900
>> After that yeah,
it's just the resources we need and

1385
01:12:18,900 --> 01:12:20,360
the calendars we're tracking.

1386
01:12:20,360 --> 01:12:24,360
The risk register might be a part of that
because part of your risk is falling

1387
01:12:24,360 --> 01:12:25,230
behind schedule.

1388
01:12:25,230 --> 01:12:27,700
So here's things that
could affect the schedule.

1389
01:12:27,700 --> 01:12:30,760
Again, something that we
prepare in the risk phase and

1390
01:12:30,760 --> 01:12:34,370
we'll see that, I mean not the risk
phase but the risk process group.

1391
01:12:34,370 --> 01:12:35,750
And so we'll see that a little later, too.

1392
01:12:37,430 --> 01:12:39,520
All right, Ronnie, can you think of
anything else that we have left out?

1393
01:12:39,520 --> 01:12:42,589
>> I don't think so, I think
everything is pretty good in coverage.

1394
01:12:42,589 --> 01:12:43,647
>> Excellent.

1395
01:12:43,647 --> 01:12:44,168
All right.

1396
01:12:44,168 --> 01:12:45,207
Well with that,

1397
01:12:45,207 --> 01:12:49,821
we have now completed what is arguably
the longest of the process groups.

1398
01:12:49,821 --> 01:12:53,372
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> Let me go back to our PMBOK here.

1399
01:12:53,372 --> 01:12:56,520
So looking at all the different
things involved in scheduling.

1400
01:12:56,520 --> 01:12:57,038
It's a lot.

1401
01:12:57,038 --> 01:13:00,340
And this is,
when you say you're a project manager,

1402
01:13:00,340 --> 01:13:01,572
in other people's minds,
>> [CROSSTALK]

1403
01:13:01,572 --> 01:13:02,378
>> This is what they think of,

1404
01:13:02,378 --> 01:13:03,950
this is what they think you do everyday.

1405
01:13:03,950 --> 01:13:06,870
So it does make up a big piece of it.

1406
01:13:06,870 --> 01:13:08,800
We're gonna see a lot more
as we go through, though,

1407
01:13:08,800 --> 01:13:11,090
cuz this is really just a small portion.

1408
01:13:11,090 --> 01:13:12,151
We still have our budget,
>> [CROSSTALK]

1409
01:13:12,151 --> 01:13:13,597
>> Which is equally important, and

1410
01:13:13,597 --> 01:13:14,810
other activities.

1411
01:13:14,810 --> 01:13:17,110
So we'll get a chance to see
a lot of those coming up, but for

1412
01:13:17,110 --> 01:13:18,100
now,
>> Yep

1413
01:13:18,100 --> 01:13:19,360
>> That wraps up project timing.

1414
01:13:19,360 --> 01:13:21,108
>> That's right.

1415
01:13:21,108 --> 01:13:24,180
>> So, all right, well let me just remind
you guys, if you have questions on

1416
01:13:24,180 --> 01:13:28,210
any of this, feel free to jump on over
to our website, live during the show.

1417
01:13:28,210 --> 01:13:32,490
You can go to itpro.tv/live You'll see
our chat box right beneath the video.

1418
01:13:32,490 --> 01:13:35,445
Post your questions, we monitor and
answer during the show.

1419
01:13:35,445 --> 01:13:37,820
>> Right.
>> If you have questions after the show,

1420
01:13:37,820 --> 01:13:42,520
like if you're watching this recorded,
well, jump on over to our Q&A forums.

1421
01:13:42,520 --> 01:13:46,226
At the top of every page on itpro.tv
you'll see a link that says "Q&A".

1422
01:13:46,226 --> 01:13:48,170
>> Yeah.
>> Click on it, takes you into our forums,

1423
01:13:48,170 --> 01:13:50,650
you can post your questions there,
we monitor and answer it.

1424
01:13:50,650 --> 01:13:52,900
We want to make sure you get
the information you need, so

1425
01:13:52,900 --> 01:13:56,210
that you can properly grasp this and
be successful on your exam.

1426
01:13:57,480 --> 01:13:58,860
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1427
01:13:58,860 --> 01:14:01,545
Signing out for itpro.tv, I'm Don Pezet.

1428
01:14:01,545 --> 01:14:02,405
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1429
01:14:02,405 --> 01:14:04,204
>> And we will see you next time.

1430
01:14:04,204 --> 01:14:14,204
[MUSIC]

1431
01:14:16,347 --> 01:14:16,847
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at the area of cost management for the project. They talk about some of the techniques used to create a budget for the project. They review all the relevant tools and techniques to estimate material and labor cost. They end the show with determining the budget for the project.
episodes.title: Cost Management
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,010 --> 00:00:10,010
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,541 --> 00:00:35,603
All right.
Good morning, good afternoon and

3
00:00:35,603 --> 00:00:38,660
good evening and welcome back
to another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,660 --> 00:00:40,130
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:40,130 --> 00:00:41,750
Back here again Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:41,750 --> 00:00:42,650
How's it going, Ronnie?

7
00:00:42,650 --> 00:00:44,168
>> It is going extremely well.

8
00:00:44,168 --> 00:00:48,700
I did photobomb the Kim Kardashian and
Kanye West wedding so

9
00:00:48,700 --> 00:00:50,630
I'm in every one of their wedding photos.

10
00:00:50,630 --> 00:00:52,050
Nice, nice.

11
00:00:52,050 --> 00:00:54,521
Was it as elegant an affair
as you had hoped it would be?

12
00:00:54,521 --> 00:00:55,802
>> It was a little on the cheap
side to tell you the truth.

13
00:00:55,802 --> 00:00:59,470
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well,

14
00:00:59,470 --> 00:01:02,930
congratulations to the newlyweds, I
suppose, if anybody even cares about them.

15
00:01:02,930 --> 00:01:07,670
But I am gonna comment here real
quick that this is a special

16
00:01:07,670 --> 00:01:10,270
sauna edition of ITProTV.

17
00:01:10,270 --> 00:01:15,300
The air conditioning team is actually
here working on the roof right now.

18
00:01:15,300 --> 00:01:19,320
So if you hear crazy footsteps, it's not
Santa Claus landing to bring us presents.

19
00:01:19,320 --> 00:01:22,220
It's Santa Claus landing to
bring us air conditioning.

20
00:01:22,220 --> 00:01:25,290
>> Yes.
>> So if you see us beading sweat on our

21
00:01:25,290 --> 00:01:28,190
brows it's not because we're panicked or
stressed out.

22
00:01:28,190 --> 00:01:29,630
It's just because it's really hot in here.

23
00:01:29,630 --> 00:01:31,590
>> Hot.
>> These studio lights are like

24
00:01:31,590 --> 00:01:32,365
an Easy-bake Oven.

25
00:01:32,365 --> 00:01:37,285
So the end of this episode we'll have
tiny little cupcakes that taste terrible.

26
00:01:37,285 --> 00:01:39,695
And that's what we're going for.

27
00:01:39,695 --> 00:01:41,305
All right.
So ladies and gentlemen,

28
00:01:41,305 --> 00:01:45,215
we are continuing on with
the planning process here inside of

29
00:01:45,215 --> 00:01:49,570
the Project Management Institute's Project
Management Professional Certification.

30
00:01:49,570 --> 00:01:51,140
And we've moved the schedule.

31
00:01:51,140 --> 00:01:52,930
Which boy, that was a big chunk, right.

32
00:01:52,930 --> 00:01:55,300
It took us three episodes
to move through that.

33
00:01:55,300 --> 00:01:58,450
This one today is gonna
be cost management.

34
00:01:58,450 --> 00:02:01,960
And it's almost a mirror
of schedule management.

35
00:02:01,960 --> 00:02:04,560
A lot of what we do under
schedule management is the same

36
00:02:04,560 --> 00:02:05,750
thing under cost management.

37
00:02:05,750 --> 00:02:10,940
The only difference is instead of dealing
with time, you're dealing with money.

38
00:02:10,940 --> 00:02:13,080
Most of the systems are the same.

39
00:02:13,080 --> 00:02:16,420
So when we look at the process groups, let
me just pull this up here in the PMBOK.

40
00:02:16,420 --> 00:02:18,820
When we go into all of our process groups,

41
00:02:19,920 --> 00:02:24,020
we have this huge chuck here for
Project Time Management and

42
00:02:24,020 --> 00:02:28,770
just three little, sad
Project Cost Management entries in here.

43
00:02:28,770 --> 00:02:30,460
The reason is twofold.

44
00:02:30,460 --> 00:02:33,460
One reason is a lot of it is duplicate
of what we have already seen.

45
00:02:33,460 --> 00:02:37,090
