We don't need a ton more infrastructure
and bureaucracy around it.

46
00:02:37,090 --> 00:02:42,850
The second reason is not all project
managers out there manage their budget.

47
00:02:42,850 --> 00:02:44,050
>> Right.
>> Also.

48
00:02:44,050 --> 00:02:47,520
Often times they'll have an accounting
team or an accounting department.

49
00:02:47,520 --> 00:02:48,330
Accounts payable.

50
00:02:48,330 --> 00:02:49,780
Accounts receivable all that good stuff.

51
00:02:49,780 --> 00:02:52,850
That is managing the finances
of your project.

52
00:02:52,850 --> 00:02:56,730
So there are many organizations that
deploy formal project management and

53
00:02:56,730 --> 00:02:58,230
just knock number seven right now.

54
00:02:58,230 --> 00:03:01,300
Just that's it,
it's not even apart of our project.

55
00:03:01,300 --> 00:03:03,340
Well, I've worked in
environments like that,

56
00:03:03,340 --> 00:03:06,740
and even in those environments,
I still tracked my cost.

57
00:03:06,740 --> 00:03:09,880
And I did it because there's some neat
techniques we'll see in the monitoring and

58
00:03:09,880 --> 00:03:13,580
controlling phase where we can try,
I glamorize it a little bit.

59
00:03:13,580 --> 00:03:15,950
We can try and predict the future.

60
00:03:15,950 --> 00:03:20,520
To see what our project is trending like
and if we're not monitoring that stuff.

61
00:03:20,520 --> 00:03:23,750
We don't stand any chance of being
able to do something like that.

62
00:03:23,750 --> 00:03:25,860
You know, it's an important thing.

63
00:03:25,860 --> 00:03:29,760
And we're really leveraging some
of the same technologies from

64
00:03:29,760 --> 00:03:30,540
Project Time Management.

65
00:03:31,630 --> 00:03:33,670
All right.
So let's dive in and take a look at it.

66
00:03:33,670 --> 00:03:37,340
The first process group we're gonna
look at is Plan Cost Management.

67
00:03:37,340 --> 00:03:39,690
Much like up here we did
Plan Schedule Management.

68
00:03:39,690 --> 00:03:42,350
Well what is plan cost management?

69
00:03:42,350 --> 00:03:43,430
It's the same thing.

70
00:03:43,430 --> 00:03:48,080
We are figuring out how we
want to manage our costs.

71
00:03:48,080 --> 00:03:49,500
How we want to manage that.

72
00:03:49,500 --> 00:03:52,740
And if you've already got a project
management plan in place,

73
00:03:52,740 --> 00:03:55,490
if your company has been doing formal
project management for a while.

74
00:03:55,490 --> 00:03:58,730
You don't even need to worry about this
process because your cost management plan

75
00:03:58,730 --> 00:04:00,520
is already made.

76
00:04:00,520 --> 00:04:03,340
But if it isn't,
then you've got to create one.

77
00:04:03,340 --> 00:04:05,910
So you go through these
other processes figuring out

78
00:04:05,910 --> 00:04:07,500
what it is that you're going to do.

79
00:04:07,500 --> 00:04:10,120
And when you find the model
that works best for you,

80
00:04:10,120 --> 00:04:14,120
you then document that, and
it becomes our cost management plan.

81
00:04:14,120 --> 00:04:18,700
So this is one of our more
simple processes right here.

82
00:04:18,700 --> 00:04:21,130
Our input would be
the project management plan.

83
00:04:21,130 --> 00:04:24,350
Because if we already have one it's
going to stay exactly what we need to do

84
00:04:24,350 --> 00:04:27,260
to manage our costs and
we're pretty much done.

85
00:04:27,260 --> 00:04:29,600
But if we don't we take what ever we have.

86
00:04:29,600 --> 00:04:31,630
Whatever we have as a management plan.

87
00:04:31,630 --> 00:04:34,890
We take our project charter, which says
what we're trying to achieve with this

88
00:04:34,890 --> 00:04:39,220
project And then we take
enterprise environmental factors.

89
00:04:39,220 --> 00:04:44,890
Whatever the laws, regulations,
statutes, standards, whatever we follow.

90
00:04:44,890 --> 00:04:46,660
Whatever they say we need to do.

91
00:04:46,660 --> 00:04:48,820
And we combine that with
organizational process assets.

92
00:04:48,820 --> 00:04:51,790
Assets, whatever paperwork
our company already has.

93
00:04:51,790 --> 00:04:54,680
If we have templates,
if we have things like that, we use them.

94
00:04:54,680 --> 00:04:55,500
All right?

95
00:04:55,500 --> 00:04:58,280
Then we just apply some
very simple things to it.

96
00:04:58,280 --> 00:04:59,180
Expert judgment.

97
00:04:59,180 --> 00:05:00,930
We've seen that one time and
time again, right?

98
00:05:00,930 --> 00:05:01,630
Use your noodle.

99
00:05:01,630 --> 00:05:02,229
What's in your head?

100
00:05:03,240 --> 00:05:05,010
Analytical techniques.

101
00:05:05,010 --> 00:05:08,100
There are a number of analytical
techniques available to us and

102
00:05:08,100 --> 00:05:09,570
we're going to see several of them.

103
00:05:09,570 --> 00:05:11,930
You don't necessarily
need to use all of them.

104
00:05:11,930 --> 00:05:15,260
So you need to pick which ones
are going to be the ones you use in

105
00:05:15,260 --> 00:05:15,980
your organization.

106
00:05:15,980 --> 00:05:17,880
And then lastly meetings.

107
00:05:17,880 --> 00:05:19,810
You have meetings with
the other project managers.

108
00:05:19,810 --> 00:05:21,560
The PMO whoever.

109
00:05:21,560 --> 00:05:25,390
To come up with at the end
this Cost Management Plan.

110
00:05:25,390 --> 00:05:27,550
How we're going to manage costs.

111
00:05:27,550 --> 00:05:29,970
So there's not a ton to it.

112
00:05:29,970 --> 00:05:33,050
If this is the very first formal
project management that we're doing.

113
00:05:33,050 --> 00:05:34,725
We're gonna skip this process.

114
00:05:34,725 --> 00:05:36,430
We're gonna skip it.

115
00:05:36,430 --> 00:05:38,210
Do the other two first.

116
00:05:38,210 --> 00:05:42,310
And by the other two,
I mean estimate cost and determine budget.

117
00:05:42,310 --> 00:05:46,540
And by the time we build that budget, we
now know what we had to go through, and we

118
00:05:46,540 --> 00:05:51,810
use that to serve as the template process
for creating a cost budget in the future.

119
00:05:53,740 --> 00:05:56,400
But if we have done this time and
time again.

120
00:05:56,400 --> 00:05:57,100
We get that data.

121
00:05:57,100 --> 00:06:00,130
And that doesn't mean we necessarily
have to run it in its stock form.

122
00:06:00,130 --> 00:06:02,670
We might need to tweak it,
optimize it, whatever.

123
00:06:02,670 --> 00:06:04,140
And so we kinda go through that process.

124
00:06:04,140 --> 00:06:07,120
So pretty straight forward, there, and so

125
00:06:07,120 --> 00:06:10,610
we won't see a whole heck of a lot for
planning cost management.

126
00:06:10,610 --> 00:06:14,060
The inputs, it's all pretty much the same
stuff that we've been dealing with so far.

127
00:06:14,060 --> 00:06:15,850
Nothing really new and
earth-shattering there.

128
00:06:17,250 --> 00:06:18,490
Tools and techniques.

129
00:06:18,490 --> 00:06:20,910
Again, nothing really new and
earth-shattering,

130
00:06:20,910 --> 00:06:22,860
just analytical techniques.

131
00:06:22,860 --> 00:06:26,400
We break down the different
tools that are available to us.

132
00:06:26,400 --> 00:06:29,150
And which ones we adopt,
which ones we choose to use.

133
00:06:29,150 --> 00:06:30,740
We're gonna take a look at
these here in a minute.

134
00:06:30,740 --> 00:06:33,710
And you'll see some of them are really
not appropriate for small businesses,

135
00:06:33,710 --> 00:06:36,125
so they're just useful for
large organizations.

136
00:06:36,125 --> 00:06:36,945
Z.
Kind of pick and

137
00:06:36,945 --> 00:06:39,825
choose based on what works for you.

138
00:06:39,825 --> 00:06:43,425
And then lastly we have our output,
you know, that Project Management Plan and

139
00:06:43,425 --> 00:06:45,955
it should contain a number
of different things.

140
00:06:45,955 --> 00:06:47,635
And we actually got
a little template here.

141
00:06:47,635 --> 00:06:51,235
I'll show you.
It's a little easier to swallow here.

142
00:06:51,235 --> 00:06:53,760
Let me get ITProTV templates.

143
00:06:53,760 --> 00:06:55,810
And cost management plan.

144
00:06:55,810 --> 00:06:57,100
Here we go.

145
00:06:57,100 --> 00:06:59,510
So we specify some really simple things.

146
00:06:59,510 --> 00:07:01,930
These are guidelines we're gonna
follow as we deal with our budget.

147
00:07:01,930 --> 00:07:04,010
First off, level of accuracy.

148
00:07:04,010 --> 00:07:07,060
When we do estimates,
there's always room for error.

149
00:07:07,060 --> 00:07:11,510
So we specify right off the top,
what is our expected level of accuracy.

150
00:07:11,510 --> 00:07:13,450
What error rate do we want to allow.

151
00:07:14,880 --> 00:07:15,770
Units of measure.

152
00:07:15,770 --> 00:07:18,710
Are we doing this in U.S.
dollars or the Euro?

153
00:07:18,710 --> 00:07:24,190
Or what is it that we're using to
serve as our currency unit of measure?

154
00:07:24,190 --> 00:07:26,650
And then, any thresholds that we have.

155
00:07:26,650 --> 00:07:28,330
If we start to have deviations.

156
00:07:28,330 --> 00:07:31,920
Our level of accuracy,
if we start to get too far.

157
00:07:31,920 --> 00:07:36,700
At which points do we set up, our,
reserves kick in, red flags, and

158
00:07:36,700 --> 00:07:37,630
things like that.

159
00:07:37,630 --> 00:07:40,960
Where do we want to consider that
area where we need to start acting.

160
00:07:42,360 --> 00:07:43,481
Rules for performance measurement.

161
00:07:43,481 --> 00:07:47,180
How do we measure what's going
on as far as our costs and

162
00:07:47,180 --> 00:07:49,843
gauge that against our original plan?

163
00:07:49,843 --> 00:07:51,353
We're not really gonna look at that now,

164
00:07:51,353 --> 00:07:53,825
we're gonna look at that in
a monitoring and In controlling phase.

165
00:07:53,825 --> 00:07:57,072
Cuz at that point, you're looking at
how that money is being spent and

166
00:07:57,072 --> 00:07:58,680
how we're getting a return on it.

167
00:08:00,520 --> 00:08:02,620
The cost reporting and format.

168
00:08:02,620 --> 00:08:06,050
So obviously as we spend money,
we need to report that it was spent, and

169
00:08:06,050 --> 00:08:08,840
tell people here's what we've done and
here's what we're gonna do.

170
00:08:08,840 --> 00:08:10,910
How does that get formatted?

171
00:08:10,910 --> 00:08:14,890
You want it to be consistent across all
of your projects, so it is easy for

172
00:08:14,890 --> 00:08:17,980
the accounting team, or whoever to be
able to determine that information.

173
00:08:19,240 --> 00:08:20,860
And then, anything else that we have.

174
00:08:20,860 --> 00:08:22,380
How we estimate cost.

175
00:08:22,380 --> 00:08:23,550
How we develop the budget.

176
00:08:23,550 --> 00:08:26,910
You will notice that both of those
are tied to our other processes.

177
00:08:26,910 --> 00:08:29,230
Estimate costs, determine budget, right?

178
00:08:29,230 --> 00:08:32,910
So we're just saying how we're gonna do
those, and then updating, monitoring,

179
00:08:32,910 --> 00:08:33,460
and controlling.

180
00:08:33,460 --> 00:08:36,500
What we're gonna see later,
how that's gonna be managed, too.

181
00:08:36,500 --> 00:08:40,040
So all of that needs to be put in here,
and it should be put in here in a way

182
00:08:40,040 --> 00:08:44,050
where it's generic enough, but it can
apply to any project in your company.

183
00:08:44,050 --> 00:08:47,070
So that when you draft it now,
it'll work time and

184
00:08:47,070 --> 00:08:48,800
time again as you do future projects.

185
00:08:50,050 --> 00:08:54,752
So this was the easiest, and
really nothing I said there was too

186
00:08:54,752 --> 00:08:57,480
significant right,
because plan cost management

187
00:08:57,480 --> 00:09:01,400
is really the same as plan schedule
management or plan scope management.

188
00:09:01,400 --> 00:09:03,100
They're all kinda the same.

189
00:09:03,100 --> 00:09:05,820
You figure out what works for
you and you document it so

190
00:09:05,820 --> 00:09:10,420
that you can then use that over and
over again and be consistent about it.

191
00:09:10,420 --> 00:09:12,680
All right, so
that knocks out our first process group.

192
00:09:12,680 --> 00:09:16,110
We're really cooking now, we did that in
the first ten minutes of the episode.

193
00:09:16,110 --> 00:09:17,620
Unfortunately that's the shortest one,
right.

194
00:09:17,620 --> 00:09:21,830
The others are where we're actually
dealing with the cost management stuff.

195
00:09:21,830 --> 00:09:23,720
And they start to grow quite a bit.

196
00:09:23,720 --> 00:09:26,870
So let's move into the next one,
which is estimate cost.

197
00:09:26,870 --> 00:09:29,630
You'll see that the third
process is determine the budget.

198
00:09:29,630 --> 00:09:32,740
We can't really figure out our budget
unless we know what things cost.

199
00:09:32,740 --> 00:09:36,110
And so logically it makes sense
to do estimate costs first.

200
00:09:36,110 --> 00:09:36,790
All right.

201
00:09:36,790 --> 00:09:38,810
Now, early on in this series,

202
00:09:38,810 --> 00:09:41,540
I mentioned that we don't have to
do this stuff chronologically.

203
00:09:41,540 --> 00:09:45,030
But there's some things that make sense or
some things that build on each other.

204
00:09:45,030 --> 00:09:49,640
Estimating cost is a tricky one because a
lot of times it is impossible to estimate

205
00:09:49,640 --> 00:09:51,530
your cost all at once.

206
00:09:51,530 --> 00:09:54,820
It's something that you do as
more information comes in.

207
00:09:54,820 --> 00:09:59,930
You can start it as early as developing
the work breakdown structure.

208
00:09:59,930 --> 00:10:03,660
When you develop that work breakdown
structure, you're creating work packages.

209
00:10:03,660 --> 00:10:06,410
Actual work that needs to be
done to complete your project.

210
00:10:06,410 --> 00:10:09,130
You can start coming up
with costs right then.

211
00:10:09,130 --> 00:10:12,170
Figuring out what things are gonna cost,
what labor and so on.

212
00:10:12,170 --> 00:10:14,750
But you might have things that
require a contractor, and

213
00:10:14,750 --> 00:10:15,960
you're going to be doing bidding.

214
00:10:15,960 --> 00:10:19,860
So you send out for quotes, and you
haven't even picked who the winner is yet.

215
00:10:19,860 --> 00:10:21,460
You don't know what that cost is.

216
00:10:21,460 --> 00:10:25,460
And so at this stage, you may be able to
get some of the information in there, but

217
00:10:25,460 --> 00:10:28,130
you're going to have some holes, right.

218
00:10:28,130 --> 00:10:30,650
Then we go into schedule management, and

219
00:10:30,650 --> 00:10:33,080
we figure out when things
are going to occur.

220
00:10:33,080 --> 00:10:39,060
Some things cost more or cost less
depending on the time they occur, right.

221
00:10:39,060 --> 00:10:44,125
We're here in Florida and in Florida
something as simple as hotel rooms.

222
00:10:44,125 --> 00:10:48,210
The price on a hotel room varies
greatly depending on the time of year.

223
00:10:48,210 --> 00:10:54,250
A hotel room in Florida in February,
the second week of February,

224
00:10:54,250 --> 00:10:59,730
is gonna be dirt cheap, but getting one
in July is going to be double the cost.

225
00:10:59,730 --> 00:11:03,020
That's just how the state of Florida
works, it's a tourism-based industry.

226
00:11:03,020 --> 00:11:07,110
So, their cost can vary widely
based on that schedule.

227
00:11:07,110 --> 00:11:10,930
So can we estimate the cost
before we know that schedule?

228
00:11:10,930 --> 00:11:15,180
You can try, but every time that data
gets updated you'll have to go and

229
00:11:15,180 --> 00:11:16,110
revise your budgets.

230
00:11:16,110 --> 00:11:18,055
So it becomes a lot of rework.

231
00:11:18,055 --> 00:11:22,585
So many people will wait,
finish the schedule first, and

232
00:11:22,585 --> 00:11:26,565
once that schedule is done,
then go into cost management.

233
00:11:26,565 --> 00:11:27,355
It's up to you.

234
00:11:27,355 --> 00:11:29,185
They don't have to be
done chronologically.

235
00:11:29,185 --> 00:11:30,990
They can be done mixed and matched.

236
00:11:30,990 --> 00:11:33,450
Personally, I usually develop it as I go.

237
00:11:33,450 --> 00:11:37,010
So as I go I'm creating those numbers,
and updating, and so on.

238
00:11:37,010 --> 00:11:41,870
And only once the scheduling is
completely done do I then go back and

239
00:11:41,870 --> 00:11:44,120
revisit and say all right,
I shouldn't have any more holes.

240
00:11:44,120 --> 00:11:46,160
Everything should have
a dollar sign attached to it.

241
00:11:46,160 --> 00:11:47,270
And go back and recalculate.

242
00:11:47,270 --> 00:11:50,884
So just be aware that the order
this occurs in can vary.

243
00:11:50,884 --> 00:11:55,500
All right, but when we're ready to
estimate cost, we wanna get granular.

244
00:11:55,500 --> 00:11:57,980
We wanna look at an individual
piece of our project.

245
00:11:57,980 --> 00:12:00,860
Normally an activity or
a work package, and

246
00:12:00,860 --> 00:12:02,150
come up with what the cost is going to be.

247
00:12:02,150 --> 00:12:06,330
And the cost is actually gonna be
a mixture of two things in most cases.

248
00:12:06,330 --> 00:12:10,160
It's usually gonna be a mixture of labor,
and materials.

249
00:12:10,160 --> 00:12:14,590
Labor, you've got employees doing work,
and they probably have an hourly or

250
00:12:14,590 --> 00:12:17,720
salary wage that's got
to be accounted for.

251
00:12:17,720 --> 00:12:19,120
And then materials.

252
00:12:19,120 --> 00:12:21,620
If you're doing something
that creates a tangible good,

253
00:12:21,620 --> 00:12:24,190
like building a house,
you've got a lot of materials.

254
00:12:24,190 --> 00:12:28,070
Wood, shingles, cement,
all that stuff that goes into it.

255
00:12:28,070 --> 00:12:32,410
And so we need to know estimates not
just on the cost of those things but

256
00:12:32,410 --> 00:12:35,120
on the quantity of those things, right?

257
00:12:35,120 --> 00:12:38,720
Ronnie, do you know like a two by four,
they normally get them in like what,

258
00:12:38,720 --> 00:12:40,340
like eight foot sections or ten foot?

259
00:12:40,340 --> 00:12:42,280
>> Yeah.
>> And they run

260
00:12:42,280 --> 00:12:43,260
couple of bucks each, right?

261
00:12:43,260 --> 00:12:45,030
Let's just say $3 each.

262
00:12:45,030 --> 00:12:45,660
Right?

263
00:12:45,660 --> 00:12:46,720
Well okay, great.

264
00:12:46,720 --> 00:12:49,460
Now I know, hey, if I get a two by four,
it's going to cost $3.

265
00:12:49,460 --> 00:12:50,440
Wonderful.

266
00:12:50,440 --> 00:12:52,590
Well, how many do I need?

267
00:12:52,590 --> 00:12:53,680
25, 2500, or I need 25,000?

268
00:12:53,680 --> 00:12:57,590
I actually have no clue how many two
by fours go into building a house, but

269
00:12:57,590 --> 00:12:59,030
I imagine it's a lot.

270
00:12:59,030 --> 00:13:02,970
And so
we need to estimate not just the cost but

271
00:13:02,970 --> 00:13:06,910
the quantity of a lot of this stuff,
and that is important.

272
00:13:06,910 --> 00:13:08,160
Same thing with your people.

273
00:13:08,160 --> 00:13:11,820
I might know that a web developer
is gonna cost me $25 an hour,

274
00:13:11,820 --> 00:13:16,540
but how many web developers do I need,
right?

275
00:13:16,540 --> 00:13:17,160
I don't know that.

276
00:13:17,160 --> 00:13:19,940
So, I might have to reach out
to my subject matter experts and

277
00:13:19,940 --> 00:13:24,850
find out that information before I
can get a really good cost estimate.

278
00:13:24,850 --> 00:13:27,750
So let's take a look at
the estimate cost process,

279
00:13:27,750 --> 00:13:29,980
which I have parked around here somewhere.

280
00:13:29,980 --> 00:13:30,480
Here.

281
00:13:31,570 --> 00:13:34,080
The first thing you'll notice,
this is another full one.

282
00:13:34,080 --> 00:13:36,220
We've got a lot of stuff in here.

283
00:13:36,220 --> 00:13:39,530
Our inputs are a lot of stuff.

284
00:13:39,530 --> 00:13:42,310
A cost management plan if we have one.

285
00:13:42,310 --> 00:13:45,130
If we don't, we can make it by without it.

286
00:13:45,130 --> 00:13:47,210
A human resource management plan.

287
00:13:47,210 --> 00:13:49,140
Now why is that important.

288
00:13:49,140 --> 00:13:51,989
Well, the human resource management
plan is gonna contain information

289
00:13:53,180 --> 00:13:56,960
on how we get people
attached to our project.

290
00:13:56,960 --> 00:13:58,560
I know I need a web developer.

291
00:13:58,560 --> 00:13:59,920
How much is that web developer gonna cost?

292
00:13:59,920 --> 00:14:04,110
Well, my company might employ
several different web developers and

293
00:14:04,110 --> 00:14:08,200
some might be brand new out of college and
they're making $20 an hour and

294
00:14:08,200 --> 00:14:12,170
others might be professionals have been
with the company for 20 years, and

295
00:14:12,170 --> 00:14:13,750
they're making $50 an hour.

296
00:14:13,750 --> 00:14:16,650
And so now,
I don't know which one I'm going to get.

297
00:14:16,650 --> 00:14:19,520
So I need to look at my human
resources' management plan.

298
00:14:19,520 --> 00:14:22,900
I need to approach whoever it is
that starts to issue people, and

299
00:14:22,900 --> 00:14:26,750
start to nail that down and say, hey, I
know I'm gonna need three web developers.

300
00:14:26,750 --> 00:14:30,200
Who can I get and what's their salary or
what's their hourly rate so

301
00:14:30,200 --> 00:14:32,130
I can start to budget for it.

302
00:14:32,130 --> 00:14:35,230
We can't just go with that generic
placeholder anymore unless we're lucky

303
00:14:35,230 --> 00:14:38,880
enough to have every person with a generic
placeholder make the same amount of money,

304
00:14:38,880 --> 00:14:40,050
which is not terribly common.

305
00:14:41,520 --> 00:14:44,240
All right, so that human resources
plan we haven't covered yet,

306
00:14:44,240 --> 00:14:47,640
we haven't gotten to the human
resources knowledge group yet.

307
00:14:47,640 --> 00:14:50,120
We'll take a look at that
in the next few days.

308
00:14:50,120 --> 00:14:52,520
But if we've got it, we'll grab that.

309
00:14:52,520 --> 00:14:57,090
Our scope baseline isn't gonna have
much in there that's terribly useful for

310
00:14:57,090 --> 00:15:01,220
that except for one big thing
which is the total project budget.

311
00:15:01,220 --> 00:15:03,240
We need to know what
we're working against.

312
00:15:03,240 --> 00:15:05,650
Our project may not have a budget yet.

313
00:15:05,650 --> 00:15:06,750
If it doesn't have a budget,

314
00:15:06,750 --> 00:15:08,930
it's the result of these
estimates that will create it.

315
00:15:08,930 --> 00:15:12,435
But if we already have a budget,
if my budget is $1 million,

316
00:15:12,435 --> 00:15:16,540
then as I start working on these estimates
I know what I'm working against and

317
00:15:16,540 --> 00:15:19,410
if I start to go over that while
I'm in the estimation phase,

318
00:15:19,410 --> 00:15:21,850
I need to find some alternatives and
do some alternatives analysis.

319
00:15:23,650 --> 00:15:24,450
All right.

320
00:15:24,450 --> 00:15:27,090
Other things that we bring in
are project schedule, right, and

321
00:15:27,090 --> 00:15:29,250
I already hit on this.

322
00:15:29,250 --> 00:15:32,380
Based on our schedule,
certain things can cost more or

323
00:15:32,380 --> 00:15:35,030
less based on timing, and so
we need to know that schedule.

324
00:15:36,690 --> 00:15:38,480
Our risk register.

325
00:15:38,480 --> 00:15:41,750
The only reason we've got risk
register here is that, and again.

326
00:15:41,750 --> 00:15:44,046
We haven't reached the risk
knowledge area yet.

327
00:15:44,046 --> 00:15:48,775
But with the risk register, one of the
things that we might do is see a risk, and

328
00:15:48,775 --> 00:15:52,659
the way we address it is by setting
up A cash reserve, all right.

329
00:15:52,659 --> 00:15:56,040
And we might set a cash reserve
just in case something happens.

330
00:15:56,040 --> 00:16:00,727
So we need to be able to look at the risk
register to factor in that cash reserve,

331
00:16:00,727 --> 00:16:01,233
right.

332
00:16:01,233 --> 00:16:06,992
Let's say that we are planning
a outdoor rock concert, all right.

333
00:16:06,992 --> 00:16:09,920
And one of the risks
is that it might rain.

334
00:16:09,920 --> 00:16:12,810
So, the risk handlers,
they're going to make some decisions.

335
00:16:12,810 --> 00:16:15,490
They could say, you know what, forget it,
let's just do an indoor concert.

336
00:16:15,490 --> 00:16:17,470
Now the risk is gone,
we don't worry about it.

337
00:16:17,470 --> 00:16:21,200
But they might say, you know what,
let's do this: Let's put down a deposit

338
00:16:21,200 --> 00:16:24,310
on renting some tents for
that day, all right?

339
00:16:24,310 --> 00:16:28,090
And if it looks like it's going
to rain we'll call that in and

340
00:16:28,090 --> 00:16:29,390
say get those tents out there, right.

341
00:16:29,390 --> 00:16:32,300
But, if it's not going to rain we
won't and we're just out the deposit.

342
00:16:32,300 --> 00:16:34,060
This is a very common thing.

343
00:16:34,060 --> 00:16:35,990
So, they put that in place.

344
00:16:35,990 --> 00:16:40,431
Now, I need to have in my estimate costs
what that deposit was because that's money

345
00:16:40,431 --> 00:16:42,970
we're going to spend no matter what.

346
00:16:42,970 --> 00:16:47,440
And then the reserve that say's if it
rains we have a call on the tents and

347
00:16:47,440 --> 00:16:49,670
here's the X amount of
dollars we have to pay extra.

348
00:16:49,670 --> 00:16:50,530
I need to be aware of that.

349
00:16:50,530 --> 00:16:53,110
So the risk register is an input here

350
00:16:53,110 --> 00:16:56,350
because I need to see anywhere
cash reserves are involved.

351
00:16:56,350 --> 00:16:59,880
Or for purchasing insurance premiums,
things like that.

352
00:16:59,880 --> 00:17:01,300
Anywhere that is, I need that info.

353
00:17:02,640 --> 00:17:03,872
And then our two favorites, right.

354
00:17:03,872 --> 00:17:05,620
>> [LAUGH]
>> Enterprise environmental factors

355
00:17:05,620 --> 00:17:07,740
an organizational process assets.

356
00:17:07,740 --> 00:17:11,230
You know, we do have one here in a minute,
under determined budget but,

357
00:17:11,230 --> 00:17:14,830
we have organizational process assets
without enterprise environmental factor.

358
00:17:14,830 --> 00:17:16,630
So, its not always a given then but,

359
00:17:16,630 --> 00:17:18,910
you do normally have those
two turkeys right there.

360
00:17:20,580 --> 00:17:22,880
All right, so
we take all that information.

361
00:17:22,880 --> 00:17:24,220
And what do we do with it?

362
00:17:24,220 --> 00:17:27,370
Well, we do a lot with it.

363
00:17:27,370 --> 00:17:29,570
Coming up with a budget is hard.

364
00:17:29,570 --> 00:17:32,000
It is hard because there are so
many variables.

365
00:17:32,000 --> 00:17:35,660
It doesn't come down to just
the purchase of a particular item.

366
00:17:35,660 --> 00:17:37,240
There is always more stuff involved.

367
00:17:37,240 --> 00:17:38,950
There are taxes and shipping.

368
00:17:38,950 --> 00:17:41,210
There are man hours for
the purchasing itself.

369
00:17:41,210 --> 00:17:43,350
There are all sorts of different things.

370
00:17:43,350 --> 00:17:46,930
Contract negotiations and stuff,
that gets in the way of cost.

371
00:17:46,930 --> 00:17:50,690
So we have a lot of tools and
techniques to help account for that.

372
00:17:50,690 --> 00:17:51,850
Some of these we've already seen.

373
00:17:51,850 --> 00:17:53,730
Right, expert judgement,
we already know that one.

374
00:17:55,010 --> 00:17:56,860
Analogous estimate.

375
00:17:56,860 --> 00:18:00,390
Analogous estimating, just to refresh
because we saw this with the schedule,

376
00:18:00,390 --> 00:18:04,140
is I need to find out how much
something is going to cost.

377
00:18:04,140 --> 00:18:06,560
I can look at my other projects, and

378
00:18:06,560 --> 00:18:08,840
see if somebody else has
already done what I'm doing.

379
00:18:08,840 --> 00:18:13,300
And if they have I can find out what
it cost them and just use that, right?

380
00:18:13,300 --> 00:18:17,460
I know I need to rent a flat bed truck for
three days.

381
00:18:17,460 --> 00:18:18,900
Let me go look at some
of these other projects.

382
00:18:18,900 --> 00:18:20,660
Did anybody rent a flat bed truck?

383
00:18:20,660 --> 00:18:22,080
Oh sure, here's somebody.

384
00:18:22,080 --> 00:18:23,300
How much did they pay?

385
00:18:23,300 --> 00:18:25,897
Let's use that for my estimate, right.

386
00:18:25,897 --> 00:18:27,820
Now if it's an old project,

387
00:18:27,820 --> 00:18:30,970
if enough time has passed, those
numbers might not be accurate anymore.

388
00:18:30,970 --> 00:18:34,200
But at least it gives us a basis to start
on, and then we can start reaching out and

389
00:18:34,200 --> 00:18:36,200
getting some quotes, right?

390
00:18:36,200 --> 00:18:38,770
That's where analogous
estimating comes in handy.

391
00:18:38,770 --> 00:18:40,230
The positive is,

392
00:18:40,230 --> 00:18:43,290
it gives you a pretty accurate result
in a very short amount of time.

393
00:18:43,290 --> 00:18:45,460
It's very fast.
Very low labor intensive to come

394
00:18:45,460 --> 00:18:47,210
up with this estimate.

395
00:18:47,210 --> 00:18:51,590
On a negative side, it kind of
assumes that you have historical data,

396
00:18:51,590 --> 00:18:55,830
you have other projects that you worked
on, or that you're dealing with a third

397
00:18:55,830 --> 00:18:58,484
party who's sharing that
information with you, all right.

398
00:18:58,484 --> 00:19:01,551
If you don't have those,
you can't use an analogous estimate.

399
00:19:01,551 --> 00:19:02,242
It's not gonna help you.

400
00:19:02,242 --> 00:19:03,690
All right.
You can go on the Internet, but

401
00:19:03,690 --> 00:19:05,335
all the numbers on
the Internet are BS anyway.

402
00:19:05,335 --> 00:19:07,562
[LAUGH] So you go on there and
somebody says, yeah,

403
00:19:07,562 --> 00:19:09,798
we deployed Linux across
our entire scoreboard.

404
00:19:09,798 --> 00:19:11,130
It cost $5!

405
00:19:11,130 --> 00:19:14,060
And then you find out,
yeah it cost $5, but

406
00:19:14,060 --> 00:19:17,710
then they spent $20,000 in
hardware cost or whatever.

407
00:19:17,710 --> 00:19:21,184
There's always these extra things
that they never mention so

408
00:19:21,184 --> 00:19:25,541
we do have to be careful with analogous
estimating, if it's even an option.

409
00:19:25,541 --> 00:19:26,898
Parametric estimating.

410
00:19:26,898 --> 00:19:33,000
This one is also fairly accurate, but
it does make some other assumptions.

411
00:19:33,000 --> 00:19:36,602
With parametric estimating,
what we're doing here is saying,

412
00:19:36,602 --> 00:19:39,952
I don't know the numbers, so
I'm gonna pay somebody else.

413
00:19:39,952 --> 00:19:43,101
I'm gonna pay somebody else, either a
third party entity, who just comes in and

414
00:19:43,101 --> 00:19:45,370
they have that information
together already.

415
00:19:45,370 --> 00:19:48,430
Or more commonly, I'm gonna get
some kind of a software package.

416
00:19:48,430 --> 00:19:51,700
Some kind of a software package
like Timberline for construction

417
00:19:51,700 --> 00:19:55,860
that I can plug in my data, and
it will generate the cost estimate for me.

418
00:19:55,860 --> 00:19:59,140
The cost of the materials, it'll even
put a little reserve in there for

419
00:19:59,140 --> 00:20:03,260
fluctuations in pricing,
the cost for labor, and so on.

420
00:20:03,260 --> 00:20:08,090
I'm getting my estimates from statistical
data gathered by a third party, and

421
00:20:08,090 --> 00:20:11,795
either presented to me directly or through
the use of some kind of software, right.

422
00:20:11,795 --> 00:20:14,440
That's what parametric estimating is.

423
00:20:14,440 --> 00:20:18,610
It's rarely free, and so
it almost always costs money.

424
00:20:18,610 --> 00:20:21,780
And it almost always
requires a subscription.

425
00:20:21,780 --> 00:20:23,880
This is data that is constantly changing.

426
00:20:23,880 --> 00:20:27,220
So if you're using parametric data
from a year ago, it's out of date.

427
00:20:27,220 --> 00:20:29,460
You're not gonna get
a very accurate result.

428
00:20:29,460 --> 00:20:33,250
So when you sign up like this, there's
usually a monthly fee that you're having

429
00:20:33,250 --> 00:20:36,780
to pay to keep subscribed so
you have the latest data.

430
00:20:36,780 --> 00:20:40,462
Again, not something that may be
a available for a small company,

431
00:20:40,462 --> 00:20:42,974
but for
a large company it can be a necessity.

432
00:20:44,440 --> 00:20:45,925
All right, bottom up estimating.

433
00:20:45,925 --> 00:20:50,841
Bottom up estimating is a technique that
we use when we have no idea what the cost

434
00:20:50,841 --> 00:20:53,000
of our project is going to be.

435
00:20:53,000 --> 00:20:55,390
So here I am looking at this
work break down structure.

436
00:20:55,390 --> 00:20:58,070
This layout of all the different
activities that need to be completed as

437
00:20:58,070 --> 00:21:00,940
part of my project, and
I don't know how much it's going to cost.

438
00:21:00,940 --> 00:21:05,062
So I need to create one big, fat number
that represents the amount of money I'm

439
00:21:05,062 --> 00:21:07,800
going to come out of pocket
to finish this project.

440
00:21:07,800 --> 00:21:10,300
But instead of looking at big picture and

441
00:21:10,300 --> 00:21:13,760
trying to figure it out,
we go to our work breakdown structure.

442
00:21:13,760 --> 00:21:17,130
And we go to the bottom level of that work
breakdown structure where the individual

443
00:21:17,130 --> 00:21:18,480
work packages are.

444
00:21:18,480 --> 00:21:20,950
And we estimate each
of those individually.

445
00:21:21,990 --> 00:21:24,870
By coming up with a cost by
the bottom level activities

446
00:21:24,870 --> 00:21:29,600
we can add that together and now we
know what the big cost is, all right.

447
00:21:29,600 --> 00:21:33,670
It's also called cost aggregation
which we don't see here on this.

448
00:21:33,670 --> 00:21:36,890
But you'll see that terminology
when you're reading books.

449
00:21:36,890 --> 00:21:39,420
You take all these individual entities,
you add them together,

450
00:21:39,420 --> 00:21:40,710
now you've got your total cost.

451
00:21:40,710 --> 00:21:45,538
This is one of the most accurate forms of
estimating because you're addressing each

452
00:21:45,538 --> 00:21:49,414
activity individually, and
you can get quotes from experts in each

453
00:21:49,414 --> 00:21:52,770
individual one, so
it works out really well.

454
00:21:52,770 --> 00:21:56,243
But it's also the most time and
labor intensive.

455
00:21:56,243 --> 00:21:58,210
It's a lot of work to go out and
get all of those quotes.

456
00:21:58,210 --> 00:22:00,790
You have got to reach
out to each individual,

457
00:22:00,790 --> 00:22:02,530
you've got to find subject matter experts.

458
00:22:02,530 --> 00:22:06,597
It really is a burden, and so that's one
that we use as kind of a last ditch,

459
00:22:06,597 --> 00:22:11,117
saying, hey I guess I have nothing else,
I don't have any analogous or parametric

460
00:22:11,117 --> 00:22:15,315
data to use, so I'm just going to figure
this out myself let's go this way and

461
00:22:15,315 --> 00:22:16,890
we total from the bottom up.

462
00:22:16,890 --> 00:22:19,094
All right.

463
00:22:19,094 --> 00:22:21,399
So those are three that
we've already seen,

464
00:22:21,399 --> 00:22:24,790
we saw those with schedule just
money now instead of time.

465
00:22:24,790 --> 00:22:28,325
And same thing with this next one,
three point estimating.

466
00:22:28,325 --> 00:22:30,693
Three point estimating,
you'll remember, actually hang on,

467
00:22:30,693 --> 00:22:32,600
you've got this in your notes,
the formula.

468
00:22:32,600 --> 00:22:37,696
It's not a crazy complex formula or
anything, but let's see if I can find it.

469
00:22:37,696 --> 00:22:38,670
Here we go.

470
00:22:38,670 --> 00:22:43,980
With three point estimating,
this is where we have our quotes.

471
00:22:43,980 --> 00:22:47,030
We go out and we get quotes from
different people, or from one person.

472
00:22:47,030 --> 00:22:47,820
We know that one person.

473
00:22:47,820 --> 00:22:49,540
We say we're gonna build this house.

474
00:22:49,540 --> 00:22:51,610
Or I need to purchase wood.

475
00:22:51,610 --> 00:22:54,860
What is the best case scenario price.

476
00:22:54,860 --> 00:22:59,350
What's the worse case scenario price and
what's the most likely or

477
00:22:59,350 --> 00:23:01,940
the normal price, okay.

478
00:23:01,940 --> 00:23:04,270
And they'll give me those three estimates.

479
00:23:04,270 --> 00:23:08,560
We then feed that through a very simple
formula to generate a result and

480
00:23:08,560 --> 00:23:11,730
that result tells us what
we're most likely to pay.

481
00:23:11,730 --> 00:23:14,660
So, the formula,
again we covered this in schedule,

482
00:23:14,660 --> 00:23:19,450
but just to refresh us in case you skipped
that episode for some reason, is that,

483
00:23:19,450 --> 00:23:24,550
if we want to do the triangular
distribution which is not as accurate.

484
00:23:24,550 --> 00:23:28,860
You basically take your optimistic value,
your most likely value, and

485
00:23:28,860 --> 00:23:30,320
your pessimistic value,

486
00:23:30,320 --> 00:23:34,560
you add them together and divide them
by three effectively averaging them.

487
00:23:34,560 --> 00:23:36,790
And you take the average and
that's the number that you act on.

488
00:23:37,920 --> 00:23:41,420
To make it a little bit more accurate
though, because the optimistic or

489
00:23:41,420 --> 00:23:42,700
the pessimistic might be outliers.

490
00:23:42,700 --> 00:23:46,550
They might be massively,
way off from what the most likely is.

491
00:23:46,550 --> 00:23:48,390
We may choose to do a beta distribution.

492
00:23:48,390 --> 00:23:50,232
And this is the way
that I normally see it.

493
00:23:50,232 --> 00:23:52,799
I don't think I've ever done
triangular in production but

494
00:23:52,799 --> 00:23:54,758
the beta distribution
is what I normally do.

495
00:23:54,758 --> 00:23:59,276
And that's where we take our
optimistic and our pessimistic, and

496
00:23:59,276 --> 00:24:01,380
we add them to our most likely.

497
00:24:01,380 --> 00:24:04,220
But we multiply the most likely by four.

498
00:24:04,220 --> 00:24:07,150
That assigns a heavier
weight to the most likely.

499
00:24:07,150 --> 00:24:09,130
It makes it count for more.

500
00:24:09,130 --> 00:24:12,900
And then we divide it by six again,
taking the average, all right.

501
00:24:12,900 --> 00:24:17,405
This makes sure that an outlier on
your pessimistic or an outlier on your

502
00:24:17,405 --> 00:24:22,452
optimistic doesn't sway your estimate
in a way that's negative, all right.

503
00:24:22,452 --> 00:24:25,900
If you've never seen that before jump back
to the schedule management episodes cuz

504
00:24:25,900 --> 00:24:28,264
we've worked through a few of them and
do the math on it and

505
00:24:28,264 --> 00:24:29,820
give you a chance to see it.

506
00:24:29,820 --> 00:24:32,480
The only difference is in that
episode we were talking about days,

507
00:24:32,480 --> 00:24:33,690
now we're talking about dollars.

508
00:24:33,690 --> 00:24:36,443
So other than that it's
the exact same concept.

509
00:24:39,718 --> 00:24:41,883
All right, so as far as that goes,

510
00:24:41,883 --> 00:24:46,310
not really seeing anything new here,
same stuff that we use.

511
00:24:46,310 --> 00:24:48,120
Reserve analysis, again, same things.

512
00:24:48,120 --> 00:24:49,950
We're about to see our deviation,
but up to this point,

513
00:24:49,950 --> 00:24:51,350
it's all pretty much the same.

514
00:24:51,350 --> 00:24:55,422
Reserve analysis, this is where we
just look at what's being done, and

515
00:24:55,422 --> 00:24:56,555
we say, all right,

516
00:24:56,555 --> 00:25:01,120
which of these estimates do we have where
the error rate might be a little higher.

517
00:25:01,120 --> 00:25:03,190
Which of these have the most unknowns?

518
00:25:03,190 --> 00:25:08,410
And in those scenarios we may need
to build in a cash reserve, right?

519
00:25:08,410 --> 00:25:13,000
Just like with schedule though, we need
to be very, very transparent about that.

520
00:25:13,000 --> 00:25:16,150
When we create our budget
if we quote one number for

521
00:25:16,150 --> 00:25:20,209
our budget for the project,
that needs to include the reserve.

522
00:25:20,209 --> 00:25:24,498
And the reserve should be clearly
noted that, hey, my project is a $1

523
00:25:24,498 --> 00:25:29,087
million project, and I've got
$50,000 in reserves built into it.

524
00:25:29,087 --> 00:25:32,280
>> So that should be clearly
noted as a budget item.

525
00:25:32,280 --> 00:25:34,460
And that way when people
look at the project,

526
00:25:34,460 --> 00:25:39,200
they know, hey, it's $1 million project,
but they only expect to pay $950,000.

527
00:25:39,200 --> 00:25:43,340
It's only if something goes wrong that
they have to tap into this other $50,000.

528
00:25:43,340 --> 00:25:46,950
We wanna make sure that's out there,
because, excuse me,

529
00:25:46,950 --> 00:25:50,480
people need to know when things
are going wrong, when something,

530
00:25:50,480 --> 00:25:52,090
when we're tapping into that reserve.

531
00:25:52,090 --> 00:25:55,250
Hopefully we don't have to, but
if we are that, then we know it's there.

532
00:25:55,250 --> 00:25:58,290
But the other thing is to avoid
the appearance of impropriety.

533
00:25:58,290 --> 00:26:03,828
That $50,000 is sitting there earmarked
for trouble days, right, rainy days.

534
00:26:03,828 --> 00:26:08,420
We don't wanna be tapping into that
to offset things that are mistakes or

535
00:26:08,420 --> 00:26:09,970
whatever that were made on our part.

536
00:26:09,970 --> 00:26:13,210
So we need to be very transparent
about those reserves.

537
00:26:13,210 --> 00:26:14,880
How much do you need in reserves?

538
00:26:14,880 --> 00:26:17,620
Well, there's no one size
fits all formula here.

539
00:26:17,620 --> 00:26:21,150
It comes down to the error
rate of your calculations.

540
00:26:21,150 --> 00:26:23,744
If you get quote from somebody,
and you have your pessimistic and

541
00:26:23,744 --> 00:26:27,340
your optimistic and your most likely,
and you start to look at these numbers.

542
00:26:27,340 --> 00:26:32,100
And the number you come up with
in your estimate is way off

543
00:26:32,100 --> 00:26:37,010
from what your most likely is, instead of
flagging that as the actual budget for

544
00:26:37,010 --> 00:26:41,470
that item, you might choose
to specify that as a reserve.

545
00:26:41,470 --> 00:26:43,050
Okay, let me give you an example.

546
00:26:43,050 --> 00:26:46,950
I know I said refer to the other episode,
but I'm gonna do an example anyway.

547
00:26:46,950 --> 00:26:50,930
So let's say I go out and
I get a quote from somebody, and

548
00:26:50,930 --> 00:26:55,470
they tell me the optimistic,
the best case scenario for

549
00:26:55,470 --> 00:26:57,360
this thing, in fact,
let me write it that way.

550
00:26:57,360 --> 00:27:01,990
The best case scenario is going to be that

551
00:27:01,990 --> 00:27:06,910
this particular activity is
gonna cost me $250, all right?

552
00:27:06,910 --> 00:27:09,153
They tell me that most likely

553
00:27:12,660 --> 00:27:17,559
it's gonna cost me around $500, okay.

554
00:27:17,559 --> 00:27:23,561
But if workers go on strike,
if political events occur,

555
00:27:23,561 --> 00:27:28,562
if who knows what goes on,
then our worst-case

556
00:27:28,562 --> 00:27:34,206
scenario is that it could
cost as much as $1000.

557
00:27:34,206 --> 00:27:35,645
Right, no, let's see if we can go higher.

558
00:27:35,645 --> 00:27:38,221
Let's just say it's $1500.

559
00:27:38,221 --> 00:27:41,040
All right, so that would be my
worst case scenario, all right?

560
00:27:41,040 --> 00:27:45,830
So I then feed that into my formula,
the optimistic

561
00:27:45,830 --> 00:27:51,720
plus the most likely, times four,

562
00:27:51,720 --> 00:27:56,480
plus the pessimistic,
all divided by six, right?

563
00:27:56,480 --> 00:28:00,100
That's that basic formula for
doing the beta distribution.

564
00:28:00,100 --> 00:28:01,260
So we feed that in here.

565
00:28:01,260 --> 00:28:06,342
Optimistic is 250

566
00:28:06,342 --> 00:28:13,970
+ (500 x 4) + 1500.

567
00:28:13,970 --> 00:28:17,057
All right, and
then we're going to divide all that by 6.

568
00:28:17,057 --> 00:28:20,780
All right, so let's work this in our head.

569
00:28:20,780 --> 00:28:22,907
So that's-
>> 3750.

570
00:28:22,907 --> 00:28:29,524
>> All right, so 3750 divided by 6,
which I don't know.

571
00:28:29,524 --> 00:28:30,920
So let's just get our old calculator up.

572
00:28:32,330 --> 00:28:35,773
We're exceeding my education level here.

573
00:28:35,773 --> 00:28:40,769
So 3,750 divide by 6 is 625, okay.

574
00:28:40,769 --> 00:28:44,087
So I get a quote.

575
00:28:44,087 --> 00:28:46,278
I get multiple quotes, and
then I average this out.

576
00:28:46,278 --> 00:28:50,109
And I come up with 625 for
my beta distribution.

577
00:28:50,109 --> 00:28:54,750
Okay, I could run with 625 as my budget.

578
00:28:54,750 --> 00:28:56,670
All right, I could budget 625.

579
00:28:56,670 --> 00:29:02,650
But when I look at this budget,
I know the most likely is 500, okay.

580
00:29:02,650 --> 00:29:09,350
This 625, that's over 20% higher
than the most likely, okay?

581
00:29:09,350 --> 00:29:13,780
So, do I want to just incorporate that
in knowing that I could be 20% off?

582
00:29:13,780 --> 00:29:16,994
Well, I need to go back and
look at my cost management plan.

583
00:29:16,994 --> 00:29:18,400
What does it say in there?

584
00:29:18,400 --> 00:29:22,510
In the cost management plan,
am I allowed to be this far off, right?

585
00:29:22,510 --> 00:29:26,970
Remember back here in
the cost management plan,

586
00:29:26,970 --> 00:29:30,280
we have level of accuracy and
control thresholds.

587
00:29:30,280 --> 00:29:34,520
Maybe we have in there that our
estimates need to be plus or minus 5%.

588
00:29:34,520 --> 00:29:38,669
Well, the number that I
just got right here is over

589
00:29:38,669 --> 00:29:42,655
20% off from my most likely scenario.

590
00:29:44,005 --> 00:29:47,245
This may exceed the control threshold
that we've got designated in

591
00:29:47,245 --> 00:29:48,575
our cost management plan.

592
00:29:48,575 --> 00:29:54,071
And if that's the case,
we'll need to list this

593
00:29:54,071 --> 00:29:59,590
as estimate $500, reserve $125.

594
00:29:59,590 --> 00:30:02,490
That way we're being very transparent.

595
00:30:02,490 --> 00:30:07,420
We're acting with that 625 that we came
up with from the beta distribution,

596
00:30:07,420 --> 00:30:09,900
but people know that this
is what we expect to pay.

597
00:30:09,900 --> 00:30:11,120
We expect to pay 500.

598
00:30:11,120 --> 00:30:12,610
That's our most likely.

599
00:30:12,610 --> 00:30:15,575
But now we've got that
reserve built in of 125.

600
00:30:15,575 --> 00:30:17,875
We stick that in our reserve funds, and

601
00:30:17,875 --> 00:30:21,760
we specify under what conditions
that money is accessible.

602
00:30:21,760 --> 00:30:25,889
You might have $50,000 in that reserve
fund, and this is just $125 of it.

603
00:30:25,889 --> 00:30:31,376
But you put in that reserve note when
you designate the reserve budget,

604
00:30:31,376 --> 00:30:36,635
you specify this $125 is earmarked for
this one activity.

605
00:30:36,635 --> 00:30:40,215
If this one activity goes over,
here's $125 for it.

606
00:30:40,215 --> 00:30:44,680
If some other activity goes over,
this $125 is not for that, right?

607
00:30:44,680 --> 00:30:45,856
It cannot be touched for that.

608
00:30:45,856 --> 00:30:47,810
So you're designating it and
being very clear and

609
00:30:47,810 --> 00:30:50,590
transparent about what that
reserve analysis is for.

610
00:30:50,590 --> 00:30:53,000
And in your documentation,
you put this formula.

611
00:30:53,000 --> 00:30:54,770
And you say, here's how I came up with it.

612
00:30:54,770 --> 00:30:56,530
I got these three quotes, and

613
00:30:56,530 --> 00:31:01,380
based on these three quotes, the worst
case scenario was really far off.

614
00:31:01,380 --> 00:31:05,140
So, I felt the need to do
a beta distribution and

615
00:31:05,140 --> 00:31:07,090
come up with a reserve to put in there.

616
00:31:07,090 --> 00:31:07,970
Here's how I did it.

617
00:31:07,970 --> 00:31:09,760
I didn't make this up.

618
00:31:09,760 --> 00:31:15,450
I am acting in good faith on the number
that I was quoted as the most likely.

619
00:31:15,450 --> 00:31:17,710
But I'm just putting in
a little safety net.

620
00:31:17,710 --> 00:31:19,390
Transparency is very important.

621
00:31:19,390 --> 00:31:21,510
That's the way reserve analysis works.

622
00:31:21,510 --> 00:31:22,950
There's other ways to do it.

623
00:31:22,950 --> 00:31:24,350
If you talk to any accountant,

624
00:31:24,350 --> 00:31:28,670
they can bend your ears for hours on end
on other ways to calculate out reserves.

625
00:31:28,670 --> 00:31:31,930
But this is the one that's the easiest and
the most likely to show up on the exam.

626
00:31:33,740 --> 00:31:36,300
All right, well, Ronnie I just noticed
that we're out of time on this segment so

627
00:31:36,300 --> 00:31:38,420
why don't we stop here and take a break?

628
00:31:38,420 --> 00:31:41,360
And when we get back we've got
some more tools and techniques.

629
00:31:41,360 --> 00:31:44,200
So everything we've talked about so
far is kind of stuff we've already seen.

630
00:31:44,200 --> 00:31:48,705
So we're about to move into some
that are new, which is exciting.

631
00:31:48,705 --> 00:31:49,205
>> Yep.
>> Right?

632
00:31:49,205 --> 00:31:49,705
>> Right.

633
00:31:49,705 --> 00:31:51,053
>> All right, well ladies and

634
00:31:51,053 --> 00:31:53,553
gentlemen stay tuned.
We'll be back after this.

635
00:31:53,553 --> 00:31:56,759
[SOUND] All right,

636
00:31:56,759 --> 00:32:02,196
welcome back, everybody.
So

637
00:32:02,196 --> 00:32:06,806
let's continue to take a look at the tools
and techniques of estimating our costs.

638
00:32:06,806 --> 00:32:08,756
We moved through the first six, and

639
00:32:08,756 --> 00:32:12,336
there really wasn't anything new there.
These are all things that we saw inside

640
00:32:12,336 --> 00:32:15,350
of our schedule plan development also.

641
00:32:15,350 --> 00:32:18,910
So now let's take a look at some that
are a little more unique, right?

642
00:32:18,910 --> 00:32:21,630
Number seven is cost of quality.

643
00:32:21,630 --> 00:32:26,600
Cost of quality is a concept
where we make two assumptions.

644
00:32:26,600 --> 00:32:30,140
And we're gonna talk about these
later in the quality knowledge areas.

645
00:32:30,140 --> 00:32:34,390
But you deal with quality control and
quality assurance.

646
00:32:34,390 --> 00:32:38,560
Quality control is where we ensure
that things are turned out right

647
00:32:38,560 --> 00:32:39,930
the first time.

648
00:32:39,930 --> 00:32:42,820
We make sure we only have to do
something once because it was done right

649
00:32:42,820 --> 00:32:44,240
from the beginning.

650
00:32:44,240 --> 00:32:47,160
Quality assurance is where we
check something after the fact,

651
00:32:47,160 --> 00:32:50,820
and we say it's already done,
did it get done to our standards?

652
00:32:50,820 --> 00:32:53,330
And if not we redo it.

653
00:32:53,330 --> 00:32:56,310
And any time you're dealing
with numbers in a project

654
00:32:56,310 --> 00:32:58,470
you're weighing those two ideas.

655
00:32:58,470 --> 00:33:03,610
Do I pay money now to prevent
a problem before it happens or

656
00:33:03,610 --> 00:33:06,580
do I pay money afterwards
to fix the problem,

657
00:33:06,580 --> 00:33:09,600
hoping that the problem just
doesn't happen in the first place?

658
00:33:09,600 --> 00:33:11,980
And normally you'll do
a mixture of the two.

659
00:33:11,980 --> 00:33:15,560
You'll do a mixture of quality control and
quality assurance.

660
00:33:15,560 --> 00:33:18,290
Well both of those have a cost.

661
00:33:18,290 --> 00:33:20,490
Quality control always has a cost.

662
00:33:20,490 --> 00:33:24,300
You're putting money in place to
prevent a problem from occurring.

663
00:33:24,300 --> 00:33:25,860
Quality assurance may or

664
00:33:25,860 --> 00:33:30,780
may not have a cost because it's dependent
on the problem actually happening, right?

665
00:33:30,780 --> 00:33:36,820
So if I'm gonna build a house, somebody's
gotta put up the walls There's a chance

666
00:33:36,820 --> 00:33:41,150
they can put the wall up wrong, and if
they do they're going to have to redo it.

667
00:33:41,150 --> 00:33:45,000
So do I spend some money
hiring somebody to go and

668
00:33:45,000 --> 00:33:49,800
check the blueprints and stuff before the
wall goes in to make sure it's done right?

669
00:33:49,800 --> 00:33:54,010
Or, do I just let them put up the wall,
and pay somebody to come in and check

670
00:33:54,010 --> 00:33:58,420
to make sure it's right after the fact,
and then have them redo it if it's wrong.

671
00:33:58,420 --> 00:34:00,589
And Ronnie,
you probably remember this building.

672
00:34:00,589 --> 00:34:04,203
We got that wall on the other side of the
building that one end of the wall is off

673
00:34:04,203 --> 00:34:05,290
by about four inches.

674
00:34:05,290 --> 00:34:06,940
It makes it a diagonal wall.

675
00:34:06,940 --> 00:34:09,110
That's the kind of mistake
that can happen in a building.

676
00:34:09,110 --> 00:34:10,390
It wasn't supposed to be that way.

677
00:34:10,390 --> 00:34:11,820
It's just kind of what happened.

678
00:34:11,820 --> 00:34:15,210
So there is a cost of quality.

679
00:34:15,210 --> 00:34:18,970
And the PMI, you know, they actually
have a little chart in the PMBOK and

680
00:34:18,970 --> 00:34:22,740
here we go, which they have
the cost of conformance And

681
00:34:22,740 --> 00:34:24,670
the cost of non-conformance.

682
00:34:24,670 --> 00:34:27,310
That cost of conformance,
that's like quality control,

683
00:34:27,310 --> 00:34:31,500
making sure that you conform,
that you do it right the first time.

684
00:34:31,500 --> 00:34:35,760
And then cost of non-conformance
is If we don't do it right,

685
00:34:35,760 --> 00:34:39,360
what's gonna cost to fix it,
to put it right?

686
00:34:39,360 --> 00:34:42,930
So under cost of conformance
it's prevention, right?

687
00:34:42,930 --> 00:34:45,890
Prevention, making sure that things get
done right from the beginning, training,

688
00:34:45,890 --> 00:34:48,282
documentation, equipment, time and so on.

689
00:34:48,282 --> 00:34:52,660
And appraisal, testing,
making sure that something works, and

690
00:34:52,660 --> 00:34:54,280
going through some experiments.

691
00:34:54,280 --> 00:34:56,590
And then nonconformance, rework.

692
00:34:56,590 --> 00:34:59,450
Maybe it's so
bad you have to scrap it, right?

693
00:34:59,450 --> 00:35:01,110
[LAUGH] Funny story,

694
00:35:01,110 --> 00:35:04,300
there was a Public's grocery store
that was being built here in town.

695
00:35:04,300 --> 00:35:05,540
It was a long time ago, it's closed now.

696
00:35:05,540 --> 00:35:09,250
But when they built it They
brought in this big crane, and

697
00:35:09,250 --> 00:35:12,110
they'd put up the four
walls to the building.

698
00:35:12,110 --> 00:35:15,410
And then they realized they didn't
have a way to get the crane out.

699
00:35:15,410 --> 00:35:16,210
>> Yeah.
>> They put these

700
00:35:16,210 --> 00:35:18,690
walls up around the crane,
and the crane was stuck, and

701
00:35:18,690 --> 00:35:21,160
they had to tear down one of
the walls to get the crane out.

702
00:35:21,160 --> 00:35:22,010
It was hilarious.

703
00:35:22,010 --> 00:35:25,780
To us, not to the people on the project.

704
00:35:25,780 --> 00:35:27,410
But that's a true story right there,

705
00:35:27,410 --> 00:35:31,140
and the crane was stuck inside
the building, very funny.

706
00:35:31,140 --> 00:35:34,160
So in that case, one of the walls
had to be completely rebuilt.

707
00:35:34,160 --> 00:35:37,880
They had to tear the wall down, get the
crane out, and then put the wall back up.

708
00:35:37,880 --> 00:35:41,440
So that's the kind of thing that
happens with non-conformance that

709
00:35:41,440 --> 00:35:42,780
obviously costs money.

710
00:35:42,780 --> 00:35:43,680
They had to buy new bricks.

711
00:35:43,680 --> 00:35:46,250
You can't tear down brick walls
without breaking a few of them.

712
00:35:46,250 --> 00:35:49,970
And so they had to redo that,
that increased the cost of the project.

713
00:35:49,970 --> 00:35:51,410
It was a big mistake.

714
00:35:51,410 --> 00:35:52,680
Where did that money come from?

715
00:35:52,680 --> 00:35:53,920
Did it come from insurance?

716
00:35:53,920 --> 00:35:57,020
Was it a bonded thing that
gets covered by insurance?

717
00:35:57,020 --> 00:35:59,810
Or did it have to come directly
from the reserves of the project?

718
00:35:59,810 --> 00:36:03,540
Or did that make the project
run over budget and

719
00:36:03,540 --> 00:36:05,960
somebody had to approve of
the expenditure to move forward?

720
00:36:05,960 --> 00:36:07,970
The money came from somewhere and

721
00:36:07,970 --> 00:36:12,070
we just wanna make sure as project
managers that we try and see that coming.

722
00:36:12,070 --> 00:36:14,990
That we see instances like
these as being possible, and

723
00:36:14,990 --> 00:36:17,272
have the reserves to be
able to deal with that.

724
00:36:17,272 --> 00:36:21,280
All right,
they also list things like liabilities.

725
00:36:21,280 --> 00:36:26,030
That if you get a workplace injury, or
something like that during the project.

726
00:36:26,030 --> 00:36:27,450
Lost business,

727
00:36:27,450 --> 00:36:31,210
you see lost business all the time when
there is road work that's being done and

728
00:36:31,210 --> 00:36:35,790
access to a building gets cut off,
that people do lose money because of that.

729
00:36:35,790 --> 00:36:39,930
As we do projects in our own organization,
there might be things where we lose money.

730
00:36:39,930 --> 00:36:42,270
We'll use IT Pro T.V. as an example.

731
00:36:42,270 --> 00:36:47,170
Any time we shut our website down for
maintenance, we might be losing customers.

732
00:36:47,170 --> 00:36:49,020
If somebody tries to come to
the site during that time and

733
00:36:49,020 --> 00:36:51,528
sees it's under maintenance they go I'm
not gonna sign up with this company,

734
00:36:51,528 --> 00:36:52,810
they're under maintenance.

735
00:36:52,810 --> 00:36:55,360
So that's the kind of thing
we have to watch out for.

736
00:36:55,360 --> 00:37:00,750
So when we talk about the cost of quality
we're talking about exactly that.

737
00:37:00,750 --> 00:37:06,050
How much money do we need to set aside to
either prevent problems from happening or

738
00:37:06,050 --> 00:37:07,890
to fix the problems once they occur?

739
00:37:07,890 --> 00:37:08,400
>> Right.

740
00:37:08,400 --> 00:37:10,850
>> And we'll see a lot more of
that when we get into risk and

741
00:37:10,850 --> 00:37:12,750
the quality knowledge areas.

742
00:37:14,710 --> 00:37:16,765
All right,
our project management software.

743
00:37:16,765 --> 00:37:18,300
Now I always thought that was funny.

744
00:37:18,300 --> 00:37:22,360
A lot of project management software
out there doesn't do budget.

745
00:37:22,360 --> 00:37:24,532
>> Right.
>> Just doesn't do it, right?

746
00:37:24,532 --> 00:37:26,560
Ganttproject doesn't do it.

747
00:37:26,560 --> 00:37:29,370
Projectlibre has some really basic stuff.

748
00:37:29,370 --> 00:37:31,800
Microsoft Project, for
the longest time wouldn't do it.

749
00:37:31,800 --> 00:37:34,080
In the latest versions
of Microsoft Project,

750
00:37:34,080 --> 00:37:37,830
they actually have budget functions in
there and they don't work very well.

751
00:37:37,830 --> 00:37:41,710
In fact, Microsoft will even tell you,
it's here, you can use it for

752
00:37:41,710 --> 00:37:45,330
estimates but
don't submit this to the IRS.

753
00:37:45,330 --> 00:37:47,960
Don't use this for
your official accounting.

754
00:37:47,960 --> 00:37:50,730
So we almost always have separate
software that's being used for

755
00:37:50,730 --> 00:37:53,790
managing the finances of our project.

756
00:37:53,790 --> 00:37:56,020
And it could be something
as simple as QuickBooks.

757
00:37:56,020 --> 00:37:58,870
But it's usually something
much more advanced.

758
00:37:58,870 --> 00:38:01,160
And so here where it says
project management software,

759
00:38:01,160 --> 00:38:03,590
it might be separate financial software.

760
00:38:03,590 --> 00:38:06,190
If you're fortunate enough to have
project management software that does do

761
00:38:06,190 --> 00:38:13,780
the accounting side, like I think Sage
actually does the accounting inside of it.

762
00:38:13,780 --> 00:38:16,360
So if you've got something
like that then great.

763
00:38:16,360 --> 00:38:18,710
But if you don't, then you're
gonna be doing it somewhere else.

764
00:38:20,800 --> 00:38:23,332
All right, vendor bid analysis.

765
00:38:23,332 --> 00:38:27,660
All right, now we are gonna get into this
a little more on the procurement knowledge

766
00:38:27,660 --> 00:38:29,530
area when we talk about contracts.

767
00:38:29,530 --> 00:38:34,600
But if you need to buy something, and
you put it out for bid, you're going

768
00:38:34,600 --> 00:38:39,470
to get bids back from various sellers,
people who want to sell you this product.

769
00:38:39,470 --> 00:38:40,520
How do you pick?

770
00:38:40,520 --> 00:38:42,630
Well, there's different
techniques available, and

771
00:38:42,630 --> 00:38:45,250
it's called vendor bid analysis.

772
00:38:45,250 --> 00:38:47,095
And let me just bring up the notes here.

773
00:38:47,095 --> 00:38:49,230
Cuz I think you listed some
of these didn't you Ronnie?

774
00:38:49,230 --> 00:38:49,730
>> No I just didn't find it.
>> No?

775
00:38:49,730 --> 00:38:51,780
All right, that's fine.

776
00:38:51,780 --> 00:38:54,870
Like I said we're gonna deal more with
this under the procurement section.

777
00:38:54,870 --> 00:38:58,060
For those of you that have
been with the PMI a while

778
00:38:58,060 --> 00:39:00,820
there used to be something called
the select seller process.

779
00:39:00,820 --> 00:39:04,250
And so we have this whole
seller selection process.

780
00:39:04,250 --> 00:39:05,370
Kinda dumb way to put it.

781
00:39:05,370 --> 00:39:07,450
But anyhow,
where you would pick the winning bid.

782
00:39:07,450 --> 00:39:09,540
Now it's been moved up under
the procurement section.

783
00:39:09,540 --> 00:39:10,990
So we're gonna see it a little bit later.

784
00:39:10,990 --> 00:39:13,450
But basically you need to
establish the criteria.

785
00:39:13,450 --> 00:39:15,730
How do you determine
who's the winning bidder?

786
00:39:15,730 --> 00:39:18,030
And a lot of people say well,
it's whoever is cheaper.

787
00:39:18,030 --> 00:39:19,660
But that's not always the case.

788
00:39:19,660 --> 00:39:23,600
Sometimes it's worth it to pay a little
more because you get better quality out of

789
00:39:23,600 --> 00:39:27,110
it, you get a faster timeline out of it,
you get better support, whatever it is.

790
00:39:27,110 --> 00:39:30,290
So it doesn't come down to the dollar
every time, unless you work for

791
00:39:30,290 --> 00:39:31,290
the U.S. government.

792
00:39:31,290 --> 00:39:34,740
So for the rest of us,
there are outlying factors.

793
00:39:34,740 --> 00:39:37,050
So how do we make that decision?

794
00:39:37,050 --> 00:39:40,470
And that's what they're talking about
when they say vendor bid analysis.

795
00:39:40,470 --> 00:39:42,350
How do we pick that winner?

796
00:39:42,350 --> 00:39:44,440
What is important for our company?

797
00:39:44,440 --> 00:39:46,570
If you've got a project
management plan in place,

798
00:39:46,570 --> 00:39:48,490
it's in there how you pick them right?

799
00:39:48,490 --> 00:39:51,115
But if it isn't, you've got to come
up with your own solution, and

800
00:39:51,115 --> 00:39:53,022
that becomes a part of
our cost management plan.

801
00:39:53,022 --> 00:39:58,322
All right, and then we have our
group decision making techniques.

802
00:39:58,322 --> 00:40:00,508
As we get our people together, and
start talking about the budgeting,

803
00:40:00,508 --> 00:40:01,572
how we're gonna be able to run it.

804
00:40:01,572 --> 00:40:05,638
We reached to our team,
our project management team and

805
00:40:05,638 --> 00:40:10,120
the subject matter experts
that we've accumulated.

806
00:40:10,120 --> 00:40:12,770
We gather the information from them and
put it together.

807
00:40:12,770 --> 00:40:15,250
Any time I get quotes,
quotes are good, but

808
00:40:15,250 --> 00:40:17,650
I always like to bounce
them off of somebody else.

809
00:40:17,650 --> 00:40:20,120
You know, get somebody and say,
hey, is this quote in line?

810
00:40:20,120 --> 00:40:22,380
Cuz you'll get weird things sometimes.

811
00:40:22,380 --> 00:40:27,680
One of my favorites, I work in IT,
I've worked in IT my entire professional

812
00:40:27,680 --> 00:40:32,860
career and one of the things I've noticed
is that when you send out bids on,

813
00:40:32,860 --> 00:40:36,060
bid requests on the internet you'll
get responses from all over.

814
00:40:36,060 --> 00:40:39,445
And a lot of times you'll get responses
from people who've never done

815
00:40:39,445 --> 00:40:43,935
what you're asking, but they'll send a bid
in anyways cuz they are willing to do it.

816
00:40:43,935 --> 00:40:46,305
And so I used to live out in Seattle for
a little while and

817
00:40:46,305 --> 00:40:49,175
one of my mentors out there,
he had this great technique.

818
00:40:49,175 --> 00:40:53,970
Any time you send out a software bid,
a request for bid, he would put in there,

819
00:40:53,970 --> 00:40:58,175
in the requirements, the software must do
A, B, and C which were real requirements.

820
00:40:58,175 --> 00:41:02,590
And then one of the last requirements
was he would put in there,

821
00:41:02,590 --> 00:41:07,060
must be able to synchronize
data with ToddStar database,

822
00:41:07,060 --> 00:41:10,430
and his name was Todd, and so must be able
to synchronize data with ToddStar database

823
00:41:10,430 --> 00:41:13,620
and I think he even went very specific,
like version 3.7 or something like that.

824
00:41:13,620 --> 00:41:16,580
And he would send out this bid and

825
00:41:16,580 --> 00:41:20,670
he would get responses back,
actual bids back from the companies.

826
00:41:20,670 --> 00:41:24,745
Ans a lot of them would say, yes I'm
compatible with ToddStar database 3.7.

827
00:41:24,745 --> 00:41:27,760
And he showed me that,
and I said why would they

828
00:41:27,760 --> 00:41:30,550
say they're compatible with
a product that you just made up?

829
00:41:30,550 --> 00:41:33,340
It's not even a real product, it's just
something made up out of his mind.

830
00:41:33,340 --> 00:41:37,200
He said the reason is, a lot of these
people will bid you the work and

831
00:41:37,200 --> 00:41:40,376
they'll say they're compatible with
the product that they're not, and

832
00:41:40,376 --> 00:41:42,400
then once you get going, they'll say, oh,

833
00:41:42,400 --> 00:41:46,560
we have to do custom development to
support that and your costs go up.

834
00:41:46,560 --> 00:41:49,092
And he learned that the hard
way years before and so

835
00:41:49,092 --> 00:41:51,323
he built that into his request for
quotes and

836
00:41:51,323 --> 00:41:54,716
that way he would be able to gauge
whether a company was doing that.

837
00:41:54,716 --> 00:41:58,342
And he knew when they put the a note
there, we're unfamiliar with that

838
00:41:58,342 --> 00:42:02,540
database, or no that that was a quote
that would be a little more accurate.

839
00:42:02,540 --> 00:42:06,260
But unfortunately in
the IT contracting world,

840
00:42:06,260 --> 00:42:07,490
a lot of people just
don't know the word no.

841
00:42:07,490 --> 00:42:11,100
They'll put whatever they want on that
quote knowing that they can charge you

842
00:42:11,100 --> 00:42:15,120
extra for additional bill time down the
rode, it's is not an uncommon practice.

843
00:42:15,120 --> 00:42:18,110
So, when we have group
decision making techniques

844
00:42:18,110 --> 00:42:19,030
these are the things that come up.

845
00:42:19,030 --> 00:42:23,090
When we get our groups together, we start
making decisions, you find information for

846
00:42:23,090 --> 00:42:26,550
people like that and you use that as
part of your decision making process.

847
00:42:26,550 --> 00:42:29,636
So yep one of the more entertaining
anecdotes that I have.

848
00:42:29,636 --> 00:42:34,266
All right, once all that's done, when
we've used whatever of these worked for

849
00:42:34,266 --> 00:42:37,890
us, and it really is you're just
gonna pick a couple of these.

850
00:42:37,890 --> 00:42:41,820
Because if I've got an analogous estimate
I don't need a parametric estimate,

851
00:42:41,820 --> 00:42:43,450
I don't need a lot of these others.

852
00:42:43,450 --> 00:42:47,890
So we figure out which one's we're going
to use and then we make our decision.

853
00:42:47,890 --> 00:42:51,880
We find out what our activity
cost estimate is going to be.

854
00:42:51,880 --> 00:42:56,320
Now notice they say the activity and
not the work package.

855
00:42:56,320 --> 00:42:59,680
When we did our schedule in
the last couple episodes,

856
00:42:59,680 --> 00:43:02,860
we were scheduling activities and
not work packages.

857
00:43:02,860 --> 00:43:07,360
The difference being that an activity
is normally going to be following that

858
00:43:07,360 --> 00:43:08,360
8-80 rule.

859
00:43:08,360 --> 00:43:11,290
Tasks that take more than eight hours but
less than 80 hours,

860
00:43:11,290 --> 00:43:13,150
not normally outside of that.

861
00:43:13,150 --> 00:43:15,650
And the reason is,
it's easier to deal with that,

862
00:43:15,650 --> 00:43:18,840
easier to deal with
the chunks of time like that.

863
00:43:18,840 --> 00:43:20,800
Well, money is the same way.

864
00:43:20,800 --> 00:43:25,650
You don't want to micro mange
your expenses based on individual

865
00:43:25,650 --> 00:43:26,430
work packages.

866
00:43:26,430 --> 00:43:29,700
It might be a one hour package,
or whatever it's just too much.

867
00:43:29,700 --> 00:43:34,594
So, by binding this to the schedule we can
track our manage at the same time it's

868
00:43:34,594 --> 00:43:38,758
tracking time and that's why these
great charts that show Ttime and

869
00:43:38,758 --> 00:43:40,970
money represented on the two axes.

870
00:43:40,970 --> 00:43:43,174
Is that the plural for axis, axes?

871
00:43:43,174 --> 00:43:44,380
>> Sure.

872
00:43:44,380 --> 00:43:46,610
>> I don't know whatever, axis I.

873
00:43:46,610 --> 00:43:48,286
>> [LAUGH]
>> So anyhow, we can map time and

874
00:43:48,286 --> 00:43:51,430
money like that because
we've tied them together.

875
00:43:51,430 --> 00:43:56,096
So you want your estimates to be tied
to the activities in your schedule,

876
00:43:56,096 --> 00:44:00,838
which in turn are usually aggregates
of work packages from your work break

877
00:44:00,838 --> 00:44:02,000
down structure.

878
00:44:02,000 --> 00:44:07,190
Any time you have an estimate, you need
to document the basis of the estimate.

879
00:44:07,190 --> 00:44:08,940
How did you come up with that number?

880
00:44:08,940 --> 00:44:11,520
You should never make a number
up off the top of your head.

881
00:44:11,520 --> 00:44:14,510
That's okay back in the charter phase and

882
00:44:14,510 --> 00:44:16,310
as you draft that
original scope statement.

883
00:44:16,310 --> 00:44:18,720
It's okay to make stuff
out of your head then, but

884
00:44:18,720 --> 00:44:22,390
by the time we get here to doing
the budget, make-up time is over.

885
00:44:22,390 --> 00:44:25,550
This needs to be real numbers,
you need to have quotes to back it up,

886
00:44:25,550 --> 00:44:27,090
or formulas that you did.

887
00:44:27,090 --> 00:44:28,600
You need to be able to show that math.

888
00:44:28,600 --> 00:44:34,510
That needs to be attached to your
estimates so that if it goes wrong,

889
00:44:34,510 --> 00:44:38,480
if the estimate turns out to be
wildly inaccurate, you can show why.

890
00:44:38,480 --> 00:44:40,560
You can show,
hey this is the information I had,

891
00:44:40,560 --> 00:44:44,130
it was the best available at the time,
here's how we reach that decision.

892
00:44:44,130 --> 00:44:48,760
Sorry it's higher, but that was
the information we had at the time.

893
00:44:48,760 --> 00:44:50,710
It's still wrong,
you still have to deal with it, but

894
00:44:50,710 --> 00:44:51,910
at least people will understand.

895
00:44:51,910 --> 00:44:53,755
It wasn't malicious, it wasn't ineptitude.

896
00:44:53,755 --> 00:44:56,690
You're only as good as
the information that you have.

897
00:44:58,580 --> 00:45:00,850
And then lastly, project document updates.

898
00:45:00,850 --> 00:45:05,510
If we don't have a cost management plan,
we look at all the tools and

899
00:45:05,510 --> 00:45:08,690
techniques that we used here and
we take that and we put it

900
00:45:08,690 --> 00:45:12,610
into a cost management plan, which becomes
a part of the project management plan.

901
00:45:12,610 --> 00:45:15,570
So that there's our project document
updates, it goes in there, and

902
00:45:15,570 --> 00:45:16,540
now we're in business.

903
00:45:17,760 --> 00:45:20,900
All right, so
this is how estimating the cost works.

904
00:45:20,900 --> 00:45:24,750
That took us, I don't know, maybe half
an hour here of talking about it.

905
00:45:24,750 --> 00:45:29,420
Remember, you're going to do that for
each and every activity

906
00:45:29,420 --> 00:45:33,750
throughout your entire project and you're
estimating not just the labor cost but

907
00:45:33,750 --> 00:45:38,110
the material cost in quantity,
also It's a lot of work.

908
00:45:38,110 --> 00:45:41,490
So, don't think that just because we
talk about it in half an hour that

909
00:45:41,490 --> 00:45:43,620
this is easy and a quick thing.

910
00:45:43,620 --> 00:45:44,770
It's gonna take a lot of work.

911
00:45:44,770 --> 00:45:50,188
You know, its a lot of nose to
the grindstone, figuring that out and

912
00:45:50,188 --> 00:45:54,100
getting these numbers as
accurate as possible.

913
00:45:54,100 --> 00:45:58,250
All right, so let's see,
that is our estimating cost.

914
00:45:58,250 --> 00:46:02,810
Once that's done, now we've got
estimates attached to every activity,

915
00:46:02,810 --> 00:46:04,420
the rest of this is easy.

916
00:46:04,420 --> 00:46:06,470
Now we create our budget.

917
00:46:06,470 --> 00:46:08,690
Now that we know what each
activity is gonna cost,

918
00:46:08,690 --> 00:46:12,170
we can add all that together and now we
know what our project's gonna cost, right?

919
00:46:12,170 --> 00:46:13,000
Well, there's still room for

920
00:46:13,000 --> 00:46:17,370
variation, but we do, we have a pretty
good idea of what our budget is.

921
00:46:17,370 --> 00:46:21,310
And that means we're ready to move into,
determine the budget.

922
00:46:21,310 --> 00:46:26,970
Determining the budget is the third
process in the planning cost

923
00:46:26,970 --> 00:46:29,150
knowledge area, if I can say it,

924
00:46:29,150 --> 00:46:32,090
and it's got a lot to it, but
most of it's pretty straight forward.

925
00:46:32,090 --> 00:46:33,550
The hard work is done.

926
00:46:35,310 --> 00:46:36,560
So we start off with our inputs.

927
00:46:36,560 --> 00:46:38,330
What are we bringing into this, right?

928
00:46:38,330 --> 00:46:43,209
So on our input side, we're bringing in
that cost management plan, if we have one,

929
00:46:43,209 --> 00:46:44,460
our scope baseline.

930
00:46:44,460 --> 00:46:48,420
Most of this is what we had on the other
side, but the main two things that we need

931
00:46:48,420 --> 00:46:52,860
are these guys right here, activity cost
estimates and basis of the estimates.

932
00:46:52,860 --> 00:46:56,080
We need those estimates cuz that's
what our budget is gonna come from.

933
00:46:56,080 --> 00:47:00,160
The rest of these are the same
as the estimate cost process.

934
00:47:01,750 --> 00:47:03,940
Then we figure out our budget.

935
00:47:03,940 --> 00:47:08,210
The easiest tool, is this first one,
cost aggregation.

936
00:47:08,210 --> 00:47:10,050
We just add up all our estimates right?

937
00:47:10,050 --> 00:47:13,520
Simple addition like we all
learned in elementary school and

938
00:47:13,520 --> 00:47:16,033
supposedly mastered,
although I still have problems with.

939
00:47:16,033 --> 00:47:17,729
[LAUGH] So we add it all together.

940
00:47:17,729 --> 00:47:23,200
When you have that all added together, now
you know the total cost of your project.

941
00:47:23,200 --> 00:47:26,520
And since every estimate
was based on fact,

942
00:47:26,520 --> 00:47:31,700
the information you could find, you're
overall project estimate is pretty good.

943
00:47:31,700 --> 00:47:33,950
It's a really good estimate.

944
00:47:33,950 --> 00:47:36,020
It's not gonna be perfect,
they never are, right?

945
00:47:36,020 --> 00:47:40,038
So, we always have to plan for that, but
if we did we've done our reserve analysis

946
00:47:40,038 --> 00:47:43,009
and if you calculated reserve
on every activities you went,

947
00:47:43,009 --> 00:47:45,880
now you add up the reserve amount too,
and you pop that in.

948
00:47:45,880 --> 00:47:50,474
And so you might say, my project
is $750,000, that's my cost, and

949
00:47:50,474 --> 00:47:52,748
I need $200,000 in reserve.

950
00:47:52,748 --> 00:47:54,031
But it's not just,

951
00:47:54,031 --> 00:47:58,344
I need a check for 200 grand sitting
on my desk ready to be signed.

952
00:47:58,344 --> 00:48:01,424
It's these activities
have these contingencies,

953
00:48:01,424 --> 00:48:05,130
here's when I'll need to
draw upon that reserve.

954
00:48:05,130 --> 00:48:06,640
Very black and white.

955
00:48:06,640 --> 00:48:09,440
That there is no just random drawing for
the reserve.

956
00:48:09,440 --> 00:48:12,060
Every dollar in the reserve
should be ear-marked.

957
00:48:12,060 --> 00:48:17,120
For not just a particular activity but
a particular scenario in that activity.

958
00:48:17,120 --> 00:48:19,220
And if a different scenario plays out,

959
00:48:19,220 --> 00:48:21,290
that doesn't mean you can
tap into that reserve.

960
00:48:21,290 --> 00:48:25,090
You need to do a change ticket and
say well, the money's in the reserve.

961
00:48:25,090 --> 00:48:28,120
It was ear-marked for this result.

962
00:48:28,120 --> 00:48:30,300
We got an unexpected result so

963
00:48:30,300 --> 00:48:33,380
I want to submit a change ticket
to allow me to draw that funding.

964
00:48:33,380 --> 00:48:35,240
