The change ticket will either
get approved or denied.

965
00:48:35,240 --> 00:48:37,850
If it's denied money stays in
the reserve and you're out of luck.

966
00:48:37,850 --> 00:48:41,320
If it gets approved you draw the money
from the reserve and you go.

967
00:48:41,320 --> 00:48:45,870
But that helps us to
prevent any improprieties.

968
00:48:45,870 --> 00:48:48,130
Right?
That it is shown the money goes in and

969
00:48:48,130 --> 00:48:50,664
out of the reserve based
on what we specified.

970
00:48:50,664 --> 00:48:51,560
All right.

971
00:48:51,560 --> 00:48:54,440
So that's where reserve
analysis comes back in.

972
00:48:54,440 --> 00:48:59,430
We're not doing some overall
generic padding or whatever,

973
00:48:59,430 --> 00:49:03,130
we're just doing an aggregate of the
reserves that we've already calculated.

974
00:49:03,130 --> 00:49:07,240
Now, I do know some projects where
once they get that total number,

975
00:49:07,240 --> 00:49:10,440
then they add 10% more, or whatever.

976
00:49:10,440 --> 00:49:11,510
You can do that.

977
00:49:11,510 --> 00:49:13,940
Technically, it's against
our code of ethics though.

978
00:49:13,940 --> 00:49:16,360
On the exam, you don't do that.

979
00:49:16,360 --> 00:49:19,400
Unless it's clearly
designated what you're doing.

980
00:49:19,400 --> 00:49:21,850
Hey, I'm padding these numbers by 10%.

981
00:49:21,850 --> 00:49:23,430
Otherwise our estimates,

982
00:49:23,430 --> 00:49:27,590
they really need to be true accurate
estimates of what's gonna be done.

983
00:49:27,590 --> 00:49:29,829
Reserve needs to be clearly
denoted as reserve.

984
00:49:32,150 --> 00:49:33,310
All right.

985
00:49:33,310 --> 00:49:33,910
Other things.

986
00:49:33,910 --> 00:49:35,070
Expert judgment.

987
00:49:35,070 --> 00:49:36,340
Use our brains, right?

988
00:49:36,340 --> 00:49:37,390
That's why we get paid.

989
00:49:37,390 --> 00:49:39,750
So, just basically evaluating these,

990
00:49:39,750 --> 00:49:43,090
putting the information together,
making 1 plus 1 equal 2.

991
00:49:43,090 --> 00:49:45,360
Historical relationships.

992
00:49:45,360 --> 00:49:49,280
This is a good one because it's kind
of like the analogous estimating.

993
00:49:49,280 --> 00:49:52,650
That if we're about to move
into various cost things,

994
00:49:52,650 --> 00:49:57,290
if we're purchasing materials and so on,
we probably already have relationships

995
00:49:57,290 --> 00:50:01,100
with various vendors and a lot of
times those can result in discounts.

996
00:50:01,100 --> 00:50:01,620
>> Right.

997
00:50:01,620 --> 00:50:02,860
>> So I used to get this all the time,

998
00:50:02,860 --> 00:50:05,872
where we would buy computer
equipment from CDW.

999
00:50:05,872 --> 00:50:10,370
CDW is a big computer and electronics
dealer here in the United States.

1000
00:50:10,370 --> 00:50:11,780
I think they're all over the world.

1001
00:50:11,780 --> 00:50:16,040
But the more you buy from them,
the bigger discount you get.

1002
00:50:16,040 --> 00:50:18,180
And so we would go and get quotes.

1003
00:50:18,180 --> 00:50:21,460
And the quotes were based off of
what we had done at that time and

1004
00:50:21,460 --> 00:50:23,720
the values that they would quote us.

1005
00:50:23,720 --> 00:50:26,260
But when we went to place the order.

1006
00:50:26,260 --> 00:50:29,080
If the order was a $60,000 order or
whatever.

1007
00:50:29,080 --> 00:50:30,580
We would get a discount on that.

1008
00:50:30,580 --> 00:50:34,060
And so our historical
relationship affected that quote,

1009
00:50:34,060 --> 00:50:36,330
affected the overall budget even.

1010
00:50:36,330 --> 00:50:40,310
Knowing that history, knowing that
background of people you purchase from,

1011
00:50:40,310 --> 00:50:41,790
contractors that you use,

1012
00:50:41,790 --> 00:50:45,520
things like that, are going to
influence your ultimate budget.

1013
00:50:45,520 --> 00:50:48,190
So be aware of those, don't discount that.

1014
00:50:48,190 --> 00:50:49,530
It does make a difference.

1015
00:50:51,920 --> 00:50:55,770
And then number five is
the funding limit reconciliation.

1016
00:50:55,770 --> 00:50:56,950
This is a weird one.

1017
00:50:56,950 --> 00:51:00,760
This is one that I always say, I ended up
just having to memorize before the exam

1018
00:51:00,760 --> 00:51:04,630
because it doesn't in my mind,
those terms don't fit together.

1019
00:51:04,630 --> 00:51:10,670
Funding limit reconciliation says, if you
have a budget of x amount of dollars,

1020
00:51:10,670 --> 00:51:14,760
over time you're supposed to
spend that amount of money..

1021
00:51:14,760 --> 00:51:17,740
So we need to reconcile
our budget to time.

1022
00:51:17,740 --> 00:51:22,890
And it is a concept that in my mind just
doesn't quite click so I made a chart.

1023
00:51:22,890 --> 00:51:25,280
Let me bring this up.

1024
00:51:25,280 --> 00:51:26,390
Cost baseline.

1025
00:51:26,390 --> 00:51:29,030
I call it a cost baseline
cuz that's how I use it.

1026
00:51:29,030 --> 00:51:33,660
But basically what you do is, if you
know what your costs are going to be,

1027
00:51:33,660 --> 00:51:35,305
you can bring up.

1028
00:51:35,305 --> 00:51:36,360
>> [LAUGH] I was worried for a second.

1029
00:51:36,360 --> 00:51:38,970
You can bring up this
completely blank spreadsheet.

1030
00:51:38,970 --> 00:51:42,690
You can bring up a chart and

1031
00:51:42,690 --> 00:51:46,960
you can plot what your
expenses are going to be.

1032
00:51:46,960 --> 00:51:51,960
So, here I am planning my budget and in my
budget of this project, I come through and

1033
00:51:51,960 --> 00:51:54,825
I put on this date, I have an activity.

1034
00:51:54,825 --> 00:51:55,815
That's gonna cost me $1,200.

1035
00:51:55,815 --> 00:51:59,745
And on this date I have an activity
that's gonna cost me 750.

1036
00:51:59,745 --> 00:52:01,765
And I lay it out like this.

1037
00:52:01,765 --> 00:52:06,170
Laying out each activity, see how I've
got the activities noted right here.

1038
00:52:06,170 --> 00:52:08,220
And what they're going to cost.

1039
00:52:08,220 --> 00:52:12,725
So now, I have a running total,
and here is my cost.

1040
00:52:12,725 --> 00:52:14,520
$36,880, right?

1041
00:52:14,520 --> 00:52:16,538
That's how much this project
is going to cost me.

1042
00:52:16,538 --> 00:52:17,864
So there we go.

1043
00:52:17,864 --> 00:52:19,861
I know I need $37,000.

1044
00:52:19,861 --> 00:52:20,860
Let me go get a check right now for
$37,000.

1045
00:52:20,860 --> 00:52:23,750
First off, that's not going to happen.

1046
00:52:23,750 --> 00:52:26,970
But secondly it's not
that I need it right now.

1047
00:52:26,970 --> 00:52:30,410
Some of the cost yeah, some of the costs
are right away May 20th, right?

1048
00:52:30,410 --> 00:52:33,030
But other costs are way
down the road here.

1049
00:52:33,030 --> 00:52:35,125
September 3rd.

1050
00:52:35,125 --> 00:52:36,465
$9,000.
That's a pretty big percent.

1051
00:52:36,465 --> 00:52:37,360
>> Mm-hm.
>> What is that?

1052
00:52:37,360 --> 00:52:40,880
25% of my budget I don't even need for
three more months.

1053
00:52:40,880 --> 00:52:42,210
I guess maybe two.

1054
00:52:42,210 --> 00:52:43,750
I don't know, three months, whatever.

1055
00:52:43,750 --> 00:52:45,200
Way down the road.

1056
00:52:45,200 --> 00:52:47,780
If I take that money now,
what am I gonna do with it?

1057
00:52:47,780 --> 00:52:50,770
I can stick it in a bank account,
maybe draw some interest on it.

1058
00:52:50,770 --> 00:52:53,870
Or my company could continue to use that.

1059
00:52:53,870 --> 00:52:57,700
My company might not have that money yet,
but my company may know that

1060
00:52:57,700 --> 00:53:02,700
sales in August will cover the $9,000
that we need to spend in September.

1061
00:53:02,700 --> 00:53:05,120
So, they may not have that money yet.

1062
00:53:05,120 --> 00:53:07,610
If I go and ask for it,
they may not have it to give it to me.

1063
00:53:07,610 --> 00:53:13,010
So what we have to do is a reconciliation,
where we tie the money to the date.

1064
00:53:13,010 --> 00:53:15,800
And I usually make a chart like this.

1065
00:53:15,800 --> 00:53:22,440
And what this chart does is it shows
the money that I need on particular dates.

1066
00:53:22,440 --> 00:53:27,110
And so I can see right here,
I need $17,800 on July 12th.

1067
00:53:27,110 --> 00:53:27,670
Right?
And

1068
00:53:27,670 --> 00:53:30,470
that's just coming from right here on
July 12th, $17,000, half my budget.

1069
00:53:30,470 --> 00:53:35,120
Half my budget I need right
there on July 12th, okay?

1070
00:53:35,120 --> 00:53:38,290
And then I plot that with another line,

1071
00:53:38,290 --> 00:53:41,670
which is my total,
the total that I've spent.

1072
00:53:41,670 --> 00:53:44,120
So my project as a whole yes.

1073
00:53:44,120 --> 00:53:46,420
It is $36,880.

1074
00:53:46,420 --> 00:53:50,290
But on day one I only need 1,200 bucks.

1075
00:53:50,290 --> 00:53:53,290
And by the time I get to the end of the
first month so if I started on May 20th.

1076
00:53:53,290 --> 00:53:58,140
By the time I get to end of June,
I only need a total of $6,080.

1077
00:53:58,140 --> 00:54:05,360
So I need a small fraction, less than
20% of my budget by the first month.

1078
00:54:05,360 --> 00:54:07,530
But that second month, boy it's a doozy.

1079
00:54:07,530 --> 00:54:12,380
I need another 50% of my budget
right there just in July.

1080
00:54:12,380 --> 00:54:16,100
But then August very few expenditures,
right.

1081
00:54:16,100 --> 00:54:18,540
Looks like I got a total
of $4,000 in August and

1082
00:54:18,540 --> 00:54:20,870
then it's in September
that we jump up to $9,000.

1083
00:54:20,870 --> 00:54:24,600
So by reconciling our
expenses to dates like this.

1084
00:54:24,600 --> 00:54:27,370
We can set not just what
our total budget is but

1085
00:54:27,370 --> 00:54:30,770
what our budget is at
points along the way.

1086
00:54:30,770 --> 00:54:34,180
And that's important when we get
to monitoring and controlling.

1087
00:54:34,180 --> 00:54:36,860
Because when you're monitoring
your project you can say here I

1088
00:54:36,860 --> 00:54:38,620
am on June 15th.

1089
00:54:38,620 --> 00:54:39,890
How much money should I have spent?

1090
00:54:39,890 --> 00:54:41,090
>> Yeah.
>> On June 15th and

1091
00:54:41,090 --> 00:54:43,520
I can look
>> And I can say all right.

1092
00:54:43,520 --> 00:54:47,120
According to this chart, by June 15th,
I should have spent $6,080.

1093
00:54:47,120 --> 00:54:49,270
How much have I actually spent.

1094
00:54:49,270 --> 00:54:50,550
Oh, I've spent $6,080.

1095
00:54:50,550 --> 00:54:51,150
I'm perfect.

1096
00:54:51,150 --> 00:54:51,830
On schedule.

1097
00:54:51,830 --> 00:54:52,480
Right.

1098
00:54:52,480 --> 00:54:55,774
Where I look at it and
I've only spent $5,000.

1099
00:54:55,774 --> 00:54:58,800
Why is that?
Why have I only spent $5,000?

1100
00:54:58,800 --> 00:55:01,570
>> Did some work not get done
that was supposed to get done?

1101
00:55:01,570 --> 00:55:02,160
Right?

1102
00:55:02,160 --> 00:55:05,340
Or maybe I got a great deal on some
lumber or something like that and

1103
00:55:05,340 --> 00:55:06,710
that's why we haven't spent so much.

1104
00:55:06,710 --> 00:55:09,400
More often than not,
it means something didn't get done.

1105
00:55:09,400 --> 00:55:12,075
Or I can say I spent $7.000.

1106
00:55:12,075 --> 00:55:12,835
Why the discrepancy?

1107
00:55:12,835 --> 00:55:14,635
Why have I spent more at this point?

1108
00:55:14,635 --> 00:55:17,385
Now they're numbers that are very,
very useful.

1109
00:55:17,385 --> 00:55:20,865
So attaching these to a date is really
handy and I usually just use Excel.

1110
00:55:20,865 --> 00:55:22,535
This is just something that I whipped up.

1111
00:55:22,535 --> 00:55:25,350
You know in Excel you can lay
out a chart like this and

1112
00:55:25,350 --> 00:55:29,250
then you can do an easy
graph right in here.

1113
00:55:29,250 --> 00:55:30,770
If I pull it up you'll see...

1114
00:55:30,770 --> 00:55:33,150
That's not what I wanted.

1115
00:55:33,150 --> 00:55:35,950
How do you edit the formula?

1116
00:55:35,950 --> 00:55:37,760
I'm the one who made this thing.

1117
00:55:37,760 --> 00:55:40,000
You'd think I'd know how to do it.

1118
00:55:40,000 --> 00:55:44,110
Somewhere in here we designate exactly
how we want this chart to function.

1119
00:55:45,390 --> 00:55:46,460
Select Data.

1120
00:55:46,460 --> 00:55:47,600
There we go, perfect.

1121
00:55:47,600 --> 00:55:51,581
So you come in here and you specify
your x and your y values, right.

1122
00:55:51,581 --> 00:55:54,925
So, this is where it's doing cost and
total and the range of sales.

1123
00:55:54,925 --> 00:55:56,690
It's not a hard thing to build.

1124
00:55:56,690 --> 00:56:00,289
I probably used a wizard to do it.

1125
00:56:00,289 --> 00:56:02,286
You'll see all the Crazy wizards up here.

1126
00:56:02,286 --> 00:56:03,775
But you do it, you lay it out,
and this really works.

1127
00:56:03,775 --> 00:56:07,960
This is a great way to determine
how your budget is doing.

1128
00:56:07,960 --> 00:56:09,920
So that is a cost baseline.

1129
00:56:12,120 --> 00:56:15,730
And again, your baseline,
this is how it is in planning.

1130
00:56:15,730 --> 00:56:17,060
So now when you get into production,

1131
00:56:17,060 --> 00:56:20,290
you're gonna actually have a third
line that I don't have in here.

1132
00:56:20,290 --> 00:56:24,640
So I would add another column to this,
which was the actual.

1133
00:56:24,640 --> 00:56:26,920
And so
I would track my actual expenditures,

1134
00:56:26,920 --> 00:56:29,230
which would be somewhere in between these,
right?

1135
00:56:29,230 --> 00:56:32,380
With where we're at for
our expenses and hopefully,

1136
00:56:32,380 --> 00:56:34,670
it's right on top of this red line.

1137
00:56:34,670 --> 00:56:37,330
But anywhere above the red line,
I'd be over budget.

1138
00:56:37,330 --> 00:56:40,674
Anywhere below the red
line I'm under budget, and

1139
00:56:40,674 --> 00:56:43,797
then I can make that decision,
how to fix that.

1140
00:56:43,797 --> 00:56:47,960
All right, so
that is funding limit reconciliation.

1141
00:56:47,960 --> 00:56:50,420
Really important there, very useful stuff.

1142
00:56:50,420 --> 00:56:51,170
If you don't do it now,

1143
00:56:51,170 --> 00:56:54,730
you're gonna end up doing it later anyway
when we do the monitoring and controlling.

1144
00:56:54,730 --> 00:56:57,130
So you might as well do it
now as you set up that plan.

1145
00:56:58,720 --> 00:56:59,760
And when we're done?

1146
00:56:59,760 --> 00:57:00,300
What do we get?

1147
00:57:00,300 --> 00:57:01,790
Well we get a handful of other things,
right?

1148
00:57:01,790 --> 00:57:04,460
We get our outputs, our cost baseline,

1149
00:57:04,460 --> 00:57:09,190
which my funding limit reconciliation,
I call that my cost baseline.

1150
00:57:09,190 --> 00:57:12,800
It may be done as a graph and a chart like
that, that's the way I normally do it.

1151
00:57:12,800 --> 00:57:16,616
Or you might have some kind of form, some
spreadsheet or whatever that you fill out,

1152
00:57:16,616 --> 00:57:17,492
but I like charts.

1153
00:57:17,492 --> 00:57:19,815
[LAUGH] It's hard to
argue against a chart.

1154
00:57:19,815 --> 00:57:21,219
When you show somebody a chart,
they think you know what you're doing.

1155
00:57:21,219 --> 00:57:21,729
>> Love it.

1156
00:57:21,729 --> 00:57:26,955
>> [LAUGH] So they're like, oh, this guy
made a chart, don't wanna argue with that.

1157
00:57:26,955 --> 00:57:28,715
Project funding requirements.

1158
00:57:28,715 --> 00:57:32,212
This is how much money do I need and
when do I need it, right?

1159
00:57:32,212 --> 00:57:34,606
This is something your
accounting team wants to know,

1160
00:57:34,606 --> 00:57:36,720
this is something your CEO wants to know.

1161
00:57:36,720 --> 00:57:41,410
This is how they recognize the money they
need to set aside to support this project.

1162
00:57:41,410 --> 00:57:44,005
And they also know if
they choke your project,

1163
00:57:44,005 --> 00:57:46,570
cuz this happens with
the government all the time.

1164
00:57:46,570 --> 00:57:52,320
They'll allocate $2 billion for a project
and the project kicks off, it moves along.

1165
00:57:52,320 --> 00:57:55,420
Then times get tough, and so
they cut money back on the project.

1166
00:57:55,420 --> 00:57:57,270
Does that mean the project's over?

1167
00:57:57,270 --> 00:58:00,280
Well if they cut 100% of the funding,
yes then the project's over.

1168
00:58:00,280 --> 00:58:02,270
But if they just cut back your funding,

1169
00:58:02,270 --> 00:58:06,940
what we normally have to do is either when
you lose cost, right, what do you do?

1170
00:58:06,940 --> 00:58:11,870
You lose some requirements to make up for
it or you expand your time.

1171
00:58:11,870 --> 00:58:14,980
Your two year project just became
a five year project cuz you had half

1172
00:58:14,980 --> 00:58:16,090
the funding, right?

1173
00:58:16,090 --> 00:58:20,240
That's what happens, so just keep that
in mind that that number, if it changes,

1174
00:58:20,240 --> 00:58:21,750
it affects the other two.

1175
00:58:24,270 --> 00:58:28,450
Alright so our project funding
requirements, what money we need and when.

1176
00:58:28,450 --> 00:58:30,150
And then lastly project document updates.

1177
00:58:30,150 --> 00:58:33,670
Again, if we didn't have a cost
management plan, we take the tools and

1178
00:58:33,670 --> 00:58:37,150
stuff that we did here, any templates
that we made, like my little template.

1179
00:58:37,150 --> 00:58:40,275
And that becomes a part of our
project management plan, and

1180
00:58:40,275 --> 00:58:43,570
specifically the cost management plan,
all right?

1181
00:58:43,570 --> 00:58:46,038
And I think that's pretty much what
you called out too, Ronnie, right?

1182
00:58:46,038 --> 00:58:47,280
>> That's it.
>> Did I leave anything out?

1183
00:58:47,280 --> 00:58:48,670
>> Nope.
>> No, pretty good there.

1184
00:58:48,670 --> 00:58:52,720
All right, so that's pretty much what's
involved in the cost side of things.

1185
00:58:52,720 --> 00:58:55,075
Now again, let me caution you,

1186
00:58:55,075 --> 00:58:59,971
we spent three episodes going
over the project schedule, right?

1187
00:58:59,971 --> 00:59:02,780
And now we're just doing
one episode on cost?

1188
00:59:02,780 --> 00:59:06,860
Boy that was easy, this must be
the simplest part of an entire project.

1189
00:59:06,860 --> 00:59:08,940
Well, let me just pull this back up.

1190
00:59:08,940 --> 00:59:10,880
Don't let it deceive you.

1191
00:59:10,880 --> 00:59:14,540
On the test, yes, this is actually a
really simple, small portion of the exam.

1192
00:59:14,540 --> 00:59:18,160
You're not gonna see a lot of questions
from this knowledge area because again,

1193
00:59:18,160 --> 00:59:20,960
a lot of project managers don't
use this knowledge area, so

1194
00:59:20,960 --> 00:59:23,320
it doesn't show up very
heavily on the exam.

1195
00:59:23,320 --> 00:59:26,410
But the main reason why it's shorter

1196
00:59:26,410 --> 00:59:29,280
is a lot of it is overlap with what
we saw up in schedule management.

1197
00:59:29,280 --> 00:59:32,820
So they are very similar, and in real
life, if you're planning your budget,

1198
00:59:32,820 --> 00:59:36,720
it will take a lot of time and
resources, it takes a lot of effort.

1199
00:59:36,720 --> 00:59:38,470
But we're also gonna
take a look at quality,

1200
00:59:38,470 --> 00:59:41,790
which is actually the next thing in line,
which factors into our cost too.

1201
00:59:41,790 --> 00:59:43,830
We saw that, cost of quality,
that's an important thing.

1202
00:59:45,320 --> 00:59:47,780
All right, well Ronnie, I think that
pretty much wraps up cost management.

1203
00:59:47,780 --> 00:59:49,470
Can you think of anything
else we should throw in?

1204
00:59:49,470 --> 00:59:50,100
>> No, I don't think so.

1205
00:59:50,100 --> 00:59:52,205
I think we're ready for
the next set when we get to it.

1206
00:59:52,205 --> 00:59:57,488
>> I think that we should mention in
the famous words of the Notorious B.I.G.,

1207
00:59:57,488 --> 00:59:59,580
mo money mo problems, right.

1208
00:59:59,580 --> 01:00:00,250
>> That's true.

1209
01:00:00,250 --> 01:00:01,200
>> So be aware of that.

1210
01:00:01,200 --> 01:00:03,530
I don't know if it'll be on the exam or
not, but it might.

1211
01:00:03,530 --> 01:00:05,750
So [LAUGH], all right.

1212
01:00:05,750 --> 01:00:07,800
Well ladies and gentlemen,
I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1213
01:00:07,800 --> 01:00:11,237
Let me just remind you if you
have any questions on this,

1214
01:00:11,237 --> 01:00:14,473
live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live.

1215
01:00:14,473 --> 01:00:16,610
You'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

1216
01:00:16,610 --> 01:00:19,550
Post your questions, we monitor and
answer during the show.

1217
01:00:19,550 --> 01:00:22,630
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

1218
01:00:22,630 --> 01:00:25,600
Just click that Q&A link at
the top of all of our web pages.

1219
01:00:25,600 --> 01:00:28,117
It'll take you into the forums,
post your questions, and again,

1220
01:00:28,117 --> 01:00:29,860
we monitor and answer.

1221
01:00:29,860 --> 01:00:32,930
Alright, well signing out for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1222
01:00:32,930 --> 01:00:33,880
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1223
01:00:33,880 --> 01:00:36,247
>> And we will see you next time
when the air conditioning's running.

1224
01:00:36,247 --> 01:00:36,770
>> That's right.

1225
01:00:36,770 --> 01:00:37,804
>> [LAUGH]

1226
01:00:37,804 --> 01:00:41,579
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss how to handle quality management, resources and communications. They describe the how to manage quality control and quality assurance. They take a look into the subject area of planning for materials and labor management. Then Ronnie and Don talk about how to manage the communication paths and communication methods to be used during the project execution.
episodes.title: Quality, Resources & Comms
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:19,596 --> 00:00:22,350
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,350 --> 00:00:32,350
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,720 --> 00:00:37,530
All right, good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening, and welcome back.

5
00:00:37,530 --> 00:00:40,800
To another episode of IT pro
Tv I'm your host Don Pizette.

6
00:00:40,800 --> 00:00:42,040
Back again with mister Ronnie Wang.

7
00:00:42,040 --> 00:00:42,820
How's it going Ronnie?

8
00:00:42,820 --> 00:00:43,920
>> We are doing well today.

9
00:00:43,920 --> 00:00:47,710
We have used none of the Beastie Boy
songs in any of our advertisements here

10
00:00:47,710 --> 00:00:48,250
at IT Pro Tv.

11
00:00:48,250 --> 00:00:49,050
>> That's important.

12
00:00:49,050 --> 00:00:50,685
>> So we're doing well.

13
00:00:50,685 --> 00:00:53,990
[LAUGH]
>> You know it's amazing which bands

14
00:00:53,990 --> 00:00:57,098
decide to apply their intellectual
property the way they do.

15
00:00:57,098 --> 00:00:58,327
[LAUGH].

16
00:00:58,327 --> 00:01:00,820
The Beastie Boys, of all things.

17
00:01:00,820 --> 00:01:04,580
All right, so today,
we are gonna continue on with planning.

18
00:01:04,580 --> 00:01:06,920
And you might be ask yourself,
come on guys.

19
00:01:06,920 --> 00:01:08,710
How many episodes are we
gonna do on planning.

20
00:01:08,710 --> 00:01:10,590
Eventually we gotta do something, right.

21
00:01:10,590 --> 00:01:11,124
>> More.
[LAUGH]

22
00:01:11,124 --> 00:01:12,010
>> Yeah, well, we got more.

23
00:01:12,010 --> 00:01:12,985
>> So it's a lot.

24
00:01:12,985 --> 00:01:16,722
Planning is a big, [CROSSTALK] big part
of what we do as project managers.

25
00:01:16,722 --> 00:01:19,190
And it's a big, big part of the exam.

26
00:01:19,190 --> 00:01:20,990
So that's why we continue on.

27
00:01:20,990 --> 00:01:23,080
Fortunately we are starting to wind down,
right.

28
00:01:23,080 --> 00:01:29,030
Let me bring up my pimbock, and
get to my good ole process groups.

29
00:01:29,030 --> 00:01:30,810
Sorry, just a second, there we go.

30
00:01:30,810 --> 00:01:33,200
And, basically we're starting
to wind things down.

31
00:01:33,200 --> 00:01:36,990
We got all the way through our
scope management, time, cost.

32
00:01:36,990 --> 00:01:41,071
And now we're going into these last
couple of ones which are pretty sure with

33
00:01:41,071 --> 00:01:42,813
the exception of risk, right.

34
00:01:42,813 --> 00:01:44,950
There's a lot involved with risk.

35
00:01:44,950 --> 00:01:49,240
But the other guys are pretty short, so
today, depends on how time goes, but

36
00:01:49,240 --> 00:01:50,530
we're gonna shoot for the triple threat.

37
00:01:50,530 --> 00:01:52,280
We're gonna try and
knock out quality management, and

38
00:01:52,280 --> 00:01:55,200
human resource management and
communications management today.

39
00:01:55,200 --> 00:01:56,690
We'll see how it goes.

40
00:01:56,690 --> 00:01:59,930
Sometimes I ramble on too much, and
then we might have to do part two,

41
00:01:59,930 --> 00:02:01,350
but we'll see.

42
00:02:01,350 --> 00:02:03,390
So we're gonna start out
right here with this guy,

43
00:02:03,390 --> 00:02:05,870
which is Plan quality management.

44
00:02:05,870 --> 00:02:09,110
Now quality management is
kind of a weird topic.

45
00:02:09,110 --> 00:02:12,960
Because it doesn't apply
to every industry.

46
00:02:12,960 --> 00:02:15,400
So I go back to what I said
in episode number one.

47
00:02:15,400 --> 00:02:19,190
Which was the PMI framework
is a modular framework.

48
00:02:19,190 --> 00:02:23,170
You pick and choose the things
that you need in your company.

49
00:02:23,170 --> 00:02:25,100
And the things that you don't need,
you cut them out.

50
00:02:25,100 --> 00:02:27,500
You just throw them on the floor and
that's it.

51
00:02:27,500 --> 00:02:30,390
And so
quality management is one of those where

52
00:02:30,390 --> 00:02:33,300
you may not need any kind of
formal quality management.

53
00:02:33,300 --> 00:02:35,420
And you might lop this out and
it's gone, right.

54
00:02:36,520 --> 00:02:38,070
So, how do we know if we need it or not.

55
00:02:38,070 --> 00:02:40,840
Well we start by saying, what is quality.

56
00:02:40,840 --> 00:02:43,640
What the heck am I even talking about,
right.

57
00:02:43,640 --> 00:02:47,850
If your project involves
the creation of a physical,

58
00:02:47,850 --> 00:02:53,030
tangible item, there's going to be
specifications that item has to meet.

59
00:02:53,030 --> 00:02:57,490
And our quality Is how well
we met those requirements.

60
00:02:57,490 --> 00:02:59,890
Now if we're talking about
process improvement, or

61
00:02:59,890 --> 00:03:03,610
a service, it's a little bit
harder to measure, right?

62
00:03:03,610 --> 00:03:06,610
But pretty much everything
can be quantified.

63
00:03:06,610 --> 00:03:11,470
If our project is to improve
the efficiency of a,

64
00:03:11,470 --> 00:03:13,010
let's use a real world example.

65
00:03:13,010 --> 00:03:14,410
This was done years ago.

66
00:03:14,410 --> 00:03:18,370
There was a project to improve the
efficiency of the McDonald's Drive Thru.

67
00:03:18,370 --> 00:03:21,470
How to make the drive thru
get people through faster.

68
00:03:21,470 --> 00:03:24,470
So they did studies,
they did some prototypes,

69
00:03:24,470 --> 00:03:26,030
they tried some various things.

70
00:03:26,030 --> 00:03:30,060
And at at the end of the day they
decided it would be best to add a second

71
00:03:30,060 --> 00:03:31,070
drive through window.

72
00:03:31,070 --> 00:03:32,970
So you had a window where you paid, and

73
00:03:32,970 --> 00:03:35,410
another window where you got your food,
right.

74
00:03:35,410 --> 00:03:37,870
And they found that got people
through the drive through faster.

75
00:03:37,870 --> 00:03:41,520
They were able to measure that by
measuring the amount of time people spent

76
00:03:41,520 --> 00:03:42,910
in the drive through.

77
00:03:42,910 --> 00:03:47,570
You improve the quality of the customer
experience by making that time shorter.

78
00:03:47,570 --> 00:03:50,470
Alright, now there's always room for
improvement.

79
00:03:50,470 --> 00:03:53,210
We have this concept called
continual improvement or

80
00:03:53,210 --> 00:03:55,110
continual process improvement.

81
00:03:55,110 --> 00:03:57,110
Which is stating that
you're never really done.

82
00:03:57,110 --> 00:03:59,830
You can always make things better, right.

83
00:03:59,830 --> 00:04:02,010
But when we're dealing with a project,

84
00:04:02,010 --> 00:04:03,850
we're not necessarily
making something better.

85
00:04:03,850 --> 00:04:05,380
That's not necessarily
what our project is.

86
00:04:05,380 --> 00:04:07,350
Maybe we're creating something all new.

87
00:04:07,350 --> 00:04:10,510
In which case we just have a set of
requirements that we need to meet.

88
00:04:10,510 --> 00:04:14,950
And in the IT world we're not normally
doing quality measurements like these.

89
00:04:14,950 --> 00:04:18,380
We're normally meeting our
requirements and that's, that.

90
00:04:18,380 --> 00:04:20,440
But if there's something
that's subjective,

91
00:04:20,440 --> 00:04:23,480
if you're creating an advertising
campaign or something.

92
00:04:23,480 --> 00:04:26,840
Then you're going to need ways to
measure quality to ensure that you

93
00:04:26,840 --> 00:04:28,680
meet your customers needs.

94
00:04:28,680 --> 00:04:32,810
So planning quality
management is creating,

95
00:04:32,810 --> 00:04:34,730
well it's creating our
quality management plan.

96
00:04:34,730 --> 00:04:39,860
And it's basically saying how are we
going to handle quality for our project.

97
00:04:39,860 --> 00:04:44,080
Then you'll see, perform quality
assurance, and control quality,

98
00:04:44,080 --> 00:04:46,440
where we actually implement that later on.

99
00:04:46,440 --> 00:04:48,830
And in fact,
if you look at all three of these,

100
00:04:48,830 --> 00:04:51,720
unlike every other one we've done so far.

101
00:04:51,720 --> 00:04:56,045
Where you created a plan, and
then you had other things that you did.

102
00:04:56,045 --> 00:04:58,075
Right?
So plan scope management,

103
00:04:58,075 --> 00:05:00,415
plan schedule management,
plan cost management.

104
00:05:00,415 --> 00:05:01,985
But then they had other things.

105
00:05:01,985 --> 00:05:05,065
These next three that we're gonna do,
the quality management,

106
00:05:05,065 --> 00:05:07,530
human resource management, and
communications management.

107
00:05:07,530 --> 00:05:09,880
We're just coming up with
a plan right here, that's it.

108
00:05:09,880 --> 00:05:14,020
That's all we're doing at this
particular phase in the planning model.

109
00:05:14,020 --> 00:05:16,540
And that's because we can't
really do much with these,

110
00:05:16,540 --> 00:05:18,470
until we're actually executing.

111
00:05:18,470 --> 00:05:22,980
We can't manage our human resources until
we actually have the human resources.

112
00:05:22,980 --> 00:05:26,390
And we don't need those
people until work starts.

113
00:05:26,390 --> 00:05:26,950
Right?

114
00:05:26,950 --> 00:05:28,970
Same thing with communications.

115
00:05:28,970 --> 00:05:32,240
We don't need to communicate
with people until work starts.

116
00:05:32,240 --> 00:05:35,240
When we're in the planning phase, we're
talking with our project management team.

117
00:05:35,240 --> 00:05:37,110
We're already in communication with them.

118
00:05:37,110 --> 00:05:39,610
So these three phases
are a little bit special,

119
00:05:39,610 --> 00:05:43,020
in that we're just kind of coming up with
how we're going to manage these things.

120
00:05:43,020 --> 00:05:46,050
When we detect it.

121
00:05:46,050 --> 00:05:48,360
So let's take a look at
planning quality management.

122
00:05:50,340 --> 00:05:53,910
Planning quality management it's
pretty standard process for us.

123
00:05:53,910 --> 00:05:57,220
On the input side, we've got our project
management plan, if we have one.

124
00:05:57,220 --> 00:06:00,510
Because if we already have
a project management plan,

125
00:06:00,510 --> 00:06:02,850
then we've already planned for
quality management.

126
00:06:02,850 --> 00:06:05,220
We've already designated how we're
gonna handle it, we're, kind of, done.

127
00:06:06,380 --> 00:06:08,680
But if we're having to
create this ourselves,

128
00:06:08,680 --> 00:06:11,350
then we're gonna have to get
information from other places.

129
00:06:11,350 --> 00:06:15,340
Our stakeholder register, that's gonna
identify the people that are involved.

130
00:06:15,340 --> 00:06:18,594
The people that I need to reach out to,
are gonna have the information that I need

131
00:06:18,594 --> 00:06:21,030
as I figure out how I
want to do this plan.

132
00:06:21,030 --> 00:06:23,930
My risk register that I know
we haven't talked about yet.

133
00:06:23,930 --> 00:06:29,560
But listing the various quality concerns
that might happen as part of our project.

134
00:06:29,560 --> 00:06:31,600
Our requirements documentation,

135
00:06:31,600 --> 00:06:36,760
how do I know whether I'm
meeting what my customer wants?

136
00:06:36,760 --> 00:06:39,920
Well, the requirements documentation
is where that data is found, so

137
00:06:39,920 --> 00:06:40,870
I need to go and look there.

138
00:06:42,340 --> 00:06:45,230
And, then our two favorites,
Enterprise environmental factors and

139
00:06:45,230 --> 00:06:48,490
Organizational process assets,
same as they always are.

140
00:06:48,490 --> 00:06:51,430
Any regulations I have to meet and
any paperwork,

141
00:06:51,430 --> 00:06:54,360
documentation, templates or whatever that
I've already got as part of the company.

142
00:06:55,890 --> 00:06:58,300
All right,
then we start to apply the magic.

143
00:06:58,300 --> 00:07:03,120
The world of quality is a very complex and
advanced world.

144
00:07:03,120 --> 00:07:06,730
You have a lot of organizations out
there that have quality managers.

145
00:07:06,730 --> 00:07:09,520
That have people that have
PhD's in quality management.

146
00:07:09,520 --> 00:07:12,810
This is a very, very robust field.

147
00:07:12,810 --> 00:07:15,330
But with PMI,
we're concerned about the project.

148
00:07:15,330 --> 00:07:15,910
Right?
So

149
00:07:15,910 --> 00:07:19,420
we reduce it down to what looks
like a very simple thing.

150
00:07:19,420 --> 00:07:21,520
It's actually a pretty complex topic.

151
00:07:21,520 --> 00:07:23,120
Fortunately we don't have
to go too crazy on it.

152
00:07:23,120 --> 00:07:23,760
So what we're gonna do,

153
00:07:23,760 --> 00:07:26,240
is we're gonna look at some of
the various ways of managing quality.

154
00:07:26,240 --> 00:07:28,600
Some of the various tools
that are available out there.

155
00:07:28,600 --> 00:07:33,400
Again you just pick and choose what it
is you want to use in your company.

156
00:07:33,400 --> 00:07:35,170
The first one is one of the easiest.

157
00:07:35,170 --> 00:07:38,660
It's what's called
a cost benefit analysis.

158
00:07:38,660 --> 00:07:43,010
There's a lot of things that we can do in
our organization to make something better.

159
00:07:43,010 --> 00:07:46,255
All right, and it's up to us to choose
whether or not we want to do it.

160
00:07:46,255 --> 00:07:48,674
And it often comes down
to something very simple.

161
00:07:48,674 --> 00:07:51,975
We look at how much it would
cost us to do something and

162
00:07:51,975 --> 00:07:54,989
what benefit we would get out of it,
all right.

163
00:07:54,989 --> 00:07:59,720
And sometimes you'll find that
the benefit is greater than the cost.

164
00:07:59,720 --> 00:08:01,830
And it makes sense to do it.

165
00:08:01,830 --> 00:08:04,590
Other times the cost is
greater than the benefit, and

166
00:08:04,590 --> 00:08:06,680
it doesn't make sense to do it.

167
00:08:06,680 --> 00:08:08,880
Let me give you guys an example.

168
00:08:08,880 --> 00:08:13,730
Here in the studio that we're in,
all of our electricity is provided by

169
00:08:13,730 --> 00:08:17,130
the electrical grid here in
the city of Gainesville, all right.

170
00:08:17,130 --> 00:08:21,710
So we have no alternate energy
solutions here in the building.

171
00:08:21,710 --> 00:08:23,340
So let's say we wanted to change that.

172
00:08:23,340 --> 00:08:26,070
We wanna put solar panels on the ceiling,
or

173
00:08:26,070 --> 00:08:28,380
on the roof,
I just wouldn't on the ceiling.

174
00:08:28,380 --> 00:08:32,900
So we'll put solar panels on our roof,
that'll capture the sun's energy,

175
00:08:32,900 --> 00:08:36,420
convert it to electricity, and maybe
offset some of our electrical costs here,

176
00:08:36,420 --> 00:08:38,950
as far as powering our lights,
and all of that.

177
00:08:38,950 --> 00:08:39,820
All right?

178
00:08:39,820 --> 00:08:43,150
Well, the solar panels cost money.

179
00:08:43,150 --> 00:08:46,080
The electricity costs money also.

180
00:08:46,080 --> 00:08:49,529
So, by installing those solar panels,

181
00:08:50,880 --> 00:08:54,730
will I save at least that
amount of electricity?

182
00:08:54,730 --> 00:08:58,540
You know my electric bill, will it go
down that much to offset the cost, or

183
00:08:58,540 --> 00:09:01,198
is offsetting the environmental
foot print enough for me?

184
00:09:01,198 --> 00:09:04,830
Mm-hm
>> Right, maybe I'm just really well for

185
00:09:04,830 --> 00:09:06,093
those who know me I'm not very upset.

186
00:09:06,093 --> 00:09:10,600
[LAUGH] But lets say I'm upset that
we're burning to many fossil fuels or

187
00:09:10,600 --> 00:09:13,580
whatever, and I'm worried,
the environment.

188
00:09:13,580 --> 00:09:16,150
And so
I wanna reduce our environmental impact.

189
00:09:16,150 --> 00:09:17,690
I wanna reduce our carbon footprint.

190
00:09:17,690 --> 00:09:21,630
So, I want to put those solar panels up,
and it's not a matter of money to me.

191
00:09:21,630 --> 00:09:23,940
I'm not worried about how
much those solar panels cost,

192
00:09:23,940 --> 00:09:26,690
I'm worried about how much I can
help the environment, right?

193
00:09:26,690 --> 00:09:28,980
So, is that the best thing to help?

194
00:09:28,980 --> 00:09:30,980
Would wind turbines be better?

195
00:09:30,980 --> 00:09:33,195
Would, what else do we have, Ronnie?

196
00:09:33,195 --> 00:09:34,550
[LAUGH] Biomass?

197
00:09:34,550 --> 00:09:36,380
>> Yeah.
>> We are going to do a biomass thing?

198
00:09:36,380 --> 00:09:41,970
Which one is gonna give me the best
improvement over, whatever my goal is?

199
00:09:41,970 --> 00:09:44,530
Now, I use the example of the environment.

200
00:09:44,530 --> 00:09:47,040
I've never dealt with a project
that dealt with environment.

201
00:09:47,040 --> 00:09:49,700
But what I normally dealt with was money.

202
00:09:49,700 --> 00:09:52,160
Everybody's concerned about money,
your bottom line.

203
00:09:52,160 --> 00:09:56,450
And we actually did a little study
right here, just a few weeks ago.

204
00:09:56,450 --> 00:09:58,110
We have some servers in place.

205
00:09:58,110 --> 00:10:00,920
And our general manager came to me and
said Don,

206
00:10:00,920 --> 00:10:05,880
those servers are getting kind of old,
and I think we should replace them.

207
00:10:05,880 --> 00:10:08,660
And I said, well, they're getting
kind of old, but they're not used for

208
00:10:08,660 --> 00:10:10,660
anything production,
they're our test servers.

209
00:10:10,660 --> 00:10:12,500
And they work fine.

210
00:10:12,500 --> 00:10:14,650
They're not under warranty, but
I'm not worried about that,

211
00:10:14,650 --> 00:10:16,430
we don't need to replace them.

212
00:10:16,430 --> 00:10:21,530
And he said well, Don they're old, so
they probably draw a lot of electricity.

213
00:10:21,530 --> 00:10:26,110
I bet if we put new servers in, it would
save enough electricity to pay for

214
00:10:26,110 --> 00:10:27,120
themselves.

215
00:10:27,120 --> 00:10:28,205
And I said Philip you're crazy.

216
00:10:28,205 --> 00:10:32,130
That' not, you know, I can't imagine
those servers drawing off power.

217
00:10:32,130 --> 00:10:36,620
So he went out and
he purchased a device called a kilowatt.

218
00:10:36,620 --> 00:10:39,190
And you plug it in between the server and
the wall and

219
00:10:39,190 --> 00:10:40,720
it measures the electrical draw.

220
00:10:40,720 --> 00:10:43,500
And so he did that,
he monitored it over a period a days,

221
00:10:43,500 --> 00:10:46,800
what each power supply
those servers would take.

222
00:10:46,800 --> 00:10:50,610
And then he took it, and
he ran the numbers he got against our

223
00:10:50,610 --> 00:10:53,580
electrical bills,
to find out what those servers cost us.

224
00:10:53,580 --> 00:10:56,940
And each servers,
there were three of them in this case,

225
00:10:56,940 --> 00:11:00,430
were costing us about $600
per year in electric,

226
00:11:00,430 --> 00:11:03,260
which is way more than I thought
it would be, so I was wrong.

227
00:11:03,260 --> 00:11:05,520
I thought it would be way less.

228
00:11:05,520 --> 00:11:06,280
$600 per year.

229
00:11:06,280 --> 00:11:06,890
Right.

230
00:11:06,890 --> 00:11:10,420
So at $600 per year,
let's think about the server here.

231
00:11:10,420 --> 00:11:13,260
So I'm going to bring up
just a blank notepad,

232
00:11:13,260 --> 00:11:17,110
and I'll show you how a simple
cost benefit analysis works.

233
00:11:17,110 --> 00:11:19,700
All right.
So the old servers,

234
00:11:23,190 --> 00:11:30,368
they basically have
an operational cost of $600

235
00:11:30,368 --> 00:11:34,850
per year just for electricity, right.

236
00:11:34,850 --> 00:11:36,970
So that's our old servers.

237
00:11:36,970 --> 00:11:42,190
We could get new servers, and the new
servers, you know, prices have come down,

238
00:11:42,190 --> 00:11:46,020
technology has advanced and so
these older servers that we have.

239
00:11:46,020 --> 00:11:48,090
I think we paid about $6,000 for
each of them.

240
00:11:48,090 --> 00:11:49,650
And there are three of them, so

241
00:11:49,650 --> 00:11:54,180
you know we got What is that 18
thousand sunk into those servers.

242
00:11:54,180 --> 00:11:58,296
We could get new servers of similar
specification for less money.

243
00:11:58,296 --> 00:12:00,830
For about $3,000 a piece, so

244
00:12:00,830 --> 00:12:04,495
I'm just going to put in here
there are three of them.

245
00:12:04,495 --> 00:12:13,220
They originally cost $6,000 each.

246
00:12:13,220 --> 00:12:13,880
Right?

247
00:12:13,880 --> 00:12:19,410
And the operational cost of $600 per year,
each, just in electricity.

248
00:12:19,410 --> 00:12:22,339
And what Phillip was showing me,
was that the new servers,

249
00:12:22,339 --> 00:12:23,987
if we wanted to get three of them.

250
00:12:26,818 --> 00:12:28,900
These cost around $3,000.

251
00:12:28,900 --> 00:12:33,680
So they cost about half as much
as they did before, right.

252
00:12:33,680 --> 00:12:35,570
Because the cost of memory comes down.

253
00:12:35,570 --> 00:12:36,950
The cost of storage comes down.

254
00:12:36,950 --> 00:12:39,060
All that comes down over time.

255
00:12:39,060 --> 00:12:39,820
Al lright.

256
00:12:39,820 --> 00:12:44,780
But he showed me where the new
ones had a much lower power draw.

257
00:12:44,780 --> 00:12:47,850
In fact it was so
low that their operational cost,

258
00:12:47,850 --> 00:12:53,860
he was showing me was right around
something like $90 per year each.

259
00:12:53,860 --> 00:12:57,930
So the newer power supplies
were far more efficient.

260
00:12:57,930 --> 00:12:59,370
They drew a much lower wattage.

261
00:12:59,370 --> 00:13:02,620
The newer CPUs required
a much lower wattage.

262
00:13:02,620 --> 00:13:09,776
So what he was showing me was, that for
each of these servers that we replace,

263
00:13:09,776 --> 00:13:16,660
you're actually saving $510 per year, so

264
00:13:16,660 --> 00:13:22,230
that equals a $510 savings per year for
each server.

265
00:13:23,250 --> 00:13:26,920
All right, and his argument was,
if the server cost $3,000 and

266
00:13:26,920 --> 00:13:32,110
you save $510 a year, doesn't it make
sense to go ahead and replace them.

267
00:13:32,110 --> 00:13:35,950
Get some new servers in there and
replace it.

268
00:13:35,950 --> 00:13:38,570
Well here's when we do our cost benefit.

269
00:13:38,570 --> 00:13:39,800
Analysis.

270
00:13:39,800 --> 00:13:42,300
We look at the cost versus the benefit.

271
00:13:42,300 --> 00:13:47,410
The cost would be $3,000 per server,
and there's three of them.

272
00:13:47,410 --> 00:13:52,450
So our cost benefit analysis.

273
00:13:52,450 --> 00:13:56,086
Our cost would actually be $9,000.

274
00:13:56,086 --> 00:14:00,090
So our cost, $9,000 for new equipment.

275
00:14:01,960 --> 00:14:06,810
All right, our benefit would be
a $510 savings per year, but

276
00:14:06,810 --> 00:14:07,840
there's three of them, right.

277
00:14:07,840 --> 00:14:14,510
So it would actually be aone $1,530

278
00:14:14,510 --> 00:14:20,071
savings in electricity per year.

279
00:14:20,071 --> 00:14:24,140
Alright electricity, there we go.

280
00:14:24,140 --> 00:14:27,050
All right, so
I'm saving about $1,500 per year, right?

281
00:14:28,320 --> 00:14:30,950
Well that sounds like a great idea,
I can save 1,500 per year,

282
00:14:30,950 --> 00:14:32,120
I should do it, right?

283
00:14:32,120 --> 00:14:35,640
Well here's the thing,
let's look at the cost to benefit.

284
00:14:35,640 --> 00:14:38,810
The cost is $9,000 to
be able to save $1,500.

285
00:14:38,810 --> 00:14:41,910
So when does that pay for itself?

286
00:14:41,910 --> 00:14:43,480
When does it start to benefit us?

287
00:14:43,480 --> 00:14:44,020
Right?

288
00:14:44,020 --> 00:14:46,195
Well we have to work that out.

289
00:14:46,195 --> 00:14:50,850
$9,000 divided by $1,500, right?

290
00:14:50,850 --> 00:14:55,780
Now I'm just going to round it
because 30 bucks is 30 bucks.

291
00:14:55,780 --> 00:14:57,670
That equals, what is it four?

292
00:14:57,670 --> 00:14:59,120
Oh no it's six right?

293
00:14:59,120 --> 00:14:59,880
>> Yeah just about six.

294
00:14:59,880 --> 00:15:00,690
>> So it's six.

295
00:15:00,690 --> 00:15:04,680
It would take six years for
these servers to pay for

296
00:15:04,680 --> 00:15:09,330
themselves and
start to earn us money back.

297
00:15:09,330 --> 00:15:13,240
So for the first six years that power
saving is just compensating us for

298
00:15:13,240 --> 00:15:14,950
the cost of the initial servers.

299
00:15:14,950 --> 00:15:16,600
We don't actually make that money back.

300
00:15:16,600 --> 00:15:20,170
Now, in some worlds,
that's perfectly fine.

301
00:15:20,170 --> 00:15:23,190
But in the IT world,
if I buy servers today,

302
00:15:23,190 --> 00:15:25,330
am I going to be running
them six years from now?

303
00:15:25,330 --> 00:15:26,940
No.
Servers don't normally make it

304
00:15:26,940 --> 00:15:28,940
three years, better yet five.

305
00:15:28,940 --> 00:15:32,640
And so, you know,
am I going to run these six years, no?

306
00:15:32,640 --> 00:15:35,080
So they won't have time to pay for

307
00:15:35,080 --> 00:15:39,620
themselves by the time they die out,
by the time I'm ready to replace them.

308
00:15:39,620 --> 00:15:43,090
So the cost to benefit
analysis here shows that,

309
00:15:43,090 --> 00:15:47,540
this should not be the sole
factor I do the upgrade.

310
00:15:47,540 --> 00:15:50,420
I say it that way because
there might be other factors.

00:15:50,420 --> 00:15:52,700
Our old servers, they are just that.

00:15:52,700 --> 00:15:53,470
They're old.

00:15:53,470 --> 00:15:54,723

00:15:54,723 --> 00:15:56,209
If I have a motherboard fail?

316

>> Yeah, I've gotta go on eBay and

317
00:16:00,262 --> 00:16:03,745
But if I get new servers,
they'll come with a three year warranty.

318
00:16:03,745 --> 00:16:04,790
So they'll be under warranty.

319
00:16:04,790 --> 00:16:06,200
If something goes wrong, I've got that.

320
00:16:06,200 --> 00:16:09,790
So there may be other benefits
that I need to be aware of.

321
00:16:09,790 --> 00:16:14,650
But just looking at raw cost here,
this looks like a pretty easy decision.

322
00:16:14,650 --> 00:16:18,700
I shouldn't be motivated to replace the
servers unless I just feel like it, right?

323
00:16:18,700 --> 00:16:20,330
This is not a reason, all right?

324
00:16:20,330 --> 00:16:23,230
So that's what a cost-benefit analysis is.

325
00:16:23,230 --> 00:16:28,330
We just need to take a honest to
goodness look, quantify our numbers,

326
00:16:28,330 --> 00:16:33,620
figure out does it make
mathematical sense to do it, right?

327
00:16:33,620 --> 00:16:38,640
And you see many projects across
the world that don't take the time

328
00:16:38,640 --> 00:16:43,490
to do a simple cost-benefit analysis,
and they end up going kinda crazy.

00:16:43,490 --> 00:16:47,860
And I said biomass earlier,

The city of Gainesville, where we are,

we approved a biomass plant

It was approved ten years ago.

00:16:56,410 --> 00:16:57,360

00:16:57,360 --> 00:16:59,880
>> It just went into operation
about two years ago.

335
00:16:59,880 --> 00:17:03,550
And it's turned out to be

336
00:17:03,550 --> 00:17:08,870
The cost of operating the plant has
far exceeded any benefit on it and

337
00:17:08,870 --> 00:17:10,500
it's turned out to just be a mess.

338
00:17:10,500 --> 00:17:12,580
And they're actually having to

339
00:17:12,580 --> 00:17:16,200
which is completely against
the environmental idea of it.

00:17:16,200 --> 00:17:19,580
So it is a mess, so
that's why I threw that one out there.

00:17:19,580 --> 00:17:21,750
But you see it in any project, right?

00:17:21,750 --> 00:17:23,030
You're building a new house.

00:17:23,030 --> 00:17:24,870
And you decide you want to

344
00:17:24,870 --> 00:17:25,610
Okay?

345
00:17:25,610 --> 00:17:27,830
The solar panels cost money.

How long does it take for

00:17:32,310 --> 00:17:34,530
Well, with solar panels it's

00:17:34,530 --> 00:17:35,380
Six years?

00:17:35,380 --> 00:17:37,290
That's too long for servers.

00:17:37,290 --> 00:17:40,960
But let's say this same thing

351
00:17:40,960 --> 00:17:46,010
Let's say that it was solar panels that

It would take six years for

But, how long am I gonna

A house could stay standing, there's

but in other cities that

For our European viewers,

00:18:03,310 --> 00:18:07,310
And so, in those scenarios,

359
00:18:07,310 --> 00:18:08,190
Absolutely.

360
00:18:08,190 --> 00:18:09,510
And is it worth it to do it?

361
00:18:09,510 --> 00:18:10,800
Absolutely.

362
00:18:10,800 --> 00:18:13,070
So it definitely depends
on what you're doing,

363
00:18:13,070 --> 00:18:15,030
the other kind of circumstances
that surround it.

364
00:18:15,030 --> 00:18:18,750
So that is a cost to benefit analysis,
very common thing.

365
00:18:18,750 --> 00:18:20,810
And it should really be done
with just about any expenditure.

366
00:18:22,860 --> 00:18:25,710
All right, other things.

367
00:18:25,710 --> 00:18:26,950
Where is my?

368
00:18:26,950 --> 00:18:27,830
There.

369
00:18:27,830 --> 00:18:29,320
Cost of quality.

370
00:18:29,320 --> 00:18:33,280
I mention cost of quality
in another episode.

371
00:18:33,280 --> 00:18:36,000
Cost of quality,
it actually takes two forms.

372
00:18:36,000 --> 00:18:41,740
We have really two different
concepts when it comes to quality.

373
00:18:41,740 --> 00:18:50,160
This was basically
a cost benefit analysis.

374
00:18:50,160 --> 00:18:55,700
All right, so
when it comes to cost of quality.

375
00:18:55,700 --> 00:18:59,540
Cost of quality normally presents
itself in one of two ways.

376
00:18:59,540 --> 00:19:00,780
Cost of quality.

377
00:19:03,130 --> 00:19:06,540
It's gonna present itself as
either quality control or

378
00:19:06,540 --> 00:19:09,130
quality assurance, all right?

379
00:19:09,130 --> 00:19:15,300
So quality assurance is the first one,
quality control is the second.

380
00:19:15,300 --> 00:19:18,200
And we're gonna see more of these
when we get into execution, but

381
00:19:18,200 --> 00:19:21,270
quality assurance,
that's preventative measures.

382
00:19:21,270 --> 00:19:23,500
And I'm writing this, Ronnie, you
already have notes for this, don't you?

383
00:19:23,500 --> 00:19:26,250
>> I do, yep.
>> I am spinning my wheels, aren't I?

384
00:19:26,250 --> 00:19:27,410
>> Right there, yep.

385
00:19:27,410 --> 00:19:28,100
>> Where?
Oh, right here.

386
00:19:28,100 --> 00:19:29,080
Cost equality.
Okay.

387
00:19:29,080 --> 00:19:33,981
So, we have quality assurance, and
we have Quality control and well,

388
00:19:33,981 --> 00:19:36,033
actually you do all that but.

389
00:19:37,891 --> 00:19:39,800
Let me just write these out and
then we'll come back to this.

390
00:19:39,800 --> 00:19:43,940
You've got important stuff there but
not exactly what I wanted to say.

391
00:19:43,940 --> 00:19:53,160
So quality of assurance that is preventing
quality issues before they occur.

392
00:19:53,160 --> 00:19:53,990
Okay?

393
00:19:53,990 --> 00:19:59,700
Quality control is correcting
quality issues after they occur.

394
00:20:00,710 --> 00:20:02,540
They're really the same concept.

395
00:20:02,540 --> 00:20:06,270
It's just one is proactive,
one is reactive.

396
00:20:06,270 --> 00:20:07,600
They both have a cost.

397
00:20:07,600 --> 00:20:09,070
They both have a benefit.

398
00:20:09,070 --> 00:20:12,630
And we have to determine whether or
not it's worthwhile to do either one.

399
00:20:12,630 --> 00:20:13,400
Okay?

400
00:20:13,400 --> 00:20:15,830
So, for example,
if you're an automotive company.

401
00:20:15,830 --> 00:20:18,550
If you're manufacturing,
what car were we manufacturing?

402
00:20:18,550 --> 00:20:19,590
>> The Ford Focus.

403
00:20:19,590 --> 00:20:20,151
>> That's it!

404
00:20:20,151 --> 00:20:21,677
>> [LAUGH]
>> The 2016 Ford Focus.

405
00:20:21,677 --> 00:20:24,574
So, you are Ford, and you're going
to be manufacturing this vehicle.

406
00:20:24,574 --> 00:20:26,420
You've got a choice.

407
00:20:26,420 --> 00:20:31,960
One, you can improve your assembly
line to produce a Better car.

408
00:20:31,960 --> 00:20:36,930
A better car will have less failures,
less failures means less warranty work.

409
00:20:36,930 --> 00:20:40,190
So you save money on the back end by
not having to do warranty work, but

410
00:20:40,190 --> 00:20:44,900
on the front end you're paying extra
to make your assembly line better.

411
00:20:45,900 --> 00:20:47,840
That is quality assurance.

412
00:20:49,550 --> 00:20:51,900
Quality control is where we say,
you know what,

413
00:20:51,900 --> 00:20:53,630
let's just make the car and send it out.

414
00:20:53,630 --> 00:20:56,980
And if anything's broken, people will
bring it back for warranty work and

415
00:20:56,980 --> 00:20:58,210
we'll fix it then.

416
00:20:58,210 --> 00:20:58,720
Right?

417
00:20:58,720 --> 00:21:03,740
So we save money on the front end by
not having to improve our processes.

418
00:21:03,740 --> 00:21:08,300
But we spend money on the back end having
to fix the problems as they occur,

419
00:21:08,300 --> 00:21:08,850
if they occur.

420
00:21:08,850 --> 00:21:10,290
All right.

421
00:21:10,290 --> 00:21:15,790
Now, it's not normally a one size
fits fits all, normally we do both.

422
00:21:15,790 --> 00:21:20,590
We find out certain things that we can
do for quality assurance ahead of time.

423
00:21:20,590 --> 00:21:22,600
And then other things we evaluate and

424
00:21:22,600 --> 00:21:26,020
say it's a low enough risk that we
push off to quality control later.

425
00:21:26,020 --> 00:21:28,830
And we're seeing that now, what is it,
like the ignition systems,

426
00:21:28,830 --> 00:21:30,080
have you read about that Ronnie?

427
00:21:31,240 --> 00:21:33,790
Something, and I don't understand this
cuz I don't have an automotive mind, but

428
00:21:33,790 --> 00:21:38,620
there's some kind of piece in the ignition
system of a particular vehicle that,

429
00:21:38,620 --> 00:21:42,800
it should have been longer than
what it was measurement wise.

430
00:21:42,800 --> 00:21:46,175
And something happened in
the manufacturing process where it was

431
00:21:46,175 --> 00:21:48,700
manufactured shorter
than it should have been.

432
00:21:48,700 --> 00:21:50,840
So, they had a choice.

433
00:21:50,840 --> 00:21:54,440
Either recall all the vehicles and
fix it, or just let it go.

434
00:21:54,440 --> 00:21:58,030
Let it go and
as problems happen they would fix them.

435
00:21:58,030 --> 00:21:59,190
And that's the choice they made.

436
00:21:59,190 --> 00:22:00,380
They said you know what?

437
00:22:00,380 --> 00:22:04,480
The cost of fixing them as problems occur
will be less than the cost of us going and

438
00:22:04,480 --> 00:22:07,300
doing the repair right now so
we'll just wait.

439
00:22:07,300 --> 00:22:08,880
That was fine until somebody died.

440
00:22:08,880 --> 00:22:11,870
Then when somebody dies
then it becomes a big deal.

441
00:22:11,870 --> 00:22:14,680
So then they went out and
now they're repairing the vehicles.

442
00:22:14,680 --> 00:22:18,210
The automotive industry's
a little cynical in that aspect.

443
00:22:18,210 --> 00:22:20,320
But now they're doing quality assurance.

444
00:22:20,320 --> 00:22:23,150
They're saying, for every vehicle
manufactured from now on we're

445
00:22:23,150 --> 00:22:25,510
gonna make sure that part is long enough,
right?

446
00:22:25,510 --> 00:22:29,180
So it's really a combination of the two
that's going to suit your environment.

447
00:22:29,180 --> 00:22:32,100
The trick is just figuring out whether
it's worth the money to fix it ahead

448
00:22:32,100 --> 00:22:34,990
of time or fix it after the fact.

449
00:22:34,990 --> 00:22:38,990
Fixing it after the fact not
only has a monetary price but

450
00:22:38,990 --> 00:22:42,520
it also has a public image,
public relations price.

451
00:22:42,520 --> 00:22:46,560
If you If you have a giant recall,
that's gonna hurt sales of your vehicle.

452
00:22:46,560 --> 00:22:48,350
That's a big deal.

453
00:22:48,350 --> 00:22:50,790
So, when we're talking
about cost of quality,

454
00:22:50,790 --> 00:22:52,350
those are the costs that we're evaluating.

455
00:22:52,350 --> 00:22:57,202
The cost of fixing things ahead of time
to ensure problems don't occur, or

456
00:22:57,202 --> 00:23:01,917
the cost of just letting it ride and
fixing the problems as they do occur.

457
00:23:01,917 --> 00:23:09,390
So let's take that idea and I'm just
gonna stick that here in the notes.

458
00:23:09,390 --> 00:23:13,560
And you went straight from the pin box so
I'm just gonna add right above it there.

459
00:23:13,560 --> 00:23:17,810
Okay, so when we talk about
cost of quality, you see it

460
00:23:17,810 --> 00:23:22,920
worded a few different ways and so
here we've got like cost of conformance.

461
00:23:22,920 --> 00:23:27,970
What's it gonna cost us during the project
to prevent that failure from occurring.

462
00:23:27,970 --> 00:23:30,358
And that's what we would call
quality assurance, or QA.

463
00:23:30,358 --> 00:23:34,720
All right, and
then you'll see cost of non-conformance,

464
00:23:34,720 --> 00:23:38,620
that is if we let the problem happen,
and we go and resolve it after the fact.

465
00:23:38,620 --> 00:23:41,190
That would be quality control, all right?

466
00:23:41,190 --> 00:23:45,900
And we'll see those two concepts
more in the execution phase or

467
00:23:45,900 --> 00:23:47,670
really monitoring and controlling.

468
00:23:47,670 --> 00:23:49,570
But you'll see here under
cost of conformance,

469
00:23:49,570 --> 00:23:51,130
you've got the prevention costs.

470
00:23:51,130 --> 00:23:54,080
So whatever it does to
improve your processes.

471
00:23:54,080 --> 00:23:56,100
Maybe you need to buy some new machinery.

472
00:23:56,100 --> 00:23:58,699
Maybe you have to add an extra
inspector on the inspector line.

473
00:23:58,699 --> 00:24:01,382
Maybe things take a little
longer to manufacture.

474
00:24:01,382 --> 00:24:05,481
So documentation, equipment,
time to do it right.

475
00:24:05,481 --> 00:24:08,948
All of these things have real
cost associated with them and

476
00:24:08,948 --> 00:24:11,648
we need to figure out
whether it's worth it.

477
00:24:11,648 --> 00:24:13,926
Same thing with non-conformance, right?

478
00:24:13,926 --> 00:24:15,911
Rework, where you have to go and
fix something.

479
00:24:15,911 --> 00:24:20,500
Scrap, maybe you have to
throw it out all together.

00:24:20,500 --> 00:24:24,130
If you're McDonald's and
you're manufacturing hamburgers for

00:24:24,130 --> 00:24:27,420

and they bring it back like,

00:24:27,420 --> 00:24:28,680
you ruined my order.

483
00:24:28,680 --> 00:24:29,540
What do you do?

484
00:24:29,540 --> 00:24:30,800
You can't just fix it.

485
00:24:30,800 --> 00:24:33,720
You have to throw it out, and
make an all new hamburger.

486
00:24:33,720 --> 00:24:37,060
Well, a hamburger probably cost
them pennies on the dollar.

487
00:24:37,060 --> 00:24:40,320
But, if you're talking about
an entire vehicle, like lemon law,

488
00:24:40,320 --> 00:24:43,310
or whatever, T then that get's expensive.

489
00:24:43,310 --> 00:24:46,300
So, what happens there?

490
00:24:46,300 --> 00:24:48,350
Liabilities, that's the big one.

491
00:24:48,350 --> 00:24:53,230
Liabilities, if the failure is shown
to be due to negligence on your part,

492
00:24:53,230 --> 00:24:55,840
the legal cost can be through the roof.

493
00:24:55,840 --> 00:25:00,060
If somebody dies as a result
of that failure to meet spec,

494
00:25:00,060 --> 00:25:03,920
that's a big deal and
it's going to cost a lot.

495
00:25:03,920 --> 00:25:06,990
And how can you put
a price on a human life?

496
00:25:06,990 --> 00:25:12,060
If you're dealing with something that is,
if somebody's life depends on it, you take

497
00:25:12,060 --> 00:25:15,200
the time, to spend that money ahead of
time, to get that product designed right.

498
00:25:17,280 --> 00:25:19,940
All right, and then warranty work,
I already talked it.

00:25:19,940 --> 00:25:23,540
And then lost business,
that public relations side.

500
00:25:23,540 --> 00:25:24,890
If you make a bad product,

501
00:25:24,890 --> 00:25:30,390
one that has a lot of returns,
it's gonna hurt your overall image.

00:25:30,390 --> 00:25:31,770
And we saw that with Packard Bell, right?

00:25:31,770 --> 00:25:33,420
>> Yeah.
>> Packard Bell was a computer company

here in the US.

I think they still sell under

So, some of you guys might be

Everybody had a Packard Bell.

And then what they did is to save money,
they started using

And so, Packard Bell's became

00:25:54,340 --> 00:25:58,897
That if you got one, you knew it was going

00:26:01,341 --> 00:26:04,400

00:26:04,400 --> 00:26:05,360
So it hurt them and

now they don't do business under
