544
00:27:39,580 --> 00:27:44,230
You'll hear it called a fishbone diagram,
or an ishikawa chart.

545
00:27:44,230 --> 00:27:46,470
There's a few different
names that are out there.

546
00:27:46,470 --> 00:27:50,330
But, at the end of the day, it's
a cause and effect and what it's doing,

547
00:27:50,330 --> 00:27:55,840
I don't know how far in can
I zoom in on this thing?

548
00:27:55,840 --> 00:27:57,840
It's still pretty clear
even zoomed in like that.

549
00:27:57,840 --> 00:27:58,460
>> Yeah.

550
00:27:58,460 --> 00:28:03,840
>> What you do is basically you set up
what it is you're trying to achieve.

551
00:28:03,840 --> 00:28:04,390
Okay?

552
00:28:04,390 --> 00:28:06,450
So what am I trying to achieve?

553
00:28:06,450 --> 00:28:09,952
Well, here it says,
awake at 2 AM daily and-

554
00:28:09,952 --> 00:28:10,491
>> Strong odors.

555
00:28:10,491 --> 00:28:13,370
[LAUGH]
>> Strong odors.

556
00:28:13,370 --> 00:28:15,705
So I don't know that I've
ever actually read this.

557
00:28:15,705 --> 00:28:17,480
>> Recalls analysis of sleeping problems.

558
00:28:17,480 --> 00:28:21,010
>> Okay, so basically they've got
somebody who's got a problem, right?

559
00:28:21,010 --> 00:28:25,760
So they're waking up at 2AM every day,
and at 2 AM they detect a strong odor and

560
00:28:25,760 --> 00:28:26,910
they don't know why.

561
00:28:26,910 --> 00:28:31,300
So now, we start to try and
identify the potential causes.

562
00:28:31,300 --> 00:28:36,760
What could be causing this person to wake
up at 2 AM and to smell a strong odor?

563
00:28:36,760 --> 00:28:41,360
So we've detected a flaw in our process,
or our project, or whatever.

564
00:28:41,360 --> 00:28:45,400
Now we're trying to identify what caused
the flaw, so that we can then go and

565
00:28:45,400 --> 00:28:46,650
take corrective actions.

566
00:28:46,650 --> 00:28:50,600
And there might be more than one
thing that contributes to it, right?

567
00:28:50,600 --> 00:28:55,170
So as we start to look at this, we see
there might be issues with our materials,

568
00:28:55,170 --> 00:28:58,470
our methods, our people,
or our environment.

569
00:28:58,470 --> 00:29:01,950
The four categories they've divided up and
you can do as many categories as you want,

570
00:29:01,950 --> 00:29:03,490
but these are pretty standard.

571
00:29:03,490 --> 00:29:07,360
And so, looking at these,
if we break that down even further,

572
00:29:07,360 --> 00:29:10,700
we'll see trying to identify
the root cause of that problem.

573
00:29:10,700 --> 00:29:14,645
So materials,
maybe they were pesticides, cleaners,

574
00:29:14,645 --> 00:29:18,680
bathroom materials that were used,
maybe dirty sheets.

575
00:29:18,680 --> 00:29:22,635
All these things could be
contributing to the odor.

576
00:29:22,635 --> 00:29:26,395
Not necessarily contributing to
waking up at 2 AM so much, right?

577
00:29:26,395 --> 00:29:29,355
Versus other things that
might be disturbing somebody.

578
00:29:29,355 --> 00:29:30,407
Here they've got-
>> Body odor.

579
00:29:30,407 --> 00:29:32,025
>> People [LAUGH], body odor with people.

580
00:29:32,025 --> 00:29:35,735
This is a really pleasant diagram, you'd
think they'd come up with something else.

581
00:29:35,735 --> 00:29:38,185
So these are all just
trying to identify that.

582
00:29:38,185 --> 00:29:41,385
In the environment,
maybe there's a skunk outside, right?

583
00:29:41,385 --> 00:29:43,780
And, so that's contributing to this odor.

584
00:29:43,780 --> 00:29:47,800
Maybe the air conditioning,
maybe the air conditioning is turning on,

585
00:29:47,800 --> 00:29:49,020
maybe it's generating a smell.

586
00:29:49,020 --> 00:29:53,300
Maybe garbage cans too close to the AC,
the garbage smell is being bought in.

587
00:29:53,300 --> 00:29:55,600
All of these are potential causes.

588
00:29:55,600 --> 00:29:57,960
Now which one is the true cause?

589
00:29:57,960 --> 00:30:00,290
Well, there's livelihoods, probabilities.

590
00:30:00,290 --> 00:30:03,480
The odds of there being a skunk
outside might be pretty low.

591
00:30:03,480 --> 00:30:07,380
Here in the US, we have skunks,
in other countries, maybe you don't.

592
00:30:07,380 --> 00:30:12,914
So, you have to kind evaluate that,
but each of these are possibilities.

593
00:30:14,195 --> 00:30:17,475
And that's the really the point of
a fishbone or ishikawa diagram,

594
00:30:17,475 --> 00:30:20,925
is just to basically break down
what are the possible causes.

595
00:30:20,925 --> 00:30:23,749
Let's do some brainstorming and
come up with things and

596
00:30:23,749 --> 00:30:27,170
then as we look at it afterwards we say,
what can we do to curb these,

597
00:30:27,170 --> 00:30:29,590
because each of these
are really a type of risk.

598
00:30:29,590 --> 00:30:34,520
There's a risk that there could be a skunk
outside, but there might not be, right?

599
00:30:34,520 --> 00:30:37,560
It's not a guarantee, so
we need to evaluate that and

600
00:30:37,560 --> 00:30:41,700
determine whether there's any mitigation
tactics that we should follow, right?

601
00:30:41,700 --> 00:30:45,530
That is a cause and
effect diagram, all right?

602
00:30:45,530 --> 00:30:47,500
The next one is a flow chart.

603
00:30:47,500 --> 00:30:52,240
With a flow chart, when we start to break
down one of our processes, we look at all

604
00:30:52,240 --> 00:30:57,260
the various activities that are happening
and the things that could go wrong.

605
00:30:57,260 --> 00:31:01,232
And anywhere there's a spot where
something could go wrong we plan what

606
00:31:01,232 --> 00:31:02,800
we'll do as a result.

607
00:31:02,800 --> 00:31:06,350
And so they show here this
is a project happening.

608
00:31:06,350 --> 00:31:10,210
So we get a project requested,
we get a plan.

609
00:31:10,210 --> 00:31:12,620
Is there artwork requested?

610
00:31:12,620 --> 00:31:14,960
And then if there is then we work on it.

611
00:31:14,960 --> 00:31:16,964
And then, is the artwork approved?

612
00:31:16,964 --> 00:31:21,630
If yes, we continue on, if no we go back
and we generate new artwork and we try and

613
00:31:21,630 --> 00:31:22,690
get it approved.

614
00:31:22,690 --> 00:31:26,260
And we might have to cycle through
here a few times to ensure that we get

615
00:31:26,260 --> 00:31:30,020
artwork that meets
the needs of our customer.

616
00:31:30,020 --> 00:31:34,140
If we don't, if we just move on, we might
reach the very end of the project, and

617
00:31:34,140 --> 00:31:35,750
they say, you know that our work,
it stinks.

618
00:31:35,750 --> 00:31:37,890
It's not what I want, and
then we have to go back again.

619
00:31:37,890 --> 00:31:40,940
So, these are the typical
type of issues that we have.

620
00:31:40,940 --> 00:31:43,800
By making a flow chart like this,
we can kind of map it out, and

621
00:31:43,800 --> 00:31:47,110
anywhere we have a decision point,
it's normally represented as a decision

622
00:31:47,110 --> 00:31:52,330
diamond, that we basically evaluate
our possible outcomes from there.

623
00:31:52,330 --> 00:31:53,440
And you'll see they've got it down here.

624
00:31:53,440 --> 00:31:58,540
So vendors make the proofs,
does the development package,

625
00:31:58,540 --> 00:32:00,200
or whatever, does it get approval?

626
00:32:00,200 --> 00:32:03,180
If it does, we move on, if not,
we go back to more proofs.

627
00:32:03,180 --> 00:32:05,300
Same thing with does it meet QA review?

628
00:32:05,300 --> 00:32:09,280
Quality assurance, before we send it to
our customer, versus quality control,

629
00:32:09,280 --> 00:32:11,198
which is after it gets to our customer.

630
00:32:11,198 --> 00:32:13,587
So, flow charts are pretty
handy with that for

631
00:32:13,587 --> 00:32:16,538
mapping out where we need to
have those decision points.

632
00:32:19,361 --> 00:32:22,930
Checklists, or checksheets,
they call them.

633
00:32:22,930 --> 00:32:28,210
Checklists are the number
one tool of quality control.

634
00:32:28,210 --> 00:32:31,060
And we're gonna see in the monitoring
controlling processes where we actually

635
00:32:31,060 --> 00:32:32,940
have to create these checklists.

636
00:32:32,940 --> 00:32:36,220
That you've got a set of
requirements that say,

637
00:32:36,220 --> 00:32:40,060
I need to meet these requirements for
the project to be successful.

638
00:32:40,060 --> 00:32:42,381
So a checksheet or
a checklist is really just saying,

639
00:32:42,381 --> 00:32:44,010
did I meet these requirements?

640
00:32:44,010 --> 00:32:44,650
Yes or no?
Right?

641
00:32:44,650 --> 00:32:46,420
And we go through and we check them off.

642
00:32:46,420 --> 00:32:48,230
Attribute one, do we meet it?

643
00:32:48,230 --> 00:32:48,980
Yes.

644
00:32:48,980 --> 00:32:49,550
Attribute two.

645
00:32:49,550 --> 00:32:50,110
Do we meet it?

646
00:32:50,110 --> 00:32:50,870
Yes.
Attribute three.

647
00:32:50,870 --> 00:32:51,660
Do we meet it?

648
00:32:51,660 --> 00:32:52,170
No.

649
00:32:52,170 --> 00:32:52,680
All right.

650
00:32:52,680 --> 00:32:53,380
We got a problem.

651
00:32:53,380 --> 00:32:54,580
We're not meeting quality.

652
00:32:54,580 --> 00:32:55,220
Right.

653
00:32:55,220 --> 00:32:56,910
And then frequency.

654
00:32:56,910 --> 00:32:58,280
How often do we check?

655
00:32:58,280 --> 00:33:00,200
Right?
Is this something that we're checking

656
00:33:00,200 --> 00:33:01,870
every day, every hour?

657
00:33:01,870 --> 00:33:06,100
If we're manufacturing, I think I used
blue jeans in an episode the other day.

658
00:33:06,100 --> 00:33:09,130
If we're manufacturing thousands
of blue jeans per day,

659
00:33:09,130 --> 00:33:12,500
I can't run every single pair
through a quality check.

660
00:33:12,500 --> 00:33:15,820
So maybe I'm sampling one
out of every hundred.

661
00:33:15,820 --> 00:33:18,900
And I'm checking, running it against this
checklist to look for tolerances right?

662
00:33:18,900 --> 00:33:19,400
It's a very common thing.

663
00:33:22,196 --> 00:33:25,850
All right, we've got Pareto diagrams.

664
00:33:25,850 --> 00:33:28,880
Now Pareto diagrams are one of
those that look really complex, but

665
00:33:28,880 --> 00:33:30,560
are actually really simple.

666
00:33:30,560 --> 00:33:35,710
Let's say that I am manufacturing
1,000 pairs of blue jeans per hour.

667
00:33:35,710 --> 00:33:37,590
And I've got a defect rate, right.

668
00:33:37,590 --> 00:33:41,070
My defect rate is 20%, and
I wanna get that defect rate down.

669
00:33:41,070 --> 00:33:43,498
I don't want it to go
out to the customer and

670
00:33:43,498 --> 00:33:46,760
have the customer have to
return 20% my product.

671
00:33:46,760 --> 00:33:48,961
That means one in five customers
will be doing a return,

672
00:33:48,961 --> 00:33:51,260
that's gonna hurt my image.

673
00:33:51,260 --> 00:33:53,780
So what I do is I look at the defects.

674
00:33:53,780 --> 00:33:58,570
So out of a batch of a thousand,
I collect the 20% that are defective.

675
00:33:58,570 --> 00:34:03,020
And we categorize where
their defect is coming from.

676
00:34:03,020 --> 00:34:10,510
So maybe, in a certain percentage,
I see that the zipper won't stay up.

677
00:34:10,510 --> 00:34:12,870
For some reason the zipper keeps falling.

678
00:34:12,870 --> 00:34:18,080
In another percentage,
the button isn't properly attached.

679
00:34:18,080 --> 00:34:20,940
In another one,
maybe the button hole is not cut out.

680
00:34:20,940 --> 00:34:21,870
>> Yeah.
>> Something happens in our

681
00:34:21,870 --> 00:34:23,500
machine where it doesn't cut out the hole.

682
00:34:23,500 --> 00:34:24,270
And so on.

683
00:34:24,270 --> 00:34:27,480
We break down all the reasons for

684
00:34:27,480 --> 00:34:30,250
a defect, cuz the defect can
come from more than one area.

685
00:34:30,250 --> 00:34:30,830
All right.

686
00:34:30,830 --> 00:34:32,600
So we break down all the reasons, and

687
00:34:32,600 --> 00:34:37,290
then we sort them by which
one happens the most.

688
00:34:37,290 --> 00:34:40,870
And we look at the one that happens
the most, this guy right here.

689
00:34:40,870 --> 00:34:44,890
We total up all the incidents.

690
00:34:44,890 --> 00:34:50,035
And if I grab 20% of my 1,000 pair of
jeans, then I should have 200 defects.

691
00:34:50,035 --> 00:34:51,490
And so these should add up to 200.

692
00:34:51,490 --> 00:34:52,765
That's what this line is here.

693
00:34:52,765 --> 00:34:55,365
It is just making sure that our
full number adds up to 200.

694
00:34:55,365 --> 00:34:58,425
If it does not add up to 200,
then I must have missed some defects.

695
00:34:58,425 --> 00:34:59,790
I need to go and find those out.

696
00:34:59,790 --> 00:35:02,650
Even if there's only one pair that
suffered from a particular defect,

697
00:35:02,650 --> 00:35:04,410
I still need to document it.

698
00:35:04,410 --> 00:35:11,480
But when it comes to finding solutions,
I wanna solve the biggest culprit first.

699
00:35:11,480 --> 00:35:15,960
If I can solve this one right here,
and it amounts to 50% of my defects,

700
00:35:15,960 --> 00:35:20,800
then I just saved, what,
100 pairs of jeans.

701
00:35:20,800 --> 00:35:24,830
All these other guys combined might
only be 100 pairs of jeans themselves.

702
00:35:24,830 --> 00:35:27,090
So it makes sense to focus in on this one.

703
00:35:27,090 --> 00:35:31,860
I say, all right, for some reason,
the zippers are not staying up in 100 out

704
00:35:31,860 --> 00:35:34,660
of 1,000 pairs of jeans
that I manufactured.

705
00:35:34,660 --> 00:35:35,940
We need to replace that zipper.

706
00:35:35,940 --> 00:35:38,890
We need to change that design or
use a different contractor, or

707
00:35:38,890 --> 00:35:40,220
something like that.

708
00:35:40,220 --> 00:35:45,360
Just by changing that one component I
now regain, I increase my yield by 10%.

709
00:35:45,360 --> 00:35:46,810
That's a big gain, right?

710
00:35:46,810 --> 00:35:50,350
That's worth it, right,
to save 10% of defects.

711
00:35:50,350 --> 00:35:55,520
Then I can say all right, what's
the cost to benefit analysis on that?

712
00:35:55,520 --> 00:35:57,350
How much does it cost to
use a different zipper?

713
00:35:57,350 --> 00:35:59,790
If it costs the same,
it's a no-brainer, do it.

714
00:35:59,790 --> 00:36:05,250
If it cost a little more though, what
did it cost us to lose those 10%, right?

715
00:36:05,250 --> 00:36:09,010
Well, if the cost of replacing the zipper
is higher than the cost of the 10%,

716
00:36:09,010 --> 00:36:12,470
then we just take that 10%
that have a bad zipper, and

717
00:36:12,470 --> 00:36:14,960
we throw them into the defect rack, right.

718
00:36:14,960 --> 00:36:19,690
And they make it over to, a lot of times
they'll sell them in outlets or whatever.

719
00:36:19,690 --> 00:36:22,530
These are defective goods and off they go.

720
00:36:22,530 --> 00:36:23,450
So maybe we do that.

721
00:36:23,450 --> 00:36:28,590
It makes sense for us not to even bother
and fix it because 80% of our jeans

722
00:36:28,590 --> 00:36:34,200
are fine, and we can sell those at full
price, and we recoup our loss, right.

723
00:36:34,200 --> 00:36:36,275
That's what a Pareto
diagram helps you to do.

724
00:36:36,275 --> 00:36:39,975
You're just doing,
this is a histogram, a bar chart,

725
00:36:39,975 --> 00:36:44,225
that is mapping the amount of
incidences of a particular defect.

726
00:36:44,225 --> 00:36:47,175
So this is one defect, this is one defect,
this is a different one,

727
00:36:47,175 --> 00:36:48,975
this is a different one, and so on.

728
00:36:48,975 --> 00:36:52,565
And then a line graph that's showing

729
00:36:52,565 --> 00:36:56,405
the total amount of defects to make sure
that we add up to 100% of our defects.

730
00:36:58,850 --> 00:37:00,849
All right, so Pareto diagrams,
they look complex but

731
00:37:00,849 --> 00:37:02,248
they're really not very hard at all.

732
00:37:02,248 --> 00:37:07,480
All right, histograms.

733
00:37:07,480 --> 00:37:11,150
Histograms are another combination
where we've got a bar chart,

734
00:37:11,150 --> 00:37:13,110
really that's the histogram
is the bar chart.

735
00:37:13,110 --> 00:37:18,170
They've done a,
like a trend analysis here, and

736
00:37:18,170 --> 00:37:20,340
that's not truly part of the histogram.

737
00:37:20,340 --> 00:37:21,620
You can have that if you want.

738
00:37:21,620 --> 00:37:24,030
But the bar chart is the histogram.

739
00:37:24,030 --> 00:37:27,630
And again, we're just ranking instances
of typically a particular defect.

740
00:37:27,630 --> 00:37:30,055
And this might be over time
that we have that defect.

741
00:37:30,055 --> 00:37:33,340
It depends on how you wanna map it.

742
00:37:33,340 --> 00:37:34,120
I'll give you an example.

743
00:37:34,120 --> 00:37:37,410
I have a friend who,
it's an odd business, but

744
00:37:37,410 --> 00:37:40,040
he makes his living
manufacturing cowboy hats.

745
00:37:40,040 --> 00:37:43,310
He hand makes leather cowboy hats.

746
00:37:43,310 --> 00:37:44,950
Apparently there's a market for this.

747
00:37:44,950 --> 00:37:47,650
And he sells them for
ridiculous amounts of money.

748
00:37:47,650 --> 00:37:50,290
I've never worn a cowboy hat,
nor do I ever intend to.

749
00:37:50,290 --> 00:37:52,170
But this is what he does.

750
00:37:52,170 --> 00:37:53,610
And he hand makes them.

751
00:37:53,610 --> 00:37:56,390
He makes them himself by hand,
which is impressive.

752
00:37:56,390 --> 00:38:00,260
And when he does it, he uses wooden molds.

753
00:38:00,260 --> 00:38:04,310
So if he's gonna make a size
seven-and-a-quarter hat,

754
00:38:04,310 --> 00:38:06,860
he's got a wooden mold for
size seven-and-a-quarter.

755
00:38:06,860 --> 00:38:10,195
And if it's gonna be seven and
three-quarters, he has got a seven and

756
00:38:10,195 --> 00:38:11,440
three-quarters mold for that.

757
00:38:11,440 --> 00:38:15,183
So he's got these little wooden, they're
not heads cuz they're shaped weird,

758
00:38:15,183 --> 00:38:17,420
cuz he actually shapes
the leather around that.

759
00:38:17,420 --> 00:38:19,630
So it's more shaped like
a cowboy hat would be.

760
00:38:19,630 --> 00:38:22,140
So anyways,
he's got these molds that he uses.

761
00:38:22,140 --> 00:38:23,900
Well the problem is they're wood.

762
00:38:23,900 --> 00:38:27,130
And after he makes a few
hundred hats on the mold,

763
00:38:27,130 --> 00:38:30,170
the leather starts to wear the wood down.

764
00:38:30,170 --> 00:38:34,650
And that seven-and-three-quarters hat all
the sudden becomes a seven-and-a-half.

765
00:38:34,650 --> 00:38:36,320
And then as he works on it even longer,

766
00:38:36,320 --> 00:38:40,210
that seven-and-a-half becomes
a seven-and-one-quarter, right.

767
00:38:40,210 --> 00:38:43,776
The mold gets smaller and smaller and
smaller as it wears down.

768
00:38:43,776 --> 00:38:47,090
You see there's some blue jeans,
we'll stick with the blue jeans example.

769
00:38:47,090 --> 00:38:51,917
If you go to the store and
you grab three pairs of size 32 jeans,

770
00:38:51,917 --> 00:38:57,575
32 waist, some of them might be size 32,
some might be 33, some might be 31.

771
00:38:57,575 --> 00:39:02,385
There is an acceptable deviation from
that measurement that they allowed, and

772
00:39:02,385 --> 00:39:03,505
still sell it out there.

773
00:39:03,505 --> 00:39:07,305
That's why two identical measured
jeans might fit differently,

774
00:39:07,305 --> 00:39:09,587
because of those
tolerances at the factory.

775
00:39:09,587 --> 00:39:12,657
So what Patrick had to do with his hats,

776
00:39:12,657 --> 00:39:17,897
is as he manufactured them, at the end
of each day, he had to measure the mold.

777
00:39:17,897 --> 00:39:21,207
And there was a certain
deviation he would allow,

778
00:39:21,207 --> 00:39:25,250
where it might not be
exactly seven-and-a-quarter.

779
00:39:25,250 --> 00:39:28,415
It might be seven-and-three-eighths,
right.

780
00:39:28,415 --> 00:39:32,020
Just a little bit more
than seven-and-one-fourth.

781
00:39:32,020 --> 00:39:35,955
So if that was the case, he'd still
sell it as a seven-and-a-quarter,

782
00:39:35,955 --> 00:39:37,086
it was okay, right.

783
00:39:37,086 --> 00:39:40,094
But once it deviated far enough,
he would then re-label

784
00:39:40,094 --> 00:39:44,660
that mold to be the different size, and
now it would work for that different size.

785
00:39:44,660 --> 00:39:47,590
So with a histogram like this
we can start to chart that.

786
00:39:47,590 --> 00:39:51,870
That how long does it take for
that mold to wear down, and

787
00:39:51,870 --> 00:39:54,554
to start manufacturing a different size.

788
00:39:54,554 --> 00:39:58,110
You know, on day one,
it was manufacturing hats at this size.

789
00:39:58,110 --> 00:40:01,530
On day two, here's our deviation
as we start to creep up.

790
00:40:01,530 --> 00:40:03,650
And so, then we replace the mold.

791
00:40:03,650 --> 00:40:05,490
We move it,
we swap it with something else.

792
00:40:05,490 --> 00:40:08,087
So, you might have one that
just goes continually up.

793
00:40:08,087 --> 00:40:10,592
You might have one that goes like this,
that goes up and

794
00:40:10,592 --> 00:40:12,996
then down based on what it
is that we're working on.

795
00:40:12,996 --> 00:40:15,547
I might say over a course of a day,

796
00:40:15,547 --> 00:40:20,206
it manufactured this many hats
that were at these two sizes.

797
00:40:20,206 --> 00:40:22,829
But these other sizes were outliers right?

798
00:40:22,829 --> 00:40:26,109
At the beginning of the day
when the mold was nice and

799
00:40:26,109 --> 00:40:30,835
cool it was manufacturing down at this
size and as it warmed up it started to

800
00:40:30,835 --> 00:40:34,740
defect into higher sizes and
so we may map that out too.

801
00:40:34,740 --> 00:40:36,000
But a histogram is a simple tool.

802
00:40:36,000 --> 00:40:38,161
It's just a bar chart that maps that out.

803
00:40:41,877 --> 00:40:44,060
Now I mentioned tolerances.

804
00:40:44,060 --> 00:40:45,220
Okay.

805
00:40:45,220 --> 00:40:47,530
In manufacturing, you've got tolerances.

806
00:40:47,530 --> 00:40:50,270
You have what are called control limits.

807
00:40:50,270 --> 00:40:53,600
And basically what you say is when
you manufacture something you know

808
00:40:53,600 --> 00:40:56,550
that it's not always going
to be exactly the same.

809
00:40:56,550 --> 00:41:00,240
It's very difficult to
reproduce something exactly.

810
00:41:00,240 --> 00:41:03,720
And, so what you're normally
going to have is a target, right?

811
00:41:03,720 --> 00:41:06,610
Here's our average, our target,
that we're trying to hit.

812
00:41:06,610 --> 00:41:10,580
And, then as you manufacture, some
things might hit the target perfectly.

813
00:41:12,680 --> 00:41:16,680
Some might go over, some might go under,
they get close but not perfect.

814
00:41:16,680 --> 00:41:19,986
So I want those pairs of jeans
to have a 32-inch waistline,

815
00:41:19,986 --> 00:41:21,950
that's what I want a 32.

816
00:41:21,950 --> 00:41:22,680
Okay.

817
00:41:22,680 --> 00:41:25,525
But I might get some that are a 33 or

818
00:41:25,525 --> 00:41:29,940
a 31 you know as long as they're close
it's good enough I can sell it that way.

819
00:41:29,940 --> 00:41:31,920
Right it's meeting my tolerance.

820
00:41:31,920 --> 00:41:34,360
So if we have a tolerance like that.

821
00:41:34,360 --> 00:41:38,730
It's important that we establish it
early on in our quality management plan.

822
00:41:38,730 --> 00:41:43,810
And we specify what we call an upper
control limit and a lower control limit.

823
00:41:43,810 --> 00:41:45,400
A UCL and a LCL.

824
00:41:45,400 --> 00:41:49,430
The upper control limit is the most
in a positive direction we can

825
00:41:49,430 --> 00:41:53,840
deviate from the norm and still sell
the product as not being defective.

826
00:41:53,840 --> 00:41:57,380
Once you cross that limit,
now you're defective, right.

827
00:41:57,380 --> 00:41:59,190
And you're lower control limit,
same thing.

828
00:41:59,190 --> 00:42:02,400
The farthest negative you
can deviate from the norm

829
00:42:02,400 --> 00:42:04,660
without being considered a defect, right.

830
00:42:04,660 --> 00:42:08,200
And in most manufacturing you do
have an acceptable window a plus or

831
00:42:08,200 --> 00:42:10,100
minus window that you can fall into.

832
00:42:10,100 --> 00:42:11,540
And still be an acceptable product.

833
00:42:13,300 --> 00:42:15,860
If this is engineering, you might
have two parts that fit together.

834
00:42:15,860 --> 00:42:19,630
And they fit together fine as long as
they're within a few millimeters of

835
00:42:19,630 --> 00:42:21,090
measurement from each other.

836
00:42:21,090 --> 00:42:25,940
But if they get more than four millimeters
different, then it's too far apart and

837
00:42:25,940 --> 00:42:27,340
they're not gonna fit together right.

838
00:42:27,340 --> 00:42:30,690
They're gonna have uneven wear and
cause breakage.

839
00:42:30,690 --> 00:42:32,420
In those cases we need
to measure that out.

840
00:42:32,420 --> 00:42:34,780
This is going to vary
from project to project.

841
00:42:34,780 --> 00:42:38,590
Whatever it is that you're dealing with
you'll have these acceptable limits.

842
00:42:38,590 --> 00:42:41,390
Now, here they are talking
about call wait times.

843
00:42:42,580 --> 00:42:44,560
They have a call center, and

844
00:42:44,560 --> 00:42:50,970
if someone calls in they only want
them to wait on average 15 seconds.

845
00:42:50,970 --> 00:42:54,890
So if somebody calls in, they want that
phone to be answered within 15 seconds.

846
00:42:54,890 --> 00:42:58,760
And they set an upper limit of, what do
you think that is Ryan, like 23 seconds or

847
00:42:58,760 --> 00:42:59,410
something?

848
00:42:59,410 --> 00:43:00,120
>> Yeah.

849
00:43:00,120 --> 00:43:02,641
>> Saying that if it takes as
long as 23 seconds we're okay.

850
00:43:02,641 --> 00:43:06,549
If it takes as little as
seven seconds we're okay.

851
00:43:06,549 --> 00:43:11,247
But if we deviate above that,
if it takes too long to answer the phone,

852
00:43:11,247 --> 00:43:13,340
we have a problem, right?

853
00:43:13,340 --> 00:43:15,110
If we answer the phone too fast,
we have a problem.

854
00:43:15,110 --> 00:43:18,680
That might sound crazy, but then maybe
that makes your company sound desperate.

855
00:43:18,680 --> 00:43:20,830
You answer the phone right away.

856
00:43:20,830 --> 00:43:22,640
So that's just not long enough.

857
00:43:22,640 --> 00:43:28,000
So we set these limits of what we consider
acceptable and we monitor our trend.

858
00:43:28,000 --> 00:43:30,460
You might notice here that
they didn't do the trend, but

859
00:43:30,460 --> 00:43:34,860
if you look at this, notice how we start
kinda below here and we're really below.

860
00:43:34,860 --> 00:43:39,560
And they we start kind of creeping up,
and now we're no so much below anymore.

861
00:43:39,560 --> 00:43:43,490
And towards the end of this,
see how we're not very far below at all.

862
00:43:43,490 --> 00:43:46,940
There's a general trend here of going up.

863
00:43:46,940 --> 00:43:50,550
So our average way call,
if we were to map that trend,

864
00:43:50,550 --> 00:43:55,830
is slowly creeping up, meaning our
wait times are starting to increase.

865
00:43:55,830 --> 00:43:59,080
Now, this is being done over
they just show 20 samples.

866
00:43:59,080 --> 00:44:01,700
I don't know what that is right,
maybe this is 20 days.

867
00:44:01,700 --> 00:44:07,150
So over 20 days I've got a general
trend of increasing call wait times.

868
00:44:07,150 --> 00:44:10,820
So is I map this out,
how many days is it going to be

869
00:44:10,820 --> 00:44:14,590
before this general trend
hits my upper control limit?

870
00:44:14,590 --> 00:44:16,900
So we can use this to
kinda predict the future.

871
00:44:16,900 --> 00:44:20,950
If this trend stays the same,
two years from now,

872
00:44:20,950 --> 00:44:23,620
I'm gonna hit my upper control limit,
okay?

873
00:44:23,620 --> 00:44:25,230
And so I can make plans for that.

874
00:44:25,230 --> 00:44:25,850
I can say, you know what?

875
00:44:25,850 --> 00:44:28,700
Two years from now, I'm gonna need
to add some more phone reps so

876
00:44:28,700 --> 00:44:30,900
that we can get that call wait time down,
right?

877
00:44:30,900 --> 00:44:34,345
That's what this stuff is all about,
is kind of planning for that eventuality.

878
00:44:37,768 --> 00:44:42,510
All right, and then the last of our
seven tools the Scatter Diagrams.

879
00:44:42,510 --> 00:44:45,000
Scatter Diagrams are where I
do my statistical samples.

880
00:44:45,000 --> 00:44:48,990
If I'm manufacturing 1000 pairs of jeans,
I don't want to go out and

881
00:44:48,990 --> 00:44:51,110
look at every single pair.

882
00:44:51,110 --> 00:44:54,760
So maybe I grab every tenth pair,
or every 100th pair.

883
00:44:54,760 --> 00:44:57,140
And I throw it on a diagram or I map.

884
00:44:57,140 --> 00:45:00,280
Here they're doing temperature
versus pounds per square inch.

885
00:45:00,280 --> 00:45:02,930
And so we map what that is.

886
00:45:02,930 --> 00:45:05,450
So here, what would you measure
temperature and PSI for?

887
00:45:05,450 --> 00:45:07,170
An engine maybe?

888
00:45:07,170 --> 00:45:07,910
So.
>> Could be yeah.

889
00:45:07,910 --> 00:45:09,460
>> Like compression on an engine.

890
00:45:10,660 --> 00:45:12,090
>> Yeah.
>> I don't know.

891
00:45:12,090 --> 00:45:13,000
Whatever it is.

892
00:45:13,000 --> 00:45:15,302
So we would measure these two values and
chart it out.

893
00:45:15,302 --> 00:45:21,583
And what you're looking for is again that
trend to see where you are on average.

894
00:45:21,583 --> 00:45:26,170
And then if you have deviation, now see
this big deviator down here, this outlier.

895
00:45:26,170 --> 00:45:26,950
What's going on there?

896
00:45:26,950 --> 00:45:28,420
What caused that?

897
00:45:28,420 --> 00:45:32,300
Is there a flaw in my manufacturing
process that led to these, or

898
00:45:32,300 --> 00:45:34,260
is that just something that happened?

899
00:45:34,260 --> 00:45:36,110
An outlier that we can disregard.

900
00:45:36,110 --> 00:45:40,350
So scatter diagrams help us to plot
that and see when we've got deviation.

901
00:45:40,350 --> 00:45:41,300
With a scatter diagram,

902
00:45:41,300 --> 00:45:45,280
the goal is to have all of your dots
be as close together as possible.

903
00:45:45,280 --> 00:45:47,770
A perfectly working system
should only have one point.

904
00:45:47,770 --> 00:45:49,230
Everybody falls at the same point.

905
00:45:49,230 --> 00:45:51,370
But it's never perfect, right?.

906
00:45:51,370 --> 00:45:55,320
So you'll see it a little more like this,
where it kind of flowers out.

907
00:45:55,320 --> 00:46:00,200
But if you've got it all over the place,
that means a very inconsistent process and

908
00:46:00,200 --> 00:46:01,240
something we need to reevaluate.

909
00:46:02,800 --> 00:46:08,170
So those are our seven tools available for
quality control.

910
00:46:08,170 --> 00:46:09,950
They're all pretty common sense.

911
00:46:09,950 --> 00:46:10,930
They're pretty powerful.

912
00:46:10,930 --> 00:46:13,015
The challenging part of the exam
is just remembering the names,

913
00:46:13,015 --> 00:46:13,960
cuz some of them are strange.

914
00:46:13,960 --> 00:46:15,220
The Pareto Diagram, right?

915
00:46:15,220 --> 00:46:16,820
You might not be familiar with that one.

916
00:46:16,820 --> 00:46:20,080
And then the Cause & Effect diagram,
because it's got three names, right?

917
00:46:20,080 --> 00:46:23,190
Also a Fishbone,
also an Ishikawa, and I think,

918
00:46:23,190 --> 00:46:24,710
Ronnie, you had all those in the notes,
right?

919
00:46:24,710 --> 00:46:25,640
>> Yep.
>> Let me

920
00:46:25,640 --> 00:46:26,730
>> Bring that up.

921
00:46:26,730 --> 00:46:30,950
So yeah cause and effect also known
as Fishbone also known as Ishikawa.

922
00:46:30,950 --> 00:46:33,000
So just be familiar with those names.

923
00:46:33,000 --> 00:46:34,199
They may turn up on the exam.

924
00:46:39,193 --> 00:46:40,375
All right.

925
00:46:40,375 --> 00:46:42,175
Some of the other things
that we might see.

926
00:46:42,175 --> 00:46:44,165
Those seven tools, that's the big deal.

927
00:46:44,165 --> 00:46:45,825
We also have benchmarking.

928
00:46:45,825 --> 00:46:51,895
Benchmarking is where, maybe we don't know
exactly how accurate our stuff should be.

929
00:46:51,895 --> 00:46:53,325
So we come up with a benchmark.

930
00:46:53,325 --> 00:46:57,095
A goal that we want to hit, and it might
be something that we set internally, or

931
00:46:57,095 --> 00:47:00,165
we might reach out to our competitors,
or other people in our industry and

932
00:47:00,165 --> 00:47:04,030
say, we're manufacturing
a thousand pairs of jeans and

933
00:47:04,030 --> 00:47:06,590
here's the defect rate
we're trying to get to.

934
00:47:06,590 --> 00:47:11,480
I wonder what Levi's hits or
what Lee or some other competitor.

935
00:47:11,480 --> 00:47:13,440
What defect rate do they have?

936
00:47:13,440 --> 00:47:16,040
And we then we kind of work towards
that we use that as our benchmark.

937
00:47:16,040 --> 00:47:20,390
We compare that against what they're
doing to see if we're being competitive.

938
00:47:20,390 --> 00:47:22,190
It might be an internal benchmark.

939
00:47:22,190 --> 00:47:24,660
Last month here's what my defect rate was.

940
00:47:24,660 --> 00:47:29,000
So this month I want my defect
rate to be the same, or better.

941
00:47:29,000 --> 00:47:32,660
So last month's defect rate
becomes this month's benchmark.

942
00:47:32,660 --> 00:47:34,510
So that, kind of,
a goal that we work towards.

943
00:47:36,990 --> 00:47:39,480
Another tool or technique we
have is design of experiments.

944
00:47:39,480 --> 00:47:41,560
This is a tough one.

945
00:47:41,560 --> 00:47:44,060
If we are manufacturing blue jeans.

946
00:47:45,260 --> 00:47:46,520
I'm a project manager.

947
00:47:46,520 --> 00:47:48,950
I have project management skills.

948
00:47:48,950 --> 00:47:51,300
Do I have manufacture blue jeans skills?

949
00:47:51,300 --> 00:47:52,300
No.
I couldn't do it.

950
00:47:52,300 --> 00:47:54,740
I don't even know how to
work a sewing machine.

951
00:47:54,740 --> 00:47:57,270
If you gave me a pair of blue jeans,

952
00:47:57,270 --> 00:48:02,696
am I capable of judging whether or
not the blue jeans are up to quality?

953
00:48:02,696 --> 00:48:04,126
No.
I don't really know what quality

954
00:48:04,126 --> 00:48:07,483
comes down to if you just stick them in my
hands and tell me to look at them, right?

955
00:48:07,483 --> 00:48:11,744
So what we need Is to come up with tests.

956
00:48:11,744 --> 00:48:15,640
Tests to evaluate
the quality of our product.

957
00:48:15,640 --> 00:48:18,761
So, we're typically gonna bring
in a subject matter expert.

958
00:48:18,761 --> 00:48:22,092
And they're gonna do
design of experiments.

959
00:48:22,092 --> 00:48:26,890
And that just means they're going
to create the tests that we use.

960
00:48:26,890 --> 00:48:29,010
And it could be as simple as a checklist.

961
00:48:29,010 --> 00:48:31,380
You look at the jeans,
you do a checklist, right?

962
00:48:31,380 --> 00:48:33,920
You ever buy a new pair of jeans, and
you stick your hand in your pocket, and

963
00:48:33,920 --> 00:48:36,200
you pull out a sticker that says,
inspected by 47, right?

964
00:48:37,560 --> 00:48:41,259
That means that there was a quality
assurance person at the factory,

965
00:48:41,259 --> 00:48:45,146
whose ID number is 47, who had
a checklist, that looked at your pair of

966
00:48:45,146 --> 00:48:48,870
jeans and said your pair of jeans
met their checklist requirements.

967
00:48:48,870 --> 00:48:51,308
That's usually all
the experimentation we get.

968
00:48:51,308 --> 00:48:52,086
All right.

969
00:48:52,086 --> 00:48:55,198
It might be a lot more sophisticated.

970
00:48:55,198 --> 00:49:00,492
There is a, I did a little bit of work for
a road paving company.

971
00:49:00,492 --> 00:49:03,173
And, when they would pave the road,
I don't think much about them.

972
00:49:03,173 --> 00:49:04,242
Just put down asphalt.

973
00:49:04,242 --> 00:49:05,216
Draw some lines on it.

974
00:49:05,216 --> 00:49:05,890
They're done.

975
00:49:05,890 --> 00:49:07,167
Easiest job in the world, right?

976
00:49:07,167 --> 00:49:12,385
Well, when they manufacture that asphalt,
they have a number of chemical experiments

977
00:49:12,385 --> 00:49:16,758
they perform on it to make sure that
it meets certain consistency levels,

978
00:49:16,758 --> 00:49:20,073
that the components are mixed
in the right quantities,

979
00:49:20,073 --> 00:49:22,701
and that it will withstand
the test of time.

980
00:49:22,701 --> 00:49:27,700
And so, every batch of asphalt that they
manufacture has to meet these tests, and

981
00:49:27,700 --> 00:49:31,409
they have a chemist on staff
that actually does those tests.

982
00:49:31,409 --> 00:49:33,939
Very sophisticated, way more
sophisticated than I thought it was.

983
00:49:33,939 --> 00:49:39,710
And then after they lay it, they have
a radioactive depth measurement tool.

984
00:49:39,710 --> 00:49:41,610
They go through and
they can measure the density and

985
00:49:41,610 --> 00:49:44,000
the depth of the asphalt at any point.

986
00:49:44,000 --> 00:49:45,780
So, they do these measurements every so

987
00:49:45,780 --> 00:49:49,630
many feet to evaluate how
dense that asphalt is.

988
00:49:49,630 --> 00:49:52,624
They're doing that because if they don't,

989
00:49:52,624 --> 00:49:57,203
the road is gonna wear down early,
and sinkholes are going to occur.

990
00:49:57,203 --> 00:50:00,814
And so, if that happens, they're gonna
have to get back out and fix them, and

991
00:50:00,814 --> 00:50:02,805
it's tough to shut down
a road to fix them.

992
00:50:02,805 --> 00:50:06,671
And, it's even more tough to have a city
that has the funding to repair the roads

993
00:50:06,671 --> 00:50:08,182
as we see here in Gainesville.

994
00:50:08,182 --> 00:50:10,109
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, it's like pothole city out there.

995
00:50:10,109 --> 00:50:11,154
>> Yeah.

996
00:50:11,154 --> 00:50:13,313
>> So, that's design of experiments.

997
00:50:13,313 --> 00:50:15,340
Somebody's got to create these tests.

998
00:50:15,340 --> 00:50:18,550
We create the tests in the planning
phase but we don't use them.

999
00:50:18,550 --> 00:50:22,970
We use them in the monitoring and
controlling phase.

1000
00:50:22,970 --> 00:50:26,260
Statistical sampling,
I've already talked about a few times now.

1001
00:50:26,260 --> 00:50:28,750
And that is, you can't test everything.

1002
00:50:28,750 --> 00:50:30,690
Well, you can,
if you have enough time and resources.

1003
00:50:30,690 --> 00:50:31,960
But for most of us,

1004
00:50:31,960 --> 00:50:38,530
we grab a sample that is big enough
to be statistically significant.

1005
00:50:38,530 --> 00:50:42,430
And if you get too small of a sampling
