01:02:06,835 --> 01:02:10,105
>> We don't send out huge amounts
of advertisements and things.

1227
01:02:10,105 --> 01:02:12,480
So we said, we really need somebody.

1228
01:02:12,480 --> 01:02:13,520
And instead of going out, and

1229
01:02:13,520 --> 01:02:16,290
trying to find them on our own,
we went to a conference.

1230
01:02:16,290 --> 01:02:18,290
We went to this conference where
there were tons of marketers, and so

1231
01:02:18,290 --> 01:02:20,650
we could shake their hands,
talk to them, and

1232
01:02:20,650 --> 01:02:23,620
get a good feel of who would be right for
us.

1233
01:02:23,620 --> 01:02:26,380
And so that's something that's very handy.

1234
01:02:26,380 --> 01:02:28,390
That's all a part of networking.

1235
01:02:28,390 --> 01:02:29,210
>> Right.

1236
01:02:29,210 --> 01:02:31,160
>> And
you don't just do networking externally,

1237
01:02:31,160 --> 01:02:32,960
you do networking internally too.

1238
01:02:32,960 --> 01:02:36,170
If you're relying on resources
coming from a functional manager,

1239
01:02:36,170 --> 01:02:36,940
you need to know them.

1240
01:02:36,940 --> 01:02:38,820
You need to go sit down,
have lunch with them.

1241
01:02:38,820 --> 01:02:42,430
Talk to them, get a good idea of
who they are, how they work, and

1242
01:02:42,430 --> 01:02:43,340
what their requirements are.

1243
01:02:45,290 --> 01:02:47,330
Organizational theory is another one.

1244
01:02:47,330 --> 01:02:52,030
Now this is a big one, and if we dive in,
Ronnie did good notes on this stuff.

1245
01:02:52,030 --> 01:02:56,230
Organizational theory, it's a big deal.

1246
01:02:56,230 --> 01:02:59,510
So, we're basically saying that there
are a number of different ways that we can

1247
01:02:59,510 --> 01:03:03,570
organize our companies, like that
functional and project eyes and all that.

1248
01:03:03,570 --> 01:03:06,030
And so we need to make sure that we've got

1249
01:03:06,030 --> 01:03:08,630
a good grasp of how our
company is organized.

1250
01:03:08,630 --> 01:03:12,290
And then when we bring in
employees into our project,

1251
01:03:12,290 --> 01:03:14,990
we're creating like a microcosm,
a small company.

1252
01:03:14,990 --> 01:03:19,610
So we have a different organizational
structure inside of the project than we do

1253
01:03:19,610 --> 01:03:22,530
in our company ourself, and
we have to be Aware of that.

1254
01:03:22,530 --> 01:03:26,570
And you know I was leading
into the RACI diagram, but

1255
01:03:26,570 --> 01:03:30,160
I see that you've already got that
up here so I skipped over it.

1256
01:03:30,160 --> 01:03:33,830
So I did talk about the matrix-based,
and hierarchical stuff, so that's good.

1257
01:03:33,830 --> 01:03:37,880
But one other thing that we might
be doing as we develop this,

1258
01:03:37,880 --> 01:03:41,980
is what's called a R-A-C-I,
or RACI diagram.

1259
01:03:41,980 --> 01:03:46,680
Which is responsible, accountable,
consult, and informed.

1260
01:03:46,680 --> 01:03:49,010
It's a chart of people, and

1261
01:03:49,010 --> 01:03:52,600
we designate what role they're
performing inside of our organization.

1262
01:03:52,600 --> 01:03:57,069
And I've got a template for this,
let me see if I've got that handy here.

1263
01:03:57,069 --> 01:04:00,140
I think I had it open this morning,
which was, here we go,

1264
01:04:00,140 --> 01:04:01,784
responsibility assignment.

1265
01:04:01,784 --> 01:04:05,269
So this is what a RACI diagram looks like.

1266
01:04:05,269 --> 01:04:07,332
Basically you have your work packages.

1267
01:04:07,332 --> 01:04:09,830
These are from your work break
down structure, your WBS.

1268
01:04:09,830 --> 01:04:11,489
So here's stuff that needs to get done.

1269
01:04:11,489 --> 01:04:14,747
And then up here is a list
of people that can do it,

1270
01:04:14,747 --> 01:04:18,420
person one through person four, and so on.

1271
01:04:18,420 --> 01:04:21,020
And what you do is you designate what

1272
01:04:21,020 --> 01:04:25,040
role that person has in that
particular work package.

1273
01:04:25,040 --> 01:04:27,720
And so you'll flag them as, and

1274
01:04:27,720 --> 01:04:32,530
you'll see the little legend down
here at the bottom, R is responsible.

1275
01:04:32,530 --> 01:04:37,800
That means if person one has an R for
Work package one,

1276
01:04:37,800 --> 01:04:41,050
then down here I can see that they
are responsible for that work package.

1277
01:04:41,050 --> 01:04:41,740
They've got to do it.

1278
01:04:41,740 --> 01:04:43,610
They're the ones who have to get it done.

1279
01:04:43,610 --> 01:04:46,480
If it was an A, they're accountable.

1280
01:04:46,480 --> 01:04:49,370
That means they're not necessarily
the one doing the work, but

1281
01:04:49,370 --> 01:04:52,510
if it doesn't get done, it's their fault.

1282
01:04:52,510 --> 01:04:55,810
So I might need web developers,
but I don't have any.

1283
01:04:55,810 --> 01:05:01,350
So I go to the CIO, the Chief Information
Officer and I request from her.

1284
01:05:01,350 --> 01:05:02,860
I say, hey,
can you give us some web developers.

1285
01:05:02,860 --> 01:05:05,020
And she says, sure,
you know, I've got them.

1286
01:05:05,020 --> 01:05:07,600
Flag me as the one who's accountable.

1287
01:05:07,600 --> 01:05:09,230
I'll make sure my web
developers get it done.

1288
01:05:10,270 --> 01:05:11,680
And so, off you go.

1289
01:05:11,680 --> 01:05:13,075
You don't even know who
the web developers are,

1290
01:05:13,075 --> 01:05:15,430
cuz she's the one who's
acting as the intermediary.

1291
01:05:15,430 --> 01:05:16,110
She takes care of it.

1292
01:05:16,110 --> 01:05:18,080
She is accountable.

1293
01:05:18,080 --> 01:05:20,150
And then consult.

1294
01:05:20,150 --> 01:05:22,160
They're not the ones who
are responsible or accountable.

1295
01:05:22,160 --> 01:05:24,500
They're not actually doing the work or
even involved in it.

1296
01:05:24,500 --> 01:05:27,370
But I am meaning to consult
with them about decisions

1297
01:05:27,370 --> 01:05:28,940
that are being made as a part of it.

1298
01:05:28,940 --> 01:05:30,790
These might be subject matter experts.

1299
01:05:30,790 --> 01:05:33,940
These might be people that
are high up in the chain, but

1300
01:05:33,940 --> 01:05:36,000
aren't the ones that who
actually do the work.

1301
01:05:36,000 --> 01:05:39,490
And so they need to be
consulted as we make decisions.

1302
01:05:39,490 --> 01:05:41,730
Your project sponsors
almost always consult.

1303
01:05:41,730 --> 01:05:44,850
And then we have inform.

1304
01:05:44,850 --> 01:05:47,930
They're not involved at all
in this particular activity.

1305
01:05:47,930 --> 01:05:52,680
But we need to inform them of the status,
and so if you have a real hands off

1306
01:05:52,680 --> 01:05:56,710
sponsor, or typically the originator,
these are the people who just need to be

1307
01:05:56,710 --> 01:05:59,330
kept informed to understand
how things are going.

1308
01:05:59,330 --> 01:06:03,070
And so, we can create a diagram
like this to try and chart that.

1309
01:06:03,070 --> 01:06:06,700
To keep a list so
that we know who to reach out to,

1310
01:06:06,700 --> 01:06:08,760
and how we need to interact with them.

1311
01:06:09,860 --> 01:06:10,460
All right.

1312
01:06:10,460 --> 01:06:14,130
So this is a part of that
human resources plan also.

1313
01:06:14,130 --> 01:06:15,780
Are we going to keep a chart like this?

1314
01:06:15,780 --> 01:06:18,210
Personally, I don't like these charts,

1315
01:06:18,210 --> 01:06:22,490
just because if you have four people on
your project, this chart works great.

1316
01:06:22,490 --> 01:06:24,510
But what if you have 400
people on your project?

1317
01:06:24,510 --> 01:06:25,680
This chart's useless.

1318
01:06:25,680 --> 01:06:29,110
And so, you know, I'll normally do
a slightly different arrangement.

1319
01:06:29,110 --> 01:06:32,480
You know, basically what I like
to do is when I do the WBS,

1320
01:06:32,480 --> 01:06:36,978
the work breakdown structure, in my
WBS dictionary for each work package,

1321
01:06:36,978 --> 01:06:41,610
I've got information detailing that
package in the WBS dictionary.

1322
01:06:41,610 --> 01:06:44,560
I list who's responsible,
accountable and so forth in there,

1323
01:06:44,560 --> 01:06:46,250
as part of the WBS dictionary.

1324
01:06:46,250 --> 01:06:46,750
You can do that.

1325
01:06:46,750 --> 01:06:49,310
Remember all this stuff is modular and
flexible.

1326
01:06:49,310 --> 01:06:52,860
The larger projects are not gonna lend
themselves well to a chart like this.

1327
01:06:56,940 --> 01:06:57,860
All right, so

1328
01:06:57,860 --> 01:07:01,892
those are some of the different things
that are available to us in there.

1329
01:07:01,892 --> 01:07:05,700
We've got other simple things
like expert judgments and

1330
01:07:05,700 --> 01:07:08,050
meetings that we seen over and over again.

1331
01:07:08,050 --> 01:07:11,490
But basically, we're specifying in
here how we're gonna get these people,

1332
01:07:11,490 --> 01:07:15,650
how we know how many people to get, and
at what process we're going to go through.

1333
01:07:15,650 --> 01:07:19,750
The end result as a human resources
management plan, which is far less

1334
01:07:19,750 --> 01:07:24,090
detailed than you'd think, because we're
not actually getting the people yet, so

1335
01:07:24,090 --> 01:07:27,930
it's really detailing what we're
going to do in the future.

1336
01:07:27,930 --> 01:07:31,600
When it comes time to get people,
how do we get them, right?

1337
01:07:31,600 --> 01:07:33,400
That's what's in our
resource management plan.

1338
01:07:33,400 --> 01:07:37,010
So let me pull up a sample of
a resource management plan.

1339
01:07:39,440 --> 01:07:40,700
>> Two down.

1340
01:07:40,700 --> 01:07:41,730
>> Human resource management plan.

1341
01:07:41,730 --> 01:07:42,230
There we go.

1342
01:07:43,420 --> 01:07:48,650
And so, what you'll see in here is
attached to your project, who is attached,

1343
01:07:48,650 --> 01:07:51,900
what their role is, their responsibility,
their authority, right?

1344
01:07:51,900 --> 01:07:54,770
These are generally people that are a part
of like your project management team but

1345
01:07:54,770 --> 01:07:57,130
it's also gonna include
things like your PMO,

1346
01:07:57,130 --> 01:07:59,380
if that's where you're
getting people from, or

1347
01:07:59,380 --> 01:08:02,330
your Human Resources Department if
that's where you're getting people from.

1348
01:08:03,430 --> 01:08:05,270
Your project organizational structure.

1349
01:08:05,270 --> 01:08:09,480
Now notice that's not the company
organization, it's the project.

1350
01:08:09,480 --> 01:08:12,134
The project manager is usually
gonna be at the top of this and

1351
01:08:12,134 --> 01:08:14,700
how people breakdown underneath that.

1352
01:08:14,700 --> 01:08:20,150
And then the most important part of
this plan, the Staffing Management Plan.

1353
01:08:20,150 --> 01:08:22,740
How do you acquire your staff?

1354
01:08:22,740 --> 01:08:26,550
If I need web developer one, two,
and 3, all right, how do I do it?

1355
01:08:26,550 --> 01:08:27,890
Well, in my acquisition plan,

1356
01:08:27,890 --> 01:08:33,270
I might put whatever possible
leverage internal personnel.

1357
01:08:33,270 --> 01:08:36,920
You'll acquire internal personnel
through the use of a PMO, or

1358
01:08:36,920 --> 01:08:40,240
through the functional manager for
that appropriate department, right?

1359
01:08:40,240 --> 01:08:46,090
And then, when not possible,
perform a request-for-bid process and

1360
01:08:46,090 --> 01:08:48,200
bring in contractors to perform that role,
all right?

1361
01:08:49,220 --> 01:08:50,590
So I'm laying that out.

1362
01:08:50,590 --> 01:08:52,140
Use internal people first.

1363
01:08:52,140 --> 01:08:55,760
If you can't, then use external
to move the project forward.

1364
01:08:55,760 --> 01:09:01,520
And anytime you have staff acquisition,
it's important that you do staff release.

1365
01:09:01,520 --> 01:09:03,970
Also, remember these employees, if
they're internal employees, they work for

1366
01:09:03,970 --> 01:09:05,640
the company, they don't work for
your project.

1367
01:09:05,640 --> 01:09:07,430
At least not in most cases.

1368
01:09:07,430 --> 01:09:08,880
And, so in that scenario,

1369
01:09:08,880 --> 01:09:11,710
when you're done with them,
how do you turn them back in, right?

1370
01:09:11,710 --> 01:09:13,510
And it sounds really negative,

1371
01:09:13,510 --> 01:09:16,760
like turning in a bowling ball at the
bowling alley when you're done bowling.

1372
01:09:16,760 --> 01:09:20,010
But, basically, when you're done with
that person, when they're done with their

1373
01:09:20,010 --> 01:09:23,890
responsibilities in the project, they're
now free to go work on other projects.

1374
01:09:23,890 --> 01:09:28,460
So you need a formal process for
releasing the employee so

1375
01:09:28,460 --> 01:09:31,690
that the company knows they are now
available to work on other projects.

1376
01:09:31,690 --> 01:09:33,010
You're not firing them.

1377
01:09:33,010 --> 01:09:36,190
You're just making them available
again for other projects.

1378
01:09:36,190 --> 01:09:40,020
But while you've got them locked in,
while you've got them acquired,

1379
01:09:40,020 --> 01:09:43,250
no one else can use them unless you've
come up with an agreement there.

1380
01:09:43,250 --> 01:09:47,580
For example, you might secure somebody
to work part time on your project and so

1381
01:09:47,580 --> 01:09:50,660
they have more time available for
other responsibilities.

1382
01:09:50,660 --> 01:09:54,710
That is incredibly common.

1383
01:09:54,710 --> 01:09:59,380
I was a network manager for
a bank and my team,

1384
01:09:59,380 --> 01:10:04,520
myself and the other network engineers,
the way we work is about 50% of our time

1385
01:10:04,520 --> 01:10:08,970
was spent on projects and 50% of our time
was spent on maintenance and operations.

1386
01:10:08,970 --> 01:10:13,620
And so in any given day, we only had
half our time to work on projects.

1387
01:10:13,620 --> 01:10:16,970
The other time, it was spent maintaining
and monitoring our networks.

1388
01:10:16,970 --> 01:10:19,590
We were always split
between those two roles.

1389
01:10:19,590 --> 01:10:22,960
Very common, and so you need to make
sure that's set out in your plan.

1390
01:10:24,360 --> 01:10:27,480
All right, some of the other
things that we might include here.

1391
01:10:27,480 --> 01:10:30,750
If we're gathering people together
their resource calendars.

1392
01:10:30,750 --> 01:10:33,120
If we're collecting them, I wouldn't
normally put them in a box here.

1393
01:10:33,120 --> 01:10:36,610
They'd normally be, like,
attached as appendices.

1394
01:10:36,610 --> 01:10:38,800
Any training requirements?

1395
01:10:38,800 --> 01:10:42,470
It might be that I need personnel and
I could contract it out, but

1396
01:10:42,470 --> 01:10:46,280
I could train somebody
internally to meet my need.

1397
01:10:46,280 --> 01:10:48,240
I need to do a cost benefit analysis.

1398
01:10:48,240 --> 01:10:52,140
The advantage of training somebody is that
they're then available to help with other

1399
01:10:52,140 --> 01:10:55,640
projects in the future and
avoid that outsourcing requirement.

1400
01:10:57,040 --> 01:10:59,300
Rewards and Recognition.

1401
01:10:59,300 --> 01:11:04,010
When somebody successfully completes
the project, as a project manager,

1402
01:11:04,010 --> 01:11:08,160
you may not have hire/fire and
evaluation roles.

1403
01:11:08,160 --> 01:11:12,110
You might not have the authority
to give somebody a raise, but

1404
01:11:12,110 --> 01:11:16,200
by building it into our plan,
we can get our sponsor to sign off on it.

1405
01:11:16,200 --> 01:11:20,200
And our sponsor may have that authority,
usually does have that authority.

1406
01:11:20,200 --> 01:11:21,710
So any kind of rewards, or

1407
01:11:21,710 --> 01:11:24,340
whatever you might be planning,
you build in to your plan.

1408
01:11:26,200 --> 01:11:27,810
Then any regulations and standards,

1409
01:11:27,810 --> 01:11:34,830
this comes right from Enterprise
Environmental Factors, there we go, EEF.

1410
01:11:34,830 --> 01:11:36,130
It comes straight from those.

1411
01:11:36,130 --> 01:11:38,460
We basically punch in anything
that we have to live up to.

1412
01:11:38,460 --> 01:11:39,940
And safety, right?

1413
01:11:39,940 --> 01:11:41,840
In the United States, we have OSHA.

1414
01:11:41,840 --> 01:11:45,830
Every single business, 100% of them,
has to comply to the, what is that?

1415
01:11:45,830 --> 01:11:48,350
Occupational Safety and
Hazard Administration?

1416
01:11:48,350 --> 01:11:49,160
That there we go.

1417
01:11:49,160 --> 01:11:51,560
So one of the few acronyms
that I got on the first try.

1418
01:11:51,560 --> 01:11:54,050
So those are things that
we have to live up to.

1419
01:11:54,050 --> 01:11:56,040
We put those in the plan too.

1420
01:11:56,040 --> 01:11:58,125
You'll notice that all of this
is pretty generic, right?

1421
01:11:58,125 --> 01:12:01,681
So if you keep it generic enough,
this human resources

1422
01:12:01,681 --> 01:12:06,180
plan is then able to apply to all of
your projects, you just reuse it.

1423
01:12:06,180 --> 01:12:08,160
So you typically only have
to draft this one time, and

1424
01:12:08,160 --> 01:12:09,218
then just keep it up to date.

1425
01:12:09,218 --> 01:12:11,390
>> Mm-hm.

1426
01:12:11,390 --> 01:12:12,016
>> All right.

1427
01:12:12,016 --> 01:12:14,970
So that is pretty much
human resources management.

1428
01:12:14,970 --> 01:12:19,570
Our outputs of this process
are the human resource management plans.

1429
01:12:19,570 --> 01:12:23,120
We're not acquiring people yet,
we're just planning for it.

1430
01:12:23,120 --> 01:12:25,820
And you'll notice that we've got
plan human resource management here

1431
01:12:25,820 --> 01:12:26,790
in planning.

1432
01:12:26,790 --> 01:12:29,600
In execution, you've got acquire the team.

1433
01:12:29,600 --> 01:12:31,900
If we acquire the team now in planning,

1434
01:12:31,900 --> 01:12:34,570
we're not ready to start the work
that we have them assigned to.

1435
01:12:34,570 --> 01:12:37,070
So we do have a project management team.

1436
01:12:37,070 --> 01:12:40,240
Notice over here, it doesn't say
acquire the project management team.

1437
01:12:40,240 --> 01:12:44,460
It says acquire the project team,
develop the project team.

1438
01:12:44,460 --> 01:12:47,410
The project management
team is already in place.

1439
01:12:47,410 --> 01:12:52,300
They were put in place back here, when we
were dealing with our scope and so on.

1440
01:12:52,300 --> 01:12:55,540
In order to get that stuff going
once our charter was signed,

1441
01:12:55,540 --> 01:12:57,200
that's where we got our
project management team.

1442
01:12:58,310 --> 01:13:02,152
Keep that in mind,
that's pretty much human resources.

1443
01:13:02,152 --> 01:13:03,885
All right.

1444
01:13:03,885 --> 01:13:05,715
We've got one more area
that we want to jump into,

1445
01:13:05,715 --> 01:13:09,565
which is our communications management
plan, before we wrap up this episode.

1446
01:13:09,565 --> 01:13:10,295
So let's do this.

1447
01:13:10,295 --> 01:13:13,565
Let's stop here and
take a break and when we get back,

1448
01:13:13,565 --> 01:13:16,525
we're gonna dive into communications and
take a look at that.

1449
01:13:16,525 --> 01:13:18,755
Kind of see what's involved and
we'll wrap up from there.

1450
01:13:18,755 --> 01:13:23,620
So stay tuned, we'll be back in a few.

1451
01:13:23,620 --> 01:13:27,927
[SOUND] All right.

1452
01:13:27,927 --> 01:13:30,717
So for our last process this afternoon,

1453
01:13:30,717 --> 01:13:35,320
we're gonna take a look at planning
communications management.

1454
01:13:35,320 --> 01:13:36,000
>> Right.

1455
01:13:36,000 --> 01:13:40,130
>> Now, we talked briefly about
communications back at the very beginning

1456
01:13:40,130 --> 01:13:41,340
of the project.

1457
01:13:41,340 --> 01:13:43,470
We created a stakeholder register,

1458
01:13:43,470 --> 01:13:46,120
where we listed all
the stakeholders of our project.

1459
01:13:46,120 --> 01:13:49,260
And we put some basic information
about how to communicate with them.

1460
01:13:49,260 --> 01:13:51,260
But now, we need to refine that.

1461
01:13:51,260 --> 01:13:55,680
A lot of that was done early on in the
project, and we've learned a lot more now.

1462
01:13:55,680 --> 01:13:59,570
The main thing we've learned is that
we've got a lot of work packages

1463
01:13:59,570 --> 01:14:03,210
that have actual workers attached to them,
that we're gonna have to communicate with.

1464
01:14:03,210 --> 01:14:05,380
Not necessarily the stakeholder
who identified earlier.

1465
01:14:05,380 --> 01:14:08,750
So we've got a whole slew of new
people attached to our project, so

1466
01:14:08,750 --> 01:14:10,820
it's time to revisit that.

1467
01:14:10,820 --> 01:14:13,620
Revisiting the communications management
plan is one of the things that I like to

1468
01:14:13,620 --> 01:14:16,280
do later in the planning phase

1469
01:14:16,280 --> 01:14:18,335
because the more planning you
do the more people you find.

1470
01:14:18,335 --> 01:14:19,710
>> Mm-hm.
>> And so, this is one that's constantly

1471
01:14:19,710 --> 01:14:22,560
getting updated
>> So I like to do a final pass before we

1472
01:14:22,560 --> 01:14:27,820
move into execution, just to make sure
that I've got all my people listed.

1473
01:14:27,820 --> 01:14:29,080
You'll see the inputs on this one.

1474
01:14:29,080 --> 01:14:31,160
The project management plan,
again, if we have it.

1475
01:14:31,160 --> 01:14:32,340
That makes this easy.

1476
01:14:32,340 --> 01:14:33,990
The stakeholder register.

1477
01:14:33,990 --> 01:14:38,080
That is really where all of our
information is going to come from.

1478
01:14:38,080 --> 01:14:39,950
And then,
enterprise environmental factors and

1479
01:14:39,950 --> 01:14:43,812
organizational process assets
like we've come used to seeing.

1480
01:14:43,812 --> 01:14:46,750
All right, on the tools and
techniques side though.

1481
01:14:46,750 --> 01:14:48,560
This is where things get really complex.

1482
01:14:48,560 --> 01:14:53,490
Because what you're trying to do, is
you're trying to come up with a plan that

1483
01:14:53,490 --> 01:14:58,350
defines how you communicate information
about your project to other people.

1484
01:14:58,350 --> 01:15:00,260
And that's a big deal, right?

1485
01:15:00,260 --> 01:15:02,990
If you are working on
a government project,

1486
01:15:02,990 --> 01:15:07,030
you may have to report to the Senate or
the House, various committees.

1487
01:15:07,030 --> 01:15:09,980
You may have to report that
information in certain formats,

1488
01:15:09,980 --> 01:15:12,840
certain intervals that they define.

1489
01:15:12,840 --> 01:15:17,500
If it's just an internal project, you may
have your own calendar that you follow.

1490
01:15:17,500 --> 01:15:20,650
What information you disseminate,
how you disseminate it, and so on.

1491
01:15:20,650 --> 01:15:23,890
And that stuff needs to be
agreed upon ahead of time.

1492
01:15:23,890 --> 01:15:26,470
And that's where
are communications plan comes in.

1493
01:15:26,470 --> 01:15:29,040
So it can be very, very simple.

1494
01:15:29,040 --> 01:15:33,300
But it can also be very incredibly
complex depending on how crazy you want

1495
01:15:34,600 --> 01:15:36,422
to go on it.

1496
01:15:36,422 --> 01:15:37,300
All right?
So, we start by doing ommunication

1497
01:15:37,300 --> 01:15:39,460
requirements analysis.

1498
01:15:39,460 --> 01:15:44,890
And that's basically where we take a look
at our people and our project, and

1499
01:15:44,890 --> 01:15:50,120
we determine what type of communications
we really need to provide for

1500
01:15:50,120 --> 01:15:51,630
this project to be successful, right?

1501
01:15:51,630 --> 01:15:53,390
So what's the bare minimums?

1502
01:15:53,390 --> 01:15:56,890
And you'll see a ton of
possible things to think about.

1503
01:15:56,890 --> 01:16:00,060
Ronnie, you've been
exhaustive here in your list.

1504
01:16:00,060 --> 01:16:03,400
So for example,
when we reach out to people,

1505
01:16:03,400 --> 01:16:07,130
we might have specific communication
methods that we want to use.

1506
01:16:07,130 --> 01:16:10,180
So we have potential communications.

1507
01:16:10,180 --> 01:16:13,605
We might have email, fax, phone,

1508
01:16:13,605 --> 01:16:18,530
physical meetings,
online meetings, mailers.

1509
01:16:18,530 --> 01:16:20,630
All sorts of communication methods.

1510
01:16:20,630 --> 01:16:23,760
We need to identify what people
are attached to our project, and

1511
01:16:23,760 --> 01:16:26,264
which communication method is suitable for
them.

1512
01:16:26,264 --> 01:16:28,920
Right?
If I'm giving a status update to my

1513
01:16:28,920 --> 01:16:32,830
key stakeholders, a physical in
person meeting might be the best way.

1514
01:16:32,830 --> 01:16:36,800
Get them in a room, sit down with them,
and say what's going on.

1515
01:16:36,800 --> 01:16:41,020
But if I'm communicating with
the general public as a whole,

1516
01:16:41,020 --> 01:16:42,980
I can't call them in for a meeting.

1517
01:16:42,980 --> 01:16:46,040
So for them,
maybe a mailer is the way to go.

1518
01:16:46,040 --> 01:16:48,830
Or maybe a email, or something like that.

1519
01:16:48,830 --> 01:16:52,080
I need to determine the methods that
are appropriate for reaching out to them.

1520
01:16:52,080 --> 01:16:52,680
All right?

1521
01:16:52,680 --> 01:16:54,330
Now, Ronnie put in a formula here, and

1522
01:16:54,330 --> 01:16:58,330
this formula has been a part of
the pin bach for a long time.

1523
01:16:58,330 --> 01:17:04,330
And what it is, is the potential
communication channels or paths, right?

1524
01:17:04,330 --> 01:17:09,730
When we think about projects, it's
really easy to think of it as everyone

1525
01:17:09,730 --> 01:17:13,280
talking to the project manager and
the project manager talking to everyone.

1526
01:17:13,280 --> 01:17:16,150
So if there's 50 people
attached to the project and

1527
01:17:16,150 --> 01:17:19,510
I'm one of them, then there's 49 paths.

1528
01:17:19,510 --> 01:17:23,130
Me talking to 49 people,
49 people talking to me.

1529
01:17:23,130 --> 01:17:25,620
But, that's not really it

1530
01:17:25,620 --> 01:17:30,090
because people within the project may talk
to each other without going through me.

1531
01:17:30,090 --> 01:17:35,250
So when we talk about communications,
there are several paths that occur.

1532
01:17:35,250 --> 01:17:39,800
And so, there's a simple formula for that
and it's not the most terribly useful one,

1533
01:17:39,800 --> 01:17:41,580
but it does show up on
the exam from time to time.

1534
01:17:41,580 --> 01:17:43,010
So it's good to highlight it.

1535
01:17:43,010 --> 01:17:47,960
Which is basically giving
us a way to figure out

1536
01:17:47,960 --> 01:17:53,150
how many people, or how many paths
of communication of may exist.

1537
01:17:53,150 --> 01:17:59,153
The n simply equals
the number of personnel.

1538
01:17:59,153 --> 01:18:01,770
It's two ns.

1539
01:18:01,770 --> 01:18:03,200
There we go.
Personnel or

1540
01:18:03,200 --> 01:18:05,530
stakeholders that are communicating,
right?

1541
01:18:05,530 --> 01:18:06,630
And we just plug it in.

1542
01:18:06,630 --> 01:18:08,480
I gave an example of 50, right?

1543
01:18:08,480 --> 01:18:13,725
So if we said 50 times 50 minus 1.

1544
01:18:13,725 --> 01:18:16,125
All divided by 2.

1545
01:18:16,125 --> 01:18:16,695
Right?

1546
01:18:16,695 --> 01:18:22,565
So we do 50 minus 1 because,
somebody's not gonna talk to themselves.

1547
01:18:22,565 --> 01:18:24,375
So we have to reduce it by one.

1548
01:18:24,375 --> 01:18:27,785
So we take 50 times 49 and
we divide that by 2.

1549
01:18:27,785 --> 01:18:30,005
And that's going to give us
the total amount of paths.

1550
01:18:30,005 --> 01:18:32,605
And that's not gonna be a number that
I'm gonna be able to do in my head.

1551
01:18:32,605 --> 01:18:35,050
So let's fire that up in here.

1552
01:18:35,050 --> 01:18:36,270
So 50 times 49.

1553
01:18:36,270 --> 01:18:37,454
>> 2450.

1554
01:18:37,454 --> 01:18:40,335
>> And we'll divide that by 4, so

1555
01:18:40,335 --> 01:18:45,360
1225 different communication
paths are present.

1556
01:18:45,360 --> 01:18:46,277
All right?

1557
01:18:46,277 --> 01:18:48,900
Now, that you have that information,
what does it mean to you?

1558
01:18:48,900 --> 01:18:50,310
Well if you're like me,
it doesn't mean much.

1559
01:18:50,310 --> 01:18:51,150
Right?
That's why I say

1560
01:18:51,150 --> 01:18:53,560
this is not a terribly useful method.

1561
01:18:53,560 --> 01:18:56,020
But, what it's doing is
it's giving me a warning.

1562
01:18:56,020 --> 01:19:00,330
It's saying, look in your project,
communications can be very complex.

1563
01:19:01,430 --> 01:19:05,850
Because there's 1225 different
combinations that could occur as people

1564
01:19:05,850 --> 01:19:07,250
start to talk to each other.

1565
01:19:07,250 --> 01:19:09,900
So are we going to plan for
every single one of them?

1566
01:19:09,900 --> 01:19:15,190
No, but what we're gonna do is we're gonna
plan for the major lines of communication.

1567
01:19:15,190 --> 01:19:18,960
How we talk to the project team members,
how we talk to the project members.

1568
01:19:18,960 --> 01:19:20,210
How we talk to the stakeholders,

1569
01:19:20,210 --> 01:19:24,759
how we talk to the sponsors,
those are all key communications.

1570
01:19:24,759 --> 01:19:25,290
Right?

1571
01:19:25,290 --> 01:19:28,340
And we need to plan for
how they're going to be handled.

1572
01:19:28,340 --> 01:19:33,590
If we plan for all 1,225 lines,
we'll be in the planning phase forever.

1573
01:19:33,590 --> 01:19:34,370
All right.

1574
01:19:34,370 --> 01:19:37,600
So in order to understand those key
communications, we need to know or

1575
01:19:37,600 --> 01:19:38,270
organization.

1576
01:19:38,270 --> 01:19:41,520
So organizational charts are something
that we'll look at as we figure out

1577
01:19:41,520 --> 01:19:42,980
who's talking to who.

1578
01:19:42,980 --> 01:19:45,690
If I have three web developers,

1579
01:19:45,690 --> 01:19:48,470
I might not wanna communicate
directly with all three of them.

1580
01:19:48,470 --> 01:19:51,945
But instead, have a team lead, or
have the functional manager for

1581
01:19:51,945 --> 01:19:54,747
the web development team and
communicate with them.

1582
01:19:54,747 --> 01:19:58,288
That way I'm talking with one person,
and they are controlling the input and

1583
01:19:58,288 --> 01:20:00,808
output of data to those three
people underneath them.

1584
01:20:00,808 --> 01:20:02,456
That really simplifies things.

1585
01:20:02,456 --> 01:20:09,310
I know mid level management gets vilified
in comic strips and movies all the time.

1586
01:20:09,310 --> 01:20:12,450
But the whole purpose
of mid level management

1587
01:20:12,450 --> 01:20:14,094
is to allow us to easily communicate

1588
01:20:15,555 --> 01:20:19,265
with large groups of our employees without
having to deal with them individually.

1589
01:20:19,265 --> 01:20:21,785
So, they better understand
the language and

1590
01:20:21,785 --> 01:20:24,805
method to communicate with their employees
so that we don't have to, and so

1591
01:20:24,805 --> 01:20:27,312
this is one of those areas where mid-level
management comes in really handy.

1592
01:20:28,982 --> 01:20:29,902
All right.

1593
01:20:29,902 --> 01:20:33,272
So some of the other things that we're
looking at are project organization,

1594
01:20:33,272 --> 01:20:36,322
which again might differ
from our organization.

1595
01:20:36,322 --> 01:20:41,020
Disciplines, departments, and
specialties involved in the project.

1596
01:20:41,020 --> 01:20:43,660
So if we've got employees
divided up different ways,

1597
01:20:43,660 --> 01:20:45,010
normally those are departments or

1598
01:20:45,010 --> 01:20:48,550
disciplines, we need to be able to
reach out and communicate with them.

1599
01:20:48,550 --> 01:20:51,680
If we're contracting then we might
have people that have specialties.

1600
01:20:51,680 --> 01:20:53,430
And you'll see this with employees, too.

1601
01:20:53,430 --> 01:20:54,930
I might have three web developers.

1602
01:20:54,930 --> 01:20:57,709
One might be an outstanding PHP developer,

1603
01:20:57,709 --> 01:21:02,452
the other two might be outstanding CGI
developers or something like that.

1604
01:21:02,452 --> 01:21:06,202
And so in those scenarios I've
got different specialties so

1605
01:21:06,202 --> 01:21:10,905
when I communicate I need to make sure
I'm talking to the right people in a way

1606
01:21:10,905 --> 01:21:12,391
that they understand.

1607
01:21:12,391 --> 01:21:14,455
So that's really what we're juggling.

1608
01:21:14,455 --> 01:21:18,095
And when we start drawing our lines,
our communication methods,

1609
01:21:18,095 --> 01:21:22,035
we're gonna have our internal and
our external methods.

1610
01:21:22,035 --> 01:21:24,105
Internally we're talking
with our own employees,

1611
01:21:24,105 --> 01:21:27,980
generally people on our project
management team and our project team.

1612
01:21:27,980 --> 01:21:33,240
Externally we're generally talking to
our contractors and the press, right.

1613
01:21:33,240 --> 01:21:35,310
You might be talking
to your customer base.

1614
01:21:35,310 --> 01:21:36,430
So for example,

1615
01:21:37,950 --> 01:21:42,060
if you're doing a project that is
a road reconstruction project, right.

1616
01:21:42,060 --> 01:21:45,740
So you're repairing some roads, you might
want to communicate out to the citizenry

1617
01:21:45,740 --> 01:21:47,790
to say hey,
this road's gonna be closed for

1618
01:21:47,790 --> 01:21:51,150
three days as part of our ongoing
project to make the town better.

1619
01:21:51,150 --> 01:21:54,490
So you put a positive spin on it while
informing them that the road's gonna

1620
01:21:54,490 --> 01:21:55,360
be closed.

1621
01:21:55,360 --> 01:21:57,590
That's the kind of communication
that needs to go out, and

1622
01:21:57,590 --> 01:22:00,600
we need to say what's the best
way to communicate with them.

1623
01:22:00,600 --> 01:22:04,450
It's gonna be different than how we
communicate with internal employees.

1624
01:22:04,450 --> 01:22:05,210
All right.

1625
01:22:05,210 --> 01:22:09,470
And then our stakeholder information,
what you're gonna find is that

1626
01:22:09,470 --> 01:22:13,420
each stakeholder might have their own
preferred method of communication.

1627
01:22:13,420 --> 01:22:16,260
I used to work for
an insurance company, and

1628
01:22:16,260 --> 01:22:19,760
the president of the insurance
company hated email.

1629
01:22:19,760 --> 01:22:23,820
Just, he didn't like computers in general,
but hated email.

1630
01:22:23,820 --> 01:22:27,551
So whenever you sent him an email, what
would happen is he had a secretary who

1631
01:22:27,551 --> 01:22:31,576
would print the email out, and when he'd
come into the office in the morning he'd

1632
01:22:31,576 --> 01:22:35,480
have a stack of papers on his desk that he
would read just like they were letters,

1633
01:22:35,480 --> 01:22:39,026
like he had been doing doing for
50 years, that is what he was used to.

1634
01:22:39,026 --> 01:22:40,795
That was how he liked to communicate.

1635
01:22:40,795 --> 01:22:45,365
So, I knew if I sent him an email,
he wouldn't read it until the next

1636
01:22:45,365 --> 01:22:49,545
morning after it was printed out on paper
and then he read it in the morning.

1637
01:22:49,545 --> 01:22:53,035
So, even email for
him could have as much as a 24 hour delay.

1638
01:22:53,035 --> 01:22:56,830
So, if I had something urgent that
needed to go out I got off my butt,

1639
01:22:56,830 --> 01:22:58,480
and I went up to his office.

1640
01:22:58,480 --> 01:23:01,420
Or I called and I scheduled
an appointment with his secretary,

1641
01:23:01,420 --> 01:23:03,160
to be able to go up there and talk to him.

1642
01:23:03,160 --> 01:23:05,480
That was how he needed to be handled.

1643
01:23:05,480 --> 01:23:07,280
It was not wrong.

1644
01:23:07,280 --> 01:23:08,850
You don't have to use email.

1645
01:23:08,850 --> 01:23:11,260
It was just how he liked to do it.

1646
01:23:11,260 --> 01:23:13,310
And so I knew that in any project,

1647
01:23:13,310 --> 01:23:17,850
if I had to communicate with him,
email was fine if I was okay with waiting.

1648
01:23:17,850 --> 01:23:19,590
If I was in a hurry, it wasn't.

1649
01:23:19,590 --> 01:23:22,870
That's the kind of stuff that needs
to go into our communications plan

1650
01:23:22,870 --> 01:23:23,430
in our project.

1651
01:23:25,290 --> 01:23:30,515
All right, now where this gets really fun
is the next one, communication technology.

1652
01:23:30,515 --> 01:23:33,745
What are all the different
ways we can communicate?

1653
01:23:33,745 --> 01:23:38,605
Email, fax, text message,
good god, text messages.

1654
01:23:38,605 --> 01:23:41,415
See now here is where
I start to show mine.

1655
01:23:41,415 --> 01:23:43,395
I hate text messages.

1656
01:23:43,395 --> 01:23:46,445
If somebody texts me, and
I don't get it, I don't care.

1657
01:23:46,445 --> 01:23:47,715
And they say well, I sent it to you.

1658
01:23:47,715 --> 01:23:49,735
And I say well it's your fault for
sending me a text.

1659
01:23:49,735 --> 01:23:51,155
I don't like texts.

1660
01:23:51,155 --> 01:23:54,230
So different people
communicate different ways.

1661
01:23:54,230 --> 01:23:56,530
We need to know the appropriate
technology, right.

1662
01:23:56,530 --> 01:23:59,430
Fax, the facsimile, it's a great system.

1663
01:23:59,430 --> 01:24:01,280
But who has a fax machine anymore?

1664
01:24:01,280 --> 01:24:03,280
Right, aside from the government.

1665
01:24:03,280 --> 01:24:05,525
So it's just not something
We see very often, so

1666
01:24:05,525 --> 01:24:09,975
we need to understand what technologies
we want to even allow in our company.

1667
01:24:09,975 --> 01:24:12,355
There might some means
that we don't allow.

1668
01:24:12,355 --> 01:24:14,992
You're starting to see this in
the medical industry a lot now,

1669
01:24:14,992 --> 01:24:17,692
where they're blocking email,
no communications via email.

1670
01:24:17,692 --> 01:24:20,504
Because email is non
encrypted by default and

1671
01:24:20,504 --> 01:24:23,839
they worry about patient
records making it in there.

1672
01:24:23,839 --> 01:24:26,670
So you may have that kind
of thing in place, so

1673
01:24:26,670 --> 01:24:30,260
you've gotta make sure that
you've got that document.

1674
01:24:30,260 --> 01:24:31,840
Communication models.

1675
01:24:31,840 --> 01:24:36,750
Communication models are different
ways to reach out to people,

1676
01:24:36,750 --> 01:24:40,560
and PMI breaks it down
into five categories.

1677
01:24:40,560 --> 01:24:41,070
Right.

1678
01:24:41,070 --> 01:24:45,920
We've got encode, transmit, decode,
acknowledge, feedback response, right.

1679
01:24:45,920 --> 01:24:47,041
Feedback and
response are kind of combined.

1680
01:24:47,041 --> 01:24:48,343
All right.

1681
01:24:48,343 --> 01:24:49,781
So starting out in code,

1682
01:24:49,781 --> 01:24:53,620
we have information that
we need to give to people.

1683
01:24:53,620 --> 01:24:58,200
But to us, it might be a Gantt chart,
it might be a resource sheet,

1684
01:24:58,200 --> 01:25:00,500
it's project management speak.

1685
01:25:00,500 --> 01:25:02,300
And when we start communicating out,

1686
01:25:02,300 --> 01:25:04,870
we'll see this with earned
value analysis later on.

1687
01:25:04,870 --> 01:25:11,200
If I start talking to the CEO about EAC
and BAC and all these other numbers

1688
01:25:11,200 --> 01:25:14,530
that we deal with as project managers,
we'll see all these in monitoring and

1689
01:25:14,530 --> 01:25:17,780
controlling, when we start talking
about that stuff their eyes glaze over.

1690
01:25:17,780 --> 01:25:19,130
They don't know what you're talking about.

1691
01:25:19,130 --> 01:25:20,500
They haven't seen these formulas.

1692
01:25:20,500 --> 01:25:21,740
They don't know what they mean.

1693
01:25:21,740 --> 01:25:23,460
So I've gotta translate it.

1694
01:25:23,460 --> 01:25:27,640
I've got to encode this data in
a way that I know the recipient

1695
01:25:27,640 --> 01:25:28,970
will be able to interpret it.

1696
01:25:28,970 --> 01:25:31,890
Don't use project management
specific terminology,

1697
01:25:31,890 --> 01:25:35,060
use terms that are understandable
within your company.

1698
01:25:35,060 --> 01:25:36,020
Transmit.

1699
01:25:36,020 --> 01:25:37,420
How do I send the data?

1700
01:25:37,420 --> 01:25:42,370
I need to get this data to the people,
and I do it via phone, email, whatever.

1701
01:25:42,370 --> 01:25:45,960
That's something that I've gotta come
up with a communication model for that.

1702
01:25:45,960 --> 01:25:47,260
Decode, right.

1703
01:25:47,260 --> 01:25:50,390
They're gonna receive it, and
they're going to interpret it.

1704
01:25:50,390 --> 01:25:53,030
If it's an email they're,
gonna open up and they're gonna read it.

1705
01:25:53,030 --> 01:25:55,690
And I need to understand
how they're doing this.

1706
01:25:55,690 --> 01:25:59,830
If it's a voicemail, you hear my voice,
you hear tone, you hear inflections,

1707
01:25:59,830 --> 01:26:01,210
it's very easy to
understand what I'm saying.

1708
01:26:01,210 --> 01:26:03,190
Well, except for
the fact that I have terrible speech.

1709
01:26:03,190 --> 01:26:08,210
But if I send you an email,
no inflection, no tone.

1710
01:26:08,210 --> 01:26:08,810
You don't know.

1711
01:26:08,810 --> 01:26:09,550
Am I angry?

1712
01:26:09,550 --> 01:26:10,610
Am I happy?

1713
01:26:10,610 --> 01:26:15,230
I've gotta make sure that I properly
address that, use the right adjectives,

1714
01:26:15,230 --> 01:26:17,840
and verbs, and stuff, to make that
message carry the information I need.

1715
01:26:19,150 --> 01:26:21,820
Acknowledge, this is a big challenge.

1716
01:26:21,820 --> 01:26:24,100
If I send somebody an email, and I say,

1717
01:26:24,100 --> 01:26:28,760
here's a problem, you need to do this to
fix it, and then they don't do it, right?

1718
01:26:28,760 --> 01:26:31,060
And I come to them and
I say why didn't you do this, I told you?

1719
01:26:31,060 --> 01:26:32,300
And they say, I didn't get the email.

1720
01:26:32,300 --> 01:26:34,420
I didn't get the voicemail.

1721
01:26:34,420 --> 01:26:38,500
Well, that happens a lot, and the majority
of the time they did get the email or

1722
01:26:38,500 --> 01:26:40,475
they did get the voicemail.

1723
01:26:40,475 --> 01:26:43,466
So we need a way to acknowledge that.

1724
01:26:43,466 --> 01:26:47,091
With email, you have read receipts,
they're not the most trustworthy, so

1725
01:26:47,091 --> 01:26:50,938
if there's a case where I need absolute,
what they call it, non-repudiation,

1726
01:26:50,938 --> 01:26:54,427
the ability or the lack of ability for
somebody to say they didn't get it.

1727
01:26:54,427 --> 01:26:59,120
And we might need to do registered mail,
or signature required.

1728
01:26:59,120 --> 01:27:01,690
Something like that,
where they have to sign off on it.

1729
01:27:01,690 --> 01:27:05,400
I might require a phone call, so
that I can have a phone call recording, or

1730
01:27:05,400 --> 01:27:09,430
I keep a phone log that says yes, I talked
to this person, at this time, at this day.

1731
01:27:09,430 --> 01:27:11,160
This is what was agreed upon.

1732
01:27:11,160 --> 01:27:13,100
That's very important, and
that's acknowledgement.

1733
01:27:13,100 --> 01:27:15,380
And then lastly is feedback and response.

1734
01:27:15,380 --> 01:27:17,500
If you're sending out a communication,

1735
01:27:17,500 --> 01:27:21,380
you probably expect some kind
of information back, not always.

1736
01:27:21,380 --> 01:27:22,430
Maybe it's a status report.

1737
01:27:22,430 --> 01:27:25,680
Everything's going great,
no actions required, that's it.

1738
01:27:25,680 --> 01:27:28,580
But, if there's even
the slightest deviation,

1739
01:27:28,580 --> 01:27:30,450
then you may expect some feedback.

1740
01:27:30,450 --> 01:27:32,770
And so in your communication,

1741
01:27:32,770 --> 01:27:36,230
you need to specify the best
way to receive that feedback.

1742
01:27:36,230 --> 01:27:39,270
If I'm reaching out to the public with
a mailer, I need to put in there hey,

1743
01:27:39,270 --> 01:27:40,350
if you have any questions,

1744
01:27:40,350 --> 01:27:43,560
call this 1-800 number we've prepared
to answer any questions you have.

1745
01:27:43,560 --> 01:27:46,690
So you specify a way to
provide that feedback.

1746
01:27:46,690 --> 01:27:48,725
An acceptable channel, right,

1747
01:27:48,725 --> 01:27:51,150
cuz you don't want people just
communicating however they want.

1748
01:27:51,150 --> 01:27:53,870
We get that Like, well, ITProTV,

1749
01:27:53,870 --> 01:27:58,320
I am amazed at the way that
our viewers reach out to us.

1750
01:27:58,320 --> 01:28:00,903
So we set up our Q&A forums,
and our live chat so

1751
01:28:00,903 --> 01:28:03,172
you guys to able to ask questions with us.

1752
01:28:03,172 --> 01:28:05,924
And so,
those are our communication methods.

1753
01:28:05,924 --> 01:28:08,073
But over the years I've gotten,

1754
01:28:08,073 --> 01:28:12,228
where people have reached out to
me through all sorts of things.

1755
01:28:12,228 --> 01:28:17,220
I get LinkedIn requests even though
I don't have a LinkedIn account.

1756
01:28:17,220 --> 01:28:19,520
I got a google hangout once,
it was actually kind of fun.

1757
01:28:19,520 --> 01:28:23,500
I talked to one of our viewers and
helped them out all via google hangouts.

1758
01:28:23,500 --> 01:28:27,320
I never even thought about it,
just ways that are out there.

1759
01:28:27,320 --> 01:28:30,160
So, understand that if you leave
people to their own devices,

1760
01:28:30,160 --> 01:28:33,390
they'll communicate with
whatever way works for them.

1761
01:28:33,390 --> 01:28:37,020
You might not be expecting,
you might miss that communication, and

1762
01:28:37,020 --> 01:28:38,510
now they think you're ignoring them.

1763
01:28:38,510 --> 01:28:40,160
Right.
I would have hated for that to happen.

1764
01:28:40,160 --> 01:28:43,350
Somebody sends me a message and
they think I'm ignoring them,

1765
01:28:43,350 --> 01:28:46,490
but it just came through
a channel I wasn't expecting.

1766
01:28:46,490 --> 01:28:51,310
So in those scenarios, if we had just
laid it out in our communication and

1767
01:28:51,310 --> 01:28:53,580
say "hey do you have feedback and
response?

1768
01:28:53,580 --> 01:28:56,670
Here's how you send it to us and
then feed that information to them.

1769
01:28:56,670 --> 01:28:59,540
So that's an important part
of that communication model.

1770
01:29:00,610 --> 01:29:05,337
All right, and then our methods,well,
we've got interactive push and pull,

1771
01:29:05,337 --> 01:29:09,060
Interactive communication,
it's like a phone call.

1772
01:29:09,060 --> 01:29:11,430
I say,
hey Ronnie what do you think about this?

1773
01:29:11,430 --> 01:29:12,060
You tell me.

1774
01:29:12,060 --> 01:29:13,070
>> That's it.
>> I respond, right?

1775

>> Right.

1776
01:29:13,900 --> 01:29:16,140
>> So it's a straightforward
communication there.

1777
01:29:16,140 --> 01:29:17,750
Push and pull though.

1778
01:29:17,750 --> 01:29:22,130
Push, I tell you, I send something
to you just like a mailer, right?

1779
01:29:22,130 --> 01:29:23,580
When I send you a letter in the mail and

1780
01:29:23,580 --> 01:29:26,070
you read it,
you can't really respond to me right then.

1781
01:29:26,070 --> 01:29:28,009
You've been given one way information.

1782
01:29:29,180 --> 01:29:32,820
And then pull, that's where I reach
out to you, or you reach out to me and

1783
01:29:32,820 --> 01:29:34,710
you say, hey Don,
I need the status update.

1784
01:29:34,710 --> 01:29:37,730
Tell me this, tell me what I need.

1785
01:29:37,730 --> 01:29:40,083
And this might be a written letter,
or subpoena-

1786
01:29:40,083 --> 01:29:40,599
>> [LAUGH]

1787

>> Those are the fun ones.

1788
01:29:42,210 --> 01:29:42,920
Something like that,

1789
01:29:42,920 --> 01:29:46,130
that says you've gotta provide us with
this information, and we provide it.

1790
01:29:46,130 --> 01:29:47,940
So pull,

1791
01:29:47,940 --> 01:29:51,960
in theory if there's ever a poll going on,
that means your system is broken down.

1792
01:29:51,960 --> 01:29:54,670
That means that there's something
that you didn't account for.

1793
01:29:54,670 --> 01:29:58,670
If somebody needs some information,
we should have identified that early on in

1794
01:29:58,670 --> 01:30:02,520
the planning phase of our project,
so that we knew to send it to them.

1795
01:30:02,520 --> 01:30:05,240
But if they're doing a pull,
if they're saying, hey,

1796
01:30:05,240 --> 01:30:08,350
I need this data, then that was
something we didn't plan for.

1797
01:30:08,350 --> 01:30:10,930
So we really need to do two things.

1798
01:30:10,930 --> 01:30:12,690
One is give them the information
they want, right?

1799

Always give people
the information that they want.

1800
01:30:14,490 --> 01:30:16,190
There's nothing that we should hide.

1801
01:30:16,190 --> 01:30:20,935
And then, two, do a change ticket
to update your communications

1802
01:30:20,935 --> 01:30:22,380
plan to say,
>> Right.

1803

>> This person did a poor request for this

01:30:25,894 --> 01:30:28,570

So that they don't have

1806

That it's already prepared.

It becomes part of our plan.

1808
01:30:35,312 --> 01:30:36,140
All right, so

01:30:36,140 --> 01:30:39,670
these are all some of the different

1810
01:30:39,670 --> 01:30:41,760
Once we've come up with

1811

And we have meetings.

Meetings to discuss communications.

That's always fun.

Meetings to discuss what kind

But once we've got that all figured out,

That plan is going to basically

One thing we may have learned as we

all the different ways they communicate.

01:32:53,104 --> 01:32:56,640

In here it's high level so when

We might have, as a method,
