1908
01:35:50,740 --> 01:35:53,585
Who do we need to talk to,
how do we need to talk to them...

1909
01:35:53,585 --> 01:35:55,075
And when we need to talk about it?

1910
01:35:55,075 --> 01:35:56,985
That's basically all we need to know.

1911
01:35:56,985 --> 01:35:57,885
I guess you could go, what?

1912
01:35:57,885 --> 01:36:00,155
Like what do we need
to talk to them about?

1913
01:36:00,155 --> 01:36:00,895
That's about it.

1914
01:36:00,895 --> 01:36:02,785
So we try and plan for that.

1915
01:36:02,785 --> 01:36:04,765
Understand that this is
a very living document.

1916
01:36:04,765 --> 01:36:09,155
This is gonna change as your project goes
on because new communication needs pop up.

1917
01:36:09,155 --> 01:36:10,525
Well, fortunately,

1918
01:36:10,525 --> 01:36:14,530
communications like these don't normally
cost us a lot of money or even a burden.

1919
01:36:14,530 --> 01:36:17,910
And so making changes to this
plan after we're in production,

1920
01:36:17,910 --> 01:36:21,000
after we're executing and
all that, usually not a big deal.

1921
01:36:21,000 --> 01:36:23,140
So just be prepared for
that, changes will happen.

1922
01:36:25,140 --> 01:36:28,370
All right, well that knocks out
a pretty decent chunk right there.

1923
01:36:28,370 --> 01:36:32,110
So we just tackled Quality Management,
Human Resource Management, and

1924
01:36:32,110 --> 01:36:33,450
Communication Management.

1925
01:36:33,450 --> 01:36:36,360
We still have risk to get through,
and then a couple other little ones.

1926
01:36:36,360 --> 01:36:38,460
We'll tackle those in our next episode.

1927
01:36:38,460 --> 01:36:41,850
But for right now, well that's a pretty
good spot for us to wrap up for today.

1928
01:36:41,850 --> 01:36:42,920
>> Sounds good.

1929
01:36:42,920 --> 01:36:46,110
>> All right, well let me just remind
you guys if you have any questions on

1930
01:36:46,110 --> 01:36:50,180
this stuff, live during the show
you can go to itpro.tv/live,

1931
01:36:50,180 --> 01:36:52,210
you can post in the chat room.

1932
01:36:52,210 --> 01:36:54,610
We monitor and answer during the show.

1933
01:36:54,610 --> 01:36:58,530
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

1934
01:36:58,530 --> 01:37:00,420
At the top of every page,
you'll see a link that says Q&A.

1935
01:37:00,420 --> 01:37:01,910
It'll take you into the forums.

1936
01:37:01,910 --> 01:37:03,350
You can post your questions there.

1937
01:37:03,350 --> 01:37:06,110
And again, we monitor and answer.

1938
01:37:06,110 --> 01:37:07,350
Well, I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1939
01:37:07,350 --> 01:37:10,200
Signing out for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1940
01:37:10,200 --> 01:37:10,980
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1941
01:37:10,980 --> 01:37:12,634
>> And we will see you next time.

1942
01:37:12,634 --> 01:37:22,634
[MUSIC]

1943
01:37:24,894 --> 01:37:29,200
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don begin the process of Risk Management within Project Management. They use the concepts of risk tolerance: risk adverse, risk seekers and risk neutral as base for risk management of the project. They also talk about the tools and techniques used to identify risks. They describe performing qualitative and quantitative risk analysis before project execution begins. They finish the risk management planning by taking a look into the risk response planning.
episodes.title: Planning for Risks
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:24,309 --> 00:00:33,414
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:33,414 --> 00:00:36,580
All right, good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening and welcome back.

4
00:00:36,580 --> 00:00:38,050
To another episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:38,050 --> 00:00:41,060
I'm your host, Don Pezet,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:41,060 --> 00:00:41,900
How's it going Ronnie?

7
00:00:41,900 --> 00:00:46,240
>> It is going well today, we had our
first Padphone announcement yesterday,

8
00:00:46,240 --> 00:00:48,045
and we still don't know
when it's coming out.

9
00:00:48,045 --> 00:00:49,178
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I'm doing okay.

10
00:00:49,178 --> 00:00:50,722
[LAUGH]
>> For

11
00:00:50,722 --> 00:00:54,650
the viewers that have been with us long
enough, I think that most people probably

12
00:00:54,650 --> 00:00:57,770
know that I am obsessed with this
Padphone device, I must have it.

13
00:00:57,770 --> 00:01:01,780
And they are obviously exercising
the greatest in project management skills,

14
00:01:01,780 --> 00:01:04,790
because they haven't
announced zero date data.

15
00:01:04,790 --> 00:01:08,380
It's really frustrating,
but that's all right.

16
00:01:08,380 --> 00:01:11,670
Anyhow, today we are gonna
take a look at risk.

17
00:01:11,670 --> 00:01:15,000
So for example,
I have a great level of risk of being

18
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:17,564
pointed disappointed when
the Padfhone never comes out.

19
00:01:17,564 --> 00:01:18,694
>> [LAUGH]
>> So yeah, so

20
00:01:18,694 --> 00:01:21,280
we're going to take a look at risk.

21
00:01:21,280 --> 00:01:26,290
Every project has risk, this possibility
that certain events can happen,

22
00:01:26,290 --> 00:01:30,520
and part of being a good project
manager is planning for that.

23
00:01:30,520 --> 00:01:34,031
And being prepared, and being able to
handle that, if in a certain event,

24
00:01:34,031 --> 00:01:35,330
were to occur, all right.

25
00:01:35,330 --> 00:01:37,030
So we're gonna take a look at that.

26
00:01:37,030 --> 00:01:39,330
We got a whole process group for it.

27
00:01:39,330 --> 00:01:41,950
Let's jump into our PMBOK here, so

28
00:01:41,950 --> 00:01:45,530
I'm going back in to my process group
chart here, in my knowledge areas.

29
00:01:45,530 --> 00:01:48,010
And we've moved through a lot
of planning at this point.

30
00:01:48,010 --> 00:01:49,860
We're kind of getting
down to the last part.

31
00:01:49,860 --> 00:01:54,260
This is the last of the large sections and
in fact, if you look at everything after

32
00:01:54,260 --> 00:01:59,300
this is really the last large section for
the whole process group arrangement.

33
00:01:59,300 --> 00:02:02,553
But you'll see for plan risk,
we've actually got five different

34
00:02:02,553 --> 00:02:05,938
processes available, there's a lot,
right, a lot of stuff here.

35
00:02:05,938 --> 00:02:11,320
There are many people out there who make
a perfectly good living as risk managers,

36
00:02:11,320 --> 00:02:16,078
this is an entire career field there
is a science you can get Masters, and

37
00:02:16,078 --> 00:02:18,430
PhDs in EN risk management.

38
00:02:18,430 --> 00:02:20,630
And it's because it's so complex.

39
00:02:20,630 --> 00:02:22,000
There's so much theory.

40
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:26,490
There's so much there that it's
really an impressive world.

41
00:02:26,490 --> 00:02:30,760
For us as a project manager,
we're just dipping our toe in it, right?

42
00:02:30,760 --> 00:02:34,680
We're just getting a little bit
into that world of risk and

43
00:02:34,680 --> 00:02:38,180
not being exposed to
the whole craziness of it.

44
00:02:38,180 --> 00:02:40,290
But that doesn't mean we
can't be familiar with it.

45
00:02:40,290 --> 00:02:43,990
We need to at least at a high
level be able to plan for

46
00:02:43,990 --> 00:02:48,770
that risk, figure what's going on,
and set up reasonable expectations.

47
00:02:48,770 --> 00:02:51,490
If we can't up, we need to hire somebody,
bring in a consultant,

48
00:02:51,490 --> 00:02:55,270
bring in somebody who is a risk manager
would be able to evaluate that for us.

49
00:02:55,270 --> 00:02:59,164
All right, so the first process group,
just like anything else,

50
00:02:59,164 --> 00:03:01,121
is coming up with a plan, right?

51
00:03:01,121 --> 00:03:03,210
So plan for risk management.

52
00:03:03,210 --> 00:03:05,390
We need to come up with
a risk management plan.

53
00:03:05,390 --> 00:03:07,040
Our company might already have one.

54
00:03:07,040 --> 00:03:08,940
If they do, we're done, right?

55
00:03:08,940 --> 00:03:13,784
If they don't though, we can skip
over this, go through the four other

56
00:03:13,784 --> 00:03:18,710
processes as we plan for risk, and
then take whatever we found worked for

57
00:03:18,710 --> 00:03:22,537
us and turn that into our
risk management plan, right.

58
00:03:22,537 --> 00:03:25,629
But let's Let's take a look at that plan
risk management process anyway because

59
00:03:25,629 --> 00:03:27,625
sooner or later you have to go through it.

60
00:03:27,625 --> 00:03:29,915
>> Right.
>> And this is it right here.

61
00:03:29,915 --> 00:03:32,935
So we start off by taking our input and
our main

62
00:03:32,935 --> 00:03:36,255
inputs here are going to be the project,
charter and the stakeholder register.

63
00:03:36,255 --> 00:03:39,980
Those two things because the project
charter is saying what we're planning on

64
00:03:39,980 --> 00:03:44,440
doing and the stake holder register,
which is saying who's involved.

65
00:03:44,440 --> 00:03:47,100
Because that's usually where
our risk is going to come from.

66
00:03:47,100 --> 00:03:50,611
What we're trying to do and
who's got their hands in it.

67
00:03:50,611 --> 00:03:54,620
So, we need those depending on
where you're at in your project.

68
00:03:54,620 --> 00:03:57,060
If you started this
right after initiation,

69
00:03:57,060 --> 00:04:00,720
which plenty of people do, then those
may be the only documents you have.

70
00:04:00,720 --> 00:04:03,360
But if you've already gone through some of
your planning cycles, if you've already

71
00:04:03,360 --> 00:04:07,120
created your schedule and your budget
then there's new risks that come in.

72
00:04:07,120 --> 00:04:09,550
So those may serve as inputs here, also.

73
00:04:09,550 --> 00:04:13,230
But, assuming that we start
this right after initiation,

74
00:04:13,230 --> 00:04:15,800
then those two documents
are pretty much all we have.

75
00:04:15,800 --> 00:04:17,580
You may have your project management plan.

76
00:04:17,580 --> 00:04:19,880
Again, if you're company has been
doing formal project management,

77
00:04:19,880 --> 00:04:21,380
you'll have that.

78
00:04:21,380 --> 00:04:24,116
And then,
our enterprise environmental factors and

79
00:04:24,116 --> 00:04:28,447
organizational process assets that we've
seen in darn near every single process.

80
00:04:28,447 --> 00:04:30,424
All right, so nothing new and
shocking there,

81
00:04:30,424 --> 00:04:33,270
all documents that we've
already got prepared.

82
00:04:33,270 --> 00:04:38,190
What we do now is we figure out
how we're gonna handle risk for

83
00:04:38,190 --> 00:04:40,120
our particular project, right.

84
00:04:40,120 --> 00:04:42,270
And there's a few different
things we need to choose from.

85
00:04:42,270 --> 00:04:44,660
The main thing being
the analytical techniques.

86
00:04:44,660 --> 00:04:48,370
Now I don't wanna dive too deep into
the analytical techniques right now,

87
00:04:48,370 --> 00:04:50,320
cuz we got a few that we'll see.

88
00:04:50,320 --> 00:04:55,000
But that's because we're gonna really
see them when we start talking about

89
00:04:55,000 --> 00:04:59,420
identifying risks, qualitative analysis,
quantitative analysis, so

90
00:04:59,420 --> 00:05:01,200
we've got a lot of tools available.

91
00:05:01,200 --> 00:05:04,870
So, when we create our risk management
plan, what we're doing is saying,

92
00:05:04,870 --> 00:05:08,550
Which analytical techniques work best for
our company?

93
00:05:08,550 --> 00:05:13,370
And if we pick certain techniques,how
do we use them for managing risks?

94
00:05:13,370 --> 00:05:19,450
Remember these plans, whenever you see
that word plan in our little title there,

95
00:05:19,450 --> 00:05:22,140
that means that we're trying
to create something generic

96
00:05:22,140 --> 00:05:26,470
that can apply to more than one project so
that it can be re-used.

97
00:05:26,470 --> 00:05:29,962
We're also gonna use our expert judgement,
and we're gonna have meetings to come up

98
00:05:29,962 --> 00:05:33,359
with what's acceptable with us, and
our management, our upper executives, and

99
00:05:33,359 --> 00:05:37,130
so on, and come up with something
that works well for the organization.

100
00:05:37,130 --> 00:05:40,370
And when we're done,
we generate our risk management plan.

101
00:05:40,370 --> 00:05:43,923
And let me bring up my template for that.

102
00:05:43,923 --> 00:05:46,550
Which apparently I'm not in so
let me get into that.

103
00:05:46,550 --> 00:05:49,730
But I've got a template for
a risk management plan.

104
00:05:51,660 --> 00:05:53,330
Which is in here somewhere.

105
00:05:57,350 --> 00:05:58,903
>> Yep, you were right there.

106
00:05:58,903 --> 00:06:00,369
To the left.

107
00:06:00,369 --> 00:06:02,290
And down.

108
00:06:03,890 --> 00:06:04,563
>> Is this not alphabetized?

109
00:06:04,563 --> 00:06:05,120
What is going on?

110
00:06:05,120 --> 00:06:06,240
>> It doesn't look like it.

111
00:06:06,240 --> 00:06:07,770
>> Hang on.
This is the problem.

112
00:06:07,770 --> 00:06:08,640
>> Oh, there you go.

113
00:06:08,640 --> 00:06:10,670
>> Alphabets.
There we go, risk management plan.

114
00:06:10,670 --> 00:06:15,480
So [LAUGH], apparently in icon view
they don't bother alphabetizing for me.

115
00:06:15,480 --> 00:06:17,580
All right, so
here's my risk management plan.

116
00:06:17,580 --> 00:06:20,330
So we're gonna have things in
here like our methodology.

117
00:06:20,330 --> 00:06:24,130
What methodology do we follow
when it comes to managing risk?

118
00:06:24,130 --> 00:06:26,300
And we're gonna talk about some
of those methodologies later,

119
00:06:26,300 --> 00:06:28,000
we just haven't seen them yet.

120
00:06:28,000 --> 00:06:30,770
As far as whether we're gonna
be proactive or reacting, and

121
00:06:30,770 --> 00:06:32,970
some of the different
responses that we have.

122
00:06:32,970 --> 00:06:35,100
What roles and responsibilities?

123
00:06:35,100 --> 00:06:37,420
Who is it that's in charge of risk?

124
00:06:37,420 --> 00:06:40,600
And your company might have a risk
management department, and so

125
00:06:40,600 --> 00:06:43,130
they'll have a big role and
responsibility there, or

126
00:06:43,130 --> 00:06:45,420
it might be all up to you
as the project manager.

127
00:06:45,420 --> 00:06:47,910
And that's very common in small companies.

128
00:06:47,910 --> 00:06:52,010
We have our risk categories,
as we start to break down our risks,

129
00:06:52,010 --> 00:06:52,650
how do we do that?

130
00:06:52,650 --> 00:06:54,970
How do we categorize them to determine
how we're gonna handle them?

131
00:06:56,270 --> 00:06:58,340
Where does the risk
management funding come from?

132
00:06:58,340 --> 00:06:59,770
This is important.

133
00:06:59,770 --> 00:07:01,840
In some organizations,

134
00:07:01,840 --> 00:07:06,780
the risk management funding has to
come from the project budget itself.

135
00:07:06,780 --> 00:07:12,130
But in other organizations, there may be
a central pool of funds available for

136
00:07:12,130 --> 00:07:14,220
risk management across
all of the projects.

137
00:07:14,220 --> 00:07:16,850
You see that in program
environments a good bit.

138
00:07:16,850 --> 00:07:21,020
You also have areas where maybe
your company is bonded, so

139
00:07:21,020 --> 00:07:24,320
it's got an insurance policy of its own
that applies to risks even inside of

140
00:07:24,320 --> 00:07:25,170
your project.

141
00:07:25,170 --> 00:07:28,450
So that risk management funding may not
come from within the project itself,

142
00:07:28,450 --> 00:07:29,230
It might come from without.

143
00:07:30,440 --> 00:07:32,460
Contingency protocols, alright?

144
00:07:32,460 --> 00:07:37,670
If we set up things like cash reserves and
schedule reserves what is the contingent?

145
00:07:37,670 --> 00:07:40,590
What are the rules for us going and
accessing those reserves?

146
00:07:42,160 --> 00:07:44,560
Frequency and timing,
this ones a little confusing.

147
00:07:44,560 --> 00:07:48,915
It's talking about how often do
we need to monitor for the risks?

148
00:07:48,915 --> 00:07:53,667
So, for example, if we're doing
an outdoor rock concert, and

149
00:07:53,667 --> 00:07:58,508
I know that it might rain, so
I set up a contingency plan for that.

150
00:07:58,508 --> 00:08:02,261
Well, how often do I need to check The
weather to see whether it's gonna rain.

151
00:08:02,261 --> 00:08:06,413
Because three months before the event
it's really hard to predict that

152
00:08:06,413 --> 00:08:08,100
weather, right?

153
00:08:08,100 --> 00:08:11,410
One month from the event,
it's really hard to predict that weather.

154
00:08:11,410 --> 00:08:14,830
Two weeks from the event,
you start getting more accurate details.

155
00:08:14,830 --> 00:08:17,430
One week from the event,
even more accurate.

156
00:08:17,430 --> 00:08:19,780
Three days before, two days, one day.

157
00:08:19,780 --> 00:08:23,080
The closer you get to the event,
the more accurate it becomes.

158
00:08:23,080 --> 00:08:26,310
And so we may need to designate
here what is the frequency and

159
00:08:26,310 --> 00:08:29,600
timing that we're going use as far as
monitoring and keeping up with that

160
00:08:29,600 --> 00:08:33,290
to ensure that we have the most
up-to-date information possible?

161
00:08:33,290 --> 00:08:37,490
Looking three months ahead,
I might say there's a 20% chance of rain.

162
00:08:37,490 --> 00:08:42,228
But one week ahead, I might look ahead and
say oh, that's like it's a 60% chance.

163
00:08:42,228 --> 00:08:43,120
Right.
So

164
00:08:43,120 --> 00:08:46,175
that's the kind of thing that
we need to keep track of.

165
00:08:46,175 --> 00:08:48,150
All right.

166
00:08:48,150 --> 00:08:50,870
Stakeholder risk tolerances.

167
00:08:50,870 --> 00:08:53,780
I know we talked about this
in episode one or two, right.

168
00:08:53,780 --> 00:08:55,146
>> Yeah.
>> It was very early on in the PMP

169
00:08:55,146 --> 00:08:56,525
show that we started with this.

170
00:08:56,525 --> 00:09:00,113
Your stake holders and
not just key like your sponsor but

171
00:09:00,113 --> 00:09:04,780
your just general stake holders fall
into one of three risk categories.

172
00:09:04,780 --> 00:09:08,739
You have people who are risk averse
you know don't want to take risks.

173
00:09:08,739 --> 00:09:12,130
You have people that are risk seekers.

174
00:09:12,130 --> 00:09:13,670
People who are looking for risk,

175
00:09:13,670 --> 00:09:17,120
because they know the bigger
the risk the bigger the reward.

176
00:09:17,120 --> 00:09:20,220
And then you have people
who are risk neutral.

177
00:09:20,220 --> 00:09:23,670
People who aren't adverse to taking a risk

178
00:09:23,670 --> 00:09:26,080
if the odds are good enough
that they're going to succeed.

179
00:09:26,080 --> 00:09:27,400
They'll weigh the numbers.

180
00:09:27,400 --> 00:09:30,350
They'll look at it and
make an informed decision.

181
00:09:30,350 --> 00:09:33,870
We hope that everybody is risk neutral,
but that's not always the case.

182
00:09:33,870 --> 00:09:38,470
And then you see these great success
stories of people who are risk seekers and

183
00:09:38,470 --> 00:09:42,400
they kinda gloss over all the failures
that have from other risk seekers.

184
00:09:42,400 --> 00:09:45,990
So we may need a document that,
each of our stakeholders,

185
00:09:45,990 --> 00:09:51,050
what their tolerances are, and
so how we need to handle it.

186
00:09:51,050 --> 00:09:52,940
Tracking and auditing, right?

187
00:09:52,940 --> 00:09:55,930
As we monitor these risks,
how do we track that?

188
00:09:55,930 --> 00:09:56,810
How do we record it?

189
00:09:56,810 --> 00:09:58,600
How do we have that information together?

190
00:09:58,600 --> 00:10:00,620
What templates or forms do we use?

191
00:10:00,620 --> 00:10:03,750
What's our accepted method of
collecting and reporting that data.

192
00:10:06,020 --> 00:10:07,590
Next comes our definitions.

193
00:10:07,590 --> 00:10:10,150
When we start to categorize our risks,

194
00:10:10,150 --> 00:10:13,330
when we start to compare them
we do apply some terminology.

195
00:10:13,330 --> 00:10:14,220
Terminology's up to us.

196
00:10:14,220 --> 00:10:15,480
You can use whatever you want.

197
00:10:15,480 --> 00:10:19,530
Here they're showing very high,
high, medium, low, very low, right?

198
00:10:19,530 --> 00:10:23,410
Well, what do I mean,
when I say there's a very low probability?

199
00:10:23,410 --> 00:10:23,960
Okay.

200
00:10:23,960 --> 00:10:26,200
Do I mean there's a less than 10% chance?

201
00:10:26,200 --> 00:10:28,250
Do I mean that there's
a less than 50% chance?

202
00:10:28,250 --> 00:10:30,090
What to me is very low?

203
00:10:30,090 --> 00:10:33,830
We need to define that, and
it needs to be numerical.

204
00:10:33,830 --> 00:10:35,770
It needs to be something
we can measure against.

205
00:10:35,770 --> 00:10:38,540
It needs to be a percentage or
a ratio, a five to one odds.

206
00:10:38,540 --> 00:10:39,910
Or something like that.

207
00:10:39,910 --> 00:10:43,490
We need a number we can work with,
that's really important.

208
00:10:43,490 --> 00:10:47,560
And that's really,
that's the magic of being a risk manager.

209
00:10:47,560 --> 00:10:52,690
That's where they're so successful is
how do you put a number on some things?

210
00:10:52,690 --> 00:10:55,630
How do you put a number
on customer happiness?

211
00:10:55,630 --> 00:10:58,210
I want to have it where
I have a support line,

212
00:10:58,210 --> 00:11:03,620
where people call it and I want to
make sure that my customers are happy.

213
00:11:03,620 --> 00:11:04,750
Okay, how do we measure that?

214
00:11:04,750 --> 00:11:06,850
How do we put a number on happiness?

215
00:11:06,850 --> 00:11:09,810
Well we can create surveys and
scales and things like that, but

216
00:11:09,810 --> 00:11:11,320
they're just really challenging.

217
00:11:11,320 --> 00:11:12,330
Doctors deal with this.

218
00:11:12,330 --> 00:11:15,050
I don't know, Ronnie,
if you've ever been do the doctor and

219
00:11:15,050 --> 00:11:17,200
you say, boy my arm hurts.

220
00:11:17,200 --> 00:11:21,530
And they say all right, well, on a scale
of one to ten, how bad does it hurt?

221
00:11:21,530 --> 00:11:22,390
>> Yeah.
>> Right?

222
00:11:22,390 --> 00:11:25,940
Well, how do you quantify that pain,
right?

223
00:11:25,940 --> 00:11:27,500
It's challenging.

224
00:11:27,500 --> 00:11:30,430
So, we need to make sure that
we account for that somehow.

225
00:11:30,430 --> 00:11:32,480
And we do that kinda stuff right here.

226
00:11:32,480 --> 00:11:35,120
Anytime we get a sign in number we need
to do that, that's what risk managers do.

227
00:11:36,920 --> 00:11:39,680
All right.
We also need to take a look at the impact.

228
00:11:39,680 --> 00:11:42,840
We're going to talk about probability and
impact quite a bit, and

229
00:11:42,840 --> 00:11:46,500
the impact can vary based
on one of the facts.

230
00:11:46,500 --> 00:11:47,890
Quality, time, cost.

231
00:11:47,890 --> 00:11:52,134
And so, we go through and we say for
very high, high, medium, very low,

232
00:11:52,134 --> 00:11:54,329
whatever what their impact would be.

233
00:11:54,329 --> 00:11:59,253
So for example something that is a very
high impact at the scope level might not

234
00:11:59,253 --> 00:12:01,978
be, well it probably
would be a big deal but

235
00:12:01,978 --> 00:12:06,636
if it was early enough in the project
it might not be a very big deal at all.

236
00:12:06,636 --> 00:12:12,970
Versus something that's a very high
risk to my time might be catastrophic.

237
00:12:12,970 --> 00:12:14,840
I have a deadline I've got to hit.

238
00:12:14,840 --> 00:12:17,390
If this risk occurs,
I won't hit my deadline, right.

239
00:12:17,390 --> 00:12:18,720
That would be catastrophic.

240
00:12:18,720 --> 00:12:23,180
So we need to define what that
impact is gonna be like for

241
00:12:23,180 --> 00:12:24,650
each objective that could be affected.

242
00:12:26,090 --> 00:12:29,770
All right, so those are some of
the things that are going in to our risk

243
00:12:29,770 --> 00:12:33,680
management plan, and again, we're
trying to keep this somewhat generic so

244
00:12:33,680 --> 00:12:36,820
that we can reuse it on our other
projects and be consistent.

245
00:12:38,980 --> 00:12:41,290
All right, so that's our first process.

246
00:12:41,290 --> 00:12:42,500
Pretty straight forward, right?

247
00:12:42,500 --> 00:12:44,090
Nothing too crazy there.

248
00:12:44,090 --> 00:12:47,900
The real work starts with the other guys.

249
00:12:47,900 --> 00:12:50,800
Identifying the risks, so
just coming up with a list.

250
00:12:50,800 --> 00:12:55,070
Right, and then figuring out
which risks we need to deal with.

251
00:12:55,070 --> 00:12:58,540
And once we figure that out,
how we're going to deal with them.

252
00:12:58,540 --> 00:13:00,000
So those are kind of the three steps.

253
00:13:00,000 --> 00:13:02,710
Now I group these two, quantitative and
qualitative, I group them together.

254
00:13:02,710 --> 00:13:05,550
But PMI calls them out separately,
because it is different math.

255
00:13:05,550 --> 00:13:10,910
All right, so
let's dive into identify risks.

256
00:13:13,640 --> 00:13:16,720
With identify risks,
we're just trying to come up with a list.

257
00:13:16,720 --> 00:13:19,620
A list of all of the risks
that affect our project.

258
00:13:19,620 --> 00:13:24,808
And you'll see as an input it's
pretty much everything when it comes

259
00:13:24,808 --> 00:13:30,365
to risk analysis the more data you
have the better off you'll be, right.

260
00:13:30,365 --> 00:13:31,526
The more informed your decisions.

261
00:13:31,526 --> 00:13:33,388
But before I dive into those,

262
00:13:33,388 --> 00:13:38,480
let me just start with one concept I
want to make sure you guys understand.

263
00:13:38,480 --> 00:13:43,000
The term risk is really misunderstood,
all right?

264
00:13:43,000 --> 00:13:47,501
When people hear the word risk,
they think negative things, right.

265
00:13:47,501 --> 00:13:50,580
They think all the bad
things that can happen.

266
00:13:50,580 --> 00:13:52,330
Risk of injury, right.

267
00:13:52,330 --> 00:13:57,430
Risk of bankruptcy,
risk of lawsuits and litigation.

268
00:13:57,430 --> 00:13:59,780
That's what people think
of when they think risk.

269
00:13:59,780 --> 00:14:02,660
But there's good risks also, right.

270
00:14:02,660 --> 00:14:08,060
There's a risk that I own some stock and
the stock value sky rockets.

271
00:14:08,060 --> 00:14:10,760
All right.
There's a risk that my lottery ticket

272
00:14:10,760 --> 00:14:11,930
might be the winner, right.

273
00:14:11,930 --> 00:14:16,200
There's a risk that I might have
millions of dollars tomorrow and

274
00:14:16,200 --> 00:14:18,030
don't have to deal with that.

275
00:14:18,030 --> 00:14:20,470
Oh, the burden of having
millions of dollars.

276
00:14:20,470 --> 00:14:22,690
So, those are real risks.

277
00:14:22,690 --> 00:14:28,060
So, that term risk,
it can be good as well as bad.

278
00:14:28,060 --> 00:14:31,273
And so a lot of organizations
don't like to use that word risk.

279
00:14:31,273 --> 00:14:36,360
Instead they like to use two terms,
threats and opportunities.

280
00:14:37,642 --> 00:14:39,410
Threat is a risk,

281
00:14:39,410 --> 00:14:44,400
that if it happens, would hurt
the company or hurt your project.

282
00:14:44,400 --> 00:14:47,080
An opportunity, is a risk,

283
00:14:47,080 --> 00:14:51,320
that if it happens would help your
company, or help your project.

284
00:14:51,320 --> 00:14:52,130
Right?

285
00:14:52,130 --> 00:14:55,910
And so when we deal with risk,
we need to plan for both sides, right.

286
00:14:55,910 --> 00:14:57,620
Plan for the good, as well as the bad.

287
00:14:57,620 --> 00:15:01,450
Because when you have a bad risk,
you want to mitigate it,

288
00:15:01,450 --> 00:15:05,920
minimize it,
reduce the impact of that threat.

289
00:15:05,920 --> 00:15:09,460
But when you have an opportunity
you want to exploit it.

290
00:15:09,460 --> 00:15:10,380
You want to take advantage.

291
00:15:10,380 --> 00:15:13,050
You want to make it as big as possible.

292
00:15:13,050 --> 00:15:17,830
So very different reactions based on
that but it all falls under risk.

293
00:15:18,830 --> 00:15:23,150
And for somebody who's not a risk manager,
it's easy to lose sight of that.

294
00:15:23,150 --> 00:15:27,180
So, when we look at all this
stuff here on the left side,

295
00:15:27,180 --> 00:15:29,030
we kind of start with our constraints.

296
00:15:29,030 --> 00:15:31,060
So here's our project constraints.

297
00:15:31,060 --> 00:15:33,080
Our scope, cost and time.

298
00:15:33,080 --> 00:15:34,870
Our requirements, budgets, and scale.

299
00:15:34,870 --> 00:15:39,480
These guys right here, if any one of these
gets messed up, it affects the other two.

300
00:15:39,480 --> 00:15:42,204
I know that's been our ongoing
theme throughout the project.

301
00:15:42,204 --> 00:15:45,216
I keep bringing this slide up,
because if our schedule,

302
00:15:45,216 --> 00:15:49,861
if we're running behind schedule, in order
to get caught back up, we're either going

303
00:15:49,861 --> 00:15:53,530
to need to kill off some requirements or
get some more money, right?

304
00:15:53,530 --> 00:15:56,271
All three of these are tied to each other.

305
00:15:56,271 --> 00:16:01,252
So when we go to identify the risks,
we need to look at our cost, our schedule,

306
00:16:01,252 --> 00:16:02,940
and our quality, right.

307
00:16:02,940 --> 00:16:03,850
Those three things,

308
00:16:03,850 --> 00:16:08,900
that's where our risk really comes from,
and here they're talking about the plans.

309
00:16:08,900 --> 00:16:10,770
How do we plan our cost?

310
00:16:10,770 --> 00:16:11,630
How do we plan our schedule?

311
00:16:11,630 --> 00:16:12,880
How do we plan our quality?

312
00:16:12,880 --> 00:16:16,470
Cuz they're going to include in
there how we can change our cost,

313
00:16:16,470 --> 00:16:18,170
how we can change our schedule, and so on.

314
00:16:18,170 --> 00:16:23,080
And then you'll see down here, the actual
fixed numbers, the scope baseline.

315
00:16:23,080 --> 00:16:26,410
That's our requirements,
right, or our quality.

316
00:16:26,410 --> 00:16:29,170
Our activity cost estimates,
there's our budget.

317
00:16:29,170 --> 00:16:31,688
Our activity duration estimates,
there's our schedule, right?

318
00:16:31,688 --> 00:16:35,629
So those 6 entries of this 13,
half the list, is really just talking

319
00:16:35,629 --> 00:16:40,506
about our triple constraints, right, the
triumvirate of project management power.

320
00:16:40,506 --> 00:16:42,307
Sounds so
much more fancy when you put it like that.

321
00:16:42,307 --> 00:16:44,289
>> It does.
So, that really accounts for

322
00:16:44,289 --> 00:16:46,140
half this list.

323
00:16:46,140 --> 00:16:49,520
The other half are just areas
where problems can creep up.

324
00:16:49,520 --> 00:16:53,030
Your stakeholder register,
your general project documents.

325
00:16:53,030 --> 00:16:55,150
I love this one, right,
number 10, project documents,

326
00:16:55,150 --> 00:16:57,660
because that just means everything, right.

327
00:16:57,660 --> 00:17:00,888
[LAUGH] All of our documentation, which
really includes all these things up here,

328
00:17:00,888 --> 00:17:03,410
so they could of made this a lot shorter.

329
00:17:03,410 --> 00:17:06,790
But I want to make sure that you see
all these individual entities, right.

330
00:17:06,790 --> 00:17:09,020
We got our procurement documents.

331
00:17:09,020 --> 00:17:12,250
That would be any contract, right,
cuz there's always a risk of breach of

332
00:17:12,250 --> 00:17:15,790
contract, and we're gonna talk about that
in the procurement knowledge area later.

333
00:17:15,790 --> 00:17:19,450
But there's always that
risk of breach of contract.

334
00:17:19,450 --> 00:17:23,910
So all of these things are data
that we gather together, and

335
00:17:23,910 --> 00:17:26,340
then we do our risk analysis.

336
00:17:26,340 --> 00:17:29,160
We look at all this data, and

337
00:17:29,160 --> 00:17:34,250
we try to find anywhere that
something could go wrong or

338
00:17:34,250 --> 00:17:38,779
where anything could exceed expectations,
right.

339
00:17:38,779 --> 00:17:42,260
In an earlier episode
we talked about doing

340
00:17:43,780 --> 00:17:45,940
like beta-
>> Distribution?

341
00:17:45,940 --> 00:17:48,390
>> Yeah, beta distributions and
triangular distributions.

342
00:17:48,390 --> 00:17:52,567
And we talked about when we get a quote or
an estimate we do a optimistic,

343
00:17:52,567 --> 00:17:54,530
pessimistic, and most likely.

344
00:17:54,530 --> 00:17:55,121
>> Most likely.

345
00:17:55,121 --> 00:17:58,810
>> So we're normally planning
around the most likely.

346
00:17:58,810 --> 00:18:01,330
But our risk is documented right there.

347
00:18:01,330 --> 00:18:07,790
Our opportunity, or our positive risk,
is that most optimistic quote.

348
00:18:07,790 --> 00:18:12,480
Our threat, or our negative risk,
that is the pessimistic,

349
00:18:12,480 --> 00:18:14,500
right, the worst-case scenario.

350
00:18:14,500 --> 00:18:16,270
The most likely is what we act on.

351
00:18:16,270 --> 00:18:20,100
So we kind of already have that idea
of where our risk is there in something

352
00:18:20,100 --> 00:18:24,730
occurring, based on those quotes that
we got as far as cost and duration.

353
00:18:24,730 --> 00:18:27,680
So, we're just going back and
gathering that data again, and

354
00:18:27,680 --> 00:18:29,410
now we're gonna make use of it, all right?

355
00:18:29,410 --> 00:18:31,460
So, we pull all that data from here.

356
00:18:31,460 --> 00:18:34,835
We go through, we identify everything,
including our stakeholders and

357
00:18:34,835 --> 00:18:36,930
risks that can come from them.

358
00:18:36,930 --> 00:18:39,050
I've got a number of stories on this.

359
00:18:39,050 --> 00:18:43,170
I've dealt with people that I knew for
a fact change their minds a lot, right?

360
00:18:43,170 --> 00:18:47,150
If you have a project sponsor,
with bottomless pockets, right, or

361
00:18:47,150 --> 00:18:51,300
bottomless wallets I guess would
be a better way of putting it.

362
00:18:51,300 --> 00:18:56,880
If you have a sponsor that has a ton
of money and isn't worried about money,

363
00:18:56,880 --> 00:19:01,060
then they are very likely to
change requirements as you go.

364
00:19:01,060 --> 00:19:03,720
And if you say, ooh, yeah,
we can do that, but it's gonna cost more,

365
00:19:03,720 --> 00:19:04,860
they go fine, do it.

366
00:19:04,860 --> 00:19:06,270
I'm cool with that, right?

367
00:19:06,270 --> 00:19:10,680
Your project's gonna be tough, because you
know early on that there's going to be

368
00:19:10,680 --> 00:19:14,220
constant change throughout this project
because they don't have a limit of money.

369
00:19:15,330 --> 00:19:17,900
It seems like a good problem to have,
but it is frustrating as hell,

370
00:19:17,900 --> 00:19:19,920
because it's hard to plan around that.

371
00:19:19,920 --> 00:19:24,120
So that is a thing that we would need to
identify in our stakeholder register.

372
00:19:25,590 --> 00:19:31,300
Other things we need to look at
are areas where we might have people who

373
00:19:31,300 --> 00:19:32,870
can't make decisions.

374
00:19:32,870 --> 00:19:36,570
Now I've bumped into this,
where you have a sponsor and

375
00:19:36,570 --> 00:19:39,230
you throw a question to them like hey,
we're

376
00:19:39,230 --> 00:19:42,790
thinking about making this modification
in order to facilitate this deadline.

377
00:19:42,790 --> 00:19:43,360
What do you think?

378
00:19:43,360 --> 00:19:47,080
And they go well,
let me think about it, right?

379
00:19:47,080 --> 00:19:49,130
Let me go back and look at some paperwork.

380
00:19:49,130 --> 00:19:53,490
And then a day goes by, two days go by,
you know I just haven't made up my mind.

381
00:19:53,490 --> 00:19:57,685
Three days goes by, four days goes by,
right, and a decision hasn't been made.

382
00:19:57,685 --> 00:19:58,950
That's a real challenge, okay.

383
00:19:58,950 --> 00:20:03,943
I have something that my
grandfather taught me.

384
00:20:03,943 --> 00:20:08,245
He said, hey, I'm going into like old,
pointless stories now,

385
00:20:08,245 --> 00:20:10,405
but he had this saying.

386
00:20:10,405 --> 00:20:13,840
He said, when you're working on something,
you gotta make decisions.

387
00:20:13,840 --> 00:20:14,790
Make a decision.

388
00:20:14,790 --> 00:20:15,890
Don't delay.

389
00:20:15,890 --> 00:20:19,390
If you delay,
that in itself is making a decision.

390
00:20:19,390 --> 00:20:20,110
You're choosing to do nothing, all right?

391
00:20:20,110 --> 00:20:23,280
And you're probably setting
yourself up for failure.

392
00:20:23,280 --> 00:20:26,970
But he said if you make a decision now and
it's wrong, you'll

393
00:20:26,970 --> 00:20:31,420
probably have time to fix it, but at least
you made a decision, you move forward.

394
00:20:31,420 --> 00:20:34,770
If you make a decision and it's right,
you've set yourself up for success.

395
00:20:34,770 --> 00:20:37,100
You made the right decision,
you move forward, right?

396
00:20:37,100 --> 00:20:40,040
But it all starts with
making a decision and

397
00:20:40,040 --> 00:20:41,610
knowing that sometimes
we're gonna be wrong.

398
00:20:41,610 --> 00:20:44,241
You can't make the right
decision every time,

399
00:20:44,241 --> 00:20:47,150
otherwise everyone would
be insanely successful.

400
00:20:47,150 --> 00:20:47,799
And that's not the case.

401
00:20:47,799 --> 00:20:51,240
So, we got to make a decision.

402
00:20:51,240 --> 00:20:53,330
If you've got a stake
holder who's notorious for

403
00:20:53,330 --> 00:20:55,760
not making decisions,
you've got to stay on top of them.

404
00:20:55,760 --> 00:20:57,276
When they say, I need to think about it.

405
00:20:57,276 --> 00:21:00,900
You say, all right, what information
do you need to make a decision?

406
00:21:00,900 --> 00:21:02,490
Let me help you get that information.

407
00:21:02,490 --> 00:21:03,770
You tell me what you want.

408
00:21:03,770 --> 00:21:05,260
What format do you want this data in?

409
00:21:05,260 --> 00:21:06,170
Do you like pie charts?

410
00:21:06,170 --> 00:21:07,780
I can make pie charts.

411
00:21:07,780 --> 00:21:11,230
Whatever you need to do,
to get them to make that decision.

412
00:21:11,230 --> 00:21:14,150
And you sit them in a room with you,
or you sit in their office.

413
00:21:14,150 --> 00:21:16,380
And you say, let me help you.

414
00:21:16,380 --> 00:21:19,030
You tell me what data you need,
I'll give the data to you.

415
00:21:19,030 --> 00:21:20,450
And then we'll make that decision.

416
00:21:20,450 --> 00:21:21,760
But you've got to make it.

417
00:21:21,760 --> 00:21:24,590
So, we can identify those
people very early on.

418
00:21:24,590 --> 00:21:29,330
There's a risk that they could derail
your project by not making a decision.

419
00:21:29,330 --> 00:21:32,482
And if you know you're going to be
working with somebody like that,

420
00:21:32,482 --> 00:21:36,242
you need to set up a change board, where
they don't have control of the changes,

421
00:21:36,242 --> 00:21:37,430
not exclusive control.

422
00:21:37,430 --> 00:21:39,910
So that they can be outvoted,
and you can move on.

423
00:21:39,910 --> 00:21:41,413
But you gotta have that process.

424
00:21:41,413 --> 00:21:42,539
All right, so

425
00:21:42,539 --> 00:21:47,490
under our Tools & Techniques, we got a lot
of things to help us with this, right?

426
00:21:47,490 --> 00:21:49,270
Documentation Reviews.

427
00:21:49,270 --> 00:21:50,490
These are important,

428
00:21:50,490 --> 00:21:54,050
especially when it comes down
to our work breakdown structure.

429
00:21:54,050 --> 00:21:57,200
Our WBS is identifying all
the work that needs to be done

430
00:21:57,200 --> 00:21:58,798
to the best of our ability.

431
00:21:58,798 --> 00:22:03,025
Whenever possible ,you should bring in
a third party to evaluate the WBS and

432
00:22:03,025 --> 00:22:05,005
see if they reach the same conclusion.

433
00:22:05,005 --> 00:22:07,385
Is there any work that
didn’t make it in there?

434
00:22:07,385 --> 00:22:08,735
Did we leave something out?

435
00:22:08,735 --> 00:22:12,225
Because anything that we left out
is going to introduce more time and

436
00:22:12,225 --> 00:22:16,000
more money that we may not have,
all right, so a documentation review.

437
00:22:16,000 --> 00:22:18,430
It's also a chance for us to look and

438
00:22:18,430 --> 00:22:21,400
see if there's any documents that
haven't been created, right.

439
00:22:21,400 --> 00:22:22,652
Is this project advancing
without a charter?

440
00:22:22,652 --> 00:22:23,418
>> Yeah.

441
00:22:23,418 --> 00:22:26,500
[LAUGH]
>> I've seen that so many times.

442
00:22:26,500 --> 00:22:29,670
It's advancing without a charter so
it's got no authority.

443
00:22:29,670 --> 00:22:32,740
So this project can be cancelled at any
moment because technically it was never

444
00:22:32,740 --> 00:22:34,050
authorized to happen.

445
00:22:34,050 --> 00:22:36,000
We identify that right here.

446
00:22:36,000 --> 00:22:38,640
And we either fix it or the project ends.

447
00:22:38,640 --> 00:22:42,070
Nip it in the bud before execution starts.

448
00:22:42,070 --> 00:22:45,270
We're not going to be out of a lot
of money until execution starts.

449
00:22:45,270 --> 00:22:47,792
If you stop once execution is running,
you've lost money.

450
00:22:47,792 --> 00:22:51,660
All right, we've also got our
information gathering techniques.

451
00:22:51,660 --> 00:22:55,790
We reach out and
we get any additional information we need.

452
00:22:55,790 --> 00:22:58,820
And there's a ton of ways to
go about things like that.

453
00:22:58,820 --> 00:22:59,683
Let's see, do we-
>> Yeah,

454
00:22:59,683 --> 00:23:00,250
there's a few of them mentioned in there.

455
00:23:00,250 --> 00:23:04,040
>> All right,
let me pull up the notes here.

456
00:23:04,040 --> 00:23:06,600
Let's see, identify risks, and

457
00:23:06,600 --> 00:23:08,780
we've got, those are all things
we've kind of talked about.

458
00:23:08,780 --> 00:23:09,280
I went too far.

459
00:23:09,280 --> 00:23:10,370
There we go.

460
00:23:10,370 --> 00:23:13,040
So information gathering techniques,
I know we've talked about some of these.

461
00:23:13,040 --> 00:23:15,650
Like brainstorming, we've talked about.

462
00:23:15,650 --> 00:23:17,210
Interviewing, we've talked about.

463
00:23:17,210 --> 00:23:20,190
Root cause analysis,
we've talked a little bit about.

464
00:23:20,190 --> 00:23:22,200
I don't think we've talked
about Delphi at all, have we?

465
00:23:22,200 --> 00:23:23,140
>> No.

466
00:23:23,140 --> 00:23:26,350
>> All right, so
Delphi technique is kinda neat.

467
00:23:26,350 --> 00:23:29,880
In a way it's kind of like
the nominal group technique

468
00:23:29,880 --> 00:23:33,970
where we get a group of people,
and we get information from them.

469
00:23:33,970 --> 00:23:36,368
And in nominal,
some people count more than others.

470
00:23:36,368 --> 00:23:37,668
There's a little bit of weight there.

471
00:23:37,668 --> 00:23:40,885
But you're trying to get ideas
from all the various people.

472
00:23:40,885 --> 00:23:42,895
The Delphi technique goes
a step further and it says,

473
00:23:42,895 --> 00:23:46,645
when you get a bunch of people in a room,
they affect each other.

474
00:23:46,645 --> 00:23:49,455
They affect and
impact what each other thinks.

475
00:23:49,455 --> 00:23:52,731
One person feeds off of the next or
one person is subverted.

476
00:23:52,731 --> 00:23:54,053
I call it steamrolling.

477
00:23:54,053 --> 00:23:59,417
Every company has that employee
who is Super alpha type, right?

478
00:23:59,417 --> 00:24:03,855
Where they have an idea, and
dag gummit, it is the best idea, and

479
00:24:03,855 --> 00:24:06,710
they won't listen to anybody else.

480
00:24:06,710 --> 00:24:09,280
And if somebody starts to promote
other ideas, they steamroll them.

481
00:24:09,280 --> 00:24:12,390
They just throw out all this information,
and

482
00:24:12,390 --> 00:24:16,790
it basically hinders other people
from presenting their ideas.

483
00:24:16,790 --> 00:24:18,450
Eventually they get to the point
where they say, you know what?

484
00:24:18,450 --> 00:24:21,100
I'm just not even gonna say anything
cuz I know Bob in accounting is

485
00:24:21,100 --> 00:24:24,640
gonna go all crazy, so
I'll just let it go, right?

486
00:24:24,640 --> 00:24:26,150
Well, with Delphi technique
we do it like this.

487
00:24:26,150 --> 00:24:28,290
We say, let's do it anonymously.

488
00:24:28,290 --> 00:24:32,460
Let's have where we send out
a questionnaire to everybody and

489
00:24:32,460 --> 00:24:33,940
they fill it out by themselves.

490
00:24:33,940 --> 00:24:36,260
They fill out their ideas and
their information, and

491
00:24:36,260 --> 00:24:39,450
we bring it all back together and
we don't necessarily know who did.

492
00:24:39,450 --> 00:24:41,490
I mean, you can do it with names but
normally you don't.

493
00:24:41,490 --> 00:24:43,310
So you don't know who
provided these ideas.

494
00:24:43,310 --> 00:24:47,290
And now you can look at it unbiased,
and figure out which one is the best.

495
00:24:47,290 --> 00:24:50,610
And nobody has that opportunity
to overrule, or whatever.

496
00:24:50,610 --> 00:24:51,440
It's a neat technique.

497
00:24:52,920 --> 00:24:53,910
All right.

498
00:24:53,910 --> 00:24:55,400
Root cause analysis.

499
00:24:55,400 --> 00:24:59,280
When we were talking a little bit
about quality, we talked about this.

500
00:24:59,280 --> 00:25:02,480
That if we have a defect,
what's causing it?

501
00:25:02,480 --> 00:25:03,470
What is the root cause?

502
00:25:03,470 --> 00:25:07,690
And there might be more then one cause,
so we're looking for the main one.

503
00:25:07,690 --> 00:25:10,330
And when you're dealing
with things like defects,

504
00:25:10,330 --> 00:25:13,710
there's always the symptom and the cause.

505
00:25:13,710 --> 00:25:15,450
Doctors talk about this a lot.

506
00:25:15,450 --> 00:25:17,230
Somebody comes in with a runny nose.

507
00:25:17,230 --> 00:25:20,580
Well the runny nose is the symptom,
what is the cause?

508
00:25:20,580 --> 00:25:26,600
Well, they've got a viral sinus infection,
right, or something like that.

509
00:25:26,600 --> 00:25:31,510
So, the runny nose is a symptom,
the sinus infection is the cause.

510
00:25:31,510 --> 00:25:33,450
So if we treat the runny nose,

511
00:25:33,450 --> 00:25:36,630
like a antihistamine, that doesn't
help with the sinus infection.

512
00:25:36,630 --> 00:25:39,920
So you've gotta make sure you
find out what that root cause is.

513
00:25:39,920 --> 00:25:42,890
So we basically break down
whatever our problem is,

514
00:25:42,890 --> 00:25:45,920
whatever it is we're dealing with, and
we try and find not just the symptoms,

515
00:25:45,920 --> 00:25:48,530
but what's actually
leading to that to occur.

516
00:25:48,530 --> 00:25:52,680
And that's where those fishbone and
Ishikawa Diagrams that we talked about,

517
00:25:52,680 --> 00:25:56,000
that's where those come in.

518
00:25:56,000 --> 00:25:59,310
The other things that we have
are pretty common sense.

519
00:25:59,310 --> 00:26:00,280
Checklist analysis.

520
00:26:01,520 --> 00:26:04,540
In the quality process group or

521
00:26:04,540 --> 00:26:08,070
knowledge area,
we came up with checklists to follow.

522
00:26:08,070 --> 00:26:09,814
When we're monitoring,
controlling our project,

523
00:26:09,814 --> 00:26:13,040
how do we know if the things
are getting done, we've got checklists.

524
00:26:13,040 --> 00:26:18,100
Well, we need to look at those checklists
and say are they thorough enough?

525
00:26:18,100 --> 00:26:21,550
Are they properly cataloging
the information to ensure success?

526
00:26:21,550 --> 00:26:25,100
Are there negative scenarios that can
happen that this checklist is not going

527
00:26:25,100 --> 00:26:27,640
to capture?

528
00:26:27,640 --> 00:26:29,370
Assumptions analysis,

529
00:26:29,370 --> 00:26:33,170
we've seen it on a few forms now where
we document any assumptions we've made.

530
00:26:33,170 --> 00:26:36,170
Well we make an assumption, I can say,

531
00:26:38,560 --> 00:26:42,960
we're gonna plan an outdoor rock concert,
and I'm assuming that we'll be able to

532
00:26:42,960 --> 00:26:46,130
reserve some tents, and
we don't actually have to rent them.

533
00:26:46,130 --> 00:26:49,520
We can just reserve them, and if we
need them, we'll have them available.

534
00:26:49,520 --> 00:26:51,390
So that's my assumption.

535
00:26:51,390 --> 00:26:52,560
Well, as we identify risk,

536
00:26:52,560 --> 00:26:56,840
we need to look at it and
say is that assumption realistic?

537
00:26:56,840 --> 00:27:01,210
What company is gonna offer for
me to reserve tents for

538
00:27:01,210 --> 00:27:04,900
the day and
not actually charge me full rental price?

539
00:27:04,900 --> 00:27:06,830
Cuz they can't use the tents
if I've reserved them,

540
00:27:06,830 --> 00:27:08,770
so I might as well be renting them.

541
00:27:08,770 --> 00:27:10,600
The only difference is
whether I set them up or not.

542
00:27:10,600 --> 00:27:12,728
That might not be a realistic assumption.

543
00:27:12,728 --> 00:27:17,880
And so, if we identify that, we need to
change that assumption to become a fact,

544
00:27:17,880 --> 00:27:19,700
to be no, that's not realistic.

545
00:27:19,700 --> 00:27:21,690
You need to plan for
not paying your reserve price but

546
00:27:21,690 --> 00:27:24,960
paying the full rental price
even if you don't use the tents.

547
00:27:24,960 --> 00:27:27,900
So that's the kind of thing we
start with in assumption analysis.

548
00:27:27,900 --> 00:27:31,380
How accurate,
how realistic are those assumptions?

549
00:27:31,380 --> 00:27:34,870
And is there anything we can
do to make them more factual?

550
00:27:36,850 --> 00:27:41,190
Our diagram techniques, we saw a lot
of diagrams in the shows yesterday.

551
00:27:41,190 --> 00:27:42,590
But, you got your cause and

552
00:27:42,590 --> 00:27:47,390
effect diagrams, your flow charts and
your influence diagrams.

553
00:27:47,390 --> 00:27:50,680
Influence, what activities
influence other ones.

554
00:27:50,680 --> 00:27:54,380
You see that with like your project
schedule network diagram and stuff.

555
00:27:54,380 --> 00:27:57,460
So identifying that information,
that's not really anything new.

556
00:27:59,500 --> 00:28:03,390
All right, but the big one here, the big
new one that we've got, the one that's

557
00:28:03,390 --> 00:28:08,260
probably the most important technique,
is what's called a SWOT analysis.

558
00:28:08,260 --> 00:28:14,380
A SWOT analysis is strength,
weakness, opportunity, threat.

559
00:28:14,380 --> 00:28:19,650
You look at every activity
in your project, every idea,

560
00:28:19,650 --> 00:28:23,220
every assumption everything,
and you say all right,

561
00:28:23,220 --> 00:28:27,550
what are the strengths, and
weaknesses, of how we're doing this?

562
00:28:27,550 --> 00:28:29,800
We've chosen a way to achieve this goal.

563
00:28:29,800 --> 00:28:30,740
What's the strength of it?

564
00:28:30,740 --> 00:28:32,321
What makes this the right way?

565
00:28:32,321 --> 00:28:33,901
What are the weaknesses?

566
00:28:33,901 --> 00:28:36,270
What are the trade offs I've
made by choosing this option?

567
00:28:37,830 --> 00:28:40,950
And then after we figured
that out we start,

568
00:28:40,950 --> 00:28:43,300
what are the opportunities and threats?

569
00:28:43,300 --> 00:28:47,320
Opportunities, what are the positive
risks that I might be able to amplify or

570
00:28:47,320 --> 00:28:51,320
exploit, and then threats,
what are the negative risks?

571
00:28:51,320 --> 00:28:55,150
The things I need to avoid,
I need to reduce whenever possible.

572
00:28:55,150 --> 00:28:59,130
So, maybe we're building a house and
we're on a tight deadline.

573
00:28:59,130 --> 00:29:02,840
And so we say, all right,
if we pour a full cement foundation,

574
00:29:02,840 --> 00:29:07,060
there's gonna be like a three
day wait while that thing dries.

575
00:29:07,060 --> 00:29:08,580
I don't have that kind of time.

576
00:29:08,580 --> 00:29:10,800
So what if we don't do
a cement poured foundation?

577
00:29:10,800 --> 00:29:14,740
What if instead we just raised the house
up a foot and a half off the ground and

578
00:29:14,740 --> 00:29:15,870
build it without a true foundation.

579
00:29:15,870 --> 00:29:18,620
We'll just those pylons down there and
stand the house on it.

580
00:29:18,620 --> 00:29:19,320
All right?

581
00:29:19,320 --> 00:29:23,610
Well the strength of that plan is that
I don't have to wait three days for

582
00:29:23,610 --> 00:29:24,210
cement to dry.

583
00:29:24,210 --> 00:29:26,560
We can act as soon as
those pylons are down.

584
00:29:26,560 --> 00:29:28,770
The pylons take like an hour to put
down and then we're in business.

585
00:29:28,770 --> 00:29:30,630
Right?
There's my strength.

586
00:29:30,630 --> 00:29:31,820
My weakness?

587
00:29:31,820 --> 00:29:33,410
I don't have a foundation.

588
00:29:33,410 --> 00:29:38,080
And so if there is a tornado, or
earthquake, or something like that,

589
00:29:38,080 --> 00:29:41,840
this house might be more susceptible
to seismic activity or whatever, right?

590
00:29:41,840 --> 00:29:43,350
And that might be my weakness.

591
00:29:43,350 --> 00:29:45,230
Or a skunk might move in under the house,
right?

592
00:29:45,230 --> 00:29:46,050
Who knows.

593
00:29:46,050 --> 00:29:47,660
So there's my weakness.

594
00:29:47,660 --> 00:29:50,350
It might also affect
the overall value of the house,

595
00:29:50,350 --> 00:29:53,800
not having a true foundation might
lower the value of the house.

596
00:29:53,800 --> 00:29:55,390
So these are weaknesses
that we need to identify.

597
00:29:55,390 --> 00:29:57,910
And then we say opportunities and threats.

598
00:29:57,910 --> 00:29:59,100
What's my opportunity?

599
00:29:59,100 --> 00:30:02,550
My opportunity is that I can
finish three days early.

600
00:30:02,550 --> 00:30:05,840
I could gain back three days, so
I'm not waiting on a foundation to dry.

601
00:30:05,840 --> 00:30:06,430
All right.

602
00:30:06,430 --> 00:30:09,540
My other opportunity is it might be
easier for the plumbers to look.

603
00:30:09,540 --> 00:30:11,030
Cuz the plumbers can
get under the house and

604
00:30:11,030 --> 00:30:14,390
run plumbing even after the floor is in,
maybe they couldn't normally do that.

605
00:30:14,390 --> 00:30:16,570
So now I can get the plumbers working,

606
00:30:16,570 --> 00:30:18,430
at the same time as the electricians or
whatever.

607
00:30:18,430 --> 00:30:21,320
So again I can fast track my project and
get things done faster.

608
00:30:21,320 --> 00:30:22,800
That's an opportunity.

609
00:30:22,800 --> 00:30:24,930
I need to look at the rest
of my activities,

610
00:30:24,930 --> 00:30:28,289
and find out where I might be able to fast
track, and how much I can shave time off.

611
00:30:29,520 --> 00:30:32,550
My threat, though, is we try and

612
00:30:32,550 --> 00:30:38,390
do this raised up house and some problem
occurs, some issue happens where

613
00:30:38,390 --> 00:30:43,590
I'm not able to perform something
properly or I violate code.

614
00:30:43,590 --> 00:30:45,580
Maybe the pylons don't sit right and

615
00:30:45,580 --> 00:30:49,750
I end up having to spend three days just
getting the pylons put in place and now I

616
00:30:49,750 --> 00:30:54,920
end up in the same time schedule I had
before, but without a solid foundation.

617
00:30:54,920 --> 00:30:58,810
So what can I do to minimize that,
to insure the pylons are put in properly?

618
00:30:58,810 --> 00:31:01,490
What kind of planning can I
go through to mitigate that?

619
00:31:01,490 --> 00:31:05,860
We find all of that in a SWOT analysis.

620
00:31:05,860 --> 00:31:08,150
So real important that we do these.

621
00:31:08,150 --> 00:31:09,760
And how do we do that analysis?

622
00:31:09,760 --> 00:31:14,650
Well we use a lot of these things, expert
judgement, meetings, Delphi technique,

623
00:31:14,650 --> 00:31:18,130
we use all these different things to find
out from everybody else what they feel

624
00:31:18,130 --> 00:31:22,385
are the strengths, weaknesses,
opportunities, and threat, or SWOT.

625
00:31:23,860 --> 00:31:25,760
If you look this up online,

626
00:31:25,760 --> 00:31:29,110
you'll find there's many arguments
as to what SWOT stands for, so

627
00:31:29,110 --> 00:31:35,160
there are other ones, but with PMI,
strength, weakness, opportunity, threat.

628
00:31:35,160 --> 00:31:38,595
That's what you want to remember for
the exam.

629
00:31:38,595 --> 00:31:43,084
All right, after we apply our
expert judgement to all of that,

630
00:31:43,084 --> 00:31:45,286
we gather the data together and

631
00:31:45,286 --> 00:31:50,468
now we create one of our super
important documents, the risk register.

632
00:31:50,468 --> 00:31:54,779
And the risk register is just
a list Of all the risks.

633
00:31:54,779 --> 00:31:58,370
We're not coming up with mathematical data
just yet, it just identifying the risk.

634
00:31:58,370 --> 00:32:01,260
Some might be outlandish,
some we might not even care about, but

635
00:32:01,260 --> 00:32:02,280
we need that list.

636
00:32:02,280 --> 00:32:04,720
We need the information,
and we put it together.

637
00:32:04,720 --> 00:32:07,490
And I think I've got a risk
registered template.

638
00:32:07,490 --> 00:32:07,990
Yeah.

639
00:32:09,420 --> 00:32:10,180
Here we go.

640
00:32:10,180 --> 00:32:12,320
So here's an example of
that risk register, and

641
00:32:12,320 --> 00:32:17,200
we'll look more into
this a little bit later.

642
00:32:17,200 --> 00:32:20,950
But, basically what you'll see
is we create a risk statement.

643
00:32:20,950 --> 00:32:24,610
What that risk is and
that's all we're creating at this point.

644
00:32:24,610 --> 00:32:28,520
We don't have any of this
other data just yet, okay.

645
00:32:28,520 --> 00:32:32,390
So, we're just trying to fill out this
risk statement, just listing in that name.

646
00:32:32,390 --> 00:32:34,310
And we'll fill the rest
of the data out as we go.

647
00:32:34,310 --> 00:32:37,250
But it's basically going to include
things like what's the probability of it

648
00:32:37,250 --> 00:32:37,760
happening.

649
00:32:37,760 --> 00:32:40,580
What's the impact at each phase and so on.

650
00:32:40,580 --> 00:32:43,610
And we'll see how we get
to that a little bit later.

651
00:32:43,610 --> 00:32:46,680
But that's an example of
a risk register right there.

652
00:32:46,680 --> 00:32:48,990
Because it's just containing the name and

653
00:32:48,990 --> 00:32:53,930
not a lot of detailed data, we'll
probably also create a risk data sheet.

654
00:32:53,930 --> 00:32:59,030
And the risk data sheet allows us to
break down an individual risk and

655
00:32:59,030 --> 00:33:00,560
the data regarding it.

656
00:33:00,560 --> 00:33:05,090
So this sheet, we fill out one for
every single risk we have.

657
00:33:05,090 --> 00:33:10,640
The risk description, the cause, the
impact, any secondary or residual risk,

658
00:33:10,640 --> 00:33:15,810
contingency plans, all of this, this is
the detailed information about the risk.

659
00:33:15,810 --> 00:33:19,595
The risk register is kind of high level,
right?

660
00:33:19,595 --> 00:33:22,585
Just the name of the risk,
and its other probabilities.

661
00:33:22,585 --> 00:33:26,435
And then the risk data sheet

If the impact is high and the probability

We start off by doing what's called

That means that we look at

We go line by line.

If there's 500 risks,

And on each one we come

And it's possible that there's different

I like numbers, so

Then once you've gathered that data for

So what I've got is I've got a few things.

First off, I have my probability and

So for each risk,
I'm going to come through and

Is it very low or whatever.

What's the quality impact, the schedule

What's the probability?

And then based on all of this information,

I need to come up with

The risk rating is the risk as whole,

If I say very low, low, medium,
