maybe we'll take them and
switch them from being like yellow here,

1120
00:56:34,110 --> 00:56:36,860
like I've got 'em right now and
go ahead and make them green which,

1121
00:56:36,860 --> 00:56:38,911
of course, is apparently not
one of the colors I can pick.

1122
00:56:38,911 --> 00:56:40,274
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's gonna

1123
00:56:40,274 --> 00:56:41,898
be a different green isn't it?

1124
00:56:41,898 --> 00:56:43,400
This is gonna look terrible.

1125
00:56:43,400 --> 00:56:45,870
I guess I could have
done something like that.

1126
00:56:45,870 --> 00:56:46,420
Oh, it doesn't work.

1127
00:56:46,420 --> 00:56:47,060
All right.
Well, whatever.

1128
00:56:47,060 --> 00:56:49,620
Do you guys see what I mean though
is that we could come in and

1129
00:56:49,620 --> 00:56:52,160
take this and change these a little bit.

1130
00:56:52,160 --> 00:56:55,510
Just to meet whatever it is
that we're trying to achieve.

1131
00:56:55,510 --> 00:56:59,940
So, pick some all new green
that just looks horrible.

1132
00:56:59,940 --> 00:57:00,830
There we go.

1133
00:57:03,340 --> 00:57:04,330
That looks better.

1134
00:57:04,330 --> 00:57:08,970
So, you decide where it is that you
need to lay out what you plan for and

1135
00:57:08,970 --> 00:57:10,770
what you don't is different for
every company.

1136
00:57:10,770 --> 00:57:13,310
Everybody does things a little
bit differently, all right?

1137
00:57:13,310 --> 00:57:17,090
But the key thing is probability and
impact are going to decide this.

1138
00:57:17,090 --> 00:57:21,430
Now, we normally don't act on
probability and impact alone.

1139
00:57:21,430 --> 00:57:24,890
We normally combine the two,
it makes sense to do it.

1140
00:57:24,890 --> 00:57:29,800
And if you used compatible values like
I have with this scale of one to ten,

1141
00:57:29,800 --> 00:57:33,410
you can do something really easy, you
can create what's called a risk rating.

1142
00:57:33,410 --> 00:57:38,540
A risk rating has one of the simplest
formulas in the entire pin box.

1143
00:57:38,540 --> 00:57:42,630
A risk rating is simply
probability times impact.

1144
00:57:42,630 --> 00:57:45,280
So, you take your probability,
you multiply it by your impact, and

1145
00:57:45,280 --> 00:57:47,870
whatever number you get,
that's your risk rating.

1146
00:57:47,870 --> 00:57:49,970
And you might of noticed in
my spreadsheet over here.

1147
00:57:49,970 --> 00:57:51,770
I had Excel doing that for me.

1148
00:57:51,770 --> 00:57:55,970
I had it taking whatever I plugged into
these two, and multiplying it out.

1149
00:57:55,970 --> 00:57:58,720
So when I look over here
at this risk rating column.

1150
00:57:58,720 --> 00:58:02,160
I can see that chance of rain
has a risk rating of 1.6.

1151
00:58:02,160 --> 00:58:07,030
But show host out sick
has a risk rating of 2.5.

1152
00:58:07,030 --> 00:58:10,930
This makes it very easy to compare
these numbers together, and

1153
00:58:10,930 --> 00:58:15,100
I'm gonna need that when we get to
the quantitative risk analysis.

1154
00:58:15,100 --> 00:58:17,420
We're still doing qualitative right now.

1155
00:58:17,420 --> 00:58:21,450
I'm just qualifying each risk, looking
at them, figuring out their details.

1156
00:58:21,450 --> 00:58:23,560
I'm not really doing comparisons just yet.

1157
00:58:23,560 --> 00:58:25,170
That's going to come with quantitative.

1158
00:58:27,390 --> 00:58:30,260
So those are some of the things
that are available to us there,

1159
00:58:30,260 --> 00:58:33,250
as far as probability and impact.

1160
00:58:33,250 --> 00:58:36,530
We map it out in a risk register,

1161
00:58:36,530 --> 00:58:39,870
as we list our risks and
then we map it out in a matrix.

1162
00:58:39,870 --> 00:58:41,190
If you want to figure that out.

1163
00:58:41,190 --> 00:58:44,770
You don't really need the matrix because
you can just the simple mathematic

1164
00:58:44,770 --> 00:58:46,200
equations to do it, too.

1165
00:58:46,200 --> 00:58:50,740
Just remember, probability times
impact equals your risk rating.

1166
00:58:52,520 --> 00:58:57,330
All right, then we have our
risk data quality assessment.

1167
00:58:57,330 --> 00:59:03,620
Your data is only as good as
the data you used to formulate it.

1168
00:59:03,620 --> 00:59:05,180
When I talk about these risks here.

1169
00:59:05,180 --> 00:59:08,550
I said there's a chance of
rain tomorrow and it's 80%.

1170
00:59:08,550 --> 00:59:09,680
Okay?

1171
00:59:09,680 --> 00:59:11,260
Where did I get that from?

1172
00:59:11,260 --> 00:59:11,970
Well I made it up.

1173
00:59:11,970 --> 00:59:14,550
I just made it up off the top of my head.

1174
00:59:14,550 --> 00:59:18,350
Alright, maybe I went a little more
scientific and went to weather.com.

1175
00:59:18,350 --> 00:59:22,470
So you know I fired up weather.com and
I got the data from there.

1176
00:59:22,470 --> 00:59:25,666
So I want to know what the weather
is going to be like tomorrow so

1177
00:59:25,666 --> 00:59:27,480
I punch in our zip code.

1178
00:59:27,480 --> 00:59:32,100
And the weather for,
where do you find tomorrow?

1179
00:59:32,100 --> 00:59:32,920
Here, tomorrow.

1180
00:59:32,920 --> 00:59:33,690
Okay.

1181
00:59:33,690 --> 00:59:35,390
So according to weather.com,

1182
00:59:35,390 --> 00:59:40,030
the weather tomorrow is going to be 90
degrees with evening thunderstorms.

1183
00:59:40,030 --> 00:59:41,107
Chance of rain 60%.

1184
00:59:41,107 --> 00:59:44,418
So weather.com is saying 60%,
so I could stop right here,

1185
00:59:44,418 --> 00:59:45,925
that's where I got my data.

1186
00:59:47,145 --> 00:59:49,415
Well, what's the quality of my data?

1187
00:59:49,415 --> 00:59:51,455
How accurate is weather.com?

1188
00:59:51,455 --> 00:59:54,810
Have they done well over the last year?

1189
00:59:54,810 --> 00:59:57,410
Are they wrong this amount of time or
that amount of time.

1190
00:59:57,410 --> 00:59:59,720
What's the error rate of their data?

1191
01:00:00,770 --> 01:00:04,790
Maybe I want to go and
use somebody else for my data.

1192
01:00:04,790 --> 01:00:07,190
So, maybe I want to use acuweather.

1193
01:00:07,190 --> 01:00:08,520
So, I'll go to acuweather.

1194
01:00:09,920 --> 01:00:12,560
And I'll punch in their data,
and they already found me.

1195
01:00:12,560 --> 01:00:13,570
Ominous, right?

1196
01:00:13,570 --> 01:00:16,910
So, they've found in Gainesville Florida.

1197
01:00:16,910 --> 01:00:22,520
And tomorrow,
it looks like they're saying a high of 89.

1198
01:00:22,520 --> 01:00:24,540
So a little bit different.

1199
01:00:24,540 --> 01:00:27,365
And are they giving us
a generic chance of rain.

1200
01:00:27,365 --> 01:00:31,176
That's 64%.

1201
01:00:34,125 --> 01:00:36,808
>> I'll try it on.
We'll see but I trust you.

1202
01:00:36,808 --> 01:00:38,210
>> [LAUGH]
>> So 64% is what they're saying.

1203
01:00:38,210 --> 01:00:43,590
So I had 60% on Weather.com,
64% on AccuWeather.

1204
01:00:43,590 --> 01:00:45,190
Which one's right?

1205
01:00:45,190 --> 01:00:49,120
Maybe I go ahead and take a third one and
I bring in Weather Underground.

1206
01:00:49,120 --> 01:00:51,930
I'm just trying to think of anybody.

1207
01:00:51,930 --> 01:00:53,610
And so I bring up Weather Underground.

1208
01:00:53,610 --> 01:00:59,230
I punch in old Gainesville here,
which they already found us too.

1209
01:00:59,230 --> 01:01:04,000
And I want tomorrow, ten day forecast.

1210
01:01:04,000 --> 01:01:06,060
>> There you go.
>> Well you know that's gonna be accurate.

1211
01:01:06,060 --> 01:01:10,969
So tomorrow is Friday, and
we got a chance of thunderstorms and

1212
01:01:12,480 --> 01:01:14,240
boy, they lay it out here
kinda crazy don't they?

1213
01:01:14,240 --> 01:01:16,830
>> By hour by hour just about.

1214
01:01:16,830 --> 01:01:17,900
>> Yeah.
And

1215
01:01:17,900 --> 01:01:19,370
sometimes you get too much information.

1216
01:01:19,370 --> 01:01:20,890
>> Yeah.
>> It makes things difficult.

1217
01:01:20,890 --> 01:01:23,890
So, do we have just a generic
straight up percentage?

1218
01:01:23,890 --> 01:01:27,160
I don't want an almanac,
I'm not Benjamin Franklin.

1219
01:01:27,160 --> 01:01:29,625
>> Right there would be the only thing.

1220
01:01:29,625 --> 01:01:30,290
>> 56% humidity.

1221
01:01:31,550 --> 01:01:33,560
Is that today?

1222
01:01:33,560 --> 01:01:35,935
>> See, this information's
already too hard to interpret.

1223
01:01:35,935 --> 01:01:39,070
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well it was just a 62%, right?

1224
01:01:39,070 --> 01:01:42,010
So now I've got three values,
60, 62, and 64%, which is right.

1225
01:01:42,010 --> 01:01:44,830
Maybe I average them together, right?

1226
01:01:44,830 --> 01:01:47,540
So I just got three values,
just average them and be done with it.

1227
01:01:47,540 --> 01:01:49,550
So, the accuracy of my data.

1228
01:01:49,550 --> 01:01:50,900
Where did I get that data from?

1229
01:01:50,900 --> 01:01:52,070
How accurate is it?

1230
01:01:52,070 --> 01:01:53,650
Did somebody just guess?

1231
01:01:53,650 --> 01:01:56,575
Am I going off of one subject
matter expert's estimate?

1232
01:01:56,575 --> 01:01:57,420
Right?

1233
01:01:57,420 --> 01:01:58,930
Where did I get that from?

1234
01:01:58,930 --> 01:02:02,610
So we've got to make sure that
our data is accurate as possible.

1235
01:02:02,610 --> 01:02:06,060
And the risk data quality
assessment does exactly that.

1236
01:02:06,060 --> 01:02:09,240
We just look and
make sure that we have some factual basis.

1237
01:02:09,240 --> 01:02:10,980
And we document it.

1238
01:02:10,980 --> 01:02:14,060
The important reason we document it,
is if we're wrong.

1239
01:02:14,060 --> 01:02:15,020
We need to see why.

1240
01:02:15,020 --> 01:02:15,760
Why were we wrong?

1241
01:02:15,760 --> 01:02:16,480
Was it our fault?

1242
01:02:16,480 --> 01:02:18,050
Did we just not do our due diligence?

1243
01:02:18,050 --> 01:02:20,040
Did we not do good prep work?

1244
01:02:20,040 --> 01:02:22,048
Or was it something out of our control?

1245
01:02:22,048 --> 01:02:26,600
Everybody predicted 60% chance of rain,
but then on that day it ended up

1246
01:02:26,600 --> 01:02:30,880
being 100%, or while it's
raining it's always 100%, right?

1247
01:02:30,880 --> 01:02:32,200
So keep that in mind.

1248
01:02:33,400 --> 01:02:35,338
We also have risk categorization.

1249
01:02:35,338 --> 01:02:42,210
Now risk categorization depends on you,
how you want to categorize things.

1250
01:02:42,210 --> 01:02:45,690
You can categorize them based
on mitigation techniques,

1251
01:02:45,690 --> 01:02:47,010
ways you would handle them.

1252
01:02:47,010 --> 01:02:50,290
You can categorize them based
on the areas that they affect.

1253
01:02:50,290 --> 01:02:53,098
If they affect your schedule,
or your budget, or so on,

1254
01:02:53,098 --> 01:02:54,970
that's what I normally do.

1255
01:02:54,970 --> 01:02:58,490
Or you can categorize them based
on whose responsible for them.

1256
01:02:58,490 --> 01:03:01,265
It's up to you,
some people categorize them just based on

1257
01:03:01,265 --> 01:03:04,545
the deliverable inside of the work
breakdown structure they affect.

1258
01:03:04,545 --> 01:03:06,435
So, figure out what works for you.

1259
01:03:06,435 --> 01:03:09,645
The main reason we wanna categorize
them is so that we can evaluate our

1260
01:03:09,645 --> 01:03:13,255
risk on a per category basis, and
we don't do that here in this process but

1261
01:03:13,255 --> 01:03:16,140
we do it in quantitative risk
analysis in the next process.

1262
01:03:18,040 --> 01:03:21,340
You also have a risk urgency assessment.

1263
01:03:21,340 --> 01:03:24,910
There are some risks that we
need to deal with immediately.

1264
01:03:26,020 --> 01:03:28,920
If we're planning an outdoor rock
concert three months from now,

1265
01:03:28,920 --> 01:03:33,730
and there's a chance that it could rain,
we need to secure the tents now.

1266
01:03:33,730 --> 01:03:37,130
Because the tents might not be available
two weeks before the show, right.

1267
01:03:37,130 --> 01:03:41,340
So some risks have a high urgency that
we need to immediately deal with.

1268
01:03:41,340 --> 01:03:48,614
Other risks, there might not be any point
to dealing with too far ahead of time.

1269
01:03:48,614 --> 01:03:50,551
What can I really do now,
three months early,

1270
01:03:50,551 --> 01:03:52,599
to make sure that a performer
doesn't get sick.

1271
01:03:52,599 --> 01:03:53,552
Do you stick him in a bubble?

1272
01:03:53,552 --> 01:03:55,367
There's not really much you can do, so

1273
01:03:55,367 --> 01:03:57,575
there's not a lot of
urgency around that risk.

1274
01:03:57,575 --> 01:04:02,680
The higher the probability and impact
of a risk, the more urgent it becomes.

1275
01:04:02,680 --> 01:04:07,340
The lower the probability and impact,
the less urgent, because low probability,

1276
01:04:07,340 --> 01:04:09,240
low impact,
is not really gonna affect our project.

1277
01:04:11,140 --> 01:04:13,760
All right, and then expert judgement.

1278
01:04:13,760 --> 01:04:17,180
If you happen to be fortunate
enough to have a risk manager Or

1279
01:04:17,180 --> 01:04:20,260
some kind of risk consultant,
they will help you to no end.

1280
01:04:20,260 --> 01:04:22,690
They are worth their weight and gold.

1281
01:04:22,690 --> 01:04:24,070
Well most of them are.

1282
01:04:24,070 --> 01:04:28,150
[Laughs] like any profession there
are some that aren’t but most of them are.

1283
01:04:28,150 --> 01:04:29,610
So they can really help you out.

1284
01:04:29,610 --> 01:04:32,770
If you don't have that and
you're on your own, well

1285
01:04:32,770 --> 01:04:36,350
you need to get all the information you
can so bring in subject matter experts for

1286
01:04:36,350 --> 01:04:41,190
the individual areas of your project and
get their best opinion over the risks.

1287
01:04:42,580 --> 01:04:44,480
All right,
now the only thing we generate here,

1288
01:04:44,480 --> 01:04:48,140
with qualitative risk analysis,
is Project Document Updates.

1289
01:04:48,140 --> 01:04:52,390
The reason is, we've probably already
created a lot of these documents.

1290
01:04:52,390 --> 01:04:57,280
Now they don't that that risk matrix is
an output even though it technically is.

1291
01:04:57,280 --> 01:04:59,030
Here's where we create it.

1292
01:04:59,030 --> 01:05:00,062
So you don't see that.

1293
01:05:00,062 --> 01:05:03,943
But what we're really doing is we're
updating our risk register, so

1294
01:05:03,943 --> 01:05:05,653
this risk register over here,

1295
01:05:05,653 --> 01:05:09,468
and you might remember fro the templates
I brought up at the beginning

1296
01:05:09,468 --> 01:05:13,382
of this show that the risk register
itself doesn't have a ton of data.

1297
01:05:13,382 --> 01:05:17,180
But it does have probability and impact.

1298
01:05:17,180 --> 01:05:20,810
So, as we get that information,
we plug it right in here and

1299
01:05:20,810 --> 01:05:22,510
see where it's got score?

1300
01:05:22,510 --> 01:05:24,290
That's the risk rating.

1301
01:05:24,290 --> 01:05:28,380
Probability times impact
equals the risk rating, so

1302
01:05:28,380 --> 01:05:30,109
they just call it score in
this particular template.

1303
01:05:31,590 --> 01:05:36,680
There's also, instead of the risk
register, there is the risk data sheet.

1304
01:05:36,680 --> 01:05:40,780
And here's where we do the same thing,
probability, impact, score, but

1305
01:05:40,780 --> 01:05:45,130
we go a step further to include
things like risk cause,

1306
01:05:45,130 --> 01:05:47,790
risk responses, contingency plans.

1307
01:05:47,790 --> 01:05:49,950
Other data surrounding that.

1308
01:05:49,950 --> 01:05:52,820
And risk response plans
in two more processes.

1309
01:05:52,820 --> 01:05:54,160
So, we'll get to that
towards the end of the show.

1310
01:05:55,822 --> 01:05:58,070
All right, so definitely things
that we want to be aware of, and

1311
01:05:58,070 --> 01:06:01,420
this is a great place to put information
in on where we can get our data from.

1312
01:06:01,420 --> 01:06:02,370
So, we've got that documented.

1313
01:06:04,192 --> 01:06:08,900
All right, so those are pretty much the
things we need to thing about as far as

1314
01:06:08,900 --> 01:06:11,280
Qualitative Risk Analysis.

1315
01:06:11,280 --> 01:06:15,680
Just remember, the main goal of
Qualitative Risk Analysis is to assign

1316
01:06:15,680 --> 01:06:20,260
values to your risk to make it
possible to compare them, right?

1317
01:06:20,260 --> 01:06:24,115
We need to qualify each risk to
understand the significance or

1318
01:06:24,115 --> 01:06:26,025
lack of significance of that risk.

1319
01:06:27,485 --> 01:06:29,135
Once we're done with that,

1320
01:06:29,135 --> 01:06:34,030
we usually immediately move into
Quantitative Risk Analysis.

1321
01:06:34,030 --> 01:06:36,950
Very similar words, very easy to confuse.

1322
01:06:36,950 --> 01:06:40,510
Qualitative, we're looking
at individual risks.

1323
01:06:40,510 --> 01:06:43,790
Quantitative, we look at the big picture,
all right?

1324
01:06:43,790 --> 01:06:44,720
So, let's see that.

1325
01:06:44,720 --> 01:06:47,030
Let me bring up that process group here.

1326
01:06:47,030 --> 01:06:47,840
All right.

1327
01:06:47,840 --> 01:06:52,350
In Quantitative Risk Analysis,
we take our inputs, and our inputs,

1328
01:06:52,350 --> 01:06:54,400
the main one is the risk register.

1329
01:06:54,400 --> 01:06:58,160
Because, really, all the other stuff: risk
management plan, cost management plan,

1330
01:06:58,160 --> 01:06:59,420
schedule management plan.

1331
01:06:59,420 --> 01:07:05,390
A lot of that stuff went into our
Qualitative Risk Analysis already.

1332
01:07:05,390 --> 01:07:07,580
So we don't normally need to
harvest that information together.

1333
01:07:07,580 --> 01:07:09,130
We've already acted upon it.

1334
01:07:09,130 --> 01:07:10,040
What we're really looking for

1335
01:07:10,040 --> 01:07:13,850
is that risk register that's now nice and
populated with probability impact.

1336
01:07:13,850 --> 01:07:15,300
Right, and a risk rating.

1337
01:07:15,300 --> 01:07:20,010
And that's when we can start to go in and
compare our data, and

1338
01:07:20,010 --> 01:07:23,570
make some important decisions,
right, some very important decisions.

1339
01:07:23,570 --> 01:07:27,530
So the first thing we need is data
gathering and representation techniques.

1340
01:07:27,530 --> 01:07:32,430
And what they're talking about there
is of the data that we've gathered, we

1341
01:07:32,430 --> 01:07:36,520
need to be able to show it in a way that's
meaningful to the people we talk to,

1342
01:07:36,520 --> 01:07:41,050
that's meaningful to our CEO, to our
sponsors to our stakeholders, right.

1343
01:07:41,050 --> 01:07:44,070
So we gather our data through
any of a number of techniques.

1344
01:07:44,070 --> 01:07:46,760
And the book specifically
calls out interviewing, right.

1345
01:07:46,760 --> 01:07:48,970
So we interview people, gather that data.

1346
01:07:48,970 --> 01:07:51,940
And then we do probability distribution.

1347
01:07:53,070 --> 01:07:55,810
There are some events that

1348
01:07:55,810 --> 01:07:59,850
may have different probabilities
based on certain criteria.

1349
01:07:59,850 --> 01:08:03,350
A great example is here in Florida,
people calling in sick.

1350
01:08:03,350 --> 01:08:07,590
There is a great instance of people
calling in sick in this springtime

1351
01:08:07,590 --> 01:08:09,100
then any other time of year.

1352
01:08:09,100 --> 01:08:14,220
And the reason is in Florida we have
a pollen count that is ridiculous.

1353
01:08:14,220 --> 01:08:17,410
There is so much pollen in the air
in spring it effects the gas

1354
01:08:17,410 --> 01:08:18,640
mileage in your car.

1355
01:08:18,640 --> 01:08:23,490
>> That it's just crazy so
in the spring people's allergies flare up.

1356
01:08:23,490 --> 01:08:25,910
People get sick, and they call in.

1357
01:08:25,910 --> 01:08:29,970
It happens every year, and
it kind of coincides with flu season or

1358
01:08:29,970 --> 01:08:33,050
the end of flu season, so it's a big deal.

1359
01:08:33,050 --> 01:08:37,350
So if I'm trying to calculate employees
calling in sick, I need to account for

1360
01:08:37,350 --> 01:08:43,200
a higher probability, a higher incidence
of that in January, February, March.

1361
01:08:43,200 --> 01:08:46,460
But then for the rest of summer,
it drops down to normal levels.

1362
01:08:46,460 --> 01:08:49,810
So depending on the day I
look It's gonna be different.

1363
01:08:49,810 --> 01:08:53,260
And so
we may have a probability distribution.

1364
01:08:53,260 --> 01:08:56,770
Things are changing based
on the time frame or

1365
01:08:56,770 --> 01:08:58,900
whatever it is that I'm measuring against.

1366
01:08:58,900 --> 01:09:00,360
So be aware of that.

1367
01:09:00,360 --> 01:09:03,440
You'll see it especially in execution,
when we're executing our project,

1368
01:09:03,440 --> 01:09:05,490
where the real work is getting done.

1369
01:09:05,490 --> 01:09:09,200
Different phases of the project might be
more dangerous or hazardous than others,

1370
01:09:09,200 --> 01:09:11,649
and so we might have higher workers'
comp claims, things of that nature.

1371
01:09:13,630 --> 01:09:19,420
All right, so then we're ready to do
our actual quantitative risk analysis.

1372
01:09:19,420 --> 01:09:23,510
And this can be very simple,
it can also be very complex.

1373
01:09:23,510 --> 01:09:25,260
It can be really hard.

1374
01:09:25,260 --> 01:09:27,690
It's up to you how exact
you want to get on this.

1375
01:09:27,690 --> 01:09:28,470
All right.

1376
01:09:28,470 --> 01:09:31,270
We already have our probability and

1377
01:09:31,270 --> 01:09:36,240
impact and from those we've extrapolated
a risk rating for our risks.

1378
01:09:37,640 --> 01:09:39,840
Now, we need to make
some kind of a decision.

1379
01:09:41,080 --> 01:09:43,640
A decision is going to
center around two things.

1380
01:09:43,640 --> 01:09:48,510
One, what risks should we manage,
and how do we manage them?

1381
01:09:48,510 --> 01:09:52,830
And two, what level of risk does
the project as a whole have?

1382
01:09:52,830 --> 01:09:56,590
And whether or not I should even
move forward with the project.

1383
01:09:56,590 --> 01:09:58,590
All right,
the first one we already talked about.

1384
01:09:58,590 --> 01:10:00,760
We've got a probability and
impact for each of our risks,

1385
01:10:00,760 --> 01:10:04,480
we calculated a risk rating,
now we just need to set a bar and

1386
01:10:04,480 --> 01:10:07,980
say, anything over this number,
we need to plan for.

1387
01:10:07,980 --> 01:10:14,440
So maybe I set that bar at one, anything
with a score over 1.0 I want to deal with.

1388
01:10:14,440 --> 01:10:21,060
So I go back to my spreadsheet and
I look at my risk ratings over here and

1389
01:10:21,060 --> 01:10:27,380
I can see like chance of rain has a 1.6,
host out sick has a 2.5,

1390
01:10:27,380 --> 01:10:31,785
host has car trouble is only .6,
meteor strike is a .9.

1391
01:10:31,785 --> 01:10:36,540
Hurricane 5.6, break in 0.8, so
I say anything over a 1.0 is

1392
01:10:36,540 --> 01:10:41,720
something I wanna deal with, so I'll
need to build a plan for chance of rain.

1393
01:10:41,720 --> 01:10:44,230
I'll need to build a plan for
show host out sick.

1394
01:10:44,230 --> 01:10:46,100
I'll need to build a plan for hurricane.

1395
01:10:46,100 --> 01:10:49,970
But these other things I'm just gonna
do what's called risk acceptance.

1396
01:10:49,970 --> 01:10:52,830
I'm just gonna accept that they can happen
and I'll deal with them when they happen.

1397
01:10:52,830 --> 01:10:55,190
But they're just so either improbable or

1398
01:10:55,190 --> 01:10:58,460
low impact that I'm not
worried about it right?

1399
01:10:58,460 --> 01:11:00,140
But I need to set that bar.

1400
01:11:00,140 --> 01:11:01,710
Where do you set the bar?

1401
01:11:01,710 --> 01:11:03,090
Well there's no formula for that.

1402
01:11:03,090 --> 01:11:04,070
There's no mathematics.

1403
01:11:04,070 --> 01:11:07,620
Well a risk manager has certain
statistical analyses they can do.

1404
01:11:07,620 --> 01:11:12,190
But normally it comes down to your
company's willingness to accept risk.

1405
01:11:12,190 --> 01:11:13,470
Are you risk averse?

1406
01:11:13,470 --> 01:11:15,550
Then you're gonna set this bar very low.

1407
01:11:15,550 --> 01:11:17,140
Are you a risk seeker?

1408
01:11:17,140 --> 01:11:19,270
Then you're gonna set this bar very high.

1409
01:11:19,270 --> 01:11:21,740
Why waste time planning for
risks that aren't likely to happen anyway,

1410
01:11:21,740 --> 01:11:22,910
so I'm just setting the bar high.

1411
01:11:24,150 --> 01:11:28,390
Or, are you risk neutral, you'll evaluate
the likelihood based on each of these and

1412
01:11:28,390 --> 01:11:31,960
you'll start to set the bar
based on the numbers you get.

1413
01:11:31,960 --> 01:11:34,970
Also, what about the risk as a whole,
I only listed six risks.

1414
01:11:34,970 --> 01:11:37,870
But you'll see my spreadsheet,
and I go down to 100.

1415
01:11:37,870 --> 01:11:40,566
When we do a risk analysis on a project,

1416
01:11:40,566 --> 01:11:45,904
it's very common that you can have 50,
100, 200 different risks.

1417
01:11:45,904 --> 01:11:48,729
Every single work package
has some kind of risks.

1418
01:11:48,729 --> 01:11:49,596
Right.

1419
01:11:49,596 --> 01:11:53,170
So you may have a lot of
risks across your project.

1420
01:11:53,170 --> 01:11:57,210
What happens if you total up
all the risk that you have?

1421
01:11:57,210 --> 01:12:01,670
So if we add up these numbers,
and divide it by the total, so,

1422
01:12:01,670 --> 01:12:04,300
I'm gonna have you do an average.

1423
01:12:04,300 --> 01:12:05,470
Is it average?

1424
01:12:05,470 --> 01:12:05,970
Oh it is.

1425
01:12:07,525 --> 01:12:08,381
So, if I use good old Excel here, and

1426
01:12:08,381 --> 01:12:09,524
I'm just gonna do an average
of my risk ratings.

1427
01:12:12,947 --> 01:12:16,755
Okay, I can see my overall
average is a 2.0, right.

1428
01:12:18,205 --> 01:12:23,172
I need to set a bar that says,
when is a project too risky?

1429
01:12:23,172 --> 01:12:26,522
When is there just too
much risk in my project?

1430
01:12:26,522 --> 01:12:29,412
And, there's so much risk that I say, you
know what, I don't wanna do it anymore.

1431
01:12:29,412 --> 01:12:30,582
Let's just cancel that.

1432
01:12:30,582 --> 01:12:32,320
Let's not do that project at all.

1433
01:12:32,320 --> 01:12:38,060
Okay, if there's enough high probability,
high impact risks.

1434
01:12:38,060 --> 01:12:41,670
If there's enough things that
could derail your whole project,

1435
01:12:41,670 --> 01:12:45,610
you need to set a limit that says,
oh I've hit that limit, I am not doing it,

1436
01:12:45,610 --> 01:12:47,080
this project needs to stop.

1437
01:12:47,080 --> 01:12:50,890
There's just too much risk in
the project as a whole, okay.

1438
01:12:50,890 --> 01:12:52,430
Where do you set this bar?

1439
01:12:52,430 --> 01:12:53,770
Again, it depends.

1440
01:12:53,770 --> 01:12:56,860
Are you risk adverse, are you risk seeker,
are you risk neutral.

1441
01:12:56,860 --> 01:13:00,040
This is the kind of thing that you
set up in your risk management plan.

1442
01:13:00,040 --> 01:13:05,950
In your risk management plan,
you might say, anything with a average

1443
01:13:05,950 --> 01:13:10,140
risk rating of 3.0 or
higher, we will not do.

1444
01:13:10,140 --> 01:13:12,818
Unless you can mitigate it,
cuz some of the stuff you can mitigate.

1445
01:13:12,818 --> 01:13:15,630
Some of it you might look at and
you could say, you know what?

1446
01:13:15,630 --> 01:13:17,490
All right.

1447
01:13:17,490 --> 01:13:20,380
There's a chance that a show
host could call out sick.

1448
01:13:20,380 --> 01:13:24,610
So for now on what I'm gonna do is
every time we schedule a show I'm

1449
01:13:24,610 --> 01:13:26,290
gonna schedule three hosts.

1450
01:13:26,290 --> 01:13:27,650
I'll schedule three hosts.

1451
01:13:27,650 --> 01:13:30,590
That way if one calls in sick I
still have two, the show goes on.

1452
01:13:32,320 --> 01:13:35,140
By mitigating that risk
my cost is gonna go up.

1453
01:13:35,140 --> 01:13:37,270
I gotta pay a third person to stand here.

1454
01:13:37,270 --> 01:13:40,430
A third person I might not even use.

1455
01:13:40,430 --> 01:13:43,850
But my show host out sick,
the probability didn't change.

1456
01:13:43,850 --> 01:13:46,080
It's still the same
likelihood of happening but

1457
01:13:46,080 --> 01:13:49,610
now the impact drops to negligible.

1458
01:13:49,610 --> 01:13:52,300
I don't really care if
they're out sick cause

1459
01:13:52,300 --> 01:13:54,490
I've already got the extra
extra person handy.

1460
01:13:54,490 --> 01:14:00,450
So if we see our number is too high,
we make a go, no go, decision.

1461
01:14:01,460 --> 01:14:05,380
Either we go, we run with the project
as it is, or we do a no go,

1462
01:14:05,380 --> 01:14:08,980
and say as it is this
project dead in the water.

1463
01:14:08,980 --> 01:14:11,200
Unless we can get the risk down.

1464
01:14:11,200 --> 01:14:15,100
And we start evaluating our risk
responses, which is the next process, and

1465
01:14:15,100 --> 01:14:16,500
what we can do to lower it.

1466
01:14:16,500 --> 01:14:20,710
Once we lower it, we come back and
we revise our risk.

1467
01:14:20,710 --> 01:14:22,555
Notice back here in my templates.

1468
01:14:24,389 --> 01:14:29,923
That in the Risk Data Sheet,
see how I've got a probability right here,

1469
01:14:29,923 --> 01:14:32,475
and then a revised probability.

1470
01:14:32,475 --> 01:14:33,385
What's that all about?

1471
01:14:33,385 --> 01:14:37,912
Well yeah there was a certain
risk when I first came in and

1472
01:14:37,912 --> 01:14:39,542
flagged this as something to deal with.

1473
01:14:39,542 --> 01:14:42,672
So here it is, this is the risk
as it was in the beginning, but

1474
01:14:42,672 --> 01:14:44,222
our risk was too high.

1475
01:14:44,222 --> 01:14:47,012
So, we took some kind
of action to reduce it.

1476
01:14:47,012 --> 01:14:52,472
So now, here's my revision,
now here's what's the probability, and so

1477
01:14:52,472 --> 01:14:59,030
I go and I update my register,
to show those lower values.

1478
01:14:59,030 --> 01:15:03,460
Now my overall project risk drops down,
and the project moves forward.

1479
01:15:04,530 --> 01:15:07,300
This is the corner stone
of quantitative analysis.

1480
01:15:07,300 --> 01:15:12,700
I don't know this information unless
I'm comparing all of my risks together.

1481
01:15:12,700 --> 01:15:16,390
I might look at it and
have a bunch of mid level risks.

1482
01:15:16,390 --> 01:15:19,010
No one risk by itself
is that big of a deal.

1483
01:15:19,010 --> 01:15:22,026
But what if two risks happen at
the same time, or three, or five, and

1484
01:15:22,026 --> 01:15:24,330
they're all negative risks right,
not positive.

1485
01:15:24,330 --> 01:15:27,040
You want five positive risks
to all happen at once.

1486
01:15:27,040 --> 01:15:29,590
Now what if all those negative
risks happen at the same time.

1487
01:15:29,590 --> 01:15:33,180
Then it can become a high impact event,

1488
01:15:33,180 --> 01:15:37,330
even though none of the risks
by themselves were there.

1489
01:15:37,330 --> 01:15:40,760
By averaging these numbers,
we're taking that into account.

1490
01:15:40,760 --> 01:15:43,890
Right by averaging this together
we're averaging these probabilities,

1491
01:15:43,890 --> 01:15:45,420
we're averaging these impacts.

1492
01:15:45,420 --> 01:15:49,120
And creating something
a little more useful.

1493
01:15:49,120 --> 01:15:53,520
And you could even go further,
you know I do the average of

1494
01:15:55,505 --> 01:15:59,275
the risk rating as a whole, but you could
come up with an average probability,

1495
01:15:59,275 --> 01:16:02,035
and an average impact, and
kind of look at those and

1496
01:16:02,035 --> 01:16:05,285
see just whether you're dealing with
a lot of high level risk or not.

1497
01:16:05,285 --> 01:16:06,755
I find that those numbers are less useful.

1498
01:16:06,755 --> 01:16:08,570
The average of the risk
rating is the most useful.

1499
01:16:09,754 --> 01:16:17,240
All right, so
quantitative risk analysis and modeling.

1500
01:16:17,240 --> 01:16:18,620
That's where we start to look at that.

1501
01:16:18,620 --> 01:16:19,970
What is our overall risk?

1502
01:16:19,970 --> 01:16:23,020
How risky is the project as a whole?

1503
01:16:23,020 --> 01:16:24,470
What's our percentage of failure?

1504
01:16:24,470 --> 01:16:27,570
Right, If we're creating a large
chance of failure on this project,

1505
01:16:27,570 --> 01:16:28,520
we probably need to rein it in.

1506
01:16:30,860 --> 01:16:32,110
Under analysis and

1507
01:16:32,110 --> 01:16:36,798
modeling techniques we do have a few
other things, sensitivity analysis.

1508
01:16:36,798 --> 01:16:42,620
That is how sensitive,
how, I don't want to say,

1509
01:16:42,620 --> 01:16:45,250
I want to say paranoid,
that's not the right word for it.

1510
01:16:45,250 --> 01:16:48,960
But, you know, how risky is our project?

1511
01:16:48,960 --> 01:16:53,380
If we have a lot of high risk stuff,
then it's a very sensitive project.

1512
01:16:53,380 --> 01:16:55,870
Any of those risks could come through and
undermine the project so

1513
01:16:55,870 --> 01:16:58,710
obviously we want, we want projects
that aren't terribly sensitive, that

1514
01:16:58,710 --> 01:17:01,730
are resilient, that if they have failures
it doesn't derail the whole project.

1515
01:17:03,360 --> 01:17:07,290
Expected monetary value analysis.

1516
01:17:07,290 --> 01:17:11,340
This one's is a tough one, we're going
to get into earned value, EVA, and

1517
01:17:11,340 --> 01:17:15,310
all of that good stuff,
in the monitoring and

1518
01:17:15,310 --> 01:17:18,500
controlling phases, so
we're gonna see that a little bit later.

1519
01:17:18,500 --> 01:17:19,800
But basically,

1520
01:17:19,800 --> 01:17:24,640
when you perform a project, the whole
point is to improve your company somehow.

1521
01:17:24,640 --> 01:17:27,880
>> Yep [LAUGH].
>> And typically to make more money.

1522
01:17:27,880 --> 01:17:32,480
And so EMV, the expected monetary value,
that's were we can look at our project and

1523
01:17:32,480 --> 01:17:36,650
come up with what we expect
our financial gain to be.

1524
01:17:36,650 --> 01:17:41,800
And if we have enough risk
we may have to take so many

1525
01:17:41,800 --> 01:17:47,080
mitigating techniques, or steps that
we offset that expected monetary value,

1526
01:17:47,080 --> 01:17:51,160
and that really starts to hurt things.

1527
01:17:51,160 --> 01:17:54,400
So that's a real thing that
a lot of companies deal with.

1528
01:17:54,400 --> 01:17:58,150
Have you ever seen,
you go to a sporting event.

1529
01:17:58,150 --> 01:18:02,920
Baseball, football, hockey, whatever,
and at halftime they bring just your

1530
01:18:02,920 --> 01:18:07,080
average Joe off the street out into
the middle of the field, and they say,

1531
01:18:07,080 --> 01:18:09,380
let's use hockey,
cuz that's a little more international.

1532
01:18:09,380 --> 01:18:12,830
So they stick a guy right in
the center of the rink, and they say,

1533
01:18:12,830 --> 01:18:17,245
if he can shoot the puck
halfway across the the rink and

1534
01:18:17,245 --> 01:18:22,545
get it into this little hole in the goal,
he'll get a million dollars.

1535
01:18:22,545 --> 01:18:25,235
One million dollars, okay?

1536
01:18:25,235 --> 01:18:28,575
Well, if the guy makes it, yeah,
he gets a million dollars.

1537
01:18:28,575 --> 01:18:33,030
Whoever put on that contest is out
a million dollars, but if he misses it he

1538
01:18:33,030 --> 01:18:36,350
doesn't get anything and the company that
put this on just gets great publicity.

1539
01:18:36,350 --> 01:18:37,140
Right?

1540
01:18:37,140 --> 01:18:41,140
So do you think they've got a stack of
a million bucks sitting in the backroom

1541
01:18:41,140 --> 01:18:42,188
waiting for that guy to make it?

1542
01:18:42,188 --> 01:18:46,750
Absolutely not,
instead they buy insurance.

1543
01:18:46,750 --> 01:18:50,140
They buy insurance that
says if this guy makes it,

1544
01:18:50,140 --> 01:18:53,510
the insurance company will pay
that million dollars and not us.

1545
01:18:53,510 --> 01:18:56,400
But if they guy misses it, well we just
pay our insurance premium and that's it.

1546
01:18:56,400 --> 01:19:02,035
And so they reach out to, usually it's
like, what is it, Sotheby's I think.

1547
01:19:02,035 --> 01:19:02,765
Well, no that's not right.

1548
01:19:02,765 --> 01:19:04,865
What's the big-
>> Sounds good to me.

1549
01:19:04,865 --> 01:19:05,655
Lloyd's of London.

1550
01:19:05,655 --> 01:19:08,055
>> Lloyd's of London that's it,
thank you Jason.

1551
01:19:08,055 --> 01:19:11,310
So Lloyd's of London, these guys,
they'll insure anything.

1552
01:19:11,310 --> 01:19:12,390
Anything you can think of.

1553
01:19:12,390 --> 01:19:14,010
And so they run the statistics.

1554
01:19:14,010 --> 01:19:17,820
What are the odds of your average joe
off the street shooting a puck halfway

1555
01:19:17,820 --> 01:19:20,160
across an ice rink and
getting it into a hole this big?

1556
01:19:20,160 --> 01:19:20,730
Right?

1557
01:19:20,730 --> 01:19:26,000
And so they calculate the odds, and
then based on those odds, they calculate

1558
01:19:26,000 --> 01:19:31,670
a dollar value that they can get paid
where they will accept that risk for us.

1559
01:19:31,670 --> 01:19:32,960
It's called risk transference.

1560
01:19:32,960 --> 01:19:35,340
We're transferring the risk
over to the insurance company.

1561
01:19:35,340 --> 01:19:37,370
We're gonna come out some money.

1562
01:19:37,370 --> 01:19:38,945
Let's say it's $100,000, right?

1563
01:19:38,945 --> 01:19:42,896
Let's say that Lloyds looks at it,
and they say, wow,

1564
01:19:42,896 --> 01:19:46,273
there is like a 2% chance
this guy can make it.

1565
01:19:46,273 --> 01:19:47,946
But we're gonna charge you 10%.

1566
01:19:47,946 --> 01:19:48,711
All right?

1567
01:19:48,711 --> 01:19:52,148
So you wanna give away $1 million,
we're gonna charge you $100,000.

1568
01:19:52,148 --> 01:19:54,150
That's what we'll do, all right?

1569
01:19:54,150 --> 01:19:58,100
So if you are Coke or Pepsi, or
whoever is putting this thing on,

1570
01:19:58,100 --> 01:19:59,460
you pay the 100 grand.

1571
01:19:59,460 --> 01:20:03,780
You pay the 100 grand so you don't
have to pay 1 million if it happens.

1572
01:20:03,780 --> 01:20:05,920
And so you pay 100,000,
you're out that money.

1573
01:20:05,920 --> 01:20:10,430
If the guy misses,
Lloyd's just made $100,000.

1574
01:20:10,430 --> 01:20:14,600
And they've got a 98%
chance of that happening.

1575
01:20:14,600 --> 01:20:20,720
But if that guy makes it, then Lloyd's
is out, 900 and whatever $1,000.

1576
01:20:20,720 --> 01:20:26,350
So they're out a ton of money but there
was only a 2% chance it was gonna happen.

1577
01:20:26,350 --> 01:20:26,920
Right.

1578
01:20:26,920 --> 01:20:29,860
That's part of what expected
monetary value analysis.

1579
01:20:29,860 --> 01:20:32,700
Does, is it let's us look at that and
come up with a concept.

1580
01:20:32,700 --> 01:20:34,650
So what do we stand to gain,

1581
01:20:34,650 --> 01:20:39,090
how much do we stand to lose,
what the average outcome will be?

1582
01:20:39,090 --> 01:20:40,960
We're trying to figure that out.

1583
01:20:40,960 --> 01:20:46,160
It all falls under this umbrella
term of analysis under uncertainty.

1584
01:20:46,160 --> 01:20:48,220
We don't know what's gonna happen.

1585
01:20:48,220 --> 01:20:53,240
We don't know if Bob from Akron,
Ohio, whose been a mailman for

1586
01:20:53,240 --> 01:20:57,020
30 years, we don't know if he can shoot
that puck across the ice rink and

1587
01:20:57,020 --> 01:20:59,230
make it, but we gotta take a guess.

1588
01:20:59,230 --> 01:20:59,790
>> Right.

1589
01:20:59,790 --> 01:21:02,950
>> And the better the information we have,
the better off we will be.

1590
01:21:06,050 --> 01:21:10,100
All right, so those are some of the things
that we've gotta keep in mind as we

1591
01:21:10,100 --> 01:21:13,020
deal with Quantitative Risk Analysis.

1592
01:21:13,020 --> 01:21:18,080
We've got our Expert Judgement and then,
at the end of the day, we output our data.

1593
01:21:18,080 --> 01:21:20,630
So, we've got our risk register and

1594
01:21:20,630 --> 01:21:26,320
you may choose to create a risk evaluation
sheet or something of that nature.

1595
01:21:26,320 --> 01:21:31,180
But typically, it's just updates to your
risk register to put that information in.

1596
01:21:31,180 --> 01:21:33,500
Any responses we'll talk about later.

1597
01:21:33,500 --> 01:21:35,730
But you're gonna put in
there any probabilities,

1598
01:21:35,730 --> 01:21:40,270
impacts and any mitigation techniques
that we've got, and that's basically it.

1599
01:21:40,270 --> 01:21:42,050
So I make it sound easy.

1600
01:21:42,050 --> 01:21:42,640
Well, maybe I don't.

1601
01:21:42,640 --> 01:21:44,720
I don't know, in my mind it sounds easy.

1602
01:21:44,720 --> 01:21:47,010
It is easy when you're talking
about one risk, but the problem is,

1603
01:21:47,010 --> 01:21:47,690
you're gonna have a meeting.

1604
01:21:47,690 --> 01:21:48,490
You're gonna sit down, and

1605
01:21:48,490 --> 01:21:51,730
you're gonna come up with
potentially hundreds of risks.

1606
01:21:51,730 --> 01:21:54,540
And so you've gotta go through and
look at each one.

1607
01:21:54,540 --> 01:21:58,290
So while it takes us an hour
to tell you about the process,

1608
01:21:58,290 --> 01:22:01,000
it may take you weeks or even months.

1609
01:22:01,000 --> 01:22:03,800
If you're putting a man on the moon,
it could take years.

1610
01:22:03,800 --> 01:22:06,580
To look at all the risks and
figure them out.

1611
01:22:06,580 --> 01:22:08,140
So, definitely keep that in mind.

1612
01:22:09,810 --> 01:22:14,420
All right, well we've talked a lot about
evaluating our risks, looking at them.

1613
01:22:14,420 --> 01:22:16,720
Now, we need to talk about
what we do to handle it.

1614
01:22:16,720 --> 01:22:19,380
How to get out of a mess if it occurs,
all right?

1615
01:22:19,380 --> 01:22:21,220
So let's stop here and

1616
01:22:21,220 --> 01:22:24,110
take a break because I did go
over our little break timer.

1617
01:22:24,110 --> 01:22:25,130
Let's stop here and take a break.

1618
01:22:25,130 --> 01:22:28,640
And when we get back, we're going to
take a look at our risk response plan.

1619
01:22:28,640 --> 01:22:32,480
Which is probably the most critical
in the different steps here,

1620
01:22:32,480 --> 01:22:33,960
inside of the risk knowledge area.

1621
01:22:33,960 --> 01:22:35,875
So, let's wrap up here and take a break.

1622
01:22:35,875 --> 01:22:38,191
When we get back, risk response plans.

1623
01:22:38,191 --> 01:22:46,310
[SOUND]
All right.

1624
01:22:46,310 --> 01:22:47,670
Welcome back, everybody.

1625
01:22:47,670 --> 01:22:52,300
So, by this point, we have created
a list of all of our project risks.

1626
01:22:52,300 --> 01:22:54,830
We understand the dangers
that are out there.

1627
01:22:54,830 --> 01:22:58,440
We have qualified and
quantified those risks, so

1628
01:22:58,440 --> 01:23:03,790
we've evaluated how significant they are,
whether we need to deal with them.

1629
01:23:03,790 --> 01:23:07,020
So now, we're at the point where
we do the last part which is,

1630
01:23:07,020 --> 01:23:09,190
we figure out how we're
gonna deal with them, right?

1631
01:23:09,190 --> 01:23:11,320
We've got a risk response.

1632
01:23:11,320 --> 01:23:14,680
How we're gonna respond to the risks
in the event that they occur?

1633
01:23:14,680 --> 01:23:18,778
Now, there are responses that we
take if the risk doesn't occur.

1634
01:23:18,778 --> 01:23:21,300
And there's this proactive
responses we take early on, so

1635
01:23:21,300 --> 01:23:24,350
there's all sorts of different
stuff that can happen right here.

1636
01:23:24,350 --> 01:23:27,600
This process is deceptively simple.

1637
01:23:27,600 --> 01:23:30,780
We've just seen some processes
that were pretty heavy, right?

1638
01:23:30,780 --> 01:23:33,990
That had like this guy right here,
13 inputs and all that.

1639
01:23:33,990 --> 01:23:38,620
So this one looks simple but
it's probably the hardest to

1640
01:23:38,620 --> 01:23:42,150
do in real life because there's so
many different ways to solve a problem and

1641
01:23:42,150 --> 01:23:46,240
we've got to figure out which
one is the best for us.

1642
01:23:46,240 --> 01:23:50,890
On our input side, our main input
is going to be our risk register.

1643
01:23:50,890 --> 01:23:52,390
And then we have our Risk Management Plan,

1644
01:23:52,390 --> 01:23:56,440
which is telling us how these things
are available to us, how we can respond.

1645
01:23:56,440 --> 01:23:59,390
What tools are there as an option for us.

1646
01:23:59,390 --> 01:24:01,380
But our risk register is the main input.

1647
01:24:01,380 --> 01:24:03,880
Because it lists all the risks.

1648
01:24:03,880 --> 01:24:07,330
And which ones are significant enough for
us to worry about, all right?

1649
01:24:07,330 --> 01:24:10,490
Now, we need to find out what to do.

1650
01:24:10,490 --> 01:24:13,870
So on our techniques here, our Tools &
Techniques, we've got strategies for

1651
01:24:13,870 --> 01:24:16,980
negative risks, and
strategies for positive risks.

1652
01:24:16,980 --> 01:24:18,580
There's a difference, right?

1653
01:24:18,580 --> 01:24:20,650
Obviously a negative risk,
we don’t want to make it happen,

1654
01:24:20,650 --> 01:24:24,050
so anything we do is trying
to minimize that occurrence.

1655
01:24:24,050 --> 01:24:27,140
But a positive risk,
we do want to happen so

1656
01:24:27,140 --> 01:24:30,580
any response that we take there is trying
to make it better and better, right?

1657
01:24:30,580 --> 01:24:33,180
What is the most likely
way we can do that.

1658
01:24:33,180 --> 01:24:36,010
So let's talk a little bit about those and

1659
01:24:36,010 --> 01:24:38,820
Ronnie threw out some good
notes here on this one.

1660
01:24:38,820 --> 01:24:43,060
On a negative risk, there's really
four different responses, right?

1661
01:24:43,060 --> 01:24:48,390
Avoid, transfer, mitigate, accept,
let's talk about each one.

1662
01:24:48,390 --> 01:24:53,400
Avoid, you can take a look at a risk and
say this risk exists,

1663
01:24:53,400 --> 01:24:57,040
what can I do to 100%
completely eliminate it?

1664
01:24:57,040 --> 01:24:57,540
Alright.

1665
01:24:58,540 --> 01:25:01,660
So I'm planning an outdoor rock concert.

1666
01:25:01,660 --> 01:25:02,700
There's a chance it could rain.

1667
01:25:02,700 --> 01:25:04,760
I'm worried about that.

1668
01:25:04,760 --> 01:25:10,290
So instead of trying to reduce the chance
of rain, which is hard to do, right?

1669
01:25:10,290 --> 01:25:11,880
Yeah, I imagine it's possible.

1670
01:25:11,880 --> 01:25:14,530
I could instead say,
you know what, forget it.

1671
01:25:14,530 --> 01:25:15,740
Let's have an indoor.

1672
01:25:15,740 --> 01:25:20,270
We move that rock concert indoor and
when we do that, we just avoided the risk.

1673
01:25:20,270 --> 01:25:21,350
The risk is gone.

1674
01:25:21,350 --> 01:25:23,570
I no longer have the risk.

1675
01:25:23,570 --> 01:25:26,550
It could still rain,
that could still happen.

1676
01:25:26,550 --> 01:25:29,000
But it no longer affects
my project in any way.

1677
01:25:29,000 --> 01:25:31,300
I've completely avoided the risk.

1678
01:25:32,890 --> 01:25:36,360
This is the nicest, right,
because it does eliminate the risk, but

1679
01:25:36,360 --> 01:25:39,230
it's also not always possible.

1680
01:25:39,230 --> 01:25:44,650
If I have to get some stuff transported
from one city to another and

1681
01:25:44,650 --> 01:25:49,700
it's going in truck, there is a risk
the truck could be in an accident, right?

1682
01:25:49,700 --> 01:25:50,790
How can I avoid that?

1683
01:25:50,790 --> 01:25:52,100
Well, I really can't.

1684
01:25:52,100 --> 01:25:54,460
I've got to get this stuff
from one city to another.

1685
01:25:54,460 --> 01:25:56,110
I could fly it, I could send it by train.

1686
01:25:56,110 --> 01:25:58,230
But they all have a risk
of being an accident.

1687
01:25:58,230 --> 01:25:59,540
And they're a lot more expensive.

1688
01:25:59,540 --> 01:26:02,250
So, I may have to use that truck.

1689
01:26:02,250 --> 01:26:04,760
So I might not be able to avoid, and

1690
01:26:04,760 --> 01:26:08,430
in those cases we start to move
into some of the other options.

1691
01:26:08,430 --> 01:26:09,790
We've got transfer.

1692
01:26:09,790 --> 01:26:13,620
Risk transference, I talked about in
the last segment is buying insurance.

1693
01:26:13,620 --> 01:26:15,330
Normally, is how it is.

1694
01:26:15,330 --> 01:26:17,550
This is where you say,
all right, the risk is there.

1695
01:26:17,550 --> 01:26:19,200
Not much I can do about it.

1696
01:26:19,200 --> 01:26:22,860
Let me put the negative
effects off on somebody else.

1697
01:26:22,860 --> 01:26:25,640
When you buy car insurance,
health insurance,

1698
01:26:25,640 --> 01:26:30,490
any kind of insurance, you're playing,
what is it Black Jack?

1699
01:26:30,490 --> 01:26:33,300
And you buy dealer's insurance
when they lay out a ten card?

1700
01:26:33,300 --> 01:26:36,310
Well in those scenarios,
you're saying there's some

1701
01:26:36,310 --> 01:26:40,380
risks here that I’m going to lose,
let me push it off on somebody else.

1702
01:26:40,380 --> 01:26:42,870
And the tradeoff is
that you're paying them

1703
01:26:42,870 --> 01:26:45,700
in the event that the risk doesn't occur,
they just keep that money, right?

1704
01:26:45,700 --> 01:26:48,940
And they make money betting
on it not happening,

1705
01:26:48,940 --> 01:26:50,750
you're paying them in case it does happen.

1706
01:26:50,750 --> 01:26:52,790
You’re both just betting different ways.

1707
01:26:52,790 --> 01:26:54,360
The odds are stacked in their favor.

1708
01:26:54,360 --> 01:26:56,610
The odds are always stacked in
the insurance company's favor.

1709
01:26:56,610 --> 01:27:00,900
But boy, you'll be glad you had it
if that risk comes to fruition.

1710
01:27:00,900 --> 01:27:03,000
So we definitely wanna be aware of that,

1711
01:27:03,000 --> 01:27:04,750
and transference is one
of the most common.

1712
01:27:04,750 --> 01:27:08,510
Now, key thing to remember about
transference for the exam.

1713
01:27:08,510 --> 01:27:10,770
If you transfer the risk to somebody else,

1714
01:27:10,770 --> 01:27:14,780
does that reduce
the probability of that risk?

1715
01:27:14,780 --> 01:27:15,570
No.

1716
01:27:15,570 --> 01:27:18,180
Does it reduce the impact of the risk?

1717
01:27:18,180 --> 01:27:18,760
Not really.

1718
01:27:18,760 --> 01:27:21,680
It does a little bit in that at least it's
not you having to pay out that money.

1719
01:27:21,680 --> 01:27:23,680
You don't have to set up a cash reserve.

1720
01:27:23,680 --> 01:27:26,370
But it's still gonna be impactful.

1721
01:27:26,370 --> 01:27:28,250
So those are things that you have.

1722
01:27:28,250 --> 01:27:29,410
In a business like this, so

1723
01:27:29,410 --> 01:27:33,800
here at ITProTV we have what we
call key man insurance policies.

1724
01:27:33,800 --> 01:27:38,080
The assumption is,
if I'm a host of a show and

1725
01:27:38,080 --> 01:27:40,940
I get in a car accident and
let's say I'm out, right?

1726
01:27:40,940 --> 01:27:41,920
Or something happens.

1727
01:27:41,920 --> 01:27:45,241
I catch some rare malarian plague or
something like that.

1728
01:27:45,241 --> 01:27:47,702
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I'm just, I'm done for, right?

1729
01:27:47,702 --> 01:27:49,560
Does that affect the show?

1730
01:27:49,560 --> 01:27:50,282
Yeah.

1731
01:27:50,282 --> 01:27:53,506
So we have a key man policy that says hey,
if this person backs off,

1732
01:27:53,506 --> 01:27:57,363
then we need some money to compensate
that, so we can hire somebody better, and

1733
01:27:57,363 --> 01:27:59,398
send Nate to acting school or something.

1734
01:27:59,398 --> 01:28:02,820
[LAUGH] And get the show going that way.

1735
01:28:02,820 --> 01:28:06,670
So that's great but
we still lost the host.

1736
01:28:06,670 --> 01:28:08,260
Right, I'm still out of commission.

1737
01:28:08,260 --> 01:28:09,910
So we still have to deal with that.

1738
01:28:09,910 --> 01:28:12,221
But at least the money makes
you feel a little better.

1739
01:28:12,221 --> 01:28:15,291
[LAUGH] So,
keep that in mind with risk transference.

1740
01:28:15,291 --> 01:28:18,270
It often times has zero
effect on probability.

1741
01:28:18,270 --> 01:28:21,540
And it has a minimal effect on impact.

1742
01:28:21,540 --> 01:28:23,090
So, those are still there.

1743
01:28:23,090 --> 01:28:24,610
At least we get monetary compensation.

1744
01:28:25,980 --> 01:28:27,580
All right, mitigate.

1745
01:28:27,580 --> 01:28:30,060
Mitigate is the one that
we might most commonly do.

1746
01:28:30,060 --> 01:28:33,990
With mitigate we say all right, we can't
really transfer this to somebody else,

1747
01:28:33,990 --> 01:28:35,300
we can't avoid it.

1748
01:28:35,300 --> 01:28:39,990
Let's just try to reduce
the probability as much as possible.

1749
01:28:39,990 --> 01:28:46,420
That outdoor rock concert in Florida,
we have a very pronounced rain season.

1750
01:28:46,420 --> 01:28:52,149
It starts raining here sometime in March
and it pretty much rains through May.

1751
01:28:52,149 --> 01:28:54,940
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> It really [LAUGH]

1752
01:28:54,940 --> 01:28:56,580
>> We get a lot of rain right here, and

1753
01:28:56,580 --> 01:28:58,160
then it does the same thing
at the end of summer,

1754
01:28:58,160 --> 01:29:02,620
so from the end of July through
about September, it rains.

1755
01:29:02,620 --> 01:29:05,040
So if I put on a rock
concert in those months,

1756
01:29:05,040 --> 01:29:07,010
there's a pretty good chance
I'm gonna get rained out.

1757
01:29:07,010 --> 01:29:11,690
Right, if I put on the concert on
in November or I put it on in July,

1758
01:29:11,690 --> 01:29:14,710
odds are it's not going to rain.

1759
01:29:14,710 --> 01:29:17,590
Right?
I can improve my chances of having a dry

1760
01:29:17,590 --> 01:29:19,950
concert by picking which
month I put it in.

1761
01:29:19,950 --> 01:29:21,450
That's mitigating.

1762
01:29:21,450 --> 01:29:24,340
I'm not eliminating it there is
still a chance it's going to rain.

1763
01:29:24,340 --> 01:29:29,030
But I reduce that probability, right.

1764
01:29:29,030 --> 01:29:32,830
What are some other
examples of mitigating.

1765
01:29:32,830 --> 01:29:37,770
Actually I gave an example earlier,
which was, if we have two show hosts.

1766
01:29:37,770 --> 01:29:40,530
And one calls in sick,
Ronnie, calls in sick.

1767
01:29:40,530 --> 01:29:43,230
I'm gonna stand up here by myself,
it affects the show.

1768
01:29:43,230 --> 01:29:44,940
But what if I book a third host?

1769
01:29:44,940 --> 01:29:47,050
>> I have a third host ready, standing by.

1770
01:29:47,050 --> 01:29:48,700
Waiting to jump up here if we need them.

1771
01:29:48,700 --> 01:29:49,390
All right?

1772
01:29:49,390 --> 01:29:52,330
And if Ronnie calls in sick,
that other person jumps in and off we go.

1773
01:29:52,330 --> 01:29:53,130
Ronnie was still sick.

1774
01:29:53,130 --> 01:29:54,130
That happened.

1775
01:29:54,130 --> 01:29:56,500
But I've got a back up plan, right?

1776
01:29:56,500 --> 01:29:59,420
I guess it's more of
a contingency than a mitigation.

1777
01:29:59,420 --> 01:30:03,080
A better example of mitigation might
be that I give everybody flue shots.

1778
01:30:03,080 --> 01:30:03,970
>> Yes
>> All right?

1779
01:30:03,970 --> 01:30:05,730
I know that we might get sick.

1780
01:30:05,730 --> 01:30:10,820
And so maybe, as a company, ITProTV
decides to go ahead and pay for flu shots.

1781
01:30:10,820 --> 01:30:14,230
We're gonna pay for Ronnie, and
Nate, and Mike, and Wes, and

1782
01:30:14,230 --> 01:30:18,020
then everybody who's on the show,
Jason, everybody get's a flu shot.

1783
01:30:19,180 --> 01:30:22,520
I'm willing to pay that because it will
reduce the chance of them getting sick.

1784
01:30:22,520 --> 01:30:23,800
I'm mitigating that.

1785
01:30:25,760 --> 01:30:26,460
All right.

1786
01:30:26,460 --> 01:30:29,040
And then the last one is accept.

1787
01:30:29,040 --> 01:30:32,470
Accept is what we do when we're saying,

1788
01:30:32,470 --> 01:30:34,480
this is just a low
probability of occurring.

1789
01:30:34,480 --> 01:30:37,060
Right, so I'm going to go ahead and
accept the risk.

1790
01:30:37,060 --> 01:30:38,465
I'm not gonna do anything.

1791
01:30:38,465 --> 01:30:41,655
I know that there's a chance that

1792
01:30:41,655 --> 01:30:44,945
Jason's car might break down on
the way to work tomorrow, right?

1793
01:30:44,945 --> 01:30:47,295
I know the odds are increased,
cuz it's, what is it, 18 years old?

1794
01:30:47,295 --> 01:30:48,299
So.
[LAUGH] So

1795
01:30:48,299 --> 01:30:50,462
the odds are somewhat increased.

1796
01:30:50,462 --> 01:30:52,344
I'm not gonna do anything about it, right?

1797
01:30:52,344 --> 01:30:56,087
I'm not gonna do anything about it,
because tomorrow, I know that Ronnie and

1798
01:30:56,087 --> 01:30:57,800
I are gonna be the hosts of the show.

1799
01:30:57,800 --> 01:31:01,437
And I know that I can always get Nate,
our producer, to jump in and

1800
01:31:01,437 --> 01:31:05,605
cover Jason until he gets in, so we
kind of already have things in place, so

1801
01:31:05,605 --> 01:31:07,217
I'm not gonna do anything.

So, those are some of techniques

That’s our risks response,
