2028
01:42:12,940 --> 01:42:14,850
And that information
all goes right in here.

2029
01:42:14,850 --> 01:42:17,920
Do we have contingency funds and
contingency time?

2030
01:42:17,920 --> 01:42:19,930
Think of that as reserves.

2031
01:42:19,930 --> 01:42:23,740
What's our reserve time, reserve budget,
in the event that this occurs?

2032
01:42:23,740 --> 01:42:28,030
We go and we update this, and if we
identified 100 risks, we have to go and

2033
01:42:28,030 --> 01:42:29,830
update 100 of these sheets.

2034
01:42:29,830 --> 01:42:31,330
It's a lot of work.

2035
01:42:31,330 --> 01:42:33,970
So, we've got to get into that,
we've got to get that knocked down.

2036
01:42:33,970 --> 01:42:35,060
So, it is a lot.

2037
01:42:35,060 --> 01:42:38,890
And you'll see the other things listed
here, budget and schedule activities.

2038
01:42:38,890 --> 01:42:40,310
We've got to account for that.

2039
01:42:41,440 --> 01:42:45,645
Any of our fallback plans are residual
risks that might happen, right?

2040
01:42:45,645 --> 01:42:48,055
What's an example of a residual risk?

2041
01:42:48,055 --> 01:42:54,115
Well, if one employee gets sick, and
we fall behind schedule, one activity

2042
01:42:54,115 --> 01:42:58,050
falling behind schedule could cause other
activities to fall behind schedule.

2043
01:42:58,050 --> 01:43:01,570
One employee getting sick could lead
to other employees getting sick.

2044
01:43:01,570 --> 01:43:02,770
You got an epidemic, right?

2045
01:43:02,770 --> 01:43:04,485
Like in that Dustin Hoffman film.

2046
01:43:04,485 --> 01:43:05,838
>> [LAUGH]
>> And before you know it you're all

2047
01:43:05,838 --> 01:43:06,882
wearing the yellow suits.

2048
01:43:06,882 --> 01:43:08,056
>> That's right.

2049
01:43:08,056 --> 01:43:09,920
>> And it's all gone crazy.
>> Looking for monkeys.

2050
01:43:09,920 --> 01:43:10,590
>> That's right.

2051
01:43:10,590 --> 01:43:13,320
Once you bring the monkeys into
it then it's an absolute mess.

2052
01:43:13,320 --> 01:43:17,750
So, those are examples of residual and
secondary risks,

2053
01:43:17,750 --> 01:43:20,900
sometimes one risk is linked to another.

2054
01:43:20,900 --> 01:43:23,320
If we have a hurricane,
we may have floods,

2055
01:43:23,320 --> 01:43:27,850
we may have decreased sales these
are all things that might be risks.

2056
01:43:27,850 --> 01:43:30,210
You might have risks that
are completely out of left field.

2057
01:43:30,210 --> 01:43:34,960
Like your projects moving forward and
a competitor moves in and opens up.

2058
01:43:34,960 --> 01:43:38,890
Or a competitor launches a similar
product ahead of yours right.

2059
01:43:38,890 --> 01:43:41,340
All of a sudden the entire
playing field changes.

2060
01:43:41,340 --> 01:43:43,110
So we've got to plan for all of that.

2061
01:43:43,110 --> 01:43:48,770
And it creates a lot of a paperwork
that comes out of our projects.

2062
01:43:48,770 --> 01:43:53,460
This is the smallest of our processes but,

2063
01:43:53,460 --> 01:43:56,970
it's descepting because it's
probably the most work.

2064
01:43:56,970 --> 01:43:58,050
>> Right.

2065
01:43:58,050 --> 01:44:02,660
>> But if you plan for this now, if you
get your risk strategies in place now

2066
01:44:02,660 --> 01:44:07,140
while you're in planning, when you get
into execution, you can sleep easy.

2067
01:44:07,140 --> 01:44:10,540
Because if a problem occurs,
you've already thought about it.

2068
01:44:10,540 --> 01:44:13,840
You've already planned for
what you're gonna do, and you act on it.

2069
01:44:13,840 --> 01:44:17,140
You don't have to do change tickets cuz
you've already got the plan in place.

2070
01:44:17,140 --> 01:44:20,735
You're just following the instructions
you've already except four, all right?

2071
01:44:20,735 --> 01:44:22,485
So very good stuff.

2072
01:44:22,485 --> 01:44:25,485
This is why risk managers are so valuable.

2073
01:44:25,485 --> 01:44:28,495
I hear people make fun of risk
managers from time to time because

2074
01:44:28,495 --> 01:44:31,595
if the risks never happen, what does
the risk manager really do, right?

2075
01:44:31,595 --> 01:44:35,690
But man, they're doing a very
important service in your company, and

2076
01:44:35,690 --> 01:44:39,120
they're basically making sure that you're
insulated from the problems that could

2077
01:44:39,120 --> 01:44:40,570
lead to your project failing.

2078
01:44:40,570 --> 01:44:41,540
So very very valuable.

2079
01:44:43,140 --> 01:44:44,020
All right.

2080
01:44:44,020 --> 01:44:46,130
Well, I think that pretty
much wraps up risk.

2081
01:44:46,130 --> 01:44:48,920
Ronnie, can you think of
anything I've left out.

2082
01:44:48,920 --> 01:44:50,360
>> Nope, I cannot. [LAUGH] >> All right,

2083
01:44:50,360 --> 01:44:56,140
well we just have a little bit more
to go in our planning processes.

2084
01:44:56,140 --> 01:44:58,870
We'll see procurement management,
which is our contracts.

2085
01:44:58,870 --> 01:45:01,890
And our stakeholder management,
which is attaching and

2086
01:45:01,890 --> 01:45:03,060
removing people from a project.

2087
01:45:03,060 --> 01:45:05,280
So, we're gonna see a little bit of those,
but

2088
01:45:05,280 --> 01:45:05,970
we're pretty much
>> Right

2089
01:45:05,970 --> 01:45:07,450
>> ready to jump into execution there, so

2090
01:45:07,450 --> 01:45:10,730
we'll have one more short episode for
planning, and

2091
01:45:10,730 --> 01:45:13,530
we're gonna jump into execution,
really start to see some things take off.

2092
01:45:13,530 --> 01:45:16,630
So, definitely stay tuned for that.

2093
01:45:16,630 --> 01:45:19,200
But otherwise,
if you guys have any questions,

2094
01:45:19,200 --> 01:45:23,160
let me just remind you, Live during
the show you can go to itpro.tv/live.

2095
01:45:23,160 --> 01:45:25,690
You'll see our chat box beneath the video.

2096
01:45:25,690 --> 01:45:26,650
Post your questions there.

2097
01:45:26,650 --> 01:45:30,220
We monitor and answer,
wanna make sure you get the help you need.

2098
01:45:30,220 --> 01:45:33,130
Also if you have questions after the show,

2099
01:45:33,130 --> 01:45:35,470
if you're watching this
recorded Use the Q & A form.

2100
01:45:35,470 --> 01:45:39,070
You'll see a link at the top of
the page that says Q & A click on that.

2101
01:45:39,070 --> 01:45:40,520
It will take you to the forms.

2102
01:45:40,520 --> 01:45:42,610
Post your questions there we monitor and
answer.

2103
01:45:42,610 --> 01:45:45,928
We want to make sure you get the help you
need so you're prepared for that exam.

2104
01:45:45,928 --> 01:45:46,733
>> Right.
>> And you're prepared for

2105
01:45:46,733 --> 01:45:47,392
managing that project.

2106
01:45:47,392 --> 01:45:49,180
All right.

2107
01:45:49,180 --> 01:45:50,320
I hope you guys have enjoyed the show.

2108
01:45:50,320 --> 01:45:52,835
Signing off for IT Pro Tv, I'm Don Pezet.

2109
01:45:52,835 --> 01:45:53,422
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

2110
01:45:53,422 --> 01:45:57,970
>> And we will see

2111
01:45:57,970 --> 01:46:02,899
you next time.

2112
01:46:02,899 --> 01:46:06,277
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at areas procurement management. They focus on contract execution, fulfillment and termination. They also show the most common contract types. Included in the episode are the concepts of stakeholder management and dealing with the motivations and agendas of stakeholders.
episodes.title: Procurements and Stakeholders
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:14,978 --> 00:00:22,375
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,375 --> 00:00:32,375
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,438 --> 00:00:36,820
All right, good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening and welcome back.

5
00:00:36,820 --> 00:00:38,260
To another episode of IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:38,260 --> 00:00:39,558
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

7
00:00:39,558 --> 00:00:41,180
Today with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:41,180 --> 00:00:41,970
How's it going Ronnie?

9
00:00:41,970 --> 00:00:43,460
>> I'm not doing too well this morning.

10
00:00:43,460 --> 00:00:46,790
I lost the retainer for
the Beastie Boys and

11
00:00:46,790 --> 00:00:50,290
suing everybody because
they are using the music.

12
00:00:50,290 --> 00:00:52,455
>> So you are becoming
an entertainment industry attorney?

13
00:00:52,455 --> 00:00:53,840
>> Apparently.
>> Or are we talking about

14
00:00:53,840 --> 00:00:54,600
a dental retainer?

15
00:00:54,600 --> 00:00:57,290
>> Both.
[LAUGH] You don't want your teeth

16
00:00:57,290 --> 00:00:59,672
to drift after you get
them straightened out.

17
00:00:59,672 --> 00:01:02,870
[LAUGH] All right,
well ladies and gentlemen,

18
00:01:02,870 --> 00:01:06,290
we've got the last of our
planning phase in this episode.

19
00:01:06,290 --> 00:01:08,400
By this point you're probably
asking yourself, good God,

20
00:01:08,400 --> 00:01:10,640
how much longer are they
gonna talk about planning?

21
00:01:10,640 --> 00:01:12,740
Well, it is important.

22
00:01:12,740 --> 00:01:13,740
I can't stress that enough.

23
00:01:13,740 --> 00:01:15,270
So, we want to make sure
that we're thorough.

24
00:01:15,270 --> 00:01:19,560
We have the last two processes
to jump into this time around.

25
00:01:19,560 --> 00:01:24,960
So, let me bring up my old trusty PMBOK
bot and we will get into the last two.

26
00:01:24,960 --> 00:01:29,250
Now the last two aren't very long and
some of them are actually kind of new.

27
00:01:29,250 --> 00:01:30,960
Let's see where did I put that?

28
00:01:30,960 --> 00:01:31,970
There we go.
Okay.

29
00:01:31,970 --> 00:01:35,350
So if we take a look at our planning
process group a lot of these are very

30
00:01:35,350 --> 00:01:36,000
very old.

31
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:39,380
They've been around in the PMBOK since
Version 1 which is before my time.

32
00:01:39,380 --> 00:01:43,380
I started with Version three And
you know, then version four came out and

33
00:01:43,380 --> 00:01:44,820
now we're on version five.

34
00:01:44,820 --> 00:01:49,340
Well, one of the things that was added in
version four, so it's one that's only been

35
00:01:49,340 --> 00:01:54,190
around for a few years,
is the procurement management, the whole

36
00:01:54,190 --> 00:01:57,010
knowledge area really, everything
associated with that was kinda new.

37
00:01:57,010 --> 00:01:59,000
About the plan procurement management.

38
00:01:59,000 --> 00:02:01,560
This is talking about contracts.

39
00:02:01,560 --> 00:02:05,010
So how we handle contracts inside of
our project that used to be done just

40
00:02:05,010 --> 00:02:07,930
underneath costs and then it was
branched out in the fourth edition.

41
00:02:07,930 --> 00:02:11,980
So now that we're in the fifth
edition of the PMBOK this is

42
00:02:11,980 --> 00:02:15,440
a well-established standard now, so it's
something you're expected to understand.

43
00:02:15,440 --> 00:02:19,250
They gave us some leniency under the
fourth edition saying, well some people

44
00:02:19,250 --> 00:02:21,990
might have learned it some way versus
another, so we'll give them a break.

45
00:02:21,990 --> 00:02:24,730
No more breaks,
right now you gotta know it this way.

46
00:02:24,730 --> 00:02:27,380
So we're gonna take a look
at procurement management.

47
00:02:27,380 --> 00:02:31,330
And then we're gonna wrap up talking
about stakeholder management.

48
00:02:31,330 --> 00:02:35,520
I know we've addressed that
a little bit because this is one of

49
00:02:35,520 --> 00:02:40,420
the few that had a process in
the initiation process group.

50
00:02:40,420 --> 00:02:43,350
So identify stakeholders,
we've already done.

51
00:02:43,350 --> 00:02:46,590
Now we're figuring out how we're
gonna manage the stakeholders,

52
00:02:46,590 --> 00:02:49,850
changing them, adding new ones,
making modifications and so on.

53
00:02:49,850 --> 00:02:53,080
So we'll get a chance to see that,
that's what we've got lined up today.

54
00:02:53,080 --> 00:02:57,370
Once that's done, then planning is over,
right, we're done!

55
00:02:57,370 --> 00:03:00,750
Then we get to move on over
into our execution and

56
00:03:00,750 --> 00:03:02,960
monitoring control which is pretty big.

57
00:03:04,090 --> 00:03:07,640
Let's take a look at planning
procurement management.

58
00:03:09,310 --> 00:03:11,130
First off, that word procurement.

59
00:03:11,130 --> 00:03:13,400
Procurement just means getting something.

60
00:03:13,400 --> 00:03:17,030
Whenever you go and get something,
it might be for free, who knows.

61
00:03:17,030 --> 00:03:20,470
But when you procure something
is when you secure it or

62
00:03:20,470 --> 00:03:23,200
obtain it to be able to
use within your project.

63
00:03:23,200 --> 00:03:27,520
In the terms of the PMBOK,
it's typically referring to a contract.

64
00:03:27,520 --> 00:03:29,970
And that contract might
be a time-based contract,

65
00:03:29,970 --> 00:03:32,990
like you're hiring somebody to come and
do some work over time.

66
00:03:32,990 --> 00:03:35,850
Or might be an outright purchase,
I'm buying a computer.

67
00:03:35,850 --> 00:03:39,720
There's not really a time associated
with that, we buy the computer and

68
00:03:39,720 --> 00:03:42,070
now it's ours, we don't pay for
it and it's not ours.

69
00:03:42,070 --> 00:03:44,690
That's pretty much it on and
off, it works or it doesn't.

70
00:03:45,950 --> 00:03:48,790
As opposed to, getting somebody
to come and do labor for us, or

71
00:03:48,790 --> 00:03:51,550
we've got to monitor that and
make sure that it happens.

72
00:03:51,550 --> 00:03:54,750
Either the computers we've bought show up,
or they don't.

73
00:03:54,750 --> 00:03:57,700
So when we enter into
any kind of contract,

74
00:03:57,700 --> 00:04:01,130
be it a purchase or an ongoing service.

75
00:04:01,130 --> 00:04:03,670
There's a lot of stuff that
we have to put into play.

76
00:04:03,670 --> 00:04:06,500
And contracts at least
in the United States and

77
00:04:06,500 --> 00:04:09,640
I know in most countries
are legally binding.

78
00:04:09,640 --> 00:04:14,400
When you enter into a contract you and
another party are agreeing to something.

79
00:04:14,400 --> 00:04:18,130
And if one of you doesn't
live up to your obligation

80
00:04:18,130 --> 00:04:19,920
there's usually a penalty associated.

81
00:04:19,920 --> 00:04:22,350
If there's no penalty you may as
well not have a contract, right?

82
00:04:22,350 --> 00:04:25,070
But there's usually a penalty
associated with it.

83
00:04:25,070 --> 00:04:27,180
So when we talk about
procurement management,

84
00:04:27,180 --> 00:04:29,870
we're not just talking about
creating the contract.

85
00:04:29,870 --> 00:04:33,720
We're talking about how we monitor it,
ensure people live up to it,

86
00:04:33,720 --> 00:04:37,120
how we penalize if they
fail to honor the contract.

87
00:04:37,120 --> 00:04:41,280
And then how we terminate the contract
when it's all said and done.

88
00:04:41,280 --> 00:04:44,990
And so
we'll see a little bit of that as we go.

89
00:04:46,552 --> 00:04:49,190
All right, couple of terms
you wanna be familiar with.

90
00:04:49,190 --> 00:04:53,090
When we talk about contracts,
you can execute a contract, and

91
00:04:53,090 --> 00:04:54,660
you can terminate a contract.

92
00:04:54,660 --> 00:04:59,260
Now, if In our common language,
if I say I'm going to execute Ronnie or

93
00:04:59,260 --> 00:05:03,210
if I'm going to terminate Ronnie,
pretty much means the same thing.

94
00:05:03,210 --> 00:05:05,510
Right?
So but in the contract world it doesn't.

95
00:05:05,510 --> 00:05:07,560
Executing the contract
means you're signing it.

96
00:05:07,560 --> 00:05:08,930
You're making it active.

97
00:05:08,930 --> 00:05:10,820
So, it's now ready to execute.

98
00:05:10,820 --> 00:05:14,960
It's ready to move into our execution
phase where it's actually going to occur.

99
00:05:14,960 --> 00:05:18,520
Terminating it means we end the contract,
and

100
00:05:18,520 --> 00:05:20,850
normally we end it because
it's been fulfilled.

101
00:05:20,850 --> 00:05:22,880
Everything we asked for has been done.

102
00:05:22,880 --> 00:05:26,040
Contract terms have been met,
we terminate the contract.

103
00:05:26,040 --> 00:05:26,610
Right?

104
00:05:26,610 --> 00:05:30,130
But you can also terminate a contract for
other things like breach of contract.

105
00:05:30,130 --> 00:05:33,560
Maybe there's been a fundamental breach
and the contract cant continue so

106
00:05:33,560 --> 00:05:34,770
then we terminate there.

107
00:05:34,770 --> 00:05:39,470
So in our Procurement Management Process,
we are trying to establish that

108
00:05:39,470 --> 00:05:43,630
process of how we go about executing and
terminating the contracts.

109
00:05:43,630 --> 00:05:47,400
What things need to be aware and
what people need to be involved.

110
00:05:47,400 --> 00:05:51,020
And I'm the first person to admit,
I am terrible at writing contracts.

111
00:05:51,020 --> 00:05:52,490
I'm not an attorney, right?

112
00:05:52,490 --> 00:05:54,080
I don't know the stuff to put in there.

113
00:05:54,080 --> 00:05:57,920
So anytime I deal with a contract,
I bring in a legal department, right?

114
00:05:57,920 --> 00:06:00,450
If you're fortunate enough
to work at an agency or

115
00:06:00,450 --> 00:06:02,960
company that has a legal department,
you can use that.

116
00:06:02,960 --> 00:06:05,250
If you don't you need one on retainer.

117
00:06:05,250 --> 00:06:06,950
Somebody you can take that contract to.

118
00:06:06,950 --> 00:06:09,960
Somebody who specializes in
contract law who can evaluate it.

119
00:06:09,960 --> 00:06:13,750
Ensure that the proper clauses are in
there to protect your company and

120
00:06:13,750 --> 00:06:14,540
to protect your interests.

121
00:06:16,136 --> 00:06:17,020
All right so

122
00:06:17,020 --> 00:06:21,460
If we're going to be doing that kind
of activity we need a lot of data.

123
00:06:21,460 --> 00:06:24,630
This is another one where
it's not as bad as some.

124
00:06:24,630 --> 00:06:25,741
I don't have 13 inputs.

125
00:06:25,741 --> 00:06:27,950
>> [LAUGH]
>> But we have a lot of inputs here.

126
00:06:27,950 --> 00:06:30,314
The key ones that we're concerned about,

127
00:06:30,314 --> 00:06:34,670
are our requirements augmentation
because that says what we need done.

128
00:06:34,670 --> 00:06:37,050
Either what equipment we need to buy or

129
00:06:37,050 --> 00:06:40,980
what work needs to be done
to fulfill our needs.

130
00:06:40,980 --> 00:06:46,145
And then our risk register, which is gonna
tell us, any potential shortfalls or

131
00:06:46,145 --> 00:06:49,005
issues that we might have, that we
might need to build another contract.

132
00:06:49,005 --> 00:06:52,735
Those are the two most important
inputs when it comes to planning for

133
00:06:52,735 --> 00:06:53,905
current management.

134
00:06:53,905 --> 00:06:55,805
But see this a lot more, right?

135
00:06:55,805 --> 00:06:58,205
Activity resource requirements.

136
00:06:58,205 --> 00:07:00,795
If I'm planning to drywall a house,

137
00:07:00,795 --> 00:07:03,665
I know I can bring a contractor
in to do that drywall, right?

138
00:07:03,665 --> 00:07:05,565
But if they send me just one person,

139
00:07:05,565 --> 00:07:07,770
it's gonna take them a lot
longer to get it done.

140
00:07:07,770 --> 00:07:11,510
So I need to make sure that I specify
in my contract exactly how many

141
00:07:11,510 --> 00:07:15,020
technicians or dry wall installers or
whatever they're called that I need so

142
00:07:15,020 --> 00:07:17,470
that I can get it done in
the amount of time that I've got.

143
00:07:17,470 --> 00:07:21,110
So our resource requirements listed
on our activities will tell us that.

144
00:07:21,110 --> 00:07:23,526
Right?
So that's another input that we have.

145
00:07:23,526 --> 00:07:24,383
Our project schedule.

146
00:07:24,383 --> 00:07:29,220
Now our project schedule is going
to serve two purposes here.

147
00:07:29,220 --> 00:07:31,680
It's going to actually be an input and
an output.

148
00:07:31,680 --> 00:07:36,480
It's an input in terms of I need to
know what work I need done when.

149
00:07:36,480 --> 00:07:40,210
So I need dry wall installed and
I need it done the second week of June.

150
00:07:40,210 --> 00:07:41,750
Can you do it?
All right.

151
00:07:41,750 --> 00:07:43,670
That's what I'm asking the contractor.

152
00:07:43,670 --> 00:07:45,530
And they come back and
they say yes, we can do it.

153
00:07:45,530 --> 00:07:47,800
Great.
So their schedule is my input, right?

154
00:07:47,800 --> 00:07:50,380
That's how I figure out when
the work was going to get done.

155
00:07:50,380 --> 00:07:52,142
Or it might be an output.

156
00:07:52,142 --> 00:07:55,845
The contractor says hey,
I can save you 50%.

157
00:07:55,845 --> 00:07:58,909
I can cut your drywall budget down by 50%.

158
00:07:58,909 --> 00:08:02,602
If you can just wait to the last week in
June, we got some other projects going on.

159
00:08:02,602 --> 00:08:04,450
Once they're wrapped up,
we can knock it out.

160
00:08:04,450 --> 00:08:06,650
We'll give you it half price, right?

161
00:08:06,650 --> 00:08:08,470
So now we say, ooh,
that's really good right?

162
00:08:08,470 --> 00:08:09,420
We can saves some money.

163
00:08:09,420 --> 00:08:10,720
That's gonna help.

164
00:08:10,720 --> 00:08:12,990
All we have to do is move that
drywall back three weeks?

165
00:08:12,990 --> 00:08:13,940
Let's do it.

166
00:08:13,940 --> 00:08:17,800
So on our output we'll have
a project document update.

167
00:08:17,800 --> 00:08:21,923
And we'll go and update that schedule to
reflect this new timeline that gave us

168
00:08:21,923 --> 00:08:24,300
a better deal or
served some kind of purpose.

169
00:08:24,300 --> 00:08:27,030
Or maybe it's just something
that we had to have.

170
00:08:27,030 --> 00:08:30,671
We had to have this done, and they could
only do it the third week of June so

171
00:08:30,671 --> 00:08:32,657
we gotta shift things around, right.

172
00:08:32,657 --> 00:08:35,128
So sometimes our input becomes our output,
right,

173
00:08:35,128 --> 00:08:37,342
that we've got to make
changes to support it.

174
00:08:37,342 --> 00:08:42,414
All right, some of the other things,
the activity cost estimates,

175
00:08:42,414 --> 00:08:46,971
we've got money that we budgeted for
each of our activities.

176
00:08:46,971 --> 00:08:50,493
And if we already determined it,
when we go to line up our contracts,

177
00:08:50,493 --> 00:08:53,790
we need to make sure they
get done within that budget.

178
00:08:53,790 --> 00:08:56,510
We're gonna see a little bit later
that there's more than one type of

179
00:08:56,510 --> 00:08:58,310
contract that we can enter into.

180
00:08:58,310 --> 00:09:02,644
And there's contracts that protect
us by ensuring they never go over

181
00:09:02,644 --> 00:09:04,597
the amount that we specified.

182
00:09:04,597 --> 00:09:08,339
And there's contracts that protect
the contractor, whoever's doing the work,

183
00:09:08,339 --> 00:09:11,333
to ensure that they don't get in
a situation where they're losing

184
00:09:11,333 --> 00:09:12,875
money on the contract.

185
00:09:12,875 --> 00:09:16,925
So we have to find a middle ground
between the two where we protect

186
00:09:16,925 --> 00:09:21,455
both our interests, ours as well as the
contractor, to ensure the work gets done.

187
00:09:21,455 --> 00:09:26,110
So, that is something that we need
to be aware of, and we'll see,

188
00:09:26,110 --> 00:09:30,430
and that's part of why the cost
estimates become part of our inputs.

189
00:09:30,430 --> 00:09:34,170
Our stakeholder register, right,
if we enter into a contract,

190
00:09:34,170 --> 00:09:35,400
we're gonna have to make some choices.

191
00:09:35,400 --> 00:09:37,280
We're gonna have to choose a vendor,
and so on.

192
00:09:37,280 --> 00:09:39,690
And our stakeholders are gonna
be a part of that process.

193
00:09:39,690 --> 00:09:41,890
And we're just gonna need
to communicate with them.

194
00:09:41,890 --> 00:09:46,830
Also if we enter into a contractor, you
might remember from that initiation phase,

195
00:09:46,830 --> 00:09:51,040
anybody we enter into a contract with
becomes a stakeholder in the project.

196
00:09:51,040 --> 00:09:54,700
So our stakeholder register is gonna
update also as we add these new

197
00:09:54,700 --> 00:09:56,930
people to it to be informed.

198
00:09:56,930 --> 00:10:00,670
And our RACI matrix, right,
the responsibility, accountability,

199
00:10:00,670 --> 00:10:03,710
that matrix,
we'll have to add in new people there.

200
00:10:03,710 --> 00:10:05,580
Because if it's contracted out,

201
00:10:05,580 --> 00:10:09,370
that contracted party is now
accountable for the work.

202
00:10:09,370 --> 00:10:12,990
But I, as the project manager,
might be responsible for it.

203
00:10:12,990 --> 00:10:16,230
Just cuz we contracted it out, doesn't
mean we can wash our hands and that's it.

204
00:10:16,230 --> 00:10:18,590
As a project manager you're
still responsible, right?

205
00:10:18,590 --> 00:10:20,724
But now it's somebody else
who's accountable for the work.

206
00:10:22,722 --> 00:10:26,210
I throw these out,
I've got this vision in my mind.

207
00:10:26,210 --> 00:10:30,380
But just in case you don't remember
what the RACI documents are,

208
00:10:30,380 --> 00:10:34,489
let me go back into our templates here,
and I'll pull that up.

209
00:10:34,489 --> 00:10:39,680
Let's see, that is our responsibility
assignment matrix, this guy right here.

210
00:10:41,422 --> 00:10:44,340
All right, so this is a document that we
brought up in an earlier episode where we

211
00:10:44,340 --> 00:10:46,070
flagged who's responsible,

212
00:10:46,070 --> 00:10:50,760
who is accountable, who gets consulted,
and who gets informed.

213
00:10:50,760 --> 00:10:53,910
And so you'll see all those right in here,
we just kinda flag each one.

214
00:10:53,910 --> 00:10:55,500
When we contract something out,

215
00:10:55,500 --> 00:10:58,680
that's a new person who is now
accountable for that work.

216
00:10:58,680 --> 00:11:01,250
But as the PM, we may be responsible.

217
00:11:01,250 --> 00:11:03,080
So, we just kind of flag
that in here to keep track.

218
00:11:03,080 --> 00:11:06,620
I think I also mentioned that I don't
like these diagrams because they don't

219
00:11:06,620 --> 00:11:07,710
scale very well.

220
00:11:07,710 --> 00:11:09,091
But that's it.

221
00:11:12,923 --> 00:11:16,156
All right, so
we gather all of our data together.

222
00:11:16,156 --> 00:11:20,340
We get that information, and
now we're ready to act upon it, right.

223
00:11:20,340 --> 00:11:24,340
So, if we want to act upon it,
we need some tools and techniques, and

224
00:11:24,340 --> 00:11:26,820
you'll see they're pretty
straightforward here.

225
00:11:26,820 --> 00:11:30,770
They actually don't list some of them so
I'm gonna deviate a little bit.

226
00:11:30,770 --> 00:11:36,317
But the first one is we have what's
called a make-or-buy analysis, all right?

227
00:11:36,317 --> 00:11:40,735
Make-or-buy analysis is one of those
terms that can be a little misleading.

228
00:11:40,735 --> 00:11:45,345
But basically whenever we have
a job that needs to be done,

229
00:11:45,345 --> 00:11:46,165
we got to make a decision.

230
00:11:47,265 --> 00:11:50,095
Is it something we can do ourselves or

231
00:11:50,095 --> 00:11:54,260
is it something I should pay
somebody else to do, all right?

232
00:11:54,260 --> 00:11:55,820
Make or buy?

233
00:11:55,820 --> 00:12:00,270
Can I make it myself or should I just
buy something that's already been built?

234
00:12:00,270 --> 00:12:03,330
So we run into this at
ITProTV all the time, right.

235
00:12:03,330 --> 00:12:07,630
We're tech guys, all of us, all the staff
here, everybody here is a techie,

236
00:12:07,630 --> 00:12:09,050
we like gadgets.

237
00:12:09,050 --> 00:12:11,200
We know computers really well, right.

238
00:12:11,200 --> 00:12:16,050
And so, then we have to look
at things like our studio.

239
00:12:16,050 --> 00:12:19,600
With all our cameras and
our lighting and stuff, we're tech guys,

240
00:12:19,600 --> 00:12:21,520
I know how a camera works.

241
00:12:21,520 --> 00:12:25,450
Do we need to hire somebody to come in and
set up the cameras for us, or

242
00:12:25,450 --> 00:12:27,460
can we do it ourselves?

243
00:12:27,460 --> 00:12:31,200
Well you do a make or buy analysis.

244
00:12:31,200 --> 00:12:35,480
You look at it, and you say well,
I could set up the cameras myself, right.

245
00:12:35,480 --> 00:12:37,610
Most of them are pretty straightforward,
you can hook them up.

246
00:12:37,610 --> 00:12:41,500
It would take me a few hours, probably,
to set the cameras up so I could do that.

247
00:12:41,500 --> 00:12:43,720
And then all the little settings in there.

248
00:12:43,720 --> 00:12:45,950
Now, things start to get a little fuzzy.

249
00:12:45,950 --> 00:12:48,150
I got a camera at home,
I just set it to auto.

250
00:12:48,150 --> 00:12:50,705
But here in the studio,
I might need to set the aperture.

251
00:12:50,705 --> 00:12:52,482
I might need to set the white balancing.

252
00:12:52,482 --> 00:12:56,187
I might need to set, Jason,
what's all the stuff we set on the camera?

253
00:12:56,187 --> 00:12:59,135
[LAUGH]
>> Stuff.

254
00:12:59,135 --> 00:13:01,016
>> The stuff, so the contrast, right.

255
00:13:01,016 --> 00:13:03,860
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> Good job video guy.

256
00:13:03,860 --> 00:13:07,528
So, [LAUGH] there's all sorts of
different things to set on a camera, and

257
00:13:07,528 --> 00:13:08,987
I don't know them, right.

258
00:13:08,987 --> 00:13:12,750
I didn't go to film school or
wherever it is you go to learn that stuff.

259
00:13:12,750 --> 00:13:15,170
So I don't really know how
a camera operates, right.

260
00:13:15,170 --> 00:13:19,194
I know there's light refraction
off of a sensor or whatever, but

261
00:13:19,194 --> 00:13:22,133
I also know that I could
probably figure it out.

262
00:13:22,133 --> 00:13:23,500
But it would time, right.

263
00:13:23,500 --> 00:13:25,043
It might take me days, or even weeks,

264
00:13:25,043 --> 00:13:28,000
to get the cameras here in
the studio set up just right.

265
00:13:28,000 --> 00:13:29,400
But I could just pay somebody.

266
00:13:29,400 --> 00:13:32,804
I could hire somebody to come in
who's a camera specialist, and

267
00:13:32,804 --> 00:13:34,955
they could set up all the cameras for us.

268
00:13:34,955 --> 00:13:37,290
And I know it's done right.

269
00:13:37,290 --> 00:13:40,550
And it freed me up to do other things,
right?

270
00:13:40,550 --> 00:13:45,740
So it costs some money, but the job
was done right, and it took less time.

271
00:13:45,740 --> 00:13:47,360
And that can be very valuable, all right.

272
00:13:47,360 --> 00:13:49,220
And, I mean, that's exactly what we did.

273
00:13:49,220 --> 00:13:51,970
Like our lighting, we actually brought
a lighting specialist in to hook these up,

274
00:13:51,970 --> 00:13:53,950
because I know how a light works.

275
00:13:53,950 --> 00:13:55,550
You flip the switch and it's on, right?

276
00:13:55,550 --> 00:13:58,770
But eliminating shadows on the face and
all that good stuff.

277
00:13:58,770 --> 00:14:00,940
It's a science and it's beyond me.

278
00:14:02,120 --> 00:14:05,230
So that's kind of the example of a make or
buy analysis.

279
00:14:05,230 --> 00:14:06,730
Can you do it internally or not?

280
00:14:06,730 --> 00:14:08,320
It is something we face all the time.

281
00:14:08,320 --> 00:14:09,940
We need a web server.

282
00:14:09,940 --> 00:14:10,803
Do we set it up ourselves?

283
00:14:10,803 --> 00:14:11,480
We know how.

284
00:14:11,480 --> 00:14:12,880
We can do it.

285
00:14:12,880 --> 00:14:18,811
Or, do I want to contract that out because
I don't want to deal with it day to day,

286
00:14:18,811 --> 00:14:19,699
all right.

287
00:14:19,699 --> 00:14:20,820
That's another great example, our website.

288
00:14:20,820 --> 00:14:25,603
You're on ITP, well, the streaming video,
you are watching this live streaming video

289
00:14:25,603 --> 00:14:28,491
right now, or
you are watching it recorded, right.

290
00:14:28,491 --> 00:14:31,928
I know how to set up
a Flash streaming server.

291
00:14:31,928 --> 00:14:35,083
I know how to set up a Wowza server so
I know how those work.

292
00:14:35,083 --> 00:14:36,988
I know how Amazon CloudFront works.

293
00:14:36,988 --> 00:14:39,194
I can set up all that, the edge CDN.

294
00:14:39,194 --> 00:14:40,796
That's all stuff that I've done before.

295
00:14:40,796 --> 00:14:42,140
I can easily do it.

296
00:14:42,140 --> 00:14:45,870
But when I come into work in the morning,
I don't want to worry about the stream.

297
00:14:45,870 --> 00:14:49,940
I want to walk right up here to this
podium or whatever we call this thing and

298
00:14:49,940 --> 00:14:51,220
do a show, right?

299
00:14:51,220 --> 00:14:53,600
I want to do a show when I come into work.

300
00:14:53,600 --> 00:14:56,020
I don't want to tweak a video stream,
right.

301
00:14:56,020 --> 00:14:59,062
And Apple releases some new encoding
that they require on the device.

302
00:14:59,062 --> 00:15:01,300
Now we got to update
all our video streams.

303
00:15:01,300 --> 00:15:02,750
I don't wanna worry about that, right?

304
00:15:02,750 --> 00:15:03,900
I want to do a show.

305
00:15:03,900 --> 00:15:06,780
So in that scenario, we do a buy.

306
00:15:06,780 --> 00:15:10,960
We say there's plenty of companies out
there that specialize in video streaming,

307
00:15:10,960 --> 00:15:12,240
we'll use them, right?

308
00:15:12,240 --> 00:15:15,470
And so we do, we use Scale Engine,
Vimeo, Amazon S3,

309
00:15:15,470 --> 00:15:17,100
we use several different providers.

310
00:15:17,100 --> 00:15:21,670
And we let them worry about the video,
so that we don't have to, right?

311
00:15:21,670 --> 00:15:24,266
And on a day like today, for
any of you watching live,

312
00:15:24,266 --> 00:15:27,060
you know the video stream
wasn't working this morning.

313
00:15:27,060 --> 00:15:30,455
And instead of us having to wrack
our brains and figure it out,

314
00:15:30,455 --> 00:15:31,903
we open a support ticket.

315
00:15:31,903 --> 00:15:34,682
And so Ronnie and I worked on our
show notes before the show, and

316
00:15:34,682 --> 00:15:35,795
the stream was working.

317
00:15:35,795 --> 00:15:39,780
And that's the kind of thing that
you really benefit from with a buy.

318
00:15:40,830 --> 00:15:44,830
But there are times where you say I need
a web developer on this project to design

319
00:15:44,830 --> 00:15:46,700
part of the website.

320
00:15:46,700 --> 00:15:50,285
I've got staff web developers, that's
what they do, that's what their job is.

321
00:15:50,285 --> 00:15:53,339
I'll just get my internal guys
to design that website, and

322
00:15:53,339 --> 00:15:57,203
then by doing that, you save some money
cuz you've already got the staff.

323
00:15:57,203 --> 00:16:00,210
You may or may not save time,
it just depends.

324
00:16:00,210 --> 00:16:02,764
But you can save money.

325
00:16:02,764 --> 00:16:05,860
That is a make or buy analysis.

326
00:16:06,950 --> 00:16:08,660
It’s up to you, your environment,

327
00:16:08,660 --> 00:16:12,220
your company whether one way is
more worthwhile over the other.

328
00:16:12,220 --> 00:16:14,751
Just remember,
don't look at it just in terms of costs.

329
00:16:14,751 --> 00:16:15,586
>> All right.

330
00:16:15,586 --> 00:16:21,780
>> It would cost us less if I set up
the lighting in the studio myself, right?

331
00:16:21,780 --> 00:16:24,560
I can read a manual,
I can flip a power switch.

332
00:16:24,560 --> 00:16:30,530
But timewise, it's going to take me a lot
longer to get it right than an actual

333
00:16:30,530 --> 00:16:36,260
certified, licensed,
union light studio set whatever person.

334
00:16:36,260 --> 00:16:37,410
I don't even know what they're called.

335
00:16:37,410 --> 00:16:37,970
>> Me neither.

336
00:16:37,970 --> 00:16:39,020
>> Hm.
Lighting techs.

337
00:16:39,020 --> 00:16:40,450
Anyhow, whatever
a lighting tech is called.

338
00:16:40,450 --> 00:16:42,130
Sorry if any of you guys
are lighting techs.

339
00:16:42,130 --> 00:16:43,525
I just don't know the title.

340
00:16:43,525 --> 00:16:45,400
>> [LAUGH]
>> The microphone guy,

341
00:16:45,400 --> 00:16:47,650
it's like a key grip to bring
you an actual key grip.

342
00:16:47,650 --> 00:16:51,800
So anyhow, that's the kind of things you
have to analyse when you do a make or

343
00:16:51,800 --> 00:16:53,082
buy analysis.

344
00:16:53,082 --> 00:16:53,930
All right.

345
00:16:53,930 --> 00:16:58,500
That term make, it's not really making
anymore, its usually service related.

346
00:16:58,500 --> 00:17:01,680
But, it could be the actual
instruction of something.

347
00:17:01,680 --> 00:17:06,790
I think I gave an example of a asphalt
company in one of the episodes, and

348
00:17:06,790 --> 00:17:09,540
they used some really
specialized equipment.

349
00:17:09,540 --> 00:17:13,600
Equipment that is so specialized that
if they go out and buy, it's really,

350
00:17:13,600 --> 00:17:14,800
really expensive.

351
00:17:14,800 --> 00:17:16,470
But, they've got engineers on staff.

352
00:17:16,470 --> 00:17:21,440
And in some cases, they can construct that
equipment themselves and save a good bit.

353
00:17:21,440 --> 00:17:22,440
Sometimes they can't, right?

354
00:17:22,440 --> 00:17:26,082
That's what the make or
buy analysis is all about.

355
00:17:26,082 --> 00:17:26,987
All right.

356
00:17:26,987 --> 00:17:30,029
The next entry I have here
is the expert judgement.

357
00:17:30,029 --> 00:17:33,767
And expert judgement,
again that's using our noodle.

358
00:17:33,767 --> 00:17:37,490
But what I wanna do is I wanna
to break out of our mold here,

359
00:17:37,490 --> 00:17:41,110
and talk about something else that
falls under expert judgement too.

360
00:17:41,110 --> 00:17:44,570
When we talk about procurement management,
we're entering into contracts.

361
00:17:44,570 --> 00:17:47,770
And there's different types
of contracts out there, and

362
00:17:47,770 --> 00:17:51,140
it's our expert judgement that
lets us know which one to pick.

363
00:17:51,140 --> 00:17:52,910
And thankfully, Ronnie,

364
00:17:52,910 --> 00:17:57,410
who is always prepared made a list
of the contract type for us.

365
00:17:57,410 --> 00:17:58,180
All right?

366
00:17:58,180 --> 00:17:59,060
So you'll see here,

367
00:17:59,060 --> 00:18:02,480
on the exam there's actually going to be,
what is it, eleven different contracts.

368
00:18:02,480 --> 00:18:04,922
>> Yep.
>> Yeah, 11 different contracts.

369
00:18:04,922 --> 00:18:08,760
So, 11 contracts in three different
categories that are available anytime

370
00:18:08,760 --> 00:18:13,240
we enter into some kind of contract or
procurement, right?

371
00:18:13,240 --> 00:18:16,540
So, some of these up here at
the top are pretty common.

372
00:18:16,540 --> 00:18:20,470
You see actual cost plus
profit margin based.

373
00:18:20,470 --> 00:18:21,210
All right?

374
00:18:21,210 --> 00:18:23,000
When you enter into
a contract with somebody,

375
00:18:23,000 --> 00:18:25,690
they're gonna charge you x
amount of dollars, right?

376
00:18:25,690 --> 00:18:30,420
And that company that's writing
the contract, they're thinking, all right.

377
00:18:30,420 --> 00:18:32,830
This is what it's gonna
cost us to actually do it,

378
00:18:32,830 --> 00:18:34,375
and then here's our profit.

379
00:18:34,375 --> 00:18:35,400
Right?

380
00:18:35,400 --> 00:18:38,930
When we enter into a contract, we might
want to be very clear about that so

381
00:18:38,930 --> 00:18:42,850
that we understand what it's actually
costing them versus what their profit is.

382
00:18:42,850 --> 00:18:44,295
Everybody deserves to make a profit,
right?

383
00:18:44,295 --> 00:18:46,870
So we're just being upfront
about it in the contract.

384
00:18:47,940 --> 00:18:53,190
You also have just the straight up agreed
price for contracted product, right?

385
00:18:53,190 --> 00:18:55,690
With this, we're normally talking
about the purchase of equipment.

386
00:18:56,990 --> 00:18:59,150
So here is just an upfront,
you purchase it,

387
00:18:59,150 --> 00:19:03,480
it's not like it's an ongoing thing and
that's basically it.

388
00:19:03,480 --> 00:19:05,750
And then we also just have
our miscellaneous contracts.

389
00:19:05,750 --> 00:19:09,350
Ones that don't really fit the mold
of the other two categories right?

390
00:19:09,350 --> 00:19:12,200
But let's take a look at each of the ones
that are in here cuz I know these guys up

391
00:19:12,200 --> 00:19:14,220
here are really common on the exam.

392
00:19:14,220 --> 00:19:17,220
So we definitely want to make sure
we have a good grasp of those.

393
00:19:17,220 --> 00:19:22,410
So I'm talking about the actual cost,
plus profit margin based.

394
00:19:22,410 --> 00:19:23,980
There's four different
varieties of this one,

395
00:19:23,980 --> 00:19:28,240
the first one is the cost plus fixed fee.

396
00:19:28,240 --> 00:19:33,080
With this one we tell the contractor,
when you give us quotes you need to

397
00:19:33,080 --> 00:19:37,840
give us your actual cost for
what its gonna take to do that work and

398
00:19:37,840 --> 00:19:43,570
then give me a fixed fee value for
what I'm gonna pay you for profits, okay.

399
00:19:43,570 --> 00:19:48,490
The nice part about this contract is
we know what it's gonna cost, and

400
00:19:48,490 --> 00:19:50,430
there's no room for overage.

401
00:19:50,430 --> 00:19:52,710
Cuz we're not really
talking about time here.

402
00:19:52,710 --> 00:19:54,880
If the contractor gets it done early,

403
00:19:56,260 --> 00:19:59,380
then they technically make
a certain amount of money.

404
00:19:59,380 --> 00:20:02,080
And if they get it done late,
they make the same amount of money.

405
00:20:02,080 --> 00:20:04,820
So the amount of money they make doesn't
vary, whether they're on time or

406
00:20:04,820 --> 00:20:05,800
behind schedule.

407
00:20:05,800 --> 00:20:10,160
But if they're behind schedule, that means
they're having to put more hours in.

408
00:20:10,160 --> 00:20:13,480
They're profit starts to shrink because
their labor costs are going up, but

409
00:20:13,480 --> 00:20:15,170
that's not our problem.

410
00:20:15,170 --> 00:20:22,790
So when we deal with that these fixed fee
type contracts they protect the buyer.

411
00:20:22,790 --> 00:20:25,820
They protect us,
reaching out to a contractor.

412
00:20:25,820 --> 00:20:28,640
So contractors don't like these
because if something goes wrong,

413
00:20:28,640 --> 00:20:31,370
if there's something that's unexpected and
their cost starts to go up,

414
00:20:31,370 --> 00:20:34,360
it eats into their fixed fee profit.

415
00:20:34,360 --> 00:20:37,820
Their profit starts to
whittle down based on that.

416
00:20:37,820 --> 00:20:42,080
They're normally gonna move us off to one
of the other type of models if possible.

417
00:20:42,080 --> 00:20:45,170
We have cost plus percentage of cost.

418
00:20:45,170 --> 00:20:47,920
And this is probably one of the more
common ones where they say,

419
00:20:47,920 --> 00:20:51,790
all right we'll do this project for
you, here's what our costs are, and

420
00:20:51,790 --> 00:20:55,550
then we'll just charge 10% for profit.

421
00:20:55,550 --> 00:20:57,220
Or 4%, or 15%, or whatever it is.

422
00:20:57,220 --> 00:20:59,580
Just being upfront about
what that profit is.

423
00:20:59,580 --> 00:21:04,030
And if we add more work to the contract,
if it ends up taking more the cost goes

424
00:21:04,030 --> 00:21:08,870
up, their percentage ensures that
they're getting money on that.

425
00:21:08,870 --> 00:21:10,970
And so this protects them also.

426
00:21:10,970 --> 00:21:15,280
It protects the contractor more
than it does us I suppose.

427
00:21:15,280 --> 00:21:17,950
There's a cost plus incentive fee.

428
00:21:17,950 --> 00:21:21,830
All right, here's an incentive
that we're adding on to say hey,

429
00:21:21,830 --> 00:21:24,250
if you can get this done, at cost on time,

430
00:21:24,250 --> 00:21:29,440
on schedule, on budget then here's
an incentive that we'll pay you.

431
00:21:29,440 --> 00:21:33,310
Then that incentive is
usually just a flat number.

432
00:21:33,310 --> 00:21:35,460
And they work towards your goal.

433
00:21:35,460 --> 00:21:37,720
We can also balance that
with like an award.

434
00:21:37,720 --> 00:21:40,140
Cost plus award fee, all right?

435
00:21:40,140 --> 00:21:41,720
Now the difference between incentive and

436
00:21:41,720 --> 00:21:44,980
award, an award fee is normally
a fixed value, and that's it.

437
00:21:44,980 --> 00:21:50,830
But an incentive fee typically decreases
as you get closer to being on time.

438
00:21:50,830 --> 00:21:54,190
So if you get done early,
you have an incentive for that, right?

439
00:21:54,190 --> 00:21:57,540
And if you get done late, there's
a penalty coupling it, and they don't

440
00:21:57,540 --> 00:22:01,150
mention that here, but you'll see cost
plus incentive plus penalty sometimes.

441
00:22:01,150 --> 00:22:07,200
So, we have different ways of
incentivizing people to get done early.

442
00:22:07,200 --> 00:22:11,620
With an award that's normally if you win
the contract you get this award fee and

443
00:22:11,620 --> 00:22:15,010
that's it, it doesn't really very,
it can but it doesn't normally.

444
00:22:15,010 --> 00:22:16,830
So, those two are very similar.

445
00:22:17,960 --> 00:22:22,250
>> Now in this one, when we start
talking about the idea of the contracts,

446
00:22:22,250 --> 00:22:26,010
the [INAUDIBLE] explicitly mentions
really two people in the contract right?

447
00:22:26,010 --> 00:22:29,230
One's called a buyer and
the other one is called the seller.

448
00:22:29,230 --> 00:22:32,940
So, in these particular contracts here,
you see that it's the seller at this

449
00:22:32,940 --> 00:22:35,550
point, that's actually responsible for
the risk.

450
00:22:35,550 --> 00:22:37,130
If he finishes early, that's fine.

451
00:22:37,130 --> 00:22:38,340
But if he doesn't,

452
00:22:38,340 --> 00:22:41,010
he's the one that actually ends
up with less money at the end.

453
00:22:41,010 --> 00:22:44,020
So a lot a times, that's what you actually
do see in that terminology there.

454
00:22:44,020 --> 00:22:46,420
Buyer and seller, don't forget that.

455
00:22:46,420 --> 00:22:49,750
>> Yeah, every contract is looking
at the interest of these two people,

456
00:22:49,750 --> 00:22:51,010
of the buyer and seller.

457
00:22:51,010 --> 00:22:54,330
And you'll see contracts that
are sometimes very uneven.

458
00:22:54,330 --> 00:22:57,390
Right that are completely
protecting one of the entities.

459
00:22:57,390 --> 00:23:01,620
Those are not good contracts because the
other party is really under the gun and

460
00:23:01,620 --> 00:23:04,260
if anything goes wrong
they're left holding the bag.

461
00:23:04,260 --> 00:23:10,000
So the best contract is one that
protects both sides equally and

462
00:23:10,000 --> 00:23:11,669
so trying to find that
balance is important.

463
00:23:12,740 --> 00:23:17,890
All right, so for those of you that
worked with a third edition pimbock and

464
00:23:17,890 --> 00:23:22,360
earlier, we didn't have the procurement
process, we had the select seller process.

465
00:23:22,360 --> 00:23:23,880
It was actually called the seller process.

466
00:23:23,880 --> 00:23:26,450
So that changed,
cuz it's not just dealing with sellers,

467
00:23:26,450 --> 00:23:27,649
it's the buyer and the seller.

468
00:23:28,870 --> 00:23:34,170
All right we also have agreed price for
contracted product based.

469
00:23:34,170 --> 00:23:36,960
This is typically when
we're buying equipment.

470
00:23:36,960 --> 00:23:41,620
We're buying a tangible good, whether
it's a sale, we're issued a receipt,

471
00:23:41,620 --> 00:23:42,240
and it's done.

472
00:23:42,240 --> 00:23:44,440
There's not some ongoing thing.

473
00:23:44,440 --> 00:23:48,690
There might be warranty, or maintenance,
some kind of support agreement.

474
00:23:48,690 --> 00:23:52,430
But for the most part it's a one time,
in and out charge.

475
00:23:52,430 --> 00:23:56,370
So these typically fall under what's
called a fixed price contract.

476
00:23:56,370 --> 00:23:58,040
Right?
We're gonna purchase this.

477
00:23:58,040 --> 00:23:59,390
It's gonna be a fixed price.

478
00:23:59,390 --> 00:24:00,200
We pay it.

479
00:24:00,200 --> 00:24:01,669
And that's it.

480
00:24:01,669 --> 00:24:05,465
But there are variations based
on things that might occur.

481
00:24:05,465 --> 00:24:08,949
Things like variable market environments.

482
00:24:08,949 --> 00:24:11,931
Whether we pay In installments, right?

483
00:24:11,931 --> 00:24:15,416
So t might be a fixed price, but
we pay monthly for six months or

484
00:24:15,416 --> 00:24:18,450
something like that a term agreement.

485
00:24:18,450 --> 00:24:20,710
So something like that
can have some variation.

486
00:24:20,710 --> 00:24:25,385
So instead, we might choose to go
with something like a lumped sum.

487
00:24:25,385 --> 00:24:31,135
Or a lump sum agreement, which says we
pay it all up front and we're done.

488
00:24:31,135 --> 00:24:34,805
When you go to the grocery store, you go
up to that cash register, you have your

489
00:24:34,805 --> 00:24:38,325
gallon of milk, your bread, and
your other items, and you pay them money.

490
00:24:38,325 --> 00:24:39,425
That's a lump sum payment.

491
00:24:39,425 --> 00:24:40,545
You pay it all up front.

492
00:24:40,545 --> 00:24:41,695
That's it and it's done.

493
00:24:41,695 --> 00:24:44,095
Then you walk out with your groceries.

494
00:24:44,095 --> 00:24:47,220
But if you're a contractor and
you're building a house.

495
00:24:47,220 --> 00:24:50,450
The bank will put you on
an installment kind of payment,

496
00:24:50,450 --> 00:24:52,400
they call it a disbursement payment.

497
00:24:52,400 --> 00:24:56,200
And so, you'll get disbursements
at certain milestones, and so

498
00:24:56,200 --> 00:24:58,240
you're getting that money as you go.

499
00:24:58,240 --> 00:25:00,900
So it is a fixed price, you know, what
you've agreed upon for that house, but

500
00:25:00,900 --> 00:25:03,208
it's over time,
lump sum it's all up front.

501
00:25:03,208 --> 00:25:06,772
A firm-fixed price, all right,

502
00:25:06,772 --> 00:25:12,840
firm-fixed price is where we don't
allow that agreed upon price to vary,

503
00:25:12,840 --> 00:25:19,730
based on stuff that's going on outside,
economic environment, things like that.

504
00:25:19,730 --> 00:25:22,520
You know here in Florida
is a great example.

505
00:25:22,520 --> 00:25:28,860
The housing market in the United States
took a dive four or five years ago now?

506
00:25:28,860 --> 00:25:30,920
A little while ago and it was bad.

507
00:25:30,920 --> 00:25:32,410
A lot of banks went under.

508
00:25:32,410 --> 00:25:37,460
A lot of construction companies
just went belly up, right?

509
00:25:37,460 --> 00:25:42,320
There was a time before that,
where it was actually just as bad, but

510
00:25:42,320 --> 00:25:43,770
it didn't really make the news.

511
00:25:43,770 --> 00:25:48,000
There was one year when four
hurricanes hit the state of Florida.

512
00:25:48,000 --> 00:25:51,530
And that's pretty uncommon, we get usually
at least one hurricane a year, but

513
00:25:51,530 --> 00:25:55,630
we had four in one year that all did
landfall ,all across the state of Florida.

514
00:25:55,630 --> 00:25:59,230
Well after that, there was so
much reconstruction going on,

515
00:25:59,230 --> 00:26:01,250
that it was hard to get wood.

516
00:26:01,250 --> 00:26:04,430
And so the price of wood,

517
00:26:04,430 --> 00:26:08,630
the price of just like a two by four
stud or whatever started going up.

518
00:26:08,630 --> 00:26:10,480
So all of the contractors,

519
00:26:10,480 --> 00:26:15,490
all these people who were building houses
who had agreed upon prices for the house.

520
00:26:15,490 --> 00:26:17,130
That wood started costing more money.

521
00:26:17,130 --> 00:26:21,490
Started cutting into their profits that
eventually It caused two problems.

522
00:26:21,490 --> 00:26:22,980
There was demand issues.

523
00:26:22,980 --> 00:26:27,220
They couldn't get enough of the studs
to be able to build the house, so

524
00:26:27,220 --> 00:26:29,500
they were going behind schedules.

525
00:26:29,500 --> 00:26:32,370
And then their costs were going up,
and they were running out of money.

526
00:26:32,370 --> 00:26:35,170
And the banks were not giving
them their next disbursement,

527
00:26:35,170 --> 00:26:37,300
because they hadn't hit their milestone.

528
00:26:37,300 --> 00:26:39,730
And there were a lot of failed
construction projects then.

529
00:26:39,730 --> 00:26:41,800
So we had that bout, then it was four or

530
00:26:41,800 --> 00:26:45,090
five years later that we had the housing
market go under, and then, you know.

531
00:26:45,090 --> 00:26:48,180
So it's been rough for
the state of Florida.

532
00:26:48,180 --> 00:26:52,050
But that's one of the problems
with firm-fixed pricing.

533
00:26:52,050 --> 00:26:54,620
As a buyer, we like firm-fixed pricing,

534
00:26:54,620 --> 00:26:58,970
because we know we're gonna pay one thing,
and that's it no matter what happens.

535
00:26:58,970 --> 00:27:01,260
But the seller is left holding the risk.

536
00:27:01,260 --> 00:27:03,560
Now it is a positive and a negative risk.

537
00:27:03,560 --> 00:27:05,930
On a negative side,
the price of materials could go up and

538
00:27:05,930 --> 00:27:07,290
then they're in real trouble.

539
00:27:07,290 --> 00:27:11,560
On a positive side, the price of materials
could come down, and now because we agreed

540
00:27:11,560 --> 00:27:16,360
on a firm fixed price, you know,
they get the entire benefit of that.

541
00:27:16,360 --> 00:27:18,170
So, this is pushing risk off to them.

542
00:27:19,690 --> 00:27:23,180
All right, and
then there's fixed price incentive fee.

543
00:27:23,180 --> 00:27:25,070
So we have a fixed price for
what we're purchasing,

544
00:27:25,070 --> 00:27:28,350
and then we have some kind of
incentive fee attached to it.

545
00:27:28,350 --> 00:27:31,970
You’ll see this a lot of times with
companies that do like referral programs,

546
00:27:31,970 --> 00:27:32,770
and so you know,

547
00:27:32,770 --> 00:27:37,550
you pay for their service, and then as
you refer people you get incentives.

548
00:27:37,550 --> 00:27:42,140
So you see that kind of as a bonus
attached to the purchase of that good.

549
00:27:42,140 --> 00:27:43,600
You see this in real estate a lot.

550
00:27:43,600 --> 00:27:47,180
Where you say, I need a warehouse, and
I need it to be this many square feet,

551
00:27:47,180 --> 00:27:51,100
I need it have great location, and
here's how much I want to pay for it .and

552
00:27:51,100 --> 00:27:55,210
if you can find this for me, here's the
incentive fee like the realtor's fee or

553
00:27:55,210 --> 00:27:56,770
whatever that we'll pay for that.

554
00:27:56,770 --> 00:27:59,650
And they go out and find the perfect
location for it, they buy it for

555
00:27:59,650 --> 00:28:01,440
you under your agreement.

556
00:28:01,440 --> 00:28:03,790
And then you pay that incentive fee for
them finding it, like a finders fee.

557
00:28:06,730 --> 00:28:09,310
The other contract types
are just miscellaneous,

558
00:28:09,310 --> 00:28:11,260
they don't really kind of
fit the models up there.

559
00:28:11,260 --> 00:28:15,500
So you'll see like fixed price,
with economic price adjustments.

560
00:28:15,500 --> 00:28:21,740
This where it's a fixed price we agree
upon, but we build in certain adjustments.

561
00:28:21,740 --> 00:28:23,300
>> Right?
Like inflation.

562
00:28:23,300 --> 00:28:26,610
Yeah, monitoring inflation is a great one.

563
00:28:26,610 --> 00:28:28,100
Cost of living for certain areas.

564
00:28:28,100 --> 00:28:29,650
>> Yes.
>> That might come into play.

565
00:28:29,650 --> 00:28:30,880
Stock market values.

566
00:28:30,880 --> 00:28:31,980
>> Yes.
>> Availability.

567
00:28:31,980 --> 00:28:33,620
We start to factor these into contract.

568
00:28:33,620 --> 00:28:37,435
These contracts are usually pretty
complex, but they are around.

569
00:28:37,435 --> 00:28:41,280
T&M, this is a really common one.

570
00:28:41,280 --> 00:28:43,150
Time and materials, right?

571
00:28:43,150 --> 00:28:47,100
We enter into a contract with somebody to
provide a service or good or whatever.

572
00:28:47,100 --> 00:28:49,990
And they bill us separately for
time and materials.

573
00:28:49,990 --> 00:28:53,030
Materials are usually at or near cost.

574
00:28:53,030 --> 00:28:54,800
And then is their labor that's involved,
and

575
00:28:54,800 --> 00:28:57,260
that's usually where
they make their money.

576
00:28:57,260 --> 00:29:00,430
So, I used to work for a company
a long time ago that sold servers.

577
00:29:00,430 --> 00:29:02,670
And we would sell
the servers at near cost.

578
00:29:02,670 --> 00:29:05,980
And then we would charge for installing
the servers and setting them up.

579
00:29:05,980 --> 00:29:10,630
And so we would enter into time and
materials contracts,where the servers,

580
00:29:10,630 --> 00:29:13,970
we would either sell them at or near cost,
or people could buy them, themselves.

581
00:29:13,970 --> 00:29:15,850
We didn't really care
where that came from, and

582
00:29:15,850 --> 00:29:18,410
then it was the time
where we made our money.

583
00:29:18,410 --> 00:29:20,120
Mechanics are like this, right?

584
00:29:20,120 --> 00:29:24,170
Time and materials, you pay for
the part to fix your car, and you pay for

585
00:29:24,170 --> 00:29:27,310
the mechanics time to do
the repair time and materials.

586
00:29:29,200 --> 00:29:30,780
>> Right.
>> And then you just have straight

587
00:29:30,780 --> 00:29:31,420
up unit price.

588
00:29:31,420 --> 00:29:32,690
Right?
A unit price contract,

589
00:29:32,690 --> 00:29:37,040
is where you enter into a contract to
buy something at a particular price, and

590
00:29:37,040 --> 00:29:41,730
it's a unit price, meaning if you
want to buy more units down the road,

591
00:29:41,730 --> 00:29:43,900
you've already contracted
a price to pay it.

592
00:29:43,900 --> 00:29:47,080
You'll see this with, like,
GSA accounts in the U.S.,

593
00:29:47,080 --> 00:29:49,650
where companies will contract
to the United States government

594
00:29:49,650 --> 00:29:53,570
to make it where all of the governmental
agencies can buy from this one vendor.

595
00:29:53,570 --> 00:29:56,160
And they all get the same
negotiated price.

596
00:29:56,160 --> 00:29:57,890
We're not constantly renegotiating.

597
00:29:57,890 --> 00:30:01,780
So, if I need to buy 200 computers
this month, my price is already set.

598
00:30:01,780 --> 00:30:05,190
If I need to buy another 200 next month,
my price is already set.

599
00:30:05,190 --> 00:30:05,740
All right.

600
00:30:05,740 --> 00:30:07,650
It's nice because we don't have
to go through negotiations.

601
00:30:07,650 --> 00:30:09,230
It's already agreed upon.

602
00:30:09,230 --> 00:30:13,080
It's not so nice in that the price
of these things might vary, and

603
00:30:13,080 --> 00:30:15,800
so I might not be getting the best deal.

604
00:30:17,280 --> 00:30:19,880
All right, so those are some of
the contract types that are out there.

00:30:19,880 --> 00:30:22,620
We definitely want to
be familiar with those.

Well, Ronnie, this is a pretty good

no we get to the real wallop on this one.

a handful of tools and techniques,

00:31:03,570 --> 00:31:07,870

there's a lot of outputs.

00:31:07,870 --> 00:31:10,650
We generate a lot of information.

00:31:10,650 --> 00:31:13,520
The main thing that we're gonna
be generating are things like

00:31:30,380 --> 00:31:34,160

00:31:40,755 --> 00:31:44,475
Because way back at the beginning of our

631

00:31:49,965 --> 00:31:52,127
Well, when we contract something out.

00:31:52,127 --> 00:31:54,657
It's like creating a subproject.

635

You have to give them a charter, which is

00:31:58,732 --> 00:32:00,966
And you got to give

637
00:32:00,966 --> 00:32:04,082

00:32:04,082 --> 00:32:06,695
That's your statement of work for

639
00:32:06,695 --> 00:32:09,944
You're telling them what you want done,

640
00:32:09,944 --> 00:32:12,040

641
00:32:12,040 --> 00:32:16,760
And then they need to live up to that for

So we're really kicking off a whole

643
00:32:19,730 --> 00:32:23,370
many outputs here, cuz it's so

644
00:32:23,370 --> 00:32:25,350
That procurement statement of work,

645
00:32:25,350 --> 00:32:31,680
the number one thing it needs to have is
a detailed, non-disputable explanation

646
00:32:31,680 --> 00:32:36,110
of what you expect to be completed

00:32:36,110 --> 00:32:40,645
All right, so it does need to

648

649
00:32:42,795 --> 00:32:47,219
We need to have that in place in that

650
00:32:47,219 --> 00:32:50,425
Now if we already have

00:32:50,425 --> 00:32:53,832

652
00:32:53,832 --> 00:32:56,632
And it will tell us how we

653
00:32:56,632 --> 00:32:59,912

654
00:32:59,912 --> 00:33:00,942
all that good stuff.

655
00:33:00,942 --> 00:33:02,582
But, if we don't have

656
00:33:02,582 --> 00:33:04,462
then that might be another

657
00:33:04,462 --> 00:33:07,582
We just went through this
whole process of figuring out

658
00:33:07,582 --> 00:33:11,892

659
00:33:11,892 --> 00:33:15,662
can reuse that in other projects, so

660
00:33:16,960 --> 00:33:19,810
Some of the other things,
procurement documents.

661
00:33:19,810 --> 00:33:21,600
Now, what are those?

662
00:33:21,600 --> 00:33:25,335
Well technically the procurement
statement of work is a document, but

663
00:33:25,335 --> 00:33:29,870
we're normally going to put that into
a contract itself, and this is something

664
00:33:29,870 --> 00:33:34,030
that as a project manager you're
probably not qualified to generate.

665
00:33:34,030 --> 00:33:35,540
Now, I'm not saying that's always true,
but

666
00:33:35,540 --> 00:33:37,800
usually a project manager
is not qualified.

667
00:33:37,800 --> 00:33:40,320
You typically need an attorney, right?

668
00:33:40,320 --> 00:33:45,081
Somebody who's trained in contract law to
draft up a legally binding contract for

669
00:33:45,081 --> 00:33:46,396
what needs to be done.

670
00:33:46,396 --> 00:33:49,640
Now if we're just purchasing goods from
somebody we don't need that right.

671
00:33:49,640 --> 00:33:51,180
But if we're laying out a contract for

672
00:33:51,180 --> 00:33:55,160
work to be performed, you want to make
sure that's it's legally binding, and

673
00:33:55,160 --> 00:33:57,940
it just takes a few mistakes in
the contract to invalidate it.

674
00:33:57,940 --> 00:34:00,500
So we need to make sure that
it is done properly, so

675
00:34:00,500 --> 00:34:03,130
that is our procurement document.

676
00:34:03,130 --> 00:34:04,680
So pretty important thing there,

677
00:34:04,680 --> 00:34:07,170
when we say procurement document
we're really meaning the contract.

678
00:34:08,980 --> 00:34:11,040
All right,
some of the other things that we have.

679
00:34:11,040 --> 00:34:14,080
Well now we start to get into
quite a bit of stuff here.

680
00:34:14,080 --> 00:34:17,720
The next one is probably
the one that looks small but

681
00:34:17,720 --> 00:34:20,970
it's actually way bigger,
source selection criteria.

682
00:34:22,355 --> 00:34:24,610
We're coming up with work
that needs to be done.

683
00:34:24,610 --> 00:34:26,450
We know it needs to be done.

684
00:34:26,450 --> 00:34:29,120
We don't necessarily know
who's going to do it yet.

685
00:34:29,120 --> 00:34:31,000
We talk about make or buy decisions.

686
00:34:31,000 --> 00:34:32,340
So if we decide to make it,

687
00:34:32,340 --> 00:34:35,570
if we're gonna do it ourselves,
then we don't necessarily need a contract.

688
00:34:35,570 --> 00:34:37,470
We are just going to do it ourselves,
and we go, right.

689
00:34:37,470 --> 00:34:41,100
And we document that with out make or buy
decision, how we've reached that decision.

690
00:34:41,100 --> 00:34:43,730
But, if we decided to go with a buy,
we're gonna buy this,

691
00:34:43,730 --> 00:34:47,160
we're gonna get somebody else
to do the work for us, then

692
00:34:47,160 --> 00:34:52,270
we need to do a source selection to find
out who it is that's gonna do the work.

693
00:34:52,270 --> 00:34:52,850
ALright.

694
00:34:52,850 --> 00:34:57,380
So through one means or another,
we're going to send out requests so

695
00:34:57,380 --> 00:35:00,730
that people can offer to do the work for
us, right?

696
00:35:00,730 --> 00:35:03,120
And then we need a way to pick
who that winner is going to be.

697
00:35:03,120 --> 00:35:04,358
And that's what it's
talking about right here.

698
00:35:04,358 --> 00:35:08,370
Source selection criteria is,
how do we pick the winner?

699
00:35:08,370 --> 00:35:12,030
And this is something that should be
