700
00:35:12,030 --> 00:35:14,900
How do we select the winner of a contract,
right?

701
00:35:14,900 --> 00:35:17,480
We're not necessarily drafting
the documents for this yet.

702
00:35:17,480 --> 00:35:21,090
This is kind of weird, because in the
other planning phases we do draft these

703
00:35:21,090 --> 00:35:25,550
documents, but for the procurement
cycle it actually happens in execution,

704
00:35:25,550 --> 00:35:27,120
that's when we draft the documents.

705
00:35:27,120 --> 00:35:31,050
But I want to do a high level overview of
some of the documents right now, just so

706
00:35:31,050 --> 00:35:33,500
we're familiar with them, and
then we'll revisit them later.

707
00:35:33,500 --> 00:35:36,509
And Rodney did a great job of
filling all of those in here.

708
00:35:38,330 --> 00:35:41,070
So when we talk about
procurement documents,

709
00:35:41,070 --> 00:35:44,850
here's an example of some of the different
ones that we might send out.

710
00:35:44,850 --> 00:35:45,720
Request for information.

711
00:35:46,780 --> 00:35:50,330
RFIs are really handy when you
don't know what you need, right.

712
00:35:50,330 --> 00:35:53,075
These typically occur
during the planning phase,

713
00:35:53,075 --> 00:35:54,590
cuz we're just trying to
figure out what's what.

714
00:35:54,590 --> 00:35:59,040
So I don't necessarily know what companies
are able to deliver something that I need.

715
00:35:59,040 --> 00:36:02,570
Maybe I need a very
specialized database developed.

716
00:36:02,570 --> 00:36:05,330
I know a lot of contractors and
consultants out there, but

717
00:36:05,330 --> 00:36:07,610
I don't know if they'll
do this specialized task.

718
00:36:07,610 --> 00:36:10,360
So I might draft up a letter
that says hey, we're looking for

719
00:36:10,360 --> 00:36:14,170
somebody who can develop a specialized
database that meets these needs,

720
00:36:14,170 --> 00:36:16,080
is that something you're able to do?

721
00:36:16,080 --> 00:36:17,942
And if you are, how would you go about it?

722
00:36:17,942 --> 00:36:20,350
What is your solution to this?

723
00:36:20,350 --> 00:36:23,770
What do you propose would be
the best way to handle this?

724
00:36:23,770 --> 00:36:27,380
And then you send this out, this request
for information, and they reply back.

725
00:36:27,380 --> 00:36:31,320
They reply back with one, whether or
not they can even do the job, right.

726
00:36:31,320 --> 00:36:32,343
They might not be able to and say no,

727
00:36:32,343 --> 00:36:34,670
thjat's kinda outside of what
we do we can't help you.

728
00:36:34,670 --> 00:36:38,390
And then if they can help us then
number two they tell us how.

729
00:36:38,390 --> 00:36:40,850
They say well for
what you're talking about,

730
00:36:40,850 --> 00:36:45,890
I would propose that we use a no
SQL database hosted on Amazon S3,

731
00:36:45,890 --> 00:36:50,130
or not S3, but Amazon what is
their dynamic database called?

732
00:36:50,130 --> 00:36:51,600
I think it's called anyhow.

733
00:36:51,600 --> 00:36:54,580
So you know hosted out there,
that would give us the best redundancy and

734
00:36:54,580 --> 00:36:55,960
that's what we propose.

735
00:36:55,960 --> 00:37:01,000
The other sellers might come in and
have different proposals.

736
00:37:01,000 --> 00:37:03,575
And so we get to evaluate those and
figure it out.

737
00:37:03,575 --> 00:37:07,420
RFIs are really handy when we just
don't know how to do something.

738
00:37:07,420 --> 00:37:10,520
We don't know what's necessary, very
difficult for us to draft up a document,

739
00:37:10,520 --> 00:37:13,650
so we're trying to get
more information on it.

740
00:37:13,650 --> 00:37:16,070
A request for proposal is similar.

741
00:37:16,070 --> 00:37:21,010
A request for proposal, we know what needs
to be done, we know who can do it, and

742
00:37:21,010 --> 00:37:24,250
so we reach out to those people,
we say, can you give us a proposal?

743
00:37:24,250 --> 00:37:28,470
What do you propose to do and how much
do you propose it's going to cost?

744
00:37:28,470 --> 00:37:32,980
So they're gonna give us different
solutions and what the cost would be.

745
00:37:32,980 --> 00:37:36,140
But if we already know the solution,
I know exactly what I need.

746
00:37:36,140 --> 00:37:41,280
I need dry wall installed in this house,
I need it done this way to these specs

747
00:37:41,280 --> 00:37:44,820
I don't want to hear about other
proposals, I want it done this way.

748
00:37:44,820 --> 00:37:49,090
In that scenario, we just want
a request for quotation, an RFQ.

749
00:37:50,120 --> 00:37:53,610
We say, here's what I want done,
how much is it going to cost,

750
00:37:53,610 --> 00:37:56,080
don't deviate from this,
I don't want to hear it.

751
00:37:56,080 --> 00:37:57,550
And that's not an uncommon thing,

752
00:37:57,550 --> 00:38:01,220
sometimes we want things done a particular
way, so RFQs are very common.

753
00:38:02,620 --> 00:38:05,230
Some of the other things that
we might have, things like,

754
00:38:05,230 --> 00:38:08,570
these become a little bit less common,
like tender notices.

755
00:38:08,570 --> 00:38:12,450
Where we talk about the tendering or
the providing of good.

756
00:38:12,450 --> 00:38:14,630
You know, we reach out and
we basically say,

757
00:38:14,630 --> 00:38:17,010
can you tell us if you're able to do this?

758
00:38:17,010 --> 00:38:19,790
Invitation for negotiation, right?

759
00:38:19,790 --> 00:38:22,305
We don't know what it's going to cost,
but whatever you say,

760
00:38:22,305 --> 00:38:23,730
we're not gonna pay that.

761
00:38:23,730 --> 00:38:26,160
So why don't you come in and
get into a negotiation with us.

762
00:38:26,160 --> 00:38:27,550
Talk to us about what you can do.

763
00:38:27,550 --> 00:38:28,540
We will talk about what we want and

764
00:38:28,540 --> 00:38:31,360
we'll come up with some kind of
agreement on what's provided.

765
00:38:31,360 --> 00:38:35,010
And then invitation for
sellers initial response.

766
00:38:35,010 --> 00:38:37,530
We reach out and we say, hey,
we're talking about this,

767
00:38:37,530 --> 00:38:39,080
we haven't really moved forward on it yet.

768
00:38:39,080 --> 00:38:43,510
But can you give us just some general
data, general information, your initial

769
00:38:43,510 --> 00:38:46,900
response to this idea, might be a bad
idea, you might tell us not to do it.

770
00:38:46,900 --> 00:38:48,570
Just give us some information, right?

771
00:38:48,570 --> 00:38:50,210
Those are not very common.

772
00:38:50,210 --> 00:38:53,570
These one, the ones up at the top here,
the ones that have nice initials,

773
00:38:53,570 --> 00:38:58,680
RFI, IFB, RFP, RFQ, those are the ones
that normally make it on the exam.

774
00:38:58,680 --> 00:39:01,310
But these are some of
the documents you might generate.

775
00:39:01,310 --> 00:39:04,070
Now we're not really generating
them now in the planning phase,

776
00:39:04,070 --> 00:39:06,120
although you might generate
them at the same time.

777
00:39:06,120 --> 00:39:09,640
It's really in the execution phase that
we create these, we send them out,

778
00:39:09,640 --> 00:39:10,710
we get our responses.

779
00:39:10,710 --> 00:39:15,160
Now you might ask yourself, if we don't
know how something's gonna get done and

780
00:39:15,160 --> 00:39:17,680
we're sending out a RFP.

781
00:39:17,680 --> 00:39:20,970
So we're asking people to
propose ways to get it done.

782
00:39:20,970 --> 00:39:23,650
If I don't know how to get it done,
I don't know how long it's gonna take.

783
00:39:23,650 --> 00:39:25,600
I don't know how much it's gonna cost.

784
00:39:25,600 --> 00:39:29,450
So if I'm doing that in the execution
phase, couldn't that affect my schedule,

785
00:39:29,450 --> 00:39:31,220
couldn't that effect my budget?

786
00:39:31,220 --> 00:39:32,590
Absolutely, right.

787
00:39:32,590 --> 00:39:37,540
So, these are some of the very first
things we do in the execution phase,

788
00:39:37,540 --> 00:39:39,000
when we're going chronologically.

789
00:39:39,000 --> 00:39:42,060
So, it's something that we move into very
rapidly, so that we can take account for

790
00:39:42,060 --> 00:39:44,150
it before we kick off
all of our other work.

791
00:39:44,150 --> 00:39:48,190
Many people opt to go ahead and
do these in the planning phase.

792
00:39:48,190 --> 00:39:48,790
I'm one of those.

793
00:39:48,790 --> 00:39:51,490
I like to do them in the planning
phase to get it done early.

794
00:39:51,490 --> 00:39:56,836
But, following the letter of the law,
following the PMBOK, in other words,

795
00:39:56,836 --> 00:40:02,602
on the exam, actually sending these out,
is a part of the execution phase alright.

796
00:40:02,602 --> 00:40:05,980
So make you separate that in your mind,
in real life you'll probably do this in

797
00:40:05,980 --> 00:40:08,650
planning, but on the exam it's
part of the execution phase.

798
00:40:08,650 --> 00:40:09,927
Cuz you're actually doing work.

799
00:40:09,927 --> 00:40:12,247
You're doing work, you're filling out
these forms, you're sending them out,

800
00:40:12,247 --> 00:40:13,852
you're getting them back,
you're making decisions.

801
00:40:13,852 --> 00:40:16,920
So in the planning phase we're just
planning for how to handle these,

802
00:40:16,920 --> 00:40:20,330
how we're gonna handle picking who
the winning proposal is, right.

803
00:40:20,330 --> 00:40:22,400
So we need to come up with those criteria,
and

804
00:40:22,400 --> 00:40:26,920
that's what leads us to our next output
which is the source selection criteria.

805
00:40:26,920 --> 00:40:29,590
And there's a ton of stuff there.

806
00:40:29,590 --> 00:40:33,290
How do we pick who the winner is
going to be, when all these people

807
00:40:33,290 --> 00:40:36,600
pose the work that they are going to do,
how do I pick the winner?

808
00:40:36,600 --> 00:40:38,830
Well, it can be as simple as cost.

809
00:40:38,830 --> 00:40:42,950
Maybe I'm in that mode where I just
want whoever is cheapest, that's it.

810
00:40:42,950 --> 00:40:45,610
But that's not normally
the right way to go.

811
00:40:45,610 --> 00:40:47,840
Normally, we're looking at other things.

812
00:40:47,840 --> 00:40:52,550
We're looking at things like
the overall or life cycle cost.

813
00:40:52,550 --> 00:40:54,000
Not just the upfront cost but

814
00:40:54,000 --> 00:40:57,000
how much it's going to cost to
maintain whatever this solution is.

815
00:40:57,000 --> 00:40:59,730
We're looking at the technical capability.

816
00:40:59,730 --> 00:41:03,600
There might be five different web
developers out there and the cheapest one

817
00:41:03,600 --> 00:41:07,320
might be a kid out of high school who
just doesn't have a lot of experience.

818
00:41:07,320 --> 00:41:11,880
The most expensive one might be one
that's been in the field for 20 years.

819
00:41:11,880 --> 00:41:15,900
Has a phD and is more expensive,
but has the knowledge and

820
00:41:15,900 --> 00:41:17,290
background to warrant it.

821
00:41:17,290 --> 00:41:21,520
We might go the more expensive one because
that technical capability results in

822
00:41:21,520 --> 00:41:24,360
something getting done faster and
being more scalable.

823
00:41:24,360 --> 00:41:26,430
So, that has to come into play, too.

824
00:41:26,430 --> 00:41:29,860
We've got to weigh all
the different criteria.

825
00:41:31,420 --> 00:41:35,630
The risk, when we contract something
out there's always risk, you know?

826
00:41:35,630 --> 00:41:37,820
That company could fold,
you just don't know.

827
00:41:37,820 --> 00:41:41,030
So, we have to take that into account
as we pick our different sellers.

828
00:41:42,340 --> 00:41:47,290
I think I gave an example of our disaster
recovery project out in Seattle.

829
00:41:47,290 --> 00:41:51,460
When we moved our disaster recovery center
we had to find a new data center to host

830
00:41:51,460 --> 00:41:56,820
it in, and I had selected a data
center that was run by AT&T.

831
00:41:56,820 --> 00:41:59,200
It was in Denver, Colorado.

832
00:41:59,200 --> 00:42:04,200
It was a massive data center and it was
run by one of the largest telecoms in

833
00:42:04,200 --> 00:42:06,880
the United States, really one of
the largest telecoms in the world.

834
00:42:06,880 --> 00:42:09,750
I knew these people knew their stuff,
right?

835
00:42:09,750 --> 00:42:12,220
Because they were of a global scale.

836
00:42:12,220 --> 00:42:14,140
They had the services we need.

837
00:42:14,140 --> 00:42:15,220
I prefered them, right?

838
00:42:16,410 --> 00:42:18,090
Ultimately we didn't pick them.

839
00:42:18,090 --> 00:42:22,110
We chose to go with another provider
that was in Spokane, Washington.

840
00:42:22,110 --> 00:42:23,230
It was very small.

841
00:42:23,230 --> 00:42:25,560
They had maybe 20, 30 employees.

842
00:42:25,560 --> 00:42:26,950
It was a fairly small environment.

843
00:42:26,950 --> 00:42:30,320
They had a very nice data center,
state of the art data center.

844
00:42:30,320 --> 00:42:30,940
But it was very small.

845
00:42:30,940 --> 00:42:33,560
They just had Spokane and that was it.

846
00:42:33,560 --> 00:42:38,200
All right, so
we opted to go with them because our CIO,

847
00:42:38,200 --> 00:42:42,000
our Chief Information Officer,
when he built his requirements, he said,

848
00:42:42,000 --> 00:42:45,630
he would rather deal with a small
company that knew us personally,

849
00:42:45,630 --> 00:42:48,590
that we could reach out and call,
and we could build a rapport with.

850
00:42:48,590 --> 00:42:51,280
That appreciated us as a customer,

851
00:42:51,280 --> 00:42:54,970
than deal with a massive conglomerate
who didn't care about us at all, right?

852
00:42:54,970 --> 00:42:58,880
That was important to him and
that criteria was more significant than

853
00:42:58,880 --> 00:43:03,410
the criteria of having a global level data
center which to me was more important.

854
00:43:03,410 --> 00:43:06,660
So, different people,
have different criteria, different things.

855
00:43:06,660 --> 00:43:08,100
And so we've got to catalog that.

856
00:43:08,100 --> 00:43:12,130
And so risk,
our CIO was willing to take the risk

857
00:43:12,130 --> 00:43:16,300
of a small company because he
felt we'd get better service.

858
00:43:16,300 --> 00:43:17,720
The trade off was there.

859
00:43:17,720 --> 00:43:21,580
Versus me, I was willing to deal with
a large entity that would probably ignore

860
00:43:21,580 --> 00:43:24,200
us, because I knew they had
a strong infrastructure and

861
00:43:24,200 --> 00:43:25,050
I knew they were stable.

862
00:43:25,050 --> 00:43:26,640
There were less risks.

863
00:43:26,640 --> 00:43:29,320
So that is something that comes into play.

864
00:43:29,320 --> 00:43:32,060
Well I kind of tied into this next one,
management approach.

865
00:43:32,060 --> 00:43:35,350
How does our management choose
to handle these contracts.

866
00:43:35,350 --> 00:43:36,400
The technical approach,

867
00:43:36,400 --> 00:43:39,110
again I kind of tied into that too,
the technical approach.

868
00:43:39,110 --> 00:43:42,890
So what is technically required of
the contract to be carried out.

869
00:43:42,890 --> 00:43:46,340
And who's gonna provide the best support.

870
00:43:46,340 --> 00:43:50,717
Warranty, right, whatever we contract out,
someone's coming in and doing work.

871
00:43:50,717 --> 00:43:54,895
They're not us, they don't work for
us full time so when the contract's over,

872
00:43:54,895 --> 00:43:56,365
do they care about us anymore?

873
00:43:56,365 --> 00:43:58,825
Probably not, they move on and that's it.

874
00:43:58,825 --> 00:44:01,775
We got rain gutters put on our
house a few months ago, and so

875
00:44:01,775 --> 00:44:04,280
we paid some guys to come out and
put the rain gutters up.

876
00:44:04,280 --> 00:44:06,140
It was a contract job,
it took him one day.

877
00:44:06,140 --> 00:44:08,130
They came in knocked it out,
did a great job.

878
00:44:08,130 --> 00:44:08,790
Alright.

879
00:44:08,790 --> 00:44:11,093
I can guarantee you today,
they don't remember my name,

880
00:44:11,093 --> 00:44:12,460
they don't remember my address.

881
00:44:12,460 --> 00:44:15,170
They have already installed
a thousand rain gutters since then.

882
00:44:15,170 --> 00:44:15,890
Right?

883
00:44:15,890 --> 00:44:19,040
And if those rain gutters
fall off my house.

884
00:44:19,040 --> 00:44:20,620
Who deals with that, all right?

885
00:44:20,620 --> 00:44:23,870
Well, mine came with I think it
was like a five year warranty.

886
00:44:23,870 --> 00:44:26,970
So if I've got five years where they'll
be you know they'll come out and

887
00:44:26,970 --> 00:44:27,890
they'll fix it.

888
00:44:27,890 --> 00:44:30,860
So different contractors have
different warranty times.

889
00:44:30,860 --> 00:44:32,250
Some don't have any warranty at all.

890
00:44:32,250 --> 00:44:33,230
They do the work and that's it.

891
00:44:33,230 --> 00:44:34,620
No liability.

892
00:44:34,620 --> 00:44:38,420
So we need to make sure that
we understand that as we pick

893
00:44:38,420 --> 00:44:40,840
who our winner is going to be.

894
00:44:40,840 --> 00:44:44,460
Financial capacity,
this is a big one that we bump into an IT.

895
00:44:44,460 --> 00:44:46,996
If your contracting somebody
to install 400 servers, and

896
00:44:46,996 --> 00:44:53,290
you wanna buy 400 servers, they've got to
buy the servers and then sell them to you.

897
00:44:53,290 --> 00:44:56,790
And if they're doing like net 60 terms,
you may not pay them for two months.

898
00:44:56,790 --> 00:45:02,190
So that means that they need to have
the cash on hand to buy 400 servers and

899
00:45:02,190 --> 00:45:03,520
sit on it for two months.

900
00:45:03,520 --> 00:45:04,320
Right?

901
00:45:04,320 --> 00:45:05,910
Not every company can do that.

902
00:45:05,910 --> 00:45:09,410
So going with larger companies
will allow you to do net 60,

903
00:45:09,410 --> 00:45:12,770
dealing with smaller companies,
you might need to do, pay in advance.

904
00:45:12,770 --> 00:45:13,820
Right.
So

905
00:45:13,820 --> 00:45:16,319
that is a criteria if that's
an important thing to you.

906
00:45:17,960 --> 00:45:20,190
Production capacity and interest.

907
00:45:20,190 --> 00:45:22,541
Boy we bumped into that with ITPRO.tv.

908
00:45:22,541 --> 00:45:25,170
ITPRO.tv when we opened we started,

909
00:45:25,170 --> 00:45:29,560
our servers were hosted by a company
that specialized in WordPress.

910
00:45:29,560 --> 00:45:31,800
The underlying infrastructure of our site,
and

911
00:45:31,800 --> 00:45:35,260
they said we can scale to
whatever size you need.

912
00:45:35,260 --> 00:45:35,960
All right?

913
00:45:35,960 --> 00:45:37,130
Well it turns out they couldn't.

914
00:45:37,130 --> 00:45:38,870
They just didn't have the capacity,

915
00:45:38,870 --> 00:45:42,610
they underestimated our
growth in our user base.

916
00:45:42,610 --> 00:45:45,750
We warned them, we said hey, we've got
technical users, they're gonna connect and

917
00:45:45,750 --> 00:45:46,600
they're gonna play videos.

918
00:45:46,600 --> 00:45:48,360
They're gonna be in there a lot.

919
00:45:48,360 --> 00:45:51,570
We're not some website where they log
in to read an article once a week.

920
00:45:51,570 --> 00:45:53,500
You know,
they're going to be watching videos.

921
00:45:53,500 --> 00:45:56,700
We need the resources, and
they couldn't handle it.

922
00:45:56,700 --> 00:45:58,970
So we ended up having to move.

923
00:45:58,970 --> 00:46:03,230
So that's something that we need to pay
attention to is thier production capacity.

924
00:46:03,230 --> 00:46:06,000
In this case they guarantee us
a certain production level, and

925
00:46:06,000 --> 00:46:09,230
they weren't able to meet their guarantee,
so we didn't have an liability.

926
00:46:09,230 --> 00:46:12,500
We were able to move
away without any issue.

927
00:46:12,500 --> 00:46:14,810
But, was it an inconvenience?

928
00:46:14,810 --> 00:46:15,400
Absolutely.

929
00:46:15,400 --> 00:46:18,040
I remember there were three days where I
was pulling my hair out as we switched

930
00:46:18,040 --> 00:46:21,670
providers, so that is something
that we want to try and identify.

931
00:46:23,420 --> 00:46:25,190
Business size and type.

932
00:46:25,190 --> 00:46:29,550
When you are contracting to someone else,
there are numerous business types,

933
00:46:29,550 --> 00:46:30,960
there's numerous corporation types.

934
00:46:30,960 --> 00:46:34,810
Limited liability corporations,
S Corps and so on.

935
00:46:34,810 --> 00:46:39,520
And each one is a different characteristic
of how that company is responsible for

936
00:46:39,520 --> 00:46:43,210
their debts, contracts and
other obligations.

937
00:46:43,210 --> 00:46:47,700
We need to make sure we pick ones
that we're safe doing business with.

938
00:46:47,700 --> 00:46:50,420
I've used construction as
an example throughout the show.

939
00:46:50,420 --> 00:46:53,490
In the state of Florida,
if you use a contractor in construction,

940
00:46:53,490 --> 00:46:55,500
they need to be licensed and bonded.

941
00:46:55,500 --> 00:46:57,710
They need to have insurance, right?

942
00:46:57,710 --> 00:46:58,610
Not all of them do.

943
00:46:58,610 --> 00:47:01,900
So the business size and type,
that really comes into play as to

944
00:47:01,900 --> 00:47:06,720
how well they are going to survive
market pitfalls and things like that.

945
00:47:06,720 --> 00:47:07,850
All right.

946
00:47:07,850 --> 00:47:10,020
Past performance is one
that I really like.

947
00:47:10,020 --> 00:47:14,073
When you have people sending in requests
for, or when they're sending in bids or

948
00:47:14,073 --> 00:47:17,150
proposals, they need to
include some references.

949
00:47:17,150 --> 00:47:18,950
I want to hear from their past customers.

950
00:47:18,950 --> 00:47:21,950
Are other people having good
experiences with them or not?

951
00:47:21,950 --> 00:47:26,310
I almost bought a new digital video
recorder, a DVR, the other day.

952
00:47:26,310 --> 00:47:27,610
Ronnie, have you heard of Simple TV?

953
00:47:27,610 --> 00:47:28,660
>> I have.

954
00:47:28,660 --> 00:47:31,120
>> Simple TV,
you see these commercials for it.

955
00:47:31,120 --> 00:47:32,560
It looks really cool.

956
00:47:32,560 --> 00:47:36,440
It's a DVR and
it'll stream to your phone and stuff.

957
00:47:36,440 --> 00:47:38,380
If you go into their forums and

958
00:47:38,380 --> 00:47:42,550
look at their forums, their support
forums, it's like one giant nightmare.

959
00:47:42,550 --> 00:47:44,240
And they don't respond.

960
00:47:44,240 --> 00:47:46,850
They do a quick response and
say we're looking into the issue and

961
00:47:46,850 --> 00:47:48,050
then they abandon it.

962
00:47:48,050 --> 00:47:50,870
And so there are tons of people
having problems with the device.

963
00:47:50,870 --> 00:47:52,800
I wouldn't know that from the commercial.

964
00:47:52,800 --> 00:47:54,280
But I read those forums and now I know.

965
00:47:54,280 --> 00:47:57,605
I looked at their past performance and
their past performance is not good, so

966
00:47:57,605 --> 00:47:58,894
not a great device to go with.

967
00:47:58,894 --> 00:48:02,039
That might change down the road but
I'm not gonna put up with that now.

968
00:48:02,039 --> 00:48:03,399
So I'm glad I did that.

969
00:48:03,399 --> 00:48:05,279
We do that with simple transactions.

970
00:48:05,279 --> 00:48:06,778
You go on Amazon and you read the reviews.

971
00:48:06,778 --> 00:48:07,833
There's that kind of thing.

972
00:48:07,833 --> 00:48:10,213
When you deal with a contractor,
read their reviews.

973
00:48:10,213 --> 00:48:13,560
They're not posted on Yelp or
anything, but ask for references,

974
00:48:13,560 --> 00:48:15,430
get some of their previous clients.

975
00:48:15,430 --> 00:48:19,170
Find other people that have used them
to see what kind of work they do,

976
00:48:19,170 --> 00:48:20,404
which is references.

977
00:48:20,404 --> 00:48:22,890
So the references,
they're what's going to feed that to you.

978
00:48:24,040 --> 00:48:25,472
Intellectual property rights.

979
00:48:25,472 --> 00:48:28,625
All right, now, if you're building
a house, you may not, well actually,

980
00:48:28,625 --> 00:48:30,337
they care about it too cuz you have plans.

981
00:48:30,337 --> 00:48:32,930
You have blueprints for the house and
that's intellectual property.

982
00:48:32,930 --> 00:48:36,141
In IT, if I have a contractor
work on our website,

983
00:48:36,141 --> 00:48:39,437
they could download copies
of all of our episodes.

984
00:48:39,437 --> 00:48:42,450
And then they could turn around and
do all sorts of crazy things with them.

985
00:48:42,450 --> 00:48:46,740
So any contract that we enter into
we have a clause in there that says,

986
00:48:46,740 --> 00:48:50,040
all of our content, our videos, our HTML,

987
00:48:50,040 --> 00:48:55,880
all that content is the property of
our parent company, EdutainmentLIVE.

988
00:48:55,880 --> 00:48:59,650
So it's part of EdutainmentLIVE,
and you're not allowed to use it.

989
00:48:59,650 --> 00:49:01,640
You can work with it while
the contract is active, but

990
00:49:01,640 --> 00:49:04,730
when the contract is over,
you relinquish all materials.

991
00:49:04,730 --> 00:49:06,520
You turn everything back in to us.

992
00:49:06,520 --> 00:49:08,330
You have no ongoing rights to that.

993
00:49:08,330 --> 00:49:08,940
That's important.

994
00:49:10,450 --> 00:49:12,110
And then proprietary rights.

995
00:49:12,110 --> 00:49:16,170
If you are dealing with copyrighted
things, patented things,

996
00:49:16,170 --> 00:49:18,740
that just because a contractor comes and
does work for you,

997
00:49:18,740 --> 00:49:24,210
that doesn't give them a license right
to use that patented material long term.

998
00:49:24,210 --> 00:49:26,870
So again they need to know
there is no extended benefits.

999
00:49:26,870 --> 00:49:28,790
These are things that are important.

1000
00:49:28,790 --> 00:49:33,520
We need to make sure that works for
our material going to them and for

1001
00:49:33,520 --> 00:49:35,480
their material to come to us.

1002
00:49:35,480 --> 00:49:40,593
If the seller comes in and does something
using their own proprietary technology,

1003
00:49:40,593 --> 00:49:43,815
they do have to give us
license to continue using it.

1004
00:49:43,815 --> 00:49:47,460
Otherwise when the contract is over,
we lose the work they did.

1005
00:49:47,460 --> 00:49:48,290
Yeah, yep,

1006
00:49:48,290 --> 00:49:53,030
so these are all things that we need to be
aware of with source selection criteria.

1007
00:49:53,030 --> 00:49:57,061
So, what we're drafting right here is
not necessarily here's the criteria.

1008
00:49:57,061 --> 00:50:01,202
What we're doing is we're putting
this in our project management plan,

1009
00:50:01,202 --> 00:50:05,007
in our procurement plan to say
here's the criteria that we look at,

1010
00:50:05,007 --> 00:50:07,570
that we classify when
we make that decision.

1011
00:50:07,570 --> 00:50:09,820
It might be all of these,
it might be half of these.

1012
00:50:09,820 --> 00:50:11,200
We pick and choose the ones that we want.

1013
00:50:13,052 --> 00:50:18,210
All right, so once we've got all that,
the only other things that we've got,

1014
00:50:18,210 --> 00:50:19,420
project document updates.

1015
00:50:19,420 --> 00:50:23,100
We update our plans and
other things, and change requests.

1016
00:50:23,100 --> 00:50:25,220
Now this is the first time
we've seen change requests,

1017
00:50:25,220 --> 00:50:27,510
and we're gonna do a whole show
on change management later on

1018
00:50:28,870 --> 00:50:31,800
because we're finding out
information about these contracts.

1019
00:50:31,800 --> 00:50:34,220
We might do some RFIs,
learn some information.

1020
00:50:34,220 --> 00:50:37,210
Odds are things in our
project are going to change.

1021
00:50:37,210 --> 00:50:41,940
Our schedule might have to change, our
budget might have to change, and so on.

1022
00:50:41,940 --> 00:50:46,070
So, this is the first time that we're
going to see change requests be generated.

1023
00:50:46,070 --> 00:50:50,360
We need to go and modify our other
documents to reflect what we just learned.

1024
00:50:50,360 --> 00:50:52,356
And at a minimum we're
updating resource names.

1025
00:50:52,356 --> 00:50:54,910
So where I had web developer one,
two, and three,

1026
00:50:54,910 --> 00:50:59,470
I might now have external company
A that we're contracting that out to.

1027
00:50:59,470 --> 00:51:01,104
They're gonna come and provide that labor.

1028
00:51:01,104 --> 00:51:06,128
So these are our changes that'll
have to go in to update our project.

1029
00:51:06,128 --> 00:51:10,261
All right, so that's really all that's
involved in procurement management.

1030
00:51:10,261 --> 00:51:13,260
It's pretty light here,
we just kind of talk about the concepts.

1031
00:51:13,260 --> 00:51:17,654
When we get in the execution phase, I'll
show you guys some examples of RFQs and

1032
00:51:17,654 --> 00:51:21,607
stuff, and so we'll get a chance to
see how that actually carries out.

1033
00:51:21,607 --> 00:51:24,740
All right, so,
you know what Ronnie let's do this.

1034
00:51:24,740 --> 00:51:26,630
Let's stop here and take a little break.

1035
00:51:26,630 --> 00:51:28,740
We have stakeholder management left.

1036
00:51:28,740 --> 00:51:31,300
That's our last one, and
stakeholder management very,

1037
00:51:31,300 --> 00:51:33,210
very short not a whole
heck of a lot there.

1038
00:51:33,210 --> 00:51:35,324
But let's stop and take a brief break.

1039
00:51:35,324 --> 00:51:37,453
When we get back, we'll knock
out stakeholder management, and

1040
00:51:37,453 --> 00:51:38,778
then we'll wrap up the show from there.

1041
00:51:38,778 --> 00:51:39,778
Sound good?

1042
00:51:39,778 --> 00:51:40,844
>> Sounds great.

1043
00:51:40,844 --> 00:51:41,430
>> All right, so, ladies and
gentlemen, stay tuned.

1044
00:51:41,430 --> 00:51:43,448
We'll be back in a few.

1045
00:51:43,448 --> 00:51:49,249
[MUSIC]

1046
00:51:49,249 --> 00:51:51,390
All right, welcome back, everybody.

1047
00:51:51,390 --> 00:51:55,190
So the last process in our planning phase,

1048
00:51:55,190 --> 00:51:57,530
is the plan stakeholder
management process.

1049
00:51:57,530 --> 00:52:00,460
And it, fortunately,
is one of the smallest ones

1050
00:52:00,460 --> 00:52:03,820
cuz we've kind of been dealing with
our stakeholders all throughout.

1051
00:52:03,820 --> 00:52:07,920
Yeah, we already did a lot of the work in
the initiation phase as we came up with

1052
00:52:07,920 --> 00:52:09,210
our stakeholder list.

1053
00:52:09,210 --> 00:52:11,450
And we've revised that
in our planning phases.

1054
00:52:11,450 --> 00:52:13,650
We've started building up
our stakeholder registers.

1055
00:52:13,650 --> 00:52:16,170
We've seen that register
several times now.

1056
00:52:16,170 --> 00:52:18,771
So here, we're just saying, all right,

1057
00:52:18,771 --> 00:52:21,531
let's finish up that
register if we need to.

1058
00:52:21,531 --> 00:52:25,056
And then let's come up with our
stakeholder management plan if we don't

1059
00:52:25,056 --> 00:52:26,340
already have one.

1060
00:52:26,340 --> 00:52:29,670
And that management plan is just
how we keep our project up to date,

1061
00:52:29,670 --> 00:52:33,710
how we add and remove stakeholders,
and that kind of information.

1062
00:52:33,710 --> 00:52:36,270
The input here is pretty straightforward,
that stakeholder register,

1063
00:52:36,270 --> 00:52:39,410
which is where we've already done
our work, that's the main input.

1064
00:52:39,410 --> 00:52:41,030
If you've got a project management plan,

1065
00:52:41,030 --> 00:52:44,140
you bring that in too because
that'll tell you how to do this.

1066
00:52:44,140 --> 00:52:45,880
Your enterprise environmental factors and

1067
00:52:45,880 --> 00:52:48,260
organizational process assets
like we're used to seeing, right?

1068
00:52:48,260 --> 00:52:51,550
Those are all of our inputs
on this particular process.

1069
00:52:51,550 --> 00:52:53,220
Tools and techniques are very light.

1070
00:52:53,220 --> 00:52:55,460
Expert judgement, right,
you've got to use your noodle.

1071
00:52:55,460 --> 00:52:58,240
And meetings, get people
together to talk about it, right?

1072
00:52:58,240 --> 00:52:59,870
Those are pretty common sense.

1073
00:52:59,870 --> 00:53:02,240
But the third one is
analytical techniques.

1074
00:53:02,240 --> 00:53:04,760
This is ways that we can break

1075
00:53:04,760 --> 00:53:07,960
down our stakeholders to figure
out how to address them.

1076
00:53:07,960 --> 00:53:10,832
And there's a few techniques called
out specifically in the PMBOK.

1077
00:53:10,832 --> 00:53:11,770
There's five, all right.

1078
00:53:13,010 --> 00:53:17,060
The first one is, all right,
they are not techniques.

1079
00:53:17,060 --> 00:53:21,033
There's five different descriptions,
categories, or

1080
00:53:21,033 --> 00:53:24,680
whatever that we apply
to our stakeholders.

1081
00:53:24,680 --> 00:53:29,220
So you'll see here unaware, resistant,
neutral, supportive, leading.

1082
00:53:30,480 --> 00:53:34,500
Each stakeholder has a different
role within our project.

1083
00:53:34,500 --> 00:53:37,580
And we talked about this back in
the initiating phase where we said,

1084
00:53:37,580 --> 00:53:40,800
I don't know why I pronounced that weird,
but the initiating phase.

1085
00:53:40,800 --> 00:53:44,770
Where we said that different people
may want to help your project,

1086
00:53:44,770 --> 00:53:47,120
some people might want
to hurt your project.

1087
00:53:47,120 --> 00:53:48,520
Some people might be ambivalent, but

1088
00:53:48,520 --> 00:53:53,320
are just attached to the project
through some tangent or whatever.

1089
00:53:53,320 --> 00:53:55,260
And so that's what these are saying.

1090
00:53:55,260 --> 00:53:57,490
Basically unaware,
that's one you don't want to have.

1091
00:53:57,490 --> 00:54:01,810
That means you don't know how that
person is going to affect your project.

1092
00:54:01,810 --> 00:54:04,010
You don't know if they support it,
they don't support it.

1093
00:54:04,010 --> 00:54:07,985
On day one all of your
stakeholders are kind of unaware.

1094
00:54:07,985 --> 00:54:10,405
We don't know exactly how
they are going to affect us.

1095
00:54:10,405 --> 00:54:12,555
We need to find out, all right.

1096
00:54:12,555 --> 00:54:17,665
After that, we have really resistant,
neutral, and supportive, okay.

1097
00:54:17,665 --> 00:54:20,665
Resistant, this is someone that
is aware of your project but

1098
00:54:20,665 --> 00:54:22,345
doesn't necessary support it.

1099
00:54:22,345 --> 00:54:27,295
Maybe they, it's change they don't want,
or they think the project is a bad idea.

1100
00:54:27,295 --> 00:54:28,735
So they don't want it to happen.

1101
00:54:28,735 --> 00:54:31,490
These are people that
are not going to help you.

1102
00:54:31,490 --> 00:54:33,970
And so we need to understand
who those people are so

1103
00:54:33,970 --> 00:54:36,150
that we can properly address that.

1104
00:54:36,150 --> 00:54:39,100
Neutral, these are people that
are attached to your project through

1105
00:54:39,100 --> 00:54:43,260
one means or another but aren't
necessarily contingent on the outcome.

1106
00:54:43,260 --> 00:54:45,590
They don't care if it succeeds or fails.

1107
00:54:45,590 --> 00:54:49,757
That's fine, as long as we know that
they're properly doing their work.

1108
00:54:49,757 --> 00:54:53,073
These are typically people that need to
be monitored a little more just to ensure

1109
00:54:53,073 --> 00:54:57,260
the work is getting done cuz they don't
have a vested interest in the project.

1110
00:54:57,260 --> 00:55:00,040
Supportive, these are the people
who are gonna help you the most.

1111
00:55:00,040 --> 00:55:02,753
These are the people who want
this project to succeed.

1112
00:55:02,753 --> 00:55:05,776
They have a vested interest
in the success of it, and so

1113
00:55:05,776 --> 00:55:09,150
we can rely upon them to be able
to move that project forward.

1114
00:55:10,980 --> 00:55:14,365
Leading, this is gonna be your
entire project management team,

1115
00:55:14,365 --> 00:55:19,100
right, as well as any other people like
sponsors who are key stakeholders.

1116
00:55:19,100 --> 00:55:23,700
They don't just want this project to
succeed, they're ready to get involved and

1117
00:55:23,700 --> 00:55:27,150
drag others along with them
to ensure that it succeeds.

1118
00:55:27,150 --> 00:55:31,910
And you're gonna need somebody leading
to overcome anybody who's resistant.

1119
00:55:31,910 --> 00:55:34,460
You might have somebody who
doesn't like your project.

1120
00:55:34,460 --> 00:55:37,120
But if the CIO comes over and says,
look you're gonna help out or

1121
00:55:37,120 --> 00:55:40,970
your fired, all the sudden
they become supportive, right.

1122
00:55:40,970 --> 00:55:42,818
That's all it takes is that authority.

1123
00:55:42,818 --> 00:55:49,130
So the stakeholders who are supportive,

1124
00:55:49,130 --> 00:55:53,600
who are leading, they're the ones that
are really gonna drive this project along.

1125
00:55:53,600 --> 00:55:55,580
So we just identify that.

1126
00:55:55,580 --> 00:55:59,610
And we've kind of already done it, because
we saw it in our stakeholder register.

1127
00:55:59,610 --> 00:56:02,026
But, what we'll do is we'll draft this up.

1128
00:56:02,026 --> 00:56:04,824
We'll update our register with
any information that we gain.

1129
00:56:04,824 --> 00:56:08,561
And we'll draft our
stakeholder management plan.

1130
00:56:08,561 --> 00:56:10,690
Now I've got a stakeholder
management plan template.

1131
00:56:10,690 --> 00:56:12,620
I just kinda wanna show you some
of the things that go in there.

1132
00:56:12,620 --> 00:56:16,980
But we've got our stake holder, and you'll
see where we're flagging them as being

1133
00:56:16,980 --> 00:56:20,480
unaware, resistant, neutral supportive,
or leading, all right.

1134
00:56:20,480 --> 00:56:23,685
And then we flag them with
a current level of engagement and

1135
00:56:23,685 --> 00:56:25,320
a desired level of engagement.

1136
00:56:25,320 --> 00:56:27,990
So, where they are now,
everybody starts at unaware.

1137
00:56:29,020 --> 00:56:31,990
And then as we engage them, we start
to categorize them with where they are.

1138
00:56:31,990 --> 00:56:35,770
So we put their current level and
their desire, where we want to get them.

1139
00:56:36,930 --> 00:56:40,870
Then our communications, and we saw this
in the communications management plan, but

1140
00:56:40,870 --> 00:56:43,640
how we're gonna communicate out to
these people, what methods or mediums,

1141
00:56:43,640 --> 00:56:45,410
what timing and frequencies.

1142
00:56:45,410 --> 00:56:49,380
When you see overlap like this between the
two plans, does that mean we do it twice?

1143
00:56:49,380 --> 00:56:51,370
No, we pick which one we want.

1144
00:56:51,370 --> 00:56:55,180
I know many organizations just
skip this whole knowledge area,

1145
00:56:55,180 --> 00:56:56,350
the stakeholder management,

1146
00:56:56,350 --> 00:57:01,450
because it doesn't necessarily affect the
whole project, but we see overlap here.

1147
00:57:01,450 --> 00:57:06,500
Pending stakeholder changes, f we have
stakeholders that are coming in or

1148
00:57:06,500 --> 00:57:08,980
going out, we identify that here.

1149
00:57:08,980 --> 00:57:13,370
If this is our plan, we just specify the
method that these people come in and out.

1150
00:57:13,370 --> 00:57:16,020
Can just anybody become
a stakeholder if they want to?

1151
00:57:16,020 --> 00:57:17,930
Is there a form they have to fill out?

1152
00:57:17,930 --> 00:57:20,730
Or does the project manager determine
who's going to be a stakeholder?

1153
00:57:20,730 --> 00:57:22,290
How do we do that, right?

1154
00:57:22,290 --> 00:57:24,804
If this is actually becoming
a part of our individual project,

1155
00:57:24,804 --> 00:57:28,700
we'll put individual people who's
gonna come on at what time.

1156
00:57:28,700 --> 00:57:31,560
Maybe they're not a stakeholder now, but
they will be two months from now, and so

1157
00:57:31,560 --> 00:57:32,100
we put that in.

1158
00:57:33,290 --> 00:57:35,020
Stakeholder relationships.

1159
00:57:35,020 --> 00:57:38,680
Oftentimes one stakeholder will
be linked to another somehow,

1160
00:57:38,680 --> 00:57:42,310
either as a functional manager,
or maybe just as a close friend.

1161
00:57:42,310 --> 00:57:46,100
And so you know that when one makes
a decision, the other is likely to follow.

1162
00:57:46,100 --> 00:57:47,449
It's good to understand those connections.

1163
00:57:49,430 --> 00:57:53,560
And then lastly,
our stakeholder engagement approach.

1164
00:57:53,560 --> 00:57:57,410
How are we going to be reaching out
to these people and handling them?

1165
00:57:57,410 --> 00:58:00,570
So if I have somebody who is
not supportive of my project,

1166
00:58:00,570 --> 00:58:03,710
they're resistant,
how do I approach them, right?

1167
00:58:03,710 --> 00:58:05,930
Maybe I never approach them directly.

1168
00:58:05,930 --> 00:58:08,930
But instead, I always approach them
through their functional manager.

1169
00:58:08,930 --> 00:58:13,580
Maybe I'll just say, look, this person
is outwardly hostile to my project.

1170
00:58:13,580 --> 00:58:16,760
So I will always deal with
their functional manager.

1171
00:58:16,760 --> 00:58:19,815
Or we say, our approach is going
to be to go and replace them.

1172
00:58:19,815 --> 00:58:22,525
We need to get them off of this
project as soon as we can, and

1173
00:58:22,525 --> 00:58:24,645
replace them with somebody
who is supportive, right?

1174
00:58:24,645 --> 00:58:26,565
No sense dragging along dead weight.

1175
00:58:26,565 --> 00:58:30,355
So those are some of the things that
we can identify in our stakeholder

1176
00:58:30,355 --> 00:58:31,210
management plan.

1177
00:58:31,210 --> 00:58:33,582
We put that information in there,
and we've got it.

1178
00:58:33,582 --> 00:58:35,752
Now, I've mentioned a lot of
companies don't do this, and

1179
00:58:35,752 --> 00:58:39,952
the reason is employees don't like
to be categorized as resistant.

1180
00:58:39,952 --> 00:58:44,042
Employees don't like to be categorized
as having an approach to handling them.

1181
00:58:44,042 --> 00:58:45,820
People don't like this stuff.

1182
00:58:45,820 --> 00:58:48,610
And so as a result,
doing it might hurt some feelings,

1183
00:58:48,610 --> 00:58:50,620
might get some people angry.

1184
00:58:50,620 --> 00:58:53,720
And so many organizations just
don't create a document like this.

1185
00:58:53,720 --> 00:58:56,112
But with the PMI the frame work is there.

1186
00:58:56,112 --> 00:58:59,710
If you want, you've got the tools,
you can use it.

1187
00:58:59,710 --> 00:59:01,280
If you don't, you leave it out.

1188
00:59:01,280 --> 00:59:04,130
But on the exam, it exists,
you need to be aware of it, and

1189
00:59:04,130 --> 00:59:06,100
it is something you definitely can use.

1190
00:59:06,100 --> 00:59:09,970
>> Yeah, this is also where a lot of
times, we had mentioned a term earlier.

1191
00:59:09,970 --> 00:59:10,926
I think maybe in the first episode we
were talking about a project champion

1192
00:59:10,926 --> 00:59:11,838
really coming in, and actually being
kind of the coach to everyone.

1193
00:59:11,838 --> 00:59:14,819
Even those people that are again,
unaware or resistant may come over if

1194
00:59:14,819 --> 00:59:18,061
you actually have the right communication
plan in method, or in place here.

1195
00:59:18,061 --> 00:59:21,860
And along with a project champion

1196
00:59:23,081 --> 00:59:27,559
she helped them win them over into where

1197
00:59:27,559 --> 00:59:32,884
they're now supportive, and even leading.

1198
00:59:32,884 --> 00:59:34,452
>> Yup, awesome.

1199
00:59:34,452 --> 00:59:36,170
All right,
well that is one of the shorter ones.

1200
00:59:36,170 --> 00:59:36,990
I mean if you take a look,

1201
00:59:36,990 --> 00:59:41,350
it's probably the only process where
the notes all fit on one screen.

1202
00:59:41,350 --> 00:59:44,090
So pretty straightforward there.

1203
00:59:44,090 --> 00:59:44,770
But yeah, it is important.

1204
00:59:44,770 --> 00:59:46,440
It's something we need to take care of.

1205
00:59:46,440 --> 00:59:51,390
So, with that one,
we've now finished the planning phase.

1206
00:59:51,390 --> 00:59:57,790
We've now covered all of the processes
in that planning process group.

1207
00:59:57,790 --> 00:59:59,380
Now we're ready to move on.

1208
00:59:59,380 --> 01:00:01,120
Now, which is the next phase?

1209
01:00:01,120 --> 01:00:05,630
The next phase is the executing process
group, but we may not move directly to it.

1210
01:00:05,630 --> 01:00:10,050
We're gonna get to the closing process
group at the end of the show, and

1211
01:00:10,050 --> 01:00:14,230
you technically call on the closing
group at the end of every phase.

1212
01:00:14,230 --> 01:00:16,880
So at the end of initiating,
we did closing.

1213
01:00:16,880 --> 01:00:19,670
At the end of planning, we now do closing.

1214
01:00:19,670 --> 01:00:22,440
And the primary goal of doing
closing is to ensure that

1215
01:00:22,440 --> 01:00:25,060
all of our paperwork is in order.

1216
01:00:25,060 --> 01:00:28,020
If we've drafted ten different
versions of the scope,

1217
01:00:28,020 --> 01:00:30,350
we need to sign off on the final one.

1218
01:00:30,350 --> 01:00:32,660
So we do closing to ensure
that that's all in order,

1219
01:00:32,660 --> 01:00:36,160
that all the paperwork is ready, and
we're ready to move to executing.

1220
01:00:36,160 --> 01:00:39,320
But when we call it at the end,
it actually closes the whole project down.

1221
01:00:39,320 --> 01:00:42,360
We're not ready to do that,
well unless it's a terrible project.

1222
01:00:42,360 --> 01:00:45,530
But we're just making
sure our ducks in a row

1223
01:00:45,530 --> 01:00:47,510
before we move to executing, all right?

1224
01:00:47,510 --> 01:00:50,820
But with that, we're done,
we're ready to move to executing.

1225
01:00:50,820 --> 01:00:53,450
So this a pretty good spot for us to stop.

1226
01:00:53,450 --> 01:00:57,170
We'll cut it here, and
that'll end the planning process group.

1227
01:00:57,170 --> 01:00:59,460
We'll pick up with executing, and
we're gonna jump right back in.

1228
01:00:59,460 --> 01:01:01,836
We'll get into directed
managed project work, and

1229
01:01:01,836 --> 01:01:04,540
you'll see that even that's
a light process group for us.

1230
01:01:04,540 --> 01:01:07,970
Because as the project manager, you're
not normally the one doing the work.

1231
01:01:07,970 --> 01:01:10,790
While other people are doing it,
you're monitoring and controlling so

1232
01:01:10,790 --> 01:01:12,750
that's where we'll see
most of our efforts.

1233
01:01:12,750 --> 01:01:14,570
But, let's go ahead and stop here.

1234
01:01:14,570 --> 01:01:17,360
Ronnie, can you think of anything
should throw in before we wrap up?

1235
01:01:17,360 --> 01:01:21,114
>> No, just remember because of how big
the section is, right, the motto that

1236
01:01:21,114 --> 01:01:24,988
we've always come up with even since
the beginning of the show is that projects

1237
01:01:24,988 --> 01:01:28,470
don't fail during the execution or
the monitoring and controlling.

1238
01:01:28,470 --> 01:01:31,060
If they tend to fail anywhere,
it's during the planning stage.

1239
01:01:31,060 --> 01:01:34,440
So, take a lot of time,
make sure you go over these processes and

1240
01:01:34,440 --> 01:01:35,460
understand them fairly well.

1241
01:01:37,160 --> 01:01:41,140
>> All right, well let me remind you guys,
if you have any questions, you can always,

1242
01:01:41,140 --> 01:01:43,400
live during the show, go to itpro.tv/live.

1243
01:01:43,400 --> 01:01:45,862
And you'll see the chat box
right beneath the video,

1244
01:01:45,862 --> 01:01:48,010
you can post your questions in there.

1245
01:01:48,010 --> 01:01:49,230
We monitor and answer.

1246
01:01:49,230 --> 01:01:52,054
If you have questions after the show,
you can use the Q & A forums.

1247
01:01:52,054 --> 01:01:55,400
You'll see the Q & A link at
the top of every single page.

1248
01:01:55,400 --> 01:01:56,520
That'll take you in there.

1249
01:01:56,520 --> 01:01:58,960
Post your questions, and
again, we monitor and answer.

1250
01:01:58,960 --> 01:02:00,860
So definitely take
advantage of that resource.

1251
01:02:00,860 --> 01:02:02,850
It is there for you.

1252
01:02:02,850 --> 01:02:05,320
Well signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1253
01:02:05,320 --> 01:02:06,100
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1254
01:02:06,100 --> 01:02:07,008
>> And we will see you next time.

1255
01:02:07,008 --> 01:02:17,008
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don begin the next phase of project management. They talk about the transition into the monitoring and controlling while the project is being executed and work packages are being accomplished. They describe the need to direct and manage the project rather than micro managing every aspect of the project. They talk about using Project Management Information Systems to see the big picture while the project is being executed.
episodes.title: Execution Part 1
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,006 --> 00:00:10,006
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,249 --> 00:00:22,497
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,497 --> 00:00:33,385
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,385 --> 00:00:36,919
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening and

5
00:00:36,919 --> 00:00:39,410
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:39,410 --> 00:00:41,180
I'm your host Don Pezet.

7
00:00:41,180 --> 00:00:42,410
Back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:42,410 --> 00:00:43,540
How's it going, Ronnie?

9
00:00:43,540 --> 00:00:46,410
>> I'm doing okay today,
because I found out that you and

10
00:00:46,410 --> 00:00:48,410
I can do the same number of pull ups.

11
00:00:48,410 --> 00:00:49,165
That's pretty bad.

12
00:00:49,165 --> 00:00:52,260
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] The sad things that go on

13
00:00:52,260 --> 00:00:54,020
around this studio when
we're not shooting,

14
00:00:54,020 --> 00:00:56,480
we did have a pull up competition.

15
00:00:56,480 --> 00:01:01,605
Ronnie and I did tie on the amount of
pull ups, sadly that number was one.

16
00:01:01,605 --> 00:01:04,330
[LAUGH] Yeah.

17
00:01:04,330 --> 00:01:07,930
All right, so,
upper body strength is not our forte.

18
00:01:07,930 --> 00:01:10,760
But fortunately, today we're gonna
do some more project management,

19
00:01:10,760 --> 00:01:13,465
which doesn't require
much upper body strength.

20
00:01:13,465 --> 00:01:16,000
[LAUGH] The real sad part, Ronnie?

21
00:01:16,000 --> 00:01:18,665
We're both gonna be sore tomorrow,
from our one pull.

22
00:01:18,665 --> 00:01:20,580
[LAUGH]
>> I'm already breathing hard.

23
00:01:20,580 --> 00:01:22,050
>> Sad state of affairs.

24
00:01:22,050 --> 00:01:23,728
President Bush would be so disappointed.

25
00:01:23,728 --> 00:01:26,120
[LAUGH] Or President Reagan,

26
00:01:26,120 --> 00:01:28,855
Reagan was the one who was really
pushing the health fitness, whatever.

27
00:01:28,855 --> 00:01:29,890
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, all right,

28
00:01:29,890 --> 00:01:34,220
so today we are kicking
off the execution phase.

29
00:01:34,220 --> 00:01:37,230
And this is one of those phases
that's really interesting cuz

30
00:01:37,230 --> 00:01:40,170
it's where the work really starts, where

31
00:01:40,170 --> 00:01:44,090
people start performing the activities
that are going to complete our project.

32
00:01:44,090 --> 00:01:47,660
And that means, boy, take out all
the stops, all the action's happening,

33
00:01:47,660 --> 00:01:49,020
things go crazy.

34
00:01:49,020 --> 00:01:53,650
Well as a project manager, for
us, things actually slow down.

35
00:01:53,650 --> 00:01:56,700
We bust our butts in the planning phases,
we're getting ready.

36
00:01:56,700 --> 00:01:59,180
And now that's it's time to execute,
it's time for

37
00:01:59,180 --> 00:02:01,800
us to turn the reigns over
to the work package owners,

38
00:02:01,800 --> 00:02:04,639
the people who are actually going
to do the work to get things done.

39
00:02:05,660 --> 00:02:09,960
That doesn't mean that we kick our feet up
on the table, drink a mai tai and relax.

40
00:02:09,960 --> 00:02:11,700
Or maybe you do,
depends on the office you work in.

41
00:02:11,700 --> 00:02:16,980
But normally what it means is that
we transition into monitoring and

42
00:02:16,980 --> 00:02:17,920
controlling.

43
00:02:17,920 --> 00:02:20,600
We start watching the work
that's getting done

44
00:02:20,600 --> 00:02:23,310
to ensure that it does in fact get done.

45
00:02:23,310 --> 00:02:27,690
So that's our role at this point and
it actually usually does ease up on us.

46
00:02:27,690 --> 00:02:30,970
Which is good cuz it takes a lot
to get through the planning phase.

47
00:02:30,970 --> 00:02:35,010
So as we move through
the execution process groups and

48
00:02:35,010 --> 00:02:36,530
the knowledge areas inside of there.

49
00:02:36,530 --> 00:02:39,230
When we start working through those,
you're gonna see there's not a whole heck

50
00:02:39,230 --> 00:02:40,790
of a lot here for
the project manager to do.

51
00:02:40,790 --> 00:02:41,970
And that's fine,

52
00:02:41,970 --> 00:02:44,900
because when this is done we're going to
take a look at monitoring and controlling.

53
00:02:44,900 --> 00:02:47,750
And there is a lot for us to do there and
it's mostly paperwork.

54
00:02:47,750 --> 00:02:50,050
So it's not the most exciting but

55
00:02:50,050 --> 00:02:52,770
it is very rewarding because we
are seeing the project move along.

56
00:02:52,770 --> 00:02:56,260
All right, so
the first one we're gonna take a look at.

57
00:02:56,260 --> 00:03:01,070
Let me bring up my process
group guide o stuff.

58
00:03:01,070 --> 00:03:02,330
Hang on just a second.

59
00:03:02,330 --> 00:03:04,490
Let me click and click and click.

60
00:03:04,490 --> 00:03:05,790
There we go.

61
00:03:05,790 --> 00:03:09,040
So here's the kind of
process group structure, and

62
00:03:09,040 --> 00:03:13,250
in the executing process group,
you'll notice how it's a little light.

63
00:03:13,250 --> 00:03:15,930
There's no risk management going on.

64
00:03:15,930 --> 00:03:18,080
There's no project cost management.

65
00:03:18,080 --> 00:03:21,330
Time management, scope management,
there is none of that going on, and

66
00:03:21,330 --> 00:03:24,760
that's because we deal with
that in monitoring control.

67
00:03:24,760 --> 00:03:29,180
We've already planned for this stuff, now
we just need to make sure that it happens.

68
00:03:29,180 --> 00:03:32,340
So, we'll start off right here under
project integration management, and

69
00:03:32,340 --> 00:03:35,430
remember that knowledge area,
integration management, that's us,

70
00:03:35,430 --> 00:03:36,680
that's the project manager.

71
00:03:36,680 --> 00:03:39,410
And it's how we handle
the overall project.

72
00:03:39,410 --> 00:03:43,420
So see what we've got here,
direct and manage project work.

73
00:03:43,420 --> 00:03:45,130
It doesn't say, do the work.

74
00:03:45,130 --> 00:03:46,720
It's just direct and manage.

75
00:03:46,720 --> 00:03:48,870
Keep an eye on things,
make sure they're going well.

76
00:03:48,870 --> 00:03:52,890
We're really gonna be doing this,
monitor and control project work.

77
00:03:52,890 --> 00:03:55,490
Perform change control,
validate scope and so on.

78
00:03:55,490 --> 00:03:58,520
Those are the things that we're
really gonna be focused on.

79
00:03:58,520 --> 00:04:03,860
But let's take a look at this process and
see what damage we can do in there.

80
00:04:03,860 --> 00:04:05,330
Direct and manage the work.

81
00:04:05,330 --> 00:04:08,690
We're telling people to get to work and
they get to work.

82
00:04:08,690 --> 00:04:09,220
That's it.

83
00:04:09,220 --> 00:04:11,640
We're done.
Easiest processed group ever.

84
00:04:11,640 --> 00:04:14,630
But there is some tools and
techniques here.

85
00:04:14,630 --> 00:04:16,010
You'll see under the inputs,

86
00:04:16,010 --> 00:04:19,640
we've got our project management plan
which is telling us how to do things.

87
00:04:19,640 --> 00:04:23,870
If there have been change requests,
any changes from our original plan,

88
00:04:23,870 --> 00:04:27,420
the approved change requests
become inputs here.

89
00:04:27,420 --> 00:04:28,900
When people go to do their work,

90
00:04:28,900 --> 00:04:31,110
if there's been a change
they need to be aware of it.

91
00:04:31,110 --> 00:04:33,930
If the date of that task has been moved or
whatever.

92
00:04:33,930 --> 00:04:37,100
Our enterprise environmental factors and
organizational process assets,

93
00:04:37,100 --> 00:04:38,860
those are the other inputs for us.

94
00:04:38,860 --> 00:04:41,720
Just like we always have,
any paperwork and so on.

95
00:04:41,720 --> 00:04:46,580
Now there is an important one here that
they don't call out specifically, but you

96
00:04:46,580 --> 00:04:52,900
may have an organizational process asset
that is called a work authorization form.

97
00:04:52,900 --> 00:04:57,840
Just because a resource is attached to an
activity, just because in our little Gantt

98
00:04:57,840 --> 00:05:01,750
chart, we say that Tom in accounting is
supposed to do an accounting review on

99
00:05:01,750 --> 00:05:06,090
Tuesday, doesn't mean he's actually going
to do an accounting review on Tuesday.

100
00:05:06,090 --> 00:05:09,690
We may need to fill out a work
authorization form that says,

101
00:05:09,690 --> 00:05:14,740
Tom is authorized to work for eight hours
on Tuesday to do this for our project in

102
00:05:14,740 --> 00:05:19,620
black and white, no uncertain terms
that we give to his functional manager.

103
00:05:19,620 --> 00:05:22,010
And then his functional manager,
she can look at it and say okay,

104
00:05:22,010 --> 00:05:24,540
Tom you're authorized to work on it,
off you go.

105
00:05:24,540 --> 00:05:28,310
So that's an important thing and
that would be an organizational process,

106
00:05:28,310 --> 00:05:29,420
that form.

107
00:05:29,420 --> 00:05:32,710
Now filling it out and
applying it, that's what we do.

108
00:05:32,710 --> 00:05:36,700
Or we may have subordinates
that we delegate that to.

109
00:05:36,700 --> 00:05:40,320
So we may have extra judgment here,
just whatever our own instincts tells us.

110
00:05:40,320 --> 00:05:44,340
What our experiences over the years
have built up to include.

111
00:05:44,340 --> 00:05:47,549
We will most likely have project
management information systems,

112
00:05:47,549 --> 00:05:50,680
we'll have software that we use for
managing all of this.

113
00:05:50,680 --> 00:05:53,250
How do I know what work needs
to get done on Thursday?

114
00:05:53,250 --> 00:05:57,490
If I have a work authorization system I
probably have software that powers that,

115
00:05:57,490 --> 00:05:59,110
scheduling software or what ever.

116
00:05:59,110 --> 00:06:03,130
So we need to leverage those
systems that our organization has.

117
00:06:03,130 --> 00:06:04,890
And then, meetings.

118
00:06:04,890 --> 00:06:08,040
When you're ready to kick off work,
you almost always start with a meeting.

119
00:06:08,040 --> 00:06:12,080
If you ever get to a construction site at
the beginning of the day, those guys don't

120
00:06:12,080 --> 00:06:15,330
just walk up to the building and then
start breaking our their hammer and nails.

121
00:06:15,330 --> 00:06:16,750
They usually stop and have a meeting,

122
00:06:16,750 --> 00:06:19,900
they lay out what they're gonna work
on that day and then they get to work.

123
00:06:19,900 --> 00:06:22,170
And so that's a pivotal
tool of starting that work.

124
00:06:23,340 --> 00:06:26,300
All right,
now our output here is normally going

125
00:06:26,300 --> 00:06:27,379
to be,
>> The work.

126
00:06:27,379 --> 00:06:29,140
[LAUGH]
>> Work yeah, [LAUGH] but

127
00:06:29,140 --> 00:06:34,380
it's hard to quantify and qualify work and
so we represent it different ways.

128
00:06:34,380 --> 00:06:36,000
We'll see deliverables.

129
00:06:36,000 --> 00:06:37,900
In other words, what they did.

130
00:06:37,900 --> 00:06:40,150
Did they actually finish
the work they set out to do?

131
00:06:40,150 --> 00:06:42,950
They said they were gonna put the roof up,
is there a roof on the house?

132
00:06:44,260 --> 00:06:46,430
Work Performance Data.

133
00:06:46,430 --> 00:06:48,870
Most of our activities
don't finish in one day.

134
00:06:48,870 --> 00:06:53,290
So at the end of the day, if I got half
the roof up, do I have a deliverable?

135
00:06:53,290 --> 00:06:53,790
No.

136
00:06:53,790 --> 00:06:55,990
Deliverables are either done or
they're not, there's no in between.

137
00:06:55,990 --> 00:06:58,030
So I don't have a deliverable.

138
00:06:58,030 --> 00:06:59,990
But that doesn't mean nothing happened.

139
00:06:59,990 --> 00:07:02,050
I may just have performance data.

140
00:07:02,050 --> 00:07:04,580
Hey, it's the end of day one,
we're 20 percent done, and

141
00:07:04,580 --> 00:07:06,860
it looks like we've got
four more days of work.

142
00:07:06,860 --> 00:07:07,500
All right?

143
00:07:07,500 --> 00:07:11,430
The reason we need that performance data
is because we can then compare it to our

144
00:07:11,430 --> 00:07:14,840
schedule, and we can see whether we
are going to be on track or not.

145
00:07:14,840 --> 00:07:20,430
If at the end of day one we are 20%
done but it's a 3 day activity,

146
00:07:20,430 --> 00:07:24,500
then I'm behind schedule,
I should be 33% done on day one, right?

147
00:07:24,500 --> 00:07:27,640
So, I can see that, and
I can start to take action.

148
00:07:27,640 --> 00:07:31,520
That performance data, we're gonna see
that in the form of status reports which

149
00:07:31,520 --> 00:07:35,200
we'll look at more in the next phase.

150
00:07:35,200 --> 00:07:38,210
But those status reports are how we're
gonna know whether things are going

151
00:07:38,210 --> 00:07:38,900
right or wrong.

152
00:07:40,300 --> 00:07:43,260
If things are going
wrong we gotta fix them.

153
00:07:43,260 --> 00:07:44,660
And how do we fix them?

154
00:07:44,660 --> 00:07:46,540
We fix them with change requests.

155
00:07:46,540 --> 00:07:47,940
>> Yep.

156
00:07:47,940 --> 00:07:50,915
>> We keep seeing change
requests keep popping up.

157
00:07:50,915 --> 00:07:54,140
I want to talk about change tickets when
we get to monitoring controlling because.

158
00:07:54,140 --> 00:07:55,714
That's how we control our projects.

159
00:07:55,714 --> 00:07:59,832
And I don't want to dive too deep into
them here, but if something's gone wrong,

160
00:07:59,832 --> 00:08:01,980
we need to update our
project to correct for

161
00:08:01,980 --> 00:08:05,770
that and we fill out a change
request to try and get it approved.

162
00:08:05,770 --> 00:08:08,170
We may not be the only ones
originating those though.

163
00:08:08,170 --> 00:08:13,120
Somebody out in the field might say, wow,
we have these estimates, they're wrong.

164
00:08:13,120 --> 00:08:14,740
Here's what's actually going on.

165
00:08:14,740 --> 00:08:15,840
I need to fill out a change ticket.

166
00:08:15,840 --> 00:08:18,630
So we need to evaluate them and
act upon that.

167
00:08:20,840 --> 00:08:24,090
After that we may see project management
plan updates if we need to change

168
00:08:24,090 --> 00:08:27,040
the plan, if you've had anything come up.

169
00:08:27,040 --> 00:08:30,430
And then project document updates as
you update your stakeholder registry,

170
00:08:30,430 --> 00:08:33,760
all the other data that may
need to get updated as a result

171
00:08:33,760 --> 00:08:35,100
of that change request.

172
00:08:35,100 --> 00:08:39,030
If the change request is approved then
it changes the schedule, or the budget.

173
00:08:39,030 --> 00:08:41,930
We've got a lot of documentation we've
got to go and update to reflect that.

174
00:08:41,930 --> 00:08:46,030
So this is all a part of directing and
managing work.

175
00:08:46,030 --> 00:08:51,430
It's a lot, a decent bit of
stuff that's going on there, but

176
00:08:51,430 --> 00:08:54,260
for the most part it's common sense.

177
00:08:54,260 --> 00:08:58,470
So, just be aware of some of
the variations of that data, all right.

178
00:08:58,470 --> 00:09:00,310
I mentioned change requests, right?

179
00:09:00,310 --> 00:09:02,880
There's several different
types of change requests.

180
00:09:02,880 --> 00:09:05,660
We have corrective and
that's the most common.

181
00:09:05,660 --> 00:09:08,490
We have a problem,
we need to do something to fix it.

182
00:09:08,490 --> 00:09:10,850
Here it is, a corrective, right?

183
00:09:10,850 --> 00:09:13,570
We might have a preventative right?

184
00:09:13,570 --> 00:09:19,160
We see a problem might be coming down
the road and so we take action now.

185
00:09:19,160 --> 00:09:20,910
It's a five day activity.

186
00:09:20,910 --> 00:09:23,640
Day one is done, they are only
ten per cent of the way through.

187
00:09:23,640 --> 00:09:29,610
I know based on that data, they are not
likely to hit their scheduled date.

188
00:09:29,610 --> 00:09:32,780
Unless something crazy happens.so I go
down and talk to the people and ask,

189
00:09:32,780 --> 00:09:36,040
is it just that we have back
loaded the work or whatever.

190
00:09:36,040 --> 00:09:40,270
And If I find out that they are actually
behind, I can take preventative action now

191
00:09:40,270 --> 00:09:44,000
to stop them from running behind,
do something to bolster up their speed.

192
00:09:45,090 --> 00:09:48,750
There might be defect repair, right?

193
00:09:48,750 --> 00:09:51,620
There may be an issue that has crept up.

194
00:09:51,620 --> 00:09:55,270
And that issue is resulting
in us having to stop and

195
00:09:55,270 --> 00:09:57,850
fix the problem,
something we didn't anticipate.

196
00:09:57,850 --> 00:10:00,880
So we've got to do a little more
work to get things done and move on.

197
00:10:02,050 --> 00:10:04,000
And then updates, right.

198
00:10:04,000 --> 00:10:08,240
An update is not normally a true
change in the sense of change.

199
00:10:08,240 --> 00:10:12,190
A great example of an update
might be I have a contract.

200
00:10:12,190 --> 00:10:14,810
And the contract is with
a third-party company.

201
00:10:14,810 --> 00:10:19,160
And the primary technical contact
is Betsy, and Betsy retires.

202
00:10:19,160 --> 00:10:21,850
And so a new employee steps in, it's Tom.

203
00:10:21,850 --> 00:10:23,930
And I just need to change the contact,
right?

204
00:10:23,930 --> 00:10:26,880
So I'm not changing the scope or budget or

205
00:10:26,880 --> 00:10:31,280
schedule, it's just changing a contact on
that contract, it's a minor change and so

206
00:10:31,280 --> 00:10:34,780
I do a change ticket with an update for
that information, right.

207
00:10:34,780 --> 00:10:37,130
I'll replace a resource,
I have a resource that's out sick,

208
00:10:37,130 --> 00:10:38,810
I'll replace him with another resource.

209
00:10:38,810 --> 00:10:39,580
Minor change, right?

210
00:10:39,580 --> 00:10:40,322
Those are updates.

211
00:10:40,322 --> 00:10:47,130
All right, so those are things that might
happen under the scope, I mean not scope,

212
00:10:47,130 --> 00:10:50,960
under the project management plan
we could be updating anything and

213
00:10:50,960 --> 00:10:53,690
Ronnie list out just all
the different plans that we have.

214
00:10:53,690 --> 00:10:59,240
Any one of those may need to be updated as
just due course of working on the project

215
00:10:59,240 --> 00:11:03,510
as we learn more we update those plans
to reflect what works best for us.

216
00:11:04,970 --> 00:11:07,275
And then on that
documentation that we output.

217
00:11:07,275 --> 00:11:11,805
A lot of it's just going to be
project logs, how we've moved along,

218
00:11:11,805 --> 00:11:16,355
our issues, assumptions, anything like
that, what's going on, all right?

219
00:11:16,355 --> 00:11:19,305
But it could be something a little
bit more significant, for

220
00:11:19,305 --> 00:11:21,275
example, remember our risk register.

221
00:11:21,275 --> 00:11:24,915
We kept track of all the risks we
could have, now we're executing,

222
00:11:24,915 --> 00:11:26,580
now things are happening.

223
00:11:26,580 --> 00:11:31,010
If one of those risks comes to fruition
we're going to see it right here.

224
00:11:31,010 --> 00:11:34,830
There was a risk that the price
of lumber could go up.

225
00:11:34,830 --> 00:11:37,490
I recognized that,
I set some cash reserves for it.

226
00:11:37,490 --> 00:11:41,250
Now I get to execution and the guys
actually go out and buy that lumber.

227
00:11:41,250 --> 00:11:43,120
Did the price go up?

228
00:11:43,120 --> 00:11:45,880
If it did, I've got my reserves,
it's taken care of.

229
00:11:45,880 --> 00:11:48,350
If it didn't, great.

230
00:11:48,350 --> 00:11:51,840
We bought the lumber, it came in at
the low price, the risk is now gone.

231
00:11:51,840 --> 00:11:54,130
We bought our lumber,
that risk is no longer present.

232
00:11:54,130 --> 00:11:57,380
So we go to our risk register and
we update it, we put in there nope.

233
00:11:57,380 --> 00:12:02,590
Lumber came in at cost,
no craziness here, this risk is resolved.

234
00:12:02,590 --> 00:12:05,920
We change that status to resolved, and
it's no longer one we have to monitor.

235
00:12:05,920 --> 00:12:11,160
So that's a nice thing that we now can do,
because we're in the execution phase.

236
00:12:11,160 --> 00:12:14,440
We're actually getting things done, we
start marking these things off the list.

237
00:12:16,260 --> 00:12:19,580
All right, so we're going to be getting
a lot of information back from our

238
00:12:19,580 --> 00:12:21,920
people as they're doing
work out in the field.

239
00:12:21,920 --> 00:12:24,720
We'll get status updates, we'll talk
about those more in monitoring and

240
00:12:24,720 --> 00:12:27,120
controlling, but
we'll also get change requests,

241
00:12:27,120 --> 00:12:29,640
again we'll also talk about those
more in monitoring and controlling.

242
00:12:29,640 --> 00:12:32,760
But that's basically all
that's going on right here

243
00:12:32,760 --> 00:12:37,610
in the direct and managed project work.

244
00:12:37,610 --> 00:12:40,310
The key element here is you're
telling people, get to work.

245
00:12:40,310 --> 00:12:42,480
And, they're getting to work that's it.

246
00:12:42,480 --> 00:12:43,840
That's what happens in this process.

247
00:12:46,100 --> 00:12:46,600
All right.

248
00:12:47,620 --> 00:12:52,180
The next one we want to take a look
at is the Perform quality assurance.

249
00:12:53,240 --> 00:12:56,690
Remember I mentioned quality in the last,
actually it was a couple episodes ago.

250
00:12:56,690 --> 00:12:59,670
We have quality assurance,
and quality control.

251
00:12:59,670 --> 00:13:01,360
And notice my two processes here.

252
00:13:01,360 --> 00:13:04,360
Perform quality assurance in execution,
and

253
00:13:04,360 --> 00:13:09,190
then control quality in
the monitoring controlling.

254
00:13:09,190 --> 00:13:11,500
They're both really
happening at the same time.

255
00:13:11,500 --> 00:13:15,030
The key difference if you've
forgotten is Quality assurance

256
00:13:15,030 --> 00:13:19,670
is trying to prevent
a problem before it occurs.

257
00:13:19,670 --> 00:13:20,510
