491
00:25:14,370 --> 00:25:15,600
ahead of schedule.

492
00:25:15,600 --> 00:25:20,960
Either one, they found some great
new way to get through faster, or

493
00:25:20,960 --> 00:25:23,820
two, something didn't get done.

494
00:25:23,820 --> 00:25:26,610
And that something didn't get done,
that's either part of the activity itself,

495
00:25:26,610 --> 00:25:31,645
or they didn't give factual numbers back
when the original estimate was done.

496
00:25:31,645 --> 00:25:34,595
So the thing that didn't get done
was the whole being honest part.

497
00:25:34,595 --> 00:25:37,495
So, something didn't get done and
that's normally what I just default to.

498
00:25:37,495 --> 00:25:40,295
I assume that something didn't get
done if they're ahead of schedule.

499
00:25:40,295 --> 00:25:44,405
But if I had auditors on the field and
they were sending me data back saying, oh,

500
00:25:44,405 --> 00:25:46,345
yeah they found a new way
to get this done faster.

501
00:25:46,345 --> 00:25:47,865
That's an area of excellence.

502
00:25:47,865 --> 00:25:49,925
Now when they finish ahead of schedule,

503
00:25:49,925 --> 00:25:51,425
I knew they were gonna
finish ahead of schedule.

504
00:25:51,425 --> 00:25:53,390
I knew it because my audit data had it.

505
00:25:53,390 --> 00:25:54,470
I'm prepared.

506
00:25:54,470 --> 00:25:56,800
I'm ready to receive that and
I don't have to get paranoid and say,

507
00:25:56,800 --> 00:25:58,598
wait a minute, what did you guys screw up?

508
00:25:58,598 --> 00:26:01,640
Because they didn't, they did it great.

509
00:26:01,640 --> 00:26:03,599
So we wanna make sure we document that.

510
00:26:03,599 --> 00:26:07,920
If there's anything that is deficient,
we catalog that.

511
00:26:07,920 --> 00:26:09,100
What's the defect?

512
00:26:09,100 --> 00:26:11,730
What action do we need
to take to correct it?

513
00:26:12,800 --> 00:26:15,589
Now, just because you put it in
here as an action doesn't mean you

514
00:26:15,589 --> 00:26:17,250
are actually going to do this.

515
00:26:17,250 --> 00:26:20,020
We need to create a change ticket
that centers around this to actually

516
00:26:20,020 --> 00:26:20,990
take the action.

517
00:26:20,990 --> 00:26:23,470
So this is kind of like
a preliminary action.

518
00:26:24,790 --> 00:26:27,870
The auditor just makes a recommendation,
they may not have one.

519
00:26:27,870 --> 00:26:31,110
They may see a defect and go, gosh,
I don't know how to fix this.

520
00:26:31,110 --> 00:26:32,590
And so
we just have to look at that later and

521
00:26:32,590 --> 00:26:35,080
come up with some other option,
have a meeting whatever.

522
00:26:36,490 --> 00:26:39,230
And then they provide their commentary, so
your auditors are constantly going out and

523
00:26:39,230 --> 00:26:41,600
gathering this data and
sending it back to you.

524
00:26:41,600 --> 00:26:45,615
As the project manager, maybe you're
going out and doing these audits, but

525
00:26:45,615 --> 00:26:48,643
more commonly you're handing
this off to someone else and

526
00:26:48,643 --> 00:26:52,181
they're collecting the data so
that you can take it and act upon it.

527
00:26:52,181 --> 00:26:52,806
All right.

528
00:26:52,806 --> 00:26:58,569
So that data is going to be fed into our
quality management and control tools and

529
00:26:58,569 --> 00:27:03,830
those tools typically represent
themselves as charts and graphs.

530
00:27:03,830 --> 00:27:04,580
Right?

531
00:27:04,580 --> 00:27:06,880
PMI, they love the charts and graphs.

532
00:27:06,880 --> 00:27:10,400
And you'll see here we've got all
sorts of ones available to us.

533
00:27:10,400 --> 00:27:11,010
Okay?

534
00:27:11,010 --> 00:27:15,190
Affinity diagrams,
process decision diagrams and so on.

535
00:27:15,190 --> 00:27:18,190
Each one kind of serves
a different purpose.

536
00:27:19,258 --> 00:27:23,510
The PMBOK, again yet another reason to
go ahead and become a PMI member, so

537
00:27:23,510 --> 00:27:27,120
you can get the PMBOK,
gives us some examples of all of these.

538
00:27:27,120 --> 00:27:29,442
And each one has a slightly
different purpose, but

539
00:27:29,442 --> 00:27:31,015
they're fairly generic charts.

540
00:27:31,015 --> 00:27:34,330
You'll see the affinity diagram,
and so on.

541
00:27:34,330 --> 00:27:38,830
Each one represents a different
aspect of our organization.

542
00:27:39,910 --> 00:27:44,700
So the affinity diagram, here's where
we start looking toward cause and

543
00:27:44,700 --> 00:27:46,050
effect type things.

544
00:27:46,050 --> 00:27:47,660
So we have an issue,

545
00:27:47,660 --> 00:27:51,260
what are some of the different things
that contribute to the one issues?

546
00:27:51,260 --> 00:27:55,020
This is kind of like
a brainstorming when we start

547
00:27:55,020 --> 00:27:58,960
doing the affinity diagrams there,
grouping things together by like idea.

548
00:27:58,960 --> 00:28:02,330
Here we're grouping things
together by like defect or cause.

549
00:28:02,330 --> 00:28:05,740
So trying to collect that together to
find out where most of our issues are.

550
00:28:05,740 --> 00:28:07,372
Fitting d diagrams are pretty useful for
that.

551
00:28:07,372 --> 00:28:12,570
PDPC, it's quite the mouthful,

552
00:28:12,570 --> 00:28:16,410
that's the process decision product chart.

553
00:28:16,410 --> 00:28:18,120
When we go through a process,

554
00:28:18,120 --> 00:28:21,600
there's certain decisions that
are made as we go through.

555
00:28:21,600 --> 00:28:23,050
How do we know that, right?

556
00:28:23,050 --> 00:28:26,980
Well, most commonly,
we know that thanks to a flow chart.

557
00:28:26,980 --> 00:28:30,660
And in the flow chart, they just kind of
representing here, is you make decisions.

558
00:28:30,660 --> 00:28:33,560
Here's decision number one,
is the answer yes or no?

559
00:28:33,560 --> 00:28:34,940
If it's yes, you go this way.

560
00:28:34,940 --> 00:28:36,940
If it's no, you go this way, all right?

561
00:28:36,940 --> 00:28:37,630
So you said no.

562
00:28:37,630 --> 00:28:38,540
Here you are.

563
00:28:38,540 --> 00:28:40,300
Now here's question number two.

564
00:28:40,300 --> 00:28:42,980
Based on what you get here,
is it yes or no?

565
00:28:42,980 --> 00:28:45,010
Yes you go here, no you go here.

566
00:28:45,010 --> 00:28:49,500
And you go through and it's guiding you
on the decision that you need to make.

567
00:28:49,500 --> 00:28:51,640
You see these in audits a lot, right?

568
00:28:51,640 --> 00:28:56,560
So you'll see maybe you're manufacturing

569
00:28:56,560 --> 00:29:00,600
some kind of pipe and
the pipe has to meet certain standards.

570
00:29:00,600 --> 00:29:05,610
So question number one, does the pipe's
measurements match the specifications?

571
00:29:05,610 --> 00:29:06,850
Is it so and so long?

572
00:29:06,850 --> 00:29:08,060
Is it so and so wide?

573
00:29:08,060 --> 00:29:09,620
Are the walls so and so thick?

574
00:29:09,620 --> 00:29:10,420
Yes or no.

575
00:29:10,420 --> 00:29:11,180
Okay.

576
00:29:11,180 --> 00:29:13,940
If yes, move on to the next thing.

577
00:29:13,940 --> 00:29:15,862
How much pressure is
the pipe able to withstand?

578
00:29:15,862 --> 00:29:20,870
Can it withstand 800 PSI or
whatever it is that we've rated it for?

579
00:29:20,870 --> 00:29:22,150
If yes, you move on and

580
00:29:22,150 --> 00:29:25,370
if you get a bunch of yeses,
the audit passes and you're done.

581
00:29:25,370 --> 00:29:29,770
But if you get a no, it then moves you
over and it says fill out this form,

582
00:29:29,770 --> 00:29:32,290
reach out to this person,
take this action.

583
00:29:32,290 --> 00:29:35,120
Because there's a problem in our
manufacturing process, right?

584
00:29:35,120 --> 00:29:39,520
By having a decision chart like this,
it takes the guess work out and

585
00:29:39,520 --> 00:29:43,400
it insures consistent action
when a defect is detected.

586
00:29:43,400 --> 00:29:47,180
So, people don't have to think too much,
they just go right down the chart.

587
00:29:47,180 --> 00:29:50,780
You see this, I'm gonna say it and
it's gonna sound mean,

588
00:29:50,780 --> 00:29:52,240
you see this in the military a lot.

589
00:29:52,240 --> 00:29:52,850
All right.

590
00:29:52,850 --> 00:29:55,390
And it's not because people can't
independently think in the military.

591
00:29:55,390 --> 00:29:57,440
There are brilliant
people in the military.

592
00:29:57,440 --> 00:30:02,330
But when you are under duress, when you're
in combat situations, when you're in

593
00:30:02,330 --> 00:30:07,710
a submarine that is underwater and
a rupture happens, you don't wanna

594
00:30:07,710 --> 00:30:12,600
have to go through a lot of thought and
decision making, and all that on your own.

595
00:30:12,600 --> 00:30:14,620
If you have a chart that just
walks you through step by step,

596
00:30:14,620 --> 00:30:16,090
here's is this happening?

597
00:30:16,090 --> 00:30:18,330
Yes or no?
All right, yes it's happening.

598
00:30:18,330 --> 00:30:19,480
Is this also happening right,

599
00:30:19,480 --> 00:30:22,110
if these two things are related
then this is the action you take.

600
00:30:22,110 --> 00:30:27,370
By telling you exactly what to do you
ensure quick, consistent action and

601
00:30:27,370 --> 00:30:30,400
it can be the difference between life and
death in the military.

602
00:30:30,400 --> 00:30:33,030
Now here at ITPro TV it's not life and
death, but

603
00:30:33,030 --> 00:30:38,190
it can be the difference between resolving
an issue when I manufacture one episode,

604
00:30:38,190 --> 00:30:41,890
versus resolving the issue after we've
already manufactured a hundred episode.

605
00:30:41,890 --> 00:30:46,780
So we need that kind of decision
tree that's what a PDPC does.

606
00:30:46,780 --> 00:30:50,890
We also have inter relationship
diagraphs and a Ronnie were joking and

607
00:30:50,890 --> 00:30:55,250
I were joking around about this earlier,
I've never used the word diagraph ever,

608
00:30:55,250 --> 00:30:58,510
but it's a combination of a graph and
a diagram.

609
00:30:58,510 --> 00:31:00,600
They got them together
with a bottle of wine and

610
00:31:00,600 --> 00:31:02,960
all of a sudden you get a diagraph.

611
00:31:02,960 --> 00:31:04,700
And what it is is an absolute mess.

612
00:31:04,700 --> 00:31:08,620
It's where you basically plot out
the various causes and effects and

613
00:31:08,620 --> 00:31:11,200
you map them together.

614
00:31:11,200 --> 00:31:16,130
One thing is related to another,
leads to another, leads to another.

615
00:31:16,130 --> 00:31:17,380
And so you kind of map it.

616
00:31:17,380 --> 00:31:19,200
The problem is that you can have so

617
00:31:19,200 --> 00:31:23,560
many interrelationships that it gets to
be a mess and that's what you see here.

618
00:31:23,560 --> 00:31:27,420
I had a student years ago who said Don,

619
00:31:27,420 --> 00:31:31,990
as I learn about the PNP I can see
a lot of times where one process

620
00:31:31,990 --> 00:31:36,280
is an output that then becomes and
input for another process.

621
00:31:36,280 --> 00:31:42,141
So could we create a flow chart of all 47
processes and see what it would look like?

622
00:31:42,141 --> 00:31:44,789
Start to finish which one's
output to which one's in?

623
00:31:44,789 --> 00:31:50,110
And I said, you can except it
becomes a giant spaghetti mess.

624
00:31:50,110 --> 00:31:53,350
A whole big picture, if you try to
put together is an absolute wreck.

625
00:31:53,350 --> 00:31:56,100
And you'll see that if we go through,

626
00:31:56,100 --> 00:31:59,230
let me see if I can find
one in the book real quick.

627
00:31:59,230 --> 00:32:01,810
The PMI actually maps some out in here.

628
00:32:03,980 --> 00:32:06,860
Well, I saw looking there,
see what they're doing here?

629
00:32:06,860 --> 00:32:09,120
They're showing planned
quality management.

630
00:32:09,120 --> 00:32:12,080
And all of these processes here,

631
00:32:12,080 --> 00:32:15,760
have outputs that feed into
plan quality management.

632
00:32:15,760 --> 00:32:19,750
And then Plan Quality Management creates
outputs that feed into different things.

633
00:32:19,750 --> 00:32:23,150
And so they've tried to map it here,
but they just took a small portion.

634
00:32:23,150 --> 00:32:24,878
Because if they did the whole thing,

635
00:32:24,878 --> 00:32:28,590
well there's five different
processes feeding into this one.

636
00:32:28,590 --> 00:32:31,240
And each of these feed
into other processes too.

637
00:32:31,240 --> 00:32:34,040
So, it does become a giant arrow mess.

638
00:32:34,040 --> 00:32:39,150
That's what we're seeing in that diagraph,
the interrelational diagraph.

639
00:32:39,150 --> 00:32:40,140
Which I've now lost.

640
00:32:42,310 --> 00:32:43,550
Shoot, what page was that on?

641
00:32:43,550 --> 00:32:44,310
Rodney, did you see?

642
00:32:44,310 --> 00:32:46,890
>> I don't.
I think, it was further down.

643
00:32:46,890 --> 00:32:47,970
>> Well, daggomit.

644
00:32:47,970 --> 00:32:48,510
You know what?

645
00:32:48,510 --> 00:32:49,930
We can probably just search for
the word digraph,

646
00:32:49,930 --> 00:32:54,060
cuz I can't imagine,
that's used anywhere else in the book.

647
00:32:54,060 --> 00:32:56,750
Or I can lose my file altogether.

648
00:32:56,750 --> 00:32:57,990
There's that.

649
00:32:57,990 --> 00:33:00,550
But, you know what,
I searched in the wrong thing.

650
00:33:02,420 --> 00:33:03,620
There we go, all right?

651
00:33:03,620 --> 00:33:06,160
So, that's what the digraph
is trying to show.

652
00:33:06,160 --> 00:33:07,110
And you can see it right there.

653
00:33:07,110 --> 00:33:07,670
I mean, look at that.

654
00:33:07,670 --> 00:33:09,880
It looks like an absolute mess.

655
00:33:09,880 --> 00:33:12,460
Just everything is kind of
thrown all over the place.

656
00:33:12,460 --> 00:33:15,620
And it can be useful,
just trying to chart it out.

657
00:33:15,620 --> 00:33:17,420
But, a lot of times it gets messy fast.

658
00:33:17,420 --> 00:33:21,694
>> Even the PMP states that,
limit it to 50.

659
00:33:21,694 --> 00:33:23,520
>> [LAUGH]
>> Once you get beyond 50.

660
00:33:23,520 --> 00:33:25,670
This is just gonna be a complete and
total mess.

661
00:33:25,670 --> 00:33:29,780
So again, even PMP doesn't say
don't try and do it for everything.

662
00:33:29,780 --> 00:33:31,550
>> We also have tree diagrams.

663
00:33:31,550 --> 00:33:34,790
Tree diagrams are basically like the PDPC,

664
00:33:34,790 --> 00:33:38,455
these guys up here,
just like that except turned on its side.

665
00:33:38,455 --> 00:33:38,970
>> Yeah.

666
00:33:38,970 --> 00:33:41,430
>> So one thing leads to another and
it kinda branches out,

667
00:33:41,430 --> 00:33:43,030
until you get to your
final decision point.

668
00:33:44,220 --> 00:33:47,170
We've got Prioritization Matrices,
all right?

669
00:33:47,170 --> 00:33:49,780
So as we branch out, and
we come to our various solutions,

670
00:33:49,780 --> 00:33:52,100
there may be more than one action to take.

671
00:33:52,100 --> 00:33:53,650
And so we prioritize them.

672
00:33:53,650 --> 00:33:55,900
So here's action number one,
and action number two, and

673
00:33:55,900 --> 00:33:59,300
they should be taken in this order
until you resolve the problem.

674
00:33:59,300 --> 00:34:03,720
Action number one is the highest priority,
it will likely resolve your problem.

675
00:34:03,720 --> 00:34:06,090
But if it doesn't,
here's action number two.

676
00:34:06,090 --> 00:34:09,500
So action number one,
reach out to the working on the field,

677
00:34:09,500 --> 00:34:11,320
get them them fix it, all right?

678
00:34:11,320 --> 00:34:14,300
If that doesn't work action number two,
go to the functional manager.

679
00:34:14,300 --> 00:34:17,630
If that doesn't work, action number three,
submit a change ticket, right?

680
00:34:17,630 --> 00:34:22,107
So, you kind of go through this process of
what to do based on prioritized entries.

681
00:34:24,012 --> 00:34:26,010
We also have our network diagrams.

682
00:34:26,010 --> 00:34:29,130
Now, we took a look at those back
in the scheduling side of things.

683
00:34:29,130 --> 00:34:33,100
The project schedule network diagram or
PSND.

684
00:34:33,100 --> 00:34:34,400
And what it's just showing is,

685
00:34:34,400 --> 00:34:37,030
how each issue of our various
activities inter-relate.

686
00:34:37,030 --> 00:34:41,570
These are useful for quality assurance
because you may have quality entries built

687
00:34:41,570 --> 00:34:45,974
into here, but also knowing that if one
activity has an issue, see the ones that

688
00:34:45,974 --> 00:34:49,680
follow it, to see how they're going
to be affected by that issue.

689
00:34:51,479 --> 00:34:54,600
And then good old
fashioned Matrix Diagrams.

690
00:34:54,600 --> 00:34:58,230
Any kind of matrix where you
plot out your various rankings.

691
00:34:58,230 --> 00:35:01,450
On a scale of one to ten or
one to six or whatever.

692
00:35:01,450 --> 00:35:04,890
Where does this activity rank, and
you go through and do your rankings.

693
00:35:04,890 --> 00:35:07,940
I usually use checklists,
but these are effective too.

694
00:35:07,940 --> 00:35:10,460
It's up to you,
to choose which ones you want.

695
00:35:10,460 --> 00:35:13,160
So these are some of
the different tools we use,

696
00:35:13,160 --> 00:35:18,530
when it comes to measuring quality and
providing quality assurance, right?

697
00:35:18,530 --> 00:35:20,300
Doing things ahead of time.

698
00:35:20,300 --> 00:35:22,250
You just manufactured one pipe.

699
00:35:22,250 --> 00:35:24,030
Go ahead and run it through these checks,

700
00:35:24,030 --> 00:35:28,050
because you don't wanna manufacture
a thousand more pipes and seed them.

701
00:35:28,050 --> 00:35:30,490
A great example of this,

702
00:35:30,490 --> 00:35:36,870
I had a friend who manufactured rifles, he
would create and he built target rifles.

703
00:35:36,870 --> 00:35:39,370
And when you build a firearm.

704
00:35:39,370 --> 00:35:45,120
If you think about how a rifle works,
you put a cartridge into the chamber,

705
00:35:45,120 --> 00:35:50,850
and a chemical explosion happens inside
of that chamber causing the bullet to go.

706
00:35:50,850 --> 00:35:54,940
So, he's building a device that's designed
to have an explosion inside of it.

707
00:35:54,940 --> 00:35:57,590
Any weakness in the metal could result in

708
00:35:57,590 --> 00:35:59,300
the thing-
>> Blowing up.

709
00:35:59,300 --> 00:36:01,453
>> Yeah.
It could cuz injury, death,

710
00:36:01,453 --> 00:36:03,770
it's a significant thing.

711
00:36:03,770 --> 00:36:06,370
So, when he would manufacture a rifle,

712
00:36:06,370 --> 00:36:10,440
he had certain devices that he would
attach to the barrel and to the chamber.

713
00:36:10,440 --> 00:36:11,950
Where he could measure the thickness and

714
00:36:11,950 --> 00:36:15,180
strength of the walls,
before he even fired that first shot.

715
00:36:15,180 --> 00:36:20,350
But then when he would take it to actually
test it, he would fire one round and

716
00:36:20,350 --> 00:36:22,490
one round only, and
make sure that it went, right?

717
00:36:22,490 --> 00:36:26,370
And then he would fire two rounds and two
rounds only, to make sure it could cycle.

718
00:36:26,370 --> 00:36:28,970
And so he had this process
that he went through, and

719
00:36:28,970 --> 00:36:32,690
that was how he quality checked each
of the rifles that he manufactured.

720
00:36:32,690 --> 00:36:34,310
It was a good system.

721
00:36:34,310 --> 00:36:38,100
It was time consuming, but
it ensured that if there was a fault,

722
00:36:38,100 --> 00:36:42,820
he could detect it before the weapon was
sold, instead of detecting it afterwards.

723
00:36:42,820 --> 00:36:44,780
Do you see that with cars?

724
00:36:44,780 --> 00:36:48,730
Nobody ever buys a car with
zero miles on the odometer.

725
00:36:48,730 --> 00:36:51,680
There's usually at least one mile
on there, cuz they do tests and

726
00:36:51,680 --> 00:36:53,790
things at the factory
before they roll out.

727
00:36:53,790 --> 00:36:56,470
That's all a part of quality assurance.

728
00:36:56,470 --> 00:37:00,175
And they just have charts like this,
little steps they go through,

729
00:37:00,175 --> 00:37:02,391
and rev the car up to 60 miles per hour.

730
00:37:02,391 --> 00:37:03,759
Does the engine sound normal?

731
00:37:03,759 --> 00:37:04,435
Yes.

732
00:37:04,435 --> 00:37:05,710
All right.
Move onto the next one.

733
00:37:05,710 --> 00:37:08,893
Now rev the car up to 80 miles per hour.

734
00:37:08,893 --> 00:37:10,110
Does the engine sound normal?

735
00:37:10,110 --> 00:37:15,090
Or if it's no then it goes down to here,
and it says are you feeling a vibration?

736
00:37:15,090 --> 00:37:16,250
Do you hear a knocking noise?

737
00:37:16,250 --> 00:37:18,960
The different things that you
can have it branches out.

738
00:37:18,960 --> 00:37:20,470
That's how they do the quality assurance?

739
00:37:22,495 --> 00:37:24,320
Another one they don't
give us a diagram for,

740
00:37:24,320 --> 00:37:29,120
it's more of a list, is that you
might have maintenance procedures.

741
00:37:29,120 --> 00:37:32,080
Let's say that we manufacture blue jeans.

742
00:37:33,180 --> 00:37:37,640
Before we even manufacture that
very first pair of blue jeans,

743
00:37:37,640 --> 00:37:40,850
we might have somebody go through and
check the machines out.

744
00:37:40,850 --> 00:37:42,340
Is the machine free and clear?

745
00:37:42,340 --> 00:37:44,420
Have the materials been loaded in there?

746
00:37:44,420 --> 00:37:47,220
Has the machine been serviced,
on its regular schedule?

747
00:37:47,220 --> 00:37:50,100
We have a checklist of
things to look out for,

748
00:37:50,100 --> 00:37:52,400
before we even flip the power
button to turn it on.

749
00:37:52,400 --> 00:37:54,310
You run through those checks.

750
00:37:54,310 --> 00:37:56,250
Make sure everything works
the way that you want.

751
00:37:56,250 --> 00:37:57,400
And then you fire it up.

752
00:37:57,400 --> 00:37:59,542
Again, all part of quality assurance.

753
00:38:02,924 --> 00:38:03,712
All right.

754
00:38:03,712 --> 00:38:06,260
And then we've got Process Analysis.

755
00:38:06,260 --> 00:38:09,670
Process analysis is where we say okay,
we've got a process, it works.

756
00:38:09,670 --> 00:38:11,650
It's doing what we need.

757
00:38:11,650 --> 00:38:13,150
Could we make it better, right?

758
00:38:13,150 --> 00:38:15,020
We need to analyze the process.

759
00:38:15,020 --> 00:38:16,130
Look at how things are going.

760
00:38:16,130 --> 00:38:17,370
Gather the data, right?

761
00:38:17,370 --> 00:38:20,750
What are auto, and
then evaluate whether there's improvement.

762
00:38:20,750 --> 00:38:22,550
Sometimes there is improvement but

763
00:38:22,550 --> 00:38:25,250
the cost of doing it outweighs
the benefit of doing it.

764
00:38:25,250 --> 00:38:27,080
So we may stop.

765
00:38:27,080 --> 00:38:29,140
Or we may look and it and say,
yeah, there's some improvement.

766
00:38:29,140 --> 00:38:31,240
Let's come up with
a better way to do this.

767
00:38:31,240 --> 00:38:33,530
So, that's something that's continual,
ongoing.

768
00:38:33,530 --> 00:38:34,540
We're always paying attention to.

769
00:38:36,200 --> 00:38:40,250
When we perform quality assurance,
we have a couple of outputs that come up.

770
00:38:40,250 --> 00:38:42,610
The most common being a change request.

771
00:38:42,610 --> 00:38:44,358
If there's a problem,
we need to resolve it.

772
00:38:44,358 --> 00:38:47,940
We need to resolve it,
before it becomes a big disaster.

773
00:38:47,940 --> 00:38:51,060
So a change request is,
the number one way to do that.

774
00:38:51,060 --> 00:38:53,315
We are out of the planning phase now.

775
00:38:53,315 --> 00:38:54,745
We're in execution.

776
00:38:54,745 --> 00:38:55,785
So everything that we've got,

777
00:38:55,785 --> 00:39:00,315
our schedule, our budget,
our requirements, all that is fixed now.

778
00:39:00,315 --> 00:39:02,285
So we wanna live up to that.

779
00:39:02,285 --> 00:39:06,620
If there's a problem that might
effect schedule, budget, or

780
00:39:06,620 --> 00:39:11,580
requirements then we need to do something
to fix it, and it might require a change.

781
00:39:11,580 --> 00:39:15,420
We might need more money to fix a problem,
or we might need to draw of from our

782
00:39:15,420 --> 00:39:19,230
reserves, or whatever and
a change ticket is how we do that.

783
00:39:19,230 --> 00:39:22,200
We may also have project
management plan updates,

784
00:39:22,200 --> 00:39:25,590
if we make changes to those forms,
the checklist or whatever.

785
00:39:25,590 --> 00:39:28,460
We find something that just wasn't on
there before we decide to modified it we

786
00:39:28,460 --> 00:39:32,180
need to go, and update create that and
so you'll see project updates also.

787
00:39:32,180 --> 00:39:33,770
That kind of falls under it.

788
00:39:33,770 --> 00:39:38,290
And lastly, this is kind of new,
Organizational Process Asset Updates.

789
00:39:38,290 --> 00:39:39,960
I don't think we've seen that one yet.

790
00:39:39,960 --> 00:39:43,250
So, when you're working with
things like checklists.

791
00:39:43,250 --> 00:39:47,800
The odds are, other projects could
benefit from those checklists also.

792
00:39:47,800 --> 00:39:51,870
And so, we make sure that we create those
and we make a generic form of them, so

793
00:39:51,870 --> 00:39:54,080
that other people can use
them in their projects.

794
00:39:54,080 --> 00:39:59,050
Another one is, we should be keeping
what's called a Lessons Learned Log.

795
00:39:59,050 --> 00:40:01,700
And we'll talk more about
that in the closing phase.

796
00:40:01,700 --> 00:40:04,910
But it's basically any time something
doesn't go the way you planned it,

797
00:40:04,910 --> 00:40:08,080
you document why it happened,
and what you did to fix it?

798
00:40:08,080 --> 00:40:10,918
And other people can
benefit from seeing that.

799
00:40:10,918 --> 00:40:15,650
That becomes an organizational process
asset, other people will benefit from

800
00:40:15,650 --> 00:40:18,700
learning what happened to you,
not necessarily your mistakes but

801
00:40:18,700 --> 00:40:24,680
just things that happen that were
out of your control in the project.

802
00:40:24,680 --> 00:40:27,260
All right, and
that in a nutshell is quality assurance,

803
00:40:27,260 --> 00:40:30,250
it doesn't sound crazy but
that's cuz it really isn't.

804
00:40:30,250 --> 00:40:31,930
As long as people are doing their checks,

805
00:40:31,930 --> 00:40:35,940
things are running as they're expected,
quality assurance is pretty cut and dry.

806
00:40:37,700 --> 00:40:38,300
All right, Ronnie,

807
00:40:38,300 --> 00:40:40,410
can you think of anything that
we have left out on that one?

808
00:40:40,410 --> 00:40:41,350
>> I don't think so, yeah.

809
00:40:41,350 --> 00:40:42,830
>> All right.

810
00:40:42,830 --> 00:40:46,570
Well remember, we're gonna continue
to revisit quality assurance.

811
00:40:46,570 --> 00:40:49,280
Let me jump back to my big diagram here.

812
00:40:49,280 --> 00:40:51,400
So, we did quality assurance.

813
00:40:51,400 --> 00:40:53,450
We still have control quality.

814
00:40:53,450 --> 00:40:55,400
So, we're gonna jump into quality
control a little bit later.

815
00:40:55,400 --> 00:40:58,980
So we've got some more of that,
but we're almost done with it.

816
00:40:58,980 --> 00:41:00,200
But yes, we'll see that.

817
00:41:00,200 --> 00:41:02,275
The next thing that we're gonna
be talking about in our next.

818
00:41:02,275 --> 00:41:04,105
Episode will be dealing with our teams,

819
00:41:04,105 --> 00:41:08,075
our project team as well as the actual
worker bees that we deal with.

820
00:41:08,075 --> 00:41:11,175
How we handle them, there's some
important concepts to understand there?

821
00:41:11,175 --> 00:41:14,325
But, there's not too much
after that left for execution.

822
00:41:14,325 --> 00:41:15,755
We're about halfway through it.

823
00:41:15,755 --> 00:41:18,765
So we'll knock those out, and then we'll
be ready to move to monitoring and

824
00:41:18,765 --> 00:41:20,159
controlling, where the real fun starts.

825
00:41:21,410 --> 00:41:23,370
So, all right, well let's wrap it up here.

826
00:41:23,370 --> 00:41:26,690
I want to remind you guys,
if you have any questions,

827
00:41:26,690 --> 00:41:29,777
live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live.

828
00:41:29,777 --> 00:41:33,790
Post your questions in the chatroom we
monitor and answer during the show.

829
00:41:33,790 --> 00:41:37,480
If you have questions after the show,
use the Q&A link at the top of screen,

830
00:41:37,480 --> 00:41:40,420
it'll take you into the the Q&A forms,
you can post your questions there.

831
00:41:40,420 --> 00:41:41,710
We monitor and answer.

832
00:41:43,090 --> 00:41:44,600
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

833
00:41:44,600 --> 00:41:47,460
Signing off for ITProTV I'm Done Pezet.

834
00:41:47,460 --> 00:41:48,190
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

835
00:41:48,190 --> 00:41:49,772
>> And we will see you next time.

836
00:41:49,772 --> 00:41:54,999
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this special episode, Don and the ITProTV team show the project planning phase of the team project--The arcade game cabinet. You see the use of project task assignments, the estimation of duration and costs as the team discusses talk about details of the project and the WBS are assigned for action on this project!
episodes.title: Developing a Plan
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,185 --> 00:00:04,425
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,505 --> 00:00:10,120
All right,
welcome back to another ITProTV special.

3
00:00:10,120 --> 00:00:12,680
What we're doing is another
segment as part of our

4
00:00:12,680 --> 00:00:15,570
project management professional
certification series.

5
00:00:15,570 --> 00:00:19,710
And we're continuing on with our
arcade cabinet build out project.

6
00:00:19,710 --> 00:00:23,940
So, in our last special we got a chance
to see kind of building our charter and

7
00:00:23,940 --> 00:00:28,390
setting up our initial scope statement,
what it was we wanted to achieve.

8
00:00:28,390 --> 00:00:30,940
And today we are going to
be going a step further and

9
00:00:30,940 --> 00:00:33,490
actually moving into our planning phase.

10
00:00:33,490 --> 00:00:38,230
Now in a full blown large project,
this can be a very drawn out thing.

11
00:00:38,230 --> 00:00:40,420
But this is a pretty simple project and

12
00:00:40,420 --> 00:00:44,230
I've got the minds right here that
have all the information we need.

13
00:00:44,230 --> 00:00:48,280
So we should be able to at
least complete a first pass

14
00:00:48,280 --> 00:00:50,560
of our triple constraints, right.

15
00:00:50,560 --> 00:00:54,770
And when I say the triple constraints,
I'm talking about our requirements,

16
00:00:54,770 --> 00:00:58,410
our budgets and our schedule, right?

17
00:00:58,410 --> 00:01:03,680
So budget, that's cost, schedule, that's
time, and requirements, that's scope.

18
00:01:03,680 --> 00:01:06,410
So we need to start planning for
our project to make that.

19
00:01:06,410 --> 00:01:09,300
And at this stage one of the tools
we use is something called

20
00:01:09,300 --> 00:01:13,020
a Work Breakdown Schedule, or
a Work Breakdown Structure,

21
00:01:13,020 --> 00:01:14,650
I gotta get my terms right.

22
00:01:14,650 --> 00:01:16,960
And so we need to figure out
when work needs to get done.

23
00:01:16,960 --> 00:01:19,610
And so
we're going to pick each other's brains.

24
00:01:19,610 --> 00:01:20,770
We're going to do a little brain storm,

25
00:01:20,770 --> 00:01:24,090
I'm going to use some software
tools to put all that together.

26
00:01:24,090 --> 00:01:26,650
And we're going to formulate that.

27
00:01:26,650 --> 00:01:27,805
Now, one of the first things,

28
00:01:27,805 --> 00:01:30,081
I don't know why I didn't think
about this before the show.

29
00:01:30,081 --> 00:01:33,920
One of the first things that we need when
we're going into the planning phase is

30
00:01:33,920 --> 00:01:35,673
some of our supporting documents.

31
00:01:35,673 --> 00:01:39,283
And one of the supporting documents for
us is going to be our scope statement.

32
00:01:39,283 --> 00:01:41,121
So let me pull that up real quick,

33
00:01:41,121 --> 00:01:46,040
I've got that buried in here somewhere in
my show notes and all that good stuff.

34
00:01:46,040 --> 00:01:50,400
So I'm gonna pull up that project charter

35
00:01:50,400 --> 00:01:54,010
that we made earlier and
we signed off on it.

36
00:01:54,010 --> 00:01:55,600
And also I'm gonna pull
that right up here.

37
00:01:55,600 --> 00:01:58,280
So, this is what we created
in that first show.

38
00:01:58,280 --> 00:02:01,550
And I know we didn't show it on screen,
but I said I was gonna get it signed and

39
00:02:01,550 --> 00:02:02,330
printed out and stuff.

40
00:02:02,330 --> 00:02:05,400
So I can see right here
we've signed off on this.

41
00:02:05,400 --> 00:02:08,712
And Nathan, your signature's awesome.

42
00:02:08,712 --> 00:02:12,320
>> [LAUGH]
>> So this is our charter.

43
00:02:12,320 --> 00:02:15,690
This is that first stab at
that scope statement and

44
00:02:15,690 --> 00:02:17,520
the things that we need to get done.

45
00:02:17,520 --> 00:02:20,460
So this is really one of the only
supporting documents I've got at

46
00:02:20,460 --> 00:02:21,290
this point.

47
00:02:21,290 --> 00:02:26,950
So as part of the planning process,
one of our inputs is our organizational

48
00:02:26,950 --> 00:02:30,290
process assets and all that other good
stuff, so we gather what we've got.

49
00:02:30,290 --> 00:02:32,955
Right now this is really
the only document that I've got.

50
00:02:32,955 --> 00:02:36,926
So we're gonna go down the line here and
look at these requirements and

51
00:02:36,926 --> 00:02:39,500
start to figure out what
our work needs to be.

52
00:02:39,500 --> 00:02:43,070
And from there we can start to
figure out what our schedule and

53
00:02:43,070 --> 00:02:46,570
our cost is going to be because
we've got a lot of, sort of,

54
00:02:46,570 --> 00:02:49,659
unknowns in our charter
the way that it's written.

55
00:02:51,220 --> 00:02:54,130
Now, to help with this,
I'm going to use some software tools and

56
00:02:54,130 --> 00:02:57,510
it's up to you what software
tools make life easier.

57
00:02:57,510 --> 00:03:01,290
Personally I have a number that I go to
but for this project we are going to be

58
00:03:01,290 --> 00:03:06,750
using a project and
task management software called Asana.

59
00:03:06,750 --> 00:03:10,190
Asana is something that
you introduced me to, Rob.

60
00:03:10,190 --> 00:03:13,983
You want to give them a little
overview of what Asana is?

61
00:03:13,983 --> 00:03:18,465
>> Well it's like an HTML5 app so
it's available on the web.

62
00:03:18,465 --> 00:03:21,190
You can use it in a browser,
which is nice.

63
00:03:21,190 --> 00:03:26,040
And you put in tasks and you can assign
tasks and invite people in on tasks.

64
00:03:26,040 --> 00:03:29,020
You can add lists to tasks and
completion dates and

65
00:03:29,020 --> 00:03:31,870
all that kind of stuff and create
projects and put task in projects, so.

66
00:03:32,870 --> 00:03:35,950
>> And you might ask yourself well Don,
Asana great,

67
00:03:35,950 --> 00:03:39,770
it looks like a to do list program,
which is kind of how we use it internally.

68
00:03:39,770 --> 00:03:43,643
And that's true but the cool thing about
Asana is they have all sorts of add ons.

69
00:03:43,643 --> 00:03:47,126
And I like to combine it with
another site called Instagantt.

70
00:03:47,126 --> 00:03:49,428
And what it allows you to do is
to take your Asana projects and

71
00:03:49,428 --> 00:03:52,390
turn them into Gantt charts like what
we're used to in project management.

72
00:03:52,390 --> 00:03:55,490
So we're gonna get a chance to use
that and kind of build this out.

73
00:03:55,490 --> 00:03:57,490
But in this stage of the game,

74
00:03:57,490 --> 00:04:01,280
our first planning meeting, normally,
I mean you might not even have a computer.

75
00:04:01,280 --> 00:04:04,382
You might just do a notepad
because we just need to figure

76
00:04:04,382 --> 00:04:06,165
out what works needs to be done.

77
00:04:06,165 --> 00:04:08,024
So guys,
let's approach it from that angle, right?

78
00:04:08,024 --> 00:04:11,605
I'm not worried about cost or
time just yet.

79
00:04:11,605 --> 00:04:13,860
Let's just talk about what
work needs to get done.

80
00:04:13,860 --> 00:04:18,886
So create that final product,
that final product for us is a functional

81
00:04:18,886 --> 00:04:24,777
arcade cabinet and in our requirements we
specify kind of what it had to do, right?

82
00:04:24,777 --> 00:04:27,910
That was going to provide
that real arcade feel.

83
00:04:27,910 --> 00:04:30,440
It was gonna run.

84
00:04:30,440 --> 00:04:31,380
>> HyperSpin.

85
00:04:31,380 --> 00:04:32,420
>> And MAME, right?

86
00:04:32,420 --> 00:04:35,450
There's a couple of the software
products that it was gonna run, and

87
00:04:35,450 --> 00:04:38,590
that it was gonna done by June 31st.

88
00:04:38,590 --> 00:04:41,181
Okay?
So that was our plan, at least initially.

89
00:04:41,181 --> 00:04:45,431
So, now, let's talk about,
a little bit about watching live,

90
00:04:45,431 --> 00:04:48,308
you might know that it is after June 31st.

91
00:04:48,308 --> 00:04:53,132
[LAUGH] Actually, there wasn't even
a June 31st this year, was there?

92
00:04:53,132 --> 00:04:55,383
There's only 30 days in June,
so that was a stupid date.

93
00:04:55,383 --> 00:04:58,612
>> That's our loophole.

94
00:04:58,612 --> 00:05:00,934
>> It means it hasn't come yet!

95
00:05:00,934 --> 00:05:02,200
That's true.

96
00:05:02,200 --> 00:05:05,240
All right, so,
let's just talk about real general stuff.

97
00:05:05,240 --> 00:05:07,130
I'm thinking about deliverables.

98
00:05:07,130 --> 00:05:09,970
Whenever you have a project, it's a good
idea to break it up into pieces, and

99
00:05:09,970 --> 00:05:12,890
that way you can tackle
the pieces individually,

100
00:05:12,890 --> 00:05:14,960
it makes it a lot more easy to manage.

101
00:05:14,960 --> 00:05:18,660
So I could just say there's one big thing,
finish the cabinet, and that's it.

102
00:05:18,660 --> 00:05:23,970
But I took a stab last night, and
this was just using my uneducated,

103
00:05:23,970 --> 00:05:26,520
I've never built an arcade cabinet,
you know, my mind.

104
00:05:26,520 --> 00:05:28,620
And I kinda broke it into five pieces,
right?

105
00:05:28,620 --> 00:05:31,179
>> Okay.
>> So the way I saw it was the cabinet

106
00:05:31,179 --> 00:05:36,230
itself, the giant wooden cabinet
with the speakers in it and stuff.

107
00:05:36,230 --> 00:05:37,790
There's that piece.

108
00:05:37,790 --> 00:05:40,700
Then there's the control surface
that has all the circuitry and

109
00:05:40,700 --> 00:05:42,970
wires, buttons and joysticks.

110
00:05:42,970 --> 00:05:46,650
Then there's the PC hardware
that's gonna drive this stuff.

111
00:05:46,650 --> 00:05:49,623
And then there's the software
on the PC itself.

112
00:05:49,623 --> 00:05:54,223
And then finally we just bring those
four components together and we're done.

113
00:05:54,223 --> 00:05:55,384
>> Yeah we should be done.

114
00:05:55,384 --> 00:05:59,192
>> So does that sound accurate to you
guys as far as like the four main pieces

115
00:05:59,192 --> 00:06:00,657

1323

that 121 is indeed the glowing ball.

1326

>> So I just kind of added it,

1328
01:03:07,790 --> 01:03:08,290
Okay.

1329

now we can [LAUGH] yeah.

1330

>> I would like to know what the normal

Is it worth waiting a month?

1333
01:03:22,610 --> 01:03:25,960
For the standard track, well you know,
so I need to know that.

1334
01:03:25,960 --> 01:03:28,590
So, we do need to get a quote needed.

1335
01:03:30,280 --> 01:03:37,690
So, price of normal trackball,

>> No, it's like a couple bucks less.

1338

1339

1340
01:03:44,498 --> 01:03:47,820
>> [LAUGH]

1341

There we go, all right.

1342
01:03:49,920 --> 01:03:52,920
The Hagstrom the control interfaces.

So with that it is 193.

1344

And that includes the keyboard parts the
breakup boards and the wires and stuff.

1345
01:04:03,296 --> 01:04:04,641

1346

>> Yes it does.

1347
01:04:06,152 --> 01:04:07,555
>> All right,
did the other one include shipping?

1348
01:04:11,816 --> 01:04:16,189
And yes it does,
because from those people,

1349
01:04:16,189 --> 01:04:22,210
if we get a certain amount ordered

1350
01:04:22,210 --> 01:04:22,960
>> Nice.

1351
01:04:22,960 --> 01:04:24,250
All right, good.

1352
01:04:24,250 --> 01:04:25,190
>> So does it include shipping?

1353
01:04:26,300 --> 01:04:29,882
>> Let me just add that so I don't ask

1354
01:04:29,882 --> 01:04:32,785
531 with trackball.

1355
01:04:32,785 --> 01:04:34,772
>> And shipping!

1356
01:04:34,772 --> 01:04:36,650
>> With shipping.

1357
01:04:36,650 --> 01:04:40,080
And the other one, you had a specific
quote, I'm looking over at your notes, and

01:04:40,080 --> 01:04:42,000
I just see pen for Hagstrom.

1359
01:04:42,000 --> 01:04:44,410
Is that an actual quote from them or?

1360
01:04:44,410 --> 01:04:46,329
>> Yes.
>> Okay, so not an estimate.

1361
01:04:46,329 --> 01:04:52,790
It's important to know whether you've
got an estimate or an actual number.

1362
01:04:52,790 --> 01:04:54,590
An actual number I can rely on.

1363
01:04:54,590 --> 01:04:57,010
I know that's what the price is gonna be,
there's some risk it might change.

1364
01:04:57,010 --> 01:05:01,610
But an estimate, a few or
a couple, words like that,

1365
01:05:01,610 --> 01:05:04,192
those are a project
managers worst enemies.

1366
01:05:04,192 --> 01:05:08,220
All right, so
I think that's it for items right?

1367
01:05:08,220 --> 01:05:10,218
Oh, there's the software,
right, so HyperSpin.

1368
01:05:10,218 --> 01:05:12,722

1369
01:05:12,722 --> 01:05:16,490

1370
01:05:16,490 --> 01:05:21,403
>> HyperSpin is free,
now there are some sync type utilities

01:05:21,403 --> 01:05:25,780
that will make the process much,
much easier.

1372
01:05:25,780 --> 01:05:30,960
Those ones are not free but if we went
straight up super manual, it's all free.

1373
01:05:30,960 --> 01:05:33,324
>> All right,
let's say we wanted the sync software,

1374
01:05:33,324 --> 01:05:35,310
do you know the prices offhand, or?

1375
01:05:35,310 --> 01:05:39,706
>> Yeah it was, I believe like 30 bucks.

1376
01:05:39,706 --> 01:05:44,090
>> That was for what?

1377
01:05:44,090 --> 01:05:47,060
>> There were two pieces of them,
I don't remember of the top of my head.

1378
01:05:47,060 --> 01:05:49,780
But there was-
>> Okay, I'm gonna add a note.

1379
01:05:49,780 --> 01:05:50,398
>> All right, yeah.

1380
01:05:50,398 --> 01:05:55,853
>> Missing quote information for
convenience software, right?

1381
01:05:55,853 --> 01:05:57,410
>> Mm-hm.
>> So it's not something we necessarily

1382
01:05:57,410 --> 01:06:00,570
need, but if we had it it would be easier,
so I'd like to know how much it costs.

1383
01:06:00,570 --> 01:06:02,870
Because if it's a reasonable amount,

1384
01:06:02,870 --> 01:06:06,450
then that convenience software
may help us meet our deadline.

1385
01:06:06,450 --> 01:06:10,580
Versus if we don't have the convenient
software and you've got to do a lot of

1386
01:06:10,580 --> 01:06:14,000
advanced programming or whatever, all of
the sudden your, I think I can get it

1387
01:06:14,000 --> 01:06:17,755
done in five days becomes,
well we're on day ten and I'm not done.

1388
01:06:17,755 --> 01:06:20,360
>> [LAUGH]
>> If it's a matter of spending $50 extra

1389
01:06:20,360 --> 01:06:24,230
to ensure the project is done,
I'm willing to do that, but

1390
01:06:24,230 --> 01:06:26,780
if it's several hundred dollars,
probably not.

1391
01:06:26,780 --> 01:06:29,979
So I can't make that judgement
right now without knowing, so

1392
01:06:29,979 --> 01:06:31,400
we need more information.

1393
01:06:31,400 --> 01:06:35,417
>> Okay.

1394
01:06:35,417 --> 01:06:37,484
>> All right, and
the graphics overlay Rob,

1395
01:06:37,484 --> 01:06:40,040
we'd have to get a quote
from somebody right?

1396
01:06:40,040 --> 01:06:41,550
>> Yeah, I'd have to get a quote.

1397
01:06:41,550 --> 01:06:43,221
>> Okay so we've got to note that.

1398
01:06:43,221 --> 01:06:44,139
>> If it's assigned to
me then that's good.

1399
01:06:44,139 --> 01:06:47,418
>> Okay, and I will assign that to Rob.

1400
01:06:47,418 --> 01:06:52,070
I need to do better about, and

1401
01:06:52,070 --> 01:06:54,760
Rob you already designed the graphics
overlay so I'm gonna flag that as done.

1402
01:06:54,760 --> 01:06:55,410
Oh!
>> Oh!

1403
01:06:55,410 --> 01:06:56,410
>> Oh, there it goes.

1404
01:06:56,410 --> 01:06:58,800
>> It doesn't leave it in the list
when you flag it as done?

1405
01:06:58,800 --> 01:06:59,700
>> I guess not.

1406
01:06:59,700 --> 01:07:01,570
>> All right well,
let's let that sit then.

1407
01:07:01,570 --> 01:07:03,620
>> I guess it's easy to make
a graphic overlay when it's just

1408
01:07:03,620 --> 01:07:05,195
one solid color, right?

1409
01:07:05,195 --> 01:07:07,330
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

1410
01:07:07,330 --> 01:07:11,590
>> All right, so good, okay.

1411
01:07:11,590 --> 01:07:16,830
All right, so at this stage we
have some basic financials, right.

1412
01:07:16,830 --> 01:07:18,890
Obviously we have some more
information we need to get.

1413
01:07:18,890 --> 01:07:19,840
We got a basic schedule.

1414
01:07:19,840 --> 01:07:22,530
We'll probably need to do some
little revisions on that.

1415
01:07:22,530 --> 01:07:25,720
I don't think we'll do another
show covering the revisions,

1416
01:07:25,720 --> 01:07:29,520
I think we'll just get the information
together, tighten it up, and then when we

1417
01:07:29,520 --> 01:07:33,900
kick off an execution we'll do another
special and kind of see the progress of

1418
01:07:33,900 --> 01:07:36,600
our work as we go through cuz we need
to do monitoring and controlling.

1419
01:07:37,600 --> 01:07:40,500
Normally I’d also launch into
risk management at this point.

1420
01:07:40,500 --> 01:07:44,570
But on a small project like this with
a reasonably small budget there's

1421
01:07:44,570 --> 01:07:47,140
not a whole lot of risk that
we're gonna have, right.

1422
01:07:47,140 --> 01:07:50,780
Sick days, if either of you guys get
sick that could delay the project a bit.

1423
01:07:50,780 --> 01:07:53,730
Because I don't have a hard deadline
I'm not so worried about that.

1424
01:07:53,730 --> 01:07:55,620
Our schedule can slip.

1425
01:07:55,620 --> 01:07:57,690
Cost is the one thing
I don't want to slip.

1426
01:07:57,690 --> 01:07:58,890
You know, I put that in the charter,

1427
01:07:58,890 --> 01:08:01,700
there is a maximum amount of
money I'm willing to spend.

1428
01:08:01,700 --> 01:08:05,000
And if we hit that maximum amount,
I'm not gonna be happy.

1429
01:08:05,000 --> 01:08:10,980
So, I'm a little more rigid on that budget
piece then I am on the schedule piece.

1430
01:08:10,980 --> 01:08:14,220
But, all right can you guys
think of anything else?

1431
01:08:15,550 --> 01:08:17,640
>> I don't think so.

1432
01:08:17,640 --> 01:08:20,180
>> All right, you guys are all
assigned this in Asana, so

1433
01:08:20,180 --> 01:08:23,840
it is attached to you guys so
go and review it on your own.

1434
01:08:23,840 --> 01:08:26,075
We’re gonna have another
meeting next week.

1435
01:08:26,075 --> 01:08:28,510
Lets just do same day, same time.

1436
01:08:28,510 --> 01:08:31,930
And so we'll do another meeting.

1437
01:08:31,930 --> 01:08:34,850
Let's bring those quotes,
the things that I've put on here that I

1438
01:08:34,850 --> 01:08:36,990
need to get quotes on,
let's get those together so

1439
01:08:36,990 --> 01:08:40,170
that we can finalize a lot information and
get it put together.

1440
01:08:40,170 --> 01:08:42,481
In fact, don't wait for the meeting for
that, get that information to me earlier.

1441
01:08:42,481 --> 01:08:43,100
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

1442
01:08:43,100 --> 01:08:45,310
>> And then that way,
when it comes time for that meeting,

1443
01:08:45,310 --> 01:08:48,650
we should have everything, you know,
all our ducks should be in a row.

1444
01:08:48,650 --> 01:08:51,500
We can just do a final review,
sign off on our plan, you know,

1445
01:08:51,500 --> 01:08:52,960
actually draft our full plan and be done.

1446
01:08:52,960 --> 01:08:56,810
I mean, well,
done with the plan so, sound good?

1447
01:08:56,810 --> 01:08:58,160
>> Sounds good.

1448
01:08:58,160 --> 01:09:01,610
>> All right, well ITPro TV viewers,
I hope you guys enjoyed that.

1449
01:09:01,610 --> 01:09:06,000
I know It seems kind of rambly,
but you kinda get an idea of,

1450
01:09:06,000 --> 01:09:08,430
when you look at something,
one person's perspective is not enough.

1451
01:09:08,430 --> 01:09:10,430
You gotta get more
information from the others.

1452
01:09:10,430 --> 01:09:13,740
If you can get everybody together,
sit them around a table, communicate,

1453
01:09:13,740 --> 01:09:15,320
you can find out all of the things.

1454
01:09:15,320 --> 01:09:17,980
You may think you have all of the
information you need, but there's always

1455
01:09:17,980 --> 01:09:21,670
something extra that you can get, so
identifying that, that's kinda key.

1456
01:09:21,670 --> 01:09:24,362
And all part of good project management,
so.

1457
01:09:24,362 --> 01:09:27,660
All right well stay tuned, we're gonna
have more of these specials as the arcade

1458
01:09:27,660 --> 01:09:31,885
cabinet, slash debacle continues.

1459
01:09:31,885 --> 01:09:34,787
And hey, this time next month
maybe we'll be playing,

1460
01:09:34,787 --> 01:09:37,087
some kind of open source
version of Galaga.

1461
01:09:37,087 --> 01:09:37,961
>> [LAUGH]
>> Nice.

1462
01:09:37,961 --> 01:09:39,586
>> Okay.
All right, stay tuned, we'll see you then.

1463
01:09:39,586 --> 01:09:47,529
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don discuss the execution phase of a project. They start with the direct and manage project work process. They discuss performing the quality assurance methods that were defined during the planning phase. They wrap up the show discussing how to manage a project team.
episodes.title: Executing Part 1
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,102 --> 00:00:10,102
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,480 --> 00:00:37,260
All right good morning, good afternoon and
good evening and welcome back.

3
00:00:37,260 --> 00:00:38,920
To another episode of ITPro TV.

4
00:00:38,920 --> 00:00:41,860
I'm Don Pezet today with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:41,860 --> 00:00:42,990
How's it going, Ronnie?

6
00:00:42,990 --> 00:00:44,360
>> It is going well today.

7
00:00:44,360 --> 00:00:49,060
I am very pleased to announce that I read
that Miley Cyrus did not twerk one time

8
00:00:49,060 --> 00:00:50,140
at the VMA Awards.

9
00:00:50,140 --> 00:00:50,868
>> Really?
>> Yes.

10
00:00:50,868 --> 00:00:54,140
>> So
this shows how much I follow the news.

11
00:00:54,140 --> 00:00:55,275
When were the VMA awards?

12
00:00:55,275 --> 00:00:57,184
[LAUGH]
>> Yesterday I think.

13
00:00:57,184 --> 00:00:58,066
Or the day before.

14
00:00:58,066 --> 00:00:58,669
I don't know.

15
00:00:58,669 --> 00:00:59,947
>> [LAUGH] Timely information.

16
00:00:59,947 --> 00:01:04,752
All right, well we are diving
right back into the world of pmp.

17
00:01:04,752 --> 00:01:07,050
>> That's right.
>> Project manager professional today.

18
00:01:07,050 --> 00:01:08,010
For those of you watching live,

19
00:01:08,010 --> 00:01:11,750
we took a little bit of a hiatus between
the first half of the show and this one.

20
00:01:11,750 --> 00:01:13,500
But for those of you watching recorded,

21
00:01:13,500 --> 00:01:15,160
know that we're just another
click on the webpage.

22
00:01:15,160 --> 00:01:18,810
So what we're doing today
is we are cracking open

23
00:01:18,810 --> 00:01:20,830
an all new process group, right?

24
00:01:20,830 --> 00:01:26,750
We are diving into the wonderful
world of the executing process group.

25
00:01:26,750 --> 00:01:30,628
So we have recorded more than
half the show at this point.

26
00:01:30,628 --> 00:01:34,424
And over half the show fell in
these first two process groups,

27
00:01:34,424 --> 00:01:38,807
initiating and planning, planning
being the one where a lot of our work

28
00:01:38,807 --> 00:01:41,305
is look at all those processes in there.

29
00:01:41,305 --> 00:01:44,795
Today we're going to dive into executing,
and aside from closing,

30
00:01:44,795 --> 00:01:47,340
executing is really one
of the shorter ones.

31
00:01:47,340 --> 00:01:48,810
You wouldn't think it is,

32
00:01:48,810 --> 00:01:52,550
because in a project, executing is
where we spend most of our time.

33
00:01:52,550 --> 00:01:54,210
But what is executing?

34
00:01:54,210 --> 00:01:57,160
It's doing the work that we planned for,
right?

35
00:01:57,160 --> 00:02:03,090
We planned all sorts of work to be done,
now we need to do it, right?

36
00:02:03,090 --> 00:02:06,850
And then what you said Ronnie is if
someone is doing it someone has got to

37
00:02:06,850 --> 00:02:08,210
manage it, right?

38
00:02:08,210 --> 00:02:12,390
So, this is where our
needs start to diverge.

39
00:02:12,390 --> 00:02:16,860
We start splitting apart what's happening
here and you'll find that executing, for

40
00:02:16,860 --> 00:02:19,190
us as a project manager,
is actually kind of boring.

41
00:02:19,190 --> 00:02:19,760
Right?

42
00:02:19,760 --> 00:02:25,150
But, not truly, we don't have a lot to
do with executing, we're monitoring.

43
00:02:25,150 --> 00:02:28,680
So while other people are doing
the actual work of the project,

44
00:02:28,680 --> 00:02:29,750
we need to be managing and

45
00:02:29,750 --> 00:02:32,820
monitoring, making sure things are going
the way the they're supposed to.

46
00:02:32,820 --> 00:02:34,840
Well, we're not ready for
monitoring just yet.

47
00:02:34,840 --> 00:02:38,180
We're gonna dive into executing, so
we're gonna look at one side of things.

48
00:02:38,180 --> 00:02:41,890
And it may seem that we're moving
kinda quickly through the material,

49
00:02:41,890 --> 00:02:43,960
that we don't have a lot of data here,
but the reason is,

50
00:02:43,960 --> 00:02:47,910
is as the project manager there's
not a lot you do in executing.

51
00:02:47,910 --> 00:02:51,010
And you know, I've shown this diagram
multiple times during the show,

52
00:02:51,010 --> 00:02:55,380
this one, where sure,
we have initiation, then planning,

53
00:02:55,380 --> 00:02:58,210
then execution, then monitoring and
controlling, then closing.

54
00:02:58,210 --> 00:03:01,590
But if you were to actually diagram it
out, it's more like this right here

55
00:03:01,590 --> 00:03:05,340
where execution and monitoring and
controlling happen at the same time.

56
00:03:06,442 --> 00:03:09,200
All right, and if we were to go
back to our process diagram,

57
00:03:09,200 --> 00:03:12,420
if you were to combine these
two processes together,

58
00:03:12,420 --> 00:03:14,920
you'll see that it actually
would be quite a bit of stuff.

59
00:03:14,920 --> 00:03:16,810
And it would even compete with planning.

60
00:03:18,412 --> 00:03:22,280
All right, so all that being said,
let's dive into this stuff, right?

61
00:03:22,280 --> 00:03:25,380
So we are going to take a look at
direct and manage project work.

62
00:03:25,380 --> 00:03:28,370
That's going to be our first
process group to tackle.

63
00:03:28,370 --> 00:03:31,680
And you'll see that theres not
a whole heck of a lot to this one.

64
00:03:31,680 --> 00:03:35,240
In fact, I don't think there is a single
thing on this slide that is new

65
00:03:35,240 --> 00:03:36,640
from what we've talked about previously.

66
00:03:37,720 --> 00:03:41,194
When we go into execution,
we basically tell people, okay guys,

67
00:03:41,194 --> 00:03:42,877
you know that schedule we made?

68
00:03:42,877 --> 00:03:44,433
Do it, right?

69
00:03:44,433 --> 00:03:46,128
Look at the days, figure out what
you are suppose to be doing.

70
00:03:46,128 --> 00:03:47,475
Get to work.

71
00:03:47,475 --> 00:03:48,680
I mean that budget we created.

72
00:03:48,680 --> 00:03:50,300
Get to cutting those checks.

73
00:03:50,300 --> 00:03:52,900
Or whatever you do the thing
we planned on you doing.

74
00:03:54,130 --> 00:03:55,900
So when it comes to directing and

75
00:03:55,900 --> 00:03:59,440
managing that, we're really just
making sure that it happens, right.

76
00:03:59,440 --> 00:04:01,200
So most of our tools and

77
00:04:01,200 --> 00:04:04,980
techniques here are really just gonna
center around information gathering.

78
00:04:04,980 --> 00:04:07,390
How do we find out about
the work people are doing.

79
00:04:07,390 --> 00:04:09,400
Well the people who are doing the work,

80
00:04:09,400 --> 00:04:11,190
they're looking at our
project management plan.

81
00:04:11,190 --> 00:04:14,850
They're looking at that plan that we came
up with that's telling them what to do.

82
00:04:14,850 --> 00:04:17,460
If there had been Change Requests
that had been approved,

83
00:04:17,460 --> 00:04:19,230
those become part of the plan too, right?

84
00:04:19,230 --> 00:04:20,790
So that's where they're
finding out what to do.

85
00:04:20,790 --> 00:04:22,270
All right.

86
00:04:22,270 --> 00:04:24,510
When a company starts actually doing work,

87
00:04:24,510 --> 00:04:27,560
there's Enterprise Environmental Factors
and Organizational Process Assets.

88
00:04:27,560 --> 00:04:29,790
We've seen those on every process so far.

89
00:04:29,790 --> 00:04:33,400
So basically your company has a way
of doing work, and that's it.

90
00:04:33,400 --> 00:04:34,350
That's the way of doing it.

91
00:04:34,350 --> 00:04:35,970
They have certain forms they fill out.

92
00:04:35,970 --> 00:04:38,150
Time cards, punch clocks whatever,

93
00:04:38,150 --> 00:04:40,780
all that's stuff that's involved
in actually doing the work.

94
00:04:40,780 --> 00:04:41,760
>> Right.

95
00:04:41,760 --> 00:04:45,510
>> For us as a project manager though
all we're doing is gathering data.

96
00:04:45,510 --> 00:04:48,770
And we gather data through
a few different systems.

97
00:04:48,770 --> 00:04:50,270
The first one is expert judgement.

98
00:04:50,270 --> 00:04:52,550
Use your noodle or your eyes in this case.

99
00:04:52,550 --> 00:04:54,900
Just look, see what's going on.

100
00:04:54,900 --> 00:04:58,280
Keep tabs on people and
make sure they're doing their work.

101
00:04:58,280 --> 00:04:59,520
Meetings are another way.

102
00:04:59,520 --> 00:05:01,280
Right?
We do these here at ITPro TV.

103
00:05:01,280 --> 00:05:03,550
Every morning we have a stand up meeting.

104
00:05:03,550 --> 00:05:04,500
We get everybody together and

105
00:05:04,500 --> 00:05:06,910
we exchange information about
what we've been working on and

106
00:05:06,910 --> 00:05:10,670
what we're going to be working on, so
that everybody knows where everything is.

107
00:05:10,670 --> 00:05:11,950
Those meetings are pivotal.

108
00:05:11,950 --> 00:05:13,620
And boy, you hear more and

109
00:05:13,620 --> 00:05:18,570
more about these all the time, with other
methodologies like agile and scrum and

110
00:05:18,570 --> 00:05:22,240
all that, where they're really pushing
gathering data through meetings.

111
00:05:23,395 --> 00:05:25,725
Meetings are a slippery
slope [LAUGH] Friday.

112
00:05:25,725 --> 00:05:27,855
I'm not a big fan of meetings
that are unstructured.

113
00:05:27,855 --> 00:05:30,885
So you need to have structured
meetings to really be successful.

114
00:05:30,885 --> 00:05:33,525
You wanna make sure that you don't bring
a bunch of people in for a meeting and

115
00:05:33,525 --> 00:05:36,700
then sit there and
get nothing out of it, right.

116
00:05:36,700 --> 00:05:39,260
I think I talked about it
in another episode, so

117
00:05:39,260 --> 00:05:40,550
I don't want to dive too deep into it.

118
00:05:40,550 --> 00:05:42,830
I have a few rules for meetings which are,

119
00:05:42,830 --> 00:05:46,160
rule number one,
invite as few people as possible.

120
00:05:46,160 --> 00:05:48,140
Smaller meetings
are always more effective.

121
00:05:48,140 --> 00:05:52,530
Rule number two, every person that comes
to the meeting, at the end of the meeting

122
00:05:52,530 --> 00:05:55,340
they should have an action item, they
should have something they need to do.

123
00:05:55,340 --> 00:05:58,020
If they don't have an action item,
they didn't need to be in the meeting,

124
00:05:58,020 --> 00:06:01,090
you could have just gotten
the information from them ahead of time.

125
00:06:01,090 --> 00:06:03,030
So those are just some of
the rules that I have, and

126
00:06:03,030 --> 00:06:06,250
then number three is always
have an agenda, right?

127
00:06:06,250 --> 00:06:10,800
Don't just go into a meeting willy nilly
with no actual plan, have something ready,

128
00:06:10,800 --> 00:06:14,100
have a list of topics you want to talk
about, and make sure you distribute it

129
00:06:14,100 --> 00:06:17,550
before the meeting so people can prepare,
they may need to bring data with them.

130
00:06:17,550 --> 00:06:20,510
You don't want to have a second meeting
because the first meeting didn't

131
00:06:20,510 --> 00:06:21,250
have all the information.

132
00:06:22,592 --> 00:06:25,120
All right, but the one I skipped
over is probably the most useful and

133
00:06:25,120 --> 00:06:28,470
that's the project management
information system the PMIS.

134
00:06:28,470 --> 00:06:31,540
And that is a pivotal tool that
I know we've talked about.

135
00:06:31,540 --> 00:06:32,280
>> Yeah.

136
00:06:32,280 --> 00:06:35,580
Now in this process, right,
for us as project managers,

137
00:06:35,580 --> 00:06:38,450
this is where we actually have to
keep track of that triangle, right?

138
00:06:38,450 --> 00:06:42,460
The constraint triangle that we actually
have here of the project cost, the time,

139
00:06:42,460 --> 00:06:44,880
and the overall scope here.

140
00:06:44,880 --> 00:06:46,700
And the easiest and most effective way for

141
00:06:46,700 --> 00:06:50,630
us to be able to do that is to use that
project management instrument that we have

142
00:06:50,630 --> 00:06:53,210
because without it right
the project continues to grow.

143
00:06:53,210 --> 00:06:56,210
It continues to, so
now that is actually executing, right.

144
00:06:56,210 --> 00:06:58,905
All of the sudden it just
grows beyond our control.

145
00:06:58,905 --> 00:07:03,398
But being able to keep track of it all in
one place is very essential for us, and

146
00:07:03,398 --> 00:07:08,379
for us to keep everything underneath that
particular constraint triangle is going to

147
00:07:08,379 --> 00:07:11,698
be how we successfully complete
our overall project, so

148
00:07:11,698 --> 00:07:13,981
we want to make sure
that we have a hold or

149
00:07:13,981 --> 00:07:17,535
at least we understand whatever
tool we're gonna be using.

150
00:07:17,535 --> 00:07:20,474
>> Yeah and what tool do you use,
it's up to you, right.

151
00:07:20,474 --> 00:07:21,970
There's a ton of them out
there you can pick and choose.

152
00:07:21,970 --> 00:07:23,520
Let me just give you an example,

153
00:07:23,520 --> 00:07:26,840
maybe you use Microsoft project
to do your project management.

154
00:07:26,840 --> 00:07:30,170
Well as people are out there doing
the work, as they're executing.

155
00:07:30,170 --> 00:07:31,420
They're filling out time cards.

156
00:07:31,420 --> 00:07:34,880
They're saying, yeah, I work from 8 AM
to 5 PM Monday through Friday, or hey,

157
00:07:34,880 --> 00:07:36,860
I did some overtime this day, or whatever.

158
00:07:36,860 --> 00:07:38,750
They're submitting those
time cards to you,

159
00:07:38,750 --> 00:07:41,960
and then you punch them
into Microsoft Project.

160
00:07:41,960 --> 00:07:42,500
Right?

161
00:07:42,500 --> 00:07:44,420
Or maybe you've got
Microsoft Project Server.

162
00:07:44,420 --> 00:07:45,280
This is nice.

163
00:07:45,280 --> 00:07:47,640
Because then there's a web page and

164
00:07:47,640 --> 00:07:50,250
instead of people filling out their own
time card they go to the web page and

165
00:07:50,250 --> 00:07:52,730
they put their time in there and
it's already entered into the system.

166
00:07:52,730 --> 00:07:53,330
>> Yes.
>> They do it for you.

167
00:07:53,330 --> 00:07:54,017
Then all you have to do is review it.

168
00:07:54,017 --> 00:07:54,834
That's kind of nice.

169
00:07:54,834 --> 00:07:56,816
Maybe use some other system.

170
00:07:56,816 --> 00:07:58,151
It's completely up to you.

171
00:07:58,151 --> 00:07:59,810
Everybody uses different
solutions it seems.

172
00:07:59,810 --> 00:08:01,634
And you just find the one that's right.

173
00:08:01,634 --> 00:08:07,279
Just remember: with a PMIS, the thing
to remember on the exam especially,

174
00:08:07,279 --> 00:08:11,890
is a PMIS is only as good as
the data you put into it, all right?

175
00:08:11,890 --> 00:08:15,110
If you haven't put data into it yet,
it's not going to be very effective.

176
00:08:15,110 --> 00:08:18,190
So, for example,
you might be looking at your PMIS, and

177
00:08:18,190 --> 00:08:22,340
it tells you your project is on schedule
and under budget; things look great.

178
00:08:22,340 --> 00:08:24,890
But meanwhile sitting
right there on your desk,

179
00:08:24,890 --> 00:08:28,080
you've got ten overtime sheets
that you have to enter in, and

180
00:08:28,080 --> 00:08:32,360
all of a sudden you will find that your
schedule is good, but your budget is shot.

181
00:08:32,360 --> 00:08:35,630
You've gone way over
budget on overtime fees.

182
00:08:35,630 --> 00:08:39,440
Your PMIS doesn't know that yet, because
you haven't given it the data, yet.

183
00:08:39,440 --> 00:08:40,050
All right?

184
00:08:40,050 --> 00:08:43,110
So that's why when it
comes to the PMP exam,

185
00:08:43,110 --> 00:08:45,920
they don't really focus on
a PMIS really very much.

186
00:08:45,920 --> 00:08:49,200
They ask questions about it but
they don't show you one.

187
00:08:49,200 --> 00:08:52,380
They don't say do this in
Microsoft Project or Timberline, or

188
00:08:52,380 --> 00:08:55,710
whatever program it is that you use,
Primavera I guess that would be bigger.

189
00:08:55,710 --> 00:09:00,590
So they don't do that, and that's
because everybody uses different stuff.

190
00:09:00,590 --> 00:09:05,710
And an effective project manager is doing
both, using the PMIS and using their own

191
00:09:05,710 --> 00:09:09,980
expert judgement, that number one tool and
technique right there, all right.

192
00:09:09,980 --> 00:09:13,750
Now as we monitor the work getting done,
we generate some outputs.

193
00:09:13,750 --> 00:09:18,580
Now obviously if work is being done, then
there's not much of an output coming from

194
00:09:18,580 --> 00:09:23,050
us, there's output coming from the people
in the form of deliverables, right.

195
00:09:23,050 --> 00:09:24,330
They finish their job and

196
00:09:24,330 --> 00:09:26,660
they create whatever it is they
were supposed to create, or

197
00:09:26,660 --> 00:09:29,745
they perform whatever activity it was
they were suppose to perform, all right.

198
00:09:29,745 --> 00:09:34,360
We're building a house, and we have some
drywallers coming in to put the walls up.

199
00:09:34,360 --> 00:09:35,700
Then when they're done with the work,

200
00:09:35,700 --> 00:09:39,220
I should be able to walk in the house and
see drywall everywhere.

201
00:09:39,220 --> 00:09:40,680
Not see struts and beams,
and all that stuff.

202
00:09:41,880 --> 00:09:44,920
But, if they're not done yet,
then at a minimum,

203
00:09:44,920 --> 00:09:48,310
they should be delivering
work performance data.

204
00:09:48,310 --> 00:09:50,960
How much work they got done,
how many hours they put in,

205
00:09:50,960 --> 00:09:54,538
how much we need to pay them:
time sheets and progress reports.

206
00:09:54,538 --> 00:09:59,880
Those are our big things that come
out of the outputs, on a good day.

207
00:09:59,880 --> 00:10:01,720
Sometimes, there's a bad day.

208
00:10:01,720 --> 00:10:03,260
Sometimes things don't go quite right.

209
00:10:03,260 --> 00:10:06,860
Sometimes things don't match up with
our plan that we defined earlier.

210
00:10:06,860 --> 00:10:10,050
And when that happen,s we end
up with change requests, right.

211
00:10:10,050 --> 00:10:13,340
So if something's not working
out according to plan,

212
00:10:13,340 --> 00:10:16,270
we need to do a change request,
and we need to get it approved.

213
00:10:16,270 --> 00:10:19,940
If it's approved, great, if it's not
approved, well now we've gotta find some

214
00:10:19,940 --> 00:10:22,810
other way to correct for
this divergence with our plan.

215
00:10:22,810 --> 00:10:26,710
All right, and the same thing goes for
these last couple of ones.

216
00:10:26,710 --> 00:10:29,860
Project management plan updates,
and project document updates.

217
00:10:29,860 --> 00:10:32,570
The most common one that
I update at this point,

218
00:10:32,570 --> 00:10:34,370
are the risk management plans, right?

219
00:10:34,370 --> 00:10:37,400
Cuz we have our risk register where
we're keeping track of all that, and

220
00:10:37,400 --> 00:10:39,130
that's designed to be a living document,

221
00:10:39,130 --> 00:10:43,650
where you're updating your odds of
effect and things of those nature.

222
00:10:43,650 --> 00:10:46,040
So you're constantly updating that
information as you move through it.

223
00:10:46,040 --> 00:10:49,630
That's all a part of direct and
manage project work.

224
00:10:49,630 --> 00:10:50,130
>> Yeah.

225
00:10:51,160 --> 00:10:52,940
>> All right.
So as far as processes go,

226
00:10:52,940 --> 00:10:54,120
this one's pretty straightforward.

227
00:10:54,120 --> 00:10:56,550
And in fact,
you could boil it down to what?

228
00:10:56,550 --> 00:10:57,720
Two sentences, right?

229
00:10:57,720 --> 00:11:00,120
Tell people to work, and
make sure they do it.

230
00:11:00,120 --> 00:11:02,280
That's really what this
process is all about.

231
00:11:02,280 --> 00:11:02,830
>> Yeah.

232
00:11:02,830 --> 00:11:06,100
At this point in our lives, right,
and especially as project managers.

233
00:11:06,100 --> 00:11:09,990
We should no longer feel, I shouldn't say
that, we should no longer need to feel

234
00:11:09,990 --> 00:11:15,170
the idea of actually jumping right in,
and having to do everything by ourselves.

235
00:11:15,170 --> 00:11:19,630
Again, when you're actually going for your
PMP, you know, I delegate it out, I just

236
00:11:19,630 --> 00:11:23,410
need to make sure that what I delegate
out is actually done at this point.

237
00:11:23,410 --> 00:11:26,420
And that's why using those tools
are actually very helpful for us.

238
00:11:26,420 --> 00:11:29,540
So directing and managing for us,
again is just the idea of monitoring,

239
00:11:29,540 --> 00:11:31,190
making sure it's done.

240
00:11:31,190 --> 00:11:33,090
>> All right, so what else do we have?

241
00:11:33,090 --> 00:11:33,990
People are doing their work.

242
00:11:33,990 --> 00:11:34,790
>> Yep.
>> Right.

243
00:11:34,790 --> 00:11:36,640
Now some other things need to happen.

244
00:11:36,640 --> 00:11:39,910
You might remember in the planning phase,
we went through quality assurance or

245
00:11:39,910 --> 00:11:41,670
wait, quality management in general.

246
00:11:41,670 --> 00:11:45,750
Quality management is made of two pieces,
quality assurance and

247
00:11:45,750 --> 00:11:47,660
quality control, right?

248
00:11:47,660 --> 00:11:51,940
Quality assurance is stopping
problems before they happen.

249
00:11:51,940 --> 00:11:56,340
Making sure that our systems are optimized
and functioning properly, to stop or

250
00:11:56,340 --> 00:11:58,510
prevent a problem from
happening in the first place.

251
00:11:58,510 --> 00:12:03,080
Quality control is detecting and
correcting the problem, after it occurs.

252
00:12:03,080 --> 00:12:03,740
Right?

253
00:12:03,740 --> 00:12:07,070
When we did quality management, so
planned quality management, we did both.

254
00:12:07,070 --> 00:12:08,640
Right?
We kind of planned for both.

255
00:12:08,640 --> 00:12:13,520
Well now, in executing,
you're executing your quality assurance,

256
00:12:13,520 --> 00:12:17,090
and in monitoring and
controlling we'll do quality control.

257
00:12:17,090 --> 00:12:17,610
All right?

258
00:12:17,610 --> 00:12:20,040
So, they're kind of broken in pieces here,
and

259
00:12:20,040 --> 00:12:24,700
the reason is, the project manager is
typically over here doing quality control.

260
00:12:24,700 --> 00:12:25,410
Right?

261
00:12:25,410 --> 00:12:27,720
But the work package owners.

262
00:12:27,720 --> 00:12:30,300
The people who are actually
doing the work.

263
00:12:30,300 --> 00:12:33,520
They're the ones who do
the quality assurance, okay?

264
00:12:33,520 --> 00:12:37,810
Maybe my project has a roofing
that needs to be done.

265
00:12:37,810 --> 00:12:40,160
So we've got to put
shingles across the roof.

266
00:12:40,160 --> 00:12:44,830
And one of the risks that I had to
quality, was that somebody could

267
00:12:44,830 --> 00:12:47,400
fall off the roof and break a leg,
and have to go to the hospital.

268
00:12:47,400 --> 00:12:49,925
And now I'd be short one person,
which would put me behind schedule.

269
00:12:49,925 --> 00:12:50,990
>> Mm-hm.
>> Okay.

270
00:12:50,990 --> 00:12:54,150
So as part of my quality assurance,
I might of said,

271
00:12:54,150 --> 00:12:56,330
you know what, we're gonna plan for this.

272
00:12:56,330 --> 00:12:59,450
We're gonna make sure that all the workers
who are up there on the roof have

273
00:12:59,450 --> 00:13:00,290
harnesses.

274
00:13:00,290 --> 00:13:01,940
So that of they fall, they'll be safe.

275
00:13:01,940 --> 00:13:02,910
They've got a harness.

276
00:13:02,910 --> 00:13:04,980
That's gonna ensure that
I have all my people,

277
00:13:04,980 --> 00:13:06,970
that the roof gets done on time and
that we move forward.

278
00:13:07,990 --> 00:13:11,270
So who's gonna make sure that those
people are wearing harnesses?

279
00:13:11,270 --> 00:13:12,780
Well, that's their job.

280
00:13:12,780 --> 00:13:15,000
That's what they are supposed
to do as part of roofing,

281
00:13:15,000 --> 00:13:17,000
they need to harness up and get up there.

282
00:13:17,000 --> 00:13:19,560
So they're doing quality assurance.

283
00:13:19,560 --> 00:13:21,500
They're putting on a harness and
getting up there,

284
00:13:21,500 --> 00:13:23,880
to make sure they don't get hurt so
they can do their work.

285
00:13:23,880 --> 00:13:25,770
Right, that's one example.

286
00:13:25,770 --> 00:13:30,360
Other examples of quality assurance are
just, you know, measuring the performance,

287
00:13:30,360 --> 00:13:32,930
or making sure the work
is actually getting done.

288
00:13:32,930 --> 00:13:36,240
If they tell me it's gonna take
four days to get the roofing done,

289
00:13:36,240 --> 00:13:38,440
at the end of day one,
I expect the work to be about 25% done.

290
00:13:38,440 --> 00:13:41,260
And at the end of day two,
they should be halfway.

291
00:13:41,260 --> 00:13:44,000
And if I go and look and they aren't
even there, then there's a problem.

292
00:13:44,000 --> 00:13:44,820
Right?

293
00:13:44,820 --> 00:13:47,780
I think in an earlier show
I made an example of,

294
00:13:47,780 --> 00:13:49,890
if you are like a blue jean factory,
right?

295
00:13:49,890 --> 00:13:52,880
And you're manufacturing a thousand
pairs of blue jeans at a time, and

296
00:13:52,880 --> 00:13:54,980
you want to get your defect rate down.

297
00:13:54,980 --> 00:13:57,340
How can we prevent problems ahead of time?

298
00:13:57,340 --> 00:13:58,210
One of the examples I gave,

299
00:13:58,210 --> 00:14:00,360
was doing routine maintenance
on the equipment, right?

300
00:14:00,360 --> 00:14:03,750
The equipment's not broken, but
we do maintenance on it anyway,

301
00:14:03,750 --> 00:14:05,100
to prevent a problem from happening.

302
00:14:05,100 --> 00:14:09,210
So perform quality assurance means,
doing that maintenance.

303
00:14:09,210 --> 00:14:13,260
Getting the worker, the support tech or
whatever, to come out and lubricate,

304
00:14:13,260 --> 00:14:15,760
or replace parts, or whatever it
is that they do on that machine,

305
00:14:15,760 --> 00:14:18,290
to prevent problems in the first place.

306
00:14:18,290 --> 00:14:20,880
As a project manager, we just need to
make sure that's getting done, right?

307
00:14:20,880 --> 00:14:23,250
We're not the ones who do it,
other people are.

308
00:14:23,250 --> 00:14:25,510
But we do have a whole process group for
this, let me pull it up.

309
00:14:26,820 --> 00:14:29,320
And we'll go perform quality assurance.

310
00:14:30,530 --> 00:14:32,050
Now our inputs on this,

311
00:14:32,050 --> 00:14:34,310
are a lot of things that I was
talking about a moment ago.

312
00:14:34,310 --> 00:14:35,700
Our quality management plan.

313
00:14:35,700 --> 00:14:37,760
We planned for how we want to do this.

314
00:14:37,760 --> 00:14:41,080
That's obviously going to be an input.

315
00:14:41,080 --> 00:14:42,950
If I can say it.

316
00:14:42,950 --> 00:14:44,460
Process improvement plan.

317
00:14:44,460 --> 00:14:48,590
There are many organizations that
do continual process improvement.

318
00:14:48,590 --> 00:14:50,770
Just because things
are running smooth now,

319
00:14:50,770 --> 00:14:53,700

00:15:20,850 --> 00:15:22,600

When we define those in our plan,

Making sure that we're staying

Quality control is also a part of this.

Now I know this is quality assurance.

Quality control is dissecting

After that we've got quality

One of the hardest things about

And so by having some type of response,

00:16:57,170 --> 00:16:58,860
>> Other things like quality audits,

we're gonna talk more about quality

00:17:01,810 --> 00:17:07,530

00:17:07,530 --> 00:17:11,610

00:17:15,460 --> 00:17:18,990
This is one of our main

We trust our employees and our employees

So that's good, we want that, but

it's never a bad idea to go and

00:17:29,210 --> 00:17:32,670
Go and do your own visual inspection
to see that the things are actually

376
00:17:32,670 --> 00:17:34,585

should be progressing and

377
00:17:34,585 --> 00:17:36,700

378
00:17:36,700 --> 00:17:40,800
I remember this story which was I was

379
00:17:40,800 --> 00:17:44,685

00:17:44,685 --> 00:17:46,540
Michigan.

00:17:46,540 --> 00:17:51,280
If you're not in the U.S., Detroit,
Michigan is a very big city that

382
