bankrupt, it's in really bad shape.

383
00:17:56,330 --> 00:18:00,630
So this guy had a chance to buy a house
for $5,000 which is a ridiculously small

384
00:18:00,630 --> 00:18:02,840
amount of money, and
so he buys this house.

385
00:18:02,840 --> 00:18:04,545
Now, he never actually went there.

386
00:18:04,545 --> 00:18:08,079
So people were sending him pictures of
the house, and he looked at it, and

387
00:18:08,079 --> 00:18:11,956
he bought it sight unseen, and he hired a
contractor out there in Detroit to go and

388
00:18:11,956 --> 00:18:15,055
remodel it to make it livable
again because it wasn't livable.

389
00:18:15,055 --> 00:18:19,299
And the contractor said, yeah, give me six
months and I think it was like $100,000,

390
00:18:19,299 --> 00:18:21,716
something like that, and
he would fix the place up and

391
00:18:21,716 --> 00:18:23,617
turn it around to where you could sell it.

392
00:18:23,617 --> 00:18:25,080
Well, there were two problems,

393
00:18:25,080 --> 00:18:27,852
the first problem was the guy
didn't know the neighborhood and

394
00:18:27,852 --> 00:18:30,740
the majority of the neighborhood
had been what to do they call it?

395
00:18:30,740 --> 00:18:32,000
>> Condemned?
[LAUGH] >> Condemned, that's it.

396
00:18:32,000 --> 00:18:33,420
Yeah, it had been condemned, so

397
00:18:33,420 --> 00:18:34,980
the majority of
the neighborhood was unlivable.

398
00:18:34,980 --> 00:18:36,530
Even if you made this one house livable,

399
00:18:36,530 --> 00:18:39,720
nobody would want to live there cuz
it's surrounded by condemned stuff.

400
00:18:39,720 --> 00:18:43,521
The other thing was, the contractor was
sending him pictures of the work to show

401
00:18:43,521 --> 00:18:47,055

the pictures were of other houses.

402
00:18:47,055 --> 00:18:49,352
>> [LAUGH]
>> And he wasn't actually doing the work,

403
00:18:49,352 --> 00:18:51,360
he had basically stolen the guy's money.

00:18:51,360 --> 00:18:55,280
So for months he kept getting
these picture status reports, and

00:18:55,280 --> 00:19:00,480
they were all fake, and it wasn't until
he actually went out to Detroit to

406
00:19:00,480 --> 00:19:04,990
look at this place that he realized that
not a single bit of work had been done.

407
00:19:04,990 --> 00:19:08,153
And by that point, the city stepped in and
demolished the building, so

408
00:19:08,153 --> 00:19:10,620
he basically lost
everything he put into it.

409
00:19:10,620 --> 00:19:11,850
That's the kind of thing that happens.

410
00:19:11,850 --> 00:19:13,680
Now, that's a worst case scenario.

411
00:19:15,540 --> 00:19:18,470
But it is possible,
especially with contractors, that

412
00:19:18,470 --> 00:19:21,350
you may not be getting the performance
other than that they're reporting.

413
00:19:21,350 --> 00:19:24,631
And what you don't want is for them to be
pushing off work and then all of a sudden

414
00:19:24,631 --> 00:19:27,915
slam you with a bunch of overtime at the
end while they're trying to correct and

415
00:19:27,915 --> 00:19:28,883
get back on schedule.

416
00:19:28,883 --> 00:19:30,875
You need to catch that ahead of time,

417
00:19:30,875 --> 00:19:34,680
which is why this falls under quality
assurance not quality control.

418
00:19:34,680 --> 00:19:37,855
>> And so a lot of times what ends up
happening is when you start seeing

419
00:19:37,855 --> 00:19:42,074
quality deteriorate, and then that's what
catches your attention, by that point,

00:19:42,074 --> 00:19:43,280
it's too late.

They've already produced 10,000
things instead of 100 things.

00:19:47,360 --> 00:19:50,600
So the idea of here of actually
making sure that we've gone and

423
00:19:50,600 --> 00:19:55,470
do the quality audits gives us the ability
to go, here's the good stuff that's going

424
00:19:55,470 --> 00:19:58,480
on, but here's what we need
to do to improve on that or

425
00:19:58,480 --> 00:20:01,118
continue to maintain
the quality that we need.

426
00:20:01,118 --> 00:20:04,231
We need to do that regularly,
because once again, if you go, okay,

427
00:20:04,231 --> 00:20:08,316
I don't have to worry about you again, and
then 10,000 more things get produced and

428
00:20:08,316 --> 00:20:11,779
we're now not satisfied with the quality,
we've let it go on for too long.

429
00:20:11,779 --> 00:20:15,533
So for us as a project manager,
doing these quality audits are very much

430
00:20:15,533 --> 00:20:18,359
an important part of whatever
process we go through.

431
00:20:18,359 --> 00:20:22,123
Or we're gonna find ourselves where cost
overruns now, and then time behind cuz we

00:20:22,123 --> 00:20:25,260
have to go back and reproduce
everything that we thought now was bad.

00:20:26,690 --> 00:20:31,040
>> Now, the tools that we actually use for
this, it's up to us and we came up with

them back in the planning phase, but
just to recap, if it's been a while since

So these are all some of the different

00:20:40,920 --> 00:20:41,450
that we used here.

00:20:41,450 --> 00:20:45,409
So affinity diagrams,
those were where we try and

00:20:45,409 --> 00:20:48,613

which is the cause of most failures of

Process decision program charts,

basically like a flow chart to

So, these are all tackled under planning,

So in planning, we talked about like what

now we're actually getting the data back.

Now we're starting to get that information

jeans, and now we're churning out

00:21:27,290 --> 00:21:32,370

00:21:48,403 --> 00:21:51,853
And so we identify that through

00:21:51,853 --> 00:21:55,054

we populate that data and

00:21:57,290 --> 00:22:01,582
So this is one of those processes that

So when we do this analysis, we then have

00:22:11,830 --> 00:22:15,040
what to do about it is oftentimes
gonna be a change request.

00:22:15,040 --> 00:22:18,560
So we change the way that we do

00:22:23,540 --> 00:22:27,390
So change requests are the number one

00:22:27,390 --> 00:22:28,250

Our plan updates,

00:22:29,512 --> 00:22:32,668
our other project document updates as we

I mentioned all those tools that came up

00:22:39,240 --> 00:22:43,005
And that'll be important because

00:22:43,005 --> 00:22:44,867

00:22:44,867 --> 00:22:49,491
I guess it does matter but
at the end of the project, either outcome,

00:22:49,491 --> 00:22:52,145

00:22:52,145 --> 00:22:53,988
And if your project succeeded,

it might be because things went a lot

00:22:58,491 --> 00:23:01,993
it might be that things went

00:23:01,993 --> 00:23:06,735
And it's generally the data we get from

480
00:23:06,735 --> 00:23:09,983

00:23:09,983 --> 00:23:13,184
our defect rate was way lower

00:23:13,184 --> 00:23:15,438
And so as a result,
we were able to produce higher yields and

00:23:15,438 --> 00:23:18,190
we were able to finish early,
and finish under budget.

484
00:23:18,190 --> 00:23:22,005
Or you might find that, man, there were
some defects that we just didn't plan for,

485
00:23:22,005 --> 00:23:25,820
we didn't know about, and they caught us
by surprise and they gave us lower yields,

486
00:23:25,820 --> 00:23:28,318
it took us longer to get done and
we came in over budget.

487
00:23:28,318 --> 00:23:30,803
But here's why, we didn't see this.

00:23:30,803 --> 00:23:34,667
Well, if you spot it during
the execution phase,

489
00:23:34,667 --> 00:23:38,899
you can do change requests
to correct your schedule and

490
00:23:38,899 --> 00:23:42,579
your budget to reflect these new outcomes,
and

00:23:42,579 --> 00:23:47,189
that way you don't come in over budget or

00:23:47,189 --> 00:23:51,747
And remember, when you come in under

00:23:51,747 --> 00:23:56,255

is, is a reflection of bad planning.

494
00:23:56,255 --> 00:23:58,345
It means that in your planning early on,

00:23:58,345 --> 00:24:00,992
there was something you
didn't take account for.

00:24:00,992 --> 00:24:04,910
Right?
Either the amount of work people could do.

497
00:24:04,910 --> 00:24:06,850
The price you could get things for.

498
00:24:06,850 --> 00:24:09,410
There was work you thought you
had to do that you didn't.

499
00:24:09,410 --> 00:24:12,770
You know, that's what it means
when you come in, under budget and

500
00:24:12,770 --> 00:24:13,550
ahead of schedule.

501
00:24:13,550 --> 00:24:16,630
A lot of people look like that,
look at that as a great thing.

502
00:24:16,630 --> 00:24:18,690
But, it's almost always
a reflection of bad planning.

503
00:24:18,690 --> 00:24:19,740
And, I shouldn't say it take way.

00:24:19,740 --> 00:24:21,150
It's just bad planning.

505
00:24:21,150 --> 00:24:25,420
It's just incomplete planning, right,
we didn't see all the possible outcomes.

And so you always wanna make

And quality assurance is probably one of

00:24:58,010 --> 00:25:02,370
the project,is by making sure we're active

543
00:26:09,990 --> 00:26:11,610
It's all centered around the project team.

544
00:26:11,610 --> 00:26:16,200
Now, before we dive too deep into that,
let's remember what the project team is.

545
00:26:16,200 --> 00:26:17,980
Right?
Who is on your team?

546
00:26:17,980 --> 00:26:21,980
This does not mean every person
who's doing work for your project.

547
00:26:21,980 --> 00:26:24,470
Right?
Not all of your work package owners.

548
00:26:24,470 --> 00:26:27,930
A work package owner, that's a person
who's either responsible for or

549
00:26:27,930 --> 00:26:32,010
actually performing the work, as defined
in our work breakdown structure.

550
00:26:32,010 --> 00:26:35,440
But the project team,
these are gonna be people like yourself.

551
00:26:35,440 --> 00:26:39,440
The project manager and any accountants,
project management assistants,

552
00:26:39,440 --> 00:26:44,320
sub project managers,
any kind of record keepers and

553
00:26:44,320 --> 00:26:48,960
other people who are actually associated
with running the project itself.

554
00:26:48,960 --> 00:26:51,900
Alright, you guys have
to work together and

555
00:26:51,900 --> 00:26:54,020
there's various steps we have to
go through to make that happen.

556
00:26:54,020 --> 00:26:58,170
Now, its kind of funny because
this one falls under executing.

557
00:26:58,170 --> 00:27:02,340
But, a lot of your project management
team members are involved in the earlier

558
00:27:02,340 --> 00:27:04,260
phases of the project.

559
00:27:04,260 --> 00:27:06,260
So if I jump back to this.

560
00:27:06,260 --> 00:27:09,549
How we gonna do our plan if we
don't have our team members?

561
00:27:10,580 --> 00:27:13,420
There's some team members you
need while your in planning, and

562
00:27:13,420 --> 00:27:14,370
there's some you don't.

563
00:27:14,370 --> 00:27:17,650
I might know that I really
need an accountant.

564
00:27:17,650 --> 00:27:18,860
I need a CPA.

565
00:27:18,860 --> 00:27:21,560
I need somebody who can
keep track of my books.

566
00:27:21,560 --> 00:27:24,670
and make sure that I'm reporting on
the up and up, and I'm following GAP, and

567
00:27:24,670 --> 00:27:25,960
all that other stuff.

568
00:27:25,960 --> 00:27:28,220
You know what, I need that accountant.

569
00:27:28,220 --> 00:27:32,100
But I'm not spending any money yet so
I don't need that accountant today.

570
00:27:33,220 --> 00:27:35,840
I don't actually need the accountant
until we start spending money,

571
00:27:35,840 --> 00:27:40,070
and we don't actually start spending
money until execution starts.

572
00:27:40,070 --> 00:27:43,900
So that accountant is going to be
on my project management team, but

573
00:27:43,900 --> 00:27:45,530
I don't need them just yet.

574
00:27:45,530 --> 00:27:49,430
So in the planning phase we're normally
dealing with the skeleton crew.

575
00:27:49,430 --> 00:27:53,190
Just the bare minimum people we need
to actually plan for this project, and

576
00:27:53,190 --> 00:27:53,890
get work done.

577
00:27:54,950 --> 00:27:59,070
Once we switch into executing, we'll need
all of our additional support staff.

578
00:27:59,070 --> 00:28:01,320
If this is a massive project.

579
00:28:01,320 --> 00:28:03,500
If you're building a shopping mall.

580
00:28:03,500 --> 00:28:05,950
A shopping mall is huge.

581
00:28:05,950 --> 00:28:08,870
And you as a project manager cannot go and

582
00:28:08,870 --> 00:28:12,000
inspect, and audit all the different
construction going on at once.

583
00:28:12,000 --> 00:28:13,460
Because there's just too much.

584
00:28:13,460 --> 00:28:15,020
So you might have assistants.

585
00:28:15,020 --> 00:28:17,120
Several other people that are going
out and doing those inspections.

586
00:28:17,120 --> 00:28:20,460
Again, you dont' need them in planning,
right?

587
00:28:20,460 --> 00:28:22,530
One person can handle
the planning just fine.

588
00:28:22,530 --> 00:28:26,030
But then we need extra assistance
when we actually get into executing.

589
00:28:26,030 --> 00:28:28,770
So, we plan for
that in our planning phase.

590
00:28:28,770 --> 00:28:31,570
We figured out who all
we needed on that team.

591
00:28:31,570 --> 00:28:33,490
Now we need to get them.

592
00:28:33,490 --> 00:28:34,100
Okay.

593
00:28:34,100 --> 00:28:36,260
So, we're bringing in
the people to fill that gap.

594
00:28:36,260 --> 00:28:38,250
And that's what this phase is all about.

595
00:28:38,250 --> 00:28:41,270
So, you'll notice that 9.2
is Acquire Project Team.

596
00:28:42,360 --> 00:28:43,210
So let's look at that one.

597
00:28:43,210 --> 00:28:45,210
If we go to Acquire Project Team.

598
00:28:45,210 --> 00:28:47,140
Basically, we go back to our plan.

599
00:28:47,140 --> 00:28:49,560
Our human resources management
plan right here, and

600
00:28:49,560 --> 00:28:51,590
our way our company does business, right?

601
00:28:51,590 --> 00:28:54,960
Enterprise environmental factors and
organizational process assets.

602
00:28:54,960 --> 00:28:58,885
We take that information that we got and
now we go and we get our team.

603
00:28:58,885 --> 00:28:59,820
>> Mm-hm.

604
00:28:59,820 --> 00:29:02,900
>> All right, now how we get our team is
going to vary from company to company.

605
00:29:02,900 --> 00:29:05,740
So you'll see there's a number
of different ways to do it.

606
00:29:05,740 --> 00:29:07,400
One way is pre-assignment.

607
00:29:07,400 --> 00:29:11,300
For somebody like the project manager, the
project managers have been pre-assigned.

608
00:29:11,300 --> 00:29:15,190
Back in the planning phase, really back
in initiation, when initiation was done,

609
00:29:15,190 --> 00:29:17,810
when your company said, yes,
we're going to roll forward with that.

610
00:29:17,810 --> 00:29:20,550
They probably pre-assigned
a project manager.

611
00:29:20,550 --> 00:29:23,310
So you've been assigned to work it,
you're already on the team.

612
00:29:24,600 --> 00:29:25,720
That's not always true.

613
00:29:26,780 --> 00:29:29,220
You might have a very large
organization that says, you know what,

614
00:29:29,220 --> 00:29:30,490
we want to go forward with this project.

615
00:29:30,490 --> 00:29:31,180
Let's initiate it.

616
00:29:31,180 --> 00:29:32,340
Let's kick it off.

617
00:29:32,340 --> 00:29:34,285
And it's a key stakeholder, right?

618
00:29:34,285 --> 00:29:35,730
>> Mm-hm.
>> Or a sponsor that's really pushing it

619
00:29:35,730 --> 00:29:36,900
forward at that point.

620
00:29:36,900 --> 00:29:39,280
And a project manager
hasn't been assigned yet.

621
00:29:39,280 --> 00:29:41,670
And it might be that planning
is all ready completed,

622
00:29:41,670 --> 00:29:43,370
and now we bring in the project manager.

623
00:29:44,570 --> 00:29:47,100
You see that with construction
fairly frequently.

624
00:29:47,100 --> 00:29:49,540
Where the house has all
ready been designed.

625
00:29:49,540 --> 00:29:52,110
If they've all ready
built it 50 times before,

626
00:29:52,110 --> 00:29:54,610
they know how long it's gonna take,
how much it's gonna cost.

627
00:29:54,610 --> 00:29:55,960
All the planning is already done.

628
00:29:55,960 --> 00:29:57,850
We don't need a project
manager in the planning phase,

629
00:29:57,850 --> 00:30:00,380
because all that work is all
ready done to build this house.

630
00:30:00,380 --> 00:30:00,989
It's cookie cutter.

631
00:30:02,060 --> 00:30:05,550
But somebody does need to run the
operation to make sure the house is built.

632
00:30:05,550 --> 00:30:08,985
So, by the time we move to
executing we bring in the PM, then.

633
00:30:08,985 --> 00:30:09,570
>> Mm-hm.

634
00:30:09,570 --> 00:30:10,230
>> After planning.

635
00:30:10,230 --> 00:30:12,910
So planning the project manager's
not involved in at all.

636
00:30:12,910 --> 00:30:14,500
Now they just have to follow the plan.

637
00:30:16,160 --> 00:30:19,750
Other reasons we might do preassignment:
you might have somebody who is an expert.

638
00:30:19,750 --> 00:30:23,370
Your company might be deploying
some software where you have

639
00:30:23,370 --> 00:30:28,150
one employee who is the expert, and
nobody else is that knowledgeable.

640
00:30:28,150 --> 00:30:31,340
So it's a given that you're going to need
that person to complete this project.

641
00:30:32,570 --> 00:30:35,450
Or, you might not have
anybody who can do that job.

642
00:30:35,450 --> 00:30:37,340
In which case you're going
to have to contract out, or

643
00:30:37,340 --> 00:30:38,680
you're going to have to train somebody.

644
00:30:38,680 --> 00:30:40,570
So again, pre-selection may be important.

645
00:30:42,580 --> 00:30:46,450
Another one is negotiation, and
this is one that I've fallen into a lot.

646
00:30:46,450 --> 00:30:50,820
Which is, you might be kicking off a
project, and you go to acquire your team,

647
00:30:50,820 --> 00:30:52,210
so you go to your PMO.

648
00:30:52,210 --> 00:30:56,350
And the PMO says, oh you need a web
developer, here I'll give you Steve.

649
00:30:56,350 --> 00:30:57,840
And you look at it and you're like.

650
00:30:57,840 --> 00:31:00,920
Oh, Steve.
I've never heard of Steve before.

651
00:31:00,920 --> 00:31:02,280
So you start asking those questions.

652
00:31:02,280 --> 00:31:04,200
Hey, how long's Steve
been with the company.

653
00:31:04,200 --> 00:31:05,110
Oh, two months.

654
00:31:05,110 --> 00:31:06,750
That's great.

655
00:31:06,750 --> 00:31:09,290
Oh, he just graduated from college.

656
00:31:09,290 --> 00:31:10,070
Wonderful.

657
00:31:10,070 --> 00:31:12,010
And in the back of your
mind you're thinking.

658
00:31:12,010 --> 00:31:14,460
Man, there's Amy down in the web
development department, and

659
00:31:14,460 --> 00:31:15,540
I've worked with her.

660
00:31:15,540 --> 00:31:18,440
She is a pro,
she's been doing it ten years.

661
00:31:18,440 --> 00:31:19,300
She's awesome.

662
00:31:19,300 --> 00:31:21,780
I really wish I could have gotten her,
but I got Steve.

663
00:31:21,780 --> 00:31:22,470
Right.

664
00:31:22,470 --> 00:31:24,420
So you go back to the PMO and
you say, boy,

665
00:31:24,420 --> 00:31:27,865
is there Is there any way that I could
get Amy on my project instead of Steve?

666
00:31:27,865 --> 00:31:31,035
And they say well Amy's already
working on this other project.

667
00:31:31,035 --> 00:31:32,685
And now you're start negotiating.

668
00:31:32,685 --> 00:31:35,665
Now you start saying, well all right,
what if I trade you this person for

669
00:31:35,665 --> 00:31:36,165
that person?

670
00:31:36,165 --> 00:31:38,255
What if I move some stuff
around on my schedule?

671
00:31:38,255 --> 00:31:42,225
And you try and work it to build
it around that person on the team.

672
00:31:42,225 --> 00:31:45,050
That, it may sound crazy, right, like
why would you go through that much work?

673
00:31:45,050 --> 00:31:47,880
But I'll tell you, in real life,
having the right person for

674
00:31:47,880 --> 00:31:51,070
the job is oftentimes the difference
between success and failure.

675
00:31:51,070 --> 00:31:54,100
And the relationships you build
when you work on projects.

676
00:31:54,100 --> 00:31:58,046
You'll want those same team members over,
and over again if you've had successes.

677
00:31:58,046 --> 00:32:02,029
Because you've already have that
I'm gonna use the work Mike.

678
00:32:02,029 --> 00:32:02,725
Synergy.

679
00:32:02,725 --> 00:32:04,525
>> You've already got that synergy right.

680
00:32:04,525 --> 00:32:07,466
Which means absolutely nothing but
you've already got that connection,

681
00:32:07,466 --> 00:32:08,970
that relationship with that person.

682
00:32:08,970 --> 00:32:10,280
It works out better.

683
00:32:10,280 --> 00:32:11,700
It makes things easier.

684
00:32:11,700 --> 00:32:12,730
So we want that.

685
00:32:12,730 --> 00:32:14,140
Not that we can't get by without it.

686
00:32:14,140 --> 00:32:16,710
If we have to deal with all new
team members, we can get by, or

687
00:32:16,710 --> 00:32:18,450
a good project manager can.

688
00:32:18,450 --> 00:32:21,370
But, it's so
much safer to have somebody you know.

689
00:32:21,370 --> 00:32:24,050
So negotiation is a not an uncommon thing.

690
00:32:24,050 --> 00:32:26,210
>> Yeah it almost sounds like
fantasy football [laugh]

691
00:32:26,210 --> 00:32:28,470
>> It's exactly like fantasy football

692
00:32:28,470 --> 00:32:35,510
except I got two web developers and
I got to change my lineup tonight.

693
00:32:35,510 --> 00:32:38,890
ALright, somebody probably
makes a video game out of that.

694
00:32:38,890 --> 00:32:40,240
Ok, acquisitions.

695
00:32:40,240 --> 00:32:42,680
Acquisitions actually
getting these people.

696
00:32:42,680 --> 00:32:46,410
Now as a project manager
you might not have hire and

697
00:32:46,410 --> 00:32:49,510
fire responsibilities inside your company,
often times you don't.

698
00:32:49,510 --> 00:32:52,150
You may not even have direct
authority over these people.

699
00:32:52,150 --> 00:32:56,190
They probably already have a functional
manager that they work for, and

700
00:32:56,190 --> 00:32:57,630
you're coming in as a project manager.

701
00:32:57,630 --> 00:32:59,550
So split differences, right?

702
00:32:59,550 --> 00:33:02,100
You've actually got to
acquire that employee.

703
00:33:02,100 --> 00:33:05,000
Either going to their functional
manager to have them assigned, or

704
00:33:05,000 --> 00:33:07,260
going to human resources, or your PMO.

705
00:33:07,260 --> 00:33:09,390
Whoever it is that actually assigns them.

706
00:33:09,390 --> 00:33:12,230
This is where we go back to our
enterprise environmental factors and

707
00:33:12,230 --> 00:33:14,090
organization process assets, right?

708
00:33:14,090 --> 00:33:16,920
We go through whatever mechanisms our
company has to get them assigned to

709
00:33:16,920 --> 00:33:19,910
the project, and
then we do our onboarding.

710
00:33:19,910 --> 00:33:22,510
Onboarding is where you bring
the person up to speed.

711
00:33:22,510 --> 00:33:26,250
This might be the very first time
they've heard of this project.

712
00:33:26,250 --> 00:33:29,180
They may not have even known this
existed prior to you talking to them.

713
00:33:29,180 --> 00:33:30,130
You say, all right.

714
00:33:30,130 --> 00:33:30,960
Here's the project.

715
00:33:30,960 --> 00:33:32,040
Here's what we're going to do.

716
00:33:32,040 --> 00:33:33,000
Here's how much time we need.

717
00:33:33,000 --> 00:33:34,500
Here's what we need from you.

718
00:33:34,500 --> 00:33:36,560
You've got to bring all of that
information to the table, so

719
00:33:36,560 --> 00:33:37,260
they understand it.

720
00:33:39,560 --> 00:33:43,650
Now a new one that we see that is,
it's kind of a hot button with PMI.

721
00:33:43,650 --> 00:33:46,220
So it's definitely something
you're going to see on the exam.

722
00:33:46,220 --> 00:33:48,130
Is what's called a virtual team.

723
00:33:49,470 --> 00:33:55,070
More and more commonly today, we don't
have our team all in one location.

724
00:33:55,070 --> 00:33:58,080
Oftentimes we'll have employees
that are spread across the country,

725
00:33:58,080 --> 00:33:59,310
across the globe.

726
00:33:59,310 --> 00:34:02,340
You have different time zones,
different countries involved,

727
00:34:02,340 --> 00:34:03,800
all sorts of complexities there.

728
00:34:03,800 --> 00:34:05,760
That's called the virtual team.

729
00:34:05,760 --> 00:34:06,640
And virtual teams are fine.

730
00:34:06,640 --> 00:34:08,980
They do require a different
management style though,

731
00:34:08,980 --> 00:34:10,640
because there's a lot of unknowns.

732
00:34:11,940 --> 00:34:14,220
Ronnie, you and I,
we work in the same office.

733
00:34:14,220 --> 00:34:17,360
When I walk into
the office in the morning,

734
00:34:17,360 --> 00:34:20,400
I know I saw Ronnie's car outside,
so I know he's here..

735
00:34:20,400 --> 00:34:24,930
And his cube, we have cubes here,
we're a cube type place.

736
00:34:24,930 --> 00:34:25,435
>> Yeah.

737
00:34:25,435 --> 00:34:27,570
[LAUGH]
>> And Ronnie's cube is positioned

738
00:34:27,570 --> 00:34:29,555
in the deepest,
darkest corner of the office.

739
00:34:29,555 --> 00:34:31,112
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I'm actually kinda pointing it out.

740
00:34:31,112 --> 00:34:32,900
>> Right. [LAUGH] >> And
I can't see over there, so

741
00:34:32,900 --> 00:34:34,420
I don't really know if Ronnie's there.

742
00:34:34,420 --> 00:34:37,980
But I just saw his car when I pulled in so
I know he's here, I know he's here and

743
00:34:37,980 --> 00:34:38,990
he's working.

744
00:34:38,990 --> 00:34:40,780
Right now, well, you are standing there.

745
00:34:40,780 --> 00:34:41,964
So I know you're working.

746
00:34:41,964 --> 00:34:46,090
But if this were a virtual team,
if you were at home, you know,

747
00:34:46,090 --> 00:34:48,270
working from a home office, or
something like that, I wouldn't know.

748
00:34:48,270 --> 00:34:50,240
There is a certain level
of trust you have to have.

749
00:34:50,240 --> 00:34:52,350
I trust that he's at home working.

750
00:34:53,600 --> 00:34:54,900
Maybe he isn't.

751
00:34:54,900 --> 00:34:58,340
So, virtual teams create complexities
there that we have to plan around.

752
00:34:58,340 --> 00:35:00,970
Some people like it, some people don't.

753
00:35:00,970 --> 00:35:02,910
I'm not a big fan of it.

754
00:35:02,910 --> 00:35:03,640
And I've done it.

755
00:35:03,640 --> 00:35:07,400
I've done it where,
actually I lived in Seattle for a while.

756
00:35:07,400 --> 00:35:10,850
And I moved back to Gainesville,
Florida and

757
00:35:10,850 --> 00:35:13,490
I was still working for
a Seattle company for six more months.

758
00:35:13,490 --> 00:35:16,560
Because I was wrapping up some
projects I was working on.

759
00:35:16,560 --> 00:35:21,150
So I was doing project management
from Gainesville Florida,

760
00:35:21,150 --> 00:35:24,200
managing entire teams
that were in Seattle.

761
00:35:24,200 --> 00:35:26,410
I was doing a disaster recovery rollout,

762
00:35:26,410 --> 00:35:28,750
to a disaster recovery center
that I had never even been to.

763
00:35:28,750 --> 00:35:32,020
And that kind of stuff,
that's what happens with virtual teams,

764
00:35:32,020 --> 00:35:33,210
and it does work.

765
00:35:33,210 --> 00:35:36,420
Now you hear a lot of times
where employers don't like it,

766
00:35:36,420 --> 00:35:37,540
and employees love it.

767
00:35:37,540 --> 00:35:39,460
Employees over there,
yeah I wanna work from home.

768
00:35:39,460 --> 00:35:42,240
Well I can say as an employee,
I did not like it.

769
00:35:42,240 --> 00:35:45,210
My home is not conducive
to getting work done.

770
00:35:45,210 --> 00:35:47,840
So, you know, kids making noise.

771
00:35:47,840 --> 00:35:50,850
The damned cat jumping on the keyboard,
stuff like that.

772
00:35:50,850 --> 00:35:53,330
Dogs barking, it's craziness.

773
00:35:53,330 --> 00:35:55,110
Now it sounds like my house is a zoo.

774
00:35:55,110 --> 00:35:58,350
It's not that bad, but
it's not as good as when I get to work.

775
00:35:58,350 --> 00:36:01,690
And I've got my monitors,
I've got my little cube and my phone and

776
00:36:01,690 --> 00:36:03,700
I'm able to focus in and get stuff done.

777
00:36:03,700 --> 00:36:04,830
I get more done at work.

778
00:36:04,830 --> 00:36:07,360
I'd rather be at the office than at home.

779
00:36:07,360 --> 00:36:09,610
Different people benefit
different ways from that.

780
00:36:09,610 --> 00:36:11,040
So just be aware, virtual teams.

781
00:36:11,040 --> 00:36:11,570
>> Yeah.

782
00:36:11,570 --> 00:36:12,470
>> They're a realistic option.

783
00:36:12,470 --> 00:36:14,820
More people are using it.

784
00:36:14,820 --> 00:36:17,490
There's also high
visibility stuff like HP.

785
00:36:17,490 --> 00:36:18,470
HP, Hewlett Packard.

786
00:36:18,470 --> 00:36:19,080
>> Yeah.

787
00:36:19,080 --> 00:36:21,080
>> They were pushing really big for
this for years, and

788
00:36:21,080 --> 00:36:24,880
then last year they announced they were
cancelling all work from home stuff.

789
00:36:24,880 --> 00:36:28,260
So employees could either come back to
the office or they can get another job.

790
00:36:28,260 --> 00:36:29,818
Yeah, they cancelled all that.

791
00:36:31,791 --> 00:36:32,468
And then,

792
00:36:32,468 --> 00:36:37,976
the last tool that we have here is what's
called multi-criteria decision analysis.

793
00:36:37,976 --> 00:36:40,420
If you have employees that
you want to work with.

794
00:36:40,420 --> 00:36:42,600
You know who you are, you pick them and
you're done, you know,

795
00:36:42,600 --> 00:36:44,100
you don't worry about this.

796
00:36:44,100 --> 00:36:46,620
But if you're dealing with
an entirely new set of employees,

797
00:36:46,620 --> 00:36:48,760
people that you've never met before.

798
00:36:48,760 --> 00:36:51,040
How are you going to pick who's right for
your project?

799
00:36:51,040 --> 00:36:53,770
And one of the ways to do that is
multi-criteria decision analysis.

800
00:36:53,770 --> 00:36:55,840
And Ronnie,
I think you did this in your notes.

801
00:36:55,840 --> 00:36:58,550
Where'd I put your notes?

802
00:36:58,550 --> 00:36:59,110
Let me find it here.

803
00:36:59,110 --> 00:37:01,250
There are a lot of
criteria we can look at.

804
00:37:01,250 --> 00:37:01,750
Here we go.

805
00:37:03,020 --> 00:37:06,620
So, what are some of the things we need
to consider when we pick a person?

806
00:37:06,620 --> 00:37:08,310
Availability is probably
the most important one.

807
00:37:08,310 --> 00:37:10,020
Because if they're not available,
you can't use them, and

808
00:37:10,020 --> 00:37:11,610
you don't care about the rest of it,
right?

809
00:37:11,610 --> 00:37:14,000
So, we need to make sure
that they're available.

810
00:37:14,000 --> 00:37:17,780
After that though is where we really
start to break into other things.

811
00:37:17,780 --> 00:37:19,110
Cost, right?

812
00:37:19,110 --> 00:37:22,640
You may have some people who
are cheaper to work with than others.

813
00:37:22,640 --> 00:37:24,750
This might be hourly wages, or salary.

814
00:37:24,750 --> 00:37:27,570
These might be contractors,
and different contract types.

815
00:37:27,570 --> 00:37:29,740
So some of them will be
less of a financial burden.

816
00:37:29,740 --> 00:37:32,640
Now normally the less you pay,
the lower quality work you get, but

817
00:37:32,640 --> 00:37:34,080
that's not always true.

818
00:37:34,080 --> 00:37:36,900
So it is a factor we
need to pay attention to.

819
00:37:36,900 --> 00:37:39,440
Experience is one that
I always care about.

820
00:37:39,440 --> 00:37:41,720
If you have somebody who
has experience doing a job.

821
00:37:41,720 --> 00:37:44,635
They're gonna give you good estimates and
they're gonna get the work done.

822
00:37:44,635 --> 00:37:46,100
Because they know what needs to be done.

823
00:37:46,100 --> 00:37:48,240
If you've got somebody who's
inexperienced, who's new,

824
00:37:48,240 --> 00:37:50,150
that kid right out of college.

825
00:37:50,150 --> 00:37:52,890
It's not that they don't
know what they're doing,

826
00:37:52,890 --> 00:37:54,440
it's just they've never done it before.

827
00:37:54,440 --> 00:37:56,700
So they can't give very
accurate estimates, and

828
00:37:56,700 --> 00:37:59,300
the odds of mistakes happening are higher.

829
00:37:59,300 --> 00:38:00,849
So somebody's experience we
definitely wanna measure.

830
00:38:02,490 --> 00:38:04,270
All right ability is next.

831
00:38:04,270 --> 00:38:05,750
Some people have it some people don't.

832
00:38:05,750 --> 00:38:08,600
This is not something we can really learn.

833
00:38:08,600 --> 00:38:10,410
I actually have this.

834
00:38:10,410 --> 00:38:13,310
You know,
I'm gonna show it here on the show.

835
00:38:13,310 --> 00:38:15,620
I have this picture on my wall.

836
00:38:15,620 --> 00:38:16,355
>> Big motivator?

837
00:38:16,355 --> 00:38:17,560
[LAUGH]
>> Yes.

838
00:38:17,560 --> 00:38:18,870
Called incompetence.

839
00:38:18,870 --> 00:38:23,425
And I've had this hanging in my office for
years.

840
00:38:23,425 --> 00:38:27,700
[LAUGH] And I just have a cube now,
so I don't have it hanging, but

841
00:38:27,700 --> 00:38:29,240
in my project management days I did.

842
00:38:29,240 --> 00:38:32,930
I love this picture; it
is somewhat negative.

843
00:38:32,930 --> 00:38:36,490
But basically it says, when you
earnestly think you can compensate for

844
00:38:36,490 --> 00:38:40,632
a lack of skill by doubling your efforts,
there's no end to what you can't do.

845
00:38:40,632 --> 00:38:42,840
>> [LAUGH]
>> And And that happens.

846
00:38:42,840 --> 00:38:47,360
If somebody doesn't have the ability
to do a job, it doesn't matter if

847
00:38:47,360 --> 00:38:50,360
they're a hard worker,
if they're cheap, if they're smart.

848
00:38:50,360 --> 00:38:51,130
It doesn't matter.

849
00:38:51,130 --> 00:38:52,390
They don't have the ability.

850
00:38:52,390 --> 00:38:53,270
They can't do it.

851
00:38:53,270 --> 00:38:56,490
And so there's just not going
to be a way to leverage them.

852
00:38:56,490 --> 00:38:58,000
But even if they do have the ability,

853
00:38:58,000 --> 00:39:00,990
there's obviously different
levels of ability.

854
00:39:00,990 --> 00:39:02,370
So you will have some people,

855
00:39:02,370 --> 00:39:06,980
when it comes to web design--
let's use IT Pro TV as an example.

856
00:39:06,980 --> 00:39:08,370
We have Rob.

857
00:39:08,370 --> 00:39:11,620
Rob is our web design,
and web developer guru.

858
00:39:11,620 --> 00:39:13,710
He really knows his stuff.

859
00:39:13,710 --> 00:39:16,610
And if there's a problem
with the IT PRO TV website,

860
00:39:16,610 --> 00:39:19,910
if somebody gives him that problem he
can have it fixed usually in minutes.

861
00:39:19,910 --> 00:39:21,110
He's a sharp guy.

862
00:39:21,110 --> 00:39:24,400
I happen to know a good
bit of that stuff too.

863
00:39:24,400 --> 00:39:25,890
Because I took a lot
of courses in college.

864
00:39:25,890 --> 00:39:28,330
And so I can do some basic PHP.

865
00:39:28,330 --> 00:39:30,380
And some web development.

866
00:39:30,380 --> 00:39:31,350
But, for

867
00:39:31,350 --> 00:39:35,760
me to do the same thing that Rob does, I
easily take four times the amount of time.

868
00:39:35,760 --> 00:39:39,210
So if it's a one hour activity, it might
take me four hours to get it done.

869
00:39:39,210 --> 00:39:41,710
I can get it done, I have the ability.

870
00:39:41,710 --> 00:39:44,080
But I don't have the same
level of ability as Rob.

871
00:39:44,080 --> 00:39:46,700
So getting the right person for
the job is important.

872
00:39:46,700 --> 00:39:47,480
That's ability.

873
00:39:47,480 --> 00:39:48,020
>> Yeah.

874
00:39:48,020 --> 00:39:51,020
And that right person for the job not
only comes down to whatever you're doing.

875
00:39:51,020 --> 00:39:54,033
But, it may be one of the persons
excellent at what they do,

876
00:39:54,033 --> 00:39:56,989
but they can't really work
in that project environment,

877
00:39:56,989 --> 00:39:59,668
in terms of a A time constraint
that they might have.

878
00:39:59,668 --> 00:40:03,510
And when you have that word you go,
man, this guy is great.

879
00:40:03,510 --> 00:40:05,630
He can do everything we need him to do.

880
00:40:05,630 --> 00:40:08,230
He just can't do it in the time
that we need him to do it.

881
00:40:08,230 --> 00:40:13,360
You gotta be realistic about that as well,
because that can clearly drive you nuts

882
00:40:13,360 --> 00:40:14,910
just as much because you
know he has the ability.

883
00:40:14,910 --> 00:40:17,140
You just know he can't
manage his time very well,

884
00:40:17,140 --> 00:40:19,200
and that's just something that would,
yeah.

885
00:40:19,200 --> 00:40:20,920
That just goes overboard.

886
00:40:20,920 --> 00:40:22,910
>> Now they have the next
entry is knowledge.

887
00:40:22,910 --> 00:40:26,430
Now that might sound like it's duplicating
ability, but there is a difference.

888
00:40:27,640 --> 00:40:32,230
Ability is not normally something
that we can gain, but knowledge is.

889
00:40:32,230 --> 00:40:35,640
I might not know how to do whatever this
activity is that's being assigned to me.

890
00:40:35,640 --> 00:40:36,570
But I can learn it.

891
00:40:36,570 --> 00:40:39,270
Maybe you'll have to send
me to some training, right.

892
00:40:39,270 --> 00:40:41,340
So, maybe we'll take Rob.

893
00:40:41,340 --> 00:40:43,400
So Rob, he knows PHP.

894
00:40:43,400 --> 00:40:47,400
But maybe I need some stuff done
in Python, or some other language.

895
00:40:47,400 --> 00:40:48,830
Well he doesn't know that language.

896
00:40:48,830 --> 00:40:51,600
But you know what, he knows development.

897
00:40:51,600 --> 00:40:52,980
He knows a programming language.

898
00:40:52,980 --> 00:40:54,870
So all he needs to do is run
through a quick course or

899
00:40:54,870 --> 00:40:57,750
whatever to learn the other language and
then he can get into it, right.

900
00:40:57,750 --> 00:41:00,100
He's got that base knowledge.

901
00:41:00,100 --> 00:41:02,300
That is an important thing.

902
00:41:02,300 --> 00:41:06,350
Some people, if we bring them onto our
project team, we might need to train them.

903
00:41:06,350 --> 00:41:10,410
If they've never worked in a PMI
project management environment before,

904
00:41:10,410 --> 00:41:11,358
we might need to train them.

905
00:41:11,358 --> 00:41:17,240
Send them through, not PMP but
like Cap M,or something like that.

906
00:41:17,240 --> 00:41:19,910
So they get some basic
project management training.

907
00:41:19,910 --> 00:41:22,730
That's something that we can
always add on to people.

908
00:41:22,730 --> 00:41:25,400
Skills.
They might have skills beyond

909
00:41:25,400 --> 00:41:29,030
what you need, and that means they can be
helpful in other areas of the project.

910
00:41:29,030 --> 00:41:30,360
So you might be able to use them for

911
00:41:30,360 --> 00:41:32,880
more then one role if they've
got the skills to do it.

912
00:41:34,370 --> 00:41:35,220
And then attitude.

913
00:41:36,360 --> 00:41:38,410
Attitude, it's important.

914
00:41:38,410 --> 00:41:41,690
If somebody is not a good fit for
your team, if they don't mesh,

915
00:41:41,690 --> 00:41:46,408
if they don't have that synergy, then
they can actually bring the project down.

916
00:41:46,408 --> 00:41:50,780
And so making sure you've got people
with the right attitude for the project.

917
00:41:50,780 --> 00:41:52,260
And then international factors.

918
00:41:52,260 --> 00:41:53,710
This is starting to become a big one.

919
00:41:53,710 --> 00:41:56,720
I used to laugh about this one
because we didn't really care.

920
00:41:56,720 --> 00:41:58,300
Nowadays, here in the U.S.

921
00:41:58,300 --> 00:42:02,120
we've got a limit on the amount
of H-1B visas that can be issued.

922
00:42:02,120 --> 00:42:04,980
If you're using employees that
are located outside of the United States,

923
00:42:04,980 --> 00:42:09,060
you have limits to how you can use them,
how much time you can use them and so on.

924
00:42:09,060 --> 00:42:10,950
Other countries have
their own requirements.

925
00:42:10,950 --> 00:42:13,420
If you're operating inside of Europe
you have things like the VAT,

926
00:42:13,420 --> 00:42:17,060
the value added tax, and stuff that starts
to apply to some of those activities.

927
00:42:17,060 --> 00:42:20,930
So, all of those are things that
are things that you've got to be

928
00:42:20,930 --> 00:42:23,330
concerned about when you're
measuring these people.

929
00:42:23,330 --> 00:42:26,060
So what you can do is you can
actually create a matrix.

930
00:42:26,060 --> 00:42:28,200
And you can start to create report cards.

931
00:42:28,200 --> 00:42:31,970
Ranking the various possible
people based on these categories.

932
00:42:31,970 --> 00:42:34,830
You determine which one's more important,
which one's less important, and

933
00:42:34,830 --> 00:42:37,650
then you rank to be able to select
the best person for the job.

934
00:42:37,650 --> 00:42:40,140
Odds are your PMO is already doing that,
but if you don't have a PMO,

935
00:42:40,140 --> 00:42:41,710
then you have to.

936
00:42:41,710 --> 00:42:42,210
>> Yeah.

937
00:42:44,270 --> 00:42:46,690
>> Alright now the outputs on this
one are pretty straight forward.

938
00:42:46,690 --> 00:42:49,320
When we figure out who our team
is going to be we get them so,

939
00:42:49,320 --> 00:42:51,080
Project Staff Assignments.

940
00:42:51,080 --> 00:42:53,480
You get the staff, and
you give them their assignment.

941
00:42:53,480 --> 00:42:55,570
You tell them what role they're going
to be performing in your project.

942
00:42:55,570 --> 00:42:59,050
So you get Steve, the web developer,
and you say all right,

943
00:42:59,050 --> 00:43:01,180
you're going to be the main web developer.

944
00:43:01,180 --> 00:43:05,820
That means you, inside of my project,
I've defined you as web developer one.

945
00:43:05,820 --> 00:43:09,100
So, any activity that I've assigned
to web developer one, that's yours.

946
00:43:09,100 --> 00:43:09,660
Right?

947
00:43:09,660 --> 00:43:12,070
Or you bring in Bob from accounting.

948
00:43:12,070 --> 00:43:15,010
You say, all right Bob you're
the project accountant.

949
00:43:15,010 --> 00:43:20,680
So I need you to read through
all of our accounting plans.

950
00:43:20,680 --> 00:43:23,680
All the financial plans that we've done.

951
00:43:23,680 --> 00:43:25,030
All of our contracts and stuff.

952
00:43:25,030 --> 00:43:25,990
You're the one managing that.

953
00:43:25,990 --> 00:43:27,710
So you take a look at that.

954
00:43:27,710 --> 00:43:30,520
On all of my activities and stuff,
I've listed you as accountant one.

955
00:43:30,520 --> 00:43:32,969
So we're going to change that
to Bob Smith or whoever you are.

956
00:43:34,600 --> 00:43:37,200
Resource calendars are another thing
that's gonna come out of this.

957
00:43:37,200 --> 00:43:41,760
So, now that we have Bob, you say all
right Bob, what's your calendar like?

958
00:43:41,760 --> 00:43:44,880
Say, you know I've got a week schedule for
vacation in November.

959
00:43:44,880 --> 00:43:48,300
That week at Thanksgiving,
we're travelling, and so I'm gonna be out.

960
00:43:48,300 --> 00:43:51,620
And, oh my son's recital is the second
of week of December, and so

961
00:43:51,620 --> 00:43:53,190
we've got that too.

962
00:43:53,190 --> 00:43:54,650
So now we start to get that.

963
00:43:54,650 --> 00:43:58,820
Now when it was just web developer one,
in my work breakdown structure.

964
00:43:58,820 --> 00:44:00,900
Well, I didn't know who
that web developer was,

965
00:44:00,900 --> 00:44:04,920
I didn't know that they might
be on vacation or whatever.

966
00:44:04,920 --> 00:44:08,550
But now that I actually know who
the person is, we can find out.

967
00:44:08,550 --> 00:44:11,270
So we've gotta go and
do Project Management Plan Updates.

968
00:44:11,270 --> 00:44:14,020
We gotta update information,
load these people's

969
00:44:14,020 --> 00:44:17,330
names into all of our previous forms
we're we had just generic names.

970
00:44:17,330 --> 00:44:18,580
And get that straightened out.

971
00:44:19,680 --> 00:44:24,510
All right, so that is all a part
of acquiring the project team.

972
00:44:24,510 --> 00:44:26,420
Now we put them to work, right?

973
00:44:26,420 --> 00:44:29,330
Well, we got two more processes
that lead into that and if we take

974
00:44:29,330 --> 00:44:33,870
a look at it you'll see develop the
project team, and manage the project team.

975
00:44:33,870 --> 00:44:36,610
This is actually putting them to work.

976
00:44:36,610 --> 00:44:37,980
Develop happens first, right?

977
00:44:37,980 --> 00:44:40,420
This is actually building team cohesion.

978
00:44:40,420 --> 00:44:42,910
Getting them together,
getting ready to move forward.

979
00:44:42,910 --> 00:44:45,660
And then managing the project team
is actually setting them to do it.

980
00:44:45,660 --> 00:44:50,430
So we need to take a look at those before
our team is officially gelled, right?

981
00:44:50,430 --> 00:44:53,685
But we probably don't have enough enough
time this segment to jump into one of

982
00:44:53,685 --> 00:44:54,575
those, do we Ronny?

983
00:44:54,575 --> 00:44:55,645
>> I don't think so.

984
00:44:55,645 --> 00:44:58,375
>> So why don't we do this,
why don't we take a break, and

985
00:44:58,375 --> 00:45:02,065
when we get back we'll continue on
with our team building exercise here,

986
00:45:02,065 --> 00:45:04,055
inside of the P and P training.

987
00:45:04,055 --> 00:45:06,775
So, stay tuned, we'll be back in a few.

988
00:45:06,775 --> 00:45:14,610
[MUSIC]

989
00:45:14,610 --> 00:45:16,590
All right, welcome back everybody.

990
00:45:16,590 --> 00:45:20,700
So in the last segment we took a look
at acquiring our project teams.

991
00:45:20,700 --> 00:45:25,060
So now we've got all these employees
sitting around, what do we do with them?

992
00:45:25,060 --> 00:45:26,845
Or virtually sitting around, I guess.

993
00:45:26,845 --> 00:45:28,200
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

994
00:45:28,200 --> 00:45:30,460
>> Time for
us to develop them into a team.

995
00:45:30,460 --> 00:45:33,060
And so we're gonna talk about
some of the concepts here

996
00:45:33,060 --> 00:45:35,560
in terms of actually making
them a cohesive unit.

997
00:45:35,560 --> 00:45:36,940
I like using that term, cohesive.

998
00:45:36,940 --> 00:45:37,710
>> Cohesive.

999
00:45:37,710 --> 00:45:39,010
It's an adhesive unit.

1000
00:45:39,010 --> 00:45:40,510
>> An adhesive.

1001
00:45:40,510 --> 00:45:43,080
>> All right, so
we really don't have much in the way of

1002
00:45:43,080 --> 00:45:45,480
different inputs here than we
did when acquiring the team.

1003
00:45:45,480 --> 00:45:47,250
We've got our human
resources management plan.

1004
00:45:47,250 --> 00:45:50,770
Because that's what we define how we're
going to define a lot of this, and

1005
00:45:50,770 --> 00:45:52,380
then we've got our project
staff assignments.

1006
00:45:52,380 --> 00:45:55,695
Which is what we created in
the acquire project teams that we know

1007
00:45:55,695 --> 00:45:58,025
What each person's responsibility is.

1008
00:45:58,025 --> 00:45:59,545
And then the resource calendars also, so

1009
00:45:59,545 --> 00:46:02,065
we can find out when somebody's
not going to be available.

1010
00:46:02,065 --> 00:46:06,455
Now we take that, and these inputs really
don't contribute as much as we normally

1011
00:46:06,455 --> 00:46:08,375
see into the tools and techniques.

1012
00:46:08,375 --> 00:46:11,215
Most of the tools and
techniques with developing a project

1013
00:46:11,215 --> 00:46:15,175
team are kind of designed to work
by themselves without inputs right?

1014
00:46:15,175 --> 00:46:18,255
You're starting from scratch,
building a team together.

1015
00:46:18,255 --> 00:46:19,275
So what are some of the things?

1016
00:46:19,275 --> 00:46:24,040
Well, number one is one that in
the IT industry we see the least of,

1017
00:46:24,040 --> 00:46:26,120
which is interpersonal skills.

1018
00:46:26,120 --> 00:46:28,860
>> Wow.
>> Yeah, it's terrible in the IT industry.

1019
00:46:28,860 --> 00:46:30,550
But if you work in another
industry it's probably great.

1020
00:46:30,550 --> 00:46:32,600
>> Yeah.
>> But interpersonal skills is simply

1021
00:46:32,600 --> 00:46:36,850
your ability to communicate and
relay information to another person.

1022
00:46:36,850 --> 00:46:39,174
Without having direct access
to their mind, right?

1023
00:46:39,174 --> 00:46:42,470
>> [LAUGH]
>> So writing a letter, speaking out loud,

1024
00:46:42,470 --> 00:46:45,440
talking on the telephone,
these are ways we communicate.

1025
00:46:45,440 --> 00:46:50,860
And poor communication is typically one
of the keystones of a failed project.

1026
00:46:50,860 --> 00:46:54,730
I mean that is the way things can really
plummet down if you're not careful.

1027
00:46:54,730 --> 00:46:56,940
So we wanna make sure that
we have good communications,

1028
00:46:56,940 --> 00:46:59,270
and that it's something
we're comfortable with.

1029
00:46:59,270 --> 00:47:03,370
If it's not something we're comfortable
with, we need to hire somebody who does.

1030
00:47:03,370 --> 00:47:05,580
Many organizations have a PR firm, or

1031
00:47:05,580 --> 00:47:08,250
public relations people to
help with that communication.

1032
00:47:08,250 --> 00:47:12,180
But a good project manager is going
to have good intrapersonal skills.

1033
00:47:12,180 --> 00:47:13,950
You might need to take a class.

1034
00:47:13,950 --> 00:47:16,990
>> Sometimes because we don't have all the
skills necessary one of the things that

1035
00:47:16,990 --> 00:47:19,430
they do call out on,
especially in the PEMBOT,

1036
00:47:19,430 --> 00:47:23,430
is the idea of the conflict management or
the conflict resolution.

1037
00:47:23,430 --> 00:47:24,280
So again,

1038
00:47:24,280 --> 00:47:27,650
if you don't have those skills, hiring out
is probably the best way to go about it.

1039
00:47:27,650 --> 00:47:29,380
If you take a look at that idea.

1040
00:47:29,380 --> 00:47:31,870
So we might be great at everything
else in terms of communicating,

1041
00:47:31,870 --> 00:47:34,210
especially our anger and feelings but

1042
00:47:34,210 --> 00:47:37,240
the idea of actually making sure we
resolve all of this is pretty much a key.

1043
00:47:37,240 --> 00:47:38,410
>> So much pent up hostility.

1044
00:47:38,410 --> 00:47:42,570
>> I know. [LAUGH] >> All right,
now after that we've got training, and

1045
00:47:42,570 --> 00:47:44,060
I've mentioned this one
in the last segment.

1046
00:47:44,060 --> 00:47:48,580
Is that when you bring on team
members they might not be trained.

1047
00:47:48,580 --> 00:47:49,906
And when I'm talking about training I

1048
00:47:49,906 --> 00:47:51,530
really mean two different
types of training.

1049
00:47:51,530 --> 00:47:54,246
One, they might not be trained for
the job they've just been assigned.

1050
00:47:54,246 --> 00:47:57,463
In which case,
we may need to get them training for that.

1051
00:47:57,463 --> 00:48:01,400
You might have brought somebody on to do
your bookkeeping, your accounting, but

1052
00:48:01,400 --> 00:48:03,750
maybe they just have
a background in computers.

1053
00:48:03,750 --> 00:48:06,030
And so, you might need to send them
through an accounting course or

1054
00:48:06,030 --> 00:48:07,610
something to get them trained up.

1055
00:48:07,610 --> 00:48:08,670
Hopefully not, but it does happen.

1056
00:48:08,670 --> 00:48:12,720
The other thing they might not be
trained for is working in a project.

1057
00:48:12,720 --> 00:48:14,830
>> Yeah.
>> If this is the first time they've

1058
00:48:14,830 --> 00:48:20,200
worked in a project, that is a project
done according to the PMI framework

1059
00:48:20,200 --> 00:48:21,640
>> Then they may not know about things

1060
00:48:21,640 --> 00:48:24,850
like the importance of change tickets,
or how to fill out a change ticket.

1061
00:48:24,850 --> 00:48:27,910
They may not know about progress
reports and how to report that.

1062
00:48:27,910 --> 00:48:31,290
All the various plans and
what the plans mean.

1063
00:48:31,290 --> 00:48:35,990
We may need to create an abbreviated
PMP course just for these people.

1064
00:48:35,990 --> 00:48:38,830
There's a lot of people that do,
they have project management fundamentals,

1065
00:48:38,830 --> 00:48:40,070
is what they normally call it.

1066
00:48:40,070 --> 00:48:43,510
>> And you have a one day workshop
where you bring your team together, and

1067
00:48:43,510 --> 00:48:48,670
you walk them through what's
expected of them in your project.

1068
00:48:48,670 --> 00:48:50,560
So they understand
the importance of paperwork,

1069
00:48:50,560 --> 00:48:53,490
that's the hard one to really
beat into somebody's head.

1070
00:48:53,490 --> 00:48:55,980
Is like, oh it's common sense I
don't need to write this down.

1071
00:48:55,980 --> 00:48:59,380
Yes, yes you do, we need that for
historical purposes.

1072
00:48:59,380 --> 00:49:02,320
So communicating that properly to them,
getting them trained up and

1073
00:49:02,320 --> 00:49:04,320
ready to operate in
a projectized environment.

1074
00:49:04,320 --> 00:49:08,410
The next one is team building,

1075
00:49:08,410 --> 00:49:10,848
and team building is one
that requires a bit of work.

1076
00:49:10,848 --> 00:49:14,386
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you are fortunate enough to have

1077
00:49:14,386 --> 00:49:18,265
been working with the same group
of employees for years and years.

1078
00:49:18,265 --> 00:49:22,135
You guys may already be a cohesive unit,
that's ready to operate and

1079
00:49:22,135 --> 00:49:25,625
do everything that you need at
the highest peak of performance.

1080
00:49:26,725 --> 00:49:29,415
But that's never happened for
me, I've read about it somewhere.

1081
00:49:29,415 --> 00:49:33,150
For most of us though, you're going to
have at least one new team member, and

1082
00:49:33,150 --> 00:49:36,420
anytime you introduce even
a single new team member.

1083
00:49:36,420 --> 00:49:37,720
It throws off the balance.

1084
00:49:37,720 --> 00:49:40,340
Yeah, it throws off the balance of
the project and the project team.

1085
00:49:40,340 --> 00:49:45,600
So you've got to get them back to
operating like a smooth unit right.

1086
00:49:45,600 --> 00:49:49,580
And there are a number of team building
exercises that are out there for that.

1087
00:49:49,580 --> 00:49:54,110
We could talk about things like
rock climbing or whatever.

1088
00:49:54,110 --> 00:49:58,054
You know, there's things you can do
to get people to from a team, and

1089
00:49:58,054 --> 00:49:59,820
form relationships.

1090
00:49:59,820 --> 00:50:01,610
You can let it happen on its own course,
right?

1091
00:50:01,610 --> 00:50:04,110
But you run risks when you do that.

1092
00:50:04,110 --> 00:50:06,840
Sometimes people will choose
to isolate themselves.

1093
00:50:06,840 --> 00:50:09,120
Other times people start to form cliques.

1094
00:50:09,120 --> 00:50:12,240
Right, so you get these divisions
inside of your project team and

1095
00:50:12,240 --> 00:50:13,670
that's always a bad thing.

1096
00:50:13,670 --> 00:50:15,950
So more often than not
as a project manager,

1097
00:50:15,950 --> 00:50:18,590
you need to get involved, all right.

1098
00:50:18,590 --> 00:50:21,900
And when we get involved it's a good
idea to recognize the various

1099
00:50:21,900 --> 00:50:23,830
phases that a team goes through.

1100
00:50:23,830 --> 00:50:26,080
And PMI specifically calls
this out in the PEMBAC.

1101
00:50:26,080 --> 00:50:31,380
They have what's called the Tuckman
Ladder, which defines like five different

1102
00:50:31,380 --> 00:50:34,800
phases that a project goes through,
and they're fairly easy to remember.

1103
00:50:34,800 --> 00:50:36,460
Let me bring these up in the notes.

1104
00:50:36,460 --> 00:50:40,370
>> Yeah, the overall developmental of the
team here, again, everybody goes through

1105
00:50:40,370 --> 00:50:43,500
psychologically something, and here we're
actually starting to take a look at that.

1106
00:50:43,500 --> 00:50:45,050
It's important that you
do understand these,

1107
00:50:45,050 --> 00:50:46,880
because I think even Don
was talking about it.

1108
00:50:46,880 --> 00:50:48,120
And, you will see this on the exam,

1109
00:50:48,120 --> 00:50:50,750
so let's make sure we go ahead and
cover this.

1110
00:50:50,750 --> 00:50:52,340
>> All right.
So, there's five phases, and

1111
00:50:52,340 --> 00:50:54,870
they all kind of sound the same
which makes them easy to remember.

1112
00:50:54,870 --> 00:51:00,440
There's Forming, Storming, Norming,
Performing and Adjourning.

1113
00:51:00,440 --> 00:51:01,430
Which doesn't sound right.

1114
00:51:01,430 --> 00:51:03,840
You can say adjourning and
it makes it a little easier to remember.

1115
00:51:03,840 --> 00:51:06,165
But then you sound Nordic.

1116
00:51:06,165 --> 00:51:08,670
[LAUGH] But adjourning is the last one.

1117
00:51:08,670 --> 00:51:12,700
Each one kind of represents
the state that a team is in, and

1118
00:51:12,700 --> 00:51:15,710
teams always start in the forming stage.

1119
00:51:15,710 --> 00:51:16,770
All right.

1120
00:51:16,770 --> 00:51:18,570
And then,
they progress through these other stages,

1121
00:51:18,570 --> 00:51:20,530
but things can happen to
make them go backward.

1122
00:51:20,530 --> 00:51:23,870
So let's walk through what each stage is,
and then we'll kind of give an example.

1123
00:51:23,870 --> 00:51:26,080
So forming is the very first stage.

1124
00:51:26,080 --> 00:51:29,370
This is where you get your team
together in the very beginning and

1125
00:51:29,370 --> 00:51:32,810
they're meeting each other, for
many, for the first time, all right?

1126
00:51:32,810 --> 00:51:35,860
So these are people that may not have
ever worked together a single moment.

1127
00:51:35,860 --> 00:51:38,980
Maybe not have even bumped into
each other in the hallway before.

1128
00:51:38,980 --> 00:51:40,950
Now they're meeting each other, and

1129
00:51:40,950 --> 00:51:44,345
they're starting to kind of
understand what the project is.

1130
00:51:44,345 --> 00:51:45,300
Yeah.

1131
00:51:45,300 --> 00:51:49,100
Now a team in the forming
phase is not ready to do work.

1132
00:51:49,100 --> 00:51:52,280
Often times when you're in the forming
phase they don't know who's responsibility

1133
00:51:52,280 --> 00:51:53,240
what is.

1134
00:51:53,240 --> 00:51:55,830
They may not even know what
the project is just yet.

1135
00:51:55,830 --> 00:51:59,410
So you wanna get through the forming
phase as quickly as possible.

1136
00:51:59,410 --> 00:52:04,590
Basically as the project manager, you
are informing them what the project is,

1137
00:52:04,590 --> 00:52:08,340
what their job role is, those things
to get them through the forming phase.

1138
00:52:08,340 --> 00:52:11,340
And this is very important in a team
building, because what we need to do is we

1139
00:52:11,340 --> 00:52:15,170
want to make sure that everybody on
the team understands what my role is in

1140
00:52:15,170 --> 00:52:17,920
the team, or what Don's role
is going to be in the team.

1141
00:52:17,920 --> 00:52:19,430
So the forming stage is very important,

1142
00:52:19,430 --> 00:52:22,950
that we go in and establish that here's
what he's going to be responsible for, and

1143
00:52:22,950 --> 00:52:25,590
here's where we're going to go if we
have problems and issues with that.

1144
00:52:25,590 --> 00:52:28,400
Because without that right a lot of
times people do come up with questions.

1145
00:52:28,400 --> 00:52:30,700
And they go, you know I don't
remember who to go to and ask.

1146
00:52:30,700 --> 00:52:32,380
So this is a very important part of it.

1147
00:52:32,380 --> 00:52:33,520
Yep.
>> Yep.

1148
00:52:33,520 --> 00:52:35,820
>> The second phase is storming,
all right.

1149
00:52:35,820 --> 00:52:41,240
When you get different people together,
there's different personality types.

1150
00:52:41,240 --> 00:52:43,980
I can't even count the amount
of different ways to measure,

1151
00:52:43,980 --> 00:52:46,655
what are some of
the personality quiz things.

1152
00:52:46,655 --> 00:52:47,805
>> Gosh.
There's so many.

1153
00:52:47,805 --> 00:52:48,875
There's Taylor Johnson.

1154
00:52:48,875 --> 00:52:49,855
There's disc.

1155
00:52:49,855 --> 00:52:50,815
There's so many.

1156
00:52:50,815 --> 00:52:52,875
>> Disc.
That's a good one.

1157
00:52:52,875 --> 00:52:53,765
You hear people.

1158
00:52:53,765 --> 00:52:54,945
Let's go really simple.

1159
00:52:54,945 --> 00:52:58,135
You hear people talk about
type A personalities.

1160
00:52:58,135 --> 00:53:00,595
You have some people who are alphas.

1161
00:53:00,595 --> 00:53:01,605
Who are aggressive.

1162
00:53:01,605 --> 00:53:02,340
Who are leaders.

1163
00:53:02,340 --> 00:53:06,000
And then you have other people who aren't,
who are followers, not

1164
00:53:06,000 --> 00:53:09,520
that they're weak minded or anything like
that, they just don't want to step up and

1165
00:53:09,520 --> 00:53:12,800
take the leadership,
they're better at doing something.

1166
00:53:12,800 --> 00:53:13,940
They're doers, right.

1167
00:53:13,940 --> 00:53:16,680
So different people have
different personalities, and

1168
00:53:16,680 --> 00:53:20,800
when a team first forms,
we don't know everybody's personality yet.

1169
00:53:20,800 --> 00:53:25,050
So when we're ready to start work,
we almost always go right into Storming.

1170
00:53:25,050 --> 00:53:28,100
Unless the team has already been
well established in the past,

1171
00:53:28,100 --> 00:53:29,710
you might skip past this phase, but

1172
00:53:29,710 --> 00:53:33,040
normally we go right into storming and
here's where people start to butt heads.

1173
00:53:33,040 --> 00:53:35,880
Right?
Here's where people start doing work and

1174
00:53:35,880 --> 00:53:38,420
they're learning about each other,
and how they do work and

1175
00:53:38,420 --> 00:53:41,800
finding out who is the alpha personality,
who is going to step up and

1176
00:53:41,800 --> 00:53:46,120
be that leader, and
kind of how things are going to roll.

1177
00:53:46,120 --> 00:53:48,910
This can be good and bad.

1178
00:53:48,910 --> 00:53:52,890
Left uncontrolled, you can end up in
situations where somebody who is not

1179
00:53:52,890 --> 00:53:56,960
a project manager, becomes the de
facto ruler of your project,

1180
00:53:56,960 --> 00:53:58,960
and that can be pretty bad, right?

1181
00:53:58,960 --> 00:54:01,950
As the project manager,
you are the leader.

1182
00:54:01,950 --> 00:54:04,810
Doesn't matter if you have five
type A personalities on your team,

1183
00:54:04,810 --> 00:54:06,870
you're the leader so
you gotta rein them in.

1184
00:54:06,870 --> 00:54:07,990
And you have to recognize that.

1185
00:54:07,990 --> 00:54:10,730
So, you're part of
the Storming process also.

1186
00:54:10,730 --> 00:54:11,620
Right?
>> Yeah, you know,

1187
00:54:11,620 --> 00:54:14,060
with that actually being unevalutated,
it doesn't see it happen.

1188
00:54:14,060 --> 00:54:16,120
And know where you have to go to control.

1189
00:54:16,120 --> 00:54:18,730
It becomes incredibly counterproductive
in anything that you're

1190
00:54:18,730 --> 00:54:21,920
trying to do as a team from that point on,
cuz now you have, you do,

1191
00:54:21,920 --> 00:54:24,140
you have that defactorial unit,
and you have you.

1192
00:54:24,140 --> 00:54:27,880
As actually being the appointed leader,
they're not exactly sure who to listen to.

1193
00:54:27,880 --> 00:54:30,710
So really getting this out in
the open right at the beginning,

1194
00:54:30,710 --> 00:54:32,690
part of a great process
to building a team.

1195
00:54:32,690 --> 00:54:33,910
>> Yep.

1196
00:54:33,910 --> 00:54:36,010
Once that's done, we shift into Norming.

1197
00:54:36,010 --> 00:54:38,810
The Norming phase is where all right.

1198
00:54:38,810 --> 00:54:40,270
>> Yeah, jolly.
>> People have learned how they work,

1199
00:54:40,270 --> 00:54:43,170
how they interact and
they start doing work, okay?

1200
00:54:43,170 --> 00:54:44,420
>> Yeah.
>> So they actually start being

1201
00:54:44,420 --> 00:54:45,620
productive at this point.

1202
00:54:45,620 --> 00:54:48,620
They may have been somewhat productive
in the Storming phase, but probably not.

1203
00:54:48,620 --> 00:54:49,680
Now they're ready to get things done.

1204
00:54:49,680 --> 00:54:53,140
People have established their role, their
dominance or submissiveness or whatever,

1205
00:54:53,140 --> 00:54:55,370
inside of the project,
and they're ready to rock.

1206
00:54:55,370 --> 00:54:56,040
Okay?

1207
00:54:56,040 --> 00:54:59,590
So Norming is a pretty decent place to be,
but

1208
00:54:59,590 --> 00:55:01,660
it just means people
are getting things done.

1209
00:55:01,660 --> 00:55:04,940
It doesn't necessarily mean they're
happy about it or they're unhappy,

1210
00:55:04,940 --> 00:55:07,400
they're just getting things done.

1211
00:55:07,400 --> 00:55:09,170
If it's a good team though.

1212
00:55:09,170 --> 00:55:13,640
If everybody's able to communicate, and
things are going well, and people like

1213
00:55:13,640 --> 00:55:19,010
each other, then all of a sudden we start
switching into what's called Performing.

1214
00:55:19,010 --> 00:55:22,520
Performing means not only are we
a team that works together, but

1215
00:55:22,520 --> 00:55:27,070
we work together highly efficiently, that
people know each other's pros and cons,

1216
00:55:27,070 --> 00:55:29,440
they kind of anticipate
each other's needs, and

1217
00:55:29,440 --> 00:55:32,590
now they are able to work
better than a normal team.

1218
00:55:32,590 --> 00:55:34,790
We can get even beyond that
because of the closeness and

1219
00:55:34,790 --> 00:55:36,560
the relationship between the team members.

1220
00:55:36,560 --> 00:55:39,360
>> Right
>> That's where you want to be.

1221
00:55:39,360 --> 00:55:41,520
When you're dealing with team building,

1222
00:55:41,520 --> 00:55:43,920
Performing is what you're
trying to achieve.

1223
00:55:43,920 --> 00:55:47,519
So even if your team is normalized,
they're working, they're doing okay,

1224
00:55:47,519 --> 00:55:48,726
that doesn't mean stop.

1225
00:55:48,726 --> 00:55:52,732
You've got to go even better, get these
people working really close together.

1226
00:55:52,732 --> 00:55:55,785
Communicating and exchanging information,
and you'll get performing.

1227
00:55:55,785 --> 00:55:59,600
That's when you get the best effort
out of all of your employees.

1228
00:55:59,600 --> 00:56:03,870
Now any little thing can
happen to disrupt this.

1229
00:56:03,870 --> 00:56:06,240
Maybe someone is out on sick leave.

1230
00:56:06,240 --> 00:56:08,140
and so you have to bring in a replacement.

1231
00:56:08,140 --> 00:56:10,990
Well, the instant you bring in
that replacement what happens?

1232
00:56:10,990 --> 00:56:13,700
You drop all the way back to storming,
right?

1233
00:56:13,700 --> 00:56:16,550
Here comes this new personality
who might be an alpha.

1234
00:56:16,550 --> 00:56:19,380
Who has their own predisposition.

1235
00:56:19,380 --> 00:56:21,940
And now you've got to
kinda set that straight.

1236
00:56:21,940 --> 00:56:25,340
Kind line those expectations back up,
and get things moving along.

1237
00:56:25,340 --> 00:56:28,910
Or it might be a person that snaps
right into the old persons place, and

1238
00:56:28,910 --> 00:56:30,650
you don't get any disruption whatsoever.

1239
00:56:30,650 --> 00:56:33,410
But it's not uncommon to drop all
the way back to storming, and

1240
00:56:33,410 --> 00:56:35,990
then you have to do norming,
and then performing.

1241
00:56:35,990 --> 00:56:37,980
Kind of go through each of those again.

1242
00:56:37,980 --> 00:56:41,520
So just because you got to performing
once doesn't mean you stay there.

1243
00:56:41,520 --> 00:56:45,070
Alright, it may not even be something
like adding a new employee,

1244
00:56:45,070 --> 00:56:46,420
it could be an existing team.

1245
00:56:46,420 --> 00:56:47,700
I can think of a great example.

1246
00:56:47,700 --> 00:56:51,410
I was working on one project,
where things were going great.

1247
00:56:51,410 --> 00:56:53,760
We were definitely in
that performing area.

1248
00:56:53,760 --> 00:56:57,110
All the team members were working
together, things were going really well.

1249
00:56:57,110 --> 00:56:59,860
And then we came to this spot where
we had to decide on a particular

1250
00:56:59,860 --> 00:57:00,460
piece of hardware.

1251
00:57:00,460 --> 00:57:02,720
We had two vendors to pick from.

1252
00:57:02,720 --> 00:57:05,530
And half the team preferred one vendor,
and

1253
00:57:05,530 --> 00:57:07,240
the other half of the team
preferred the other vendor.

1254
00:57:07,240 --> 00:57:11,100
So there became this divide in the project
based on this certain decision that

1255
00:57:11,100 --> 00:57:12,030
had to be made.

1256
00:57:12,030 --> 00:57:14,500
Now we went through our
decision making process.

1257
00:57:14,500 --> 00:57:17,770
We did graded matrix cards and stuff.

1258
00:57:17,770 --> 00:57:19,399
And then we selected one of the vendors.

1259
00:57:20,470 --> 00:57:25,070
Well, from that point on,
the people that liked the other vendor,

1260
00:57:25,070 --> 00:57:26,300
it was like a divide.

1261
00:57:26,300 --> 00:57:26,890
It really did.

1262
00:57:26,890 --> 00:57:31,360
It created a separation, and those
employees were not performing anymore.

1263
00:57:31,360 --> 00:57:34,530
And since they weren't performing,
the other people couldn't perform.

1264
00:57:34,530 --> 00:57:36,590
So the whole team dropped down to norming.

1265
00:57:36,590 --> 00:57:37,490
We were still working.

1266
00:57:37,490 --> 00:57:39,210
We were still getting things done.

1267
00:57:39,210 --> 00:57:40,540
But that divide was there.

1268
00:57:40,540 --> 00:57:41,630
It was present.

1269
00:57:41,630 --> 00:57:44,940
And basically I had to step in and
straighten that out.

1270
00:57:44,940 --> 00:57:47,090
Get it where they understand, hey,

1271
00:57:47,090 --> 00:57:51,520
at the end of the day your job isn't to
interact with this vendor or that vendor.

1272
00:57:51,520 --> 00:57:53,200
It's to move this project forward.

1273
00:57:53,200 --> 00:57:54,950
So we may deal with different vendors.

1274
00:57:54,950 --> 00:57:55,680
That's how it goes.

1275
00:57:55,680 --> 00:57:59,520
We had a scoring system that we all
agreed upon in the planning phase.

1276
00:57:59,520 --> 00:58:00,910
And we followed it right.

1277
00:58:00,910 --> 00:58:02,840
So you have to get people back in line.

1278
00:58:02,840 --> 00:58:06,860
And we'll talk about that later when
we talk about issue management.

1279
00:58:06,860 --> 00:58:11,960
And conflict resolution,
which we get monitoring and controlling.

1280
00:58:11,960 --> 00:58:13,570
So we'll get a chance to see those later.

1281
00:58:13,570 --> 00:58:16,180
But that's what we need to keep our
eye out for as a project manager.

1282
00:58:16,180 --> 00:58:20,960
To make sure that we always see
ourselves in our performing phase.

1283
00:58:20,960 --> 00:58:25,460
Now, when the project is done,
when things start winding down.

1284
00:58:25,460 --> 00:58:27,590
We start getting our deliverables,
and so on.

1285
00:58:27,590 --> 00:58:29,220
That's when we get into adjourning.

1286
00:58:29,220 --> 00:58:32,710
Okay, adjourning is where our
team completes the work, and

1287
00:58:32,710 --> 00:58:34,010
starts to break apart.

1288
00:58:34,010 --> 00:58:37,460
We send our people back out to, you know,
return them to the PMO or wherever, so

1289
00:58:37,460 --> 00:58:39,870
they can go and
get assigned to the next project.

1290
00:58:39,870 --> 00:58:44,870
Now, the reason adjourning is called out
here as a special phase is, as a PM,

1291
00:58:44,870 --> 00:58:46,630
there's some work we need to do.

1292
00:58:46,630 --> 00:58:50,450
We'll see this in the closing process
group when we get to that, or

1293
00:58:50,450 --> 00:58:51,680
the closing phase.

1294
00:58:51,680 --> 00:58:55,580
Because what we want to do is we
want to create a score card, or

1295
00:58:55,580 --> 00:58:58,510
a report card for each person
that was a member of that team.

1296
00:58:58,510 --> 00:59:02,050
And in there we want to report things like
how well they participated in the team.

1297
00:59:02,050 --> 00:59:05,480
How well they got along with person A or
person B, or person C.

1298
00:59:05,480 --> 00:59:08,450
So, that in the future when
we build our next team

1299
00:59:08,450 --> 00:59:11,150
we can make sure to get
the best team members possible.

1300
00:59:11,150 --> 00:59:12,620
May be I'm making a team of ten people,

1301
00:59:12,620 --> 00:59:16,130
and there was one in particular that
was dragging the whole team down.

1302
00:59:16,130 --> 00:59:18,250
Well, you can whip them into shape and
get them in line, and

1303
00:59:18,250 --> 00:59:21,640
turn them into a great employee, but
sometimes that just doesn't work out.

1304
00:59:21,640 --> 00:59:23,550
And so at the end of the day you
can mark that employee and say,

1305
00:59:23,550 --> 00:59:27,230
you know what, I wanna make sure I
don't have that guy on my next team.

1306
00:59:27,230 --> 00:59:30,220
The next time I form a team, we would
be better off without that person.

1307
00:59:30,220 --> 00:59:31,870
So that's information we need to know.

1308
00:59:31,870 --> 00:59:34,530
And that's why we have
a designated adjourning phase.

1309
00:59:34,530 --> 00:59:36,820
So we can recognize that stuff and
kind of document it.

1310
00:59:38,770 --> 00:59:42,550
All right, so those are all part
of team building activities.

1311
00:59:42,550 --> 00:59:44,570
There are a few other things, and

1312
00:59:44,570 --> 00:59:47,575
be careful with these, team building
activities can go horribly wrong.

1313
00:59:47,575 --> 00:59:49,520
[LAUGH]
>> One of my favorites.

1314
00:59:49,520 --> 00:59:52,890
I went to work for a company and they
wanted to have a team building exercise.

1315
00:59:52,890 --> 00:59:57,720
So they decided that the best thing to
do would be to take the whole team and

1316
00:59:57,720 --> 00:59:59,840
go go-kart racing.

1317
00:59:59,840 --> 01:00:03,801
And Ronnie, you've known me long enough,
you know I hate go-kart racing.

1318
01:00:03,801 --> 01:00:06,940
And so we go go-kart racing.

1319
01:00:06,940 --> 01:00:10,160
And I was thinking about it as I'm in this
stupid little car driving around a track.

1320
01:00:10,160 --> 01:00:14,280
And I'm thinking, boy,
what better way to do team building

1321
01:00:14,280 --> 01:00:17,090
than to isolate each team
member in a separate car so

1322
01:00:17,090 --> 01:00:20,270
they can't talk to each other And
then pit them against each other, right?

1323
01:00:20,270 --> 01:00:22,870
That's just the ultimate in team building,
and

1324
01:00:22,870 --> 01:00:26,650
it was just a great example
of a very poor exercise.

1325
01:00:26,650 --> 01:00:30,780
You want to create exercises
that get people talking,

1326
01:00:30,780 --> 01:00:31,830
get people working together.

1327
01:00:31,830 --> 01:00:34,571
Something just as simple as going
to lunch together as a team.

1328
01:00:34,571 --> 01:00:38,200
You know, kind of stuff to create
that non workplace chatter.

1329
01:00:38,200 --> 01:00:40,580
Just to get people to understand
each other's personalities.

1330
01:00:42,010 --> 01:00:43,960
Some people have a hard time
coming out of their shells, and

1331
01:00:43,960 --> 01:00:45,530
in the workplace that may not happen.

1332
01:00:45,530 --> 01:00:47,650
So, you've got to find out what works for
you.

1333
01:00:49,140 --> 01:00:52,220
Now we've got a laundry list of
other tools here, like ground rules.

1334
01:00:53,250 --> 01:00:55,850
Ground rules are an important one for
me, especially in meetings.

1335
01:00:55,850 --> 01:00:59,380
You can have ground rules for everything,
but meetings are one of the best places.

1336
01:00:59,380 --> 01:01:00,950
I've noticed over the years.

1337
01:01:00,950 --> 01:01:04,360
That if you're gonna manage
personality types like type As.

1338
01:01:04,360 --> 01:01:06,360
What's a type A going to do in a meeting?

1339
01:01:06,360 --> 01:01:07,560
They're gonna have an idea.

1340
01:01:07,560 --> 01:01:10,310
So if I say all right, does anybody have
any idea of how we can get this done on

1341
01:01:10,310 --> 01:01:13,890
schedule, a type A is gonna have an idea,
right?

1342
01:01:13,890 --> 01:01:16,410
But what about somebody
who's not a type A,

1343
01:01:16,410 --> 01:01:21,370
somebody who's a type B or
whatever's not a type A?

1344
01:01:21,370 --> 01:01:23,550
Well, they might have a great idea.

1345
01:01:23,550 --> 01:01:24,800
But not want to say it.

1346
01:01:24,800 --> 01:01:28,290
They might say man, I could recommend it,
but that type A person,

1347
01:01:28,290 --> 01:01:29,570
they're just gonna steamroll me.

1348
01:01:29,570 --> 01:01:33,730
They're gonna bulldoze my idea,
and just brow beat me, and

1349
01:01:33,730 --> 01:01:34,770
their idea's gonna win out.

1350
01:01:34,770 --> 01:01:37,140
So I'll just keep it quiet.

1351
01:01:37,140 --> 01:01:39,590
But we wanna make sure that
everybody participates equally.

1352
01:01:39,590 --> 01:01:42,310
So how do we do that?

1353
01:01:42,310 --> 01:01:43,850
We can establish ground rules.

1354
01:01:43,850 --> 01:01:47,350
We can set up rules for the meeting,
and these can be very simple rules,

1355
01:01:47,350 --> 01:01:48,540
very complex rules,

1356
01:01:48,540 --> 01:01:52,640
they can be silly rules, like talking
stick, if you've ever seen that one.

1357
01:01:52,640 --> 01:01:54,940
You can only talk if you've
got the talking stick.

1358
01:01:54,940 --> 01:01:56,050
And you pass it around, and

1359
01:01:56,050 --> 01:02:00,250
that helps to eliminate the whole idea
of somebody steamrolling other people.

1360
01:02:00,250 --> 01:02:02,370
You might have other rules that say like,

1361
01:02:02,370 --> 01:02:05,490
hey when we have a decision in a meeting
we always use the Delfi technique.

1362
01:02:05,490 --> 01:02:07,590
The anonymous voting system or

1363
01:02:07,590 --> 01:02:10,460
something like that,
to make sure that we've got that.

1364
01:02:10,460 --> 01:02:13,110
Other ground rules might
be to just say things like,

1365
01:02:14,320 --> 01:02:16,890
we don't allow people to raise
their voices in the meetings.

1366
01:02:16,890 --> 01:02:19,410
Meetings are always held to 30 minutes,
and are not allowed to go over.

1367
01:02:19,410 --> 01:02:21,870
You're not allowed to
eat during the meetings.

1368
01:02:21,870 --> 01:02:24,230
They can be very simple mundane things.

1369
01:02:24,230 --> 01:02:26,213
But help the meetings stay cohesive.

1370
01:02:28,512 --> 01:02:30,020
Alright, colocation.

1371
01:02:30,020 --> 01:02:32,960
I kind of talked about this
earlier with virtual teams.

1372
01:02:32,960 --> 01:02:35,750
With virtual teams you might have
employees all over the country,

1373
01:02:35,750 --> 01:02:37,080
all over the world.

1374
01:02:37,080 --> 01:02:38,950
And you lose that cohesive unit.

1375
01:02:38,950 --> 01:02:43,940
You lose the banter, the daily chit
chat that helps to build a strong team.

1376
01:02:43,940 --> 01:02:45,980
So many organizations
choose to do colocation.

1377
01:02:45,980 --> 01:02:49,530
Now, This applies even if all
