the employees work in the same city.

1378
01:02:49,530 --> 01:02:52,960
So, for example I used to
work in a skyscraper, and

1379
01:02:52,960 --> 01:02:55,940
our offices were spread
across five floors.

1380
01:02:55,940 --> 01:02:59,210
So we had like the 17th through
21st floors, is what we had.

1381
01:02:59,210 --> 01:03:01,380
And that meant employees could
be on any of those floors.

1382
01:03:01,380 --> 01:03:03,700
There were many employees
that I never saw in a day.

1383
01:03:03,700 --> 01:03:06,090
I would go straight to the 19th floor,
where my office was.

1384
01:03:06,090 --> 01:03:06,600
I'd go in there.

1385
01:03:06,600 --> 01:03:08,010
I'd see my department, right?

1386
01:03:08,010 --> 01:03:09,710
The IT guys, that's what I would see.

1387
01:03:09,710 --> 01:03:12,750
But I wouldn't see anybody in
underwriting, or accounting, or

1388
01:03:12,750 --> 01:03:13,990
these other departments.

1389
01:03:13,990 --> 01:03:15,660
Because they were on different floors.

1390
01:03:15,660 --> 01:03:19,510
So when you have a project,
a cool technique to use to

1391
01:03:19,510 --> 01:03:23,480
build cohesiveness between your project
management team is co-location.

1392
01:03:23,480 --> 01:03:27,650
Have them move their desks,
move their offices all to the same area.

1393
01:03:27,650 --> 01:03:30,620
So now it's not just me
in the IT department.

1394
01:03:30,620 --> 01:03:32,100
It's me surrounded by my project team.

1395
01:03:32,100 --> 01:03:34,130
Which might have an accountant and so on.

1396
01:03:34,130 --> 01:03:35,140
All a part of that.

1397
01:03:35,140 --> 01:03:36,620
They're non IT people.

1398
01:03:36,620 --> 01:03:41,300
The nice thing about co-location is if
I'm on the phone call with somebody and

1399
01:03:41,300 --> 01:03:45,500
I'm talking to them about information And
I'm like, hey, why are you over budget?

1400
01:03:45,500 --> 01:03:48,430
Meanwhile, my accountant is
sitting over beside me, and

1401
01:03:48,430 --> 01:03:50,210
they overhear the phone call and
say, oh wait.

1402
01:03:50,210 --> 01:03:51,360
I've got some information on that.

1403
01:03:51,360 --> 01:03:53,045
Right.
Now we get better communication.

1404
01:03:53,045 --> 01:03:55,623
They had information I didn't,
but they were right there.

1405
01:03:55,623 --> 01:03:58,289
So it was able to happen And
that solved the problem,

1406
01:03:58,289 --> 01:04:00,175
it's not always realistic though.

1407
01:04:00,175 --> 01:04:04,165
In a cube office like what we do here, I
could move cubes it would take me like ten

1408
01:04:04,165 --> 01:04:08,850
minutes, right not a big deal, there's
nothing in my cube I really care about.

1409
01:04:08,850 --> 01:04:11,240
Well, it would really tick me off
if someone took my computer but for

1410
01:04:11,240 --> 01:04:14,720
the most part, there's not anything
in there that I care about but

1411
01:04:14,720 --> 01:04:17,510
if you have an actual office, right?

1412
01:04:17,510 --> 01:04:19,670
Actually moving your
entire office contents or

1413
01:04:19,670 --> 01:04:21,280
something is not necessarily realistic.

1414
01:04:21,280 --> 01:04:25,528
So it's not an option for every
company but it is an option for some.

1415
01:04:27,121 --> 01:04:29,780
All right, recognition and rewards.

1416
01:04:29,780 --> 01:04:32,550
With each of your team
members they provide a role,

1417
01:04:32,550 --> 01:04:34,790
they provide a service to your project.

1418
01:04:34,790 --> 01:04:39,520
And as your project moves along, some
people might do exemplary performance and

1419
01:04:39,520 --> 01:04:41,630
we wanna make sure we reward that but

1420
01:04:41,630 --> 01:04:43,570
rewarding them actually
serves two purposes.

1421
01:04:43,570 --> 01:04:46,090
One, it cements that person's
position in the project.

1422
01:04:46,090 --> 01:04:49,150
They understand they're doing a great job,
you've bolstered their confidence and

1423
01:04:49,150 --> 01:04:53,350
morale and it keeps them working,
right, and it keeps them working well.

1424
01:04:53,350 --> 01:04:57,160
But it also encourages those who didn't
get the award to say, man, if I do

1425
01:04:57,160 --> 01:05:01,230
a better job, this is the recognition
I'll get, I'd really like that.

1426
01:05:01,230 --> 01:05:03,080
And so it is a good idea to draw that out.

1427
01:05:03,080 --> 01:05:06,140
We also mentioned recognition and
rewards at the close of a project,

1428
01:05:06,140 --> 01:05:08,050
to reward the team there too.

1429
01:05:08,050 --> 01:05:10,850
But these are part of the team process.

1430
01:05:10,850 --> 01:05:13,830
When somebody does an exceptional
job you should recognize that.

1431
01:05:13,830 --> 01:05:15,520
Make sure that the rest
of the team is aware.

1432
01:05:17,410 --> 01:05:19,650
And then personnel assessment tools.

1433
01:05:19,650 --> 01:05:23,360
This is what I mentioned earlier as
far as a scorecard or a grade report,

1434
01:05:23,360 --> 01:05:27,790
whatever you want to call it,
where we need to assess our team members.

1435
01:05:27,790 --> 01:05:31,730
And you may create ahead of time
a little score sheet that says,

1436
01:05:31,730 --> 01:05:33,000
get's along well with others,

1437
01:05:33,000 --> 01:05:35,675
attendance, things like that, all
the things we had in elementary school.

1438
01:05:35,675 --> 01:05:38,360
[LAUGH] Use that to gauge your employees.

1439
01:05:38,360 --> 01:05:41,000
If you have a team member
who is falling behind,

1440
01:05:41,000 --> 01:05:45,700
who is not communicating with the team,
you've got two choices, right.

1441
01:05:45,700 --> 01:05:48,080
Choice number one is to can them,
dump them out of the project,

1442
01:05:48,080 --> 01:05:49,230
get a replacement employee.

1443
01:05:49,230 --> 01:05:50,870
You can do that, certainly.

1444
01:05:50,870 --> 01:05:54,550
But the better options, option two,
which is to correct that.

1445
01:05:54,550 --> 01:05:57,710
Train them to be better,
make sure they recognize their faults.

1446
01:05:57,710 --> 01:05:59,770
A lot of times they just
don't even know it.

1447
01:05:59,770 --> 01:06:03,060
So you make sure they recognize it,
you inform them, you let them know and

1448
01:06:03,060 --> 01:06:05,410
give them the chance to
become a better employee.

1449
01:06:05,410 --> 01:06:08,630
Because when they're a better employee,
not only does it help your project but

1450
01:06:08,630 --> 01:06:12,180
it helps the next project that's
gonna get that same employee, too.

1451
01:06:12,180 --> 01:06:15,040
Better to craft somebody who's
a successful employee than to just

1452
01:06:15,040 --> 01:06:18,570
keep starting from scratch until you hope
to hit somebody who meets your needs by

1453
01:06:18,570 --> 01:06:19,370
luck, right?

1454
01:06:19,370 --> 01:06:21,160
That's not really effective.

1455
01:06:21,160 --> 01:06:23,280
>> Yeah, and
you read about this a lot of times and

1456
01:06:23,280 --> 01:06:25,430
the idea of the management books
that you actually see out there,

1457
01:06:25,430 --> 01:06:29,450
where it talks about the idea of finding
the right person, then training them up,

1458
01:06:29,450 --> 01:06:32,830
instead of trying to look for every skill
that you need and then hoping that they're

1459
01:06:32,830 --> 01:06:35,700
the right person and this is a part
of the idea of the assessment.

1460
01:06:35,700 --> 01:06:38,060
Most people don't know if they're
actually doing a great job or

1461
01:06:38,060 --> 01:06:42,220
if they're doing an okay or mediocre or
not even a great job at all.

1462
01:06:42,220 --> 01:06:44,110
By helping them out to
be able to see that,

1463
01:06:44,110 --> 01:06:47,830
it really does actually help them in
terms of what they're doing every day.

1464
01:06:47,830 --> 01:06:50,530
It really just helps you because
they're going to become a more

1465
01:06:50,530 --> 01:06:51,810
productive team member.

1466
01:06:51,810 --> 01:06:53,100
So do remember that.

1467
01:06:53,100 --> 01:06:59,070
>> There is a saying out on the internet
right now, you're various IT companies,

1468
01:06:59,070 --> 01:07:04,960
very edgy, silicon valley,
they say, hire slow, fire fast.

1469
01:07:04,960 --> 01:07:09,765
So what they're saying is hire slow,
take time to find the right employee.

1470
01:07:09,765 --> 01:07:13,210
And if they're not the right fit,
fire them fast and move on.

1471
01:07:13,210 --> 01:07:17,580
Now there's something to be said about
that approach but the fire fast thing

1472
01:07:17,580 --> 01:07:21,100
means, instead of trying to correct the
problem, just give up on them and move on.

1473
01:07:21,100 --> 01:07:24,870
And that's not really right for
most environments so be wary of that.

1474
01:07:24,870 --> 01:07:29,580
We hear about it because of companies
like Facebook and Amazon and Zappos and

1475
01:07:29,580 --> 01:07:33,450
stuff where they are massive,
multi billion dollar companies, so

1476
01:07:33,450 --> 01:07:36,010
when they fire somebody, a replacement?

1477
01:07:36,010 --> 01:07:39,750
Well they've probably got a stack of
resumes 10,000 high for that replacement.

1478
01:07:39,750 --> 01:07:43,430
But if you're a small or medium
organization, somewhere like here in

1479
01:07:43,430 --> 01:07:48,840
Gainesville, if I got tired of Ronnie and
fired him it's not like I've got a stack

1480
01:07:48,840 --> 01:07:52,950
of show host resumes sitting over on my
desk that I could go and pick through.

1481
01:07:52,950 --> 01:07:54,610
>> Wait, wait.
You have a whole

1482
01:07:54,610 --> 01:07:56,230
Chat room full probably now.

1483
01:07:56,230 --> 01:07:59,430
>> That's right, everybody's like wow,
I need to email Don.

1484
01:07:59,430 --> 01:08:03,560
So, it can be hard to line up that
next person and having a poor

1485
01:08:03,560 --> 01:08:08,140
employee that can be trained up better is
more valuable than having no employee.

1486
01:08:08,140 --> 01:08:11,190
So, you want to make sure you take
the approach that's right for

1487
01:08:11,190 --> 01:08:15,870
your situation and don't let
Silicon Valley serve as your model.

1488
01:08:17,110 --> 01:08:22,190
It's like, have you ever heard the Steam,
not Steam, Valve.

1489
01:08:22,190 --> 01:08:24,280
Valve is a video game company.

1490
01:08:24,280 --> 01:08:28,406
And they released their employee handbook
out into the internet and people were

1491
01:08:28,406 --> 01:08:32,430
going crazy over it because they had this
interesting project selection process.

1492
01:08:32,430 --> 01:08:34,960
So when they pick up a new project,
what do they do?

1493
01:08:34,960 --> 01:08:36,530
They don't,
they let their employees do it.

1494
01:08:36,530 --> 01:08:40,120
And they just they leave their
employees unassigned to teams and

1495
01:08:40,120 --> 01:08:42,580
if the employees want,
they meet each other in the hallways and

1496
01:08:42,580 --> 01:08:44,940
say hey how do you feel
about working on this game?

1497
01:08:44,940 --> 01:08:46,540
And they form a team right there and

1498
01:08:46,540 --> 01:08:49,570
they start to work on projects that
weren't selected by the company.

1499
01:08:49,570 --> 01:08:52,920
And some people see it like,
man that sounds great.

1500
01:08:52,920 --> 01:08:56,330
And I tell you, it does not work
in most environments, right.

1501
01:08:56,330 --> 01:08:59,100
And maybe the video game industry is
different, cuz they're very successful.

1502

But if you were to do like,
building houses and

1503

you just left it up to your
contractors to come together and

1504

say, what do you think about building a

1505
01:09:08,140 --> 01:09:11,480
They could come up with all sorts of
crazy things, so finding the right

1506
01:09:11,480 --> 01:09:14,640
team methodology for your environment,
obviously very important.

1507
01:09:14,640 --> 01:09:17,310
All right, now our outputs on this

Enterprise environmental factors,

remember that's how we do

We might say, boy,

1523

That really didn't work out.

1525

So my second favorite, so
the go-kart racing was a bad one.

Crew, are you familiar with crew?

The boating.

I can't even swim.

Alright, so maybe that strengthens

I'm counting on one of them

1545

[LAUGH]

1546

If they can breath.

As long as they can breath.

>> Alright, anyway I don't like

Team Performance Assessments, Issue Logs,

Team performance assessments,

when you've got a team and

01:12:42,330 --> 01:12:45,640

When you've done all of that,

Team performance does.

Scope, Quality, Schedule, okay?

What kind of broken up scope and

So scope and quality, how well is

1604
01:13:21,916 --> 01:13:26,550

Do they exceed expectations, do they meet

Meets expectations, that means we're

1607
01:13:37,030 --> 01:13:38,700

1608
01:13:38,700 --> 01:13:41,520
Exceeds expectations means

when we're in these storming or

1610

storming or forming phases that's where

And we can identify that and kind of

01:13:52,830 --> 01:13:57,180
So this is just an example of

Communication, collaboration,

Each of these different things,

Now, how often do you need to

We were just talking about Star Trek,

A five year, anyhow,

in a manner that leaves you

That's a Team Performance Assessment.

Scope, quality, schedule, cost, and

So, if we find that we're needing

There are other forms and

All right, here's where we set

our meeting guidelines.

Right, the ground rules

If we've defined these things out we use

1639

What are our guidelines,

There are others, let's see, what else

1643
01:15:27,890 --> 01:15:29,690

1644
01:15:29,690 --> 01:15:31,259
The issue log is pretty important.

1645
01:15:32,340 --> 01:15:35,130
When there's an issue,
a conflict, an argument,

1646
01:15:35,130 --> 01:15:38,270
a problem, we need to address it.

1647
01:15:38,270 --> 01:15:41,590
One employee comes to you and says,
look, I'm working really hard here.

1648
01:15:41,590 --> 01:15:43,600
This other guy, he's not.

1649
01:15:43,600 --> 01:15:45,980
He's not pulling his weight and
I'm having to double up my effort.

1650
01:15:45,980 --> 01:15:48,800
It's gonna hurt the project,
it's definitely gonna hurt my moral.

1651
01:15:48,800 --> 01:15:50,590
As a Project Manager,
you need to step in and

1652
01:15:50,590 --> 01:15:54,120
do something about it,
whether it's a real problem or not.

1653
01:15:54,120 --> 01:15:57,010
Because sometimes people will
bring you silly things like,

1654
01:15:57,010 --> 01:16:01,710
I really like the Seattle Seahawks but
that guy's a San Diego Chargers fan and

1655
01:16:01,710 --> 01:16:03,100
I just can't work with him!

1656

Well, we don't care about that.

1657
01:16:05,170 --> 01:16:06,920
But it's an issue, right?

1658
01:16:06,920 --> 01:16:09,910
We need to report it in the issue log so

1659
01:16:09,910 --> 01:16:12,900
It especially helps if you

1660
01:16:12,900 --> 01:16:16,930

1661

1662

Look at all these issues we've

1663
01:16:21,900 --> 01:16:24,090

1664
01:16:24,090 --> 01:16:26,360
The other thing is that
when your project is done.

01:16:26,360 --> 01:16:31,290
Your project may be successful, come in

1666
01:16:31,290 --> 01:16:35,320
meets needs, it meets the scope in
qualities, things coming great, but

1667

you might have had a problem employee

1668
01:16:39,050 --> 01:16:41,640
Well, when the next
project comes around and

They look at the project history and

1671

project and Don's project was a success,

1672

But,if we have our issue log,

1673

Don's project came in successful,

1674
01:16:57,630 --> 01:16:59,950

1675

An issue log is what does that.

01:17:01,390 --> 01:17:02,850
And if you look at it,

The way this is laid out, it's actually,

So with each issue, you assign an ID.

1680
01:17:11,530 --> 01:17:14,480
It's normally just going to be issue 1,

01:17:14,480 --> 01:17:17,270
You give it a category if
you've got categories for

1682
01:17:17,270 --> 01:17:20,050
issues, and then what the issue is.

1683
01:17:20,050 --> 01:17:24,250
So, I might have an issue

1684
01:17:24,250 --> 01:17:26,410
maybe it's something serious, right?

1685
01:17:26,410 --> 01:17:29,090
Maybe it's like a harassment issue,
a harassment claim,

1686
01:17:29,090 --> 01:17:29,940
which I'm spelling wrong.

01:17:32,440 --> 01:17:36,150
There we go.
[LAUGH] You know a harassment claim and

1688
01:17:36,150 --> 01:17:39,150
I might specify the impact on objectives,

If I have two employees who can't work
together I have to separate them out,

1690
01:17:42,380 --> 01:17:43,910
can't have them in the same room.

1691
01:17:43,910 --> 01:17:48,110
That's going to reduce their productivity
and it's going to extend my project

1692
01:17:48,110 --> 01:17:53,830
schedule due to the special needs, urgency
on a harassment issue should be high.

1693
01:17:53,830 --> 01:17:57,240
The responsible party, you know who it is
that's handling that, that's usually gonna

1694
01:17:57,240 --> 01:18:00,990
be the project manager or you might have
to get human resources involved in it.

1695
01:18:00,990 --> 01:18:02,840
All right.

1696
01:18:02,840 --> 01:18:09,290
Action, separate employees or
it might be terminate employee.

1697
01:18:09,290 --> 01:18:14,070
Your status, this might be ongoing, and a
due date you need to take action if you've

1698
01:18:14,070 --> 01:18:16,290
got one If it's ongoing,
I might not have one.

1699
01:18:16,290 --> 01:18:20,090
And then, in the comments, I detail
what the issue is and so as we go,

1700
01:18:20,090 --> 01:18:21,040
we're tracking this.

1701
01:18:21,040 --> 01:18:24,470
Tracking what the issue is and
it might be issues with people.

1702
01:18:24,470 --> 01:18:27,100
It might be issues with just
the project as a whole.

1703
01:18:27,100 --> 01:18:28,950
Hey, there was a risk, right?

1704
01:18:28,950 --> 01:18:31,660
That the price of wood might go up.

1705
01:18:31,660 --> 01:18:35,020
And as a result in my house building
project my expense is now high.

1706
01:18:35,020 --> 01:18:37,060
I would record that as an issue.

1707
01:18:37,060 --> 01:18:39,430
So an issue log is a living document.

1708
01:18:39,430 --> 01:18:41,210
It doesn't really affect your project.

1709
01:18:41,210 --> 01:18:42,600
The issues affect your project but

1710
01:18:42,600 --> 01:18:46,690
the log itself is more to
benefit projects of the future.

1711
01:18:46,690 --> 01:18:49,300
And to allow you to see trends if
you've got a problem area that's

1712
01:18:49,300 --> 01:18:50,810
constantly creeping up.

1713
01:18:50,810 --> 01:18:52,860
If you have more than one project manager,

1714
01:18:52,860 --> 01:18:56,040
if you have subproject managers and
issue log is essential.

1715
01:18:56,040 --> 01:18:59,420
It's the only way you can track this
kind of activity across your project.

1716
01:19:01,820 --> 01:19:04,710
Other things that we might have,
things like a team directory, just to

1717
01:19:04,710 --> 01:19:08,290
be able to identify who your team members
are, their phone numbers and so on.

1718
01:19:08,290 --> 01:19:10,560
Team member status reports.

1719
01:19:10,560 --> 01:19:14,700
As you do individual evaluations of your
team members, you can go in and break

1720
01:19:14,700 --> 01:19:19,220
it down like this indicating what their
activities are that are assigned to them.

1721
01:19:19,220 --> 01:19:23,125
What their activities that they've
accomplished, activities planned but

1722
01:19:23,125 --> 01:19:24,555
not accomplished this reporting period.

1723
01:19:24,555 --> 01:19:28,015
What's outstanding,
just kind of keeping track of that and

1724
01:19:28,015 --> 01:19:30,425
any root causes for variance.

1725
01:19:30,425 --> 01:19:34,165
Anytime they didn't meet the requirements
that you set forth, why?

1726
01:19:35,345 --> 01:19:37,275
So you can kind of lay all
that information out there,

1727
01:19:37,275 --> 01:19:39,995
tracking exactly how that employee
is operating in your environment.

1728
01:19:41,990 --> 01:19:44,690
And the last one I have is this
team member performance report.

1729
01:19:44,690 --> 01:19:47,570
You'll notice overlap between these
documents, you're not gonna use them all.

1730
01:19:47,570 --> 01:19:49,990
You're gonna pick which one is right for
your environment.

1731
01:19:49,990 --> 01:19:52,720
This one just has a simple audit,
a progress report.

1732
01:19:52,720 --> 01:19:54,796
How well are they doing in
a particular area audited.

1733
01:19:54,796 --> 01:19:57,050
That's why this is real general,
area audited.

1734
01:19:57,050 --> 01:19:59,810
We have to tell them what it
is that we're monitoring And

1735
01:19:59,810 --> 01:20:02,993
then areas where they excelled,
areas where they can improve.

1736
01:20:02,993 --> 01:20:06,649
If there's areas where they can improve,
any deficiencies or defects, and

1737
01:20:06,649 --> 01:20:08,350
then our comments, right.

1738
01:20:08,350 --> 01:20:11,910
So, this type of paperwork is how we're
going to track this progress, and

1739
01:20:11,910 --> 01:20:15,210
on a large project team, where you
might have hundreds of people, or

1740
01:20:15,210 --> 01:20:17,950
thousands of people,
you can't do it all by yourself.

1741
01:20:17,950 --> 01:20:21,800
You can other people who are completing
this data and turning it in to you.

1742
01:20:21,800 --> 01:20:24,850
Which is why in this project or

1743
01:20:24,850 --> 01:20:29,670
in this process group, right here,
we'll see those are inputs.

1744
01:20:29,670 --> 01:20:32,850
The issue log, the work performance
reports, the team performance assessment.

1745
01:20:32,850 --> 01:20:38,120
All of that is an input into
manage the project team.

1746
01:20:38,120 --> 01:20:43,590
So we take all that data, and we use that
for our project performance appraisal.

1747
01:20:43,590 --> 01:20:44,830
So now we've seen several, right?

1748
01:20:44,830 --> 01:20:49,920
We saw team member performance appraisal,
we've seen team performance appraisal,

1749
01:20:49,920 --> 01:20:52,230
and now, project performance.

1750
01:20:52,230 --> 01:20:53,780
How is our project performing?

1751
01:20:53,780 --> 01:20:56,430
Is it running like a well oiled machine,
nice and smooth,

1752
01:20:56,430 --> 01:20:59,770
things are going great or
am I hitting a lot of bumps?

1753
01:20:59,770 --> 01:21:02,460
Am I hitting a lot of issues now
that are burning up time and

1754
01:21:02,460 --> 01:21:05,890
resources that may make it more difficult
for me to be successful down the road.

1755
01:21:07,610 --> 01:21:09,070
So, that is important.

1756
01:21:09,070 --> 01:21:10,550
We want to make sure that
we pay attention to that.

1757
01:21:10,550 --> 01:21:12,030
That we keep on top of it.

1758
01:21:12,030 --> 01:21:14,600
Conflict Management is going
to be a big piece of that.

1759
01:21:14,600 --> 01:21:18,600
When we have conflict, conflict is such
an aggressive word, I don't mean like one

1760
01:21:18,600 --> 01:21:22,010
employee punches another in the face, i
just mean, you've got a decision to make.

1761
01:21:22,010 --> 01:21:24,370
Anytime you have a decision,
there is a conflict.

1762
01:21:24,370 --> 01:21:28,290
If you have two possible outcomes, and
people are choosing different ones,

1763
01:21:28,290 --> 01:21:29,240
you've got conflict.

1764
01:21:29,240 --> 01:21:32,840
It may be a very amicable,
friendly, peaceful conflict, but

1765
01:21:32,840 --> 01:21:34,760
it's still a conflict, nonetheless.

1766
01:21:34,760 --> 01:21:37,530
As a Project Manager,
we need to resolve it.

1767
01:21:37,530 --> 01:21:40,350
We come up with a solution that works for
everyone and

1768
01:21:40,350 --> 01:21:42,000
we move forward,
I shouldn't say it that way.

1769
01:21:42,000 --> 01:21:43,650
That's a trap, right?

1770
01:21:43,650 --> 01:21:46,000
There's never a solution that works for
everyone, right?

1771
01:21:46,000 --> 01:21:51,060
So we need to choose the solution
that's best for our project, right?

1772
01:21:51,060 --> 01:21:55,890
Which one ensures the highest degree
of success and gets us moving forward.

1773
01:21:55,890 --> 01:21:58,750
Sometimes that might not be
the best decision for everyone.

1774
01:21:58,750 --> 01:22:00,860
In fact,
it might not even be the best decision for

1775
01:22:00,860 --> 01:22:04,230
a majority,
you might have to step in and override.

1776
01:22:04,230 --> 01:22:07,950
And then we talked about that earlier,
projects can be run as a democracy or

1777
01:22:07,950 --> 01:22:13,080
as a dictatorship or whatever, and often
times you have to make that decision.

1778
01:22:14,210 --> 01:22:16,480
But if a conflict arises,

1779
01:22:16,480 --> 01:22:19,640
PMI has a specific set of ways
that they can be handled.

1780
01:22:19,640 --> 01:22:21,040
Let me bring up Ronnie's notes.

1781
01:22:22,370 --> 01:22:23,170
Here we go.

1782
01:22:23,170 --> 01:22:25,740
The five techniques for
resolving a conflict.

1783
01:22:27,490 --> 01:22:30,620
If we've got a conflict,
we can choose any of these five.

1784
01:22:30,620 --> 01:22:32,820
Most of them are wrong, and
you don't want to do them.

1785
01:22:32,820 --> 01:22:36,020
So they're really here as
an example of what not to do.

1786
01:22:36,020 --> 01:22:38,980
But there's at least one that's
the good way to do it and

1787
01:22:38,980 --> 01:22:40,220
what we need to know for the exam.

1788
01:22:40,220 --> 01:22:43,500
So you want to be familiar with these, but
let's run through all of them, all right?

1789
01:22:43,500 --> 01:22:45,730
The first one is withdraw/avoid, right?

1790
01:22:45,730 --> 01:22:46,652
Withdraw or avoid.

1791
01:22:48,161 --> 01:22:51,511
You may have an issue that's
going on with the project, and

1792
01:22:51,511 --> 01:22:53,600
you come up with an idea to fix it.

1793
01:22:53,600 --> 01:22:58,060
So here's your idea, now,
someone else has an idea on how to fix it.

1794
01:22:58,060 --> 01:23:00,570
So now you've got two different
ways on how to fix your project and

1795
01:23:00,570 --> 01:23:03,180
get it back on track, and you gotta pick.

1796
01:23:03,180 --> 01:23:07,620
Well, there's a conflict between the two
different solutions and one person,

1797
01:23:07,620 --> 01:23:10,590
after arguing long enough or whatever,
finally just says, you know what?

1798
01:23:10,590 --> 01:23:11,830
Forget it.
We'll go with your way.

1799
01:23:11,830 --> 01:23:12,710
Whatever.

1800
01:23:12,710 --> 01:23:13,410
Right?

1801
01:23:13,410 --> 01:23:16,020
They withdraw their recommendation.

1802
01:23:16,020 --> 01:23:18,720
They avoid the argument by just saying,
forget it.

1803
01:23:18,720 --> 01:23:19,880
I'm done.
We'll go your way.

1804
01:23:19,880 --> 01:23:20,920
Whatever.

1805
01:23:20,920 --> 01:23:23,090
Well, is that the problem solved?

1806
01:23:23,090 --> 01:23:24,280
Problem solved, move on?

1807
01:23:24,280 --> 01:23:27,170
Well the problem is solved in a way,
right?

1808
01:23:27,170 --> 01:23:30,980
But now, you've got an employee who's no
longer gonna be in that performing phase.

1809
01:23:30,980 --> 01:23:34,820
They're no longer gonna be in tight mesh
lock step with the rest of the team.

1810
01:23:34,820 --> 01:23:37,560
They're going to feel like they
had a perfectly good solution and

1811
01:23:37,560 --> 01:23:38,550
we didn't go that way.

1812
01:23:38,550 --> 01:23:41,450
And we may find later on that their
solution was better, and then you get

1813
01:23:41,450 --> 01:23:45,730
the I told you so syndrome, right, which
is really hard for people to overcome.

1814
01:23:45,730 --> 01:23:49,880
So when you see this, it's important that
you recognize it, because it's not you.

1815
01:23:49,880 --> 01:23:52,210
The project manager's not
the one that initiates this,

1816
01:23:52,210 --> 01:23:55,350
it's usually the person who's
involved in the argument, right?

1817
01:23:55,350 --> 01:23:59,270
When you see somebody do withdrawing,
recognize that.

1818
01:23:59,270 --> 01:24:00,800
Recognize that that's a problem,

1819
01:24:00,800 --> 01:24:05,100
Don't say, oh thank goodness now I don't
have to worry about it let's move on.

1820
01:24:05,100 --> 01:24:07,950
Because it's easy to do that,
as a PM you can do that.

1821
01:24:07,950 --> 01:24:10,900
But your team is wounded, right?

1822
01:24:10,900 --> 01:24:12,720
And you need to get it healthy again.

1823
01:24:12,720 --> 01:24:15,750
So, you need to recognize that that
wound happened and stop it and

1824
01:24:15,750 --> 01:24:19,340
say wait a minute, wait, don't take
your idea back, it's a good idea.

1825
01:24:19,340 --> 01:24:23,150
Maybe you have an alpha personality,
you're steam rolling the other person,

1826
01:24:23,150 --> 01:24:24,720
the other person says, forget it.

1827
01:24:24,720 --> 01:24:25,930
Step in and champion that person.

1828
01:24:25,930 --> 01:24:27,200
Say, no, wait, that's a great idea.

1829
01:24:27,200 --> 01:24:29,560
Let's look at these on the merits.

1830
01:24:29,560 --> 01:24:30,930
Let's do the scorecard.

1831
01:24:30,930 --> 01:24:35,306
Let's do an anonymous decision cycle like
a Delphi, let's do something to make sure

1832
01:24:35,306 --> 01:24:38,430
that that's on the table and
then we'll make the decision.

1833
01:24:38,430 --> 01:24:41,578
And we may ultimately not choose their
way, but at least now we know why, right,

1834
01:24:41,578 --> 01:24:42,331
we had a document.

1835
01:24:42,331 --> 01:24:45,120
They could say all right,
I had my idea, it was a good idea, but

1836
01:24:45,120 --> 01:24:48,031
we went with the other guy's idea
because it was better, right?

1837
01:24:48,031 --> 01:24:50,410
And they understand that.

1838
01:24:50,410 --> 01:24:53,540
But if you just let them withdraw,
they don't know that.

1839
01:24:53,540 --> 01:24:55,790
And in their mind,
they had the right idea, and

1840
01:24:55,790 --> 01:24:59,210
in their mind they were wrong by the
project, by not moving forward with it.

1841
01:25:00,480 --> 01:25:05,340
The other one is smooth/accommodate.

1842
01:25:05,340 --> 01:25:11,310
With this one, you have the conflict,
you need to pick a solution.

1843
01:25:11,310 --> 01:25:16,930
So what you do is you pick a solution, and
then for the people who didn't succeed,

1844
01:25:16,930 --> 01:25:21,830
you start to highlight the part of
the solution that were in common, right?

1845
01:25:21,830 --> 01:25:22,950
Just the good parts.

1846
01:25:22,950 --> 01:25:26,660
You highlight the good, and
kinda push the bad under the rug.

1847
01:25:26,660 --> 01:25:29,920
And say look, I know it's not your
solution, but this one's pretty similar.

1848
01:25:29,920 --> 01:25:32,771
And yeah, it's got a lot of stuff
in common with what you had, and so

1849
01:25:32,771 --> 01:25:35,289
it's gonna work out well,
let's go this way, all right?

1850
01:25:35,289 --> 01:25:38,000
What you're doing when you do
smoothing and accommodating,

1851
01:25:38,000 --> 01:25:41,557
is you're not actually resolving the
problem, you're just trying to hide it.

1852
01:25:41,557 --> 01:25:47,354
And that's a really big problem
because when you hide the problem,

1853
01:25:47,354 --> 01:25:49,093
it's still there.

1854
01:25:49,093 --> 01:25:50,812
And sure it might go away for
a month or two but

1855
01:25:50,812 --> 01:25:52,309
then it's gonna pop back up later on.

1856
01:25:52,309 --> 01:25:55,176
And you're gonna say man,
we went with that EMC san,

1857
01:25:55,176 --> 01:25:57,788
I really thought we should
go with the HP san, and

1858
01:25:57,788 --> 01:26:02,154
I know they had some common features and
stuff but man, this problem stinks now.

1859
01:26:02,154 --> 01:26:03,460
I hate it!

1860
01:26:03,460 --> 01:26:05,692
If we had only gone HP, right?
Even though we made that decision

1861
01:26:05,692 --> 01:26:09,453
two months, that kind of thing start
to creep up and cause problems.

1862
01:26:09,453 --> 01:26:12,504
That's smooth and accomodating, and also
another one that you don't want to do.

1863
01:26:12,504 --> 01:26:16,344
>> A lot of times a smoothing and
accommodating for us really does come down

1864
01:26:16,344 --> 01:26:20,860
to not very effective, they are ready
to champion their bigger position.

1865
01:26:20,860 --> 01:26:24,300
But because I feel like that it would
be better harmony for the team and

1866
01:26:24,300 --> 01:26:28,180
then that compromise the overall project
deliverable that we might have instead.

1867
01:26:28,180 --> 01:26:32,640
That's why you go, oh, no,
that's exactly what I would rather do.

1868
01:26:32,640 --> 01:26:36,430
You may want that because it does provide
harmony, but it really doesn't provide

1869
01:26:36,430 --> 01:26:39,200
the overall project deliverable so,
let's understand that, too.

1870
01:26:40,320 --> 01:26:42,070
>> The next one is compromise/reconcile.

1871
01:26:42,070 --> 01:26:43,760
So no this is one you hear a lot.

1872
01:26:44,810 --> 01:26:46,182
This is where there's a conflict.

1873
01:26:46,182 --> 01:26:51,036
You have two parties that are in
disagreement, and you mediate,

1874
01:26:51,036 --> 01:26:54,030
you step in and
you get them both to compromise.

1875
01:26:54,030 --> 01:26:58,030
To come up with a single solution
that they're both happy with, right?

1876
01:26:58,030 --> 01:26:59,310
And it's not even about happiness,

1877
01:26:59,310 --> 01:27:01,450
the single solution that
they both can agree upon.

1878
01:27:02,510 --> 01:27:06,300
Now, on a positive side, you look at
this like, hey, I'm a great conflict

1879
01:27:06,300 --> 01:27:10,440
resolution person, I got these both
to agree on like terms, all right?

1880
01:27:10,440 --> 01:27:12,240
Here's the problem with compromise.

1881
01:27:12,240 --> 01:27:17,080
In a normal argument there's a winner and
a loser, and the winner is happy,

1882
01:27:17,080 --> 01:27:20,880
they got what they want, and the loser is
unhappy they didn't get what they want.

1883
01:27:20,880 --> 01:27:24,350
In a compromise,
there is no winner, right?

1884
01:27:24,350 --> 01:27:27,060
No one team got what they wanted.

1885
01:27:27,060 --> 01:27:30,550
So, in a compromise everyone's a loser.

1886
01:27:30,550 --> 01:27:33,750
Now the project as a whole may be a winner
cuz now you're moving forward, right?

1887
01:27:33,750 --> 01:27:37,463
But, the team members themselves
will not feel like they won.

1888
01:27:37,463 --> 01:27:40,080
They'll feel like we created a patchwork,

1889
01:27:40,080 --> 01:27:42,980
a hodgepodge of these
two different solutions,

1890
01:27:42,980 --> 01:27:48,170
taking what worked and not really getting
what was best about the two solutions.

1891
01:27:48,170 --> 01:27:53,565
It's hard to do a compromise where people
feel like it was the best decision.

1892
01:27:53,565 --> 01:27:58,264
Compromises, while they appear
attractive to us as a easy way to solve

1893
01:27:58,264 --> 01:28:02,422
a problem Really just kind of
creates that hidden animosity.

1894
01:28:02,422 --> 01:28:06,310
So a compromise, well you hear a lot
of people say it's perfectly fine,

1895
01:28:06,310 --> 01:28:08,160
is not a solution you want.

1896
01:28:08,160 --> 01:28:10,040
>> Yeah.
The problem also with a compromise,

1897
01:28:10,040 --> 01:28:12,310
is that once you make it
with one decision, right,

1898
01:28:12,310 --> 01:28:15,190
for your project,
the next one becomes easier.

1899
01:28:15,190 --> 01:28:17,750
Okay, and
then the following becomes even easier.

1900
01:28:17,750 --> 01:28:18,410
And all of a sudden,

1901
01:28:18,410 --> 01:28:22,420
once again now are overall quality of
our deliverable is not where we want it.

1902
01:28:22,420 --> 01:28:26,820
Or our project is not exactly where we
need to be, because we've now conceded so

1903
01:28:26,820 --> 01:28:29,030
often, and we've compromised so

1904
01:28:29,030 --> 01:28:32,250
often, we're really not even satisfied
with pushing for with the project.

1905
01:28:32,250 --> 01:28:32,860
>> Yeah, yeah.

1906
01:28:32,860 --> 01:28:34,640
And it's gotta lot of downstream problems.

1907
01:28:36,020 --> 01:28:38,294
The next one is Force/direct.

1908
01:28:38,294 --> 01:28:39,190
All right.

1909
01:28:39,190 --> 01:28:40,880
This is where there's a conflict.

1910
01:28:40,880 --> 01:28:44,280
You have two parties in disagreement, and
you step in as the project manager and

1911
01:28:44,280 --> 01:28:46,070
you say all right, here's how it is.

1912
01:28:46,070 --> 01:28:46,960
Right?

1913
01:28:46,960 --> 01:28:49,140
No more talking,
no more arguments, this is it.

1914
01:28:49,140 --> 01:28:50,920
This is the decision we're making.

1915
01:28:50,920 --> 01:28:52,210
We're moving forward.

1916
01:28:52,210 --> 01:28:53,090
All right?

1917
01:28:53,090 --> 01:28:56,290
On a positive side,
it solves the problem, doesn't it?

1918
01:28:56,290 --> 01:28:57,630
Right?
And gets the project moving in

1919
01:28:57,630 --> 01:28:59,090
the shortest amount of time.

1920
01:28:59,090 --> 01:29:03,860
On a negative side, the winners, the
people who's side you pick, they're fine.

1921
01:29:03,860 --> 01:29:05,760
But the other team is gonna feel slighted.

1922
01:29:05,760 --> 01:29:08,190
You didn't even bother to
listen to their argument.

1923
01:29:08,190 --> 01:29:11,280
You just cast it down and
moved on forward.

1924
01:29:11,280 --> 01:29:11,860
Right?

1925
01:29:11,860 --> 01:29:13,800
So while it might be what's best for

1926
01:29:13,800 --> 01:29:17,060
the project, it is gonna seed
some disharmony amongst the team.

1927
01:29:17,060 --> 01:29:18,750
So there we have a problem also, right,

1928
01:29:18,750 --> 01:29:22,590
that we basically are slighting
at least part of our team.

1929
01:29:22,590 --> 01:29:26,320
Yeah, and I hate to bring this up
again but again down the line right?

1930
01:29:26,320 --> 01:29:31,340
Once you use that human resource capital,
that idea of the good interpersonal

1931
01:29:31,340 --> 01:29:34,210
capital that you made with the team and
now you do this.

1932
01:29:34,210 --> 01:29:37,570
You've used up all that, and then next
time when it comes along and you do that,

1933
01:29:37,570 --> 01:29:41,560
it becomes much more difficult to enforce
what you feel like needs to be enforced,

1934
01:29:41,560 --> 01:29:45,030
because then people really
have that built up wall now.

1935
01:29:45,030 --> 01:29:46,780
They think that you're
going to treat them fairly.

1936
01:29:48,050 --> 01:29:51,970
So far we've gone through four solutions
and they've all been pretty bad, right?

1937
01:29:51,970 --> 01:29:55,500
And you guys, you're probably thinking
about past experiences right now, and

1938
01:29:55,500 --> 01:29:57,170
how you view this some of these four.

1939
01:29:57,170 --> 01:29:58,750
Well, its the fifth one.

1940
01:29:58,750 --> 01:30:02,830
That's the one we want to use,
which is collaborate/problem solve.

1941
01:30:03,890 --> 01:30:05,520
That means, collaborate.

1942
01:30:05,520 --> 01:30:08,616
Talk, exchange of information,
learn about both sides.

1943
01:30:08,616 --> 01:30:11,250
And then problem solve.

1944
01:30:11,250 --> 01:30:12,940
Figure out which one is the best.

1945
01:30:12,940 --> 01:30:15,690
And don't just like think about it,
and say yeah, I like that one.

1946
01:30:15,690 --> 01:30:16,730
It sounds better.

1947
01:30:16,730 --> 01:30:17,470
Quantify it.

1948
01:30:17,470 --> 01:30:18,000
Put it together.

1949
01:30:18,000 --> 01:30:19,620
Create scorecards.

1950
01:30:19,620 --> 01:30:20,680
Take a vote.

1951
01:30:20,680 --> 01:30:22,010
Do the Delphi technique.

1952
01:30:22,010 --> 01:30:22,630
Do whatever.

1953
01:30:22,630 --> 01:30:25,060
We talked about all of
those earlier in the show.

1954
01:30:25,060 --> 01:30:29,350
Figure out which method is the best
with a quantifiable means, right?

1955
01:30:29,350 --> 01:30:33,590
So that when you pick the winning team,
you know it's the right one, because it

1956
01:30:33,590 --> 01:30:37,130
got the best scores with the information
you had, it was the best decision.

1957
01:30:37,130 --> 01:30:41,030
And for the team that lost, the people who
are backing the wrong idea, they know why.

1958
01:30:41,030 --> 01:30:43,410
They can look at the scorecard and
they can say, well all right,

1959
01:30:43,410 --> 01:30:47,590
I can see why they chose to go that
way because of these various things.

1960
01:30:47,590 --> 01:30:48,630
We understand that.

1961
01:30:48,630 --> 01:30:51,980
We like this other idea, but
we understand why we're going this way.

1962
01:30:51,980 --> 01:30:55,960
That moment of creating understanding,
that moment of closure for people,

1963
01:30:55,960 --> 01:30:57,210
that's important.

1964
01:30:57,210 --> 01:31:00,840
Because now they don't feel like
we went with the wrong idea,

1965
01:31:00,840 --> 01:31:02,480
because we didn't have enough information.

1966
01:31:02,480 --> 01:31:04,520
We took the time to make the right call.

1967
01:31:04,520 --> 01:31:06,570
And you should be doing that anyway.

1968
01:31:06,570 --> 01:31:08,830
Any time you use your
decision making techniques,

1969
01:31:08,830 --> 01:31:10,340
this should be happening, right?

1970
01:31:10,340 --> 01:31:13,920
So you take a deep breath, you gather
the information from the people,

1971
01:31:13,920 --> 01:31:17,090
you hear both sides, you create
your scorecards, you quantify it,

1972
01:31:17,090 --> 01:31:19,170
and you come up with a solution.

1973
01:31:19,170 --> 01:31:22,505
People don't have to agree with it, but
they can understand why you made it,

1974
01:31:22,505 --> 01:31:24,305
and you can get the project
moving forward.

1975
01:31:24,305 --> 01:31:28,245
So that's the way that we wanna go.

1976
01:31:28,245 --> 01:31:31,035
All right, now there is one that
they don't really mention in here,

1977
01:31:31,035 --> 01:31:34,995
which is the postpone,
where you just delay.

1978
01:31:34,995 --> 01:31:36,575
When there is a problem,

1979
01:31:36,575 --> 01:31:40,025
as a project manager,
you really need to be very confrontive.

1980
01:31:40,025 --> 01:31:42,445
All right, when there's
a problem that needs a decision,

1981
01:31:42,445 --> 01:31:44,130
you need to step in and do it.

1982
01:31:44,130 --> 01:31:48,090
The longer you delay, the worse it's gonna
get, the harder it's gonna be to resolve.

1983
01:31:48,090 --> 01:31:51,410
So, if you're one of those that says, I'm
just gonna let it kind of work itself out.

1984
01:31:51,410 --> 01:31:52,630
Well, that's bad.

1985
01:31:52,630 --> 01:31:55,390
Because when it works itself out, it'll
work out using one of those four other

1986
01:31:55,390 --> 01:31:56,790
methods, and that's not what you want.

1987
01:31:56,790 --> 01:31:59,490
So you need to get in there and
confront the issue.

1988
01:31:59,490 --> 01:32:01,260
The sooner the better.

1989
01:32:01,260 --> 01:32:04,850
If you recognize somebody's performance
is dropping, don't just wait and

1990
01:32:04,850 --> 01:32:05,988
see if they pick back up.

1991
01:32:05,988 --> 01:32:06,850
They might, right?

1992
01:32:06,850 --> 01:32:08,090
But in the meantime,

1993
01:32:08,090 --> 01:32:10,920
you're wasting valuable time
while they're underperforming.

1994
01:32:10,920 --> 01:32:13,610
Step in, recognize it right away;
find out what the problem is.

1995
01:32:13,610 --> 01:32:15,160
There could be something very serious.

1996
01:32:15,160 --> 01:32:19,290
Maybe they had a relative pass away.

1997
01:32:19,290 --> 01:32:21,760
And so they're, they're obviously not
going to be very happy about that, and

1998
01:32:21,760 --> 01:32:24,240
it's going to affect their
workplace performance.

1999
01:32:24,240 --> 01:32:26,620
So if you know that,
you can say you know what?

2000
01:32:26,620 --> 01:32:27,570
Why don't you take a week off?

2001
01:32:27,570 --> 01:32:30,430
Take a week off, we'll bring somebody else
in, and the you can come back, you know,

2002
01:32:30,430 --> 01:32:32,930
take some time to collect yourself.

2003
01:32:32,930 --> 01:32:36,110
That way you can bring somebody else
in and cover them for that week.

2004
01:32:36,110 --> 01:32:39,620
If you just wait for them to pick back up
a week later, yeah they'll pick back up.

2005
01:32:39,620 --> 01:32:41,910
But you just gotta week
of poor performance.

2006
01:32:41,910 --> 01:32:43,440
Your project has been affected.

2007
01:32:43,440 --> 01:32:44,930
You want to take care of your people, but

2008
01:32:44,930 --> 01:32:46,530
you've got to take care of your project,
too.

2009
01:32:46,530 --> 01:32:48,430
So, you've gotta find
that healthy solution.

2010
01:32:50,910 --> 01:32:52,140
All right.

2011
01:32:52,140 --> 01:32:54,050
The other thing is just
interpersonal skills.

2012
01:32:54,050 --> 01:32:55,060
Right?
That's the other tool and

2013
01:32:55,060 --> 01:32:56,750
technique we have here.

2014
01:32:56,750 --> 01:32:59,170
And it really influences everything
that we've talked about so far.

2015
01:32:59,170 --> 01:33:01,080
You've got to be able to
communicate to people,

2016
01:33:01,080 --> 01:33:04,530
exchange information to find
out you know about the issues,

2017
01:33:04,530 --> 01:33:08,230
about the problems, how we make those
decisions, how we get informed.

2018
01:33:08,230 --> 01:33:10,950
The end result of this is usually
gonna be a change request.

2019
01:33:10,950 --> 01:33:12,990
Right?
We had to make a decision.

2020
01:33:12,990 --> 01:33:15,550
If we're making a decision
during the execution phase,

2021
01:33:15,550 --> 01:33:16,970
then it's something we didn't plan for.

2022
01:33:16,970 --> 01:33:18,980
All of our decisions
should already be made.

2023
01:33:18,980 --> 01:33:20,500
So if you're making
a decision at this point,

2024
01:33:20,500 --> 01:33:23,210
whatever you choose is gonna
result in a change request.

2025
01:33:23,210 --> 01:33:23,920
All right.

2026
01:33:23,920 --> 01:33:26,930
Hopefully it gets approved,
otherwise you're in bigger trouble.

2027
01:33:26,930 --> 01:33:29,480
But, it gets approved and
that becomes part of the project.

2028
01:33:29,480 --> 01:33:32,060
Some of the other things,
project management plan updates.

2029
01:33:32,060 --> 01:33:34,460
As we update with the information
that we've gathered.

2030
01:33:34,460 --> 01:33:37,580
Project document updates,
specifically the issue log, right?

2031
01:33:37,580 --> 01:33:40,020
Any decision needs to get
logged in the issue log.

2032
01:33:40,020 --> 01:33:43,600
Enterprise environmental factors and
organizational process updates,

2033
01:33:43,600 --> 01:33:49,090
those are all things that we may need to
do as a result of the output of this one.

2034
01:33:49,090 --> 01:33:51,720
All right, but
when we follow that procedure,

2035
01:33:51,720 --> 01:33:55,800
we should have a team that is performing,
operating at their optimal.

2036
01:33:55,800 --> 01:33:59,160
Even when a disagreement occurs,
because we resolve it quickly,

2037
01:33:59,160 --> 01:34:01,760
we continue to move forward, and
the team understands what's going on.

2038
01:34:01,760 --> 01:34:03,180
That's really what's important here.

2039
01:34:03,180 --> 01:34:03,850
>> Yeah.

2040
01:34:03,850 --> 01:34:07,510
This is where your leadership skills, and
your influence are really gonna shine

2041
01:34:07,510 --> 01:34:10,312
in the overall project when
you start doing this, right?

2042
01:34:10,312 --> 01:34:13,180
Your team will now start taking on
some of the characteristics that

2043
01:34:13,180 --> 01:34:17,040
you really do approve of, and
that you can actually use to influence and

2044
01:34:17,040 --> 01:34:19,650
to benefit the entire project here.

2045
01:34:19,650 --> 01:34:22,680
So doing the management
part of this project, or

2046
01:34:22,680 --> 01:34:27,500
the team building, is really kind of
where you have your biggest thumbprint

2047
01:34:27,500 --> 01:34:30,140
that you will have in terms of
getting done what you want done.

2048
01:34:30,140 --> 01:34:33,690
And so, do take the time to make sure you
take a look at this part of the process.

2049
01:34:34,790 --> 01:34:37,390
>> All right.
Well Ronnie, as far as the executing phase

2050
01:34:37,390 --> 01:34:41,490
goes, that pretty much wraps up the human
resource management knowledge area.

2051
01:34:42,900 --> 01:34:44,880
We still have some more to
talk about with executing.

2052
01:34:44,880 --> 01:34:48,090
We still have managed communications,
conduct procurements,

2053
01:34:48,090 --> 01:34:49,610
managed stakeholder engagement.

2054
01:34:49,610 --> 01:34:52,770
So we still have a few more on executing,
not too much more though and

2055
01:34:52,770 --> 01:34:56,100
you'll see a lot of what we've talked
about in executing is pretty common sense.

2056
01:34:56,100 --> 01:34:59,500
It's controlling where we'll get the real
work, so this is a pretty good spot for

2057
01:34:59,500 --> 01:35:00,930
us to stop and wrap up the show.

2058
01:35:00,930 --> 01:35:02,220
You got anything else to throw in, Ronnie?

2059
01:35:02,220 --> 01:35:03,200
>> No, I do not.

2060
01:35:03,200 --> 01:35:04,240
>> All right.

2061
01:35:04,240 --> 01:35:07,440
Ladies and gentlemen let me just
remind you that if you ever have any

2062
01:35:07,440 --> 01:35:10,740
questions on this, be sure to use us.

2063
01:35:10,740 --> 01:35:12,660
That's what we're here for.

2064
01:35:12,660 --> 01:35:15,000
Live during the show you can
go to itpro.tv/live, and

2065
01:35:15,000 --> 01:35:17,940
you'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

2066
01:35:17,940 --> 01:35:21,630
You can post your questions there; we
monitor and answer during the show.

2067
01:35:21,630 --> 01:35:24,840
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

2068
01:35:24,840 --> 01:35:26,840
There is a link at the top
of the page that says "Q&A".

2069
01:35:26,840 --> 01:35:28,560
Click on it, post your question there.

2070
01:35:28,560 --> 01:35:30,680
Again, we monitor and answer.

2071
01:35:30,680 --> 01:35:32,200
So, take advantage of that resource.

2072
01:35:32,200 --> 01:35:34,260
It is there for you.

2073
01:35:34,260 --> 01:35:35,880
All right, well,
I hope you've enjoyed the show.

2074
01:35:35,880 --> 01:35:37,550
Signing off for ITPro TV, I'm Don Pezet.

2075
01:35:37,550 --> 01:35:38,350
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

2076
01:35:38,350 --> 01:35:39,569
>> And we will see you next time.

2077
01:35:39,569 --> 01:35:49,569
[MUSIC].

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce the last few executing processes. They describe the tools and techniques used to manage communication during the project execution and what is needed to get contracts working during the project. The finish the show describing keeping the Stakeholders engaged with the project.
episodes.title: Executing Part 2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,664 --> 00:00:37,676
All right, good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening and welcome back to

3
00:00:37,676 --> 00:00:41,871
another episode of IT Pro TV I'm your host
Don Pezet backing you is Mr. Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:41,871 --> 00:00:42,730
How's it going Ronnie.

5
00:00:42,730 --> 00:00:43,930
>> I am disappointed.

6
00:00:43,930 --> 00:00:48,720
Last night the Emmy awards happened and
we did not receive any nomination for

7
00:00:48,720 --> 00:00:49,970
best comedy at all.

8
00:00:49,970 --> 00:00:50,880
>> Not even a nomination?

9
00:00:50,880 --> 00:00:52,693
>> Not even a nomination and
so I'm disappointed.

10
00:00:52,693 --> 00:00:54,521
>> Well you know I'm holding out for
the viewer's choice awards.

11
00:00:54,521 --> 00:00:56,120
>> Yes.

12
00:00:56,120 --> 00:00:57,150
>> Or cable ace?

13
00:00:57,150 --> 00:00:59,030
Cable ace is a cost issue.

14
00:00:59,030 --> 00:01:00,650
>> Oh, we'll have to work something out.

15
00:01:00,650 --> 00:01:02,590
>> We'll get Anna Ward
one day it'll happen.

16
00:01:02,590 --> 00:01:03,210
>> That's right.

17
00:01:03,210 --> 00:01:07,590
>> So until then,
let's keep up our broadcasting excellence,

18
00:01:07,590 --> 00:01:09,810
into the world of project management.

19
00:01:09,810 --> 00:01:13,790
So we're diving right back into the
executing process group, you'll remember

20
00:01:13,790 --> 00:01:16,610
we covered that in the last episode,
and we started moving through it.

21
00:01:16,610 --> 00:01:19,860
This is one of the lighter topics
because as a project manager,

22
00:01:19,860 --> 00:01:22,750
we're not typically the ones
doing the executing.

23
00:01:22,750 --> 00:01:26,780
So, really what it boils down to is
people taking what we did in our

24
00:01:26,780 --> 00:01:28,600
planning phase and applying it.

25
00:01:28,600 --> 00:01:30,280
And we just make sure they do it.

26
00:01:30,280 --> 00:01:33,019
Now most of what we do is happening
in the monitoring phase but

27
00:01:33,019 --> 00:01:36,691
we do still have a few more processes here
in executing that we need to talk about.

28
00:01:36,691 --> 00:01:37,339
All right.

29
00:01:37,339 --> 00:01:40,870
So, let me just bring up my handy PIN
block here and we'll take a look at those.

30
00:01:40,870 --> 00:01:43,540
So here we are in
the executing process group.

31
00:01:43,540 --> 00:01:46,630
And we covered these other processes
yesterday, so we developed our team and

32
00:01:46,630 --> 00:01:47,980
all that good stuff.

33
00:01:47,980 --> 00:01:51,010
Now we're ready to take a look
at managing our communications,

34
00:01:51,010 --> 00:01:54,690
conducting our procurements, and
managing our stakeholder engagement.

35
00:01:54,690 --> 00:01:58,474
All right, a lot of these
are centering around paperwork, right?

36
00:01:58,474 --> 00:01:59,124
>> That does, yeah.

37
00:01:59,124 --> 00:02:02,430
Unfortunately this is
the bureaucratic action of a project.

38
00:02:02,430 --> 00:02:08,520
Very important but kind of, not menial,
just mundane and redundant.

39
00:02:08,520 --> 00:02:10,640
>> Yeah, this is by far the process for

40
00:02:10,640 --> 00:02:15,040
us, that it requires us to be on the ball,
every time.

41
00:02:15,040 --> 00:02:18,210
So the good communications that we have
here, that's carried throughout the very

42
00:02:18,210 --> 00:02:21,660
time we begin the planning,
all the way through into the completion.

43
00:02:21,660 --> 00:02:25,240
So, this part of the process,
while not exciting, is very important,

44
00:02:25,240 --> 00:02:29,990
but it is so pervasive that you kind of
just bypass and go, we don't really care,

45
00:02:29,990 --> 00:02:31,240
cuz we're already good at it.

46
00:02:31,240 --> 00:02:35,180
But it is something we do focus in on,
because you're gonna see it on the PMP.

47
00:02:35,180 --> 00:02:37,100
>> All right, so
let's talk about managing communications.

48
00:02:37,100 --> 00:02:38,340
Let me bring up that process.

49
00:02:38,340 --> 00:02:39,390
Here we go.

50
00:02:39,390 --> 00:02:41,980
So when it comes to managing
communications, what we're talking about

51
00:02:41,980 --> 00:02:45,280
is in the planning phase we came
up with a communications plan.

52
00:02:45,280 --> 00:02:48,240
Now we need to make sure that it happens,
that it's being followed.

53
00:02:48,240 --> 00:02:51,310
We already know what stakeholders
need to be communicated with.

54
00:02:51,310 --> 00:02:54,240
We already know what ways they
want us to communicate with them.

55
00:02:54,240 --> 00:02:58,280
That was all set forth right
here in the communications plan.

56
00:02:58,280 --> 00:03:00,430
Now, what are we gonna
communicate to them?

57
00:03:00,430 --> 00:03:01,810
Well, then that was already communicated,
too, right?

58
00:03:01,810 --> 00:03:05,910
These are gonna be things like, progress
reports, status updates, change tickets,

59
00:03:05,910 --> 00:03:07,020
and information like that.

60
00:03:07,020 --> 00:03:08,890
Things that impact the project.

61
00:03:08,890 --> 00:03:11,310
Maybe it's something very,
very simple like just a status.

62
00:03:11,310 --> 00:03:13,830
Like hey, we're moving along,
things are going great.

63
00:03:13,830 --> 00:03:15,980
Or maybe it's something very,
very detailed.

64
00:03:15,980 --> 00:03:17,960
Here's the work that was
completed yesterday.

65
00:03:17,960 --> 00:03:20,430
Here's a summary of the activities and
events.

66
00:03:20,430 --> 00:03:22,010
Those are the things that we provide.

67
00:03:22,010 --> 00:03:26,560
So as an input, the main input that we
get here is the Work Performance Reports.

That's usually the status that we are

00:03:30,270 --> 00:03:34,200
And then our enterprise Environmental
Factors and Organizational Process Assets,

which encompass all the different means

71

the type of data we relay.

All defined by our company.

00:03:41,500 --> 00:03:43,950
>> Yeah, and
that work performance report for us,

00:03:43,950 --> 00:03:47,150
right, this is where we
again get whether or not

75
00:03:47,150 --> 00:03:51,840
the information coming in form those work

76
00:03:51,840 --> 00:03:54,920
And so that way we can adjust our

00:03:54,920 --> 00:03:57,160
be able to say whether we
need something done faster,

78
00:03:57,160 --> 00:03:59,340
or we can slow down on something her.

00:03:59,340 --> 00:04:02,910
And so it really is key that we take a

80
00:04:02,910 --> 00:04:04,710
It's always easy to have assumptions here.

81
00:04:04,710 --> 00:04:08,300
But those performance reports are how we
know that we're actually gonna be saying

00:04:08,300 --> 00:04:09,790
the right things at the right time.

00:04:09,790 --> 00:04:10,650
Yeah.
>> Yeah.

So, we're going to collect that data,

Because, you know,
a lot of times you get that data and

00:04:17,430 --> 00:04:20,370
We've got to interpret it in

And then we turn that into

00:04:23,890 --> 00:04:26,180
Those are our project communications.

90
00:04:26,180 --> 00:04:27,810
That's what we're sending
out to other people.

00:04:27,810 --> 00:04:33,610
Now to interpret the data we've got

00:04:33,610 --> 00:04:36,830
We put it into our various charts and

00:04:36,830 --> 00:04:38,570

94
00:04:38,570 --> 00:04:40,600
So let's take a look at some

00:04:40,600 --> 00:04:42,310
there's actually quite a few of them.

00:04:42,310 --> 00:04:44,190
They're broken out for
this particular process.

00:04:44,190 --> 00:04:47,690
Some of them are really straightforward

00:04:47,690 --> 00:04:48,300
What is that?

00:04:48,300 --> 00:04:52,090
Well, it's whatever you use to
communicate, do you use telephone calls?

00:04:52,090 --> 00:04:53,340

00:04:53,340 --> 00:04:55,520
Do you do web meetings,
like through WebEx?

00:04:55,520 --> 00:04:58,860

00:04:58,860 --> 00:04:59,940
Emails?

00:04:59,940 --> 00:05:00,780
Postal letter?

105
00:05:02,070 --> 00:05:04,870
In person meetings, whatever it
is that you use to communicate,

00:05:04,870 --> 00:05:06,740
that's your communication technology,
right?

107
00:05:06,740 --> 00:05:09,920
So, that's a tool of communication,
we use that.

00:05:09,920 --> 00:05:12,290
And, then, communication models, right?

00:05:12,290 --> 00:05:13,720
How do we communicate it out?

00:05:13,720 --> 00:05:15,830
Well, this might be

00:05:15,830 --> 00:05:18,470
I want to tell Ronnie something so

00:05:18,470 --> 00:05:22,820
Or if I want to tell the whole company,

00:05:22,820 --> 00:05:28,250
Edutainment Live, I want to tell all the
employees here that somethings going on.

So I can call an all hands meeting,

00:05:31,510 --> 00:05:34,330
that might not be realistic,

116
00:05:34,330 --> 00:05:39,280
So what we might want to do instead

117
00:05:39,280 --> 00:05:40,750
a communications tree, right?

00:05:40,750 --> 00:05:45,000
Where I talk to two people and those
two people talk to two people each, so

00:05:45,000 --> 00:05:48,520

00:05:48,520 --> 00:05:50,970
And that way, nobody's having to

121
00:05:50,970 --> 00:05:53,410
the entire company gets
notified pretty quickly.

122
00:05:53,410 --> 00:05:55,710
That is a communication model also.

123
00:05:55,710 --> 00:06:00,346
It's whatever you've designed to
work inside of your organization.

124
00:06:00,346 --> 00:06:02,417
That's kind of like a pyramid
scheme with communications.

125
00:06:02,417 --> 00:06:07,440
[LAUGH] So the method, it's up to you and

00:06:07,440 --> 00:06:09,260
In the PMBOK they list a bunch of them.

00:06:09,260 --> 00:06:11,300

00:06:11,300 --> 00:06:13,730
Hard copy documents like letters,

digital stuff like email,
electronic project management tools.

00:06:17,560 --> 00:06:19,040
I didn't mention that one.

If we have something like

employees are logging into

00:06:25,720 --> 00:06:29,880

134
00:06:29,880 --> 00:06:32,510
And then you can communicate
back again with reports and

135
00:06:32,510 --> 00:06:35,130
other information via that same PMIS.

136
00:06:35,130 --> 00:06:36,810
So you may or may not have that.

137
00:06:36,810 --> 00:06:39,180
All right.

138
00:06:39,180 --> 00:06:42,240
Now, the majority of what we're gonna be
communicating is performance reports, and

139
00:06:42,240 --> 00:06:45,440
performance reports, they make up, or

00:06:45,440 --> 00:06:47,560
they're built up of a lot
of different components.

00:06:47,560 --> 00:06:49,920
The main one that we think

00:06:49,920 --> 00:06:51,800
Analysis of past performance.

00:06:51,800 --> 00:06:52,300
Right?

144
00:06:52,300 --> 00:06:55,370
If I send you a status report today,
it's likely gonna have the last week or

00:06:55,370 --> 00:06:59,780
last month of activity and
show where we're at on our plan,

146
00:06:59,780 --> 00:07:03,430
on our schedule,
on our budget, on our scope.

147
00:07:03,430 --> 00:07:06,370
How many requirements have
we met of our project.

148
00:07:06,370 --> 00:07:07,450
These are things that people wanna know.

149
00:07:07,450 --> 00:07:09,750
They wanna know where we're at right now.

150
00:07:09,750 --> 00:07:11,630
So most of that is past performance.

151
00:07:12,750 --> 00:07:16,510
But to be truly useful,
you need to not just look at the past, but

00:07:16,510 --> 00:07:17,850
look at the future.

153
00:07:17,850 --> 00:07:21,680
You need to extrapolate that data and say,
all right, based on what we've done so

154
00:07:21,680 --> 00:07:27,180
far, if we continue at this pace, in the
future, we're gonna finish on schedule.

155
00:07:27,180 --> 00:07:27,720
All right.

156
00:07:27,720 --> 00:07:33,630
So, right now in the project I
am three days ahead of schedule.

157
00:07:33,630 --> 00:07:38,480
If we continue on that pace, we're going
to finish the project ahead of schedule.

158
00:07:38,480 --> 00:07:41,770
If I notice that each week, I'm getting a
little further, and a little further, and

00:07:41,770 --> 00:07:45,390
a little further behind, then I know
that if we continue on that pace,

00:07:45,390 --> 00:07:48,420

00:07:48,420 --> 00:07:51,770
Forecasting it forward

00:07:51,770 --> 00:07:53,766
If you tell somebody yeah,

They might thing, well that's no big deal.

That's just one day.

But, if it means we missed

That's a big deal, right?

We missed our date, so that's important.

We wanna forecast forward.

00:08:06,279 --> 00:08:10,059
All right, time and cost are the main ones

00:08:10,059 --> 00:08:13,155

don't forget your scope and requirements,

00:08:13,155 --> 00:08:17,168
that if you haven't met some, the thing

Some of the other things that

All of our risks, some of them we knew

The probabilities that are in

For example, if we're doing a outdoor.

Rock concert, right?

And we know there's

As we get closer to the actual event,

So saying now the odds

Now its 15%,

right, communicating a lot

Now, when we talk about analysis

includes work completed during the period,

So, they called us specifically here

I gave an example,

Right, we're saying what

What changes Right?

Now, this might not be something that

Maybe they don't need to know the brass

A lot of times we may see

So that's a nice little kinda gauge for

That's pretty important, too.

If you've done a change ticket,

00:10:50,200 --> 00:10:54,090

When you have an approved change,

00:10:56,430 --> 00:11:00,090

You don't want people acting under

Or congratulate so and so,

they just had a new baby right

00:12:16,400 --> 00:12:19,920
Whatever is relevant now you don't want

Right, because the more fluff, the more

So you want to be sure you convey

So that people aren't overwhelmed.

And that's a great point.

Sometimes we get so

Hey Ronnie, this is where its gonna affect
