doing proper communication.

300
00:13:58,570 --> 00:14:02,800
You shouldn't be communicating important
stuff with a happy birthday email, right?

301
00:14:02,800 --> 00:14:07,350
You know, so tacking a happy birthday onto
the end of a progress report is one thing,

302
00:14:07,350 --> 00:14:09,940
tacking a progress report onto a happy
birthday is a different thing, so

303
00:14:09,940 --> 00:14:14,400
make sure you've got your priorities
straight with your communications and

304
00:14:14,400 --> 00:14:17,396
don't try and connect to me on LinkedIn,
that's the other thing.

305
00:14:17,396 --> 00:14:19,704
Way is not to communicate with Don.

306
00:14:19,704 --> 00:14:23,073
>> [LAUGH]
>> LinkedIn, Facebook, off.

307
00:14:23,073 --> 00:14:24,400
[LAUGH] So

308
00:14:24,400 --> 00:14:30,750
those are some of the things we need to be
aware of with our communications process.

309
00:14:30,750 --> 00:14:32,290
There's a lot in there right?

310
00:14:32,290 --> 00:14:34,470
How we reach out to people and
communicate that.

311
00:14:34,470 --> 00:14:37,990
It's really just putting into
effect what we defined in our plan.

312
00:14:39,290 --> 00:14:43,610
Now on the output side, when we start
to provide this data to people Well,

313
00:14:43,610 --> 00:14:46,340
we're providing them typically with
project communications, right?

314
00:14:46,340 --> 00:14:49,400
The data that represents
how our project is doing.

315
00:14:49,400 --> 00:14:51,640
And these might be pie charts,
or Gantt charts.

316
00:14:51,640 --> 00:14:53,360
It might just be written emails.

317
00:14:53,360 --> 00:14:56,940
It's whatever you've decided
to use inside of your project.

318
00:14:56,940 --> 00:14:59,900
The other outputs that we
might have are updates.

319
00:14:59,900 --> 00:15:02,790
As we communicate with people,
we find out information.

320
00:15:02,790 --> 00:15:05,650
We find Find out additional
things like status updates.

321
00:15:05,650 --> 00:15:09,990
They may say, you flagged this
activity as complete in this email but

322
00:15:09,990 --> 00:15:12,560
it's actually not complete,
we still have all this to do.

323
00:15:12,560 --> 00:15:15,750
That might result in
project document updates or

324
00:15:15,750 --> 00:15:17,560
organizational process asset updates.

325
00:15:17,560 --> 00:15:18,520
Things like that.

326
00:15:18,520 --> 00:15:21,690
As you learn and
develop from your communications.

327
00:15:23,920 --> 00:15:26,890
So that's pretty much the managed
communications process.

328
00:15:26,890 --> 00:15:29,760
There's not all that much to it
in the general scheme of things,

329
00:15:29,760 --> 00:15:31,320
just applying your plan.

330
00:15:33,730 --> 00:15:37,350
Another one that we've got that's pretty
straightforward is conduct procurements.

331
00:15:37,350 --> 00:15:43,570
In the planning phase, we came up with
our various contract types and things

332
00:15:43,570 --> 00:15:47,480
that we might wanna engage in with third
parties to operate inside of our project.

333
00:15:47,480 --> 00:15:49,710
Well, those are our procurements.

334
00:15:49,710 --> 00:15:54,276
And when we get into the executing phase,
now it's time to execute these.

335
00:15:54,276 --> 00:15:57,560
And when it comes to the executing phase,
I know I mentioned in an earlier episode

336
00:15:57,560 --> 00:15:59,992
that sometimes The executing
phase gets a little blurred.

337
00:15:59,992 --> 00:16:01,873
That the planning phase and

338
00:16:01,873 --> 00:16:06,710
the executing phase might actually
overlap a little bit, all right?

339
00:16:06,710 --> 00:16:08,350
And that sounds counterintuitive.

340
00:16:08,350 --> 00:16:11,690
How can I be planning and
executing at the same time?

341
00:16:11,690 --> 00:16:14,530
And I know we have things
like rolling wave planning,

342
00:16:14,530 --> 00:16:19,240
where you're always planning even while
executing for really long term projects.

343
00:16:19,240 --> 00:16:24,270
But even in a normal small project,
if you're gonna be engaging in contracts,

344
00:16:24,270 --> 00:16:28,720
a lot of times we will initiate those
contracts while we're still planning

345
00:16:28,720 --> 00:16:32,330
because the terms of the contract may
affect things like our schedule, okay.

346
00:16:32,330 --> 00:16:34,810
So for example, let's say that
we're gonna be building a house.

347
00:16:34,810 --> 00:16:37,710
And I know that we need drywall put in,
and I know that I can't do it.

348
00:16:37,710 --> 00:16:39,860
So I know I'm gonna subcontract that out.

349
00:16:39,860 --> 00:16:41,300
So I reach out to a contractor.

350
00:16:41,300 --> 00:16:43,820
Now, in my planning phase I
defined that procurement.

351
00:16:43,820 --> 00:16:45,030
I say, all right,
here's how we're gonna do it.

352
00:16:45,030 --> 00:16:46,793
We're gonna do a request for bid, and

353
00:16:46,793 --> 00:16:50,054
we're gonna have various drywall
contractors come and give me bids.

354
00:16:50,054 --> 00:16:54,340
And I'll pick the winning bid, and
that's who I'm gonna contract with, right?

355
00:16:54,340 --> 00:16:56,130
We define all that in planning.

356
00:16:56,130 --> 00:16:59,160
And actually sending out the RFPs,

357
00:16:59,160 --> 00:17:02,075
actually doing that,
is part of the executing phase.

358
00:17:02,075 --> 00:17:05,461
So I might stop right there in my plan and
say, all right, let's finish planning and

359
00:17:05,461 --> 00:17:07,195
then go into executing.

360
00:17:07,195 --> 00:17:09,969
The problem is when we do that,
I pick my winning big, and I say, okay,

361
00:17:09,969 --> 00:17:11,844
you're the company I
want to do business with.

362
00:17:11,844 --> 00:17:13,695
Right, I'm in executing.

363
00:17:13,695 --> 00:17:16,414
I say I want to do business with you,
and they say, okay,

364
00:17:16,414 --> 00:17:18,529
our next availability is December 12th.

365
00:17:18,529 --> 00:17:22,605
And I look at my calendar and I'm like,
oh, my goodness we're in August right now.

366
00:17:22,605 --> 00:17:24,260
That's months away.

367
00:17:24,260 --> 00:17:25,510
That's the earliest you can do it?

368
00:17:25,510 --> 00:17:30,430
And they say, yeah, we're the best and
we're the cheapest, so we're busy, right?

369
00:17:30,430 --> 00:17:31,690
And it's gonna be December.

370
00:17:31,690 --> 00:17:34,237
So now I've gotta go back and
retool my schedule around that, and say,

371
00:17:34,237 --> 00:17:36,926
well crap, if I wanna use those guys,
I'm gonna have to wait a few months.

372
00:17:36,926 --> 00:17:39,250
I'm gonna have to extend out my schedule.

373
00:17:39,250 --> 00:17:43,550
So because contract can influence
your schedule and your budget and

374
00:17:43,550 --> 00:17:46,790
things like that, a lot of times
we'll engage in those contracts,

375
00:17:46,790 --> 00:17:50,940
we'll engage in those procurements
while we're still in planning so

376
00:17:50,940 --> 00:17:52,840
that we can plan around those resources.

377
00:17:52,840 --> 00:17:57,910
So this is one of those gray areas
where we start to get overlap between

378
00:17:57,910 --> 00:18:01,390
the process of the phases, right.

379
00:18:01,390 --> 00:18:03,900
So let's go back into
conduct procurements, right.

380
00:18:03,900 --> 00:18:05,576
We had a procurement plan, and

381
00:18:05,576 --> 00:18:09,455
the plan stated how we were going
to engage these contractors, right.

382
00:18:09,455 --> 00:18:13,198
If we already had somebody selected,
if we already had other things that were

383
00:18:13,198 --> 00:18:16,340
defined, then there's not
a whole lot of work to do here.

384
00:18:16,340 --> 00:18:19,230
But if there was a selection process,
and that selection process

385
00:18:19,230 --> 00:18:22,090
was defined in there and
here's where we go about that process.

386
00:18:23,230 --> 00:18:25,820
Some of the other inputs
that we're gonna use here,

387
00:18:25,820 --> 00:18:28,070
we might already have
procurement documents drawn up.

388
00:18:29,080 --> 00:18:33,420
We might already have a contract
in hand ready to be executed.

389
00:18:33,420 --> 00:18:35,130
This is when we need the contract.

390
00:18:35,130 --> 00:18:36,950
We need to go in and
get it and get ready for that.

391
00:18:36,950 --> 00:18:39,100
We may have quotes some people
already generated, right?

392
00:18:39,100 --> 00:18:42,480
These are all things that
are going to be inputs, all right.

393
00:18:42,480 --> 00:18:45,480
Then, source selection criteria, right?

394
00:18:45,480 --> 00:18:48,696
When we go to pick somebody as
a contractor, we have multiple,

395
00:18:48,696 --> 00:18:50,650
they're called sources, right.

396
00:18:50,650 --> 00:18:54,040
We have,
let me clarify this terminology here.

397
00:18:54,040 --> 00:18:56,860
If you were certified in
a previous version of the PMBOK

398
00:18:56,860 --> 00:18:58,200
they used to be called sellers.

399
00:18:58,200 --> 00:19:02,069
And so we had what was called the select
seller process, and that's all gone now.

400
00:19:02,069 --> 00:19:05,420
And it's called procurements, and so
the terminology, it's a little weird.

401
00:19:05,420 --> 00:19:09,400
So see how I've got like seller proposals
here and source selection criteria.

402
00:19:09,400 --> 00:19:12,640
This used to be seller selection criteria,
that we'd actually pick who was going to

403
00:19:12,640 --> 00:19:14,590
be the seller,
who was going to sell us that good.

404
00:19:14,590 --> 00:19:18,407
But the thing is, the terminology is
just weird for services and stuff.

405
00:19:18,407 --> 00:19:21,110
So, now it's the source selection.

406
00:19:21,110 --> 00:19:25,230
Who is going to be the source for this
product or service that we need, right?

407
00:19:25,230 --> 00:19:26,460
Which source are we going to use?

408
00:19:26,460 --> 00:19:29,140
What are the selection criteria, right?

409
00:19:29,140 --> 00:19:30,592
And do we break those down in the notes?

410
00:19:30,592 --> 00:19:31,968
>> Yep, we do.
>> Let's pull that up.

411
00:19:31,968 --> 00:19:34,880
Procurement, here we go.

412
00:19:34,880 --> 00:19:37,600
So under source selection criteria,
how do we make that decision?

413
00:19:37,600 --> 00:19:41,410
How do we pick who's going to be
the person who provides us that service?

414
00:19:42,530 --> 00:19:44,500
>> That first one there,
on the capabilities, right?

415
00:19:44,500 --> 00:19:48,100
A lot of times you have a company,
and you go, I know I want to use this.

416
00:19:48,100 --> 00:19:49,910
But then you talk to them about it, and

417
00:19:49,910 --> 00:19:53,710
all of a sudden you realize they can do
part of the job, but not the whole thing.

418
00:19:53,710 --> 00:19:55,495
As much as you like the company,
you've got to say, well,

419
00:19:55,495 --> 00:19:57,125
they just don't meet
the capabilities that we need.

420
00:19:57,125 --> 00:20:00,401
And so sometimes that happens, where
you know that that's what you want to

421
00:20:00,401 --> 00:20:02,698
work with, but they just go,
look, I can't do it.

422
00:20:02,698 --> 00:20:06,187
So, again, that's one of the selection
criteria that we have to be aware.

423
00:20:06,187 --> 00:20:08,620
>> We see it in IT all the time.

424
00:20:08,620 --> 00:20:09,954
It's different in other industries.

425
00:20:09,954 --> 00:20:14,783
But in IT If you need a development
project, if you need to somebody to write

426
00:20:14,783 --> 00:20:20,090
software for you and you reach out to a
contractor, IT contractors hate to say no.

427
00:20:20,090 --> 00:20:25,440
They almost never say no, because what
they do is, if they can't do something,

428
00:20:25,440 --> 00:20:28,880
they turn around and subcontract it
out themselves to somebody else.

429
00:20:28,880 --> 00:20:30,300
They do that all the time.

430
00:20:30,300 --> 00:20:35,160
It's just, I don't know, it's
something in the way they do business.

431
00:20:35,160 --> 00:20:36,140
It's not nice.

432
00:20:36,140 --> 00:20:39,920
So, we need to make sure we understand
what their capabilities are actually of.

433
00:20:39,920 --> 00:20:42,770
And I don't remember if I
told this story or not,

434
00:20:42,770 --> 00:20:47,400
cuz I had a mentor that taught me a lot
about project management years ago.

435
00:20:47,400 --> 00:20:49,179
And he showed me that
this trick that he used.

436
00:20:49,179 --> 00:20:53,376
And whenever he would write up a
requirement sheet, cuz when you engage in

437
00:20:53,376 --> 00:20:57,316
a contract like this, you're gonna
do a statement of work, an SOW.

438
00:20:57,316 --> 00:21:00,790
And this statement of work says
here's what I need you to do, right?

439
00:21:00,790 --> 00:21:01,850
Can you do it?

440
00:21:01,850 --> 00:21:03,390
And then if you can, let's sign off on it.

441
00:21:03,390 --> 00:21:04,480
That's what you're gonna do.

442
00:21:04,480 --> 00:21:07,840
And he had found for years that he
would write these statements of work.

443
00:21:07,840 --> 00:21:10,820
People would say they could do stuff,
and then it would turn out it couldn't.

444
00:21:10,820 --> 00:21:13,361
So what he did is he made
up a software product.

445
00:21:13,361 --> 00:21:14,837
All right,
I can't remember what it was called.

446
00:21:14,837 --> 00:21:16,665
It was like Star Database or
something like that.

447
00:21:16,665 --> 00:21:21,725
And he would put on there, must be able
to integrate with Star Database 5.2.

448
00:21:21,725 --> 00:21:25,093
And it was a made up
product that didn't exist.

449
00:21:25,093 --> 00:21:28,227
And he would send out this RFB or
whatever, RFQ,

450
00:21:28,227 --> 00:21:30,301
whatever you're sending out.

451
00:21:30,301 --> 00:21:34,044
And when he'd get replies back, he would
find where a lot of people would say, yes,

452
00:21:34,044 --> 00:21:35,935
we can integrate with that.

453
00:21:35,935 --> 00:21:37,365
And it's not a real product.

454
00:21:37,365 --> 00:21:38,385
So you knew what they were saying.

455
00:21:38,385 --> 00:21:42,740
What they were saying was, we can do it
if we get paid more to develop it, or

456
00:21:42,740 --> 00:21:44,310
we subcontract it out.

457
00:21:44,310 --> 00:21:46,149
And the people who said they couldn't
do it, he would say all right,

458
00:21:46,149 --> 00:21:47,846
these are people who are properly
reflecting what they can do.

459
00:21:47,846 --> 00:21:50,920
So little things like that can help.

460
00:21:50,920 --> 00:21:55,450
It's a shame you have to do that stuff,
but it does work.

461
00:21:55,450 --> 00:21:57,120
So capabilities are important.

462
00:21:57,120 --> 00:21:59,278
Capacity is another one, right.

463
00:21:59,278 --> 00:22:05,360
I might have one contract web
developer that I know is brilliant,

464
00:22:05,360 --> 00:22:08,890
just a genius,
can do everything that I need.

465
00:22:08,890 --> 00:22:10,035
But it's one person.

466
00:22:10,035 --> 00:22:14,250
And I might have so
much work that one person can't do it.

467
00:22:14,250 --> 00:22:17,040
Then I need a team of ten
people working on it.

468
00:22:17,040 --> 00:22:18,410
When I contract this out,

469
00:22:18,410 --> 00:22:21,850
I need a real organization
that's got a lot of employees.

470
00:22:21,850 --> 00:22:23,140
Now, on the Internet it's tough.

471
00:22:23,140 --> 00:22:25,890
You see all these companies, they
might have a really nice web page, but

472
00:22:25,890 --> 00:22:28,760
it turns out it's just one
person running the show.

473
00:22:28,760 --> 00:22:30,530
And so you look at this product and
you're like, wow,

474
00:22:30,530 --> 00:22:31,885
that product could really do what I want.

475
00:22:31,885 --> 00:22:36,120
But it's one person, and
it's just not gonna fly.

476
00:22:36,120 --> 00:22:38,610
So, we need to make sure
they have the capacity

477
00:22:38,610 --> 00:22:40,260
to handle the workload
that we have got here.

478
00:22:40,260 --> 00:22:41,490
Do they have enough employees?

479
00:22:43,090 --> 00:22:44,340
Delivery dates, that's another one, right.

480
00:22:44,340 --> 00:22:46,140
I mentioned that one earlier.

481
00:22:46,140 --> 00:22:49,134
If we're gonna be contracting out to
somebody for a good or a service,

482
00:22:49,134 --> 00:22:50,728
we need it by a certain time, right.

483
00:22:50,728 --> 00:22:54,640
Are they gonna be able to do that
in the time that I need, right.

484
00:22:54,640 --> 00:22:59,426
When you start shopping for
the lowest price, I know computers, right.

485
00:22:59,426 --> 00:23:03,164
I know for a fact that I can
order a computer from China and

486
00:23:03,164 --> 00:23:06,610
get it cheaper than if
I buy one from here.

487
00:23:06,610 --> 00:23:07,666
But I know if I order it from China,

488
00:23:07,666 --> 00:23:09,500
there's gonna be a three week
shipping time on it, right.

489
00:23:09,500 --> 00:23:11,630
And that may be too long.

490
00:23:11,630 --> 00:23:15,120
So, those are some of the things
that we have to be aware of.

491
00:23:15,120 --> 00:23:16,590
Product cost.

492
00:23:16,590 --> 00:23:18,470
Cost, in my opinion,

493
00:23:18,470 --> 00:23:22,330
should not be the number one deciding
factor when you're doing a contract.

494
00:23:22,330 --> 00:23:23,695
But for most people it is.

495
00:23:23,695 --> 00:23:25,940
Right, so that cost becomes really,
really important.

496
00:23:25,940 --> 00:23:28,046
How much is it gonna cost to
use that particular contractor?

497
00:23:28,046 --> 00:23:32,586
The reason I say it shouldn't be is
when you go for the lowest bidder,

498
00:23:32,586 --> 00:23:37,310
you're sacrificing things like quality,
right, and reliability.

499
00:23:37,310 --> 00:23:40,220
That's what gets sacrificed
to get that lower price.

500
00:23:40,220 --> 00:23:42,240
And so it may or may not be the way to go.

501
00:23:43,870 --> 00:23:45,440
Life cycle cost.

502
00:23:45,440 --> 00:23:49,371
When you buy something, or purchase a
service, they're normally quoting you for

503
00:23:49,371 --> 00:23:52,685
the initial installation or
implementation of whatever that is, but

504
00:23:52,685 --> 00:23:55,064
there's usually ongoing maintenance,
right.

505
00:23:55,064 --> 00:23:58,805
If you buy a vehicle,
there's a vehicle cost.

506
00:23:58,805 --> 00:24:02,091
But then there's maintenance to keep
it running, fuel to keep it running.

507
00:24:02,091 --> 00:24:04,603
All of that stuff adds
to that cost over time.

508
00:24:04,603 --> 00:24:08,454
With software products Updates, upgrades,
right, supporting new operating systems,

509
00:24:08,454 --> 00:24:09,664
supporting new databases.

510
00:24:09,664 --> 00:24:11,780
That all requires additional development.

511
00:24:11,780 --> 00:24:14,000
So what are the back-end costs?

512
00:24:14,000 --> 00:24:17,933
What's the cost gonna be over the long
run of utilizing that service or product?

513
00:24:20,898 --> 00:24:22,660
All right, technical expertise.

514
00:24:24,690 --> 00:24:28,061
Do they actually specialize
in what it is that you need?

515
00:24:28,061 --> 00:24:31,590
All right, because there are a lot
of people that have general

516
00:24:31,590 --> 00:24:34,010
knowledge that can do a lot
of different things, but

517
00:24:34,010 --> 00:24:37,231
do they specialize in what you want,
all right.

518
00:24:37,231 --> 00:24:40,937
For example, we use ITProTV
because I went through this way

519
00:24:40,937 --> 00:24:43,767
back when we first opened
up on the Internet.

520
00:24:43,767 --> 00:24:46,450
We decided that we wanted
to do a Roku channel.

521
00:24:46,450 --> 00:24:49,720
And we've had our Roku channel for
a long time now, and it's very stable and

522
00:24:49,720 --> 00:24:50,730
works great.

523
00:24:50,730 --> 00:24:52,117
But in the early days it didn't, right?

524
00:24:52,117 --> 00:24:57,510
In the first roll out of that Roku
channel, this was well over a year ago.

525
00:24:57,510 --> 00:24:58,653
It was a little bit iffy.

526
00:24:58,653 --> 00:25:01,060
Sometimes the videos wouldn't play and
stuff.

527
00:25:01,060 --> 00:25:04,340
What was happening was we were
using a video hosting provider.

528
00:25:04,340 --> 00:25:07,250
They hosted videos,
it's what they did, right.

529
00:25:07,250 --> 00:25:10,000
But they didn't really have a lot
of experience with the Roku.

530
00:25:10,000 --> 00:25:12,400
And the Roku boxes had
some weird requirements,

531
00:25:12,400 --> 00:25:16,490
and it was causing videos to stop playing
halfway through and things like that.

532
00:25:16,490 --> 00:25:21,790
So we ended up going with another video
provider that actually had expertise

533
00:25:21,790 --> 00:25:25,650
in the Roku device itself, and they said,
all right, we can directly support that.

534
00:25:25,650 --> 00:25:26,860
Yeah, there are some weird caveats.

535
00:25:26,860 --> 00:25:28,180
We know how to deal with it.

536
00:25:28,180 --> 00:25:31,960
And by going to them,
now our Roku channel is rock solid, right?

537
00:25:31,960 --> 00:25:34,410
So we went with people that were
really good in video hosting, but

538
00:25:34,410 --> 00:25:38,740
we needed somebody who was a specialist,
that has that technical expertise

539
00:25:38,740 --> 00:25:43,610
in that particular area that we needed,
all right.

540
00:25:43,610 --> 00:25:46,500
And then the last part here is
the approach to the contract, right.

541
00:25:46,500 --> 00:25:50,530
In the planning phase, we talk about the
different contracts that were out there,

542
00:25:50,530 --> 00:25:56,120
like the Cost Plus and
other contract types like that.

543
00:25:56,120 --> 00:25:59,100
So which contract type
are they wanting to sign?

544
00:25:59,100 --> 00:26:01,866
If it's a flat-fee contract
that's nice and safe for you.

545
00:26:01,866 --> 00:26:05,115
And so you might prefer that over
somebody who is doing a time and

546
00:26:05,115 --> 00:26:09,225
materials contract or something that's
a little bit more nebulous on what that

547
00:26:09,225 --> 00:26:11,010
final price is going to be.

548
00:26:11,010 --> 00:26:15,550
So that's another weighing factor in
which person you're going to pick,

549
00:26:15,550 --> 00:26:18,475
which source you're going to go with for
engaging in that contract.

550
00:26:18,475 --> 00:26:23,400
So, what we'll normally do is we'll
normally take these categories, and

551
00:26:23,400 --> 00:26:26,060
we'll assign a priority to them, right.

552
00:26:26,060 --> 00:26:27,800
What's the most important to us?

553
00:26:27,800 --> 00:26:29,330
Is cost the most important?

554
00:26:29,330 --> 00:26:31,450
Then we make that our number one category,
right?

555
00:26:31,450 --> 00:26:34,660
Is capability or technical expertise,
is that second place?

556
00:26:34,660 --> 00:26:36,570
We make that number two, and so on.

557
00:26:36,570 --> 00:26:41,330
And then we score all of our
submitted contracts that come in,

558
00:26:41,330 --> 00:26:42,580
all the proposed contracts.

559
00:26:42,580 --> 00:26:45,130
We score them based on
this little score sheet.

560
00:26:45,130 --> 00:26:47,068
And, we can then compare them, right.

561
00:26:47,068 --> 00:26:48,404
You quantify, you give them a number so

562
00:26:48,404 --> 00:26:50,730
you can compare them together
to figure out who is the best.

563
00:26:50,730 --> 00:26:53,450
This are generally the criteria
we're looking for.

564
00:26:53,450 --> 00:26:56,010
>> This particular process, once you
actually start getting several of them in

565
00:26:56,010 --> 00:26:59,150
hand, this is where it takes
even more time, right?

566
00:26:59,150 --> 00:27:00,870
You already know what your
criteria is going to be.

567
00:27:00,870 --> 00:27:03,564
And then once you actually get that
information out to your sellers,

568
00:27:03,564 --> 00:27:05,747
whoever is actually trying
to provide you the service,

569
00:27:05,747 --> 00:27:07,892
that's when it actually takes a little but
more time.

570
00:27:07,892 --> 00:27:09,700
Because all of a sudden you get two or
three that,

571
00:27:09,700 --> 00:27:11,850
all of a sudden the score
sheet's almost identical.

572
00:27:11,850 --> 00:27:14,700
And now you're like, okay,
what's going to be the determining factor?

573
00:27:14,700 --> 00:27:17,400
And then, that's actually when it
gets a little more complicated.

574
00:27:17,400 --> 00:27:18,670
But this is part of that process.

575
00:27:18,670 --> 00:27:20,470
We have to go through it,
have to be able to actually go,

576
00:27:20,470 --> 00:27:22,900
okay, here's what our
deciding factor's gonna be.

577
00:27:22,900 --> 00:27:25,380
And this is what we have
in terms of most important.

578
00:27:25,380 --> 00:27:26,670
>> Yep.
>> Yep.

579
00:27:26,670 --> 00:27:29,890
>> All right, well, we've got a lot
more to talk about on procurements.

00:27:29,890 --> 00:27:32,583
We're gonna get into some of the other
components we need to worry about and

581
00:27:32,583 --> 00:27:35,295
some of the different things that go
in our statements of work and all that.

582
00:27:35,295 --> 00:27:36,690
That's really important.

583
00:27:36,690 --> 00:27:39,450
But this is a pretty good spot for
us to stop and take a break.

00:27:39,450 --> 00:27:40,199
So why don't we take a pause here.

00:27:40,199 --> 00:27:43,566
When we get back,
more procurement management after this.

So before the break we were talking

00:27:58,130 --> 00:28:00,460
And I mention how we use a score, and

00:28:00,460 --> 00:28:02,520
I wanted to show everybody
an example of that.

00:28:02,520 --> 00:28:05,560
So I've got one of our little

592
00:28:05,560 --> 00:28:08,790
this is the source selection
criteria template.

593
00:28:08,790 --> 00:28:11,660
And basically what we do is
we weigh our criteria, and

594
00:28:11,660 --> 00:28:14,750
those were all the things that we
were talking about before the break.

595
00:28:14,750 --> 00:28:19,665
That was things like capabilities,
capacity, delivery dates, and so on.

596
00:28:19,665 --> 00:28:23,415
They can be really general like this,
or they can be extremely specific,

597
00:28:23,415 --> 00:28:24,631
based on what you need.

598
00:28:24,631 --> 00:28:28,479
And I know I talked about this in the
planning phase, but just to kind of recap.

599
00:28:28,479 --> 00:28:32,562
So, one project that I
worked on was building

600
00:28:32,562 --> 00:28:37,440
a disaster recovery center for
an organization.

601
00:28:37,440 --> 00:28:41,075
And so we had to choose from several
different centers that we could

602
00:28:41,075 --> 00:28:42,510
co-locate with.

603
00:28:42,510 --> 00:28:47,113
So we came up with some criteria, and
one criteria was must have multiple ISPs,

604
00:28:47,113 --> 00:28:49,112
multiple internet connections.

605
00:28:49,112 --> 00:28:51,510
I can't even type it.

606
00:28:51,510 --> 00:28:55,920
So must have multiple internet
connections, another one was, must have

607
00:28:57,080 --> 00:29:01,510
secured, redundant power, was another one.

608
00:29:02,600 --> 00:29:03,910
A lot of places will have generators,

609
00:29:03,910 --> 00:29:07,510
but they're just on the outside of
the building and not necessarily secured.

610
00:29:07,510 --> 00:29:13,888
We had another one,
which was separate tectonic plates.

611
00:29:15,869 --> 00:29:17,970
How do you even spell tectonic?

612
00:29:17,970 --> 00:29:18,820
Apparently not like that.

613
00:29:18,820 --> 00:29:20,970
Techtronic, that's not what I wanted.

614
00:29:20,970 --> 00:29:23,440
So anyhow, separate tectonic plate.

615
00:29:23,440 --> 00:29:26,490
We had these different requirements,
oh, no H I guess.

616
00:29:27,518 --> 00:29:29,780
So we had these different requirements
that were important for us for

617
00:29:29,780 --> 00:29:33,610
these disaster recovery facilities,
to make sure that they met our needs.

618
00:29:33,610 --> 00:29:36,820
We needed multiple ISPs because
we were an Internet company, and

619
00:29:36,820 --> 00:29:40,920
if the Internet connection failed,
we still needed to have service, right.

620
00:29:40,920 --> 00:29:42,930
Secured redundant power, well,

621
00:29:42,930 --> 00:29:46,860
just like the Internet, you need power
otherwise your servers aren't gonna work.

622
00:29:46,860 --> 00:29:50,160
And then the separate tectonic plate,
we were in Washington State.

623
00:29:50,160 --> 00:29:51,876
You have earthquakes on
the West Coast of the United States.

624
00:29:51,876 --> 00:29:54,962
And so if an earthquake hits and
it affects your center or

625
00:29:54,962 --> 00:29:59,627
something, your disaster recovery center
should be in a different area unaffected

626
00:29:59,627 --> 00:30:02,900
by that same disaster,
so, a separate plate.

627
00:30:02,900 --> 00:30:07,481
Now, what we did is we ranked each of our
candidates on a score of one to five,

628
00:30:07,481 --> 00:30:11,418
all right, where one meant that
they didn't meet our needs, and

629
00:30:11,418 --> 00:30:14,445
five meant that they exceeded our needs,
right.

630
00:30:14,445 --> 00:30:17,390
A three was that they just met our needs.

631
00:30:17,390 --> 00:30:19,150
That was kind of how we gauged it.

632
00:30:19,150 --> 00:30:22,240
So when we reach out to the candidates,
we might find

633
00:30:22,240 --> 00:30:26,940
Candidate 1 might just have two
Internet connections, all right.

634
00:30:26,940 --> 00:30:29,320
So they're redundant.
They meet our needs, 3.

635
00:30:29,320 --> 00:30:32,260
But Candidate 2 might have
five internet connections.

636
00:30:32,260 --> 00:30:33,235
They exceed our need.

637
00:30:33,235 --> 00:30:36,860
You have connections through multiple
ISPs, so we might go all the way up.

638
00:30:36,860 --> 00:30:39,080
Candidate 3, on the other hand,
might only have,

639
00:30:39,080 --> 00:30:41,120
let's say three Internet connections.

640
00:30:41,120 --> 00:30:44,460
So they exceed our need, but
it's not exceptional, so

641
00:30:44,460 --> 00:30:46,970
maybe I give them a score of 4, right?

642
00:30:46,970 --> 00:30:50,670
Secured redundant power, maybe they
all have that, and they all exceed,

643
00:30:50,670 --> 00:30:53,270
so I'll just give them all 5s on that one,
all right?

644
00:30:53,270 --> 00:30:58,730
And then separate tectonic plate, maybe
the first place here, Candidate 1, yeah

645
00:30:58,730 --> 00:31:02,810
they're absolutely, they're on the other
side of the country so I give them a 5.

646
00:31:02,810 --> 00:31:06,390
Candidate 2, well maybe they're
on the same tectonic plate as us,

647
00:31:06,390 --> 00:31:09,560
so they don't meet our needs,
so I'll give them a 1.

648
00:31:09,560 --> 00:31:12,958
And then Candidate 3,
maybe they are not too far away.

649
00:31:12,958 --> 00:31:15,660
We'll just say that they barely meet it,
all right?

650
00:31:15,660 --> 00:31:19,070
Now that I've given these scores,
how do I compare them together?

651
00:31:19,070 --> 00:31:23,180
Because if I think about it,
multiple ISPs, Candidate 2 wins.

652
00:31:23,180 --> 00:31:25,840
Secured redundant power,
it's a three way tie.

653
00:31:25,840 --> 00:31:28,080
Separate tectonic plate, Candidate 1 wins.

654
00:31:28,080 --> 00:31:31,010
So who's the big winner?

655
00:31:31,010 --> 00:31:33,380
Looking at the numbers like this,
we can't really decide.

656
00:31:33,380 --> 00:31:38,050
So what we need to do is,
we need to apply a weight to each one.

657
00:31:38,050 --> 00:31:41,530
Sometimes you have requirements
that are nice to have, but

658
00:31:41,530 --> 00:31:46,940
shouldn't cause your whole project
to go offline or whatever, right?

659
00:31:46,940 --> 00:31:50,359
We might even have another entry in here
that says something about the financial

660
00:31:50,359 --> 00:31:52,972
liability of that company, so
different things like that.

661
00:31:52,972 --> 00:31:55,490
You might not wanna change
your decision based on it.

662
00:31:55,490 --> 00:31:56,360
But you wanna track it.

663
00:31:56,360 --> 00:31:58,127
Anyway, so you assign a weight.

664
00:31:58,127 --> 00:32:01,106
And I might say something like,
you know what, multiple ISPs,

665
00:32:01,106 --> 00:32:02,440
that's really important.

666
00:32:02,440 --> 00:32:03,647
We've got to have that.

667
00:32:03,647 --> 00:32:06,712
And so
I'm going to give that a weight of 10.

668
00:32:06,712 --> 00:32:08,453
Secured redundant power.

669
00:32:08,453 --> 00:32:10,199
That's really important,
we've got to have that.

670
00:32:10,199 --> 00:32:15,340
I'll give it a weight of ten but separate
tectonic plate it would be nice to have.

671
00:32:15,340 --> 00:32:18,100
But at the end of the day, if they're on
the same tectonic plate as us as long as

00:32:18,100 --> 00:32:19,750

673
00:32:19,750 --> 00:32:22,610
Earthquakes generally only

00:32:22,610 --> 00:32:25,720

distance away it might be okay.

675
00:32:25,720 --> 00:32:28,849
So I might give that one a lower weight,
something like a five.

676
00:32:30,210 --> 00:32:35,310
So now, when I do these scores,
I have to adjust them based on the weight.

677
00:32:35,310 --> 00:32:39,890
So for candidate one, I would take
this 3 and multiply it by 10 so

678
00:32:39,890 --> 00:32:41,960
their score would actually be a 30.

679
00:32:41,960 --> 00:32:46,850
This 5 multiplied by 10 becomes a 50,
this 5 times 5 becomes 25.

680
00:32:48,390 --> 00:32:52,010
And I continue doing the scoring that
way for each of the other candidates,

681
00:32:52,010 --> 00:32:54,730
updating their score based on the weight.

682
00:32:54,730 --> 00:32:59,910
So this one would be a 50, this one
would be a 50 and this one would be a 5.

683
00:32:59,910 --> 00:33:04,479
And then over here we've got let's see,
4 times 10 that's a 40.

684
00:33:04,479 --> 00:33:07,718
We've got a 50 and then we've got a 15.

685
00:33:07,718 --> 00:33:14,030
Now, these scores are adjusted
based on what's important to us.

686
00:33:14,030 --> 00:33:17,320
So once they've been adjusted, now these
numbers can all be treated the same so

687
00:33:17,320 --> 00:33:19,940
we just aggregate them
together to form a total.

688
00:33:21,060 --> 00:33:27,363
So our total score for
candidate 1 here would actually be 105.

00:33:27,363 --> 00:33:28,430

At a minimum you should usually

00:34:26,734 --> 00:34:29,890

Let's say that was like

00:34:34,890 --> 00:34:36,300

Now, it becomes a lot

00:35:32,230 --> 00:35:34,946
That's what we can do when we

741
00:35:34,946 --> 00:35:37,142
it makes decisions very straightforward.

742
00:35:37,142 --> 00:35:39,684
What I'll normally do is
actually a combination of things.

743
00:35:39,684 --> 00:35:43,635
So I'll get my information back from

00:35:43,635 --> 00:35:46,522

And then I take their numbers and

00:36:00,510 --> 00:36:04,220
So I might have ten people that all

00:36:04,220 --> 00:36:07,980
Multiple ISP, but I average them

00:36:07,980 --> 00:36:11,420
Then we lay it out on the scoresheet

00:36:11,420 --> 00:36:14,810

00:36:14,810 --> 00:36:18,600
So now, there's no arguments no, we really

came about those numbers?

757
00:36:22,270 --> 00:36:23,850
How we came across those results?

758
00:36:23,850 --> 00:36:27,200
Now, when you're averaging
people's scores together,

759
00:36:27,200 --> 00:36:27,860
some people's-
>> [LAUGH]

760
00:36:27,860 --> 00:36:29,370
>> Scores might count more than others so

761
00:36:29,370 --> 00:36:31,510
you might actually have
weights attached to that too.

762
00:36:31,510 --> 00:36:34,790
You can really get complex
with this stuff if you want.

763
00:36:34,790 --> 00:36:38,830
But it is a good way to pick who
the best contractor is going to be.

764
00:36:38,830 --> 00:36:40,940
And it can be fairly impartial.

765
00:36:40,940 --> 00:36:44,270
One thing we talked about in
an earlier show was ethics, and

766
00:36:44,270 --> 00:36:48,260
how you want to avoid
the appearance of impropriety?

767
00:36:48,260 --> 00:36:51,660
Well, one example of that,
is if you put out a request for

768
00:36:51,660 --> 00:36:56,240
bids and one company that responds back
happens to be a relative of yours.

769
00:36:56,240 --> 00:36:57,790
Maybe it's your brother or sister or

770
00:36:57,790 --> 00:37:01,210
brother in law, it doesn't have to
be blood, but a legal relationship.

771
00:37:01,210 --> 00:37:05,570
So that person you've got
a relationship with them.

772
00:37:05,570 --> 00:37:09,370
So the instinct that we have
is to just decline that bid.

773
00:37:09,370 --> 00:37:12,140
We're not gonna consider that bid
because they're a relative of mine.

774
00:37:12,140 --> 00:37:15,611
I don't want that to weigh on
the choice and we knock them out.

775
00:37:15,611 --> 00:37:19,630
But you might be passing
on a good opportunity.

776
00:37:19,630 --> 00:37:23,350
Sure, they might be your brother-in-law,
but they might be doing the best work for

777
00:37:23,350 --> 00:37:27,840
the lowest cost and by negating their bid,
you're actually hurting your project.

778
00:37:27,840 --> 00:37:32,050
So it's okay to do business with your
brother-in-law or sister-in-law or

779
00:37:32,050 --> 00:37:36,980
whatever, it's okay to do business with
them as long as you do two things.

780
00:37:36,980 --> 00:37:41,020
One, you recuse yourself from the scoring.

781
00:37:41,020 --> 00:37:43,410
You don't score that particular candidate.

782
00:37:43,410 --> 00:37:47,180
You let everybody else score it,
so it's their numbers, not yours.

783
00:37:47,180 --> 00:37:50,190
And then you weigh all
the candidates evenly like this.

784
00:37:50,190 --> 00:37:53,270
Here I can show exactly,
how we made that decision, and.

785
00:37:53,270 --> 00:37:59,550
Sure enough, my brother came in with
the best quote providing the best work.

786
00:37:59,550 --> 00:38:00,520
I didn't score them.

787
00:38:00,520 --> 00:38:02,700
I scored the other companies,
but I didn't score that one.

788
00:38:02,700 --> 00:38:06,330
Everybody else did and they all
decided that this is the way to go.

789
00:38:06,330 --> 00:38:10,310
It's a great way to show that and
avoid the appearance of impropriety.

790
00:38:10,310 --> 00:38:11,940
We meet our ethics needs.

791
00:38:11,940 --> 00:38:16,570
That's a question a lot of people miss on
the exam because your instinct is to say,

792
00:38:16,570 --> 00:38:18,090
I'm not gonna do business with my brother.

793
00:38:19,330 --> 00:38:21,400
A lot of companies have
anti nepotism clauses and

794
00:38:21,400 --> 00:38:24,670
things, but it can be at
the detriment of your project.

795
00:38:24,670 --> 00:38:27,430
So as long as you follow the straight and
narrow, you'll be fine.

796
00:38:29,290 --> 00:38:34,125
So that's an example of a source
selection criteria matrix or

797
00:38:34,125 --> 00:38:38,225
score card, and how we can come up with
who is going to be the best vendor.

798
00:38:41,335 --> 00:38:43,815
So some of the other things that
we need to talk about well,

799
00:38:43,815 --> 00:38:46,215
we've got seller proposals and
all these other inputs.

800
00:38:46,215 --> 00:38:48,025
We're still doing with the inputs here,

801
00:38:48,025 --> 00:38:50,610
we haven't actually even got to
work with our procurements yet.

802
00:38:50,610 --> 00:38:53,920
So if we take a look at some of
the other inputs that we've got,

803
00:38:53,920 --> 00:38:56,850
we've got things like
our seller proposals.

804
00:38:56,850 --> 00:38:59,510
Where do I get the data about
all these different contractors?

805
00:38:59,510 --> 00:39:01,480
Well they send us proposals.

806
00:39:01,480 --> 00:39:05,844
You remember in the planning phase we
talk about RFQ, Request for Quote.

807
00:39:05,844 --> 00:39:08,143
RFPs, Request for Proposal.

808
00:39:08,143 --> 00:39:10,546
RFB, Request for Bid.

809
00:39:10,546 --> 00:39:12,065
Each one's a little bit different, but

810
00:39:12,065 --> 00:39:14,095
these are all proposals
that we get from people.

811
00:39:14,095 --> 00:39:16,615
So I guess I could add these in here.

812
00:39:16,615 --> 00:39:18,735
So Request for Bid.

813
00:39:20,505 --> 00:39:25,685
That's what we're asking somebody to tell
us, how much would we need to pay them.

814
00:39:25,685 --> 00:39:28,099
How much would it cost for
them to do this project for us?

815
00:39:29,580 --> 00:39:31,290
Request for Quote is very similar.

816
00:39:32,300 --> 00:39:35,630
RFQ the terms can practically
be interchangeable.

817
00:39:35,630 --> 00:39:37,320
Request for proposal is the cool one.

818
00:39:38,330 --> 00:39:41,038
Because that's where we say,
we need something done.

819
00:39:41,038 --> 00:39:42,510
But we don't know how to do it.

820
00:39:42,510 --> 00:39:45,190
So propose to us how you would do it?

821
00:39:45,190 --> 00:39:47,720
Maybe you've got some unique way
of doing some of this better than

822
00:39:47,720 --> 00:39:49,020
somebody else's way.

823
00:39:49,020 --> 00:39:53,150
Maybe I've got two companies that
can do the exact same thing for me.

824
00:39:53,150 --> 00:39:56,370
They can both lay the foundation for
this house.

825
00:39:56,370 --> 00:39:58,271
And they both have the same price.

826
00:39:58,271 --> 00:40:03,325
But one of them uses an environmentally
friendly source for their concrete mixture

827
00:40:03,325 --> 00:40:08,107
versus the other one that is doing strip
mining or whatever for the materials.

828
00:40:08,107 --> 00:40:10,974
So, I might choose to go the
environmentally friendly way because it's

829
00:40:10,974 --> 00:40:13,240
part of a green initiative in my company.

830
00:40:13,240 --> 00:40:16,790
The price was the same, it didn't
impact my schedule or deadline, but

831
00:40:16,790 --> 00:40:18,330
it was a nice thing to have.

832
00:40:18,330 --> 00:40:22,370
Those are things that you can find when
you get RFPs, Request For Proposals.

833
00:40:22,370 --> 00:40:22,920
All right?

834
00:40:22,920 --> 00:40:26,050
There's a ton of other documents
that are out there, and

835
00:40:26,050 --> 00:40:27,240
we'll talk about some other ones.

836
00:40:27,240 --> 00:40:29,970
But those are some of the bigger ones
right there that people will send out.

837
00:40:29,970 --> 00:40:31,470
You draft these documents, and

838
00:40:31,470 --> 00:40:34,290
you send it out to any company you
think that might be able to do this.

839
00:40:34,290 --> 00:40:37,840
Or if you're somebody big like the U.S.
government, you don't even send them out.

840
00:40:37,840 --> 00:40:40,320
You just post them on your website and
people come to you.

841
00:40:40,320 --> 00:40:41,570
Like, hey I want to do this work.

842
00:40:41,570 --> 00:40:44,750
Let me see if the government has
any contracts out right now.

843
00:40:44,750 --> 00:40:48,290
And they'll submit their bids,
their quotes, their proposals.

844
00:40:48,290 --> 00:40:49,970
And then, you just have to pick from them.

845
00:40:49,970 --> 00:40:53,510
You use your cell or selection
criteria to go and pick the best one.

846
00:40:55,102 --> 00:40:57,670
All right, some of the other
documents that we might have:

847
00:40:57,670 --> 00:41:01,415
we've got things in here like
our risk related documents.

848
00:41:01,415 --> 00:41:05,320
Anytime we make a risk related decision,
like engaging in insurance.

849
00:41:05,320 --> 00:41:07,660
We're gonna have documents that
are generated based on that insurance

850
00:41:07,660 --> 00:41:08,540
policy and so on.

851
00:41:08,540 --> 00:41:10,840
And you might pick between
multiple companies for that.

852
00:41:12,340 --> 00:41:14,350
Make or
buy decisions are another big part.

853
00:41:15,490 --> 00:41:20,340
When we contract something out, there's
always this moment in the beginning.

854
00:41:20,340 --> 00:41:22,480
And I know we do this at ITProTV a lot,

855
00:41:22,480 --> 00:41:25,045
where you say boy,
we could do that ourselves.

856
00:41:25,045 --> 00:41:26,680
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let me go back to the video

857
00:41:26,680 --> 00:41:27,570
hosting story.

858
00:41:27,570 --> 00:41:30,330
Right?
We used all third party video hosting

859
00:41:30,330 --> 00:41:35,320
servers because those companies are
companies that specialize in that service.

860
00:41:35,320 --> 00:41:38,580
They monitor it 24/7 they
do a great job of doing it.

861
00:41:38,580 --> 00:41:42,390
But I would say at least
half of our employees here

862
00:41:42,390 --> 00:41:44,635
know how to set up video
streaming servers.

863
00:41:44,635 --> 00:41:45,190
Right?

864
00:41:45,190 --> 00:41:50,420
So we could have gone to Amazon S3
spun up some Wowza servers or

865
00:41:50,420 --> 00:41:51,910
flashed media servers.

866
00:41:51,910 --> 00:41:55,160
And I brought those online and
set up our own streaming environment.

867
00:41:55,160 --> 00:41:56,690
All right?
We know how to do it.

868
00:41:56,690 --> 00:41:57,350
I've done it.

869
00:41:57,350 --> 00:41:58,130
Right?

870
00:41:58,130 --> 00:42:00,110
But I'm busy.

871
00:42:00,110 --> 00:42:01,070
I got a work.

872
00:42:01,070 --> 00:42:02,500
Right now, I'm doing the show.

873
00:42:02,500 --> 00:42:04,900
If something goes wrong with the video
stream, I don't want to stop and

874
00:42:04,900 --> 00:42:05,840
go and fix it.

875
00:42:05,840 --> 00:42:07,590
So we leverage a third party.

876
00:42:07,590 --> 00:42:10,190
Right?
Somebody else who is monitoring it 24/7,

877
00:42:10,190 --> 00:42:11,510
who is specializing in that and does it.

878
00:42:11,510 --> 00:42:14,780
So we could have made our product.

879
00:42:14,780 --> 00:42:16,260
But we chose to buy it.

880
00:42:16,260 --> 00:42:17,010
Right?

881
00:42:17,010 --> 00:42:18,550
For various reasons.

882
00:42:18,550 --> 00:42:21,580
That's part of a Make or Buy Decision.

883
00:42:21,580 --> 00:42:26,980
If you have the core capabilities of that
activity built into your company already.

884
00:42:26,980 --> 00:42:29,430
If you've already got
personnel that can do it,

885
00:42:29,430 --> 00:42:32,025
you may well be able to do that
solution without contracting it out.

886
00:42:32,025 --> 00:42:33,580
Right?

887
00:42:33,580 --> 00:42:34,984
Assuming you've got the resources.

888
00:42:34,984 --> 00:42:36,960
>> Yeah.
>> The talent, and you can do it for

889
00:42:36,960 --> 00:42:39,290
effectively the same cost
as contracting it out.

890
00:42:39,290 --> 00:42:42,251
But sometimes you can contract it out and
it costs less.

891
00:42:42,251 --> 00:42:44,511
Right?
The value delivered by the vendor might

892
00:42:44,511 --> 00:42:46,058
actually exceed what you can do.

893
00:42:46,058 --> 00:42:48,060
Right?
They might save you money, or

894
00:42:48,060 --> 00:42:50,450
in our case with the video streaming,
it costs us more.

895
00:42:50,450 --> 00:42:50,956
>> Right?
>> Yeah.

896
00:42:50,956 --> 00:42:52,006
>> We could save money if we

897
00:42:52,006 --> 00:42:53,820
set up our video streaming servers.

898
00:42:53,820 --> 00:42:56,180
But those guys do a better job of it.

899
00:42:56,180 --> 00:42:57,640
So the value they bring us,

900
00:42:57,640 --> 00:43:01,055
to have reliable video up every single
day, we're willing to pay for that.

901
00:43:01,055 --> 00:43:03,150
Right?
That is something that is valuable to me.

902
00:43:04,830 --> 00:43:06,741
I'm starting to get that
way with things at home.

903
00:43:06,741 --> 00:43:08,810
>> [LAUGH]
>> It used to be

904
00:43:08,810 --> 00:43:11,170
>> That I would build my own computer.

905
00:43:11,170 --> 00:43:13,830
So my computer at home,
I would build it from parts.

906
00:43:13,830 --> 00:43:16,240
But as I've gotten older, I get less and

907
00:43:16,240 --> 00:43:19,740
less patient with getting all the little
parts mixed together and working.

908
00:43:19,740 --> 00:43:22,200
And so I might just go out and
buy a Dell or

909
00:43:22,200 --> 00:43:26,830
an HP because it's worth more
to me to save the time and

910
00:43:26,830 --> 00:43:30,760
it's not, I say that but I just built
my own computer what six months ago.

911
00:43:30,760 --> 00:43:34,630
So I do still dabble in it, but
that's the thing is that you might get

912
00:43:34,630 --> 00:43:36,275
additional value out of
using those numbers.

913
00:43:36,275 --> 00:43:39,310
All right, the other thing; risks

914
00:43:39,310 --> 00:43:42,072
associated with meeting the need
in a cost effective manner.

915
00:43:42,072 --> 00:43:44,550
Right?
When you choose to make the solution,

916
00:43:44,550 --> 00:43:47,660
to do it yourself,
there's a risk you're taking on.

917
00:43:47,660 --> 00:43:49,660
Right?
That you might not meet your schedule or

918
00:43:49,660 --> 00:43:50,330
your budget/ Right?

919
00:43:50,330 --> 00:43:51,860
You are accepting the risk for that.

920
00:43:51,860 --> 00:43:54,995
Versus when you contract it out,
the contractors are taking the risk.

921
00:43:54,995 --> 00:43:55,530
Right?

922
00:43:55,530 --> 00:43:58,290
If they fail to meet the schedule,
you can penalize them.

923
00:43:58,290 --> 00:44:00,935
You can't penalize yourself,
you just fail your project.

924
00:44:00,935 --> 00:44:01,710
Right?
So

925
00:44:01,710 --> 00:44:05,140
there's a risk transference that happens
when you contract something out.

926
00:44:06,660 --> 00:44:10,200
And then lastly, whether or
not you have the same capabilities

927
00:44:10,200 --> 00:44:12,940
inside of your company that
the vendors would have.

928
00:44:12,940 --> 00:44:13,510
Right?

929
00:44:13,510 --> 00:44:15,130
That's what we've got here.

930
00:44:15,130 --> 00:44:18,248
We've got the talent at ITProTV to
set up video streaming service.

931
00:44:18,248 --> 00:44:19,575
We We've got it.

932
00:44:19,575 --> 00:44:23,495
But what we don't have is someone ready
to sit there 24/7 monitoring those

933
00:44:23,495 --> 00:44:24,815
servers and ensuring they're working.

934
00:44:24,815 --> 00:44:25,455
Right?

935
00:44:25,455 --> 00:44:29,015
We've got support personnel, we've got the
people that monitor the support tickets

936
00:44:29,015 --> 00:44:30,675
and the Q&A forums and stuff.

937
00:44:30,675 --> 00:44:31,480
We do that a lot.

938
00:44:31,480 --> 00:44:33,395
>> Yeah.
>> But we don't want to sit here and

939
00:44:33,395 --> 00:44:34,435
monitor streaming services.

940
00:44:34,435 --> 00:44:35,405
>> Right.
>> So

941
00:44:35,405 --> 00:44:38,125
you get that capability
from somebody outside so

942
00:44:38,125 --> 00:44:39,275
that you don't have to provide it inside.

943
00:44:40,390 --> 00:44:41,880
That's the key thing to
remember with make or

944
00:44:41,880 --> 00:44:44,290
buy decisions and
this is the point where we make them.

945
00:44:45,900 --> 00:44:48,620
All right,
now if we decide to contract it out,

946
00:44:48,620 --> 00:44:52,410
I mentioned the key document were gonna
send is the procurement statement of work.

947
00:44:52,410 --> 00:44:54,580
Right?
And if we look at our inputs,

948
00:44:54,580 --> 00:44:58,420
we've got that listed in here and
it falls under the project documents.

949
00:44:58,420 --> 00:44:59,380
>> Yeah.
>> Oh no, I'm sorry,

950
00:44:59,380 --> 00:45:03,040
it's actually listed specifically,
procurement statement of work.

951
00:45:03,040 --> 00:45:05,260
If you're gonna contract something out,
it's a contract.

952
00:45:05,260 --> 00:45:07,990
Right?
It's a legal agreement to specify what

953
00:45:07,990 --> 00:45:09,150
somebody's gonna do.

954
00:45:09,150 --> 00:45:12,130
So you need to create a statement
of work that identifies that.

955
00:45:12,130 --> 00:45:15,670
And this is just like creating a work
breakdown structure back in our

956
00:45:15,670 --> 00:45:16,680
planning phase.

957
00:45:16,680 --> 00:45:20,880
Except here,
it's just identifying a portion of your

958
00:45:20,880 --> 00:45:23,360
overall project that you're
gonna be contracting out.

959
00:45:23,360 --> 00:45:26,860
It needs to be very detailed because
when you contract something out,

960
00:45:26,860 --> 00:45:27,850
you need to be specific.

961
00:45:27,850 --> 00:45:28,530
If there's room for

962
00:45:28,530 --> 00:45:32,710
interpretation, you may not get
back what it is that you expected.

963
00:45:32,710 --> 00:45:33,700
Right?

964
00:45:33,700 --> 00:45:36,590
So these should have all ready been
drafted in the planning phase, that's why

965
00:45:36,590 --> 00:45:40,080
their input's here, but if they haven't
been drafted, now's the time to do it.

966
00:45:40,080 --> 00:45:42,843
You draw up what you want
that contractor to do, and

967
00:45:42,843 --> 00:45:45,496
this is normally what becomes your RFPs,
RFQs.

968
00:45:45,496 --> 00:45:47,854
Right?
Your statement of work is what you put

969
00:45:47,854 --> 00:45:48,450
in there.

970
00:45:48,450 --> 00:45:50,370
And you say Here's the work I need done.

971
00:45:50,370 --> 00:45:52,580
How much is it gonna cost?

972
00:45:52,580 --> 00:45:53,210
Right?

973
00:45:53,210 --> 00:45:55,000
How fast can you get it done?

974
00:45:55,000 --> 00:45:55,680
How reliable.

975
00:45:55,680 --> 00:45:56,620
Give me some references.

976
00:45:56,620 --> 00:45:59,390
That kind of stuff is what we tack onto
that document, but the most of it,

977
00:45:59,390 --> 00:46:01,442
the bulk of that document
Is your statement of work.

978
00:46:01,442 --> 00:46:06,160
All right, so some of the things that
we'll have in there, at a minimum,

979
00:46:06,160 --> 00:46:07,305
your specifications.

980
00:46:07,305 --> 00:46:07,960
Right?

981
00:46:07,960 --> 00:46:12,480
What matches up with
your requirements list.

982
00:46:12,480 --> 00:46:13,350
Right?

983
00:46:13,350 --> 00:46:15,300
But after that you want
to punch in other things,

984
00:46:15,300 --> 00:46:17,185
if it's a product the quantity desired.

985
00:46:17,185 --> 00:46:17,990
Right?

986
00:46:17,990 --> 00:46:20,420
Whether it's a product or
a service the quality levels,

987
00:46:20,420 --> 00:46:25,180
how you're going to measure whether or
not this is good enough for your customer.

988
00:46:25,180 --> 00:46:28,895
Performance data, period of performance,
how we're gonna measure that.

989
00:46:28,895 --> 00:46:31,540
Cuz you don't want to just say,
all right, contractor do it and

990
00:46:31,540 --> 00:46:32,290
have it for me on the 31st.

991
00:46:32,290 --> 00:46:35,180
And then you just don't talk to them for
months and

992
00:46:35,180 --> 00:46:37,240
then on the 31st you check in,
all right, where is it?

993
00:46:37,240 --> 00:46:39,060
You want to be monitoring it throughout.

994
00:46:39,060 --> 00:46:40,980
So how do we measure that performance?

995
00:46:40,980 --> 00:46:42,940
Where's the work gonna be done at?

996
00:46:42,940 --> 00:46:45,550
Do they need to come to your office
to do the work so you can monitor it?

997
00:46:45,550 --> 00:46:48,220
Or are they gonna do it just
at their office separately?

998
00:46:48,220 --> 00:46:49,110
All right?

999
00:46:49,110 --> 00:46:52,030
And then any other requirements
that you might have as a result of

1000
00:46:52,030 --> 00:46:52,810
doing that contract.

1001
00:46:54,100 --> 00:46:57,421
>> Yeah, what's clear for us in this
statement of work is that, notice that

1002
00:46:57,421 --> 00:47:01,080
every one of those requirements is
something that is quantifiable.

1003
00:47:01,080 --> 00:47:05,520
That way, the actual seller knows
here's what needs to be done.

1004
00:47:05,520 --> 00:47:07,420
Here's how we can prove that it's done.

1005
00:47:07,420 --> 00:47:10,108
It's not one of those well,
I'll tell you when I get ready.

1006
00:47:10,108 --> 00:47:11,900
>> [LAUGH]
>> Ideas here.

1007
00:47:11,900 --> 00:47:14,530
So every single one of these
here is truly quantifiable and

1008
00:47:14,530 --> 00:47:15,880
that's what we need to have here.

1009
00:47:15,880 --> 00:47:18,780
Something that there's no
particular wiggle room at all, and

1010
00:47:18,780 --> 00:47:20,100
that's why it's very important.

1011
00:47:21,990 --> 00:47:24,690
>> Yeah, the last input is just
organizational process assets.

1012
00:47:24,690 --> 00:47:27,360
You likely have drafted contracts, or

1013
00:47:27,360 --> 00:47:30,480
a procurement officer already in place
in your company, and you leverage that.

1014
00:47:30,480 --> 00:47:31,710
Right?
You leverage those resources.

1015
00:47:31,710 --> 00:47:32,540
You reach out.
But

1016
00:47:32,540 --> 00:47:34,230
you also have your historical projects,

1017
00:47:34,230 --> 00:47:36,700
where other people have engaged
in contract activities, and

1018
00:47:36,700 --> 00:47:39,080
you can use that to help determine
which seller you go with.

1019
00:47:39,080 --> 00:47:40,624
Right?
Historical performance is important.

1020
00:47:40,624 --> 00:47:41,670
>> Yeah.

1021
00:47:41,670 --> 00:47:45,240
>> We take all that and now we're
ready to conduct the procurement.

00:47:45,240 --> 00:47:49,560
Conducting the procurement means actually
sending out the RFQ's or RFP's or

1023
00:47:49,560 --> 00:47:51,550
whatever it is we're sending out.

1024
00:47:51,550 --> 00:47:52,890
Getting back the results.

1025
00:47:52,890 --> 00:47:53,750
Sorting through them.

1026
00:47:53,750 --> 00:47:54,918
Scoring them.
Picking the seller.

1027
00:47:54,918 --> 00:47:56,870
Right?
These are the activities that we do when

1028
00:47:56,870 --> 00:47:58,410
we conduct the procurement.

1029
00:47:58,410 --> 00:48:01,760
So, some of the tools we've got,
a bidder conference.

1030
00:48:01,760 --> 00:48:03,746
Bidder conferences are really cool.

1031
00:48:03,746 --> 00:48:08,385
When you send out RFPs and RFQs,
the bidders, the people responding back,

1032
00:48:08,385 --> 00:48:10,646
the sellers, they have questions.

1033
00:48:10,646 --> 00:48:11,248
>> Yeah.

1034
00:48:11,248 --> 00:48:12,804
>> They almost always have questions.

1035
00:48:12,804 --> 00:48:14,082
If they're good, they have questions.

1036
00:48:14,082 --> 00:48:16,460
So they come back and they say all right,
we read through that, how about this,

1037
00:48:16,460 --> 00:48:17,005
this, and this.

1038
00:48:17,005 --> 00:48:19,228
Well if you're sending
this out to hundreds or

1039
00:48:19,228 --> 00:48:23,280
thousands of prospective sellers,
you'll get a lot of questions back.

1040
00:48:23,280 --> 00:48:26,010
So sometimes it's faster just
to have a better conference.

1041
00:48:26,010 --> 00:48:30,202
Say, okay everybody, we're doing
