1042
00:48:30,202 --> 00:48:30,720
or 10 a.m.

1043
00:48:30,720 --> 00:48:33,140
whatever, I don't know why
I picked the nighttime.

1044
00:48:33,140 --> 00:48:35,110
And let's go ahead and
fire up this call, and

1045
00:48:35,110 --> 00:48:38,220
just everybody can ask their questions and
get answers at the same time.

1046
00:48:38,220 --> 00:48:42,595
That's very convenient for
you as the purchaser, the procurer.

1047
00:48:42,595 --> 00:48:43,680
>> Mm-hm.

1048
00:48:43,680 --> 00:48:46,670
>> But if you're the person who's bidding,

1049
00:48:46,670 --> 00:48:49,255
you get a chance to see who
all the other bidders are.

1050
00:48:49,255 --> 00:48:51,430
>> Mm-hm.
>> You know what competition is out there,

1051
00:48:51,430 --> 00:48:53,530
and that may not be
something that you want.

1052
00:48:53,530 --> 00:48:55,631
>> So, you know, it's up to you whether
a bidder conference is actually

1053
00:48:55,631 --> 00:48:56,690
realistic or not.

1054
00:48:56,690 --> 00:48:59,670
If you're the U.S. Government,
bidder conferences work out great.

1055
00:48:59,670 --> 00:49:03,890
If you're a five person dentist office,
bidder conferences aren't very realistic.

1056
00:49:03,890 --> 00:49:04,560
So, you know,

1057
00:49:04,560 --> 00:49:09,660
it just depends on whether or not your
organization is suitable for that.

1058
00:49:09,660 --> 00:49:11,990
All right?
Proposal evaluation techniques.

1059
00:49:11,990 --> 00:49:15,570
When we get these proposals
back from everybody how do we,

1060
00:49:15,570 --> 00:49:17,630
how do we know if they're good or bad?

1061
00:49:17,630 --> 00:49:19,880
Well one of the best techniques is that,

1062
00:49:19,880 --> 00:49:22,330
that scoring matrix that I
showed you guys earlier.

1063
00:49:22,330 --> 00:49:25,070
We assign weights to our categories and
then we rank,

1064
00:49:25,070 --> 00:49:27,690
we score people based on
the information that they give you,

1065
00:49:27,690 --> 00:49:31,980
so you can gauge that data based
on something that's quantifiable.

1066
00:49:31,980 --> 00:49:33,690
Something that you've predefined.

1067
00:49:33,690 --> 00:49:35,970
>> Yeah, now this is again one
of those important processes,

1068
00:49:35,970 --> 00:49:39,690
especially in the procurement area that
we make sure we judge them fairly.

1069
00:49:39,690 --> 00:49:40,300
Right?

1070
00:49:40,300 --> 00:49:43,600
I don't sit there and go, well,
I know that I prefer this bidder and

1071
00:49:43,600 --> 00:49:47,870
I start to actually do just these things
that I want them to score well on.

1072
00:49:47,870 --> 00:49:51,290
The formalized process in making sure
that we go through these techniques,

1073
00:49:51,290 --> 00:49:53,750
really does kind of even
out the playing field, and

1074
00:49:53,750 --> 00:49:56,730
it does show that while we're trying to
select this we're actually being fair.

1075
00:49:56,730 --> 00:49:58,280
A very important process again.

1076
00:49:58,280 --> 00:49:59,110
>> Yeah.

1077
00:49:59,110 --> 00:50:00,890
Another thing is independent estimates.

1078
00:50:00,890 --> 00:50:05,400
It is a good idea to get an estimate
from more than one person.

1079
00:50:05,400 --> 00:50:05,920
Right?

1080
00:50:05,920 --> 00:50:10,750
And an area where I see this a lot is,
you'll go to an IT company,

1081
00:50:10,750 --> 00:50:13,090
and maybe they have a project.

1082
00:50:13,090 --> 00:50:15,810
And in the project they need
to purchase 40 more servers.

1083
00:50:15,810 --> 00:50:16,350
Right?

1084
00:50:16,350 --> 00:50:19,310
Well, you go in their server room and
it's all Dell.

1085
00:50:19,310 --> 00:50:20,069
All Dell servers.

1086
00:50:21,470 --> 00:50:23,220
So when they say they need
to get 40 more servers,

1087
00:50:23,220 --> 00:50:25,220
they just go and
get a quote from Dell and that's it.

1088
00:50:25,220 --> 00:50:25,940
Right?

1089
00:50:25,940 --> 00:50:29,110
Well, because they have all Dell servers,
that's what they want to do.

1090
00:50:29,110 --> 00:50:31,050
It's one vendor.
You can only buy directly from Dell,so

1091
00:50:31,050 --> 00:50:32,440
it makes sense.

1092
00:50:32,440 --> 00:50:35,660
But, that may not be a competitive price.

1093
00:50:35,660 --> 00:50:38,940
So what you do is, you turn around and
you get quote from HP,

1094
00:50:38,940 --> 00:50:40,700
or IBM, Lenovo, whatever.

1095
00:50:40,700 --> 00:50:41,750
And you get a quote from them, too.

1096
00:50:41,750 --> 00:50:43,510
Now you know you're not
gonna purchase from them.

1097
00:50:43,510 --> 00:50:47,200
But you get a quote from them,
too to provide service of the same grade.

1098
00:50:47,200 --> 00:50:50,760
And if they're able to come
in under Dell's price,

1099
00:50:50,760 --> 00:50:53,570
that becomes part of your bargaining,
your negotiation power.

1100
00:50:53,570 --> 00:50:56,570
And you reach out to Dell and you say hey,
if we were to switch to HP, we'd save

1101
00:50:56,570 --> 00:51:00,320
this much money, and I can guarantee
you Dell will come down on their price.

1102
00:51:00,320 --> 00:51:03,650
So even if you only have one
seller you wanna do business with,

1103
00:51:03,650 --> 00:51:06,320
you still wanna get
estimates from other people.

1104
00:51:06,320 --> 00:51:09,410
If for no other reason than to use it for
negotiations, right?

1105
00:51:09,410 --> 00:51:12,190
But oftentimes when you get
estimates from different people,

1106
00:51:12,190 --> 00:51:15,020
you'll find that they
can vary quite a bit.

1107
00:51:15,020 --> 00:51:18,270
And so it helps you to do these
six-point estimates, right.

1108
00:51:18,270 --> 00:51:21,700
Or three point, where you've got
the pessimistic, optimistic, and

1109
00:51:21,700 --> 00:51:24,390
most likely, so
you can start to do those calculations.

1110
00:51:25,952 --> 00:51:30,230
All right, expert judgement, it's always a
good idea to have a subject matter expert,

1111
00:51:30,230 --> 00:51:33,300
or use your noodle is
what I usually say here,

1112
00:51:33,300 --> 00:51:35,790
to gauge the information that's coming in.

1113
00:51:35,790 --> 00:51:40,440
Advertising is another technique,
with the RFP's, RFQ's, RFB's,

1114
00:51:40,440 --> 00:51:45,740
all those things, I mentioned you're going
to send them out to prospective sellers.

1115
00:51:45,740 --> 00:51:48,650
Well, do you know all
the sellers that are out there?

1116
00:51:48,650 --> 00:51:49,430
Probably not.

1117
00:51:49,430 --> 00:51:52,890
So, you might wanna do an advertisement
to say hey, we're looking for this.

1118
00:51:52,890 --> 00:51:56,380
We're looking for a person or company that
can come in and develop this website.

1119
00:51:56,380 --> 00:51:58,940
Then you might find that there's other
sellers out there that you hadn't even

1120
00:51:58,940 --> 00:52:01,580
heard of, that see the advertisement and
come in that way.

1121
00:52:01,580 --> 00:52:05,450
You have a lot of that going on today in
the IT world, because you've got these

1122
00:52:05,450 --> 00:52:11,960
websites like freelancer.com and,
what are some of the other bigger names?

1123
00:52:11,960 --> 00:52:13,400
Freelancer's probably the biggest one, but

1124
00:52:13,400 --> 00:52:17,610
there's several others where you
can quickly get contract work.

1125
00:52:19,100 --> 00:52:20,920
Analytical techniques, right?

1126
00:52:20,920 --> 00:52:23,030
Ways that we analyze the data and
break it down.

1127
00:52:23,030 --> 00:52:25,090
Do they actually call out
any specific techniques?

1128
00:52:25,090 --> 00:52:26,520
>> No, not one specific one.

1129
00:52:26,520 --> 00:52:27,190
They just describe it.

1130
00:52:27,190 --> 00:52:28,910
>> Okay.
Just in general, okay.

1131
00:52:28,910 --> 00:52:30,270
So yeah, analytic techniques,

1132
00:52:30,270 --> 00:52:34,980
that's just our method for
analyzing that data and breaking it down.

1133
00:52:34,980 --> 00:52:38,970
We use that really as part
of our proposal evaluation.

1134
00:52:38,970 --> 00:52:44,010
And then the last one is just
procurement negotiations,

1135
00:52:44,010 --> 00:52:49,790
which is when you get that initial
proposal that may not be the final number.

1136
00:52:49,790 --> 00:52:50,980
Right?
You start to negotiate, and

1137
00:52:50,980 --> 00:52:52,750
you might be negotiating on price.

1138
00:52:52,750 --> 00:52:56,160
You might be negotiating on requirements.

1139
00:52:56,160 --> 00:52:59,800
In your request, you might have said,
we need this done by September 12th.

1140
00:52:59,800 --> 00:53:02,620
And they come back and they say, well we
can do it and we can do it cheap, but

1141
00:53:02,620 --> 00:53:04,840
we can only do it by September 30th.

1142
00:53:04,840 --> 00:53:06,050
Is that okay?

1143
00:53:06,050 --> 00:53:07,620
Now we start negotiating.

1144
00:53:07,620 --> 00:53:11,480
What's the date that we can get it
down to to make things effective.

1145
00:53:11,480 --> 00:53:14,490
You may have a professional
negotiator on your staff,

1146
00:53:14,490 --> 00:53:16,080
you may have to do it yourself.

1147
00:53:16,080 --> 00:53:17,760
As a project manager, that's not uncommon.

1148
00:53:19,520 --> 00:53:23,150
>> A lot of times, this particular idea,
the procurement of negotiation, really

1149
00:53:23,150 --> 00:53:28,710
does happen before that final contract
is actually signed and cemented in here.

1150
00:53:28,710 --> 00:53:33,340
So that way you know, before we sign
everything, here's all the final things

1151
00:53:33,340 --> 00:53:36,330
after we've kind of adjusted everything,
that we're gonna agree to, so

1152
00:53:36,330 --> 00:53:39,760
a very last important process before
you actually do procure anything.

1153
00:53:39,760 --> 00:53:41,150
Yeah.

1154
00:53:41,150 --> 00:53:45,010
And after that, we're pretty
much done dealing with our data.

1155
00:53:45,010 --> 00:53:47,100
Now we're ready to move
forward with the procurement.

1156
00:53:47,100 --> 00:53:50,760
So our outputs here, the main output
is the selected seller, right?

1157
00:53:50,760 --> 00:53:51,660
>> Right.
>> Who's the winner?

1158
00:53:51,660 --> 00:53:53,670
Who do we decide to go ahead and
purchase through?

1159
00:53:53,670 --> 00:53:54,240
Right?

1160
00:53:54,240 --> 00:53:57,500
And we always want to document
how we made that decision, so

1161
00:53:57,500 --> 00:53:58,960
the supporting paperwork,

1162
00:53:58,960 --> 00:54:03,230
the supporting paperwork becomes part of
our project documents updates, right?

1163
00:54:03,230 --> 00:54:05,450
We add that to our project history.

1164
00:54:05,450 --> 00:54:07,870
We also have the agreement itself, right?

1165
00:54:07,870 --> 00:54:11,780
The agreement is usually a contract, but
it might just be a written statement or

1166
00:54:11,780 --> 00:54:13,050
something like that.

1167
00:54:13,050 --> 00:54:14,200
Typically it's a contract, though.

1168
00:54:14,200 --> 00:54:15,900
It says what work is going to be done.

1169
00:54:15,900 --> 00:54:18,270
And the agreement, well,
it should be terminated, right?

1170
00:54:18,270 --> 00:54:21,130
So we should actually have it signed
off on and then it's active and

1171
00:54:21,130 --> 00:54:24,410
it's ready to rock on whatever
dates were specified.

1172
00:54:24,410 --> 00:54:26,580
Now, on the agreement side,
let me bring it up.

1173
00:54:26,580 --> 00:54:27,610
>> There's a lot.
>> There is a lot.

1174
00:54:27,610 --> 00:54:28,690
Where is that in the mix?

1175
00:54:28,690 --> 00:54:29,890
>> Right there.
>> Here we go.

1176
00:54:29,890 --> 00:54:32,985
So the agreement is going to
contain a number of things.

1177
00:54:32,985 --> 00:54:35,370
>> Mm-hm.
>> It can be very small, but

1178
00:54:35,370 --> 00:54:36,760
the more detail, the better.

1179
00:54:36,760 --> 00:54:41,740
When you're dealing with a contract,
you need no room for debate.

1180
00:54:41,740 --> 00:54:43,180
No inconsistency.

1181
00:54:43,180 --> 00:54:45,990
It needs to be well defined
of what you expect.

1182
00:54:45,990 --> 00:54:47,030
Black and white.

1183
00:54:47,030 --> 00:54:48,160
Clear as day.

1184
00:54:48,160 --> 00:54:51,070
So we want to have things like,
seller's place of performance.

1185
00:54:52,340 --> 00:54:54,460
How we measure their performance.

1186
00:54:54,460 --> 00:54:58,050
That we know that they are actually
getting the work done as we specified.

1187
00:54:58,050 --> 00:55:00,420
Their pricing and payment terms.

1188
00:55:00,420 --> 00:55:01,950
Now payment terms is important.

1189
00:55:01,950 --> 00:55:04,530
If you agree that you're
gonna pay $50,000 for

1190
00:55:04,530 --> 00:55:07,780
this project,
when do they want the money, right?

1191
00:55:07,780 --> 00:55:11,050
Is there a charge up front,
like 50% up front?

1192
00:55:11,050 --> 00:55:15,200
Are there installments paid throughout
while the work is getting done, pay for

1193
00:55:15,200 --> 00:55:16,090
performance?

1194
00:55:16,090 --> 00:55:20,660
Or is it a flat fee paid net
60 at the end of the contract?

1195
00:55:20,660 --> 00:55:22,790
So, how is that going to be defined?

1196
00:55:22,790 --> 00:55:26,630
That's important, because you need to
make sure you pay your contractors.

1197
00:55:26,630 --> 00:55:29,500
If you don't pay a contractor,
all of a sudden their work stops and

1198
00:55:29,500 --> 00:55:31,040
you shoot your schedule, right.

1199
00:55:31,040 --> 00:55:32,610
That's definitely not
something you wanna do.

1200
00:55:32,610 --> 00:55:34,070
So that needs to be in the contract.

1201
00:55:35,380 --> 00:55:36,500
A place of delivery.

1202
00:55:36,500 --> 00:55:39,940
When they actually have the delivery,
when they've created whatever it is you're

1203
00:55:39,940 --> 00:55:42,350
expecting them to create,
are they delivering it?

1204
00:55:42,350 --> 00:55:43,490
Do you have to go and get it?

1205
00:55:43,490 --> 00:55:45,290
How is that information kind of flow?

1206
00:55:46,520 --> 00:55:49,240
Inspection and acceptance criteria.

1207
00:55:49,240 --> 00:55:52,160
When the contractor tells you
the job is done, that's nice, but

1208
00:55:52,160 --> 00:55:53,300
it doesn't mean anything.

1209
00:55:53,300 --> 00:55:54,050
Right.

1210
00:55:54,050 --> 00:55:55,910
You have to decide if the job is done.

1211
00:55:55,910 --> 00:55:59,090
And only when you're both in
agreement that the job is done,

1212
00:55:59,090 --> 00:56:00,700
is it actually considered done.

1213
00:56:00,700 --> 00:56:02,950
Well, what if there's a difference.

1214
00:56:02,950 --> 00:56:05,750
What if I told Ronnie, hey Ronnie,
I was gonna lay the foundation for

1215
00:56:05,750 --> 00:56:06,790
you and it's done.

1216
00:56:06,790 --> 00:56:08,328
>> Right.
>> And you look at it and you say,

1217
00:56:08,328 --> 00:56:11,797
well the foundation's not dry yet,
and so when it dries, it might crack.

1218
00:56:11,797 --> 00:56:12,914
So it's not done.

1219
00:56:12,914 --> 00:56:13,516
>> Right.

1220
00:56:13,516 --> 00:56:14,563
>> Now we're in a debate.

1221
00:56:14,563 --> 00:56:16,232
And I'm saying, hey,
it's done, where's my money?

1222
00:56:16,232 --> 00:56:19,630
And you say, well, it's not done, right?

1223
00:56:19,630 --> 00:56:21,270
So, how do we establish that?

1224
00:56:21,270 --> 00:56:24,520
Well, the acceptance criteria
is what defines that, and

1225
00:56:24,520 --> 00:56:28,680
if, in my acceptance criteria, I didn't
specify the foundation needed to be dry,

1226
00:56:28,680 --> 00:56:33,980
if I say, the foundation needed to
be poured, right, well, it's done.

1227
00:56:33,980 --> 00:56:35,960
You didn't put it in the contract.

1228
00:56:35,960 --> 00:56:37,440
I should get paid.

1229
00:56:37,440 --> 00:56:40,210
But if it was specified in
there that it had to dry and

1230
00:56:40,210 --> 00:56:43,580
cracks needed to be repaired,
well then I'm wrong, and we need to wait.

1231
00:56:43,580 --> 00:56:46,260
So that acceptance criteria
is really important.

1232
00:56:46,260 --> 00:56:50,040
It's basically a check list of what needs
to be met, what should have been achieved,

1233
00:56:50,040 --> 00:56:51,790
for this to be considered done.

1234
00:56:51,790 --> 00:56:54,690
And if there's disagreement,
it doesn't matter, as long as that stuff

1235
00:56:54,690 --> 00:56:58,880
has been met, as long as we met the terms
of the contract, it's done, and

1236
00:56:58,880 --> 00:57:03,540
if it does go to litigation or mitigation,
if you go to court or whatever, that

1237
00:57:03,540 --> 00:57:07,120
it's clear as day, right there, whether or
not you met the terms as specified.

1238
00:57:07,120 --> 00:57:09,760
Now there is acting in good faith, so,

1239
00:57:09,760 --> 00:57:14,020
you know, you do have the spirit of
the contract that needs to be met, but

1240
00:57:14,020 --> 00:57:16,590
what's in black and
white is really what stands up in court.

1241
00:57:18,140 --> 00:57:21,150
A lot of contracts will
contain a warranty, okay.

1242
00:57:21,150 --> 00:57:24,120
Where the work is warranted for
a certain period of time or

1243
00:57:24,120 --> 00:57:25,550
a certain level of quality.

1244
00:57:25,550 --> 00:57:30,480
So if we pour the foundation and it's wet,
we might chose to say that's done,

1245
00:57:30,480 --> 00:57:34,520
I get paid, but
I'll do a warranty on it for 90 days and

1246
00:57:34,520 --> 00:57:37,720
if something goes wrong with that
foundation in 90 days, I'll fix it.

1247
00:57:37,720 --> 00:57:41,020
So that way I don't have to wait for
it to dry to get paid.

1248
00:57:41,020 --> 00:57:43,230
But at the same time,
you don't have to worry about it,

1249
00:57:43,230 --> 00:57:45,640
because I'll fix it in the next 90 days.

1250
00:57:45,640 --> 00:57:48,030
There are a number of
different types of warranties.

1251
00:57:48,030 --> 00:57:49,325
Did we talk about those?

1252
00:57:49,325 --> 00:57:49,849
>> We did.

1253
00:57:49,849 --> 00:57:53,710
>> Oh, that's right,
in the planning phase, because we have

1254
00:57:53,710 --> 00:57:58,460
the express warranties and things like
that, that kind of come into play there,

1255
00:57:58,460 --> 00:58:01,910
so your contract will have one of
the various types of warranties in it.

1256
00:58:01,910 --> 00:58:03,550
Or it might not have any warranty at all.

1257
00:58:03,550 --> 00:58:04,210
That's not uncommon.

1258
00:58:05,710 --> 00:58:07,310
Product support.

1259
00:58:07,310 --> 00:58:11,080
After the product or service has been
delivered what support do we get?

1260
00:58:11,080 --> 00:58:11,710
Maybe none.

1261
00:58:11,710 --> 00:58:12,890
Maybe this is a cut and dry.

1262
00:58:12,890 --> 00:58:16,205
You get somebody to do the work work and
that's the end of it.

1263
00:58:16,205 --> 00:58:20,375
Or maybe you have some kind of
ongoing agreement that's in place.

1264
00:58:20,375 --> 00:58:22,645
So you get routine support added on.

1265
00:58:22,645 --> 00:58:24,605
That needs to be defined
in the contract too.

1266
00:58:24,605 --> 00:58:25,875
Or in a follow up contract.

1267
00:58:25,875 --> 00:58:29,370
You might actually have the initial
contract for getting the work done, and

1268
00:58:29,370 --> 00:58:31,750
then a separate service
contract that you maintain.

1269
00:58:31,750 --> 00:58:32,700
That's not unusual.

1270
00:58:34,510 --> 00:58:36,170
All right, limitation of liability.

1271
00:58:36,170 --> 00:58:39,990
I can't remember the last time I saw
a contract that didn't have some kind of

1272
00:58:39,990 --> 00:58:44,720
limitation of liability in it, which is
saying, hey, we'll pour the foundation for

1273
00:58:44,720 --> 00:58:49,340
you but later on if you drive a tractor
on it and it cracks that's not our fault.

1274
00:58:49,340 --> 00:58:52,580
Or if somebody trips on the foundation and
breaks their head that's not our fault.

1275
00:58:52,580 --> 00:58:54,790
We poured it, we did what we said.

1276
00:58:54,790 --> 00:58:57,660
Now we're done, our liability is over.

1277
00:58:57,660 --> 00:58:59,340
Liability goes two ways.

1278
00:58:59,340 --> 00:59:01,980
There's liabilities on
the purchaser's side and

1279
00:59:01,980 --> 00:59:03,850
there's liability on the seller side.

1280
00:59:03,850 --> 00:59:06,910
So we want to make sure that
there's limitations for both.

1281
00:59:06,910 --> 00:59:08,970
You'll see things like
indemnity clauses and

1282
00:59:08,970 --> 00:59:12,450
other things in the contract that are all
kind of centered around limiting your

1283
00:59:12,450 --> 00:59:16,170
legal liability in the event
that something happens.

1284
00:59:16,170 --> 00:59:17,710
Fees and retainer.

1285
00:59:17,710 --> 00:59:19,960
When you hire somebody to be a contractor,

1286
00:59:19,960 --> 00:59:24,370
if you're doing the select seller process,
you will probably secure that seller

1287
00:59:24,370 --> 00:59:26,990
well in advance of the actual
activity needing to be done.

1288
00:59:26,990 --> 00:59:32,770
So I need drywallers to come in in
July to put drywall in this house.

1289
00:59:32,770 --> 00:59:35,630
But right now it's only March,
so I'm booking them in advance.

1290
00:59:35,630 --> 00:59:38,360
So there might be a retainer
that I need to pay.

1291
00:59:38,360 --> 00:59:42,890
Or a deposit, a reservations, whatever, to
make sure that they will be available for

1292
00:59:42,890 --> 00:59:45,880
me at that time,
cuz what if I cancel a month from now?

1293
00:59:45,880 --> 00:59:48,083
Well they blocked out
a spot in their schedule,

1294
00:59:48,083 --> 00:59:50,188
now they got to find
somebody else to fill it.

1295
00:59:50,188 --> 00:59:53,750
So that hurts them, so
a deposit is not an unreasonable request.

1296
00:59:55,520 --> 00:59:58,700
Penalties and incentives,
those are pretty important.

1297
00:59:58,700 --> 01:00:01,630
When you do a contract,
there is a legal obligation for

1298
01:00:01,630 --> 01:00:04,810
people to complete the contract, and
you would think that is enough, right?

1299
01:00:04,810 --> 01:00:09,262
That people would do the contract, but
in construction you see it all the time.

1300
01:00:09,262 --> 01:00:13,798
They go over schedule,
it's just commonplace, road work.

1301
01:00:13,798 --> 01:00:17,470
What's that city that's west of here?

1302
01:00:17,470 --> 01:00:18,420
Pulaka.

1303
01:00:18,420 --> 01:00:20,750
So we're in Gainesville Florida, and

1304
01:00:20,750 --> 01:00:23,160
there's this city,
I almost said a little city,

1305
01:00:23,160 --> 01:00:24,360
I think it's bigger than Gainesville,
>> [LAUGH]

1306
01:00:24,360 --> 01:00:26,440
>> It's a pretty decent size city, and

1307
01:00:26,440 --> 01:00:30,130
they had a road work project scheduled
that was supposed to take ten months,

1308
01:00:30,130 --> 01:00:33,020
well it ended up taking four years.

1309
01:00:33,020 --> 01:00:37,580
And the reason was the company that
originally bid it, they under bid and

1310
01:00:37,580 --> 01:00:39,050
they ran out of money, and

1311
01:00:39,050 --> 01:00:43,140
they just had all sorts of problems,
and it ran super way over schedule.

1312
01:00:43,140 --> 01:00:45,948
Finally the state had to step in and
finish the project, so

1313
01:00:45,948 --> 01:00:47,160
it was an absolute mess.

1314
01:00:48,182 --> 01:00:52,280
Well, the problem with a lot of
contracts is they center around cost.

1315
01:00:52,280 --> 01:00:56,596
And so this paving company had cut
their budget so low to win the bid,

1316
01:00:56,596 --> 01:01:00,154
that in the end,
they made it where it was impossible for

1317
01:01:00,154 --> 01:01:03,480
them to go and
actually complete the project.

1318
01:01:03,480 --> 01:01:08,240
So, it's not necessarily
the greatest idea to fixate on cost.

1319
01:01:08,240 --> 01:01:12,510
And, in fact, we might want to increase
our cost by introducing incentives.

1320
01:01:12,510 --> 01:01:15,160
Incentives say, hey,
we really need this done by July 31st, but

1321
01:01:15,160 --> 01:01:20,160
if you finish on July 1st,
we'll pay you an extra 10%.

1322
01:01:20,160 --> 01:01:25,010
We will incentivize you to
finish early if you can, or

1323
01:01:25,010 --> 01:01:26,870
if you come in under budget or
something like that.

1324
01:01:26,870 --> 01:01:29,745
If you can find a better way
to do this that saves money,

1325
01:01:29,745 --> 01:01:32,630
we'll split the difference 50/50,
or whatever, right?

1326
01:01:32,630 --> 01:01:34,110
Those are incentives.

1327
01:01:34,110 --> 01:01:40,100
Penalties are to say hey, if you don't
meet this deadline, you have to pay us,

1328
01:01:40,100 --> 01:01:43,240
or we don't have to pay you, or
something of that nature, right?

1329
01:01:43,240 --> 01:01:46,860
Usually you're saying you have to pay
us is not a good idea because if their

1330
01:01:46,860 --> 01:01:49,650
missing their deadline it's probably
because they're already out of money.

1331
01:01:49,650 --> 01:01:52,260
And if you say they have to pay you you'll
probably just run them bankrupt and

1332
01:01:52,260 --> 01:01:54,040
then you don't end up anywhere.

1333
01:01:54,040 --> 01:01:57,650
So normally the penalty should simply
be that you don't have to pay them, and

1334
01:01:57,650 --> 01:02:00,060
that way you can go and
bring in somebody else to fix it up.

1335
01:02:02,130 --> 01:02:05,090
If it's construction work,
especially, you'll have insurance and

1336
01:02:05,090 --> 01:02:06,060
performance bonds.

1337
01:02:06,060 --> 01:02:09,520
You may have things
licensed with the state.

1338
01:02:09,520 --> 01:02:12,904
It depends on your municipality, and what
their requirements, what their rules and

1339
01:02:12,904 --> 01:02:13,660
regulations are.

1340
01:02:15,190 --> 01:02:20,210
This is one that gets overlooked a lot,
subordinate subcontractor approvals.

1341
01:02:20,210 --> 01:02:25,040
In IT, it is commonplace for
you to hire a contractor, and

1342
01:02:25,040 --> 01:02:28,250
then that contractor can turn around and
subcontract it out to somebody else.

1343
01:02:28,250 --> 01:02:30,970
The problem with that is,
you don't know who that subcontractor is.

1344
01:02:30,970 --> 01:02:32,030
You didn't interact with them.

1345
01:02:32,030 --> 01:02:33,950
You weren't involved in that process.

1346
01:02:33,950 --> 01:02:36,545
So you may want to specifically
state in your statement of work,

1347
01:02:36,545 --> 01:02:37,740
that that's not allowed.

1348
01:02:37,740 --> 01:02:40,280
That you do not want to have that,
or if they do it,

1349
01:02:40,280 --> 01:02:43,770
they've got to get it approved by you,
right.

1350
01:02:43,770 --> 01:02:47,430
I have a friend, Bill,
who lives in Orlando, and

1351
01:02:47,430 --> 01:02:51,490
he's a programmer, and
he bid on a contract.

1352
01:02:51,490 --> 01:02:52,641
This was years and years ago.

1353
01:02:52,641 --> 01:02:56,210
That it was for
developing software to do bus routes.

1354
01:02:56,210 --> 01:02:59,780
And he knew he could write it, but they
needed it in a certain amount of time that

1355
01:02:59,780 --> 01:03:01,220
he just didn't have the time to do it.

1356
01:03:01,220 --> 01:03:03,220
So he bid anyway, and he won the bid.

1357
01:03:03,220 --> 01:03:05,420
And I don't remember the exact amount,
I think it was like $60,000.

1358
01:03:05,420 --> 01:03:10,665
And then he turned around and
he subbed it out to another developer for

1359
01:03:10,665 --> 01:03:14,890
$20,000 and that developer wrote all
the software and deployed it, sold it.

1360
01:03:14,890 --> 01:03:18,390
So the buyer got what they wanted and
Bill,

1361
01:03:18,390 --> 01:03:22,040
well he made $40,000 for
not doing anything, he just subbed it out.

1362
01:03:22,040 --> 01:03:22,970
It worked out.

1363
01:03:22,970 --> 01:03:27,670
So its not that there's always a negative
side to that, but there was risk.

1364
01:03:27,670 --> 01:03:29,320
Now Bill was taking that risk.

1365
01:03:29,320 --> 01:03:33,310
If that sub didn't deliver on what they
promised, he was the one left holding

1366
01:03:33,310 --> 01:03:35,886
the bag, but he knew he could
write the software if he had to.

1367
01:03:35,886 --> 01:03:38,290
So, pros and cons of that,

1368
01:03:38,290 --> 01:03:41,070
there's a lot of risk involved,
you may want to prevent it.

1369
01:03:41,070 --> 01:03:42,120
I usually do.

1370
01:03:42,120 --> 01:03:45,780
So you put in there an approval or
a forbiddance.

1371
01:03:45,780 --> 01:03:49,270
You just say you can't sub it out,
we contracted with you, you do the work.

1372
01:03:49,270 --> 01:03:51,940
But you want them to be able
to get help if they need it.

1373
01:03:51,940 --> 01:03:54,900
So if they do use a sub, you just make
sure you're involved in the process.

1374
01:03:56,390 --> 01:03:57,240
Change requests.

1375
01:03:58,320 --> 01:04:03,110
Even in the best laid plans, right,
things can happen that weren't planned.

1376
01:04:03,110 --> 01:04:07,462
And so, you may need to change the terms
of the contract to add new requirements,

1377
01:04:07,462 --> 01:04:10,790
or the company that's the seller,
right, they might need to

1378
01:04:10,790 --> 01:04:14,375
change the contract based on some
element that wasn't foreseen.

1379
01:04:14,375 --> 01:04:15,747
We need a process for that.

1380
01:04:15,747 --> 01:04:17,742
You never wanna just say,
nope, this is set in stone.

1381
01:04:17,742 --> 01:04:19,110
You're going to deliver on this.

1382
01:04:19,110 --> 01:04:21,180
I don't care what happened, right?

1383
01:04:21,180 --> 01:04:24,210
That's not gonna build a good relationship
between you and the contractor.

1384
01:04:24,210 --> 01:04:26,270
And it's gonna lessen
your odds of success.

1385
01:04:26,270 --> 01:04:28,280
So, we wanna have a change mechanism.

1386
01:04:28,280 --> 01:04:29,370
It may actually be a good thing.

1387
01:04:29,370 --> 01:04:32,270
It may be something you wanna add, and
you're willing to pay more money for it or

1388
01:04:32,270 --> 01:04:32,910
adjust the schedule.

1389
01:04:32,910 --> 01:04:35,150
So you need a way to be able
to change that contract.

1390
01:04:35,150 --> 01:04:38,230
Otherwise, you have to invalidate
the contract and draft a whole new one.

1391
01:04:38,230 --> 01:04:41,150
So, build your change
request process into there.

1392
01:04:41,150 --> 01:04:44,210
And we've got change request coming up in
a future episode, we'll get into that.

1393
01:04:45,320 --> 01:04:47,150
And then lastly, termination clauses.

1394
01:04:47,150 --> 01:04:50,820
How do we know when the contract is done,
right?

1395
01:04:50,820 --> 01:04:51,570
It's signed off.

1396
01:04:51,570 --> 01:04:52,845
The work has been delivered.

1397
01:04:52,845 --> 01:04:54,130
Now it's over.

1398
01:04:54,130 --> 01:04:56,220
And I used the wrong term earlier,
I said terminated.

1399
01:04:56,220 --> 01:05:00,655
So, when we talk about contracts,
an executed contract is one that we've

1400
01:05:00,655 --> 01:05:05,750
signed off on that is ready to run,
right, that is ready to go.

1401
01:05:05,750 --> 01:05:08,600
A terminated contract is one
that's completed, right.

1402
01:05:08,600 --> 01:05:12,850
So executed means it's basically started,
and then terminated means it's done.

1403
01:05:12,850 --> 01:05:16,130
So, a termination clause,
it's not normally saying, hey,

1404
01:05:16,130 --> 01:05:18,070
the project is done the way we wanted,
right?

1405
01:05:18,070 --> 01:05:22,053
That's just we met our acceptance
criteria right here, but

1406
01:05:22,053 --> 01:05:25,579
termination is usually early termination,
right.

1407
01:05:25,579 --> 01:05:27,504
We had a three year contract.

1408
01:05:27,504 --> 01:05:31,290
We're in year two, and it's become obvious
that you can't complete this contract.

1409
01:05:31,290 --> 01:05:34,290
So, there's no point going
the rest of the way to year three.

1410
01:05:34,290 --> 01:05:36,599
We might as well terminate now, okay.

1411
01:05:36,599 --> 01:05:38,310
So you may have mechanisms,

1412
01:05:38,310 --> 01:05:41,930
termination clauses built in that
say we do performance reports.

1413
01:05:41,930 --> 01:05:45,213
And if three performance
benchmarks aren't hit in a row,

1414
01:05:45,213 --> 01:05:47,495
the contract gets terminated, right.

1415
01:05:47,495 --> 01:05:48,580
So you may wanna have that.

1416
01:05:48,580 --> 01:05:52,440
You may also have alternative
dispute resolution, ADR.

1417
01:05:52,440 --> 01:05:54,780
That's usually gonna be like a mitigator.

1418
01:05:54,780 --> 01:05:57,765
You might bring in a, well,
what's the other word for that?

1419
01:05:57,765 --> 01:05:59,240
A mitigator.

1420
01:05:59,240 --> 01:06:00,200
>> Mediator.
>> Mediator!

1421
01:06:00,200 --> 01:06:00,940
There we go.

1422
01:06:00,940 --> 01:06:03,930
A mediator that can come in and
talk to the two parties and

1423
01:06:03,930 --> 01:06:06,060
try to work things out,
try to get things in line.

1424
01:06:06,060 --> 01:06:07,900
So you may have back-up plans, right.

1425
01:06:07,900 --> 01:06:11,753
And those kind of things can be
built into the contract too.

1426
01:06:11,753 --> 01:06:16,530
All right, so quite a bit of stuff,
all inside of that statement of work.

1427
01:06:16,530 --> 01:06:20,250
The important piece there is just to
remember to be very, very thorough.

1428
01:06:20,250 --> 01:06:23,841
The more detailed,
the safer your contract will be.

1429
01:06:23,841 --> 01:06:25,906
All right, now we still have some
more stuff I was hoping to get

1430
01:06:25,906 --> 01:06:26,720
through this segment.

1431
01:06:26,720 --> 01:06:27,495
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

1432
01:06:27,495 --> 01:06:30,340
I know we've already shot past our
little marker on the clock there.

1433
01:06:30,340 --> 01:06:31,800
So, let's stop and take a break.

1434
01:06:31,800 --> 01:06:35,310
When we get back, we'll continue on and
wrap up procurements.

1435
01:06:35,310 --> 01:06:36,330
So stay tuned.

1436
01:06:36,330 --> 01:06:38,935
We'll be back after this.

1437
01:06:38,935 --> 01:06:42,387
[SOUND] All right,

1438
01:06:42,387 --> 01:06:47,457
welcome back everybody.

1439
01:06:47,457 --> 01:06:51,009
So, now we're just gonna wrap up a few
of the last outputs that we have for

1440
01:06:51,009 --> 01:06:52,660
procurement management.

1441
01:06:52,660 --> 01:06:55,590
We got through selected sellers and
the agreements, right,

1442
01:06:55,590 --> 01:06:58,380
and I didn't realize how
long I talked there.

1443
01:06:58,380 --> 01:07:02,230
So sorry,
we went way over the time on that one.

1444
01:07:02,230 --> 01:07:04,850
But our next one is resource calendars,
all right?

1445
01:07:04,850 --> 01:07:07,203
Resource calendars are really important.

1446
01:07:07,203 --> 01:07:11,202
If you're contracting or bringing in
contractors, right, bringing in people,

1447
01:07:11,202 --> 01:07:14,300
personnel, right,
those resources have a calendar, right?

1448
01:07:14,300 --> 01:07:18,120
You might have those drywall
installers that are available for

1449
01:07:18,120 --> 01:07:19,219
two weeks at the end of May, all right.

1450
01:07:20,370 --> 01:07:22,850
So that's it, that's their calendar.

1451
01:07:22,850 --> 01:07:28,080
If you have activities to get done ahead
of schedule, well, it doesn't matter.

1452
01:07:28,080 --> 01:07:31,640
The drywallers aren't able to work
until those last two weeks of May.

1453
01:07:31,640 --> 01:07:35,399
So your project may have to sit idle while
you wait on those weeks to roll around.

1454
01:07:35,399 --> 01:07:38,713
So we need to know that because
when we put them into our schedule,

1455
01:07:38,713 --> 01:07:42,635
you remember we talked about the schedule
activity relationships, right,

1456
01:07:42,635 --> 01:07:45,155
that you have finish to start and
start to start.

1457
01:07:45,155 --> 01:07:49,480
And then you have constraints attached
to them, so start no later than,

1458
01:07:49,480 --> 01:07:51,420
start no earlier than, or so on.

1459
01:07:51,420 --> 01:07:53,035
When you deal with contractors,

1460
01:07:53,035 --> 01:07:56,660
oftentimes they give you a fixed
window that is not movable.

1461
01:07:56,660 --> 01:07:59,211
It's a constrained activity.

1462
01:07:59,211 --> 01:08:02,752
And the reason they do that is they've
got other companies they're working with

1463
01:08:02,752 --> 01:08:04,300
before and after you.

1464
01:08:04,300 --> 01:08:07,690
So, we need to make sure we have
resource calendars for that.

1465
01:08:07,690 --> 01:08:11,190
If we're renting equipment,
the same thing goes true, right?

1466
01:08:11,190 --> 01:08:15,130
If you have to rent a moving truck
as part of your project, well,

1467
01:08:15,130 --> 01:08:17,820
you've only got that truck available for
a certain window of time.

1468
01:08:17,820 --> 01:08:21,090
If you fall behind schedule,
you already rented that truck.

1469
01:08:21,090 --> 01:08:22,900
You have to pay for it, and
now you've gotta pay for

1470
01:08:22,900 --> 01:08:25,100
it again when you're actually ready for
it.

1471
01:08:25,100 --> 01:08:27,033
So we need to have that
schedule defined for

1472
01:08:27,033 --> 01:08:28,974
whatever it is that we're doing, right.

1473
01:08:28,974 --> 01:08:32,080
And here we're not talking about
the schedule of the contract,

1474
01:08:32,080 --> 01:08:35,950
when the contract starts or when the
contract finishes, what you pay out when.

1475
01:08:35,950 --> 01:08:37,273
We're not talking about that.

1476
01:08:37,273 --> 01:08:39,454
We're talking about the actual resources,
the personnel and

1477
01:08:39,454 --> 01:08:41,522
equipment that's involved in
performing that activity.

1478
01:08:41,522 --> 01:08:46,203
All right, now project management
updates and project document updates,

1479
01:08:46,203 --> 01:08:50,240
there's a lot of other information
that can come out on this one.

1480
01:08:50,240 --> 01:08:53,500
And Ronnie, you kind of laid out a lot
of that stuff in the notes here.

1481
01:08:53,500 --> 01:08:54,430
But you'll see,

1482
01:08:54,430 --> 01:08:58,070
our cost base line is probably the one
that gets affected the most, right.

1483
01:08:58,070 --> 01:09:00,180
Because when we get these quotes back,

1484
01:09:00,180 --> 01:09:04,040
when we pick our seller, we might not know
actually how much it's going to cost.

1485
01:09:04,040 --> 01:09:08,250
So, back in the earliest parts of
the planning phase, we might have had

1486
01:09:08,250 --> 01:09:11,700
a subject matter expert come in and say,
oh, you want to get a foundation laid?

1487
01:09:11,700 --> 01:09:14,730
Well, it normally costs
about $20 per square foot.

1488
01:09:14,730 --> 01:09:18,930
And so we work out what the house's
square footage is going to be,

1489
01:09:18,930 --> 01:09:22,460
we multiply it by $20,
and that's our estimate.

1490
01:09:22,460 --> 01:09:26,490
Well, when we go out and do our request
for quotes and we get actual quotes and

1491
01:09:26,490 --> 01:09:28,920
proposals back,
it's not an estimate anymore.

1492
01:09:28,920 --> 01:09:29,690
It's a quote.

1493
01:09:29,690 --> 01:09:31,990
This is what they're gonna
charge to get the work done.

1494
01:09:31,990 --> 01:09:35,900
It may be under what we budgeted,
which would be great.

1495
01:09:35,900 --> 01:09:37,290
It might be over what we budgeted.

1496
01:09:37,290 --> 01:09:38,780
It's rarely dead on, right.

1497
01:09:38,780 --> 01:09:41,820
It does happen, I suppose,
but rarely does it happen.

1498
01:09:41,820 --> 01:09:43,320
Normally it's gonna be above or below.

1499
01:09:43,320 --> 01:09:47,050
Well, if it's below does that
mean I'm now under budget?

1500
01:09:47,050 --> 01:09:48,110
No, unfortunately, it doesn't.

1501
01:09:48,110 --> 01:09:49,920
And if it's above,
does it mean I'm over budget?

1502
01:09:49,920 --> 01:09:51,990
Well, if we didn't
correct things it would.

1503
01:09:51,990 --> 01:09:55,300
But what we normally do is
immediately create change tickets,

1504
01:09:55,300 --> 01:09:58,900
change requests,
to say now that I've got the quote,

1505
01:09:58,900 --> 01:10:03,760
I need to adjust the cost of that
activity to match the quote, all right?

1506
01:10:03,760 --> 01:10:07,040
If it was less than what you
planned on paying before,

1507
01:10:07,040 --> 01:10:09,240
some people like to leave it that way.

1508
01:10:09,240 --> 01:10:09,950
Leave it there so

1509
01:10:09,950 --> 01:10:13,640
we save money which gives us padding in
case something else goes over, all right.

1510
01:10:13,640 --> 01:10:14,570
That's the instinct.

1511
01:10:14,570 --> 01:10:16,720
That's what a lot of companies encourage.

1512
01:10:16,720 --> 01:10:18,995
On the exam, that's bad, all right.

1513
01:10:18,995 --> 01:10:20,230
That's impropriety.

1514
01:10:20,230 --> 01:10:22,310
You are lying about the numbers, right?

1515
01:10:22,310 --> 01:10:24,220
So, when you get that new number in,

1516
01:10:24,220 --> 01:10:26,550
you need to do a change
ticket to correct for it.

1517
01:10:26,550 --> 01:10:30,960
If you've got padded money in your budget,
in your schedule, you've got padded time

1518
01:10:30,960 --> 01:10:33,770
in your schedule, those are supposed
to be part of the reserve, right.

1519
01:10:33,770 --> 01:10:37,340
And getting a lower quote than
what you were originally budgeted,

1520
01:10:37,340 --> 01:10:39,370
that doesn't create a built-in reserve.

1521
01:10:39,370 --> 01:10:41,510
It creates a bad estimate
that you're acting on.

1522
01:10:41,510 --> 01:10:43,630
You're still acting on that
bad estimate from before,

1523
01:10:43,630 --> 01:10:46,400
even though you now have a quote
that shows the actual value.

1524
01:10:46,400 --> 01:10:51,800
So, you will do a change request to
reflect the new cost cuz we know that,

1525
01:10:51,800 --> 01:10:55,810
the new schedule, right,
that schedule baseline.

1526
01:10:55,810 --> 01:10:57,990
Now we know the timing,
how long it's gonna take.

1527
01:10:57,990 --> 01:10:59,660
We had an estimate before.

1528
01:10:59,660 --> 01:11:02,430
Now we've got a quote,
now we've got an actual contract.

1529
01:11:03,790 --> 01:11:07,670
Now they call out a scope baseline also,
changes to the scope.

1530
01:11:07,670 --> 01:11:12,100
Well, hopefully when you draw up
your statement of work asking for

1531
01:11:12,100 --> 01:11:17,370
certain services to be provided, they come
at you and offer exactly what you want.

1532
01:11:17,370 --> 01:11:20,510
And as a result we don't have to update
our scope baseline at all, right.

1533
01:11:20,510 --> 01:11:24,190
It's gonna be done exactly the way
we want it, and that's it.

1534
01:11:24,190 --> 01:11:28,290
But if you do RFP's, request for
proposals, they might propose things to

1535
01:11:28,290 --> 01:11:31,570
you that you didn't know about,
things that you weren't aware about.

1536
01:11:31,570 --> 01:11:34,490
Some of your requirements
might negate each other, or

1537
01:11:34,490 --> 01:11:36,930
might not be possible together, all right?

1538
01:11:36,930 --> 01:11:40,590
And in that scenario, you might need
to adjust your scope as a result.

1539
01:11:40,590 --> 01:11:45,980
So, maybe for example you said
that you want to build a house.

1540
01:11:45,980 --> 01:11:48,540
I'm trying to think of an example
real fast in my mind here.

1541
01:11:48,540 --> 01:11:51,240
And you wanna have an attached garage.

1542
01:11:51,240 --> 01:11:54,840
But you also want it to be an A-frame
style house that's up on stilts,

1543
01:11:54,840 --> 01:11:56,360
maybe it's on the beach, right?

1544
01:11:56,360 --> 01:12:00,554
And they come back and they say, well, if
you're having a house built up on stilts,

1545
01:12:00,554 --> 01:12:02,519
you can't put the garage up on stilts.

1546
01:12:02,519 --> 01:12:05,019
So it's gotta be down on the ground so
it can't be a attached.

1547
01:12:05,019 --> 01:12:07,374
So, you gotta make a choice here.

1548
01:12:07,374 --> 01:12:10,135
You can have an under the house garage,
or beside.

1549
01:12:10,135 --> 01:12:11,727
You've got some decisions to make there.

1550
01:12:11,727 --> 01:12:14,258
So we might look at it and go,
oh, wow, I didn't think of that.

1551
01:12:14,258 --> 01:12:16,580
If the house is elevated,
the garage can't be elevated.

1552
01:12:16,580 --> 01:12:19,016
So You know,
maybe we could put an elevator in there.

1553
01:12:19,016 --> 01:12:23,610
But it's going to change the scope and
so it may result in that.

1554
01:12:23,610 --> 01:12:25,620
Hopefully that doesn't happen if
you've done the right planning,

1555
01:12:25,620 --> 01:12:28,080
but these contractors, they're experts.

1556
01:12:28,080 --> 01:12:29,350
Well, they should be experts, right?

1557
01:12:29,350 --> 01:12:31,170
They should know what they're doing.

1558
01:12:31,170 --> 01:12:33,490
So they may come at you
with recommendations, and

1559
01:12:33,490 --> 01:12:35,940
other information that you
just didn't know about.

1560
01:12:35,940 --> 01:12:37,690
And that may result in a scope change.

1561
01:12:39,250 --> 01:12:42,420
The other thing is our communications
plan needs to be updated.

1562
01:12:42,420 --> 01:12:45,220
The contractors,
we have to communicate with them,

1563
01:12:45,220 --> 01:12:46,740
they have to communicate with us.

1564
01:12:46,740 --> 01:12:47,920
We can't really plan for

1565
01:12:47,920 --> 01:12:53,370
that communication prior to engaging
the contractor, selecting the seller.

1566
01:12:53,370 --> 01:12:55,700
So once we've selected them.

1567
01:12:55,700 --> 01:12:58,720
Now we start to say, okay, who's
the point of contact at your company?

1568
01:12:58,720 --> 01:13:00,700
And we usually need two points of contact.

1569
01:13:00,700 --> 01:13:04,680
One for managing the project,
and one for the billing side.

1570
01:13:04,680 --> 01:13:05,940
Who is that we pay?

1571
01:13:05,940 --> 01:13:08,830
Who is it that's your accounts receivable
or accounts payable or whatever?

1572
01:13:08,830 --> 01:13:11,210
To engage for that organization.

1573
01:13:11,210 --> 01:13:12,080
That's important.

1574
01:13:12,080 --> 01:13:14,050
We have got to have that information.

1575
01:13:14,050 --> 01:13:17,310
They usually will identify that.

1576
01:13:17,310 --> 01:13:19,170
A great example.

1577
01:13:19,170 --> 01:13:22,215
I did a roll out for
a bank out in Washington,

1578
01:13:22,215 --> 01:13:24,570
that we got some T1 lines installed.

1579
01:13:24,570 --> 01:13:28,260
They're high data rate reserve lines, and

1580
01:13:28,260 --> 01:13:31,580
we got those deployed at it was
like 40 different branch offices.

1581
01:13:31,580 --> 01:13:33,770
So we were getting 40 T1's installed.

1582
01:13:33,770 --> 01:13:36,830
We got them all through a company
called Quest Communications.

1583
01:13:36,830 --> 01:13:39,150
So all purchased from the same company,
and

1584
01:13:39,150 --> 01:13:42,630
the project was getting them installed
at these 40 different branch offices.

1585
01:13:42,630 --> 01:13:46,170
Well, they had different
installers at every branch.

1586
01:13:46,170 --> 01:13:51,110
Because some of them were in Idaho,
some were in Oregon, different places.

1587
01:13:51,110 --> 01:13:54,330
So you didn't have the same
installer going everywhere.

1588
01:13:54,330 --> 01:13:58,730
So Quest actually attached they're
own project manager to that project.

1589
01:13:58,730 --> 01:14:04,590
They had a project manager, we had
a project manager, and we worked together.

1590
01:14:04,590 --> 01:14:05,930
That was my point of contact.

1591
01:14:05,930 --> 01:14:09,620
I don't think that I talked to a single,
I think that I did talk to one installer,

1592
01:14:09,620 --> 01:14:12,470
they called me because they
couldn't find the wiring closet.

1593
01:14:12,470 --> 01:14:16,490
But I didn't talk to most
of the actual installers,

1594
01:14:16,490 --> 01:14:18,410
the people that were
actually doing the work.

1595
01:14:18,410 --> 01:14:23,110
I talked to Quest's Project Manager,
and they talked to all the installers.

1596
01:14:23,110 --> 01:14:25,280
So I got the information
relayed through them.

1597
01:14:25,280 --> 01:14:27,860
I had to update our
communications management plan, so

1598
01:14:27,860 --> 01:14:31,550
that I included Quest's Project Manager
in everything that we did.

1599
01:14:31,550 --> 01:14:34,620
And they included us and
I would relay that information.

1600
01:14:34,620 --> 01:14:37,210
So a single point of contact
is really important.

1601
01:14:38,590 --> 01:14:40,190
And then the procurement management plan.

1602
01:14:40,190 --> 01:14:44,920
The procurement management plan states
how we pay out to people and so on.

1603
01:14:44,920 --> 01:14:47,820
So when we get the information
on who's their billing person.

1604
01:14:47,820 --> 01:14:49,320
Who is it that we need
to send the checks to?

1605
01:14:49,320 --> 01:14:51,570
What address do we need to
send the checks too and stuff.

1606
01:14:51,570 --> 01:14:54,680
That goes in the procurement
management plan.

1607
01:14:55,990 --> 01:14:58,950
After that there's a few other
project document updates that we do.

1608
01:14:58,950 --> 01:15:01,270
Most of these are pretty straightforward.

1609
01:15:01,270 --> 01:15:03,310
The requirements documentation.

1610
01:15:03,310 --> 01:15:06,490
If we've modified our scope,
our requirements might modify too.

1611
01:15:06,490 --> 01:15:08,640
So that might be a change
that has to happen.

1612
01:15:08,640 --> 01:15:11,110
Our requirements
traceability documentation.

1613
01:15:12,420 --> 01:15:15,689
If we're adding new requirements as
part of this contract, or whatever.

1614
01:15:15,689 --> 01:15:16,770
Where do those come from?

1615
01:15:17,850 --> 01:15:19,370
The risk register.

1616
01:15:19,370 --> 01:15:23,530
When you deal with a contractor,
you might be deferring some risks to them.

1617
01:15:23,530 --> 01:15:25,250
So you put that in your risk register.

1618
01:15:25,250 --> 01:15:27,330
You say hey this risk is here, but
we don't worry about it anymore.

1619
01:15:27,330 --> 01:15:28,720
Now it's their problem.

1620
01:15:28,720 --> 01:15:31,480
Or You may have eliminated
a risk by contracting out.

1621
01:15:31,480 --> 01:15:34,100
Maybe this contract is
an insurance contract.

1622
01:15:34,100 --> 01:15:36,770
So you've now just insured
yourself against that risk.

1623
01:15:36,770 --> 01:15:39,390
You can defer the risk off
to the insurance company.

1624
01:15:39,390 --> 01:15:40,710
So you'd put that in the register too.

1625
01:15:41,990 --> 01:15:43,440
And then your stakeholder register.

1626
01:15:43,440 --> 01:15:45,200
Now, this one is kind of weird.

1627
01:15:46,510 --> 01:15:49,630
Basically, your stakeholders don't
really change as far as your

1628
01:15:49,630 --> 01:15:50,940
internal project team,

1629
01:15:50,940 --> 01:15:54,280
and the other people who are associated
with the project in your company.

1630
01:15:54,280 --> 01:15:55,880
But that contractor.

1631
01:15:55,880 --> 01:15:57,830
They just became a stakeholder.

1632
01:15:57,830 --> 01:16:02,100
They need to know if stuff leading up
to that project is behind schedule.

1633
01:16:02,100 --> 01:16:03,640
Because then they won't be
ready to do their work.

1634
01:16:03,640 --> 01:16:05,440
Or they won't be able to do their work.

1635
01:16:05,440 --> 01:16:08,340
So they need to be kept in the loop and
aware, and

1636
01:16:08,340 --> 01:16:10,800
that means bringing them into
your stakeholder register.

1637
01:16:10,800 --> 01:16:12,860
They don't necessarily,

1638
01:16:12,860 --> 01:16:15,490
they don't necessarily care if
the whole project finishes or not.

1639
01:16:15,490 --> 01:16:17,330
They really just care about their part.

1640
01:16:17,330 --> 01:16:20,650
But they will recognize that other aspects
of the project may affect them, so

1641
01:16:20,650 --> 01:16:22,110
they need to be informed.

1642
01:16:22,110 --> 01:16:24,870
And it's real important
to figure out a single

1643
01:16:24,870 --> 01:16:26,680
point of contact with the other company.

1644
01:16:26,680 --> 01:16:29,530
You don't want to deal with trying to
reach out to all their various employees.

1645
01:16:29,530 --> 01:16:32,220
If they have staff changes, you don't
want to get involved in all that.

1646
01:16:32,220 --> 01:16:34,990
Try and have a single point of contact,
and a backup is usually a good idea.

1647
01:16:36,710 --> 01:16:37,590
All right.

1648
01:16:37,590 --> 01:16:39,820
So that in a nutshell
>> [LAUGH]

1649
01:16:39,820 --> 01:16:40,870
>> Is conducting procurements.

1650
01:16:40,870 --> 01:16:42,230
It's a lot, right?

1651
01:16:42,230 --> 01:16:44,760
It doesn't really look like a lot,
but it really is.

1652
01:16:44,760 --> 01:16:45,740
Because it's contracts.

1653
01:16:45,740 --> 01:16:47,260
You're gonna have lawyers involved.

1654
01:16:47,260 --> 01:16:49,170
Things like that and
that always makes things complex.

1655
01:16:50,650 --> 01:16:54,470
But, the key thing I want you guys to
remember though, is that this process,

1656
01:16:54,470 --> 01:16:56,190
this conduct procurements process.

1657
01:16:56,190 --> 01:17:00,490
When we look at the official matrix
here for our process groups,

1658
01:17:00,490 --> 01:17:04,108
you'll see that it does fall
right here under executing.

1659
01:17:04,108 --> 01:17:06,320
We're actually performing
these activities, but

1660
01:17:06,320 --> 01:17:08,950
a lot of people started
way back here in planning.

1661
01:17:08,950 --> 01:17:11,930
So these two overlap a good bit.

1662
01:17:11,930 --> 01:17:14,630
Because of the nature of the schedule and

1663
01:17:14,630 --> 01:17:20,120
budget stuff that we just don't know
until we engage in the contracts.

1664
01:17:20,120 --> 01:17:23,010
We still have stakeholder
engagement to jump into, so

1665
01:17:23,010 --> 01:17:24,190
we're gonna get to that next.

1666
01:17:24,190 --> 01:17:27,890
I know we've done kind of short segment
here, but we did such a long one before.

1667
01:17:27,890 --> 01:17:30,030
Let's stop here and take a break.

1668
01:17:30,030 --> 01:17:31,310
And when we get back,

1669
01:17:31,310 --> 01:17:35,370
we'll wrap up the executing phase by
taking a look at stakeholder engagement.

1670
01:17:35,370 --> 01:17:37,372
So stay tuned, we'll be back in a few.

1671
01:17:37,372 --> 01:17:45,361
[MUSIC]

1672
01:17:45,361 --> 01:17:46,810
Welcome back everybody.

1673
01:17:46,810 --> 01:17:49,720
So for
our final process of the executing group,

1674
01:17:49,720 --> 01:17:52,250
we've got managed stakeholder engagement.

1675
01:17:52,250 --> 01:17:56,340
And this is another one where there's
not a whole heck of a lot for us to do.

1676
01:17:56,340 --> 01:17:59,640
We've already come up with our plan,
our stakeholder management plan.

1677
01:17:59,640 --> 01:18:03,570
This is just applying it, doing all
the things we said we were going to do.

1678
01:18:03,570 --> 01:18:07,340
Our obvious input is the stakeholder
management plan itself,

1679
01:18:07,340 --> 01:18:08,900
that's what we're applying.

1680
01:18:08,900 --> 01:18:12,200
Our communications management
plan comes into this too because

1681
01:18:12,200 --> 01:18:14,000
how do you interact
with your stakeholders?

1682
01:18:14,000 --> 01:18:17,330
Through communications right,
so that's a big piece of it.

1683
01:18:17,330 --> 01:18:20,880
We've also got our change management log
and our organizational process assets,

1684
01:18:20,880 --> 01:18:23,590
the things we kind of expect to
see going into one of these.

1685
01:18:23,590 --> 01:18:27,710
So nothing really new and
earth shattering for our inputs there.

1686
01:18:27,710 --> 01:18:30,110
Same thing really goes for
tools and techniques.

1687
01:18:30,110 --> 01:18:33,140
A lot of these are the same things we
talked about when it came to managing

1688
01:18:33,140 --> 01:18:34,820
our team.

1689
01:18:34,820 --> 01:18:37,910
Managing your stakeholders is not really
any different than managing your project

1690
01:18:37,910 --> 01:18:40,100
management team,
there's just more of them.

1691
01:18:41,130 --> 01:18:43,240
So our communication
methods might be different.

1692
01:18:43,240 --> 01:18:45,860
A project management team,
we might do a lot of meetings.

1693
01:18:46,910 --> 01:18:49,830
Stand up meetings,
get people together all in one room.

1694
01:18:49,830 --> 01:18:54,240
But stakeholders It can be near impossible
to get them all together at the same time.

1695
01:18:54,240 --> 01:18:56,570
So these might be things like phone calls,

1696
01:18:56,570 --> 01:19:00,480
recorded phone calls, it might just be
emails, or other messages like that.

1697
01:19:00,480 --> 01:19:03,040
Whatever is the appropriate
communication method.

1698
01:19:03,040 --> 01:19:06,720
And you know there's all sorts of
different communication methods available.

1699
01:19:06,720 --> 01:19:07,630
Where are my notes on that?

1700
01:19:07,630 --> 01:19:09,440
Let's see, here.

1701
01:19:09,440 --> 01:19:12,200
All sorts of communications methods
available based on whatever it is that

1702
01:19:12,200 --> 01:19:14,010
we're trying to do.

1703
01:19:14,010 --> 01:19:15,448
But we've got those.

1704
01:19:15,448 --> 01:19:16,003
>> Mm-hm.

1705
01:19:16,003 --> 01:19:19,200
>> The other thing is
interpersonal skills.

1706
01:19:19,200 --> 01:19:22,320
That's us communicating and
building trust,

1707
01:19:22,320 --> 01:19:26,370
resolving conflict, active listening,
overcoming resistance to change.

1708
01:19:26,370 --> 01:19:28,360
These are the same as with the team.

1709
01:19:28,360 --> 01:19:31,990
One of the bigger ones though is that last
one, overcoming resistance to change.

1710
01:19:31,990 --> 01:19:36,090
Your stakeholders, remember way back
in some of our earlier episodes, we

1711
01:19:36,090 --> 01:19:40,150
said there are some stakeholders who want
to help your project and see it succeed.

1712
01:19:40,150 --> 01:19:43,590
And there are some stakeholders who
don't want to help your project, and

1713
01:19:43,590 --> 01:19:45,140
don't want to see it succeed.

1714
01:19:45,140 --> 01:19:47,670
We have to manage both types.

1715
01:19:47,670 --> 01:19:50,850
So how do we encourage them to
understand the benefits of the project?

1716
01:19:50,850 --> 01:19:53,570
Or maybe not the benefits,
maybe the necessity of it.

1717
01:19:53,570 --> 01:19:56,250
Maybe this is a project
that you have to do.

1718
01:19:56,250 --> 01:19:57,600
A new legal requirement.

1719
01:19:57,600 --> 01:20:00,470
A regulation was passed and
your company has to meet it.

1720
01:20:00,470 --> 01:20:02,380
People might not like it,
but you don't have a choice.

1721
01:20:02,380 --> 01:20:04,070
It's either that or go out of business.

1722
01:20:04,070 --> 01:20:06,640
So overcoming that resistance to change.

1723
01:20:06,640 --> 01:20:07,889
How we communicate and

1724
01:20:07,889 --> 01:20:11,710
smooth those people to get things
running along the way we need them.

1725
01:20:11,710 --> 01:20:15,706
>> This is where your skills and
the intrapersonal relationships You become

1726
01:20:15,706 --> 01:20:19,580
more of the coach and you hate say it,
even the ad hoc project champion.

1727
01:20:19,580 --> 01:20:22,450
We don't have an official one,
because this is what you need done, right?

1728
01:20:22,450 --> 01:20:25,090
And you need your stakeholders
to be on the same page you are.

1729
01:20:25,090 --> 01:20:27,270
And so,
the better you are at these skills,

1730
01:20:27,270 --> 01:20:30,220
the more you're going to actually see
them come on board behind you and

1731
01:20:30,220 --> 01:20:33,320
actually really help you now become
a champion for your project.

1732
01:20:33,320 --> 01:20:34,910
So great skills to have.

1733
01:20:34,910 --> 01:20:37,010
>> Yep.
And then our general management skills.

1734
01:20:37,010 --> 01:20:38,570
We're managing people here, right?

1735
01:20:38,570 --> 01:20:41,970
And we might not be
their direct management.

1736
01:20:41,970 --> 01:20:44,560
They might have a functional
manager they answer to but

1737
01:20:44,560 --> 01:20:47,120
in terms of the project they answer to us.

1738
01:20:47,120 --> 01:20:50,360
And so we've gotta be able to
facilitate consensus, right?

1739
01:20:50,360 --> 01:20:51,915
That's problem solving.

1740
01:20:51,915 --> 01:20:53,950
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or conflict resolution, right?

1741
01:20:53,950 --> 01:20:54,700
>> Right.

1742
01:20:54,700 --> 01:20:56,550
Influence people to support the project.

1743
01:20:56,550 --> 01:21:01,110
Get those people who aren't necessarily in
support of it to become supporters of it.

1744
01:21:01,110 --> 01:21:02,750
Negotiating agreements, right?

1745
01:21:02,750 --> 01:21:04,500
Handling the contract side of things.

1746
01:21:04,500 --> 01:21:08,910
And modifying organizational behavior
to accept the project outcomes.

1747
01:21:08,910 --> 01:21:10,670
There's more than one
outcome to a project.

1748
01:21:10,670 --> 01:21:14,220
Obviously we hope that it's going
to be a successful project, but if

1749
01:21:14,220 --> 01:21:18,940
the project is doomed to failure, if it's
beyond that point of recovery, being ready

1750
01:21:18,940 --> 01:21:22,040
to make the next steps to correct for
it after the project has failed, right?

1751
01:21:22,040 --> 01:21:23,760
So being set up for that.

1752
01:21:23,760 --> 01:21:26,320
These are all things that get
kind of involved in this process.

1753
01:21:27,490 --> 01:21:29,565
All right, now,
our outputs are pretty straightforward.

1754
01:21:29,565 --> 01:21:32,030
But we are going to see
a few new things here.

1755
01:21:32,030 --> 01:21:35,440
I know I talked about the issue log in
the last episode we talked about it.

1756
01:21:35,440 --> 01:21:40,470
Any problems or issues that occur in terms
of our stakeholders who want to record,

1757
01:21:40,470 --> 01:21:43,840
we mentioned in the last episode in
terms of our project management team,

1758
01:21:43,840 --> 01:21:46,340
it's the same thing for
the stakeholders, all right?

1759
01:21:46,340 --> 01:21:49,790
Our change requests,
especially your sponsor,

1760
01:21:49,790 --> 01:21:53,430
your key stakeholder,
may have changes or recommendations.

1761
01:21:53,430 --> 01:21:54,510
Other ones may come from

1762
01:21:54,510 --> 01:21:56,820
other stakeholders that
are attached to the project.

1763
01:21:56,820 --> 01:22:00,160
Those will lead to change requests
which may or may not be approved.

1764
01:22:00,160 --> 01:22:02,430
It just depends on what
it is they're asking and

1765
01:22:02,430 --> 01:22:04,509
what the tolerances
are within your organization.

1766
01:22:05,960 --> 01:22:09,170
And then just our normal updates,
project management plan updates,

1767
01:22:09,170 --> 01:22:11,290
project document updates,
nothing new there.

1768
01:22:11,290 --> 01:22:14,430
But the one we want to pay attention
to is organizational process assets.

1769
01:22:14,430 --> 01:22:16,490
We see this one all the time, right?

1770
01:22:16,490 --> 01:22:19,420
And the majority of what's in here,
it makes sense, right?

1771
01:22:19,420 --> 01:22:23,400
Stakeholder notifications,
project reports, project presentations.

1772
01:22:23,400 --> 01:22:25,910
But we get this new one in here,
lessons learned documentation.

1773
01:22:27,260 --> 01:22:29,480
I know I've referenced it before too.

1774
01:22:29,480 --> 01:22:33,090
When you're dealing with stakeholders,
if this is the very

1775
01:22:33,090 --> 01:22:37,000
first project that stakeholder's ever
been a part of, then they're an unknown.

1776
01:22:37,000 --> 01:22:39,140
You don't know what it's going
to be like to deal with them.

1777
01:22:39,140 --> 01:22:42,650
They may turn out to be extremely pleasant
and very forthcoming with information.

1778
01:22:42,650 --> 01:22:44,960
Things may work great with that person.

1779
01:22:44,960 --> 01:22:48,000
Or they might be extremely change averse.

1780
01:22:48,000 --> 01:22:49,909
And while they might not be the sponsor,

1781
01:22:49,909 --> 01:22:52,831
they might have a large degree
of influence over the company,

1782
01:22:52,831 --> 01:22:56,270
and maybe even over the project,
so it'd be nice to know that.

1783
01:22:56,270 --> 01:22:59,420
Well, if they had participated
in a previous project, and

1784
01:22:59,420 --> 01:23:02,570
the project manager kept their
lessons learned documentation, right,

1785
01:23:02,570 --> 01:23:04,560
their notes, we could benefit from that.

1786
01:23:05,800 --> 01:23:06,860
That's what that's all about, right?

1787
01:23:06,860 --> 01:23:09,760
It's sharing information
between your projects.

1788
01:23:09,760 --> 01:23:12,900
If your company has more
than one project manager,

1789
01:23:12,900 --> 01:23:16,260
then each one has their own
separate sets of knowledge.

1790
01:23:16,260 --> 01:23:19,760
It's nice to be able to consolidate that
together into an information database.

1791
01:23:19,760 --> 01:23:21,590
Or a project management database.

1792
01:23:21,590 --> 01:23:24,817
That you can look at and get that data and
share that information, okay?

1793
01:23:26,300 --> 01:23:29,460
But the thing I always remember
is that when it comes to managing

1794
01:23:29,460 --> 01:23:33,560
stakeholder engagement it's really
not any different than your team and

1795
01:23:33,560 --> 01:23:35,300
your team's communication.

1796
01:23:35,300 --> 01:23:38,170
So it's really the same
process over again.

1797
01:23:38,170 --> 01:23:39,020
Not too terribly exciting.

1798
01:23:39,020 --> 01:23:39,520
>> No.

1799
01:23:39,520 --> 01:23:40,790
All right.

1800
01:23:40,790 --> 01:23:43,420
Ronny, can you think of anything
that we left off on that one?

1801
01:23:43,420 --> 01:23:44,910
It's pretty straightforward.

1802
01:23:44,910 --> 01:23:46,450
>> Yeah,
nothing that we really left off here.

1803
01:23:46,450 --> 01:23:49,970
But remember, the idea of actually keeping
your stakeholders engaged in this.

1804
01:23:49,970 --> 01:23:51,790
Once you start actually getting
somebody to lose interest,

1805
01:23:51,790 --> 01:23:55,180
they become maybe more adverse
to your project succeeding, so

1806
01:23:55,180 --> 01:23:58,240
the idea of you as project manager
becoming a coach at this point.

1807
01:23:58,240 --> 01:24:01,810
Like I said it's really kind of one of
those key aspects of something that

1808
01:24:01,810 --> 01:24:03,240
we do need to develop.

1809
01:24:03,240 --> 01:24:05,810
Not just saying okay, here is what
the company says needs to be done, but

1810
01:24:05,810 --> 01:24:09,306
this is why you should also remain
involved and support this project.

1811
01:24:09,306 --> 01:24:10,510
>> You know the one I've seen,

1812
01:24:10,510 --> 01:24:13,650
and we actually have it happen
here at ITProTV is that you might

1813
01:24:13,650 --> 01:24:17,359
have a stakeholder who's actually
a participant in more than one project.

1814
01:24:17,359 --> 01:24:17,870
>> Yeah.
>> And

1815
01:24:17,870 --> 01:24:21,510
one project may be more glamorous and
exciting than the other one.

1816
01:24:21,510 --> 01:24:24,110
It doesn't mean that one project's more
important than the other it's just one

1817
01:24:24,110 --> 01:24:24,894
might be more glamorous.

1818
01:24:24,894 --> 01:24:26,200
>> Yeah.
>> They might want to do one and

1819
01:24:26,200 --> 01:24:27,021
not want to do the other.

1820
01:24:27,021 --> 01:24:28,310
>> Right.
>> So managing that engagement,

1821
01:24:28,310 --> 01:24:31,900
part of that is keeping them involved
in the less glamorous project

1822
01:24:31,900 --> 01:24:33,380
keeping that moving forward.

1823
01:24:33,380 --> 01:24:36,730
You don't want to sacrifice one project
for another, and that's a very real thing.

1824
01:24:39,690 --> 01:24:43,360
Working at ITProTV we have a lot
of stuff here that's really cool.

1825
01:24:43,360 --> 01:24:47,330
A lot of the technology we work with, the
server side and stuff, it's a lot of fun.

1826
01:24:47,330 --> 01:24:51,420
But then there's things
like uploading notes

1827
01:24:51,420 --> 01:24:56,140
into the website which is just monotonous,
long tedious work.

1828
01:24:56,140 --> 01:24:57,730
And it's not exciting.

1829
01:24:57,730 --> 01:24:59,960
It's not glamorous but
it needs to get done.

1830
01:24:59,960 --> 01:25:04,750
It's just as important as doing that new
how to video on how to set up an arcade

1831
01:25:04,750 --> 01:25:06,378
cabinet or something like that.

1832
01:25:06,378 --> 01:25:09,810
So how to kind of balance those two
together to keep people working in

1833
01:25:09,810 --> 01:25:10,510
the various projects?

1834
01:25:10,510 --> 01:25:11,010
It's all part of it.
>> Yes.

1835
01:25:12,810 --> 01:25:13,780
>> All right.

1836
01:25:13,780 --> 01:25:16,170
Well that pretty much wraps
up the executing phase.

1837
01:25:16,170 --> 01:25:19,340
So the entire executing phase
really just took us two episodes.

1838
01:25:19,340 --> 01:25:21,960
And that should show you guys what
you are going to see on the exam.

1839
01:25:21,960 --> 01:25:24,834
Not a lot of the exam is going to
come from the executing phase,

1840
01:25:24,834 --> 01:25:28,360
because the project manager
is mostly just watching.

1841
01:25:28,360 --> 01:25:30,637
Right, and
that watching can be very detailed, but

1842
01:25:30,637 --> 01:25:33,432
the data that we collect ,we then
have to analyze and process and

1843
01:25:33,432 --> 01:25:36,360
that's what we do in the monitoring and
controlling phase.

1844
01:25:36,360 --> 01:25:38,090
So we're about to move into a doozy.

1845
01:25:38,090 --> 01:25:39,900
The monitoring and
controlling phase is big.

1846
01:25:39,900 --> 01:25:41,368
A lot of stuff there.

1847
01:25:41,368 --> 01:25:44,100
So all right,
well let me just remind everybody,

1848
01:25:44,100 --> 01:25:47,130
if you have questions on any
of this feel free to ask.

1849
01:25:47,130 --> 01:25:49,770
Live during the show,
you can go to itpro.tv/live.

1850
01:25:49,770 --> 01:25:53,730
You'll see the chat box right beneath
the video, post your questions there.

1851
01:25:53,730 --> 01:25:55,220
We monitor and answer during the show.

1852
01:25:56,360 --> 01:25:57,786
If you have questions after the show.

1853
01:25:57,786 --> 01:25:58,389
>> Q and A.

1854
01:25:58,389 --> 01:26:00,720
>> Use the Q and A forums, right?

1855
01:26:00,720 --> 01:26:04,836
At the top of every page on the itpro.tv
website, you'll see a link that says Q and

1856
01:26:04,836 --> 01:26:07,220
A, it will take you into the forums.

1857
01:26:07,220 --> 01:26:08,090
Post your questions there.

1858
01:26:08,090 --> 01:26:11,960
We monitor and answer all throughout the
week, so take advantage of that resource.

1859
01:26:11,960 --> 01:26:14,140
It is there for you.

1860
01:26:14,140 --> 01:26:15,890
Well, I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1861
01:26:15,890 --> 01:26:18,010
Signing off for ITProTV, I am Don Pezet.

1862
01:26:18,010 --> 01:26:18,850
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1863
01:26:18,850 --> 01:26:20,602
>> And we will see you next time.

1864
01:26:20,602 --> 01:26:30,602
[MUSIC]

1865
01:26:32,685 --> 01:26:38,507
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don start next phase of Project Management: the Monitoring and Controlling phase. They talking about the importance of setting good controls in place to facilitate project work. Also, the guys emphasize the controls to help out with change management. They end the show talking about keeping scope creep out of the project.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Controlling
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:19,323 --> 00:00:22,817
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,817 --> 00:00:32,817
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:34,082 --> 00:00:36,196
All right.
Good morning, good afternoon, and

5
00:00:36,196 --> 00:00:36,971
good evening.

6
00:00:36,971 --> 00:00:37,860
And welcome back.

7
00:00:37,860 --> 00:00:42,530
To another episode of IP Pro TV, I am
your host, Don, never misses a cue Pezet,

8
00:00:42,530 --> 00:00:45,430
back again with Mr.
Ronnie Wong, how is it going Ronnie?

9
00:00:45,430 --> 00:00:49,760
>> I am very excited,
I have come up with a new possible show,

10
00:00:49,760 --> 00:00:52,293
taking off Off of Breaking Bad
called Fixing Good.

11
00:00:52,293 --> 00:00:54,055
[LAUGH]
>> Fixing Good?

12
00:00:54,055 --> 00:00:54,925
>> And you'll make what?

13
00:00:54,925 --> 00:00:56,285
>> Nothing.
>> Delicious breakfast treats

14
00:00:56,285 --> 00:00:57,092
instead of methamphetamines?

15
00:00:57,092 --> 00:00:57,672
>> Yeah, nothing.

16
00:00:57,672 --> 00:01:00,800
I thought it was a little bit funny so I
thought we would just throw that in there.

17
00:01:00,800 --> 00:01:02,380
>> [LAUGH] We're gonna run with it.

18
00:01:02,380 --> 00:01:07,490
We're gonna jump right back
into project management today.

19
00:01:07,490 --> 00:01:10,323
We left off in our previous
episode with the executing phase,

20
00:01:10,323 --> 00:01:12,786
which, to be honest with you,
it was kind of boring.

21
00:01:12,786 --> 00:01:17,050
I mean, there wasn't a whole heck of
a lot for us to do as a project manager.

22
00:01:17,050 --> 00:01:21,110
You might have been scratching your head
as you went through that, saying, man,

23
00:01:21,110 --> 00:01:24,250
that was a lot of watching stuff happen,
but what am I doing?

24
00:01:24,250 --> 00:01:24,910
I'm doing nothing.

25
00:01:24,910 --> 00:01:27,418
I'm just watching and collecting data.

26
00:01:27,418 --> 00:01:30,050
Now we're gonna talk about what we're
supposed to be doing while that's

27
00:01:31,090 --> 00:01:32,230
happening.

28
00:01:32,230 --> 00:01:34,030
I've probably mentioned it a 1000 times.

29
00:01:34,030 --> 00:01:35,660
Let me just do it again.

30
00:01:35,660 --> 00:01:38,000
When we're in the executing phase,

31
00:01:38,000 --> 00:01:42,120
when execution is occurring the project
manager and most of the project management

32
00:01:42,120 --> 00:01:47,420
team is shifting their role over
to monitoring and controlling.

33
00:01:47,420 --> 00:01:48,990
Now what does that mean?

34
00:01:48,990 --> 00:01:49,910
Monitoring.

35
00:01:49,910 --> 00:01:51,870
We're watching what happens, right.

36
00:01:51,870 --> 00:01:54,350
A lot of what we describe in execution.

37
00:01:54,350 --> 00:01:57,890
We're watching that data, and
then we're interpreting it.

38
00:01:57,890 --> 00:01:59,690
That's the unsaid thing right here, right.

39
00:01:59,690 --> 00:02:03,880
We're interpreting that data that we get,
to figure out how the project is going.

40
00:02:03,880 --> 00:02:06,170
And if things are going great.

00:02:06,170 --> 00:02:10,360

45

that our project stays on track,

46
00:02:24,370 --> 00:02:25,800
we need to keep the train on the rails.

47
00:02:25,800 --> 00:02:28,460
So that we meet our
destination as planned.

In monitoring and controlling,

And when we have that information

00:05:18,580 --> 00:05:21,940

Anywhere we have variance,

All variance is bad, but

112
00:05:33,450 --> 00:05:35,260
You can tolerate a certain

113
00:05:35,260 --> 00:05:37,390

You've got that Window you've

00:05:41,890 --> 00:05:44,700

00:05:44,700 --> 00:05:46,970

We need a forecast,

We get that from our historical data.

If we've been spending more money, or

what's that gonna look like over time?

Is it gonna get bigger,

That variance, right.

And what can we do to stop it.

Or is there a reason?

There might be a very valid reason.

I might have planned on buying

147

And maybe that didn't happen,
so I call in and I'm like,

00:06:46,420 --> 00:06:48,600
hey guys why didn't you buy those servers?

149
00:06:48,600 --> 00:06:53,150
And they said well, it turns out there's

150
00:06:53,150 --> 00:06:58,440
And if we wait just one week, the sale
will save us a bunch of money, and

151
00:06:58,440 --> 00:07:02,910
we can pay to overnight the servers and
get them here faster, and still pay less.

152
00:07:02,910 --> 00:07:04,020
We're gonna save money.

153
00:07:04,020 --> 00:07:04,830
That's great!

154
00:07:04,830 --> 00:07:06,440
Wonderful, we're gonna save some money.

155
00:07:06,440 --> 00:07:08,420
That's why the variance is there.

156

Now, let's clear up the variance, right?

Let's do a change ticket to say, oh, those

00:07:13,990 --> 00:07:16,221
now they're going to cost $45,000, right?

00:07:16,221 --> 00:07:19,860
That's what we need to do,
that's controlling that variance and

making sure it gets

161

Validated changes, all right?

00:07:26,000 --> 00:07:28,970
Somebody put forth a change,
a change request,

163
00:07:28,970 --> 00:07:31,220
we can actually see it

00:07:31,220 --> 00:07:34,020
I think ever since we got into executing,

166
00:07:38,030 --> 00:07:41,200
Just because a change request is output,

Notice it's a change request.

168
00:07:43,760 --> 00:07:47,917
We're requesting the change,
the change board could deny it.

169
00:07:47,917 --> 00:07:51,647
Just because it's output
doesn't mean it happens, but

170
00:07:51,647 --> 00:07:56,619
if it's accepted, if the change is
allowed, then it gets put into place and

171
00:07:56,619 --> 00:07:58,655
it's now a validated change.

172
00:07:58,655 --> 00:08:01,956
We validate to ensure the change
was made as specified and

173
00:08:01,956 --> 00:08:04,840

as part of our routine.

174
00:08:04,840 --> 00:08:06,680
So that's another input for us.

175
00:08:08,090 --> 00:08:08,840
All right.

Work Performance Information,

People who are actually

So the things our company already

00:08:27,160 --> 00:08:29,000
we've got that information too.

183
00:08:29,000 --> 00:08:32,400
All of that feeds into how we monitor and

00:08:34,030 --> 00:08:37,260
So once we've got that,

185
00:08:37,260 --> 00:08:40,990
We analyze the data, and
if necessary we act upon it.

00:08:40,990 --> 00:08:44,190
So the number one way to do

You're a project manager,
you have a certain set of skills,

188

things that you have in your mind that you
know how to apply in this environment,

189

it just made me think of that movie,
Taken.

00:08:52,930 --> 00:08:54,340
>> Yeah.
>> With Liam Neeson and

191
00:08:54,340 --> 00:08:56,450
he said I've got
a particular set of skills.

192
00:08:56,450 --> 00:08:56,950

193
00:08:56,950 --> 00:08:58,150
>> That's how a project manager is, and

[LAUGH] But you get to keep

Moving along on schedule and on budget.

197
00:09:07,790 --> 00:09:10,120
That's what we want and that's what
