198
00:09:12,030 --> 00:09:13,730
Now, analytical techniques.

199
00:09:14,905 --> 00:09:17,560
Yeah, this is talking about
how we break down that data.

200
00:09:17,560 --> 00:09:21,610
When you get all this information,
it's not necessarily in usable format.

201
00:09:21,610 --> 00:09:24,400
It's not listing stuff in the future,
it's just listing right now.

202
00:09:24,400 --> 00:09:26,460
I mentioned we need to predict the future.

203
00:09:26,460 --> 00:09:30,990
Well we use analytical
techniques to do that.

204
00:09:30,990 --> 00:09:36,202
And you'll see,
I'm the the completely wrong thing.

205
00:09:36,202 --> 00:09:39,900
All right well when we talk about
analytical techniques, we're talking about

206
00:09:39,900 --> 00:09:44,540
ways that we can analyze that data and
turn it into usable information.

207
00:09:44,540 --> 00:09:48,620
And they call out a few specifically,
let me bring up that document,

208
00:09:48,620 --> 00:09:51,740
I've got the show notes for
the last episode here.

209
00:09:51,740 --> 00:09:55,851
So we need to get into our,
>> Controlling and

210
00:09:55,851 --> 00:09:59,370
monitoring and project integration.

211
00:09:59,370 --> 00:10:00,350
>> There we go.

212
00:10:00,350 --> 00:10:01,370
Okay.

213
00:10:01,370 --> 00:10:04,630
So, let me just find it here.

214
00:10:04,630 --> 00:10:06,250
There we go, analytical techniques.

215
00:10:06,250 --> 00:10:09,250
So you'll see some of the different things
that we can use to analyze that data.

216
00:10:09,250 --> 00:10:11,910
And there's quite a bit
tucked away in here.

217
00:10:11,910 --> 00:10:13,680
Let me turn off my word wrap there.

218
00:10:13,680 --> 00:10:16,760
So things like regression analysis.

219
00:10:16,760 --> 00:10:21,480
When a change happens, how does that
affect the rest of our project?

220
00:10:21,480 --> 00:10:25,930
Remember that a single change can cause a
cascading change throughout your project.

221
00:10:25,930 --> 00:10:31,150
And you may find that by fixing one thing
you've actually broken something else.

222
00:10:31,150 --> 00:10:35,740
So maybe something that is falling behind
schedule, so you get a change request,

223
00:10:35,740 --> 00:10:38,540
say hey can we have a bit more time,
the change request got approved,

224
00:10:38,540 --> 00:10:40,010
great that's solved.

225
00:10:40,010 --> 00:10:42,540
But by moving that one back,

226
00:10:42,540 --> 00:10:46,830
now you got a constrained scheduled
activity later on that can't move.

227
00:10:46,830 --> 00:10:48,610
And now it's overlapping
with something else.

228
00:10:48,610 --> 00:10:50,770
You've created another problem.

229
00:10:50,770 --> 00:10:53,440
So, looking at how an action or a change

230
00:10:53,440 --> 00:10:56,720
cascades through our project is basically
what we do with regression analysis.

231
00:10:57,940 --> 00:10:59,820
We've got things like grouping methods.

232
00:10:59,820 --> 00:11:01,950
Where we can take the data
that we're getting and

233
00:11:01,950 --> 00:11:04,390
group it together to form a big picture.

234
00:11:04,390 --> 00:11:07,720
If you're getting performance reports back
from multiple people on the same team,

235
00:11:07,720 --> 00:11:11,160
you can aggregate that data
together to form a team report.

236
00:11:11,160 --> 00:11:13,400
And there's a number of different
group techniques that are out there.

237
00:11:14,460 --> 00:11:15,590
Causal analysis.

238
00:11:15,590 --> 00:11:17,320
This is one of my favorites.

239
00:11:17,320 --> 00:11:20,850
You will see stuff in the news
all of the time that will say,

240
00:11:22,720 --> 00:11:26,270
people who live in houses painted green
have a higher chance of getting cancer.

241
00:11:27,320 --> 00:11:31,660
There are a lot of times
where you have causality.

242
00:11:31,660 --> 00:11:35,640
And they call them correlations and
causality.

243
00:11:35,640 --> 00:11:39,540
And just because something correlates
doesn't necessarily mean that you've found

244
00:11:39,540 --> 00:11:40,990
the cause of the problem.

245
00:11:40,990 --> 00:11:44,890
So there's a lot of outlying
factors that could cause,

246
00:11:44,890 --> 00:11:47,410
cancer in a person who happens
to live in a green house.

247
00:11:47,410 --> 00:11:50,280
It may just be coincidence
that the house was green, and

248
00:11:50,280 --> 00:11:54,680
that in that sample that we took, those
people just had a higher degree of cancer.

249
00:11:54,680 --> 00:11:56,790
It could be the location
of those green houses.

250
00:11:56,790 --> 00:11:59,860
Maybe houses closer to power lines
have a tendency to be painted

251
00:11:59,860 --> 00:12:01,280
green more frequently, I don't know.

252
00:12:01,280 --> 00:12:05,040
But that's something that we have
to deal with with causal analysis.

253
00:12:05,040 --> 00:12:07,380
We're trying to make sure
that when we have an issue,

254
00:12:07,380 --> 00:12:11,570
we actually know the real cause cuz you
don't want to take a corrective action for

255
00:12:11,570 --> 00:12:12,920
something that isn't the true cause.

256
00:12:12,920 --> 00:12:13,420
>> Right.

257
00:12:14,700 --> 00:12:17,890
>> All right, and
that goes to root cause analysis, right?

258
00:12:17,890 --> 00:12:21,760
When you have a problem what we
normally see are the symptoms and

259
00:12:21,760 --> 00:12:25,900
you don't want to correct the symptoms
because the root cause is still there.

260
00:12:25,900 --> 00:12:28,530
You want to make sure you fix the cause.

261
00:12:28,530 --> 00:12:32,150
So if I have a blue jean
manufacturing plant, and

262
00:12:32,150 --> 00:12:35,980
I'm manufacturing blue jeans and my fault
rate starts climbing, my defect rate.

263
00:12:35,980 --> 00:12:40,890
So it starts at 5% and
then it gets to 6 and 7%, and

264
00:12:40,890 --> 00:12:44,670
before I know it I'm at 15% of
the blue jeans I create are defective.

265
00:12:44,670 --> 00:12:45,270
And I look and

266
00:12:45,270 --> 00:12:50,050
I find out that there is a needle in
one of the devices that's worn out.

267
00:12:50,050 --> 00:12:51,610
And that's why my defect rate is higher.

268
00:12:51,610 --> 00:12:52,800
So I replaced the needle.

269
00:12:52,800 --> 00:12:53,480
Okay.

270
00:12:53,480 --> 00:12:55,640
Well that fixes it, right?

271
00:12:55,640 --> 00:12:57,050
Well no.

272
00:12:57,050 --> 00:12:58,500
The needle wore out.

273
00:12:58,500 --> 00:13:00,460
And so
what's gonna happen to this new needle?

274
00:13:00,460 --> 00:13:02,010
It's gonna wear out too.

275
00:13:02,010 --> 00:13:04,960
So while I've fixed the symptom,
the needle was worn out and

276
00:13:04,960 --> 00:13:07,830
it was causing defects,
I haven't fixed the root cause.

277
00:13:07,830 --> 00:13:11,440
The root cause is I don't have a good
maintenance plan for that needle.

278
00:13:11,440 --> 00:13:12,960
I need a scheduler.

279
00:13:12,960 --> 00:13:16,040
If it takes two months for
that needle to wear out, I should be

280
00:13:16,040 --> 00:13:20,340
replacing it every six weeks, and
that way I replace it before it wears out.

281
00:13:20,340 --> 00:13:23,810
So I stop the defects
before they even start.

282
00:13:23,810 --> 00:13:26,010
That's what we can do
with root cause analysis.

283
00:13:26,010 --> 00:13:28,113
We try and
locate what that actual root cause is.

284
00:13:30,507 --> 00:13:32,030
All right, now forecasting methods.

285
00:13:32,030 --> 00:13:36,910
We are gonna talk about this
a lot in later episodes.

286
00:13:36,910 --> 00:13:41,380
When you have a schedule,
when you have a budget,

287
00:13:41,380 --> 00:13:45,700
it's easy to look at the trend
of what you've done, and

288
00:13:45,700 --> 00:13:48,932
forecast it out into the future to
get an idea of what's gonna happen.

289
00:13:48,932 --> 00:13:52,790
We're gonna do something called
variance analysis later and

290
00:13:52,790 --> 00:13:56,230
EVA, earned value analysis and
a couple of other ones.

291
00:13:56,230 --> 00:14:00,480
And we've got formulas for that and a lot
of really, really cool stuff to deal with.

292
00:14:00,480 --> 00:14:03,720
But we're gonna just stick high level for
this section right here.

293
00:14:03,720 --> 00:14:07,020
So what we do is we take
the information we have and

294
00:14:07,020 --> 00:14:09,890
we just try and figure out what's
going to happen from there.

295
00:14:09,890 --> 00:14:11,890
It could take a number
of different methods.

296
00:14:11,890 --> 00:14:14,840
Time series are what we normally do,
or what I normally do.

297
00:14:14,840 --> 00:14:18,890
If I lay out week after week after week
after week what things have been like,

298
00:14:18,890 --> 00:14:22,800
I can estimate what it's gonna be like in
the future just following that same trend.

299
00:14:22,800 --> 00:14:25,860
You can do other things like scenario and
simulation.

300
00:14:25,860 --> 00:14:28,270
Simulation are like the what if scenarios.

301
00:14:28,270 --> 00:14:29,300
We do that with scheduling.

302
00:14:29,300 --> 00:14:32,190
You say like what if this
activity fell behind schedule?

303
00:14:32,190 --> 00:14:33,830
How would that affect everything else?

304
00:14:33,830 --> 00:14:35,800
So you start kind of trending to
figure out what may happen there.

305
00:14:37,506 --> 00:14:41,610
Failure mode and effect analysis.

306
00:14:41,610 --> 00:14:44,720
Very similar to like,
the what if simulations.

307
00:14:44,720 --> 00:14:46,100
If something fails,

308
00:14:46,100 --> 00:14:49,820
if a particular activity were not to
come off successful, what's the effect?

309
00:14:49,820 --> 00:14:51,270
What's the effect on
the rest of the project?

310
00:14:52,600 --> 00:14:54,700
You can do this hopefully beforehand.

311
00:14:54,700 --> 00:14:56,190
But you can do it afterwards too.

312
00:14:56,190 --> 00:14:57,100
You've had a failure.

313
00:14:57,100 --> 00:15:01,050
Something's gone behind schedule or
over budget.

314
00:15:01,050 --> 00:15:02,640
Now we start to look at the effect.

315
00:15:02,640 --> 00:15:05,030
We analyze across our systems
to find out where that is.

316
00:15:06,650 --> 00:15:07,980
Fault tree analysis.

317
00:15:07,980 --> 00:15:11,960
This one we don't really
use in IT that much, but

318
00:15:11,960 --> 00:15:13,900
it in like manufacturing and stuff.

319
00:15:13,900 --> 00:15:16,780
This is where you have a root cause and

320
00:15:16,780 --> 00:15:20,450
then you have all the various
symptoms that branch out from it.

321
00:15:20,450 --> 00:15:23,470
That's why they call it
the fault tree analysis.

322
00:15:23,470 --> 00:15:25,920
So we start kind of figuring that out.

323
00:15:25,920 --> 00:15:28,020
You have defects, why?

324
00:15:28,020 --> 00:15:31,400
There could be more than one reason,
leading to that defect.

325
00:15:31,400 --> 00:15:33,290
You start kind of gauging those together.

326
00:15:33,290 --> 00:15:35,620
We talked about this a bit
with like Fishbone or

327
00:15:35,620 --> 00:15:40,430
Ishikawa diagrams, it's the same
concept here with fault tree analysis.

328
00:15:42,520 --> 00:15:43,667
Reserve analysis.

329
00:15:43,667 --> 00:15:48,413
Okay, reserve analysis is,
if we've set aside time and money, or

330
00:15:48,413 --> 00:15:53,592
time or money, as a reserve for our
project, how do we know when to use it?

331
00:15:53,592 --> 00:15:56,928
When we created that reserve we should
have designated exactly when we

332
00:15:56,928 --> 00:15:57,840
were gonna use it.

333
00:15:57,840 --> 00:16:00,490
So, how do we know when it's time?

334
00:16:00,490 --> 00:16:03,950
Somebody needs to be looking at the
project, looking at the activities that

335
00:16:03,950 --> 00:16:07,990
are occurring, and identifying when the
time is right to pull from those reserves,

336
00:16:07,990 --> 00:16:09,960
that's reserve analysis, all right.

337
00:16:09,960 --> 00:16:12,330
The other things is,
as we start to pull from the reserves,

338
00:16:12,330 --> 00:16:15,350
somebody should be double checking to
insure we're not gonna run out, right.

339
00:16:15,350 --> 00:16:19,100
That we haven't exceeded the amounts that
we allocated back in the original plan.

340
00:16:19,100 --> 00:16:23,700
If you're doing proper change management,
it's impossible, you manage that.

341
00:16:23,700 --> 00:16:25,400
But if you're not doing
good change management,

342
00:16:25,400 --> 00:16:28,780
people could be pulling from
the reserves when they shouldn't be.

343
00:16:28,780 --> 00:16:31,220
And that could be,
well two problems, right?

344
00:16:31,220 --> 00:16:32,100
One would be impropriety,

345
00:16:32,100 --> 00:16:35,190
they could be stealing, or
embezzling funds from the reserve.

346
00:16:35,190 --> 00:16:37,120
Or two, it could just be.

347
00:16:37,120 --> 00:16:39,250
They're pulling from it,
not reporting it, so

348
00:16:39,250 --> 00:16:43,390
now they're trying to hide the fact that
they went over budget or over schedule.

349
00:16:43,390 --> 00:16:46,350
And the result is that you're
less capable to correct for

350
00:16:46,350 --> 00:16:49,600
errors later in the project and that's
when things become really sensitive.

351
00:16:52,142 --> 00:16:55,180
All right, trend analysis I've kind of
already talked about with forecast.

352
00:16:55,180 --> 00:16:58,550
If you've got a repeating sequence of
events, you can look at the trend.

353
00:16:58,550 --> 00:16:59,890
The blue jean example.

354
00:16:59,890 --> 00:17:02,660
Week after week, my defect was increasing.

355
00:17:02,660 --> 00:17:04,860
Going up more and more each week.

356
00:17:04,860 --> 00:17:06,310
You use that to build a trend.

357
00:17:06,310 --> 00:17:09,460
It looks like I'm
increasing by 3% each week.

358
00:17:09,460 --> 00:17:14,540
If I keep going like that, in X number
of weeks I'm gonna be at a 100% failure.

359
00:17:14,540 --> 00:17:16,275
That's something we can predict.

360
00:17:16,275 --> 00:17:19,780
Earn-to-value management.

361
00:17:19,780 --> 00:17:21,750
I mentioned that earlier.

362
00:17:21,750 --> 00:17:25,460
EVM or Earned Value Management, you also
hear it as EVA, Earned Value Analysis.

363
00:17:26,620 --> 00:17:29,120
These are a collection of formulas.

364
00:17:29,120 --> 00:17:31,620
And what they do,
is they let you aggregate two things.

365
00:17:31,620 --> 00:17:33,760
Basically when you're
performing an activity,

366
00:17:33,760 --> 00:17:37,070
the two main things we track
are schedule and budget, right?

367
00:17:37,070 --> 00:17:40,920
Schedule is measured in time, and
budget is measured in dollars.

368
00:17:40,920 --> 00:17:45,040
And what EV does is it combines the two,
right?

369
00:17:45,040 --> 00:17:47,200
It quantifies them,
turns them into numbers, and

370
00:17:47,200 --> 00:17:50,550
then combines them to
create a single number, and

371
00:17:50,550 --> 00:17:56,140
that number is a reflection of
the progress you've made on that activity.

372
00:17:56,140 --> 00:18:01,121
If I've got a four day
activity with a $1,000 budget,

373
00:18:01,121 --> 00:18:04,940
if I've spent $500, and I'm on day two.

374
00:18:05,950 --> 00:18:12,310
That's 50% of my budget, 50% of schedule,
I should be 50% complete of that activity.

375
00:18:12,310 --> 00:18:14,860
Right?
50% complete being a reflection of both

376
00:18:14,860 --> 00:18:18,270
schedule and cost, right, of money.

377
00:18:18,270 --> 00:18:22,160
So it aggregates those two
together into a single value.

378
00:18:22,160 --> 00:18:25,880
You can then use that to create things
like a schedule performance index or

379
00:18:25,880 --> 00:18:27,440
a cost performance index.

380
00:18:27,440 --> 00:18:33,120
Which are, again, just reflections
of your budget and your schedule.

381
00:18:33,120 --> 00:18:36,140
As a project manager we work
with these numbers a lot and

382
00:18:36,140 --> 00:18:38,490
these are some of the formulas that
we're going to have to learn and

383
00:18:38,490 --> 00:18:40,370
we'll talk about in the next episode.

384
00:18:40,370 --> 00:18:43,770
But for regular people,
your project team members,

385
00:18:43,770 --> 00:18:47,480
your stakeholders, they don't
understand Earned Value Analysis.

386
00:18:47,480 --> 00:18:51,560
So this is a set of numbers that we use
but when we communicate it out we've

387
00:18:51,560 --> 00:18:54,530
always gotta translate it into
language that other people understand.

388
00:18:54,530 --> 00:18:56,530
You don't really see these used
outside of project managing.

389
00:18:58,265 --> 00:18:58,945
All right.

390
00:18:58,945 --> 00:19:03,835
And when we have earned value calculated
we usually calculate it in two ways.

391
00:19:03,835 --> 00:19:07,155
One is the earned value that we should
have at this point according to our plan.

392
00:19:07,155 --> 00:19:09,815
And the other is the earned value
that we actually have according to

393
00:19:09,815 --> 00:19:11,102
what's been done.

394
00:19:11,102 --> 00:19:15,632
We look at the difference and that's our
variance which leads to variance analysis.

395
00:19:15,632 --> 00:19:19,232
If there's a difference, we need to
find out why and try and correct it.

396
00:19:19,232 --> 00:19:23,212
Or if it's within our tolerances then
we let it ride and you go from there.

397
00:19:23,212 --> 00:19:27,102
So it just kind of depends on
how your project is going.

398
00:19:27,102 --> 00:19:28,122
>> Yeah.

399
00:19:28,122 --> 00:19:31,352
All of these different types of analysis
are really there to help us to be able

400
00:19:31,352 --> 00:19:34,980
to take whatever we've done in the past,
take that information and

401
00:19:34,980 --> 00:19:38,030
then be able to forecast into the future.

402
00:19:38,030 --> 00:19:40,860
But part of that of course is then
knowing exactly where you are in

403
00:19:40,860 --> 00:19:42,640
relationship to what you started.

404
00:19:42,640 --> 00:19:46,030
So a lot of these things here,
right, in terms of controlling and

405
00:19:46,030 --> 00:19:49,180
monitoring, right, is always about
taking a look at that past and

406
00:19:49,180 --> 00:19:53,800
then going here's a great way, that we can
see a little bit into the future here.

407
00:19:53,800 --> 00:19:57,410
And so once you actually start getting
these techniques down as you continue to

408
00:19:57,410 --> 00:20:02,670
go on toward the PMP exam, you've got
to actually kind of bear down and

409
00:20:02,670 --> 00:20:05,700
you'll see that the rest of this, when we
get into the rest of controlling here,

410
00:20:05,700 --> 00:20:07,560
we're going to get into
some detailed formulas.

411
00:20:07,560 --> 00:20:08,980
You've got to know those.

412
00:20:08,980 --> 00:20:09,820
>> Yeah absolutely.

413
00:20:09,820 --> 00:20:13,270
So yeah,
we'll spend a good bit of time on that.

414
00:20:13,270 --> 00:20:15,810
The only other two things
we've got are the PMIS,

415
00:20:15,810 --> 00:20:19,970
the project management information system,
and good old-fashioned meetings.

416
00:20:19,970 --> 00:20:23,320
So those are all some of
the things we're gonna be using

417
00:20:23,320 --> 00:20:28,410
when it comes to the analytical techniques
of breaking down our project work.

418
00:20:28,410 --> 00:20:30,570
It's a lot, but
we need to analyze this stuff.

419
00:20:30,570 --> 00:20:34,880
If you have a PMIS, you feed the data
into it, and it generates it all for you.

420
00:20:34,880 --> 00:20:38,266
All the formulas that we're gonna learn,
Mycoft Project has them built in.

421
00:20:38,266 --> 00:20:38,770
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

422
00:20:38,770 --> 00:20:41,010
>> You just punch in your data and
it does all the calculations,

423
00:20:41,010 --> 00:20:44,500
gives you the numbers, you don't even
have to know the formula exists.

424
00:20:44,500 --> 00:20:45,225
On the exam, you do.

425
00:20:45,225 --> 00:20:46,200
>> Yeah.

426
00:20:46,200 --> 00:20:49,950
The value of PMIS that I've found
when I've used it is that ability for

427
00:20:49,950 --> 00:20:51,520
it to create the reports that I want and

428
00:20:51,520 --> 00:20:55,590
to be able to visually see the base
line versus variances here, and

429
00:20:55,590 --> 00:21:00,800
then to see the forecasting of how far I'm
gonna be in two weeks of time from now.

430
00:21:00,800 --> 00:21:03,540
Lot of times me just looking at
a spreadsheet or a number doesn't really

431
00:21:03,540 --> 00:21:07,970
help me out until I can see that, and
that's where that PMIS really does help.

432
00:21:07,970 --> 00:21:08,470
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

433
00:21:09,470 --> 00:21:11,260
>> All right.
Now, on our outputs,

434
00:21:11,260 --> 00:21:14,410
this is gonna be what we
release as a project manager.

435
00:21:14,410 --> 00:21:17,280
When we see a problem that
we have to step in and

436
00:21:17,280 --> 00:21:21,600
correct, when we have to do a control,
the result is always a change request.

437
00:21:21,600 --> 00:21:22,110
Right?

438
00:21:22,110 --> 00:21:24,690
You've gotta make a change for
that to happen.

439
00:21:24,690 --> 00:21:27,140
The exception is drawing
from the reserves.

440
00:21:27,140 --> 00:21:29,830
When there was a plan for reserve, right?

441
00:21:29,830 --> 00:21:32,470
You don't have to do a change ticket for
that because it was already planned for.

442
00:21:32,470 --> 00:21:33,610
Same thing with a risk.

443
00:21:33,610 --> 00:21:36,470
If you've already formulated your
risk response you don't need

444
00:21:36,470 --> 00:21:37,200
a change ticket for that.

445
00:21:37,200 --> 00:21:38,660
The risk response is there.

446
00:21:38,660 --> 00:21:41,790
So if when we have variance,
when we have a risk we didn't expect.

447
00:21:41,790 --> 00:21:43,520
When we have a change we didn't expect.

448
00:21:43,520 --> 00:21:46,260
When we have a budget shortage.

449
00:21:46,260 --> 00:21:48,200
or a schedule overage
that we didn't expect.

450
00:21:49,320 --> 00:21:51,416
Those are where we need
that change request.

451
00:21:51,416 --> 00:21:54,370
>> Right.
>> Other outputs, or performance reports?

452
00:21:54,370 --> 00:21:57,335
Now, a work performance report
was really an input here,

453
00:21:57,335 --> 00:21:58,975
Work Performance Information.

454
00:21:58,975 --> 00:22:03,655
We're just translating it into whatever
form our company requires as part of our

455
00:22:03,655 --> 00:22:05,875
organizational process assets or

456
00:22:05,875 --> 00:22:08,299
as something that we communicate
out to our stakeholders.

457
00:22:09,360 --> 00:22:12,590
We also have our Project Management Plan
Updates and Project Documents Updates,

458
00:22:12,590 --> 00:22:14,470
things we kind of expect to see.

459
00:22:14,470 --> 00:22:18,020
But the main output is going to
be a set of change requests, or

460
00:22:18,020 --> 00:22:22,210
nothing if things are running great and
smooth, there is no output right?

461
00:22:22,210 --> 00:22:25,330
You have your reports I suppose but
then otherwise you stop there, but

462
00:22:25,330 --> 00:22:27,850
if there's a problem, change requests
are what you created to try and

463
00:22:27,850 --> 00:22:29,030
get things back in line.

464
00:22:30,870 --> 00:22:31,550
All right.

465
00:22:31,550 --> 00:22:33,530
I think that's basically it for that one.

466
00:22:33,530 --> 00:22:34,625
Did I leave anything out?
>> Yes.

467
00:22:34,625 --> 00:22:35,125
Nope.

468
00:22:35,125 --> 00:22:36,348
>> Yeah.
We're gonna

469
00:22:36,348 --> 00:22:38,520
post these notes with the episodes.

470
00:22:38,520 --> 00:22:40,110
We always do.
Ronnie does amazing notes on

471
00:22:40,110 --> 00:22:40,730
some of these.

472
00:22:40,730 --> 00:22:44,590
As far as, exactly which section these
are discussed in the pinbok and so on.

473
00:22:44,590 --> 00:22:47,020
But the majority of these,
are ones we've already seen.

474
00:22:47,020 --> 00:22:49,450
Nothing we need to dive into too deeply.

475
00:22:50,680 --> 00:22:54,370
All right well that's monitoring and
controlling the project work.

476
00:22:54,370 --> 00:23:00,310
The other piece of this project or
this process group is,

477
00:23:00,310 --> 00:23:03,510
Perform Integrated Change Control,
and that's a big topic.

478
00:23:03,510 --> 00:23:06,150
I know we've said repeatedly
in other episodes,

479
00:23:06,150 --> 00:23:09,870
yeah we'll talk about change
control later now's that time.

480
00:23:09,870 --> 00:23:11,680
Well, now's almost that time.

481
00:23:11,680 --> 00:23:13,540
We really don't have enough
time in this segment.

482
00:23:13,540 --> 00:23:15,060
So why don't we stop and take a break.

483
00:23:15,060 --> 00:23:18,360
And when we get back,
we'll jump into change control and

484
00:23:18,360 --> 00:23:22,000
start to describe that process,
what's involved, and how important it is.

485
00:23:22,000 --> 00:23:23,722
So stay tuned, we'll be back after this.

486
00:23:23,722 --> 00:23:28,377
[MUSIC]

487
00:23:28,377 --> 00:23:32,324
[SOUND] All right, welcome back everybody.

488
00:23:32,324 --> 00:23:37,640
So now we're going to take a moment and
talk about change control, all right.

489
00:23:37,640 --> 00:23:40,940
Change control is a very
important part of our project.

490
00:23:40,940 --> 00:23:45,840
We spend a lot of time planning for what's
going to happen during our project and

491
00:23:45,840 --> 00:23:49,220
we want to make sure that
things go off without a hitch.

492
00:23:49,220 --> 00:23:52,025
But we know that things might
not go exactly as planned and

493
00:23:52,025 --> 00:23:53,260
we might have to change.

494
00:23:53,260 --> 00:23:55,349
Change is not a bad thing, right?

495
00:23:55,349 --> 00:23:57,797
I know it can be sometimes,
but it isn't normally.

496
00:23:57,797 --> 00:24:01,244
So what we need to do is
we need to prepare for it.

497
00:24:01,244 --> 00:24:06,190
And when change happens it's okay,
as long as we fully understand the change.

498
00:24:06,190 --> 00:24:10,850
We don't want to do any shooting from
the hip, knee jerk reaction to problems.

499
00:24:10,850 --> 00:24:15,360
Because they may have larger repercussions
that we're not ready to deal with.

500
00:24:15,360 --> 00:24:16,850
Or that we just don't foresee.

501
00:24:16,850 --> 00:24:20,330
We make one little change that doesn't
seem to be that big of a deal, and

502
00:24:20,330 --> 00:24:23,250
a few months later it turns out to have
been a massive mistake that's going to be

503
00:24:23,250 --> 00:24:24,710
difficult to correct from.

504
00:24:24,710 --> 00:24:26,660
These are the types of
problems that we can have.

505
00:24:26,660 --> 00:24:29,110
So change control helps to prevent that.

506
00:24:29,110 --> 00:24:31,820
Now there are many different

507
00:24:31,820 --> 00:24:35,210
schools of thought on how to properly
implement change management.

508
00:24:35,210 --> 00:24:37,310
PMI kind of leaves it open to you and

509
00:24:37,310 --> 00:24:40,450
your company to pick from the various
methodologies that are out there.

510
00:24:40,450 --> 00:24:43,870
But they all basically work the same way.

511
00:24:43,870 --> 00:24:46,800
You come up with a plan and
you stick to it.

512
00:24:46,800 --> 00:24:52,680
And any time you deviate from that plan,
you have to fill out a change request.

513
00:24:52,680 --> 00:24:56,395
A form of some sort that details
the change you want to make.

514
00:24:56,395 --> 00:25:00,505
That change then goes before
either a single person in like

515
00:25:00,505 --> 00:25:05,135
a dictatorial environment, or
a board, a group of people, that will

516
00:25:05,135 --> 00:25:09,355
make the decision over to whether that
change should be approved or not.

517
00:25:09,355 --> 00:25:13,315
If it's approved,
then the project corrects itself and

518
00:25:13,315 --> 00:25:16,900
moves ahead as planned,
or as it's newly planned.

519
00:25:16,900 --> 00:25:18,710
If the change is not approved,

520
00:25:18,710 --> 00:25:22,830
the change is declined and
now your project is set up for failure

521
00:25:22,830 --> 00:25:27,050
you need to find either another way to
correct it or that's it you've failed.

522
00:25:27,050 --> 00:25:30,240
So that's basically the two
outcomes of a change ticket.

523
00:25:30,240 --> 00:25:33,990
So it's a neat system in that
it does work really well.

524
00:25:33,990 --> 00:25:35,910
The change board could be called anything.

525
00:25:35,910 --> 00:25:38,620
You might have a change
advisory committee,

526
00:25:38,620 --> 00:25:43,800
a change control board, it's all
sorts of different names out there.

527
00:25:43,800 --> 00:25:49,070
You hear CAB a lot, change advisory board,
or change approval board.

528
00:25:49,070 --> 00:25:49,840
I've heard that one too.

529
00:25:49,840 --> 00:25:52,130
So, there's different
names that are there, but

530
00:25:52,130 --> 00:25:53,230
it doesn't matter they do the same thing.

531
00:25:53,230 --> 00:25:57,090
They're just approving or
declining a change in your environment.

532
00:25:58,110 --> 00:26:01,890
Sometimes the rejection of that
change is not an outright no,

533
00:26:01,890 --> 00:26:02,840
we're not going to do it.

534
00:26:02,840 --> 00:26:05,090
It's a, we need some more information.

535
00:26:05,090 --> 00:26:07,760
You need to gather some more datum and
provide it to us.

536
00:26:07,760 --> 00:26:11,610
So it's postponing the change to make sure
we have all the necessary information to

537
00:26:11,610 --> 00:26:12,968
make the right call.

538
00:26:12,968 --> 00:26:14,982
All right?

539
00:26:14,982 --> 00:26:18,210
So why do they call it
integrated change control?

540
00:26:18,210 --> 00:26:22,590
Well, a lot of companies probably
have change control already for

541
00:26:22,590 --> 00:26:23,989
their standard environment.

542
00:26:25,080 --> 00:26:29,220
Let's say you're a bank and
you've got online accounting software.

543
00:26:29,220 --> 00:26:32,990
If you make a change to that online
accounting software without testing it,

544
00:26:32,990 --> 00:26:34,160
what can happen?

545
00:26:34,160 --> 00:26:37,860
It can all go offline or you could open
yourself up to a security vulnerability

546
00:26:37,860 --> 00:26:39,020
and leak out your customer data.

547
00:26:39,020 --> 00:26:40,240
You don't want that.

548
00:26:40,240 --> 00:26:43,650
So anytime somebody goes to
make a change to that software

549
00:26:43,650 --> 00:26:46,700
they need to get it approved, somebody
needs to review the code they're pushing,

550
00:26:46,700 --> 00:26:49,130
and then authorize it to be rolled out,
right.

551
00:26:49,130 --> 00:26:52,130
It's just simple,
taking the right precautions right,

552
00:26:52,130 --> 00:26:53,910
doing the best practices.

553
00:26:53,910 --> 00:26:58,090
Well, in your project you may have
change that pertains to the project.

554
00:26:58,090 --> 00:27:00,470
The project is creating
something that isn't there yet,

555
00:27:00,470 --> 00:27:04,200
typically, so it's not like you're
changing production systems.

556
00:27:04,200 --> 00:27:07,515
So you don't necessarily want to use
the change control system that's

557
00:27:07,515 --> 00:27:09,430
a part of your organization already.

558
00:27:09,430 --> 00:27:13,540
Instead, you want to have a change
control system that is integrated

559
00:27:13,540 --> 00:27:14,402
into the project.

560
00:27:14,402 --> 00:27:17,800
That's built to your project
system that may be different.

561
00:27:17,800 --> 00:27:21,390
It may be the same as the change control
system for your organization, but

562
00:27:21,390 --> 00:27:24,330
a lot of the times it will be separate
because it'll be the stakeholders,

563
00:27:24,330 --> 00:27:27,020
the key stakeholders, and
the project managers.

564
00:27:27,020 --> 00:27:29,440
The people that are involved
in the project.

565
00:27:29,440 --> 00:27:30,210
All right.

566
00:27:30,210 --> 00:27:33,890
So, when we talk about performing
integrated change control,

567
00:27:33,890 --> 00:27:35,820
we're talking about basically doing that.

568
00:27:35,820 --> 00:27:40,140
Doing that change control that's
a part of our project and and

569
00:27:40,140 --> 00:27:42,200
ensuring that our project is
moving in the right direction.

570
00:27:42,200 --> 00:27:45,050
All right, so
what are our inputs for this?

571
00:27:45,050 --> 00:27:45,810
Well the inputs are simple.

572
00:27:45,810 --> 00:27:47,570
We need to have our plan.

573
00:27:47,570 --> 00:27:49,570
Our plan is what we're
supposed to be doing.

574
00:27:49,570 --> 00:27:51,680
We're supposed to be following this.

575
00:27:51,680 --> 00:27:52,380
All right.

576
00:27:52,380 --> 00:27:54,200
But apparently there's a deviation.

577
00:27:54,200 --> 00:27:58,150
The deviation is normally be recognized
by our work performance reports.

578
00:27:58,150 --> 00:28:00,270
That's going to show
where our deviation is.

579
00:28:01,320 --> 00:28:02,940
All right.
Then as a project manager,

580
00:28:02,940 --> 00:28:06,950
we recognize the deviation, and
so we create a change request.

581
00:28:06,950 --> 00:28:08,050
A change request to fix it.

582
00:28:08,050 --> 00:28:09,850
Now, I say the project manager.

583
00:28:09,850 --> 00:28:13,240
Most change requests will
come from the project manger.

584
00:28:13,240 --> 00:28:14,400
But that doesn't mean they have to.

585
00:28:14,400 --> 00:28:16,830
Change requests can come from
anywhere within the project.

586
00:28:16,830 --> 00:28:18,290
Anybody can submit that.

587
00:28:18,290 --> 00:28:21,610
And another common place to
get it is from the sponsor.

588
00:28:21,610 --> 00:28:24,890
The project sponsor says man,
this project is awesome and

589
00:28:24,890 --> 00:28:28,400
I know you guys have been working on it
for six months now, but I had this idea.

590
00:28:28,400 --> 00:28:30,720
I had this idea for a great new feature.

591
00:28:30,720 --> 00:28:32,790
Can we add this feature to the project?

592
00:28:32,790 --> 00:28:36,000
And you say can we finish this project and

593
00:28:36,000 --> 00:28:39,030
then add it as like a product 2.0 or
something like that?

594
00:28:39,030 --> 00:28:41,960
And they say, oh no, let's try and
get it for launch date, let's try and

595
00:28:41,960 --> 00:28:43,100
get it as part of this project.

596
00:28:43,100 --> 00:28:45,750
And you say all right well,
it's going to take more money, and

597
00:28:45,750 --> 00:28:47,490
it's going to take more time.

598
00:28:47,490 --> 00:28:51,850
And the sponsor says, "well, I'm not okay
on time, I want this on launch date;

599
00:28:51,850 --> 00:28:55,490
I'm cool on money, I can add more
money to the project, we can do that".

600
00:28:55,490 --> 00:28:59,780
Well that is a change,
that the sponsor is pushing,

601
00:28:59,780 --> 00:29:01,990
they're willing to pay for it,
might as well bring it in.

602
00:29:01,990 --> 00:29:04,920
That's what they want and
we'll provide the customer what they need.

603
00:29:04,920 --> 00:29:08,390
So those type of change requests
might originate from somebody

604
00:29:08,390 --> 00:29:09,640
other than the project manager.

605
00:29:10,860 --> 00:29:13,870
The other place you make a change
request are from contractors.

606
00:29:13,870 --> 00:29:15,010
When you contract out to them,

607
00:29:15,010 --> 00:29:18,060
you've got to contract that specifically
states what they're going to be doing.

608
00:29:18,060 --> 00:29:21,250
That statement of work and all that
other information they signed off on.

609
00:29:21,250 --> 00:29:24,260
They might have a change, something
happens, something unforeseen, and

610
00:29:24,260 --> 00:29:25,610
a change might occur.

611
00:29:25,610 --> 00:29:29,260
So all of these things,
they originated from different places, but

612
00:29:29,260 --> 00:29:31,620
they go through the same approval process.

613
00:29:31,620 --> 00:29:35,990
We have our change committee that's
going to review those changes and

614
00:29:35,990 --> 00:29:38,300
determine whether or
not we should accept them or decline them.

615
00:29:39,490 --> 00:29:41,690
All right,
now enterprise environmental factors,

616
00:29:41,690 --> 00:29:43,310
that's the way that our
company does business.

617
00:29:43,310 --> 00:29:46,660
And if we already have a change advisory
board, or a change control system, or

618
00:29:46,660 --> 00:29:50,340
whatever, we just make use of that,
all right?

619
00:29:50,340 --> 00:29:51,880
Organizational process assets,

620
00:29:51,880 --> 00:29:55,550
that's going to be detailing things like
the paperwork, the forms, the bureaucracy.

621
00:29:55,550 --> 00:29:59,650
When somebody fills out a change request,
what is that, what is the request?

622
00:29:59,650 --> 00:30:01,290
Well, let me show you an example.

623
00:30:01,290 --> 00:30:04,120
So I've got a change request right here.

624
00:30:04,120 --> 00:30:07,640
And this is an example of what one
would look like when we fill it out.

625
00:30:07,640 --> 00:30:09,400
So you fill it out with
what the project is,

626
00:30:09,400 --> 00:30:13,580
who the project manager is, when this
was prepared, who the requester is.

627
00:30:13,580 --> 00:30:15,840
Because it might not be
the project manager.

628
00:30:15,840 --> 00:30:18,610
And a change number if we're
keeping track of that.

629
00:30:18,610 --> 00:30:21,790
It might be blank when you submit it and
it gets numbered after its submitted.

630
00:30:23,050 --> 00:30:25,280
Then we identify what it
is we are trying to change.

631
00:30:25,280 --> 00:30:27,310
Are we trying to change our scope?

632
00:30:27,310 --> 00:30:29,930
Modifying our requirements list.

633
00:30:29,930 --> 00:30:32,540
They've got scope and
requirements kind of separate here.

634
00:30:32,540 --> 00:30:37,580
Do we modify our quality, costs,
schedule, just general documentation?

635
00:30:37,580 --> 00:30:38,980
What is it that we are wanting to modify?

636
00:30:38,980 --> 00:30:40,590
It might be a combination of these.

637
00:30:40,590 --> 00:30:41,510
Right?

638
00:30:41,510 --> 00:30:44,830
Then we specify what the change is,
all right?

639
00:30:44,830 --> 00:30:50,200
So let's say for
example that I've got a project and

640
00:30:50,200 --> 00:30:54,810
I was supposed to purchase 40 servers
from Dell, and when it comes time for

641
00:30:54,810 --> 00:30:57,780
me to purchase them, they tell me
they're back-ordered, and they say no,

642
00:30:57,780 --> 00:30:59,840
their back-order's going
to be an extra three weeks.

643
00:30:59,840 --> 00:31:01,700
Well I know that's going
to shoot our schedule.

644
00:31:01,700 --> 00:31:04,170
So I want to make sure
that doesn't happen.

645
00:31:04,170 --> 00:31:06,380
So I decide, well you know what,
let me go and purchase them from HP.

646
00:31:06,380 --> 00:31:09,120
It's the same price,
just a different vendor and

647
00:31:09,120 --> 00:31:10,990
I can get them on
the schedule that I want.

648
00:31:10,990 --> 00:31:13,070
So I come in here and
I say what am I going to modify?

649
00:31:13,070 --> 00:31:17,510
Well I'm actually going to be modifying,
not our cost or our schedule, right?

650
00:31:17,510 --> 00:31:19,100
Because those are going to stay the same.

651
00:31:19,100 --> 00:31:22,851
What I'm going to modify are my
procurement documents because we're going

652
00:31:22,851 --> 00:31:26,610
to be buying from HP instead of Dell,
and more than likely my requirements.

653
00:31:26,610 --> 00:31:29,530
If the requirements said we needed
to purchase the service form Dell,

654
00:31:29,530 --> 00:31:31,770
I'm wanting to change that to HP.

655
00:31:31,770 --> 00:31:36,165
And so I'll specify that here in my
detailed description of proposed change.

656
00:31:36,165 --> 00:31:41,032
I'll say requesting to purchase

657
00:31:41,032 --> 00:31:45,897
servers from HP instead of Dell in

658
00:31:45,897 --> 00:31:50,588
order to meet schedule plan, or

659
00:31:50,588 --> 00:31:57,365
plan schedule and
then we can indicate cost and

660
00:31:57,365 --> 00:32:02,435
schedule will remain unchanged.

661
00:32:02,435 --> 00:32:04,189
With HP, right.

662
00:32:04,189 --> 00:32:08,160
Or maybe it's less money or more money,
we may need to indicate that.

663
00:32:08,160 --> 00:32:10,280
Justification for the proposed change?

664
00:32:10,280 --> 00:32:16,490
Well the change results in
maintaining the planned schedule

665
00:32:18,030 --> 00:32:23,890
without incurring additional costs,
which is what I want.

666
00:32:23,890 --> 00:32:25,880
If it costs more money,
I would have to justify that and

667
00:32:25,880 --> 00:32:27,780
say look, we've got two choices here.

668
00:32:27,780 --> 00:32:32,150
We can spend a little more money now or
we can take a three week delay.

669
00:32:32,150 --> 00:32:33,430
Which one would you rather do?

670
00:32:33,430 --> 00:32:35,800
You could submit two change tickets.

671
00:32:35,800 --> 00:32:38,380
One that recommends extending
the schedule three weeks.

672
00:32:38,380 --> 00:32:40,456
One that recommends spending a little
more money so you don't have to do it.

673
00:32:40,456 --> 00:32:43,180
One will get approved,
one will get declined.

674
00:32:43,180 --> 00:32:45,470
But it's not you, the requester,
that's making that decision.

675
00:32:46,620 --> 00:32:48,310
It's the change board
that makes that call.

676
00:32:48,310 --> 00:32:50,950
So you may have two tickets
that conflict with each other.

677
00:32:50,950 --> 00:32:53,450
That's definitely not uncommon.

678
00:32:53,450 --> 00:32:55,880
All right, so then impactive change.

679
00:32:55,880 --> 00:32:59,796
Well the impact is gonna be negligible so

680
00:32:59,796 --> 00:33:06,142
we might indicate server
configuration software is different.

681
00:33:08,545 --> 00:33:12,063
But functionality impact is negligible,
right.

682
00:33:12,063 --> 00:33:15,348
So whatever it is that we
need to dictate in here.

683
00:33:18,029 --> 00:33:20,363
So impact is negligible.

684
00:33:25,646 --> 00:33:26,840
Which I think I'm spelling wrong.

685
00:33:27,900 --> 00:33:30,560
Yep.
[LAUGH] There we go, alright,

686
00:33:30,560 --> 00:33:34,220
any other comments that I might
wanna add and then we submit it.

687
00:33:34,220 --> 00:33:38,290
Now the second page is not for us, the
submitter, it's the change advisory board.

688
00:33:38,290 --> 00:33:40,210
They are going to review this, okay.

689
00:33:40,210 --> 00:33:42,710
Did we give them enough information,
right?

690
00:33:42,710 --> 00:33:45,260
I didn't really put all
that much data here, right.

691
00:33:45,260 --> 00:33:46,930
So if we didn't put enough information,

692
00:33:46,930 --> 00:33:50,450
they may decline this,
requesting information, right.

693
00:33:50,450 --> 00:33:52,460
Or they may just decline it out right,
and say, no,

694
00:33:52,460 --> 00:33:56,720
lets stick with ordering from Dell,
lets deal with the time delay, right.

695
00:33:56,720 --> 00:34:00,390
Or, they might approve it, and if they
approve it, they'll indicate that here and

696
00:34:00,390 --> 00:34:03,280
justification for disposition, all right.

697
00:34:03,280 --> 00:34:06,350
If we decline it, why do we decline it?

698
00:34:06,350 --> 00:34:08,290
If we approve it, why do we approve it.

699
00:34:08,290 --> 00:34:11,550
And if we defer it, right, this is
usually when we request more information.

700
00:34:11,550 --> 00:34:14,850
We indicate that here and say,
well, you looked at Dell and HP,

701
00:34:14,850 --> 00:34:16,010
are there any vendors, right.

702
00:34:16,010 --> 00:34:17,260
Have you checked anybody else?

703
00:34:17,260 --> 00:34:20,460
Or have we checked to see if there's a
third party that sells Dell that we could

704
00:34:20,460 --> 00:34:22,010
have gone with, right.

705
00:34:22,010 --> 00:34:25,930
And then the change control board or
change advisory board signs off right

706
00:34:25,930 --> 00:34:28,630
here, their name, their role,
and their signature.

707
00:34:28,630 --> 00:34:32,630
And now we know who made the decision and
why, all right.

708
00:34:32,630 --> 00:34:37,340
This process right here ensures that
nobody's making changes to the schedule

709
00:34:37,340 --> 00:34:39,590
without proper review happening.

710
00:34:39,590 --> 00:34:43,900
And the people doing the review should be
at a minimum the project manager, right.

711
00:34:43,900 --> 00:34:46,520
Somebody who understands
the ramification of that change.

712
00:34:46,520 --> 00:34:49,418
What is it gonna do to the rest of
my project if I make this change?

713
00:34:49,418 --> 00:34:50,618
All right.

714
00:34:50,618 --> 00:34:53,645
Who are some of the other people
we might have on that board?

715
00:34:53,645 --> 00:34:56,130
Well, at a minimum,
you want your project manager.

716
00:34:56,130 --> 00:34:58,349
You'll normally will have
your project sponsor too.

717
00:34:58,349 --> 00:35:01,735
The one who's just ponying up the bill,
right, the one who is paying for all this.

718
00:35:01,735 --> 00:35:05,055
They had a budget, and
they had a schedule that we promised them.

719
00:35:05,055 --> 00:35:08,155
Now we wanna change it, so
they need to be involved in that.

720
00:35:08,155 --> 00:35:09,735
And they may be very cool with this stuff.

721
00:35:09,735 --> 00:35:12,255
They may be like,
a couple extra grand, no big deal.

722
00:35:12,255 --> 00:35:14,192
Or a couple extra weeks, fine.

723
00:35:14,192 --> 00:35:15,552
But they may be very strict and

724
00:35:15,552 --> 00:35:19,562
they may say what, you promised we would
have it on this date for this much money.

725
00:35:19,562 --> 00:35:20,772
You need to make it happen.

726
00:35:20,772 --> 00:35:24,212
So they may be declining that and
that's definitely their prerogative.

727
00:35:24,212 --> 00:35:26,662
We made promises,
we need to try and keep them.

728
00:35:26,662 --> 00:35:29,730
So those are two people
who might be there.

729
00:35:29,730 --> 00:35:30,870
Who else?

730
00:35:30,870 --> 00:35:32,210
Subject men are experts.

731
00:35:32,210 --> 00:35:34,060
Right?
We might need to have specialists,

732
00:35:34,060 --> 00:35:37,340
people who understand this change
more in depth as part of that change

733
00:35:37,340 --> 00:35:38,490
control board.

734
00:35:38,490 --> 00:35:40,560
We might wanna have
other project managers,

735
00:35:40,560 --> 00:35:42,640
that's something that I'm kind of fond of.

736
00:35:42,640 --> 00:35:45,180
Getting another project manager
to get their eyes on this.

737
00:35:45,180 --> 00:35:47,250
A second set of eyes can be very,
very handy.

738
00:35:48,690 --> 00:35:51,475
All right, they sign off on it and
that's it.

739
00:35:51,475 --> 00:35:53,640
Now the change is in play.

740
00:35:53,640 --> 00:35:58,270
When a change request gets approved,
if we're changing in our case,

741
00:35:58,270 --> 00:36:02,420
the requirements list and other documents,
I need to go and edit those.

742
00:36:02,420 --> 00:36:05,090
I need to go edit my requirements
list to reflect the new requirements.

743
00:36:05,090 --> 00:36:07,930
So, if we edit our schedule, we need to
go edit the schedule to reflect that.

744
00:36:07,930 --> 00:36:09,410
That becomes part of our baseline.

745
