We're just trusting that
everybody's actually saying.

974
00:47:22,290 --> 00:47:24,720
I'm getting done what I
need to get done here.

975
00:47:24,720 --> 00:47:29,130
Validation is a good way to go okay,
here's where you should be and

976
00:47:29,130 --> 00:47:33,330
I'm here to check it so that we know that
we're actually continuing on this process.

977
00:47:33,330 --> 00:47:37,430
So, the obvious skipping of this
validation is not something we want to do.

978
00:47:37,430 --> 00:47:40,870
>> Yeah, otherwise you would end up with
a situation where people complete all

979
00:47:40,870 --> 00:47:41,760
their work.

980
00:47:41,760 --> 00:47:44,270
And there may have been mistakes
that were made that weren't caught.

981
00:47:44,270 --> 00:47:45,870
And now it's done.

982
00:47:45,870 --> 00:47:48,590
It's really hard to go back and
make those changes.

983
00:47:48,590 --> 00:47:49,320
All right.

984
00:47:49,320 --> 00:47:52,280
The last things we have here for
outputs work performance information.

985
00:47:52,280 --> 00:47:53,761
Right?
Which is just interpreted

986
00:47:53,761 --> 00:47:55,018
work performance data.

987
00:47:55,018 --> 00:47:56,319
And project document updates.

988
00:47:56,319 --> 00:47:58,444
Right?
If we chose to change our scope or

989
00:47:58,444 --> 00:48:01,435
whatever then we need to go and
make those modifications.

990
00:48:01,435 --> 00:48:02,943
But all in all this is
really straightforward.

991
00:48:02,943 --> 00:48:04,985
It does really boil down to inspection.

992
00:48:04,985 --> 00:48:08,493
You go and examine what's being done,
you run down your list of requirements and

993
00:48:08,493 --> 00:48:10,150
make sure that they're being met.

994
00:48:10,150 --> 00:48:11,700
You tick them off as you go, check, check,

995
00:48:11,700 --> 00:48:16,055
check, and when they're all checked
your project is done, well in theory.

996
00:48:16,055 --> 00:48:18,120
[LAUGH] So

997
00:48:18,120 --> 00:48:22,220
the next process we're gonna take
a look at is the control scope process.

998
00:48:22,220 --> 00:48:25,830
Now, that sounds a lot like validate
scope that we just talked about.

999
00:48:25,830 --> 00:48:27,090
And they really go hand in hand.

1000
00:48:27,090 --> 00:48:29,000
You don't do one without the other.

1001
00:48:29,000 --> 00:48:31,720
Validating the scope was all
about gathering data and

1002
00:48:31,720 --> 00:48:35,550
making sure the work that was being
done conformed to our requirements list.

1003
00:48:35,550 --> 00:48:39,010
Controlling the scope is
making sure that we don't

1004
00:48:39,010 --> 00:48:42,920
go beyond [LAUGH] what's really
happening inside our scope statement.

1005
00:48:42,920 --> 00:48:44,340
This is something that
is very very common.

1006
00:48:44,340 --> 00:48:47,120
We have a term that is called scope creep.

1007
00:48:47,120 --> 00:48:51,600
That's where people start adding
stuff to your project after the fact.

1008
00:48:51,600 --> 00:48:53,550
Sure, you define this nice little scope.

1009
00:48:53,550 --> 00:48:56,430
A list of requirements for
a website that's gonna be designed.

1010
00:48:56,430 --> 00:48:59,600
Then, as you're going through it,
the sponsor or whoever comes in and says,

1011
00:48:59,600 --> 00:49:02,250
you know,
can we change that background to be blue?

1012
00:49:02,250 --> 00:49:03,460
That's innocent request.

1013
00:49:03,460 --> 00:49:05,440
Not a big deal.
Sure, we'll change it to blue, right?

1014
00:49:05,440 --> 00:49:07,110
We won't even do a change statement.

1015
00:49:07,110 --> 00:49:08,090
We'll just go ahead and do that.

1016
00:49:08,090 --> 00:49:09,150
Not a big deal.

1017
00:49:09,150 --> 00:49:11,550
I say, well, while you are in there,
can you change this text around?

1018
00:49:11,550 --> 00:49:13,010
I really don't like that font.

1019
00:49:13,010 --> 00:49:14,090
Can we make that bigger?

1020
00:49:14,090 --> 00:49:15,680
All the sudden, it starts to snowball.

1021
00:49:15,680 --> 00:49:16,950
It gets bigger and bigger.

1022
00:49:16,950 --> 00:49:18,080
All of the sudden, you are spending so

1023
00:49:18,080 --> 00:49:23,410
much time on all these innocent changes,
you fall behind on the other activities.

1024
00:49:23,410 --> 00:49:24,520
That's scope creep.

1025
00:49:24,520 --> 00:49:26,700
It's a very real problem, very prominent.

1026
00:49:26,700 --> 00:49:31,190
Especially when the extra add
ons are coming from the sponsor,

1027
00:49:31,190 --> 00:49:32,940
the person who's paying for all of this.

1028
00:49:32,940 --> 00:49:35,980
All the sudden,
your project gets outta hand.

1029
00:49:35,980 --> 00:49:38,990
Controlling the scope is all about
making sure that doesn't happen.

1030
00:49:38,990 --> 00:49:42,910
Making sure that the work that's being
done is in line with what's defined in our

1031
00:49:42,910 --> 00:49:45,310
scope and requirements documentation.

1032
00:49:45,310 --> 00:49:51,640
The inputs for it are almost
identical to validating the scope.

1033
00:49:51,640 --> 00:49:53,010
Project management plan, right?

1034
00:49:53,010 --> 00:49:54,920
That's where our scope
statement is stored.

1035
00:49:54,920 --> 00:49:56,770
Our requirements documentation,

1036
00:49:56,770 --> 00:49:59,490
basically the check list of
what should be happening.

1037
00:49:59,490 --> 00:50:01,600
Our requirements traceability matrix.

1038
00:50:01,600 --> 00:50:04,380
Who it was that's tied to
each of these requirements.

1039
00:50:04,380 --> 00:50:09,150
Who's responsible for completing it,
or who initiated that requirement.

1040
00:50:09,150 --> 00:50:12,010
Our work performance data that we're
gathering from the employees that

1041
00:50:12,010 --> 00:50:13,200
are working in the field.

1042
00:50:13,200 --> 00:50:16,480
And finally our organizational
process assets like we always see.

1043
00:50:16,480 --> 00:50:20,330
Almost identical to what
we had with validate scope.

1044
00:50:20,330 --> 00:50:22,630
The big different here is our tool and
technique.

1045
00:50:22,630 --> 00:50:24,730
We have variance analysis.

1046
00:50:24,730 --> 00:50:27,330
Under validated scope our main
thing was inspection, right?

1047
00:50:27,330 --> 00:50:30,240
We would go in and inspect the work and
see what was going on.

1048
00:50:30,240 --> 00:50:32,450
Variance analysis though
is a lot different.

1049
00:50:32,450 --> 00:50:34,310
This is where we look
at what's been done and

1050
00:50:34,310 --> 00:50:38,230
we compare it to what should've
been done and look for deviations.

1051
00:50:38,230 --> 00:50:39,560
Requirements are easy to measure on.

1052
00:50:39,560 --> 00:50:42,470
If there were requirements that
weren't done, you spot them, right?

1053
00:50:42,470 --> 00:50:46,130
But things like schedule and
budget, right, our time and

1054
00:50:46,130 --> 00:50:49,800
our money, if we see variations there,
we need to ask the question of why.

1055
00:50:50,810 --> 00:50:53,880
Why have we spent more money
then we should of, right?

1056
00:50:53,880 --> 00:50:56,820
Or why haven't we spent as
much money as we planned?

1057
00:50:56,820 --> 00:50:59,380
Either one can indicate
work that hasn't been done.

1058
00:50:59,380 --> 00:51:03,030
If you spent too much money,
you probably have scope creep.

1059
00:51:03,030 --> 00:51:06,320
New things have worked their way in and
you're wasting money on them, right?

1060
00:51:06,320 --> 00:51:07,220
Or people are not

1061
00:51:07,220 --> 00:51:09,370
doing the work they said they were doing
>> Right.

1062
00:51:09,370 --> 00:51:13,140
>> If you haven't spent enough money,
it usually means people are behind.

1063
00:51:13,140 --> 00:51:16,440
They haven't gotten certain activities yet
that require us to spend money.

1064
00:51:16,440 --> 00:51:18,740
So even though it looks
like you're under budget,

1065
00:51:18,740 --> 00:51:20,890
you're actually falling
behind on the project.

1066
00:51:20,890 --> 00:51:22,850
So we need to monitor for that variance.

1067
00:51:22,850 --> 00:51:26,040
And this is where our
Earned Value Analysis comes in, EVA, and

1068
00:51:26,040 --> 00:51:27,930
Earned Value Management, EVM.

1069
00:51:27,930 --> 00:51:29,950
We're going to talk about
those in the next episode.

1070
00:51:29,950 --> 00:51:35,540
But they're all tools at our disposal to
go and identify where we're deviating,

1071
00:51:35,540 --> 00:51:38,890
where we've got that variance
from our original plan.

1072
00:51:38,890 --> 00:51:42,430
Almost always indicates that
something has happened to our scope,

1073
00:51:42,430 --> 00:51:43,360
that we're not following it.

1074
00:51:44,850 --> 00:51:47,780
>> A lot of times, in terms of
changes that end up going on and

1075
00:51:47,780 --> 00:51:51,720
getting scope creep, and we actually
end up with scope creep in our project.

1076
00:51:51,720 --> 00:51:54,730
What ends up happening here is that
it's not that changes can't go on.

1077
00:51:54,730 --> 00:51:58,260
We already talked about the processing
of integrating change management.

1078
00:51:58,260 --> 00:51:59,520
And those are accounted for.

1079
00:51:59,520 --> 00:52:01,030
What we're worried about here is the idea,

1080
00:52:01,030 --> 00:52:04,100
the uncontrolled changes
that end up getting that in.

1081
00:52:04,100 --> 00:52:06,660
The uncontrolled expansion
that we have here.

1082
00:52:06,660 --> 00:52:11,220
And variance analysis is what will
help us to identify especially that.

1083
00:52:11,220 --> 00:52:15,310
When we're actually close to the end or
when we're starting this process.

1084
00:52:15,310 --> 00:52:19,460
Either way, we're gonna see
that without this particular

1085
00:52:19,460 --> 00:52:23,730
part of the variance analysis, very
difficult for us to even know where we

1086
00:52:23,730 --> 00:52:27,050
actually started that scope creep and
how to even control it.

1087
00:52:27,050 --> 00:52:28,160
>> Yeah, absolutely.

1088
00:52:28,160 --> 00:52:30,350
So you guys see where this really fits in.

1089
00:52:30,350 --> 00:52:31,630
>> Yeah.
>> With validate scope.

1090
00:52:31,630 --> 00:52:32,620
We do this hand to hand.

1091
00:52:32,620 --> 00:52:34,350
You typically do them at the same time.

1092
00:52:34,350 --> 00:52:36,520
We don't even really treat
them as separate processes.

1093
00:52:36,520 --> 00:52:37,110
>> Yeah.

1094
00:52:37,110 --> 00:52:40,540
>> And I imagine in some future version of
the PMBOK, it'll just combine these two.

1095
00:52:40,540 --> 00:52:43,290
But for right now the idea is
that it is a little bit separate,

1096
00:52:43,290 --> 00:52:46,380
that validating the scope,
just making sure we meet our requirements.

1097
00:52:46,380 --> 00:52:50,160
Controlling the scope, making sure we
don't deviate from those requirements.

1098
00:52:50,160 --> 00:52:52,300
Just kind of two separate ideas.

1099
00:52:52,300 --> 00:52:56,150
Our outputs, again almost
identical to validate the scope.

1100
00:52:56,150 --> 00:52:59,520
Our work performance information,
what's been done,

1101
00:52:59,520 --> 00:53:03,250
which is just interpretations
of work performance data.

1102
00:53:03,250 --> 00:53:07,240
We've got change requests anything we
need to modify to get back in line.

1103
00:53:07,240 --> 00:53:09,110
Our project management plan updates,

1104
00:53:09,110 --> 00:53:12,180
if those requests are approved
we gotta modify the plan.

1105
00:53:12,180 --> 00:53:13,640
Project document updates and

1106
00:53:13,640 --> 00:53:18,600
organizational process asset updates
also right, all pretty much in line so.

1107
00:53:18,600 --> 00:53:19,310
Very, very similar.

1108
00:53:19,310 --> 00:53:21,460
If I were to flip back and
forth between these two,

1109
00:53:21,460 --> 00:53:23,720
you'll notice that they
are almost identical.

1110
00:53:23,720 --> 00:53:27,500
A few extra outputs on control,
but very similar.

1111
00:53:27,500 --> 00:53:28,750
Still two separate entities.

1112
00:53:28,750 --> 00:53:31,460
That makes it really easy to
confuse them on the exam.

1113
00:53:31,460 --> 00:53:33,910
So these are good ones that we need to
memorize, and make sure that we remember.

1114
00:53:35,520 --> 00:53:38,540
All right,
well that pretty much wraps up that piece.

1115
00:53:38,540 --> 00:53:41,120
I know it seems like we've been
moving through these pretty quick

1116
00:53:41,120 --> 00:53:41,710
under monitoring and

1117
00:53:41,710 --> 00:53:45,480
controlling, we just knocked out these
first two knowledge areas, right?

1118
00:53:45,480 --> 00:53:49,750
But we're about to move into some really
complex things, controlling the schedule

1119
00:53:49,750 --> 00:53:53,460
and controlling costs and that's when
we're going to break into our formulas,

1120
00:53:53,460 --> 00:53:55,320
so we don't want to jump into it today,

1121
00:53:55,320 --> 00:53:57,520
we don't have enough time
left in this episode.

1122
00:53:57,520 --> 00:54:01,810
But in our next episode we're gonna
dive into that world of formulas and

1123
00:54:01,810 --> 00:54:05,000
it's going to be a ton of fun, right?

1124
00:54:05,000 --> 00:54:06,560
>> Yes. [LAUGH] >> [LAUGH]
Anyhow it can be a lot of fun,

1125
00:54:06,560 --> 00:54:07,890
it depends on you apply it.

1126
00:54:07,890 --> 00:54:10,800
But we'll get a chance
to see that next time.

1127
00:54:10,800 --> 00:54:12,670
Well let me remind you guys,

1128
00:54:12,670 --> 00:54:16,480
if you have questions on anything
we've covered here feel free to ask.

1129
00:54:16,480 --> 00:54:18,770
Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live.

1130
00:54:18,770 --> 00:54:22,150
You'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

1131
00:54:22,150 --> 00:54:22,890
Post your questions.

1132
00:54:22,890 --> 00:54:24,770
We monitor and answer during the show.

1133
00:54:24,770 --> 00:54:29,030
If you have questions after the show
when we're in reruns, use our Q and

1134
00:54:29,030 --> 00:54:34,010
A forums, at the top of every page is
a link that says Q and A, click on it.

1135
00:54:34,010 --> 00:54:34,850
It takes you to the forums,

1136
00:54:34,850 --> 00:54:38,190
you can post your questions there,
we monitor and answer.

1137
00:54:38,190 --> 00:54:40,408
Take advantage of that resource,
it is there for you.

1138
00:54:40,408 --> 00:54:41,520
>> Right.
>> All right,

1139
00:54:41,520 --> 00:54:45,430
well I hope you enjoyed the show,
signing off for IT Pro TV, I'm Don Pezet.

1140
00:54:45,430 --> 00:54:46,280
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1141
00:54:46,280 --> 00:54:47,481
>> And we'll see you next time.

1142
00:54:47,481 --> 00:54:57,481
[MUSIC]

1143
00:54:59,370 --> 00:55:05,480
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don give an overview of controlling time management and cost within the project. This episode demonstrates that within a project the close ties between cost, time and scope.
episodes.title: Schedule and Cost Management
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,643 --> 00:00:37,280
All right, good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening, and welcome back.

3
00:00:37,280 --> 00:00:38,770
To another episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:38,770 --> 00:00:40,650
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:40,650 --> 00:00:41,860
Back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:41,860 --> 00:00:42,600
How's it going, Ronnie?

7
00:00:42,600 --> 00:00:44,160
>> I am incredibly excited.

8
00:00:44,160 --> 00:00:47,530
I understand that there is
a possibility of a Full House reunion.

9
00:00:47,530 --> 00:00:48,070
>> No way.

10
00:00:48,070 --> 00:00:49,865
>> Yes, in the near future, so.

11
00:00:49,865 --> 00:00:53,440
[LAUGH]
>> The reunions,

12
00:00:53,440 --> 00:00:56,880
they always kill me, cuz
>> There's always like one cast member

13
00:00:56,880 --> 00:01:00,850
who's gone crazy so [LAUGH] we should
have an ITProTV reunion one day.

14
00:01:00,850 --> 00:01:04,620
Do we have anybody that been
entered into a psychological ward?

15
00:01:04,620 --> 00:01:06,470
>> We don't talk about it anymore, Don.

16
00:01:06,470 --> 00:01:09,520
We've stopped talking about
those issues anymore.

17
00:01:09,520 --> 00:01:10,620
>> All right, well.

18
00:01:10,620 --> 00:01:12,960
>> We're gonna dive back into
project management today,

19
00:01:12,960 --> 00:01:18,160
and this next couple of process,

20
00:01:18,160 --> 00:01:23,260
it's kinda interesting and let me just
jump into my process group schedule here.

21
00:01:23,260 --> 00:01:26,135
It's kind of interesting because
it's a little bit confusing,

22
00:01:26,135 --> 00:01:27,540
that blend together a good bit.

23
00:01:27,540 --> 00:01:32,320
So we've been going through our monitoring
and controlling and we did validate scope,

24
00:01:32,320 --> 00:01:34,780
control scope,
pretty straightforward stuff there.

25
00:01:34,780 --> 00:01:38,450
Now we're ready to look at control
schedule and control costs and

26
00:01:38,450 --> 00:01:41,100
these are very, very important.

27
00:01:41,100 --> 00:01:43,450
>> Right.
>> When we deal with a project,

28
00:01:43,450 --> 00:01:46,050
making sure you hit your requirements,
that's pretty cut and dry.

29
00:01:46,050 --> 00:01:47,620
You either hit them your you don't, right?

30
00:01:47,620 --> 00:01:49,280
There's no gray areas.

31
00:01:49,280 --> 00:01:52,970
But when it comes to cost and
schedule it's a moving target.

32
00:01:52,970 --> 00:01:54,400
>> Right.
>> It's constantly changing,

33
00:01:54,400 --> 00:01:58,540
really hard to keep track of,
so in this episode we're gonna

34
00:01:58,540 --> 00:02:02,530
talk about the general process
of controlling the schedule and

35
00:02:02,530 --> 00:02:07,440
controlling the costs
>> And we'll talk about how we do that,

36
00:02:07,440 --> 00:02:12,050
how we watch the numbers and
the actions we can take to correct those.

37
00:02:12,050 --> 00:02:15,760
But a big piece of what the PMI calls for

38
00:02:15,760 --> 00:02:20,420
in doing these is what's called EVM or
Earned Value Management.

39
00:02:20,420 --> 00:02:23,620
And EVM requires a ton of formulas.

40
00:02:24,620 --> 00:02:27,900
For a lot of people they've never done
it by hand, or they're intimidated

41
00:02:27,900 --> 00:02:31,890
by the math or whatever it's really
not that bad once you learn it.

42
00:02:31,890 --> 00:02:35,330
But what we want to do is we want to
split that off into a separate episode.

43
00:02:35,330 --> 00:02:39,450
So for this episode we're gonna
focus on the processes themselves.

44
00:02:39,450 --> 00:02:42,610
And then, in our next episode,
we'll go formula crazy.

45
00:02:42,610 --> 00:02:44,740
Right?
It'll be like Formula One up in here.

46
00:02:44,740 --> 00:02:45,265
Why not?
>> [LAUGH]

47
00:02:45,265 --> 00:02:46,120
>> So anyhow,

48
00:02:46,120 --> 00:02:48,770
that's what we're gonna
tackle with the next episode.

49
00:02:48,770 --> 00:02:51,860
But, for right now,
let's take a look at these process groups.

50
00:02:51,860 --> 00:02:53,730
So, what we'll go ahead and
start with schedule.

51
00:02:53,730 --> 00:02:58,340
Controlling our schedule, in a real
general sense, what does that mean?

52
00:02:58,340 --> 00:03:05,070
Well, if you have a specific end
point of your project, a date

53
00:03:05,070 --> 00:03:08,460
that you need to finish by, December 31,
2015, we've got to be done by then.

54
00:03:09,720 --> 00:03:13,120
How do we watch the activities
being performed on our project

55
00:03:13,120 --> 00:03:15,660
to ensure that we're done by December 31,
2015?

56
00:03:15,660 --> 00:03:19,880
You don't wait until December
30th 2015 to decide, "Wow,

57
00:03:19,880 --> 00:03:24,220
I don't think we're gonna make that date."
>> All throughout the project.

58
00:03:24,220 --> 00:03:27,050
Starting on day one of execution,

59
00:03:27,050 --> 00:03:32,090
you start monitoring to see whether or
not you're going to be in line.

60
00:03:32,090 --> 00:03:34,525
And then hopefully you don't
have to take any actions.

61
00:03:34,525 --> 00:03:36,845
Things go nice and smooth.

62
00:03:36,845 --> 00:03:39,415
But if things start to fall behind or

63
00:03:39,415 --> 00:03:41,775
things start to get ahead
that's when we step in.

64
00:03:41,775 --> 00:03:45,555
Now before I jump in to the process
itself let me just cover

65
00:03:45,555 --> 00:03:49,815
one other real important concept and
that's the concept of variance.

66
00:03:49,815 --> 00:03:51,960
I know I've used that word before but

67
00:03:51,960 --> 00:03:56,020
I wanna show you guys the PMI's
definition [LAUGH] of variance.

68
00:03:56,020 --> 00:03:57,450
And really what it is.

69
00:03:57,450 --> 00:04:02,280
Variance at its heart and soul if you
boil it down is just the difference

70
00:04:02,280 --> 00:04:07,850
between what you plan to happen and
what's actually happened.

71
00:04:07,850 --> 00:04:10,680
So we might make a chart, for example, and

72
00:04:10,680 --> 00:04:12,190
actually I think I did
this before the show.

73
00:04:12,190 --> 00:04:15,570
You can think I had planned for
this, there we go.

74
00:04:15,570 --> 00:04:17,990
Showing what our plan is right?

75
00:04:17,990 --> 00:04:21,736
During the planning phase,
maybe I charted out and

76
00:04:21,736 --> 00:04:25,680
let's say that over here
on the left is our budget.

77
00:04:25,680 --> 00:04:27,120
How much money we've spent.

78
00:04:27,120 --> 00:04:29,300
And over here on the bottom side,

79
00:04:29,300 --> 00:04:32,270
this will be how much
>> Time has passed.

80
00:04:32,270 --> 00:04:37,460
So I've expected to spend a certain amount
of money across time til I get to the end

81
00:04:37,460 --> 00:04:40,830
of my project and that's the total amount
of money that I would have spent, right?

82
00:04:40,830 --> 00:04:41,880
So that's my plan.

83
00:04:41,880 --> 00:04:44,240
That's what we come up with
in the planning phase.

84
00:04:44,240 --> 00:04:46,880
As out project goes on we
start to track that and

85
00:04:46,880 --> 00:04:48,520
we set up our various time intervals.

86
00:04:48,520 --> 00:04:52,430
So maybe at month two, and
then at month four, month six, or

87
00:04:52,430 --> 00:04:57,110
whatever our measuring interval is,
we start tracking that expense.

88
00:04:57,110 --> 00:05:01,250
Right, that money we spent, and we start
to notice right here that we're getting

89
00:05:01,250 --> 00:05:05,080
a little over budget, and that we're
getting a little more, and a little more,

90
00:05:05,080 --> 00:05:08,420
until we reach down here where
we've got a huge difference between

91
00:05:08,420 --> 00:05:12,570
what's actually happening and
what we plan for.

92
00:05:12,570 --> 00:05:16,330
And the difference between them,
that's our variance.

93
00:05:16,330 --> 00:05:19,940
In this example, it would be
the amount we went over budget.

94
00:05:19,940 --> 00:05:20,470
Right.

95
00:05:20,470 --> 00:05:23,970
But in terms of time, right, cuz we're
talking about schedule right now,

96
00:05:23,970 --> 00:05:26,910
this might be here's you're
measurement of time.

97
00:05:26,910 --> 00:05:30,910
And here's the measurement of the amount
of work we expected to get done, so

98
00:05:30,910 --> 00:05:34,830
I expected to have a certain amount
of work done in my plan, and

99
00:05:34,830 --> 00:05:38,320
I find as we move along that I'm
actually getting further and

100
00:05:38,320 --> 00:05:42,840
further ahead, and so
when I look at my numbers right here,

101
00:05:42,840 --> 00:05:46,790
I can see this huge difference between the
amount of work I planned to get done and

102
00:05:46,790 --> 00:05:50,070
the amount of work that was actually done,
this is great, right?

103
00:05:50,070 --> 00:05:51,980
I got a lot of extra work done.

104
00:05:51,980 --> 00:05:55,820
Well, I probably need to go evaluate that
and find out what's going on, right?

105
00:05:55,820 --> 00:05:59,240
Usually it's one of two things either one,
people are cutting corners, right?

106
00:05:59,240 --> 00:06:01,770
So some of the work is not
actually getting done or

107
00:06:01,770 --> 00:06:06,280
it's not being done right,or two
>> More work is getting done, but

108
00:06:06,280 --> 00:06:07,660
you're paying for it.

109
00:06:07,660 --> 00:06:09,480
OT, extra people.

110
00:06:09,480 --> 00:06:10,210
Overtime, you know.

111
00:06:10,210 --> 00:06:11,740
Extra people, things like that.

112
00:06:11,740 --> 00:06:15,510
So while we might be ahead of schedule,
our budget may be out of whack.

113
00:06:15,510 --> 00:06:17,910
We may be paying more to get there.

114
00:06:17,910 --> 00:06:21,000
So, just because I'm ahead of schedule
doesn't mean that's a great thing.

115
00:06:21,000 --> 00:06:24,220
I may need to go and revisit that and
find out what's going on.

116
00:06:24,220 --> 00:06:27,780
So, we have what we planned for,
what's actually happening, and

117
00:06:27,780 --> 00:06:30,500
variance is simply
the difference between the two.

118
00:06:30,500 --> 00:06:33,620
So, when we talk about
the control schedule process,

119
00:06:33,620 --> 00:06:36,940
what we're really talking
about is measuring variance.

120
00:06:36,940 --> 00:06:39,980
Once that difference and
then taking actions upon it.

121
00:06:41,190 --> 00:06:46,120
Alright so, for the schedule side of
things, to do this we need to gather data.

122
00:06:46,120 --> 00:06:48,180
And that data comes in as our plan.

123
00:06:48,180 --> 00:06:51,080
Your project management plan
serves as your baseline.

124
00:06:51,080 --> 00:06:54,350
Your plan tells you what you should
have achieved at certain dates.

125
00:06:54,350 --> 00:06:56,970
Your schedule, that information,
your work break down structure,

126
00:06:56,970 --> 00:06:58,879
it's all in there, the data that you need.

127
00:07:00,060 --> 00:07:03,530
Then our project schedule which
again is part of our plan,

128
00:07:03,530 --> 00:07:05,650
then our work performance data.

129
00:07:05,650 --> 00:07:09,060
The project schedule is
what should have been done,

130
00:07:09,060 --> 00:07:12,090
the work performance data
is what actually was done.

131
00:07:12,090 --> 00:07:15,350
Those are the two things that we need to
compare the difference between the two

132
00:07:15,350 --> 00:07:16,870
resulting in our variance.

133
00:07:16,870 --> 00:07:18,360
And now,
we know whether we are ahead or behind.

134
00:07:18,360 --> 00:07:20,230
Right?
It's pretty straight forward.

135
00:07:20,230 --> 00:07:21,940
And, you know, when you say it like that.

136
00:07:21,940 --> 00:07:24,590
When you just speak the words,
it's not a big deal.

137
00:07:24,590 --> 00:07:26,860
But, that was actually a formula, right?

138
00:07:26,860 --> 00:07:32,830
The planned value, the planned work,
versus the actual work.

139
00:07:32,830 --> 00:07:36,590
You take one, subtract the other,
and your result is your variance.

140
00:07:36,590 --> 00:07:39,240
That's one of the formulas
that we'll see later on.

141
00:07:39,240 --> 00:07:42,760
There's actually a ton of formulas,
but they're mostly common sense so

142
00:07:42,760 --> 00:07:47,060
if you think about it logically
this stuff kind of snaps together.

143
00:07:47,060 --> 00:07:48,540
We also have our project calendars.

144
00:07:48,540 --> 00:07:52,520
Now, notice how we've got a project
schedule and a project calendar.

145
00:07:52,520 --> 00:07:53,281
What's the difference, right?

146
00:07:53,281 --> 00:07:57,411
Well, a project schedule is showing
things like the work to be done

147
00:07:57,411 --> 00:07:59,421
at particular periods of time.

148
00:07:59,421 --> 00:08:04,178
It's not taking into account, in a lot of
cases The availability of our resources,

149
00:08:04,178 --> 00:08:06,864
we have to schedule our
resources separately.

150
00:08:06,864 --> 00:08:11,130
So we may have calendars that
are built around that, holidays,

151
00:08:11,130 --> 00:08:13,250
other things like that.

152
00:08:13,250 --> 00:08:16,750
A holiday is not an activity
in your project schedule, but

153
00:08:16,750 --> 00:08:20,320
it is in the project calendar is
a period where work can't get done, so

154
00:08:20,320 --> 00:08:22,230
it's kind of a differentiator there.

155
00:08:22,230 --> 00:08:23,880
Now I'll be honest with you, for me,

156
00:08:23,880 --> 00:08:26,290
I always get confused dealing
with multiple sources.

157
00:08:26,290 --> 00:08:29,520
So I usually log holidays as an activity
just to be able to track them a little

158
00:08:29,520 --> 00:08:33,970
more easily, but employee vacations, you
don't want to track that as an activity.

159
00:08:33,970 --> 00:08:37,180
So, those are scenarios where
you'd still have those calendars.

160
00:08:38,780 --> 00:08:41,270
Any other schedule data that we have, and

161
00:08:41,270 --> 00:08:45,970
that schedule data may include what
resources were assigned to an activity and

162
00:08:45,970 --> 00:08:49,400
things like the times during
a day where they work.

163
00:08:49,400 --> 00:08:53,980
If I'm tracking work, then I say there's
eight hours of work schedule for that day,

164
00:08:53,980 --> 00:08:58,680
I usually don't care if its eight
hours performed all in the morning or

165
00:08:58,680 --> 00:09:00,730
all in the afternoon, or
spread between the two,

166
00:09:00,730 --> 00:09:02,720
as long as the eight
hours of work gets done.

167
00:09:02,720 --> 00:09:04,780
If you're on a construction project,

168
00:09:04,780 --> 00:09:08,310
doesn't matter what time a day the work
gets done as long as it gets done.

169
00:09:08,310 --> 00:09:11,780
But there are some scenarios where you're
trying to coordinate resources those

170
00:09:11,780 --> 00:09:13,430
times become very important.

171
00:09:13,430 --> 00:09:16,470
And so we may need to get all the way
down into that with our scheduling data.

172
00:09:17,580 --> 00:09:20,127
And then our organizational
process assets,

173
00:09:20,127 --> 00:09:23,849
the paperwork and other resources
that our company has available,

174
00:09:23,849 --> 00:09:28,364
all those different things that we need to
adhere to, these are all of our inputs.

175
00:09:28,364 --> 00:09:32,110
We're just gathering that data
together to begin working with it.

176
00:09:32,110 --> 00:09:35,700
And the way we work with it,
well, we've actually talked about

177
00:09:35,700 --> 00:09:40,180
a lot of these already, performance
reviews with the individual people.

178
00:09:40,180 --> 00:09:43,870
We assess the amount of work that they've
been doing and their performance.

179
00:09:43,870 --> 00:09:46,960
Just because two people each work 8 hours,

180
00:09:46,960 --> 00:09:49,140
doesn't mean you got 16
hours worth of work.

181
00:09:49,140 --> 00:09:51,790
If one person is a expert in their field,

182
00:09:51,790 --> 00:09:55,930
they might have achieved twice as
much work as the other person.

183
00:09:55,930 --> 00:09:59,900
So take something like Ronnie.

184
00:09:59,900 --> 00:10:03,347
In a past life, Ronnie,
you used to work on cars, right?

185
00:10:03,347 --> 00:10:06,552
>> I did.
And your car knowledge outstrips mine,

186
00:10:06,552 --> 00:10:07,759
by far, right.

187
00:10:07,759 --> 00:10:08,692
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now,

188
00:10:08,692 --> 00:10:10,745
I know how to change the brakes on a car.

189
00:10:10,745 --> 00:10:11,760
>> Mm-hm.
>> So do you.

190
00:10:11,760 --> 00:10:12,930
>> I do.

191
00:10:12,930 --> 00:10:16,760
>> You, it would probably take what, like
an hour maybe to change brakes on a car?

192
00:10:16,760 --> 00:10:18,245
>> Right.
>> I know the last time I did it,

193
00:10:18,245 --> 00:10:20,055
it took me darn near four hours.

194
00:10:20,055 --> 00:10:21,545
And you know, I'm not good at it.

195
00:10:21,545 --> 00:10:22,695
I had to figure it out.

196
00:10:22,695 --> 00:10:25,845
We both did the same activity, right?

197
00:10:25,845 --> 00:10:28,255
But it took me four hours
where it took him one hour.

198
00:10:28,255 --> 00:10:32,078
So if we both worked one hour,
he's 100% done.

199
00:10:32,078 --> 00:10:34,280
I'm only 25% done.

200
00:10:34,280 --> 00:10:37,500
So, time is not necessarily
the greatest reflection of somebody's

201
00:10:37,500 --> 00:10:38,820
actual achievement.

202
00:10:38,820 --> 00:10:40,990
And so in a performance review,
that's what we're trying to break down.

203
00:10:40,990 --> 00:10:43,680
How much work did they actually
get done in that amount of time?

204
00:10:46,070 --> 00:10:47,990
Our project management software, right?

205
00:10:49,090 --> 00:10:53,960
Tracking schedules, especially when you're
getting tons of progress reports or

206
00:10:53,960 --> 00:10:57,720
work statements from all sorts of
employees, can be really difficult

207
00:10:57,720 --> 00:11:00,650
to correlate all that data and
put it together and get a big picture.

208
00:11:00,650 --> 00:11:04,140
And it's constantly changing, so you could
be mired in paperwork the rest of your

209
00:11:04,140 --> 00:11:06,050
life if you tried to do it by hand.

210
00:11:06,050 --> 00:11:07,860
Most of us use software, right.

211
00:11:07,860 --> 00:11:10,820
I'll bring up a Microsoft Project
in the next episode and

212
00:11:10,820 --> 00:11:13,900
kind of show where it can
make this stuff a lot easier.

213
00:11:13,900 --> 00:11:17,480
You start feeding in your data,
your status reports, and

214
00:11:17,480 --> 00:11:20,920
it's letting you know what's behind or
what's not coming up.

215
00:11:20,920 --> 00:11:23,910
And it'll do really all
the formulas we talked about.

216
00:11:23,910 --> 00:11:25,360
It does all that stuff for us.

217
00:11:25,360 --> 00:11:27,440
We don't even have to
think about the formulas.

218
00:11:27,440 --> 00:11:28,318
It's really, really handy.

219
00:11:28,318 --> 00:11:33,375
All right then, if we have a problem,
right, that's where we need to

220
00:11:33,375 --> 00:11:38,713
step in with things like our resource
optimization techniques, right.

221
00:11:38,713 --> 00:11:42,217
And we talk about those in another
episode, but just to kind of refresh,

222
00:11:42,217 --> 00:11:45,720
we have things like resource leveling and
resource smoothing.

223
00:11:45,720 --> 00:11:50,350
And that's where we take our resources,
where I might have them scheduled to work

224
00:11:50,350 --> 00:11:52,330
eight hours today and
eight hours tomorrow.

225
00:11:53,470 --> 00:11:57,120
But in order to meet some other needs of
my project, I might smooth them out so

226
00:11:57,120 --> 00:11:59,710
they do instead of eight
hours two days in a row,

227
00:11:59,710 --> 00:12:02,500
they do four hours four days in a row.

228
00:12:02,500 --> 00:12:05,560
And that frees them up with an extra
four hours in those first two days to

229
00:12:05,560 --> 00:12:08,030
help another activity get caught back up.

230
00:12:08,030 --> 00:12:12,130
So you can start to smooth and
then level your resources to make room or

231
00:12:12,130 --> 00:12:15,100
free up people to work on
other activities, right.

232
00:12:15,100 --> 00:12:18,760
Those are some examples of
resource optimization techniques.

233
00:12:18,760 --> 00:12:23,929
We also have modeling techniques,
things like, shoot, what's

234
00:12:23,929 --> 00:12:29,830
a great example here,
as far as how we lay out our resources.

235
00:12:29,830 --> 00:12:33,088
Actually, you know what I think I threw
these in the notes as I get my brain

236
00:12:33,088 --> 00:12:34,270
freeze here.

237
00:12:34,270 --> 00:12:35,573
There we go.

238
00:12:35,573 --> 00:12:38,900
Yeah, our what-if scenarios and
simulations.

239
00:12:38,900 --> 00:12:42,726
So when we are looking at our environment
and looking at that upcoming schedule and

240
00:12:42,726 --> 00:12:43,612
we see a problem and

241
00:12:43,612 --> 00:12:46,507
we want to fix it, the solution
might not be there right away.

242
00:12:46,507 --> 00:12:48,481
And so we experiment, we do modeling.

243
00:12:48,481 --> 00:12:50,536
We add in a few values,
we change things, and

244
00:12:50,536 --> 00:12:52,990
we see how it affects
the rest of the calendar.

245
00:12:52,990 --> 00:12:56,057
If you're doing that by hand,
it's a huge exercise.

246
00:12:56,057 --> 00:12:59,279
It takes a lot of effort, but
if you have project management software,

247
00:12:59,279 --> 00:13:01,110
it just takes a matter of moments.

248
00:13:01,110 --> 00:13:03,810
You plug in some alternate values and
see what happens and

249
00:13:03,810 --> 00:13:06,090
get an idea of what's gonna happen.

250
00:13:06,090 --> 00:13:09,304
All right, and then there's other
things that aren't here in the notes,

251
00:13:09,304 --> 00:13:11,407
things like schedule
crashing that we might do.

252
00:13:11,407 --> 00:13:13,439
And maybe we get extra resources.

253
00:13:13,439 --> 00:13:14,780
We throw money at our problem,

254
00:13:14,780 --> 00:13:17,550
I think is how I described
it in the earlier episodes.

255
00:13:17,550 --> 00:13:20,685
You can do whatever it takes to get
your schedule back on line, but

256
00:13:20,685 --> 00:13:24,219
those are the tools that you have at
your disposal to try and correct that,

257
00:13:24,219 --> 00:13:24,792
all right.

258
00:13:24,792 --> 00:13:28,615
Now sometimes you might fall behind
schedule, and it's not a big deal,

259
00:13:28,615 --> 00:13:31,686
because you may have leads and
lags, right, lead time and

260
00:13:31,686 --> 00:13:35,070
lag times that are available
that compensate for that.

261
00:13:35,070 --> 00:13:38,257
Activity C starts to get
a little bit behind, but

262
00:13:38,257 --> 00:13:41,380
activity D has a couple of
days of lag time on it.

263
00:13:41,380 --> 00:13:43,220
So that's okay.

264
00:13:43,220 --> 00:13:46,100
It can get pushed back a little bit,
and it will be fine.

265
00:13:46,100 --> 00:13:50,170
Remember how we calculated our float,
our total float and our free float.

266
00:13:50,170 --> 00:13:51,000
If you don't remember those,

267
00:13:51,000 --> 00:13:56,230
jump back to the scheduling section
of the planning process groups.

268
00:13:56,230 --> 00:13:57,870
We covered a lot of that there.

269
00:13:57,870 --> 00:14:00,590
But, in those theories,
you don't have to act, right.

270
00:14:00,590 --> 00:14:04,180
But if there is no float available, if
you're dealing with an activity that's on

271
00:14:04,180 --> 00:14:07,320
your critical path, it can't fall behind.

272
00:14:07,320 --> 00:14:10,700
If that critical path activity falls
behind, your whole project falls behind.

273
00:14:10,700 --> 00:14:13,880
And that's where we need to jump
over to our other techniques.

274
00:14:15,372 --> 00:14:19,360
All right, oh, I guess I gotta handle
myself with schedule compression, right?

275
00:14:19,360 --> 00:14:23,300
Schedule compression, where we look for
all the gaps in our schedule where we

276
00:14:23,300 --> 00:14:26,010
might be able to slide our
activities closer together.

277
00:14:26,010 --> 00:14:29,570
Or you may have more than one activity
that can occur at the same time.

278
00:14:29,570 --> 00:14:32,500
And again, we discuss those
in the planning section too.

279
00:14:32,500 --> 00:14:35,520
So remember,
that's always available to you.

280
00:14:35,520 --> 00:14:39,910
You may purposefully not do schedule
compression during planning

281
00:14:39,910 --> 00:14:41,190
to use that as a reserve.

282
00:14:41,190 --> 00:14:43,890
Now, you wanna be up front about that
with the powers that be when you set

283
00:14:43,890 --> 00:14:44,526
your schedule.

284
00:14:44,526 --> 00:14:48,573
But when the time comes where
you're actually executing the work,

285
00:14:48,573 --> 00:14:53,030
you might find that you need to
compress in order to meet your goals.

286
00:14:53,030 --> 00:14:55,960
And then the last one
is a scheduling tool.

287
00:14:57,630 --> 00:14:59,147
Again, some people look at this and
say, well,

288
00:14:59,147 --> 00:15:00,449
I've got project management software.

289
00:15:00,449 --> 00:15:02,435
Isn't that a scheduling tool?

290
00:15:02,435 --> 00:15:05,085
It can be, but it isn't always, right?

291
00:15:05,085 --> 00:15:06,845
Microsoft Project is a great example.

292
00:15:06,845 --> 00:15:09,665
If you've got the desktop
version of Microsoft Project,

293
00:15:09,665 --> 00:15:12,220
it is an amazing project
management program.

294
00:15:12,220 --> 00:15:16,800
And as far as arranging your employees,
as far as resources allows you to track if

295
00:15:16,800 --> 00:15:19,860
they've been over allocated and so
on, so it does a good job there.

296
00:15:19,860 --> 00:15:23,560
But what it doesn't do is it doesn't
track anything outside of the project.

297
00:15:23,560 --> 00:15:26,670
Things like sick time,
right, and leave requests.

298
00:15:26,670 --> 00:15:29,830
It doesn't track activities that they're
performing with other projects, right?

299
00:15:29,830 --> 00:15:32,150
You're really tied inside
of that single project.

300
00:15:32,150 --> 00:15:35,910
So with Microsoft Project, you really have
to go up to Microsoft Project server to

301
00:15:35,910 --> 00:15:38,990
really get the full scheduling
functionality out of it.

302
00:15:38,990 --> 00:15:43,230
A lot of people, instead, will leverage
a separate scheduling software, and

303
00:15:43,230 --> 00:15:44,222
we do that here.

304
00:15:44,222 --> 00:15:47,040
Our software, I can never remember
the name of it, Easy Clocking or

305
00:15:47,040 --> 00:15:48,030
something like that.

306
00:15:48,030 --> 00:15:51,432
So yeah, we have a different scheduling
software that we use outside of

307
00:15:51,432 --> 00:15:52,574
our project software.

308
00:15:52,574 --> 00:15:56,328
And it's just because that other software
does great with our payroll system and

309
00:15:56,328 --> 00:16:00,039
tracking vacations hours and benefits and
stuff that's specialized to that.

310
00:16:00,039 --> 00:16:04,024
So you may have a separate
scheduling pool for that.

311
00:16:04,024 --> 00:16:06,806
Very useful if you're trying to arrange
your resources to work in a certain time

312
00:16:06,806 --> 00:16:09,062
period and make sure you don't
conflict with their schedules.

313
00:16:12,075 --> 00:16:14,526
All right,
now as we work with our schedule,

314
00:16:14,526 --> 00:16:16,600
if everything is running as planned.

315
00:16:16,600 --> 00:16:17,100
Right?
>> Right.

316
00:16:17,100 --> 00:16:18,610
>> If there's nothing wrong

317
00:16:18,610 --> 00:16:21,760
then our only outputs here are gonna be
our work performance information, which,

318
00:16:21,760 --> 00:16:23,980
I know I've said this over and over again.

319
00:16:23,980 --> 00:16:26,380
It's just the way we interpret
that work performance data.

320
00:16:26,380 --> 00:16:28,826
Our schedule forecasts,
which will be good.

321
00:16:28,826 --> 00:16:29,326
Right?

322
00:16:29,326 --> 00:16:30,530
>> Right, yeah.
>> If everything's going great

323
00:16:30,530 --> 00:16:31,900
our forecast will be fine.

324
00:16:33,090 --> 00:16:34,270
And then that's really about it.

325
00:16:34,270 --> 00:16:36,980
We won't even really need to do any
updates other than updating our project

326
00:16:36,980 --> 00:16:39,720
documentation to show that
progress has occurred.

327
00:16:39,720 --> 00:16:41,090
But if things are going bad.

328
00:16:41,090 --> 00:16:42,900
Right?
If we're behind schedule or

00:16:42,900 --> 00:16:44,420
ahead of schedule or if we over budget or

330
00:16:44,420 --> 00:16:47,780
under budget, then we're gonna need
to generate some other documents.

331
00:16:47,780 --> 00:16:49,070
Like our forecasts.

332
00:16:49,070 --> 00:16:49,680
All right.

333
00:16:49,680 --> 00:16:52,240
Forecasts are where we try and
predict the future.

334
00:16:52,240 --> 00:16:55,290
We say based on where we're at today,

335
00:16:55,290 --> 00:16:59,920
if we continue on like this,
here's how we're gonna finish.

336
00:16:59,920 --> 00:17:03,670
We're gonna finish this much over budget,
or this much behind scheduled, or

337
00:17:03,670 --> 00:17:05,730
this much over, whatever it is.

338
00:17:05,730 --> 00:17:09,065
You find out what that's gonna
be like if you stay the course.

339
00:17:09,065 --> 00:17:09,920
Right?

340
00:17:09,920 --> 00:17:13,990
And that's gonna give you an idea of
whether you need to correct or not.

341
00:17:13,990 --> 00:17:15,350
If you find that the deviation,

342
00:17:15,350 --> 00:17:19,830
that the variance from the plan is small
enough to fit within your reserves.

343
00:17:19,830 --> 00:17:20,896
>> Then you might not worry about it.

344
00:17:20,896 --> 00:17:21,405
>> Yeah.
>> Right?

345
00:17:21,405 --> 00:17:22,480
You might just cruise along,

346
00:17:22,480 --> 00:17:23,930
you got reserves to cover it.

347
00:17:23,930 --> 00:17:27,830
But if you have no reserves, or
if you've exceeded the reserves,

348
00:17:27,830 --> 00:17:30,550
then you're gonna have to take action,
the forecast, do that.

349
00:17:30,550 --> 00:17:32,350
Now the way we do the forecast?

350
00:17:32,350 --> 00:17:32,930
Math.
>> [LAUGH]

351
00:17:32,930 --> 00:17:34,720
>> Lots and lots of math.

352
00:17:34,720 --> 00:17:38,035
So we're gonna see that in the next
episode generating those forecasts.

353
00:17:38,035 --> 00:17:39,010
Right?

354
00:17:39,010 --> 00:17:42,520
Now based on the forecast if
we do decide to take action,

355
00:17:42,520 --> 00:17:44,830
if we do resource leveling or smoothing.

356
00:17:44,830 --> 00:17:47,020
If we do schedule crashing,
schedule compression.

357
00:17:47,020 --> 00:17:50,760
If we do any of those various things,those
are going to result in change requests.

358
00:17:50,760 --> 00:17:53,650
Right?
We've got to change the activities inside

359
00:17:53,650 --> 00:17:56,450
of our project to accommodate
our new scenario and

360
00:17:56,450 --> 00:17:58,490
that in turn is gonna require
changing out baseline.

361
00:17:58,490 --> 00:17:59,150
So that's important.

362
00:18:00,270 --> 00:18:01,760
>> And speaking of changing baseline.

363
00:18:01,760 --> 00:18:03,540
Right?
There's a particular term that you'll

364
00:18:03,540 --> 00:18:05,228
find in the PMBOK every once in a while.

365
00:18:05,228 --> 00:18:07,730
They call re-baselining.

366
00:18:07,730 --> 00:18:10,928
And that particular term there
is usually our last effort.

367
00:18:10,928 --> 00:18:12,856
Right?
Once we've done all of these different

368
00:18:12,856 --> 00:18:16,433
things, we've tried it and we've just
realized there's no way this is gonna come

369
00:18:16,433 --> 00:18:19,295
underneath anything that I've tried,
we may have to do that.

370
00:18:19,295 --> 00:18:20,895
So, do remember that term.

371
00:18:20,895 --> 00:18:22,615
>> Yeah,
an example of where you'd read baseline.

372
00:18:22,615 --> 00:18:27,060
Let's say you had a deadline of December
1st and you're behind schedule.

373
00:18:27,060 --> 00:18:28,755
>> Yeah.
>> And you do everything you can.

374
00:18:28,755 --> 00:18:31,245
Schedule compression, crashing, you burn,
>> Everything.

375
00:18:31,245 --> 00:18:31,984
>> Your deserves.

376
00:18:31,984 --> 00:18:33,610
>> Yeah.
>> You do everything.

377
00:18:33,610 --> 00:18:35,219
And you still cant' hit December 1st.

378
00:18:35,219 --> 00:18:35,740
Right?

379
00:18:35,740 --> 00:18:37,780
Well your project is slated to fail.

380
00:18:37,780 --> 00:18:40,020
So you go to the sponsor, and
you explain the situation to him.

381
00:18:40,020 --> 00:18:42,260
You say look,
we're not gonna be successful right now,

382
00:18:42,260 --> 00:18:44,310
we're not gonna be able to
hit that December 1st date.

383
00:18:44,310 --> 00:18:47,080
And the sponsor says, well what can we do?

384
00:18:47,080 --> 00:18:50,020
And you say well,
if we could have a little more time.

385
00:18:50,020 --> 00:18:51,470
How about December 15th instead?

386
00:18:51,470 --> 00:18:52,320
If we had December 15th,

387
00:18:52,320 --> 00:18:55,610
we had those two extra weeks,
we could finish and be successful.

388
00:18:55,610 --> 00:18:58,190
And the sponsor says all right,

389
00:18:58,190 --> 00:19:01,510
I'm okay with that, I'm okay with
December 15th being our new start date.

390
00:19:01,510 --> 00:19:07,490
When that happens you do a change ticket,
change your finish date to December 15th.

391
00:19:07,490 --> 00:19:09,970
And then you re-balance your schedule.

392
00:19:09,970 --> 00:19:12,520
Right?
You move things around to fit within that

393
00:19:12,520 --> 00:19:14,210
window of time.

394
00:19:14,210 --> 00:19:17,300
Now that change ticket becomes
part of your new baseline.

395
00:19:17,300 --> 00:19:21,110
You're re-baselined, and
sure there was that December 1 date,

396
00:19:21,110 --> 00:19:23,945
your original baseline, but
that's not what you're working on anymore.

397
00:19:23,945 --> 00:19:25,530
>> Right.
>> Now you're working on baseline 2.0.

398
00:19:25,530 --> 00:19:27,280
>> Yeah.
>> Or whatever you wanna call it, and

399
00:19:27,280 --> 00:19:31,100
your new finish date is December 15th,
and now your project is back on for

400
00:19:31,100 --> 00:19:32,080
success again.

401
00:19:32,080 --> 00:19:33,150
Right?
It's part of that change

402
00:19:33,150 --> 00:19:34,710
management procedure.

403
00:19:34,710 --> 00:19:35,805
And that doesn't happen a lot.

404
00:19:35,805 --> 00:19:37,220
>> [LAUGH].
>> Where the sponsor is like, yeah,

405
00:19:37,220 --> 00:19:38,270
sure, fine, whatever.

406
00:19:40,115 --> 00:19:42,865
It is one of those things that creeps up,
though.

00:19:42,865 --> 00:19:43,535
All right.

Otherwise, we have our standard

Your project document updates,

Right?

Just remember that.

while this process is pretty

We watch what's being done,

There are some very specific operations

Now the reason we don't want to

Right?
One,

we want to make sure we have
the basic concepts understood

And two earned value management, EVM.

It really works by aggregating

Combining the values.

So you end up with this really
neat kind of dashboard or

measurement utility that or

00:20:32,660 --> 00:20:34,430

00:20:34,430 --> 00:20:38,850
You end up with these really cool

00:20:38,850 --> 00:20:42,590
So we want to talk about schedule and
costs and

00:20:42,590 --> 00:20:47,780
then once we've got those concepts down,

00:20:47,780 --> 00:20:50,740
All right, but that's basically it for

See what's going on, correct if you

can you think of anything else on

Just remember

this particular process even though

There's no way that you can

So, yeah, diligence is pretty much the key

>> That's really where you need

00:21:49,741 --> 00:21:53,543
So now we're gonna take a look at Cost.

>> Cost is a lot easier to maintain in

With schedule, you've got work and

the only real way to interpret

A lot of times they're just

00:22:39,010 --> 00:22:41,020

00:22:41,020 --> 00:22:43,750
But there are some challenges to cost.

00:22:43,750 --> 00:22:47,552
When you talk about a job being done,

Well, 0% is the job hasn't started,

And when they're halfway through,

So it's a nice, even distribution, but

cost is not always an even distribution.

00:23:01,289 --> 00:23:02,100

00:23:02,100 --> 00:23:03,390

00:23:03,390 --> 00:23:08,220
you might have an activity where you have

then you've gotta pay labor for employees

And when you track your costs

you end up with something like a weighted

I expect work to get done every day

But with a cost,
that initial plan maybe very different.

00:23:52,790 --> 00:23:55,843
All right.
So with something like cost,

So when I start tracking that as far as

I should expect to see that giant

then at the end I should expect to see it

00:24:36,830 --> 00:24:38,870
But if something happens.

Maybe we don't order the equipment right

purchase happens a few days later so

That should be okay, because I purchase

So, schedule might be fine even
though our budget's a little

00:24:56,110 --> 00:24:57,200
wonky there in the beginning.

Now, I'll notice when I go and check

00:25:16,680 --> 00:25:20,420
