to the end of the project because

529
00:25:24,820 --> 00:25:26,120
you saved the money at the beginning.

530
00:25:26,120 --> 00:25:28,819
So the variance is gonna
be there all the way along.

531
00:25:28,819 --> 00:25:31,077
Week after week,
you'll see that same difference,

532
00:25:31,077 --> 00:25:32,791
because you saved money back on day one.

533
00:25:32,791 --> 00:25:35,573
All right, there are some scenarios
where the reverse is true,

534
00:25:35,573 --> 00:25:37,320
where there's a lot of work up front.

535
00:25:37,320 --> 00:25:39,710
And then you actually do
equipment purchases at the end, so

536
00:25:39,710 --> 00:25:42,020
you see a sweeping model like that.

537
00:25:42,020 --> 00:25:46,130
But, just be aware,
cost is not always evenly distributed.

538
00:25:46,130 --> 00:25:48,480
And that can make it difficult to track.

539
00:25:48,480 --> 00:25:52,940
So don't assume that if an activity
has a cost of $80,000 and

540
00:25:52,940 --> 00:25:56,770
it's an eight day activity,
don't assume it's gonna be $10,000 a day.

541
00:25:56,770 --> 00:25:57,290
Right?

542
00:25:57,290 --> 00:26:01,979
If you do that, your variance is gonna
be huge all the way up until day eight,

543
00:26:01,979 --> 00:26:04,998
when things level out if
all the cost is up front.

544
00:26:04,998 --> 00:26:09,845
So, if I assume an even distribution
in my plan, across eight days,

545
00:26:09,845 --> 00:26:12,280
so here's my even distribution.

546
00:26:12,280 --> 00:26:16,849
But I buy the equipment on day one,
well now I've got this massive variance,

547
00:26:16,849 --> 00:26:21,715
especially like right in here, in the
middle, I've got this massive variance.

548
00:26:21,715 --> 00:26:23,990
And it slowly corrects itself.

549
00:26:23,990 --> 00:26:27,230
But if I'm just looking at the report,
right here on day four,

550
00:26:27,230 --> 00:26:31,640
I'm looking at that report and I'm saying,
holy moly I'm over 50% over budget.

551
00:26:31,640 --> 00:26:33,166
Actually this is more like
over 100% over budget.

552
00:26:33,166 --> 00:26:35,860
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm almost doubled what I had budgeted

553
00:26:35,860 --> 00:26:36,950
to spend here.

554
00:26:36,950 --> 00:26:38,740
So we have to understand that.

555
00:26:38,740 --> 00:26:43,870
If your plan does not incorporate that
information, you're gonna get bad numbers.

556
00:26:43,870 --> 00:26:47,425
And cost will be near impossible to
measure until you're actually done with

557
00:26:47,425 --> 00:26:50,530
the activity,
which is too late to do anything about it.

558
00:26:50,530 --> 00:26:51,200
Right?

559
00:26:51,200 --> 00:26:53,650
Because what if I see
that huge variance and

560
00:26:53,650 --> 00:26:56,798
I say okay I've got a huge variance but
you know what?

561
00:26:56,798 --> 00:27:00,190
I bet it's gonna arc back down and
we'll level out of the end and

562
00:27:00,190 --> 00:27:01,440
finish on schedule.

563
00:27:01,440 --> 00:27:03,010
But, it doesn't, right?

564
00:27:03,010 --> 00:27:05,740
Then it just continues on,
growing, growing, growing.

565
00:27:05,740 --> 00:27:07,230
And sure it comes back a little bit, but

566
00:27:07,230 --> 00:27:10,350
you still end up with a pretty big
variance, now you're over budget.

567
00:27:10,350 --> 00:27:11,410
There's no way to track that.

568
00:27:11,410 --> 00:27:15,640
So your cost as far as tracking
it is only gonna be as good

569
00:27:15,640 --> 00:27:19,720
as the original plan you set
underneath it, your original baseline.

570
00:27:19,720 --> 00:27:22,460
So we make sure we set an accurate
baseline to what our expenses

571
00:27:22,460 --> 00:27:23,570
are going to be.

572
00:27:23,570 --> 00:27:27,370
And then we track on that, and
now when I start to see that variance,

573
00:27:27,370 --> 00:27:29,900
that deviation, I can see it and

574
00:27:29,900 --> 00:27:34,780
I can spot it early on while I still
have time to do something about it.

575
00:27:34,780 --> 00:27:37,360
Actually, I really don't have
enough room for errors there do I?

576
00:27:37,360 --> 00:27:39,440
But I still have time to
do something about it and

577
00:27:39,440 --> 00:27:42,620
get it corrected and
hopefully we can bring that back in line.

578
00:27:42,620 --> 00:27:45,205
So maybe we were paying
unauthorized overtime, and

579
00:27:45,205 --> 00:27:48,669
we tell people, wait a minute,
that was not authorized overtime, so

580
00:27:48,669 --> 00:27:50,330
you've got to make that up to us.

581
00:27:50,330 --> 00:27:54,362
The contractor says okay, sorry about
that, we'll get it back in line and

582
00:27:54,362 --> 00:27:57,416
we'll cover the cost of some
of the additional labor.

583
00:27:57,416 --> 00:27:59,910
And so now,
towards the end of the project here,

584
00:28:01,170 --> 00:28:06,110
sure we had that little boost right here
where there was unauthorized overtime.

585
00:28:06,110 --> 00:28:10,380
But, wow, I'm just not able to
grab my little pointer there.

586
00:28:10,380 --> 00:28:11,500
There we go.

587
00:28:11,500 --> 00:28:14,000
But they compensated for

588
00:28:14,000 --> 00:28:17,480
it out of their own pocket to bring
it back in line towards the finish.

589
00:28:17,480 --> 00:28:20,870
So sure, we ended up with some
variance right there, but

590
00:28:20,870 --> 00:28:24,330
at the end of the day
it sorted itself out.

591
00:28:24,330 --> 00:28:27,950
That's what we hope to see, and
we get things kind of put back.

592
00:28:27,950 --> 00:28:30,900
When it comes to cost,
it's not necessarily as cut and

593
00:28:30,900 --> 00:28:32,460
dry as looking at the bank account.

594
00:28:32,460 --> 00:28:33,700
We've got to make sure
we've got a good plan.

595
00:28:35,080 --> 00:28:35,760
All right.

596
00:28:35,760 --> 00:28:37,640
So, if I go back to
the control costs process,

597
00:28:37,640 --> 00:28:40,720
we're gonna see a lot of the same
stuff that we saw with the schedule.

598
00:28:40,720 --> 00:28:42,380
Right?
Because it's the same idea.

599
00:28:42,380 --> 00:28:44,800
Our inputs, the project management plan.

600
00:28:44,800 --> 00:28:45,330
Right?

601
00:28:45,330 --> 00:28:48,560
That's what's gonna be containing all
the activities that get performed and

602
00:28:48,560 --> 00:28:50,010
that information.

603
00:28:50,010 --> 00:28:54,970
My project funding requirements,
that's a fancy way of saying your budget.

604
00:28:54,970 --> 00:28:58,810
You've got a budget and
the budget itself may just be one number.

605
00:28:58,810 --> 00:28:59,750
I have a project.

606
00:28:59,750 --> 00:29:01,430
It's a $5 million project.

607
00:29:01,430 --> 00:29:02,650
That's my budget.

608
00:29:02,650 --> 00:29:07,480
But the project funding requirements,
that's where we map out what days,

609
00:29:07,480 --> 00:29:10,300
what weeks, what months we
actually need that expense on.

610
00:29:10,300 --> 00:29:12,640
We talked about that back
in the planning episodes.

611
00:29:12,640 --> 00:29:15,634
You want to know when those
expenses are going to be incurred,

612
00:29:15,634 --> 00:29:20,050
cuz you might not need all $5 million
of that $5 million project on day one.

613
00:29:20,050 --> 00:29:24,070
So don't set it aside if you
don't need it right away.

614
00:29:24,070 --> 00:29:25,830
So you can set it aside as time goes on.

615
00:29:25,830 --> 00:29:29,590
That allows companies to take on projects
they couldn't afford all at once.

616
00:29:29,590 --> 00:29:31,820
So we need to know what those
requirements are, what days,

617
00:29:31,820 --> 00:29:34,330
what months we need
that money to be spent.

618
00:29:34,330 --> 00:29:35,570
That's gonna give us our accurate data.

619
00:29:36,840 --> 00:29:38,870
Then we've got our work performance data.

620
00:29:38,870 --> 00:29:41,630
In scheduling, work performance
data was really percent complete,

621
00:29:41,630 --> 00:29:43,080
how much work they had done.

622
00:29:43,080 --> 00:29:47,765
But here, work performance data,
is gonna be what's called our actual cost.

623
00:29:47,765 --> 00:29:49,915
Actual cost is how much money you spent.

624
00:29:49,915 --> 00:29:53,385
So I planned on spending
$300,000 by month three.

625
00:29:53,385 --> 00:29:56,705
How much have I actually spent?

626
00:29:56,705 --> 00:29:57,775
I've actually spent $300,000.

627
00:29:57,775 --> 00:29:59,425
I'm on budget.

628
00:29:59,425 --> 00:30:02,249
Or I've actually spent $250,000.

629
00:30:02,249 --> 00:30:03,705
I'm below budget.

630
00:30:03,705 --> 00:30:04,285
Maybe that's good.

631
00:30:04,285 --> 00:30:05,565
Maybe that's bad.

632
00:30:05,565 --> 00:30:06,595
Or I'm over budget.

633
00:30:06,595 --> 00:30:11,080
We find that our really easy based on
our actual cost versus our planned cost,

634
00:30:11,080 --> 00:30:12,675
what we expected to spend.

635
00:30:12,675 --> 00:30:14,626
And then our organizational
process assets.

636
00:30:14,626 --> 00:30:18,429
In this case it's gonna usually be our
bookkeeping, whatever resources as far as

637
00:30:18,429 --> 00:30:22,250
accountants, bank accounts and financial
reporting information that we have.

638
00:30:23,770 --> 00:30:26,960
On our tools and techniques,
It's almost all math.

639
00:30:26,960 --> 00:30:29,750
And like I said, we're gonna hold that for
the next episode.

640
00:30:29,750 --> 00:30:32,440
But earned value management
is a big part of it.

641
00:30:32,440 --> 00:30:36,941
Looking at what you spent so far versus
what you should have spent so far and

642
00:30:36,941 --> 00:30:40,146
determining whether you're over or
under budget.

643
00:30:40,146 --> 00:30:43,540
And then trending that out to the future,
the forecasting piece,

644
00:30:43,540 --> 00:30:46,455
to see what's gonna happen as you go on,
right?

645
00:30:46,455 --> 00:30:51,195
Now there is a series of numbers that we
can calculate here that show us this.

646
00:30:51,195 --> 00:30:55,145
But one of the cooler ones that
the PMI calls out pretty strongly

647
00:30:55,145 --> 00:30:59,070
is the To-Complete Performance Index,
all right?

648
00:30:59,070 --> 00:31:02,620
And what, anytime you see to complete,
we're going to see a lot of calculations.

649
00:31:02,620 --> 00:31:05,620
It'll be budget at completion,
things like that.

650
00:31:05,620 --> 00:31:09,180
And then there's going to
be budget to complete.

651
00:31:09,180 --> 00:31:13,130
And that means how much more money
do we need to finish this project?

652
00:31:13,130 --> 00:31:16,210
Or how much more time do we
need to finish this project?

653
00:31:16,210 --> 00:31:19,590
So it'll give you that idea of
what's coming down the line.

654
00:31:19,590 --> 00:31:23,565
So when we talk about
the To Complete Performance Index that's

655
00:31:23,565 --> 00:31:25,665
a percentage number basically.

656
00:31:25,665 --> 00:31:27,534
That'll show how much more money or

657
00:31:27,534 --> 00:31:31,660
how much less money we'll need to finish
than what we'd originally planned.

658
00:31:31,660 --> 00:31:35,440
And it's really just one piece
of several other things.

659
00:31:35,440 --> 00:31:40,240
We have a cost performance index,
a CPI, that's where you are right now.

660
00:31:40,240 --> 00:31:42,730
To Complete is where
you'll be when you finish.

661
00:31:42,730 --> 00:31:43,960
That's seeing the future.

662
00:31:45,730 --> 00:31:47,660
We've got our performance reviews.

663
00:31:47,660 --> 00:31:51,810
Performance reviews in a matter of
cost is really just bookkeeping.

664
00:31:51,810 --> 00:31:55,745
Checking what was spent in the bank
accounts versus what's been reported

665
00:31:55,745 --> 00:31:58,100
inside of our project and
what was planned.

666
00:31:58,100 --> 00:32:01,728
And kind of correlating those numbers
together and figuring out where we fall.

667
00:32:03,726 --> 00:32:04,874
And then we've got our
project management software.

668
00:32:04,874 --> 00:32:08,885
You may have project management software
that does all of this stuff for you and

669
00:32:08,885 --> 00:32:09,810
does a great job.

670
00:32:09,810 --> 00:32:12,585
I'll tell you,
I've never had that experience though.

671
00:32:12,585 --> 00:32:14,716
>> [LAUGH]
>> Most project management software is not

672
00:32:14,716 --> 00:32:15,977
good financial software.

673
00:32:15,977 --> 00:32:19,523
Microsoft Project only recently,
really in Project 2010,

674
00:32:19,523 --> 00:32:23,197
did they even start addressing
monetary values in any real way, and

675
00:32:23,197 --> 00:32:26,042
they've gotten better in
some of the new versions.

676
00:32:26,042 --> 00:32:30,020
But at the end of the day,
it's not accounting software.

677
00:32:30,020 --> 00:32:34,490
So it can do basic numbers and give us
a general idea for tracking purposes, but

678
00:32:34,490 --> 00:32:38,195
it's not something you'd want to submit
to the IRS for taxes, or whatever.

679
00:32:38,195 --> 00:32:40,625
So, you know,
we need to make sure we keep that in mind,

680
00:32:40,625 --> 00:32:44,285
that our project manager software
might not be the perfect solution.

681
00:32:44,285 --> 00:32:44,965
All right.

682
00:32:44,965 --> 00:32:48,895
But it does give you a good idea and, in
fact, if you're using Microsoft Project,

683
00:32:48,895 --> 00:32:53,125
if you feed it your financial data,
it will calculate out things like TCPI for

684
00:32:53,125 --> 00:32:55,205
you so you don't even have to
worry about the math behind it.

685
00:32:56,780 --> 00:33:00,060
Now, one of the most
important things we do when

686
00:33:00,060 --> 00:33:02,990
we're talking about controlling costs,
is reserve analysis.

687
00:33:04,080 --> 00:33:09,190
If you set up a reserve in your planning
phase, to say I've got this amount

688
00:33:09,190 --> 00:33:14,830
of dollars set aside just in case we go
over, or just in case certain risks occur.

689
00:33:14,830 --> 00:33:19,530
Well, when you did that, the reserve,
those funds should be earmarked for

690
00:33:19,530 --> 00:33:22,000
those contingencies that you planned for,
right?

691
00:33:22,000 --> 00:33:26,750
So no one should be drawing
money from the reserve unless it

692
00:33:26,750 --> 00:33:30,240
fulfills the requirements we specified
when we set up that reserve, right?

693
00:33:30,240 --> 00:33:34,350
So if we're doing an outdoor rock concert,
and there's a chance it might rain, I

694
00:33:34,350 --> 00:33:40,410
might have set aside $10,000 in reserve so
that if it rains, we can get those tents.

695
00:33:41,420 --> 00:33:45,040
Well, as we come up on the festival,
we realize it's not gonna rain.

696
00:33:45,040 --> 00:33:46,850
It's the middle of a drought,
it's not gonna happen,

697
00:33:46,850 --> 00:33:48,425
we don't need that ten grand.

698
00:33:48,425 --> 00:33:52,130
That doesn't mean we can go and
use that ten grand for something else.

699
00:33:52,130 --> 00:33:54,610
It means that the ten grand
was earmarked for tents.

700
00:33:54,610 --> 00:33:55,790
We didn't need the tenths.

701
00:33:55,790 --> 00:33:57,760
We gave the money back to the company.

702
00:33:57,760 --> 00:33:59,730
It wasn't used, all right.

703
00:33:59,730 --> 00:34:02,790
If you want to use it for something else,
you got to go change ticket.

704
00:34:02,790 --> 00:34:06,560
A change ticket to say, we want to
reallocate this reserve to another area

705
00:34:06,560 --> 00:34:10,120
that has fallen behind because it needs
help or it could be better with some extra

706
00:34:10,120 --> 00:34:14,970
money and if the sponsor is okay with
that, now you can reallocate the reserve.

707
00:34:14,970 --> 00:34:16,780
But it's not yours to
do with as you please.

708
00:34:16,780 --> 00:34:18,260
It needs to be earmarked.

709
00:34:18,260 --> 00:34:19,388
If you don't do that.

710
00:34:19,388 --> 00:34:23,590
If you don't do a reserve
system that's tracked and

711
00:34:23,590 --> 00:34:28,086
controlled then it leaves room for
impropriety right?

712
00:34:28,086 --> 00:34:28,724
I mean you could be.

713
00:34:28,724 --> 00:34:29,540
Money's disappearing.

714
00:34:29,540 --> 00:34:32,440
>> You're spending money on
all sorts of crazy things.

715
00:34:32,440 --> 00:34:34,780
And that's something you
absolutely want to avoid.

716
00:34:34,780 --> 00:34:36,496
There are a lot of people
who do that in real life.

717
00:34:36,496 --> 00:34:39,340
They actually set up a reserve with
no earmarks on it and just say,

718
00:34:39,340 --> 00:34:41,100
I'm gonna hold onto this money in case.

719
00:34:41,100 --> 00:34:44,080
And that may be fine for their company.

720
00:34:44,080 --> 00:34:45,760
On the exam,
it's gonna be the wrong answer though.

721
00:34:45,760 --> 00:34:47,460
You wanna make sure that's reserved.

722
00:34:48,490 --> 00:34:51,800
All right, so that's kind of some of
the things that are involved there.

723
00:34:51,800 --> 00:34:55,400
Reserve analysis, you may not even be the
one that does it, as the project manager.

724
00:34:55,400 --> 00:34:58,870
If you have an accounting team or
an accounts payable department or

725
00:34:58,870 --> 00:35:03,520
whatever, that is controlling the funds,
then they may be the ones that do it.

726
00:35:03,520 --> 00:35:06,910
And most of the environments that
I've worked in, as a project manager,

727
00:35:06,910 --> 00:35:09,640
I didn't have check writing authority for
the company.

728
00:35:09,640 --> 00:35:12,270
So I couldn't just cut
a check to somebody.

729
00:35:12,270 --> 00:35:15,490
What I would have to do is any time
I needed to pay out to a vendor,

730
00:35:15,490 --> 00:35:18,060
to a contractor or whatever,
I'd submit a form.

731
00:35:18,060 --> 00:35:21,970
Submit a form to the accounting department
saying, I'm Don Pezet, project manager for

732
00:35:21,970 --> 00:35:25,280
this project,
Word package number blah, blah, blah,

733
00:35:25,280 --> 00:35:27,520
because we use a work
breakdown structure number.

734
00:35:27,520 --> 00:35:29,340
And we'd say that code of accounts,

735
00:35:29,340 --> 00:35:31,780
that activity,
needs to be paid out to this vendor.

736
00:35:31,780 --> 00:35:33,080
The work was complete.

737
00:35:33,080 --> 00:35:36,150
The accounting department would review
it and then they would cut the check.

738
00:35:36,150 --> 00:35:39,845
And if I was trying to approve funds for
something that wasn't predetermined,

739
00:35:39,845 --> 00:35:42,438
then they'd reject it and
require more information and

740
00:35:42,438 --> 00:35:45,547
I would have to get the sponsor
involved to be able to achieve that.

741
00:35:45,547 --> 00:35:48,050
It's a very common scenario.

742
00:35:48,050 --> 00:35:52,750
In a projectized organization though,
you as a project manager might have check

743
00:35:52,750 --> 00:35:55,750
writing authority and
if that's the case, then it's

744
00:35:55,750 --> 00:35:59,260
all on your shoulders to make sure that
money's being properly portioned out.

745
00:36:02,130 --> 00:36:04,110
All right, that leads us to our outputs.

746
00:36:04,110 --> 00:36:06,700
On the output side,
just like on the schedule side, right?

747
00:36:06,700 --> 00:36:08,080
Work performance information.

748
00:36:08,080 --> 00:36:10,530
That's how we've interpreted
our financial data.

749
00:36:10,530 --> 00:36:13,310
And usually converted it into
numbers that make sense.

750
00:36:13,310 --> 00:36:16,420
When we do all the formulas in the next
episode, you'll see there's a lot of

751
00:36:16,420 --> 00:36:20,220
numbers that'll make sense to us
cause we just learned about them.

752
00:36:20,220 --> 00:36:22,890
But the average Joe, or
your CEO or whatever,

753
00:36:22,890 --> 00:36:24,280
they may not know what
those numbers mean so

754
00:36:24,280 --> 00:36:27,980
we need to translate them into a way
that is a little more understandable.

755
00:36:27,980 --> 00:36:29,520
We'll have our cost forecasts,

756
00:36:29,520 --> 00:36:32,620
so what things are gonna look like
in the future at our current rate.

757
00:36:32,620 --> 00:36:35,710
We'll have our change requests,
if we need to take an action,

758
00:36:35,710 --> 00:36:38,000
if we need to tap into a reserve or
whatever.

759
00:36:38,000 --> 00:36:41,130
You know, tapping into a reserve doesn't
always require a change request.

760
00:36:41,130 --> 00:36:44,720
If you've already earmarked it for that
contingency, and the contingency happens,

761
00:36:44,720 --> 00:36:45,960
that's part of the plan.

762
00:36:45,960 --> 00:36:47,480
So you don't need a change request.

763
00:36:47,480 --> 00:36:50,920
If you're reallocating those reserves,
then that's where you'd need a change.

764
00:36:50,920 --> 00:36:53,150
Project Management Plan updates.

765
00:36:53,150 --> 00:36:57,810
Again, if you have changes that are gonna
result in a modification to the plan,

766
00:36:57,810 --> 00:36:58,990
you need to do that.

767
00:36:58,990 --> 00:37:01,650
Usually though, what we're talking
about here are more things like

768
00:37:01,650 --> 00:37:04,540
the risk register, so
if a risk happens or doesn't happen,

769
00:37:04,540 --> 00:37:07,450
we enter that in the risk register, which
is part of our project management plan.

770
00:37:08,490 --> 00:37:10,830
Any other project document
updates that we may need to,

771
00:37:10,830 --> 00:37:16,122
any accounting work that we need to do and
organizational process asset updates.

772
00:37:16,122 --> 00:37:18,924
Remember that when we engage in
contracts and we pay out to vendors,

773
00:37:18,924 --> 00:37:21,790
that we generate a lot of documentation
based on their performance.

774
00:37:21,790 --> 00:37:25,608
And we want to share that with other
project managers so they can see how it

775
00:37:25,608 --> 00:37:28,926
happened for us and they can
recreate that in their projects and

776
00:37:28,926 --> 00:37:31,776
that's part of our
organizational process assets.

777
00:37:31,776 --> 00:37:33,300
>> The overall goal for

778
00:37:33,300 --> 00:37:36,766
us here on the controlling costs a lot
of times is not really just goin,

779
00:37:36,766 --> 00:37:40,240
I know things are actually on budget,
which they're great when they are.

780
00:37:40,240 --> 00:37:43,240
But it's to actually build and
control any uncontrolled spending, right?

781
00:37:43,240 --> 00:37:43,890
Right?

782
00:37:43,890 --> 00:37:47,160
So someone actually takes too
much when they don't need to.

783
00:37:47,160 --> 00:37:48,910
We're not sure where the money's going.

784
00:37:48,910 --> 00:37:52,550
The whole goal of getting all of
the information that we need here,

785
00:37:52,550 --> 00:37:53,350
is that idea.

786
00:37:53,350 --> 00:37:55,690
So that we know exactly where it's going.

787
00:37:55,690 --> 00:37:57,430
Because, we're reporting stakeholders.

788
00:37:57,430 --> 00:37:59,550
And they need to know,
and we need to know too.

789
00:37:59,550 --> 00:38:03,080
So really, that's the key behind
all the numbers that we're facing.

790
00:38:03,080 --> 00:38:03,620
Yep.
>> Yeah.

791
00:38:04,790 --> 00:38:08,540
All right, so that in a nutshell
is controlling the cost.

792
00:38:08,540 --> 00:38:11,110
The processes themselves
are not that hard, but

793
00:38:11,110 --> 00:38:13,030
we left out a pretty big chunk there,
didn't we.

794
00:38:13,030 --> 00:38:14,720
Items one, two, and three.

795
00:38:14,720 --> 00:38:17,110
These are the math that we use.

796
00:38:17,110 --> 00:38:20,840
And there are common sense metrics that
you can use for monitoring your project,

797
00:38:20,840 --> 00:38:22,120
if you want to go that way.

798
00:38:22,120 --> 00:38:26,170
But remember, you are working to become
a project management professional

799
00:38:26,170 --> 00:38:29,240
as certified by the PMI,
the Project Management Institute.

800
00:38:29,240 --> 00:38:32,390
And the exam is based on the PMBOK,
the Project Management Body Of Knowledge.

801
00:38:32,390 --> 00:38:34,020
You'll see how many acronyms
I can throw out here.

802
00:38:34,020 --> 00:38:38,120
>> Yeah. [LAUGH] >> So they have
a prescribed method for tracking this,

803
00:38:38,120 --> 00:38:42,140
a method that has been tested and proven
across companies all across the world.

804
00:38:42,140 --> 00:38:47,000
And if you use those numbers, they're
known to be reliable, well-founded, and

805
00:38:47,000 --> 00:38:50,340
scientifically proven numbers
that you can count on.

806
00:38:50,340 --> 00:38:52,400
Versus numbers that could
potentially be modified or

807
00:38:52,400 --> 00:38:55,440
changed to reflect a situation
differently than it is.

808
00:38:55,440 --> 00:38:58,630
So we're gonna tackle that,
but it is a lot.

809
00:39:00,510 --> 00:39:02,910
So let's do this Ronnie, why don't
we go ahead and wrap this show here?

810
00:39:02,910 --> 00:39:05,160
>> Okay.
>> This will be one of our shorter shows.

811
00:39:05,160 --> 00:39:09,030
And in the next episode,
we're gonna go formula crazy.

812
00:39:09,030 --> 00:39:10,410
We'll see how long it takes,

813
00:39:10,410 --> 00:39:12,740
depends on your questions we
get in the chatroom and stuff.

814
00:39:12,740 --> 00:39:15,120
That maybe a longer episode or
shorter one, we'll see.

815
00:39:15,120 --> 00:39:17,750
But I want to make sure that's separate,
so people can focus in on it.

816
00:39:18,930 --> 00:39:23,840
All right, well, if you have any questions
on what we've talked about be sure to ask.

817
00:39:23,840 --> 00:39:26,570
Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live and

818
00:39:26,570 --> 00:39:29,320
you'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

819
00:39:29,320 --> 00:39:30,160
Post your questions there.

820
00:39:30,160 --> 00:39:32,690
We monitor and answer during the show.

821
00:39:32,690 --> 00:39:36,090
If you have questions after the show,
use the Q & A forms.

822
00:39:36,090 --> 00:39:38,660
At the top of ever page is
a link that says Q & A.

823
00:39:38,660 --> 00:39:39,510
Jump on in there.

824
00:39:39,510 --> 00:39:43,030
You can post your questions,
we monitor and answer there too.

825
00:39:43,030 --> 00:39:45,740
So take advantage of that resource,
it is there for you.

826
00:39:46,840 --> 00:39:48,990
All right, well,
hope you guys enjoyed the show.

827
00:39:48,990 --> 00:39:51,310
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

828
00:39:51,310 --> 00:39:52,080
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

829
00:39:52,080 --> 00:39:52,670
>> And we will see you next time.

830
00:39:52,670 --> 00:39:57,619
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show the most common formulas found in the PMBOK and demonstrate how they are used when having to do forecasting for time and cost management within a project. They use the formulas in context of a project, emphasizing the need to memorize these for the PMP exam. The formula sheets Don uses in this episode are available for download bundled in a ZIP file. The download URL can be found in the Overview episode description.
episodes.title: Earned Value Management
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,382 --> 00:00:07,811
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,811 --> 00:00:12,601
All

3
00:00:12,601 --> 00:00:22,601
right.

4
00:00:23,782 --> 00:00:29,386
Good morning,

5
00:00:29,386 --> 00:00:36,610
good afternoon and good evening.

6
00:00:36,610 --> 00:00:38,820
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:38,820 --> 00:00:40,690
I'm you host Don Pezet.

8
00:00:40,690 --> 00:00:43,730
Back again with Ronnie Wong [LAUGH]
how's it going Ronnie I can't even say

9
00:00:43,730 --> 00:00:45,510
your name.

10
00:00:45,510 --> 00:00:47,600
>> It is going well but I am saddened.

11
00:00:47,600 --> 00:00:50,310
I once again did not get
chosen to be on the Bachelor.

12
00:00:50,310 --> 00:00:50,860
>> No way.
>> No.

13
00:00:50,860 --> 00:00:52,530
>> How many times can you get passed up?

14
00:00:52,530 --> 00:00:53,680
>> Apparently, a lot.

15
00:00:53,680 --> 00:00:56,225
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

16
00:00:56,225 --> 00:00:56,955
Wow.

17
00:00:56,955 --> 00:00:59,795
I'm sure you'd have the best of luck,
if you were on that show.

18
00:00:59,795 --> 00:01:01,651
You've got the moral caliber for it.

19
00:01:01,651 --> 00:01:03,353
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

20
00:01:04,505 --> 00:01:05,165
>> We are gonna jump

21
00:01:05,165 --> 00:01:07,500
back into the world of project management.

22
00:01:07,500 --> 00:01:11,010
Specifically, jumping into
earned value management.

23
00:01:11,010 --> 00:01:14,260
If you watched our last episode,
we introduced you guys to the topics of

24
00:01:14,260 --> 00:01:18,320
cost and schedule control,
which are very important.

25
00:01:18,320 --> 00:01:22,130
As a project manager, we need to
recognize when our costs are high or

26
00:01:22,130 --> 00:01:27,360
low, when our schedule is fast or
slow and make corrective actions.

27
00:01:27,360 --> 00:01:30,000
The corrective actions, there's only
a hand full we can even pick from, so

28
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:31,110
that's pretty easy.

29
00:01:31,110 --> 00:01:35,740
The hard part is knowing when to
take the action and a lot of us can

30
00:01:35,740 --> 00:01:39,700
get wrapped up in this world where we're
looking at individual activities and

31
00:01:39,700 --> 00:01:41,560
losing sight of the big picture.

32
00:01:41,560 --> 00:01:47,120
So, the PMI stresses
a set of tools basically,

33
00:01:47,120 --> 00:01:52,130
or a methodology, that we can use to
gauge the progress of our project.

34
00:01:52,130 --> 00:01:55,570
And not just gauge what
we're at right now but

35
00:01:55,570 --> 00:01:59,970
trend it out into the future to get an
idea of what's gonna happen down the road.

36
00:01:59,970 --> 00:02:03,410
So there's a series of formulas that
we can use to get these values.

37
00:02:03,410 --> 00:02:07,870
The nice part about this is if everybody
manages their project using the same earn

38
00:02:07,870 --> 00:02:12,850
value formulas, then it becomes very
easy to compare one project to another.

39
00:02:12,850 --> 00:02:15,750
It's apples to apples with these
numbers that are being generated,

40
00:02:15,750 --> 00:02:18,820
versus if people are measuring
their performance different ways.

41
00:02:18,820 --> 00:02:22,440
There are other ways to do it but
a standardized method is the best one.

42
00:02:22,440 --> 00:02:26,720
So the PMI, they have obviously shopped
around a number of different methods and

43
00:02:26,720 --> 00:02:29,700
they selected this one as
being the most flexible and

44
00:02:29,700 --> 00:02:31,040
the most generally applicable.

45
00:02:31,040 --> 00:02:33,440
So a lot of organizations can use this.

46
00:02:33,440 --> 00:02:34,050
It makes sense.

47
00:02:34,050 --> 00:02:37,370
It's very common even
in non-PMI environments

48
00:02:37,370 --> 00:02:40,506
to use earned value management.

49
00:02:40,506 --> 00:02:42,835
Now, EVM is made up of a lot of formulas,
and

50
00:02:42,835 --> 00:02:44,755
that's why we didn't want to jump
into it in the last episode,

51
00:02:44,755 --> 00:02:48,955
we wanted to dedicate this episode
just to figuring all that out.

52
00:02:48,955 --> 00:02:51,967
So before we even get
started on that though,

53
00:02:51,967 --> 00:02:53,927
there's a few pieces of
information we need.

54
00:02:53,927 --> 00:02:57,027
If you're going to start dealing
with formulas you've got values,

55
00:02:57,027 --> 00:03:01,227
you've got a plugin, you need to know what
those values are and we also need to know

56
00:03:01,227 --> 00:03:04,973
how this is going to be presented to us
on the exam so we can be ready for that.

57
00:03:04,973 --> 00:03:08,868
Oftentimes, what your gonna see on
the exam is where they describe a project.

58
00:03:08,868 --> 00:03:13,098
So they tell you what the project is and
they tell you some of the information

59
00:03:13,098 --> 00:03:15,648
about it, like your expenses and
your schedule and stuff like that.

60
00:03:16,710 --> 00:03:21,630
They oftentimes give you a lot more
information than you actually need, and

61
00:03:21,630 --> 00:03:23,900
then they ask you a question about it.

62
00:03:23,900 --> 00:03:27,590
So they say, In the above project,
calculate out this value, or

63
00:03:27,590 --> 00:03:31,720
that value, and you need to be able to
look at that word problem and figure out

64
00:03:31,720 --> 00:03:36,140
what pieces of information you actually
need and which pieces you can ignore.

65
00:03:36,140 --> 00:03:39,760
Which pieces you need now versus which
pieces you might need later, and

66
00:03:39,760 --> 00:03:41,320
you've gotta work it out.

67
00:03:41,320 --> 00:03:45,770
Now when you go to sit for
that exam, you get paper and pencil.

68
00:03:45,770 --> 00:03:48,370
The exam is on the computer but
you get a paper and pencil for

69
00:03:48,370 --> 00:03:51,330
scratch pad to work with and
you need to do this by hand.

70
00:03:51,330 --> 00:03:54,210
They do not give you
the formulas on the exam and

71
00:03:54,210 --> 00:03:56,950
you can't take a formula
sheet in with you either.

72
00:03:56,950 --> 00:04:00,820
So you need to make sure that you've
got these formulas memorized,

73
00:04:00,820 --> 00:04:03,300
that you can recall
them without effort and

74
00:04:03,300 --> 00:04:06,730
that you know when to apply
one formula versus another.

75
00:04:06,730 --> 00:04:08,960
That's pretty easy because it's
based on what we're trying to get.

76
00:04:08,960 --> 00:04:11,480
There's always one result that
comes out of these formulas.

77
00:04:12,760 --> 00:04:16,140
So, what are the pieces that
make up these formulas?

78
00:04:16,140 --> 00:04:21,050
We start off with something
called Planned Value.

79
00:04:21,050 --> 00:04:23,300
Actually, even before we get to that,

80
00:04:23,300 --> 00:04:26,320
let me mention a few other
values that we might see.

81
00:04:26,320 --> 00:04:29,890
We have a value called
Budget at Completion, BAC.

82
00:04:30,970 --> 00:04:32,710
BAC is a very important value,

83
00:04:32,710 --> 00:04:36,230
it's a cornerstone that's used
in almost all of our formulas.

84
00:04:36,230 --> 00:04:38,300
This is one of the easiest ones to grasp.

85
00:04:38,300 --> 00:04:40,750
Budget at Completion is
like its name implies,

86
00:04:40,750 --> 00:04:45,030
when the project is complete, what was our
budget, how much should we have spent?

87
00:04:45,030 --> 00:04:47,450
So in the planning phase
we came up with a budget.

88
00:04:47,450 --> 00:04:52,040
We came up with the total dollar amount
for what our project was gonna cost.

89
00:04:52,040 --> 00:04:55,770
That total dollar amount, that's your BAC.

90
00:04:55,770 --> 00:04:58,250
So when a formula calls for
budget at completion,

91
00:04:58,250 --> 00:05:02,680
it's just saying, by the end of this
project, how much did you expect to spend?

92
00:05:02,680 --> 00:05:06,550
If you hit that number on the head you'd
be happy, that's the happy number,

93
00:05:06,550 --> 00:05:09,080
that's what they want, BAC.

94
00:05:09,080 --> 00:05:13,340
Then we start modifying
BAC with other things.

95
00:05:13,340 --> 00:05:16,020
So planned value, for example.

96
00:05:16,020 --> 00:05:21,600
Planned value is how much work should
we have achieved at this point?

97
00:05:21,600 --> 00:05:24,030
Budget at completion,
that's at the end of the project.

98
00:05:24,030 --> 00:05:25,620
What if we're halfway through a project?

99
00:05:25,620 --> 00:05:29,332
What if I've got a two year project,
and I'm at the end of year one?

100
00:05:29,332 --> 00:05:34,120
In a balanced project, you'd expect
to be about 50% of the way through.

101
00:05:34,120 --> 00:05:37,590
You'd expect to have spent half of your
budget, halfway through the project.

102
00:05:37,590 --> 00:05:42,910
So your budget at completion will
be at 100% of your expenses but

103
00:05:42,910 --> 00:05:45,540
your planned work at that stage,

104
00:05:45,540 --> 00:05:50,510
at the end of year one,
it should be half of your expenses.

105
00:05:50,510 --> 00:05:56,200
So, you multiply your final
budget times what your budget

106
00:05:56,200 --> 00:06:00,800
is that you've spent already, and that
results in what's called planned value,

107
00:06:00,800 --> 00:06:05,090
the amount of work that you've expected
to have achieved by a certain point.

108
00:06:05,090 --> 00:06:09,190
Where this gets tricky is that we're
not just worried about budget,

109
00:06:09,190 --> 00:06:12,590
we're also worried about our schedule and

110
00:06:12,590 --> 00:06:16,320
earned value management is all
about mixing those two together.

111
00:06:16,320 --> 00:06:20,370
Mixing schedule or
time information with budget or money,

112
00:06:20,370 --> 00:06:25,690
monetary information, and when you combine
the two you get these numbers that

113
00:06:25,690 --> 00:06:29,860
don't make a lot of sense but
they help to balance out the information.

114
00:06:29,860 --> 00:06:33,710
Now we've got a ton of formulas
that we can run through but

115
00:06:33,710 --> 00:06:37,080
if I just start describing them here and
rattling them off, I find that that's

116
00:06:37,080 --> 00:06:41,960
really not a great way to learn and
you guys don't really get much from it.

117
00:06:41,960 --> 00:06:45,050
You end up watching the episode
ten times just to be able to grasp

118
00:06:45,050 --> 00:06:46,400
some of the formulas.

119
00:06:46,400 --> 00:06:50,210
So what I like to do instead
is kind of do like the exam.

120
00:06:50,210 --> 00:06:53,670
Take a project where they're
giving me some information and

121
00:06:53,670 --> 00:06:57,280
then we start to calculate
some things out of it.

122
00:06:57,280 --> 00:07:00,260
I'll show the approach that I've used
to be successful on these problems and

123
00:07:00,260 --> 00:07:03,670
we'll work through some examples and
we'll get a chance to see it.

124
00:07:03,670 --> 00:07:07,950
Now we are gonna go through a lot
of formulas in this show and

125
00:07:07,950 --> 00:07:15,140
when I studied for the PMP, now I've been
PMP Certified for seven or eight years.

126
00:07:15,140 --> 00:07:18,910
When I got PMP Certified originally,
I had to study these too, and

127
00:07:18,910 --> 00:07:22,490
a lot of these were formulas I wasn't used
to using because I used Microsoft Project,

128
00:07:22,490 --> 00:07:24,900
which can actually do all of these for us.

129
00:07:24,900 --> 00:07:29,630
So what I did is I created a cheat sheet,
a little study guide,

130
00:07:29,630 --> 00:07:34,550
a list of all the formulas I knew would be
on the exam, and that I needed to know for

131
00:07:34,550 --> 00:07:36,010
the exam, and I studied those.

132
00:07:37,160 --> 00:07:41,960
That was back under PMBOK third edition,
and then the PMBOK fourth edition came

133
00:07:41,960 --> 00:07:44,195
out I was already certified,
so I didn't have to take it.

134
00:07:44,195 --> 00:07:46,665
I was doing my continuing education but

135
00:07:46,665 --> 00:07:49,415
I continued to update that
spreadsheet because I found, for

136
00:07:49,415 --> 00:07:52,325
a lot of the people that I taught,
they really benefited from that.

137
00:07:52,325 --> 00:07:54,303
>> Right.
>> Now that the fifth edition is out,

138
00:07:54,303 --> 00:07:57,616
I've continued to update that, and
so I have my little cheat sheet and

139
00:07:57,616 --> 00:08:00,672
I'm gonna post that on the ITProTV
website, so you can have it.

140
00:08:00,672 --> 00:08:01,833
Let me just show it to you real quick.

141
00:08:01,833 --> 00:08:06,151
It's just a Word document but it could
open up an Open Office or Google Docs,

142
00:08:06,151 --> 00:08:10,080
any of the different applications
out there it can open it.

143
00:08:10,080 --> 00:08:13,730
And what I did was I just
laid out all of the formulas

144
00:08:13,730 --> 00:08:16,510
that are really called out in the PMBOK.

145
00:08:16,510 --> 00:08:19,810
Now just because it's in the PMBOK
doesn't mean you necessarily are going to

146
00:08:19,810 --> 00:08:20,460
see it in the exam.

147
00:08:20,460 --> 00:08:23,060
So you'll see where I put
little stars on some.

148
00:08:23,060 --> 00:08:26,130
The ones with the star, it's not
a guarantee they'll be on the exam, right,

149
00:08:26,130 --> 00:08:29,990

382
00:19:55,710 --> 00:20:00,700
They're all useful to a project manager,
but some of them are presented in a way

383
00:20:00,700 --> 00:20:03,300
that doesn't make a lot of
sense to non-project managers.

384
00:20:03,300 --> 00:20:04,220
So we'll have to take them and

385
00:20:04,220 --> 00:20:07,709
manipulate them a little more to turn them
into values that people will recognize.

386
00:20:09,360 --> 00:20:10,900
CPI, Cost Performance Index
is a great one.

387
00:20:10,900 --> 00:20:14,080
And if you give someone the CPI a lot of
times they have no idea what it means.

388
00:20:14,080 --> 00:20:16,790
But you convert that into a simple
percentage or something and

389
00:20:16,790 --> 00:20:18,070
they really know.

390
00:20:18,070 --> 00:20:20,500
Your CPI is 0.75.

391
00:20:20,500 --> 00:20:21,400
All right.

392
00:20:21,400 --> 00:20:22,710
Well, what does that mean?

393
00:20:22,710 --> 00:20:26,220
But if you tell them oh,
you know what, we are 25% over budget.

394
00:20:26,220 --> 00:20:27,680
They know what that means.

395
00:20:27,680 --> 00:20:29,180
So those are things that we can quantify,

396
00:20:29,180 --> 00:20:33,500
we can turn into values, we're not
25% over budget, we are 1 million,

397
00:20:33,500 --> 00:20:37,830
or our current budget is 1,250,000,
so we're 250,000 over budget, right?

398
00:20:37,830 --> 00:20:39,560
That's stuff that people understand.

399
00:20:39,560 --> 00:20:40,980
So we may have to manipulate a little bit

400
00:20:40,980 --> 00:20:44,010
further before we turn
it over to the others.

401
00:20:44,010 --> 00:20:49,360
The others, that's what I'm gonna
call them now is just the other.

402
00:20:49,360 --> 00:20:53,870
So I specifically called out planned
value earlier and earned value.

403
00:20:53,870 --> 00:20:57,760
Planned value is what you should've
achieved by this point and

404
00:20:57,760 --> 00:21:02,840
earned value is what you have achieve,
what you've earned by working the project.

405
00:21:02,840 --> 00:21:05,090
So those are two of the next things
that we want to calculate and

406
00:21:05,090 --> 00:21:07,070
I usually calculate them at the same time.

407
00:21:07,070 --> 00:21:09,940
Plan value versus earned value.

408
00:21:09,940 --> 00:21:15,130
If you are a super energetic project
manger, back when you do the plan

409
00:21:15,130 --> 00:21:19,400
in the planning stage if you say you're
gonna be doing reports every two week so

410
00:21:19,400 --> 00:21:21,320
every two weeks you're gonna do reporting.

411
00:21:21,320 --> 00:21:24,440
What you might do is way back in
the planning phase, you might go ahead and

412
00:21:24,440 --> 00:21:28,650
calculate your plan values for every two
weeks throughout the life of that project.

413
00:21:28,650 --> 00:21:30,010
Cuz this is what you plan for.

414
00:21:31,050 --> 00:21:33,930
The only negative of doing this
calculation early is that if

415
00:21:33,930 --> 00:21:38,120
change tickets occur, it changes the plan,
you just lost all these numbers.

416
00:21:38,120 --> 00:21:38,890
That you calculated.

417
00:21:38,890 --> 00:21:40,130
They have to be redone.

418
00:21:40,130 --> 00:21:42,740
So a lot of people
calculate them on the fly.

419
00:21:42,740 --> 00:21:44,130
Or we use project software.

420
00:21:44,130 --> 00:21:46,560
Microsoft project will calculate
out your plan value for you.

421
00:21:46,560 --> 00:21:48,370
You don't have to worry about
it when it would get changed,

422
00:21:48,370 --> 00:21:49,940
it just automatically does the recalcs.

423
00:21:49,940 --> 00:21:51,260
That really helps.

424
00:21:51,260 --> 00:21:52,630
On the exam, not so much.

425
00:21:52,630 --> 00:21:54,250
All right, so, Planned Value.

426
00:21:55,330 --> 00:21:58,720
Planned Value's got that simple
formula which is right here.

427
00:21:58,720 --> 00:22:01,760
Our budget at completion
times our planned work.

428
00:22:02,970 --> 00:22:06,060
And if we look at what I've got,

429
00:22:06,060 --> 00:22:10,310
I've got my planned percent complete and
I've got my budget at completion,

430
00:22:10,310 --> 00:22:13,880
you know I've got these values
already right from the word problem.

431
00:22:13,880 --> 00:22:17,420
I just needed to pull them out and
then throw them into the formula so

432
00:22:17,420 --> 00:22:23,250
the planned value in my case,
that's BAC times planned work

433
00:22:25,400 --> 00:22:30,530
and if we write that out
it's going to be $1,000,000.

434
00:22:30,530 --> 00:22:32,840
Right, that's my budget at completion.

435
00:22:32,840 --> 00:22:35,410
And I'm gonna multiply
that by my planned work.

436
00:22:35,410 --> 00:22:39,210
Now my planned work is this guy
right here, Planned Complete.

437
00:22:39,210 --> 00:22:42,140
The amount of work that I had
planned to get done by this point.

438
00:22:42,140 --> 00:22:47,802
And it's 25%, so
I'm gonna be multiplying this by .25.

439
00:22:47,802 --> 00:22:48,458
Okay.

440
00:22:48,458 --> 00:22:55,836
So $1,000,000 times .25 gives us 250,000.

441
00:22:55,836 --> 00:22:56,492
Okay.

442
00:22:56,492 --> 00:23:00,070
Now, again, I did that in my head at
the beginning of the segment, but

443
00:23:00,070 --> 00:23:02,650
you can see where I did it in my
head because it was easy math.

444
00:23:02,650 --> 00:23:05,430
If it was hard math,
I might not have been able to do that.

445
00:23:05,430 --> 00:23:07,350
This is the formula we
used to create that.

446
00:23:07,350 --> 00:23:12,650
So, my planned value, three months in,
is 250,000, but what's my earned value?

447
00:23:12,650 --> 00:23:15,210
And here's where things
are going to start to get weird.

448
00:23:15,210 --> 00:23:17,490
You might look at it and say,
well my earned value is $380,000,

449
00:23:17,490 --> 00:23:21,610
but that's not really true
because this planned value,

450
00:23:21,610 --> 00:23:25,530
notice how it's not really taking into
account how much money we've spent.

451
00:23:25,530 --> 00:23:28,330
It's taking in the full
cost of the project.

452
00:23:28,330 --> 00:23:30,260
What it really cares about
is this guy right here,

453
00:23:30,260 --> 00:23:32,280
the percentage of the work complete.

454
00:23:32,280 --> 00:23:36,400
So earned value is actually
calculated off of this,

455
00:23:36,400 --> 00:23:38,200
the actual work that's been completed.

456
00:23:38,200 --> 00:23:42,180
And if we take a look at my earned
value slide, we'll see that.

457
00:23:42,180 --> 00:23:46,120
Earned value equals my planned
value times my percent complete,

458
00:23:46,120 --> 00:23:49,630
the actual percent complete, right.

459
00:23:49,630 --> 00:23:53,040
Now let me point out something
over here on the left side.

460
00:23:53,040 --> 00:23:56,067
On the slide and
I did this on my formula cheat sheet too.

461
00:23:56,067 --> 00:23:58,994
I put what the components
are of the formula.

462
00:23:58,994 --> 00:24:00,640
So this formula's made up of three pieces.

463
00:24:00,640 --> 00:24:01,522
Earned Value.

464
00:24:01,522 --> 00:24:02,242
Planned Value.

465
00:24:02,242 --> 00:24:03,311
Percent complete.

466
00:24:03,311 --> 00:24:06,144
So that's what I've got over here, earned
value, planned value, percent complete.

467
00:24:06,144 --> 00:24:08,480
I just wrote up full names so
you'd know what they were.

468
00:24:08,480 --> 00:24:09,970
But notice on earned value and

469
00:24:09,970 --> 00:24:13,070
planned value I have two other
things underneath it, right?

470
00:24:13,070 --> 00:24:16,548
Earned value or
budgeted cost of work performed.

471
00:24:16,548 --> 00:24:17,198
Okay?

472
00:24:17,198 --> 00:24:23,370
In PMBOK versions one through three,
that's what it was called.

473
00:24:23,370 --> 00:24:27,160
In PMBOK version four,
they had both names and

474
00:24:27,160 --> 00:24:30,480
now in PMBOK version five,
you just have the new name, all right?

475
00:24:30,480 --> 00:24:32,840
On the exam,
you will only see the new name.

476
00:24:32,840 --> 00:24:35,140
You'll just see earned value, all right?

477
00:24:35,140 --> 00:24:38,680
But if you go out on the Internet or if
you've used project managing software like

478
00:24:38,680 --> 00:24:41,510
Microsoft Project or
other things like that.

479
00:24:41,510 --> 00:24:45,860
A lot of them, I mean a huge portion
of them still use the old terms.

480
00:24:45,860 --> 00:24:47,747
So I went ahead and
included the old names so

481
00:24:47,747 --> 00:24:49,644
you could recognize them if you spot that.

482
00:24:49,644 --> 00:24:51,833
If you're out there on the Internet and
you find some kind of study source.

483
00:24:51,833 --> 00:24:54,437
And it's got these weird values
that you don't recognize,

484
00:24:54,437 --> 00:24:58,610
well they're probably the old names for
the same values we're talking about today.

485
00:24:58,610 --> 00:25:02,320
So earned value used to be called
budgeted cost of work performed.

486
00:25:03,490 --> 00:25:05,410
Notice that's work performed,

487
00:25:05,410 --> 00:25:09,780
stuff we've already done,
versus budgeted cost of work scheduled.

488
00:25:09,780 --> 00:25:13,180
What's been scheduled out all the way
to the end of the project, right?

489
00:25:13,180 --> 00:25:15,420
That's planned value and earned value.

490
00:25:15,420 --> 00:25:18,920
The old names are a little more
descriptive but they were long and

491
00:25:18,920 --> 00:25:20,490
they used that word budget.

492
00:25:20,490 --> 00:25:23,992
And with budget, people think money,
and they don't think time.

493
00:25:23,992 --> 00:25:28,010
Earned value's a combination of the two,
and so, several years ago,

494
00:25:28,010 --> 00:25:29,830
they opted to change it.

495
00:25:29,830 --> 00:25:31,736
That's why we have two names for
these things and

496
00:25:31,736 --> 00:25:35,004
fortunately on the exam we just have the
new name, earned value and planned value.

497
00:25:35,004 --> 00:25:38,529
So, as we go through these
formulas you'll notice that

498
00:25:38,529 --> 00:25:42,436
I've done that on most of these
where I'll have BCWP, BCWS.

499
00:25:42,436 --> 00:25:44,689
You'll see a few other ones
that are spread around there.

500
00:25:44,689 --> 00:25:46,865
ACWP, right there, let's see,

501
00:25:46,865 --> 00:25:50,780
it seems like there was one other
one that had some crazy ones.

502
00:25:52,740 --> 00:25:53,379
Maybe that's it.

503
00:25:53,379 --> 00:25:55,308
All right.
Well you'll see that as we go though so

504
00:25:55,308 --> 00:25:58,714
just be aware that you may see a second
name out there on the internet or

505
00:25:58,714 --> 00:25:59,320
whatever.

506
00:25:59,320 --> 00:26:02,600
But over here on the right side I just
use the new values cuz that's really

507
00:26:02,600 --> 00:26:03,990
all we care about now.

508
00:26:03,990 --> 00:26:04,690
All right.

509
00:26:04,690 --> 00:26:09,190
So on the earned value side, we're saying
take our plan of value, what we should

510
00:26:09,190 --> 00:26:13,630
have achieved, And we're gonna multiply
that by what we actually did achieve.

511
00:26:14,650 --> 00:26:19,393
So if I go back to my
example here my earned

512
00:26:19,393 --> 00:26:23,858
value that PV * % Complete, right,

513
00:26:23,858 --> 00:26:30,138
that is going to be $1,000,000 * .28,

514
00:26:30,138 --> 00:26:35,820
which is gonna result in $280,000.

515
00:26:35,820 --> 00:26:40,680
So my earned value, what I've actually
earned at this point, is $280,000.00.

516
00:26:40,680 --> 00:26:45,230
I should've only earned $250,000 but
I've earned $280,000.

517
00:26:45,230 --> 00:26:50,610
So I've actually earned more than
I expected to at this point right?

518
00:26:50,610 --> 00:26:53,680
And so the reason is I got more work done.

519
00:26:53,680 --> 00:26:56,640
Now I'm over budget but
this doesn't reflect that.

520
00:26:56,640 --> 00:26:58,980
This is reflecting the schedule
side of things, right?

521
00:26:58,980 --> 00:27:01,470
We'll see formulas in a minute
that will show the budget side.

522
00:27:01,470 --> 00:27:05,460
It all gets tangled together so that's why
we're kind of combining scheduling and

523
00:27:05,460 --> 00:27:06,630
cost together.

524
00:27:06,630 --> 00:27:07,690
But these are the two values.

525
00:27:07,690 --> 00:27:08,855
Plan value and earned value.

526
00:27:08,855 --> 00:27:12,390
Planned value, that's your plan,
right on the money.

527
00:27:12,390 --> 00:27:16,150
Earned value, that's where we're
saying what we've actually done.

528
00:27:16,150 --> 00:27:18,250
We've done $280,000 worth of work.

529
00:27:18,250 --> 00:27:21,690
We may have spent more,
which is a problem.

530
00:27:21,690 --> 00:27:23,710
But that's what we've
achieved of our project, so

531
00:27:23,710 --> 00:27:25,840
we're actually ahead of schedule.

532
00:27:25,840 --> 00:27:26,560
Which makes sense,

533
00:27:26,560 --> 00:27:29,400
I mean we kind of knew that just looking
at the status report right here.

534
00:27:29,400 --> 00:27:32,800
You might be screaming at your computer
right now going Don, this is stupid.

535
00:27:32,800 --> 00:27:33,760
Why would I do that?

536
00:27:33,760 --> 00:27:34,920
It was right there in the status report.

537
00:27:34,920 --> 00:27:36,900
Why do I need a formula
to show me this garbage?

538
00:27:36,900 --> 00:27:38,280
>> Because you need to know this.

539
00:27:38,280 --> 00:27:39,640
>> You need to know it for the exam.

540
00:27:39,640 --> 00:27:40,600
That's one reason.

541
00:27:40,600 --> 00:27:43,920
But the other reason is these numbers
are gonna be building blocks for

542
00:27:43,920 --> 00:27:45,130
other formulas.

543
00:27:45,130 --> 00:27:48,800
And the other formulas are gonna
give us data that's not right here,

544
00:27:48,800 --> 00:27:52,730
that isn't reflected in the data
that we just see right off hand.

545
00:27:52,730 --> 00:27:53,840
So bear with me.

546
00:27:53,840 --> 00:27:55,790
We're setting up the foundation.

547
00:27:55,790 --> 00:27:56,667
But you need that foundation.

548
00:27:56,667 --> 00:28:00,387
If you can't calculate these numbers,
if you can't calculate PV and EV,

549
00:28:00,387 --> 00:28:03,885
then you might as well not even
bother memorizing the other formulas.

550
00:28:03,885 --> 00:28:08,980
Because PV and EV are inputs to
almost every other formula we use.

551
00:28:08,980 --> 00:28:09,837
You've got to know them.

552
00:28:09,837 --> 00:28:10,395
Right?

553
00:28:10,395 --> 00:28:11,048
It's really important.

554
00:28:11,048 --> 00:28:14,386
All right, well,
that's kind of heavy, so far, so

555
00:28:14,386 --> 00:28:17,817
why don't we stop right here and
take a break, right?

556
00:28:17,817 --> 00:28:20,661
It's kind of heavy and we really
just did the foundational values.

557
00:28:20,661 --> 00:28:24,059
So we got a lot more to go through as
we start to calculate this stuff but

558
00:28:24,059 --> 00:28:25,730
let's take a break here.

559
00:28:25,730 --> 00:28:27,651
When we get back, we'll continue
on with that, so stay tuned.

560
00:28:27,651 --> 00:28:28,940
We'll be back in a minute.

561
00:28:28,940 --> 00:28:33,700
[SOUND] All right,

562
00:28:33,700 --> 00:28:37,829
welcome back.

563
00:28:37,829 --> 00:28:40,900
So, before the break, we did some math.

564
00:28:40,900 --> 00:28:41,615
I know it's exciting.

565
00:28:41,615 --> 00:28:44,000
[LAUGH] That's why we have these breaks.

566
00:28:44,000 --> 00:28:45,480
We can take a breather.

567
00:28:45,480 --> 00:28:46,250
>> That's right.

568
00:28:46,250 --> 00:28:49,990
>> So, we created some numbers
that were fairly common sense.

569
00:28:51,410 --> 00:28:54,730
What we need to figure
out next is our variance.

570
00:28:54,730 --> 00:28:56,360
Remember in the last episode.

571
00:28:56,360 --> 00:28:57,500
Actually do I still have that chart?

572
00:28:57,500 --> 00:28:59,890
I probably still have that chart
pulled up around here somewhere.

573
00:28:59,890 --> 00:29:00,510
Here we go.

574
00:29:00,510 --> 00:29:04,900
I showed this chart right here,
how variance is the difference between

575
00:29:04,900 --> 00:29:07,900
what you've planned and
what's actually happening.

576
00:29:08,910 --> 00:29:12,750
Well, we need to be able to
calculate what that variance is.

577
00:29:12,750 --> 00:29:14,540
You've got two different variances.

578
00:29:14,540 --> 00:29:19,300
You've got a cost variance for your budget
and you've got a schedule variance for

579
00:29:19,300 --> 00:29:21,515
your, well, schedule, calendar, whatever.

580
00:29:21,515 --> 00:29:24,260
[LAUGH] So
we need to calculate those two variances,

581
00:29:24,260 --> 00:29:26,160
figure out what our differences are.

582
00:29:26,160 --> 00:29:30,350
Well fortunately when we do EVM everything
is being represented as numbers.

583
00:29:30,350 --> 00:29:32,680
Really being represented as money, right?

584
00:29:32,680 --> 00:29:35,800
Cost is being measured in terms of
the money we've actually spent, and

585
00:29:35,800 --> 00:29:43,390
then the schedule is being represented as
the dollar value of the work we've put in.

586
00:29:43,390 --> 00:29:45,530
So everything's really
being turned into dollars.

587
00:29:45,530 --> 00:29:48,860
We can represent our variance
in terms of dollars.

588
00:29:48,860 --> 00:29:51,870
So we have two very,
very similar formulas for this.

589
00:29:51,870 --> 00:29:55,795
Now having similar formulas is
a blessing and a curse, all right?

590
00:29:55,795 --> 00:29:57,910
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's a blessing because it comes super

591
00:29:57,910 --> 00:29:59,700
easy to remember them.

592
00:29:59,700 --> 00:30:02,306
It's a curse in that it become
super easy to mix them up so

593
00:30:02,306 --> 00:30:03,809
we have to be careful with that.

594
00:30:03,809 --> 00:30:06,176
But when we calculate variance,

595
00:30:06,176 --> 00:30:11,256
what we need is we've got our cost
variance and our schedule variance.

596
00:30:11,256 --> 00:30:15,627
And the cost variance,
if we look at, where is it here,

597
00:30:15,627 --> 00:30:19,900
cost variance,
it's a really simple formula.

598
00:30:19,900 --> 00:30:25,510
We take our earned value,
what we've actually earned as far as work,

599
00:30:25,510 --> 00:30:30,680
and then we subtract our actual cost,
what we've actually spent dollar wise.

600
00:30:30,680 --> 00:30:35,130
Earned value is being calculated off
of that 28% of our project is done.

601
00:30:35,130 --> 00:30:36,980
That's what its being calculated off of.

602
00:30:36,980 --> 00:30:40,300
But actual cost is just raw dollars,
what we've done, what we've spent.

603
00:30:40,300 --> 00:30:45,220
And so this is gonna put our costs
in the perspective of time also and

604
00:30:45,220 --> 00:30:48,600
give us a representation of whether
we're over or under budget, all right.

605
00:30:48,600 --> 00:30:50,320
It works out really well.

606
00:30:50,320 --> 00:30:52,630
Schedule variance is
basically the same thing.

607
00:30:52,630 --> 00:30:57,810
If we look at schedule variance,
it's earned value minus planned value.

608
00:30:57,810 --> 00:31:00,970
So instead of subtracting the actual cost,
we subtract the planned value,

609
00:31:00,970 --> 00:31:03,360
the amount of work that
we should've gotten done.

610
00:31:03,360 --> 00:31:07,760
The result is gonna be a dollar amount,
a dollar amount that represents time.

611
00:31:07,760 --> 00:31:09,190
So it's kind of bizarre.

612
00:31:09,190 --> 00:31:11,440
Let's start with cost though cuz
that's the easier one to understand.

613
00:31:11,440 --> 00:31:14,710
So I'm gonna go back to
my little note screen and

614
00:31:14,710 --> 00:31:17,538
if I want to calculate out my cost
variance, I need to remember my formula.

615
00:31:17,538 --> 00:31:19,418
EV-AC.

616
00:31:19,418 --> 00:31:23,830
And just so you guys know, my technique,

617
00:31:23,830 --> 00:31:28,350
my approach to being successful in an exam
with this is to memorize these formulas.

618
00:31:28,350 --> 00:31:31,245
And when you go in and
sit down in that testing booth,

619
00:31:31,245 --> 00:31:33,075
you're not allowed to take
in any papers in with you.

620
00:31:33,075 --> 00:31:35,925
They give you blank sheets of paper and
a pencil.

621
00:31:35,925 --> 00:31:38,110
And when you sit down and start that exam,

622
00:31:38,110 --> 00:31:41,265
the first thing that I do
is write my formulas down.

623
00:31:41,265 --> 00:31:42,425
I do it for two reasons.

624
00:31:42,425 --> 00:31:43,635
One, I don't want to forget them.

625
00:31:43,635 --> 00:31:46,220
I've got them fresh in my mind and
I don't want to forget.

626
00:31:46,220 --> 00:31:49,050
But the other reason is when I come
to a question that's asking me

627
00:31:49,050 --> 00:31:51,110
about the formulas,
I don't want to have to sit there and

628
00:31:51,110 --> 00:31:52,280
dredge through my mind to find it.

629
00:31:52,280 --> 00:31:54,530
I want to just look through my papers and
have it.

630
00:31:54,530 --> 00:31:57,557
So if you jot those formulas down,
the more you write them down,

631
00:31:57,557 --> 00:32:00,773
the more they get committed to memory,
the more you remember them.

632
00:32:00,773 --> 00:32:02,759
So I try and
write them out whenever I can, so

633
00:32:02,759 --> 00:32:06,593
that's why I'm kind of starting each one
of these by writing out the formula first.

634
00:32:06,593 --> 00:32:10,581
So my CV is earned value minus AC and
so now I just need to go up here and

635
00:32:10,581 --> 00:32:12,640
find those building blocks.

636
00:32:12,640 --> 00:32:15,970
We calculated earned value,
it was $280,000 so

637
00:32:15,970 --> 00:32:20,540
it's going to be $280,000
minus my actual cost.

638
00:32:20,540 --> 00:32:25,500
Actual cost we didn't have to calculate,
that came from our status report.

639
00:32:25,500 --> 00:32:27,736
Our status report say we spent $380,000.

640
00:32:27,736 --> 00:32:29,530
So I'll subtract $380,000.

641
00:32:29,530 --> 00:32:32,030
And here you can kind of already
see what's gonna happen.

642
00:32:32,030 --> 00:32:34,380
We're going to end up with
a negative number, right?

643
00:32:34,380 --> 00:32:35,698
For our cost variance,

644
00:32:35,698 --> 00:32:40,330
280,000 minus 380,000 is going
to be a negative $100,000.

645
00:32:40,330 --> 00:32:44,060
Now be careful with this too.

646
00:32:44,060 --> 00:32:47,250
Sometimes on the exam, they can
use a negative notation like that.

647
00:32:47,250 --> 00:32:50,620
Other times they use the accounting method
of writing it which is to put it in

648
00:32:50,620 --> 00:32:51,930
parenthesis.

649
00:32:51,930 --> 00:32:56,620
So a number written in parentheses
is considered to be negative

650
00:32:56,620 --> 00:32:58,240
in the accounting circles.

651
00:32:58,240 --> 00:33:01,040
They do that cuz when you see a dash,
you know the negative symbol.

652
00:33:01,040 --> 00:33:04,450
Does that mean we're doing a dash or
are we subtracting, which one is it?

653
00:33:04,450 --> 00:33:05,340
We don't necessarily know.

654
00:33:05,340 --> 00:33:07,150
So, you might see either way.

655
00:33:07,150 --> 00:33:08,990
I'll go ahead and use the negative sign.

656
00:33:08,990 --> 00:33:12,978
So my cost variance is a -100,000.

657
00:33:12,978 --> 00:33:14,732
That's a pretty big variance, right.

658
00:33:14,732 --> 00:33:16,200
That's a pretty big deal.

659
00:33:16,200 --> 00:33:18,960
So I know on my costs I'm in trouble.

660
00:33:18,960 --> 00:33:21,090
When I was looking up here
things were looking good, right.

661
00:33:21,090 --> 00:33:22,670
When we did our plan value and our EV,

662
00:33:22,670 --> 00:33:27,530
our earned value was a nice positive
$280,000, things were looking good, Right?

663
00:33:27,530 --> 00:33:29,190
But now I'm starting
to see some negatives.

664
00:33:29,190 --> 00:33:32,110
So these are where we really
start to see that difference.

665
00:33:32,110 --> 00:33:36,060
And if we were charting this
out in a very precise chart,

666
00:33:36,060 --> 00:33:39,900
there would be a difference here,
of basically a hundred thousand dollars.

667
00:33:41,380 --> 00:33:43,950
All right, so now that we've got that.

668
00:33:43,950 --> 00:33:46,060
We can take a look at
our schedule variance.

669
00:33:46,060 --> 00:33:48,680
Same thing, but with time.

670
00:33:48,680 --> 00:33:51,680
So we come in and
we say earned value just like before.

671
00:33:51,680 --> 00:33:56,730
Except instead of subtracting our actual
cost, we subtract our plan value right?

672
00:33:56,730 --> 00:33:58,200
What we should have had at this point.

673
00:33:58,200 --> 00:34:01,020
So EV minus PV.

674
00:34:01,020 --> 00:34:05,168
So my earned value is still the same,
its $280,000.

675
00:34:05,168 --> 00:34:09,730
And I subtract out my plan value
which we also calculated right here,

676
00:34:09,730 --> 00:34:13,296
at 250,000 okay?

677
00:34:13,296 --> 00:34:20,112
Now when we work that out, we gonna put
the nice positive number which is $30,000.

678
00:34:20,112 --> 00:34:22,669
Right?
$30,000 means we are ahead of schedule,

679
00:34:22,669 --> 00:34:23,802
its positive, right.

680
00:34:23,802 --> 00:34:26,230
Positive numbers are ahead or over.

681
00:34:26,230 --> 00:34:29,980
Now, being over budget is
represented negatively.

682
00:34:29,980 --> 00:34:31,880
As in negative, the bad side of things.

683
00:34:31,880 --> 00:34:34,880
Being under budget would
be a positive number here.

684
00:34:34,880 --> 00:34:36,280
So it's kind of different.

685
00:34:36,280 --> 00:34:38,870
A negative number here is bad.

686
00:34:38,870 --> 00:34:41,460
A negative number here is bad, but

687
00:34:41,460 --> 00:34:45,570
they kind of represent different things,
well, time versus money.

688
00:34:45,570 --> 00:34:49,090
So here I can see that I am
currently $30,000 positive, so

689
00:34:49,090 --> 00:34:51,790
I'm ahead of schedule, all right?

690
00:34:51,790 --> 00:34:53,480
So that's a good thing, right?

691
00:34:53,480 --> 00:34:54,730
I want to be ahead of schedule, don't I?

692
00:34:54,730 --> 00:34:56,370
Not necessarily,

693
00:34:56,370 --> 00:34:59,930
it usually is highlighting some
kind of problem in my project.

694
00:34:59,930 --> 00:35:02,580
In this case,
I've already got a pretty good guess.

695
00:35:02,580 --> 00:35:06,790
I'm probably ahead of schedule because
I've spent too much money, right?

696
00:35:06,790 --> 00:35:08,490
Maybe I've got people doing overtime,

697
00:35:08,490 --> 00:35:11,280
maybe I've got more employees
on the clock than I had planned.

698
00:35:11,280 --> 00:35:15,260
Maybe people are just trying to get work
done early, so this might work itself out,

699
00:35:15,260 --> 00:35:15,810
if that's it.

700
00:35:15,810 --> 00:35:18,610
If people are trying to get work done
early it'll just work itself out, but

701
00:35:18,610 --> 00:35:21,120
if people are doing unauthorized overtime.

702
00:35:21,120 --> 00:35:23,570
I might have a bigger problem,
I might go over budget.

703
00:35:23,570 --> 00:35:27,200
I've gotta be careful, so
these are numbers we need to know, right.

704
00:35:27,200 --> 00:35:30,160
Now, these numbers though
are a little bit strange.

705
00:35:30,160 --> 00:35:33,420
If somebody say's how's
your schedule doing?

706
00:35:33,420 --> 00:35:36,320
You go, we're $30,000 ahead of schedule.

707
00:35:36,320 --> 00:35:39,010
They're gonna say $30,000
ahead of schedule?

708
00:35:39,010 --> 00:35:40,070
Well what does that even mean?

709
00:35:40,070 --> 00:35:44,005
Because we don't think of time in terms
of money although the saying is time is

710
00:35:44,005 --> 00:35:45,020
money right?

711
00:35:45,020 --> 00:35:47,490
But we don't think of it that way.

712
00:35:47,490 --> 00:35:50,620
So these numbers as
they're presented even for

713
00:35:50,620 --> 00:35:53,740
us as project managers
aren't terribly useful.

714
00:35:53,740 --> 00:35:57,410
What we need to do is we need to
look at them in the terms of our

715
00:35:57,410 --> 00:36:00,380
entire project from that perspective.

716
00:36:00,380 --> 00:36:04,450
So we actually have two other things
that we'll normally calculate out

717
00:36:04,450 --> 00:36:07,390
right after doing the CV and the SV.

718
00:36:07,390 --> 00:36:09,590
All right.
And we'll see those in just a second.

719
00:36:09,590 --> 00:36:12,960
But, just based on these values,
just based on what we've got here,

720
00:36:12,960 --> 00:36:15,780
what can we determine about our project?

721
00:36:15,780 --> 00:36:23,170
Well, our project is over budget,
but ahead of schedule.

722
00:36:23,170 --> 00:36:23,840
All right?

723
00:36:23,840 --> 00:36:27,320
I know I'm over budget because I
got a negative $100,000 here for

724
00:36:27,320 --> 00:36:28,820
my cost variance.

725
00:36:28,820 --> 00:36:31,760
I've deviated from my
planned cost quite a bit.

726
00:36:31,760 --> 00:36:36,880
But I know I'm ahead of schedule because
I've got a positive $30,000 here for

727
00:36:36,880 --> 00:36:38,200
my schedule variance.

728
00:36:39,400 --> 00:36:41,460
All right, so I could stop right there.

729
00:36:41,460 --> 00:36:41,960
I could stop.

730
00:36:41,960 --> 00:36:44,830
I just got a good status
report of my project.

731
00:36:44,830 --> 00:36:47,150
So, there we go, done, that' s it.

732
00:36:47,150 --> 00:36:48,730
But, there's a lot more formulas.

733
00:36:49,800 --> 00:36:53,620
One thing that we use very typically
in project management software,

734
00:36:53,620 --> 00:36:55,020
is what's called a performance index.

735
00:36:55,020 --> 00:36:59,640
A performance index is a number that
reflects the overall performance of

736
00:36:59,640 --> 00:37:00,660
your project.

737
00:37:00,660 --> 00:37:04,080
And you can do it in terms of your
schedule, and in terms of your cost.

738
00:37:04,080 --> 00:37:07,110
And so you have a schedule
performance index or SPI,

739
00:37:07,110 --> 00:37:10,292
and a cost performance index or CPI.

740
00:37:10,292 --> 00:37:12,010
All right?

741
00:37:12,010 --> 00:37:16,090
You'll see these used very commonly in
a lot of project management software.

742
00:37:16,090 --> 00:37:18,530
The formulas for
them are pretty straightforward.

743
00:37:18,530 --> 00:37:20,890
We just calculated our variances, right?

744
00:37:20,890 --> 00:37:22,820
So earned value minus AC or

745
00:37:22,820 --> 00:37:27,850
earned value minus PV, planned value
in the case of schedule variance.

746
00:37:27,850 --> 00:37:31,972
But with schedule performance index and
cost performance index,

747
00:37:31,972 --> 00:37:35,073
notice instead of subtracting
we just do divide.

748
00:37:35,073 --> 00:37:35,910
Right?

749
00:37:35,910 --> 00:37:39,560
When you division,
what you result in is not a,

750
00:37:39,560 --> 00:37:44,210
like a dollar value, but
a percentage, and the percentages,

751
00:37:44,210 --> 00:37:47,550
those are a lot more useful for
relaying information to people.

752
00:37:47,550 --> 00:37:49,670
If you say,
hey we're 15% ahead of schedule,

753
00:37:49,670 --> 00:37:52,560
that's something that's
a lot more meaningful.

754
00:37:52,560 --> 00:37:53,800
So, SPI and

755
00:37:53,800 --> 00:37:57,880
CPI are just a manipulation of those
same formulas that we saw a moment ago.

756
00:37:57,880 --> 00:37:59,660
In fact, if we write them side by side.

757
00:37:59,660 --> 00:38:01,700
Let me jump to my notes here.

758
00:38:01,700 --> 00:38:02,234
All right.

759
00:38:02,234 --> 00:38:04,800
So, let me move that up on the screen.

760
00:38:04,800 --> 00:38:06,360
So if we write these things side by side.

761
00:38:06,360 --> 00:38:10,550
So, up here was my cost variance and
my schedule variance, and

762
00:38:10,550 --> 00:38:14,880
if I do like CPI and SPI.

763
00:38:14,880 --> 00:38:17,650
My performance indexes.

764
00:38:17,650 --> 00:38:22,784
The CPI is Earn value,
divided by actual cost.

765
00:38:22,784 --> 00:38:24,280
All right.

766
00:38:24,280 --> 00:38:28,207
And SPI is earn value
divided by plan value.

767
00:38:28,207 --> 00:38:29,410
All right.

768
00:38:29,410 --> 00:38:32,200
If we look at our formulas
from the last example,

769
00:38:32,200 --> 00:38:36,450
we just changed the minus sign for
a division sign, and that's it.

770
00:38:36,450 --> 00:38:39,310
So that makes it easy to
remember these formulas.

771
00:38:39,310 --> 00:38:42,620
And it really is just a different way
of representing the same exact data,

772
00:38:42,620 --> 00:38:48,082
in fact I can really kind of copy and
paste some of this stuff and grab it.

773
00:38:48,082 --> 00:38:53,413
I'm trying to remember,
where is my block highlight command?

774
00:38:53,413 --> 00:38:54,186
Whatever.

775
00:38:54,186 --> 00:39:00,140
[LAUGH] So we can go in and we can kind
of take some of this previous math here,

776
00:39:00,140 --> 00:39:05,543
and just swap out that one character
to represent our new formula.

777
00:39:05,543 --> 00:39:07,902
Right.
Now obviously the result of this data is

778
00:39:07,902 --> 00:39:11,200
gonna be a good bit different
when we go to do that division.

779
00:39:11,200 --> 00:39:14,250
So I'm gonna fire up my trusty calculator.

780
00:39:14,250 --> 00:39:17,290
To do that, all right,
which is apparently gigantic.

781
00:39:18,450 --> 00:39:24,590
Lets start here, so we'll start
with 280,000 divided by 380,000.

782
00:39:24,590 --> 00:39:25,442
All right.

783
00:39:25,442 --> 00:39:30,066
Which is going to result in 0.736,

784
00:39:30,066 --> 00:39:35,237
I'll go ahead and round that up to 0.74.

785
00:39:35,237 --> 00:39:38,340
And then I'll take 280,000 and

786
00:39:38,340 --> 00:39:43,520
I'll divide that by 250,000 and
I get 1.12 exactly.

787
00:39:43,520 --> 00:39:46,074
So no rounding needed there.

788
00:39:46,074 --> 00:39:46,794
All right.

789
00:39:46,794 --> 00:39:50,846
So there is my CPI and my SPI,
my cost performance index and

790
00:39:50,846 --> 00:39:54,065
my scheduled performance index.

791
00:39:54,065 --> 00:39:56,873
These numbers are percentages, okay.

792
00:39:56,873 --> 00:40:00,894
So when I look at these,
what I've got here is,

793
00:40:00,894 --> 00:40:05,737
one that is effectively 26%
On the negative, right.

794
00:40:05,737 --> 00:40:10,200
So I'm at 74% of what I'd expect for
my cost.

795
00:40:10,200 --> 00:40:12,030
I'm over budget.

796
00:40:12,030 --> 00:40:16,240
But on my SPI, I'm 12% over, right.

797
00:40:16,240 --> 00:40:17,550
I'm ahead of schedule.

798
00:40:17,550 --> 00:40:20,850
So I can see that right here,
represented pretty easily.

799
00:40:20,850 --> 00:40:22,310
But it gets very confusing.

800
00:40:22,310 --> 00:40:24,440
I know for me, I get confused too.

801
00:40:24,440 --> 00:40:26,880
So what I did is.

802
00:40:26,880 --> 00:40:30,490
Well, on my slides, you'll notice I've got
a little legend down here at the bottom.

803
00:40:30,490 --> 00:40:32,120
And we'll post these
with the episodes too,

804
00:40:32,120 --> 00:40:34,380
although it's a little
easier in the cheat sheet.

805
00:40:34,380 --> 00:40:36,170
But if we look at our CPI,

806
00:40:36,170 --> 00:40:40,805
with CPI anything less than
a one means you're under budget.

807
00:40:41,885 --> 00:40:43,166
But anything, actually, you know what,

808
00:40:43,166 --> 00:40:44,835
I've got that backwards
on my slide don't I?

809
00:40:44,835 --> 00:40:47,295
>> No, I think you're right.

810
00:40:47,295 --> 00:40:48,455
SOM is over budget.

811
00:40:52,145 --> 00:40:52,645
>> You know, I'm.

812
00:40:54,090 --> 00:40:55,390
>> Yeah, lesson one should be.

813
00:40:55,390 --> 00:40:56,834
>> Should be, yeah,
I've got them backwards on a slide,

814
00:40:56,834 --> 00:40:57,838
let me fix that on my slide real quick.

815
00:40:57,838 --> 00:41:02,280
So we are, less than one is over budget,
and greater than one is under budget.

816
00:41:02,280 --> 00:41:04,770
>> And then 1, on budget.

817
00:41:06,440 --> 00:41:06,988
>> There we go.

818
00:41:06,988 --> 00:41:10,970
So if you are dead on,

819
00:41:10,970 --> 00:41:16,640
if your actual cost matches
exactly what you plan for right?

820
00:41:16,640 --> 00:41:18,570
You know in your earned
value what you've achieved.

821
00:41:18,570 --> 00:41:23,330
If those match identically dividing one
number by the same number gets a one.

822
00:41:23,330 --> 00:41:27,195
So hopefully that's what you get for
you CPI is one.

823
00:41:27,195 --> 00:41:29,475
Right, that's perfect,
you're right on track.

824
00:41:29,475 --> 00:41:32,685
But if it is less than one,
you're over budget.

825
00:41:32,685 --> 00:41:33,785
And that's how my project is.

826
00:41:33,785 --> 00:41:36,115
That's how I spotted that
error on my slide there.

827
00:41:36,115 --> 00:41:38,965
Because it's, we're obviously
over budget on our project.

828
00:41:38,965 --> 00:41:39,690
>> Yeah.

829
00:41:39,690 --> 00:41:43,750
If you are under budget the number
will actually be higher than one, so

830
00:41:43,750 --> 00:41:45,130
easy way to tell.

831
00:41:45,130 --> 00:41:48,290
And what I did is on that cheat
sheet which I guess I closed,

832
00:41:48,290 --> 00:41:51,500
I actually put the same little
legend on with the formula there so

833
00:41:51,500 --> 00:41:53,470
you could see it and kind of retain it.

834
00:41:53,470 --> 00:41:59,830
Now on the schedule side, if you are less
than one, you're behind schedule,

835
00:41:59,830 --> 00:42:02,045
but if you're greater than one,
you're ahead of schedule.

836
00:42:02,045 --> 00:42:02,860
Alright.

837
00:42:02,860 --> 00:42:05,730
So, greater than is usually a good thing.

838
00:42:05,730 --> 00:42:06,330
Greater than one on your SPI:
you're ahead of schedule.

839
00:42:06,330 --> 00:42:12,250
Greater than one on your
CPI: you're under budget.

840
00:42:12,250 --> 00:42:14,180
That's what people normally look for.

841
00:42:14,180 --> 00:42:16,090
But that's not really what
you should be looking for.

842
00:42:16,090 --> 00:42:17,790
What you should be looking for
is a dead one.

843
00:42:17,790 --> 00:42:19,740
And the same thing goes for SPI.

844
00:42:19,740 --> 00:42:24,620
If you get a dead one, exactly one,
you are perfect, right on schedule.

845
00:42:24,620 --> 00:42:26,560
OK, that's what we really want.

846
00:42:26,560 --> 00:42:29,710
So, on the exam, don't say you
prefer to have it greater than one.

847
00:42:29,710 --> 00:42:31,190
You prefer to have exactly one.

848
00:42:31,190 --> 00:42:33,590
That's living up to your plan.

849
00:42:33,590 --> 00:42:37,770
So nice that we don't have to deviate
too much from the other formulas, so

850
00:42:37,770 --> 00:42:39,630
instead of subtraction, we do division.

851
00:42:39,630 --> 00:42:43,130
But the number that results is this
performance index that a lot of

852
00:42:43,130 --> 00:42:46,120
companies use,
it's a lot of things that people rely on.

853
