1078
00:54:07,440 --> 00:54:11,810
that's letting us see where
we're at right now but the TCPI,

1079
00:54:11,810 --> 00:54:16,060
the To-Complete Cost Performance Index.

1080
00:54:16,060 --> 00:54:18,737
Let me bring my slide up so
you can see how that's written.

1081
00:54:18,737 --> 00:54:21,477
Here we go, so it's like To-Complete.

1082
00:54:21,477 --> 00:54:22,661
Cost.

1083
00:54:22,661 --> 00:54:25,460
>> [LAUGH]
>> I left out the word cost right there.

1084
00:54:27,040 --> 00:54:28,381
There we go.
So that's it,

1085
00:54:28,381 --> 00:54:31,490
the To-Complete complete
cost performance index,

1086
00:54:31,490 --> 00:54:36,150
is a modification of the CPI to reflect
what things are gonna be like at the end.

1087
00:54:36,150 --> 00:54:36,850
To complete, right?

1088
00:54:36,850 --> 00:54:39,870
So, in order to complete
this particular project,

1089
00:54:39,870 --> 00:54:41,660
what's things gonna be
like way down there.

1090
00:54:41,660 --> 00:54:46,140
Now, this is the hardest of the formulas
that I'm gonna show you guys.

1091
00:54:46,140 --> 00:54:49,880
The reason is,
there's two variations of it.

1092
00:54:49,880 --> 00:54:53,080
If your project is running
along like normal and

1093
00:54:53,080 --> 00:54:58,670
things are still good, then you
have one formula to use, all right?

1094
00:54:58,670 --> 00:55:03,790
But if you're sitting here calculating
TCPI, the odds are things have gone wrong.

1095
00:55:03,790 --> 00:55:06,290
We don't normally calculate
TCPI if things are going well.

1096
00:55:06,290 --> 00:55:09,750
So things are going wrong, we need to see
that vision of how bad things are gonna be

1097
00:55:09,750 --> 00:55:11,690
so we sit down and figure out the TCPI.

1098
00:55:11,690 --> 00:55:13,790
If things are really bad,

1099
00:55:13,790 --> 00:55:19,070
your budget at completion,
your original budget may already be shot.

1100
00:55:19,070 --> 00:55:21,850
You may already be over it,
that's when you normally see this.

1101
00:55:21,850 --> 00:55:25,290
If you're already over
your budget at completion,

1102
00:55:25,290 --> 00:55:27,450
there's no way to unspend money.

1103
00:55:27,450 --> 00:55:30,230
The only solution there is a change
ticket to increase your budget,

1104
00:55:30,230 --> 00:55:32,080
that's really the only solution.

1105
00:55:32,080 --> 00:55:34,980
So if you're at that point in the game,

1106
00:55:34,980 --> 00:55:40,610
where your actual cost have exceed your
budget at completion, the formulas break.

1107
00:55:40,610 --> 00:55:43,240
It actually breaks this formula here and
you end up with these you know,

1108
00:55:43,240 --> 00:55:44,990
divide by negative numbers and
things like that.

1109
00:55:44,990 --> 00:55:45,920
It's a mess, right?

1110
00:55:45,920 --> 00:55:49,280
See how I've got budget at
completion minus actual cost?

1111
00:55:49,280 --> 00:55:51,710
So if our actual cost is higher
than the budget of completion,

1112
00:55:51,710 --> 00:55:53,040
we get a negative number.

1113
00:55:53,040 --> 00:55:57,050
So you're dividing something by a negative
number which doesn't work out so well.

1114
00:55:57,050 --> 00:55:58,240
You end up with what, like i?

1115
00:55:58,240 --> 00:55:59,060
>> Yeah.
>> You know, imaginary

1116
00:55:59,060 --> 00:56:00,260
numbers or something.

1117
00:56:00,260 --> 00:56:03,618
So if that's the case,
you can't use this formula.

1118
00:56:03,618 --> 00:56:07,694
So there's a variation of it right here,
where instead of using the budget

1119
00:56:07,694 --> 00:56:11,070
at completion, we use the estimate
at completion, the EAC.

1120
00:56:11,070 --> 00:56:15,788
The EAC is what we calculated
Just a moment ago right here.

1121
00:56:15,788 --> 00:56:19,179
Now, the EAC is an estimate based
on your current performance, and

1122
00:56:19,179 --> 00:56:21,750
so that will result in
a positive number down here.

1123
00:56:21,750 --> 00:56:24,410
Your EAC will be less
than your actual cost.

1124
00:56:24,410 --> 00:56:25,970
I mean it will be greater
than your actual cost.

1125
00:56:25,970 --> 00:56:28,370
So you'll always get
a positive number on that one.

1126
00:56:28,370 --> 00:56:30,300
It fixes the formula.

1127
00:56:30,300 --> 00:56:33,480
When your on the exam,
here's the really challenging part.

1128
00:56:33,480 --> 00:56:36,420
You have to look and
see if the project is broken.

1129
00:56:36,420 --> 00:56:40,980
The easy way to spot that Is if
the actual cost is bigger than

1130
00:56:40,980 --> 00:56:44,540
the budget at completion, you may not
even worry about that, like identifying.

1131
00:56:44,540 --> 00:56:46,130
You may just go and work the formula.

1132
00:56:46,130 --> 00:56:48,660
And if you get a negative number here,
the division won't work.

1133
00:56:48,660 --> 00:56:51,900
And when that happens that's when you
remember, oh, I need to change that.

1134
00:56:51,900 --> 00:56:54,990
And instead of using BAC,
we use EAC to handle it.

1135
00:56:54,990 --> 00:56:56,750
All right.

1136
00:56:56,750 --> 00:56:58,870
Otherwise we're just plugging
our values in there, and

1137
00:56:58,870 --> 00:57:02,220
we get our performance index that
represents our project status.

1138
00:57:02,220 --> 00:57:03,910
So let's run our project through it.

1139
00:57:03,910 --> 00:57:08,880
Now on ours,
if we look at the data on ours, our budget

1140
00:57:08,880 --> 00:57:13,600
at completion is a million dollars, and
our actual cost so far is $380,000.

1141
00:57:13,600 --> 00:57:16,930
So a million minus $380,00 is
still a positive number, so

1142
00:57:16,930 --> 00:57:18,690
our project is not broken.

1143
00:57:18,690 --> 00:57:21,330
We can use the normal TCPI formula.

1144
00:57:22,670 --> 00:57:25,870
So for my TCPI, I just need to
remember what that formula is, right?

1145
00:57:25,870 --> 00:57:32,724
TCPI = and it's our (BAC-

1146
00:57:32,724 --> 00:57:40,945
EV) / (BAC-AC)
>> What was it?

1147
00:57:40,945 --> 00:57:41,513
>> BAC minus AC.

1148
00:57:41,513 --> 00:57:42,960
>> There.

1149
00:57:42,960 --> 00:57:47,635
All right, so now we can feed in our
values into that and then get it.

1150
00:57:47,635 --> 00:57:51,705
So our BAC is a million dollars, so
we know this is gonna be $1 million.

1151
00:57:52,810 --> 00:57:55,580
Minus our EV and our EV is $280,000.

1152
00:57:55,580 --> 00:58:00,800
And that's all gonna be
divided by our BAC which

1153
00:58:02,840 --> 00:58:07,230
is $1,000,000 minus and
then whatever our actual cost is,

1154
00:58:07,230 --> 00:58:08,290
our actual cost being $380,000.

1155
00:58:08,290 --> 00:58:14,240
Let me move that up on the screen
my head's covering it.

1156
00:58:14,240 --> 00:58:15,848
There we go.

1157
00:58:15,848 --> 00:58:19,450
All right, I'll just feed that into my
trusty calculator to get my actual value.

1158
00:58:19,450 --> 00:58:27,472
So for me, so far I have TCPI equals
100,000 minus 280,000 is 720,000?

1159
00:58:27,472 --> 00:58:32,254
So, we are looking at
720,000 divided by 620,000.

1160
00:58:32,254 --> 00:58:34,976
>> Mm-hm.

1161
00:58:36,754 --> 00:58:40,736
>> This is when it gets dangerous when I
start doing the math in my head instead of

1162
00:58:40,736 --> 00:58:41,990
using the calculator.

1163
00:58:44,030 --> 00:58:47,520
And then we divide those out.

1164
00:58:47,520 --> 00:58:51,180
I'll use the calculator for that.

1165
00:58:51,180 --> 00:58:56,775
If we take 720,000 divided
by 620,000 we get 1.1612 so,

1166
00:58:56,775 --> 00:58:59,200
our TCPI is a positive number.

1167
00:58:59,200 --> 00:59:00,920
It's high.

1168
00:59:00,920 --> 00:59:05,230
And that lets us know that in this case
our two complete performance indexes.

1169
00:59:05,230 --> 00:59:09,820
In order to complete this project, we're
going to end up spending more money and

1170
00:59:09,820 --> 00:59:12,900
we're over 16% higher
than where we should be.

1171
00:59:12,900 --> 00:59:14,150
A one is what we expect to see.

1172
00:59:14,150 --> 00:59:17,550
Where this all breaks even and
we end up with our solid numbers.

1173
00:59:17,550 --> 00:59:18,930
So we know we're in trouble here.

1174
00:59:18,930 --> 00:59:22,500
We need to get that back
closer to our one on this one.

1175
00:59:22,500 --> 00:59:25,970
On this one a value
higher than one is bad.

1176
00:59:25,970 --> 00:59:28,110
Although a value lower than
one isn't good either.

1177
00:59:28,110 --> 00:59:30,780
You really do want to be on that one.

1178
00:59:30,780 --> 00:59:33,930
But a value over is definitely
worse than what we want.

1179
00:59:33,930 --> 00:59:36,120
So our two complete performance
index here is a little bit high.

1180
00:59:36,120 --> 00:59:39,980
So if you notice, it's not all
that different from our SPI and

1181
00:59:39,980 --> 00:59:40,970
CPI that we had before.

1182
00:59:40,970 --> 00:59:44,170
Well, I guess it is pretty different from
CPI but that's because it's factoring

1183
00:59:44,170 --> 00:59:46,630
the two together and
it's creating this new number.

1184
00:59:46,630 --> 00:59:50,270
So that is the two complete
cost performance index.

1185
00:59:50,270 --> 00:59:53,490
Now, you might look at that and go, Don,
you're crazy, I'm never going to use this,

1186
00:59:53,490 --> 00:59:56,580
this is the dumbest thing in the world,
but remember the purpose of it.

1187
00:59:56,580 --> 00:59:59,380
The purpose is,
you might have ten different projects, and

1188
00:59:59,380 --> 01:00:01,340
you wanna compare
the status of all of them.

1189
01:00:01,340 --> 01:00:04,750
Maybe your company is running
out of money, and you say,

1190
01:00:04,750 --> 01:00:07,190
all right,
we've got ten projects going on,

1191
01:00:07,190 --> 01:00:11,220
we've gotta cut two of them where we
gotta cut three or however many projects.

1192
01:00:11,220 --> 01:00:12,570
Which one do we pick?

1193
01:00:12,570 --> 01:00:17,350
Well, let's look at them and let's
pull the TCPI of all ten projects and

1194
01:00:17,350 --> 01:00:18,460
let's compare that.

1195
01:00:18,460 --> 01:00:19,000
Right?

1196
01:00:19,000 --> 01:00:22,870
The projects that are closer to a one,
we know how much they're gonna cost.

1197
01:00:22,870 --> 01:00:23,710
They're doing great.

1198
01:00:23,710 --> 01:00:25,930
They're on their budget,
we can stick with them.

1199
01:00:25,930 --> 01:00:30,130
But ones with a TCPI that's
widely deviated, right?

1200
01:00:30,130 --> 01:00:32,230
Like a 0.16, that's really deviated.

1201
01:00:32,230 --> 01:00:36,550
If it's that far off, well this is one
that's gonna be costing us a lot more than

1202
01:00:36,550 --> 01:00:40,470
we planned and it's all ready out of
control, so it's a dangerous project.

1203
01:00:40,470 --> 01:00:42,400
Maybe we should just shut it down, right?

1204
01:00:42,400 --> 01:00:45,210
Shut it down instead of
continuing on because if we look,

1205
01:00:45,210 --> 01:00:48,190
we already know that we're
over budget on this guy.

1206
01:00:48,190 --> 01:00:48,870
Right?

1207
01:00:48,870 --> 01:00:52,150
And to complete we're gonna
end up way over budget.

1208
01:00:52,150 --> 01:00:56,630
So if we just stop now, we'll save
ourselves not only the $300,000 we'd

1209
01:00:56,630 --> 01:01:00,490
be extra over budget, but we would also
save ourselves the rest of the expenses of

1210
01:01:00,490 --> 01:01:02,200
this project just by stopping it.

1211
01:01:02,200 --> 01:01:06,280
So it's a good measure that companies
can use to evaluate which projects

1212
01:01:06,280 --> 01:01:07,200
are at risk.

1213
01:01:07,200 --> 01:01:08,220
Right?
That's fine.

1214
01:01:08,220 --> 01:01:10,200
But also which projects are prime for

1215
01:01:10,200 --> 01:01:12,670
the chopping block when it
comes time to cancel projects.

1216
01:01:13,850 --> 01:01:17,360
>> A lot of times for us, remember that
the goal is not to wait until you're so

1217
01:01:17,360 --> 01:01:21,020
close to the end of the project that then
you go, hey, we decided this then, but

1218
01:01:21,020 --> 01:01:23,020
is to do this along the way.

1219
01:01:23,020 --> 01:01:25,330
The more often that you're
doing this the easier it is for

1220
01:01:25,330 --> 01:01:28,810
you to actually project that trend out and
for you to know.

1221
01:01:28,810 --> 01:01:32,590
So remember that when this point when
the established port that we're getting is

1222
01:01:32,590 --> 01:01:35,990
that we're about 25% in well we're
now starting to see that and so

1223
01:01:35,990 --> 01:01:40,850
it gives us a great marker at every point
that we do this that we can say all right

1224
01:01:40,850 --> 01:01:45,080
if we continue to go up next month it's
gonna continue to trend this way and

1225
01:01:45,080 --> 01:01:46,520
that's where it's gonna be bad.

1226
01:01:46,520 --> 01:01:48,160
So doing these numbers early is the key.

1227
01:01:48,160 --> 01:01:48,660
>> Yep.

1228
01:01:48,660 --> 01:01:49,400
>> Yeah.

1229
01:01:49,400 --> 01:01:50,240
>> And you're gonna do that.

1230
01:01:50,240 --> 01:01:51,610
You're not gonna use these formulas once.

1231
01:01:51,610 --> 01:01:54,040
>> Yeah.
>> You're gonna use them every week and

1232
01:01:54,040 --> 01:01:55,340
the core or every month
>> Yeah.

1233
01:01:55,340 --> 01:01:56,790
>> However depending on
how long your project is.

1234
01:01:56,790 --> 01:01:58,270
Every week might be too aggressive.

1235
01:01:58,270 --> 01:02:02,240
But if you do it ever week the cool
part is you can have your CPI

1236
01:02:02,240 --> 01:02:03,285
week after week after week.

1237
01:02:03,285 --> 01:02:06,290
>> Mm-hm.
>> And you can compare them one week

1238
01:02:06,290 --> 01:02:06,925
to the next.

1239
01:02:06,925 --> 01:02:07,900
>> Mm-hm.
>> All right

1240
01:02:07,900 --> 01:02:10,050
>> And when you do those measurements,

1241
01:02:10,050 --> 01:02:11,410
there is actually a slight variation here.

1242
01:02:11,410 --> 01:02:13,090
So I'm glad you mentioned it Ronnie.

1243
01:02:13,090 --> 01:02:16,330
Normally when we do this,
we might be doing the reporting just for

1244
01:02:16,330 --> 01:02:17,770
that one period.

1245
01:02:17,770 --> 01:02:22,310
Or we might be doing it for the cumulative
periods throughout the entire project.

1246
01:02:22,310 --> 01:02:23,500
So you may see a variation.

1247
01:02:23,500 --> 01:02:26,420
And I actually did put
this on my cheat sheet.

1248
01:02:26,420 --> 01:02:28,750
Notice how a lot of these values,
like I've got,

1249
01:02:28,750 --> 01:02:33,560
let me find a good one,
well here it is, CPI.

1250
01:02:33,560 --> 01:02:38,660
So here's CPI, cost performance index,
and I've got CPI equals EV divided by AC.

1251
01:02:38,660 --> 01:02:42,720
But then I've got cumulative cost
performance index, all right.

1252
01:02:42,720 --> 01:02:45,970
While CPI, we might be calculating
the cost performance index for

1253
01:02:45,970 --> 01:02:49,610
a particular period of
the project that one time.

1254
01:02:49,610 --> 01:02:53,700
But cumulative means we are looking
at the project as a whole.

1255
01:02:53,700 --> 01:02:56,530
>> Right.
>> And so that will often times be denoted

1256
01:02:56,530 --> 01:03:00,650
with a little, what's that called,
superscript, when it's up like that?

1257
01:03:00,650 --> 01:03:06,180
A little C up above it, so if you
see CPI with a superscript C, or EV,

1258
01:03:06,180 --> 01:03:10,720
or AC, with that superscript, if I zoom
in we can see that a little bit better,

1259
01:03:10,720 --> 01:03:16,170
that little up there C, that's letting
us know that it's a cumulative value.

1260
01:03:16,170 --> 01:03:21,350
And I put those here in my cheat sheet and
I didn't put a star on them, right?

1261
01:03:21,350 --> 01:03:23,000
>> Not because they won't
show up on the exam but

1262
01:03:23,000 --> 01:03:24,660
just because it's not something
we worry about too much.

1263
01:03:24,660 --> 01:03:26,240
It's the same formula.

1264
01:03:26,240 --> 01:03:30,040
CPI and CPIC, it's just the same formula.

1265
01:03:30,040 --> 01:03:32,700
The difference is
the values we feed into it.

1266
01:03:32,700 --> 01:03:35,630
Right?
The earned value for that particular

1267
01:03:35,630 --> 01:03:40,110
period and the actual cost for that
particular period or the earned value for

1268
01:03:40,110 --> 01:03:44,170
our project as a whole and the actual
cost for our project as a whole.

1269
01:03:44,170 --> 01:03:50,200
Most people don't differentiate
those as two separate formulas.

1270
01:03:50,200 --> 01:03:51,380
All right.

1271
01:03:51,380 --> 01:03:54,160
Based on that hopefully I've
given you a good example here,

1272
01:03:54,160 --> 01:03:56,685
showing you the way we
can take a project and

1273
01:03:56,685 --> 01:04:00,095
we can calculate these different
numbers and how we use them.

1274
01:04:00,095 --> 01:04:03,771
If you have the formulas memorized then
it's not such a big deal to do these,

1275
01:04:03,771 --> 01:04:04,754
it's simple Math.

1276
01:04:04,754 --> 01:04:07,802
And you do actually have a little
calculator you can use on the test so

1277
01:04:07,802 --> 01:04:10,120
you don't even have to do
the heavy math yourself.

1278
01:04:10,120 --> 01:04:12,975
But If you don't know these formulas.

1279
01:04:12,975 --> 01:04:14,090
This is not intuitive stuff.

1280
01:04:14,090 --> 01:04:17,546
Some of the earlier parts are, but
the later parts, these later formulas,

1281
01:04:17,546 --> 01:04:19,290
they're not very intuitive.

1282
01:04:19,290 --> 01:04:21,490
But if they ask you to
calculate the TCPI for

1283
01:04:21,490 --> 01:04:23,400
a project, you need to know how to do it.

1284
01:04:23,400 --> 01:04:26,430
And if I had just this
information here at the top,

1285
01:04:26,430 --> 01:04:30,710
could I immediately jump and
calculate my TCPI?

1286
01:04:30,710 --> 01:04:34,420
No, in that formula, budget at completion.

1287
01:04:34,420 --> 01:04:37,790
I got that from the original description,
and actual cost,

1288
01:04:37,790 --> 01:04:41,710
I got those from the original description,
but earned value?

1289
01:04:41,710 --> 01:04:43,430
I didn't get that from
the original description.

1290
01:04:43,430 --> 01:04:49,330
So, you get this data, you'd have to
turn around and calculate earned value.

1291
01:04:49,330 --> 01:04:52,805
And once you add earned value,
then you could go and do TCPI.

1292
01:04:52,805 --> 01:04:57,170
So often times you'll need more than
one formula to solve the problem.

1293
01:04:57,170 --> 01:05:00,230
So understanding how these formulas
tie together is pretty important.

1294
01:05:00,230 --> 01:05:01,490
>> Right.

1295
01:05:01,490 --> 01:05:04,260
>> So those are some examples.

1296
01:05:04,260 --> 01:05:07,418
If you've already registered
with the PMI and joined, and

1297
01:05:07,418 --> 01:05:10,765
you've gotten your copy of the PMBOK,
in the PMBOK is a table,

1298
01:05:10,765 --> 01:05:14,134
I'm not the fondest of it because
it is really, really small.

1299
01:05:14,134 --> 01:05:15,526
>> That's tiny.

1300
01:05:15,526 --> 01:05:18,430
>> But it's table 7.1,
where they go through and

01:05:18,430 --> 01:05:21,020
they lay things out kind
of the same way I did.

1302
01:05:21,020 --> 01:05:24,720
Here's PV, EV, AC, and
they say what they are, right?

1303
01:05:24,720 --> 01:05:28,010
Now the nice part is they do give you a
good description and when to use them, and

1304
01:05:28,010 --> 01:05:29,100
then they show the formula.

1305
01:05:29,100 --> 01:05:31,840
So very similar to the cheat
sheet that I've done.

1306
01:05:31,840 --> 01:05:34,410
If you like this formula better,
by all means, use it.

1307
01:05:34,410 --> 01:05:38,170
They have the how to use it value,
which I don't have in my cheat sheet.

1308
01:05:38,170 --> 01:05:41,960
So if you're just going to straight
up memorize my sheet might be better.

1309
01:05:41,960 --> 01:05:45,590
But if you're learning in the beginning
the sheet in the PMBOK can be a lot

1310
01:05:45,590 --> 01:05:46,668
more helpful.

1311
01:05:46,668 --> 01:05:50,560
And so as you go down the list all
the various ones that you may see.

1312
01:05:50,560 --> 01:05:55,850
So there just kinda laid out there's TCPI,
ETC, EAC, and so on.

1313
01:05:55,850 --> 01:05:59,010
And so these are the ones
that I have starred in mine

1314
01:05:59,010 --> 01:06:01,720
because these are the ones that
are going to be on the exam, right.

1315
01:06:01,720 --> 01:06:05,200
There are other formulas out
there though that I call forth

1316
01:06:05,200 --> 01:06:08,170
in your like lines of communications and
estimated value.

1317
01:06:08,170 --> 01:06:10,270
We talk about these in other shows, right.

1318
01:06:10,270 --> 01:06:13,785
Like doing a six point estimate,
or three point estimate modified.

1319
01:06:13,785 --> 01:06:15,750
So that's that formula right there.

1320
01:06:15,750 --> 01:06:17,400
Or calculating total float.

1321
01:06:17,400 --> 01:06:19,080
So I've got a little bit more in there.

1322
01:06:19,080 --> 01:06:20,280
But that one table.

1323
01:06:20,280 --> 01:06:21,142
It was what? Table 7, dash. >> One.

1324
01:06:21,142 --> 01:06:22,756
>> One?

1325
01:06:22,756 --> 01:06:23,271
>> Mm-hm.
>> Yeah.

1326
01:06:23,271 --> 01:06:27,460
So, table 7.1 in the PMBOK fifth edition.

1327
01:06:27,460 --> 01:06:30,500
It's got the majority of
that stuff listed, also.

1328
01:06:30,500 --> 01:06:32,240
It also had the little legend on the side.

1329
01:06:32,240 --> 01:06:33,930
Positive, neutral, negative, right?

1330
01:06:33,930 --> 01:06:37,320
Those are the things that we need to
know about when we calculate this.

1331
01:06:37,320 --> 01:06:41,140
So, hopefully, that's a good overview.

1332
01:06:42,170 --> 01:06:44,286
Expect to probably watch
this episode more than once,

1333
01:06:44,286 --> 01:06:46,814
I know the first time that I learned this
>> [LAUGH]

1334
01:06:46,814 --> 01:06:47,760
>> It was a lot,

1335
01:06:47,760 --> 01:06:50,720
it was definitely a lot to grasp.

1336
01:06:50,720 --> 01:06:53,310
The concepts make sense, but
just memorizing the formulas,

1337
01:06:53,310 --> 01:06:54,440
that takes a lot of work.

1338
01:06:54,440 --> 01:06:56,190
Oh, you know what, I did say I was
going to show you guys one thing,

1339
01:06:56,190 --> 01:06:57,550
let me show you this.

1340
01:06:57,550 --> 01:07:00,550
If you're an in-the-field project manager,

1341
01:07:00,550 --> 01:07:02,320
the odds are you've never
used these formulas, and

1342
01:07:02,320 --> 01:07:05,700
the reason is, your project management
software probably does it for you.

1343
01:07:05,700 --> 01:07:09,780
So, as a great example, I wanted to
show you guys Microsoft Project, and

1344
01:07:09,780 --> 01:07:13,880
I just kinda whipped up a sample
project before the show.

1345
01:07:13,880 --> 01:07:18,760
And this is the sample project that
comes with Microsoft Project and they

1346
01:07:18,760 --> 01:07:22,470
have this default Gantt Chart View where
you see what your project is doing and

1347
01:07:22,470 --> 01:07:26,600
stuff, but
I created a custom view right here.

1348
01:07:26,600 --> 01:07:31,380
And in Microsoft Project, it actually can
calculate out a lot of these values, but

1349
01:07:31,380 --> 01:07:32,980
notice they're the old names.

1350
01:07:32,980 --> 01:07:36,210
ACWPB, BCWP, BCWS,
they've been renamed but

1351
01:07:36,210 --> 01:07:39,520
they are the same things
that we just talked about.

1352
01:07:39,520 --> 01:07:44,551
And as I scroll over we will
start to see cost variance, CPI,

1353
01:07:44,551 --> 01:07:51,570
there's our performance index, EAC, SPI,
SV, and even TCPI, all right there.

1354
01:07:51,570 --> 01:07:55,848
It's calculating them for us and
that's pretty awesome stuff,

1355
01:07:55,848 --> 01:07:58,970
because it means we don't
have to deal with it.

1356
01:07:58,970 --> 01:08:01,694
So when we start flagging
things as complete, and

1357
01:08:01,694 --> 01:08:06,370
maybe we're 76% complete there and so on,

1358
01:08:06,370 --> 01:08:11,940
it's going to start calculating out all
these values to reflect what we're doing.

1359
01:08:11,940 --> 01:08:16,160
And what we should see, here we go, when
we start to get our schedule variance,

1360
01:08:16,160 --> 01:08:17,520
I've got some negatives, right.

1361
01:08:17,520 --> 01:08:19,910
I'm not where I should
be on some of these.

1362
01:08:19,910 --> 01:08:24,620
And so it's calculating that out
saving us a heck of a lot of time.

1363
01:08:24,620 --> 01:08:27,240
All right,
now I didn't actually enter in work hours.

1364
01:08:27,240 --> 01:08:30,230
That's why a lot of this stuff
is still going to show as good.

1365
01:08:30,230 --> 01:08:33,170
But my schedule variance is off because
I didn't change my status date.

1366
01:08:33,170 --> 01:08:34,950
So it's showing things as
being behind schedule.

1367
01:08:36,080 --> 01:08:38,660
So that's a great way to be
able to use this stuff and

1368
01:08:38,660 --> 01:08:41,180
not have to know the formulas,
but you can see them.

1369
01:08:41,180 --> 01:08:44,020
So if you wanna experiment around in
an environment you're familiar with,

1370
01:08:44,020 --> 01:08:46,550
you can do it and kind of see how
all this stuff gets affected.

1371
01:08:46,550 --> 01:08:47,900
But it's really cool stuff.

1372
01:08:47,900 --> 01:08:49,060
>> It is.

1373
01:08:49,060 --> 01:08:50,570
>> Never thought I'd say it about math.

1374
01:08:50,570 --> 01:08:54,211
I wasn't the greatest math student.

1375
01:08:54,211 --> 01:08:57,020
So, all right, so
those are some of the formulas.

1376
01:08:57,020 --> 01:08:58,110
It's a lot to take in.

1377
01:08:58,110 --> 01:08:58,670
>> Yeah.

1378
01:08:58,670 --> 01:09:02,060
>> So, definitely take
advantage of us as a resource.

1379
01:09:02,060 --> 01:09:05,500
If you have questions on any of this,
be sure to ask.

1380
01:09:05,500 --> 01:09:07,060
Live, during the show,

1381
01:09:07,060 --> 01:09:10,360
you can go to itpro.tv/live and you can
post your questions in the chat room.

1382
01:09:10,360 --> 01:09:11,730
It's right beneath the video.

1383
01:09:11,730 --> 01:09:13,160
We monitor and answer during the show.

1384
01:09:13,160 --> 01:09:15,230
If you're watching a recorded show though,

1385
01:09:15,230 --> 01:09:16,720
like if you're watching
this one in the future.

1386
01:09:16,720 --> 01:09:18,990
You know, our estimate at completion.

1387
01:09:18,990 --> 01:09:20,940
Then you can use the Q&A forums.

1388
01:09:20,940 --> 01:09:23,660
At the top of every page
is a link that says Q&A.

1389
01:09:23,660 --> 01:09:24,300
Check it out.

1390
01:09:24,300 --> 01:09:25,280
We got forums in there.

1391
01:09:25,280 --> 01:09:26,340
You can post your question.

1392
01:09:26,340 --> 01:09:27,690
We monitor and answer there too.

1393
01:09:27,690 --> 01:09:29,210
So be sure to use that.

1394
01:09:29,210 --> 01:09:31,260
It is there for you.

1395
01:09:31,260 --> 01:09:34,500
All right, well I know it was a little bit
dry, but I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1396
01:09:34,500 --> 01:09:36,670
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1397
01:09:36,670 --> 01:09:37,480
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1398
01:09:37,480 --> 01:09:38,170
>> And we will see you next time.

1399
01:09:38,170 --> 01:09:48,170
[MUSIC]

1400
01:09:51,276 --> 01:09:57,960
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take us through the final work knowledge areas of controlling quality, communications, risks, procurements and stakeholders. Identifying the importance of keeping current and up to date while the project is executing and while receiving work progress reports so that good decisions can be made to keep the project on time, on scope and on budget.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Controlling Part 2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:30,463 --> 00:00:33,467
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:33,467 --> 00:00:36,920
welcome back To another episode of
IT Pro TV I'm your host Don Pezet.

4
00:00:36,920 --> 00:00:39,320
Backing on Mr. Ronnie Wong,
how's it going Ronnie?

5
00:00:39,320 --> 00:00:42,930
>> It's going well but
I am still surprised that there is no,

6
00:00:42,930 --> 00:00:48,580
that Hello Kitty is not a cat [LAUGH].

7
00:00:48,580 --> 00:00:51,000
>> Now I've got to inquire.

8
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:52,850
Were you on a Hello Kitty news website?

9
00:00:52,850 --> 00:00:53,870
>> I was.

10
00:00:53,870 --> 00:00:56,560
Yeah it was my fan mail.

11
00:00:56,560 --> 00:01:00,190
No I was reading and I found that out and
so my world views changed.

12
00:01:00,190 --> 00:01:02,820
I found out from the official
curator of Hello Kitty.

13
00:01:02,820 --> 00:01:04,150
>> So there's a curator.

14
00:01:04,150 --> 00:01:06,980
>> There's a curator for Hello Kitty, yes.

15
00:01:06,980 --> 00:01:09,510
As a project manager
sometimes we get accused of

16
00:01:09,510 --> 00:01:12,194
introducing needless bureaucracy and
wasting people's time.

17
00:01:12,194 --> 00:01:13,560
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now we got a new defense, right?

18
00:01:13,560 --> 00:01:14,080
>> That's right.

19
00:01:14,080 --> 00:01:15,601
>> If everybody ever says
that you can say, hey,

20
00:01:15,601 --> 00:01:17,088
did you know there's
a Hello Kitty curator?

21
00:01:17,088 --> 00:01:21,740
[LAUGH]
>> I know.

22
00:01:21,740 --> 00:01:24,690
>> We're gonna jump back into
the world of project management.

23
00:01:24,690 --> 00:01:29,740
We've been moving along in our monitoring
and controlling phase or process group.

24
00:01:30,960 --> 00:01:33,390
Now we're on the downhill slope of things.

25
00:01:33,390 --> 00:01:36,950
We've gone through a lot of technical and
heavy stuff this section.

26
00:01:36,950 --> 00:01:41,450
So, we talked about all of our various
controls, and we took a look at EVM,

27
00:01:41,450 --> 00:01:43,510
right, and all the mathematical formulas.

28
00:01:43,510 --> 00:01:47,550
And between that and all the stuff
we did back in planning, it's a lot.

29
00:01:47,550 --> 00:01:49,280
Right?
Your brain's probably hurting by now with

30
00:01:49,280 --> 00:01:50,980
all the information you gotta gather.

31
00:01:50,980 --> 00:01:55,092
Well, the last handful of processes
it's really down hill, right?

32
00:01:55,092 --> 00:01:58,120
It's really just applying
the things we have already covered,

33
00:01:58,120 --> 00:02:01,850
so now we just move into our last few
episodes as we discuss and wrap up.

34
00:02:01,850 --> 00:02:03,843
We are definitely on the down
hill side of things.

35
00:02:03,843 --> 00:02:10,073
Let me show you I'll just show you the pin
box, in the monitoring process group.

36
00:02:10,073 --> 00:02:12,370
We can move the control schedule,
control cost.

37
00:02:12,370 --> 00:02:14,860
Today we're picking up with
control quality, all right.

38
00:02:14,860 --> 00:02:16,260
Controlling quality.

39
00:02:16,260 --> 00:02:20,210
We've really already visited a lot of
that because we did quality assurance,

40
00:02:20,210 --> 00:02:22,570
which is stopping problems
before they occur.

41
00:02:22,570 --> 00:02:26,070
Now we're doing quality control,
identifying problems after they occur.

42
00:02:26,070 --> 00:02:29,720
But it was all developed
back in our plan originally.

43
00:02:29,720 --> 00:02:31,530
We'll do control communications which,

44
00:02:31,530 --> 00:02:34,950
again is really just implementing
the communications we planned from before.

45
00:02:34,950 --> 00:02:38,800
Controlling our risks taking all
the action that we set forth before.

46
00:02:38,800 --> 00:02:41,610
Controlling procurements and
controlling stakeholder engagement.

47
00:02:41,610 --> 00:02:43,860
You know these are really,
really simple things.

48
00:02:43,860 --> 00:02:45,670
So we're going to jump
through those this episode.

49
00:02:45,670 --> 00:02:47,470
I think we'll be able to get
through all that this episode.

50
00:02:47,470 --> 00:02:50,890
We'll see and then start to wind
down our project management,

51
00:02:50,890 --> 00:02:54,530
hey after that is just closing
which is mostly empty, right?

52
00:02:54,530 --> 00:02:56,420
>> Yeah.
>> So we'll get a chance to see

53
00:02:56,420 --> 00:02:57,750
that later.

54
00:02:57,750 --> 00:02:58,530
>> All right.

55
00:02:58,530 --> 00:02:59,680
>> So let's go ahead and dive in.

56
00:02:59,680 --> 00:03:04,540
We are gonna start with control quality,
and the control quality process, let me

57
00:03:04,540 --> 00:03:08,340
just pull it up here, is, it's one of the
bigger ones we're gonna talk about today.

58
00:03:08,340 --> 00:03:10,620
It's got a lot of stuff involved.

59
00:03:10,620 --> 00:03:13,740
Remember that control quality is taking
a look at the work that's being done,

60
00:03:13,740 --> 00:03:17,740
and evaluating it to make sure it
meets your quality requirements.

61
00:03:17,740 --> 00:03:20,260
Now, even if you're not
a manufacturing plant,

62
00:03:20,260 --> 00:03:21,510
you still have quality requirements.

63
00:03:21,510 --> 00:03:24,645
Your qualities are your requirements.

64
00:03:24,645 --> 00:03:25,935
Right?
When you created your

65
00:03:25,935 --> 00:03:28,815
project scope you had a requirements list.

66
00:03:28,815 --> 00:03:31,505
Is the work being done
meeting your requirements?

67
00:03:31,505 --> 00:03:33,175
Right, that's your quality.

68
00:03:33,175 --> 00:03:34,985
But if you're a manufacturing environment,

69
00:03:34,985 --> 00:03:37,527
you might have very
specific quality controls.

70
00:03:37,527 --> 00:03:39,637
You might have things
like units of measure.

71
00:03:39,637 --> 00:03:42,387
There was an example
in a book I read once.

72
00:03:42,387 --> 00:03:47,197
It was talking about a factory where they
made I think it was like pickles right?

73
00:03:47,197 --> 00:03:50,663
And so you had a jar, they filled it with
pickles and a machine would come down and

74
00:03:50,663 --> 00:03:52,253
screw the lid on the jar.

75
00:03:52,253 --> 00:03:55,903
And when it screwed the lid on the jar,
it measured it in pounds per square inch,

76
00:03:55,903 --> 00:03:57,033
so PSI.

77
00:03:57,033 --> 00:04:00,803
So they had to measure the PSI
as they screwed that on and

78
00:04:00,803 --> 00:04:03,313
make sure it was within
a certain tolerance range.

79
00:04:03,313 --> 00:04:04,963
Very very precise.

80
00:04:04,963 --> 00:04:05,763
Right.
I know I've made

81
00:04:05,763 --> 00:04:07,553
the reference of like
in a blue jean factory.

82
00:04:07,553 --> 00:04:10,383
Monitoring for the amount of
defects in jeans manufactured.

83
00:04:10,383 --> 00:04:12,863
Those things may be very
precise measurements

84
00:04:12,863 --> 00:04:14,870
in a manufacturing type environment.

85
00:04:14,870 --> 00:04:18,100
In a IT environment where
it's mostly service oriented,

86
00:04:19,400 --> 00:04:20,470
we don't normally have that.

87
00:04:20,470 --> 00:04:22,375
But we might have other
quality measures that we use.

88
00:04:22,375 --> 00:04:27,880
So, first off, if we're going to be
monitoring the work that's been done and

89
00:04:27,880 --> 00:04:29,750
measuring it against our
quality requirements,

90
00:04:29,750 --> 00:04:31,720
well, we need ways to get that data.

91
00:04:31,720 --> 00:04:33,510
And that's where inputs come from.

92
00:04:33,510 --> 00:04:35,880
The first input is the project
management plan, right.

93
00:04:35,880 --> 00:04:38,780
It sets forth our quality statement.

94
00:04:38,780 --> 00:04:41,310
Our quality control plan is in there.

95
00:04:41,310 --> 00:04:43,210
We need that to know what to do.

96
00:04:43,210 --> 00:04:45,890
After that, the rest of this is
data that feeds as an input, right?

97
00:04:45,890 --> 00:04:47,580
So, quality metrics.

98
00:04:47,580 --> 00:04:49,810
I need to know, all right,
here's the work that's been done.

99
00:04:49,810 --> 00:04:51,495
Give me the metrics on it.

100
00:04:51,495 --> 00:04:54,255
And those quality metrics,
they can be a number of different things.

101
00:04:54,255 --> 00:04:57,245
Let me bring up the notes
we've got on this one.

102
00:04:57,245 --> 00:04:58,045
Here we go.

103
00:04:58,045 --> 00:05:02,075
Things like function points, mean time
between failure, mean time to repair.

104
00:05:02,075 --> 00:05:03,845
These are quality metrics that we get.

105
00:05:03,845 --> 00:05:05,755
They may be specific measurements.

106
00:05:05,755 --> 00:05:09,490
They may be the amount of failures that
we've had in a certain environment.

107
00:05:09,490 --> 00:05:11,390
Things like mean time between failure.

108
00:05:11,390 --> 00:05:14,100
Sometimes we know failure
is going to happen and

109
00:05:14,100 --> 00:05:17,560
we just need to measure
the time in between it.

110
00:05:17,560 --> 00:05:21,730
I gave an example in an earlier episode
about a manufacturing company that makes

111
00:05:21,730 --> 00:05:23,130
cowboy hats.

112
00:05:23,130 --> 00:05:27,660
And how after a certain amount of hats,
the equipment wears out, and so

113
00:05:27,660 --> 00:05:31,750
they have to retool the equipment every so
many months or weeks or years,

114
00:05:31,750 --> 00:05:33,720
whatever their interval is.

115
00:05:33,720 --> 00:05:37,300
Well that's the mean time between failure,
how long it take that it could fail and

116
00:05:37,300 --> 00:05:38,940
need to be retooled.

117
00:05:38,940 --> 00:05:41,320
If we notice that time
is getting shorter and

118
00:05:41,320 --> 00:05:43,650
shorter it may be indicative
of another problem.

119
00:05:43,650 --> 00:05:45,810
But if we're not tracking
that then we don't know so

120
00:05:45,810 --> 00:05:47,930
it's something we got to keep an eye on.

121
00:05:47,930 --> 00:05:50,600
Mean time to repair is after a failure.

122
00:05:50,600 --> 00:05:54,530
How long does it take to get it up and
operational again?

123
00:05:54,530 --> 00:05:56,680
When we go to retool that equipment,

124
00:05:56,680 --> 00:05:58,300
is this something that's
only going to take a week?

125
00:05:58,300 --> 00:06:02,220
Or is it something that's
going to take months?

126
00:06:02,220 --> 00:06:04,107
My wife just bought a Subaru.

127
00:06:04,107 --> 00:06:07,802
And when she bought it,
it was supposed to come in one week and

128
00:06:07,802 --> 00:06:10,277
ended up coming two or three weeks late.

129
00:06:10,277 --> 00:06:12,574
So she didn't get when
she was supposed to, and

130
00:06:12,574 --> 00:06:15,849
it turned out that there was something
going on at the manufacturing

131
00:06:15,849 --> 00:06:18,678
plant where they had to redesign
their assembly process.

132
00:06:18,678 --> 00:06:21,335
And it shut the plant down for two months.

133
00:06:21,335 --> 00:06:25,185
So, they identified a problem and then,
for two months, they did not make

134
00:06:25,185 --> 00:06:28,615
a single vehicle up there while they
retooled and corrected the issue.

135
00:06:28,615 --> 00:06:30,695
And then they started manufacturing again.

136
00:06:30,695 --> 00:06:35,975
If that happens during your project,
what's that gonna do to your end result?

137
00:06:35,975 --> 00:06:38,645
That's really gonna hurt your schedule,
so these are things that we need to keep

138
00:06:38,645 --> 00:06:41,440
track of and make sure that
we've got good estimates for.

139
00:06:41,440 --> 00:06:43,530
We'll need those in our
communications later on.

140
00:06:45,200 --> 00:06:47,360
All right.
Some of the other things that we've got.

141
00:06:47,360 --> 00:06:49,210
Quality checklists, right?

142
00:06:49,210 --> 00:06:53,712
The quality checklists are our go-to
tool to make sure the quality's being

143
00:06:53,712 --> 00:06:54,567
maintained.

144
00:06:54,567 --> 00:06:58,515
If you've got a list of requirements,
at a minimum that works.

145
00:06:58,515 --> 00:07:01,368
Or if you've got a detailed quality
checklist that was developed in

146
00:07:01,368 --> 00:07:04,569
the planning phase, you just walk up to
the people that are doing the work and

147
00:07:04,569 --> 00:07:05,810
you run down the checklist.

148
00:07:05,810 --> 00:07:09,970
Have they done this, have they done that,
has this requirement been met?

149
00:07:09,970 --> 00:07:10,810
What's going on.

150
00:07:10,810 --> 00:07:13,480
And then you see what's happened and
what hasn't.

151
00:07:13,480 --> 00:07:16,350
So those checklists get filled
out as part of executing.

152
00:07:16,350 --> 00:07:19,670
And then they get turned over to us in
monitoring and controlling to review.

153
00:07:19,670 --> 00:07:20,930
So it's an input here.

154
00:07:22,530 --> 00:07:23,820
Work performance data, right?

155
00:07:23,820 --> 00:07:27,440
All the progress and status reports that
we get from our employees on the ground,

156
00:07:27,440 --> 00:07:29,170
the ones who are doing the executing.

157
00:07:29,170 --> 00:07:29,700
Right?

158
00:07:29,700 --> 00:07:33,090
We get their data and
then we monitor and control it.

159
00:07:33,090 --> 00:07:34,620
Approved change requests.

160
00:07:34,620 --> 00:07:37,100
Now, this is an important one
here with control quality,

161
00:07:37,100 --> 00:07:41,010
because the change requests may
directly affect our quality control.

162
00:07:41,010 --> 00:07:45,070
So what we check for
what we consider is tolerant and so on.

163
00:07:45,070 --> 00:07:46,970
If that changes we need to be aware of it.

164
00:07:46,970 --> 00:07:49,720
So those are always gonna be input.

165
00:07:49,720 --> 00:07:51,230
Our deliverables.

166
00:07:51,230 --> 00:07:54,771
If the people who are executing create
a product, or a service or whatever it is

167
00:07:54,771 --> 00:07:58,224
that's one of our deliverables inside
of the project we need to measure it.

168
00:07:58,224 --> 00:08:00,399
We need to take a look at it,
make sure it meets our requirements.

169
00:08:00,399 --> 00:08:05,215
This is kind of like the scope validation
that we talked in another episode.

170
00:08:05,215 --> 00:08:07,631
This is very similar,
except we're focused on the quality side.

171
00:08:07,631 --> 00:08:10,811
So it might not be the overall scope
that we're comparing against, but

172
00:08:10,811 --> 00:08:14,150
a separate set of quality requirements
set forward from the quality plan.

173
00:08:16,070 --> 00:08:19,920
Then we've got our project documents and
our organizational process assets,

174
00:08:19,920 --> 00:08:22,780
we don't have our enterprise
environmental factors here.

175
00:08:22,780 --> 00:08:23,920
The way you do business,

176
00:08:23,920 --> 00:08:28,280
because the way you do business shouldn't
affect the way you do quality control.

177
00:08:28,280 --> 00:08:31,160
Quality control doesn't care
what kind of business you're in.

178
00:08:31,160 --> 00:08:35,020
It says, you need to meet these
requirements, have you met them?

179
00:08:35,020 --> 00:08:37,610
So that's why we don't see
enterprise environmental factors.

180
00:08:39,966 --> 00:08:43,246
When it comes to actually working
with all that data that we get,

181
00:08:43,246 --> 00:08:45,391
we get a handful of tools and techniques.

182
00:08:45,391 --> 00:08:48,415
These are all ones that we've seen before,
in other episodes so

183
00:08:48,415 --> 00:08:50,128
there's nothing really new here.

184
00:08:50,128 --> 00:08:55,120
But to kind of review them,
there's these seven basic quality tools.

185
00:08:55,120 --> 00:08:59,121
And these are really seven different types
of charts that we can use when mapping out

186
00:08:59,121 --> 00:09:00,180
for quality.

187
00:09:00,180 --> 00:09:02,584
The PMBOK has a great example of that.

188
00:09:02,584 --> 00:09:06,241
Let met pull that up here.

189
00:09:06,241 --> 00:09:07,210
Here we go.

190
00:09:07,210 --> 00:09:12,912
So, this is table figure 8-7 in the PMBOK,
you can find it and

191
00:09:12,912 --> 00:09:17,876
it basically shows these seven
common quality tools and

192
00:09:17,876 --> 00:09:21,160
they're pretty straightforward.

193
00:09:22,310 --> 00:09:24,560
So we got things like our cause and
effect diagram.

194
00:09:24,560 --> 00:09:27,350
If we're having failures,
where are they coming from?

195
00:09:27,350 --> 00:09:28,812
The effect is a failure,
what was the cause?

196
00:09:28,812 --> 00:09:30,170
What led to that?

197
00:09:30,170 --> 00:09:34,130
And so we start to identify it,
you'll hear these called different things.

198
00:09:34,130 --> 00:09:39,190
You'll see Ishikawa diagrams or fish bone
but those are cause and effect diagrams.

199
00:09:39,190 --> 00:09:43,860
Flow charts, now flow charts are usually
used as part of our checking process to

200
00:09:43,860 --> 00:09:45,550
see if quality has been met.

201
00:09:45,550 --> 00:09:46,700
Is this measurement accurate?

202
00:09:46,700 --> 00:09:47,700
Yes or no?

203
00:09:47,700 --> 00:09:49,100
If yes, go this route.

204
00:09:49,100 --> 00:09:51,830
If no, go this route and
different actions happen.

205
00:09:51,830 --> 00:09:54,420
Flow charts are nice because you can
actually have corrective measures

206
00:09:54,420 --> 00:09:55,480
built into them.

207
00:09:55,480 --> 00:10:00,000
So yes, the defect might be present, but
you might already have a way to fix it.

208
00:10:00,000 --> 00:10:04,340
So 10% of the blue jeans you
manufacture come out missing a button.

209
00:10:04,340 --> 00:10:07,960
And so you just send them back through
the conveyor belt or whatever, and

210
00:10:07,960 --> 00:10:09,350
you can stick a button on them.

211
00:10:09,350 --> 00:10:11,320
So if that's already
built into your process,

212
00:10:11,320 --> 00:10:13,190
you have a flow chart that shows that.

213
00:10:13,190 --> 00:10:14,545
Flow chart that shows that-
>> [LAUGH]

214
00:10:14,545 --> 00:10:16,390
>> Kinda screw up my letters there.

215
00:10:16,390 --> 00:10:16,940
Check sheets.

216
00:10:16,940 --> 00:10:19,060
>> Yeah.
>> That's another one.

217
00:10:19,060 --> 00:10:20,480
Check sheets.
I use them all the time.

218
00:10:20,480 --> 00:10:21,820
You basically, the check sheet or

219
00:10:21,820 --> 00:10:24,260
checklist you have just
an entry requirement.

220
00:10:24,260 --> 00:10:27,250
And you just walk down ticking
off the ones that they've got and

221
00:10:27,250 --> 00:10:32,245
leaving the ones that they don't and
that's a great way to measure progress.

222
00:10:32,245 --> 00:10:36,805
Pareto diagrams, here's where we map
out all of our causes of failure.

223
00:10:36,805 --> 00:10:39,265
So anywhere we have something
that's not meeting quality,

224
00:10:39,265 --> 00:10:41,055
we map out what was the cause.

225
00:10:41,055 --> 00:10:44,535
And then we arrange it so
that the greatest cause is first.

226
00:10:44,535 --> 00:10:49,710
So we can spot which one is the biggest
source of failures inside our process.

227
00:10:49,710 --> 00:10:53,170
The reason we map them all out together
is that we can sure that they add up and

228
00:10:53,170 --> 00:10:55,132
total the full amount of
failures in the system.

229
00:10:55,132 --> 00:10:57,560
You wanna make sure you account for
all sources.

230
00:10:58,830 --> 00:10:59,672
We also have histograms.

231
00:10:59,672 --> 00:11:03,632
Again, very similar just mapping out
our causes and laying them out and

232
00:11:03,632 --> 00:11:06,866
kind of putting the most common
causes toward the center so

233
00:11:06,866 --> 00:11:09,060
we can identify which ones to address.

234
00:11:10,200 --> 00:11:11,580
Control charts are another one.

235
00:11:12,820 --> 00:11:16,240
It's really hard to see here in this
diagram, because it's really small.

236
00:11:16,240 --> 00:11:17,360
Let me show you.

237
00:11:17,360 --> 00:11:21,540
I whipped up a little bit of
an example of a control chart earlier.

238
00:11:21,540 --> 00:11:25,070
Control charts are neat,
because when you have a project and

239
00:11:25,070 --> 00:11:29,520
you set for some kind of a design.

240
00:11:29,520 --> 00:11:35,270
Your design likely has a target
that you're trying to hit.

241
00:11:35,270 --> 00:11:39,855
So I'm gonna just call it my target and
let me change this around a little bit.

242
00:11:44,812 --> 00:11:46,510
>> [LAUGH]
>> Put those a little too close.

243
00:11:46,510 --> 00:11:49,240
>> So let's say we have a target
number that we're trying to hit.

244
00:11:49,240 --> 00:11:53,310
So when we design something we want
a measurement to be a very specific value

245
00:11:53,310 --> 00:11:54,880
and that's going to be my target.

246
00:11:58,350 --> 00:12:01,278
So when I design my project
I get things set up,

247
00:12:01,278 --> 00:12:04,821
I come up with all this stuff
is gonna keep overlapping.

248
00:12:04,821 --> 00:12:06,900
>> [LAUGH]
>> There we go, with a target.

249
00:12:06,900 --> 00:12:11,350
So when I go from manufacturing,
I'm trying to hit a particular value.

250
00:12:11,350 --> 00:12:13,990
And so I lay that one.

251
00:12:13,990 --> 00:12:15,730
Wow, I just cannot click on things today.

252
00:12:18,120 --> 00:12:19,400
There we go.
Here's my target.

253
00:12:19,400 --> 00:12:21,310
So as I manufacture this,

254
00:12:21,310 --> 00:12:24,160
I want the measurement to be right
there where that blue line is and

255
00:12:24,160 --> 00:12:28,190
that blue line's actually pretty hard to
see, so let's change that to green, there.

256
00:12:28,190 --> 00:12:30,430
So that's my target,
that's what I want to hit.

257
00:12:30,430 --> 00:12:33,600
That's where I expect my stuff
to be as I manufacture it.

258
00:12:33,600 --> 00:12:35,480
That's my target.

259
00:12:35,480 --> 00:12:39,000
Over time I start doing measurements.

260
00:12:39,000 --> 00:12:40,050
So maybe these are months.

261
00:12:40,050 --> 00:12:42,210
So in January, I am right on target.

262
00:12:42,210 --> 00:12:44,200
Things are exactly where they need to be.

263
00:12:44,200 --> 00:12:48,440
In February, I was a little bit
above where I needed to be.

264
00:12:48,440 --> 00:12:50,420
In March, things are back in line.

265
00:12:50,420 --> 00:12:52,250
That was exactly where I needed to be.

266
00:12:52,250 --> 00:12:53,940
In April,
they started to go back above again.

267
00:12:53,940 --> 00:12:55,520
But I'm keeping track of that.

268
00:12:55,520 --> 00:13:00,430
Now, when I'm above,
do I need to do something about it?

269
00:13:00,430 --> 00:13:01,930
Maybe, maybe not, okay?

270
00:13:01,930 --> 00:13:07,080
Maybe, depending on our tolerance,
our control limits.

271
00:13:07,080 --> 00:13:11,410
You have a control limit that specifies
how many defects or how many failures or

272
00:13:11,410 --> 00:13:12,460
how many deviations?

273
00:13:12,460 --> 00:13:14,770
They're usually at standard
deviations from the norm.

274
00:13:14,770 --> 00:13:18,600
That you will accept without
having to take action.

275
00:13:18,600 --> 00:13:24,532
So I might say, man I am shooting for
less than 30% defects.

276
00:13:24,532 --> 00:13:29,890
But I might have an upper
control limit of 35 defects and

277
00:13:29,890 --> 00:13:33,200
a lower control limit, well you probably
wouldn't have a lower control limit,

278
00:13:33,200 --> 00:13:38,030
the upper is the most defects that I would
allow without having to take action.

279
00:13:38,030 --> 00:13:39,570
A lower well, if I had zero defects,

280
00:13:39,570 --> 00:13:40,162
I'd be-
>> Yeah.

281
00:13:40,162 --> 00:13:41,460
>> Perfectly happy with that.

282
00:13:41,460 --> 00:13:43,750
So you might just have an upper limit.

283
00:13:43,750 --> 00:13:46,640
Let's go back to that pickle jar example.

284
00:13:46,640 --> 00:13:49,220
So screwing that lid on to a pickle jar.

285
00:13:49,220 --> 00:13:53,180
Well, if I need that to go on at four psi.

286
00:13:53,180 --> 00:13:55,910
That's the amount of pressure,
I need for that lid to be on.

287
00:13:55,910 --> 00:14:01,100
If it's under four psi, it might not
go on tight enough and it'll leak.

288
00:14:01,100 --> 00:14:05,880
If it's over four psi, it might go
on too tight and shatter the glass.

289
00:14:05,880 --> 00:14:09,040
So there I've got an upper and
a lower limit.

290
00:14:09,040 --> 00:14:12,460
So we create those control limits,
upper limits and lower limits.

291
00:14:13,860 --> 00:14:19,800
And they identify that threshold,
what we're willing to get?

292
00:14:19,800 --> 00:14:24,720
So I might come in an define
an upper limit right here.

293
00:14:26,030 --> 00:14:29,550
And then do a lower limit also, okay.

294
00:14:29,550 --> 00:14:35,430
Now, [COUGH] when we do this,
when we map our points.

295
00:14:35,430 --> 00:14:39,070
We're saying here's where we're at or
where we're going and so on.

296
00:14:39,070 --> 00:14:43,390
What we're doing is we're measuring
against the target, what we wanna hit and

297
00:14:43,390 --> 00:14:44,500
our limits.

298
00:14:46,160 --> 00:14:49,895
And as we start to have defects as long as
they're within the upper and lower limits,

299
00:14:49,895 --> 00:14:50,890
I'm okay.

300
00:14:50,890 --> 00:14:54,367
Yeah, these jars right here, the lids
on a little too tight but it's fine.

301
00:14:54,367 --> 00:14:57,260
It wasn't enough to break the glass and
it's definitely not going to leak.

302
00:14:57,260 --> 00:15:00,440
And over here it dips down just
a little bit but it's fine.

303
00:15:00,440 --> 00:15:03,120
It's not gonna leak,
it's not gonna shatter, it's good.

304
00:15:03,120 --> 00:15:06,980
So as we map, I actually see
I'm really close right here.

305
00:15:06,980 --> 00:15:10,560
But it's at this point which
is probably July or August,

306
00:15:10,560 --> 00:15:15,010
now my lids are going on too tight which
is probably resulting in shattered jars.

307
00:15:15,010 --> 00:15:16,580
Or just angry customers who can't get-
>> Yeah.

308
00:15:16,580 --> 00:15:18,310
>> It open without having to get a wrench.

309
00:15:18,310 --> 00:15:20,470
So [COUGH] there's a problem.

310
00:15:20,470 --> 00:15:22,430
When you see a limit like this or

311
00:15:22,430 --> 00:15:27,780
a measure a metric that's over the limit
you're said to be out of control.

312
00:15:27,780 --> 00:15:29,960
That's where that term
comes from out of control.

313
00:15:29,960 --> 00:15:32,450
You've exceeded your control limit.

314
00:15:32,450 --> 00:15:34,740
So in this case my upper
limit versus my lower.

315
00:15:35,770 --> 00:15:38,130
Now, when we map this we're looking for
two things.

316
00:15:38,130 --> 00:15:40,630
One, I wanna see if I'm out of control.

317
00:15:40,630 --> 00:15:42,430
If that happens,
I need to do something about it.

318
00:15:43,470 --> 00:15:44,162
After the fact, right?

319
00:15:44,162 --> 00:15:46,390
>> Right.
>> That's quality control.

320
00:15:46,390 --> 00:15:48,410
Quality assurance uses these too though.

321
00:15:48,410 --> 00:15:49,870
We should have seen this problem coming.

322
00:15:50,890 --> 00:15:55,712
If you look at all of these numbers,
we could have done a trend.

323
00:15:55,712 --> 00:16:00,395
There's been a standard trend
from start to finish on these

324
00:16:00,395 --> 00:16:03,495
that shows my defects are increasing.

325
00:16:03,495 --> 00:16:06,480
I see this general upward slope.

326
00:16:06,480 --> 00:16:09,569
And so, we should have been able
to spot that very early on.

327
00:16:09,569 --> 00:16:14,429
As we started way back here and
kind of moved along our numbers,

328
00:16:14,429 --> 00:16:19,670
I guess we kind of averaged it out,
it would be something like that.

329
00:16:22,350 --> 00:16:26,690
And what that's showing us is
that if we just left this be,

330
00:16:26,690 --> 00:16:31,140
if we just left it running the way that
it was running, it's getting worse and

331
00:16:31,140 --> 00:16:34,970
worse and worse and we probably could
have spotted that way back here and

332
00:16:34,970 --> 00:16:37,160
fixed it before we broke that limit.

333
00:16:37,160 --> 00:16:39,000
That's quality assurance.

334
00:16:39,000 --> 00:16:41,750
Quality control,
we're looking to see if we crossed it.

335
00:16:41,750 --> 00:16:43,330
So, if we've crossed it,
now we take action.

336
00:16:43,330 --> 00:16:46,497
These types of charts,
they're called control charts and

337
00:16:46,497 --> 00:16:48,092
they're extremely useful.

338
00:16:48,092 --> 00:16:54,710
>> The usefulness [LAUGH] of this chart
also helps especially in manufacturing.

339
00:16:54,710 --> 00:16:58,400
When you start to be able to trend this
kind of stuff, it may even point you to

340
00:16:58,400 --> 00:17:02,510
the fact that as you take a look at
the defect that happened, you may go,

341
00:17:02,510 --> 00:17:06,420
is this due to the idea that there's
something wrong with the product assembly.

342
00:17:06,420 --> 00:17:09,730
Or is there something that we actually
can fix and then go back and go alright,

343
00:17:09,730 --> 00:17:12,890
we're going to replace something in six
months instead of eight months here.

344
00:17:12,890 --> 00:17:15,740
So, just by being able to spot this
here inside of the control limits,

345
00:17:15,740 --> 00:17:18,940
which way that they go, it may tell you
that a piece of machinery is wearing out.

346
00:17:18,940 --> 00:17:20,940
>> Yeah, absolutely.

347
00:17:20,940 --> 00:17:23,630
So, the only way we know this,
though, is if we measure it.

348
00:17:23,630 --> 00:17:25,420
And we measure it regularly, routinely.

349
00:17:25,420 --> 00:17:27,710
So, we need to be watching these,
and the interval,

350
00:17:27,710 --> 00:17:28,920
it really depends on your business.

351
00:17:28,920 --> 00:17:32,040
Do you need to watch it every day,
every week, every month?

352
00:17:32,040 --> 00:17:35,630
And it's your people on the field who
are gonna be sending you this data.

353
00:17:35,630 --> 00:17:39,840
But it's you that puts the data
together to see the big picture.

354
00:17:39,840 --> 00:17:43,720
So that we can see week after week, or
month after month what that trend is.

355
00:17:45,270 --> 00:17:46,810
Some of the other ones that were in here,
well,

356
00:17:46,810 --> 00:17:48,750
I guess the only other
one is a scatter diagram.

357
00:17:48,750 --> 00:17:50,120
Scatter diagrams are very similar.

358
00:17:50,120 --> 00:17:54,280
We start to plot those instances
of that particular thing and

359
00:17:54,280 --> 00:17:55,840
notice where the average is.

360
00:17:55,840 --> 00:18:00,080
You'll see outliers and
you can kinda see one way down here, so

361
00:18:00,080 --> 00:18:05,120
maybe on this chart they're measuring
the tightness of that jar's lid for

362
00:18:05,120 --> 00:18:08,816
a hundred of those jars so
each dot represents one jar.

363
00:18:08,816 --> 00:18:12,675
And I can see the bulk of them
are following right where I want them to.

364
00:18:12,675 --> 00:18:14,350
We got a few outliers,

365
00:18:14,350 --> 00:18:18,025
those are our defects, but as long as
they're within our limits, we're okay.

366
00:18:19,690 --> 00:18:22,710
Those are our seven standard tools.

367
00:18:22,710 --> 00:18:24,110
That's what they're
talking about back here.

368
00:18:24,110 --> 00:18:28,150
Seven basic quality tools that we use and
they can be used for quality assurance and

369
00:18:28,150 --> 00:18:28,760
quality control.

370
00:18:30,418 --> 00:18:34,690
Statistical standpoint,
if you are generating a large

371
00:18:34,690 --> 00:18:38,430
quantity of things,1,000 pairs of
blue jeans, as part of your project.

372
00:18:38,430 --> 00:18:42,540
Well, you can't check every single one,
can you?

373
00:18:42,540 --> 00:18:45,150
Maybe, if you got the time you can.

374
00:18:45,150 --> 00:18:48,327
But if you're on a schedule,
then you're probably pressed for time and

375
00:18:48,327 --> 00:18:50,008
you can't inspect every single one.

376
00:18:50,008 --> 00:18:53,620
So, the general practice is to do
what's called statistical sampling.

377
00:18:53,620 --> 00:18:59,370
You grab maybe every tenth pair,
if you grab every tenth pair of jeans,

378
00:18:59,370 --> 00:19:02,530
now instead of having to look at a 1,000
pairs, you're only looking at a 100.

379
00:19:02,530 --> 00:19:04,275
It's a smaller number, but

380
00:19:04,275 --> 00:19:08,195
you'll get a good enough idea of
what your defect rate is from that.

381
00:19:08,195 --> 00:19:10,445
It does need to be
statistically significant.

382
00:19:10,445 --> 00:19:13,985
So, you don't just wanna grab one pair,
or grab three pairs in a row.

383
00:19:13,985 --> 00:19:16,635
It needs to be spread out
through the population.

384
00:19:16,635 --> 00:19:19,865
And grab that nice generality,
get that poll together, and sample it.

385
00:19:19,865 --> 00:19:22,735
It's how political polls work,
it's how a lot of systems work.

386
00:19:22,735 --> 00:19:24,860
It's a very generally accepted practice.

387
00:19:26,310 --> 00:19:30,560
But it does lead to inspection, inspection
where we just go and we actually look.

388
00:19:30,560 --> 00:19:31,870
That is the best way to verify.

389
00:19:31,870 --> 00:19:36,000
If you're applying those quality
checklists, you're doing an inspection.

390
00:19:37,900 --> 00:19:41,650
And then, approved change request review,
now what does that mean?

391
00:19:41,650 --> 00:19:44,500
Well, when there's a change
request that goes in

392
00:19:44,500 --> 00:19:47,400
that modifies something like our upper or
lower control limits, or

393
00:19:47,400 --> 00:19:50,980
uppers the manufacturing process,
or it modifies something.

394
00:19:50,980 --> 00:19:53,369
When something like that gets changed,

395
00:19:53,369 --> 00:19:57,020
we need to review it to see if we
need to update our checklists,

396
00:19:57,020 --> 00:20:00,972
update our flow charts,
update our other quality control items.

397
00:20:00,972 --> 00:20:04,682
So that we can be measuring them properly
within the new limits that we're set

398
00:20:04,682 --> 00:20:07,030
forth, based on those change requests.

399
00:20:07,030 --> 00:20:09,960
A good change request would
already indicate those downstream

400
00:20:09,960 --> 00:20:12,340
changes that need to be made,
but they don't always.

401
00:20:12,340 --> 00:20:15,750
So, we need to make sure we review
any approved change request and

402
00:20:15,750 --> 00:20:18,329
make sure that we take
the appropriate action.

403
00:20:20,850 --> 00:20:24,970
Now, our outputs, they're big or
at least they look big.

404
00:20:24,970 --> 00:20:27,540
There's a lot of stuff in here but
most of it's pretty straightforward.

405
00:20:27,540 --> 00:20:30,988
Our quality control measurements,
that's our charts,

406
00:20:30,988 --> 00:20:34,630
our measurements that we made,
that data that we output.

407
00:20:34,630 --> 00:20:36,450
Any validated changes.

408
00:20:36,450 --> 00:20:38,480
We looked at the changes
that were requested.

409
00:20:38,480 --> 00:20:39,460
We've implemented.

410
00:20:39,460 --> 00:20:41,450
We made sure that they were done properly.

411
00:20:42,550 --> 00:20:44,450
Our verified deliverables.

412
00:20:44,450 --> 00:20:46,440
We got deliverables back here.

413
00:20:46,440 --> 00:20:50,490
Now, that we ran quality control against
them to make sure they met our needs,

414
00:20:50,490 --> 00:20:53,820
they met the requirements and
they fell within our tolerances then,

415
00:20:53,820 --> 00:20:55,510

00:20:55,510 --> 00:20:59,310
Now, they're good and
they're ready to go to scope validation.

Scope validation wants those

00:21:03,300 --> 00:21:05,140
Our work performance information, WPI.

419
00:21:05,140 --> 00:21:06,370
We've mentioned that many times.

00:21:06,370 --> 00:21:11,420
It's just our interpreted results based

421
00:21:11,420 --> 00:21:14,660
Work performance data being just for
a particular period of time.

422
00:21:14,660 --> 00:21:17,500
Work performance information
usually being trends over time.

423
00:21:19,040 --> 00:21:22,920
Change requests, we may have to generate
new change requests based on the result

424
00:21:22,920 --> 00:21:25,530
of the quality of
the information that we found.

425
00:21:25,530 --> 00:21:28,900
You start to notice these defects and

426
00:21:28,900 --> 00:21:30,400
After that, it's just paperwork.

Those are just changes to our paperwork

00:21:43,980 --> 00:21:48,490
Controlling quality, like I said,

It is a lot of work but
it's really just applying those checks and

00:21:51,960 --> 00:21:54,420

Definitely, for the exam, you definitely

00:21:58,100 --> 00:22:01,860
Because they show up in planning quality

Three separate process areas, so

Ronnie, I think that about

>> Nope, just kinda remember that for

quality really is about, hey, we're
about to finish the final product here.

00:22:19,792 --> 00:22:22,920
We wanna make sure that our stakeholders
are pleased with what's actually gonna

end up happening.

We can't be the project manager that says,

we'll just accept whatever

We've got to actually make sure that this

particular process in itself is
where our stakeholders are gonna

00:22:36,830 --> 00:22:39,810
be really happy with whatever we

00:23:35,110 --> 00:23:37,850
So, our inputs here

Our project management plan,

00:23:51,870 --> 00:23:54,700

It's either one, people complaining

We're going to do daily status updates and

we're gonna do other

And they say, you know what just send

00:24:22,090 --> 00:24:24,800

It's kind of a waste.

Or, I've been going to the meetings and

00:24:29,780 --> 00:24:32,480
Can I just not come to those,

00:24:32,480 --> 00:24:37,901
So we put those in the issue log and

495
00:24:37,901 --> 00:24:41,537
We'll talk about stakeholders a little bit
later, but when we make updates to our

496
00:24:41,537 --> 00:24:45,310

to reflect those new communications.

If people aren't getting enough data,

I wish you would have told me that.

00:24:49,570 --> 00:24:53,660
And you say, well, you know,
you asked to get a monthly summary.

00:24:53,660 --> 00:24:56,880
If you want a weekly or

00:24:56,880 --> 00:24:59,270
That goes in the issue log
to show that that happened.

502
00:24:59,270 --> 00:25:00,980
And then we make the changes
to make it happen.

503
00:25:00,980 --> 00:25:03,950
So that's why we need to
make sure we've got that.

504
00:25:03,950 --> 00:25:04,535
>> Yeah.

505
00:25:04,535 --> 00:25:07,825
This communication process also involves
that idea that the dominant is here in

506
00:25:07,825 --> 00:25:08,725
terms of timing.

507
00:25:09,755 --> 00:25:14,745
Because changes can happen very rapidly in
a project we have to make sure that we're

508
00:25:14,745 --> 00:25:18,805
controlling the communications lines
in terms of official communications and

509
00:25:18,805 --> 00:25:19,315
unofficial.

510
00:25:19,315 --> 00:25:22,875
We had mentioned this before that
sometimes these communications get

511
00:25:22,875 --> 00:25:24,280

00:25:24,280 --> 00:25:28,440
Where now business takes place in

00:25:28,440 --> 00:25:30,600
Were we supposed to act on that or not?

00:25:30,600 --> 00:25:34,350
Being able to control that, as well as
making sure we get the timely approvals,

515
00:25:34,350 --> 00:25:37,630
the timely, you know,
here's the change that actually happened.

516
00:25:37,630 --> 00:25:39,570
And all of a sudden somebody looks
at it and goes, when did it happen?

517
00:25:39,570 --> 00:25:41,620
Well, that's what this process is to do.

518
00:25:41,620 --> 00:25:43,840
Is to help us to ensure that
that stuff doesn't happen.

519
00:25:45,310 --> 00:25:49,540
>> Our tools and techniques are really

00:25:49,540 --> 00:25:51,470
Expert judgement, that's the main one.

Talking to people, so meetings

But your information management

And notice this time that this is

It's information management system not

00:26:05,760 --> 00:26:07,690
what they're talking about here is

00:26:08,760 --> 00:26:12,330

00:26:12,330 --> 00:26:15,290
Whatever it is your organization

00:26:15,290 --> 00:26:15,840
Right?

00:26:15,840 --> 00:26:17,860
That's your system, that's important.

So here at ITProTV, we actually,

And when I wanna send a notification to

00:26:36,260 --> 00:26:40,380
All right, and then our outputs,

Change requests are what I was alluding

You may not need to do

If you're just changing the notifications

But those will lead to updates to

But you'll also get some work

00:27:08,460 --> 00:27:12,405
Now this one's odd because normally,

00:27:13,895 --> 00:27:14,915

We've got our work performance data and

00:27:16,975 --> 00:27:19,685

But controlled communications,

00:27:32,880 --> 00:27:36,820
We're just making sure it runs

558
00:27:41,180 --> 00:27:43,380
Now that leads us to control risk.

559
00:27:43,380 --> 00:27:45,330
Control risk is our next process.

560
00:27:45,330 --> 00:27:49,340
And this is another one where,
if we've done all our planning and

561
00:27:49,340 --> 00:27:53,060
we've come up with every
possible risk that there was.

562
00:27:53,060 --> 00:27:56,990
This process will really just boil
down to following out whatever

563
00:27:56,990 --> 00:27:59,380

564
00:27:59,380 --> 00:28:01,640
With each risk we made a decision.

565
00:28:01,640 --> 00:28:05,530
We said all right, we are going to
mitigate the risk and try and reduce it.

566
00:28:05,530 --> 00:28:10,360
We're going to defer the risk and push it
onto somebody else, or transfer the risk,

567
00:28:10,360 --> 00:28:11,730
like buying insurance.

568
00:28:11,730 --> 00:28:15,510
We're going to accept the risk and
just let it happen.

569
00:28:15,510 --> 00:28:16,050
Right?

570
00:28:16,050 --> 00:28:18,310
But we plan for some kind of contingency.

571
00:28:18,310 --> 00:28:20,468
Some kind of reaction to that risk.

572
00:28:20,468 --> 00:28:25,030
The control risk process basically says,
you watch the risks, and

573
00:28:25,030 --> 00:28:28,240
if they happen,
you take whatever action you planned.

574
00:28:28,240 --> 00:28:29,990
You make that happen, right?

575
00:28:29,990 --> 00:28:31,500
You do that activity.

576
00:28:31,500 --> 00:28:36,430
If you didn't have a plan, if it was
a risk you didn't foresee, control risk is

577
00:28:36,430 --> 00:28:40,640
about coming up with a solution,
coming up with a reaction to that risk.

578
00:28:40,640 --> 00:28:43,360
To take advantage of it or
to try and eliminate it, right?

579
00:28:43,360 --> 00:28:45,370
Remember, you've got positive and
negative risks.

580
00:28:45,370 --> 00:28:48,710
It could be a good thing and
you want to take advantage of it.

581
00:28:48,710 --> 00:28:50,640
Control risk is where we do that.

582
00:28:50,640 --> 00:28:51,360
All right.

583
00:28:51,360 --> 00:28:54,190
Our main input here is
gonna be the risk register.

584
00:28:54,190 --> 00:28:57,380
We've got our project management plan cuz
it's got all the information on how we

585
00:28:57,380 --> 00:28:58,540
manage our risks.

586
00:28:58,540 --> 00:29:02,650
But the risk register itself is what lists
the risks that we need to be watching for,

587
00:29:02,650 --> 00:29:04,080
that's our monitoring part.

588
00:29:04,080 --> 00:29:08,670
And then it lists the actions to take if
they occur, that's the controlling part,

589
00:29:08,670 --> 00:29:10,450
right, monitoring and controlling.

590
00:29:10,450 --> 00:29:12,880
So that risk register is what
we're going to be monitoring and

591
00:29:12,880 --> 00:29:14,300
if you don't remember.

00:29:14,300 --> 00:29:22,120
Let me see if started my risk register
template, somewhere buried in here.

00:29:22,120 --> 00:29:23,790
It's in my show notes I am sure.

00:29:25,660 --> 00:29:29,380
We talked about our risk register and

00:29:29,380 --> 00:29:33,230
if I take a look at the risk register,

00:29:33,230 --> 00:29:34,690
how it effects things.

And then a response.

00:29:35,970 --> 00:29:36,550
Right?

599
00:29:36,550 --> 00:29:39,190
So we just use this as our little chart.

600
00:29:39,190 --> 00:29:40,640
So we're watching this and saying, okay,

601
00:29:40,640 --> 00:29:42,930
here's some risks,
let me just watch for them.

602
00:29:42,930 --> 00:29:46,080
And I'm updating my probabilities
over time to reflect

00:29:46,080 --> 00:29:49,070
whether that risk is more likely or
less likely to happen.

604
00:29:49,070 --> 00:29:52,720
If it does happen, here's my response.

605
00:29:52,720 --> 00:29:55,470
If we identify a new risk,
we're going to have to update this.

606
00:29:55,470 --> 00:29:58,010
We're going to have to update the risk
register to identify that and

607
00:29:58,010 --> 00:29:59,430
we're going to have to take the response.

608
00:29:59,430 --> 00:30:00,705
So we might do it after the fact, but

609
00:30:00,705 --> 00:30:03,686
it's always better to have a plan
in place before that happens.

610
00:30:03,686 --> 00:30:09,570
All right, so looking at control risks,

611
00:30:09,570 --> 00:30:12,620
that's the input side of things, right,
the data that we've already got.

612
00:30:12,620 --> 00:30:14,950
The tools and
techniques are pretty straightforward.

613
00:30:14,950 --> 00:30:16,350
Risk assessment, right?

614
00:30:16,350 --> 00:30:20,420
We need to look at the risks we
know about and reassess them.

615
00:30:20,420 --> 00:30:21,680
And you need to do it periodically.

616
00:30:21,680 --> 00:30:25,090
I know the example I keep using
is like an outdoor rock concert

617
00:30:25,090 --> 00:30:27,320
I know there's a chance it could rain.

618
00:30:27,320 --> 00:30:29,260
Six months before the show,

619
00:30:29,260 --> 00:30:31,805
I really don't know what the chance
of rain is gonna be like.

620
00:30:31,805 --> 00:30:35,080
There's rain season, so I can work
around that, but that's about it.

621
00:30:35,080 --> 00:30:38,820
As we get closer and closer though,
my data becomes more and more accurate.

622
00:30:38,820 --> 00:30:42,250
So I might be reassessing
that risk every single day.

623
00:30:42,250 --> 00:30:46,190
The day before the show I might be
reassessing that risk hour by hour, right?

624
00:30:46,190 --> 00:30:50,040
We're constantly reassessing the risk to
find out what are the odds of increased or

00:30:50,040 --> 00:30:54,390
decreased of that occurring so
we can start to mobilize our reaction.

626
00:30:56,300 --> 00:30:59,260
Risk audits are basically the same thing,
right?

627
00:30:59,260 --> 00:31:00,620
Reassessment, we go in and

00:31:00,620 --> 00:31:04,080
we change our various values to
reflect what's currently there.

629
00:31:04,080 --> 00:31:06,330
A risk audit is where we also try and

00:31:06,330 --> 00:31:10,830
identify unforseen risks, risks that
didn't make it in the risk register.

631
00:31:10,830 --> 00:31:14,510
It might be that this was a three
year project, and when we did our

00:31:14,510 --> 00:31:19,180
planning three years ago, there were
some things we just didn't know about.

633
00:31:19,180 --> 00:31:22,770
And now, a year and a half has gone by,

00:31:22,770 --> 00:31:24,010
Things have changed.

00:31:24,010 --> 00:31:25,610
And so now we have some new risks.

00:31:25,610 --> 00:31:28,250
They might be good risks,
risks that we can take advantage of.

00:31:28,250 --> 00:31:34,330
So in our audit we identify those new
risks and we get them added to the risk

00:31:34,330 --> 00:31:38,430
register and we come up with a response

00:31:38,430 --> 00:31:41,260
Now it might not result in any

00:31:41,260 --> 00:31:44,760
But it may, there may be actions

641
00:31:44,760 --> 00:31:47,076
>> Yeah.
And in this risk audit part as well,

642
00:31:47,076 --> 00:31:51,117
the response that we have as we actually
do go and deal with some particular risk

643
00:31:51,117 --> 00:31:55,423
data, take a look at what we actually did

00:31:55,423 --> 00:31:59,649
Or auditing it and saying, hey, was that
a effective response to something, or

00:31:59,649 --> 00:32:00,279
was it not?

646
00:32:00,279 --> 00:32:03,316
Now feeds back into the entire,
you know, processing in,

647
00:32:03,316 --> 00:32:04,911
in terms of controlling here.

648
00:32:04,911 --> 00:32:09,681
And, so we not only look at the risk and
what may happen to them also,

649
00:32:09,681 --> 00:32:13,487
how we responded so
that we can do it better next time.

650
00:32:13,487 --> 00:32:16,980
>> Now with the risk it's
not always cut and dry.

651
00:32:16,980 --> 00:32:21,810
I don't always know whether or not it's
gonna happen, on or off and that's it.

652
00:32:21,810 --> 00:32:26,020
So, I might need to monitor variance and
trend analysis, okay?

00:32:26,020 --> 00:32:29,550
There are certain things that
might contribute to that risk.

00:32:29,550 --> 00:32:32,710
So, here in the state of Florida,
we have hurricanes, or we used to.

00:32:32,710 --> 00:32:34,420

00:32:34,420 --> 00:32:40,250
We used to get nice, big, super

but the last like five years
we've kind of been without.

00:32:42,810 --> 00:32:43,770

So if we're planning a construction
project and we're gonna be doing

00:32:47,360 --> 00:32:52,010

00:32:52,010 --> 00:32:54,700
If I'm doing construction at that time

A hurricane at a minimum will

00:33:10,910 --> 00:33:14,130

If temperatures are at a certain level,

I can watch what's going on to try and

That's just one example, there's

For example, a strike.

00:34:09,370 --> 00:34:11,800
You might have an employee strike, right?

00:34:11,800 --> 00:34:15,290
Well, if there's an employee strike,

00:34:15,290 --> 00:34:18,870

Those labor disputes,

It's not like one day all of

Labor disputes like that arise

We can spot that,

Or, request for pay increase,

The amount of turnover you're having,

They usually are fairly visible,

So especially if you're

So, in a lot of cases

But, if there is gonna be a work

00:35:13,563 --> 00:35:16,064
That's a real risk that

00:35:18,108 --> 00:35:20,860

technical performance measurements.

Well, when we're dealing with risks.

Things like a weather risk, there's

Things that we can measure

00:35:30,370 --> 00:35:33,610
just technical things

00:35:33,610 --> 00:35:35,810
The word technical there,

This could come from any number of

00:35:48,300 --> 00:35:49,550

00:35:49,550 --> 00:35:52,630
We take that data that we get and

Then we've got our reserve analysis,

Money we don't plan on spending

When you have risks,

so you have 60 days

823
00:41:04,130 --> 00:41:08,870
after they perform to pay them the net,
the amount of money you owe them.

824
00:41:08,870 --> 00:41:11,462
Well, you need to make sure that happens.

825
00:41:11,462 --> 00:41:14,407
The work is done, we tick it off on our
list and say yeah, foundations done,

826
00:41:14,407 --> 00:41:15,820
let's move on.

827
00:41:15,820 --> 00:41:19,130
But there's still the contract associated
with it, we've got to pay out on that.

828
00:41:19,130 --> 00:41:22,830
So two sides of that is
very important to remember.

829
00:41:22,830 --> 00:41:25,960
We've got any agreements we
might have entered into because

830
00:41:25,960 --> 00:41:29,710
sometimes it might not be
an official legal contract.

831
00:41:29,710 --> 00:41:31,390
But there was an agreement nonetheless,

832
00:41:31,390 --> 00:41:34,740
maybe a close partnership with another
company or something that we're gonna deal

833
00:41:34,740 --> 00:41:37,840
with, we need to make sure we're
aware of those agreements.

834
00:41:37,840 --> 00:41:40,050
Any approved change requests that come in,

835
00:41:40,050 --> 00:41:44,260
because we might be acting on a contract
that has had a change to a clause in it.

836
00:41:44,260 --> 00:41:46,900
We need to be aware of that information.
