837
00:41:46,900 --> 00:41:50,760
Any work performance reports, that's how
we're gonna know what work has been done.

838
00:41:50,760 --> 00:41:55,370
And the work performance data itself so
all the status updates that we get.

839
00:41:55,370 --> 00:41:58,750
Those are all the inputs that
feed into control procurements.

840
00:41:58,750 --> 00:42:01,240
On the tools and techniques side
here's where we get to work.

841
00:42:01,240 --> 00:42:02,990
And remember what our main job here is.

842
00:42:02,990 --> 00:42:06,365
Our main job is to make sure that
the procurements are being executed

843
00:42:06,365 --> 00:42:07,315
as planned.

844
00:42:07,315 --> 00:42:10,525
That we are following through
with all the obligations and

845
00:42:10,525 --> 00:42:15,695
that the other side of the agreement, they
are also following through with the terms.

846
00:42:15,695 --> 00:42:17,432
So what are some of the things we use?

847
00:42:17,432 --> 00:42:19,962
Well there's the contract
change control system.

848
00:42:19,962 --> 00:42:24,690
When you enter to a contract there are
times when you needed to make changes and

849
00:42:24,690 --> 00:42:26,593
the changes can go either way.

850
00:42:26,593 --> 00:42:28,903
Maybe you contracted
a company to come in and

851
00:42:28,903 --> 00:42:33,087
lay a foundation the last week of July,
but your project starts to get behind and

852
00:42:33,087 --> 00:42:37,145
you say hey, guys, we're not gonna be
ready for you in the last week of July,

853
00:42:37,145 --> 00:42:41,120
but we don't want to negate the contract,
still a good contract.

854
00:42:41,120 --> 00:42:44,090
Can we just move it back a week or two?

855
00:42:44,090 --> 00:42:46,515
And if they say yes, no problem we
have some openings in the schedule,

856
00:42:46,515 --> 00:42:48,370
let's go ahead and move it no big deal.

857
00:42:48,370 --> 00:42:51,650
Both sides are amicable to the change so

858
00:42:51,650 --> 00:42:55,860
we go into our contract change control
system and we modify the terms then.

859
00:42:55,860 --> 00:43:00,430
Now, there's several different levels of
changes that can happen with a contract.

860
00:43:00,430 --> 00:43:06,030
Some can be really drastic, like when
we negate the contract as a whole.

861
00:43:06,030 --> 00:43:09,810
When there's been a violation of the terms
of the contract or something like that.

862
00:43:09,810 --> 00:43:12,400
But there's also a lot
that are just procedural.

863
00:43:12,400 --> 00:43:16,390
Maybe on the contract it has a billing
address and it says, we're supposed to

864
00:43:16,390 --> 00:43:20,940
send a monthly payment while the work
is being done, to this address.

865
00:43:20,940 --> 00:43:24,300
And then the other side says,
well we're actually moving buildings.

866
00:43:24,300 --> 00:43:27,460
And so now, we have a PO Box, so we
need you guys to send the payment there.

867
00:43:28,670 --> 00:43:31,270
We're not changing how
much you've got to pay,

868
00:43:31,270 --> 00:43:34,260
we're not changing when the work is gonna
get done, we're not changing what work is

869
00:43:34,260 --> 00:43:37,880
getting done, we're just changing
where you mail the bill to.

870
00:43:37,880 --> 00:43:42,620
So that's not a significant change
to the contract, it's a minor thing.

871
00:43:42,620 --> 00:43:44,960
So we go in and we update that.

872
00:43:44,960 --> 00:43:47,060
We need to have a change
control system for

873
00:43:47,060 --> 00:43:51,450
the contract but be careful,
sometimes changes can be really bad.

874
00:43:51,450 --> 00:43:55,550
Maybe the people who are laying
the foundation quoted this one price and

875
00:43:55,550 --> 00:43:57,980
as they get to work they say,
you know what?

876
00:43:57,980 --> 00:43:59,890
It's actually gonna be more expensive.

877
00:43:59,890 --> 00:44:04,540
Well, if they can justify why and
we understand then we take care of them.

878
00:44:04,540 --> 00:44:08,650
But it's just more expensive cuz
they did a bad quote to win the bid.

879
00:44:08,650 --> 00:44:09,600
That's their own fault-
>> Yeah.

880
00:44:09,600 --> 00:44:11,070
>> And you need to say, I'm sorry guys.

881
00:44:11,070 --> 00:44:13,370
You quoted me this price.

882
00:44:13,370 --> 00:44:15,533
I realize that you guys are having
a problem doing it, but

883
00:44:15,533 --> 00:44:17,753
you shouldn't have bid that
price if you couldn't do it.

884
00:44:17,753 --> 00:44:19,087
So get to work.

885
00:44:19,087 --> 00:44:19,620
Right?

886
00:44:19,620 --> 00:44:22,506
We need to make sure that
we weigh the pros and

887
00:44:22,506 --> 00:44:26,736
cons of all of that when we deal
with the changes to the contract.

888
00:44:26,736 --> 00:44:29,062
So that's an important thing and Ronnie,

889
00:44:29,062 --> 00:44:32,160
you added some of this
stuff into the notes.

890
00:44:32,160 --> 00:44:35,960
In that contract change control system
you have got the paperwork itself,

891
00:44:35,960 --> 00:44:39,425
tracking systems to make sure
that things are being done.

892
00:44:39,425 --> 00:44:41,815
Dispute resolution procedures.

893
00:44:42,955 --> 00:44:48,185
There are times when terms of the contract
could be interpreted more than one way.

894
00:44:48,185 --> 00:44:48,707
It shouldn't happen, right?

895
00:44:48,707 --> 00:44:49,316
>> Right.

896
00:44:49,316 --> 00:44:55,380
>> Contracts should be written in a very
straightforward, non-debatable manner.

897
00:44:55,380 --> 00:44:59,520
But if there is a debate and if there's
a dispute, how do we settle that?

898
00:44:59,520 --> 00:45:03,581
Disputes normally center around
when the contract is done.

899
00:45:03,581 --> 00:45:06,159
And the one side says, hey we're
finished and the other side says no,

900
00:45:06,159 --> 00:45:07,524
you still have this, this and this.

901
00:45:07,524 --> 00:45:11,720
And the second side says well no,
actually we did what the contract stated.

902
00:45:11,720 --> 00:45:13,580
That stuff you're asking for is extra.

903
00:45:13,580 --> 00:45:17,280
Now, we get into a dispute so we need
to have a dispute resolution procedure.

904
00:45:17,280 --> 00:45:20,410
And that needs to be agreed upon
before the contract is executed,

905
00:45:20,410 --> 00:45:21,790
before we sign off on it.

906
00:45:21,790 --> 00:45:25,740
So if that wasn't put in place you
can end up having to go to court,

907
00:45:25,740 --> 00:45:26,460
that does happen.

908
00:45:26,460 --> 00:45:26,960
>> Yep.

909
00:45:28,450 --> 00:45:33,030
>> And then who has to sign
off to authorize a change?

910
00:45:33,030 --> 00:45:37,020
Any change to the contract needs
to be signed off by both parties.

911
00:45:37,020 --> 00:45:40,040
But who within those parties
has the authority to do it?

912
00:45:41,120 --> 00:45:43,880
As a project manager you may or
may not have signing authority for

913
00:45:43,880 --> 00:45:46,330
your company to enter
into binding contracts.

914
00:45:46,330 --> 00:45:48,260
We see this with government
contracts a lot.

915
00:45:48,260 --> 00:45:52,331
Sure, you might be the department head for
your department but to sign a contract on

916
00:45:52,331 --> 00:45:54,672
behalf of the US government-
>> [LAUGH]

917
00:45:54,672 --> 00:45:56,400
>> You might not have that authority.

918
00:45:56,400 --> 00:45:58,910
So we need to make sure we
identify who those people are.

919
00:45:58,910 --> 00:45:59,660
So that we know hey,

920
00:45:59,660 --> 00:46:03,820
changes can't occur without these people
being involved in that process to make

921
00:46:03,820 --> 00:46:07,360
sure we've got that gatekeeper to make
sure we're not making bad changes.

922
00:46:09,890 --> 00:46:11,970
There are a lot of other tools and

923
00:46:11,970 --> 00:46:15,690
techniques built into
procurement management.

924
00:46:15,690 --> 00:46:18,150
Things like our procurement
performance reviews.

925
00:46:18,150 --> 00:46:21,310
This really just kind of
goes with monitoring.

926
00:46:21,310 --> 00:46:24,160
When we sign on somebody for
a contract and

927
00:46:24,160 --> 00:46:27,520
they say they're gonna lay
a foundation the last week of July,

928
00:46:27,520 --> 00:46:31,440
we should probably be watching each
day in July to see what happens.

929
00:46:31,440 --> 00:46:35,290
I remember we moved into this building,
the building where the studio is.

930
00:46:35,290 --> 00:46:39,980
When we first purchased this building
the construction guys were here

931
00:46:39,980 --> 00:46:42,220
every single day,
lots of work getting done.

932
00:46:42,220 --> 00:46:45,360
We saw walls coming up one day and
doors going in and things so

933
00:46:45,360 --> 00:46:46,920
there was a lot of stuff happening.

934
00:46:46,920 --> 00:46:48,710
We would come by each day and look.

935
00:46:48,710 --> 00:46:51,115
And there was one day that we came by and
the place was empty.

936
00:46:51,115 --> 00:46:52,740
>> [LAUGH]
>> Nobody was here.

937
00:46:52,740 --> 00:46:53,640
And the next day we came by and

938
00:46:53,640 --> 00:46:58,740
it was empty, and three days in a row this
place was just empty, no work happened.

939
00:46:58,740 --> 00:47:02,860
And so we called up the PM and
we said hey, what is going on?

940
00:47:02,860 --> 00:47:04,030
No work is happening and he said,

941
00:47:04,030 --> 00:47:07,710
well we've got another project going on,
and it's falling behind.

942
00:47:07,710 --> 00:47:09,690
So I pulled the guys from your project and

943
00:47:09,690 --> 00:47:12,080
moved them over there to get
that one caught up to speed.

944
00:47:13,260 --> 00:47:16,750
But that project is finishing so
when it's done,

945
00:47:16,750 --> 00:47:20,480
we'll take both of those teams and bring
it back over here to get back up to speed.

946
00:47:20,480 --> 00:47:25,655
Now, at the end of the day that meant
that we had three days of inactivity.

947
00:47:25,655 --> 00:47:28,270
But we were still gonna
come in at the deadline.

948
00:47:28,270 --> 00:47:31,080
So we talked about it and
we're like that's okay, but

949
00:47:31,080 --> 00:47:33,220
remember you got your
deadline you got to meet,

950
00:47:33,220 --> 00:47:38,000
I'm sorry your other project left behind
but ours doesn't need to suffer for that.

951
00:47:38,000 --> 00:47:41,650
Well at the end of the day, they brought
the extra people back over here and

952
00:47:41,650 --> 00:47:43,870
sure enough, they got done on deadline.

953
00:47:43,870 --> 00:47:46,402
Very much unlike our last building-
>> [LAUGH]

954
00:47:46,402 --> 00:47:48,392
>> This building we moved into on time,

955
00:47:48,392 --> 00:47:51,355
the building we used to be in,
we were a year and a half-

956
00:47:51,355 --> 00:47:52,067
>> Yeah.

957
00:47:52,067 --> 00:47:52,680
>> Behind on that one?

958
00:47:52,680 --> 00:47:53,921
That one was a mess.

959
00:47:53,921 --> 00:47:56,936
There were some permit
issues with that building.

960
00:47:56,936 --> 00:47:58,481
And yeah, it was a mess.

961
00:47:58,481 --> 00:47:59,896
So things like that happen and

962
00:47:59,896 --> 00:48:01,219
they need to be addressed-
>> Right.

963
00:48:01,219 --> 00:48:03,466
>> And they need to be
addressed in a timely manner.

964
00:48:03,466 --> 00:48:07,354
I find that often times contract disputes
can be resolved if you just talk to

965
00:48:07,354 --> 00:48:07,854
people.

966
00:48:07,854 --> 00:48:09,317
Open your communications.

967
00:48:09,317 --> 00:48:13,807
Never assume that the other
side is thinking one thing.

968
00:48:13,807 --> 00:48:16,687
When this place was empty for three days,
I could have assumed like oh,

969
00:48:16,687 --> 00:48:17,550
they've given up.

970
00:48:17,550 --> 00:48:19,290
They're just gonna take our money and run.

971
00:48:19,290 --> 00:48:21,260
But they had all ready made plans.

972
00:48:21,260 --> 00:48:24,770
They had all ready designed
to address the issue.

973
00:48:24,770 --> 00:48:27,050
I just needed to know that, right?

974
00:48:27,050 --> 00:48:29,830
So, that's what we deal with
inspections and audits,

975
00:48:29,830 --> 00:48:31,010
that's also a part of that, right?

976
00:48:31,010 --> 00:48:32,920
Yeah.
Going and inspecting the work sites,

977
00:48:32,920 --> 00:48:34,530
auditing what's being done,

978
00:48:34,530 --> 00:48:37,440
ensuring that the terms of
the contract are being followed.

979
00:48:39,070 --> 00:48:42,780
All right, performance reporting, right,
falls right along in that same side.

980
00:48:42,780 --> 00:48:45,590
Performance reporting is a little bit
different because what we're doing

981
00:48:45,590 --> 00:48:48,760
is we're measuring their
performance against something else.

982
00:48:48,760 --> 00:48:50,892
Either someone else has done
the same work before or

983
00:48:50,892 --> 00:48:53,520
some kind of milestones that
we've established, they should

984
00:48:53,520 --> 00:48:56,513
have achieved in each period and
seeing whether or not they have hit it.

985
00:48:56,513 --> 00:48:59,190
So, have they been
hitting their milestones?

986
00:48:59,190 --> 00:49:03,110
If they fall behind on one but then they
make it up when they jump into the next

987
00:49:03,110 --> 00:49:06,380
one, then we're okay, but
if it's consistent with falling behind

988
00:49:06,380 --> 00:49:09,970
then we know the end of the contract is
not going to finish on time, and if it

989
00:49:09,970 --> 00:49:14,920
deviates enough, you may have grounds
to terminate the contract early and

990
00:49:14,920 --> 00:49:19,010
say look, you guys are beyond the point
where you can finish this work on time,

991
00:49:19,010 --> 00:49:21,800
we need to end this contract,
we'll bring somebody else in to finish.

992
00:49:23,820 --> 00:49:27,040
All right, some of the other things that
we have in here are pretty shaped or

993
00:49:27,040 --> 00:49:28,890
payment systems, right?

994
00:49:28,890 --> 00:49:29,950
We need to pay these people.

995
00:49:29,950 --> 00:49:32,330
They're are coming and doing work for
us, they need to get compensated,

996
00:49:32,330 --> 00:49:33,660
we need to pay them.

997
00:49:33,660 --> 00:49:37,620
If you're one of those Project managers
that has ultimate authority, you've

998
00:49:37,620 --> 00:49:41,030
got control of the bank accounts, and
you cut the checks,then great, you do it.

999
00:49:41,030 --> 00:49:44,050
Most of the times,
we deal with our Accounting department.

1000
00:49:44,050 --> 00:49:46,880
We have accounts payable and receivable
and all that stuff that we deal with.

1001
00:49:46,880 --> 00:49:49,320
So, we reach out to them and
issue payments.

1002
00:49:49,320 --> 00:49:51,680
We authorize payment out to our vendors.

1003
00:49:51,680 --> 00:49:53,220
So that's a payment system, and

1004
00:49:53,220 --> 00:49:56,100
that's going to be a big part
of Control Procurements.

1005
00:49:56,100 --> 00:49:59,300
We need to make sure that
we're paying on time, right?

1006
00:49:59,300 --> 00:50:03,140
These people did work for us, so we need
to make sure that they're compensated.

1007
00:50:03,140 --> 00:50:06,745
If they aren't, if we don't pay them in
a timely manner, what are they gonna do?

1008
00:50:06,745 --> 00:50:08,349
They're gonna start working, and

1009
00:50:08,349 --> 00:50:10,924
that means other parts of our
project is going to suffer.

1010
00:50:12,942 --> 00:50:15,230
All right, Claims Administration.

1011
00:50:15,230 --> 00:50:18,930
This is a part that gets overlooked,
but it's important.

1012
00:50:18,930 --> 00:50:23,720
In a project where we've got contracts,
the contracts are a legal obligation for

1013
00:50:23,720 --> 00:50:25,000
the parties to do things.

1014
00:50:25,000 --> 00:50:26,200
We are obligated to pay.

1015
00:50:26,200 --> 00:50:29,870
They are obligated to do things that
we specified in the statement of work.

1016
00:50:29,870 --> 00:50:34,910
If there's ever a dispute, and
it goes beyond what can be agreed

1017
00:50:34,910 --> 00:50:39,420
to just through speaking,
we need a way to handle claims, right?

1018
00:50:39,420 --> 00:50:41,570
Actually filing for penalties.

1019
00:50:41,570 --> 00:50:46,390
So, if it's the contractor
that is doing the dispute,

1020
00:50:46,390 --> 00:50:51,180
we're not paying them,
they may assess penalties and say, well,

1021
00:50:51,180 --> 00:50:56,330
you've gotta pay me 1% interest for
each day that you don't pay debt, right?

1022
00:50:56,330 --> 00:51:00,710
And so now, as a penalty on top of it,
if we continue to resist,

1023
00:51:00,710 --> 00:51:05,720
then they can take it to court and
sue us for damages and the unpaid amount.

1024
00:51:05,720 --> 00:51:08,770
So that's all part of
Claims Administration.

1025
00:51:08,770 --> 00:51:12,000
We need to be watching for that when one
of our vendors submits a claim to us

1026
00:51:12,000 --> 00:51:13,610
saying hey, you guys haven't paid us.

1027
00:51:13,610 --> 00:51:16,580
We need to make sure that gets handled and
there needs to be a process for that.

1028
00:51:16,580 --> 00:51:19,910
When you have a split responsibilities,
it's really easy for

1029
00:51:19,910 --> 00:51:22,150
a project manager to reach out
to the accounting department and

1030
00:51:22,150 --> 00:51:23,900
say hey,
I need you guys to pay this bill here.

1031
00:51:23,900 --> 00:51:25,230
Take it, it's authorized by me.

1032
00:51:25,230 --> 00:51:27,070
I sign off on it, all right?

1033
00:51:27,070 --> 00:51:29,550
But, what if we don't follow up?

1034
00:51:29,550 --> 00:51:30,050
We
>> Yeah.

1035
00:51:30,050 --> 00:51:31,770
>> assume that person in accounting is

1036
00:51:31,770 --> 00:51:33,450
going to pay that bill, but did they?

1037
00:51:33,450 --> 00:51:34,550
We need to follow up.

1038
00:51:34,550 --> 00:51:36,920
We need to do that as part of
our Claims Administration.

1039
00:51:36,920 --> 00:51:39,940
We need to go and check, wait a few
days or a week and you go back and say,

1040
00:51:39,940 --> 00:51:42,650
okay, Ddd you actually
send out that payment?

1041
00:51:42,650 --> 00:51:46,400
I need you to give me a photocopy of the
check whenever you send a check out for

1042
00:51:46,400 --> 00:51:48,170
one of these things,
that way I can add it to my records so

1043
00:51:48,170 --> 00:51:50,230
I know that it was actually done.

1044
00:51:50,230 --> 00:51:53,050
And I need to know what date it was
mailed out so I have a record of that.

1045
00:51:53,050 --> 00:51:57,270
Or maybe you wanna send it as a registered
mail, something with a tracking number.

1046
00:51:57,270 --> 00:52:00,120
Again, same thing, just so you can
show that it was actually delivered.

1047
00:52:00,120 --> 00:52:03,050
This is all part of follow through to make
sure we don't get to that point where we

1048
00:52:03,050 --> 00:52:03,960
have to deal with claims.

1049
00:52:05,760 --> 00:52:08,850
And then our Records Management System
is extremely important.

1050
00:52:08,850 --> 00:52:13,460
You should be recording every expense
throughout your project, every contract

1051
00:52:13,460 --> 00:52:16,880
within your project and that's because
we need to make sure it's terminated.

1052
00:52:16,880 --> 00:52:20,920
We're going to talk about the closing
process in the next episode, and

1053
00:52:20,920 --> 00:52:25,580
a part of that is making sure that all of
our contracts are completely resolved,

1054
00:52:25,580 --> 00:52:30,340
that all of the liabilities and
requirements inside of the contract have

1055
00:52:30,340 --> 00:52:34,070
been addressed, and that it's over, and
that both sides agree that it's closed.

1056
00:52:34,070 --> 00:52:35,940
Well, your
Records Management System is what

1057
00:52:35,940 --> 00:52:37,720
gives us the information to show that.

1058
00:52:37,720 --> 00:52:39,370
We see that all the work has been done,

1059
00:52:39,370 --> 00:52:42,680
we see that all the bills have been paid,
contract is over, right?

1060
00:52:42,680 --> 00:52:45,260
We wouldn't know that unless
we had our paper trail.

1061
00:52:45,260 --> 00:52:47,170
And if there's a dispute,
if we've send out a payment and

1062
00:52:47,170 --> 00:52:48,400
they say, you guys are late.

1063
00:52:48,400 --> 00:52:49,480
You didn't pay us.

1064
00:52:49,480 --> 00:52:51,900
We can say, well,
here's the wire transfer information,

1065
00:52:51,900 --> 00:52:55,460
I've got it right here,
it was sent, your bank accepted it.

1066
00:52:55,460 --> 00:52:56,980
Well, what's the deal?

1067
00:52:56,980 --> 00:52:59,990
Or we got a cancelled check back that
shows you guys cashed the check and

1068
00:52:59,990 --> 00:53:01,110
you're gonna tell us you didn't get paid?

1069
00:53:01,110 --> 00:53:02,880
We've got that paperwork.

1070
00:53:02,880 --> 00:53:04,650
Otherwise we just have to act on faith.

1071
00:53:04,650 --> 00:53:07,870
All right, I guess we didn't pay you,
let's go cut a second check.

1072
00:53:07,870 --> 00:53:09,889
There we start to have some problems.

1073
00:53:11,490 --> 00:53:14,020
Alright, so
that's what an RMS provides in control.

1074
00:53:15,772 --> 00:53:17,680
All right,
the last parts here are just our Outputs.

1075
00:53:17,680 --> 00:53:22,910
Our outputs, hopefully, are not much,
it's just executing the contract, right?

1076
00:53:22,910 --> 00:53:25,840
So our output really should
just be payment paperwork, so

1077
00:53:25,840 --> 00:53:29,150
that's going to be part of our
project document update and so on.

1078
00:53:29,150 --> 00:53:32,440
But there may be other things our
work performance information, right?

1079
00:53:32,440 --> 00:53:35,640
We're showing that parts of that
contract have been resolved,

1080
00:53:35,640 --> 00:53:36,420
that they've been done.

1081
00:53:36,420 --> 00:53:38,540
So, we're showing that
performance information.

1082
00:53:38,540 --> 00:53:41,870
We've got our change request in the event
that any modifications happen from our

1083
00:53:41,870 --> 00:53:44,040
Contract Change Control System.

1084
00:53:44,040 --> 00:53:47,640
Then, it just updates to our regular
documents, like we've seen in darn near

1085
00:53:47,640 --> 00:53:50,360
every [LAUGH] process here in
monitoring and controlling.

1086
00:53:52,630 --> 00:53:55,430
>> Remember that for
us here in procurement, right?

1087
00:53:55,430 --> 00:53:58,460
The reason that we don't want to be,
make sure that we're actually on top of

1088
00:53:58,460 --> 00:54:02,610
everything here, is because it is a legal
requirement that we are fulfilling.

1089
00:54:02,610 --> 00:54:06,080
Not only to our contractors but
they're fulfilling to us and so

1090
00:54:06,080 --> 00:54:09,240
you just making quick changes and
deciding that, hey,

1091
00:54:09,240 --> 00:54:11,210
things are going to go this
way instead of that way.

1092
00:54:11,210 --> 00:54:13,830
It can lead to more
damage than you realize.

1093
00:54:13,830 --> 00:54:15,140
So, make sure you are on top of this.

1094
00:54:15,140 --> 00:54:18,020
Make sure you're actually fulfilling
those obligations that you need to.

1095
00:54:18,020 --> 00:54:19,107
This is where we ask you to control that.

1096
00:54:19,107 --> 00:54:20,163
>> Yeah.
Absolutely.

1097
00:54:20,163 --> 00:54:21,453
All right.

1098
00:54:21,453 --> 00:54:23,905
Now, the last process we
have in Monitoring and

1099
00:54:23,905 --> 00:54:26,799
Controlling is
Controlling Stakeholder Engagement.

1100
00:54:27,880 --> 00:54:31,280
And this is simply keeping
an eye on our stakeholders and

1101
00:54:31,280 --> 00:54:33,410
how they're interacting with our project.

1102
00:54:33,410 --> 00:54:35,390
The number one way we do this
is through communications.

1103
00:54:35,390 --> 00:54:37,330
We've already talked about communications.

1104
00:54:37,330 --> 00:54:41,800
But, what about when there's a change,
when they want more information, or

1105
00:54:41,800 --> 00:54:46,370
when they want to modify the project and
we're typically talking about our

1106
00:54:46,370 --> 00:54:49,860
sponsor here, our key stakeholder that
we're trying to manage with them.

1107
00:54:49,860 --> 00:54:52,550
But it could be any of our
stakeholders for that matter.

1108
00:54:52,550 --> 00:54:56,310
Now a lot of this we've already addressed
in our Project Management Plan,

1109
00:54:56,310 --> 00:54:59,755
we've got information [INAUDIBLE] that
states how each of our stakeholders needs

1110
00:54:59,755 --> 00:55:00,785
to be handled.

1111
00:55:00,785 --> 00:55:03,655
Whether they are risk averse or
whatever, you know?

1112
00:55:03,655 --> 00:55:06,335
All that stuff that we kind of set
up way back in the planning phase.

1113
00:55:06,335 --> 00:55:09,785
So, that's one of our key inputs
is to get that information.

1114
00:55:09,785 --> 00:55:14,735
Our issue log, if any of our
stakeholders has an issue, a request,

1115
00:55:14,735 --> 00:55:18,810
it's usually gonna go in the issue log
first, and so that's our next input.

1116
00:55:18,810 --> 00:55:21,330
Our work performance data and
our project documents, right,

1117
00:55:21,330 --> 00:55:23,610
all standard stuff to bring in for inputs.

1118
00:55:24,690 --> 00:55:27,150
Now, what we do from there
is kind of up to us.

1119
00:55:27,150 --> 00:55:29,480
It depends on which stakeholder
it is that we're addressing and

1120
00:55:29,480 --> 00:55:31,410
what their main grievance is.

1121
00:55:31,410 --> 00:55:34,020
Our main thing is just our
Information Management System, right?

1122
00:55:34,020 --> 00:55:36,210
This is normally dealing
with Communications.

1123
00:55:37,230 --> 00:55:39,940
They want the information
we need to provide it.

1124
00:55:39,940 --> 00:55:42,940
We've already got
a communication management plan,

1125
00:55:42,940 --> 00:55:45,980
I mean a control communications process,

1126
00:55:45,980 --> 00:55:49,510
so why do we need a control stakeholder
engagement, what if it's the same.

1127
00:55:49,510 --> 00:55:52,890
Well, this is really talking
about one off requests.

1128
00:55:52,890 --> 00:55:56,872
It is not uncommon for
your project sponsor to come down and say,

1129
00:55:56,872 --> 00:56:00,063
can you give me a report for
this, this, and this?

1130
00:56:00,063 --> 00:56:02,828
And it's not something we established
in our communications plan, and

1131
00:56:02,828 --> 00:56:05,924
is not even something we're going to do
again, it's more like a one time thing.

1132
00:56:05,924 --> 00:56:06,752
This one time,

1133
00:56:06,752 --> 00:56:10,515
they need to get this particular
report that shows some information.

1134
00:56:10,515 --> 00:56:14,020
But we get it here at
IT pro tv all the time.

1135
00:56:14,020 --> 00:56:15,610
Tim one of the gentlemen
here at the office.

1136
00:56:15,610 --> 00:56:19,650
He'll come back and he'll want some
kind of utilization numbers like,

1137
00:56:19,650 --> 00:56:22,640
hey can you guys generate some
kind of report that shows how many

1138
00:56:22,640 --> 00:56:26,250
people are viewing the site from
internet explorer eight, right?

1139
00:56:26,250 --> 00:56:27,824
Which is one of our banes.

1140
00:56:27,824 --> 00:56:30,530
[LAUGH] So then we go and
we generate a report on that, and

1141
00:56:30,530 --> 00:56:33,180
it's not something we normally do,
we don't normally worry about that,

1142
00:56:33,180 --> 00:56:35,900
but that one time we need that report for
it, right?

1143
00:56:35,900 --> 00:56:39,050
So the control stakeholder engagement
process is really designed for

1144
00:56:39,050 --> 00:56:42,260
those situations, where we go,
and we gather that data.

1145
00:56:42,260 --> 00:56:44,490
We don't want to tell them no,
no, that's not in the plan,

1146
00:56:44,490 --> 00:56:46,850
I'm not gonna make that report,
forget you, right?

1147
00:56:46,850 --> 00:56:48,950
You wanna [LAUGH] take
care of your stakeholders.

1148
00:56:48,950 --> 00:56:50,830
So you wanna give them that information.

1149
00:56:50,830 --> 00:56:53,530
But you shouldn't have to go and
do a bunch of change tickets and so

1150
00:56:53,530 --> 00:56:54,870
on just to provide that.

1151
00:56:54,870 --> 00:56:57,090
Especially if it's just
simple report gathering.

1152
00:56:57,090 --> 00:56:59,200
So that's where this process comes from.

1153
00:56:59,200 --> 00:57:02,600
We have our information management system,
we gather our data,

1154
00:57:02,600 --> 00:57:05,290
we distribute it using email, whatever.

1155
00:57:05,290 --> 00:57:08,370
We use our expert judgement to get the
information we're looking for and we may

1156
00:57:08,370 --> 00:57:12,720
need to use meetings to gather people
together again, to get that information.

1157
00:57:12,720 --> 00:57:16,890
We wanna make sure this is done in
a way that doesn't derail the project.

1158
00:57:16,890 --> 00:57:17,980
But if it is.

1159
00:57:17,980 --> 00:57:20,360
If it's a big report,
it's gonna cost money.

1160
00:57:20,360 --> 00:57:23,630
It's gonna take more time then
that's where one of our outputs

1161
00:57:23,630 --> 00:57:24,427
is a change request, right?

1162
00:57:25,640 --> 00:57:29,435
In order to do what they're asking,
if we can do it within the means

1163
00:57:29,435 --> 00:57:32,405
of our project without derailing
anything we should do it.

1164
00:57:32,405 --> 00:57:37,165
Take care of your stakeholders because
they're the reason you have a job, but

1165
00:57:37,165 --> 00:57:39,405
if it's going to require extra money,
extra effort,

1166
00:57:39,405 --> 00:57:41,915
extra resources,
you've got to do a change ticket.

1167
00:57:41,915 --> 00:57:44,972
If they they want that they've
got to be willing to pay for it.

1168
00:57:44,972 --> 00:57:47,902
They are going to pay for
it in terms of either out right money,

1169
00:57:47,902 --> 00:57:52,972
it is going to cost more on the budget or
our other ones, time, it is going to take

1170
00:57:52,972 --> 00:57:56,782
longer to complete the project because
of this information they've requested.

1171
00:57:56,782 --> 00:57:59,772
Or thirdly, we might have to
eliminate some requirements.

1172
00:57:59,772 --> 00:58:02,662
Bump a few requirements often make
time to generate this additional

1173
00:58:02,662 --> 00:58:04,942
information they are asking for.

1174
00:58:04,942 --> 00:58:06,759
All three of those would
result in change requests.

1175
00:58:08,190 --> 00:58:11,010
But typically it's just work performance
information they're looking for, so

1176
00:58:11,010 --> 00:58:13,180
we generate that data and
we give it to them.

1177
00:58:13,180 --> 00:58:16,660
There might be updates or
other documentation updates to show that.

1178
00:58:16,660 --> 00:58:20,050
At a minimum, you wanna put
an entry in issue log that says

1179
00:58:20,050 --> 00:58:23,260
this is something that they requested,
so that was one of our inputs.

1180
00:58:23,260 --> 00:58:27,090
But, going forward, you also want
to keep track of that report.

1181
00:58:27,090 --> 00:58:31,100
If they say, we want this report all
of the time, not just this week, but

1182
00:58:31,100 --> 00:58:32,260
let's do it for the rest of the project.

1183
00:58:32,260 --> 00:58:34,060
From now on,
I want to get this report every week.

1184
00:58:34,060 --> 00:58:35,220
Well, then, we've got to go and

1185
00:58:35,220 --> 00:58:38,470
update our communications
management plan and all of those.

1186
00:58:38,470 --> 00:58:41,780
To show this new report, who should
get it, how they should get it, and

1187
00:58:41,780 --> 00:58:43,910
all of that information.

1188
00:58:43,910 --> 00:58:47,050
Just remember for the exam that this
process, this control stakeholder

1189
00:58:47,050 --> 00:58:51,050
engagement, really similar to
control communications, right.

1190
00:58:51,050 --> 00:58:52,220
In fact, if I flip between them,

1191
00:58:52,220 --> 00:58:55,590
you'll notice there's only a few
little changes between the two.

1192
00:58:55,590 --> 00:58:58,570
The Tools & Techniques and
Outputs are actually identical.

1193
00:58:58,570 --> 00:58:59,430
The inputs.

1194
00:58:59,430 --> 00:59:01,430
Actually the inputs
are a little bit different.

1195
00:59:01,430 --> 00:59:03,330
We've got our project
communications there.

1196
00:59:03,330 --> 00:59:05,940
But they're almost identical.

1197
00:59:05,940 --> 00:59:08,550
The stakeholder and
various engagement is really designed for

1198
00:59:08,550 --> 00:59:11,450
those one off times where that
stakeholder comes to you looking for

1199
00:59:11,450 --> 00:59:14,360
information or
other data about the project.

1200
00:59:14,360 --> 00:59:15,640
And you're interacting with them.

1201
00:59:15,640 --> 00:59:19,639
So that's what this
process is geared towards.

1202
00:59:19,639 --> 00:59:20,240
>> Yep.

1203
00:59:20,240 --> 00:59:22,340
>> Well with those,

1204
00:59:22,340 --> 00:59:27,580
we've now seen the processes involved in
the monitoring and controlling phase.

1205
00:59:27,580 --> 00:59:30,890
Most, whoops as I just
jump all over the place.

1206
00:59:30,890 --> 00:59:32,730
Most of those are pretty common sense.

1207
00:59:32,730 --> 00:59:36,220
We don't have to be a rocket
scientist to figure those out.

1208
00:59:36,220 --> 00:59:39,140
But you'll remember
the control schedule and

1209
00:59:39,140 --> 00:59:42,430
control costs, those are the ones
that we did earned value management.

1210
00:59:42,430 --> 00:59:43,560
Those were pretty hard, right?

1211
00:59:43,560 --> 00:59:45,730
A lot of stuff to be said in there.

1212
00:59:45,730 --> 00:59:46,450
But the rest of them,

1213
00:59:46,450 --> 00:59:49,770
for the most part we're just executing
what was set forth in our plan.

1214
00:59:51,410 --> 00:59:53,840
All right, so
that's a pretty good spot to wrap it up.

1215
00:59:53,840 --> 00:59:55,730
Ronnie, can you think of
anything else to throw in?

1216
00:59:55,730 --> 00:59:56,280
>> Nope.

1217
00:59:56,280 --> 00:59:57,660
Yeah.
>> All right.

1218
00:59:57,660 --> 01:00:01,250
Now we still have our closing process that
we're gonna tackle in the next episode.

1219
01:00:01,250 --> 01:00:03,680
But for right now, we'll wrap this one up.

1220
01:00:03,680 --> 01:00:05,040
I do wanna remind you guys,

1221
01:00:05,040 --> 01:00:08,660
if you have questions on any of this,
feel free to ask.

1222
01:00:08,660 --> 01:00:10,710
Live during the show you
can go to ITPro.tv/live.

1223
01:00:10,710 --> 01:00:13,670
You'll see the chat
right beneath the video.

1224
01:00:13,670 --> 01:00:14,650
Post your questions there.

1225
01:00:14,650 --> 01:00:16,590
We monitor and answer during the show.

1226
01:00:16,590 --> 01:00:20,930
If you have questions after the show,
use the Q and A forums, right?

1227
01:00:20,930 --> 01:00:22,950
You'll see a link at the top
of the page that says Q and A.

1228
01:00:22,950 --> 01:00:25,110
Click on it and post your questions there.

1229
01:00:25,110 --> 01:00:29,950
We monitor and answer all the time usually
Ron you always beat me to the answers but

1230
01:00:29,950 --> 01:00:32,850
one of us will answer your questions.

1231
01:00:32,850 --> 01:00:36,170
We wanna make sure you guys have
the information you need to be successful

1232
01:00:36,170 --> 01:00:36,753
on the exam.

1233
01:00:36,753 --> 01:00:37,870
>> Right.
>> Alright

1234
01:00:37,870 --> 01:00:39,430
well I hope you guys enjoy the show.

1235
01:00:39,430 --> 01:00:41,427
Signing off for IT Pro TV I'm Don Pazete.

1236
01:00:41,427 --> 01:00:42,511
>> And I'm Ronnie Long.

1237
01:00:42,511 --> 01:00:44,614
>> And we will see ya next time!

1238
01:00:44,614 --> 01:00:54,614
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don guide through some of the most common methodologies used in process management.  These processes include the Six Sigma, Lean and Kanban methods use wildly in project management. Project Managers may be directly involved in implementing these but should be aware.
episodes.title: Process Analysis
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.029 --> 00:00:10.411
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.411 --> 00:00:13.408
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.408 --> 00:00:14.755
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:14.755 --> 00:00:18.201
And today we're taking a look
Project Management Professional and

5
00:00:18.201 --> 00:00:21.010
here to help us, Mr.
Don Pezet, how's it going?

6
00:00:21.010 --> 00:00:22.020
>> It is going great, Ronnie.

7
00:00:22.020 --> 00:00:23.040
I'm glad to be back on the show.

8
00:00:23.040 --> 00:00:25.860
I'm ready to jump into the world
of project management.

9
00:00:25.860 --> 00:00:29.930
In this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at Process Analysis.

10
00:00:29.930 --> 00:00:33.295
And this is kind of one of those
funny topics where in the past,

11
00:00:33.295 --> 00:00:36.230
we usually leave this one
out of project management.

12
00:00:36.230 --> 00:00:39.740
Because, inside of the [COUGH] project
management world, we're really concerned

13
00:00:39.740 --> 00:00:44.200
with moving the project forward, creating
those deliverables, hitting our goals.

14
00:00:44.200 --> 00:00:47.920
And wrapping the project up on time,
on budget, and

15
00:00:47.920 --> 00:00:50.150
meeting everybody's requirements.

16
00:00:50.150 --> 00:00:54.380
But there's ongoing activities
that happen inside of our company.

17
00:00:54.380 --> 00:00:57.140
Things that our company does over,
and over, and over again.

18
00:00:57.140 --> 00:01:01.170
And there's processes that are a part
of those ongoing activities and

19
00:01:01.170 --> 00:01:04.880
they can be improved or
corrected, made more efficient.

20
00:01:04.880 --> 00:01:08.390
And that's a real thing, something
that happens inside of organizations.

21
00:01:08.390 --> 00:01:12.710
But we don't normally deal with it in
terms of a project, because remember our

22
00:01:12.710 --> 00:01:16.420
definition of a project way back probably
in episode of one in this series.

23
00:01:16.420 --> 00:01:22.850
We said, a project is something that
has a well defined start and finish.

24
00:01:22.850 --> 00:01:23.370
Right?

25
00:01:23.370 --> 00:01:26.663
That a project is not something
that just rambles on and on and

26
00:01:26.663 --> 00:01:28.027
on without definition.

27
00:01:28.027 --> 00:01:31.742
That you have a well defined beginning and
end.

28
00:01:31.742 --> 00:01:33.953
And you got a set of requirements
that you need to meet, and

29
00:01:33.953 --> 00:01:36.485
if you meet those requirements then
your project is successful and

30
00:01:36.485 --> 00:01:38.356
if you don't meet those
requirements you fail.

31
00:01:38.356 --> 00:01:39.310
Right?

32
00:01:39.310 --> 00:01:44.120
So an ongoing activity, that's kind
of outside of the ramble project, so

33
00:01:44.120 --> 00:01:46.110
why are we bothering
to talk about it here?

34
00:01:46.110 --> 00:01:48.800
Well, in every single
episode we've covered so

35
00:01:48.800 --> 00:01:51.270
far we've talked about processes.

36
00:01:51.270 --> 00:01:51.810
Right?

37
00:01:51.810 --> 00:01:55.060
And each process had inputs, had tools and

38
00:01:55.060 --> 00:01:58.260
techniques that we applied to those
inputs to then create outputs,

39
00:01:58.260 --> 00:02:01.800
which all hopefully led to
the completion of our project.

40
00:02:01.800 --> 00:02:02.946
Right?
At a minimum,

41
00:02:02.946 --> 00:02:06.043
they created information we can
use to measure our project.

42
00:02:06.043 --> 00:02:09.320
But hopefully they created deliverables,
they then combined like a Lego kit and

43
00:02:09.320 --> 00:02:11.354
all of a sudden you end up
with this giant product.

44
00:02:11.354 --> 00:02:14.630
All right, so that's what we hope to have.

45
00:02:14.630 --> 00:02:19.060
Now those processes,
those are being done over and over and

46
00:02:19.060 --> 00:02:21.550
over again throughout
all of your projects.

47
00:02:21.550 --> 00:02:24.480
And so there's areas that can be improved
there, there's areas that can be

48
00:02:24.480 --> 00:02:27.610
tweaked and adjusted and
that maybe part of our project.

49
00:02:27.610 --> 00:02:32.090
Or it might be our project
to find areas to improve.

50
00:02:32.090 --> 00:02:35.880
And so this is one of those areas where
processes analysis is not normally

51
00:02:35.880 --> 00:02:41.170
a project management concept but
can be a part of project management.

52
00:02:41.170 --> 00:02:43.190
And so
we need to have an understanding of that.

53
00:02:43.190 --> 00:02:44.950
Now the PMI,

54
00:02:44.950 --> 00:02:48.530
the Project Management Institute didn't
really harp on this much in the past.

55
00:02:48.530 --> 00:02:51.070
But starting with their
January 2016 update,

56
00:02:51.070 --> 00:02:55.140
they're really putting a little bit
more of an emphasis on process analysis.

57
00:02:55.140 --> 00:02:58.725
So it's a good idea to have at
least a foundational understanding

58
00:02:58.725 --> 00:03:00.475
of what process analysis is.

59
00:03:00.475 --> 00:03:03.435
You as a project manager will
likely not have to do this.

60
00:03:03.435 --> 00:03:05.635
But you need to be familiar
with what it is, so

61
00:03:05.635 --> 00:03:07.745
you can get the right
people to make them do it.

62
00:03:07.745 --> 00:03:11.145
And actually have this be successful and
keep your company running smoothly.

63
00:03:11.145 --> 00:03:12.165
All right?

64
00:03:12.165 --> 00:03:13.375
So that's what we're
gonna do in this episode,

65
00:03:13.375 --> 00:03:16.975
we're gonna take a look at some of those
different methodologies or schools of

66
00:03:16.975 --> 00:03:21.290
thought on process analysis, what can we
do, what can we do to improve things.

67
00:03:21.290 --> 00:03:23.807
And how that kinda gets
rolled into a project.

68
00:03:23.807 --> 00:03:27.517
>> Now Don, I understand that we might
actually choose as an individual company

69
00:03:27.517 --> 00:03:28.324
to do it our way.

70
00:03:28.324 --> 00:03:31.616
But there are some different
methodologies that have been tried and

71
00:03:31.616 --> 00:03:34.848
true that really do help,
well just about everything that you do,

72
00:03:34.848 --> 00:03:37.634
especially project related and
those ongoing process.

73
00:03:37.634 --> 00:03:41.875
And there’s really three main
methodologies that we do need to focus on.

74
00:03:41.875 --> 00:03:44.420
So Don, the first one,
I’ve heard about it.

75
00:03:44.420 --> 00:03:47.580
I've heard all different things about it,
I still don't know much about it itself.

76
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:50.000
It's one that we call Six Sigma.

77
00:03:50.000 --> 00:03:52.158
So, it's even harder for me to say.

78
00:03:52.158 --> 00:03:54.301
>> I get a lot of
questions about Six Sigma,

79
00:03:54.301 --> 00:03:58.272
viewers like you out there where they
will send me an e-mail and say, Don,

80
00:03:58.272 --> 00:04:01.252
I'm thinking about getting
into Project Management.

81
00:04:01.252 --> 00:04:06.750
Should I do PNP or should I do like
Six Sigma green belt or something.

82
00:04:06.750 --> 00:04:10.110
And I kind of look at and I'm like
well all right here is a person who

83
00:04:10.110 --> 00:04:14.870
hasn't used Google and [LAUGH] to find out
that they're really two different things.

84
00:04:14.870 --> 00:04:17.384
Right?
Project management is one thing and

85
00:04:17.384 --> 00:04:21.462
process improvement or Six Sigma for
that matter is a different thing.

86
00:04:21.462 --> 00:04:22.715
They have different purposes.

87
00:04:22.715 --> 00:04:23.528
Right?

88
00:04:23.528 --> 00:04:27.634
What Six Sigma looks to do is it
looks to improve processes to make

89
00:04:27.634 --> 00:04:30.610
them more efficient and
to create less waste.

90
00:04:30.610 --> 00:04:32.096
Right?
Less defects.

91
00:04:32.096 --> 00:04:34.630
Right?
It all boils down to defects.

92
00:04:34.630 --> 00:04:37.180
Remember that a lot of this
stuff didn't originate in

93
00:04:37.180 --> 00:04:39.160
IT departments like what we do.

94
00:04:39.160 --> 00:04:41.330
It originated in manufacturing.

95
00:04:41.330 --> 00:04:42.330
Factory floors.

96
00:04:42.330 --> 00:04:42.910
Right?

97
00:04:42.910 --> 00:04:44.930
Six Sigma came out of Motorola.

98
00:04:44.930 --> 00:04:48.350
Now, Motorola, if you're familiar
with them, they make cellphones,

99
00:04:48.350 --> 00:04:51.820
they make all sorts of electronic devices,
they do a ton of stuff.

100
00:04:51.820 --> 00:04:55.040
And when you make electronic
devices they actually build it

101
00:04:55.040 --> 00:04:58.325
into their process that some of
the devices they make are gonna be broken.

102
00:04:58.325 --> 00:05:01.550
Right?
So if they make 100 cellphones,

103
00:05:01.550 --> 00:05:05.040
they may know that just through
a part of manufacturing

104
00:05:05.040 --> 00:05:07.060
five of those phones are gonna be broken.

105
00:05:07.060 --> 00:05:09.370
And then when they build it out,

106
00:05:09.370 --> 00:05:15.160
if they need 1000 phones they don't just
do ten runs of 100, they do 11 runs.

107
00:05:15.160 --> 00:05:17.470
Because they know they're
gonna lose five with each run,

108
00:05:17.470 --> 00:05:19.220
so that's 50 total that they lose.

109
00:05:19.220 --> 00:05:22.380
They need one extra run to be able to
get the extra phones to meet their need.

110
00:05:22.380 --> 00:05:23.030
Right?

111
00:05:23.030 --> 00:05:25.130
They do that to meet their goal.

112
00:05:25.130 --> 00:05:26.700
Now, they could just stop right there and
say, well,

113
00:05:26.700 --> 00:05:27.910
that's the cost of doing business.

114
00:05:27.910 --> 00:05:30.760
We lose five out of 100, that's just it.

115
00:05:30.760 --> 00:05:33.180
But, if we look at it.

116
00:05:33.180 --> 00:05:35.490
Right?
We start to find the problems,

117
00:05:35.490 --> 00:05:36.630
try and find the defect,

118
00:05:36.630 --> 00:05:39.960
why are those five failing,
we might be able to find some solutions.

119
00:05:39.960 --> 00:05:44.040
And we did talk about that in some of
our other episodes where we did some

120
00:05:44.040 --> 00:05:45.850
of the risk analysis.

121
00:05:45.850 --> 00:05:48.200
Really cuz it's a type of risk.

122
00:05:48.200 --> 00:05:53.940
But we talked about continual process
improvement, and ways to do the cause and

123
00:05:53.940 --> 00:05:58.065
effect model,
to say five phones failed, why?

124
00:05:58.065 --> 00:05:59.554
Right?
What caused it?

125
00:05:59.554 --> 00:06:02.851
And it maybe more than one thing,
and so you can do a Pareto diagram.

126
00:06:02.851 --> 00:06:03.965
We saw those too.

127
00:06:03.965 --> 00:06:07.304
And we talked about how we can isolate,
which one is the primary cause and

128
00:06:07.304 --> 00:06:08.800
see if we can fix it.

129
00:06:08.800 --> 00:06:11.930
And when something is a defect,
there are different levels of defect.

130
00:06:11.930 --> 00:06:12.450
Right?

131
00:06:12.450 --> 00:06:14.940
It could be that it is
completely unfit for use and

132
00:06:14.940 --> 00:06:17.115
it just has to go in the trash,
and that's that.

133
00:06:17.115 --> 00:06:17.800
Right?

134
00:06:17.800 --> 00:06:22.440
But sometimes they can be repaired, and
the repair might even be really simple.

135
00:06:22.440 --> 00:06:24.441
If the repair is simple,
it might be worth it for us to do it.

136
00:06:24.441 --> 00:06:25.833
If the repair is complex,

137
00:06:25.833 --> 00:06:29.138
the cost to repair it maybe more
than just making another one.

138
00:06:29.138 --> 00:06:32.147
And that's when we just accept that
device has failed and that's the end,

139
00:06:32.147 --> 00:06:32.876
we throw it away.

140
00:06:32.876 --> 00:06:33.840
Right?

141
00:06:33.840 --> 00:06:35.660
So somebody has to make that judgement.

142
00:06:35.660 --> 00:06:37.590
Somebody has to evaluate it and
it's normally engineers.

143
00:06:37.590 --> 00:06:39.740
It's normally the people that are building
this equipment that are building

144
00:06:39.740 --> 00:06:42.690
the process line, not the project manager.

145
00:06:42.690 --> 00:06:47.120
But we need to be aware of it because
somebody may have told us, yeah,

146
00:06:47.120 --> 00:06:47.958
it's just how it is.

147
00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.910
We lose five for every 100 we make,
that's just how it is.

148
00:06:50.910 --> 00:06:53.400
Well, okay, I'll grant you that.

149
00:06:53.400 --> 00:06:58.450
That may be how it is, but
it isn't necessarily how it has to be.

150
00:06:58.450 --> 00:07:00.560
Right?
Maybe we could make it better.

151
00:07:00.560 --> 00:07:04.200
And if I can improve that yield,
not only am I gonna be more efficient,

152
00:07:04.200 --> 00:07:06.230
but we can get things done faster.

153
00:07:06.230 --> 00:07:08.340
It can help my schedule
as well as my budget.

154
00:07:08.340 --> 00:07:10.210
So, for a project manager that's valuable.

155
00:07:10.210 --> 00:07:10.870
Right?

156
00:07:10.870 --> 00:07:14.590
So, at Motorola the gentleman
who came up with it,

157
00:07:14.590 --> 00:07:15.821
the most generic name in the planet.

158
00:07:15.821 --> 00:07:16.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> Bill Smith,

159
00:07:16.880 --> 00:07:19.190
I guess it could be John Doe,
but Bill Smith.

160
00:07:19.190 --> 00:07:21.340
He created this back in the 1980s.

161
00:07:21.340 --> 00:07:26.560
And what it was was just a process
used for monitoring production.

162
00:07:26.560 --> 00:07:28.870
And it's really designed for
a factory floor.

163
00:07:28.870 --> 00:07:29.570
Right?
Industry,

164
00:07:29.570 --> 00:07:31.460
where you're actually
making a tangible good.

165
00:07:31.460 --> 00:07:35.060
But you can do this in IT or project
management, where it is a soft skill.

166
00:07:35.060 --> 00:07:35.900
Right?
This could be

167
00:07:35.900 --> 00:07:38.470
things like looking at
your help desk calls.

168
00:07:38.470 --> 00:07:42.770
And you could measure defects based
on customer satisfaction scores.

169
00:07:42.770 --> 00:07:46.564
At the end of a help desk call, you ask
whoever called in to do a survey and

170
00:07:46.564 --> 00:07:48.921
rank the experience on
a scale of one to ten.

171
00:07:48.921 --> 00:07:52.176
And you can say look, we're trying to
create an eight to ten experience.

172
00:07:52.176 --> 00:07:55.819
And if somebody says they had a seven or
lower, that's a defect.

173
00:07:55.819 --> 00:07:59.851
And do we have an acceptable level for
that, that we're okay with or

174
00:07:59.851 --> 00:08:01.940
do we need to get that up higher?

175
00:08:01.940 --> 00:08:05.140
So it doesn't have to be a tangible item
and that's where Six Sigma gets really

176
00:08:05.140 --> 00:08:08.820
weird, cuz it was designed for
industry and now people are applying it in

177
00:08:08.820 --> 00:08:12.340
all sorts of different places, and
it becomes really, really powerful.

178
00:08:13.690 --> 00:08:16.220
Now, the name Six Sigma.

179
00:08:16.220 --> 00:08:19.950
What it actually derives from is
sigma is a statistics term and

180
00:08:19.950 --> 00:08:21.880
it means a standard deviation.

181
00:08:21.880 --> 00:08:25.640
So when they say Six Sigma,
Motorola had this target back in the day,

182
00:08:25.640 --> 00:08:28.210
that they wanted to make
sure they stayed within

183
00:08:28.210 --> 00:08:31.890
six standard deviations of
what was considered perfect.

184
00:08:31.890 --> 00:08:34.560
So you could get a little
bit off of perfect and

185
00:08:34.560 --> 00:08:36.720
still have an item that was sellable.

186
00:08:36.720 --> 00:08:39.444
That still fit its need,
fulfilled its purpose.

187
00:08:39.444 --> 00:08:42.513
Remember your warranties,
you gotta be fit for use and

188
00:08:42.513 --> 00:08:44.790
fit for purpose and all that good stuff.

189
00:08:44.790 --> 00:08:48.890
So that's basically what we see with Six
Sigma and that's where that name cam from.

190
00:08:48.890 --> 00:08:51.630
Now, they don't actually shoot for
Six Sigma.

191
00:08:51.630 --> 00:08:53.913
They shoot for something like 4.5 sigma's-
>> [LAUGH]

192
00:08:53.913 --> 00:08:55.080
>> Or something.

193
00:08:55.080 --> 00:08:56.020
>> But that was the name.

194
00:08:56.020 --> 00:08:57.550
I'm not quite sure why
they switched that one up.

195
00:08:57.550 --> 00:09:00.430
I guess that maybe they just
got more efficient over time.

196
00:09:00.430 --> 00:09:03.890
But basically, it's a pretty lofty goal.

197
00:09:03.890 --> 00:09:07.180
Their goal originally was something,
I gotta try and remember this.

198
00:09:07.180 --> 00:09:14.070
It was something like 3.4 defects for
every 1 million possibilities of defect.

199
00:09:14.070 --> 00:09:18.650
Right now, when you produce one
cellphone there are thousands of

200
00:09:18.650 --> 00:09:22.980
possible places, possible opportunities
for defect in that phone.

201
00:09:22.980 --> 00:09:28.110
So to produce a valid phone, that could be
a thousand successes in that one phone.

202
00:09:28.110 --> 00:09:29.550
It could be 10,000 successes.

203
00:09:29.550 --> 00:09:34.486
So when they say 3.4 defects per million
opportunities, it doesn't mean they made

204
00:09:34.486 --> 00:09:38.422
a million devices but it means that
it could be a much smaller number.

205
00:09:38.422 --> 00:09:40.920
But that was kind of what they
were shooting for back then.

206
00:09:40.920 --> 00:09:43.350
When you apply it it
doesn't necessarily matter.

207
00:09:43.350 --> 00:09:46.580
When you apply it what really
matters is the process, and

208
00:09:46.580 --> 00:09:47.600
this all goes back to Deming.

209
00:09:47.600 --> 00:09:49.760
I know we mentioned Deming in other shows.

210
00:09:49.760 --> 00:09:55.304
But he's got that whole plan,
do, check, act methodology.

211
00:09:55.304 --> 00:09:57.410
Plan, we plan what we're gonna do.

212
00:09:57.410 --> 00:09:58.751
We figure out how we're
gonna run through it.

213
00:09:58.751 --> 00:10:00.190
We plan our project.

214
00:10:01.360 --> 00:10:02.460
We do, we execute.

215
00:10:02.460 --> 00:10:05.660
We actually perform
whatever that action is.

216
00:10:05.660 --> 00:10:07.830
Check, we evaluate the results.

217
00:10:07.830 --> 00:10:12.000
Did it work the way that we planned it or
do not match up with a plan?

218
00:10:12.000 --> 00:10:16.510
If it matched what we planned perfectly
to perfection then we move on,

219
00:10:16.510 --> 00:10:17.350
then we're done.

220
00:10:17.350 --> 00:10:21.070
But if it didn't match,
if it was too good or too bad.

221
00:10:21.070 --> 00:10:22.970
Remember like any risk
there's good risk and

222
00:10:22.970 --> 00:10:25.230
bad risk so it could be too good,
why was it too good?

223
00:10:25.230 --> 00:10:27.840
Let's find out, and then we act.

224
00:10:27.840 --> 00:10:30.910
We make any changes necessary to get
things back in line with our plan.

225
00:10:30.910 --> 00:10:32.320
Plan, do, check, act.

226
00:10:32.320 --> 00:10:34.070
Very old methodology there.

227
00:10:34.070 --> 00:10:37.640
That's Deming's kinda key analysis.

228
00:10:37.640 --> 00:10:40.632
So what Bill Smith did, is he took that
and he just modified it a little bit.

229
00:10:40.632 --> 00:10:42.850
And it's implemented in five steps.

230
00:10:42.850 --> 00:10:46.630
And there's a little acronym that you'll
see used anytime you read a Six Sigma book

231
00:10:46.630 --> 00:10:51.240
which is DMAIC,
this guy right here D-M-A-I-C.

232
00:10:51.240 --> 00:10:56.350
You'll hear people call it d maic or
da maic, I've heard both.

233
00:10:56.350 --> 00:11:00.760
I think da maic is kind of
the most common one which to me,

234
00:11:00.760 --> 00:11:01.810
almost sounds like demonic.

235
00:11:01.810 --> 00:11:02.560
So I don't normally-
>> [LAUGH]

236
00:11:02.560 --> 00:11:03.620
>> Use that one.

237
00:11:03.620 --> 00:11:09.195
But DMAIC, define measure,
analyze, improve, control.

238
00:11:09.195 --> 00:11:12.180
Define, that's like our plan.

239
00:11:12.180 --> 00:11:16.080
We figure out what it is that we're
gonna be measuring to evaluate,

240
00:11:16.080 --> 00:11:17.750
what it is we expect to get?

241
00:11:18.950 --> 00:11:21.308
Measure, we collect data.

242
00:11:21.308 --> 00:11:24.290
If we're gonna be evaluating this we have
to have some kind of measurable thing.

243
00:11:24.290 --> 00:11:26.360
Remember the help desk example I gave you?

244
00:11:26.360 --> 00:11:29.440
I can't just arbitrarily decide if
a help desk call was good or bad.

245
00:11:29.440 --> 00:11:34.920
But if I base it on customer satisfaction,
now I've got something that I can measure.

246
00:11:34.920 --> 00:11:38.130
Let's say, that you're a fast food
restaurant and you make hamburgers.

247
00:11:38.130 --> 00:11:41.892
How do you measure whether
that hamburger tastes good?

248
00:11:41.892 --> 00:11:43.340
Can you measure taste like that?

249
00:11:43.340 --> 00:11:46.079
I don't have a taste meter,
I can stick in there and

250
00:11:46.079 --> 00:11:49.601
say no, this ones a 7.5 on
the taste scale, it doesn't work.

251
00:11:49.601 --> 00:11:52.824
But if you measure your customer
satisfaction or something

252
00:11:52.824 --> 00:11:57.700
else temperature, appearance something
like that those are measurable items.

253
00:11:57.700 --> 00:12:02.080
So we measure and then we analyze,
we analyze the data we got to see,

254
00:12:02.080 --> 00:12:04.350
does it match what we
defined in the beginning?

255
00:12:04.350 --> 00:12:07.260
This is basically plan, do, check, act.

256
00:12:07.260 --> 00:12:10.140
The act part though becomes improved.

257
00:12:10.140 --> 00:12:11.010
Can we make it better?

258
00:12:12.120 --> 00:12:15.930
I'm getting nine out of ten support calls,
that are getting eight or

259
00:12:15.930 --> 00:12:16.690
higher on their evals.

260
00:12:16.690 --> 00:12:17.361
That's great.

261
00:12:17.361 --> 00:12:18.650
But what about that tenth one?

262
00:12:18.650 --> 00:12:22.530
Can I get that better or
what if all ten were an eight or higher?

263
00:12:22.530 --> 00:12:24.313
Could I get all ten to be a nine or
higher?

264
00:12:24.313 --> 00:12:25.070
Let's improve.

265
00:12:25.070 --> 00:12:26.350
Let's see if we can make it better.

266
00:12:26.350 --> 00:12:32.063
Now there does come a tipping point where
improving would cost more than it's worth.

267
00:12:32.063 --> 00:12:33.430
You wouldn't get the necessary benefit.

268
00:12:33.430 --> 00:12:37.400
So you go through this cycle a few times
before you kind of reach that cost of

269
00:12:37.400 --> 00:12:40.300
benefit equalizer.

270
00:12:40.300 --> 00:12:42.292
And the last one we got control.

271
00:12:42.292 --> 00:12:43.430
Control says,

272
00:12:43.430 --> 00:12:47.880
we're gonna keep doing this how do I make
sure that I always get consistent results?

273
00:12:47.880 --> 00:12:50.895
And the best example I can give for
control is maintenance.

274
00:12:50.895 --> 00:12:54.429
I know if I get my car in the morning,
I can turn the key it starts up and

275
00:12:54.429 --> 00:12:55.810
I can drive to work.

276
00:12:55.810 --> 00:12:58.590
I've done it a thousand times
well probably more than that.

277
00:12:58.590 --> 00:13:02.060
So I've done it thousands of times get in
the car drive to work I know the car can

278
00:13:02.060 --> 00:13:03.190
do it.

279
00:13:03.190 --> 00:13:08.150
But I still have to change the oil in
the car, I've got to put gas in it.

280
00:13:08.150 --> 00:13:09.630
That's me controlling.

281
00:13:09.630 --> 00:13:12.690
I'm controlling to make sure that car
will be able to get me to work tomorrow.

282
00:13:13.750 --> 00:13:16.570
I already know that I've measured it.

283
00:13:16.570 --> 00:13:19.150
One tank of gas will get me to the office.

284
00:13:19.150 --> 00:13:20.360
I know my car can do that.

285
00:13:20.360 --> 00:13:21.560
I've analyzed that.

286
00:13:21.560 --> 00:13:27.130
But if I don't control it, if I let it
run out of gas, if I don't change the oil

287
00:13:27.130 --> 00:13:31.670
then everything kind of goes off and
it just doesn't work anymore.

288
00:13:31.670 --> 00:13:33.250
So we've got a control.

289
00:13:33.250 --> 00:13:37.680
And that's really the core principle of
Six Sigma is this process right here.

290
00:13:37.680 --> 00:13:39.090
And it's a constant cycle.

291
00:13:39.090 --> 00:13:42.990
You're going over and over it and
over again, cycling through that

292
00:13:42.990 --> 00:13:46.450
to make it better, and better, and
better and minimize those defects.

293
00:13:46.450 --> 00:13:50.170
>> Now Don, with this process we that
it's main function then is really,

294
00:13:50.170 --> 00:13:53.400
when we talk about Six Sigma is to try and
eliminate those deficiencies that

295
00:13:53.400 --> 00:13:56.800
are in our products as well as
actually to become more efficient and

296
00:13:56.800 --> 00:13:58.680
making better products as well.

297
00:13:58.680 --> 00:14:02.910
But sometimes we have to do the opposite
which is that the process that we're doing

298
00:14:02.910 --> 00:14:05.270
has to do with a lot of wasted motion.

299
00:14:05.270 --> 00:14:08.920
And in this we might turn to another
type of methodology that we called Lean,

300
00:14:08.920 --> 00:14:09.970
I think is what the term is.

301
00:14:09.970 --> 00:14:12.650
>> Yeah, and
boy Lean is thrown around a lot.

302
00:14:12.650 --> 00:14:15.976
So Lean is another one
that comes from the past.

303
00:14:15.976 --> 00:14:18.926
So this one just comes
from way back in the past.

304
00:14:18.926 --> 00:14:22.710
I mentioned how Six Sigma came
out of Motorola in the 1980s.

305
00:14:22.710 --> 00:14:27.430
Lean actually came out of
Toyota back in the 1950s.

306
00:14:27.430 --> 00:14:30.357
So we're talking about a 60
year old methodology here,

307
00:14:30.357 --> 00:14:31.919
creeping up on 70 years old.

308
00:14:31.919 --> 00:14:34.950
>> [LAUGH]
>> The gentleman who kinda created Lean,

309
00:14:34.950 --> 00:14:38.680
his name and I'm gonna have to read
this off the paper is Taiichi Ohno.

310
00:14:38.680 --> 00:14:41.930
Taiichi Ohno, who actually he's
responsible for a number of

311
00:14:41.930 --> 00:14:45.980
different things in the project management
and the process improvement world.

312
00:14:45.980 --> 00:14:48.400
So you'll see his name in various books.

313
00:14:48.400 --> 00:14:50.060
But what he did is he said,

314
00:14:50.060 --> 00:14:53.900
is no matter how good a process is
when you look at it, there's waste.

315
00:14:53.900 --> 00:14:56.210
There's always waste, waste of some sort.

316
00:14:56.210 --> 00:15:00.660
And so we need a way to improve upon that,
by minimizing the waste.

317
00:15:00.660 --> 00:15:02.450
If we can minimize the waste,

318
00:15:02.450 --> 00:15:04.870
our process might still take
the same amount of time to complete.

319
00:15:04.870 --> 00:15:06.710
We might have the same amount of defects.

320
00:15:06.710 --> 00:15:09.572
But maybe we can reduce
our company's expenses or

321
00:15:09.572 --> 00:15:12.037
whatever to make us better in other areas.

322
00:15:12.037 --> 00:15:18.251
So he took a little bit more of a holistic
approach to process improvement and

323
00:15:18.251 --> 00:15:23.103
what he came up with was this
list of what he called Muda which

324
00:15:23.103 --> 00:15:26.872
is the Japanese word for waste or garbage-
>> [LAUGH]

325
00:15:26.872 --> 00:15:28.500
>> Or something, I don't know.

326
00:15:28.500 --> 00:15:30.530
But basically we have this,

327
00:15:30.530 --> 00:15:34.695
seven places where people will
typically generate waste.

328
00:15:34.695 --> 00:15:36.736
And there's a simple acronym for this,

329
00:15:36.736 --> 00:15:39.867
I've got it here kind of on my
screen which is called Tim Wood.

330
00:15:39.867 --> 00:15:41.168
If you read a Lean book out there,

331
00:15:41.168 --> 00:15:44.720
you'll see this acronym mentioned
somewhere because it's easy to remember.

332
00:15:44.720 --> 00:15:48.116
But basically it boils down to the seven
areas where people are wasteful,

333
00:15:48.116 --> 00:15:49.669
where a process can be wasteful.

334
00:15:49.669 --> 00:15:51.376
The first one is transport.

335
00:15:51.376 --> 00:15:52.914
If you think about transport,

336
00:15:52.914 --> 00:15:56.177
anytime you have to move something
from one location to another.

337
00:15:56.177 --> 00:15:59.356
The whole time it's being moved,
it's like being held in reserve.

338
00:15:59.356 --> 00:16:02.390
You can't make money on something
that's in the process of being moved.

339
00:16:02.390 --> 00:16:04.941
And you can't use something while
it's in the process of being moved.

340
00:16:04.941 --> 00:16:08.414
So if we can minimize the amount
of time that it's being moved,

341
00:16:08.414 --> 00:16:10.257
that can help to minimize waste.

342
00:16:10.257 --> 00:16:14.925
All right, and putting this in terms
of Toyota, when they manufacture a car,

343
00:16:14.925 --> 00:16:19.592
if they then have to stick it on a barge,
one of those giant freightliners, and

344
00:16:19.592 --> 00:16:22.440
ship it from Japan to the United States.

345
00:16:22.440 --> 00:16:23.890
That could take two months.

346
00:16:23.890 --> 00:16:26.590
And during those two months they're
holding on to that inventory.

347
00:16:26.590 --> 00:16:29.830
That's money that they're
not gaining interest on.

348
00:16:29.830 --> 00:16:31.280
That they're basically losing money on.

349
00:16:31.280 --> 00:16:34.190
And then as soon as it gets here
to the States, they can sell it,

350
00:16:34.190 --> 00:16:35.680
and they make the money back.

351
00:16:35.680 --> 00:16:39.530
But the shorter they make that trip, the
faster they can get their money back and

352
00:16:39.530 --> 00:16:41.990
the faster the money can go
into their next project and

353
00:16:41.990 --> 00:16:43.495
continue to improve the company.

354
00:16:43.495 --> 00:16:44.100
Right?

355
00:16:44.100 --> 00:16:46.156
So transport is kind of a big one.

356
00:16:46.156 --> 00:16:48.780
Right?
In IT we don't see transport as much, but

357
00:16:48.780 --> 00:16:51.300
in other industries
it's a very real thing.

358
00:16:51.300 --> 00:16:52.720
Inventory is another one.

359
00:16:52.720 --> 00:16:53.340
Right?

360
00:16:53.340 --> 00:16:57.580
Inventory, if you have to hold things
on your shelf, look at a grocery store.

361
00:16:57.580 --> 00:16:58.260
Right?

362
00:16:58.260 --> 00:17:01.070
If you were to take a grocery store and
close the doors, and

363
00:17:01.070 --> 00:17:05.350
tally up the dollar value of all of
the items inside that grocery store.

364
00:17:05.350 --> 00:17:07.190
It's a lot of money,

365
00:17:07.190 --> 00:17:10.340
money that they're sitting on that they
don't recoup until they sell that item.

366
00:17:10.340 --> 00:17:11.949
And when they sell the item,
what do they do?

367
00:17:11.949 --> 00:17:13.580
They buy a replacement
to put on the shelf, so

368
00:17:13.580 --> 00:17:15.350
they've always got that
inventory in place.

369
00:17:15.350 --> 00:17:19.830
Anything we can do to reduce
the inventory that we need but

370
00:17:19.830 --> 00:17:21.566
still keep the customer happy.

371
00:17:21.566 --> 00:17:23.570
Right?
That's the real trick right there because

372
00:17:23.570 --> 00:17:25.750
you don't wanna make your item hard to
get because then people just go and

373
00:17:25.750 --> 00:17:26.760
buy a different item.

374
00:17:26.760 --> 00:17:27.290
Right?

375
00:17:27.290 --> 00:17:31.875
So by keeping it to the minimal level
necessary is gonna help our company to be

376
00:17:31.875 --> 00:17:34.105
able to respond to changes faster.

377
00:17:35.225 --> 00:17:36.635
Motion.
This

378
00:17:36.635 --> 00:17:38.335
is kind of a weird one because
we talk about transport.

379
00:17:38.335 --> 00:17:39.315
What is motion?

380
00:17:39.315 --> 00:17:41.855
Well, it's really not
just motion by itself.

381
00:17:41.855 --> 00:17:45.525
It's really talking about too much or
too little motion.

382
00:17:45.525 --> 00:17:46.045
Right?

383
00:17:46.045 --> 00:17:50.810
So for example, lets say you get
a new appliance like a dishwasher and

384
00:17:50.810 --> 00:17:53.270
you're installing the dishwasher and
you push it into place and

385
00:17:53.270 --> 00:17:55.080
you push it a little too far in.

386
00:17:55.080 --> 00:17:56.330
Or you don't push it far enough in.

387
00:17:56.330 --> 00:17:57.590
What do you have to do then?

388
00:17:57.590 --> 00:17:59.170
You have to do is called Rework.

389
00:17:59.170 --> 00:18:03.210
You have to go in and push it to
be right back in the correct spot.

390
00:18:03.210 --> 00:18:09.390
So anytime you have a moving part there's
this possibility that things may go wrong.

391
00:18:09.390 --> 00:18:11.167
Right?
The moving part that we're out,

392
00:18:11.167 --> 00:18:13.322
the movie part could go too far or
too short and

393
00:18:13.322 --> 00:18:15.040
now you've got to adjust for that.

394
00:18:15.040 --> 00:18:18.520
So anytime you have motion,
you can have unnecessary motion.

395
00:18:18.520 --> 00:18:21.520
And that's an area where
we can have waste waiting.

396
00:18:21.520 --> 00:18:22.056
Just waiting in general.
And

397
00:18:22.056 --> 00:18:25.042
this is one in IT that I
can absolutely relate to.

398
00:18:25.042 --> 00:18:26.635
>> [LAUGH]
>> I know Ronnie,

399
00:18:26.635 --> 00:18:30.713
I've told you before like, half my career
has been spent watching a blue bar scroll

400
00:18:30.713 --> 00:18:32.591
across the screen to get to 100%.

401
00:18:32.591 --> 00:18:34.274
That's the world of IT.

402
00:18:34.274 --> 00:18:37.310
>> [LAUGH]
>> Could I have been doing something else?

403
00:18:37.310 --> 00:18:38.630
Right?
Can we multitask?

404
00:18:38.630 --> 00:18:39.640
Can we do other things to achieve?

405
00:18:39.640 --> 00:18:42.650
So when we wait on something, and
using Toyota, they paint a car.

406
00:18:42.650 --> 00:18:44.050
Gotta wait for the paint to dry.

407
00:18:44.050 --> 00:18:47.260
Is there something we could do
to minimize that waiting time?

408
00:18:47.260 --> 00:18:50.568
Could we have heat lamps that bake
the paint so it dries faster or whatever?

409
00:18:50.568 --> 00:18:51.926
I imagine so.

410
00:18:51.926 --> 00:18:52.448
Right?

411
00:18:52.448 --> 00:18:53.899
I've never made a car,
so I don't really know.

412
00:18:53.899 --> 00:18:55.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I imagine so.

413
00:18:55.240 --> 00:18:57.430
And those are ways that we
can improve our process.

414
00:18:58.780 --> 00:18:59.870
Overproduction.

415
00:18:59.870 --> 00:19:03.965
All right, overproduction, Ronnie you
are the master of overproduction.

416
00:19:03.965 --> 00:19:06.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sometimes we can put too much effort

417
00:19:06.750 --> 00:19:08.400
into something to achieve it.

418
00:19:08.400 --> 00:19:13.731
Right?
So, I might need, so I might go to Ronnie.

419
00:19:13.731 --> 00:19:15.310
I'm gonna throw you under the bus here,
Ronnie.

420
00:19:15.310 --> 00:19:16.157
>> [LAUGH] Okay, that's fine.

421
00:19:16.157 --> 00:19:18.440
>> I go to Ronnie and I say,
Ronnie I need a web server fired up.

422
00:19:18.440 --> 00:19:20.530
Can you spin me up a, you know,

423
00:19:20.530 --> 00:19:24.260
just a Windows virtual machine
with a web server on it?

424
00:19:24.260 --> 00:19:28.590
And then he'll come to me the next day and
say oh, your web server is up.

425
00:19:28.590 --> 00:19:30.930
Oh and I set up antivirus on it and

426
00:19:30.930 --> 00:19:32.930
I configured the firewall
to allow these rules and

427
00:19:32.930 --> 00:19:36.420
I applied all the updates and all this
extra stuff that he did, which is great.

428
00:19:36.420 --> 00:19:38.254
Right?
I mean it really creates that perfect

429
00:19:38.254 --> 00:19:39.560
environment.

430
00:19:39.560 --> 00:19:42.320
But, it put a lot more work into it,
and I might not need that.

431
00:19:42.320 --> 00:19:43.520
I might have just wanted
to test something, and

432
00:19:43.520 --> 00:19:44.303
I'm gonna delete the server.

433
00:19:44.303 --> 00:19:46.775
So, that's overproduction.

434
00:19:46.775 --> 00:19:47.321
Right?

435
00:19:47.321 --> 00:19:48.335
More than we need.

436
00:19:48.335 --> 00:19:52.405
Anytime you go beyond your customers'
requirements, that's overproduction.

437
00:19:52.405 --> 00:19:53.730
Right?

438
00:19:53.730 --> 00:19:57.175
Overproduction can also be where
we created too much of an item.

439
00:19:57.175 --> 00:19:57.830
Right?

440
00:19:57.830 --> 00:20:01.335
So, they needed 100,
we made 200 just for the heck of it.

441
00:20:01.335 --> 00:20:04.070
We might end up having to eat up
that extra hundred that we made, and

442
00:20:04.070 --> 00:20:05.150
that can be a part of it too.

443
00:20:06.740 --> 00:20:08.030
Over Processing.

444
00:20:08.030 --> 00:20:08.610
Right?

445
00:20:08.610 --> 00:20:11.670
Over processing is kinda
similar to overproduction.

446
00:20:11.670 --> 00:20:14.816
You see over processing usually when
you're manufacturing something like paper

447
00:20:14.816 --> 00:20:15.620
or whatever.

448
00:20:15.620 --> 00:20:19.280
So, paper for example, is actually brown,
they bleach it to be white.

449
00:20:19.280 --> 00:20:22.350
And you can over bleach it like
it's already white enough and

450
00:20:22.350 --> 00:20:26.120
you continue processing it more,
you've done more work than was necessary.

451
00:20:26.120 --> 00:20:28.670
And then lastly it's just defects.

452
00:20:28.670 --> 00:20:30.240
And defects are what we normally look for.

453
00:20:30.240 --> 00:20:31.870
Right?
This is where we expected one thing and

454
00:20:31.870 --> 00:20:33.430
we got something else and
it's not suitable.

455
00:20:33.430 --> 00:20:34.312
That's a defect.

456
00:20:34.312 --> 00:20:36.694
Right?
So these seven are kind of the core areas,

457
00:20:36.694 --> 00:20:39.170
now there are other ones
that are out there.

458
00:20:39.170 --> 00:20:39.714
Right?

459
00:20:39.714 --> 00:20:43.290
But these are the core seven
that they call out in Lean.

460
00:20:43.290 --> 00:20:47.680
Now the interesting thing about Lean is
that you rarely see it employed by itself.

461
00:20:47.680 --> 00:20:49.416
Okay.
It's a methodology for

462
00:20:49.416 --> 00:20:53.193
identifying areas of waste, so
that we can then work to improve them.

463
00:20:53.193 --> 00:20:57.615
So, the improvement part,
that kind of comes with something else,

464
00:20:57.615 --> 00:21:02.038
like Six Sigma or other methodologies
where it might create a project

465
00:21:02.038 --> 00:21:04.804
to try to improve it and
move that forward.

466
00:21:04.804 --> 00:21:07.223
So, you'll hear about people talking,

467
00:21:07.223 --> 00:21:10.940
well you'll hear people
talking about Lean Six Sigma.

468
00:21:10.940 --> 00:21:12.850
Right?
Or Lean Agile.

469
00:21:12.850 --> 00:21:15.740
Right?
You'll hear Lean Scrums sometimes or

470
00:21:15.740 --> 00:21:18.240
whatever, and it's where they're
taking one methodology, and

471
00:21:18.240 --> 00:21:19.350
combining it with Lean.

472
00:21:19.350 --> 00:21:22.440
So, hey, we're doing this activity,
but we're also watching for

473
00:21:22.440 --> 00:21:24.480
waste, to see if we can
improve along the way.

474
00:21:24.480 --> 00:21:26.151
So, Lean is not so
much a stand alone item.

475
00:21:26.151 --> 00:21:31.539
>> Now, Don, I also understand from
Toyota that guy, what is it, Taiichi?

476
00:21:31.539 --> 00:21:33.035
>> Taiichi Ohno.

477
00:21:33.035 --> 00:21:36.984
>> Taiichi Ohno that not only did he
produce Lean though, another part that's

478
00:21:36.984 --> 00:21:41.800
very important of course to Toyota was the
idea of inventory processing and control.

479
00:21:41.800 --> 00:21:44.140
And so that one is actually called Kanban?

480
00:21:44.140 --> 00:21:45.380
>> Kanban, yep.

481
00:21:45.380 --> 00:21:47.000
Kanban, another Japanese word.

482
00:21:47.000 --> 00:21:49.407
I believe it means sign or something.

483
00:21:49.407 --> 00:21:50.103
>> Billboard, yeah, signs.

484
00:21:50.103 --> 00:21:51.566
>> Yeah, billboard,
something like that, yes.

485
00:21:51.566 --> 00:21:55.064
Basically, it really,
it literally translates a sign, but

486
00:21:55.064 --> 00:21:57.500
a better translation for it would be card.

487
00:21:57.500 --> 00:22:00.124
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because Kanban works on this principle

488
00:22:00.124 --> 00:22:01.180
of cards.

489
00:22:01.180 --> 00:22:03.560
That, it stems from Toyota.

490
00:22:03.560 --> 00:22:04.970
Right?
So, basically,

491
00:22:04.970 --> 00:22:07.760
as part of eliminating ways to
making these more efficient.

492
00:22:07.760 --> 00:22:12.150
What Taiichi Ohno found was that, a lot
of times they had a bunch of inventory.

493
00:22:12.150 --> 00:22:14.750
Right?
Just a bunch of, let's just say, mufflers.

494
00:22:14.750 --> 00:22:17.010
All right, car mufflers or
car wheels, for that matter.

495
00:22:17.010 --> 00:22:19.150
So maybe they had 10,000 wheels.

496
00:22:19.150 --> 00:22:22.710
And they're about to make 200 cars.

497
00:22:22.710 --> 00:22:24.570
Well how many wheels do I need for
200 cars?

498
00:22:24.570 --> 00:22:26.480
800 wheels.

499
00:22:26.480 --> 00:22:28.320
Right?
So if I have 10,000 wheels,

500
00:22:28.320 --> 00:22:30.930
I've got way too many wheels for
what I need.

501
00:22:30.930 --> 00:22:33.440
So all those other wheels
are just sitting there.

502
00:22:33.440 --> 00:22:34.169
Right?
Their inventory.

503
00:22:34.169 --> 00:22:37.757
And the problem with having
inventory is kind of twofold.

504
00:22:37.757 --> 00:22:38.680
Right?

505
00:22:38.680 --> 00:22:42.430
The main problem is that it's money
sitting there and you're not using it.

506
00:22:42.430 --> 00:22:43.160
Right?

507
00:22:43.160 --> 00:22:46.330
But the second thing is it
stops your company's agility.

508
00:22:46.330 --> 00:22:49.767
And what I mean by that is,
let's say that, all right,

509
00:22:49.767 --> 00:22:53.730
it's 2015,
the 2016 model cars are about to come out.

510
00:22:53.730 --> 00:22:56.440
And I decided, you know what,
instead of 16 inch wheels,

511
00:22:56.440 --> 00:22:58.780
let's go to 17 inch wheels.

512
00:22:58.780 --> 00:23:01.920
Well, we've kinda got 8,000
wheels sitting here in inventory,

513
00:23:01.920 --> 00:23:05.235
let's just stay with the 16 inches, so
we can burn through all this inventory.

514
00:23:05.235 --> 00:23:06.830
Right?
That's what companies do.

515
00:23:06.830 --> 00:23:08.730
You gotta do that otherwise
you have eat the inventory.

516
00:23:08.730 --> 00:23:14.270
So the more inventory you have,
the smaller your ability to change is.

517
00:23:14.270 --> 00:23:15.110
Right?
You can't

518
00:23:15.110 --> 00:23:17.160
switch out because you've
got all this extra stuff.

519
00:23:17.160 --> 00:23:19.820
And inventory actually
applies to two things.

520
00:23:19.820 --> 00:23:21.430
One, inventory is just
sitting there on the ground.

521
00:23:21.430 --> 00:23:22.130
Right?
But

522
00:23:22.130 --> 00:23:25.700
also inventory applied
to work in progress.

523
00:23:25.700 --> 00:23:29.230
At anytime you can go to a Toyota
factory and they're making cars.

524
00:23:29.230 --> 00:23:31.610
There is a number of cars that
are beyond their conveyor belt.

525
00:23:31.610 --> 00:23:33.100
It could be a 100, it could be a 1000.

526
00:23:33.100 --> 00:23:36.570
And those cars are already in production,
