if I wanna make a change.

527
00:23:36.570 --> 00:23:40.060
If I say let's go to this better tire,
this time because we can get it for

528
00:23:40.060 --> 00:23:41.870
less money and it's just as good.

529
00:23:41.870 --> 00:23:44.340
Well I've kind of already
got 1000 cars in process.

530
00:23:44.340 --> 00:23:46.870
I can't change those, so
I have to wait for those to finish.

531
00:23:46.870 --> 00:23:49.374
Right?
So inventory or work in progress,

532
00:23:49.374 --> 00:23:54.089
you'll hear those terms kind of
interchangeably if you start studying.

533
00:23:54.089 --> 00:23:57.642
Kanban and you even see that
with Six Sigma and Lean also.

534
00:23:57.642 --> 00:23:59.810
It's kind of pervasive through them.

535
00:23:59.810 --> 00:24:02.030
Kanban, though,
really focuses on that inventory side.

536
00:24:02.030 --> 00:24:05.604
And it basically says instead of
sitting on a ton of inventory,

537
00:24:05.604 --> 00:24:07.790
we're going to use cards.

538
00:24:07.790 --> 00:24:11.780
And these cards will indicate
when we need to buy more tires or

539
00:24:11.780 --> 00:24:14.340
when we need to buy more steering wheels.

540
00:24:14.340 --> 00:24:16.140
And we'll apply them as we need them.

541
00:24:16.140 --> 00:24:19.600
So for example,
I might have a bin, bin and car,

542
00:24:19.600 --> 00:24:22.980
those are the two really important
terms you'll hear in Kanban.

543
00:24:22.980 --> 00:24:26.230
We'll have a bin that has a bunch
of steering wheels in it, and

544
00:24:26.230 --> 00:24:28.330
this is how it was back in the 1950s.

545
00:24:28.330 --> 00:24:31.480
That when they go to grab a steering
wheel, you look at it and

546
00:24:31.480 --> 00:24:33.600
you see how many steering
wheels are still in the bin.

547
00:24:33.600 --> 00:24:37.850
And if I get down to five or
ten steering wheels, I take a red card.

548
00:24:37.850 --> 00:24:40.509
And it may just have one word,
it may just say order, and that's it.

549
00:24:40.509 --> 00:24:42.525
It could have very detailed
information on there right,

550
00:24:42.525 --> 00:24:44.510
it's up to you how you
wanna deploy the cards.

551
00:24:44.510 --> 00:24:48.061
But let's just say it's a red card that
says order, and you drop it in the bin.

552
00:24:48.061 --> 00:24:50.670
And then someone else,
who's the ordering agent, comes along and

553
00:24:50.670 --> 00:24:54.030
sees the red card and says, oop, I need to
order steering wheels, and they order ten.

554
00:24:55.050 --> 00:24:58.345
And then, as we continue to fill
that up and to take it out again,

555
00:24:58.345 --> 00:25:00.859
when we get down to five
we drop that card back in.

556
00:25:00.859 --> 00:25:02.520
Time to order more, right.

557
00:25:02.520 --> 00:25:08.600
So the cards are an indicator of what
needs to be ordered so we can minimize

558
00:25:08.600 --> 00:25:13.090
our inventory, which saves us money,
and it allows us to change more easily.

559
00:25:13.090 --> 00:25:16.760
We can say, look we need to switch
steering wheels to this new one that's got

560
00:25:16.760 --> 00:25:18.430
volume controls built into it.

561
00:25:18.430 --> 00:25:22.058
All right, well we've only got ten in
inventory so just the next time we order,

562
00:25:22.058 --> 00:25:23.316
we're gonna switch it up.

563
00:25:23.316 --> 00:25:27.576
So on the card,
we put order new part number.

564
00:25:27.576 --> 00:25:30.040
And you drop that in the bin and
now they order the new part number and

565
00:25:30.040 --> 00:25:30.600
you move forward.

566
00:25:30.600 --> 00:25:34.954
Now this is from the 1950s and I know what
some of you guys are thinking, well I

567
00:25:34.954 --> 00:25:39.269
don't have bins, first off and secondly
this sounds pretty labor intensive.

568
00:25:39.269 --> 00:25:41.579
We've got manual cards and
people gotta write stuff.

569
00:25:41.579 --> 00:25:43.500
You see this electronically too.

570
00:25:43.500 --> 00:25:44.486
A great example,

571
00:25:44.486 --> 00:25:48.246
I don't know if any of you guys ever
used the service called Trello.

572
00:25:48.246 --> 00:25:53.017
Trello is like a to do list kind of
software for tracking your own stuff, but

573
00:25:53.017 --> 00:25:57.511
it's also great for projects and
it follows Kanban's methodology.

574
00:25:57.511 --> 00:25:59.452
When you come in and
you whip up a project,

575
00:25:59.452 --> 00:26:02.684
you create what are called lists and
the lists are effectively bins.

576
00:26:02.684 --> 00:26:06.994
I could have a bin that was called,
maybe, like,

577
00:26:06.994 --> 00:26:11.625
work breakdown structure,
or tasks, or whatever.

578
00:26:11.625 --> 00:26:14.280
So I might call it Upcoming Tasks,
all right?

579
00:26:14.280 --> 00:26:19.217
So there's that list and then I might
have a list called Work in Progress.

580
00:26:19.217 --> 00:26:21.345
These are things that
are going on right now.

581
00:26:21.345 --> 00:26:24.985
And then I might have Completed Tasks,
all right?

582
00:26:24.985 --> 00:26:26.810
So I've got three bins.

583
00:26:26.810 --> 00:26:28.552
And then in each bin,
see how it says Add a card,

584
00:26:28.552 --> 00:26:31.619
that terminology is right out of Kanban,
that's basically what they're doing.

585
00:26:31.619 --> 00:26:35.100
So I can come in here and
start to list the tasks that I've got.

586
00:26:35.100 --> 00:26:37.559
So if I'm building a car, right?

587
00:26:37.559 --> 00:26:40.948
We might have Order tires,
we might have whatever,

588
00:26:40.948 --> 00:26:44.737
each of these different items
that are going to be in here.

589
00:26:44.737 --> 00:26:48.069
And so Paint the frame, so
we're gonna paint the frame,

590
00:26:48.069 --> 00:26:50.400
we're gonna do each of things.

591
00:26:50.400 --> 00:26:54.634
And as you start to do that work, okay,
I've got this upcoming task paint a frame.

592
00:26:54.634 --> 00:26:55.977
I'm ready to start painting.

593
00:26:55.977 --> 00:26:58.389
I'm just going to drag that and
drop it in to Work in Progress.

594
00:26:58.389 --> 00:27:01.150
And so now I've moved the card.

595
00:27:01.150 --> 00:27:03.941
And if somebody comes along and
looks in the Work in Progress bin,

596
00:27:03.941 --> 00:27:06.547
they can see oh we're painting
the frame right now, right?

597
00:27:06.547 --> 00:27:10.880
And we haven't ordered the tires yet,
we probably should have done that, right?

598
00:27:10.880 --> 00:27:14.560
Or they see where maybe Order tires
is already in Completed Tasks.

599
00:27:14.560 --> 00:27:18.050
And so they can look and see the card and
they know what hasn't been done,

600
00:27:18.050 --> 00:27:22.560
what's currently being done, and
what's already done at a quick glance.

601
00:27:22.560 --> 00:27:25.963
These are cards in bins,
and it's the same idea.

602
00:27:25.963 --> 00:27:30.269
This is Kanban implemented
electronically in a modern format.

603
00:27:30.269 --> 00:27:32.665
There's tons of people out
there that use Trello and

604
00:27:32.665 --> 00:27:34.196
have never even heard of Kanban.

605
00:27:34.196 --> 00:27:37.249
And they're basically using
the principle every single day, so

606
00:27:37.249 --> 00:27:39.869
this is something that is pervasive,
we do see it a lot.

607
00:27:39.869 --> 00:27:43.482
>> Now in the area of process analysis
then, there's probably a lot more of

608
00:27:43.482 --> 00:27:45.984
the different methodologies
that are out there.

609
00:27:45.984 --> 00:27:49.541
But these are by far, probably the most
popular and probably even some of the most

610
00:27:49.541 --> 00:27:52.753
effective ones, that maybe the newer
systems are based off of, right?

611
00:27:52.753 --> 00:27:56.593
>> Yeah, and what you want to do is you
want to take this and kind of fit it for

612
00:27:56.593 --> 00:28:00.177
your own company and
you're gonna apply it differently, right,

613
00:28:00.177 --> 00:28:03.380
different people have different
needs to make it work out.

614
00:28:03.380 --> 00:28:06.118
And so, fortunately you don't
have to re-invent the wheel,

615
00:28:06.118 --> 00:28:09.736
there's plenty of organizations out there
that can kind of give you a framework for

616
00:28:09.736 --> 00:28:11.900
this, but PMI doesn't, right.

617
00:28:11.900 --> 00:28:14.784
We saw it in some of the other episodes
where we saw process improvement,

618
00:28:14.784 --> 00:28:17.259
some of the different tools and
techniques we had available.

619
00:28:17.259 --> 00:28:21.270
But PMI doesn't really get into process
improvement because that's really

620
00:28:21.270 --> 00:28:23.880
an ongoing activity,
not a project, all right.

621
00:28:23.880 --> 00:28:25.736
But there are some
standards organizations and

622
00:28:25.736 --> 00:28:27.598
other people out there
that can help us with it.

623
00:28:27.598 --> 00:28:29.920
I wanna talk about each
one just kind of in brief,

624
00:28:29.920 --> 00:28:33.277
but I know I've kind of already run
a little long on this one, Ronnie.

625
00:28:33.277 --> 00:28:37.209
So why don't we do this, why don't we
stop this one and we'll do a part two.

626
00:28:37.209 --> 00:28:40.578
And I want to talk about some of the
organizations that are out there that can

627
00:28:40.578 --> 00:28:43.896
actually kind of give you that starting
point to be able to implement these

628
00:28:43.896 --> 00:28:45.678
without having to reinvent the wheel.

629
00:28:45.678 --> 00:28:48.489
>> All right so in this episode
remember that we took a look at three

630
00:28:48.489 --> 00:28:52.364
of the different methodologies that you'll
probably end up finding out about which is

631
00:28:52.364 --> 00:28:53.386
going to be Six Sigma.

632
00:28:53.386 --> 00:28:54.756
Lean as well as Kanban and

633
00:28:54.756 --> 00:28:59.530
this is part of those ongoing processes
that help us to improve our efficiency.

634
00:28:59.530 --> 00:29:02.580
As well as to try and
eliminate as much waste as possible and

635
00:29:02.580 --> 00:29:06.260
also to improve that process in
inventory and control, as well.

636
00:29:06.260 --> 00:29:10.239
And that is actually what we need to make
sure that we focus on, preparing for

637
00:29:10.239 --> 00:29:11.493
the PMP exam, as well.

638
00:29:11.493 --> 00:29:14.940
So signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

639
00:29:14.940 --> 00:29:15.489
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

640
00:29:15.489 --> 00:29:17.439
>> And we'll see you next time.

641
00:29:17.439 --> 00:29:23.760
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into the world of Best Practices and Standards.  They help us to differentiate them and talk about some of the standards organization that affect projects.
episodes.title: Process Analysis Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.449
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.449 --> 00:00:13.460
Welcome to another great
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.460 --> 00:00:14.370
I'm your host Ronnie Wong,

4
00:00:14.370 --> 00:00:19.210
and we're taking a look at the PMP,
the Project Management Professional.

5
00:00:19.210 --> 00:00:21.590
And today with us, Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:21.590 --> 00:00:22.250
How's it going?

7
00:00:22.250 --> 00:00:23.190
>> It is going great, Ronnie.

8
00:00:23.190 --> 00:00:26.270
Ready to continue on with our
process analysis episode.

9
00:00:26.270 --> 00:00:30.829
If you didn't watch the last part, we got
a chance to take a look at Six Sigma,

10
00:00:30.829 --> 00:00:36.393
Lean, and and how they kind of influence
how we handle process improvement today.

11
00:00:36.393 --> 00:00:40.011
And at the very end of the episode
I said something to the effect of,

12
00:00:40.011 --> 00:00:42.930
you don't have to start from
scratch on a lot of this.

13
00:00:42.930 --> 00:00:47.420
There's a lot of organizations
out there that wanna help you

14
00:00:47.420 --> 00:00:50.350
implement efficient processes
from the very beginning and

15
00:00:50.350 --> 00:00:53.330
not have to go through a ton of
process improvement to make it better.

16
00:00:53.330 --> 00:00:57.320
So, what we have are basically,
what PMI boils down to,

17
00:00:57.320 --> 00:01:00.720
standards and best practices, all right?

18
00:01:00.720 --> 00:01:02.744
So, let's say that I'm
forming up a new company or

19
00:01:02.744 --> 00:01:05.191
I'm moving into an area that I'm
not really familiar with and

20
00:01:05.191 --> 00:01:08.035
I want to make sure that things
are running as efficiently as possible.

21
00:01:08.035 --> 00:01:12.549
And I just need a good starting point,
a good place to kind of pick up from and

22
00:01:12.549 --> 00:01:15.590
know that I'm in as good
a shape as I can be.

23
00:01:15.590 --> 00:01:20.470
And what I can do is I can look out to
the world and look out for my industry and

24
00:01:20.470 --> 00:01:23.480
say, is there a standard's body out there?

25
00:01:23.480 --> 00:01:27.440
Or is there a collective of best
practices that I can follow to at

26
00:01:27.440 --> 00:01:30.330
least put me in the best footing
from the very beginning?

27
00:01:30.330 --> 00:01:32.010
We can always change, right?

28
00:01:32.010 --> 00:01:34.860
But, at least get me
started in the right place.

29
00:01:34.860 --> 00:01:36.000
Well, the first thing we
need to understand is

30
00:01:36.000 --> 00:01:39.380
the difference between a standard and
a best practice.

31
00:01:39.380 --> 00:01:43.470
Standards are important,
best practices are even more important.

32
00:01:43.470 --> 00:01:46.970
A best practice is, it's not a law,

33
00:01:46.970 --> 00:01:50.620
it's not even a rule really its more
of a guideline or suggestion, and

34
00:01:50.620 --> 00:01:54.240
it's usually organizations that deal
with a certain kind of equipment.

35
00:01:54.240 --> 00:01:56.630
So, like in IT,
we have wireless access points.

36
00:01:57.680 --> 00:02:00.280
Wireless access points can use
a number of different frequencies and

37
00:02:00.280 --> 00:02:02.070
encryption standards and so on.

38
00:02:02.070 --> 00:02:07.850
So, there is the WIFI Alliance which
puts out a collection of best practices,

39
00:02:07.850 --> 00:02:10.490
that say if you're gonna
deploy a wireless network,

40
00:02:10.490 --> 00:02:11.410
here's how we recommend you do it.

41
00:02:11.410 --> 00:02:14.860
Here's the frequencies we recommend you
use, here's how we recommend you position

42
00:02:14.860 --> 00:02:18.850
your access points, here's how we
recommend equipment that we know will be

43
00:02:18.850 --> 00:02:24.010
compatible with each other, right, and
you can choose to take their advice and

44
00:02:24.010 --> 00:02:27.310
follow it or you could choose to
ignore it, disregard it, right.

45
00:02:27.310 --> 00:02:29.680
But the idea is that if
you don't know anything

46
00:02:29.680 --> 00:02:32.670
you can follow their best practices and
you'll end up okay.

47
00:02:32.670 --> 00:02:36.350
You might of been able to do a better job
if you had the experience, expertise,

48
00:02:36.350 --> 00:02:37.680
technique, whatever, but

49
00:02:37.680 --> 00:02:42.040
if you didn't know anything you'll do
fine following the best practices, right.

50
00:02:42.040 --> 00:02:44.576
You see that with servers,
you see it with construction,

51
00:02:44.576 --> 00:02:47.959
you see it in medical environments,
there's always these best practices.

52
00:02:47.959 --> 00:02:49.830
If you don't follow them,
what's your penalty?

53
00:02:50.860 --> 00:02:52.680
Nothing.
Well, you might fail, right?

54
00:02:52.680 --> 00:02:54.510
You might fail unnecessarily.

55
00:02:54.510 --> 00:02:58.170
Or you might know more than the people
who did these best practices.

56
00:02:58.170 --> 00:03:01.380
Because when they create a best practice,
they're trying to think about everybody.

57
00:03:01.380 --> 00:03:05.650
What's the best solution for
everybody as a whole, right.

58
00:03:05.650 --> 00:03:08.090
And the thing about that most common,
what is it?

59
00:03:08.090 --> 00:03:09.200
>> Most common denominator?

60
00:03:09.200 --> 00:03:10.590
>> Yes.
There we go.

61
00:03:10.590 --> 00:03:12.105
I usually use.

62
00:03:12.105 --> 00:03:14.230
[LAUGH] In a more sarcastic light.

63
00:03:14.230 --> 00:03:15.720
But in this case it actually makes sense.

64
00:03:15.720 --> 00:03:19.210
The lowest common denominator,
what everybody has in common.

65
00:03:19.210 --> 00:03:21.610
But you might have things
that make you different.

66
00:03:21.610 --> 00:03:22.870
And you know that.

67
00:03:22.870 --> 00:03:25.120
The best practices
organizations don't know that.

68
00:03:25.120 --> 00:03:28.340
So, you might have a very good reason for
moving away from a best practice, and

69
00:03:28.340 --> 00:03:29.130
that's perfectly fine.

70
00:03:30.150 --> 00:03:32.520
So, that's kind of the advantage
of a best practice.

71
00:03:32.520 --> 00:03:35.180
And, there's organizations out
there that are packed full of them.

72
00:03:35.180 --> 00:03:37.710
A great example would be the CMMI, right?

73
00:03:37.710 --> 00:03:40.456
Let me just bring up their website here,
the CMMI Institute.

74
00:03:40.456 --> 00:03:44.776
And what these guys do,
is they basically do a lot of things,

75
00:03:44.776 --> 00:03:48.250
they focus on capabilities, though.

76
00:03:48.250 --> 00:03:51.230
Your company does something, right?

77
00:03:51.230 --> 00:03:54.010
It produces an item that
provides a service.

78
00:03:54.010 --> 00:03:56.810
Every company does something,
unless you're in politics and then,

79
00:03:56.810 --> 00:03:57.875
you probably don't do anything.

80
00:03:57.875 --> 00:03:59.040
>> [LAUGH]
>> But everybody else,

81
00:03:59.040 --> 00:04:00.660
you do something, right?

82
00:04:00.660 --> 00:04:06.630
And they help you with what's called
a capability maturity model, right?

83
00:04:06.630 --> 00:04:10.240
How you can make sure that you're
capability is being provided

84
00:04:10.240 --> 00:04:13.430
in a mature fashion,
to use the words in their own definition.

85
00:04:13.430 --> 00:04:16.430
And these guys have a ton of
best practices processes.

86
00:04:16.430 --> 00:04:18.310
And if you want, you can even pay them,

87
00:04:18.310 --> 00:04:21.490
and they'll send consultants out to
you to help to make sure that you get

88
00:04:21.490 --> 00:04:23.774
the right processes in place
from the very beginning.

89
00:04:23.774 --> 00:04:26.610

practices is probably the easiest place.

316
00:16:17.129 --> 00:16:21.818
And then of course if you do live in
a potential or a particular potential,

317
00:16:21.818 --> 00:16:26.296
a particular country may also have
to follow those practices as well.

318
00:16:26.296 --> 00:16:30.469
So as project managers being familiar with
just both of them really do help us out

319
00:16:30.469 --> 00:16:34.600
when we start actually having to
deal with these processes as well.

320
00:16:34.600 --> 00:16:38.490
So, Don, are there any other things that
we need to really worry about as far as

321
00:16:38.490 --> 00:16:40.610
the standards and best practices?

322
00:16:40.610 --> 00:16:41.250
>> Not really.

323
00:16:41.250 --> 00:16:43.690
The ones that we've called
out are the ones that

324
00:16:43.690 --> 00:16:46.130
PMI is specifically calling
out on the exam objectives.

325
00:16:46.130 --> 00:16:47.700
So, we want to make sure
you're familiar with those.

326
00:16:47.700 --> 00:16:48.920
But there are other ones
that are out there.

327
00:16:48.920 --> 00:16:50.760
Your industry may be different.

328
00:16:50.760 --> 00:16:53.480
We didn't talk about like medical or
construction for example, and

329
00:16:53.480 --> 00:16:58.470
there's different standards that you'll
have for those guys, fire code and so on.

330
00:16:58.470 --> 00:17:03.610
Those all come into play and you have the,
what is it, NSTA for National Safety and

331
00:17:03.610 --> 00:17:07.620
so you get different ones that have
all their own different standards or

332
00:17:07.620 --> 00:17:09.290
regulations that you need to follow.

333
00:17:09.290 --> 00:17:11.340
So, just be aware of those so
that you don't,

334
00:17:11.340 --> 00:17:15.070
when you go to build a process,
you don't have to reinvent the wheel.

335
00:17:15.070 --> 00:17:16.410
You can go and look at these standards and

336
00:17:16.410 --> 00:17:20.990
follow them even optionally, I might
just choose to follow the standard so

337
00:17:20.990 --> 00:17:23.960
that I know I'm going to be compatible
with other people, knowing that if I don't

338
00:17:23.960 --> 00:17:28.930
follow it I'll still be okay, but
it doesn't hurt to try and stay in line.

339
00:17:28.930 --> 00:17:31.380
Because who knows, down the road
I might be required to do that.

340
00:17:31.380 --> 00:17:33.752
And it would be better if I
was already in that position.

341
00:17:33.752 --> 00:17:37.840
>> All right, so in this episode remember
that what we actually took a look at is

342
00:17:37.840 --> 00:17:41.220
really the differences between best
practices as well as standards.

343
00:17:41.220 --> 00:17:43.995
And we also mentioned some of
the different standards organizations that

344
00:17:43.995 --> 00:17:44.809
you'll tend to see.

345
00:17:44.809 --> 00:17:51.750
The IEEE, the ISO, the BSI or BS,
British Standard that or other.

346
00:17:51.750 --> 00:17:55.710
And then also another one that really
focuses and more on the process side,

347
00:17:55.710 --> 00:17:56.490
the CMMI.

348
00:17:57.490 --> 00:18:00.990
Those are also some of these
places that you can go and

349
00:18:00.990 --> 00:18:04.520
check out those different standards and
those best practices as well.

350
00:18:04.520 --> 00:18:06.760
So, that's a great place for
us to end this episode.

351
00:18:06.760 --> 00:18:08.090
Signing off for ITPro TV.

352
00:18:08.090 --> 00:18:09.284
I'm Ronnie Wong.

353
00:18:09.284 --> 00:18:10.160
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

354
00:18:10.160 --> 00:18:12.112
>> And we'll see you next time.

355
00:18:12.112 --> 00:18:17.839
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don finish the entire series on the PMP by taking a look the final 2 knowledge areas in the Closing Process Group: Closing the Project or Phase and Closing the Procurements. The last phase is often overlooked but its importance shouldn't be underestimated. It is here we ensure the stakeholder satisfaction, release project teams to other projects and terminate contracts.
episodes.title: Closing
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:17,170 --> 00:00:27,170
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:34,104 --> 00:00:37,453
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

4
00:00:37,453 --> 00:00:40,190
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:40,190 --> 00:00:44,340
We are back once again with another
episode of project management.

6
00:00:44,340 --> 00:00:49,390
And not just another episode,
an all special final episode.

7
00:00:49,390 --> 00:00:53,120
Yep, we are winding things down here for
the closing process.

8
00:00:53,120 --> 00:00:55,640
So, it's a pretty exciting moment,
right Ronnie?

9
00:00:55,640 --> 00:00:56,870
>> It is an exciting moment.

10
00:00:56,870 --> 00:00:59,630
I have tears in my, no I don't.

11
00:00:59,630 --> 00:01:00,170
>> Tears in your beer?

12
00:01:00,170 --> 00:01:01,545
>> Yeah, yeah, tears in my beer.

13
00:01:01,545 --> 00:01:03,270
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's right, tears in my beer,

14
00:01:03,270 --> 00:01:04,460
there you go.

15
00:01:04,460 --> 00:01:05,945
>> All right, well, the closing process.

16
00:01:05,945 --> 00:01:12,340
It is the last process
group tackled by the PMBOK.

17
00:01:12,340 --> 00:01:15,525
Actually, I guess I closed my
PMBOK down so let me fire that up.

18
00:01:15,525 --> 00:01:16,070
>> [LAUGH]
>> But,

19
00:01:16,070 --> 00:01:19,230
it's also one of the most
underrated of the processes.

20
00:01:19,230 --> 00:01:20,890
>> Right.
>> The one that gets skipped the most and

21
00:01:20,890 --> 00:01:23,680
that we'll see here is
a little bit dangerous.

22
00:01:23,680 --> 00:01:27,496
When your project is moving along, one of
the last things we think about is closing,

23
00:01:27,496 --> 00:01:30,612
and that's when we wrap everything up,
we tie up our loose ends, and

24
00:01:30,612 --> 00:01:31,880
we close the doors.

25
00:01:31,880 --> 00:01:35,770
So, we only have two process here,
it's nice and small.

26
00:01:35,770 --> 00:01:41,770
We got the close project or phase,
and the close procurements processes.

27
00:01:41,770 --> 00:01:44,320
Now, close procurements,
that's talking about contracts.

28
00:01:44,320 --> 00:01:46,420
There's not a whole ton there.

29
00:01:46,420 --> 00:01:49,950
You'll find there's not a whole ton up
here in closed project phase, either.

30
00:01:49,950 --> 00:01:53,830
This will probably be our shortest episode
on record, cuz there's just not a ton

31
00:01:53,830 --> 00:01:57,960
here, and that's part of why this
process group gets ignored so much.

32
00:01:58,980 --> 00:02:02,190
All right, now the problem we have is if
you ignore closing, you can always leave

33
00:02:02,190 --> 00:02:05,140
loose ends in your project, so
that's why this is so important.

34
00:02:05,140 --> 00:02:07,380
We're gonna take a look
at what's involved.

35
00:02:07,380 --> 00:02:09,940
The first thing I wanna point
out is the name of the process.

36
00:02:09,940 --> 00:02:13,930
We've got the closed project or
phase, right?

37
00:02:13,930 --> 00:02:15,510
It didn't use to be like that.

38
00:02:15,510 --> 00:02:20,070
If you've gotten certified under
an earlier version of the PMBOK,

39
00:02:20,070 --> 00:02:22,610
this may have just been
called the closing process.

40
00:02:22,610 --> 00:02:26,610
And they added that or phase part to
remind you that the closing process can be

41
00:02:26,610 --> 00:02:32,250
used not just at the end of your project,
but at the end of each phase.

42
00:02:32,250 --> 00:02:34,800
And, so
it's not really closing all together.

43
00:02:34,800 --> 00:02:38,670
You're closing one phase and
transitioning to the next.

44
00:02:38,670 --> 00:02:43,140
So when we were done with initiating,
we would actually close and

45
00:02:43,140 --> 00:02:43,970
then go to planning.

46
00:02:43,970 --> 00:02:47,460
And then, we would close the planning
phase and then go to executing.

47
00:02:47,460 --> 00:02:50,570
And then, we would close executing and
then go to full closing and

48
00:02:50,570 --> 00:02:51,780
then that would be the end.

49
00:02:51,780 --> 00:02:55,250
So you're actually going into
the closing process group several

50
00:02:55,250 --> 00:03:00,100
times throughout your project as we
transition from phase to phase, right?

51
00:03:00,100 --> 00:03:02,870
As we move through those
different stages of our project.

52
00:03:03,950 --> 00:03:07,935
So that's a little, I guess,
counter intuitive based on the name,

53
00:03:07,935 --> 00:03:09,530
you're closing you think
it's just the very end but

54
00:03:09,530 --> 00:03:11,082
it might be the end of
an individual phase.

55
00:03:11,082 --> 00:03:18,040
All right, now what is involved in
the actual closing of a project or phase?

56
00:03:18,040 --> 00:03:22,290
Well, what we're doing is we're taking any
loose ends that we have and just wrapping

57
00:03:22,290 --> 00:03:27,260
them up, by this point, our controlling is
pretty much done all the heavy lifting.

58
00:03:27,260 --> 00:03:30,440
When we were controlling, we did things
like validating our scope, right.

59
00:03:30,440 --> 00:03:34,140
We made sure that the deliverables
people were providing us with

60
00:03:34,140 --> 00:03:36,660
met the requirements of our scope.

61
00:03:36,660 --> 00:03:40,270
And in our control quality,
we were checking there too to make sure we

62
00:03:40,270 --> 00:03:44,270
validated our deliverables and then we
made accepted deliverables out of it.

63
00:03:44,270 --> 00:03:46,350
So, by the time we get here,

64
00:03:46,350 --> 00:03:49,520
we've already received whatever
it is that we were asking for.

65
00:03:49,520 --> 00:03:52,560
So if our project was to build a house,
the house should be done.

66
00:03:52,560 --> 00:03:53,140
>> Right.

67
00:03:53,140 --> 00:03:54,630
>> Quality control should have happened.

68
00:03:54,630 --> 00:03:57,640
Already say yep,
these are our validated deliverables.

69
00:03:57,640 --> 00:04:00,420
The validate scope process would
have kicked in to say yes,

70
00:04:00,420 --> 00:04:05,010
this house meets our needs, everything's
on here, we're good to go, all right?

71
00:04:05,010 --> 00:04:06,640
So our primary input for

72
00:04:06,640 --> 00:04:11,410
closing the project is going to be
the accepted deliverable, right?

73
00:04:11,410 --> 00:04:16,250
But if we're closing a phase, the
deliverable is something different, right?

74
00:04:16,250 --> 00:04:18,510
When we wrapped up initiating,

75
00:04:18,510 --> 00:04:22,090
what was our primary deliverable there,
a project charter.

76
00:04:22,090 --> 00:04:24,920
The project charter will what gave
us authority to be able to move

77
00:04:24,920 --> 00:04:25,640
forward with our project.

78
00:04:25,640 --> 00:04:29,260
It was the most important document
in the life of our project and

79
00:04:29,260 --> 00:04:30,460
that was the deliverable.

80
00:04:30,460 --> 00:04:33,450
So as an input to closing the phase for

81
00:04:33,450 --> 00:04:35,900
initiation, it would be
that project charter.

82
00:04:35,900 --> 00:04:38,530
If we don't have that,
we're not ready to close initiation.

83
00:04:38,530 --> 00:04:41,110
We're still in initiation, initiating.

84
00:04:41,110 --> 00:04:44,770
When we closed planning,
what was our important thing?

85
00:04:44,770 --> 00:04:46,150
The project management plan,

86
00:04:46,150 --> 00:04:49,160
which is an amalgam of a ton
of different plans, right?

87
00:04:49,160 --> 00:04:50,930
But that was our main output.

88
00:04:50,930 --> 00:04:54,070
If we didn't have our plans, we're not
ready to move out of planning yet.

89
00:04:54,070 --> 00:04:58,100
We need to stay in there and then when
we get into executing, and monitoring,

90
00:04:58,100 --> 00:05:02,920
and controlling our outputs there, are
the final accepted deliverables, right?

91
00:05:02,920 --> 00:05:04,680
So that's what we expect to see.

92
00:05:04,680 --> 00:05:07,760
So, we have different things coming in
based on which phase we're coming from.

93
00:05:09,600 --> 00:05:13,841
All right, our other inputs are the
project manager plan because in the plan

94
00:05:13,841 --> 00:05:17,300
we put how we close this out,
how we accept our deliverables.

95
00:05:17,300 --> 00:05:22,100
We talked about acceptance criteria way
back probably in episode number one,

96
00:05:22,100 --> 00:05:23,130
maybe episode number two.

97
00:05:23,130 --> 00:05:24,030
I don't know but,

98
00:05:24,030 --> 00:05:27,320
in one of our earlier episodes,
we tackled the acceptance criteria.

99
00:05:27,320 --> 00:05:29,740
How you know that the project is done.

100
00:05:29,740 --> 00:05:34,080
How, you as a project manager and whoever
the sponsor is, can come to agreement and

101
00:05:34,080 --> 00:05:35,100
say yes, it's done.

102
00:05:35,100 --> 00:05:38,340
You've achieved what we wanted to achieve,
all right.

103
00:05:38,340 --> 00:05:40,610
And then, we've got our
organizational processed assets,

104
00:05:40,610 --> 00:05:44,140
all the other information that's
a part of our company's assets.

105
00:05:45,340 --> 00:05:46,740
Now, our tools and techniques,

106
00:05:46,740 --> 00:05:50,720
super straight forward on this one,
right, because what are we really doing?

107
00:05:50,720 --> 00:05:54,440
We're looking at those accepted
deliverables and saying, are they good.

108
00:05:54,440 --> 00:05:57,300
Are we ready to transition
to that next phase?

109
00:05:57,300 --> 00:06:00,350
And that's it, and the main way to
do that is expert judgement, right?

110
00:06:00,350 --> 00:06:03,560
We use our mind powers,
our Jedi mind powers,

111
00:06:03,560 --> 00:06:07,040
to evaluate the materials and
make sure they meet our needs.

112
00:06:07,040 --> 00:06:10,500
If they don't, we find out what's
missing and we correct it, right?

113
00:06:10,500 --> 00:06:15,080
That's why this is important to do after
every phase, if you're trying to move in

114
00:06:15,080 --> 00:06:19,040
to planning but initiating is not done,
you don't have authority for

115
00:06:19,040 --> 00:06:21,980
your project yet, if you don't have that
charter in hand you don't have authority.

116
00:06:21,980 --> 00:06:25,180
So, you might do a bunch of work and
planning which costs money,

117
00:06:25,180 --> 00:06:26,420
time and money.

118
00:06:26,420 --> 00:06:29,820
And then whoever was supposed to
give you authority comes in and

119
00:06:29,820 --> 00:06:31,680
says, wait I didn't authorize this.

120
00:06:31,680 --> 00:06:32,800
What are you guys doing?

121
00:06:32,800 --> 00:06:34,032
You just wasted company time.

122
00:06:34,032 --> 00:06:36,200
>> Right.
>> Right, that's the challenge.

123
00:06:36,200 --> 00:06:41,130
So we look and we say,
based on my expert judgement,

124
00:06:41,130 --> 00:06:44,200
I'm missing these documents, we should
not move forward, not until we have them.

125
00:06:44,200 --> 00:06:47,300
Not until we have that
official authorization, right?

126
00:06:47,300 --> 00:06:49,440
Analytical techniques, same idea there.

127
00:06:49,440 --> 00:06:54,890
We just need to evaluate and
ensure that is, what is meeting our needs.

128
00:06:54,890 --> 00:06:58,590
And, you can use whatever techniques
are appropriate for that particular phase.

129
00:06:58,590 --> 00:07:02,130
We'll see that's more important
in closing procurements.

130
00:07:02,130 --> 00:07:05,840
And in meetings, it's a good idea to call
a meeting together with the project team

131
00:07:05,840 --> 00:07:10,390
members who are still around and
communicate, to ensure that all the loose

132
00:07:10,390 --> 00:07:13,240
ends are tied up cuz they may
know of things that you don't.

133
00:07:13,240 --> 00:07:14,750
Now, I made a comment there.

134
00:07:14,750 --> 00:07:17,490
I said, the project team
members that are still around.

135
00:07:18,770 --> 00:07:23,280
In our human resources management plan,
we defined not only how we

136
00:07:23,280 --> 00:07:27,760
acquire our team members, but
how we release our team members.

137
00:07:27,760 --> 00:07:30,230
As you were moving through executing,

138
00:07:30,230 --> 00:07:32,470
there are times where you no
longer need a team member.

139
00:07:32,470 --> 00:07:36,040
They've wrapped up the last activity
assigned to them, last work package or

140
00:07:36,040 --> 00:07:38,440
whatever, and so you're done with them.

141
00:07:38,440 --> 00:07:42,730
Maybe it was a sub-project manager,
and their sub-project is already done.

142
00:07:42,730 --> 00:07:45,835
Well, you can release them,
way back in the executing phase,

143
00:07:45,835 --> 00:07:49,538
somewhere in the middle, wherever they
happen to be, so they may be gone.

144
00:07:49,538 --> 00:07:53,090
This meeting is gonna be with
the team members that are left.

145
00:07:53,090 --> 00:07:55,813
If we had a project building a house.

146
00:07:55,813 --> 00:07:59,927
Just because the house is done,
doesn't mean we've released everybody.

147
00:07:59,927 --> 00:08:03,127
We're still going to be holding on
to some employees, at a minimum,

148
00:08:03,127 --> 00:08:06,052
the project manager, and
usually an accountant of some sort,

149
00:08:06,052 --> 00:08:08,220
because you're still settling financials.

150
00:08:08,220 --> 00:08:12,330
You'll still have some stakeholders
hanging around the sponsor in particular,

151
00:08:12,330 --> 00:08:15,070
so there'll still be at least
a handful of people that are attached

152
00:08:15,070 --> 00:08:16,140
to the project by the time
you reach this point.

153
00:08:16,140 --> 00:08:19,130
You may have a lot of people, right,

154
00:08:19,130 --> 00:08:21,960
If you're holding them
to do final acceptance.

155
00:08:21,960 --> 00:08:23,730
NASA's a great example of that.

156
00:08:23,730 --> 00:08:27,150
When they launch that rocket into space,
a lot of the team members are already done

157
00:08:27,150 --> 00:08:29,620
with their work, but
they stick around to see it done.

158
00:08:29,620 --> 00:08:33,410
You know, it's been a ten year project,
let's see the final result.

159
00:08:33,410 --> 00:08:37,137
So you may still have all of your
team members, it just depends.

160
00:08:37,137 --> 00:08:38,710
Now, we have that meeting.

161
00:08:38,710 --> 00:08:41,030
And based on the results of it,

162
00:08:41,030 --> 00:08:45,390
if everyone is in agreement that
the phase has reached its goals or

163
00:08:45,390 --> 00:08:49,870
the project as a whole has reached its
goals and the sponsor signs off on it.

164
00:08:49,870 --> 00:08:51,510
They accept the deliverable.

165
00:08:51,510 --> 00:08:54,450
They say yes this is what I want and
we are all done.

166
00:08:54,450 --> 00:08:58,990
Then we're ready to wrap up, and so
our output is the final product.

167
00:08:58,990 --> 00:09:01,890
The final product is what
we set out to create.

168
00:09:01,890 --> 00:09:05,842
It could be a service, not a product,
or it could be a transition.

169
00:09:05,842 --> 00:09:07,260
Right.
And by transition,

170
00:09:07,260 --> 00:09:08,870
this is at the end of a phase.

171
00:09:08,870 --> 00:09:11,440
So we transition from
initiating to planning or

172
00:09:11,440 --> 00:09:14,430
we transition from planning to executing,
right, but

173
00:09:14,430 --> 00:09:18,050
if it's the end of the project,
we have the final product or service.

174
00:09:18,050 --> 00:09:20,490
That's what comes out of this.

175
00:09:20,490 --> 00:09:24,770
You'll also have organizational process
asset updates, or paperwork and

176
00:09:24,770 --> 00:09:25,535
other documents.

177
00:09:25,535 --> 00:09:30,040
So things like where the sponsor signs
off to say, yes, I got what I want.

178
00:09:30,040 --> 00:09:30,960
I'm happy.

179
00:09:30,960 --> 00:09:32,820
You have no more obligation to me.

180
00:09:32,820 --> 00:09:36,860
The project as far as I,
the sponsor, am concerned is over.

181
00:09:36,860 --> 00:09:39,520
Now, just because the sponsor says
it's over doesn't mean the project is

182
00:09:39,520 --> 00:09:41,020
actually over.

183
00:09:41,020 --> 00:09:43,980
You still have paperwork,
you still have stuff to do.

184
00:09:43,980 --> 00:09:47,910
If you're done with the remainder of your
team members, you need to release them.

185
00:09:47,910 --> 00:09:51,030
And that means either going
back to the PMO and saying,

186
00:09:51,030 --> 00:09:52,660
hey these team members are now available.

187
00:09:52,660 --> 00:09:56,040
Or going to their functional managers and
saying hey we're done with these guys,

188
00:09:56,040 --> 00:10:01,080
you can have them back, back to full time
or whatever, we don't need them anymore.

189
00:10:01,080 --> 00:10:04,200
You normally will accompany
that with a review.

190
00:10:04,200 --> 00:10:07,020
An evaluation of that
employee's performance.

191
00:10:07,020 --> 00:10:10,610
As you release the team members,
you let their functional manager or

192
00:10:10,610 --> 00:10:13,110
you let the PMO know how they
performed on the project.

193
00:10:13,110 --> 00:10:14,190
Did they do a great job?

194
00:10:14,190 --> 00:10:15,530
Would you recommend them again?

195
00:10:16,550 --> 00:10:18,190
What were your lessons learned?

196
00:10:18,190 --> 00:10:21,320
And they don't call that out
specifically as an output here.

197
00:10:21,320 --> 00:10:24,240
But that's one of the big things
that will come out of closing,

198
00:10:24,240 --> 00:10:26,900
is that you will create a lessons learned.

199
00:10:26,900 --> 00:10:29,690
You should have been building
that all throughout your project.

200
00:10:29,690 --> 00:10:32,440
Your issue log is really what feeds that.

201
00:10:32,440 --> 00:10:37,430
And so, it will have all the things
that didn't quite go as planned, right?

202
00:10:37,430 --> 00:10:38,750
That there's some reason.

203
00:10:38,750 --> 00:10:40,190
We wanna explain what that reason was,

204
00:10:40,190 --> 00:10:44,760
about why things didn't go right, what we
did to fix it, how we got beyond that.

205
00:10:44,760 --> 00:10:48,290
So that we can add that to our
Organizational Process Assets, and

206
00:10:48,290 --> 00:10:52,390
our other project managers can look to
that and benefit from our experience, and

207
00:10:52,390 --> 00:10:54,250
we can do the same with their projects.

208
00:10:54,250 --> 00:10:57,400
We look at their data, and
we learn and benefit there too.

209
00:10:57,400 --> 00:11:00,380
>> Yeah, there's a lot of times
in this particular process,

210
00:11:00,380 --> 00:11:04,690
it's very important during the phases
to make sure that we close them out.

211
00:11:04,690 --> 00:11:09,090
And the reason why, right, is because if
we just go, OK, we're done with this phase

212
00:11:09,090 --> 00:11:12,790
and we go and we release employees and
don't even think about it, and now all

213
00:11:12,790 --> 00:11:15,660
of a sudden somebody comes out and goes,
wait a minute, we're not quite done yet.

214
00:11:15,660 --> 00:11:18,750
There's a possibility that people that are
working on our project are now assigned to

215
00:11:18,750 --> 00:11:19,690
other things.

216
00:11:19,690 --> 00:11:21,430
And now we can't call them back in, and

217
00:11:21,430 --> 00:11:24,090
now we're actually under more
constraints than we realize.

218
00:11:24,090 --> 00:11:27,800
So closing out of every phase here,
making sure that we do this properly.

219
00:11:27,800 --> 00:11:30,950
So we go, I didn't know you'd
reassigned that to somebody else.

220
00:11:30,950 --> 00:11:32,550
Well, too late now.

221
00:11:32,550 --> 00:11:35,310
So that's why making sure that
this is done, so along the way,

222
00:11:35,310 --> 00:11:37,070
this is more important than we think.

223
00:11:37,070 --> 00:11:39,540
Yeah.
>> Yeah and as you release the employees,

224
00:11:39,540 --> 00:11:42,210
the last employee to be released
is the project manager.

225
00:11:42,210 --> 00:11:44,170
>> You, yeah.
>> You're the last person to be released,

226
00:11:44,170 --> 00:11:47,480
so you wanna make sure that you've
wrapped up all of your loose ends.

227
00:11:47,480 --> 00:11:48,220
Now.

228
00:11:48,220 --> 00:11:52,680
One big area that we have, that this
doesn't really reflect, are our contracts.

229
00:11:52,680 --> 00:11:54,850
>> Yep.
>> Contracts have a way of living on

230
00:11:54,850 --> 00:11:56,980
beyond the project, right?

231
00:11:56,980 --> 00:12:01,270
So, when you write a contract one of
the main things is your statement of work.

232
00:12:01,270 --> 00:12:02,575
What work needs to be done?

233
00:12:02,575 --> 00:12:03,170
>> Mm-hm.

234
00:12:03,170 --> 00:12:07,310
>> And
assuming that the contractor does the work

235
00:12:07,310 --> 00:12:08,980
>> Then it meets the statement of work.

236
00:12:08,980 --> 00:12:12,100
Everything's done, the project is over or
the contract is over, right?

237
00:12:12,100 --> 00:12:16,520
Well, you still have that whole issue
of billing and paying and so on.

238
00:12:16,520 --> 00:12:20,600
So if the payment is late,
then there's penalties.

239
00:12:20,600 --> 00:12:26,100
I've seen this before where you
contract with somebody for $10,000.

240
00:12:26,100 --> 00:12:29,020
>> And then what happens is
the payment ends up late, and

241
00:12:29,020 --> 00:12:31,760
they assess an interest fee because of it.

242
00:12:31,760 --> 00:12:34,140
So when you do pay the $10,000,

243
00:12:34,140 --> 00:12:37,670
it turns out there was another
$25 in interest charge.

244
00:12:37,670 --> 00:12:38,430
But you didn't pay that,

245
00:12:38,430 --> 00:12:41,870
you paid the $10,000, now there's
this outstanding charge of 25 bucks.

246
00:12:41,870 --> 00:12:43,440
And it's not a lot of money.

247
00:12:43,440 --> 00:12:47,030
But it kicks around, coming back to you
every 30 days you get a notification.

248
00:12:47,030 --> 00:12:47,850
>> Yep.
>> Eventually, they send

249
00:12:47,850 --> 00:12:49,500
you to collections, things like that.

250
00:12:49,500 --> 00:12:52,620
And while your project is over,
you've released all these employees

251
00:12:52,620 --> 00:12:56,220
there's this outstanding debt that's
now turning into a legal liability.

252
00:12:56,220 --> 00:12:58,350
>> Oh, yeah.
>> You know, that turns into a big mess.

253
00:12:58,350 --> 00:13:02,530
So, our contracts have a dedicated
process specifically for that.

254
00:13:02,530 --> 00:13:04,720
And that is the close procurements.

255
00:13:04,720 --> 00:13:05,350
All right?

256
00:13:05,350 --> 00:13:07,270
And it's really common sense.

257
00:13:07,270 --> 00:13:10,380
We take our project management plan and
our procurement documents, right?

258
00:13:10,380 --> 00:13:11,870
So, our actual contracts.

259
00:13:11,870 --> 00:13:13,165
And then we just do an audit.

260
00:13:13,165 --> 00:13:13,900
>> Mm-hm.

261
00:13:13,900 --> 00:13:18,090
>> We look at the contract, we do
an audit to see if it's been fulfilled.

262
00:13:18,090 --> 00:13:20,740
If it's fulfilled,
we terminate the contract.

263
00:13:20,740 --> 00:13:22,150
We close it down.

264
00:13:22,150 --> 00:13:23,780
It's over and it's done.

265
00:13:23,780 --> 00:13:27,780
And it's extremely important
that you write a letter.

266
00:13:27,780 --> 00:13:28,910
Not a phone call.

267
00:13:28,910 --> 00:13:31,108
Not a conversation in the hallway,

268
00:13:31,108 --> 00:13:35,510
write a letter to the other party
saying this bill has been paid in full.

269
00:13:35,510 --> 00:13:37,080
You guys did exemplary work.

270
00:13:37,080 --> 00:13:38,150
Or you guys did terrible work.

271
00:13:38,150 --> 00:13:38,940
Whatever.

272
00:13:38,940 --> 00:13:43,410
You guys did work and
we've accepted the deliverable, and

273
00:13:43,410 --> 00:13:46,200
this contract is now closed.

274
00:13:46,200 --> 00:13:48,810
By sending that to them,
you're giving them in

275
00:13:48,810 --> 00:13:52,500
no uncertain terms the fact that
you think the contract is closed.

276
00:13:52,500 --> 00:13:55,370
If they think otherwise,
they'll let you know.

277
00:13:55,370 --> 00:13:57,450
This is our way of being sure.

278
00:13:57,450 --> 00:13:59,690
And get confirmation from them.

279
00:13:59,690 --> 00:14:01,820
That they're in agreement too
that the contract is closed.

280
00:14:01,820 --> 00:14:05,310
You've paid the invoice,
it's over and it's closed.

281
00:14:05,310 --> 00:14:08,580
You wanna make sure you get that in
writing so that three months from now,

282
00:14:08,580 --> 00:14:11,850
six months, a year from now, if they
come back and they say wait a minute,

283
00:14:11,850 --> 00:14:12,870
this isn't right.

284
00:14:12,870 --> 00:14:13,480
You can say look,

285
00:14:13,480 --> 00:14:16,990
"We told you it was closed you
told us it was closed." It's done.

286
00:14:16,990 --> 00:14:20,430
That's water under the bridge and
now we move on.

287
00:14:20,430 --> 00:14:24,100
It helps to make sure that that contract
doesn't come back to haunt you and

288
00:14:24,100 --> 00:14:29,695
in a project, remember that projects are
not designed to be unending tasks, right?

289
00:14:29,695 --> 00:14:34,360
Because you have your project stuff, and
then you have your regular run of the mill

290
00:14:34,360 --> 00:14:37,480
work that's going on at your office,
your ongoing activities.

291
00:14:37,480 --> 00:14:40,140
A project should never be unending.

292
00:14:40,140 --> 00:14:43,490
So, when we draft contracts for
our project, they should always

293
00:14:43,490 --> 00:14:46,950
terminate within the time of the project,
but there are exceptions.

294
00:14:46,950 --> 00:14:51,080
A lot of times, that contract that you
enter into might include a warranty.

295
00:14:51,080 --> 00:14:55,633
>> So while you are getting somebody to
come and pour the foundation, they say,

296
00:14:55,633 --> 00:14:58,490
we will warrant that foundation for
ten years.

297
00:14:58,490 --> 00:15:02,570
If any defects in the foundation occur,
we'll fix it on our tab.

298
00:15:03,900 --> 00:15:07,122
Well, the project for building that
house might only take a year, so

299
00:15:07,122 --> 00:15:10,210
your involvement in the contract
is just in that first year.

300
00:15:10,210 --> 00:15:14,050
It's done, foundation's poured, house
is built, house is sold, and it's gone.

301
00:15:14,050 --> 00:15:17,230
But there's nine more years
of warranty sticking around.

302
00:15:17,230 --> 00:15:20,720
So the contract is still alive,
even though the project is over.

303
00:15:20,720 --> 00:15:22,750
So you need to plan for that.

304
00:15:22,750 --> 00:15:24,710
That's part of closing the procurements,

305
00:15:24,710 --> 00:15:27,875
is that we will need to change
who the point of contact is.

306
00:15:27,875 --> 00:15:29,100
Right.

307
00:15:29,100 --> 00:15:32,880
You, as the project manager, aren't
attached to that house anymore, right.

308
00:15:32,880 --> 00:15:35,740
So you don't need to be the point
of contact for that warranty.

309
00:15:35,740 --> 00:15:37,400
It needs to change to
whoever the owner is.

310
00:15:37,400 --> 00:15:40,070
Or the functional manager, whoever it
is that's going to be responsible for

311
00:15:40,070 --> 00:15:43,180
that entity,
they become the person who runs that.

312
00:15:43,180 --> 00:15:45,430
You see this in like automotive plants.

313
00:15:45,430 --> 00:15:49,625
You might have a project to design
the new assembly line procedures for,

314
00:15:49,625 --> 00:15:51,840
what car were we using the Ford Focus?

315
00:15:51,840 --> 00:15:55,509
So you're designing the 2015
Ford Focus assembly line right?

316
00:15:55,509 --> 00:15:59,363
Well your project builds
the assembly line, that's done.

317
00:15:59,363 --> 00:16:02,521
Now the assembly line has to kick in and
work.

318
00:16:02,521 --> 00:16:04,797
And they'll manufacture that car for
an entire year, and

319
00:16:04,797 --> 00:16:07,340
they'll make hundreds of
thousands of that vehicle.

320
00:16:07,340 --> 00:16:10,672
Well, for that remaining year, you don't
need to be the point of contact for

321
00:16:10,672 --> 00:16:13,130
all that equipment and
service and maintenance.

322
00:16:13,130 --> 00:16:15,610
You plan for it, but
you don't need to be the point of contact.

323
00:16:15,610 --> 00:16:17,790
It now transitions over to
the functional managers,

324
00:16:17,790 --> 00:16:21,490
the people who are actually going to be
operating that equipment on a daily basis.

325
00:16:21,490 --> 00:16:23,890
So, that's part of
closing our procurements,

326
00:16:23,890 --> 00:16:26,040
is wrapping up that stuff, too.

327
00:16:26,040 --> 00:16:29,800
So the contract may live on, but
you're not tied to it anymore.

328
00:16:29,800 --> 00:16:31,900
Your project is no longer tied to it.

329
00:16:31,900 --> 00:16:35,870
So we have to audit any contracts
to look for areas like that,

330
00:16:35,870 --> 00:16:38,630
areas where stuff continues to
be on the end of the project.

331
00:16:38,630 --> 00:16:45,010
>> A lot of times these audits also reveal
where you thought that the contract, when

332
00:16:45,010 --> 00:16:48,863
it was developed during planning or during
the initiation here, we said this is rock

333
00:16:48,863 --> 00:16:52,240
solid, and then as you start carrying the
process through, you might say this was

334
00:16:52,240 --> 00:16:55,460
really not something we really needed
to include in here, and this is good.

335
00:16:55,460 --> 00:16:57,510
Again, it goes into those lessons learned.

336
00:16:57,510 --> 00:17:00,560
So doing this particular auditing
is a very important process for

337
00:17:00,560 --> 00:17:02,105
us, especially into the future.

338
00:17:02,105 --> 00:17:03,300
>> Yeah.

339
00:17:03,300 --> 00:17:06,940
And at this time, if there's anything
extra that we want to negotiate in,

340
00:17:06,940 --> 00:17:08,820
we've got our procurement negotiations.

341
00:17:08,820 --> 00:17:11,120
You may wanna extend
that warranty beyond or

342
00:17:11,120 --> 00:17:13,580
whatever other types of services
you might wanna provide.

343
00:17:13,580 --> 00:17:16,220
Maybe there's some features you tried
to add before, and they said you know,

344
00:17:16,220 --> 00:17:17,980
let's push that off to another project.

345
00:17:17,980 --> 00:17:20,050
Well, we can start to kick
some of that off, but

346
00:17:20,050 --> 00:17:23,340
you do not want to initiate a new
project inside of this one.

347
00:17:23,340 --> 00:17:24,710
It does need to be a separate project.

348
00:17:24,710 --> 00:17:26,720
So those negotiations can happen and

349
00:17:26,720 --> 00:17:29,750
kinda start here but
not to be a part of the project.

350
00:17:29,750 --> 00:17:32,120
Your records management
system is gonna be important.

351
00:17:32,120 --> 00:17:35,550
You need to save a copy of every contract.

352
00:17:35,550 --> 00:17:36,960
Every single contract that you sign,

353
00:17:36,960 --> 00:17:40,910
you should save a copy because
the project is over, right?

354
00:17:40,910 --> 00:17:44,590
But if something ever resurfaces down
the road, you start getting sent into

355
00:17:44,590 --> 00:17:48,030
collections for some reason, you need to
be able to go and pull the record of that.

356
00:17:48,030 --> 00:17:51,790
So your records management system is
where we're going to store that, right?

357
00:17:51,790 --> 00:17:54,380
Our final outputs, well,
a closed procurement.

358
00:17:54,380 --> 00:17:57,411
The contract, when it's been terminated,
when it's over,

359
00:17:57,411 --> 00:17:59,260
is called a closed procurement.

360
00:17:59,260 --> 00:18:01,830
So we want to stamp that
right on the front closed.

361
00:18:01,830 --> 00:18:06,720
Contract is over, no more liabilities or
outstanding debts or

362
00:18:06,720 --> 00:18:08,550
anything like that exist on the contract.

363
00:18:08,550 --> 00:18:13,330
It's now part of history, and it goes
into our organizational process assets.

364
00:18:14,540 --> 00:18:16,440
So that's where that ends up.

365
00:18:16,440 --> 00:18:20,808
When the last contract is closed and
all of our objectives have been met and

366
00:18:20,808 --> 00:18:24,966
our sponsor signs off on the deliverable
and everything is complete,

367
00:18:24,966 --> 00:18:29,427
that's the point where you,
as the product manager, release yourself.

368
00:18:29,427 --> 00:18:30,042
Right.

369
00:18:30,042 --> 00:18:34,526
>> And now you go back into the PMO pool
or out into the job market if that's

370
00:18:34,526 --> 00:18:39,680
the kind of contract you were on, and
you move on to your next project, right?

371
00:18:39,680 --> 00:18:42,200
This becomes a part of your history.

372
00:18:42,200 --> 00:18:45,130
Now, it is recommend that
you create a very good

373
00:18:45,130 --> 00:18:46,540
document collection of your project.

374
00:18:46,540 --> 00:18:48,350
>> Right.
>> And one of the things that I do is

375
00:18:48,350 --> 00:18:50,230
I create, I call it my project book.

376
00:18:50,230 --> 00:18:52,970
And so when the project is done,
you collect your plan and

377
00:18:52,970 --> 00:18:57,840
all of your other paperwork, your quotes,
your RFQs, RFPs, all that other stuff, and

378
00:18:57,840 --> 00:19:00,430
you collect it together
into one big fat document.

379
00:19:00,430 --> 00:19:03,880
It might be electronic, mine usually are,
just a bunch of PDFs, or

380
00:19:03,880 --> 00:19:06,750
it might be a physical book
that you can hold on to.

381
00:19:06,750 --> 00:19:12,530
When it's done, though, just be aware that
that project book is not your property.

382
00:19:12,530 --> 00:19:16,050
It's the property of the company
that you performed the project for.

383
00:19:16,050 --> 00:19:21,110
So if you leave that company and go work
somewhere else, do not take that project

384
00:19:21,110 --> 00:19:24,780
with you to use as a template, to say I'll
just use this and mirror it for this next

385
00:19:24,780 --> 00:19:28,650
project because it's full of information
that pertains to the other company.

386
00:19:28,650 --> 00:19:32,320
So understanding the intellectual property
rights of the data that you generate with

387
00:19:32,320 --> 00:19:36,030
a project is really important from
the ethics side of things, and

388
00:19:36,030 --> 00:19:38,550
you may see questions on
the exam regarding that.

389
00:19:38,550 --> 00:19:39,050
>> Yeah.

390
00:19:40,350 --> 00:19:43,220
>> Alright, so when that's done,
we basically double-back to our closed

391
00:19:43,220 --> 00:19:46,570
project or phase, and we ensure that
everything's wrapped up, right?

392
00:19:46,570 --> 00:19:49,960
Again, using our expert judgment,
we have any final meetings that we need to

393
00:19:49,960 --> 00:19:52,700
have with the sponsor,
with any other key stakeholders,

394
00:19:52,700 --> 00:19:56,040
anybody who needs to be involved, and
now, we're ready to shut it down.

395
00:19:56,040 --> 00:19:58,653
Now, they used to actually call
out celebrate in here, and

396
00:19:58,653 --> 00:19:59,656
they did remove that.

397
00:19:59,656 --> 00:20:00,861
But it doesn't mean you can't, right?

398
00:20:00,861 --> 00:20:05,135
A lot of people do have an end of project
celebration just to show hey, we did it.

399
00:20:05,135 --> 00:20:07,919
We wrapped it up,
you know an awards ceremony recognition,

400
00:20:07,919 --> 00:20:09,883
I think we did see that
in another process,

401
00:20:09,883 --> 00:20:14,290
but you know, that's the kind of thing
that happens at the end of the project.

402
00:20:14,290 --> 00:20:19,305
Now your project might have been a very
short one like our arcade cabinet

403
00:20:19,305 --> 00:20:20,240
build-out project, right?

404
00:20:20,240 --> 00:20:23,890
That's just a couple of weeks, or it
might be a massive project like launching

405
00:20:23,890 --> 00:20:28,920
the Mars Rover and exploring Mars
where it's expanded over 15 years now.

406
00:20:29,950 --> 00:20:31,740
Projects vary in size.

407
00:20:31,740 --> 00:20:36,490
So this closing phase could be very
drawn out, could be very protracted

408
00:20:36,490 --> 00:20:39,210
if you've got a lot to wrap up,
if you've got a ton of contracts.

409
00:20:39,210 --> 00:20:41,560
You might have to get lawyers involved
before you close things down.

410
00:20:41,560 --> 00:20:42,120
>> Yeah.

411
00:20:42,120 --> 00:20:43,740
>> That is not uncommon.

412
00:20:43,740 --> 00:20:47,990
But in small and medium size projects,
closing is usually the blink of an eye.

413
00:20:47,990 --> 00:20:50,250
The risk here is if we don't do it,

414
00:20:50,250 --> 00:20:53,940
there's two main risks that
they call out in the pinby.

415
00:20:53,940 --> 00:20:57,750
Risk number one is that the sponsor might
not be satisfied with what they get.

416
00:20:57,750 --> 00:20:59,400
So you think the project is over,

417
00:20:59,400 --> 00:21:02,830
you wrap it up, and three months later
the sponsor's like this isn't right,

418
00:21:02,830 --> 00:21:04,850
this isn't right, this isn't right,
you need to fix it.

419
00:21:04,850 --> 00:21:06,420
Well, you don't have your team anymore.

420
00:21:06,420 --> 00:21:09,090
Everything's torn down, and
now you've got a problem.

421
00:21:09,090 --> 00:21:12,230
And the other side is
outstanding contracts, right?

422
00:21:12,230 --> 00:21:15,650
So you have procurements that
are still active that got overlooked.

423
00:21:15,650 --> 00:21:17,190
Payments didn't get issued.

424
00:21:17,190 --> 00:21:21,060
This is, I mentioned it earlier, you tell
the accounting department to cut a check,

425
00:21:21,060 --> 00:21:22,349
but if you don't follow up,

426
00:21:22,349 --> 00:21:25,300
you don't actually know if
the check got issued or not.

427
00:21:25,300 --> 00:21:28,389
And so you might have something going
to collections, your project is over,

428
00:21:28,389 --> 00:21:29,148
you walk away, and

429
00:21:29,148 --> 00:21:32,300
now the accounting department is dealing
with a bill they don't understand.

430
00:21:32,300 --> 00:21:34,080
That's the kind of thing that can happen.

431
00:21:34,080 --> 00:21:36,350
So closing is very important, right?

432
00:21:37,380 --> 00:21:41,190
All that being said, though, it does make
up a very small portion of the final exam.

433
00:21:41,190 --> 00:21:42,500
Because, well you guys see right here,

434
00:21:42,500 --> 00:21:45,710
we've got a maximum of three
values in each of these.

435
00:21:45,710 --> 00:21:48,790
It is not a giant process area,
you know, so.

436
00:21:48,790 --> 00:21:49,290
>> Yep.

437
00:21:51,370 --> 00:21:52,210
>> All right, but

438
00:21:52,210 --> 00:21:57,190
with that, that is the final
information involved in the PMP exam,

439
00:21:57,190 --> 00:22:01,030
the Project Management Professional exam,
so it's now time for us to wrap that up.

440
00:22:01,030 --> 00:22:01,570
>> It is.

441
00:22:01,570 --> 00:22:02,900
>> We need to go into our closing phase.

442
00:22:02,900 --> 00:22:04,970
>> Yes we do.
>> Do we have any outstanding contracts?

443
00:22:04,970 --> 00:22:05,905
>> Probably just mine.

444
00:22:05,905 --> 00:22:08,450
>> [LAUGH] I don't think we're
gonna pay you anymore, Ronnie, so

445
00:22:08,450 --> 00:22:10,210
we'll see how that works out.

446
00:22:10,210 --> 00:22:12,310
So that's basically it.

447
00:22:13,720 --> 00:22:17,206
Keep in mind, if you have any questions
on any of this cuz it was a ton,

448
00:22:17,206 --> 00:22:20,550
I mean we really went from
initiating all the way into closing,

449
00:22:20,550 --> 00:22:23,373
if you have questions on any of it,
definitely make sure you ask.

450
00:22:23,373 --> 00:22:24,017
>> Right.
>> Right?

451
00:22:24,017 --> 00:22:27,440
You can go to itpro.tv/live
if we're recording a show.

452
00:22:27,440 --> 00:22:31,080
Well, we're kinda wrapping this one up,
but if we're live,

453
00:22:31,080 --> 00:22:33,590
you can post right in the chat
room beneath the video.

454
00:22:33,590 --> 00:22:36,560
If you have questions about anything else,
use the Q&A forums.

455
00:22:36,560 --> 00:22:37,736
>> Right.
>> Jump right in there.

456
00:22:37,736 --> 00:22:40,545
You'll see the link that says Q&A
at the top of all of our pages.

457
00:22:40,545 --> 00:22:41,461
It takes you into the forums.

458
00:22:41,461 --> 00:22:42,828
You can post your questions there and
answers.

459
00:22:42,828 --> 00:22:43,489
We monitor.

460
00:22:43,489 --> 00:22:46,630
And so definitely take advantage of that.

461
00:22:46,630 --> 00:22:48,400
It is there for you.

462
00:22:48,400 --> 00:22:50,470
I feel like I'm leaving something out.

463
00:22:51,630 --> 00:22:52,450
What am I leaving out?

464
00:22:52,450 --> 00:22:54,270
>> I don't, I can't think of anything.

465
00:22:54,270 --> 00:22:59,030
>> All right, well, let me just give
you guys a couple of words of advice.

466
00:22:59,030 --> 00:23:01,440
First off, make sure you study hard.

467
00:23:01,440 --> 00:23:04,850
If you haven't already,
I would get a copy of the PMBOK.

468
00:23:04,850 --> 00:23:07,588
If you just buy it outright,
it's fairly expensive.

469
00:23:07,588 --> 00:23:09,380
I recommend you join the PMI.

470
00:23:09,380 --> 00:23:11,870
If you join
the Project Management Institute,

471
00:23:11,870 --> 00:23:16,460
the one year membership fee will
get you a free copy of the PMBOK,

472
00:23:16,460 --> 00:23:18,080
which is already worth it
>> Right.

473
00:23:18,080 --> 00:23:20,850
>> But the other thing is it will
get you discount on the exam

474
00:23:20,850 --> 00:23:26,100
that effectively pays for the one year of
membership, so you save money by doing it.

475
00:23:26,100 --> 00:23:27,360
So I really do encourage you to do that.

476
00:23:27,360 --> 00:23:28,960
You also get access to webinars and

477
00:23:28,960 --> 00:23:32,430
all sorts of other things that
help you to expand your knowledge.

478
00:23:32,430 --> 00:23:34,390
But that PDF copy of
the PMBOK is really handy.

479
00:23:34,390 --> 00:23:37,170
Now, I've referred to it
all throughout the show.

480
00:23:37,170 --> 00:23:41,710
Just remember that the PMBOK is not
arranged in chronological order.

481
00:23:41,710 --> 00:23:43,810
It's not arranged in
the order a project executes.

482
00:23:43,810 --> 00:23:47,760
So we did that during the show
cuz it makes more sense, right?

483
00:23:47,760 --> 00:23:49,700
But if you break open
their table of contents,

484
00:23:49,700 --> 00:23:52,670
you'll see where it's
organized by knowledge area.

485
00:23:52,670 --> 00:23:57,420
So all of the scope management
stuff is right there.

486
00:23:57,420 --> 00:23:59,020
Let me jump down a little further.

487
00:23:59,020 --> 00:24:02,080
So you'll get all of
the scheduling is in one place.

488
00:24:02,080 --> 00:24:06,800
The planning for scheduling, the execution
for scheduling, the monitoring/controlling

489
00:24:06,800 --> 00:24:10,630
for scheduling, and the closing for
scheduling all right in one chapter.

490
00:24:10,630 --> 00:24:15,210
And so if it basically does the life
cycle of a project from that perspective.

491
00:24:15,210 --> 00:24:20,330
And if you're trying to get the whole
picture, that gets a little confusing.

492
00:24:20,330 --> 00:24:23,200
But if you're a team member and
all you care about is the schedule,

493
00:24:23,200 --> 00:24:24,710
that's actually a good way to arrange it.

494
00:24:24,710 --> 00:24:26,710
You can read right through there and
just see what you want.

495
00:24:26,710 --> 00:24:29,110
So depending on your need,
that may be very valuable.

496
00:24:29,110 --> 00:24:32,600
The PMBOK is designed to be a reference
that you grab off the shelf to look up

497
00:24:32,600 --> 00:24:33,890
something real quick.

498
00:24:33,890 --> 00:24:36,920
It's not designed to be a textbook
you read cover to cover,

499
00:24:36,920 --> 00:24:39,930
so, that's one of
the challenges of learning.

500
00:24:39,930 --> 00:24:44,190
But I do recommend it, especially since
it's where the test questions come from,

501
00:24:44,190 --> 00:24:48,180
this and the code of conduct
that you can download from PMI.

502
00:24:48,180 --> 00:24:52,980
We posted links way back in
Episode Number One on how to get that.

503
00:24:52,980 --> 00:24:53,990
Although there's another one.

504
00:24:53,990 --> 00:24:57,860
If you sign up for the PMI, they actually
send you a copy of the code of conduct,

505
00:24:57,860 --> 00:24:58,660
the code of ethics.

506
00:24:58,660 --> 00:25:00,570
So you'll get a paper copy of that.

507
00:25:00,570 --> 00:25:02,390
It's six, seven pages.

508
00:25:02,390 --> 00:25:03,340
>> Yeah.
>> It's not very big.

509
00:25:03,340 --> 00:25:05,070
You can read it in one
sitting pretty easy.

510
00:25:06,690 --> 00:25:09,170
All right.
Well Ronnie, I think that's it.

511
00:25:09,170 --> 00:25:11,540
>> I think that's it.
>> It's been a long road, but we made it.

512
00:25:11,540 --> 00:25:14,010
So, alright well ladies and gentlemen,

513
00:25:14,010 --> 00:25:18,320
I hope you guys enjoyed the show,
signing off for itpro.tv, I'm Don Pezet.

514
00:25:18,320 --> 00:25:19,270
>> and I'm Ronnie Wong.

515
00:25:19,270 --> 00:25:20,962
>> And we will see you next time.

516
00:25:20,962 --> 00:25:30,962
[MUSIC]

517
00:25:33,215 --> 00:25:38,390
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into the project management tasks found the January 2016 objectives for the PMP exam.  The describe the tasks, skills and techniques and the processes that Project Managers should know and use in their Projects.
episodes.title: Project Management Tasks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.421
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.421 --> 00:00:12.731
Welcome to another great
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.735 --> 00:00:17.715
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today we're
taking a look at the project management

4
00:00:17.715 --> 00:00:22.635
professionals exam objectives, and
who better to help us than Mr. Don Pezet.

5
00:00:22.635 --> 00:00:23.415
How's it going, Don?

6
00:00:23.415 --> 00:00:27.525
>> It is going great, Ronnie, and
I know what you guys are thinking.

7
00:00:27.525 --> 00:00:31.235
Exam objectives, I don't want to watch
this, but let's approach it from

8
00:00:31.235 --> 00:00:34.630
a slightly different angle and
not think of them as exam objectives.

9
00:00:34.630 --> 00:00:40.030
When the PMI builds the exam that you're
going to be taking, what they do is,

10
00:00:40.030 --> 00:00:43.710
they don't think of it in terms
of straight out of the Pin-Bot.

11
00:00:43.710 --> 00:00:47.590
They don't think of it in terms of
this process group, or that process,

12
00:00:47.590 --> 00:00:48.890
this tool or technique.

13
00:00:48.890 --> 00:00:51.320
What they do is they
think of it in terms of,

14
00:00:51.320 --> 00:00:54.010
how are you going to
apply this in real life?

15
00:00:54.010 --> 00:00:58.750
And so what they do is they basically
take your role as a project manager and

16
00:00:58.750 --> 00:01:00.550
they break it down into what they call,
tasks.

17
00:01:00.550 --> 00:01:04.090
It's easy to confuse with
the tasks that we schedule,

18
00:01:04.090 --> 00:01:07.170
the activities that we schedule,
inside of a project, but

19
00:01:07.170 --> 00:01:12.070
they're tasks that you perform as part
of your job as a project manager.

20
00:01:12.070 --> 00:01:15.600
And so, when they create their exam
objectives, it's really just a laundry

21
00:01:15.600 --> 00:01:21.210
list of the stuff you do every day, and
what you need to know to do it, right?

22
00:01:21.210 --> 00:01:24.090
So it's not as bad as some other exams
that are out there where we have

23
00:01:24.090 --> 00:01:27.410
this huge outline of a ton of crazy
things that don't make a lot of sense.

24
00:01:27.410 --> 00:01:30.510
This one you can read down the list like,
all right, well, I do that,

25
00:01:30.510 --> 00:01:33.580
I do that, I do that, too,
and here's how I do it.

26
00:01:33.580 --> 00:01:35.700
Here's the things that I use to do it.

27
00:01:35.700 --> 00:01:40.470
So, I wanna just spend some time to go
over that outline that they provide,

28
00:01:40.470 --> 00:01:42.770
to make sure you guys understand
how that process works.

29
00:01:42.770 --> 00:01:45.110
Now, this is completely optional.

30
00:01:45.110 --> 00:01:46.970
If you've watched every other episode, and

31
00:01:46.970 --> 00:01:49.590
you're comfortable with all the material,
you can skip this episode.

32
00:01:49.590 --> 00:01:51.460
You'll do just fine on the exam.

33
00:01:51.460 --> 00:01:56.270
But if you're trying to correlate the
stuff that we talked about in all of our

34
00:01:56.270 --> 00:02:00.450
episodes with the official exam outline,
it can be a little challenging sometimes,

35
00:02:00.450 --> 00:02:02.170
and that's what this episode
is designed to help with.

36
00:02:02.170 --> 00:02:04.350
It's to show you how
that connection works.

37
00:02:05.390 --> 00:02:09.800
So let's start at the beginning
with project initiation, right,

38
00:02:09.800 --> 00:02:12.200
the initiating phase of a project.

39
00:02:12.200 --> 00:02:16.160
And what I did is I took
the PMI's exam outline, and

40
00:02:16.160 --> 00:02:19.670
I just turned it into some simple tables
that I could bring up here on the screen.

41
00:02:19.670 --> 00:02:22.020
And we'll kind of run through
those different tasks.

42
00:02:22.020 --> 00:02:23.510
So, let's take a look at that here.

43
00:02:23.510 --> 00:02:26.780
And what I've got here is
Domain 1: Initiating, right.

44
00:02:26.780 --> 00:02:30.550
So when we do project initiation,
this is where the project kicks off.

45
00:02:30.550 --> 00:02:34.450
And the PMI has identified
eight different tasks

46
00:02:34.450 --> 00:02:38.090
that a project manager may
undertake as a part of that, right.

47
00:02:38.090 --> 00:02:41.780
And most of these are pretty
self-explanatory, right.

48
00:02:41.780 --> 00:02:45.910
We need to perform a project assessment
based upon available information.

49
00:02:47.100 --> 00:02:47.680
What does that mean?

50
00:02:47.680 --> 00:02:50.810
All right, well,
if you're about to do a project,

51
00:02:50.810 --> 00:02:55.440
you kinda need to know what the project
is, how you're gonna move forward with it,

52
00:02:55.440 --> 00:02:57.900
what you need to do,
what are your responsibilities?

53
00:02:57.900 --> 00:02:59.960
And where do you find
all that information?

54
00:02:59.960 --> 00:03:03.020
You find it from lessons
learned in previous projects.

55
00:03:03.020 --> 00:03:05.670
You find it from meetings
with relevant stakeholders.

56
00:03:05.670 --> 00:03:09.240
You find it from your evaluations,

57
00:03:09.240 --> 00:03:12.440
your feasibility evaluations,
if they've been done.

58
00:03:12.440 --> 00:03:14.610
They may not have been done at this point.

59
00:03:14.610 --> 00:03:17.500
So you find it from all the information
that's basically laying around your

60
00:03:17.500 --> 00:03:20.390
company that kicked off this project,
right.

61
00:03:20.390 --> 00:03:23.010
And that's what I mean by when I
say this is kinda self-explanatory.

62
00:03:23.010 --> 00:03:26.190
This stuff just makes sense,
these are the tasks that we perform.

63
00:03:26.190 --> 00:03:30.760
But from PMI's perspective,
how do you do this?

64
00:03:30.760 --> 00:03:34.710
Well, they break it down in their
objectives based on knowledge,

65
00:03:34.710 --> 00:03:36.950
skills and processes.

66
00:03:36.950 --> 00:03:40.070
So if I want to gather this information
together I need certain knowledge skills.

67
00:03:40.070 --> 00:03:42.260
Things like analytical skills.

68
00:03:42.260 --> 00:03:43.740
I need to be able to
look at information and

69
00:03:43.740 --> 00:03:47.790
analyze it to be able to use
it in my own context, right?

70
00:03:47.790 --> 00:03:51.460
And that's a skill that we develop as we
understand how our company does business,

71
00:03:51.460 --> 00:03:53.520
and the resources that
are available to us.

72
00:03:53.520 --> 00:03:56.700
Benefit analysis techniques,
we covered those in other episodes, right,

73
00:03:56.700 --> 00:03:59.910
ways than we can do cost to
benefit analysis, whether or

74
00:03:59.910 --> 00:04:01.430
not this actually meets our goals.

75
00:04:01.430 --> 00:04:03.340
We can do our scope verification,

76
00:04:03.340 --> 00:04:06.400
all those different pieces that are out
there that help us to evaluate whether or

77
00:04:06.400 --> 00:04:09.040
not this is moving in the right direction,
right?

78
00:04:09.040 --> 00:04:11.110
Elements of a project charter.

79
00:04:11.110 --> 00:04:14.630
So when you draft that project charter,
if you're the one that drafts it, or

80
00:04:14.630 --> 00:04:18.490
if it's already been drafted,
what each of those pieces mean

81
00:04:18.490 --> 00:04:22.690
in that charter as far as influencing what
you're gonna be doing in the project.

82
00:04:22.690 --> 00:04:24.390
Estimation tools and techniques.

83
00:04:24.390 --> 00:04:27.470
It's all about estimates at
the very beginning of a project.

84
00:04:27.470 --> 00:04:29.960
You don't have hard data to rely on, so

85
00:04:29.960 --> 00:04:31.820
you're trying to estimate
what it's gonna be like,

86
00:04:31.820 --> 00:04:35.820
knowing that we can refine all that in the
planning phase and start to nail it down.

87
00:04:35.820 --> 00:04:38.370
And then just strategic management.

88
00:04:38.370 --> 00:04:41.610
And that's strategic management
of resources, it could be people,

89
00:04:41.610 --> 00:04:43.660
it could be money,
it could be the schedule, right?

90
00:04:43.660 --> 00:04:46.290
It's strategic management
of all of that that, and

91
00:04:46.290 --> 00:04:48.370
making sure everything moves forward.

92
00:04:48.370 --> 00:04:51.190
Now, that sounds like a lot
of stuff because it is.

93
00:04:51.190 --> 00:04:55.080
But when you read the PMBOK it doesn't
sound like a lot of stuff cuz there's only

94
00:04:55.080 --> 00:04:58.440
two processes, develop a project charter,
and identify stakeholders.

95
00:04:58.440 --> 00:04:59.490
And that's it.

96
00:04:59.490 --> 00:05:01.590
And we covered those in other episodes.

97
00:05:01.590 --> 00:05:05.550
But the key thing is that each of these
have a number of tools and techniques.

98
00:05:05.550 --> 00:05:08.940
And that's where these knowledge and
skills come in, are those tools and

99
00:05:08.940 --> 00:05:10.150
techniques, right.

100
00:05:10.150 --> 00:05:16.160
So all of this comes into play as we
do our project assessment, right?

101
00:05:16.160 --> 00:05:19.880
Figure out what our footing is before
we launch off on this big project.

102
00:05:19.880 --> 00:05:22.730
We identify our key deliverables.

103
00:05:22.730 --> 00:05:26.955
We're not gonna need that right away,
but we need it before we set a scope.

104
00:05:26.955 --> 00:05:29.745
And the scope is typically
part of the charter, so

105
00:05:29.745 --> 00:05:32.565
we do need it before
we move into planning.

106
00:05:32.565 --> 00:05:34.855
There are some projects where they
move forward in the planning and

107
00:05:34.855 --> 00:05:36.215
they haven't solidified their scope yet.

108
00:05:36.215 --> 00:05:39.085
It's dangerous, but
it can be done and it can work out,

109
00:05:39.085 --> 00:05:40.640
but you gotta be really careful with that.

110
00:05:40.640 --> 00:05:42.770
We need to know what those key
deliverables are because that's

111
00:05:42.770 --> 00:05:44.760
how we're gonna measure our success.

112
00:05:44.760 --> 00:05:47.960
If my key deliverable is,
maybe we're in construction,

113
00:05:47.960 --> 00:05:52.560
so to have a house built and ready for
sale by January 1st, 2017, all right?

114
00:05:54.040 --> 00:05:55.480
That's a key deliverable.

115
00:05:55.480 --> 00:05:58.230
I've now got a milestone and a date,
something that I can work towards, and

116
00:05:58.230 --> 00:05:59.590
I can hit and finish.

117
00:05:59.590 --> 00:06:02.870
And I'll know if I've missed it or
if I'm not gonna make that, right?

118
00:06:02.870 --> 00:06:06.170
If I don't have a hard set date,
I just need to build this house and

119
00:06:06.170 --> 00:06:08.440
get it ready for
sale with no hard set date.

120
00:06:08.440 --> 00:06:12.540
Well, I've got my deliverable, but I don't
really have a point of responsibility, and

121
00:06:12.540 --> 00:06:15.840
so I can start pushing it back and
pushing it back and pushing it back.

122
00:06:15.840 --> 00:06:19.810
And, technically, I'm still successful
in terms of the project, but

123
00:06:19.810 --> 00:06:23.190
because I don't have a hard set date,
whoever the stakeholders are are gonna

124
00:06:23.190 --> 00:06:26.240
