We might have budget reserves or
schedule reserves,

357
00:17:25.330 --> 00:17:28.600
we're approving the use of those reserves.

358
00:17:28.600 --> 00:17:30.595
We're managing the flow of information.

359
00:17:30.595 --> 00:17:34.070
You're getting status reports back from
the people who are doing the real work so

360
00:17:34.070 --> 00:17:36.160
you can keep track and
make sure it's happening.

361
00:17:36.160 --> 00:17:40.283
And during all of this your stakeholders
are going to be asking for information,

362
00:17:40.283 --> 00:17:44.481
and they're gonna be receiving information
and they're gonna have questions.

363
00:17:44.481 --> 00:17:49.330
And so we're have be able to manage that,
also stakeholders import changes.

364
00:17:49.330 --> 00:17:52.500
You might have somebody who's very
influential at the beginning of

365
00:17:52.500 --> 00:17:53.570
the project.

366
00:17:53.570 --> 00:17:56.360
But as the project nears the end,
their influence gets smaller and

367
00:17:56.360 --> 00:17:57.170
smaller and smaller.

368
00:17:57.170 --> 00:18:01.250
Their part is done and so
they become not a key stakeholder, but

369
00:18:01.250 --> 00:18:03.290
just a regular stakeholder or a secondary.

370
00:18:03.290 --> 00:18:05.850
And so we track all of that.

371
00:18:05.850 --> 00:18:10.390
And for that, you've got just a ton
processes available there too.

372
00:18:10.390 --> 00:18:12.050
Directing and managing the project work,

373
00:18:12.050 --> 00:18:16.340
doing quality assurance in each of these
then we implement to achieve those tasks.

374
00:18:16.340 --> 00:18:21.330
But again, it's just corresponding
to real world tasks that you perform

375
00:18:21.330 --> 00:18:22.590
as part of managing a project.

376
00:18:24.660 --> 00:18:26.880
Monitoring controlling,
this is another pretty big one.

377
00:18:26.880 --> 00:18:31.240
It's only got seven tasks, so it doesn't
seem big but they're important tasks and

378
00:18:31.240 --> 00:18:32.730
they require a lot of work.

379
00:18:32.730 --> 00:18:37.273
If you watched our earn value analysis
episode, there's formulas and

380
00:18:37.273 --> 00:18:38.088
evil math-
>> [LAUGH]

381
00:18:38.088 --> 00:18:38.813
>> That you have to do,

382
00:18:38.813 --> 00:18:40.370
there's all sorts of things there.

383
00:18:40.370 --> 00:18:44.010
But it's really important cuz here's where
we do our trend analysis and all of that.

384
00:18:44.010 --> 00:18:46.650
We're measuring performance and

385
00:18:46.650 --> 00:18:49.840
by using the tools associated with it,
we can use that to kind of predict

386
00:18:49.840 --> 00:18:53.030
the future to see what's gonna
happen as our project moves forward.

387
00:18:53.030 --> 00:18:54.720
Are we gonna be on schedule?

388
00:18:54.720 --> 00:18:57.790
Are we gonna be under or at budget?

389
00:18:57.790 --> 00:19:02.610
Are we going to meet all the requirements
as requested by the original sponsor?

390
00:19:02.610 --> 00:19:06.320
That's all stuff we can look at as we're
going through the execution phase and

391
00:19:06.320 --> 00:19:07.399
we're monitoring it and controlling it.

392
00:19:08.850 --> 00:19:10.201
Managing changes.

393
00:19:10.201 --> 00:19:13.899
That's kind of a big deal cuz change
can really get out of control if you're

394
00:19:13.899 --> 00:19:14.779
not careful, and

395
00:19:14.779 --> 00:19:18.910
you've got to make sure that it doesn't
impact your overall triple constraints.

396
00:19:20.250 --> 00:19:22.350
We've got verifying the deliverables.

397
00:19:22.350 --> 00:19:24.550
Just because somebody in
the field says that it's done,

398
00:19:24.550 --> 00:19:25.880
does that actually mean that it's done?

399
00:19:25.880 --> 00:19:27.440
Did it meet our requirements?

400
00:19:27.440 --> 00:19:28.840
We've got to verify.

401
00:19:28.840 --> 00:19:30.080
Now how do we verify?

402
00:19:30.080 --> 00:19:31.490
We've talked about it in episodes.

403
00:19:31.490 --> 00:19:34.170
Check lists and
other ways of evaluating it.

404
00:19:34.170 --> 00:19:36.680
Well again, we've got processes for that.

405
00:19:36.680 --> 00:19:39.270
How do we validate the scope?

406
00:19:39.270 --> 00:19:42.780
Validating the scope, are we actually
living up to what the scope is asking for?

407
00:19:42.780 --> 00:19:45.670
And that applies to deliverables
as well as the project as a whole.

408
00:19:45.670 --> 00:19:47.800
So we've got the tools to do that.

409
00:19:47.800 --> 00:19:50.400
Control the scope,
schedule, cost, quality.

410
00:19:50.400 --> 00:19:55.020
All these different process groups
available to achieve each of these.

411
00:19:55.020 --> 00:19:59.110
Monitoring and assessing risk,
reviewing the issue log.

412
00:19:59.110 --> 00:20:02.080
Issues happen, sometimes they don't
actually influence the project.

413
00:20:02.080 --> 00:20:05.580
I've got an employee
who is falling behind.

414
00:20:05.580 --> 00:20:07.950
So I terminate them and
I bring in a different employee.

415
00:20:07.950 --> 00:20:10.260
Now the project moves on as normal.

416
00:20:10.260 --> 00:20:12.420
But my schedule's not affected,
my budget's not affected,

417
00:20:12.420 --> 00:20:14.350
everything kinda runs fine.

418
00:20:14.350 --> 00:20:16.020
I still need the issue log to track that,

419
00:20:16.020 --> 00:20:18.760
so that I can avoid that
situation in the future.

420
00:20:18.760 --> 00:20:21.850
How can I have avoided that situation?

421
00:20:21.850 --> 00:20:24.760
And if you look at your knowledge and
skills, there's things in here

422
00:20:24.760 --> 00:20:29.670
like our measurement tools,
our project quality and so on.

423
00:20:29.670 --> 00:20:32.800
We can leverage these tools to
ensure we've got the right people.

424
00:20:32.800 --> 00:20:37.840
Tools like LEAN and Kanban and Six Sigma,
they help you spot inefficiencies

425
00:20:37.840 --> 00:20:42.280
in your system, where you might be falling
behind schedule because of defects.

426
00:20:42.280 --> 00:20:44.150
So we can identify those and clarify.

427
00:20:45.440 --> 00:20:48.081
We'll use the bad employee as an example.

428
00:20:48.081 --> 00:20:52.350
If I have a bad employee, was it my
fault for not training the employee?

429
00:20:52.350 --> 00:20:52.940
Very well could be.

430
00:20:54.180 --> 00:20:58.500
Or was it the employee just
not being a good employee?

431
00:20:58.500 --> 00:21:00.430
Not living up to what they said.

432
00:21:00.430 --> 00:21:03.940
And if that's the case how could
I identified that earlier?

433
00:21:03.940 --> 00:21:08.111
So the issue log becomes a lesson learned.

434
00:21:08.111 --> 00:21:12.191
I've got an employee who says they
can put up a brick wall, maybe I just

435
00:21:12.191 --> 00:21:16.340
do a quick test to say here, just build
me a wall that's one foot tall and

436
00:21:16.340 --> 00:21:19.401
one foot wide just real quick,
build me something.

437
00:21:19.401 --> 00:21:20.981
And actually verify that skill.

438
00:21:20.981 --> 00:21:24.263
It doesn't take long to do and it could
avoid a situation down the road or

439
00:21:24.263 --> 00:21:25.261
give me a portfolio.

440
00:21:25.261 --> 00:21:27.810
Show me the projects
you've already worked on.

441
00:21:27.810 --> 00:21:30.379
And if they don't have one
then it's a risky employee,

442
00:21:30.379 --> 00:21:32.902
cuz they might not have
the skills they attest to have.

443
00:21:35.541 --> 00:21:38.330
And then that moves us to our
last domain which is closing.

444
00:21:38.330 --> 00:21:41.890
And in closing,
you actually got quite a few tasks here.

445
00:21:41.890 --> 00:21:44.630
Although in real life,
it kinda happens really fast.

446
00:21:44.630 --> 00:21:45.410
Doesn't it?

447
00:21:45.410 --> 00:21:48.410
Remember that closing is supposed to
happen at the end of every phase.

448
00:21:48.410 --> 00:21:50.860
So you're really closing
like five different times.

449
00:21:50.860 --> 00:21:55.860
And it's the last phase when you close
that, it's closing the whole project and

450
00:21:55.860 --> 00:21:56.890
you got a ton of work there.

451
00:21:56.890 --> 00:22:00.250
So obtain final acceptance
of the deliverables.

452
00:22:00.250 --> 00:22:02.880
That happens at the end of the project.

453
00:22:02.880 --> 00:22:04.410
Transfer ownership of the deliverables.

454
00:22:04.410 --> 00:22:06.330
Again, at the end of the project.

455
00:22:06.330 --> 00:22:09.280
Obtain financial legal and
administrative closure.

456
00:22:09.280 --> 00:22:11.710
Prepare and
share the final project report.

457
00:22:11.710 --> 00:22:13.800
Collate the lessons learned.

458
00:22:13.800 --> 00:22:16.040
Now the first four were all at
the end of the project, but

459
00:22:16.040 --> 00:22:19.570
collate lessons learned,
we can do that throughout the project.

460
00:22:19.570 --> 00:22:22.191
I just finished planning,
what have I learned as a part of that?

461
00:22:22.191 --> 00:22:24.339
How could I have done that
better in the next project or

462
00:22:24.339 --> 00:22:26.360
other projects that are going
on at the same time?

463
00:22:26.360 --> 00:22:29.470
How could they benefit from
what we just went through?

464
00:22:29.470 --> 00:22:31.240
Archiving project documents.

465
00:22:31.240 --> 00:22:34.260
If you wait to the end of the project to
do that, it's a nightmare of work but

466
00:22:34.260 --> 00:22:37.410
if you do it throughout the project,
saving all your change tickets and

467
00:22:37.410 --> 00:22:38.980
everything else, all your reports.

468
00:22:38.980 --> 00:22:42.180
Then it's all kind of assembled already
and you got one nice big project book.

469
00:22:43.280 --> 00:22:47.660
And then obtaining feedback
from the relevant stakeholders,

470
00:22:47.660 --> 00:22:50.390
you can do that at the end
of the project if you want.

471
00:22:50.390 --> 00:22:54.430
But you should be doing it
throughout the whole project,

472
00:22:54.430 --> 00:22:59.380
because what may happen is a stakeholder
may have presented the project one way.

473
00:22:59.380 --> 00:23:02.340
You solidified a scope, you're moving
forward, things are running great,

474
00:23:02.340 --> 00:23:06.260
you're living up to that scope and then
the stakeholder realizes halfway through

475
00:23:06.260 --> 00:23:08.210
this is not working out
the way they wanted.

476
00:23:09.480 --> 00:23:12.580
And as a project manager you can say well,
it's too late buddy.

477
00:23:12.580 --> 00:23:13.790
We got the scope in place.

478
00:23:13.790 --> 00:23:14.630
The wheels are in motion.

479
00:23:14.630 --> 00:23:15.430
We're gonna finish this.

480
00:23:15.430 --> 00:23:17.220
You should've known better back then.

481
00:23:17.220 --> 00:23:18.740
You could do that.

482
00:23:18.740 --> 00:23:23.170
But if you communicate with that
stakeholder, you might be able to find

483
00:23:23.170 --> 00:23:27.820
that the two of you or the team, can
work to a resolution and say, okay well,

484
00:23:27.820 --> 00:23:31.200
all right I recognize that this
no longer fits your needs.

485
00:23:31.200 --> 00:23:32.690
Is there a way that we can correct that?

486
00:23:32.690 --> 00:23:35.800
Is there a way that we can try and
steer this in the right direction?

487
00:23:35.800 --> 00:23:38.340
And you may have to completely
rewrite your scope.

488
00:23:38.340 --> 00:23:40.280
You may have to backtrack
on a lot of stuff.

489
00:23:40.280 --> 00:23:44.020
But it might be better than just going and
finishing and

490
00:23:44.020 --> 00:23:46.870
having something that doesn't work
the way that we intended it to work.

491
00:23:46.870 --> 00:23:48.730
So that's open communications.

492
00:23:49.890 --> 00:23:51.865
And you'll see that in the Knowledge and

493
00:23:51.865 --> 00:23:55.831
Skills as it talks about all the various
things here, but feedback techniques.

494
00:23:55.831 --> 00:23:58.190
Which really comes from our
communications management plan.

495
00:23:58.190 --> 00:24:01.940
When you've got that plan in place,
how you talk and gather that data.

496
00:24:01.940 --> 00:24:05.630
And then in our processes,
we don't really see that come out.

497
00:24:05.630 --> 00:24:08.280
Close Procurements,
Close Project or Phase.

498
00:24:08.280 --> 00:24:13.020
Well, that's because some of these skills
are coming from the other processes that

499
00:24:13.020 --> 00:24:15.740
are outside of this particular domain.

500
00:24:15.740 --> 00:24:18.950
So we get these knowledge and skills.

501
00:24:18.950 --> 00:24:21.340
Sometimes you'll hear them
called cross knowledge and

502
00:24:21.340 --> 00:24:23.420
skills or cut over knowledge and skills.

503
00:24:23.420 --> 00:24:24.840
You'll hear those terms used.

504
00:24:24.840 --> 00:24:26.320
And that's because they're saying,
this knowledge or

505
00:24:26.320 --> 00:24:31.750
skill is not tied just to closing it's
actually tied to the project as a whole.

506
00:24:31.750 --> 00:24:34.230
You'll use these skills everywhere.

507
00:24:34.230 --> 00:24:40.340
So on the exam, they don't normally
call out a specific process.

508
00:24:40.340 --> 00:24:44.090
They called it task and
when you read that task,

509
00:24:44.090 --> 00:24:46.970
in your mind you're associating
the process with the task.

510
00:24:46.970 --> 00:24:49.200
What process would I use
to solve this problem?

511
00:24:49.200 --> 00:24:52.160
What achieves that goal and
then you go through and you solve that and

512
00:24:52.160 --> 00:24:55.925
if you've studied your processes
then it's fine, it's easy.

513
00:24:55.925 --> 00:24:58.916
If you studied the tasks instead
it becomes a lot harder.

514
00:24:58.916 --> 00:25:02.756
And that's why our show was structured
around the processes themselves and

515
00:25:02.756 --> 00:25:03.536
not the tasks.

516
00:25:03.536 --> 00:25:07.945
Because it's easy to apply one
process to more than one task.

517
00:25:07.945 --> 00:25:11.155
It's hard to take one task and
apply it to more than one process.

518
00:25:11.155 --> 00:25:13.590
So it's a little more intuitive
the way that we did it.

519
00:25:13.590 --> 00:25:16.240
But understanding both ways is important.

520
00:25:16.240 --> 00:25:19.520
So if you're every reading through PMP's
exam objectives and you're looking at

521
00:25:19.520 --> 00:25:22.460
these task lists and wondering
what's going on there, that's why.

522
00:25:22.460 --> 00:25:26.791
They're just trying to attach all
this to the real world experience.

523
00:25:26.791 --> 00:25:28.670
>> Don, that's a lot of information.

524
00:25:28.670 --> 00:25:29.480
Thank you for

525
00:25:29.480 --> 00:25:33.960
helping us to put that into a nice little
chunk of information that we can review.

526
00:25:33.960 --> 00:25:36.970
And actually helps when we see where
it does apply to our real world

527
00:25:36.970 --> 00:25:38.380
experience as well.

528
00:25:38.380 --> 00:25:41.686
Don, any parting words of wisdom
as we're preparing for this exam,

529
00:25:41.686 --> 00:25:43.231
now knowing these objectives?

530
00:25:43.231 --> 00:25:46.440
>> Yeah, I'll post these tables as part
of the show notes with the episode.

531
00:25:46.440 --> 00:25:49.920
And I need to go back and I'll edit
planning to correct that duplicate one

532
00:25:49.920 --> 00:25:52.050
that I got in there,
so that'll be accurate.

533
00:25:52.050 --> 00:25:55.120
But if you don't wanna wait on that.

534
00:25:55.120 --> 00:25:56.021
PMI, they post all this.

535
00:25:56.021 --> 00:26:00.746
If you go to the PMI's website, and
just go to the exam objective outline,

536
00:26:00.746 --> 00:26:04.951
they have these official tables from
them and you can go and get it.

537
00:26:04.951 --> 00:26:08.381
My information here is really just
drawn from that source of data.

538
00:26:08.381 --> 00:26:11.205
So you can always pull it
right from the PMI, but

539
00:26:11.205 --> 00:26:13.681
I'll make sure the notes are corrected.

540
00:26:13.681 --> 00:26:17.000
>> Well thank you Don again, for
presenting that information.

541
00:26:17.000 --> 00:26:18.930
And thank you for watching.

542
00:26:18.930 --> 00:26:21.710
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

543
00:26:21.710 --> 00:26:22.560
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

544
00:26:22.560 --> 00:26:24.157
>> And we'll see you next time.

545
00:26:24.157 --> 00:26:30.520
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this example, Ronnie and Don review the Critical Path Method to determine Critical Path. They review the formula used to determine float and the method used to determine starts and finishes of each task.  Taking a single example, they start from just the duration and name of a task and show how to calculate simple forward pass and backward pass.  They determine the float and free float as well.
episodes.title: CPM Example Number 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.479 --> 00:00:15.997
Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.997 --> 00:00:19.868
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and
today we're gonna be taking a look at PMP,

4
00:00:19.868 --> 00:00:22.220
Project Management Professional.

5
00:00:22.220 --> 00:00:25.990
And we're specifically gonna be diving
into the critical path method and

6
00:00:25.990 --> 00:00:28.060
who else better to help us than Mr.
Don Pezet.

7
00:00:28.060 --> 00:00:28.940
How's it going, Don?

8
00:00:28.940 --> 00:00:29.900
>> It is going great, Ronnie.

9
00:00:29.900 --> 00:00:31.910
Thanks for having me on the show and

10
00:00:31.910 --> 00:00:35.530
I'm excited to be kicking off
our formulas in action series.

11
00:00:35.530 --> 00:00:38.350
We're gonna be taking a look at a lot of
the formulas that we need to know for

12
00:00:38.350 --> 00:00:40.730
the PMP exam,
just running through some examples.

13
00:00:40.730 --> 00:00:44.990
How to use them, how to get really
comfortable with them because on the exam

14
00:00:44.990 --> 00:00:48.600
you shouldn't dread the formula questions
you should really appreciate them and

15
00:00:48.600 --> 00:00:49.680
go boy that's going to be an easy one.

16
00:00:49.680 --> 00:00:52.950
All I have to do is a little math and
that's usually what it boils down to.

17
00:00:52.950 --> 00:00:56.240
So in this episode we're gonna tackle the
critical path method, we'll get a chance

18
00:00:56.240 --> 00:00:59.960
to see a great example, we'll run through
it and do the forward pass, the backwards

19
00:00:59.960 --> 00:01:03.300
pass, all the different things that we
talked about earlier in the series.

20
00:01:03.300 --> 00:01:06.380
And not only are we calculating critical
path, we're also gonna be calculating

21
00:01:06.380 --> 00:01:10.050
things like float and free float and
getting a chance to see those also.

22
00:01:10.050 --> 00:01:13.140
All just right here wrapped
up into one nice big example.

23
00:01:13.140 --> 00:01:15.980
>> All right so Don, before we get
started, it's probably best if

24
00:01:15.980 --> 00:01:19.600
you remind us cuz I know it's like me,
you may have actually gone through this

25
00:01:19.600 --> 00:01:23.520
several times in your head and you've seen
the actual little template that's there.

26
00:01:23.520 --> 00:01:27.200
A lot of times we forget so this is
a good place to remind us about this.

27
00:01:27.200 --> 00:01:29.170
>> Yeah, on the exam,
what they're gonna do is,

28
00:01:29.170 --> 00:01:31.780
is well, there's a few different
ways they can do it on the exam.

29
00:01:31.780 --> 00:01:34.050
We'll see it in some of
the examples I'll give.

30
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:37.830
But they're normally gonna show you
a project schedule network diagram, right,

31
00:01:37.830 --> 00:01:38.460
a PSND.

32
00:01:38.460 --> 00:01:41.670
And if you don't remember what a project
schedule network diagram looks like,

33
00:01:41.670 --> 00:01:44.090
it looks like what I've
got here on my laptop.

34
00:01:44.090 --> 00:01:46.310
Is a bunch of boxes that
are kind of arranged,

35
00:01:46.310 --> 00:01:50.400
and I've added a little bit to it right,
that in the normal template you don't have

36
00:01:50.400 --> 00:01:53.940
float at the bottom of a box,
but you do have the ES,

37
00:01:53.940 --> 00:01:57.880
EF, LS, LF, and a couple of other
bits of the data jammed in there.

38
00:01:57.880 --> 00:02:01.200
So let's talk a little bit
about what all that is.

39
00:02:01.200 --> 00:02:05.530
So when you're looking at one
of these boxes, it may or

40
00:02:05.530 --> 00:02:07.105
may not have flow, like I said.

41
00:02:07.105 --> 00:02:09.800
That may just not be there,
may look like that, right?

42
00:02:09.800 --> 00:02:15.040
And if it looks like this, what you've
got is early start, early finish,

43
00:02:15.040 --> 00:02:17.070
late start, late finish.

44
00:02:17.070 --> 00:02:20.510
They're four values that you don't
necessarily have when you launch

45
00:02:20.510 --> 00:02:21.260
a project.

46
00:02:21.260 --> 00:02:23.460
You have to determine
what those values are and

47
00:02:23.460 --> 00:02:26.150
that's really what
critical path method does.

48
00:02:26.150 --> 00:02:29.030
In fact, when you start a project
there's normally only two pieces of data

49
00:02:29.030 --> 00:02:29.990
that you have.

50
00:02:29.990 --> 00:02:34.650
The task name and the duration,
that's what D is right here, duration.

51
00:02:34.650 --> 00:02:37.440
So the duration is how long
that task is going to take.

52
00:02:37.440 --> 00:02:41.530
And then we've got to arrange all
those tasks together to figure out

53
00:02:41.530 --> 00:02:44.250
exactly how long this
is all going to take.

54
00:02:44.250 --> 00:02:46.700
When is my project going to finish and

55
00:02:46.700 --> 00:02:53.060
where do I have little gaps of space where
I can slow down or speed up if need be?

56
00:02:53.060 --> 00:02:56.140
And that whole slowing down and speeding
up part that's where float comes in.

57
00:02:56.140 --> 00:03:00.810
That's why I normally add float onto the
bottom of this so I can keep track of it.

58
00:03:00.810 --> 00:03:03.610
Now, when it comes to
critical path method,

59
00:03:03.610 --> 00:03:06.800
the bulk of the math that we're
doing is really just addition.

60
00:03:06.800 --> 00:03:09.730
Simple addition, so
not really crazy formulas.

61
00:03:09.730 --> 00:03:12.140
And the only real formula we need
to remember is the formula for

62
00:03:12.140 --> 00:03:13.400
calculating float.

63
00:03:13.400 --> 00:03:16.840
And float is simply late
start minus early start.

64
00:03:17.910 --> 00:03:21.170
Early start is the earliest
this task can start.

65
00:03:21.170 --> 00:03:24.565
I mean we can't start before
this particular point in time.

66
00:03:24.565 --> 00:03:28.760
And early finish is if we're
running perfectly on schedule,

67
00:03:28.760 --> 00:03:30.120
what's the earliest we can finish.

68
00:03:31.240 --> 00:03:34.140
Late start is how late can we start it and

69
00:03:34.140 --> 00:03:39.150
still finish our project on schedule,
without going over our schedule.

70
00:03:39.150 --> 00:03:42.420
So late start's pretty important, and then
late finish would be the latest we could

71
00:03:42.420 --> 00:03:45.550
finish, and again,
still have our project finish on schedule.

72
00:03:45.550 --> 00:03:51.010
If there's no difference between these,
if late start minus early start is zero or

73
00:03:51.010 --> 00:03:54.200
late finish minus early finish is zero,
that means there's no difference, right?

74
00:03:54.200 --> 00:03:58.710
They're the same value and
you've got no float, zero flexibility.

75
00:03:58.710 --> 00:04:02.450
But if there's a difference between these
numbers, then you're gonna have some time.

76
00:04:02.450 --> 00:04:04.960
Some time that you could fall
behind if you needed to.

77
00:04:04.960 --> 00:04:07.480
That you could take resources
off of one task and

78
00:04:07.480 --> 00:04:08.980
assign to another to
make up your schedule.

79
00:04:08.980 --> 00:04:11.640
So that's important that we
recognize where that is and

80
00:04:11.640 --> 00:04:13.690
critical path method will let us do that.

81
00:04:13.690 --> 00:04:17.070
So we calculate our critical path and
we calculate our float,

82
00:04:17.070 --> 00:04:20.080
really all at the same time
using the same techniques.

83
00:04:20.080 --> 00:04:22.690
And that's what we're gonna
run through in this example.

84
00:04:22.690 --> 00:04:26.420
And so the example that I've got
worked up is this topology right here.

85
00:04:26.420 --> 00:04:31.260
And I've got the basic elements of what
we know about a project when we kick off.

86
00:04:31.260 --> 00:04:33.360
So I've got my task names and
I just use letters.

87
00:04:33.360 --> 00:04:37.190
So a, b, c all the way through,
what's my highest one, i.

88
00:04:37.190 --> 00:04:40.230
So a through i are my task names.

89
00:04:40.230 --> 00:04:43.110
And then I've got the durations,
and I did durations in days.

90
00:04:43.110 --> 00:04:46.550
You could do hours, you could do weeks,
depends how long your project is but

91
00:04:46.550 --> 00:04:47.610
I did mine in days.

92
00:04:47.610 --> 00:04:50.860
So this is task A, and
task A is gonna take 1 day.

93
00:04:50.860 --> 00:04:54.500
Or up here I've got task C and
it's gonna take 4 days, right?

94
00:04:54.500 --> 00:04:55.890
That's all the information I have.

95
00:04:55.890 --> 00:04:58.040
This is like very indicative
of what you would get out of

96
00:04:58.040 --> 00:04:59.160
a work breakdown structure.

97
00:04:59.160 --> 00:05:02.210
That's all it's gonna have, is Has to do,
how long it's going to take.

98
00:05:03.690 --> 00:05:06.470
It's up to us to then
calculate everything else.

99
00:05:06.470 --> 00:05:10.970
And for the exam you need to know how
calculate all of these other values.

100
00:05:10.970 --> 00:05:16.620
Now in our first two examples we're gonna
run through calculating the whole thing.

101
00:05:16.620 --> 00:05:18.430
On the exam they're not
gonna have you do that.

102
00:05:18.430 --> 00:05:21.120
On the exam they're normally gonna have
you just calculate out just one of these

103
00:05:21.120 --> 00:05:23.720
squares and
usually it's one particular value.

104
00:05:23.720 --> 00:05:27.460
So, for example,
you might see a square like this one and

105
00:05:27.460 --> 00:05:30.710
everything else is filled in but
this one has blanks.

106
00:05:30.710 --> 00:05:33.940
And it says,
what would be the early finish of task C?

107
00:05:33.940 --> 00:05:36.350
And you've got multiple choice
answers with just numbers in them and

108
00:05:36.350 --> 00:05:37.270
you pick the appropriate ones.

109
00:05:37.270 --> 00:05:39.070
So you just need to
calculate a single value.

110
00:05:39.070 --> 00:05:42.230
But working through a whole example like
this will help you better understand it.

111
00:05:42.230 --> 00:05:44.460
So we're gonna do the whole path first.

112
00:05:44.460 --> 00:05:48.980
And then in a follow-up episode we'll
break it down more like the exam does and

113
00:05:48.980 --> 00:05:49.900
hit just a single area.

114
00:05:51.030 --> 00:05:52.580
All right, well let's get started.

115
00:05:52.580 --> 00:05:55.310
The first thing we need to
do with critical path method

116
00:05:55.310 --> 00:05:57.940
is to calculate out what's
called a forward pass.

117
00:05:57.940 --> 00:06:00.210
We need to start from the beginning, and

118
00:06:00.210 --> 00:06:02.810
basically we're gonna
calculate all of the earlies.

119
00:06:02.810 --> 00:06:04.940
The earliest that we can do things.

120
00:06:04.940 --> 00:06:08.030
So assuming that everything runs great,

121
00:06:08.030 --> 00:06:11.770
everything runs according to plan,
what is this gonna look like?

122
00:06:11.770 --> 00:06:15.350
So we're gonna calculate out the early
starts and the early finishes.

123
00:06:15.350 --> 00:06:18.650
Now one of the challenges
that we hear from a lot,

124
00:06:18.650 --> 00:06:20.350
you know we get viewers that write in and
say Don,

125
00:06:20.350 --> 00:06:24.760
I'm really having a problem with this,
is that a lot of us are IT guys and so,

126
00:06:24.760 --> 00:06:27.535
when we start counting,
we always start from zero, right?

127
00:06:27.535 --> 00:06:29.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so, when I have a project start,

128
00:06:29.700 --> 00:06:33.170
we're starting on day zero and
it's going to take one day and so on.

129
00:06:33.170 --> 00:06:34.200
But in project management,

130
00:06:34.200 --> 00:06:37.740
we don't start at zero because these
are actually units of time and

131
00:06:37.740 --> 00:06:42.520
so, we need to start them based on,
for example, days and I'm doing days.

132
00:06:42.520 --> 00:06:47.220
So, when I say this is day one that
these project is going to occur on,

133
00:06:47.220 --> 00:06:48.850
I don't actually start at zero.

134
00:06:48.850 --> 00:06:51.640
My early start isn't zero,
my early start is one.

135
00:06:51.640 --> 00:06:54.640
I'm starting on day one and
then will continue on.

136
00:06:54.640 --> 00:06:58.428
The way I like to do it is think of
this duration as days of the month.

137
00:06:58.428 --> 00:07:03.950
So this might be January 1st 2016, so

138
00:07:03.950 --> 00:07:08.588
this task is going to start and
finish on January 1st.

139
00:07:08.588 --> 00:07:11.290
It's not gonna start on day zero and
finish on day one,

140
00:07:11.290 --> 00:07:13.998
that would technically be two days.

141
00:07:13.998 --> 00:07:19.340
So, we're gonna start on the first, and
we're going to finish on the first.

142
00:07:19.340 --> 00:07:22.500
No crazy math needed there, it's a one
day task, it starts on that day and

143
00:07:22.500 --> 00:07:23.042
it finishes.

144
00:07:23.042 --> 00:07:26.680
Now task B and

145
00:07:26.680 --> 00:07:30.870
E both have dependencies, and
their dependency is task A.

146
00:07:30.870 --> 00:07:33.390
Task A has to finish before B and
E can start,

147
00:07:33.390 --> 00:07:35.410
it's a finish-to-start relationship.

148
00:07:35.410 --> 00:07:40.670
And so, if task A started on day one and
finished on day one and

149
00:07:40.670 --> 00:07:44.610
it was an entire day of activity,
can I get any more work done on that day?

150
00:07:45.660 --> 00:07:50.440
No, so anybody that follows on after
that is gonna have to start on day two.

151
00:07:50.440 --> 00:07:51.965
So now I'm in day two.

152
00:07:51.965 --> 00:07:54.670
So when I look at task B and task E,

153
00:07:54.670 --> 00:07:58.754
the earliest they can start is on day two,
right.

154
00:07:58.754 --> 00:08:03.003
This one took up day one, and so
now these guys are gonna start.

155
00:08:03.003 --> 00:08:04.338
On day two, all right?

156
00:08:04.338 --> 00:08:06.504
So I fill both of those in.

157
00:08:06.504 --> 00:08:10.560
Now, task B is a two-day activity, right?

158
00:08:10.560 --> 00:08:14.120
And here's where things really,
really get dangerous, right?

159
00:08:14.120 --> 00:08:17.420
As dangerous as it gets,
cuz the temptation is to say, all right,

160
00:08:17.420 --> 00:08:20.580
I'm on day two, let me add 2,
finish on day four, okay.

161
00:08:21.700 --> 00:08:23.809
But that's just traditional math.

162
00:08:23.809 --> 00:08:24.970
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's normal numbers,

163
00:08:24.970 --> 00:08:27.420
that's not what we're doing here,
we're thinking of days.

164
00:08:27.420 --> 00:08:31.520
So I took all of day two, January 2nd, but

165
00:08:31.520 --> 00:08:34.750
this is a two-day activity,
so I also need January 3rd.

166
00:08:34.750 --> 00:08:37.310
So this one is gonna
finish on January 3rd.

167
00:08:37.310 --> 00:08:39.950
I find that thinking of them as dates
really helps me to make sure I get

168
00:08:39.950 --> 00:08:40.920
these numbers right.

169
00:08:40.920 --> 00:08:45.680
So January 2nd, January 3rd,
there's by two days for task B.

170
00:08:45.680 --> 00:08:47.410
Task E's only one day though.

171
00:08:47.410 --> 00:08:51.650
So it starts on January 2nd,
it finishes on January 2nd.

172
00:08:51.650 --> 00:08:53.590
So I fill those values in.

173
00:08:53.590 --> 00:08:54.670
And now I continue on.

174
00:08:54.670 --> 00:08:58.680
Now this particular project
has two very obvious paths.

175
00:08:58.680 --> 00:09:01.560
I've got BCD and then I've got EFGH.

176
00:09:01.560 --> 00:09:04.040
So, a path across the top,
a path across the bottom.

177
00:09:04.040 --> 00:09:08.220
If all I'm trying to do is find my
critical path, on a simple one like this,

178
00:09:08.220 --> 00:09:11.890
I really wouldn't even bother with
the forward and backwards paths.

179
00:09:11.890 --> 00:09:13.730
I would just add up the durations, right?

180
00:09:13.730 --> 00:09:17.401
Whichever path has the longest duration,
that's gonna be the one that wins,

181
00:09:17.401 --> 00:09:19.137
that's gonna be our critical path.

182
00:09:19.137 --> 00:09:23.423
So, if the question is just asking me
which of these is the critical path, well,

183
00:09:23.423 --> 00:09:26.900
I've got two, four, three, so
that's nine across the top.

184
00:09:26.900 --> 00:09:27.670
Is that good math?

185
00:09:27.670 --> 00:09:28.242
Yeah, yep.
[LAUGH] So

186
00:09:28.242 --> 00:09:29.990
that's nine days across the top.

187
00:09:29.990 --> 00:09:33.470
And then down here I've got 1,
5, 4, and 1.

188
00:09:33.470 --> 00:09:34.805
So I've got 11 days across the bottom.

189
00:09:34.805 --> 00:09:36.385
Nine days across the top,

190
00:09:36.385 --> 00:09:40.260
eleven days across the bottom,
the bottom is my critical path, right.

191
00:09:40.260 --> 00:09:43.970
It's longer, but they might not
all be simple like this one.

192
00:09:43.970 --> 00:09:46.850
And we'll see in my next example,
it's a little bit more complex, and so

193
00:09:46.850 --> 00:09:48.800
just adding those up
doesn't necessarily work.

194
00:09:48.800 --> 00:09:51.710
But if I'm also looking for things like
float, or if they're asking me for

195
00:09:51.710 --> 00:09:54.880
the early start of a particular task,
it doesn't matter to me

196
00:09:54.880 --> 00:09:57.590
which one is the critical path,
I need to find that particular day.

197
00:09:57.590 --> 00:09:59.870
So, that's why you need to be comfortable
with all the different methods of

198
00:09:59.870 --> 00:10:00.500
calculating this out.

199
00:10:01.980 --> 00:10:03.170
All right, so, let's continue on.

200
00:10:03.170 --> 00:10:06.550
And I'm just gonna focus on the top path
for right now, and fill this out, right?

201
00:10:06.550 --> 00:10:10.760
So, we have task B finishing on day 3,

202
00:10:10.760 --> 00:10:15.290
which means the next task can't
start before day 4, right?

203
00:10:15.290 --> 00:10:18.519
This one finished on the 3rd,
this one can start on the 4th, and

204
00:10:18.519 --> 00:10:20.350
it's a four-day activity.

205
00:10:20.350 --> 00:10:24.566
So it's gonna take the 4th, the 5th,
the 6th, and the 7th, and so,

206
00:10:24.566 --> 00:10:27.690
the earliest it can finish is on the 7th.

207
00:10:27.690 --> 00:10:30.350
All right, continuing on with D,

208
00:10:30.350 --> 00:10:32.900
the earliest it can start is on the 8th,
right?

209
00:10:32.900 --> 00:10:36.520
So it's gonna start on the 8th of the
month, and then it's a three-day activity,

210
00:10:36.520 --> 00:10:38.190
so we'll need the 8th,
the 9th, and the 10th,

211
00:10:38.190 --> 00:10:41.700
and we'll finish right there on the 10th,
okay?

212
00:10:41.700 --> 00:10:46.020
So the top path, BCD,
will finish January 10th.

213
00:10:46.020 --> 00:10:47.480
All right.
I'm just using January

214
00:10:47.480 --> 00:10:48.390
10th as an example here.

215
00:10:48.390 --> 00:10:51.530
It could be whatever day your
particular project is designed.

216
00:10:51.530 --> 00:10:53.640
And boy, there's another complexity.

217
00:10:53.640 --> 00:10:55.710
They won't hit you with this on the exam,
but

218
00:10:55.710 --> 00:10:57.850
what if you have to factor
weekends into this?

219
00:10:57.850 --> 00:11:02.640
If you have to factor weekends in, I might
have two days that we can't work, and so

220
00:11:02.640 --> 00:11:04.760
I might start on the 8th and
finish on the 12th.

221
00:11:05.940 --> 00:11:09.530
Because maybe the 9th and
the 10th were Saturday and Sunday.

222
00:11:09.530 --> 00:11:12.000
So that's when things really
start to get a little bit messy.

223
00:11:12.000 --> 00:11:15.610
But fortunately, your other path will
be doing the exact same thing, and so

224
00:11:15.610 --> 00:11:17.090
you'll have that same delay for both.

225
00:11:17.090 --> 00:11:19.870
But that's where project management
software really comes in handy.

226
00:11:21.210 --> 00:11:24.330
All right, so I've got that path
kind of laid out right there,

227
00:11:24.330 --> 00:11:26.870
now I'm gonna go back to the bottom and
continue on with this one.

228
00:11:26.870 --> 00:11:32.170
So task E is finishing on day 2,
task F can start on day 3 if it wants,

229
00:11:32.170 --> 00:11:36.080
and it's a five-day activity,
so it will finish on day 7.

230
00:11:36.080 --> 00:11:41.880
Then, task G, we're gonna bump that one up
to the 8th, it can start on January 8th.

231
00:11:41.880 --> 00:11:46.020
And it's a four-day activity, and so
that one's gonna finish on, let's see,

232
00:11:46.020 --> 00:11:46.530
that would be the 11th.

233
00:11:46.530 --> 00:11:47.330
>> The 11th.

234
00:11:47.330 --> 00:11:48.260
>> There we go.

235
00:11:48.260 --> 00:11:51.880
All right, so if you need help
coming up with these numbers,

236
00:11:51.880 --> 00:11:53.770
you can count on your fingers
if it's a small number, right?

237
00:11:53.770 --> 00:11:57.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I can say eighth, ninth, tenth,

238
00:11:57.670 --> 00:11:58.260
eleventh, right?

239
00:11:58.260 --> 00:11:59.290
That's one way to do it.

240
00:11:59.290 --> 00:12:02.140
Or what I'm actually doing
in my head is I go ahead and

241
00:12:02.140 --> 00:12:05.470
do eight plus four and
then I just subtract one, right?

242
00:12:05.470 --> 00:12:07.330
I do eight plus four and
that gives me 12 and

243
00:12:07.330 --> 00:12:09.740
I subtract one because I
have to count the eighth.

244
00:12:09.740 --> 00:12:11.292
Right?
So that's a little shortcut that

245
00:12:11.292 --> 00:12:14.810
I use that makes it a little easier and
it works better with bigger numbers.

246
00:12:14.810 --> 00:12:18.600
What if this was, I start on the eighth,
and it's a 15-day duration?

247
00:12:18.600 --> 00:12:21.660
Well, you can't really use your fingers
anymore if it's a 15-day duration.

248
00:12:21.660 --> 00:12:25.216
But you can do 8 plus 15 and get 23,
and then subtract 1 to get 22.

249
00:12:25.216 --> 00:12:26.493
And so, now you know it's 22.

250
00:12:26.493 --> 00:12:29.475
So, that's kind of a little
shortcut that I use,

251
00:12:29.475 --> 00:12:33.100
which should be the early start
plus the duration minus one.

252
00:12:33.100 --> 00:12:35.460
That's not an official PMI formula.

253
00:12:35.460 --> 00:12:39.360
All right, and then we move over
here to this last one, task H,

254
00:12:39.360 --> 00:12:43.100
which only has a duration of 1, and
so it can start on the 12th and

255
00:12:43.100 --> 00:12:48.088
its duration is 1, so I can just
finish it on the 12th also, all right?

256
00:12:48.088 --> 00:12:50.690
And then lastly,
we get all the way down here to task I.

257
00:12:50.690 --> 00:12:54.200
Now, task I has two dependencies, right?

258
00:12:54.200 --> 00:13:01.090
It needs task D and task H to finish
before task I can start, okay?

259
00:13:01.090 --> 00:13:04.590
Well, if I look at task D,
the earliest it can finish is on the 10th.

260
00:13:05.640 --> 00:13:09.860
And if I look at task H, the earliest it
can finish is on the 12th, all right?

261
00:13:09.860 --> 00:13:16.840
So because this one can't finish until the
12th, task I can't start until the 13th.

262
00:13:16.840 --> 00:13:19.710
Even though this guy up here is done,
we have to wait for

263
00:13:19.710 --> 00:13:20.560
the other one to finish too.

never have float in your critical path.

486
00:24:29.920 --> 00:24:31.750
So when I look up here at B, C, and D,

487
00:24:31.750 --> 00:24:34.988
because I've got float,
that means these guys are not critical.

488
00:24:34.988 --> 00:24:37.020
These guys have a little
bit of breathing room.

489
00:24:37.020 --> 00:24:38.360
They could still impact the project.

490
00:24:38.360 --> 00:24:41.560
I could still end up behind
schedule because of these guys.

491
00:24:41.560 --> 00:24:43.520
But assuming things are running
the way they're supposed to,

492
00:24:43.520 --> 00:24:45.050
these guys have wiggle room.

493
00:24:45.050 --> 00:24:47.510
And so they're not critical.

494
00:24:47.510 --> 00:24:53.440
But, down here, E, F, G, H, I've got
zero float all the way across that line.

495
00:24:53.440 --> 00:24:54.620
I've got no wiggle room.

496
00:24:54.620 --> 00:24:57.130
Those are critical,
that's my critical path.

497
00:24:58.220 --> 00:25:02.560
A, E, F, G, H, I, this whole bottom path,
those are critical.

498
00:25:02.560 --> 00:25:06.310
If any one of those tasks falls behind,
my project falls behind.

499
00:25:06.310 --> 00:25:10.650
And I go from being a 13 day project to
being a 14 or, 15 or, 16 day project,

500
00:25:10.650 --> 00:25:13.250
as we fall further and
further behind, right?

501
00:25:13.250 --> 00:25:15.730
So now we've spotted that
critical path and we've got it.

502
00:25:17.330 --> 00:25:24.710
There's one more thing we might be tasked
with on the exam, and that is free float.

503
00:25:24.710 --> 00:25:27.780
Okay, now I calculated float,
and float's the most common.

504
00:25:27.780 --> 00:25:31.260
That's what we worry about, or if you use
Microsoft Project this would be slack.

505
00:25:31.260 --> 00:25:33.050
And so we're calculating that out.

506
00:25:33.050 --> 00:25:34.370
On the exam, they'll always call it float.

507
00:25:35.420 --> 00:25:37.210
Free float's a little bit different.

508
00:25:37.210 --> 00:25:41.680
The definition of float,
is any activity that could fall behind

509
00:25:41.680 --> 00:25:46.020
without impacting the project, right,
talking about the project as a whole.

510
00:25:46.020 --> 00:25:50.320
But free float,
is where an activity can fall behind and

511
00:25:50.320 --> 00:25:53.578
not impact any other activity, right?

512
00:25:53.578 --> 00:25:57.880
Technically, B has two days of free,
two days of float.

513
00:25:57.880 --> 00:26:02.370
So it could fall behind two days and
my project could still finish on schedule.

514
00:26:02.370 --> 00:26:07.860
But if it falls behind two days,
if it was supposed to start on the second,

515
00:26:07.860 --> 00:26:12.990
and instead it starts on the fourth,
well can task c start on the fourth?

516
00:26:12.990 --> 00:26:15.360
No, it now starts on the sixth.

517
00:26:15.360 --> 00:26:16.710
All right?
And we know that's okay.

518
00:26:16.710 --> 00:26:18.830
It can start on the sixth and
we'll still finish on time.

519
00:26:18.830 --> 00:26:21.100
But this one just got
bumped back two days.

520
00:26:21.100 --> 00:26:25.970
What if I had contractors scheduled
to be here on the fourth?

521
00:26:25.970 --> 00:26:27.400
And this one falls behind.

522
00:26:27.400 --> 00:26:30.750
And now I tell the contractors,
hey can you come out on the sixth instead?

523
00:26:30.750 --> 00:26:33.100
And they say,
no I'm sorry we're booked for another job.

524
00:26:34.550 --> 00:26:38.550
Well this task could have started on
the sixth, and I'd finish on time.

525
00:26:38.550 --> 00:26:40.070
But now I don't have contractors.

526
00:26:40.070 --> 00:26:40.770
Now I've got a problem.

527
00:26:40.770 --> 00:26:45.460
All right, so on the exam,
flow is usually what they go for, but

528
00:26:45.460 --> 00:26:49.310
in real life land free float is
what we normally care about.

529
00:26:49.310 --> 00:26:53.080
Because just because this activity
can fall behind two days,

530
00:26:53.080 --> 00:26:54.270
doesn't mean we want that to happen.

531
00:26:54.270 --> 00:26:57.260
Especially if you've got contractors
scheduled on particular days, right.

532
00:26:57.260 --> 00:26:58.790
You can have staff issues.

533
00:26:58.790 --> 00:27:02.621
I might have staff assigned to work
task C on the fourth and fifth.

534
00:27:03.650 --> 00:27:07.350
But then on the sixth and seventh, I might
have them scheduled to come down here and

535
00:27:07.350 --> 00:27:08.830
help on task F.

536
00:27:08.830 --> 00:27:12.080
And now if this one falls behind,
I can't have them help on task F, and

537
00:27:12.080 --> 00:27:13.960
task F falls behind, right?

538
00:27:13.960 --> 00:27:17.048
I might have my employees
spread across that way.

539
00:27:17.048 --> 00:27:19.490
So free float's a little
harder to calculate,

540
00:27:19.490 --> 00:27:24.900
because basically what you have to look
at is environments where you have a gap

541
00:27:24.900 --> 00:27:29.870
in between the finish of one task,
and the start of the next.

542
00:27:29.870 --> 00:27:32.330
See how this one finished on the third and
the next one starts on the fourth?

543
00:27:32.330 --> 00:27:33.480
There's no gap.

544
00:27:33.480 --> 00:27:35.570
This on finishes on the seventh,
the next one starts on the eighth.

545
00:27:35.570 --> 00:27:37.150
There's no gap.

546
00:27:37.150 --> 00:27:43.010
But this one finished on the tenth and
the next task starts on the 13th.

547
00:27:43.010 --> 00:27:44.480
There's a gap, right?

548
00:27:44.480 --> 00:27:48.470
There's a gap of two days,
the 11th and the 12th, and

549
00:27:48.470 --> 00:27:54.110
during that time we have a gap where
task D could fall behind two days,

550
00:27:54.110 --> 00:27:58.130
and we'd be okay, because this one isn't
scheduled to start until the 13th.

551
00:27:58.130 --> 00:27:59.560
That's called free float.

552
00:27:59.560 --> 00:28:03.530
So, while I've got two
days across the top here,

553
00:28:03.530 --> 00:28:07.570
this one is actually
a little bit special right?

554
00:28:07.570 --> 00:28:10.710
These are just regular old float,
but this one is free float.

555
00:28:10.710 --> 00:28:12.720
And free float is worth
it's weight in gold,

556
00:28:12.720 --> 00:28:15.130
that's the one that doesn't
impact your project at all.

557
00:28:15.130 --> 00:28:18.410
You don't really have to take any kind
of special measures when you use it.

558
00:28:18.410 --> 00:28:20.580
Versus these other ones that
would continually push the other

559
00:28:20.580 --> 00:28:21.800
activities behind.

560
00:28:21.800 --> 00:28:24.250
So on the exam they may ask
you to locate free float.

561
00:28:24.250 --> 00:28:27.330
Which of the following
tasks has free float?

562
00:28:27.330 --> 00:28:30.480
And now you've gotta calculate it out,
you've gotta figure out your

563
00:28:30.480 --> 00:28:33.550
early start and late start, and
your early finish and late finish.

564
00:28:33.550 --> 00:28:37.210
So then you can spot where the gaps
are in between the tasks, and

565
00:28:37.210 --> 00:28:38.710
that's where your free float is.

566
00:28:38.710 --> 00:28:41.060
I've you've got no gaps,
you've got no free float, you may not.

567
00:28:41.060 --> 00:28:43.500
Right?
So it's important to note that.

568
00:28:43.500 --> 00:28:47.870
>> Now Don, that's a great example for us,
a great reminder of some of the things we

569
00:28:47.870 --> 00:28:51.080
may have forgotten along the way as
we've been preparing for the exam.

570
00:28:51.080 --> 00:28:53.030
And it's something that we
really need to pay attention to.

571
00:28:53.030 --> 00:28:56.250
Being able to determine
that overall critical path.

572
00:28:56.250 --> 00:29:00.800
A lot of times we take a look at these
numbers and we get a little bit confused.

573
00:29:00.800 --> 00:29:05.260
Go back, watch this episode, make sure
you do take a note of this example.

574
00:29:05.260 --> 00:29:07.870
Work through the math,
feel very comfortable with it.

575
00:29:07.870 --> 00:29:09.770
But, we've got some more
examples coming up.

576
00:29:09.770 --> 00:29:13.440
Don, any last words on just
this first example here?

577
00:29:13.440 --> 00:29:14.580
>> Just run through them.

578
00:29:14.580 --> 00:29:16.470
And maybe I'll show it in another episode.

579
00:29:16.470 --> 00:29:17.780
If you have Microsoft Project,

580
00:29:17.780 --> 00:29:20.600
you can actually create diagrams
like this in Microsoft Project.

581
00:29:20.600 --> 00:29:24.610
And you can create a project,
work it out yourself.

582
00:29:24.610 --> 00:29:27.020
And feed it all into Microsoft Project and
it kinda grades you.

583
00:29:27.020 --> 00:29:29.640
So you can create your own
practice tests for these things.

584
00:29:29.640 --> 00:29:30.650
But just get used to it.

585
00:29:30.650 --> 00:29:31.260
Run through them.

586
00:29:31.260 --> 00:29:32.450
Run forward, run backwards.

587
00:29:32.450 --> 00:29:33.160
Check your work.

588
00:29:33.160 --> 00:29:35.990
It's easy to make mistakes,
especially if we're not thinking of days.

589
00:29:35.990 --> 00:29:37.560
If we're thinking of
numbers instead of days,

590
00:29:37.560 --> 00:29:39.750
it's easy to kinda screw things up there.

591
00:29:39.750 --> 00:29:43.020
So definitely be wary of that, and
always double check your work.

592
00:29:43.020 --> 00:29:45.410
And just get to where you're
proficient and fast at it.

593
00:29:45.410 --> 00:29:47.990
>> Well, Don, thank you again for
showing us that example.

594
00:29:47.990 --> 00:29:50.040
Thank you for joining us today.

595
00:29:50.040 --> 00:29:52.830
Signing off for I-T Pro T-V,
I'm Ronnie Wong.

596
00:29:52.830 --> 00:29:53.460
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

597
00:29:53.460 --> 00:29:55.877
>> And we'll see you next time.

598
00:29:55.877 --> 00:30:02.520
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this example, Ronnie and Don take another example that is a little more complex when the forward path has multiple predecessors.  This add complexity to determine the critical path. They show the calculation of the forward pass must be determined based on latest of the Early Finish between multiple predecessors.  They also determine the float for each task
episodes.title: CPM Example Number 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.088 --> 00:00:15.200
Welcome to another great
episode right here on iTproTV.

3
00:00:15.200 --> 00:00:19.236
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today
we're going to be taking a look at PMP.

4
00:00:19.236 --> 00:00:21.570
The Project Management Professional.

5
00:00:21.570 --> 00:00:25.890
We're specifically going to be looking
at calculating the critical path method.

6
00:00:25.890 --> 00:00:27.860
And who better to help us than Mr.
Don Pezet.

7
00:00:27.860 --> 00:00:28.950
Don, how's it going?

8
00:00:28.950 --> 00:00:30.000
>> It is going great, Ronnie.

9
00:00:30.000 --> 00:00:33.050
Ready to jump right back into
CPM with another example.

10
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:36.070
If you haven't watched already,
we filmed a first example problem.

11
00:00:36.070 --> 00:00:39.020
Where we walked through the whole
process of calculating it out.

12
00:00:39.020 --> 00:00:42.650
And we used a pretty straightforward
project schedule network diagram.

13
00:00:42.650 --> 00:00:46.260
The kind that you'll see on
most textbooks or whatever.

14
00:00:46.260 --> 00:00:49.420
But I wanted to do another example that
goes a little more complex, right.

15
00:00:49.420 --> 00:00:51.710
Because anybody can do
the simple diagrams.

16
00:00:51.710 --> 00:00:54.020
When you start adding in
a few multiple paths,

17
00:00:54.020 --> 00:00:55.470
now you really start to get a challenge.

18
00:00:55.470 --> 00:00:58.150
So, in this example we're going
to go a little more complex.

19
00:00:58.150 --> 00:01:00.950
Let me just bring this
up here on my laptop and

20
00:01:00.950 --> 00:01:02.800
similar model to what we saw before.

21
00:01:02.800 --> 00:01:05.700
We had a long path and a short path, but

22
00:01:05.700 --> 00:01:09.430
now we've got a cross in the middle and
that's really challenging.

23
00:01:09.430 --> 00:01:11.040
Because what might happen is,

24
00:01:11.040 --> 00:01:12.990
you might have a critical path
that runs across the top.

25
00:01:12.990 --> 00:01:15.710
You might have a critical path
that runs across the bottom.

26
00:01:15.710 --> 00:01:19.380
Or you might have a critical path
that starts on the bottom and

27
00:01:19.380 --> 00:01:20.490
jumps up to the top.

28
00:01:20.490 --> 00:01:24.100
And comes across like that a little
snake kind of going through the project.

29
00:01:24.100 --> 00:01:27.660
So, you can really end up with some
interesting stuff this way, and

30
00:01:27.660 --> 00:01:29.340
it takes a little more work.

31
00:01:29.340 --> 00:01:32.618
This one's harder to just look at and
guess and be done with.

32
00:01:32.618 --> 00:01:33.840
You're going to have to calculate it out,

33
00:01:33.840 --> 00:01:36.010
so it makes things just
a little more exciting.

34
00:01:37.050 --> 00:01:39.090
All right, so
what I want to do is run through this one.

35
00:01:39.090 --> 00:01:42.090
I've just blanked everything out except
for the task name and the duration.

36
00:01:42.090 --> 00:01:43.270
Because normally,

37
00:01:43.270 --> 00:01:46.440
When we're doing the planning phase of our
project this is all we have at this point.

38
00:01:46.440 --> 00:01:49.320
And so we start calculating things out to
figure out how long our project's gonna

39
00:01:49.320 --> 00:01:51.400
take and where we have float.

40
00:01:51.400 --> 00:01:53.930
The only difference here
is that we just have to pay

41
00:01:53.930 --> 00:01:55.610
attention to a few extra dependencies.

42
00:01:55.610 --> 00:01:59.280
That might be in place,
like here in Task G and over in Task I, so

43
00:01:59.280 --> 00:02:00.596
we'll watch out for those.

44
00:02:00.596 --> 00:02:03.290
But I'm going to start right at
the very beginning with task A, and

45
00:02:03.290 --> 00:02:04.280
we'll just start filling this out.

46
00:02:04.280 --> 00:02:07.700
Now remember,
when you look at these boxes,

47
00:02:07.700 --> 00:02:11.120
what these fields align to
are the early start, and

48
00:02:11.120 --> 00:02:15.480
the early finish, the late start,
and the late finish, right?

49
00:02:15.480 --> 00:02:19.020
And so, I'm starting with the early
start and the early finish.

50
00:02:19.020 --> 00:02:21.420
And we're just going to play in
the earlys all the way across.

51
00:02:21.420 --> 00:02:24.950
And then, we'll come back and
do the lates on the reverse pass.

52
00:02:24.950 --> 00:02:26.260
So on our forward pass.

53
00:02:26.260 --> 00:02:28.090
it's all about earlys.

54
00:02:28.090 --> 00:02:30.750
This is a one day duration, so
I'm going to come in here and

55
00:02:30.750 --> 00:02:32.540
just say that's one day.

56
00:02:32.540 --> 00:02:36.160
And if it's one day then it's
going to finish on one day.

57
00:02:36.160 --> 00:02:39.370
And remember from the first example,
I like to think of these as dates, right.

58
00:02:39.370 --> 00:02:42.390
So if this starts on January first,
it's going to finish on January first.

59
00:02:42.390 --> 00:02:46.668
Because it's a one day duration,
all right.

60
00:02:46.668 --> 00:02:50.840
Now, task one then branches out
to task E and task B, right.

61
00:02:50.840 --> 00:02:52.430
So, it branches out these two.

62
00:02:52.430 --> 00:02:55.610
And if task A can't
finish until the first,

63
00:02:55.610 --> 00:02:59.020
these guys can't start until the second,
right, the next day.

64
00:02:59.020 --> 00:02:59.740
So, I'm going to come in and

65
00:02:59.740 --> 00:03:03.140
populate the early starts of
these two guys with the second.

66
00:03:04.220 --> 00:03:07.940
From there, I can now start to
plot out each of these separately,

67
00:03:07.940 --> 00:03:09.100
if I want, right.

68
00:03:09.100 --> 00:03:12.600
So, I'll go up here to the top, and
I'll start to plan this one, right.

69
00:03:12.600 --> 00:03:15.870
So, we've got task E
starting on the second.

70
00:03:15.870 --> 00:03:19.400
It's a one day duration, so
it will finish on the second.

71
00:03:19.400 --> 00:03:20.650
And if it's done on January 2nd,

72
00:03:20.650 --> 00:03:23.760
that means that task F
can start on January 3rd.

73
00:03:23.760 --> 00:03:28.200
And it's a one day duration, so it can
start, or it can finish on the third.

74
00:03:29.200 --> 00:03:33.150
And then, that means that G can
get started on the third, right.

75
00:03:33.150 --> 00:03:34.920
Well, I'm not sure.

76
00:03:34.920 --> 00:03:37.420
Wait, I shouldn't have said the third,
I should have said the fourth, right.

77
00:03:37.420 --> 00:03:43.500
So, if task F finishes January third, task
G should be able to start January fourth.

78
00:03:43.500 --> 00:03:46.580
It should, except I do have this
other dependency down here.

79
00:03:46.580 --> 00:03:49.270
Right, it's dependent on task C,

80
00:03:49.270 --> 00:03:52.236
and I don't know when task
C is gonna finish yet.

81
00:03:52.236 --> 00:03:55.940
So, I'm going to have to stop
working the top path and go down and

82
00:03:55.940 --> 00:03:56.868
work the bottom path.

83
00:03:56.868 --> 00:04:00.160
I got to work these two guys down here,
to figure out when task G can start.

84
00:04:00.160 --> 00:04:02.400
So, I'm going tohave to create
a little interruption there.

85
00:04:02.400 --> 00:04:05.230
That's the complexity we have
with more than one path.

86
00:04:05.230 --> 00:04:09.610
So, I'll just go down here to B,
and with B we've got,

87
00:04:09.610 --> 00:04:11.840
it can start on January second.

88
00:04:11.840 --> 00:04:14.850
It's a two day duration, so that means
it'll finish on January third, right.

89
00:04:14.850 --> 00:04:17.910
It takes January second and
January third, two days.

90
00:04:17.910 --> 00:04:22.680
That means that task C can start on
January 4th, and it takes two days.

91
00:04:22.680 --> 00:04:27.908
So, it'll finish on January fifth,
so now we're up to January fifth.

92
00:04:27.908 --> 00:04:32.130
And now I can come up here and
I can look at task G.

93
00:04:32.130 --> 00:04:34.890
Notice that task F
finished on January third,

94
00:04:34.890 --> 00:04:38.190
but task C didn't finish
until January fifth.

95
00:04:38.190 --> 00:04:42.726
So, that means that task G cannot
start until January sixth.

96
00:04:42.726 --> 00:04:44.460
The earliest it can
start is January sixth,

97
00:04:44.460 --> 00:04:47.340
because it's having to
wait on that other task.

98
00:04:48.980 --> 00:04:51.820
Now, if it starts on January sixth and
it's a three day duration,

99
00:04:51.820 --> 00:04:54.260
that means it'll finish on January eighth,
right?

100
00:04:54.260 --> 00:04:57.280
The sixth, the seventh and the eighth,
and then we can continue to move on.

101
00:04:58.460 --> 00:05:03.260
Task H can start on the ninth,
and it is a three day duration,

102
00:05:03.260 --> 00:05:04.720
so it'll finish on the 11th.

103
00:05:06.050 --> 00:05:08.600
And then that brings me down to I,
but I can't calculate I,

104
00:05:08.600 --> 00:05:10.550
because it also has another dependency.

105
00:05:10.550 --> 00:05:12.700
So, I'm done with my top path, right?

106
00:05:12.700 --> 00:05:16.650
So, I've got my early starts and early
finishes all the way across the top path.

107
00:05:16.650 --> 00:05:19.500
Now, I need to jump down here and
finish off the bottom path.

108
00:05:19.500 --> 00:05:21.920
I'm already most of the way on that,
right, because we had to do B and

109
00:05:21.920 --> 00:05:23.490
C a minute ago.

110
00:05:23.490 --> 00:05:28.880
So if I take a look at D, well if task
C doesn't finish until the fifth.

111
00:05:28.880 --> 00:05:32.260
That means that task D can't
start until the sixth.

112
00:05:32.260 --> 00:05:37.240
And it's a five day duration, so

Make sure you watch this episode again.

337
00:16:44.470 --> 00:16:48.140
Don, any other methods or any other things
that we can actually give as hints for

338
00:16:48.140 --> 00:16:50.570
somebody getting ready for the PMP here?

339
00:16:50.570 --> 00:16:51.840
>> The big thing is on the exam,

340
00:16:51.840 --> 00:16:55.540
they're never going to have you
calculate out a whole chart like this.

341
00:16:55.540 --> 00:16:56.920
Because they know there's a timer.

342
00:16:56.920 --> 00:16:58.255
They kind of built
the exam Exam around that.

343
00:16:58.255 --> 00:17:01.605
So, they're normally going to ask you
to look into just one box, right?

344
00:17:01.605 --> 00:17:02.635
Not the whole thing.

345
00:17:02.635 --> 00:17:05.225
And so,
stay tuned because in example three,

346
00:17:05.225 --> 00:17:06.985
we're going to do it a little
more like the exam does.

347
00:17:06.985 --> 00:17:08.885
We're going to focus in
on a particular box and

348
00:17:08.885 --> 00:17:10.345
get a chance to see how that works out.

349
00:17:10.345 --> 00:17:12.935
So stay tuned for that,
you'll definitely want to watch it.

350
00:17:12.935 --> 00:17:15.975
>> Alright, well thank you again Don,
for showing us that other example.

351
00:17:15.975 --> 00:17:20.560
And for showing us how to get faster at
working at what we need to, for the exam.

352
00:17:20.560 --> 00:17:23.760
Signing off for
ITProTV I've been Ronnie Wong.

353
00:17:23.760 --> 00:17:24.660
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

354
00:17:24.660 --> 00:17:26.101
>> And I'll see you next time.

355
00:17:26.101 --> 00:17:33.649
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this example, Ronnie and Don show another example.  In this example, Don and Ronnie show how determining the critical path helps answer multiple types of questions that a PMP candidate may be expected to answer.  They emphasize the key to success will be math and practice of the techniques shown in this series of examples.
episodes.title: CPM Example Number 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.335 --> 00:00:15.074
Welcome to another great
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.074 --> 00:00:18.854
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and
today we're gonna be taking a look at PMP,

4
00:00:18.854 --> 00:00:20.904
the Project Management Professional.

5
00:00:20.904 --> 00:00:24.402
We're specifically going to be taking
a look at the critical path method,

6
00:00:24.402 --> 00:00:27.305
making sure that we understand
it as we get ready for our exam.

7
00:00:27.305 --> 00:00:29.230
And who better to help us than Mr.
Don Pezet.

8
00:00:29.230 --> 00:00:30.360
Don, how's it going?

9
00:00:30.360 --> 00:00:31.450
>> It is going great, Ronnie.

10
00:00:31.450 --> 00:00:33.060
Ready to jump right back into CPM.

11
00:00:33.060 --> 00:00:36.330
And if you've been watching,
in the first two examples, we did a really

12
00:00:36.330 --> 00:00:39.960
thorough job of running through a full
project schedule network diagram.

13
00:00:39.960 --> 00:00:42.360
Calculating out our early starts,
our early finishes and

14
00:00:42.360 --> 00:00:44.460
all that other good stuff,
figuring out our float.

15
00:00:44.460 --> 00:00:47.410
And that's all fine and good, right?

16
00:00:47.410 --> 00:00:50.640
But on the exam, they're not really gonna
have you calculate out a full diagram

17
00:00:50.640 --> 00:00:51.640
like we've been doing.

18
00:00:51.640 --> 00:00:54.945
So in this episode, what I wanna do
is make it a little more exam like.

19
00:00:54.945 --> 00:00:57.255
Where you focus in on
a particular task and

20
00:00:57.255 --> 00:01:00.365
have to calculate out some
kind of information from it.

21
00:01:00.365 --> 00:01:03.088
And that's much more realistic
to what you'll see on the exam.

22
00:01:03.088 --> 00:01:05.808
So we're gonna run through
a couple of quick examples here.

23
00:01:05.808 --> 00:01:10.720
We'll actually do three of them just to
get a feel for what it's like on the exam.

24
00:01:10.720 --> 00:01:14.250
All right, so let's start just by
kind of refreshing our memory.

25
00:01:14.250 --> 00:01:17.078
So I've got my original
template kind of fired up here.

26
00:01:17.078 --> 00:01:20.830
Remember when you see a task what you've
got is your early start, early finish,

27
00:01:20.830 --> 00:01:22.430
late start, late finish.

28
00:01:22.430 --> 00:01:25.100
It's important you memorize
the position of those numbers

29
00:01:25.100 --> 00:01:27.250
because see how I keep labeling them?

30
00:01:27.250 --> 00:01:28.395
On the exam, they won't be labeled.

31
00:01:28.395 --> 00:01:28.902
Right?

32
00:01:28.902 --> 00:01:31.112
So on the exam,
when you jump into a problem,

33
00:01:31.112 --> 00:01:33.475
what you're gonna see
is something like this.

34
00:01:33.475 --> 00:01:35.980
Right?
And we've got a bunch of numbers.

35
00:01:35.980 --> 00:01:39.487
And I don't know, are the early ones
on the bottom or the early ones on top?

36
00:01:39.487 --> 00:01:42.276
Is this early start, early finish,
late start, late finish?

37
00:01:42.276 --> 00:01:42.844
I don't remember.

38
00:01:42.844 --> 00:01:46.760
You gotta remember the positioning
in the squares of where these are.

39
00:01:46.760 --> 00:01:48.780
You've got your early
start at the top left,

40
00:01:48.780 --> 00:01:51.270
and your early finish at the top right.

41
00:01:51.270 --> 00:01:54.651
Your late start in the bottom left, and
your late finish at the bottom right.

42
00:01:54.651 --> 00:01:58.139
If you don't remember the positioning,
these problems become really challenging.

43
00:01:58.139 --> 00:01:58.824
All right?

44
00:01:58.824 --> 00:02:04.233
And then, she how I've got C right here
as the only one that's completely blank.

45
00:02:04.233 --> 00:02:06.498
Well I the exam,
it may not be completely blank.

46
00:02:06.498 --> 00:02:09.473
They may have letters in her like A,
B, C, D.

47
00:02:09.473 --> 00:02:13.285
And then, they say which of the following
is the appropriate value for A?

48
00:02:13.285 --> 00:02:14.777
And now you've got to come up here and
say, all right.

49
00:02:14.777 --> 00:02:18.080
Well this block is labeled A, what
should be the appropriate number there?

50
00:02:18.080 --> 00:02:19.440
Well I need to go and figure that out.

51
00:02:19.440 --> 00:02:20.220
All right?

52
00:02:20.220 --> 00:02:23.240
Or what is the float for Activity C?

53
00:02:23.240 --> 00:02:25.275
And I've got to calculate that out, right?

54
00:02:25.275 --> 00:02:30.715
And you'll have a multiple choice
answer in that it might have A is five,

55
00:02:30.715 --> 00:02:32.954
B is two, C is one, D is zero.

56
00:02:32.954 --> 00:02:34.248
And now I've gotta figure this out so

57
00:02:34.248 --> 00:02:36.480
I can match it up to the letter
to answer the question.

58
00:02:36.480 --> 00:02:41.090
So that's really what you're gonna get,
is they might show a topology or

59
00:02:41.090 --> 00:02:43.382
a project shared network
diagram like this.

60
00:02:43.382 --> 00:02:44.614
It might even be far more complex.

61
00:02:44.614 --> 00:02:45.609
But at the end of the day,

62
00:02:45.609 --> 00:02:47.993
you're really just dialed into
one of those little boxes.

63
00:02:47.993 --> 00:02:52.082
And you might even see the same topology
come up more than once on the exam.

64
00:02:52.082 --> 00:02:55.900
They might say what value,
what's the early start of task C?

65
00:02:55.900 --> 00:03:00.038
Then a few questions later you might
see what's the late finish of task C?

66
00:03:00.038 --> 00:03:04.848
Same topology, same task,
we're just figuring out a different value.

67
00:03:04.848 --> 00:03:07.700
Remember, don't calculate
anymore than you have to.

68
00:03:07.700 --> 00:03:11.240
Calculate the bare minimum you
need to answer the question.

69
00:03:11.240 --> 00:03:12.350
Don't go crazy.

70
00:03:12.350 --> 00:03:14.170
But once you get proficient at it,

71
00:03:14.170 --> 00:03:17.180
you'll find that you can fill
all this stuff out really fast.

72
00:03:17.180 --> 00:03:20.320
For this one for example, if I wanna
figure out its late start, early start,

73
00:03:20.320 --> 00:03:21.170
and all that.

74
00:03:21.170 --> 00:03:25.720
I really just need to focus in on
three other tasks, B, G, and D,

75
00:03:25.720 --> 00:03:27.130
the ones we have shared dependencies with.

76
00:03:27.130 --> 00:03:29.121
And then we can fill this out really fast.

77
00:03:29.121 --> 00:03:34.214
So starting off with the earlies,
early start and early finish.

78
00:03:34.214 --> 00:03:37.404
Because activity B is
gonna finish on the 8th,

79
00:03:37.404 --> 00:03:40.851
the earliest we can start
is going to be on the 9th.

80
00:03:40.851 --> 00:03:44.660
So we'll make this one a 9,
we'll just plug that right in there.

81
00:03:44.660 --> 00:03:48.040
And if it's a three day duration,
well we need the 9th, 10th, and 11th.

82
00:03:48.040 --> 00:03:49.920
And so that'll finish on the 11th.

83
00:03:49.920 --> 00:03:53.230
So now, I've got my early start and
my early finish.

84
00:03:53.230 --> 00:03:56.150
Now for figuring out my late finish,

85
00:03:56.150 --> 00:03:58.810
I need to look at the other
tasks I have dependencies with.

86
00:03:58.810 --> 00:04:02.047
Task D over here has a late start of 16.

87
00:04:02.047 --> 00:04:06.200
So based on that, I know my late
finish would need be to be 15.

88
00:04:06.200 --> 00:04:08.920
But I need to look up here and
see this one and

89
00:04:08.920 --> 00:04:11.349
see how it's got a late start of 12?

90
00:04:11.349 --> 00:04:12.254
That's gonna impact me.

91
00:04:12.254 --> 00:04:15.520
That means my late finish needs to be 11.

92
00:04:15.520 --> 00:04:16.910
In order to meet that.

93
00:04:16.910 --> 00:04:20.290
So I'll punch that in for my late finish,
and there's a three day duration.

94
00:04:20.290 --> 00:04:22.970
So my late start will be a 9.

95
00:04:22.970 --> 00:04:26.931
And then I can just figure
out my float by 9 minus 9, or

96
00:04:26.931 --> 00:04:30.680
11 minus 11 and coming up with 0.

97
00:04:30.680 --> 00:04:35.210
So now if they ask me what my float was,
if they ask me what my late start was, or

98
00:04:35.210 --> 00:04:38.000
my early finish was,
I just calculated that out.

99
00:04:38.000 --> 00:04:41.290
But I calculated out probably more
than what I necessarily needed to.

100
00:04:41.290 --> 00:04:45.748
If they just wanna know what my
earliest start was, well, 8 plus 1.

101
00:04:45.748 --> 00:04:46.600
9, done.

102
00:04:46.600 --> 00:04:47.380
Right?
No point in

103
00:04:47.380 --> 00:04:49.290
calculating the other boxes, right?

104
00:04:49.290 --> 00:04:53.102
Or if they wanted me to know what my
late finish was, I'd calculate that out.

105
00:04:53.102 --> 00:04:56.379
And even though it's super easy
to subtract the duration and

106
00:04:56.379 --> 00:04:59.023
get the late start,
I wouldn't bother with it.

107
00:04:59.023 --> 00:05:01.630
Why waste the brain cycles on that one.

108
00:05:01.630 --> 00:05:03.490
Move on to the next question.

109
00:05:03.490 --> 00:05:05.430
Or calculating out float, right?

110
00:05:05.430 --> 00:05:07.020
If I'm calculating out float,

111
00:05:07.020 --> 00:05:09.680
I need to subtract my late
finish from my late start.

112
00:05:09.680 --> 00:05:12.293
I don't necessarily need to
calculate that early finish.

113
00:05:12.293 --> 00:05:15.154
Right, I can leave that off,
and figure that out and

114
00:05:15.154 --> 00:05:16.987
get the float value right there.

115
00:05:16.987 --> 00:05:19.990
Now the only other thing I haven't looked
at is whether or not I have free float.

116
00:05:19.990 --> 00:05:23.360
I know that I don't have a gap right here.

117
00:05:23.360 --> 00:05:26.450
So I don't even have to look at the other
dependencies since there's no gap here,

118
00:05:26.450 --> 00:05:27.310
I don't have free float.

119
00:05:27.310 --> 00:05:28.730
No, actually I have zero float anyway.

120
00:05:28.730 --> 00:05:30.533
So now I'm really wasting time.

121
00:05:30.533 --> 00:05:32.553
If you have zero float,
who cares if it's free or not.

122
00:05:32.553 --> 00:05:36.406
So in this case, that's pretty much it.

123
00:05:36.406 --> 00:05:38.057
And that really wasn't that hard, was it?

124
00:05:38.057 --> 00:05:39.335
And we answered it pretty quickly.

125
00:05:39.335 --> 00:05:42.000
So you guys see how that
can be an exam question.

126
00:05:42.000 --> 00:05:47.190
I'll take a slightly different typology
here, and just block out a different one.

127
00:05:47.190 --> 00:05:49.400
Now this is the same typology,
but different time.

128
00:05:49.400 --> 00:05:52.220
So different dates or
durations assigned to it.

129
00:05:52.220 --> 00:05:55.530
And if we wanna go in and calculate it,
it's that same basic process.

130
00:05:55.530 --> 00:05:57.290
This one's actually easier.

131
00:05:57.290 --> 00:06:00.498
Because I don't have the multiple
dependencies like I did on task C.

132
00:06:00.498 --> 00:06:03.957
Task D really just has C
as the predecessor and

133
00:06:03.957 --> 00:06:07.700
I as the dependency, and
so that's it, right?

134
00:06:07.700 --> 00:06:09.760
We just have this very simple model here.

135
00:06:09.760 --> 00:06:14.000
So figuring out this one doesn't even
require a whole like of a lot of effort.

136
00:06:14.000 --> 00:06:17.690
We can just come in and
kinda dial it in based on what we see.

137
00:06:17.690 --> 00:06:21.780
If task C finished on the 11th, that means
that this one can start on the 12th.

138
00:06:21.780 --> 00:06:26.190
And it's an eight day duration,
so it's gonna finish on the 19th.

139
00:06:27.470 --> 00:06:30.730
And now I've got my early start and
my early finish, right?

140
00:06:30.730 --> 00:06:34.970
I've got the 12, that's why you're adding
one to task C's finish time, right?

141
00:06:34.970 --> 00:06:37.800
And I've got the 19 by adding eight days.

142
00:06:37.800 --> 00:06:38.960
Well, we have to count to 12, right?

143
00:06:38.960 --> 00:06:41.943
So 12 plus 8 minus 1 gives me that 19,
right?

144
00:06:41.943 --> 00:06:45.686
And then I see this nice big gap
between the 19th and the 24th, so

145
00:06:45.686 --> 00:06:47.010
I know I've got float.

146
00:06:47.010 --> 00:06:48.370
And I know I'm gonna
have to figure that out.

147
00:06:48.370 --> 00:06:49.919
And I also know it's free float.

148
00:06:49.919 --> 00:06:51.161
I know it's got free float.

149
00:06:51.161 --> 00:06:54.173
And if that's all they're asking me for,
does it have free float?

150
00:06:54.173 --> 00:06:56.774
True or false, Task G has free float.

151
00:06:56.774 --> 00:07:00.106
Well, I can tell that right now and
I don't even know what the float is.

152
00:07:00.106 --> 00:07:01.849
I just know that it exists, right?

153
00:07:01.849 --> 00:07:04.430
I know that it exists
because I see that gap.

154
00:07:04.430 --> 00:07:07.990
Then as far as the way back,
I can look at that late start of a 24.

155
00:07:07.990 --> 00:07:11.965
So my late start would be 23,
the day before.

156
00:07:11.965 --> 00:07:15.322
Then if I'm gonna finish on
the 23rd of the month and

157
00:07:15.322 --> 00:07:19.359
I've got an eight day activity,
then I need to do 23 minus 8.

158
00:07:19.359 --> 00:07:22.321
Which is 15, and I need to add 1 to that.

159
00:07:22.321 --> 00:07:24.979
So it'll be 16, if I recall correctly.

160
00:07:24.979 --> 00:07:25.779
And there we go.

161
00:07:25.779 --> 00:07:29.795
So now I've got my late start.

162
00:07:29.795 --> 00:07:33.715
And once I've got that, I can calculate
up my float, which 16 minus 12 is 4.

163
00:07:33.715 --> 00:07:35.497
23 minus 19 is 4.

164
00:07:35.497 --> 00:07:38.352
Had I calculated that duration wrong,
I'd see the variation right there.

165
00:07:38.352 --> 00:07:39.769
Ronnie mentioned that in the last episode.

166
00:07:39.769 --> 00:07:41.970
Like that's a great way to
spot if you screw that up.

167
00:07:41.970 --> 00:07:44.150
[LAUGH] Which I do from time to time.

168
00:07:44.150 --> 00:07:44.995
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

169
00:07:44.995 --> 00:07:48.515
I can see that I've got
this four days of float.

170
00:07:48.515 --> 00:07:54.100
And I know it's free float because
of the gap in between these guys.

171
00:07:54.100 --> 00:07:55.398
Right?
19 and 24.

172
00:07:55.398 --> 00:07:56.941
24 minus 19.

173
00:07:56.941 --> 00:08:00.600
That's gonna get me a nice gap
there to get that free flow.

174
00:08:00.600 --> 00:08:02.020
So now I've calculated those values.

175
00:08:02.020 --> 00:08:04.700
And so you see where we can
answer true/false questions,

176
00:08:04.700 --> 00:08:06.510
multiple choice questions, and so on.

177
00:08:06.510 --> 00:08:08.190
We just get right to the data and
get an answer.

178
00:08:10.010 --> 00:08:11.229
All right.
Let's do one more example.

179
00:08:12.390 --> 00:08:13.620
Here's another one.

180
00:08:13.620 --> 00:08:17.623
When we did Task C,
it had two dependencies on the way out.

181
00:08:17.623 --> 00:08:21.990
Task G has two predecessors on the way in.

182
00:08:21.990 --> 00:08:25.350
So this is gonna effect our earlies,
not so much out lates.

183
00:08:25.350 --> 00:08:27.450
And so when I go to figure out my early,

184
00:08:27.450 --> 00:08:29.910
this is where people in a hurry
start to make mistakes.

185
00:08:29.910 --> 00:08:31.863
People who don't really know what
they're doing make a mistake.

186
00:08:31.863 --> 00:08:35.840
Because the early start, I might base
it right off of the seven, right?

187
00:08:35.840 --> 00:08:40.600
If task F finishes on the seventh, task G
could start on the eighth, couldn't it?

188
00:08:40.600 --> 00:08:42.550
So we just pop in an eight and we're done.

189
00:08:42.550 --> 00:08:46.570
Well, I don't necessarily know that cuz I
haven't looked at this task down here and

190
00:08:46.570 --> 00:08:49.340
the earliest this task can
finish is on the 11th.

191
00:08:49.340 --> 00:08:53.640
So I need to come back up here and
change that 8 to a 12, right?

192
00:08:53.640 --> 00:08:55.721
If task C doesn't finish until the 11th,

193
00:08:55.721 --> 00:08:59.440
task G can't start until the 12th
even though this guy is done, right?

194
00:08:59.440 --> 00:09:02.560
And my warning flag should have
been the float but on the exam,

195
00:09:02.560 --> 00:09:04.350
they might not have the float filled in.

196
00:09:04.350 --> 00:09:08.300
And so if I don't see that float, then
I don't necessarily know that I need to

197
00:09:08.300 --> 00:09:11.300
pay attention to
the predecessor's very activity.

198
00:09:11.300 --> 00:09:15.520
And then 12, the twelfth of the month
is the earliest I can start it.

199
00:09:15.520 --> 00:09:16.630
If it's a three-day task,

200
00:09:16.630 --> 00:09:20.740
it'll finish on the 14th, and
that leads to the 15th, right?

201
00:09:20.740 --> 00:09:22.690
So, I know that makes sense.

202
00:09:22.690 --> 00:09:24.240
And then as far as the lates,

203
00:09:24.240 --> 00:09:26.580
the lates are easier cuz I
only have one predecessor.

204
00:09:26.580 --> 00:09:31.034
Well, it's a reverse predecessor,
so it's a dependency.

205
00:09:31.034 --> 00:09:36.544
[LAUGH] So anyhow, the 15th here
is when this one, its late start.

206
00:09:36.544 --> 00:09:39.483
So that means the latest this
one can finish is the 14th.

207
00:09:39.483 --> 00:09:41.157
And if it's a three-day duration,

208
00:09:41.157 --> 00:09:44.320
