that's gonna drop it with
a late start of the 12th.

209
00:09:44.320 --> 00:09:48.980
And I can see I'm kind of on the critical
path here, so my float is gonna be 0.

210
00:09:48.980 --> 00:09:51.240
And no need to calculate whether or
not it's free float.

211
00:09:51.240 --> 00:09:55.120
Just pay attention to those dependencies
and you can calculate it right out,

212
00:09:55.120 --> 00:09:57.430
get it mapped out, and
answer any of the questions.

213
00:09:57.430 --> 00:10:00.324
If they're asking early start,
late start, early finish, late finish.

214
00:10:00.324 --> 00:10:03.070
If they're asking for
the float, the free float.

215
00:10:03.070 --> 00:10:03.700
If they're asking for

216
00:10:03.700 --> 00:10:06.680
any of that information,
you can get it all right there.

217
00:10:06.680 --> 00:10:09.740
And it just takes a matter of seconds,
not a big deal to calculate out.

218
00:10:09.740 --> 00:10:11.920
Don has a lot of great examples for
us, but

219
00:10:11.920 --> 00:10:14.046
it seemed like the key here is practice.

220
00:10:14.046 --> 00:10:18.255
More than anything else is to sit down and
actually work through multiples of these

221
00:10:18.255 --> 00:10:22.760
until you feel very confident when you
look at this that you can determine that.

222
00:10:22.760 --> 00:10:24.710
And don't just do the simple ones, right?

223
00:10:24.710 --> 00:10:28.370
Make sure you actually add some in
that do have multiple predecessors or

224
00:10:28.370 --> 00:10:30.640
do have multiple dependencies.

225
00:10:30.640 --> 00:10:31.701
I'm gonna get that wrong, too.

226
00:10:31.701 --> 00:10:32.259
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

227
00:10:32.259 --> 00:10:35.050
>> To make sure that we
can actually do this.

228
00:10:35.050 --> 00:10:36.710
And make sure you take advantage and

229
00:10:36.710 --> 00:10:40.190
understand that the time that you have
right before you go into the exam.

230
00:10:40.190 --> 00:10:42.091
Don't worry about calculating
out the whole thing.

231
00:10:42.091 --> 00:10:43.878
Take advantage of saying, hey look.

232
00:10:43.878 --> 00:10:48.830
They're only asking me about
determining the late start.

233
00:10:48.830 --> 00:10:51.545
Don't have to go through and
do everything else that's actually there,

234
00:10:51.545 --> 00:10:52.522
just determine that one.

235
00:10:52.522 --> 00:10:54.401
Make sure you take a look at the question.

236
00:10:54.401 --> 00:10:57.511
Only answer what you actually
have been asked as well.

237
00:10:57.511 --> 00:11:01.291
Don, in the other kind of key
things right before the exam.

238
00:11:01.291 --> 00:11:04.671
If you were saying, I'm gonna take
the exam tomorrow on critical path that,

239
00:11:04.671 --> 00:11:06.340
I need to make sure that I understand.

240
00:11:06.340 --> 00:11:09.890
>> I would just say practice, so
you know you can calculate this out.

241
00:11:09.890 --> 00:11:11.250
And if you're doing this on your own,

242
00:11:11.250 --> 00:11:14.770
just start making up your topology, your
own project schedule network diagrams.

243
00:11:14.770 --> 00:11:17.180
And I encourage you to use
software like Microsoft Project,

244
00:11:17.180 --> 00:11:19.520
which can tell you exactly
what those dates are.

245
00:11:19.520 --> 00:11:22.860
It calculates out late start,
early start, late finish, early finish.

246
00:11:22.860 --> 00:11:25.540
It calculates a float and free float even.

247
00:11:25.540 --> 00:11:30.010
Except in Project, they call it slack and
they don't call it free slack.

248
00:11:30.010 --> 00:11:31.411
They call it something else.

249
00:11:31.411 --> 00:11:32.014
No actually,
I think it is called free slack.

250
00:11:32.014 --> 00:11:32.804
[CROSSTALK]
>> Yeah, I think it's called free slack.

251
00:11:32.804 --> 00:11:34.313
>> So slack and free slack.

252
00:11:34.313 --> 00:11:36.810
But it's float in PMI's world.

253
00:11:36.810 --> 00:11:38.050
So you can get it to calculate it.

254
00:11:38.050 --> 00:11:40.300
And that way you know it's right and
you can practice.

255
00:11:40.300 --> 00:11:43.170
So you've almost got like somebody
grading you, which is nice.

256
00:11:43.170 --> 00:11:45.510
I'll do it all the time where
I'll take a project, and

257
00:11:45.510 --> 00:11:48.550
you just put it in Microsoft Project,
add the activities, link them, and

258
00:11:48.550 --> 00:11:50.860
throw durations on each of the days.

259
00:11:50.860 --> 00:11:52.320
And then that's it.
Stop right there, and

260
00:11:52.320 --> 00:11:54.941
then map it out myself,
calculate all of the values.

261
00:11:54.941 --> 00:11:57.749
And then you can go into the diagram
in Project and get it to show all that.

262
00:11:57.749 --> 00:11:59.980
So definitely a neat tool to use.

263
00:11:59.980 --> 00:12:02.030
Take advantage of what's out there.

264
00:12:02.030 --> 00:12:04.980
>> And don't forget to also make
sure you memorize that template and

265
00:12:04.980 --> 00:12:07.270
where those numbers actually go.

266
00:12:07.270 --> 00:12:11.990
When you're given the early or late start,
early finish or late finish as well.

267
00:12:11.990 --> 00:12:13.390
That's gonna help you out tremendously.

268
00:12:13.390 --> 00:12:16.070
None of those diagrams are labeled for
you, and yet

269
00:12:16.070 --> 00:12:18.810
you still have to calculate
this stuff out as well.

270
00:12:18.810 --> 00:12:19.320
Okay.

271
00:12:19.320 --> 00:12:22.251
So that's a great place for
us to go ahead and end this episode.

272
00:12:22.251 --> 00:12:24.906
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I'm Ronnie Wong.

273
00:12:24.906 --> 00:12:25.788
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

274
00:12:25.788 --> 00:12:28.190
>> And we'll see you next time.

275
00:12:28.190 --> 00:12:34.859
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a closer look at how to face the challenge of determining the Earned Value.  They begin with establishing the importance of the PV, Planned Value.  Don shows the basic formulas and then sets it it the context of questions.  The guys demonstrate how to take the given information to determine the EV of a given scenario.  Working through the scenarios, they show us how the Earned Value represent the value at a specific point in time helping us see where were should be at any given time in our project vs where we are.
episodes.title: Earned Value
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.266 --> 00:00:15.528
Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.528 --> 00:00:16.990
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:16.990 --> 00:00:21.370
And today we're gonna be taking a look
at Project Management Professional, PNP.

5
00:00:21.370 --> 00:00:25.911
And we're actually gonna get in to that
weird realm of actually formulas a little

6
00:00:25.911 --> 00:00:30.534
bit and learning how to do earn value, and
do better help us down Mister Don Pezet.

7
00:00:30.534 --> 00:00:31.416
How is it going Don?

8
00:00:31.416 --> 00:00:32.576
>> It is going great Ronnie,

9
00:00:32.576 --> 00:00:36.374
ready to jump right back into our formulas
in action series, we're gonna get a chance

10
00:00:36.374 --> 00:00:39.125
to see some of these
>> Some of these formulas actually get

11
00:00:39.125 --> 00:00:40.930
used, which is really nice.

12
00:00:40.930 --> 00:00:43.560
Sometimes, we memorize the formulas,
we learn about them, but

13
00:00:43.560 --> 00:00:47.660
it you don't actually use them, it's hard
to really grasp exactly what they do.

14
00:00:47.660 --> 00:00:50.140
So we're going back and
revisiting each of these formulas and

15
00:00:50.140 --> 00:00:53.520
getting a chance to kinda see them and
see how they might turn up on the exam.

16
00:00:53.520 --> 00:00:56.270
So in this episode,
we're gonna kick off earned value, and

17
00:00:56.270 --> 00:00:59.490
if you've watched our other series,
you know that Earned Value Management

18
00:00:59.490 --> 00:01:03.250
is kind of a big deal,
it's really a lot of stuff to understand.

19
00:01:03.250 --> 00:01:07.510
But at the end of the day,
it boils down to a very simple formula for

20
00:01:07.510 --> 00:01:11.705
calculating out your Earned Value,
and so we wanna take a look at that.

21
00:01:11.705 --> 00:01:15.759
But there is one thing that was always
bothered me about Project Minister

22
00:01:15.759 --> 00:01:19.878
textbook that were out there that
the books that I was study from the course

23
00:01:19.878 --> 00:01:24.624
that I took 10 years ago, 11 years ago
compared to the courses available today.

24
00:01:24.624 --> 00:01:26.359
They are really all the same and

25
00:01:26.359 --> 00:01:31.110
they can have neglect one little thing
which is called Planned Value, right?

26
00:01:31.110 --> 00:01:32.700
Planned Value is really important.

27
00:01:32.700 --> 00:01:34.450
If you're gonna do anything
with earned value,

28
00:01:34.450 --> 00:01:37.900
you've gotta have your
planned value first, right?

29
00:01:37.900 --> 00:01:39.189
Now, remember the difference
between these.

30
00:01:39.189 --> 00:01:42.870
Earned value, not even thinking formulas,
just conceptually, right?

31
00:01:42.870 --> 00:01:47.040
Earned value is, in your project, you've
done a certain amount of work, right,

32
00:01:47.040 --> 00:01:49.880
a certain amount of things have happened,
if we're in the executing phase, right?

33
00:01:49.880 --> 00:01:54.230
Actions have gone on, stuff has happened,
and as that work is done,

34
00:01:54.230 --> 00:01:58.141
it creates a value and
your earning value is that work is done.

35
00:01:58.141 --> 00:02:00.420
If the work's not getting done,
you're not earning value.

36
00:02:00.420 --> 00:02:03.730
If work's getting done too fast,
you're earning too much value, right?

37
00:02:03.730 --> 00:02:07.478
So earned value is a great way to just
measure the performance of your project.

38
00:02:07.478 --> 00:02:11.217
The planned value is kinda the same thing
except you're not in the execution phase.

39
00:02:11.217 --> 00:02:12.413
You're in the planning phase.

40
00:02:12.413 --> 00:02:17.392
And you're saying, hey, on this date, I
plan things to be valued at this amount or

41
00:02:17.392 --> 00:02:21.740
at this other date, I plan on being
valued at a different amount.

42
00:02:21.740 --> 00:02:25.020
And so, we need to understand
how to get that planned value so

43
00:02:25.020 --> 00:02:28.220
we can then measure the earned
value against it, and

44
00:02:28.220 --> 00:02:33.100
it is value so it's easy just think money,
but it also has to kind be kind of

45
00:02:33.100 --> 00:02:37.500
factored into the work complete and that
means that this is an aggregate metric.

46
00:02:37.500 --> 00:02:40.130
It's a metric that combines,
or a composite metric.

47
00:02:40.130 --> 00:02:43.070
This combining two different elements.

48
00:02:43.070 --> 00:02:48.298
It's combining the money you spent,
with the percentage of work complete.

49
00:02:48.298 --> 00:02:51.959
And so earned value and planned value,
while a lot of time is represented in

50
00:02:51.959 --> 00:02:55.050
dollar signs, it's not truly
dollars we're talking about.

51
00:02:55.050 --> 00:02:59.590
It's like [LAUGH] what they say
about those YouTube people.

52
00:02:59.590 --> 00:03:01.606
They make internet money,
it's not real money.

53
00:03:01.606 --> 00:03:03.460
>> [LAUGH]
>> They might have a million views, but

54
00:03:03.460 --> 00:03:04.960
that haven't really seen any real money.

55
00:03:04.960 --> 00:03:06.080
That's kinda how earned value is.

56
00:03:06.080 --> 00:03:07.220
It's not real money.

57
00:03:07.220 --> 00:03:08.720
There is real money behind the scenes.

58
00:03:08.720 --> 00:03:12.623
But earned value itself is more of just
a placeholder number that let's us gauge

59
00:03:12.623 --> 00:03:13.620
that performance.

60
00:03:13.620 --> 00:03:16.070
All right, so
let's start with planned value.

61
00:03:16.070 --> 00:03:19.200
And I've got my planned value kind
of up here on my chart on my screen.

62
00:03:19.200 --> 00:03:24.500
And when you calculate out planned value,
it's a pretty straightforward formula.

63
00:03:24.500 --> 00:03:29.780
What you do is you take
your budget at completion.

64
00:03:29.780 --> 00:03:33.360
And this could be your budget at
completion for the entire project.

65
00:03:33.360 --> 00:03:36.580
Or it could be just for
an individual activity, right?

66
00:03:36.580 --> 00:03:38.490
Remember, when it comes to earned value,

67
00:03:38.490 --> 00:03:40.650
you can be looking at
your project as a whole.

68
00:03:40.650 --> 00:03:44.750
But if your project has numerous
activities going on at the same time.

69
00:03:44.750 --> 00:03:48.074
Looking at the project as a whole is
not necessarily beneficial, right?

70
00:03:48.074 --> 00:03:50.550
That's something a PMO might do.

71
00:03:50.550 --> 00:03:54.481
So if you've got a project management
office, they might just say we got

72
00:03:54.481 --> 00:03:58.864
a portfolio of 20 projects, let's just
get a high level view of what our earned

73
00:03:58.864 --> 00:04:03.327
values are across all 20 projects so we
can identify which projects are at risk.

74
00:04:03.327 --> 00:04:07.369
A PMO or a CEO,
somebody high up in the organization.

75
00:04:07.369 --> 00:04:12.319
They want that big picture, and so they
might be looking for a planned value and

76
00:04:12.319 --> 00:04:15.696
an earned value calculated
on the project as a whole.

77
00:04:15.696 --> 00:04:19.907
And if that's what you're doing your
budgeted completion that's your total

78
00:04:19.907 --> 00:04:21.400
project budget right.

79
00:04:21.400 --> 00:04:25.290
The whole shebang the entire project
what's your budget what you're dollar

80
00:04:25.290 --> 00:04:28.950
sign, and
then you multiply that by the plan work.

81
00:04:28.950 --> 00:04:30.467
Now what do we mean by plan work?

82
00:04:30.467 --> 00:04:35.816
Well, let's say it's a five year project,
and we're at the two year mark.

83
00:04:35.816 --> 00:04:37.626
And according to our plan,

84
00:04:37.626 --> 00:04:41.726
we should be 30% done with our
project at the two year mark.

85
00:04:41.726 --> 00:04:43.800
And now we're at that two year mark.

86
00:04:43.800 --> 00:04:47.520
So I would take my budget of completion
and I would multiply it by 20%.

87
00:04:47.520 --> 00:04:50.978
I should be 20% done, so I multiply by
20% and that's my planned value, right?

88
00:04:50.978 --> 00:04:53.003
The number that I get there, and

89
00:04:53.003 --> 00:04:57.120
then I can turn around a look
at what's actually going on.

90
00:04:57.120 --> 00:05:01.781
I can look at the earned value, which is
where we take the planned value that we

91
00:05:01.781 --> 00:05:06.890
just came up with, and we multiply it by
the percentage that's actually complete.

92
00:05:06.890 --> 00:05:10.594
We multiplied it by percent, 20% earlier
because that's what we planned to be

93
00:05:10.594 --> 00:05:14.568
completed, but here, maybe we're only
eighteen percent complete, or we're thirty

94
00:05:14.568 --> 00:05:18.512
percent complete, or whatever, we multiply
that out and now we get out earned value.

95
00:05:18.512 --> 00:05:23.598
And when we compare the earn value to
the plan value, we can determine whether

96
00:05:23.598 --> 00:05:28.152
we're ahead of schedule,
behind schedule, or right on schedule.

97
00:05:28.152 --> 00:05:31.662
And, I say schedule,
it also factors in budget too, right, so

98
00:05:31.662 --> 00:05:35.350
it's not just schedule,
it's really all rolled together.

99
00:05:35.350 --> 00:05:37.890
So it's really just kind of a red light,
yellow light,

100
00:05:37.890 --> 00:05:41.560
green light type scenario with a project
to know whether or not it's at risk.

101
00:05:41.560 --> 00:05:45.380
And remember for
the exam that being ahead of schedule or

102
00:05:45.380 --> 00:05:48.880
being under budget are not
necessarily a good thing.

103
00:05:48.880 --> 00:05:50.820
If you're ahead of schedule,

104
00:05:50.820 --> 00:05:54.600
it could mean that work's not getting
done that is being reported as done.

105
00:05:54.600 --> 00:05:56.710
Or if you are under budget,

106
00:05:56.710 --> 00:05:59.640
it could mean that money should
have been spent that wasn't.

107
00:05:59.640 --> 00:06:01.370
And so
certain work might not be getting done or

108
00:06:01.370 --> 00:06:03.540
certain items might not
be getting purchased.

109
00:06:03.540 --> 00:06:05.270
You might be deviating from your plan.

110
00:06:05.270 --> 00:06:09.371
So those are as big a red light as being
behind schedule or being over budget.

111
00:06:09.371 --> 00:06:11.590
So we always have to
remember that on the exam.

112
00:06:11.590 --> 00:06:14.240
That the only good number
is when these equal out.

113
00:06:14.240 --> 00:06:18.500
When your earn value equals your plan
value, and then everything's nice and

114
00:06:18.500 --> 00:06:22.900
works out great and
you end up where things are running well.

115
00:06:22.900 --> 00:06:26.380
>> So Don what I hear you also saying
is that we need to keep in mind those

116
00:06:26.380 --> 00:06:30.320
project constraints, making sure that we
understand that we're talking about not

117
00:06:30.320 --> 00:06:35.800
only the idea of cost but the resources or
deliverables that we might have on hand,

118
00:06:35.800 --> 00:06:39.560
as well as the time constraints too,
that we wanna make sure that that's all

119
00:06:39.560 --> 00:06:42.160
balanced and this is what really
helps us to show that we're on track.

120
00:06:42.160 --> 00:06:42.790
>> That's it.

121
00:06:42.790 --> 00:06:47.570
And I mentioned it like from a PMO
perspective, from the whole company, but

122
00:06:47.570 --> 00:06:48.800
if you're a project manager,

123
00:06:48.800 --> 00:06:51.480
you might just be looking
at one particular activity.

124
00:06:51.480 --> 00:06:53.490
I might have an activity
that is only two weeks long.

125
00:06:53.490 --> 00:06:58.260
It is a two week activity,
it is ten days, and I am on day four.

126
00:06:58.260 --> 00:07:00.430
Okay, well how is it looking so far?

127
00:07:00.430 --> 00:07:01.510
Am I going to finish on day ten?

128
00:07:01.510 --> 00:07:03.180
I am not sure yet.

129
00:07:03.180 --> 00:07:06.020
We can use earned value and
planned value to figure that out, right?

130
00:07:06.020 --> 00:07:07.980
So this does not have to
be the project as a whole.

131
00:07:07.980 --> 00:07:11.210
As the project manager you will
normally do this based on an activity.

132
00:07:11.210 --> 00:07:14.568
As a PMO, as a CEO, somebody like that,
you'll do it on the project as a whole.

133
00:07:14.568 --> 00:07:17.400
But at the end of the day,
the formula's really the same.

134
00:07:17.400 --> 00:07:20.090
That budget at completion (BAC)
times the Planned Work will give you

135
00:07:20.090 --> 00:07:21.790
the Planned Value (PV) for
whatever you're managing.

136
00:07:21.790 --> 00:07:25.530
And it's the Planned Work
as of that point in time.

137
00:07:25.530 --> 00:07:27.900
Earned value is all about a point in time.

138
00:07:27.900 --> 00:07:31.870
We're gonna talk in another
episode about forecasting.

139
00:07:31.870 --> 00:07:34.230
And how you can start
predicting the future.

140
00:07:34.230 --> 00:07:37.670
And that's when you start moving
away from a point in time.

141
00:07:37.670 --> 00:07:41.080
And those formulas are really easy to
spot, cuz they'll always have a lower,

142
00:07:41.080 --> 00:07:45.620
a little, what's it called when
the letter that's beneath the letter?

143
00:07:45.620 --> 00:07:46.690
It's not a super-
>> A subscript.

144
00:07:46.690 --> 00:07:48.722
>> A subscript.
They'll have a little subscript c on

145
00:07:48.722 --> 00:07:51.016
them that let's you know
it's a cumulative value.

146
00:07:51.016 --> 00:07:54.848
So you've got these cumulative that'll
be measuring multiple plan values or

147
00:07:54.848 --> 00:07:56.131
multiple earned values.

148
00:07:56.131 --> 00:07:59.450
And you can use those to trend and
predict the future right?

149
00:07:59.450 --> 00:08:00.472
That's different.

150
00:08:00.472 --> 00:08:01.448
With earn value and

151
00:08:01.448 --> 00:08:05.295
plan value by default you're really
just looking at single point in time.

152
00:08:05.295 --> 00:08:06.535
And you pick that time.

153
00:08:06.535 --> 00:08:07.815
And the time is normally now.

154
00:08:07.815 --> 00:08:10.801
We normally say as of right now,
what do I have?

155
00:08:10.801 --> 00:08:14.306
But you might be looking at something
in the past and saying you know,

156
00:08:14.306 --> 00:08:16.428
where were we at at
this point in the past?

157
00:08:16.428 --> 00:08:20.898
And the scenario there might be,
I think my project is falling behind.

158
00:08:20.898 --> 00:08:23.763
You know, things aren't quite
working out the way that I think.

159
00:08:23.763 --> 00:08:27.034
We have another project that was done
in the company that followed the same

160
00:08:27.034 --> 00:08:29.209
pattern, right that did
the same type of thing.

161
00:08:29.209 --> 00:08:30.386
You see this in construction a lot.

162
00:08:30.386 --> 00:08:31.423
I'm building a house.

163
00:08:31.423 --> 00:08:32.926
I'm not the first person to build a house.

164
00:08:32.926 --> 00:08:34.795
Somebody else built a similar house.

165
00:08:34.795 --> 00:08:38.904
Let me go look at their project and look
at their calendar and go back in the past

166
00:08:38.904 --> 00:08:42.841
and say, on this day what was their
earned value and compare that to mine.

167
00:08:42.841 --> 00:08:46.118
And where mine starts to look behind and I
look at theirs and theirs look behind too.

168
00:08:46.118 --> 00:08:48.916
It turns out we just didn't have
an even distribution at work.

169
00:08:48.916 --> 00:08:53.187
That happens a lot where you might
have a four day activity, and

170
00:08:53.187 --> 00:08:58.282
it might be 25% of the work getting
done each day, 100% of the work.

171
00:08:58.282 --> 00:09:02.731
Or you might have front loaded or
back loaded work.

172
00:09:02.731 --> 00:09:04.764
You see this especially where
there's a lot of materials.

173
00:09:04.764 --> 00:09:08.130
So on day one you've got to
spend $10,000 on material,

174
00:09:08.130 --> 00:09:12.525
but on day two, three and four you're
just spending $1,000 a day on labor.

175
00:09:12.525 --> 00:09:15.531
So, the bulk of your cost
is right there on day one.

176
00:09:15.531 --> 00:09:16.323
It’s frontloaded or

177
00:09:16.323 --> 00:09:19.452
you can have it backloaded too where it's
payment on delivery, that kind of thing.

178
00:09:19.452 --> 00:09:22.821
And those can really skew these numbers
and so that's why it's important to be

179
00:09:22.821 --> 00:09:25.693
able compare with other projects and
start looking into the past.

180
00:09:25.693 --> 00:09:31.116
So, planned value and earned value,
all about a particular point in time.

181
00:09:31.116 --> 00:09:32.823
So, what are we gonna see
in the exam with this?

182
00:09:32.823 --> 00:09:37.111
Well, you'll see questions in a few
different formats and here's one example.

183
00:09:37.111 --> 00:09:39.263
They're giving me some information.

184
00:09:39.263 --> 00:09:43.958
They tell me that my project has a total
budget of 1.2 million dollars, right.

185
00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:44.952
We’ve got a pretty big projecthre.

186
00:09:44.952 --> 00:09:46.110
1.2 million.

187
00:09:46.110 --> 00:09:52.388
And on July 1st 2016 we
are scheduled to be 30% complete.

188
00:09:52.388 --> 00:09:55.192
So we should be 30% complete on July 1st.

189
00:09:55.192 --> 00:09:58.037
What is the planned value for July 1st?

190
00:09:58.037 --> 00:10:01.484
Now, the first thing you might notice in
this question is that there's a lot of

191
00:10:01.484 --> 00:10:02.852
data that's missing, okay.

192
00:10:02.852 --> 00:10:05.919
What is the duration of this project?

193
00:10:05.919 --> 00:10:09.029
Is it one month, is it one year,
is it five years?

194
00:10:09.029 --> 00:10:09.862
I don't know.

195
00:10:09.862 --> 00:10:13.010
All right and what date that it start?

196
00:10:13.010 --> 00:10:14.270
What date is the end?

197
00:10:14.270 --> 00:10:15.388
I don't know that either.

198
00:10:15.388 --> 00:10:19.004
All I know is that on July 1st
I'm supposed to be 30% complete.

199
00:10:19.004 --> 00:10:22.137
And it's easy to panic when you get
something like this cuz you look at it and

200
00:10:22.137 --> 00:10:23.900
you're like it's missing so much data.

201
00:10:23.900 --> 00:10:25.851
So much here that I don't have.

202
00:10:25.851 --> 00:10:30.585
But at the end of the day,
planned value doesn't need a whole lot.

203
00:10:30.585 --> 00:10:32.048
It needs our budget of completion.

204
00:10:32.048 --> 00:10:33.286
What's the budget for my project?

205
00:10:33.286 --> 00:10:34.994
$1.2 million right?

206
00:10:34.994 --> 00:10:36.924
And, I need the planned work.

207
00:10:36.924 --> 00:10:41.089
Well on July first my
planned work is 30% complete.

208
00:10:41.089 --> 00:10:45.619
So, I've got all the data I need to
calculate out the planned value.

209
00:10:45.619 --> 00:10:49.459
Now once I have an answer,
how does it help me?

210
00:10:49.459 --> 00:10:52.466
Well, it doesn't help all that much,
because you need to put in context.

211
00:10:52.466 --> 00:10:56.201
But on the exam, it's not so
much about putting it into context and

212
00:10:56.201 --> 00:10:57.545
solving that problem.

213
00:10:57.545 --> 00:11:01.567
It's about knowing what formula to use and
how to get the results, right?

214
00:11:01.567 --> 00:11:05.225
If you read this right here, and
you had no idea what the formula was for

215
00:11:05.225 --> 00:11:08.211
planned value,
It's really hard to extrapolate that.

216
00:11:08.211 --> 00:11:11.198
It'd be not impossible, but close.

217
00:11:11.198 --> 00:11:13.128
But if you know the formula,
you just look at it.

218
00:11:13.128 --> 00:11:15.342
And you go, okay, well,
here's my budget at completion.

219
00:11:15.342 --> 00:11:16.501
Here's my planned value.

220
00:11:16.501 --> 00:11:18.004
Let's multiply those out, right?

221
00:11:18.004 --> 00:11:22.230
So what is $1.2 million times 30%?

222
00:11:22.230 --> 00:11:24.141
And sadly,
the answer is that I don't know.

223
00:11:24.141 --> 00:11:26.365
So [LAUGH]-
>> 360,000.

224
00:11:26.365 --> 00:11:27.228
>> Thank you Ronnie.

225
00:11:27.228 --> 00:11:28.874
So Ronnie has already figured it out for
me.

226
00:11:28.874 --> 00:11:33.224
So, if we do budget to completion or

227
00:11:33.224 --> 00:11:40.475
$1,200,000 and
we multiply that by our 30%,

228
00:11:40.475 --> 00:11:45.268
then we end up with $360,000.

229
00:11:45.268 --> 00:11:51.140
So, $360,000 is our planned value and I
should've written this a little different.

230
00:11:51.140 --> 00:11:52.299
I normally write it this way.

231
00:11:52.299 --> 00:11:58.921
So, PV = $1.2 million * 30% = $360,000.

232
00:11:58.921 --> 00:12:05.890
So as of July 1st, I should have achieved
the equivalent of $360,000 of value.

233
00:12:05.890 --> 00:12:09.635
And that value is labor and
other things that were budgeted and

234
00:12:09.635 --> 00:12:14.261
assigned to it at that point, and
I should be 30% complete at that stage.

235
00:12:14.261 --> 00:12:19.026
And if I go and check my books and
see that I spent more than $360,000,

236
00:12:19.026 --> 00:12:21.791
then I should be more than 30% complete.

237
00:12:21.791 --> 00:12:24.165
And if I see that I've
spent less than $360,000,

238
00:12:24.165 --> 00:12:25.964
then I should be less than 30% complete.

239
00:12:25.964 --> 00:12:28.480
So I can start to use that as
a gauge of where we're at, and

240
00:12:28.480 --> 00:12:30.432
that's what we'll see with earned value.

241
00:12:30.432 --> 00:12:34.700
But on a planned value side,
I now have a number, all right.

242
00:12:34.700 --> 00:12:37.389
And, that number by itself is not
terribly useful until I start

243
00:12:37.389 --> 00:12:38.921
comparing it with my earned value.

244
00:12:38.921 --> 00:12:43.789
But, what you can do, nobody does this,
but, you could take your project while

245
00:12:43.789 --> 00:12:47.942
you're in the planning phase, and
you could plan out, or you know,

246
00:12:47.942 --> 00:12:52.839
predetermine your planned value for
every single day throughout your project.

247
00:12:52.839 --> 00:12:55.317
Well imagine if you got
a five year project.

248
00:12:55.317 --> 00:12:57.429
And so
you're talking about over 1,500 days,

249
00:12:57.429 --> 00:13:00.030
over 1,500 planned values that
you have to calculate out.

250
00:13:00.030 --> 00:13:01.480
And if you're doing it per activity,

251
00:13:01.480 --> 00:13:03.302
you could have many
activities on the same day.

252
00:13:03.302 --> 00:13:04.378
It becomes a nightmare.

253
00:13:04.378 --> 00:13:08.970
But if you're using Primavera or
Microsoft Project, or any of the other

254
00:13:08.970 --> 00:13:13.113
various project management software
suites that are out there,

255
00:13:13.113 --> 00:13:15.613
they calculate this stuff no problem.

256
00:13:15.613 --> 00:13:18.516
And so you can just look at it and
say all right what's my planned value and

257
00:13:18.516 --> 00:13:20.430
what's my earned value and
it tells you right?

258
00:13:20.430 --> 00:13:22.827
But on the exam, they want you
to know how to do it by hand.

259
00:13:22.827 --> 00:13:24.776
Calculating it out, not very hard, right?

260
00:13:24.776 --> 00:13:27.601
Budget and
completion times the planned work.

261
00:13:27.601 --> 00:13:30.344
Now I did for the project as a whole here.

262
00:13:30.344 --> 00:13:34.549
If you take it for like an individual
activity It's not much different.

263
00:13:34.549 --> 00:13:38.119
So this question says, the contractors for

264
00:13:38.119 --> 00:13:45.073
Work Breakdown Structure Task 3.1.1
won the contract with a $2,400 bid.

265
00:13:45.073 --> 00:13:47.817
All right, so that's the bid
they put in to do this work.

266
00:13:47.817 --> 00:13:51.897
It says they've indicated
the work will take six days and

267
00:13:51.897 --> 00:13:54.800
will be complete on July 7, 2016.

268
00:13:54.800 --> 00:14:00.240
What is the planned value for July 4th
assuming an even distribution of labor?

269
00:14:02.270 --> 00:14:04.697
This question,
it's almost the opposite of the last one.

270
00:14:04.697 --> 00:14:07.466
Remember the last one how I said it was so
devoid of information,

271
00:14:07.466 --> 00:14:10.210
it only gave us the bare
minimum of what we needed.

272
00:14:10.210 --> 00:14:13.354
This one is giving us too
much information, and

273
00:14:13.354 --> 00:14:15.325
you will see this on the exam.

274
00:14:15.325 --> 00:14:16.360
They love to do this.

275
00:14:16.360 --> 00:14:18.555
They give you more
information than you need.

276
00:14:18.555 --> 00:14:22.612
And the reason is some people will
memorize formulas, and they don't even pay

277
00:14:22.612 --> 00:14:26.132
attention to the question as much
as just what values are provided.

278
00:14:26.132 --> 00:14:29.525
And they know what formula to use because
of the values that were provided.

279
00:14:29.525 --> 00:14:31.737
So by giving you too much information,

280
00:14:31.737 --> 00:14:34.828
it's now up to you to pick
out the pieces that you need.

281
00:14:34.828 --> 00:14:36.738
And again,
you need to be familiar with that formula.

282
00:14:36.738 --> 00:14:39.360
You need to have the formula memorized so
you know what to grab.

283
00:14:39.360 --> 00:14:42.877
So this one's given me too
much information, and yet

284
00:14:42.877 --> 00:14:46.551
it hasn't given me some of
the information that I need,

285
00:14:46.551 --> 00:14:51.102
like what is my percentage complete
on a particular day here, okay?

286
00:14:51.102 --> 00:14:54.150
They didn't come right out and
give that to me.

287
00:14:54.150 --> 00:14:56.690
They gave it in a bit of a roundabout way,
right?

288
00:14:56.690 --> 00:14:59.970
Notice here where it says, they've
indicated the work will take six days and

289
00:14:59.970 --> 00:15:01.790
will be completed on July 7th.

290
00:15:01.790 --> 00:15:05.520
When you see it would be completed,
it means 100% right?

291
00:15:05.520 --> 00:15:10.840
it would be a 100% done on July 7 and
it takes six days.

292
00:15:10.840 --> 00:15:14.500
So that means that we start on with
the second right a second, third,

293
00:15:14.500 --> 00:15:16.415
fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh.

294
00:15:16.415 --> 00:15:21.924
It’s a good math [CROSSTALK] so
were going to start on July 2nd and

295
00:15:21.924 --> 00:15:27.853
then each day, we're doing work
all the way to July 7th, six days.

296
00:15:27.853 --> 00:15:32.265
And so
if I'm 100% complete on the sixth day, and

297
00:15:32.265 --> 00:15:37.667
they're asking for me to figure
it out on the fourth day, right?

298
00:15:37.667 --> 00:15:39.677
On July 4th, not the fourth day, sorry.

299
00:15:39.677 --> 00:15:44.798
On July 4th well, I've got the second,
the third and the fourth right?

300
00:15:44.798 --> 00:15:47.143
And then after that I've got my fifth,
sixth and seventh.

301
00:15:47.143 --> 00:15:51.932
That's halfway through, and
they're telling me it's an even

302
00:15:51.932 --> 00:15:56.188
distribution of labor And so
each day is seeing roughly,

303
00:15:56.188 --> 00:16:00.670
what is it,
like 16.66% of the work or whatever.

304
00:16:00.670 --> 00:16:02.340
But what it works out
to is because July 4th

305
00:16:02.340 --> 00:16:03.990
is right in the middle, it's 50%, right?

306
00:16:05.870 --> 00:16:12.740
If I'm at the end of day three on a six
day activity, that's 50% of the duration.

307
00:16:12.740 --> 00:16:15.440
And if it's an even distribution of labor,

308
00:16:15.440 --> 00:16:18.690
then I should expect to be
50% complete on July 4th.

309
00:16:18.690 --> 00:16:20.760
So while they didn't come right out and
say it,

310
00:16:20.760 --> 00:16:24.940
they did give me the information I
needed to figure that out, all right?

311
00:16:24.940 --> 00:16:28.385
So now I know my budgeted
completion is $2,400.

312
00:16:28.385 --> 00:16:29.716
I don't care that it's a bid.

313
00:16:29.716 --> 00:16:32.874
I don't care that it's
a Work Breakdown Structure Task 3.1.1.

314
00:16:32.874 --> 00:16:34.780
I don't care about any of that.

315
00:16:34.780 --> 00:16:36.250
I just needed that number right there.

316
00:16:36.250 --> 00:16:38.656
They said they could do the work for
$2,400.

317
00:16:38.656 --> 00:16:41.350
And they said it would take six days.

318
00:16:41.350 --> 00:16:46.810
On July 4th that's halfway,
they should be 50% done on July 4th.

319
00:16:46.810 --> 00:16:49.001
And so if I take my formula here and

320
00:16:49.001 --> 00:16:53.778
start to write that out my planned
value equals my budget at completion,

321
00:16:53.778 --> 00:16:58.657
$2,400, multiplied by my planned work,
which should be 50%.

322
00:16:58.657 --> 00:17:03.256
And, if we work that out, that should be,
I can do this math in my head,

323
00:17:03.256 --> 00:17:05.274
look at that, $1,200.

324
00:17:05.274 --> 00:17:06.435
I'm so proud of myself.

325
00:17:06.435 --> 00:17:10.962
So, 2,400 times 50%, $1,200, halfway.

326
00:17:10.962 --> 00:17:15.680
So my planned value as
of July 4th is $1,200.

327
00:17:15.680 --> 00:17:18.810
The reality is we could have figured
it out for any of the days in there,

328
00:17:18.810 --> 00:17:24.100
just the percentages make it a little
bit harder, you might 66.66% or

329
00:17:24.100 --> 00:17:26.990
something like that
you've got to work with.

330
00:17:26.990 --> 00:17:29.760
On the exam, they usually try
to use numbers that work out so

331
00:17:29.760 --> 00:17:32.750
you don't need a calculator,
because you don't have a calculator.

332
00:17:34.070 --> 00:17:36.620
Right, so if you can avoid it,
you know, get better at doing these.

333
00:17:36.620 --> 00:17:39.960
You'll have scratch paper so
you can do math by hand if you need to.

334
00:17:39.960 --> 00:17:42.590
But don't count on a calculator,
you're not going to have one.

335
00:17:42.590 --> 00:17:47.010
So it will normally be numbers like
these that you can do in your head.

336
00:17:47.010 --> 00:17:49.480
So that's planned value.

337
00:17:49.480 --> 00:17:52.510
These can be done very early
on in your planning stage,

338
00:17:52.510 --> 00:17:54.270
before you're actually executing.

339
00:17:54.270 --> 00:17:57.050
Just while you're thinking about it,
you can lay these out.

340
00:17:57.050 --> 00:18:01.000
Maybe you when you signed this
contract with the contractor,

341
00:18:01.000 --> 00:18:04.300
you made an agreement that you guys said
hey, it's going to be a six day activity,

342
00:18:04.300 --> 00:18:06.560
we're going to do progress
reports every two days.

343
00:18:06.560 --> 00:18:08.272
Right?
So, on day two, day four, day six and

344
00:18:08.272 --> 00:18:09.370
day six should be acceptance.

345
00:18:09.370 --> 00:18:10.560
You know that should be 100% done,

346
00:18:10.560 --> 00:18:13.690
you accept the product from
the contractor and you're done.

347
00:18:13.690 --> 00:18:16.260
So, we are going to do three measures.

348
00:18:16.260 --> 00:18:20.550
And you can calculate the planned value
for those three measures very early on,

349
00:18:20.550 --> 00:18:22.340
right there in the planning phase.

350
00:18:22.340 --> 00:18:25.300
And then when you get to
the execution phase, now when

351
00:18:25.300 --> 00:18:28.540
you're doing monitoring and controlling,
you notice those three measures.

352
00:18:28.540 --> 00:18:30.640
Those three milestones for
this particular activity.

353
00:18:30.640 --> 00:18:33.550
So on day two, you need to go and
collect your earned value, and

354
00:18:33.550 --> 00:18:35.410
then on day four you need to go and
collect your earned value,

355
00:18:35.410 --> 00:18:39.180
and on day six you need to collect
your earned value and compare those,

356
00:18:39.180 --> 00:18:41.990
to the planned values that you set
out way back in the planning phase.

357
00:18:41.990 --> 00:18:44.400
Alright, so
let's take a look at earned value now,

358
00:18:44.400 --> 00:18:46.380
we've talked about planned value enough.

359
00:18:46.380 --> 00:18:52.510
So, earned value, very similar except
instead of taking our budgeted completion,

360
00:18:52.510 --> 00:18:56.960
we're taking our plan value, okay,
our planned value that was assigned and

361
00:18:56.960 --> 00:18:59.960
we're multiplying that by our
percentage complete, right?

362
00:18:59.960 --> 00:19:02.360
What of the work has actually been done?

363
00:19:02.360 --> 00:19:08.180
And that should result in us
getting our earned value.

364
00:19:08.180 --> 00:19:12.610
So, when we start to compare this,
we can jump over to an example here.

365
00:19:12.610 --> 00:19:20.010
Activity 7.1 is budgeted at $5,000 and
is scheduled to complete on February 28th.

366
00:19:20.010 --> 00:19:25.600
A status report dated February 26th
indicates the activity is 20% completed.

367
00:19:25.600 --> 00:19:28.960
What is your earn value as of the 26th?

368
00:19:28.960 --> 00:19:29.660
All right.

369
00:19:29.660 --> 00:19:34.170
Now, this question can get a little bit
tricky when you start to look at it.

370
00:19:34.170 --> 00:19:36.190
We just worked through planned value.

371
00:19:36.190 --> 00:19:41.920
And when you look at planned value, I
mentioned how it's really a point in time.

372
00:19:41.920 --> 00:19:43.240
And when we take the planned value,

373
00:19:43.240 --> 00:19:45.090
its a planned value of
a particular point in time.

374
00:19:45.090 --> 00:19:47.930
The budget at completion times
the work we have planned for

375
00:19:47.930 --> 00:19:51.330
that moment at that particular time.

376
00:19:51.330 --> 00:19:55.070
And so that's the way that the planned
value can work, and when you

377
00:19:55.070 --> 00:19:59.990
calculate it out that way, it is looking
at that moment for what our plan is.

378
00:19:59.990 --> 00:20:03.690
When we get into the earned value formula,
things get a little trickier here.

379
00:20:03.690 --> 00:20:08.540
Because reading this question,
what is my planned value for the 26th?

380
00:20:09.870 --> 00:20:11.400
Well, I don't really know,
it doesn't tell me.

381
00:20:11.400 --> 00:20:15.070
It tells me my budget is $5,000,
that would be my budget at completion.

382
00:20:15.070 --> 00:20:19.990
And it's scheduled to complete on
February 28th and this is February 26th.

383
00:20:19.990 --> 00:20:22.620
I don't really know my planned value for
the 26th.

384
00:20:24.160 --> 00:20:27.600
So I might be tempted to choose
that option on the exam.

385
00:20:27.600 --> 00:20:30.870
On the exam you'll see a couple of
different exam options, you know,

386
00:20:30.870 --> 00:20:33.210
usually just numbers for
the various formula results.

387
00:20:33.210 --> 00:20:35.910
But there will usually be one that
says not enough information provided.

388
00:20:35.910 --> 00:20:36.490
Right?
And

389
00:20:36.490 --> 00:20:39.370
I might be tempted to provide that
not enough information provided.

390
00:20:39.370 --> 00:20:42.870
But when you look at the earned value
formula here, when it talks about the plan

391
00:20:42.870 --> 00:20:46.440
value, it's really talking about
the plan value at completion.

392
00:20:46.440 --> 00:20:50.650
What's our plan value for this activity
as a whole, not necessarily on the 26th?

393
00:20:50.650 --> 00:20:55.620
So I don't know my plan value for
the 26th, but I know my plan value for

394
00:20:55.620 --> 00:20:59.890
the activity as a whole is $5,000, so
when I come down here to calculate out my

395
00:20:59.890 --> 00:21:05.210
earned value,
my earned value would be my plan value

396
00:21:05.210 --> 00:21:10.885
of $5,000 times the work that's complete,
which I know is 20%, all right?

397
00:21:10.885 --> 00:21:15.770
So 20% of the work is done and
it's a $5,000 plan value.

398
00:21:15.770 --> 00:21:18.900
So if we multiply that out,
fact check me here Ronnie, but

399
00:21:18.900 --> 00:21:19.680
that should be $1,000, right?

400
00:21:19.680 --> 00:21:20.539
>> It should be $1,000.

401
00:21:20.539 --> 00:21:22.642
>> All right so that is $1,000.

402
00:21:22.642 --> 00:21:26.970
Now that means my earned value
as of the 26th is $1,000.

403
00:21:26.970 --> 00:21:28.410
Is that good or bad?

404
00:21:28.410 --> 00:21:34.630
Well, if the exam is asking you
to pick what the earned value is,

405
00:21:34.630 --> 00:21:35.570
you know the answer.

406
00:21:35.570 --> 00:21:36.610
Right?
You got it right there.

407
00:21:36.610 --> 00:21:40.530
The earned value is $1,000 as of the 26th,
but if the exam is asking you whether it's

408
00:21:40.530 --> 00:21:43.960
good or bad, we actually don't
have enough information for that.

409
00:21:43.960 --> 00:21:45.870
We don't know how long this activity is.

410
00:21:45.870 --> 00:21:47.170
This could be a three day activity.

411
00:21:47.170 --> 00:21:51.350
We could be on day one, which is the 26th,
then you've got the 27th and the 28th, so

412
00:21:51.350 --> 00:21:53.230
we are only a third of the way through.

413
00:21:53.230 --> 00:21:55.920
We are not a third of the way
percentage wise, so it looks bad.

414
00:21:57.370 --> 00:21:59.495
This could be 100 day activity,
so it'd look really bad.

415
00:21:59.495 --> 00:22:02.200
[LAUGH] It could be bad, or

416
00:22:02.200 --> 00:22:05.130
it could be that we have
an uneven distribution of labor.

417
00:22:05.130 --> 00:22:07.020
This could be a back-loaded
labor activity,

418
00:22:07.020 --> 00:22:09.000
where we expect to only be at 20%.

419
00:22:09.000 --> 00:22:12.800
Since I don't know the planned value for
the 26th specifically,

420
00:22:12.800 --> 00:22:16.840
I can't say whether this is good or
bad, so if they're asking me that,

421
00:22:16.840 --> 00:22:21.190
if they're asking me, am I ahead or
behind, I don't really know, and

422
00:22:21.190 --> 00:22:23.970
I will have to choose that option that
says not enough information provided.

423
00:22:23.970 --> 00:22:27.060
But if they're just asking for
the earned value, I've got that.

424
00:22:27.060 --> 00:22:29.580
I've got my budgeted,
what I should be at 100%.

425
00:22:29.580 --> 00:22:33.280
When I'm at 100% completion, my planned
value is $5,000, that's what I've planned.

426
00:22:34.350 --> 00:22:38.490
Right now on the 26th, I'm only 20% of
the way through and so my earned value,

427
00:22:38.490 --> 00:22:40.870
regardless of date, is $1,000.

428
00:22:40.870 --> 00:22:44.560
If my plan value for the 26th is $2,000,
then I'm in trouble.

429
00:22:44.560 --> 00:22:49.330
But if my plan value for the 26th
is $1,000, then I'm right on track.

430
00:22:49.330 --> 00:22:52.280
And that very well may be that
I'm right on track with plan,

431
00:22:52.280 --> 00:22:54.680
I just don't necessarily
have that information here.

432
00:22:54.680 --> 00:22:55.240
Okay.

433
00:22:55.240 --> 00:22:58.630
So calculating out earned
value can be pretty simple.

434
00:22:58.630 --> 00:22:59.990
It is easy to get tripped up though,

435
00:22:59.990 --> 00:23:03.050
especially when we look at our plan
value here and calculated it out.

436
00:23:03.050 --> 00:23:06.480
The another thing we can
triples up is present value.

437
00:23:06.480 --> 00:23:09.940
Plan value and present value they
both give the preview in PV.

438
00:23:09.940 --> 00:23:12.780
And present value is really
talking about materials, usually

439
00:23:12.780 --> 00:23:16.800
your present value materials versus
their value in the future and the past.

440
00:23:16.800 --> 00:23:20.340
The plan value is what we see
in earn value analysis or

441
00:23:20.340 --> 00:23:24.250
earn value management and EVM is what
you're really being test on them.

442
00:23:24.250 --> 00:23:26.430
Alright, let's take a look
at another example here.

443
00:23:26.430 --> 00:23:28.600
This one gives us a good
chunk of information.

444
00:23:28.600 --> 00:23:32.990
It says activity 4.3 is scheduled for
July 3rd through July 6th, so

445
00:23:32.990 --> 00:23:35.800
we're looking at a four day activity.

446
00:23:35.800 --> 00:23:38.290
We've got a budget of $12,000.

447
00:23:38.290 --> 00:23:42.503
Labor and costs are evenly
distributed across all days.

448
00:23:42.503 --> 00:23:46.790
A status report for July 4th indicates
accounting has paid out $8,000.

449
00:23:46.790 --> 00:23:49.483
What is your EV for July 4th?

450
00:23:49.483 --> 00:23:53.654
Now, as I read through this What I'm
trying to do is take this information and

451
00:23:53.654 --> 00:23:56.104
catalog it with where it needs to be,
right?

452
00:23:56.104 --> 00:23:59.330
So I see that we're scheduled
July 3rd through July 6th.

453
00:23:59.330 --> 00:24:03.030
So the first thing I thought was,
duration, four days, okay?

454
00:24:03.030 --> 00:24:05.009
So now I've got a duration,
this is a four day activity.

455
00:24:05.009 --> 00:24:07.029
A budget of $12,000, great.

456
00:24:07.029 --> 00:24:08.990
There's my budget at completion.

457
00:24:08.990 --> 00:24:11.500
Labor and costs are evenly
distributed across all four days.

458
00:24:11.500 --> 00:24:16.486
Now I'm thinking, okay, I should have 25%
of my labor, done each of the four days

459
00:24:16.486 --> 00:24:21.753
and if my budget is $12000, I should
be spending, roughly, $3000 per day for

460
00:24:21.753 --> 00:24:26.509
four days, these are the things running
through my head as I start reading this.

461
00:24:26.509 --> 00:24:29.630
I get a status report for July 4.

462
00:24:29.630 --> 00:24:31.810
Well, this is July 3 to July 6.

463
00:24:31.810 --> 00:24:35.229
So we're only on day two, so at the end
of day two but it's a four day project so

464
00:24:35.229 --> 00:24:37.190
that means we're actually half way right?

465
00:24:37.190 --> 00:24:38.350
So half way through,

466
00:24:38.350 --> 00:24:42.490
I get a status report telling me
we've paid out $8,000 to date okay?

467
00:24:42.490 --> 00:24:47.480
Now before I've even thought of a formula
I know that if I'm spending roughly $3,000

468
00:24:47.480 --> 00:24:50.890
a day I should be at $6,000
at the end of day four or

469
00:24:50.890 --> 00:24:55.060
at the end of the 4th and
I see I'm at $8,000 today.

470
00:24:55.060 --> 00:24:58.970
So without even a formula, we kinda know
that this project has some problems.

471
00:24:58.970 --> 00:25:02.760
It's advancing too rapidly for some
reason, and so we've got a problem there.

472
00:25:02.760 --> 00:25:04.630
But they're not asking me about that.

473
00:25:04.630 --> 00:25:07.080
They just wanna know what's
my earned value for July 4th.

474
00:25:07.080 --> 00:25:10.210
That's all I needed to know,
what is my earned value, right?

475
00:25:10.210 --> 00:25:14.040
I actually have enough information here
to calculate out my planned value too but

476
00:25:14.040 --> 00:25:15.680
all they're asking for is earned value.

477
00:25:15.680 --> 00:25:17.110
So if I take a look at that formula.

478
00:25:17.110 --> 00:25:18.870
I come in here and I can say,

479
00:25:18.870 --> 00:25:23.790
EV = my planned value times
my percentage complete.

480
00:25:23.790 --> 00:25:26.680
Well, my planned value was $12,000,

481
00:25:26.680 --> 00:25:30.910
right, that's my overall project cost or
activity cost.

482
00:25:30.910 --> 00:25:33.150
And I'm gonna multiply
that by my work complete.

483
00:25:33.150 --> 00:25:38.380
My work complete well, I don't have it
as a percentage of completion, do I?

484
00:25:38.380 --> 00:25:41.382
I have it as a dollar value, as $8000.

485
00:25:41.382 --> 00:25:43.081
So what do I have to do?

486
00:25:43.081 --> 00:25:44.962
I've kind of gotta convert that.

487
00:25:44.962 --> 00:25:50.067
$8000 is a percentage of $12000,
it is 66%,

488
00:25:50.067 --> 00:25:56.170
so I'm going to just kind of put this,
actually 66.66 recurring,

489
00:25:56.170 --> 00:26:01.280
you know it's basically
two thirds of $12,000.

490
00:26:01.280 --> 00:26:03.650
So that's where I'm at right now, okay.

491
00:26:03.650 --> 00:26:05.700
That's my $8,000,
that's what I've paid out and

492
00:26:05.700 --> 00:26:09.330
in fact I really didn't even need to do
that because they're telling me here,

493
00:26:09.330 --> 00:26:12.040
July 4th indicates accounting
has paid out $8,000 to date.

494
00:26:12.040 --> 00:26:14.420
What is your earned value for July 4th?

495
00:26:14.420 --> 00:26:15.500
I've paid out $8,000.

496
00:26:15.500 --> 00:26:17.260
That is my earned value, right?

497
00:26:17.260 --> 00:26:22.630
And so if you take $12,000 and multiply
it by that 66.66%, you get $8,000.

498
00:26:22.630 --> 00:26:24.130
There's my earned value.

499
00:26:24.130 --> 00:26:25.720
I didn't even need a formula.

500
00:26:25.720 --> 00:26:30.250
They told me the earned value
as part of the question, right?

501
00:26:30.250 --> 00:26:34.370
But I had to know that that's what I was
looking at, that that's what I was seeing.

502
00:26:34.370 --> 00:26:37.660
Meanwhile, they gave me all the data for
plan value and so, a question like this

503
00:26:37.660 --> 00:26:41.270
would normally be followed with,
what's the current status of the project?

504
00:26:41.270 --> 00:26:42.350
Ahead?

505
00:26:42.350 --> 00:26:44.000
On plan?

506
00:26:44.000 --> 00:26:45.000
Behind?

507
00:26:45.000 --> 00:26:47.700
Or not enough information provided, right?

508
00:26:47.700 --> 00:26:50.700
And based on this, I do have enough
to figure out my plan value.

509
00:26:50.700 --> 00:26:53.710
My plan value,
if we just kinda update this,

510
00:26:53.710 --> 00:26:58.218
my plan value equals my budget at
completion, which is $12,000, right?

511
00:26:58.218 --> 00:27:03.760
Times and
then what my work completed should be.

512
00:27:03.760 --> 00:27:08.930
Well, on July 4th, that's the end of
the second day of a four day activity

513
00:27:08.930 --> 00:27:13.950
with evenly distributed costs,
I should be at 50%, right.

514
00:27:13.950 --> 00:27:15.820
And so if I multiply that out,

515
00:27:15.820 --> 00:27:21.660
that's going to be $6,000 right,
and if I take this one.

516
00:27:21.660 --> 00:27:23.620
Let me just make this kind of
look a little evenly here.

517
00:27:25.880 --> 00:27:26.386
There we go.

518
00:27:26.386 --> 00:27:32.220
So I've got $6,000 is my planned value and
$8,000 is my earned value.

519
00:27:32.220 --> 00:27:33.700
I've earned more than I've planned.

520
00:27:33.700 --> 00:27:37.660
And while that might sound like a good
thing like hey we're getting work done,

521
00:27:37.660 --> 00:27:39.490
it can be it could be a good thing.

522
00:27:39.490 --> 00:27:41.200
And it might not be.

523
00:27:41.200 --> 00:27:44.180
Maybe I had contractors
arranged to come out.

524
00:27:44.180 --> 00:27:45.590
Let's say it's construction, right?

525
00:27:45.590 --> 00:27:48.660
So they're putting up drywall, and
originally they planned to send me

526
00:27:48.660 --> 00:27:52.350
four contractors for
four days to put up the drywall.

527
00:27:52.350 --> 00:27:56.200
But at the last minute they said I
got two extra guys available, so

528
00:27:56.200 --> 00:27:59.440
how about I send you six guys and
they come and

529
00:27:59.440 --> 00:28:04.080
they work three days, and
then they're just done on day three.

530
00:28:04.080 --> 00:28:05.520
And so they do that.
They send me six guys.

531
00:28:05.520 --> 00:28:06.880
They come out and
they start doing the work.

532
00:28:06.880 --> 00:28:08.770
And so I get ahead, right.

533
00:28:08.770 --> 00:28:11.040
It's gonna cost me the same except for

534
00:28:11.040 --> 00:28:13.510
being spread over four days now
it's spread over three days.

535
00:28:13.510 --> 00:28:14.460
And that's good.

536
00:28:14.460 --> 00:28:18.150
So now I'm on track and
I'm ahead of schedule, right.

537
00:28:18.150 --> 00:28:21.830
And I'm gonna come out at the same
budget numbers, so I'm okay.

538
00:28:21.830 --> 00:28:23.859
But it could also be a problem.

539
00:28:23.859 --> 00:28:25.877
It could be hey I'm going
to send you four guys and

540
00:28:25.877 --> 00:28:27.759
remember how I said they were $15/hour?

541
00:28:27.759 --> 00:28:30.019
Now they're $17/hour, right?

542
00:28:30.019 --> 00:28:31.980
And now it changes so
I'm having to pay more and

543
00:28:31.980 --> 00:28:34.130
now I'm going to come in over budget.

544
00:28:34.130 --> 00:28:37.430
So what this tells me is not that
I necessarily have a problem, but

545
00:28:37.430 --> 00:28:39.670
I need to find out why
there's a discrepancy.

546
00:28:39.670 --> 00:28:40.600
I see that difference.

547
00:28:40.600 --> 00:28:42.340
I need to go and find out why, okay.

548
00:28:43.500 --> 00:28:48.530
If they had contacted me and said, hey we
can send you six guys instead of three.

549
00:28:48.530 --> 00:28:50.210
Sorry, what did I say earlier?

550
00:28:50.210 --> 00:28:51.610
Like four guys instead of three?

551
00:28:51.610 --> 00:28:52.490
>> Four.
>> So if they could send

552
00:28:52.490 --> 00:28:53.970
me four guys instead of three.

553
00:28:53.970 --> 00:28:54.770
Great.

554
00:28:54.770 --> 00:28:56.090
Let's do a change ticket.

555
00:28:56.090 --> 00:28:58.410
Let's put a change ticket in,
let's update our baseline,

556
00:28:58.410 --> 00:29:01.600
let's update our art project to reflect
this new change and put it in place.

557
00:29:01.600 --> 00:29:02.530
And now our plan value and

558
00:29:02.530 --> 00:29:06.450
our earn value will match because
our plan has been updated, right.

559
00:29:06.450 --> 00:29:08.740
When you're plan value and
and earn value are different,

560
00:29:08.740 --> 00:29:12.420
it means that something deviated
from the plan and that's never good.

561
00:29:12.420 --> 00:29:13.450
It's never good.

562
00:29:13.450 --> 00:29:17.160
I shouldn't say never, I guess there are
possibilities where there's risks that you

563
00:29:17.160 --> 00:29:22.950
didn't recognize that come through and you
are able to capitalize on those and make

564
00:29:22.950 --> 00:29:26.491
a gain, that does happen, but for the most
part, when those are different, it's bad.

565
00:29:26.491 --> 00:29:31.070
All right, so just be aware that when
they give you information on a question,

566
00:29:31.070 --> 00:29:33.160
there's more than one thing
they can be asking for.

567
00:29:33.160 --> 00:29:36.630
And potentially I could see this
same question more than once.

568
00:29:36.630 --> 00:29:39.740
One that asks me my earned value and
it's easy cuz they already told it to me.

569
00:29:39.740 --> 00:29:42.840
Or one that asks me for
the planned value on that day.

570
00:29:42.840 --> 00:29:46.840
Or one that asks me for the variance
between earned value and planned value.

571
00:29:46.840 --> 00:29:48.600
All of that could be built
off of this same question.

572
00:29:48.600 --> 00:29:50.910
I could see the same question four times.

573
00:29:50.910 --> 00:29:54.390
But then they ask me for a different
detail out of it each time, right?

574
00:29:54.390 --> 00:29:56.390
So lot of power can come from these.

575
00:29:56.390 --> 00:30:00.170
The trick is to just get used to that,
get used to the word problem format,

576
00:30:00.170 --> 00:30:03.690
read through them, practice,
make sure you know the formulas.

577
00:30:03.690 --> 00:30:07.340
Cuz as you read through you've gotta be
picking out the details that they give you

578
00:30:07.340 --> 00:30:10.400
and saying all right,
that's budget at completion.

579
00:30:10.400 --> 00:30:11.550
There's my planned value.

580
00:30:11.550 --> 00:30:12.790
There's my earned value.

581
00:30:12.790 --> 00:30:16.440
And that way when you get to the formula
part, you're just plugging in values and

582
00:30:16.440 --> 00:30:18.230
doing math.

583
00:30:18.230 --> 00:30:21.250
>> Don, thank you again for showing us
those demonstrations there on some of

584
00:30:21.250 --> 00:30:26.090
the different ways that we might actually
be tackling word problems on the PNP exam.

585
00:30:26.090 --> 00:30:28.960
Remember that what we focused
on here is the earned value.

586
00:30:28.960 --> 00:30:32.590
You can't really determine the earned
value without knowing that planned value

587
00:30:32.590 --> 00:30:35.730
as well so it's very essential that
we know how to calculate that so

588
00:30:35.730 --> 00:30:37.630
we can determine what
we're really asked here.

589
00:30:37.630 --> 00:30:41.890
And that last little bit of information,
about maybe possibly seeing that same

590
00:30:41.890 --> 00:30:45.700
question, but being asked about different
pieces of that information, that's

591
00:30:45.700 --> 00:30:49.670
something you've got to be thinking about
when you actually in your studies here.

592
00:30:49.670 --> 00:30:53.430
Focus in on actually determining all
those answers during your practice,

593
00:30:53.430 --> 00:30:55.290
that way when you're asked
about it on the exam,

594
00:30:55.290 --> 00:30:59.070
you know exactly what you're actually
asked about and what you actually need to

595
00:30:59.070 --> 00:31:02.890
determine from that without you having to
go, all right, that same question again.

596
00:31:02.890 --> 00:31:05.020
Let me re-determine every single one.

597
00:31:05.020 --> 00:31:09.260
Don, any last hints there
before we close out the show?

598
00:31:09.260 --> 00:31:10.850
>> Definitely don't stop here, right?

599
00:31:10.850 --> 00:31:12.610
So we got a chance to see earned value,
but

600
00:31:12.610 --> 00:31:15.750
you're normally gonna see it
in line with variance, right?

601
00:31:15.750 --> 00:31:17.110
I mentioned variance a few minutes ago.

602
00:31:17.110 --> 00:31:20.010
So we're gonna do some more shows where
we'll cover schedule variance and

603
00:31:20.010 --> 00:31:22.490
cost variance,
which are important to understand so

604
00:31:22.490 --> 00:31:25.060
you can start to measure that
difference from your plan.

605
00:31:25.060 --> 00:31:27.400
All that gets factored in together,
so those are kind of key.

606
00:31:27.400 --> 00:31:30.130
And then we're gonna do another
episode down a little bit further,

607
00:31:30.130 --> 00:31:34.300
we'll take a look at the cumulative values
because you'll need to be able to forecast

608
00:31:34.300 --> 00:31:38.430
out to the future, so we'll have to take a
look at things like estimated completion,

609
00:31:38.430 --> 00:31:40.640
and budgeted completion,
and all those other things.

610
00:31:40.640 --> 00:31:43.490
And start to figure out
where we're gonna end up

611
00:31:43.490 --> 00:31:46.620
when a project kinda hits a future stage.

612
00:31:46.620 --> 00:31:49.750
So what we looked at here was really
just looking at the present But

613
00:31:49.750 --> 00:31:52.730
be aware that were going to be looking
towards the future a little bit later

614
00:31:52.730 --> 00:31:54.485
on so we'll see that in the future.

615
00:31:54.485 --> 00:31:56.990
[LAUGH]
>> All right excellent advice for us and

616
00:31:56.990 --> 00:31:59.540
that a great place for
us to end this episode.

617
00:31:59.540 --> 00:32:02.190
Signing off for ITProTV, I’m Ronnie Wong.

618
00:32:02.190 --> 00:32:02.899
>> And I’m Don Pezet.

619
00:32:02.899 --> 00:32:05.308
>> And we'll see you next time.

620
00:32:05.308 --> 00:32:12.970
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss how to determine Schedule Performance.  The Schedule Performance helps us to determine whether we are ahead of schedule based on time, deliverables or even cost.  The determination of the SPI tells us how much we can be ahead or behind schedule and  provide an indicator of where Project Mangers may need to act to bring a project back on schedule, according to the guys.  They show some of the most common types of questions likely encountered by a PMP candidate.
episodes.title: Schedule Performance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.566 --> 00:00:15.431
Welcome to another great
episode here on ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:15.431 --> 00:00:18.903
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and
today we're taking a look at PMP,

4
00:00:18.903 --> 00:00:21.150
Project Management Professional.

5
00:00:21.150 --> 00:00:24.600
We're actually gonna a little bit of
time going into some different formulas.

6
00:00:24.600 --> 00:00:27.885
Today, we're gonna be hitting
the idea of schedule performance, and

7
00:00:27.885 --> 00:00:30.760
showing how we can also discover
the idea of variance too.

8
00:00:30.760 --> 00:00:32.940
And who'd better to help us then,
well, Mr. Don Pezet himself.

9
00:00:32.940 --> 00:00:33.820
How's it going, Don?

10
00:00:33.820 --> 00:00:34.890
>> It is going great, Ronnie.

11
00:00:34.890 --> 00:00:39.070
Ready to jump into the world of
variance and just as a refresher.

12
00:00:39.070 --> 00:00:42.588
When we setup our schedule we do
our whole project plan, right.

13
00:00:42.588 --> 00:00:46.193
All in the planning phase you're
coming up with how things should be.

14
00:00:46.193 --> 00:00:49.840
And then when the project actually starts
rolling into execution we're monitoring.

15
00:00:49.840 --> 00:00:52.330
And we're gathering data back
on where things are going.

16
00:00:52.330 --> 00:00:55.120
And what you're gonna notice is that what
happens in the real world is a little

17
00:00:55.120 --> 00:00:56.340
different than your plan.

18
00:00:56.340 --> 00:00:57.410
Well, hopefully, it isn't.

19
00:00:57.410 --> 00:00:59.410
Hopefully they're identical and
things are great.

20
00:00:59.410 --> 00:01:02.760
But, sometimes you get ahead of schedule,
sometimes you get behind schedules.

21
00:01:02.760 --> 00:01:04.730
Sometimes you get over or under budget.

22
00:01:04.730 --> 00:01:05.980
These things happen.

23
00:01:05.980 --> 00:01:09.950
And our main goal is to track those and
make sure they stay in control,

24
00:01:09.950 --> 00:01:11.340
they don't go too far.

25
00:01:11.340 --> 00:01:15.310
But the further away you get from
the plan, that's called variance, right.

26
00:01:15.310 --> 00:01:17.328
We're deviating from what we planned.

27
00:01:17.328 --> 00:01:18.698
And we need to be able to measure that.

28
00:01:18.698 --> 00:01:21.431
And we need to do it repeatedly
throughout our project,

29
00:01:21.431 --> 00:01:22.953
that way we can create trends.

30
00:01:22.953 --> 00:01:25.250
So we can see if things are getting
worse and worse, and worse.

31
00:01:25.250 --> 00:01:27.940
If if they're getting better,
we need to have an understanding of that.

32
00:01:27.940 --> 00:01:30.840
So calculating variance
is really important.

33
00:01:30.840 --> 00:01:33.330
And in a project you're gonna
be doing this all the time.

34
00:01:33.330 --> 00:01:36.050
Now you probably have project
management software doing it for you.

35
00:01:36.050 --> 00:01:38.210
But if you don't,
well you can do it by hand.

36
00:01:38.210 --> 00:01:40.310
On the exam you have to do it by hand.

37
00:01:40.310 --> 00:01:43.160
So that's why it's important for
us to look at that, see how it works and

38
00:01:43.160 --> 00:01:44.220
make sure we've a good grasp on it.

39
00:01:44.220 --> 00:01:47.260
And that's what we are going to do
right here is look at calculating out

40
00:01:47.260 --> 00:01:48.050
schedule variance.

41
00:01:49.120 --> 00:01:50.430
All right, well let's kick things off.

42
00:01:50.430 --> 00:01:53.520
I got a fancy little picture here just to
kinda make sure we have a good handle on

43
00:01:53.520 --> 00:01:54.850
what variance is.

44
00:01:54.850 --> 00:01:58.280
Remember that we have a plan,
which in my case, is this blue line.

45
00:01:58.280 --> 00:02:00.610
And then we have what's
actually happening.

46
00:02:00.610 --> 00:02:02.050
And I've got this red line.

47
00:02:02.050 --> 00:02:06.410
But if I'm measuring my schedule
variance at every point on this graph,

48
00:02:06.410 --> 00:02:10.110
I can see that I'm right in line here,
right in line, right in line.

49
00:02:10.110 --> 00:02:13.000
And once I get to this measuring instance,

50
00:02:13.000 --> 00:02:15.620
right here I start to
see a little deviation.

51
00:02:15.620 --> 00:02:18.290
But it's small enough that I probably
don't think about it, right?

52
00:02:18.290 --> 00:02:21.280
I'm like, it's a little bit off,
but not a big deal.

53
00:02:21.280 --> 00:02:24.560
But by the time I get to
the next measuring point here,

54
00:02:24.560 --> 00:02:26.480
now that variance is starting to grow.

55
00:02:26.480 --> 00:02:29.440
And by the time I get to the next
one it's getting really big.

56
00:02:29.440 --> 00:02:33.650
I'm really getting a significantly
larger gap in between these lines, And

57
00:02:33.650 --> 00:02:35.200
that's my warning sign.

58
00:02:35.200 --> 00:02:38.320
That means I need to take action.

59
00:02:38.320 --> 00:02:41.470
I had a warning back here, but
I didn't know if it was a fluke, if

60
00:02:41.470 --> 00:02:45.160
things were just gonna curve back again,
or if it was gonna continue to get worse.

61
00:02:45.160 --> 00:02:47.980
And if it continues to get worse,
we need to correct it.

62
00:02:47.980 --> 00:02:51.160
We correct it, we bring things back
in line, and we get ourselves back.

63
00:02:51.160 --> 00:02:52.840
Now, I'm showing the red line going up.

64
00:02:52.840 --> 00:02:54.050
The red can be going down.

65
00:02:54.050 --> 00:02:55.280
It can be doing an S curve.

66
00:02:55.280 --> 00:02:57.900
You could be all over the place
with these things, right?

67
00:02:57.900 --> 00:03:00.710
That happens just as
often as anything else.

68
00:03:00.710 --> 00:03:04.780
For example, I might have something
a little more skewed like this.

69
00:03:04.780 --> 00:03:08.050
Especially if we made project corrections,
right.

70
00:03:08.050 --> 00:03:12.800
I could have it where maybe in
the beginning I got off to a slow start.

71
00:03:12.800 --> 00:03:14.560
And so
I started making some phone calls, and

72
00:03:14.560 --> 00:03:16.540
saying what the heck is
going on down there.

73
00:03:16.540 --> 00:03:19.614
And notice how the variation
kinda stabilizes right here.

74
00:03:19.614 --> 00:03:22.450
It doesn't get any worse, but
it doesn't get any better.

75
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:24.040
We've identified the problem.

76
00:03:24.040 --> 00:03:28.390
We've stopped it and now we start
correcting it and we get back in line.

77
00:03:28.390 --> 00:03:29.990
But maybe we over correct.

78
00:03:29.990 --> 00:03:32.600
I used some of my reserves to
bring in some extra staff and

79
00:03:32.600 --> 00:03:35.320
I still have that extra
staff hanging about.

80
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:38.470
And now I'm starting to go the opposite
way, where I'm going over budget,

81
00:03:38.470 --> 00:03:41.740
or something of that nature, and
I've gotta bring that back in line.

82
00:03:41.740 --> 00:03:44.010
And so
you may see your variance go like this,

83
00:03:44.010 --> 00:03:47.040
where it's constantly getting bigger and
smaller over time.

84
00:03:47.040 --> 00:03:48.750
That's just how projects go.

85
00:03:48.750 --> 00:03:51.840
But the point is,
by the end of the project,

86
00:03:51.840 --> 00:03:54.190
we need to be as close to
that point as possible.

87
00:03:54.190 --> 00:03:56.870
That we have everything right
where it's supposed to be.

88
00:03:56.870 --> 00:04:00.430
So in order to do that we need
to be taking measurements

89
00:04:00.430 --> 00:04:04.858
on a regular basis to make sure we
can spot when this is happening.

90
00:04:04.858 --> 00:04:09.700
All right, now in another episode we
talked about planned value and earned

91
00:04:09.700 --> 00:04:13.780
value and how those work for calculating
kind of where we're at right now.

92
00:04:13.780 --> 00:04:16.860
Those are still important
concepts here in scheduling

93
00:04:16.860 --> 00:04:20.830
because when we talk about schedule
variance what's the formula?

94
00:04:20.830 --> 00:04:24.140
Well, the formula for schedule
variance is one of the easier ones.

95
00:04:24.140 --> 00:04:27.380
Schedule variance equals earned
value minus planned value.

96
00:04:27.380 --> 00:04:29.010
And so what does that mean?

97
00:04:29.010 --> 00:04:32.023
It means I need to know my earned value
and I need to know my planned values.

98
00:04:32.023 --> 00:04:37.480
And if I don't know those values, then I
can't figure out my schedule variance.

99
00:04:37.480 --> 00:04:42.000
So when you're on the exam, and you get
to a question and it's asking about

100
00:04:42.000 --> 00:04:45.440
schedule variance, you actually
could have a really hard question.

101
00:04:45.440 --> 00:04:47.940
You could have one that's gonna
require a lot of work, all right.

102
00:04:47.940 --> 00:04:50.050
But, let's just kind of focus in
on the individual pieces here.

103
00:04:50.050 --> 00:04:55.240
So, schedule variance, how far am I
deviating from my current schedule?

104
00:04:55.240 --> 00:04:59.150
And the result of this formula
is gonna be one of three things.

105
00:04:59.150 --> 00:05:04.332
It's gonna either be a positive number,
a negative number, or a zero.

106
00:05:04.332 --> 00:05:08.880
All right, if its a positive number,
than we're ahead of schedule.

107
00:05:08.880 --> 00:05:12.110
More work has gotten done than what
we anticipated, that may be good or

108
00:05:12.110 --> 00:05:13.330
bad, right.

109
00:05:13.330 --> 00:05:16.690
If its a zero we're right on schedule,
things are perfect.

110
00:05:16.690 --> 00:05:17.700
And if its less than zero,

111
00:05:17.700 --> 00:05:21.770
if its a negative number than we're behind
schedule, now we've got a problem, okay.

112
00:05:21.770 --> 00:05:24.950
So those are the three possible
outcomes of this formula.

113
00:05:24.950 --> 00:05:28.250
But all three of them require us to know
our earned value and our planned value.

114
00:05:28.250 --> 00:05:30.470
Cuz that's really what we're
comparing at the end of the day,

115
00:05:30.470 --> 00:05:32.360
is the variance between those two.

116
00:05:33.750 --> 00:05:36.550
So when we look at this formula,
I know I need that information.

117
00:05:36.550 --> 00:05:39.110
Let's take a look at an example
question and see how that pans out.

118
00:05:39.110 --> 00:05:43.030
All right, this is is one of the most
straight forward types of questions you'll

119
00:05:43.030 --> 00:05:46.830
get on the exam because they feed
us exactly the data we need.

120
00:05:46.830 --> 00:05:52.550
It says we've received a status report for
activity 7.9, it's dated July 23rd.

121
00:05:52.550 --> 00:05:55.999
The report indicates
an earned value of $3,000.

122
00:05:55.999 --> 00:06:01.860
According to the project plan,
the value should be $3,500.

123
00:06:01.860 --> 00:06:02.840
What is your schedule variance?

124
00:06:03.840 --> 00:06:06.850
This question is straightforward because
they give me my planned value and

125
00:06:06.850 --> 00:06:10.820
they give me my earned value, and all I
have to do is run it through a formula.

126
00:06:10.820 --> 00:06:14.810
All I have to do is take my earned
value and subtract my planned value.

127
00:06:14.810 --> 00:06:17.840
Now if those two are equal,
I'll get a zero, right?

128
00:06:17.840 --> 00:06:21.970
Because a number minus the same number
is always zero and I have no variance,

129
00:06:21.970 --> 00:06:23.910
I'm right on schedule.

130
00:06:23.910 --> 00:06:26.880
If the numbers are different though,
that's where things start to get a little

131
00:06:26.880 --> 00:06:31.020
screwy, and I have to be really
careful because I could mix this up.

132
00:06:31.020 --> 00:06:35.090
If I do planned value minus earned
value instead, where I normally might

133
00:06:35.090 --> 00:06:39.280
normally get a negative number I might
now get a positive number or vice versa.

134
00:06:39.280 --> 00:06:41.490
And so
instead of thinking I'm behind schedule,

135
00:06:41.490 --> 00:06:43.180
I actually think I'm ahead of schedule.

136
00:06:43.180 --> 00:06:47.440
So when you memorize the formula
the order is really important.

137
00:06:47.440 --> 00:06:53.470
So when I fill this out I need to say that
my schedule variance is my earned value.

138
00:06:53.470 --> 00:06:57.219
So we've earned $3,000.

139
00:06:57.219 --> 00:07:01.402
That's how much we've kind of paid out so
far, and

140
00:07:01.402 --> 00:07:05.894
I need to subtract my plan and
my plan is $3,500.

141
00:07:05.894 --> 00:07:13.391
All right, and if I work that out,
I end up with a ($500), right.

142
00:07:13.391 --> 00:07:18.010
And if you deal with accountants,
they'll write it like that.

143
00:07:18.010 --> 00:07:21.020
Right, see in parenthesis,
you might just say negative $500.

144
00:07:21.020 --> 00:07:24.650
If i had gotten these backwards, if I had
said planned value minus earned value.

145
00:07:24.650 --> 00:07:27.210
I would have ended up with
a positive $500 right?

146
00:07:27.210 --> 00:07:29.220
A positive $500 means that I'm ahead.

147
00:07:29.220 --> 00:07:31.980
I've done more work than I
thought I would at this point.

148
00:07:31.980 --> 00:07:33.690
A negative number means I'm behind.

149
00:07:33.690 --> 00:07:34.940
I've done less work.

150
00:07:34.940 --> 00:07:36.262
They are both a problem, right.

151
00:07:36.262 --> 00:07:38.450
Never assume that being
ahead good is a good thing.

152
00:07:38.450 --> 00:07:40.760
There is a reason why you are ahead.

153
00:07:40.760 --> 00:07:43.740
And it's something you didn't plan for,
and that's bad, right?

154
00:07:43.740 --> 00:07:46.460
If it's something you planned for, you
would've already done a change ticket and

155
00:07:46.460 --> 00:07:49.300
already updated your numbers and
your variance would be zero, right?

156
00:07:49.300 --> 00:07:51.359
So any time you see variance,
it's not a good thing.

157
00:07:51.359 --> 00:07:56.031
It's something that you need to find out
the root cause of and either stop or

158
00:07:56.031 --> 00:07:57.079
capitalize on.

159
00:07:57.079 --> 00:08:00.962
Right, you know with risks you can always
jump in and really take advantage or

160
00:08:00.962 --> 00:08:04.844
exploit the risk to make it even better,
and it gets just better and better and

161
00:08:04.844 --> 00:08:07.440
better, but
either way you need to be aware.

162
00:08:07.440 --> 00:08:10.240
So here I see a negative $500 though and
that means hey,

163
00:08:10.240 --> 00:08:14.900
I should have gotten $500 more
worth of work done by this point.

164
00:08:14.900 --> 00:08:17.140
Why not, why hasn't that happened?

165
00:08:17.140 --> 00:08:18.760
And I can go in the field and find out.

166
00:08:18.760 --> 00:08:22.700
Maybe I was supposed to have ten
contractors on the job site and

167
00:08:22.700 --> 00:08:24.180
one called in sick and I only had nine.

168
00:08:24.180 --> 00:08:28.360
And since only nine were there,
I didn't have to pay for the tenth one.

169
00:08:28.360 --> 00:08:31.890
But less work got done cuz there were
only nine instead of ten, right?

170
00:08:31.890 --> 00:08:34.090
That's a problem,
now we gotta make that up.

171
00:08:34.090 --> 00:08:37.440
So maybe the next day instead of 10,
I need 11 people to make up for the 1

172
00:08:37.440 --> 00:08:40.840
I was short yesterday, to even things up,
I need to be aware of that, right.

173
00:08:40.840 --> 00:08:44.130
But calculating that various,
really easy here, okay.

174
00:08:45.220 --> 00:08:50.150
However on the exam you might
get one question like this but

175
00:08:50.150 --> 00:08:51.980
normally it's going to be
a little harder then that, right.

176
00:08:51.980 --> 00:08:54.020
Scheduled variance is kind
of an easy to calculate so

177
00:08:54.020 --> 00:08:56.110
they normally like to throw
a little wrench in there.

178
00:08:56.110 --> 00:08:59.905
Here they very specifically gave me my
earned value and my plan value right.

179
00:08:59.905 --> 00:09:03.062
So I've got to, they didn't call it plan
value here but I know that's what is

180
00:09:03.062 --> 00:09:06.240
because they tell me according to
the project plan blah, blah, blah right.

181
00:09:06.240 --> 00:09:12.882
So I know that's my plan value, but
if they had put the question like this.

182
00:09:12.882 --> 00:09:19.710
Work breakdown structure task 3.1.1 has
spent for $4,000 and is 25% complete.

183
00:09:19.710 --> 00:09:22.560
The project plan shows that
$4,000 is correct, but

184
00:09:22.560 --> 00:09:27.390
the task should be 50% complete,
what is the schedule variance?

185
00:09:27.390 --> 00:09:32.410
Okay, well, what is my earned value and
what is my planned value?

186
00:09:33.810 --> 00:09:37.440
We actually don't know,
they give us how much has been spent and

187
00:09:37.440 --> 00:09:39.010
how much is complete.

188
00:09:39.010 --> 00:09:41.730
They haven't actually
factored those together yet.

189
00:09:41.730 --> 00:09:48.300
Remember that earned value is your
planned value times the work complete.

190
00:09:48.300 --> 00:09:52.680
And so, I've got my plan value up here,
$4,000, and my work completed 50%.

191
00:09:52.680 --> 00:09:55.030
But I have to factor that in, all right?

192
00:09:55.030 --> 00:09:57.850
And I know that my plan value
is my budget at completion,

193
