00:09:57.850 --> 00:10:00.110
which I actually don't know.

194
00:10:00.110 --> 00:10:02.930
We'll have to extrapolate that ourselves,
and then my,

195
00:10:02.930 --> 00:10:07.400
multiply that by the, what I expect of
the work should be complete at that point.

196
00:10:07.400 --> 00:10:10.790
So looking at this,
I have a little bit more math to do.

197
00:10:10.790 --> 00:10:14.170
I'm gonna have to calculate earned value,
and I'm gonna have to calculate

198
00:10:14.170 --> 00:10:18.870
planned value, and then I can measure
the difference to get my schedule value.

199
00:10:18.870 --> 00:10:20.614
So we end up with something
a little more complex.

200
00:10:20.614 --> 00:10:23.415
Here my schedule value is going to equal,
or

201
00:10:23.415 --> 00:10:28.410
my schedule variance is going to equal
I need my earned value first, right?

202
00:10:28.410 --> 00:10:35.180
An earned value is my planned
value times my %complete, right?

203
00:10:35.180 --> 00:10:40.193
And then I need to
subtract my planned value.

204
00:10:40.193 --> 00:10:45.096
And my planned value is my budget
at completion times %complete,

205
00:10:45.096 --> 00:10:51.046
which you know would really be 100% if
it were the end, but in this case we're

206
00:10:51.046 --> 00:10:56.780
doing at this particular point in time so
we'll use that information.

207
00:10:56.780 --> 00:11:02.490
So now this formula becomes a lot
more complex, in fact let me just,

208
00:11:02.490 --> 00:11:06.450
complex enough that I've gotta
shrink my font so this will all fit.

209
00:11:06.450 --> 00:11:08.260
There we go, okay, so

210
00:11:08.260 --> 00:11:12.200
now, what was a simple formula
becomes a little more complex.

211
00:11:12.200 --> 00:11:15.640
But it's still not that bad because
they did give me the information I need.

212
00:11:15.640 --> 00:11:18.960
So SV equals my plan value,

213
00:11:18.960 --> 00:11:24.500
which is $4,000 * and here I'm talking

214
00:11:24.500 --> 00:11:29.640
about my earned value, so it's what
I've actually done, which is only 25%.

215
00:11:29.640 --> 00:11:34.610
And then I need to subtract
from that my planned value,

216
00:11:34.610 --> 00:11:38.294
or budgeted completion,
which at this particular stage is $4000.

217
00:11:40.600 --> 00:11:44.345
I don't actually know what the budget is
for the full task, but I'm wanting to

218
00:11:44.345 --> 00:11:48.261
calculate at this point in time so I can
use this number that they've provided me,

219
00:11:48.261 --> 00:11:50.281
$4000 and multiply that by 50%.

220
00:11:50.281 --> 00:11:55.029
We're supposed to be 50% done,
okay, and now when we take that and

221
00:11:55.029 --> 00:11:58.906
run it, actually need a little
more room in this square.

222
00:11:58.906 --> 00:12:01.902
There we go, now we run all that,

223
00:12:01.902 --> 00:12:07.366
we get SV = 4,000 x 25%
is a whopping $1,000.

224
00:12:07.366 --> 00:12:12.635
And we're gonna subtract 4,000 x 50%,

225
00:12:12.635 --> 00:12:20.090
which is a whopping $ 2,000
which equals a loss of $1000,

226
00:12:20.090 --> 00:12:25.885
so our variance right
here ends up being $1000.

227
00:12:25.885 --> 00:12:29.050
So I had to do a little
extra work on this one.

228
00:12:29.050 --> 00:12:32.920
I had to calculate my earned value,
I had to calculate my planned value, and

229
00:12:32.920 --> 00:12:38.100
then I had to subtract those out to find
that variation, and then I got it, right?

230
00:12:38.100 --> 00:12:40.040
It wasn't that hard but

231
00:12:40.040 --> 00:12:43.570
I actually needed to know three
formulas to solve one problem.

232
00:12:43.570 --> 00:12:47.090
I had to know the earn value formula,
the plan value formula, and

233
00:12:47.090 --> 00:12:51.340
the schedule variance formula and
then applied each one to get the data.

234
00:12:51.340 --> 00:12:53.565
That is not uncommon on the exam,

235
00:12:53.565 --> 00:12:57.340
[LAUGH] you will see that happen where
you got to use all of your formulas.

236
00:12:57.340 --> 00:13:00.220
And so to help with this, this is one of
the little pieces of advice that I always

237
00:13:00.220 --> 00:13:05.190
give people is when you go in to take
the exam, right at the very beginning of

238
00:13:05.190 --> 00:13:09.440
the exam you sit down, the exam starts,
and you have got this scratch paper.

239
00:13:09.440 --> 00:13:14.190
Pieces of notebook paper that are blank,
well, if you've got formulas memorized,

240
00:13:14.190 --> 00:13:16.210
just write them down real quick,
it only takes a second.

241
00:13:16.210 --> 00:13:18.060
It doesn't take long to
write the formulas down.

242
00:13:18.060 --> 00:13:19.620
And that way when you get
to questions like these,

243
00:13:19.620 --> 00:13:21.920
you're not racking your brain trying to
come with them, you just look over and

244
00:13:21.920 --> 00:13:25.140
see the formulas and you just run
through them, and it's no big deal.

245
00:13:25.140 --> 00:13:29.550
And I assembled this to write it out
like this, but I didn't have to do that,

246
00:13:29.550 --> 00:13:31.180
you can do a lot of this in your head.

247
00:13:31.180 --> 00:13:34.440
The exam, will typically use numbers
that are easy to do in your head,

248
00:13:34.440 --> 00:13:36.400
because they don't give you a calculator,
right?

249
00:13:36.400 --> 00:13:41.382
So, when you talk about 25% of $4000 or
50% of $4000,

250
00:13:41.382 --> 00:13:46.961
that's easy stuff to do,
it's not like, I need 17% of $273,412.

251
00:13:46.961 --> 00:13:47.661
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right?

252
00:13:47.661 --> 00:13:49.803
Which would take forever, so,
it's not normally crazy like that.

253
00:13:49.803 --> 00:13:52.330
But, the end result,
is I now have my variance, and

254
00:13:52.330 --> 00:13:55.320
I can go find the answer on
the exam that matches that.

255
00:13:55.320 --> 00:13:56.140
And I'm in business, and

256
00:13:56.140 --> 00:13:58.820
if I don't find an answer that matches
that then I probably have a formula wrong

257
00:13:58.820 --> 00:14:00.160
and then you go back and revisit that.

258
00:14:00.160 --> 00:14:02.840
So, but that's how we can
get that schedule variant.

259
00:14:02.840 --> 00:14:06.957
Just know that even though it's
an easy formula, SV = EV- PV,

260
00:14:06.957 --> 00:14:11.550
that it can be made more complex if we
have to calculate out our earn value and

261
00:14:11.550 --> 00:14:16.447
our plan value, to find out what to
feed into the schedule variants formula.

262
00:14:17.780 --> 00:14:20.741
All right, now, in real life land,
in real life land,

263
00:14:20.741 --> 00:14:23.990
schedule variance is not
a very useful number, right?

264
00:14:23.990 --> 00:14:27.890
If your CEO comes to you and says, hey,
what's the status on your project,

265
00:14:27.890 --> 00:14:28.710
how's it going so far?

266
00:14:28.710 --> 00:14:32.560
And you say well, we're plus $1,000, or

267
00:14:32.560 --> 00:14:35.830
we're negative $1,000,
what does that really mean to them?

268
00:14:35.830 --> 00:14:39.620
Okay, well it can sound good or bad, it
depends on the size of the project and so

269
00:14:39.620 --> 00:14:43.940
on, but project numbers like these
can easily get skewed because

270
00:14:43.940 --> 00:14:47.280
it's not necessarily meaningful
beyond project managers.

271
00:14:47.280 --> 00:14:51.700
And so typically when we go to represent
these numbers to other people we don't use

272
00:14:51.700 --> 00:14:56.760
schedule variance like this, instead
we use our performance indexes, right.

273
00:14:56.760 --> 00:14:59.864
You've got SPI and CPI,
your Schedule Performance Index and

274
00:14:59.864 --> 00:15:01.422
your Cost Performance Index.

275
00:15:01.422 --> 00:15:05.780
And we're just talking about schedule in
this episode so I'm gonna talk about SPI.

276
00:15:05.780 --> 00:15:09.244
Schedule Performance Index
is really the same

277
00:15:09.244 --> 00:15:14.051
basic process except instead
of SV=EV-PV it's SV=EV/PV.

278
00:15:14.051 --> 00:15:14.691
Okay?

279
00:15:14.691 --> 00:15:17.412
And the reason it does that,
actually do I have a slide for that?

280
00:15:17.412 --> 00:15:18.132
I do.

281
00:15:18.132 --> 00:15:20.200
Here I'm talking about it,
I've got a slide for it.

282
00:15:20.200 --> 00:15:25.890
So the reason it does this is that SPI is

283
00:15:25.890 --> 00:15:30.830
far better for giving people
numbers that are meaningful and

284
00:15:30.830 --> 00:15:34.710
making it where you can compare
projects together, okay?

285
00:15:34.710 --> 00:15:39.610
So SPI=EV/PV, if I'm on schedule,

286
00:15:39.610 --> 00:15:44.500
if everything's going great,
my Ev and my PV should be equal.

287
00:15:44.500 --> 00:15:49.132
And a number divided by itself is 1,
so if I get an SPI of 1,

288
00:15:49.132 --> 00:15:53.419
that means I'm on schedule,
things are going great.

289
00:15:53.419 --> 00:15:56.569
If I get a number that's less
than 1 I'm behind schedule,

290
00:15:56.569 --> 00:16:00.168
if it's a number that's greater than 1,
I'm ahead of schedule.

291
00:16:00.168 --> 00:16:02.779
And the number really works
out to be a percentage.

292
00:16:02.779 --> 00:16:09.670
And so if I get 1.2 as my result,
then I'm 20% ahead of schedule.

293
00:16:09.670 --> 00:16:15.710
If I get .8 as my result,
then I'm behind 20% on my schedule, right?

294
00:16:15.710 --> 00:16:18.930
So 1, that is on schedule,
that's your baseline.

295
00:16:18.930 --> 00:16:23.220
And then anything above or below is that
percentage that you are ahead or behind.

296
00:16:23.220 --> 00:16:26.630
And that's really handy especially
if you are like, a PMO.

297
00:16:26.630 --> 00:16:29.680
If you are a project management office and
you are measuring the performance of

298
00:16:29.680 --> 00:16:33.080
multiple projects on your portfolio,
right?

299
00:16:33.080 --> 00:16:36.091
You might have a multi-million
dollar project and

300
00:16:36.091 --> 00:16:38.620
you might have a $25,000 project.

301
00:16:39.970 --> 00:16:43.310
And when you start looking at the schedule
variance, the multi-million dollar project

302
00:16:43.310 --> 00:16:47.740
is always gonna look worse because
the number is so much bigger, right?

303
00:16:47.740 --> 00:16:52.740
But when you turn them into percentages
like this, now it's more in line, now we

304
00:16:52.740 --> 00:16:56.430
can compare them more accurately and
understand what we're dealing with, right?

305
00:16:56.430 --> 00:16:58.100
So let me show you an example of that,

306
00:16:58.100 --> 00:17:00.770
I've got a couple of
different examples actually.

307
00:17:00.770 --> 00:17:02.760
SPI here, just your base SPI,

308
00:17:02.760 --> 00:17:07.230
so they might throw on the exam a question
that just gives you the data you need,

309
00:17:07.230 --> 00:17:10.180
you factor it into the formula,
we kinda saw that earlier in the show.

310
00:17:10.180 --> 00:17:12.970
So here they tell us,
you have received a status report for

311
00:17:12.970 --> 00:17:15.440
activity 7.9 dated July 23rd.

312
00:17:16.470 --> 00:17:19.330
So the status report is dated July 23rd.

313
00:17:19.330 --> 00:17:21.790
The report indicates
an earned value of $3,000.

314
00:17:21.790 --> 00:17:26.328
According to the project plan,
the value should be $3,500.

315
00:17:26.328 --> 00:17:27.849
What is your SPI?

316
00:17:27.849 --> 00:17:32.751
All right, we saw this same question
earlier, except instead of asking for

317
00:17:32.751 --> 00:17:35.899
SPI, it was asking for
schedule variance, SV.

318
00:17:35.899 --> 00:17:39.657
So same thing here, except instead of
asking for SV, they're asking for SPI,

319
00:17:39.657 --> 00:17:42.480
and all we have to do is
use the alternate formula.

320
00:17:42.480 --> 00:17:45.880
Instead of EV- PV, we use EV/PV.

321
00:17:45.880 --> 00:17:50.530
So for this one,
we say our SPI equals, and

322
00:17:50.530 --> 00:17:54.564
it's going to be our earned value,
$3,000, and

323
00:17:54.564 --> 00:17:58.935
that's gonna be divided by $3,500.

324
00:17:58.935 --> 00:18:03.438
And then we need to figure
out what that is and

325
00:18:03.438 --> 00:18:08.304
in my head I don't know,
but if we fire up a quick

326
00:18:08.304 --> 00:18:14.030
calculator we can say
3,000 divided by 3,500

327
00:18:14.030 --> 00:18:19.660
Is 0.8571 so I'm gonna round that to 0.86.

328
00:18:19.660 --> 00:18:22.625
Okay, 0.86 that's my SPI.

329
00:18:22.625 --> 00:18:27.660
Alright, and remember what we said,
if it's a negative, not a negative, sorry,

330
00:18:27.660 --> 00:18:32.980
if it's below one, then we're behind,
and if it's above one, then we're ahead.

331
00:18:32.980 --> 00:18:35.503
And in this case I've got 0.86.

332
00:18:35.503 --> 00:18:36.820
I've got an earned value of $3,000.

333
00:18:36.820 --> 00:18:39.317
I was supposed to have earned $3,500.

334
00:18:39.317 --> 00:18:43.180
I already knew I was behind,
I just didn't know how bad.

335
00:18:43.180 --> 00:18:45.010
Let's put it into perspective.

336
00:18:45.010 --> 00:18:48.480
And if you tell me I'm $500 behind that
doesn't necessarily mean anything.

337
00:18:48.480 --> 00:18:55.540
But I can look at this and I can see
that 1 minus 0.86 would be .14, or 14%.

338
00:18:55.540 --> 00:18:57.305
I'm 14% behind.

339
00:18:57.305 --> 00:18:58.530
Okay now, how bad is that?

340
00:18:58.530 --> 00:18:59.390
Is that really bad?

341
00:18:59.390 --> 00:19:00.800
Not really, no.

342
00:19:00.800 --> 00:19:02.010
I'm just 14% behind.

343
00:19:02.010 --> 00:19:04.910
I can probably make that up, I probably
have resources I can apply to really get

344
00:19:04.910 --> 00:19:08.900
that corrected versus if I was 70% behind.

345
00:19:08.900 --> 00:19:10.245
That's pretty bad, that's pretty bad, and

346
00:19:10.245 --> 00:19:11.742
we're definitely going to
need to deal with that.

347
00:19:11.742 --> 00:19:16.371
This takes the size of the project out
of the mix and that's really handy,

348
00:19:16.371 --> 00:19:18.180
not in a one-off like this.

349
00:19:18.180 --> 00:19:20.830
And this might be useful for talking
to a CEO and communicating with people,

350
00:19:20.830 --> 00:19:25.920
right, but when we're comparing more
than one project to each other and

351
00:19:25.920 --> 00:19:30.320
the budgets vary widely,
this becomes really, really, handy, right?

352
00:19:30.320 --> 00:19:32.440
And that's my next example,
let me show you guys this one.

353
00:19:33.710 --> 00:19:35.600
So let's say that you work for
a PMO, right?

354
00:19:35.600 --> 00:19:39.050
So you work in a project
management office, and

355
00:19:39.050 --> 00:19:40.940
you're looking at your project portfolio.

356
00:19:40.940 --> 00:19:41.930
And so here it says,

357
00:19:41.930 --> 00:19:46.130
you've been brought in to salvage
four projects at risk of failure.

358
00:19:46.130 --> 00:19:47.640
So there are four projects
going on in this company,

359
00:19:47.640 --> 00:19:49.710
they're all at risk of failure.

360
00:19:49.710 --> 00:19:54.360
Which of the four projects is in
the most need of attention, right?

361
00:19:54.360 --> 00:19:58.150
So, which one is your highest risk,
basically.

362
00:19:58.150 --> 00:20:01.340
They're all at risk, they're all behind,
which one is the worst?

363
00:20:01.340 --> 00:20:04.350
Well, when we look at this,
it can be hard to tell.

364
00:20:04.350 --> 00:20:09.030
If I just look at variance, right,
so here's project 1, 2, 3, and 4,

365
00:20:09.030 --> 00:20:12.210
project one has a planned
value of $80,000.

366
00:20:12.210 --> 00:20:16.910
Project 2, 25,500, project 3, 25,000,
and project 4, 1.4 million, alright?

367
00:20:18.710 --> 00:20:22.850
Projects 2 and
3 are very close in budget, right?

368
00:20:22.850 --> 00:20:27.551
So they very closely match each other,
one's 25,000, one's 25,500.

369
00:20:27.551 --> 00:20:31.720
And when I look at those earned values,
I see a huge difference there.

370
00:20:31.720 --> 00:20:34.660
And so if you give me the earned value,
and one of them is $500 and

371
00:20:34.660 --> 00:20:39.418
the other one is $17,000, it's pretty
obvious which one's at greater risk.

372
00:20:39.418 --> 00:20:43.410
Okay, project 3 is at a greater
risk than project two because

373
00:20:43.410 --> 00:20:44.540
they have similar budgets.

374
00:20:45.760 --> 00:20:51.528
But when you skew the budgets,
right, when I look at project 3 and

375
00:20:51.528 --> 00:20:57.010
project 4,
project 3 has a $17,000 variance.

376
00:20:57.010 --> 00:21:04.540
Project 4 is a $200,000 variance, that's
more than all the other projects combined.

377
00:21:04.540 --> 00:21:07.200
And so I might look at that and
say, shoot,

378
00:21:07.200 --> 00:21:11.860
I need to tackle project 4 because
its variance is actually bigger than

379
00:21:11.860 --> 00:21:16.500
the full budget of all three of the other
projects, number 4 is the highest risk.

380
00:21:16.500 --> 00:21:19.210
I need to focus on that one, okay, but

381
00:21:19.210 --> 00:21:23.710
that can be misleading, because in
the general scheme of things $200,000

382
00:21:23.710 --> 00:21:28.420
might not be a lot when you're
talking about $1.4 million all right.

383
00:21:29.910 --> 00:21:34.660
And that's where SPI really comes in,
is that we can create a number that's far

384
00:21:34.660 --> 00:21:39.870
more reasonable, that's easier to
compare between these different systems,

385
00:21:39.870 --> 00:21:43.020
to figure out which one is
actually the worst off, okay?

386
00:21:43.020 --> 00:21:44.270
So SPI lets us do that.

387
00:21:44.270 --> 00:21:45.780
And here we've got the earned value and
planned value.

388
00:21:45.780 --> 00:21:48.340
We just have to calculate it for
each of these four

389
00:21:48.340 --> 00:21:53.130
to find out which one actually has
the true worst schedule variance, alright?

390
00:21:53.130 --> 00:21:54.440
So let's run through that.

391
00:21:54.440 --> 00:21:56.928
If we take our earned value and
our planned value,

392
00:21:56.928 --> 00:22:00.557
I need to start with that $76,000 and
divide it by 84,000.

393
00:22:00.557 --> 00:22:07.061
So if I take 76,000 and
divide it by 84,000, I end up with 0.904.

394
00:22:07.061 --> 00:22:08.444
So I'll round that to 0.90.

395
00:22:08.444 --> 00:22:10.162
So I'm just gonna fill that in here.

396
00:22:10.162 --> 00:22:15.398
And then we'll kind of move
down the line here and

397
00:22:15.398 --> 00:22:19.876
go to the next one which is 25,500.

398
00:22:19.876 --> 00:22:26.059
So we need to do 25,000 divided by 25,500,

399
00:22:26.059 --> 00:22:29.617
and that's gonna be 0.98.

400
00:22:29.617 --> 00:22:30.939
0.98.

401
00:22:30.939 --> 00:22:32.389
And then we just keep going, and

402
00:22:32.389 --> 00:22:35.200
all I'm doing is earned value
divided by plan value, right?

403
00:22:35.200 --> 00:22:37.450
I'm applying the formula
we've got right here.

404
00:22:37.450 --> 00:22:42.377
So next is, this one's gonna be nice,
8,000 divided by

405
00:22:42.377 --> 00:22:47.050
25,000, which is 0.32, that's pretty bad.

406
00:22:47.050 --> 00:22:52.650
And then our last one, which is gonna
be 1.2 million divided by 1.4 million.

407
00:22:52.650 --> 00:22:57.041
All right, and
I'm gonna round that to 0.86.

408
00:22:59.862 --> 00:23:05.035
Okay, so now when I start to
look at these It becomes pretty

409
00:23:05.035 --> 00:23:10.080
obvious who's the real high risk project,
okay?

410
00:23:10.080 --> 00:23:14.823
When you're talking about .86 that's 14%.

411
00:23:14.823 --> 00:23:18.550
We're 14% behind where we need to be,
alright?

412
00:23:18.550 --> 00:23:21.070
That's not an insurmountable obstacle.

413
00:23:21.070 --> 00:23:22.950
That's something that can be overcome.

414
00:23:22.950 --> 00:23:26.597
We probably have reserves, hopefully
you don't have 14% reserves cuz that's

415
00:23:26.597 --> 00:23:28.471
a little on the high side for
reserves, but

416
00:23:28.471 --> 00:23:31.751
you've got things you can shift around,
people that you can put in place,

417
00:23:31.751 --> 00:23:35.050
that you've got the resources
available to try and overcome that.

418
00:23:35.050 --> 00:23:36.160
It's just 14%.

419
00:23:36.160 --> 00:23:41.638
It's bad, don't get me wrong,
that's bad, but it's not insurmountable.

420
00:23:41.638 --> 00:23:45.390
0.98, that's only 2%, 2%, who cares?

421
00:23:45.390 --> 00:23:48.790
That's probably just normal
operations right there.

422
00:23:48.790 --> 00:23:50.960
Something that should've happened
on Monday happened on Tuesday.

423
00:23:50.960 --> 00:23:53.560
Next week, something that should've
happened on Tuesday happens on Monday and

424
00:23:53.560 --> 00:23:54.610
it goes away, right?

425
00:23:54.610 --> 00:23:56.606
You might not even need
to take action at 0.98.

426
00:23:56.606 --> 00:23:58.347
You can practically ignore that one.

427
00:23:58.347 --> 00:24:02.121
0.90, 10%, that's not great.

428
00:24:02.121 --> 00:24:05.807
That's not something you want
to brag about to the team, but

429
00:24:05.807 --> 00:24:07.841
it's not that bad either right?

430
00:24:07.841 --> 00:24:10.341
0.32, though, boy,
that one's off the rails.

431
00:24:10.341 --> 00:24:11.941
That's a project that
needs to be canceled.

432
00:24:11.941 --> 00:24:18.701
It would be really, really difficult
to overcome being 68% behind.

433
00:24:18.701 --> 00:24:20.290
That's significant.

434
00:24:20.290 --> 00:24:23.440
We've got a $25,000 plan value at
this point, and we're only at $8,000.

435
00:24:23.440 --> 00:24:27.980
Does it mean that it's impossible
to recover this project?

436
00:24:27.980 --> 00:24:29.970
No, you can still overcome it.

437
00:24:29.970 --> 00:24:30.630
But, it's so

438
00:24:30.630 --> 00:24:35.920
far behind that it is going to fail
unless you take significant action.

439
00:24:35.920 --> 00:24:37.240
And then what action is that going to be?

440
00:24:37.240 --> 00:24:41.190
Well, it could be putting in
change tickets to just allow for

441
00:24:41.190 --> 00:24:42.650
a different completion date.

442
00:24:42.650 --> 00:24:47.030
Hey, we were planning on finishing January
1st, let's go back to March 1st now.

443
00:24:47.030 --> 00:24:48.750
So you do a delayed rollout.

444
00:24:48.750 --> 00:24:51.170
Or, you request more funds.

445
00:24:51.170 --> 00:24:52.840
Hey, I'm sorry the project went over.

446
00:24:52.840 --> 00:24:57.030
Can we get some more funds associated with
it and see if we can't overcome that?

447
00:24:57.030 --> 00:24:59.200
Or, you just get down there and
kick some butts, right?

448
00:24:59.200 --> 00:25:01.670
Maybe there's work that's supposed to be
getting done that's not getting done and

449
00:25:01.670 --> 00:25:02.920
you get in there and correct it.

450
00:25:02.920 --> 00:25:04.740
You could salvage this project.

451
00:25:04.740 --> 00:25:08.190
But it needs to be your first priority,
right?

452
00:25:08.190 --> 00:25:12.650
Granted it's a lower amount of money that
we're talking about in project 4, but

453
00:25:12.650 --> 00:25:16.350
it's in far worse shape,
far worse shape than the other one.

454
00:25:16.350 --> 00:25:20.020
And SPI really makes it where
we can compare these guys,

455
00:25:20.020 --> 00:25:23.110
where Schedule Variance
is not easy to compare.

456
00:25:23.110 --> 00:25:26.320
Schedule Variance is great for
just looking at one project, but

457
00:25:26.320 --> 00:25:29.830
when you're comparing multiple projects,
SPI, Schedule Performance Index,

458
00:25:29.830 --> 00:25:31.440
that's the one that really works out.

459
00:25:31.440 --> 00:25:35.010
And so on the exam when they ask for
an SPI, they might ask for

460
00:25:35.010 --> 00:25:38.660
it on a single project, but more
commonly it'll be something like this.

461
00:25:38.660 --> 00:25:39.880
Here's four projects.

462
00:25:39.880 --> 00:25:42.170
Which is the one that's in the most risk?

463
00:25:42.170 --> 00:25:44.750
And you've got to calculate
the SPI to figure that out.

464
00:25:44.750 --> 00:25:45.890
And we just kinda run down the line.

465
00:25:45.890 --> 00:25:47.230
It's simple math.

466
00:25:47.230 --> 00:25:48.490
They could make it hard.

467
00:25:48.490 --> 00:25:49.730
Here they gave me the EV and PV.

468
00:25:49.730 --> 00:25:52.010
Maybe they don't give you that, right?

469
00:25:52.010 --> 00:25:53.746
And now you've got to
calculate those out too, so

470
00:25:53.746 --> 00:25:56.370
you've got a little extra work
that's going to be before you.

471
00:25:56.370 --> 00:25:58.767
But otherwise you just kinda run
through them, calculate it out, and

472
00:25:58.767 --> 00:26:00.600
now you've got your answer.

473
00:26:00.600 --> 00:26:04.250
So Schedule Performance Index definitely
one of the more useful ones out there

474
00:26:04.250 --> 00:26:04.820
in the real world, too.

475
00:26:05.820 --> 00:26:07.750
>> Don, is there anything
else we need to consider in

476
00:26:07.750 --> 00:26:11.840
terms of the Schedule Performance Index,
besides just calculating that out?

477
00:26:11.840 --> 00:26:16.020
I see where it actually is valuable when
we compare it against other projects, but

478
00:26:16.020 --> 00:26:18.690
is there anything else that we
need to worry about on that one?

479
00:26:18.690 --> 00:26:20.100
>> As far as the schedule side,

480
00:26:20.100 --> 00:26:22.820
no, but keep in mind we haven't
talked about cost yet, right?

481
00:26:22.820 --> 00:26:23.532
The budgetary side.

482
00:26:23.532 --> 00:26:25.759
We're gonna do another episode where
we'll take a look at cost and budget.

483
00:26:27.260 --> 00:26:29.530
The hard part on the exam
is they're easy to confuse.

484
00:26:29.530 --> 00:26:31.019
>> Yeah.
>> Right, the formulas are very,

485
00:26:31.019 --> 00:26:31.560
very similar.

486
00:26:31.560 --> 00:26:33.140
They use a lot of the same data.

487
00:26:33.140 --> 00:26:36.020
You end up with indexes that
are effectively the same.

488
00:26:36.020 --> 00:26:41.010
It's really easy to confuse,
so everything you just saw,

489
00:26:41.010 --> 00:26:42.080
that's pretty straightforward.

490
00:26:42.080 --> 00:26:43.080
There wasn't anything confusing there.

491
00:26:43.080 --> 00:26:45.720
When we talk about cost, there really
won't be anything confusing there.

492
00:26:45.720 --> 00:26:49.280
But when you put the two together, that's
when it starts getting a little messy.

493
00:26:49.280 --> 00:26:52.020
So make sure you take your time
when you read the question.

494
00:26:52.020 --> 00:26:54.690
Make sure you understand exactly
what they're asking for.

495
00:26:54.690 --> 00:26:57.463
Are they asking for
the Schedule Performance Index or

496
00:26:57.463 --> 00:26:59.300
the Cost Performance Index?

497
00:26:59.300 --> 00:27:03.410
Are we calculating out our schedule
variants or our cost variants?

498
00:27:03.410 --> 00:27:05.110
Make sure you're using the right ones and

499
00:27:05.110 --> 00:27:07.880
the right numbers, cuz sometimes they'll
give you all the information for both.

500
00:27:07.880 --> 00:27:11.390
And then you've got to know which one
it is that you're trying to work for.

501
00:27:11.390 --> 00:27:13.233
And it's all right there in
the wording of the question.

502
00:27:13.233 --> 00:27:15.000
Just take your time and read it.

503
00:27:15.000 --> 00:27:17.850
>> So remember that what we actually
took a look at here is the idea of

504
00:27:17.850 --> 00:27:22.110
the schedule variance itself, and
the Schedule Performance Index, too.

505
00:27:22.110 --> 00:27:24.170
And even those formulas are similar.

506
00:27:24.170 --> 00:27:26.850
The very fact that we are actually
using subtraction in one and

507
00:27:26.850 --> 00:27:28.930
division in the other doesn't help.

508
00:27:28.930 --> 00:27:31.920
So you want to make sure that
those are locked into your mind

509
00:27:31.920 --> 00:27:34.440
before you get ready for
that exam, as well.

510
00:27:34.440 --> 00:27:37.310
Thank you, Don, for showing us those
examples to help us to get ready for

511
00:27:37.310 --> 00:27:38.300
the exam.

512
00:27:38.300 --> 00:27:39.640
Thank you for also joining us.

513
00:27:39.640 --> 00:27:42.190
This is a great place for
us to end this episode.

514
00:27:42.190 --> 00:27:45.000
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

515
00:27:45.000 --> 00:27:45.720
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

516
00:27:45.720 --> 00:27:47.964
>> And we'll see you next time.

517
00:27:47.964 --> 00:27:54.810
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue to look at different formulas, this time focus on Cost  Performance.  Using the basic formula, Don shows how to determine what we’ve spent in comparison to what we expected to spend.  This will give us the Cost Variance. Along with the CV, they show how to get the CPI, the cost performance index too.  This is will help when we compare it against another part of the project to help us understand whether we’re over budget or under budget at that particular point in time.
episodes.title: Cost Performance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.586 --> 00:00:15.531
Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:15.531 --> 00:00:17.780
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:17.780 --> 00:00:21.830
today we're taking a look at the PMP,
the Project Management Professional.

5
00:00:21.830 --> 00:00:24.420
Now we're specifically
diving into a few formulas.

6
00:00:24.420 --> 00:00:27.760
And today, we're taking a look
at cost performance itself.

7
00:00:27.760 --> 00:00:30.040
And who better to help us than Mr.
Don Pezet.

8
00:00:30.040 --> 00:00:31.230
Don, how's it going?

9
00:00:31.230 --> 00:00:32.340
>> It is going great, Ronnie.

10
00:00:32.340 --> 00:00:33.570
Thanks for having me back on the show.

11
00:00:33.570 --> 00:00:37.160
And we're continuing on with our
formulas in action series, right?

12
00:00:37.160 --> 00:00:39.770
Getting a chance to see these
formulas as they're used and

13
00:00:39.770 --> 00:00:42.310
some of the types of things
that might pop up on the exam.

14
00:00:42.310 --> 00:00:46.480
Now, in our last episode we took
a look at schedule variance, and

15
00:00:46.480 --> 00:00:47.690
schedule variance is great.

16
00:00:47.690 --> 00:00:51.153
It's a wonderful way to be able to see
whether or not your project is going to be

17
00:00:51.153 --> 00:00:54.429
coming in ahead or behind schedule or
hopefully on schedule.

18
00:00:54.429 --> 00:00:57.790
But, schedule variance is usually only
important to project managers, right?

19
00:00:57.790 --> 00:00:59.930
It's really just something
that we care about.

20
00:00:59.930 --> 00:01:01.830
It's not something so
much that other people care about.

21
00:01:01.830 --> 00:01:04.574
They just want to know that you're
coming in on schedule, right?

22
00:01:04.574 --> 00:01:08.520
They don't want you to be late, but
otherwise, they usually don't care.

23
00:01:08.520 --> 00:01:12.360
Cost variance, on the other hand, is
something they absolutely do care about.

24
00:01:12.360 --> 00:01:16.010
And so typically, when you're in a company
and people are asking for the performance

25
00:01:16.010 --> 00:01:18.910
of your project, they don't normally
ask about schedule variance.

26
00:01:18.910 --> 00:01:22.870
They normally ask about cost variance,
watching that budget.

27
00:01:22.870 --> 00:01:26.490
The deadline is still important,
you've gotta hit your deadline.

28
00:01:26.490 --> 00:01:28.980
But at the end of the day,
most companies fixate on the dollar bill,

29
00:01:28.980 --> 00:01:31.570
the amount of money that we're gonna
spend to complete that project.

30
00:01:31.570 --> 00:01:35.330
So, we're gonna take the same concepts
that we saw with schedule variance, but

31
00:01:35.330 --> 00:01:37.000
we're going to apply it to cost variance.

32
00:01:37.000 --> 00:01:40.057
And you'll see that the formulas
are almost identical.

33
00:01:40.057 --> 00:01:44.345
And when we did schedule variance,
we actually took cost into account.

34
00:01:44.345 --> 00:01:45.055
That's a part of it, right?

35
00:01:45.055 --> 00:01:47.265
Let me bring some of
these formulas back up.

36
00:01:47.265 --> 00:01:51.385
So, we talked about variance, and how
that's just simply the difference between

37
00:01:51.385 --> 00:01:54.325
what our plan was and
what we're actually getting, right?

38
00:01:54.325 --> 00:01:58.525
So this little gap that gets created here,
that's our variance.

39
00:01:58.525 --> 00:02:00.275
And when we measure variance,

40
00:02:00.275 --> 00:02:05.290
we're normally dealing with two concepts,
plan value and earn value, right?

41
00:02:05.290 --> 00:02:10.160
Plan value is the amount of work we expect
to have been done at a certain point.

42
00:02:10.160 --> 00:02:13.240
And it's normally phrased as
the amount of effort, right?

43
00:02:13.240 --> 00:02:14.240
And why do they say effort?

44
00:02:14.240 --> 00:02:18.095
Well, effort is usually that
combination of time and money, right?

45
00:02:18.095 --> 00:02:22.225
I know that somebody's gotta do some work,
and that person makes $15 an hour, and

46
00:02:22.225 --> 00:02:23.415
there's two hours of work.

47
00:02:24.515 --> 00:02:29.250
That's their effort, the two hours and the
$15 kind of combine to form that effort.

48
00:02:29.250 --> 00:02:33.650
And so when we talk about planned value,
it's taking that budget at completion and

49
00:02:33.650 --> 00:02:34.860
multiplying it by planned work.

50
00:02:34.860 --> 00:02:37.161
We saw that back when we started
talking about earned value analysis, so

51
00:02:37.161 --> 00:02:39.920
if you haven't watched that episode,
definitely check it out.

52
00:02:39.920 --> 00:02:41.670
But it's a composite metric, right.

53
00:02:41.670 --> 00:02:45.658
It's combining money, or
our budget, and our planned work,

54
00:02:45.658 --> 00:02:47.328
which is labor or effort.

55
00:02:47.328 --> 00:02:51.110
You're kinda merging all that
together to create this metric, and

56
00:02:51.110 --> 00:02:52.840
earned value does the same thing, right?

57
00:02:52.840 --> 00:02:55.880
Our planned value, which we already
saw brought in our budget, but

58
00:02:55.880 --> 00:02:57.150
factoring in the work.

59
00:02:57.150 --> 00:02:58.720
And that's why it's not so good for

60
00:02:58.720 --> 00:03:02.740
cost variance, because it's taking
into account things like the schedule.

61
00:03:02.740 --> 00:03:04.810
And for schedule variance that's perfect,
that's what we wanted.

62
00:03:04.810 --> 00:03:06.350
For cost, it's not.

63
00:03:06.350 --> 00:03:09.100
When we're dealing with cost,
we have different formulas.

64
00:03:09.100 --> 00:03:13.420
And the formulas work to eliminate
some of that reliance on scheduling.

65
00:03:13.420 --> 00:03:19.428
So notice that cost variance is your
earn value minus your actual cost.

66
00:03:19.428 --> 00:03:23.750
All right, not earned value
minus planned value, right?

67
00:03:23.750 --> 00:03:26.240
My planned value is that
amount of effort and

68
00:03:26.240 --> 00:03:27.960
cost that I expected to
incur by a certain point.

69
00:03:27.960 --> 00:03:30.110
Here it's just the actual
straight up cost.

70
00:03:30.110 --> 00:03:31.670
How many dollars have I spent?

71
00:03:31.670 --> 00:03:33.430
That's what I want to know, right?

72
00:03:33.430 --> 00:03:37.260
I don't really care what percentage
is complete or whatever.

73
00:03:37.260 --> 00:03:39.820
I just need to know the raw dollars and
cents.

74
00:03:39.820 --> 00:03:42.550
So, cost variance is really no different
than scheduled variance, except that we

75
00:03:42.550 --> 00:03:47.880
drop some of reliance on time, and
we put the reliance on the actual money.

76
00:03:47.880 --> 00:03:49.610
Now, notice we are still using earn value.

77
00:03:49.610 --> 00:03:53.040
And that means we do still care
about time, because earn value,

78
00:03:53.040 --> 00:03:58.640
as I just showed you back here,
is your planned

79
00:03:58.640 --> 00:04:03.830
value is our budget at complete times,
our planned work.

80
00:04:03.830 --> 00:04:07.720
So that amount of work,
that time is still in there, right?

81
00:04:07.720 --> 00:04:12.000
But the reliance on it is reduced as
we focus strictly on that dollar,

82
00:04:12.000 --> 00:04:15.400
that actual cost, which is a pretty
important piece, all right?

83
00:04:15.400 --> 00:04:19.130
Now the trickiest thing to remember for
the exam when it comes to cost variance

84
00:04:19.130 --> 00:04:23.010
is that the result is a little bit weird,
right?

85
00:04:23.010 --> 00:04:25.140
When we talk about schedule variance,

86
00:04:25.140 --> 00:04:29.700
schedule variance you get a result
back and hopefully it's zero.

87
00:04:29.700 --> 00:04:31.730
You want your earned value and
your planned value to be equal, and

88
00:04:31.730 --> 00:04:33.080
you get a zero back.

89
00:04:33.080 --> 00:04:37.130
And if it's a higher number, like
a positive number or a negative number,

90
00:04:37.130 --> 00:04:38.510
you get different results.

91
00:04:38.510 --> 00:04:41.340
And so we've gotta remember that, there's
something you have to memorize here.

92
00:04:41.340 --> 00:04:47.040
With cost variance,
if we get a number that is less than zero,

93
00:04:47.040 --> 00:04:51.110
if it's less than zero,
we're actually over budget.

94
00:04:51.110 --> 00:04:53.480
And if it's greater than zero,
we're under budget.

95
00:04:53.480 --> 00:04:55.550
It's kind of the opposite
of what you'd think.

96
00:04:55.550 --> 00:04:59.270
If we had a greater number for schedule,
we'd actually be ahead of schedule.

97
00:04:59.270 --> 00:05:02.760
Or a lesser number than zero, a negative
number, then we'd be behind schedule.

98
00:05:02.760 --> 00:05:04.830
But in cost, it's the exact opposite.

99
00:05:04.830 --> 00:05:05.790
So memorize that.

100
00:05:05.790 --> 00:05:07.020
Don't get confused.

101
00:05:07.020 --> 00:05:10.360
Don't go in there and
calculate out a cost variance, and

102
00:05:10.360 --> 00:05:12.910
then assume that you're under budget
when you're actually over budget.

103
00:05:12.910 --> 00:05:15.470
Because you just mixed up which one was
positive and which one was negative.

104
00:05:15.470 --> 00:05:19.220
So, if I get a negative result,
I'm actually over budget.

105
00:05:19.220 --> 00:05:23.940
And the way I remember it, is what happens
if you spend more money than you have?

106
00:05:23.940 --> 00:05:24.900
You go into the red.

107
00:05:24.900 --> 00:05:25.650
You go into the negative.

108
00:05:25.650 --> 00:05:26.760
You now have negative money.

109
00:05:26.760 --> 00:05:29.720
You spent more than you had and
so that's how I remember this.

110
00:05:29.720 --> 00:05:33.290
If I have a negative number,
it's like I spent more than I had, and so

111
00:05:33.290 --> 00:05:34.610
I'm over budget.

112
00:05:34.610 --> 00:05:37.700
But if I have a positive number, right?

113
00:05:37.700 --> 00:05:39.160
I haven't spend all my money yet.

114
00:05:39.160 --> 00:05:41.760
I still have a positive number,
and so I'm under budget.

115
00:05:41.760 --> 00:05:43.940
That's the kinda pneumonic
I use to remember that.

116
00:05:45.320 --> 00:05:48.800
So the formula is pretty simple, and
we apply it just like schedule variance.

117
00:05:48.800 --> 00:05:51.880
So, here I've got an example kind of
like what you might see on the exam, and

118
00:05:51.880 --> 00:05:54.440
this would be one of
the simpler forms of it.

119
00:05:54.440 --> 00:05:56.570
Now in typical PMI fashion here,

120
00:05:56.570 --> 00:05:59.260
I've given us a lot of
information in the question.

121
00:05:59.260 --> 00:06:01.820
Some of it we need,
some of it we don't need.

122
00:06:01.820 --> 00:06:05.310
Some of it will be very clear and
tell us what our earned value is.

123
00:06:05.310 --> 00:06:08.020
Other times we might have to
calculate our earned value.

124
00:06:08.020 --> 00:06:09.840
Sometimes they might tell us
what our actual cost is, or

125
00:06:09.840 --> 00:06:11.230
they might give us several costs, and

126
00:06:11.230 --> 00:06:13.900
we have to add them up,
create a sum to get that.

127
00:06:13.900 --> 00:06:17.000
So, as we read through this, we need to
be thinking about the data we get and

128
00:06:17.000 --> 00:06:18.200
what's important.

129
00:06:18.200 --> 00:06:19.415
We've got this one here.

130
00:06:19.415 --> 00:06:23.559
You have received a status report for
activity 4.9, dated August 1st.

131
00:06:24.560 --> 00:06:27.240

That's a big deal, that's a problem.

00:18:08.360 --> 00:18:15.880
But if this is a $10 million project and
I'm off by $500, that's hardly anything.

359
00:18:15.880 --> 00:18:19.450
And so when you calculate your CV,
your cost variance,

360
00:18:19.450 --> 00:18:23.370
it doesn't help you interpret that, how
bad is this in comparison to the project?

361
00:18:23.370 --> 00:18:24.980
CPI will.

362
00:18:24.980 --> 00:18:27.160
So a CPI, we just plug in
the values we've been given.

363
00:18:27.160 --> 00:18:31.300
So CPI equals earned value,
which they told me was $3,000.

364
00:18:31.300 --> 00:18:37.872
And then we divide that by our actual cost
which accounting told me that was $3,500.

365
00:18:37.872 --> 00:18:42.130
Now notice how they gave me my plan.

366
00:18:42.130 --> 00:18:46.120
It says your project plan indicates
you should have spent 3,500 and

367
00:18:46.120 --> 00:18:47.200
that we actually have.

368
00:18:47.200 --> 00:18:49.890
Do I care what the project plan says here?

369
00:18:49.890 --> 00:18:50.640
I don't.

370
00:18:50.640 --> 00:18:51.790
Right?
The earned value does,

371
00:18:51.790 --> 00:18:53.370
the earned value cares about the plan.

372
00:18:53.370 --> 00:18:56.900
But as far as this formula here,
if they've given me my earned value, this

373
00:18:56.900 --> 00:19:00.410
extra bit of information is just useless
fluff that I kind of ignore because

374
00:19:00.410 --> 00:19:04.140
the actual cost, what the accounting
department says, that's what I care about.

375
00:19:04.140 --> 00:19:06.559
And so now I just divide that out, right?

376
00:19:06.559 --> 00:19:07.824
3,000 divided by 3,500.

377
00:19:07.824 --> 00:19:09.400
So, I'll take good old 3,000.

378
00:19:09.400 --> 00:19:11.330
We'll divide that by 3,500.

379
00:19:11.330 --> 00:19:14.970
And I end up with 0.857,
which I'll round up to 0.86.

380
00:19:14.970 --> 00:19:19.788
0.86, there we go.

381
00:19:19.788 --> 00:19:23.020
And so now,
I've got my cost performance syntax.

382
00:19:23.020 --> 00:19:26.910
Now if we jump back over to my CPI slide
here, and kind of zoom in on the results.

383
00:19:26.910 --> 00:19:27.860
We can interpret what we got.

384
00:19:27.860 --> 00:19:32.260
And you'll see if I have less than 1,
I'm over budget.

385
00:19:32.260 --> 00:19:33.150
1 is on budget.

386
00:19:33.150 --> 00:19:34.810
> 1 is under budget.

387
00:19:34.810 --> 00:19:36.600
In my case, what did I get?

388
00:19:36.600 --> 00:19:37.883
Well, I got 0.86.

389
00:19:37.883 --> 00:19:40.540
And 0.86 is < 1.

390
00:19:40.540 --> 00:19:42.130
I'm over budget.

391
00:19:42.130 --> 00:19:45.270
And not only am I over budget,
I can kind of take this.

392
00:19:45.270 --> 00:19:49.920
It really works on a percentage,
so I'm actually 14% over budget.

393
00:19:49.920 --> 00:19:51.790
So if we wanna interpret it that way,

394
00:19:51.790 --> 00:19:55.490
I can see the extent to which
I'm over budget on my project.

395
00:19:55.490 --> 00:19:59.756
So, this is a great indicator and it's
even better because I can take this number

396
00:19:59.756 --> 00:20:03.833
and compare it to other projects, which
is how you're more likely to see it on

397
00:20:03.833 --> 00:20:06.610
the exam and
that's my second example here.

398
00:20:06.610 --> 00:20:09.280
Is we've been brought into salvage

399
00:20:09.280 --> 00:20:12.240
four projects that are currently
at risk of failure.

400
00:20:12.240 --> 00:20:15.170
Which of the four projects is
in the most need of attention?

401
00:20:15.170 --> 00:20:19.120
And they're giving me me the earned
values and the actual cost-to-date.

402
00:20:19.120 --> 00:20:21.680
Now I can calculate out the cost variance,
if I want.

403
00:20:22.980 --> 00:20:28.380
Or I can just skip that and go right
to my CPI and calculate out the CPI.

404
00:20:28.380 --> 00:20:32.850
If I do that, this CPI's really
easy to compare between these.

405
00:20:32.850 --> 00:20:37.190
The cost variance is harder to compare,
but let's do both for completeness here.

406
00:20:37.190 --> 00:20:42.310
My first one I've got an earned value
of $85,000, an actual cost of $84,500.

407
00:20:42.310 --> 00:20:47.744
My CV is just EV- AC, so I can see
on this one my CV is going to be,

408
00:20:47.744 --> 00:20:50.116
what are we talking about.

409
00:20:50.116 --> 00:20:50.755
500 bucks.
Right?

410
00:20:50.755 --> 00:20:55.250
$500, and apparently it's in red for
some reason.

411
00:20:55.250 --> 00:20:56.510
So $500.

412
00:20:56.510 --> 00:20:57.900
If I look at my next one, you know what?

413
00:20:57.900 --> 00:21:01.205
This actually needs to be white, because.

414
00:21:01.205 --> 00:21:05.499
[SOUND] There we go, there we go,
because this is a positive number.

415
00:21:05.499 --> 00:21:08.985
My actual cost is lower than my earned
value, so I'm doing well there,

416
00:21:08.985 --> 00:21:10.466
I'm actually under budget.

417
00:21:10.466 --> 00:21:14.520
This one, $1.8 million minus my
actual cost, $1.5 million, so

418
00:21:14.520 --> 00:21:18.220
just like the one above,
I'm actually under budget on this one.

419
00:21:18.220 --> 00:21:20.910
I've apparently got several of
these that are under budget.

420
00:21:20.910 --> 00:21:22.394
This one's gonna be under budget $300,000,
right?

421
00:21:22.394 --> 00:21:28.750
Which again let me make that white instead
of red because we're not in the red.

422
00:21:28.750 --> 00:21:29.540
All right.

423
00:21:29.540 --> 00:21:32.764
But this next one is the first one that
I have that is gonna go negative, right?

424
00:21:32.764 --> 00:21:36.454
$17,000, my actual cost is $25,000 so

425
00:21:36.454 --> 00:21:40.556
I've got a $8,000 dollar
discrepancy between them.

426
00:21:40.556 --> 00:21:45.564
And so this one is going to be $8,000,
right, negative.

427
00:21:45.564 --> 00:21:49.790
And then this last one 2.2 million,
my actually cost 2.3 million, and so

428
00:21:49.790 --> 00:21:52.771
I've got a $100,000
discrepancy on that one.

429
00:21:52.771 --> 00:21:56.882
All right, now as I look at these when I
start thinking about ones that are a risk

430
00:21:56.882 --> 00:22:00.930
of failure, when I see $500, I don't
think of that being a lot of money,

431
00:22:00.930 --> 00:22:03.520
especially when the budget is $84,500.

432
00:22:03.520 --> 00:22:07.867
It just doesn't seem that significant.

433
00:22:07.867 --> 00:22:10.614
$300,000, though,
that sounds pretty darn significant.

434
00:22:10.614 --> 00:22:12.565
$100,000, pretty significant.

435
00:22:12.565 --> 00:22:15.520
$8,000, well, it depends.

436
00:22:15.520 --> 00:22:19.555
If it was a $2.3 million project,
$8,000 is not that big of a deal.

437
00:22:19.555 --> 00:22:24.530
But $8,000 on a $25,000 project,
that can be a big deal.

438
00:22:24.530 --> 00:22:27.928
And so I need a better way to compare
these to figure out which one is most at

439
00:22:27.928 --> 00:22:29.842
risk because it's kind of hard to tell.

440
00:22:29.842 --> 00:22:32.526
And I know what you're thinking,
this guy's $300,000 under budget,

441
00:22:32.526 --> 00:22:33.720
how is that at risk?

442
00:22:33.720 --> 00:22:36.940
Well, to have a discrepancy that big,
$300,000,

443
00:22:36.940 --> 00:22:42.582
that more than likely means there is
a lot of work that has not been done.

444
00:22:42.582 --> 00:22:45.490
Work thatwas supposed to have been done,
supposed to be built, but hasn't been, or

445
00:22:45.490 --> 00:22:47.890
maybe it means we aren't
paying our contractors.

446
00:22:47.890 --> 00:22:49.190
And so now our contractors are gonna walk,

447
00:22:49.190 --> 00:22:51.210
they're not gonna do anymore work
because they haven't gotten paid.

448
00:22:51.210 --> 00:22:53.720
And we need to find out what that
problem is and get it solved.

449
00:22:53.720 --> 00:22:56.540
An overage is not
necessarily a good thing.

450
00:22:57.610 --> 00:23:05.861
So if I calculate my CPI I can really
figure this out a little bit better.

451
00:23:05.861 --> 00:23:11.405
And so if I start with this $85,000 and
divide it by $84,500.

452
00:23:11.405 --> 00:23:15.311
So 85,000 divided by
84,500 that is a 1.005, so

453
00:23:15.311 --> 00:23:20.490
I'm gonna round that up to 1.01 right, and
I use just the standard rounding rules.

454
00:23:20.490 --> 00:23:24.020
If that last decimal place is a 5 or
a higher, I go up.

455
00:23:24.020 --> 00:23:26.430
If it's a 4 or lower, I go down.

456
00:23:26.430 --> 00:23:31.120
And then we've got 1.8
million versus 1.5 million.

457
00:23:31.120 --> 00:23:35.270
So I'll take $1.8 million and
divide that by $1.5 million.

458
00:23:37.490 --> 00:23:38.560
And I get a 1.2, right?

459
00:23:39.890 --> 00:23:44.744
Nice big overage there, so
we're under budget on those guys,

460
00:23:44.744 --> 00:23:47.410
or these numbers that are over 1.

461
00:23:47.410 --> 00:23:51.244
And then we start to get to our negatives,
right?

462
00:23:51.244 --> 00:23:53.961
So 17,000 divided by 25,000 is 0.68.

463
00:23:53.961 --> 00:24:00.945
And then my last one,
2.2 million versus 2.3 million and

464
00:24:00.945 --> 00:24:05.571
we divide that out, and it's 0.96.

465
00:24:08.304 --> 00:24:09.624
Okay, whoops.

466
00:24:09.624 --> 00:24:11.062
Zero, slash, I don't know.

467
00:24:11.062 --> 00:24:12.662
We'll make all new numbering systems.

468
00:24:12.662 --> 00:24:13.642
There!

469
00:24:13.642 --> 00:24:15.182
Now, I've got my CPIs.

470
00:24:15.182 --> 00:24:18.280
And what my CPIs do is let me
start to compare these things.

471
00:24:18.280 --> 00:24:21.460
Now, I already knew that 500
bucks was not a big deal, right?

472
00:24:21.460 --> 00:24:23.288
And so, I get a CPI of 1.01.

473
00:24:23.288 --> 00:24:25.930
I mean, we are practically 1.0 there.

474
00:24:25.930 --> 00:24:27.410
I wouldn't really bat an eye at that.

475
00:24:27.410 --> 00:24:28.318
That's not a big deal.

476
00:24:28.318 --> 00:24:30.440
We're really in line.

477
00:24:30.440 --> 00:24:35.286
And down here on this $2.3 million
project, I'm off $100,000.

478
00:24:35.286 --> 00:24:36.390
That's a lot of money.

479
00:24:36.390 --> 00:24:37.920
Ronnie, do you have
$100,000 in your pocket?

480
00:24:37.920 --> 00:24:38.570
>> I do not.

481
00:24:38.570 --> 00:24:41.270
>> So, it's a ton of money, right?

482
00:24:41.270 --> 00:24:43.496
But I've got a 0.96.

483
00:24:43.496 --> 00:24:46.596
In the general scheme of this activity,
it's really not that far off.

484
00:24:46.596 --> 00:24:48.900
And this could just simply
be delayed billing.

485
00:24:48.900 --> 00:24:53.488
This could be any number of simple things
that will resolve itself pretty quickly.

486
00:24:53.488 --> 00:24:55.636
So, while that number's
pretty daunting at first,

487
00:24:55.636 --> 00:24:57.556
it's really not that big of a deal,
all right.

488
00:24:57.556 --> 00:25:01.090
That $300,000 overage, that was a lot.

489
00:25:01.090 --> 00:25:03.018
That's a lot of money
to be sitting on there.

490
00:25:03.018 --> 00:25:04.838
$300,000 that we haven't paid out.

491
00:25:04.838 --> 00:25:06.958
And if I look at my CPI, it's a 1.2.

492
00:25:06.958 --> 00:25:08.138
That's pretty significant, right?

493
00:25:08.138 --> 00:25:10.420
Significant compared to project one and
project four.

494
00:25:10.420 --> 00:25:12.300
So, that's definitely a problem.

495
00:25:12.300 --> 00:25:17.708
But this next guy, the $25,000 project
with the $8000 discrepancy, right?

496
00:25:17.708 --> 00:25:21.345
Well, if I look at that, it's a 0.68.

497
00:25:21.345 --> 00:25:26.280
That's 32% off from
target versus 20% over.

498
00:25:26.280 --> 00:25:29.101
This one,
project number 3 is at the most risk.

499
00:25:29.101 --> 00:25:33.420
It's at the most risk because my actual
costs are far exceeding my earned value.

500
00:25:33.420 --> 00:25:36.230
And at this rate,
the project's gonna fail, right?

501
00:25:36.230 --> 00:25:40.040
This one is much closer to
failing than project two is.

502
00:25:40.040 --> 00:25:44.165
Project two has a bigger risk because of
the bigger dollar signs attached to it.

503
00:25:44.165 --> 00:25:48.505
But as far as odds of failure, project
3 has the greatest odds of failure.

504
00:25:48.505 --> 00:25:51.295
And so when they're saying which one
is in the most need of attention,

505
00:25:51.295 --> 00:25:52.155
it's project 3.

506
00:25:52.155 --> 00:25:54.725
Project 3 then needs to be cancelled or
corrected, all right?

507
00:25:54.725 --> 00:25:57.365
We've gotta make that determination and
act on it.

508
00:25:57.365 --> 00:25:59.075
So, that's something that
we can do with a CPI,

509
00:25:59.075 --> 00:26:02.190
really gives us a great way to compare
things, just like schedule variance.

510
00:26:02.190 --> 00:26:05.405
And remember, the key difference
between schedule variance and

511
00:26:05.405 --> 00:26:08.973
cost variance is that we're kind of
removing reliance on scheduling and

512
00:26:08.973 --> 00:26:10.858
time and focusing purely on the cost.

513
00:26:10.858 --> 00:26:13.080
That actual cost that gets broken in.

514
00:26:13.080 --> 00:26:15.960
And you'll find that this is
what most companies want.

515
00:26:15.960 --> 00:26:19.165
As a project manager, we usually think
schedule variance cuz it's a little more

516
00:26:19.165 --> 00:26:20.710
all-encompassing, right?

517
00:26:20.710 --> 00:26:22.450
Time and cost factored in.

518
00:26:22.450 --> 00:26:26.190
But this one is what companies want,
because they wanna know that bottom line,

519
00:26:26.190 --> 00:26:27.480
the dollar that they're paying out.

520
00:26:27.480 --> 00:26:28.650
Are they getting the value for it?

521
00:26:28.650 --> 00:26:30.800
So, you'll see this one
used more commonly.

522
00:26:30.800 --> 00:26:34.660
>> Now Don, with numbers that might
look as close as what we saw there,

523
00:26:34.660 --> 00:26:37.170
if they're just a tenth off,
you would still pick

524
00:26:37.170 --> 00:26:40.400
the number that's farthest away
from one is what we're saying?

525
00:26:40.400 --> 00:26:41.086
>> Yeah, for the most part.

526
00:26:41.086 --> 00:26:44.010
Now, your company is gonna
have a policy for this, right?

527
00:26:44.010 --> 00:26:46.370
Your company should have, if you
have a PMO, they definitely have it.

528
00:26:46.370 --> 00:26:48.770
But you should have a project
management plan, right?

529
00:26:48.770 --> 00:26:50.990
Not a project plan,
a project management plan.

530
00:26:50.990 --> 00:26:52.760
How you manage your projects.

531
00:26:52.760 --> 00:26:57.180
And in the project management plan, it
should say, when you calculate your SV, or

532
00:26:57.180 --> 00:27:01.590
when you calculate your CV, here's the
amount that we'll tolerate that being off.

533
00:27:01.590 --> 00:27:07.230
Okay, so that if you're off 4%,
maybe that's okay for your company.

534
00:27:07.230 --> 00:27:09.178
Another company might say, no, only 2%.

535
00:27:09.178 --> 00:27:11.500
And so, that's your acceptable window.

536
00:27:11.500 --> 00:27:16.210
And if your project completes and
it's over 2% or under 2%, it's okay.

537
00:27:16.210 --> 00:27:19.100
It's still a win because that's
the number your company decided on.

538
00:27:19.100 --> 00:27:20.610
But there is no official number.

539
00:27:20.610 --> 00:27:23.470
The PMI, they don't have
an official number for you.

540
00:27:23.470 --> 00:27:25.940
It's up to your company to
decide your tolerance and

541
00:27:25.940 --> 00:27:29.050
what you're willing to accept for
success, right?

542
00:27:29.050 --> 00:27:30.913
So, these numbers here,

543
00:27:30.913 --> 00:27:35.668
I might have an organization that
we say if it's more than 10%.

544
00:27:35.668 --> 00:27:38.668
If it's more than 0.1,
then we need to act on it.

545
00:27:38.668 --> 00:27:42.157
And so looking at these projects
right here, both project 2 and

546
00:27:42.157 --> 00:27:46.758
project 3, would be an equal level of
risk, because they're both beyond 0.1.

547
00:27:46.758 --> 00:27:50.468
They're both beyond 10% versus
project 1 and 4 that aren't, right.

548
00:27:50.468 --> 00:27:52.090
They're in the acceptable means.

549
00:27:52.090 --> 00:27:57.058
But if my limit is 3%, then even project
4 is at a pretty big risk there, right?

550
00:27:57.058 --> 00:27:59.570
Because it's 4% away from
where it's supposed to be.

551
00:27:59.570 --> 00:28:01.570
So, it is just up to the company.

552
00:28:01.570 --> 00:28:04.600
>> Well, Don, thank you again for
showing us about the cost variance and

553
00:28:04.600 --> 00:28:06.220
the cost performance index.

554
00:28:06.220 --> 00:28:07.800
Remember that the cost variance for
us, right,

555
00:28:07.800 --> 00:28:11.570
is actually compared to that planned work
that we had that we said we were gonna

556
00:28:11.570 --> 00:28:15.430
spend versus what we actually do have or
what we actually have spent at that point.

557
00:28:15.430 --> 00:28:18.600
And then, that cost performance index,
just like what Don showed us,

558
00:28:18.600 --> 00:28:21.200
allows us to be able to tell
whether we're over budget or

559
00:28:21.200 --> 00:28:25.460
under budget fairly easily,
even when the numbers get large, right?

560
00:28:25.460 --> 00:28:28.320
You'll still be able to actually
determine that fairly easily on which

561
00:28:28.320 --> 00:28:30.170
one you actually want to be able to use.

562
00:28:30.170 --> 00:28:34.150
Don, thank you for also putting that in
the context of the PNP exam, as well.

563
00:28:34.150 --> 00:28:35.870
Helping us to be able to look at that.

564
00:28:35.870 --> 00:28:37.400
And we do appreciate it.

565
00:28:37.400 --> 00:28:39.930
Any last words as people
are practicing this?

566
00:28:39.930 --> 00:28:40.790
>> So what we just saw right

567
00:28:40.790 --> 00:28:42.920
there was the most basic
implementation of cost variance.

568
00:28:42.920 --> 00:28:43.568
We do have a little more.

569
00:28:43.568 --> 00:28:47.611
I want to cover cumulative cost
variance or cumulative CPI, really,

570
00:28:47.611 --> 00:28:49.180
is the important one.

571
00:28:49.180 --> 00:28:49.870
So, stay tuned.

572
00:28:49.870 --> 00:28:51.918
We're gonna film another episode
that'll cover that after this.

573
00:28:51.918 --> 00:28:54.478
We'll also do the cumulative
schedule performance index too.

574
00:28:54.478 --> 00:28:56.390
So, you'll want to see those.

575
00:28:56.390 --> 00:28:58.199
Not as common out there in the real world,
but

576
00:28:58.199 --> 00:29:00.158
common enough on the exam
that we need to know it.

577
00:29:00.158 --> 00:29:01.580
So, stay tuned for that episode.

578
00:29:01.580 --> 00:29:04.562
But as far as cost variance though,
that's a pretty good run down.

579
00:29:04.562 --> 00:29:07.930

00:29:14.217 --> 00:29:20.607
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don talk about the Cumulative Indexes that allow us to determine whether we are ahead of schedule or behind schedule, under budget or over up to the time you run these formulas.  This will allow you to take a historical look at the project’s cost and schedule performance up to that point.  Don shows how to calculate both and reminds us to watch out for unusual figures that can cause some issues.
episodes.title: Cumulative Performance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.570 --> 00:00:15.361
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.361 --> 00:00:19.160
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and
today we're taking a look at the PMP,

4
00:00:19.160 --> 00:00:21.660
the Project Management Professional.

5
00:00:21.660 --> 00:00:24.620
We're specifically going into some
of the different formulas and

6
00:00:24.620 --> 00:00:27.120
this time thought we're taking
an accumulative approach and

7
00:00:27.120 --> 00:00:28.900
talking about some of
the different indexes.

8
00:00:28.900 --> 00:00:30.820
Who better to help us than Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:30.820 --> 00:00:31.870
Don, how it going?

10
00:00:31.870 --> 00:00:33.660
>> It is going gret Ron,
thanks for having me back.

11
00:00:33.660 --> 00:00:36.860
And we're gonna basically jump right
back into our formulas and action.

12
00:00:36.860 --> 00:00:40.570
The ones we're gonna take a look at
today are some interesting ones.

13
00:00:40.570 --> 00:00:43.620
Ones that I don't admittedly use in
production very often cuz I have software

14
00:00:43.620 --> 00:00:44.250
that does it for me.

15
00:00:44.250 --> 00:00:45.920
But there are ones that we
need to be aware of and

16
00:00:45.920 --> 00:00:47.550
we need to understand
why they're available.

17
00:00:47.550 --> 00:00:50.200
And what they are, are cumulative indexes.

18
00:00:50.200 --> 00:00:53.150
Now, in previous episodes,
we've covered cost variance, and

19
00:00:53.150 --> 00:00:54.640
we covered schedule variance.

20
00:00:54.640 --> 00:00:57.030
And with both of those,
we calculated indexes.

21
00:00:57.030 --> 00:01:02.240
The Schedule Performance Index or SPI and
the CPI, or Cost Performance Index.

22
00:01:02.240 --> 00:01:05.930
When both of those indexes, or indices?

23
00:01:05.930 --> 00:01:06.670
>> Indices, yeah.

24
00:01:06.670 --> 00:01:09.150
>> Whatever, both those indexes,
just all remember that.

25
00:01:09.150 --> 00:01:13.970
With both of those indexes, they're
really just a single point in time.

26
00:01:13.970 --> 00:01:17.720
We look at our earned, like with a,
we'll use SPI as an example.

27
00:01:17.720 --> 00:01:21.960
You look at your earned value and your
planned value for that moment in time or

28
00:01:21.960 --> 00:01:22.780
costs, right?

29
00:01:22.780 --> 00:01:27.200
We look at our earned value and
our actual cost for that moment in time.

30
00:01:28.350 --> 00:01:31.650
Here's the problem with that,
you might look at things right now and

31
00:01:31.650 --> 00:01:36.960
they might be fine, but they have
a track record of being really bad.

32
00:01:36.960 --> 00:01:38.670
What can happen is if you
look at it right now and

33
00:01:38.670 --> 00:01:42.420
everything looks fine,
well next week things might be bad again.

34
00:01:42.420 --> 00:01:45.380
But you didn't see that coming
because you didn't look historically.

35
00:01:45.380 --> 00:01:49.230
So, where cumulative indexes come in is
they try to help you get a better handle

36
00:01:49.230 --> 00:01:54.170
on how things have been running to date,
not just on this date, but to that date.

37
00:01:54.170 --> 00:01:55.990
Everything that happened before.

38
00:01:55.990 --> 00:02:00.860
This is incredibly useful if
you're a new project manager or

39
00:02:00.860 --> 00:02:03.590
an existing project manager
assigned to a new project, right?

40
00:02:03.590 --> 00:02:06.060
So, maybe there's
a project that's failing.

41
00:02:06.060 --> 00:02:07.690
And they bring you into this area,

42
00:02:07.690 --> 00:02:10.720
you're the new PM,
take this project and make it better.

43
00:02:10.720 --> 00:02:13.860
And you sit down and you just run your CPI
and your SPI and everything looks good.

44
00:02:13.860 --> 00:02:15.510
And you're like woo this
is going to be easy,

45
00:02:15.510 --> 00:02:19.350
I'm just gonna kick back, this project,
it's not in danger at all.

46
00:02:19.350 --> 00:02:23.860
But if you run your cumulative indexes,
you'll start to see the history.

47
00:02:23.860 --> 00:02:27.860
You'll see the problem and you'll see
what you're most likely to end up with.

48
00:02:27.860 --> 00:02:29.540
And this is not true forecasting,

49
00:02:29.540 --> 00:02:32.110
we're gonna talk about true
forecasting in another episode.

50
00:02:32.110 --> 00:02:35.880
So this isn't like EAC and
all that good stuff.

51
00:02:35.880 --> 00:02:40.670
But this does give you a better idea on
the health of the project compared to

52
00:02:40.670 --> 00:02:43.060
what it's been doing historically.

53
00:02:43.060 --> 00:02:45.520
So enough jabbering about it,
let me show you how this works.

54
00:02:45.520 --> 00:02:48.080
We'll start with cost, cuz cost is
usually the one that we deal with,

55
00:02:48.080 --> 00:02:49.810
schedules is less common.

56
00:02:49.810 --> 00:02:53.175
With cost what we do is we take
our cost performance index,

57
00:02:53.175 --> 00:02:55.864
the same formula we saw
in previous episodes.

58
00:02:55.864 --> 00:02:58.390
CPI + EV / AC.

59
00:02:58.390 --> 00:03:00.570
Nothing new there,
there's just the standard formula.

60
00:03:01.640 --> 00:03:04.050
Well, except for these little cs
that are stuck up here, right.

61
00:03:04.050 --> 00:03:06.100
So what do all those little cs mean?

62
00:03:06.100 --> 00:03:09.250
What they mean is the cumulative value.

63
00:03:09.250 --> 00:03:14.740
Not just one actual cost, but
the actual cost over a period of time, and

64
00:03:14.740 --> 00:03:20.050
not just one earned value, but the earned
value over several periods of time, okay.

65
00:03:20.050 --> 00:03:24.370
So we have to take the numbers that
we've gathered and sum them up.

66
00:03:24.370 --> 00:03:26.730
If I have five different reports for

67
00:03:26.730 --> 00:03:28.860
my actual cost I need to
add up all five of them.

68
00:03:28.860 --> 00:03:33.520
And I need to take the corresponding five
earned value reports and add them up and

69
00:03:33.520 --> 00:03:38.560
take the cumulative EV and
divide it by the cumulative AC and

70
00:03:38.560 --> 00:03:43.550
that will give me my cumulative cost
performance index which factors in not

71
00:03:43.550 --> 00:03:48.210
just the latest report but
the previous reports also.

72
00:03:48.210 --> 00:03:51.200
The biggest challenge
that we have with CPI

73
00:03:51.200 --> 00:03:53.880
is making sure our data set is accurate.

74
00:03:53.880 --> 00:03:56.930
If I want to work with CPI,
here's a great example, right?

75
00:03:56.930 --> 00:03:59.420
So they're giving me some information.

76
00:03:59.420 --> 00:04:00.870
They've been running reports already.

77
00:04:00.870 --> 00:04:03.900
I'm the new guy, I come in,
I'm here to save this project.

78
00:04:03.900 --> 00:04:07.760
And so they give me a report
that looks like this, okay.

79
00:04:07.760 --> 00:04:09.980
Looks like they do
reporting every two weeks.

80
00:04:09.980 --> 00:04:13.960
So we've got a report on January 15,
February 1st, February 15,

81
00:04:13.960 --> 00:04:16.020
March 1st,
its a little more than two weeks.

82
00:04:16.020 --> 00:04:19.534
But it's the 1st and 15th of every month,
I'm getting a status report.

83
00:04:19.534 --> 00:04:23.450
And on each status report they calculate
the earned value and the actual cost.

84
00:04:24.710 --> 00:04:28.390
Now these reports if I'm
gonna use this formula I've

85
00:04:28.390 --> 00:04:31.190
gotta have an earned value for
every actual cost.

86
00:04:31.190 --> 00:04:32.030
I have to have the same number.

87
00:04:32.030 --> 00:04:33.200
So I'm fortunate here.

88
00:04:33.200 --> 00:04:36.290
I've got four actual costs I've got four
EVs, they're for the same time period,

89
00:04:36.290 --> 00:04:37.830
this is accurate data.

90
00:04:37.830 --> 00:04:41.820
If one group like the accounting
department is doing actual cost and

91
00:04:41.820 --> 00:04:44.130
then the people in the field
are doing the earned value,

92
00:04:44.130 --> 00:04:46.830
you might have reports
from different dates, or

93
00:04:46.830 --> 00:04:49.330
you might have more of one report than
the another and that becomes a challenge.

94
00:04:49.330 --> 00:04:50.710
So you've got to do a little
data sanitation and

95
00:04:50.710 --> 00:04:52.460
make sure that things line up.

96
00:04:52.460 --> 00:04:55.790
The other thing is that there's
two ways to track this.

97
00:04:55.790 --> 00:04:57.803
Notice my earned value numbers here.

98
00:04:57.803 --> 00:05:02.448
20,500, then 38,000,
then 60,000, then 84,000.

99
00:05:02.448 --> 00:05:04.376
See how it's getting bigger each time?

100
00:05:04.376 --> 00:05:06.970
That's because more and
more work is getting done.

101
00:05:06.970 --> 00:05:12.880
These are actually already cumulative,
this 84,000 here is actually

102
00:05:12.880 --> 00:05:17.420
everything before it plus what
happened between February 16th and

103
00:05:17.420 --> 00:05:19.710
February 28th, or
29th if it's a leap year.

104
00:05:19.710 --> 00:05:21.690
Gotta factor that one it.

105
00:05:21.690 --> 00:05:23.870
So it's kinda already cumulative, and

106
00:05:23.870 --> 00:05:28.200
that's okay, as long as my actual
cost is that way also, right?

107
00:05:28.200 --> 00:05:28.714
And it is, see?

108
00:05:28.714 --> 00:05:33.525
22,000, 38,000, 65,000 but
let's say that the accounting

109
00:05:33.525 --> 00:05:37.442
department was saying,
you had 22,000 on January 15th.

110
00:05:37.442 --> 00:05:42.876
But then, what would it be,
16,000 is what you had up to February 1st.

111
00:05:42.876 --> 00:05:47.338
Right, 16,000 plus 22,000
gets us to 38,000, right, so

112
00:05:47.338 --> 00:05:50.490
that's the new expenses and
then so on like that.

113
00:05:50.490 --> 00:05:54.570
So if one has been tracked
per reporting period, and

114
00:05:54.570 --> 00:05:57.050
the other is cumulative,
that can screw up your numbers.

115
00:05:57.050 --> 00:05:59.560
So they need to either
both be cumulative or

116
00:05:59.560 --> 00:06:02.490
they need to both be per reporting period.

117
00:06:02.490 --> 00:06:05.110
And it's up to your company to
decide which one you're gonna do.

118
00:06:05.110 --> 00:06:08.420
As far as calculating out your CPI,
all that matters is that they match.

119
00:06:08.420 --> 00:06:09.210
They just have to match.

120
00:06:09.210 --> 00:06:13.630
They have to be the same, either per
reporting period or cumulative already.

121
00:06:13.630 --> 00:06:18.620
Once you've determined that,
you can calculate out your cumulative CPI.

122
00:06:18.620 --> 00:06:21.430
Now they've calculated out the CPI for
each one.

123
00:06:21.430 --> 00:06:22.930
I don't necessarily care about that.

124
00:06:22.930 --> 00:06:27.710
I'm gonna ignore that because the
cumulative basically makes it where I sum

125
00:06:27.710 --> 00:06:32.220
up all my earned values and
I sum up all my actual costs and

126
00:06:32.220 --> 00:06:35.160
I plug that into the formula, right.

127
00:06:35.160 --> 00:06:36.820
So let's run through that process, right.

128
00:06:36.820 --> 00:06:39.480
If I take my earned value and
I sum that up.

129
00:06:39.480 --> 00:06:41.600
Well, I'm gonna need a little
calculator help on this one so

130
00:06:41.600 --> 00:06:42.903
let me get my trusty calculator out.

131
00:06:42.903 --> 00:06:45.830
And so we'll take 20,500.

132
00:06:45.830 --> 00:06:51.036
And I'm gonna add to that $38,000 and
I'm gonna add to that $60,000 and

133
00:06:51.036 --> 00:06:54.370
I'm gonna add to that $84,000, okay?

134
00:06:54.370 --> 00:06:56.231
And I get $202,500.

135
00:06:56.231 --> 00:07:00.364
Now, I haven't spent $202,500, right?

136
00:07:00.364 --> 00:07:03.003
The accounting department is actually
telling me, as of March 1st,

137
00:07:03.003 --> 00:07:04.357
I've only spent $80,000.

138
00:07:04.357 --> 00:07:07.540
But I'm okay with that because I
know this is a cumulative value.

139
00:07:07.540 --> 00:07:08.990
Because that's the way it was given to me.

140
00:07:08.990 --> 00:07:11.700
It doesn't have to be that way but
that's how it is.

141
00:07:11.700 --> 00:07:15.960
So I'm gonna take 202,500 and
just plug that in here.

142
00:07:15.960 --> 00:07:18.811
All right and I'm okay with that
being cumulative because my actual

143
00:07:18.811 --> 00:07:20.020
costs are cumulative also.

144
00:07:20.020 --> 00:07:22.200
And you can see where I could
convert these if I needed to.

145
00:07:22.200 --> 00:07:26.390
I could go in and subtract out and
convert them to per period if I need it.

146
00:07:26.390 --> 00:07:30.303
But for the numbers that I've got here,
let me just go through and add these up.

147
00:07:30.303 --> 00:07:38.087
So 22,000 plus 38,000
plus 65,000 plus 80,000.

148
00:07:38.087 --> 00:07:41.587
Gives me $205,000.

149
00:07:41.587 --> 00:07:44.080
So it looks like whatever I get
it's not gonna be that off.

150
00:07:44.080 --> 00:07:46.463
Right, this is gonna be
a fairly good project.

151
00:07:46.463 --> 00:07:47.926
So I get $205,000.

152
00:07:47.926 --> 00:07:52.725
Now, all I have to do is take these two
numbers and run them through my formula,

153
00:07:52.725 --> 00:07:55.293
the same formula that we've been using.

154
00:07:55.293 --> 00:07:59.950
So I take my earned value, $202,500 And

155
00:07:59.950 --> 00:08:05.175
I divide that by my actual cost $205,000,
and

156
00:08:05.175 --> 00:08:10.211
I get 0.987 which I
would round up to 0.99.

157
00:08:10.211 --> 00:08:12.560
0.99, okay.

158
00:08:12.560 --> 00:08:16.370
Now, if I just came into
this project today and

159
00:08:16.370 --> 00:08:19.550
I just pulled the latest
report from March 1st, right?

160
00:08:19.550 --> 00:08:21.700
The latest report shows me at 1.05.

161
00:08:21.700 --> 00:08:24.430
I'm 5% over.

162
00:08:24.430 --> 00:08:27.180
Right, so I'm spending too much.

163
00:08:27.180 --> 00:08:33.096
Right, I've earned $84,000,
and I've spent $80,000.

164
00:08:33.096 --> 00:08:38.058
I'm actually under budget in this case,
so I haven't spent enough, but

165
00:08:38.058 --> 00:08:42.140
I can see that historically,
I'm 1% over budget.

166
00:08:42.140 --> 00:08:45.560
So while I look like I'm ahead,
I actually have a little of a deficit now.

167
00:08:45.560 --> 00:08:48.920
To be honest with you guys, 5%,
1% here is not that big of a deal.

168
00:08:48.920 --> 00:08:50.930
This is a good healthy project, right.

169
00:08:50.930 --> 00:08:54.210
So I'm not too worried about it,
but there have been hiccups.

170
00:08:54.210 --> 00:08:58.230
There had been times when we
are dead on with our CPI, but

171
00:08:58.230 --> 00:09:00.170
we got off to a rocky start, 7% off.

172
00:09:01.250 --> 00:09:06.220
And then we hit that rocky part again,
8% off, but now we have an overage and

173
00:09:06.220 --> 00:09:09.130
that can make it where we lose sight
of the fact that we had a couple of bad

174
00:09:09.130 --> 00:09:10.820
reporting periods back there.

175
00:09:10.820 --> 00:09:13.710
The cumulative CPI helps us see that, so

176
00:09:13.710 --> 00:09:16.450
now I get a more realistic
view of that project.

177
00:09:18.430 --> 00:09:22.480
Now, on the exam you might be tempted
to just add up all your CPIs and

178
00:09:22.480 --> 00:09:23.255
take the average of them.

179
00:09:23.255 --> 00:09:24.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right,

180
00:09:24.120 --> 00:09:27.050
which in theory would get you the same
number, but it actually doesn't.

181
00:09:27.050 --> 00:09:29.340
It gets you close, and
it's because these numbers are rounded.

182
00:09:29.340 --> 00:09:31.020
So you'd have actually
have to have the true,

183
00:09:31.020 --> 00:09:34.990
full laid out decimal points to be able
to get the right number going that way.

184
00:09:34.990 --> 00:09:39.010
So in the exam if they give you the CPI
like that, don't just total those up.

185
00:09:39.010 --> 00:09:40.400
Generate your own.

186
00:09:40.400 --> 00:09:43.430
Unless you know that they're accurate
all the way to the decimal point, or

187
00:09:43.430 --> 00:09:46.900
if you look at the multiple choice
answers, and the answers are all kind of

188
00:09:46.900 --> 00:09:51.000
in the same, are far enough apart that you
know which one it is without rounding,

189
00:09:51.000 --> 00:09:53.550
then you can go that route, but I usually
go ahead and pull them up myself.

190
00:09:55.950 --> 00:10:01.450
They might even give you a chart like
this where the CPI field is blank, but

191
00:10:01.450 --> 00:10:03.830
again, you don't need the CPIs for
each individual period.

192
00:10:03.830 --> 00:10:05.380
You don't care about that, right?

193
00:10:05.380 --> 00:10:08.970
So you can just leave that out and
just jump right down here.

194
00:10:08.970 --> 00:10:12.630
Sum these guys up and then calculate
your CPI, your cumulative CPI.

195
00:10:12.630 --> 00:10:14.417
That's all you care about.
You don't necessarily care about

196
00:10:14.417 --> 00:10:15.970
the individual CPIs for each one.

197
00:10:15.970 --> 00:10:17.450
It's nice to see that, and

198
00:10:17.450 --> 00:10:19.480
if you have project management
software it will calculate it for you.

199
00:10:19.480 --> 00:10:20.660
You'll have that, right?

200
00:10:20.660 --> 00:10:23.840
But on the exam,
answer the question they ask.

201
00:10:23.840 --> 00:10:26.200
Not some question that
you create in your head.

202
00:10:26.200 --> 00:10:30.160
They're not asking me for the CPI of
each individual one, they're asking me

203
00:10:30.160 --> 00:10:33.750
to get a good picture of the financial
health of the project, right?

204
00:10:33.750 --> 00:10:37.360
I don't need to know each individual
period CPI when I can just pull up

205
00:10:37.360 --> 00:10:41.340
the cumulative and get a good view of the
financial health of the project, right?

206
00:10:41.340 --> 00:10:42.296
So let's run through
this one really quick.

207
00:10:42.296 --> 00:10:43.876
These are slightly bigger numbers.

208
00:10:43.876 --> 00:10:50.475
If I take $120,000, and we'll add 200,000,

209
00:10:50.475 --> 00:10:57.458
and then 350,000, and
then 400,000, all right?

210
00:10:57.458 --> 00:11:03.500
So that's 1.07 million, so
let's hope that fits in here.

211
00:11:03.500 --> 00:11:04.390
It does.
All right, so

212
00:11:04.390 --> 00:11:10.440
there's our cumulative earned value, and
now let's take my cumulative actual cost.

213
00:11:10.440 --> 00:11:14.650
So I'm gonna take 100,000,
and we'll add on 190,000.

214
00:11:14.650 --> 00:11:19.878
We'll add on 300,000, and
we'll add on 375,000.

215
00:11:19.878 --> 00:11:25.203
So we're at $965,000, and
now we can just take those values and

216
00:11:25.203 --> 00:11:28.210
feed them into our formula, right.

217
00:11:28.210 --> 00:11:32.057
So it's gonna be $1,070,000.

218
00:11:34.882 --> 00:11:35.882
Come on, what have I done.

219
00:11:37.780 --> 00:11:41.771
There we go.
Divided by $965,000, and

220
00:11:41.771 --> 00:11:46.621
I get a 1.108, so I round it up to 1.11.

221
00:11:46.621 --> 00:11:49.390
So this is a 1.11.

222
00:11:49.390 --> 00:11:54.162
All right, and so looking at this
I've earned more value than I've paid

223
00:11:54.162 --> 00:11:56.300
