gonna work with every day, and that makes

447
00:24:05.540 --> 00:24:08.210
it even harder for the exam, cuz now
you've gotta make sure you know it.

448
00:24:08.210 --> 00:24:10.700
You might have 20 years of
project management experience and

449
00:24:10.700 --> 00:24:11.760
just not do these by hand.

450
00:24:11.760 --> 00:24:13.665
So just practice with it, get used to it.

451
00:24:13.665 --> 00:24:19.066
Remember the formula is really the same as
what we had for our regular CPI and SPI.

452
00:24:19.066 --> 00:24:20.810
We're just totaling up the values for
each reporting period.

453
00:24:20.810 --> 00:24:24.010
>> All right that's a great place for
us to go ahead and end this episode.

454
00:24:24.010 --> 00:24:26.570
Signing off for ITPro TV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

455
00:24:26.570 --> 00:24:31.636
>> And I'm Don Pezet and
we'll see you next time.

456
00:24:31.636 --> 00:24:37.000
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don dive into schedule and budget forecasting formulas.  They begin by addressing the issue of using an ETC, estimate to completion formula.  We learn why we would use it and how you’re likely to see it on the exam.  Don also then shows us that result of this formula is helpful when determining the TCPI, To Completion Cost Performance Index.  Using these formulas will help us to forecast what we expect to need in comparison to the Budget at Completion (BAC).  They also can show us that we can use the TCPI to forecast based on current rate of expenditures.
episodes.title: Forecasting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.042 --> 00:00:10.042
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.371 --> 00:00:15.210
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro TV.

3
00:00:15.210 --> 00:00:18.920
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and
today we're taking a look at the PMP.

4
00:00:18.920 --> 00:00:22.340
The project management professional, and
we're specifically gonna be looking at

5
00:00:22.340 --> 00:00:27.000
a few formulas, but this time we're not
only looking at formulas about the past or

6
00:00:27.000 --> 00:00:27.800
even about the present.

7
00:00:27.800 --> 00:00:30.980
What we're actually looking at
of course is about forecasting.

8
00:00:30.980 --> 00:00:33.270
And who better to help us out than Mr.
Don Pezet.

9
00:00:33.270 --> 00:00:34.380
Don, how's it going?

10
00:00:34.380 --> 00:00:35.500
>> It is going great, Ronnie.

11
00:00:35.500 --> 00:00:38.370
Ready to jump into our episode
on Groundhogs day, right?

12
00:00:38.370 --> 00:00:42.570
We're gonna predict the future and
see what the weather's gonna be like.

13
00:00:42.570 --> 00:00:46.120
Well not the weather temperature wise but
the weather financially and

14
00:00:46.120 --> 00:00:48.420
schedule wise inside of our projects.

15
00:00:48.420 --> 00:00:49.840
When we run these formulas,

16
00:00:49.840 --> 00:00:52.810
the whole thing is they really
act as a status report.

17
00:00:52.810 --> 00:00:54.510
How's my project doing?

18
00:00:54.510 --> 00:00:56.690
Well you can see how you're
project's doing right now.

19
00:00:56.690 --> 00:00:58.490
You can see how you project
was doing in the past.

20
00:00:58.490 --> 00:01:00.500
We've seen plenty of formulas for that.

21
00:01:00.500 --> 00:01:04.220
But taking that data and applying it
to the future is what really matters.

22
00:01:04.220 --> 00:01:08.710
To say, if I stay on my current course,
how's this gonna end?

23
00:01:08.710 --> 00:01:11.860
Is my project gonna come in on schedule,
on budget?

24
00:01:11.860 --> 00:01:13.080
Am I gonna meet my requirements?

25
00:01:13.080 --> 00:01:14.550
Well, the requirements, that's easy.

26
00:01:14.550 --> 00:01:17.220
You got a checklist of requirements
to follow, and you're done.

27
00:01:17.220 --> 00:01:21.250
But the schedule and
the budget are constantly changing

28
00:01:21.250 --> 00:01:24.200
items based on the performance
reports you're getting from the field.

29
00:01:24.200 --> 00:01:28.510
So we've got a collection of formulas
that we can use that help us see that

30
00:01:28.510 --> 00:01:29.400
future, right?

31
00:01:29.400 --> 00:01:31.860
And it's not 100% foolproof, right?

32
00:01:31.860 --> 00:01:36.860
A lot of these formulas you guys will see
are a little bit, kind of assuming, right?

33
00:01:36.860 --> 00:01:39.430
They assume certain
things are gonna happen.

34
00:01:39.430 --> 00:01:43.090
And so in some cases,
we'll have a formula where they might be

35
00:01:43.090 --> 00:01:47.060
more than one variation
of that same formula.

36
00:01:47.060 --> 00:01:49.450
And it's because of different
conditions that can affect it.

37
00:01:49.450 --> 00:01:53.870
So this is not a be all end all,
here's what the future is going to be.

38
00:01:53.870 --> 00:01:56.820
But it's a most likely
scenario type situation.

39
00:01:56.820 --> 00:02:00.600
So you can say, boy, it looks like
I'm gonna come in behind schedule.

40
00:02:00.600 --> 00:02:03.340
So I need to start taking
action now to fix that

41
00:02:03.340 --> 00:02:06.300
before I actually am behind schedule,
and I can't recover.

42
00:02:06.300 --> 00:02:08.340
That's what these formulas are all about.

43
00:02:08.340 --> 00:02:10.340
And so that's we're gonna get
a chance to see right here.

44
00:02:10.340 --> 00:02:13.989
>> So Don, when we talk of these types of
formulas for forecasting, is it something

45
00:02:13.989 --> 00:02:17.264
that we necessarily have to do, or
is this something like what you said,

46
00:02:17.264 --> 00:02:20.540
were you're just assuming that you
may becoming in under schedule, and

47
00:02:20.540 --> 00:02:22.200
that's when we need it?

48
00:02:22.200 --> 00:02:24.560
>> So you don't have to do anything,
I suppose.

49
00:02:24.560 --> 00:02:28.100
It's the difference between a good project
manager and a bad project manager, right?

50
00:02:28.100 --> 00:02:29.870
You don't have to do anything.

51
00:02:29.870 --> 00:02:34.020
But with these formulas, I use them a lot
in a couple of different scenarios.

52
00:02:34.020 --> 00:02:38.060
So, if it's my project and
I've been managing it from day one,

53
00:02:38.060 --> 00:02:40.100
I don't normally need these formulas.

54
00:02:40.100 --> 00:02:40.670
Alright.
And

55
00:02:40.670 --> 00:02:42.930
the reason is I know the trends
that we're following.

56
00:02:42.930 --> 00:02:44.400
I've been watching the status reports.

57
00:02:44.400 --> 00:02:47.280
I've been involved in that
project all along the way.

58
00:02:47.280 --> 00:02:47.990
I don't need this data.

59
00:02:47.990 --> 00:02:50.860
I've already got it because we
see the trends and the patterns.

60
00:02:52.100 --> 00:02:57.100
But if you're newly assigned to a project,
let's say it's a three year project, and

61
00:02:57.100 --> 00:03:00.840
a year into the project, that PM leaves
and goes to work for another company.

62
00:03:00.840 --> 00:03:04.320
You are hired on, and
you take over the helm of that project.

63
00:03:04.320 --> 00:03:04.850
Right?

64
00:03:04.850 --> 00:03:05.760
Well it's already a year in.

65
00:03:05.760 --> 00:03:07.370
You need to get up to speed.

66
00:03:07.370 --> 00:03:10.250
You need to see where you're going,
what those trends are, and

67
00:03:10.250 --> 00:03:11.890
these formulas help with that.

68
00:03:11.890 --> 00:03:13.770
Right?
So definitely useful for you,

69
00:03:13.770 --> 00:03:18.110
and then the other part where it;'s useful
is let's say that you answer to a PMO.

70
00:03:18.110 --> 00:03:19.700
This is the project management office, and

71
00:03:19.700 --> 00:03:22.710
they're monitoring a whole
portfolio of projects.

72
00:03:22.710 --> 00:03:25.280
Well hopefully they're
not micromanaging you.

73
00:03:25.280 --> 00:03:27.220
And so
they don't see the daily status reports.

74
00:03:27.220 --> 00:03:31.610
They don't see the trends, but they need a
way to measure the health of your project,

75
00:03:31.610 --> 00:03:33.700
and these formulas come in there too.

76
00:03:33.700 --> 00:03:37.510
So as a project manager, you may or
may not actually need these formulas.

77
00:03:37.510 --> 00:03:39.310
If you're new to the project you will.

78
00:03:39.310 --> 00:03:40.630
But if you're a PMO,

79
00:03:40.630 --> 00:03:44.300
if you're somebody else like in the
governance side of things, you'll need it.

80
00:03:44.300 --> 00:03:46.370
You'll need these numbers to
tell the health of that project.

81
00:03:46.370 --> 00:03:48.600
So definitely important.

82
00:03:48.600 --> 00:03:50.490
I guess the other thing is if
you're gonna take the exam,

83
00:03:50.490 --> 00:03:52.360
you need to know these numbers if
you wanna get the questions right.

84
00:03:52.360 --> 00:03:54.920
So there's a bit of that too,
but they are very useful.

85
00:03:54.920 --> 00:03:57.270
Most project management software
will generate these for you,

86
00:03:57.270 --> 00:04:00.910
which saves you a lot of time, but
we need to know how to do them by hand.

87
00:04:00.910 --> 00:04:03.830
>> Now Don, looking at the actual
different formulas that we're going

88
00:04:03.830 --> 00:04:07.900
to be going over It's hard for me to tell
which one we need to begin with first.

89
00:04:07.900 --> 00:04:09.460
So Don, where are we gonna begin?

90
00:04:09.460 --> 00:04:11.370
>> All right,
let's start off with an easy one.

91
00:04:11.370 --> 00:04:12.080
I'm gonna say easy.

92
00:04:12.080 --> 00:04:13.890
The formula actually looks a little scary.

93
00:04:13.890 --> 00:04:16.600
But it's called estimate to complete.

94
00:04:16.600 --> 00:04:19.955
Whenever you have an activity that's being
worked on, the activity has a budget,

95
00:04:19.955 --> 00:04:22.385
a certain amount of money
that you expect to expend.

96
00:04:22.385 --> 00:04:25.185
And we normally measure it in efforts,
so it's not just straight up money, but

97
00:04:25.185 --> 00:04:28.535
it's usually hours, how many man-hours or

98
00:04:28.535 --> 00:04:31.295
just labor hours have to go
into that particular activity.

99
00:04:31.295 --> 00:04:33.485
And we measure the percentage
complete on that.

100
00:04:33.485 --> 00:04:36.350
And we've seen these with our other
formulas and our other episodes.

101
00:04:36.350 --> 00:04:39.960
But what estimate to complete
does is it's a formula that says,

102
00:04:39.960 --> 00:04:42.920
okay, here's how much we've done so far.

103
00:04:42.920 --> 00:04:44.370
How much do I have left?

104
00:04:44.370 --> 00:04:45.070
Right?

105
00:04:45.070 --> 00:04:50.370
And if you've got a BAC, right, a budget
at completion, which you already have.

106
00:04:50.370 --> 00:04:51.450
You set that in the planning phase.

107
00:04:51.450 --> 00:04:53.370
Right?
You planned for a certain budget for

108
00:04:53.370 --> 00:04:55.190
this thing to have when it's completed.

109
00:04:55.190 --> 00:05:00.450
So, you have that BAC, but
if things are running over budget,

110
00:05:00.450 --> 00:05:04.340
or running under budget, or whatever, that
BAC is not necessarily accurate anymore.

111
00:05:04.340 --> 00:05:04.900
Is it?

112
00:05:04.900 --> 00:05:08.060
Right?
Because now we're off from that budget.

113
00:05:08.060 --> 00:05:12.140
And so an ETC, an estimate to complete,
tries to fill in that gap and say,

114
00:05:12.140 --> 00:05:14.110
all right,
here's what you've already spent.

115
00:05:14.110 --> 00:05:17.410
Here's how much more we're
going to need to finish it.

116
00:05:17.410 --> 00:05:17.960
Right?
And

117
00:05:17.960 --> 00:05:19.950
let me show you the estimate
to complete formula here.

118
00:05:19.950 --> 00:05:23.950
So basically, the way it works is
it's made up of a few components,

119
00:05:23.950 --> 00:05:25.960
the BAC, the budget and completion.

120
00:05:25.960 --> 00:05:27.850
Right?
We definitely have to have that.

121
00:05:27.850 --> 00:05:29.070
The earned value.

122
00:05:29.070 --> 00:05:31.960
Now the earned value, notice is EVc.

123
00:05:31.960 --> 00:05:34.830
This is the cumulative earned value.

124
00:05:34.830 --> 00:05:37.480
So if the activities been going on for
three weeks,

125
00:05:37.480 --> 00:05:39.600
it's not just the earned value for
this reporting period.

126
00:05:39.600 --> 00:05:41.710
It would be the earned value for
all three weeks.

127
00:05:41.710 --> 00:05:43.420
Right?
So we might need to add that up, or

128
00:05:43.420 --> 00:05:45.920
if we've been tracking it in a cumulative
manor, we've already got that.

129
00:05:45.920 --> 00:05:46.430
Right?

130
00:05:46.430 --> 00:05:48.490
So I need my cumulative earned value.

131
00:05:48.490 --> 00:05:53.630
And then I need to divide
that by my cumulative CPI.

132
00:05:53.630 --> 00:05:55.410
And we covered that in another episode.

133
00:05:55.410 --> 00:05:56.150
Right?

134
00:05:56.150 --> 00:05:58.250
Our cost performance index.

135
00:05:58.250 --> 00:06:01.680
And not just the cost performance index
for the last reporting period, but

136
00:06:01.680 --> 00:06:04.300
the cumulative one for
the all of the reporting periods

137
00:06:04.300 --> 00:06:06.470
which we may have been tracking
that way or we may not have.

138
00:06:06.470 --> 00:06:09.730
But if I have the cumulative value,
then I'm going to be dividing by that.

139
00:06:09.730 --> 00:06:14.380
So we take the budget, which is basically
what we planned on spending, and

140
00:06:14.380 --> 00:06:16.790
then we subtract what we've earned.

141
00:06:16.790 --> 00:06:17.800
And so what's left?

142
00:06:17.800 --> 00:06:22.194
Well, whatever's left, in theory,
is how much more money we need to spend.

143
00:06:22.194 --> 00:06:23.502
Right?
We need to spend, so

144
00:06:23.502 --> 00:06:27.142
let's say our budget at completion
is $5,000, and our earned value so

145
00:06:27.142 --> 00:06:31.678
far is $3,000, so we plan on spending
$5,000, so far we've spent $3,000.

146
00:06:31.678 --> 00:06:34.970
If I subtract $3,000 from $5,000,
I get $2,000 left.

147
00:06:34.970 --> 00:06:37.887
So in theory, I gotta pay $2,000 more.

148
00:06:37.887 --> 00:06:41.400
But what if I'm under budget or
over budget?

149
00:06:41.400 --> 00:06:44.620
Well, CPI will bring that into effect.

150
00:06:44.620 --> 00:06:45.420
Right?

151
00:06:45.420 --> 00:06:50.670
If I'm over budget, lets say my CPI
is like 1.2 and I'm over budget.

152
00:06:50.670 --> 00:06:54.350
Well I'm sorry other way around,
by point eight and I'm over budget.

153
00:06:54.350 --> 00:07:01.180
So if I take this $2,000 and I divide it
by that number, whatever my CPI is, that

154
00:07:01.180 --> 00:07:05.570
will correct it to make it more accurate
to reflect where I am budget wise.

155
00:07:05.570 --> 00:07:07.850
So factoring in that CPI
is pretty important,

156
00:07:07.850 --> 00:07:10.700
and that's what is going to
make things kind of go in line.

157
00:07:10.700 --> 00:07:13.650
Now here's one of the examples
of where our formula might have

158
00:07:13.650 --> 00:07:14.970
two different versions.

159
00:07:14.970 --> 00:07:15.840
Right?

160
00:07:15.840 --> 00:07:19.270
With the first version,
the one that you're most likely to use,

161
00:07:19.270 --> 00:07:22.940
with this version you're assuming
that everything's staying the same.

162
00:07:22.940 --> 00:07:26.675
That if I was over budget,
I'm gonna continue to be over budget.

163
00:07:26.675 --> 00:07:27.390
Right?

164
00:07:27.390 --> 00:07:30.270
And if you're new to the project,
if you're just coming in and

165
00:07:30.270 --> 00:07:31.760
doing a health test,
that's what you normally want.

166
00:07:31.760 --> 00:07:35.030
So this is the most common
form of the formula.

167
00:07:35.030 --> 00:07:39.040
But let's say that you just
took corrective action.

168
00:07:39.040 --> 00:07:42.100
You just stepped in and
made a big change in the project.

169
00:07:42.100 --> 00:07:44.290
And so
while you might have been over budget,

170
00:07:44.290 --> 00:07:46.980
you know that from now on
you're gonna be on budget.

171
00:07:46.980 --> 00:07:48.020
Right?

172
00:07:48.020 --> 00:07:52.928
If you just took corrective action, then
this CPI is just gonna skew your numbers.

173
00:07:52.928 --> 00:07:56.468
It's gonna show you as being off in
the future, even though you just fixed it.

174
00:07:56.468 --> 00:08:00.728
So if you know you've fixed things,
then you know conditions are gonna change.

175
00:08:00.728 --> 00:08:04.608
Right, and so at that point you
can just leave the CPI off.

176
00:08:04.608 --> 00:08:06.510
Don't even factor in the CPI.

177
00:08:06.510 --> 00:08:10.250
And just do budget at completion minus
that cumulative earned value, and

178
00:08:10.250 --> 00:08:12.050
now you get that estimate to complete.

179
00:08:12.050 --> 00:08:14.720
How much money you need to
complete this activity, right?

180
00:08:14.720 --> 00:08:17.050
So, two different variations here.

181
00:08:17.050 --> 00:08:19.160
And the way you know which to use.

182
00:08:19.160 --> 00:08:21.370
Well, in real life,
you'll typically use this one.

183
00:08:21.370 --> 00:08:25.570
But if you know conditions are changing,
then you use the second one, right.

184
00:08:25.570 --> 00:08:26.659
And you've gotta know both for the exam.

185
00:08:26.659 --> 00:08:30.272
And in the word problem they give you,
they'll give you the hints that tell you

186
00:08:30.272 --> 00:08:33.580
which one you need to use, right,
whether things are changing or not.

187
00:08:34.670 --> 00:08:35.780
Now let's look at an example of this.

188
00:08:35.780 --> 00:08:37.770
So here's an example.

189
00:08:37.770 --> 00:08:40.840
And it's telling us you're a project
team member responsible for

190
00:08:40.840 --> 00:08:46.510
Work Breakdown Structure Activity 4.1.1,
which has an assigned budget of $250,000.

191
00:08:46.510 --> 00:08:50.640
Your project manager has
requested an ETC for your task.

192
00:08:50.640 --> 00:08:51.230
Okay?

193
00:08:51.230 --> 00:08:52.919
So we need to get that
estimate to complete it.

194
00:08:52.919 --> 00:08:54.529
The project manager's come to us and said,

195
00:08:54.529 --> 00:08:57.890
how much more money does it look like
we're gonna spend to get this thing done?

196
00:08:57.890 --> 00:08:58.620
We've got a budget.

197
00:08:58.620 --> 00:09:00.090
We know what that is, right?

198
00:09:00.090 --> 00:09:00.808
We've got a budget of $250,000.

199
00:09:00.808 --> 00:09:03.666
But they want to know,
at our current trajectory,

200
00:09:03.666 --> 00:09:08.750
how much more are we gonna need to finish
this based on what we've spent so far.

201
00:09:08.750 --> 00:09:11.070
And so these are our status
reports that we've got right here,

202
00:09:11.070 --> 00:09:15.350
I've got my earned values,
my actual costs, and my CPI, right.

203
00:09:15.350 --> 00:09:19.069
So looking at it so far, you can see
this activity is kinda varied a bit.

204
00:09:19.069 --> 00:09:24.046
I've got four reporting periods here,
January 15th, February 1st, February 15th,

205
00:09:24.046 --> 00:09:25.470
March 1st.

206
00:09:25.470 --> 00:09:30.488
And In January, my CPI was at 0.93,
then I went to a 1.0.

207
00:09:30.488 --> 00:09:32.080
I was right on budget.

208
00:09:32.080 --> 00:09:32.940
That's perfect.

209
00:09:32.940 --> 00:09:34.958
Then I went back to a 0.92,
then up to a 1.05.

210
00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.098
I mean, we're all over the place.

211
00:09:37.098 --> 00:09:40.270
We're over budget,
we're under budget, things fluctuate.

212
00:09:40.270 --> 00:09:41.650
But that's pretty realistic.

213
00:09:41.650 --> 00:09:42.500
Projects do that.

214
00:09:42.500 --> 00:09:45.723
Now, some of these are pretty large,
like a 0.08.

215
00:09:45.723 --> 00:09:47.840
That's an 8% budget offset.

216
00:09:47.840 --> 00:09:49.110
That's kind of significant.

217
00:09:50.520 --> 00:09:53.940
But it's not super critical
danger zone yet, right.

00:09:53.940 --> 00:09:55.000
Like, alarms aren't going off.

I know that the odds are I'm gonna finish

00:10:02.160 --> 00:10:05.640

00:10:05.640 --> 00:10:10.080
But if my budget's $250,000 and these are

00:10:10.080 --> 00:10:14.460

00:10:23.310 --> 00:10:27.820
So we have to assume the conditions

00:10:27.820 --> 00:10:33.720
It's not saying in here, you just

There's no change associated with this.

00:10:43.070 --> 00:10:46.110
So I know I'm not gonna use
the smaller version of the formula,

00:10:46.110 --> 00:10:48.720
I'm gonna factor in my CPI, okay?

237
00:10:48.720 --> 00:10:50.922
And looking at this,
we've got our budgeted completion,

00:10:50.922 --> 00:10:52.250
which I know is $250,000.

00:10:52.250 --> 00:10:56.090
And then my cumulative earned value.

00:10:56.090 --> 00:10:59.152
And if we look at the way this

accumulated earned value, where it's

242
00:11:03.010 --> 00:11:05.718
So looking at this one,

00:11:05.718 --> 00:11:06.430
It was 20,500,

00:11:06.430 --> 00:11:11.054
then we went up to 38,000, then we went

00:11:11.054 --> 00:11:14.420
So we're steadily gaining in

So by March 1st, this is our cumulative

247
00:11:19.690 --> 00:11:23.100
If these were earned values for the

need to add all these together to

249
00:11:27.320 --> 00:11:29.727
Okay, so it just depends on how this
report's been given to me, whether or

00:11:29.727 --> 00:11:31.158
not I'm going to have to add those up or

251
00:11:31.158 --> 00:11:34.790
And in this scenario,
we can see they're already added up.

252
00:11:34.790 --> 00:11:38.180
So my actual cost at this stage is 80,000.

253
00:11:38.180 --> 00:11:41.240
My earned value is 84,000,
and that's cumulative for

00:11:41.240 --> 00:11:43.860
the entire series of activities, right?

255
00:11:43.860 --> 00:11:48.780
And my current CPI is 1.05, and
that's calculated off of these, so

256
00:11:48.780 --> 00:11:51.860
that's my cumulative CPI also, all right?

257
00:11:51.860 --> 00:11:53.470
If these were individual
reporting periods,

00:11:53.470 --> 00:11:55.730
one of the easiest ways to do

259
00:11:55.730 --> 00:11:58.840
Add them up, and then you've got your

00:11:58.840 --> 00:12:01.719
All right, except for CPI,

00:12:01.719 --> 00:12:05.870
All right, so then we just plug

262
00:12:05.870 --> 00:12:07.090
Right?
Not too big of a deal.

263
00:12:07.090 --> 00:12:10.550
I'm gonna get rid of this bottom
formula since I don't need it.

00:12:10.550 --> 00:12:14.220
And we'll replace that

265
00:12:14.220 --> 00:12:17.970
So if I have my ETC is going

00:12:17.970 --> 00:12:19.960
which we know is $250,000.

00:12:19.960 --> 00:12:20.574
Right?
And

00:12:20.574 --> 00:12:25.580
I'm gonna subtract out my cumulative

00:12:25.580 --> 00:12:26.210
All right.

00:12:26.210 --> 00:12:28.740
And then I'm gonna divide that by my CPI.

00:12:29.820 --> 00:12:33.270
And that is gonna give me

272
00:12:33.270 --> 00:12:37.170
Now, let's assume that I

273
00:12:37.170 --> 00:12:40.680
that we did just make a change and

274
00:12:40.680 --> 00:12:42.650
We're gonna have a CPI of effectively one.

275
00:12:43.930 --> 00:12:45.950
Any number divided by
one is just the number.

276
00:12:45.950 --> 00:12:49.150
And so that's why CPI gets left
off from that simple formula.

277
00:12:49.150 --> 00:12:56.639
And if we work out the math on this,
where's my calculator, here.

278
00:12:56.639 --> 00:13:00.608
If we take 250,000 minus 84,000, assuming
that everything was going the way that

279
00:13:00.608 --> 00:13:03.940
it's supposed to, we're gonna need
$166,000 more to complete this.

280
00:13:03.940 --> 00:13:05.349
That's my estimate to complete.

281
00:13:06.350 --> 00:13:11.090
But if I factor in my CPI of 1.05, and so

282
00:13:11.090 --> 00:13:17.760
I divide that by 1.05,
I end up at $158,095.

283
00:13:17.760 --> 00:13:18.990
It went down.

284
00:13:18.990 --> 00:13:19.630
Okay?

285
00:13:19.630 --> 00:13:23.810
And the reason is, my CPI shows
that I'm actually under budget.

286
00:13:23.810 --> 00:13:25.450
I'm coming in under budget, right.

287
00:13:25.450 --> 00:13:31.608
Anything over a 1 is under budget,
anything under a 1 is over budget.

288
00:13:31.608 --> 00:13:32.908
It's kind of the opposite
of what you'd think.

289
00:13:32.908 --> 00:13:36.328
So it drops to that $158,095.

290
00:13:36.328 --> 00:13:37.980
So that's gonna be my ETC.

291
00:13:37.980 --> 00:13:39.695
$158,095.

292
00:13:39.695 --> 00:13:44.899
So if I take that,
now what your project manager can do is,

293
00:13:44.899 --> 00:13:48.725
your project manager can say, all right,

294
00:13:48.725 --> 00:13:53.208
your estimate to complete is $158,095.

295
00:13:53.208 --> 00:13:55.940
To date, we've spent $80,000, right?

296
00:13:55.940 --> 00:14:00.030
And if we add those two together,
what do we get?

297
00:14:00.030 --> 00:14:03.110
Well, you'll actually see
something kinda interesting here.

298
00:14:03.110 --> 00:14:08.158
If I take a $158,095, oops,
[LAUGH] if I get in my calculator.

299
00:14:08.158 --> 00:14:12.959
If I take this number, and I'm gonna
add that to what I've spent today,

300
00:14:12.959 --> 00:14:14.778
which is $80,000.

301
00:14:14.778 --> 00:14:20.920
And so if I add $80,000,
I end up at $238,095.

302
00:14:20.920 --> 00:14:24.288
This activity is gonna cost me $238,095,

303
00:14:24.288 --> 00:14:27.750
which is below my budget at completion,
right?

304
00:14:27.750 --> 00:14:29.240
So for some reason,

305
00:14:29.240 --> 00:14:32.530
we're gonna finish this activity
$12,000 cheaper than we thought.

306
00:14:33.580 --> 00:14:34.690
We need to find out why.

307
00:14:34.690 --> 00:14:35.958
Why is that?

308
00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.400
And it wasn't always like that.

309
00:14:37.400 --> 00:14:41.390
As we look at some of these earlier
reports here, there were times where we

310
00:14:41.390 --> 00:14:45.410
were over budget, and so then we'd
get some number higher than $250,000.

311
00:14:45.410 --> 00:14:48.320
But right now we get that
estimate to complete, and

312
00:14:48.320 --> 00:14:49.751
we can tell the accounting department or
whoever,

313
00:14:49.751 --> 00:14:52.140
like, this is the amount of money that
we're still gonna need in order for

314
00:14:52.140 --> 00:14:52.950
this to finish up.

315
00:14:52.950 --> 00:14:54.260
So that's estimate to complete.

316
00:14:55.620 --> 00:14:56.880
All right, pretty straightforward formula.

317
00:14:56.880 --> 00:15:00.240
The hardest part is just
remembering which one to use.

318
00:15:00.240 --> 00:15:02.018
And just, that CPI.

319
00:15:02.018 --> 00:15:05.752
If you think about it, if your project
is doing exactly what it's supposed to,

320
00:15:05.752 --> 00:15:07.940
if you're on budget,
your CPI is gonna be 1.

321
00:15:07.940 --> 00:15:11.870
And any number divided by 1 is just that
number, so that value becomes useless.

322
00:15:11.870 --> 00:15:14.762
So if you just made change to
bring yourself back in level,

323
00:15:14.762 --> 00:15:16.128
you just leave the CPI off.

324
00:15:16.128 --> 00:15:20.569
Now, for the exam, you could just remember
the main formula, the long formula, and

325
00:15:20.569 --> 00:15:22.120
forget the short one.

326
00:15:22.120 --> 00:15:25.340
And then if they don't tell you a CPI,
you can just use a CPI of 1, and

327
00:15:25.340 --> 00:15:27.250
you effectively have the other formula.

328
00:15:27.250 --> 00:15:30.620
But really, you have one formula for
normal activities, and

329
00:15:30.620 --> 00:15:34.070
a separate formula for when things
have just been put right back online.

330
00:15:35.770 --> 00:15:41.160
All right, a similar formula
that's related to ETC is the TCPI.

331
00:15:41.160 --> 00:15:43.771
All right,
TCPI is the to complete performance index,

332
00:15:43.771 --> 00:15:45.970
let me bring it up here on the screen.

333
00:15:45.970 --> 00:15:49.370
So this is the to-complete
performance index.

334
00:15:49.370 --> 00:15:54.064
And the way this one work is very similar
to cost performance index or, you know,

335
00:15:54.064 --> 00:15:57.118
schedule performance index,
those guys, right.

336
00:15:57.118 --> 00:16:00.290
We just did ETC, the estimate to complete,
how much money we needed to finish.

337
00:16:00.290 --> 00:16:03.368
Well, TCPI is basically the same thing.

338
00:16:03.368 --> 00:16:08.860
Except it's an index instead of
being a straight up dollar sign.

339
00:16:08.860 --> 00:16:11.920
So it's kind of like when you
calculate cost variance, you know,

340
00:16:11.920 --> 00:16:15.630
what's the difference between where I'm
at now versus what I was planned for, or

341
00:16:15.630 --> 00:16:17.160
calculating CPI,

342
00:16:17.160 --> 00:16:20.650
where CPI gives you basically
a percentage of how far off you are.

343
00:16:20.650 --> 00:16:22.810
Well, the to-complete performance
index is the same thing.

344
00:16:22.810 --> 00:16:27.500
We get a percentage that shows us how
far off we are from where we should be.

345
00:16:27.500 --> 00:16:31.136
Now, just like with estimate to complete,

346
00:16:31.136 --> 00:16:35.278
we have two forms of the TCPI formula,
all right?

347
00:16:35.278 --> 00:16:38.440
One for when our budget at
complete is still valid, right,

348
00:16:38.440 --> 00:16:41.300
where our budget is still
what we expect to finish at.

349
00:16:41.300 --> 00:16:46.696
And other one where we may have decided
that the budget at complete is just dead,

350
00:16:46.696 --> 00:16:49.280
that we know we're not gonna be
able to meet that budget and so

351
00:16:49.280 --> 00:16:51.000
now we're working on something different,
right?

352
00:16:51.000 --> 00:16:53.190
Just, we're trying to figure
out where we're gonna end up.

353
00:16:53.190 --> 00:16:56.850
So two different formulas, but
they are very, very similar, all right?

354
00:16:56.850 --> 00:16:58.690
The way the formula works is this.

355
00:16:58.690 --> 00:17:02.890
We take our budget at completion and
we subtract our earned value, right?

356
00:17:02.890 --> 00:17:06.290
So the budget at completion,
whatever we planned on spending, and

357
00:17:06.290 --> 00:17:09.120
we subtract our earned value,
what we've already spent, right?

358
00:17:09.120 --> 00:17:10.880
Not the actual cost, though,
but the earned value, so

359
00:17:10.880 --> 00:17:12.450
we factor in some scheduling too.

360
00:17:12.450 --> 00:17:16.230
So we subtract that from the BAC and
you end up with a number, which is

361
00:17:16.230 --> 00:17:20.210
basically what we saw a moment ago with
the estimate to complete, right, the ETC.

362
00:17:20.210 --> 00:17:25.405
But then we divide that by the budget
at complete minus the actual cost.

363
00:17:25.405 --> 00:17:27.251
So now we take schedule
out of the picture, right?

364
00:17:27.251 --> 00:17:30.263
This is very similar to our
cost performance index,

365
00:17:30.263 --> 00:17:34.340
which was earned value divided
by actual cost, right?

366
00:17:34.340 --> 00:17:39.500
Now we're just subtracting that
from the budget at complete

367
00:17:39.500 --> 00:17:41.970
to figure out what's our to-complete.

368
00:17:41.970 --> 00:17:45.460
You know, how much more do we need to
finish, not just where we're at right now.

369
00:17:45.460 --> 00:17:48.500
So this is really just
a variation of the CPI formula.

370
00:17:48.500 --> 00:17:51.927
And this guy right here is really easy to
implement and then you get that index.

371
00:17:51.927 --> 00:17:54.023
And this is useful if we're
trying to measure it against

372
00:17:54.023 --> 00:17:55.100
other activities, right?

373
00:17:55.100 --> 00:17:57.840
Remember, the indexes are always
about comparing things.

374
00:17:57.840 --> 00:18:00.483
And when I wanna compare
more than one project,

375
00:18:00.483 --> 00:18:04.792
when I wanna compare more than one
activity, I don't wanna just use CV or SV.

376
00:18:04.792 --> 00:18:07.906
I don't wanna use those guys because
depending on the size of the project,

377
00:18:07.906 --> 00:18:09.590
those numbers get skewed.

378
00:18:09.590 --> 00:18:13.420
But an index, I can compare an index
between projects regardless of how

379
00:18:13.420 --> 00:18:15.200
different their budgets are and

380
00:18:15.200 --> 00:18:18.390
get a good idea of how they're
doing health-wise, all right?

381
00:18:18.390 --> 00:18:21.158
The problem with this, though,
is if our budget is shot.

382
00:18:21.158 --> 00:18:24.910
If we know that we're over budget,
and we're kind of in trouble,

383
00:18:24.910 --> 00:18:29.805
and we know we're over budget, and we say,
we've really gotta do a change ticket.

384
00:18:29.805 --> 00:18:33.085
We gotta request some more funding to
get this project back in line, right?

385
00:18:33.085 --> 00:18:36.460
And we do a change ticket,
we do an estimate to complete,

386
00:18:36.460 --> 00:18:39.430
we find out how much more money we're
gonna need, we do a change ticket,

387
00:18:39.430 --> 00:18:42.690
we submit it, we show the ETC we
calculated and why we need more money.

388
00:18:42.690 --> 00:18:46.020
If we get approved, the change goes in and

389
00:18:46.020 --> 00:18:49.560
the new budget becomes your BAC,
and now your BAC is valid.

390
00:18:49.560 --> 00:18:53.510
But for that window of time where you
know you've gotta do a change ticket,

391
00:18:53.510 --> 00:18:55.320
your BAC is not valid.

392
00:18:55.320 --> 00:18:58.890
And so when you calculate your TCPI,
it's gonna be wrong.

393
00:18:58.890 --> 00:19:03.810
It's not technically wrong,
it's just not terribly accurate, right?

394
00:19:03.810 --> 00:19:08.980
And so we can make it more
accurate if we throw out the BAC

395
00:19:08.980 --> 00:19:15.030
from the divisor here and swap that out
for something called an EAC, all right?

396
00:19:15.030 --> 00:19:18.410
Now, we saw ETC just a moment ago,
the estimate to complete.

397
00:19:18.410 --> 00:19:21.430
That's how much more money
we need to complete.

398
00:19:21.430 --> 00:19:24.840
But an EAC,
that's the estimate at completion.

399
00:19:24.840 --> 00:19:27.420
So in other words,
by the time we reach completion,

400
00:19:27.420 --> 00:19:29.690
how much money do we think
we'll have spent total?

401
00:19:29.690 --> 00:19:32.900
Estimate to complete is how much
more money we're gonna spend.

402
00:19:32.900 --> 00:19:35.410
EAC is how much total money
we're gonna spend, all right?

403
00:19:35.410 --> 00:19:37.402
And we haven't seen the EAC formula yet.

404
00:19:37.402 --> 00:19:39.370
We're gonna see that next.

405
00:19:39.370 --> 00:19:42.640
But basically it's just an updated BAC.

406
00:19:42.640 --> 00:19:45.340
It's a BAC that's more accurate for
the situation you're in.

407
00:19:45.340 --> 00:19:48.610
As soon as that change ticket goes in and
gets approved, you get a new BAC.

408
00:19:48.610 --> 00:19:51.210
And so you don't need the EAC anymore,
you just go back to the BAC.

409
00:19:51.210 --> 00:19:54.090
And so this is the formula
you're normally gonna use

410
00:19:54.090 --> 00:19:56.350
unless you're in that window of time
where you know you're in trouble.

411
00:19:56.350 --> 00:19:59.820
And you're planning for that support
change ticket to update things.

412
00:19:59.820 --> 00:20:01.830
That's when you use this variation,
all right?

413
00:20:01.830 --> 00:20:03.060
And that's the only change,

414
00:20:03.060 --> 00:20:05.700
is swapping from the BAC to
the EAC just for the accuracy.

415
00:20:05.700 --> 00:20:07.690
You still use BAC in the top part.

416
00:20:07.690 --> 00:20:09.930
You still use that budget
at completion minus EV.

417
00:20:09.930 --> 00:20:11.060
And the reason is,

418
00:20:11.060 --> 00:20:14.320
your earned value is calculated
against your budget at completion.

419
00:20:14.320 --> 00:20:18.200
If you swap if for the EAC, your earned
value is not calculated against an EAC and

420
00:20:18.200 --> 00:20:19.070
now that's not accurate.

421
00:20:19.070 --> 00:20:22.211
So that's why you've got to keep that
budget at completion up at the top,

422
00:20:22.211 --> 00:20:22.725
all right?

423
00:20:22.725 --> 00:20:24.238
So if we implement this,

424
00:20:24.238 --> 00:20:27.560
we can get a better picture
of how our project is going.

425
00:20:27.560 --> 00:20:31.414
And so here we've just got an example of,
you're a new project manager.

426
00:20:31.414 --> 00:20:35.199
You've been assigned to a project that
it's at risk and you need to salvage it,

427
00:20:35.199 --> 00:20:36.180
all right?

428
00:20:36.180 --> 00:20:38.720
There's five activities that
are going on right now, so

429
00:20:38.720 --> 00:20:42.140
five simultaneous activities that are all
in some various state of completion.

430
00:20:42.140 --> 00:20:45.980
There's stuff that's already done, there's
stuff that hasn't even been started yet.

431
00:20:45.980 --> 00:20:48.610
But these five are the activities
that are running right now.

432
00:20:48.610 --> 00:20:52.210
And the old project manager, on their way
out the door, they give you the project

433
00:20:52.210 --> 00:20:55.680
book, and you can see the latest status
reports on each of these activities.

434
00:20:55.680 --> 00:21:00.036
He gave you the earned value, the actual
cost, the budget at completion, and

435
00:21:00.036 --> 00:21:01.885
even an estimate at completion.

436
00:21:01.885 --> 00:21:04.957
Because they knew the project was in
trouble, that we were gonna need to

437
00:21:04.957 --> 00:21:08.360
take action, so they took the time to
calculate the EAC out for us, all right?

438
00:21:08.360 --> 00:21:10.170
Now, that doesn't always happen, and so

439
00:21:10.170 --> 00:21:12.880
we'll see how to calculate
EAC in a little bit.

440
00:21:12.880 --> 00:21:16.040
But for right now,
we've basically got that kind of out here.

441
00:21:16.040 --> 00:21:18.480
But what they didn't do is they
didn't give us a TCPI, and so
