we still haven't calculated that.

662
00:32:18.720 --> 00:32:20.220
So we'll see that in another episode.

663
00:32:20.220 --> 00:32:23.600
But those are kinda the key components
there and what you're gonna have to have.

664
00:32:23.600 --> 00:32:24.190
>> All right, so

665
00:32:24.190 --> 00:32:28.270
we're looking forward to actually taking
a look at that EAC in a future episode.

666
00:32:28.270 --> 00:32:31.110
That's a great place for
us to go and end this episode then.

667
00:32:31.110 --> 00:32:34.570
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong,
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

668
00:32:34.570 --> 00:32:35.730
>> And we'll see you next time.

669
00:32:35.730 --> 00:32:38.581
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Forecasting Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.533 --> 00:00:10.533
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.006 --> 00:00:15.100
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:15.100 --> 00:00:18.850
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today
we're gonna be taking a look at the PMP,

4
00:00:18.850 --> 00:00:21.350
the Project Management Professional.

5
00:00:21.350 --> 00:00:25.100
We're specifically gonna get
into the realm of forecasting.

6
00:00:25.100 --> 00:00:27.880
We've already taken a look at
a little bit of forecasting,

7
00:00:27.880 --> 00:00:29.700
talking about a couple
of different formulas.

8
00:00:29.700 --> 00:00:31.760
But that's when everything is going OK,
and

9
00:00:31.760 --> 00:00:33.660
you think that you can still reign it in.

10
00:00:33.660 --> 00:00:36.960
Sometimes though,
we need to actually go beyond that, and

11
00:00:36.960 --> 00:00:39.560
who better to help us, than Mr.
Don Pizet himself.

12
00:00:39.560 --> 00:00:40.440
How's it going Don?

13
00:00:40.440 --> 00:00:43.500
>> It's going great, Ronnie, ready to jump
right back in the world of forecasting,

14
00:00:43.500 --> 00:00:45.360
and if you haven't
watched the last episode,

15
00:00:45.360 --> 00:00:47.020
definitely check out our part one.

16
00:00:47.020 --> 00:00:48.690
This is part two to forecasting.

17
00:00:48.690 --> 00:00:51.820
And in that episode we talked
about some interesting formulas.

18
00:00:51.820 --> 00:00:56.430
And e saw estimate two complete and we did
a two complete performance index, a TCPI.

19
00:00:56.430 --> 00:00:59.780
And while we were doing the TCPI,
I mentioned a new value,

20
00:00:59.780 --> 00:01:01.230
I mentioned EAC, right?

21
00:01:01.230 --> 00:01:05.770
The estimate add completion and EAC is
an important one because it's estimating

22
00:01:05.770 --> 00:01:09.440
what you think your total budget is going
to be when an activity completes or

23
00:01:09.440 --> 00:01:10.910
when your whole project completes.

24
00:01:10.910 --> 00:01:14.230
So, that's important, but we hadn't
really looked at the formulas yet.

25
00:01:14.230 --> 00:01:16.080
In this episode,
we're gonna look at those formulas.

26
00:01:16.080 --> 00:01:18.660
And notice how I'm saying those formulas.

27
00:01:18.660 --> 00:01:20.160
EAC's a tricky one.

28
00:01:20.160 --> 00:01:23.930
There is one formula for EAC,
and we're gonna see that.

29
00:01:25.040 --> 00:01:28.680
But, like Ronnie said, if things aren't
going right, there's all sorts of

30
00:01:28.680 --> 00:01:31.440
conditions that can change, and
your EAC number becomes garbage.

31
00:01:31.440 --> 00:01:36.340
And so, there's actually three variations
of EAC that we can run through.

32
00:01:36.340 --> 00:01:40.180
And so at the end of the day,
there's four different formulas.

33
00:01:40.180 --> 00:01:40.970
Now on the exam,

34
00:01:40.970 --> 00:01:43.810
if they just give you some numbers and
tell you to calculate the EAC, then

35
00:01:43.810 --> 00:01:47.580
there really is just one formula you need
to remember, the main formula for EAC.

36
00:01:47.580 --> 00:01:50.820
But if they start giving you a story,
you know one of those word problems,

37
00:01:50.820 --> 00:01:54.610
where they start explaining a situation
that's going in on the project,

38
00:01:54.610 --> 00:01:58.750
well that's normally a hint to you
saying this is a variation and so

39
00:01:58.750 --> 00:02:01.340
you to use one of those variations of EAC.

40
00:02:01.340 --> 00:02:05.030
So were gonna take a look at each one but
let's just start with straight up EAC and

41
00:02:05.030 --> 00:02:06.150
how it worked.

42
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:07.290
The formula itself for

43
00:02:07.290 --> 00:02:10.560
EAC I've got it pulled here,
it's actually straight forward.

44
00:02:10.560 --> 00:02:14.050
It's basically saying if you wanna
estimate how much you're gonna spend at

45
00:02:14.050 --> 00:02:18.372
completion, well if your project is
going exactly the way it suppose to,

46
00:02:18.372 --> 00:02:21.300
then your EAC is simply
going to equal your BAC.

47
00:02:21.300 --> 00:02:22.820
Your budget at completion, your BAC,

48
00:02:22.820 --> 00:02:25.300
that's what you plan to
spend at completion.

49
00:02:25.300 --> 00:02:27.540
Your estimate at completion
should be the same thing.

50
00:02:27.540 --> 00:02:30.400
We estimate we're gonna finish
exactly what we plan, and that's that.

51
00:02:30.400 --> 00:02:31.910
You don't even need a formula for

52
00:02:31.910 --> 00:02:34.570
that if everything is going
the way it's supposed to.

53
00:02:34.570 --> 00:02:35.710
But if you're not sure,

54
00:02:35.710 --> 00:02:38.310
if you don't know things are going
the way there supposed to.

55
00:02:38.310 --> 00:02:40.320
You take your actual cost.

56
00:02:40.320 --> 00:02:42.300
So how much money have you spent so far?

57
00:02:42.300 --> 00:02:49.070
Whatever that actual cost is, and you
add to it what's called a Bottom Up ETC.

58
00:02:49.070 --> 00:02:50.800
Now we saw ETCs in the last episode,
right?

59
00:02:50.800 --> 00:02:52.040
Estimate to complete.

60
00:02:52.040 --> 00:02:55.049
How much more money we need to
spend to complete an activity.

61
00:02:56.300 --> 00:02:59.550
Well that estimate to complete
can be pretty accurate.

62
00:02:59.550 --> 00:03:00.060
We saw that.

63
00:03:00.060 --> 00:03:02.910
It can be inaccurate too and so
you have variations of ETC also.

64
00:03:02.910 --> 00:03:04.730
But it's normally pretty accurate.

65
00:03:04.730 --> 00:03:06.030
But what's a bottom up ETC?

66
00:03:07.130 --> 00:03:11.770
Well that means I have to go out to all
of my task holders, all the people who

67
00:03:11.770 --> 00:03:16.120
are doing the work on my project and I
have to get an ETC from every one of them.

68
00:03:16.120 --> 00:03:16.970
And it's bottom up.

69
00:03:16.970 --> 00:03:20.270
I start at the base layer of that
work breakdown structure, and

70
00:03:20.270 --> 00:03:21.540
I give an estimate to complete.

71
00:03:21.540 --> 00:03:23.410
And I move up to the next tier and
up to the next tier, and

72
00:03:23.410 --> 00:03:26.929
I consolidate it all down to a milestone,
or a deliverable.

73
00:03:26.929 --> 00:03:30.150
And I say, here's the estimate to complete
for this deliverable and this deliverable.

74
00:03:30.150 --> 00:03:33.680
And you add all that up to get your whole
project, if that's the way you're going.

75
00:03:33.680 --> 00:03:35.840
Or you can do this on
an individual activity.

76
00:03:35.840 --> 00:03:37.920
It's up to you,
how you want to measure that.

77
00:03:37.920 --> 00:03:42.530
But a bottom up ETC is where you
get an estimate to complete for

78
00:03:42.530 --> 00:03:46.680
every single activity that's
ongoing right now in your project.

79
00:03:46.680 --> 00:03:48.500
If you've got a small project,
that's no big deal.

80
00:03:48.500 --> 00:03:51.310
You just go and talk to a couple
of people and you get the numbers.

81
00:03:51.310 --> 00:03:55.250
But if you've got a massive project
involving thousands of people and

82
00:03:55.250 --> 00:03:59.100
numerous simultaneous tasks,
this can be pretty hard data to get.

83
00:03:59.100 --> 00:04:00.490
So sometimes you're in a hurry, and

84
00:04:00.490 --> 00:04:03.720
there's things that we can substitute
out instead of the this Bottom Up ETC.

85
00:04:03.720 --> 00:04:07.950
But the basic formula, the most important
one for you to remember, is that EAC

86
00:04:08.950 --> 00:04:14.080
equals your actual cost plus
a Bottom Up ETC for your project.

87
00:04:14.080 --> 00:04:15.610
So let's take a look at an example.

88
00:04:15.610 --> 00:04:16.600
Here I've got a project.

89
00:04:16.600 --> 00:04:19.050
Right.
And it says you are becoming concerned

90
00:04:19.050 --> 00:04:23.050
that your project may finish over
its 350 thousand dollar budget.

91
00:04:23.050 --> 00:04:24.850
So, right there I've got a BAC, right?

92
00:04:24.850 --> 00:04:27.320
My budget at completion
is 350 thousand dollars.

93
00:04:27.320 --> 00:04:30.515
You have requested ETCs for
all active tasks.

94
00:04:30.515 --> 00:04:34.230
I reached out to all my task workers and
I said give me your estimate to complete.

95
00:04:34.230 --> 00:04:37.910
We need to generate an EAC so that we can
report it to the primary stakeholders.

96
00:04:37.910 --> 00:04:40.480
We need to let them know what our
estimate at completion is gonna be.

97
00:04:40.480 --> 00:04:42.120
Hopefully it matches our budget.

98
00:04:43.260 --> 00:04:45.500
And so we've got the ETCs for
everything that's active.

99
00:04:45.500 --> 00:04:49.110
Now if I was just doing this for
a particular activity that's all I need.

100
00:04:49.110 --> 00:04:52.180
But if I want the project as
a whole I need to remember

101
00:04:52.180 --> 00:04:54.590
that there's activities that
have already completed.

102
00:04:54.590 --> 00:04:56.850
I don't need an ETC from somebody
that's already completed.

103
00:04:56.850 --> 00:04:57.680
I don't need an estimate.

104
00:04:57.680 --> 00:04:58.870
I have the factual data.

105
00:04:58.870 --> 00:05:00.560
So I go and get my actual cost for
that, right?

106
00:05:00.560 --> 00:05:02.360
So here's my project cost to date.

107
00:05:02.360 --> 00:05:07.790
And my budget for activities that haven't
even started, I don't need an ETC for

108
00:05:07.790 --> 00:05:11.080
something that hasn't even started,
because I just use the plan.

109
00:05:11.080 --> 00:05:12.770
Whatever's in the plan is
what I'm gonna go with.

110
00:05:12.770 --> 00:05:15.410
So there's stuff outside
of what's currently active.

111
00:05:15.410 --> 00:05:19.680
But here's the four activities for me
that are currently active right now, and

112
00:05:19.680 --> 00:05:21.470
their estimate to completes.

113
00:05:21.470 --> 00:05:26.030
So when I wanna find out my EAC,
my estimate at completion,

114
00:05:26.030 --> 00:05:30.009
I need to take my actual cost,
what I've spent so far, and

115
00:05:30.009 --> 00:05:36.890
a bottom up ETC from everybody else
that's out there, and add them together.

116
00:05:36.890 --> 00:05:38.722
My actual cost is $200 thousand.

117
00:05:38.722 --> 00:05:41.469
I've actually spent $200
thousand at this point.

118
00:05:42.630 --> 00:05:46.640
Then I need by Bottom-Up ETCs, my
estimates to complete for everybody else.

119
00:05:46.640 --> 00:05:50.666
Well, I've got my estimates
to complete right here.

120
00:05:50.666 --> 00:05:51.560
7,000, 2,000, 24,000, 3,000.

121
00:05:51.560 --> 00:05:53.810
Now notice, they're not telling
me what their costs are.

122
00:05:53.810 --> 00:05:56.230
I don't know their earned values or
actual costs.

123
00:05:56.230 --> 00:05:58.540
Well, we've got Project Costs to Date.

124
00:05:58.540 --> 00:05:59.250
That's my whole project.

125
00:05:59.250 --> 00:06:03.350
That would include the expenses that
I've already spent on these activities.

126
00:06:03.350 --> 00:06:06.970
This is my ETC,
what they're gonna need past that, right?

127
00:06:06.970 --> 00:06:11.803
But what about this over here, budget for
activities that haven't even begun yet?

128
00:06:11.803 --> 00:06:14.660
Well we count those as ETCs.

129
00:06:14.660 --> 00:06:16.500
Those are estimates to complete.

130
00:06:16.500 --> 00:06:17.440
They are estimates, right?

131
00:06:17.440 --> 00:06:18.550
We created them back in the plan.

132
00:06:18.550 --> 00:06:20.420
They haven't actually started,
so I don't have to collect them,

133
00:06:20.420 --> 00:06:22.680
I just use the plan data,
but it's right here.

134
00:06:22.680 --> 00:06:26.600
So I'm gonna add up all of my ETCs and
the budget for

135
00:06:26.600 --> 00:06:27.660
any activity that hasn't started.

136
00:06:27.660 --> 00:06:29.500
I'm gonna treat those as ETCs.

137
00:06:29.500 --> 00:06:32.390
And that is how much more I think
I'm gonna have to spend to finish

138
00:06:32.390 --> 00:06:32.920
this project.

139
00:06:32.920 --> 00:06:36.130
And then I combine that with
what I've already spent, and

140
00:06:36.130 --> 00:06:40.110
I'll have my estimate at completion, what
I think that full expense is going to be.

141
00:06:40.110 --> 00:06:43.720
So if we work this out,
the math starts to escape me, right?

142
00:06:43.720 --> 00:06:45.430
So our actual cost is easy,
that's 200 thousand.

143
00:06:45.430 --> 00:06:47.638
We know what our actual cost is.

144
00:06:47.638 --> 00:06:55.100
But then I need to add my ETCs, right?

145
00:06:55.100 --> 00:07:01.200
So my EAC is going to equal $200 thousand
plus all of these other ones summed up.

146
00:07:01.200 --> 00:07:03.870
So I'm going to break out my
friendly calculator here.

147
00:07:03.870 --> 00:07:06.000
And we'll sum all these up.

148
00:07:06.000 --> 00:07:07.806
So-
>> It would be 136 thousand.

149
00:07:07.806 --> 00:07:08.490
I believe.

150
00:07:08.490 --> 00:07:10.580
>> Your math skills
Ronnie far exceed mine.

151
00:07:10.580 --> 00:07:13.780
So let's just run this
through a calculator.

152
00:07:13.780 --> 00:07:16.580
And we'll say 100,000 right,
cuz that's the budget for

153
00:07:16.580 --> 00:07:18.297
stuff I haven't even started yet.

154
00:07:18.297 --> 00:07:20.559
7,000 for activity 1.1.7.

155
00:07:20.559 --> 00:07:23.280
We got 2,000 for activity 3.2.

156
00:07:23.280 --> 00:07:28.226
We've got 24 thousand for activity 4.5 and

157
00:07:28.226 --> 00:07:33.860
3,000 for activity 4.6,
and you were right.

158
00:07:33.860 --> 00:07:40.265
So, it is 136 thousand is what my current
ETC is, so I can punch that in here.

159
00:07:40.265 --> 00:07:43.420
136 thousand dollars.

160
00:07:43.420 --> 00:07:45.223
All right, remember the hundred
thousand coming from here, and

161
00:07:45.223 --> 00:07:46.354
36 thousand ETCs from what I got open.

162
00:07:46.354 --> 00:07:50.292
Well if I add those together,

163
00:07:50.292 --> 00:07:56.128
I end up with a nice cool $336 thousand.

164
00:07:56.128 --> 00:07:59.729
Now my fear was that we were gonna
exceed my $350 thousand budget,

165
00:07:59.729 --> 00:08:02.795
now that I've seen this We're
gonna come in under budget.

166
00:08:02.795 --> 00:08:06.827
Now you get an all new fear of what work
hasn't been done that was supposed to

167
00:08:06.827 --> 00:08:07.340
be done?

168
00:08:07.340 --> 00:08:09.530
Why are we ahead like this?

169
00:08:09.530 --> 00:08:10.120
Who knows.

170
00:08:10.120 --> 00:08:13.610
Maybe I had $14,000 in reserves
baked into the project or something.

171
00:08:13.610 --> 00:08:16.980
I don't know, if you padded your numbers,
which you shouldn't do that, but

172
00:08:16.980 --> 00:08:18.380
maybe that explains it.

173
00:08:18.380 --> 00:08:22.070
We need to go find out why, but the point
is I now have an estimate to complete for

174
00:08:22.070 --> 00:08:23.260
my project.

175
00:08:23.260 --> 00:08:24.980
And I'm showing I'm in pretty good shape.

176
00:08:24.980 --> 00:08:26.940
I wanna be under budget right?

177
00:08:26.940 --> 00:08:30.320
That's what an EAC can do and
it's pretty common sense right?

178
00:08:30.320 --> 00:08:33.050
We're just taking
the numbers that we've got.

179
00:08:33.050 --> 00:08:36.990
The numbers that we know are fact and
then we're factoring in estimates.

180
00:08:36.990 --> 00:08:39.340
Either estimates that people
are giving us right now or

181
00:08:39.340 --> 00:08:43.180
estimates that we came up with back in the
project plan, well we're combining it all

182
00:08:43.180 --> 00:08:46.100
together to create that final
estimate of where we're gonna end up.

183
00:08:46.100 --> 00:08:49.040
And here my EAC is $336,000 dollars.

184
00:08:50.100 --> 00:08:52.980
Now I need this for
the whole project, right?

185
00:08:52.980 --> 00:08:57.100
If I just did a single activity, like if
I took Activity 1.1.7, I could go and

186
00:08:57.100 --> 00:09:00.500
find the actual cost for 1.1.7.

187
00:09:00.500 --> 00:09:06.730
And I could add the ETC for 1.1.7, and
then I would have the EAC just for 1.1.7.

188
00:09:06.730 --> 00:09:11.510
So you can calculate it on
a single activity if you want, and

189
00:09:11.510 --> 00:09:13.220
you get that EAC for it.

190
00:09:13.220 --> 00:09:15.880
And you might need that when you're
running some of the other formulas that

191
00:09:15.880 --> 00:09:16.970
are out there.

192
00:09:16.970 --> 00:09:19.230
But usually we do it for
a project as a whole.

193
00:09:19.230 --> 00:09:22.030
And the real challenge with this
is simply getting the data,

194
00:09:22.030 --> 00:09:23.950
getting an estimate to complete for
everybody.

195
00:09:23.950 --> 00:09:26.690
So imagine going to all of
the people who are in the field,

196
00:09:26.690 --> 00:09:30.000
who are actually doing the work,
all the contractors or whoever and

197
00:09:30.000 --> 00:09:32.340
saying I need that estimate to
complete for what you're doing.

198
00:09:32.340 --> 00:09:34.900
How much more money do you
think you're gonna spend?

199
00:09:34.900 --> 00:09:38.030
And calculate it out as you know,

200
00:09:38.030 --> 00:09:40.170
dollars like this cause you gotta
factor in hours and all that.

201
00:09:40.170 --> 00:09:41.620
This is really earned value.

202
00:09:41.620 --> 00:09:44.100
So calculate that out and
turn it back in to me.

203
00:09:44.100 --> 00:09:45.690
It's a lot of burden,
it's a lot of effort.

204
00:09:45.690 --> 00:09:48.080
So we don't like to pull
this if we don't have to and

205
00:09:48.080 --> 00:09:50.090
that's why we have some more
other variations of this.

206
00:09:51.272 --> 00:09:53.510
All right, so let's take a look
at one of those variations.

207
00:09:53.510 --> 00:09:56.230
The first variation is
this guy right here.

208
00:09:56.230 --> 00:09:56.790
Okay?

209
00:09:56.790 --> 00:09:58.030
Now notice what we're doing.

210
00:09:58.030 --> 00:10:02.450
Instead of doing actual
cost plus a bottom up ETC,

211
00:10:02.450 --> 00:10:06.122
here it's actual cost plus budgeted
completion minus earn value.

212
00:10:06.122 --> 00:10:09.360
All right, what's going on here?

213
00:10:09.360 --> 00:10:12.450
We're swapping out the ETC,
the bottom up ETC.

214
00:10:12.450 --> 00:10:16.620
We're taking that out and replacing
that with our budgeted completion,

215
00:10:16.620 --> 00:10:19.760
what we plan to spend,
minus our earned value,

216
00:10:19.760 --> 00:10:23.490
which is what we've spent in
terms of effort so far, right?

217
00:10:23.490 --> 00:10:26.160
And earned value is more accurate than AC
in this case, because it's taking into

218
00:10:26.160 --> 00:10:29.420
account schedule, where AC doesn't
take into account schedule so

219
00:10:29.420 --> 00:10:35.200
we're gonna factor that in and
determine what's left for us to spend.

220
00:10:35.200 --> 00:10:38.840
So we end up with a number that's
not necessarily as accurate as

221
00:10:38.840 --> 00:10:40.810
what we would have gotten a moment ago.

222
00:10:40.810 --> 00:10:43.540
When you get those ETCs from the field,

223
00:10:43.540 --> 00:10:46.180
these are the people that
are actually doing the work.

224
00:10:46.180 --> 00:10:48.460
And they've got a good idea
of how things are going and

225
00:10:48.460 --> 00:10:50.990
how much more they're going to need,
right?

226
00:10:50.990 --> 00:10:56.490
Versus this variation that's using a plan
we came up with potentially years ago.

227
00:10:56.490 --> 00:10:59.050
That isn't taking into account what
is actually going on in the field.

228
00:10:59.050 --> 00:11:02.790
So it's less accurate, but
then it brings in earned value.

229
00:11:02.790 --> 00:11:05.390
Earned value is calculated on
what's actually happening, so

230
00:11:05.390 --> 00:11:07.180
that makes it a little
more accurate again.

231
00:11:07.180 --> 00:11:08.300
Okay.

232
00:11:08.300 --> 00:11:11.120
The end result is you end
up with an EAC that is

233
00:11:11.120 --> 00:11:14.350
pretty close to where you'd expect to be,
right?

234
00:11:14.350 --> 00:11:18.760
That it's pretty close to where you
think you would be at on this anyway and

235
00:11:18.760 --> 00:11:20.065
it's usually good enough.

236
00:11:20.065 --> 00:11:22.560
[LAUGH] I hate saying that, right?

237
00:11:22.560 --> 00:11:24.170
It's good enough.

238
00:11:24.170 --> 00:11:28.070
This is normally the one
that I start with, right?

239
00:11:28.070 --> 00:11:30.960
I don't necessarily want to go and
get an ETC from everybody in the field.

240
00:11:30.960 --> 00:11:32.000
I don't want to burden them with that.

241
00:11:32.000 --> 00:11:33.020
They've got their own work to do.

242
00:11:33.020 --> 00:11:35.320
They're already giving me status reports.

243
00:11:35.320 --> 00:11:38.660
I have to be in a real situation to go and
say, all right, it's time we go out and

244
00:11:38.660 --> 00:11:40.030
get those ETC's.

245
00:11:40.030 --> 00:11:41.800
So with this one we can use it.

246
00:11:41.800 --> 00:11:46.720
When we've got good data, if we already
have our actual costs from accounting.

247
00:11:46.720 --> 00:11:48.800
If we already have our budgeted
completion from our plan,

248
00:11:48.800 --> 00:11:51.680
which you certainly should have If we've
already got our earned values from

249
00:11:51.680 --> 00:11:55.350
status reports,
we can take the data we already have and

250
00:11:55.350 --> 00:12:00.140
get results that are very close to what
we would get with a full bottom up ETC.

251
00:12:00.140 --> 00:12:04.140
So this is faster,
it reduces the effort of getting ETCs.

252
00:12:04.140 --> 00:12:07.950
And so I'll normally start with
this one and see the numbers I get.

253
00:12:07.950 --> 00:12:12.450
And if I'm not happy with the numbers
then I go out and, alright guys

254
00:12:12.450 --> 00:12:16.290
we need to shore things up everybody turn
in your ETC I need it by Friday, right?

255
00:12:16.290 --> 00:12:19.400
And then we get the number that is
accurate as it's going to get and

256
00:12:19.400 --> 00:12:20.520
we start to act on it.

257
00:12:20.520 --> 00:12:24.580
But if these numbers come back good, then
I don't belabor the point I'm not going to

258
00:12:24.580 --> 00:12:27.680
request an ETC from everybody when
the numbers are looking good, right?

259
00:12:27.680 --> 00:12:32.340
So the first variation is just sacrificing
a little bit of accuracy in exchange for

260
00:12:32.340 --> 00:12:35.360
being able to reuse data that you normally
already have from your typical status

261
00:12:35.360 --> 00:12:36.890
reports, right.

262
00:12:36.890 --> 00:12:41.460
So an example of this might be, like here,
we wanna get a ballpark EAC for

263
00:12:41.460 --> 00:12:42.270
our project.

264
00:12:42.270 --> 00:12:47.310
But we don't wanna waste team resources
collecting ETCs from the task workers.

265
00:12:47.310 --> 00:12:50.180
Our project budget is $250,000,
that's our BAC.

266
00:12:50.180 --> 00:12:51.570
And our expenses to date are $175,000.

267
00:12:51.570 --> 00:12:55.110
That's gonna be our AC,
or our actual cost.

268
00:12:55.110 --> 00:12:59.640
The EVs from your incoming status
reports add up to $160,000.

269
00:12:59.640 --> 00:13:05.430
So we've totaled up the earned value from
all of our various activities At $160,000,

270
00:13:05.430 --> 00:13:07.430
what is our EAC?

271
00:13:07.430 --> 00:13:13.390
Well, if we plug all that in,
our EAC is gonna equal our actual cost.

272
00:13:13.390 --> 00:13:17.070
So $175,000 plus our budget at completion,

273
00:13:17.070 --> 00:13:22.890
which is $250,000 minus our
earned value which is $160,000.

274
00:13:22.890 --> 00:13:26.180
Now, I already know I've
got a problem here.

275
00:13:26.180 --> 00:13:30.664
Because my earned value adds up to 160,000
but my current expenses are 175,000.

276
00:13:30.664 --> 00:13:33.860
So it doesn't take a wizard to figure out
this project has got some issues, but

277
00:13:33.860 --> 00:13:36.550
when we calculate our
estimate at completion,

278
00:13:36.550 --> 00:13:40.550
we should see that things aren't
painting the greatest picture for us.

279
00:13:40.550 --> 00:13:45.020
So, let me just come in here and
plug this in.

280
00:13:45.020 --> 00:13:49.930
So if I take $175,000 and
I add $250,000 and

281
00:13:49.930 --> 00:13:56.956
then I subtract $160,000
I end up with $265,000.

282
00:13:56.956 --> 00:13:57.581
Right?

283
00:13:57.581 --> 00:14:00.710
So $265,000.

284
00:14:00.710 --> 00:14:03.790
My budget is $250,000.

285
00:14:03.790 --> 00:14:07.170
My estimated completion is $265,000,
right?

286
00:14:07.170 --> 00:14:09.040
I'm gonna be $15,000 over budget.

287
00:14:09.040 --> 00:14:10.330
Is that good math, Tony?

288
00:14:10.330 --> 00:14:10.860
>> Yeah.

289
00:14:10.860 --> 00:14:11.380
It is.

290
00:14:11.380 --> 00:14:12.660
>> I saw you squinting your eyes.

291
00:14:12.660 --> 00:14:14.800
I was like, shoot, I screwed something up.

292
00:14:14.800 --> 00:14:16.556
>> If it was me it was $200,000.

293
00:14:16.556 --> 00:14:18.186
I saw $200,000, not $250,000.

294
00:14:18.186 --> 00:14:19.550
>> Okay.
So I'm going to

295
00:14:19.550 --> 00:14:21.280
end up $15,000 over budget, right?

296
00:14:21.280 --> 00:14:23.050
That's what this estimate shows me.

297
00:14:23.050 --> 00:14:24.435
And so that's a problem.

298
00:14:24.435 --> 00:14:25.890
$15,000 is a lot of money.

299
00:14:25.890 --> 00:14:28.530
So, especially in the general
scheme of this project here.

300
00:14:28.530 --> 00:14:34.160
That's a good, it's not 10%, it's what is
that end up being like 7% or something.

301
00:14:34.160 --> 00:14:36.230
So still a pretty good chunk, right?

302
00:14:36.230 --> 00:14:38.190
So I want to go in and
take corrective action and

303
00:14:38.190 --> 00:14:40.420
this might be the point where I say,
you know what?

304
00:14:40.420 --> 00:14:41.450
Time to go collect some ETCs.

305
00:14:41.450 --> 00:14:45.310
Because when I have the ETCs, I can
figure out exactly who the problem is.

306
00:14:45.310 --> 00:14:48.650
Or, honestly, I can just go and
look at my schedule or cost variance and

307
00:14:48.650 --> 00:14:49.520
find out there too.

308
00:14:49.520 --> 00:14:51.690
There's a few different ways you
can go and isolate the problem.

309
00:14:51.690 --> 00:14:54.680
But as a whole, I can see that my
project's not in the greatest shape,

310
00:14:54.680 --> 00:14:56.280
it's not he healthiest
project in the world.

311
00:14:56.280 --> 00:14:59.800
So definitely something I wanna act on,
but it didn't require me going out and

312
00:14:59.800 --> 00:15:01.250
getting a bunch of ETCs to do it.

313
00:15:01.250 --> 00:15:05.480
So that's the first variation and
on the exam, what you're going to see

314
00:15:05.480 --> 00:15:09.980
are questions that ask you to calculate
in EAC and they're gonna give you values.

315
00:15:09.980 --> 00:15:14.090
And you gotta look at the values
they give you and make do with it.

316
00:15:14.090 --> 00:15:17.300
So the questions will read like mine
did where they feed you data and

317
00:15:17.300 --> 00:15:18.370
you have to calculate in EAC.

318
00:15:18.370 --> 00:15:22.360
Well, you got four different formulas for
EAC, so you look at the data but

319
00:15:22.360 --> 00:15:24.060
sometimes they give you
more than you need.

320
00:15:24.060 --> 00:15:26.580
And so you gotta interpret the question
to figure out the right formula.

321
00:15:26.580 --> 00:15:28.290
And sometimes they don't
give you enough and so

322
00:15:28.290 --> 00:15:31.470
they usually put that answer on there,
not enough information provided.

323
00:15:31.470 --> 00:15:34.430
And don't be scared to choose that,
it is right sometimes.

324
00:15:34.430 --> 00:15:36.240
And so if they just didn't give
you enough information for

325
00:15:36.240 --> 00:15:39.780
any of the formulas, or maybe they
did give you enough information for

326
00:15:39.780 --> 00:15:43.330
one formula but they put a statement
in here, like mine where it said

327
00:15:43.330 --> 00:15:47.490
you don't wanna waste resources by
collecting ETCs from the team, right?

328
00:15:47.490 --> 00:15:50.574
But maybe they give me enough information
that includes ETCs or something,

329
00:15:50.574 --> 00:15:52.558
I guess that wouldn't make
a whole lot of sense.

330
00:15:52.558 --> 00:15:54.743
But if they did that,
I still wouldn't wanna use that formula,

331
00:15:54.743 --> 00:15:56.007
cuz they told me not to do it, right?

332
00:15:56.007 --> 00:15:59.692
So we just have to make sure we
interpret that question properly.

333
00:15:59.692 --> 00:16:01.562
All right, so that's variation number one.

334
00:16:01.562 --> 00:16:03.541
That one pretty much makes sense.

335
00:16:03.541 --> 00:16:05.780
Let's take a look at variation number two.

336
00:16:05.780 --> 00:16:07.270
Variation number two
gets a little stranger.

337
00:16:07.270 --> 00:16:09.250
And each of these variations has a name,
right?

338
00:16:09.250 --> 00:16:12.850
The first variation,
it's actually called EAC Forecast for

339
00:16:12.850 --> 00:16:15.340
ETC Work Performed at the Budgeted Rate.

340
00:16:15.340 --> 00:16:19.450
And what they're saying here is,
instead of work performed with an estimate

341
00:16:19.450 --> 00:16:23.260
to complete, it's the estimate to complete
being calculated off of the budgeted rate.

342
00:16:23.260 --> 00:16:25.940
That's what we did,
that Budget At Completion minus EV.

343
00:16:25.940 --> 00:16:27.850
So that's the name of that one.

344
00:16:27.850 --> 00:16:33.650
Variation Two is EAC forecast for
ETC work performed at the present CPI.

345
00:16:33.650 --> 00:16:34.260
All right?

346
00:16:34.260 --> 00:16:40.510
So instead of using the budgeted rate,
we're using the cost performance index.

347
00:16:40.510 --> 00:16:44.120
We've got this index that indicates
how we're doing in terms of cost.

348
00:16:44.120 --> 00:16:47.570
We can just use that to calculate
out what our EAC is going to be.

349
00:16:47.570 --> 00:16:50.680
This is even less accurate
than variation one, though.

350
00:16:50.680 --> 00:16:54.870
And so this one, on each of these I
kind of put when you would use it.

351
00:16:54.870 --> 00:16:58.490
On the other one, I said the big advantage
that it, you would use it when you had

352
00:16:58.490 --> 00:17:02.010
good data, and you didn't want
to bother everybody with ETCs.

353
00:17:03.080 --> 00:17:05.490
This one, variation two,
when would you use it?

354
00:17:05.490 --> 00:17:06.380
When you are in a hurry.

355
00:17:06.380 --> 00:17:09.030
Okay, if you're in a hurry,
you just need a quick and

356
00:17:09.030 --> 00:17:12.680
dirty number, this is the guy for you,
right, you will use this formula.

357
00:17:12.680 --> 00:17:13.710
It's simple.

358
00:17:13.710 --> 00:17:16.690
Your budgeted completion,
divided by your CPI, and

359
00:17:16.690 --> 00:17:18.380
that will give you your
estimated completion.

360
00:17:18.380 --> 00:17:23.350
If your CPI is one,
if you are perfectly on budget right?

361
00:17:23.350 --> 00:17:26.510
Then your budgeted completion divided by
one is just your budgeted completion.

362
00:17:26.510 --> 00:17:30.270
Your estimated completion now equals your
budgeted completion, you are perfect.

363
00:17:30.270 --> 00:17:35.470
But if your CPI is 1.1, or
your CPI is .90 Right, when

364
00:17:35.470 --> 00:17:38.570
you divide your budget at completion by
that, you're gonna get a different number.

365
00:17:38.570 --> 00:17:40.400
And it's not gonna be incredibly accurate.

366
00:17:40.400 --> 00:17:43.340
But it's good enough to let you
know whether you're in trouble, or

367
00:17:43.340 --> 00:17:47.210
whether you're within that small window,
where it's acceptable to vary, right?

368
00:17:47.210 --> 00:17:48.940
So we use this when we're in a hurry.

369
00:17:48.940 --> 00:17:52.720
And typically this one is not used
in any reports to give to people.

370
00:17:52.720 --> 00:17:57.260
It's just used for you to get a quick view
of the project, and determine whether or

371
00:17:57.260 --> 00:17:58.650
not you need to go more in depth.

372
00:17:58.650 --> 00:17:59.250
Right.
So

373
00:17:59.250 --> 00:18:00.790
this one is definitely
when you're in a hurry.

374
00:18:00.790 --> 00:18:03.370
But you'll see, you can calculate EAC,
which is two values.

375
00:18:03.370 --> 00:18:07.030
Your budget completion, and
your cumulative CPI, right.

376
00:18:07.030 --> 00:18:12.080
The CPI for all of the work, to date,
not just that one reporting period.

377
00:18:12.080 --> 00:18:16.440
So, as an example, let's say that
I've got a project like this, and

378
00:18:16.440 --> 00:18:20.250
they're telling me, we've been making
changes to bring our project back in line.

379
00:18:20.250 --> 00:18:20.810
All right?

380
00:18:20.810 --> 00:18:23.810
So we had a project that was
off in our first example.

381
00:18:23.810 --> 00:18:25.170
And so we've taken that first project, and

382
00:18:25.170 --> 00:18:26.740
we've made some changes to try and
bring it back.

383
00:18:26.740 --> 00:18:30.210
Remember in the first example
we were off by $15,000.

384
00:18:30.210 --> 00:18:32.780
So we've made some changes.

385
00:18:32.780 --> 00:18:34.530
Hopefully it's coming back in line.

386
00:18:34.530 --> 00:18:37.620
All right, we wanna figure out
the effectiveness of our change.

387
00:18:37.620 --> 00:18:40.190
We just wanna see if we can get it better,

388
00:18:40.190 --> 00:18:42.470
if we've actually made
the improvements we need.

389
00:18:42.470 --> 00:18:48.480
So, we run some numbers and
our current cumulative CPI is 0.96.

390
00:18:48.480 --> 00:18:53.400
All right, so if we're at a 0.96,
what's our new estimated completion?

391
00:18:53.400 --> 00:18:56.790
Well, if I was using my old formula.

392
00:18:56.790 --> 00:19:00.690
I would need my earned values and
my actual costs and all that.

393
00:19:00.690 --> 00:19:03.470
But I don't necessarily have that here,
and I'm just in a hurry.

394
00:19:03.470 --> 00:19:04.820
So I'm going to take the numbers I've got.

395
00:19:04.820 --> 00:19:06.390
And I'm going to say that my EAC

396
00:19:07.830 --> 00:19:10.960
is going to equal my budget of
completion which is $250,000.

397
00:19:10.960 --> 00:19:12.510
That was from the first example.

398
00:19:12.510 --> 00:19:17.950
And I'm going to divide that by
my current CPI, which is 0.96.

399
00:19:17.950 --> 00:19:24.770
So I made some changes, my CPI is now
0.96, and we run that through our formula,

400
00:19:24.770 --> 00:19:30.990
250,000 divided by 0.96,
and I get 260,417 dollars.

401
00:19:30.990 --> 00:19:36.510
So that's gonna equal 260,000 and
$417.00, right?

402
00:19:36.510 --> 00:19:41.208
>> It's 17.
>> $417, we'll get it sooner or later.

403
00:19:41.208 --> 00:19:45.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> There we go, all right.

404
00:19:45.280 --> 00:19:51.261
So now we're at 200, and my touch pad's
going crazy, we're at $260,000, okay.

405
00:19:51.261 --> 00:19:56.050
So when I ran it before
we were at $265,000.

406
00:19:56.050 --> 00:19:58.950
We made some changes to try and
improve things.

407
00:19:58.950 --> 00:20:02.570
And when I ran my quick formula,
we get 260,000.

408
00:20:02.570 --> 00:20:09.700
So we did go from 265 down to 260,
right, so I'm a little bit back in line.

409
00:20:09.700 --> 00:20:13.890
But I'm still not perfect,
I'm still off by $10,000.

410
00:20:13.890 --> 00:20:17.760
So we have made an improvement, but
it's not necessarily enough, so

411
00:20:17.760 --> 00:20:18.940
we continue making more improvements.

412
00:20:18.940 --> 00:20:21.810
Now because we're using cumulative CPI,

413
00:20:21.810 --> 00:20:23.960
improvements don't necessarily
show up right away.

414
00:20:23.960 --> 00:20:27.540
And when we covered ETC,
I kinda talked about that a little bit,

415
00:20:27.540 --> 00:20:31.170
that sometimes you might want to throw
out your CPI, cuz it's cumulative for

416
00:20:31.170 --> 00:20:32.290
the whole thing to date.

417
00:20:32.290 --> 00:20:35.570
So the bad times are still
reported in your CPI.

418
00:20:35.570 --> 00:20:38.525
And so this formula might not be
the most accurate in that scenario,

419
00:20:38.525 --> 00:20:40.450
it's very hard to see those changes.

420
00:20:40.450 --> 00:20:43.390
But if that's all the information we have,
at least we can get a ball park and

421
00:20:43.390 --> 00:20:45.120
then we can go and act upon it.

422
00:20:45.120 --> 00:20:47.260
And we can go get more detailed
information or whatever.

423
00:20:47.260 --> 00:20:48.790
So that's two variations of the formula.

424
00:20:48.790 --> 00:20:50.640
There's one more that I
want to show you guys, and

425
00:20:50.640 --> 00:20:55.530
this one is interesting because
the other two, one of them uses CPI.

426
00:20:55.530 --> 00:20:59.630
Or we used our budget in our plan,
but they really focused on cost,

427
00:20:59.630 --> 00:21:02.010
and really estimate to
completion is about cost.

428
00:21:02.010 --> 00:21:04.180
Most people care about how much
more money they need to spend.

429
00:21:04.180 --> 00:21:07.390
But we haven't really been
taking schedule into account.

430
00:21:07.390 --> 00:21:10.080
Now they all use earned value, and
earned value involves scheduling, so

431
00:21:10.080 --> 00:21:11.110
there is some of that.

432
00:21:11.110 --> 00:21:14.550
But the third variation
brings in scheduling.

433
00:21:14.550 --> 00:21:20.040
And the reason it does it, is when
you got a project that's in trouble,

434
00:21:20.040 --> 00:21:21.600
you've got your triple constraints, right.

435
00:21:21.600 --> 00:21:26.140
You've got your quality or
your requirements, you've got your cost or

436
00:21:26.140 --> 00:21:29.290
your budget, and you've got your
schedule or your time, right.

437
00:21:29.290 --> 00:21:33.130
So cost, time, quality, those are the
three big constraints that we deal with.

438
00:21:33.130 --> 00:21:37.750
And when you have a problem, you can
normally fix it by either increasing your

439
00:21:37.750 --> 00:21:42.440
cost, or decreasing your quality,
increasing your schedule, whatever, right.

440
00:21:42.440 --> 00:21:44.420
And when you adjust one
it adjusts the other.

441
00:21:44.420 --> 00:21:49.860
And so sometimes it's not so much the cost
that's the problem, as it is the schedule.

442
00:21:49.860 --> 00:21:51.870
And with each of the ones
we've been looking at,

443
00:21:51.870 --> 00:21:53.070
we really haven't accounted for that.

444
00:21:53.070 --> 00:21:55.380
We've said, we've got a problem,
we'll figure out how to fix it later,

445
00:21:55.380 --> 00:21:57.550
we just need to identify
that we have a problem.

446
00:21:57.550 --> 00:22:02.350
But what if you've got a project
sponsor that comes in and says look.

447
00:22:02.350 --> 00:22:04.180
This is the date you're going to finish.

448
00:22:04.180 --> 00:22:07.010
When we planned this project, you said
you were gonna be done January first.

449
00:22:07.010 --> 00:22:09.720
You're going to be done January first.

450
00:22:09.720 --> 00:22:14.340
Well, if you're in that scenario,
where your project dates are kinda fixed.

451
00:22:14.340 --> 00:22:18.770
You want to hold to that project date,
you've gotta factor schedule into this,

452
00:22:18.770 --> 00:22:19.910
because you're not gonna change it.

453
00:22:19.910 --> 00:22:20.890
The schedule's not gonna change.

454
00:22:20.890 --> 00:22:23.380
So it's gotta be a bigger
part of the formula.

455
00:22:23.380 --> 00:22:28.790
And so we can take the formulas that we've
seen, and adjust them just a little bit.

456
00:22:28.790 --> 00:22:29.330
Right?

457
00:22:29.330 --> 00:22:32.680
So here's the third variation,
and with this one

458
00:22:32.680 --> 00:22:37.240
you'll notice the big differences that
we're bringing in accumulative SPI.

459
00:22:37.240 --> 00:22:37.930
Right?

460
00:22:37.930 --> 00:22:41.450
What we saw a moment ago was budget
at completion divided by CPI, or

461
00:22:41.450 --> 00:22:42.700
accumulative CPI.

462
00:22:42.700 --> 00:22:45.020
But here we're going
back to the old formula.

463
00:22:45.020 --> 00:22:50.420
The actual cost, plus the budget
at completion, earned value.

464
00:22:50.420 --> 00:22:51.000
Okay.

465
00:22:51.000 --> 00:22:53.360
So straightforward formula right there.

466
00:22:53.360 --> 00:22:54.140
Nothing original, right?

467
00:22:54.140 --> 00:22:57.260
The original formula was actual
cost plus bottom up etcetera.

468
00:22:57.260 --> 00:22:59.630
Right?
That's the real formula for EAC,

469
00:22:59.630 --> 00:23:01.140
that original one.

470
00:23:01.140 --> 00:23:06.240
But the first variation we saw was
EAC equals AC plus BAC minus EV.

471
00:23:06.240 --> 00:23:10.700
And the difference here,
is we're dividing that by our CPI,

472
00:23:10.700 --> 00:23:13.450
our cumulative CPI times
our cumulative SPI.

473
00:23:14.610 --> 00:23:17.980
Our cost performance and
our schedule performance index.

474
00:23:17.980 --> 00:23:21.730
We're factoring both of these in, and
remember, if you've got an index that's at

475
00:23:21.730 --> 00:23:28.350
a one, one times one is one, and any
number divided by one is just that number.

476
00:23:28.350 --> 00:23:33.590
And we end up right back at that formula,
EAC = AC plus BAC- EV Right?

477
00:23:33.590 --> 00:23:38.270
But if your cost performance index is off,
or your schedule performance index is off,

478
00:23:38.270 --> 00:23:41.580
then that's gonna effect the ultimate
EAC that this results in.

479
00:23:41.580 --> 00:23:44.659
So this one requires a little
bit more data to be fed into it

480
00:23:44.659 --> 00:23:46.533
to get accurate results out of it.

481
00:23:46.533 --> 00:23:49.595
But, if you're dealing
with a fixed schedule,

482
00:23:49.595 --> 00:23:53.404
if you intend to fold to
the current project schedule dates,

483
00:23:53.404 --> 00:23:56.934
then you're going to need to
factor in SPI, all right?

484
00:23:56.934 --> 00:23:59.880
And that's really the only
time we use this variation.

485
00:23:59.880 --> 00:24:01.990
Variation three is just when
you've got a hold of those dates.

486
00:24:01.990 --> 00:24:04.140
So in the word problem,
if they tell you that,

487
00:24:04.140 --> 00:24:06.960
if the dates are not flexible,
be thinking about this formula here.

488
00:24:06.960 --> 00:24:10.300
And this formula requires
a lot of information, and so

489
00:24:10.300 --> 00:24:13.010
you gotta make sure all the information
is in the question otherwise you gotta

490
00:24:13.010 --> 00:24:15.070
choose that not enough
information provided.

491
00:24:15.070 --> 00:24:16.460
Now I made a little note here.

492
00:24:16.460 --> 00:24:20.090
This formula only works when over budget,
all right?

493
00:24:20.090 --> 00:24:21.320
What does that mean?

494
00:24:21.320 --> 00:24:26.900
Well, if you're under budget, right, if
things are going well, your CPI multiplied

495
00:24:26.900 --> 00:24:30.640
by your SPI starts to skew things and
things can really start to get off, right?

496
00:24:30.640 --> 00:24:32.540
And then it doesn't work out quite right.

497
00:24:32.540 --> 00:24:34.660
Your numbers get skewed and
it kinda breaks things.

498
00:24:34.660 --> 00:24:37.840
So if you're under budget, in other
words if things are going great for

499
00:24:37.840 --> 00:24:40.810
your project,
then you don't need this formula, and

500
00:24:40.810 --> 00:24:44.840
you're probably not even calculating EACs
at that point because you're under budget.

501
00:24:44.840 --> 00:24:47.470
But either way,
this one doesn't work, right?

502
00:24:47.470 --> 00:24:51.620
So we need to make sure that our budget
is bad, that we are over budget and

503
00:24:51.620 --> 00:24:54.360
that's where this formula's
going to come in, right?

504
00:24:54.360 --> 00:24:56.180
So let's see an example of that.

505
00:24:56.180 --> 00:24:58.850
This is the only formula we have that
actually has that kind of contingency.

506
00:24:58.850 --> 00:25:00.470
All the other ones work, no matter what.

507
00:25:01.760 --> 00:25:03.060
All right.
So, here we've got an example, and

508
00:25:03.060 --> 00:25:07.080
it says changes to your project have been
fairly effective at getting back inline

509
00:25:07.080 --> 00:25:09.330
with your budget of $250,000.

510
00:25:09.330 --> 00:25:11.790
However further change is needed.

511
00:25:11.790 --> 00:25:14.650
Your project sponsor has indicated
that she will not approve

512
00:25:14.650 --> 00:25:16.530
any further schedule changes.

513
00:25:16.530 --> 00:25:20.000
Adjust your EAC to account for
the fixed schedule.

514
00:25:20.000 --> 00:25:22.990
Your current project SPI,
your cumulative SPI is 0.97, right?

515
00:25:22.990 --> 00:25:28.190
This is the same project from the last two
examples, so we've already got the other

516
00:25:28.190 --> 00:25:34.120
information, our actual cost,
our BAC, our EV, our CPI and our SPI.

517
00:25:34.120 --> 00:25:37.100
We can go and get those and kind of
plug them in from the other side, right?

518
00:25:37.100 --> 00:25:41.030
So our EAC is going equal our actual cost,
right,

519
00:25:41.030 --> 00:25:44.040
which I take a look at the last one.

520
00:25:44.040 --> 00:25:46.280
Where was our actual cost?

521
00:25:46.280 --> 00:25:48.760
Here.
$175,000 so I'll plug that in, $175,000.

522
00:25:48.760 --> 00:25:55.820
And I'm going to add to
that my budgeted completion

523
00:25:55.820 --> 00:26:01.070
minus my earned value, and I can get
both of those from the first one where

524
00:26:01.070 --> 00:26:04.810
my budget at completion was $250 dollars
and my earned value was $160,000, right?

525
00:26:04.810 --> 00:26:05.940
So let me just copy these.

526
00:26:05.940 --> 00:26:12.520
We're just going to lift those right out
of there, kind of cheat a little bit.

527
00:26:13.860 --> 00:26:18.050
There we go, and
then I need to divide that by my CPI,

528
00:26:18.050 --> 00:26:22.382
my cumulative CPI,
which I believe was 0.96, wasn't it?

00:26:22.382 --> 00:26:23.720
Mm-hm.

00:26:23.720 --> 00:26:27.071
>> Let's go find out.

531
00:26:27.071 --> 00:26:34.790
0.96, yep, times 0.97,
which is our SPI, okay?

532
00:26:34.790 --> 00:26:37.820
So when I start to plug all that data in,
I'm gonna get my results.

533
00:26:37.820 --> 00:26:40.750
Now, my biggest challenge here is I've
got some order of operations that

534
00:26:40.750 --> 00:26:45.350
I've gotta execute here, right, the whole
please my dear Aunt Sally kind of thing.

535
00:26:45.350 --> 00:26:48.470
So I've got a series of parenthesis
here that I've gotta sort out.

536
00:26:48.470 --> 00:26:51.339
My budgeted completion minus my earned
value, that needs to happen first, so

537
00:26:51.339 --> 00:26:54.310
I've got $250,000 minus
$160,000 which is $90,000.

00:26:54.310 --> 00:27:00.133
All right, so we'll just change
that to a quick $90,000, all right?

539
00:27:00.133 --> 00:27:06.315
And then I'm not even going to pretend
to do 0.96 times 0.97 in my head,

00:27:06.315 --> 00:27:09.933
so let's just get
the calculator on that one.

541
00:27:09.933 --> 00:27:14.441
0.96 times 0.97 is 0.9312, all right.

00:27:14.441 --> 00:27:16.657
Now, normally I round these things, but

00:27:16.657 --> 00:27:19.644
that's a small enough number
that I might just keep it.

00:27:19.644 --> 00:27:21.910
0.9132 I think is what I said, right?

545
00:27:21.910 --> 00:27:22.880
9312.

546
00:27:22.880 --> 00:27:26.260
Always gotta double check the math.

547
00:27:26.260 --> 00:27:27.500
I'm terrible about that.

548
00:27:27.500 --> 00:27:28.500
All right, there.

549
00:27:28.500 --> 00:27:30.901
So now I've got a little bit
simpler of a formula to handle, but

00:27:30.901 --> 00:27:32.683
notice that this portion
has to be done first.

551
00:27:32.683 --> 00:27:35.323
If you get the order of
operations out of order,

552
00:27:35.323 --> 00:27:37.730
then things really get messed up, right?

553
00:27:37.730 --> 00:27:42.031
So now I need to take this and

554
00:27:42.031 --> 00:27:48.953
do 90,000 divided by 0.9312.

555
00:27:48.953 --> 00:27:52.626
And I get $96,649 which
I will round 96649.

556
00:28:00.866 --> 00:28:07.479
So this is just gonna become $96,649.

557
00:28:07.479 --> 00:28:09.899
All right, I guess I don't really
need these parentheses anymore.

558
00:28:09.899 --> 00:28:13.170
And then I can add that up,
and I'll have my new EAC.

559
00:28:13.170 --> 00:28:15.350
So if I add $250,000, ugh, shoot.

560
00:28:15.350 --> 00:28:20.730
175, let me subtract that back out.

561
00:28:20.730 --> 00:28:21.800
So I'm going to add $175,000 dollars.

562
00:28:21.800 --> 00:28:24.940
Otherwise my project
will be way over budget.

563
00:28:24.940 --> 00:28:29.659
I get $271,649, right?

564
00:28:29.659 --> 00:28:34.990
Now, and the problem the changes

565
00:28:34.990 --> 00:28:38.970
to my project have been fairly effective
at getting us back inline, but

00:28:38.970 --> 00:28:43.135
I can see that things are actually worse,
okay?

00:28:43.135 --> 00:28:44.845
Now, how does that happen?

00:28:44.845 --> 00:28:49.230
Why did I think I was affected of giving
back to 250 but things are actually worse?

00:28:49.230 --> 00:28:50.130
What the heck happened?

00:28:51.190 --> 00:28:53.300
The schedule happened, okay?

571
00:28:53.300 --> 00:28:58.080
I'm behind schedule, If I'm behind
schedule, then that's a problem.

572
00:28:58.080 --> 00:29:00.432
I need to be at or ahead of schedule.

573
00:29:00.432 --> 00:29:01.060
All right?

574
00:29:01.060 --> 00:29:03.410
But in this case I'm not
I'm behind schedule, and so

00:29:03.410 --> 00:29:04.920
that makes this number go higher.

576
00:29:04.920 --> 00:29:10.460
So while my cost, my CPI,
is pretty close to 0.96, it's not 1.

00:29:10.460 --> 00:29:13.120
It's not perfect, right?

578
00:29:13.120 --> 00:29:18.270
And even though I'm making strides to get
better, ,y schedule's still messed up.

579
00:29:18.270 --> 00:29:21.040
And when I factor that in,
I get an EAC of 271.

580
00:29:21.040 --> 00:29:23.160
Things are not right.

581
00:29:23.160 --> 00:29:24.990
I need to fix my schedule.

582
00:29:24.990 --> 00:29:27.715
I need to get that back in line,
and my schedule's not that bad.

583
00:29:27.715 --> 00:29:29.950
0.97 is pretty close, right?

584
00:29:29.950 --> 00:29:32.890
But if you've got a fixed target
date that you're working on,

00:29:32.890 --> 00:29:36.050
close is not good enough and
it starts to skew the formula.

586
00:29:36.050 --> 00:29:40.000
Combined with a budget that's not right,
then it gets even worse.

587
00:29:40.000 --> 00:29:43.410
And so now you might have a project
that looks like it's in good shape or

588
00:29:43.410 --> 00:29:47.650
at least better than it was, and it turns
out to not be in that good of shape.

589
00:29:47.650 --> 00:29:51.680
And now I've really got to pull in my
resources and try and get this corrected.

590
00:29:51.680 --> 00:29:53.960
So factoring in SPI it makes a difference.

591
00:29:53.960 --> 00:29:55.630
It really does, and it is important.

592
00:29:55.630 --> 00:30:03.170
So in my first example we got an EAC
of $265,000, then we worked to fix it.

593
00:30:03.170 --> 00:30:04.800
And we saw where we got
it down to $260,000.

594
00:30:04.800 --> 00:30:09.800
But when we factored in that schedule,
back up, even higher than where

00:30:09.800 --> 00:30:12.350
we were in the very beginning
because we never calculated this in.

596
00:30:12.350 --> 00:30:15.650
And the reality is,
if a fixed date was part of the equation,

00:30:15.650 --> 00:30:17.360
we should have been using this
formula from the beginning.

598
00:30:17.360 --> 00:30:20.400
We shouldn't even have wasted our
time with the other formula's because

599
00:30:20.400 --> 00:30:22.460
that schedule's so important, all right.

600
00:30:22.460 --> 00:30:27.340
Now the original formula way back,
this guy, because it's got

601
00:30:27.340 --> 00:30:30.860
bottom up ETC's coming up from all
the people in the field and stuff,

602
00:30:30.860 --> 00:30:36.000
this Is taking into account things like
schedule and earned values and all that.

603
00:30:36.000 --> 00:30:39.226
And so this is the most reliable
of all the formulas, and so

604
00:30:39.226 --> 00:30:41.180
this is the true formula for EAC.

605
00:30:41.180 --> 00:30:44.750
It's the one you wanna use assuming
you can those bottom-up ETCs.

606
00:30:44.750 --> 00:30:47.550
That's really important, right.

607
00:30:47.550 --> 00:30:50.730
If you don't have that, that's where
you've got the three variations.

608
00:30:50.730 --> 00:30:55.080
Just to run over the variations again,
the first variation, EAC forecast for

609
00:30:55.080 --> 00:30:57.470
ETC work performed at the budgeted rate.

610
00:30:57.470 --> 00:31:00.480
This is one that we wanna do if we
want fairly accurate numbers, but

611
00:31:00.480 --> 00:31:03.520
we don't wanna collect ETCs for
everything, that we know the work is being

612
00:31:03.520 --> 00:31:07.680
performed at the budgeted rate, that we
know things are kind of going as expected,

613
00:31:07.680 --> 00:31:11.270
and we use this and we get our numbers and
they're pretty accurate, all right?

614
00:31:11.270 --> 00:31:16.960
The next one was EAC forecast for
ETC work performed the present CPI.

615
00:31:16.960 --> 00:31:21.150
This is where we're just in a hurry,
and so we take our CPI,

616
00:31:21.150 --> 00:31:25.010
our cumulative CPI, and we just apply
it to the budget, and we get a number.

617
00:31:25.010 --> 00:31:28.010
This is not necessarily indicative of
what's actually happening in the field, so

618
00:31:28.010 --> 00:31:28.770
it's a ballpark.

619
00:31:28.770 --> 00:31:29.670
We use it when we're in a hurry.

620
00:31:30.900 --> 00:31:33.790
And then number three was EAC forecast for

621
00:31:33.790 --> 00:31:37.020
ETC work considering both SPI and
CPI factors.

622
00:31:37.020 --> 00:31:41.800
And this is the one that we use when we
know we've got a schedule that has to be

623
00:31:41.800 --> 00:31:43.070
met, that we don't have flexibility there.

624
00:31:43.070 --> 00:31:44.640
It's not all about cost.

625
00:31:44.640 --> 00:31:46.546
Schedule needs to be factored in, too.

626
00:31:46.546 --> 00:31:49.690
So on the exam when they ask you a
question, it's gonna be in the wording of

627
00:31:49.690 --> 00:31:52.045
the question which one you
should be leaning towards.

00:31:52.045 --> 00:31:54.573
And if they don't give you any hints,

629
00:31:54.573 --> 00:31:58.839
then you either assume the default one,
the original you know,

630
00:31:58.839 --> 00:32:03.910
ac plus your bottom of atc, or you just

631
00:32:03.910 --> 00:32:06.950
Look at the numbers and see which one
gives you enough numbers to run a formula,

632
00:32:06.950 --> 00:32:08.610
and that kinda give you a hint there too.

633
00:32:08.610 --> 00:32:12.830
All of these result in an EAC, it's
just some are more accurate than others.

00:32:12.830 --> 00:32:14.350
>> So Don, that's a great reminder for

00:32:14.350 --> 00:32:17.500

Remember that we're determining

that that budget is not gonna be complete,

00:32:25.210 --> 00:32:29.730
how much money we really do need to have

00:32:29.730 --> 00:32:32.980
Those variations are gonna come in handy

00:32:33.630 --> 00:32:36.840
But remember also on the exam, you may

information, it's a great reminder and

Don, any last words of advice for

cuz these are not formulas
